headline: Immigrant Groups and R.N.C. Split on Outcome of Meeting
text: Immigrant advocates seeking to raise Republican support for an immigration overhaul met on Wednesday with Michael Steele, chairman of the Republican National Committee, but the effort got off to a rocky start when a dispute arose over what promises, if any, Mr. Steele had made during the meeting.

headline: Borders Repays $42.5 Million Loan From Ackman
text: The Borders Group said late Wednesday that it had repaid a $42.5 million loan from William A. Ackman’s Pershing Square Capital Management, its largest investor, and secured a new $700 million credit line from Bank of America and other banks. The struggling bookseller said it had also closed on a new $90 million term line.

headline: The Pace of Deal-Making Picks Up
text: CORPORATE buyers are intensifying their hunt for deals — and they’re becoming a bit bolder.

headline: Furor Over Promotions of Palin TV Show
text: David Itzkoff and Bill Carter examine the contretemps over promotions suggesting appearances by certain celebrities on Sarah Palin’s planned television show, with the celebrities — LL Cool J and Toby Keith — claiming they did not give their authorization.

headline: Calculating Morgan Stanley’s Fees for Citi Stock Sale
text: Morgan Stanley could could earn at least $23.1 million — and as much as $134.8 million — for its work advising the government on the sale of its Citigroup stake, according to the terms of its contract with the Treasury Department. (Read the contract after the jump.)

headline: No Confetti as Apollo and K.K.R Move to List
text: As Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Apollo Global Management finally limp into the stock markets, the question again arises: does it make sense to buy into publicly traded private equity firms?

headline: Zimbabwe: New Charge in Terror Trial
text: More than a year after Roy Bennett, one of Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai’s closest allies, was put on trial for terrorism-related offenses, the attorney general’s office has notified him that he will face a new charge of hoarding maize nine years ago, Mr. Bennett’s party, the Movement for Democratic Change, reported Wednesday. The party contends that Mr. Bennett is being persecuted by its partner in governing, the ZANU-PF party of President Robert Mugabe. Mr. Bennett, who is white, is a former commercial farmer whose land was confiscated. State agents recently blocked him from collecting his father’s remains from the farm he used to own, his party said. Mr. Tsvangirai nominated him as deputy agriculture minister, but Mr. Mugabe has refused to appoint him.

headline: Court Requires Warning About Deportation Risk
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that lawyers for people thinking of pleading guilty to a crime must advise their clients who are not citizens about the possibility that they will be deported.

headline: France: More Publishers Sue Google
text: Several French publishing houses intend to bring a joint copyright infringement suit against Google, publishing executives said this week. As part of its Book Search project, since 2005 Google has digitized and made publicly accessible portions of at least 12 million literary works, many under copyright. Brice Amor, legal director at Éditions Gallimard, the publishing house leading the suit, said that Google had continued scanning and posting Gallimard works despite requests that it stop doing so. Google declined to comment on the pending legal action. In December, a Paris court found Google guilty of copyright infringement in a similar suit brought by the French publishing group La Martinière. Google has appealed the decision.

headline: For Start-Ups, Late Bursts of Private Cash
text: A FEW years ago, Facebook, which brought social networking to college students and grandparents alike, was expected to be a public company by now. Founded in 2004, it is cash-flow positive and is expected to bring in $1 billion in revenue this year.

headline: Belgium: Burqa Bill in Parliament
text: In a reflection of growing anxiety in Europe over the use of Islamic symbols, a committee of Belgian lawmakers voted Wednesday to ban the wearing of burqas in public, paving the way for the first clampdown of its kind on the Continent. Exceptions would be possible for some festivities if the municipal authorities decided to grant them. The proposal will be put to the full Parliament after the Easter break. Caroline Sagesser, a social policy expert at the Université Libre de Bruxelles, said the move was more significant politically than in terms of social impact. Some of the most likely offenders could be wealthy visitors from the Persian Gulf states staying in Belgium’s luxury hotels and visiting its most exclusive stores, she added.

headline: Applications to Elite Universities Rise
text: With many of the nation’s most selective colleges and universities scheduled to inform applicants of their decisions on Thursday, one trend already appears to be emerging: Applications to elite private colleges rose again this academic year, despite the economic constraints on many families.

headline: Texas: Changing Her Mind, Senator Says She’ll Stay
text: Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, announced Wednesday that she would serve out the rest of her term, after previously indicating she would resign before it ended. Ms. Hutchison, 66, fresh off an unsuccessful bid for governor, wrote in an open letter to Texas residents that she would stay put to fight the Democrats’ agenda and work to repeal the recently enacted health care legislation. The seat is next up for election in 2012.

headline: California: Good-Bye to Ghost Fleet
text: The federal Maritime Administration has agreed to remove more than 50 obsolete military troop ships and tankers from World War II that have been anchored in the San Francisco Bay since the 1960s. Environmental groups sued the agency in 2007, after a study found that some 20 tons of lead-based paint had flaked off the warships, known as the ghost fleet. The 25 most decrepit ships will be removed by 2012, and stripped of loose paint, barnacles and plants before they are towed to Texas to be cut apart and recycled. The remaining ships will be removed by 2017.

headline: Top Bloomberg Aide Will Lead His Charity Board
text: As he unveiled plans to vastly expand the foundation that will give away his fortune, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Wednesday formally appointed Patricia E. Harris, his first deputy mayor, as both chairwoman and chief executive of the $1.75 billion charity.

headline: After 3 Days, Police Give Description of Subway Killer
text: Slowed by a shortage of surveillance cameras in New York City’s subway system, the police on Wednesday released their first detailed description of a man accused of fatally stabbing two other men on a No. 2 subway train, three days after a brawl that led to the deaths.

headline: Schedule Favors Rangers in Push for the Playoffs
text: There is bad news and good news in the Rangers’ chase to make up 4 points in the season’s final six games and grab the final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference.

headline: A .483 Batting Average? Not Quite Good Enough
text: TAMPA, Fla. — In the long, rectangular-shaped Yankees clubhouse at Steinbrenner Field, players likely to make the team are assigned lockers on the perimeter. The four rows in the middle, parallel to the shorter walls, are mostly for nonroster invitees, long-shot rookies, those with no chance of making the team and players who are just passing through. More and more of those lockers go empty as camp progresses.

headline: At Law Firms, Reconsidering the Model for Associates’ Pay
text: “BIG firms are in a crucible of change. Some don’t realize it yet. But the fat will be wrought from the system.”

headline: Twins’ Span Hits His Mother With a Foul Ball
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Minnesota center fielder Denard Span, who is from Tampa, purchased tickets for his family to sit next to the Twins’ dugout at Steinbrenner Field for Wednesday’s game against the Yankees.

headline: New York and Airline to Team Up on Tourism
text: The competition for supremacy among major airlines at New York’s airports is paying dividends for the city’s campaign to attract more visitors.

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of Holy Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations in

headline: Christie Survives His Dive Into Uncharted Political Waters. For Now.
text: In more normal times, you would think the new governor had gone out and promptly laid an egg.

headline: N.Y. Repeat Felon Law Is Found Unconstitutional
text: A key provision of a New York State law under which repeat offenders can be sentenced more harshly is unconstitutional because the longer prison terms are based on findings by judges, not juries, a federal appeals court ruled on Wednesday.

headline: Court Ruling May Imperil Florida Deal
text: MIAMI — The federal judge supervising Everglades restoration issued a ruling on Wednesday that could make it impossible for Gov. Charlie Crist to complete a land acquisition he has described as the signature environmental achievement of his administration.

headline: The Iraq Drawdown and Afghan Buildup
text: In one of the most complex logistical operations in military history, American troops and equipment are being pulled out of  Iraq and sent on to Afghanistan, or back home to refit the armed services.

headline: No Shortcuts When Military Moves a War
text: JOINT BASE BALAD, Iraq — Early this year a “fob in a box” — military slang for 80 shipping containers with all the tents, showers and construction material needed to set up a remote forward operating base — was put on trucks here for the trip from one war to another.

headline: Everyman on Everest
text: SEATTLE — My friend John Rudolf left for Mount Everest on Monday, off to clamber up toward the roof of the world at an age, 62, when some people have trouble getting out of bed in the morning — or at least finding a motivation to greet the dawn.

headline: Iraq: The Wrong Type of Sand
text: CAMP ARIFJAN, Kuwait — On the very long and expensive list of materials that the American military had to ship to Iraq since 2003 — many of which it is now shipping out again — one might not have expected to find sand.

headline: Looking at the iPad From Two Angles
text: In 10 years of reviewing tech products for The New York Times, I’ve never seen a product as polarizing as Apple’s iPad, which arrives in stores on Saturday.

headline: Bloggingheads: Avant-Garde Politics
text: David Weigel, left, of The Washington Independent and James Pinkerton of Fox News debate whether Democrats are ignoring the concerns of average Americans.

headline: Go Mad
text: "Perhaps you've never heard of the choreographer Faye Driscoll. But if you're reasonably plugged into the contemporary arts scene in New York, chances are you've seen some of her work," writes Claudia La Rocco. " 'Loneliness,' her video flip-book dance, was part of the New Museum's 'Younger Than Jesus' triennial. She was a member of Doug Varone and Dancers, has performed with Yasmeen Godder and served as the choreographic assistant to David Neumann, when he created a duet for himself and Mikhail Baryshnikov." Those who want to get more familiar with her work should head to Dance Theater Workshop to see "There Is So Much Mad in Me." "The piece, which includes fine dancers like Tony Orrico and Lindsay Clark, is drawn in part from media images of people in extreme states and investigates their enduring need to be seen. What better time to catch a glimpse of Ms. Driscoll?"

headline: Urban Disaster
text: "Treme," the new HBO series from David Simon, about New Orleans in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, doesn't begin until next Sunday, but you don't have to wait until then to see a work that explores disaster in the modern American city. Tonight, The Kitchen presents the world premiere of "Bellona, Destroyer of Cities." The interdisciplinary theater work is adapted and directed by Jay Scheib from Samuel R. Delany's science fiction novel "Dhalgren," and is set in a city after a cataclysmic event. It is the second part in Mr. Scheib's trilogy, "Simulated Cities/Simulated Systems," and features passages from the novel with original material, movement and live video. Performances begin at 8 p.m.

headline: Wonder Show
text: "The latest guise of the singer and songwriter Will Oldham, Bonnie (Prince) Billy sings rowdy and devastating songs in an Appalachian squeal that can be described only as miraculous," writes Amanda Petrusich. Tonight he is performing with the Cairo Gang, the alias of his longtime collaborator Emmett Kelly. At 8 and 10:15 p. m. at Monster Island Basement in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Mississippi A.C.L.U. Rejects $20,000 for Alternate Prom
text: To avoid further controversy, the American Civil Liberties Union of Mississippi has rejected a $20,000 gift intended to underwrite an alternate prom replacing one canceled by a local school district after a lesbian student demanded that she be allowed to attend with her girlfriend.

headline: Successes (and Some Growing Pains) at Hulu
text: Hulu, the popular and free online video hub, has some things to celebrate as it heads into its third year.

headline: Skepticism on Pledges for Haiti
text: UNITED NATIONS — An international effort to finance the reconstruction of Haiti attracted billions of dollars in pledges at a conference here on Wednesday, but the very size of the outpouring raised questions about whether the commitments would be met and how fast the financial support could help salve the needs of the Haitian people.

headline: Drill, but Not Everywhere
text: For years, the debate over offshore drilling for gas and oil has been a war of sound bites between the “drill now, drill everywhere” crowd that dominated the Bush administration and the Republican campaign in 2008, and members of the environmental community who would leave the country’s outer continental shelf untouched.

headline: A Web of Insider Trading Charges
text: Prosecutors charge that Galleon Group hedge fund was the at the hub of a broad network of traders who swapped insider information. Go to DealBook »

headline: Court Authorizes Inquiry of Kenyans
text: PARIS — The International Criminal Court has given the green light to open formal criminal investigations of the political leaders who organized the violence that shook Kenya after its disputed election in 2007, the court announced Wednesday.

headline: Rushed From Haiti, Then Jailed for Lacking Visas
text: More than two months after the earthquake that devastated Haiti, at least 30 survivors who were waved onto planes by Marines in the chaotic aftermath are prisoners of the United States immigration system, locked up since their arrival in detention centers in Florida.

headline: The Collector
text: Not many ex-wards of the New York City public school system would cherish a splinter that pierced the rear of their principal in 1942, but Martin Raskin, it is safe to say, is in a class by himself.

headline: Charles Ryskamp
text: I owe an almost inexpressible debt to Charles Ryskamp, an extraordinary museum director, literary scholar, and a man of unlimited generosity. When I met him, I was a graduate student in the English department at Princeton University and he was a professor there. He also was the director of the Pierpont Morgan Library.

headline: Scions of Detroit Families Share Hockey Passion
text: DETROIT — Since birth, William Clay Ford Jr. and Christopher Ilitch have been judged by their last names and their families’ businesses. It comes with being the great-grandson of Henry Ford and, for Ilitch, being the son of the founder of Little Caesars Pizza.

headline: What France Can Do
text: President Nicolas Sarkozy of France got nearly everything he could have hoped for from his visit to the United States this week. Now he needs to return the favor by significantly increasing French combat strength in Afghanistan.

headline: Hedge Funds’ Mediocre Middlemen
text: Hedge Funds’ Mediocre Middlemen

headline: Events in the Case of an Accused Priest
text: The case of the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphy, accused of molesting as many as 200 deaf boys at a school in Wisconsin, stands out among the cases of sexual abuse by Catholic priests because of the number and vulnerability of the victims, and the availability of documents revealing how church officials handled the matter.

headline: China, Concubines and Google
text: Some 2,400 years ago, a Chinese king invited a legendary military strategist named Sun Tzu to give a demonstration in military training  using women from the palace.

headline: Interpreting the Test Scores
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Real Census
text: The Census Bureau  the real Census Bureau  reports the good news that 50 percent of American households have mailed in their decennial head-count forms so far. There’s no word on the ersatz “census” forms mailed out this year by the Republican National Committee and the National Republican Congressional Committee as a fund-raising gambit.

headline: Mitt Romney, Liberal Icon
text: I need to apologize to Mitt Romney.

headline: Are You Buying Illegal Drugs?
text: LAST month, thieves cut through the roof of an Eli Lilly warehouse in Enfield, Conn., shimmied down a rope, disabled the alarms and made off with $75 million worth of psychiatric drugs, including the antidepressants Prozac and Cymbalta and the antipsychotic Zyprexa. It is thought to have been the largest pharmaceutical theft in history.

headline: The Pope and the Abuse Scandal
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Israel and France Broke Up
text: Princeton, N.J.

headline: Risk Is Clear in Drilling; Payoff Isn’t
text: WASHINGTON — In proposing a major expansion of offshore oil and gas development, President Obama set out to fashion a carefully balanced plan that would attract bipartisan support for climate and energy legislation while increasing production of domestic oil.

headline: Inquiry Into Ex-G.O.P. Leader
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — The man chosen by Gov. Charlie Crist to lead the Republican Party of Florida is under criminal investigation after a new audit showed that he may have steered nearly $200,000 in party money to a company he owned.

headline: Views on Reform, Then and Now
text: TWO and a half years have passed since the credit crisis upset the markets, leading to the collapse of several major investment firms.

headline: Militia Draws Distinctions Between Groups
text: ADRIAN, Mich. — The Stone family, and the fiercely militant Christian group that revolved around them at a ramshackle homestead outside of town here, were best known by their neighbors for their active use of guns and their increasingly heated talk about fighting back violently against the government.

headline: U.S. Agent Infiltrated Militia, Lawyer Says
text: DETROIT — An undercover federal agent attended training exercises with the Hutaree militia for at least eight months before nine members of the militant Christian group were arrested last weekend and charged with plotting an uprising against the government, prosecutors said Wednesday.

headline: Coaches Finding No Tolerance for Losing
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Three years ago, when Royce Waltman was fired as the coach at Indiana State, he gave a memorable and prophetic news conference at the Missouri Valley Conference tournament.

headline: Where All Are Counted
text: In Wolford, N.D., everyone who received a census questionnaire has filled it out and returned it. This is a distinction held by a smattering of tiny towns, mostly in the Midwest.

headline: Trying to Break Down Resistance to the Census
text: “Ni hao!” the young volunteer exclaimed in Mandarin, greeting the stranger on the other side of an apartment door in Queens. First there was silence, but then the door cracked open, and the volunteer announced the reason for her visit.

headline: Mets’ Murphy Will Miss Opener With a Knee Injury
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — With only a handful of days remaining before the regular season, the Mets were on the verge of concluding spring training without having sustained a single on-field injury. But then one faulty base-running play in the middle of a meaningless game on Tuesday brought back all the bad memories of 2009, and the Mets find themselves without their starting first baseman.

headline: Donovan (and Willard) Take Over at Seton Hall
text: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J. — Three decades before Brittney Griner caused such a commotion at Baylor, a 6-foot-8 colossus named Anne Donovan swatted aside shots — and misconceptions about women’s basketball — to build an astonishing résumé as a player, then as a coach.

headline: Lavin Prepares for His Close-Up at St. John’s
text: Just about every coach can break down film, but Steve Lavin takes it to a different level. Lavin, the new boss at St. John’s, is married to an actress, Mary Ann Jarou, whose television roles include an appearance on “The King of Queens.”

headline: Welsh, a Coach Who Has Won, Gets a Chance to Contend at Hofstra
text: The former Providence and Iona coach Tim Welsh had been looking to get back into coaching since leaving the Friars in 2008, but the right fit did not become available until Wednesday, when Hofstra handed him the keys to its program.

headline: Like the Clues
text: “Once upon a dreary midnight …”

headline: Finding That Elusive One Person in Every 116 Acres in Mississippi
text: MAYERSVILLE, Miss. — According to the last census, there is one person — one hard-to-find, hard-to-prod, hard-to-pin-down person — for every 116 acres in Issaquena County, whose western horizon is narrowed by the bright green band of the levee along the Mississippi River.

headline: Inventive New Private School Hits Old Hurdles
text: The founders of the Blue School aspired to create something different: a private school not fixated on the Ivy League prospects of preschoolers and devoid of admissions hysteria. An education that, as they put it, “you don’t have to recover from.”

headline: Pay of Hedge Fund Managers Roared Back Last Year
text: The Lazarus-like recovery of the nation’s big banks did not benefit just the bankers — it also created huge paydays for hedge fund managers, including a record $4 billion gain in 2009 for one bold investor who bet big on the financial sector.

headline: Parking Lot Is a Battleground for a Bronx Hospital and a Doctors Union
text: To officials at St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx, replacing an overcrowded parking lot with a five-story parking garage would end the daily hassle of fighting for a space, benefiting staff members and visitors alike.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 31, 2010

headline: Blood on Defendant’s Knife Was Victim’s, Scientist Says
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — Bloodstains on the blade of a knife that the police recovered from the Long Island teenager accused of fatally stabbing an Ecuadorean immigrant matched the DNA of the victim, a forensic scientist testified on Wednesday. Other bloodstains on the jeans and tank top the teenager was wearing also matched the victim’s DNA.

headline: Empire Built by Developer Shows Signs of Distress
text: Sheldon H. Solow’s swooping 50-story office tower on West 57th Street with the giant red “9” in front is half empty, a stunning development for a building that commands some of the highest rents in Manhattan.

headline: Few to Count, but All Eager to Get It Done
text: WOLFORD, N.D. — Kyle Yoder, 8, heard at school that the Census Bureau was starting to count the country and began asking his parents the same question every night: Had their form arrived in the mail today?

headline: Nets Unable to Slow Nash or the Suns
text: Steve Nash had 24 points and 14 assists, Jason Richardson scored 23 points, and the Phoenix Suns ran their winning streak to nine games by beating the Nets, 116-105, on Wednesday night at the Izod Center.

headline: Pfizer Chief Says Growth Is Imminent
text: The world’s largest drug company, Pfizer, has handled mergers badly, invented too few drugs and left its reputation in disrepair after two criminal cases.

headline: David Mills, Television Writer and Producer, Dies at 48
text: David Mills, a former journalist who explored race relations and racial tensions as an Emmy-winning television writer for dramas like “NYPD Blue,” “The Wire” and “Homicide,” died on Tuesday in New Orleans on the set of a new show, “Treme.” He was 48 and had homes in Los Angeles and Silver Spring, Md.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on March 13 about the arrest in Yemen of Sharif Mobley, a New Jersey man accused of joining Al Qaeda and killing a hospital guard, described his family’s origins incorrectly. According to law enforcement officials and friends of the family, both of Mr. Mobley’s parents were born in the United States and his ancestors have lived in this country for generations. His ancestors were not Somali immigrants.

headline: Tournament Tipoff: Unlikely Final Four
text: Butler and Michigan State broke a lot of brackets on their way to the Final Four, and they might not be done yet.

headline: Deadlock Is Ending on Labor Board
text: Because of President Obama’s recess appointments of two union lawyers to the National Labor Relations Board, business groups are warning that the panel will kick quickly into a pro-union gear after 26 months of near paralysis, when just two of its five seats were filled.

headline: Mortimer D. Sackler, Arts Patron, Dies at 93
text: Mortimer D. Sackler, a psychiatrist who was a co-owner of the pharmaceutical company Purdue Pharma, makers of the controversial painkiller OxyContin, and whose lavish gifts to the Guggenheim Museum, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Columbia University made him one of New York City’s most prominent benefactors, died March 24 in Gstaad, Switzerland. He was 93 and had homes in London, Gstaad and Antibes, France.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about a speech by the former Federal Reserve chairman Paul A. Volcker misstated, in some copies, part of the name of the organization he addressed on Tuesday. It is the Peterson Institute for International Economics  not “Institute of.”

headline: Jaime Escalante, Inspiration for a Movie, Dies at 79
text: Jaime Escalante, the high school teacher whose ability to turn out high-achieving calculus students from a poor Hispanic neighborhood in East Los Angeles inspired the 1988 film “Stand and Deliver,” with Edward James Olmos in the starring role, died Tuesday at his son’s home in Rosedale, Calif. He was 79 and lived in Cochabamba, Bolivia.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Wednesday about the Charleston Symphony Orchestra’s cancellation of the rest of its season because of financial problems misstated the action the orchestra’s board intends to take by May 1. It plans to notify ticketholders for next season of their options by that date  not make a decision by then on whether to go ahead with the 2010-11 season.

headline: German Cabinet Agrees on Bank Tax for Bailouts
text: PARIS — The German cabinet agreed in principle on Wednesday to impose a tax on banks to help finance bailouts but left details of the plan to be worked out in legislation in coming months.

headline: Corrections
text: A film review on Friday about “Hot Tub Time Machine,” in suggesting that the movie might give viewers of a certain age and background “a twinge of pained, slightly nauseated nostalgia,” misspelled part of the title of a song whose lyrics such viewers would know. The song, released by Rick Springfield in 1981, is “Jessie’s Girl,” not “Jesse’s Girl.”

text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Fed Ends Its Purchasing of Mortgage Securities
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s single largest intervention to prop up the American economy, its $1.25 trillion program to buy mortgage-backed securities, came to a long-anticipated end on Wednesday.

headline: Corrections
text: The Front Row column last Thursday, about Patrick McCarthy’s departure as editorial director at Women’s Wear Daily, misstated the date of that publication’s 100th anniversary. It will be this May; it did not occur last year.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption last Thursday with an article about hiring fitness trainers for home workouts referred imprecisely to the people shown. Amber O’Neal, the trainer, is at the right, next to Kristen Leigh, her client; the words “at left” referred to the picture’s position in relation to the caption.

headline: Optimism and Doubt Feed a Duel Over Greece
text: Even as Moody’s downgraded its ratings on five Greek banks, the European Central Bank and Greece on Wednesday trumpeted optimism about the country’s financial prospects.

headline: Haiti’s Founding Document Found in London
text: There is no prouder moment in Haiti’s history than Jan. 1, 1804, when a band of statesmen-warriors declared independence from France, casting off colonialism and slavery to become the world’s first black republic.

headline: Albany Misses Its Deadline on the Budget
text: ALBANY — The state budget is officially late. Again.

headline: One Last Sitting for Holocaust Survivors
text: ﻿﻿Maciek Nabrdalik set out to photograph Holocaust survivors with a case full of studio equipment. At times, his subjects waited for him dressed in their best attire. He quickly realized that such formality would detract from his goal: to capture memories of the Holocaust through his subjects’ facial expressions.

headline: Update: If You See a Quote from Professor Lirpaloof, Beware
text: Madison Avenue and marketers enjoy an April Fool’s Day prank just as much as the next person — or perhaps even more, given that fakes, gags and goofs can help draw attention to a product or brand.

headline: Carbon Permits Said to Be in Excess in Europe
text: BRUSSELS — As the global economy faltered last year and factories idled, industries in the European Union benefited from one of the most lucrative outcomes of the recession: a huge excess of permits to emit carbon dioxide.

headline: Fed Ends Its Purchasing of Mortgage Securities
text: The Federal Reserve‘s single largest intervention to prop up the U.S. economy, its $1.25 trillion program to buy mortgage-backed securities, came to a long-anticipated end on Wednesday, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: A Call for Hong Kong to Clean the Air
text: HONG KONG — Top business leaders in Asia’s financial hub are sounding a bit like environmental activists these days, taking a stand against the persistently unhealthy levels of air pollution gripping this city.

headline: SS&C Tech Sees Static Debut
text: Shares of SS&C Technologies Holdings remained almost flat in their market debut after the company raised $160.9 million in its initial public offering, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Unemployment and Inflation Rise in Europe
text: PARIS — The unemployment rate in the euro area rose to 10 percent in February, while inflation accelerated more than economists had forecast, probably a result of higher food and oil prices, according to data released Wednesday.

headline: Critics Exploit Télécom Suicides, Ex-Executive Says
text: PARIS — Outsiders have taken advantage of the wave of suicides at France Télécom to push their own agenda, a former top executive at the company said in an interview posted Wednesday on a Web site.

headline: Peter Gowland, Pinup Photographer and Author, Dies at 93
text: Peter Gowland, who used camera, sunshine and imagination to portray ravishing women at a time when the pinup girl was a nearly ubiquitous fixture of American life, died on March 17 in Los Angeles. He was 93.

headline: Behind the Fight to Regulate Derivatives
text: 8:46 a.m. | Updated By CYRUS SANATI

headline: Crumbling Knicks Lose in Portland
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — The indignities came in waves Wednesday night, in alley-oops and ankle sprains and a scoreboard that seemed to light up only on one side. On a celebratory night at the Rose Garden, the Knicks were gloomy guests.

headline: How to Register a Start-Up
text: Think registering your business sounds like a perfunctory and insignificant task? Think again.

headline: Britain Questions ‘Too Big to Fail’
text: Speeches by central bankers tend to be dry affairs. For this reason alone, remarks by Andrew Haldane, the Bank of England’s executive director in charge of financial stability, deserve attention.

headline: Immigrants and the Census in New York
text: New York Times editor Diego Ribadeneira discusses the challenges faced by census takers in Flushing, Queens.

headline: Dr. Martens Kicks Off 50 Years of Boot Business With ‘Cover’ Campaign
text: The British shoe brand Dr. Martens is marking the anniversary of its mainstay boot, introduced on April 1, 1960, with a campaign that salutes its youthful customers and their ardor for music.

headline: Financial Laugh Lines
text: Because everyone needs a little laugh during these times of economic uncertainty. We’ve compiled some recent cartoons about the financial crisis and efforts to prevent the next one from being as bad.

headline: Successes (and Some Growing Pains) at Hulu
text: Hulu, the popular and free online video hub, has some things to celebrate as it heads into its third year, The New York Times’s Brian Stelter and Brad Stone write.

headline: At Law Firms, Reconsidering the Model for Associates’ Pay
text: Chris Kleponis/Bloomberg News, Comstock/Getty Images NEW OUTLOOK Mark Chandler, general counsel of Cisco Systems, said lawfirms’ attitudes were changing.

headline: Views on Reform, Then and Now

headline: Bicycles Built for You
text: When it comes to bespoke bicycles, Michael Maharam happily calls himself a dilettante. A lifelong collector of one-of-a-kind bikes from around the world, Maharam, of the New York textile company of the same name, recently made friends with a true expert — Sacha White, a master builder who owns Vanilla Bicycles in Portland, Ore. Together, they conceived an exhibition devoted to the work of craftsmen like White, who make a living cutting steel, welding and filing for weeks on end. (‘‘You wouldn’t want to be their manicurist,’’ Maharam says.) The show, ‘‘Bespoke: The Handbuilt Bicycle,’’ which opens May 12 at the Museum of Arts and Design, collects 21 of the finest contemporary examples from America and abroad, from charming, Old World road bikes to aggressively styled titanium and steel mountain bikes. On the gallery’s back wall, a set of drawings by the design firm 2×4 explains how bicycles are built. Maharam hopes the exhibition will open up the city’s bicycle culture to more people. ‘‘One reason bicycles have become so popular is because manufacturers are making the well designed and beautiful accessible to the masses,’’ he says. ‘‘This is the epitome of the well designed and beautiful.’’

headline: Poor Diana – Engines Need Love Too

As the Brazilian driver arrived at the table, another journalist and I were speaking with a person from the Cosworth engine program. Cosworth supplies engines to four teams, including HRT. At the Bahrain Grand Prix, Senna’s engine blew out, and I think it was no fault of the poor engine, but perhaps something leading into it.

headline: Sampler: Warrantless Wiretapping Ruled Illegal, and Suede Stays Closed
text: Judge Rules Wiretapping Without a Warrant Was Illegal | Vaughn R. Walker, the chief United States district judge of San Francisco, ruled that federal agents had eavesdropped illegally on an Islamic charity based in the United States. Judge Walker said that the Bush administration lacked the authority to act without warrants to intercept phone calls and e-mail messages between Americans and foreigners as part of an effort to prevent terrorist attacks. The ruling delivered a blow to the Bush administration’s claims that its surveillance program, which Mr. Bush authorized shortly after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, was lawful. The intercepts, Judge Walker ruled, violated a 1978 federal statute requiring court approval for domestic surveillance. The organization monitored by the taps, in this case, was Al Haramain, a now-defunct Islamic charity in Oregon. Two lawyers representing it in 2004 were also tapped. The judge said the plaintiffs had been “subjected to unlawful surveillance,” and said the government was liable to pay them damages. [The New York Times, The San Francisco Chronicle]

headline: The Management Styles of Harold Hooper, Cosmo G. Spacely, and Eugene H. Krabs
text: One of the most memorable classes I took in business school was an elective called “Management as Seen by the Arts.” It was taught by Professor Culbertson, a character straight out central casting if ever there was one: Harvard-educated, bespectacled, gray hair and beard, slight paunch concealed by a tweed jacket with leather elbow patches. We read “Bonfire of the Vanities” and “Death of a Salesman,” and we discussed how drastically the economic landscape had changed since the filming of “Norma Rae.”

The  English National Ballet used the occasion for some spinoffs, like the premiere of David Dawson’s “Faun(e).” Sadler’s Wells Theater presented another spinoff, “In the Spirit of Diaghilev,” which involved collaborations between artists and choreographers like Russell Maliphant, who made “Afterlight (Part One).” This week brought a spinoff of those spinoffs, “Ballet Russes — Encounters,” involving both the English National Ballet and Sadler’s Wells. Inevitably, parts of it had nothing to do with Diaghilev at all.

headline: Thursday Reading
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Plan For 2012 London Olympic Tower Is Unveiled
text: Hours after the design for the tower that Anish Kapoor and Cecil Balmond will create for the 2012 Olympic Park in London was revealed, the work had already earned a few not-so-flattering nicknames, The Guardian reported, including the Colossus of Stratford and the Hubble Bubble. But the official name of the 377-foot, $29 million red steel structure is the ArcelorMittal Orbit, and when it is finished it will stand taller than Big Ben or the Statue of Liberty (though it will be several hundred feet shorter than its Parisian ancestor, the Eiffel Tower). Lakshmi Mittal, the chief executive of the steel company ArcelorMittal, is providing about $24 million for the cost of the structure, with the remaining amount coming from the Greater London Authority. Boris Johnson, the city’s mayor, told The Guardian that while some people will say “we are nuts, we are barmy in the depths of a recession to be building Britain’s biggest ever piece of public art,” London’s Olympic Park needed it to spark people’s “curiosity and wonder.”

headline: The 21st-Century Orchestra: Now Hear It This Way

headline: Norris Church Mailer: The Last Wife
text: Imagine this: It is 1975, and you are a 26-year-old high-school art teacher, the divorced mother of a 3-year-old boy, living in Russellville, Ark. You hear that a world-famous novelist is in town for one night, so you wangle an invitation to the party in his honor, hoping he’ll autograph your book. You find yourself smitten with this 52-year-old man — as he is with you — and at the end of the evening you go home together. After he leaves, you pour out your heart in a love poem and mail it to him. He mails it back — copy-edited, in red pencil. Do you:

headline: Mary Gaitskill and Wells Tower Among Public Library’s Cullman Fellows
text: The New York Public Library’s Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers has announced its 2010-2011 fellows, a group that includes the novelist Mary Gaitskill; the historian Annette Gordon-Reed, author of the Pulitzer Prize-winning “The Hemingses of Monticello: An American Family”; and the New Yorker writer Larissa MacFarquhar. Other fellows include the fiction writers David Bezmozgis, Maile Chapman, and Wells Tower; David Sandlin, a graphic novelist; Geoffrey Brock, a poet; David Hinton, an essayist and translator of classical Chinese poetry; Michael Meyer, who is writing a book about a family’s organic rice farm in China; and Matthew Stewart, who is writing a book about the role of Deism in the founding of the United States. The academics are Sara Lipton, who teaches medieval history at the State University of New York, Stony Brook; James Romm, a professor of Classics at Bard College; and Andrew McConnell Stott, who teaches English at the State University of New York, Buffalo.

headline: The Calm Before the Semifinals
text: Thursday is a perfect opportunity to take a breath, enjoy a pause in the madness, perhaps consider cleaning out your refrigerator — really, those mystery items are not going to become edible for your Final Four party — because we know what’s ahead. March madness bleeds into April, which transforms into Tiger mania (otherwise known as Tiger Woods blotting out the Masters), which begets hyperventilating over the first month of baseball season, which will mean nothing by the second month of baseball season, leads to N.F.L. draft overanalysis and then Tiger mania will be coming to the United States Open at Pebble Beach! Yes, let’s all breathe. Pause. Repeat.

headline: Leonor Scherrer | Death Becomes Her
text: “Death has become banal,” proclaims Leonor Scherrer, the daughter of the French couturier Jean-Louis Scherrer and the mind behind one of the ghastliest start-ups since the Grim Reaper: Leonor Funeral Couture. Scherrer is building a fashion line to outfit the bereaved that harks back to a time when “a widow’s mourning dress was closely observed,” as in Goya’s painting of the Duchess of Alba. Her line even comes complete with its own fragrance, Maximilia, named after Maximilian Kolbe, the Polish friar who took the place of a condemned man at Auschwitz. Scherrer’s lavish youth is a roman à clef waiting to happen: Catholic school, a caretaker named Guigui, her father’s boutique on the Avenue Montaigne, which, she notes, was once called “L’Allée des Veuves” or “Widows’ Way.” Lately, she’s been dabbling in music, and one of the tracks off her forthcoming album is a cover of Schubert’s “Death and The Maiden.” Givenchy’s Riccardo Tisci digs the six-feet-under-obsessed Scherrer, featuring her in a recent ad campaign. “I’m completely in love with her,” he told Women’s Wear Daily. “For me, she represents France in all senses: the elegance, the aristocracy” — and, évidemment — “the darkness.”

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Panthers’ Date With Futility

headline: London Dance Journal: One Actor Who Can Really Dance
text: LONDON — There are more important reasons to see the National Theater’s new production of Dion Boucicault’s 1841 comedy “London Assurance” than its dances: this is a vintage production, already hailed by  Ben Brantley on this blog. But the actor Simon Russell Beale — never slim, sometimes apparently embarrassed by his girth — gives the most remarkable physical performance of his career as the fop Sir Harcourt Courtly and shows the audience how much he knows about ballet.

headline: Hidden Corners of a City Within a City
text: Never mind the celebrities and the television studios, which house “Saturday Night Live,” the  “Today”  show, “30 Rock” and “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon.” Rockefeller Center remains the star of its own universe. Embodying John D. Rockefeller’s vision of a “city within a city,” the 19-building complex has its own post office (for outgoing mail only), postage stamp (issued in 2001, a 10-cent depiction of Atlas) and, according to the 2000 census, a lone resident (a man). As one of Manhattan’s most conspicuous areas, the complex may astonish tourists, but a closer look also reveals hidden corners. To discover them, take the B, D, F or V train to the complex’s namesake subway station, 47th-50th Streets/Rockefeller Center.

Without going into a lot of specifics, no, you do not want to draw a bath, light candles and read O magazine in the tub. But, yes, the iPad works great with other appliances in that room.

headline: The iPad Consumer Case #3: A Device That Can See Through Walls
text: You are shopping for a house in an unfamiliar town with your partner and a 3G-equipped iPad. You fire up Zillow, a real estate app, and it shows you everything that is for sale. As you drive, a rolling list appears and you see a domicile in your price range. You pull up in front of a house that looks perfectly quaint and lovely. You open up the digital listing and discover through photos that the people who own it are either “Leave It to Beaver” nostalgics or have not redecorated since it was a well-rated show. You finger drop it from your list of favorites and keep moving, on to the next highlighted property on your illustrated wish list.

headline: Seeing Things | Yelena Zhelezov’s Modern Puppets

Japanese cleaning implements and vintage craft and design books were highlighted in March.)

headline: Afghan President Rebukes West and U.N.

headline: Inside the List
text: MARRIED TO MONEY: “The Devil’s Casino,” Vicky Ward’s book about the rise and fall of the banking giant Lehman Brothers, jumps onto the hardcover nonfiction list this week at No. 14. An excerpt in the April issue of Vanity Fair has raised eyebrows for its intimate account of employees’ marriages. “For all the senior-executive wives,” Ward writes, “there were ‘unwritten rules.’ If you were married to a Lehmanite, you belonged to the firm.” She goes on to quote one desperate housewife: “As a Lehman wife, you raised your kids by yourself. You had your babies by yourself in the hospital. And then you were supposed to be happy and pretty and smiling when there was an event, and you really would have liked to strangle somebody.”

headline: The iPad Consumer Case #4: Memories, of the Way They Were
text: You are drinking coffee at the breakfast table on Sunday, reading The New York Times, and you notice someone in Vows you think your partner went to school with. You slide it across the table. He/she picks it up, the story and images pivot to the new orientation. Yes, it’s true; it is that jerk whom your partner once dated. Together you go to the person’s Facebook page and laugh. A shared, digitally enabled Sunday morning media experience.

headline: The iPad Consumer Case #5: You See It, You Want It

The person next to you pulls out an iPad and opens up “Broken Embraces,” a movie you are dying to see. Your seatmate has headphones on, but even from the side, the images of Penelope Cruz are achingly, gorgeously beautiful. You stay with the movie by glancing sidelong at the subtitles and vow that sometime after you land, you are going to buy one of these suckers. You can’t sit next to it and not want it.

headline: A Closer Reading of Roman Vishniac
text: In 1983, Farrar,  Straus & Giroux published a book of pictures of prewar Eastern European Jewish life by the photographer Roman Vishniac. Titled “A Vanished World,” the book evoked what many have come to imagine as life in the shtetl: elegiac images of small cities and provincial villages, their hunchback rabbis walking cobblestone streets, Talmud prodigies studying by candlelight, men whispering in courtyards — a vision lighted with authenticity and charged with nostalgia. Through this and other books, Vishniac’s body of work has come to be thought of as the last photographic record of a universe on the cusp of being comprehensively and cataclysmically destroyed. His pictures were used in so many influential books about Jewish life before the Holocaust — as illustrations for books by Isaac Bashevis Singer and Irving Howe and later serving as what Janusz Kaminski called the “guiding force” for his Oscar-winning cinematography of  “Schindler’s List”  — that Vishniac, who died in 1990, has virtually become, in the words of Leon Wieseltier, the literary editor of The New Republic, “the official mortuary photographer of Eastern European Jewry.”

headline: A Bold Vision, Still Ahead of Its Time
text: IT is perhaps inevitable that we are still catching up with Rainer Werner Fassbinder, who worked practically at the speed of thought and who died of a drug overdose in 1982 at 37, leaving behind more than 40 films. “World on a Wire,” an obscure two-part television movie he made in 1973, is a textbook example of a film that was ahead of its time. Head-trip cinema about virtual-reality immersions, it’s an analog-age “Avatar,” a movie that anticipates “Blade Runner” in its meditation on artificial and human intelligence and “The Matrix” in its conception of reality as a computer-generated illusion.

headline: A Composer at Ease With Conflicts
text: THE Dutch composer Louis Andriessen has a gift for embracing conflicting values, musical and otherwise, and making it seem as if they fit together naturally. He has, for example, written 12-tone works and Minimalist scores, and has no problem using elements of both  along with rock rhythms, quotations from Bach, Mozart or Sweelinck and occasional jazz harmonies  in the same piece. He considers himself influenced by the French Romantics and staunchly anti-Germanic, yet he describes Bach as “the real god in the house” and says he plays and studies something from “The Well-Tempered Clavier” or Bach’s organ works every day.

headline: London Olympic Tower Plan Is Unveiled
text: Hours after the design for the tower that Anish Kapoor and Cecil Balmond will create for the 2012 Olympic Park in London was revealed on Wednesday, the plan had already earned a few not-so-flattering nicknames, The Guardian reported, including the Hubble Bubble and the Colossus of Stratford, after the London neighborhood. But the official name of the 377-foot, $29 million red steel structure, right, is the ArcelorMittal Orbit; and when it is finished, it will stand taller than Big Ben or the Statue of Liberty (though it will be several hundred feet shorter than its Parisian ancestor, the Eiffel Tower). Lakshmi Mittal, the chief executive of the steel company ArcelorMittal, is providing about $24 million for the cost of the structure, with the remaining amount coming from the Greater London Authority. Boris Johnson, the city’s mayor, told The Guardian that while some people will say “we are nuts, we are barmy in the depths of a recession to be building Britain’s biggest ever piece of public art,” Olympic Park needed it to spark people’s “curiosity and wonder.”

headline: BBC News and WNET Are Together Again
text: Nearly two years after a nasty split, “BBC World News” and WNET.org have made up. The weeknight newscast will return on Monday to WNET, Channel 13 in New York, where it will air at 5:30 p.m., and to its sister station, WLIW, Channel 21, which will broadcast it at 11 p.m. WNET.org, the parent company of the two public stations, announced in April 2008 that it planned to drop the BBC newscast, which WLIW also distributed to public stations nationwide, in favor of an in-house-produced international news program called “Worldfocus.” At the time Neal Shapiro, the president and chief executive of WNET.org, criticized the BBC program for not presenting enough context for American viewers. But “Worldfocus,” which had its debut in October 2008, was unable to find enough financing to keep going, despite strong viewer support. A WNET spokeswoman, Kellie Specter, said that Mr. Shapiro, who was not available for comment, still firmly believes in the “Worldfocus” goal to make foreign news less foreign to the audience, but with that show being canceled, “we are still committed to international news and analysis and that’s the reason he brought ‘BBC World News’ back.”

headline: ‘The Illusion’ Is Added to Kushner Lineup
text: What, a new play by Tony Kushner and the first New York revival of his epic “Angels in America” aren’t enough to constitute a full-on, yearlong celebration of his work? Well, there’s still one more component to the Signature Theater Company’s Kushner-theme 2010-11 season. On Thursday the company said it would present “The Illusion,” Mr. Kushner’s adaptation of “L’Illusion Comique” by Pierre Corneille, to be directed by Michael Mayer (“Spring Awakening,” “American Idiot”) and performed in the spring of 2011. The play, about a lawyer in search of his son and a magician who conjures up visions of the lost child, joins Signature’s previously announced repertory productions of “Angels in America,” planned for the fall, and the New York debut of “The Intelligent Homosexual’s Guide to Capitalism and Socialism With a Key to the Scriptures,” which it is producing with the Public Theater next spring. The season will also feature a reading series of Mr. Kushner’s other plays; casting for these productions has not been announced.

headline: Bye-Bye to Didi
text: Will you ever win? In the case of Didi Benami, above, the answer is no, not this season. With a bittersweet performance of the Fleetwood Mac song “Rhiannon,” Ms. Benami, 23, an “American Idol” contestant from Knoxville, Tenn., bid farewell to the competition on Wednesday night. She received the fewest votes this week from “Idol” viewers, but the results show was, as usual, the night’s most-watched program, drawing an audience of just under 20 million people, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Fox placed first for the night, and NBC was second with a lineup that included “Law & Order: SVU” (10 million). ABC saw a slight uptick for an episode of its comedy “Modern Family” (9.3 million) that prominently featured the Apple iPad, but the network was fourth over all. CBS was third with repeats.

headline: Library Names New Fellows
text: The Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers at the New York Public Library announced its 2010-11 fellows, who include the novelist Mary Gaitskill; the historian Annette Gordon-Reed, author of the Pulitzer Prize winner “The Hemingses of Monticello: An American Family”; and the New Yorker writer Larissa MacFarquhar. Others include the fiction writers David Bezmozgis, Maile Chapman and Wells Tower; David Sandlin, a graphic novelist; Geoffrey Brock, a poet; David Hinton, an essayist and translator of classical Chinese poetry; Michael Meyer, who is writing a book about a family’s organic rice farm in China; and Matthew Stewart, who is writing a book about the role of deism in the founding of the United States. Scholars chosen are Sara Lipton, who teaches medieval history at the State University of New York, Stony Brook; James Romm, a professor of Classics at Bard College; and Andrew McConnell Stott, who teaches English at the State University of New York, Buffalo. The fellowship lasts from September to May. Each fellow gets an office in the library’s Stephen A. Schwarzman Building at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, full access to the library’s research collections, and a stipend of $60,000.

headline: The iPad and Consumer Case #8: Back-Seat Driver
text: Hour Three in the car and you are stuck on an interstate that has turned into a very slow-moving meat grinder. Your son and daughter have begun to play something called the “hitting game.” You hand back the iPad and they pounce on it like feral animals, working their way though Topple 2, Scrabble, Tap Tap Revenge Three. Hour Four they begin arguing about whose turn it is. You wait for the right moment and snatch it back.

headline: Charles W. Colson’s House of Worship
text: Charles W. ColsonAge: 78Occupation: Commentator and prison activistNext Project: Writing a book with his daughter about her autistic son.

headline: Mail Call for Marines in Marja, Afghanistan
text: Yes, it is a moment of calm in Afghanistan. And it is set in Helmand Province, in Marja, the Taliban stronghold that was the objective of a major air assault in February. Lens has been following the operation, from the standpoint of Tyler Hicks, who was embedded with Company K, Third Battalion, Sixth Marines (“Into the Maw at Marja“), and Moises Saman, who was getting around on his own (“A Perilous Route to Marja.”) This photograph was taken by Asmaa Waguih of Reuters.

headline: Longtime M.L.B. Spokesman to Retire
text: Richard Levin, Major League Baseball’s chief spokesman for the past 25 years and a close adviser to Commissioner Bud Selig, said Thursday that he would retire at the end of the year.

headline: New York Auto Show: As Mileage Rules Go Into Effect, the Green Tour
text: In his speech at the New York auto show on Wednesday, Dave McCurdy, president and chief executive of the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers, praised the rules regulating auto fuel economy and tailpipe greenhouse gas emissions that were completed on Thursday. And on the floor of the show, Jim Kliesch, senior engineer at the Union of Concerned Scientists, praised them, too.

headline: The Janitor, It Seems, Always Rings Twice
text: Quirky goes a surprisingly long way before stalling out in “Don McKay,” an oddball comedy with the knowing, festering heart of a neo-noir. Thomas Haden Church, lips flat-lining, voice droning, plays the title character, a school janitor in a lonely place whose life takes a detour after he receives a blast out of the past. Somewhere in the night a phantom lady beckons. Suddenly Don heads down mystery street, unaware that he’s about to tread dangerous ground alongside the writer and director Jake Goldberger. In the reckless moment the damned don’t cry: they kiss tomorrow goodbye and pile on the movie allusions.

headline: Ferrets, Tasty Ink and a Nastier Gordon Brown
text: LONDON — For some odd reason, Prime Minister Gordon Brown emerged relatively unscathed earlier this year when a book depicted him as a volatile bully who swears at underlings, destroys office supplies and jabs his pen compulsively into the upholstery of his car in a bad-tempered manner at times of stress.

headline: Roundabout Picks a Replacement Play
text: Patton Oswalt won’t have his Broadway debut this season, but Sherie Rene Scott’s “Everyday Rapture” will. On Thursday, Roundabout Theater Company said it would replace a planned production of “Lips Together, Teeth Apart” with “Everyday Rapture,” confirming the rumblings that surfaced soon after “Lips Together” collapsed. Roundabout’s production of that Terrence McNally play was postponed in late March when the actress Megan Mullally quit, amid accounts of a conflict over whether Mr. Oswalt, her co-star, had the experience to perform his part. “Everyday Rapture,” which Ms. Scott, above, wrote with Dick Scanlan and in which she plays a semi-fictionalized version of herself grappling with a “half-Mennonite” upbringing and struggling to break into New York theater, was widely acclaimed when it ran last year at Second Stage Theater. Roundabout said the production would begin previews at the American Airlines Theater on April 19 and open on April 29. Its limited engagement is scheduled to end on July 11.

headline: Jeff Jacobson: The Last Roll
text: Photographer Jeff Jacobson confronts his own mortality in this stunning selection of images.

headline: Dry Heat: Early Innings in the Cactus League
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

headline: Selfridges in London Gets New Restaurant
text: If there weren’t enough options at Selfridges’s flagship store in London, you can add one more: high-end dining. Mark Hix, the British chef, restaurateur and fervent proponent of locavore fare, opened his fourth restaurant, Hix Restaurant and Champagne Bar, in the upscale department store in early March.

headline: Popcast: The Bieber Phenomenon
text: This week: a review of the latest album from the country music stalwart Alan Jackson and a roundtable discussion about Justin Bieber, the 16-year-old pop music star. Ben Sisario is the host.

headline: The iPad Consumer Case #9: This Is Your Grandma’s Oldsmobile
text: Your mother-in-law hates computers. Hates. Them. “Too old, too stupid,” she says. She comes for a Christmas visit and you show her pictures from your daughter’s kindergarten graduation. She watches with increasing interest as you scatter and scan the photos with a flick of the finger. She takes a turn and it goes well. Then you show her the YouTube video of the fall pageant. The satellite map of your childhood home. She takes a turn and this time she does not give it back. You leave her alone for an hour and come back to find her scanning recipes on Epicurious. “This isn’t really a computer,” she says. “It can’t be. I actually might like having one of these around.” Is that so? Merry Christmas, beloved, Luddite mother-in-law. We bought it for you.

headline: Iran Plays Host to Delegations After Iraq Elections
text: BAGHDAD — Iran may seem an unlikely place to turn for guidance when it comes to putting together a democratic government, but that is exactly what most of Iraq’s political class did immediately after last month’s parliamentary elections.

headline: Scenes From Reality TV and Other Madness
text: With a sure idea of how much or how little it takes to fill a stage with madness  in the sense of euphoria, hysteria, desperation and rage  the choreographer Faye Driscoll’s new work explores extreme states, from those found in actual wars to the sort of battles waged on television shows like “Jerry Springer.”

headline: Courtesy of Brahms, Some 19th-Century Pop
text: The English tenor Ian Bostridge commented recently in a radio interview that the lieder tradition is closer to pop music than to opera. Mr. Bostridge certainly avoids the decorous stage presence adopted by most lieder singers for a more pop-star approach, his lanky frame swaying and twisting as he clutches the piano and staggers unpredictably around the stage.

headline: Judge Throws Out Suit Against Moody’s and S.&P.
text: A federal judge in Manhattan threw out a class-action lawsuit accusing the ratings agencies Moody’s Investors Service and Standard & Poor’s of defrauding investors about the safety of $63.4 billion of mortgage debt, Reuters reports.

headline: Formalism and Boasts
text: The point of actual overlap came and went quickly for the rappers K’Naan and Wale at the Fillmore at Irving Plaza on Wednesday night. It happened during K’Naan’s half of a double bill, on a boast track that appears on Wale’s most recent album. And the lyrical particulars of the tune, “TV in the Radio,” invited easy comparison. Wale’s verses spoke to a frisky formalism, studded with internal rhymes and winking pop-culture references. K’Naan went more for the jugular, pledging to draw blood from any challenger, though he had his own sly twists. “I’ve been on more red carpets than Ryan Seacrest,” he cracked.

headline: Demystify the Lehman Shell Game
text: Making unattractive assets disappear from corporate balance sheets was one of the great magical tricks performed by accountants over the last few decades.

headline: Dreamy Fantasies of Femininity and Nature
text: Too small for crowd-pleasing spectaculars, the Frick Collection has specialized in what you might call the un-blockbuster: miniature shows of old masters carefully selected and borrowed from other museums. That any of the nine works in the current sweet dream of an exhibition, “Masterpieces of European Painting From Dulwich Picture Gallery,” could easily be mistaken for works from the Frick’s incomparable collection tells you all you need to know about the quality on display.

headline: Upward With the Arts | The Louvre’s Cy Twombly Ceiling
text: Last week, the Musée du Louvre introduced its newest acquisition, a 3,750-square-foot ceiling painting created by Cy Twombly to hang in the Salle de Bronzes.

headline: For Theater Troupe Without a Home, All the World’s a Stage
text: “Are you content” the bard once asked, “to make a virtue of necessity / And live, as we do, in this wilderness?”

headline: Father Did the Math; The Maid Solved Problems
text: James Newman (1907-1966) was the kind of bad father who makes for good reading. He was a mathematical genius, the man who popularized the terms “googol” and “googolplex” in a 1940 book, written with Edward Kasner, called “Mathematics and the Imagination.” (The notion of a googol provided the name for Google, the internet search behemoth.) His friends included Albert Einstein and I. F. Stone, and he was a noisy opponent of nuclear proliferation. During the McCarthy era his phones were often tapped, and G-men loitered on the stoop across from his house, watching.

headline: Visual Diary: The Drawdown From Iraq
text: So it ends where it began, a juggernaut of American armor sitting in the Kuwaiti desert waiting to move. This video, filmed in Kuwait, Iraq and Afghanistan, shows the scale of the logistical exercise that Stephen Farrell and Elisabeth Bumiller describe in “When Military Moves a War, There Are No Shortcuts.”

headline: Local Paper Creates iPhone App
text: Thursday’s Phone Smart column is partly dedicated to apps that’ll help you spoof your friends with texts and calls sent to your phone.

headline: Theater Listings: April 2 — 8
text: THEATER

headline: Police Shoot and Kill Man in Brooklyn During Struggle
text: The police, searching for a robbery suspect in Brooklyn, fatally shot a man on Thursday when he  walked up to a car with three plainclothes officers inside and waved a gun, the authorities said.

headline: British Libel Laws Challenged by Journalist Who Called Chiropractic Treatments ‘Bogus’
text: On Thursday, a British court denounced the “chilling effect on public debate” of the country’s expansive libel laws by ruling that a journalist’s comment that certain chiropractic treatments are “bogus” may not be libelous.

headline: Apple Adds iPad Apps to Its Store
text: Big-screen applications are going to be a big selling point for the iPad. But it has largely been unclear what most of those applications would be, since Apple has asked developers to keep quiet about the programs they are creating.

headline: Fabulous Dead People | Mark Hampton
text: In “Interior Decoration,’’ as far as anyone knows the only play ever written about a decorator, the characters Gerald and Phillipa Detweiler (rhymes with Rottweiler) are at a job site waiting for a client when Phillipa reminds her husband what he owes his success to.

headline: The Voices of Autism
text: The latest installment in the Patient Voices series offers a fascinating glimpse into the often silent world of autism.

headline: The iPad Consumer Case #10: A Mousetrap for Old Tech
text: You spend a night surfing, answering e-mail messages, checking your Twitter on Twitterific, the Tweets arrayed in glorious colors according to origin. It is all a scrolling wonder as you marvel at how wicked fast it browses, how quickly you move across content, how natural it is to touch and manipulate stuff you want to learn about.

headline: Beware of Greeks Bearing Buzz Cuts
text: Clanging swords, thundering gods, shrieking monsters  about all that’s missing from the self-consciously kitsch retread of “Clash of the Titans” is Laurence Olivier pitching a fit in a toga. Released in 1981, the first “Clash” starred Sir Larry as Zeus alongside titans of the stage and screen like Claire Bloom (as Hera), Maggie Smith (Thetis) and Ursula Andress (Aphrodite). Harry Hamlin, wearing the “dry look” and robes so voluminous he could have rigged the entire Greek fleet, played Perseus, the half-human son of Zeus, whose adventures and pillowy lips pushed this mythic tale straight into the realm of cinematic camp.

headline: Lucille Lortel Nominees Announced
text: Theatergoers, time to start predicting who should win and who will win awards for the best shows of the season. Nominations for the Lucille Lortel Awards recognizing Off Broadway achievement were announced on Thursday, with the productions of “The Glass Menagerie,” “The Pride” and “When the Rain Stops Falling” each receiving six nods, the highest number.

headline: Two Methods to Evoke Soul Sounds That Shrug
text: What must it have been like when the xx met jj? Did they feverishly chat as if they’d known each other for years? Immediately start trading MP3s of their favorite 1990s R&B songs?

headline: Sarah Staveley-O’Carroll and Michael Matthews
text: ON a spring morning in 2002, Michael Kerry Matthews, a history major and an aspiring filmmaker, watched as a beautiful young woman walked across a cafeteria at Brown University and put two pieces of bread in the toaster on her way to the omelet line. Mr. Matthews felt an overwhelmingly urgency to act.

headline: Tax Burdens by State
text: Just ahead of April 15, the Tax Foundation, an organization that promotes lower tax rates,  released its annual report on state and local taxes. It shows cigarette, gas and alcohol excise tax rates by state; lottery ticket sales per capita in each state; and state debt per capita, among other interesting statistics.

headline: ‘Jenniemae & James’
text: Chapter 1

headline: The Greening of the Waterfront
text: The mayor’s office was in such a rush to showcase the completion of the first phase of its new Brooklyn Bridge Park in Brooklyn that it opened it too soon. Construction crews are still installing handrails. Walkways remain unpaved. Only a few early buds are showing on the freshly planted trees.

headline: E.P.A. to Limit Water Pollution From Mining
text: The Environmental Protection Agency issued tough new water quality guidelines on Thursday that could curtail some of the most contentious coal mining techniques used across Appalachia.

headline: Obama, in Maine, Needles Republicans Over Calls to Repeal Health Care Overhaul
text: PORTLAND, Me. — President Obama continued on Thursday what might be called his Go-for-It Tour, traveling to this Northeastern state — represented by two moderate Republican senators who balked at his health care overhaul — to dare the opposition party to run against it this fall.

headline: Ska Revivalists Enjoy a Revival
text: LONDON

headline: They Treat Trauma but Not Oddballs
text: Shock trauma units like the one depicted in “Miami Medical,” Jerry Bruckheimer’s new drama on CBS, follow the rule of the “golden hour,” the 60 or so minutes doctors have to treat injuries before shock does fatal damage.

headline: Another Bloomberg Aide Exits City Hall
text: Another day, another high-profile departure from the Bloomberg administration.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: New Works to Celebrate a Flutist’s Influence
text: You might think that in celebrating a four-decade concert career, the flutist Carol Wincenc would opt to anthologize past achievements. To the contrary, in two previous concerts during what she has termed her Ruby Anniversary Series, Ms. Wincenc has emphasized her lasting involvement with contemporary music. The final event, presented on Wednesday night in the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at the Juilliard School, followed suit: playing for a full house, Ms. Wincenc offered two substantial premieres and two further works of recent vintage.

headline: ‘Scottsboro Boys’ Not Moving to Broadway, for Now
text: The producers of the Off Broadway musical “The Scottsboro Boys” said on Thursday that they will not try to pursue a transfer to the two Broadway theaters that are going to be vacant beginning next week, Circle in the Square Theater and the Henry Miller’s Theater, because neither were a good fit for the John Kander–Fred Ebb show.

headline: Obama to Boehner: Where’s the Armageddon?
text: At a rally in Maine, President Obama pushed back a bit on Republican assertions that the new health care legislation would herald the end of days.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Seen and Not Heard
text: I was at a party at the home of a semiprofessional artist. Her paintings covered the walls, and the guests ooh’d and ahh’d over them. I thought the work was terrible, but kept my mouth shut. (Later, I showed her Web site to different artists, who all agreed with me.) But I’m wondering: Was I obliged to join the chorus of praise, just to be polite? Is it ever acceptable to be truthful in these circumstances?

headline: Finding the Musical Hidden in a Punk Album
text: AS they assessed the pre-Broadway tryout of the new musical “American Idiot” in California last fall, the director, Michael Mayer, and his creative team kept coming back to the same question: Should they add more dialogue to flesh out the tormented journeys of the three main characters or continue to rely on the songs  by the band Green Day  to do the storytelling?

text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

headline: F.T.C. Role Seen in Exit at Amazon
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Last month, John Doerr, one of America’s most celebrated venture capitalists, announced that he would step down from the board of Amazon.com, a company that he helped to finance and build. At the time, Amazon said Mr. Doerr “has decided not to stand for re-election and will focus more of his time on new ventures.”
