text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Frank Bans Ex-Adviser From Dealing With Panel
text: 6:53 p.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Sewell Chan provides more details in this article about Barney Frank’s rebuke of a former committee adviser.

headline: Lawmaker Rebukes Aide Who Left Work on Finance Bill to Be Lobbyist
text: WASHINGTON — A leading House member issued a stern rebuke on Thursday of a former aide who had become an industry lobbyist after working on legislation to overhaul the nation’s financial regulations.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: A New York City Pillow Fight
text: Prepare to release your inner child this weekend, and not only because the Easter Bunny is coming. Hundreds of people are expected to swarm the area around Union Square on Saturday for the fifth-annual New York City Pillow Fight, promoted by Newmindspace, an interactive public art group based in New York and Toronto.

headline: Teenager Dies, Leaving Love, and a Life, Behind
text: “The Greatest,” an earnest, high-minded, would-be sobfest about grief and healing, left me dry-eyed and squirming with impatience. The first feature written and directed by Shana Feste, this study of a family’s emotional devastation after the death of a perfect teenage son, whom everyone remembers as “the greatest” (awful title!), wants to be a contemporary “Ordinary People.”

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: ‘ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO’  (Friday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series “Dora the Explorer” and “Go, Diego, Go!” have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Children’s Museum of Manhattan, whose exhibition has separate Dora and Diego environments, including Diego’s Animal Rescue Center and Dora’s Fiesta. Intended for ages 2 to 6, the interactive, bilingual displays are designed to teach language, science and music skills, as well as facts about Latin America. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. (until 8 p.m. this Friday); Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street , (212) 721-1223, cmom.org; free with museum admission: $10; $7 for 65+; free for under 1 and members; free to all this Friday from 5 to 8 p.m.20100401

headline: ‘The Velveteen Rabbit’
text: Toward the end of Margery Williams’s 1922 children’s book, “The Velveteen Rabbit,” the title character is about to be consigned to a rubbish fire. It’s not a pleasant fate for a much-loved stuffed animal, but a doctor has declared him infested with germs from his young owner’s bout of scarlet fever. Before the dreaded burning a fairy transforms the shabby toy into a real rabbit. Later he exchanges a brief look of near recognition with the boy who cherished him.

headline: Obama Is Briefed on Floods
text: PORTLAND, Maine — President Obama made an unscheduled stop at a Massachusetts emergency center to meet with Gov. Deval Patrick and receive an update on floods that have been plaguing New England in recent days.

headline: John Bunch, Pianist With Goodman and Bennett, Dies at 88
text: John Bunch, a jazz pianist whose elegant style led to prominent sideman posts with Benny Goodman and Tony Bennett as well as an accomplished solo career, died on Tuesday in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 88.

headline: Subway Nudity Possibly O.K. With Everyone.
text: Update, 7:40 a.m. | So of course, whaddya know, as we suspected, it was a hoax, our supposed friend Charlie lied right into our ears, and we will never trust him again. Happy April 2.

headline: ‘Ash Wednesday, New Orleans’
text: In the first installment of “Continental Picture Show,” the photographer Alec Soth explores cycles of sin and redemption in the aftermath of Mardi Gras.

headline: Slatkin Withdraws From Met’s ‘Traviata’
text: “I do not know whose fault it was,” Verdi wrote after the first performances of “La Traviata” were panned in 1853. “It is best not to talk about it.” Fingers were pointed, however, after the troubled opening-night performance on Monday of “La Traviata” at the Metropolitan Opera, conducted by Leonard Slatkin.

headline: Apple iPad Town Meeting
text: David Pogue answers questions about the Apple iPad.

headline: How to Improve the N.C.A.A. Tournament
text: Critics have long complained that the selection process in the N.C.A.A. tournament favors big-conference teams and excludes smaller colleges. The huge amounts of corporate money involved, they say, turns the tournament into a pre-packaged commercial event. This year, though, fans have been treated to some real drama.

headline: How Fat Was Your Envelope?
text: This evening, applicants to Harvard, Yale, Princeton and a handful of other highly selective colleges will anxiously log on to the institutions’ Web sites to learn whether they have been admitted, denied or invited into limbo with an offer to join the waiting list.

headline: In Fields of Art, Snapping Photos
text: If you want to subject your eye and brain to a stimulating exercise in frustration, see “Haunted: Contemporary Photography/Video/Performance” at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. Next read the show’s catalog. Then try to fit them together in a cohesive way.

headline: After Traveling the World, Hunting for Bugs in Central Park
text: He survived malaria in the Amazon, burned leeches off his body with cigarettes in Nepal, infiltrated the cricket-fighting underworld in Shanghai, and ate fried locusts in Niger.

headline: For Pizza, Thomas H. Lee Goes to Papa Murphy’s
text: The billionaire private equity executive Thomas H. Lee is betting that he can deliver fat returns to his investors by acquiring Papa Murphy’s, a pizza chain that doesn’t even offer delivery. Mr. Lee’s firm, Lee Equity Partners, announced Thursday that it had acquired the “take and bake” fast-food chain from Charlesbank Capital Partners, another private equity firm, for an undisclosed amount.

headline: Memories of a Family, With a Few Detours
text: Watching the work of the French fabulist Michel Gondry can be an intoxicating yet frustrating experience. Few directors share his ability to make images that seem to plug directly into our feelings, particularly those of nostalgia, melancholy and childhood joy.

headline: A Tale of Two Japanese Pitchers
text: Appearing on consecutive days for the first time, the Mets’ Hisanori Takahashi faced two batters in Thursday’s 9-3 loss to the Nationals and got two ground balls as he ended an impressive spring.

headline: Eames Experts Selling Their Singular Trove
text: John and Marilyn Neuhart, designers and historians in Southern California, have devoted much of their careers to documenting the life and work of Mr. Neuhart’s former employers: the mid-20th-century masters Charles and Ray Eames, known for contouring plywood and fiberglass sheets into lightweight chairs.

headline: Picasso Leads the Way Through a Maze of Cubism
text: PHILADELPHIA  Size alone does not a blockbuster make. That’s the lesson of “Picasso and the Avant-Garde in Paris,” at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Rethinking the museum blockbuster isn’t necessarily a bad idea, even if it’s a budgetary necessity. Exhibitions of Vermeer and van Gogh at the Metropolitan and the Modern have shown that the “mini-blockbuster,” an intimate exhibition focused on a single masterpiece, is a viable option. The Philadelphia Museum of Art has done this too, with last summer’s show of works surrounding Duchamp’s “Étant Donnés.”

headline: An Airborne Afghan Folktale
text: It was pretty much a normal day in Afghanistan on Monday.

headline: Lacking Shelter at Home and Abroad
text: It’s all in the eyes. Remember that as you watch “Teza.”

headline: Countries Blame China, Not Nature, for Water Shortage
text: BANGKOK — In southern China, the worst drought in at least 50 years has dried up farmers’ fields and left tens of millions of people short of water.

headline: 19th-Century Battles, Epic and Personal
text: A potent mix of war, wuxia and male bonding, “The Warlords” uses a large canvas  the Taiping Rebellion in 19th-century China  as the backdrop for a small personal drama.

headline: As A.I.G. Gets Good Marks, Benmosche Beams
text: Over the past month, the American International Group has raised more than $51 billion to pay back government financing by selling off two units, and another major subsidiary sold $750 million worth of bonds. And on Thursday, Standard & Poor’s upgraded its outlook for the insurer.

headline: The Vietnam Wars: ‘Matterhorn’
text: Every war novel must at some point confront a central contradiction. Only the truth has any real value, but the truth about war is that it contains nearly unbearable levels of repetition, boredom and meaninglessness. To write honestly about war, you should make readers feel they have endured those things as well. Yet no sane novelist wants to inflict that much discomfort on the audience. And so we read novels (and watch movies) filled with the kind of bravery and drama that make war look at least entertaining, if not admirable. Many of those works are tremendous artistic achievements. But they’re not war.

headline: The Vietnam Wars: ‘The Lotus Eaters’
text: It is April 1975. The North Vietnamese are marching into Saigon, the Americans are fleeing in helicopters. And in Tatjana Soli’s splendid first novel, “The Lotus Eaters,” a group of Western journalists sip “liberated” Champagne on the roof of the Caravelle Hotel as they reflect on all that has been lost. For Helen, a veteran photographer who made her name covering the war, the resounding absence of planes and artillery has transformed Saigon into an eerie place of “nostalgia and history and failure.” Failed dreams and failed ambitions may be the very stuff from which Vietnam narratives are fashioned; but although Helen’s war is over, there is no guarantee she will be on a plane home. As one of her colleagues says ominously, “The war doesn’t ever have to end for us.” For the interpreters of violence there will always be another war zone with new treasures of heartbreaking stories.

headline: Dissecting the Relationship of Self-Aware Urbanites
text: Separation anxiety proves tough to manage in “Breaking Upwards,” a thoroughly charming romantic comedy that takes a fresh look at a spoiled relationship.

headline: Up Front: Vietnam
text: April 30 will mark the 35th anniversary of the fall of Saigon, the event that ended the Vietnam War and with it the belief in the inevitability of American victory in wars fought on foreign soil.

headline: What’s Left?
text: In his 1977 Inaugural Address, Jimmy Carter called the United States “a purely idealistic nation” and expressed the hope that his presidency would be one of “competent and compassionate” government, even as he had to allow for diminished expectations. “We have learned,” he explained, that “even our great nation has its recognized limits.” Nixon, Vietnam and Watergate had exhausted our political spirits. As the 1970s gave way to the 1980s, we waited for the cold war to catch fire, the oil shortage to become utter depletion, the Iran hostage crisis to end in disaster. Potential spies and traitors could be anywhere, but optimism was hard to find.

headline: The Parent Problem in Young Adult Lit
text: It took a surprisingly long time for bad parents to show up in children’s books. Did you ever notice how few there are, compared with, say, the self-centered and murderous parents in Greek mythology or the Bible? In American literature, children’s and adult books didn’t sharply diverge as categories until the 20th century, so it’s not clear whether we should even include that mean, kidnapping drunk, Pap Finn.

headline: Journey’s End
text: We’ve all met Kevin Quinn, the 50-year-old protagonist of James Hynes’s fourth novel, “Next”; indeed, a fair number of us actually are Kevin Quinn, caught at midlife somewhere between jaunty and defeated, living with one foot in the present and one foot firmly in the past. In some ultimately perilous way, as we should be warned by the novel’s title, Kevin isn’t very good at thinking about what’s next.

headline: As I Am Egypt’s Queen
text: The name Cleopatra calls up cheap flashes of Hollywood glitz, a diva in jewels, not a regal eminence invested with the power to drive armies. Those who think they know anything about her at all can do little more than recall some nebulous fame as a beautiful, cunning seductress of mighty men in togas. She’s more the stuff of fable for us than a real person who inhabited her own square of time and space. But inhabit one she did, and with a good deal more intelligence, élan and tact than exercised by most of her male allies and enemies in the Roman world.

headline: Thine Is the Kingdom
text: It is only a brief moment, a seemingly inconclusive ­exchange in the midst of one of the most significant interviews in human history. In the Gospel of John, Jesus of Nazareth has been arrested and brought before Pontius Pilate, the Roman governor of Judea. Improbably polite, reflective and reluctant to sentence Jesus to death (the historical Pilate was in fact brutal and quick-tempered), Pilate is portrayed as a patient questioner of this charismatic itinerant preacher. “So you are a king?” Pilate asks, and Jesus says: “You say that I am a king. I was born for this, and I came into the world for this: to testify to the truth. Everyone who is committed to the truth listens to my voice.” Then, in what I imagine to be a cynical, world-weary tone, Pilate replies, “What is truth?”

headline: Culture Clash
text: It’s a long way from Park Avenue: the beautiful, desolate, casually despoiled landscape of the Pyrénées-Orientales in southernmost France, where Fernanda Eberstadt moved with her husband and children in 1998 and where she has set her latest novel. Eberstadt grew up in a fancifully ornate Upper East Side apartment with pistachio-green velvet walls, ancient statuary and a gold Marilyn by Andy Warhol in the living room, as she reminisced in The New York Observer in 2007. It was a childhood studded with glamour: in 1962 (little Fernanda was just 2 at the time) her parents — the photographer and psychotherapist Fredrick Eberstadt and the novelist Isabel Eberstadt — gave a legendary costume party at which Jacqueline Kennedy, flanked by Secret Service escorts, danced to a reggae band till dawn.

headline: Under the Dome
text: One of the paradoxes of punk is that a movement based on nihilism led to such a wealth of creativity. This dichotomy is at the heart of Peter Bognanni’s first novel, “The House of Tomorrow,” which unexpectedly pits the teaching of R. Buckminster Fuller, architect, philosopher and futurist, against the misanthropy of punk. There’s only going to be one winner, but it is a measure of Bognanni’s empathy that his narrator’s decision is never an easy one.

headline: Swept Away
text: The Dutch author Margriet de Moor, a classical singer turned novelist, writes fiction that is musical, even when it doesn’t star castrati (“The Virtuoso”) or suggest a four-part fugue (“First Gray, Then White, Then Blue”). Her epigraphs cite musicians (Schoenberg, Schubert); her prose is shot through with recurring leitmotifs and song; and her sensitivity to sound and tempo permeates her new novel.

headline: We Three Kings
text: In July 1917 — the point at which Miranda Carter opens this enterprising his­tory of imperial vicissitudes and royal reversals — George V, king of Great Britain and emperor of India, resolved to change his name. In that scorching summer, King George was a worried man. His Russian cousin, Czar Nicholas II, had recently lost his throne and was under house arrest. In Germany, another imperial cousin, Wilhelm II, had been stripped of his proudest title, “supreme warlord.” Deprived of power, Wilhelm discovered a hitherto absent sense of humor. Hearing that the English king had decided to bury his German connections by proclaiming himself a member of the newly formed House of Windsor, the emperor pondered the possibilities for a forthcoming Shakespearean production: “The Merry Wives of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha.”

headline: Ratings Fall on Newscasts at 2 Networks
text: With buyouts and layoffs in progress, the mood at ABC News cannot be good. It was probably not enhanced by the ratings report for the first quarter of the year showing that the network’s evening newscast, “World News,” had sunk to the lowest numbers the program has had in a first quarter since the People Meter was introduced by Nielsen in 1987.

headline: Adaptation
text: Here’s one idea for what not to do if you’re young, unsure of yourself and burdened with unresolved grief: Take your mess to a foreign culture for a year and try to dump it there.

headline: Seized
text: About midway through Siri ­Hustvedt’s memoir, she tells the story of a 50-year-old embarrassment: As a young child visiting relatives in Norway, she tried to comfort an older cousin who’d begun weeping, by reaching up and patting her on the back. When the adults laughed, the little girl was “seized by burning humiliation.” This sense of powerlessness in a grown-ups’ world may bring to mind similar incidents for readers of “The Shaking Woman; Or, A History of My Nerves.” Yet Hustvedt, who grew up to become an accomplished novelist and essayist, stresses the moment’s particularity. “I now understand,” she writes, “that the adults’ laughter wasn’t malicious, but the assault on my dignity has lasted, and it shaped my motherhood with my own daughter.”

headline: Dance Dance Revolution
text: Most of the lingering images of the disco era aren’t pretty: strobe-lit suburbanites doing the hustle, John Travolta’s white polyester suit and campy preening in “Saturday Night Fever,” mobs pushing and screaming to get into Studio 54. The music itself is easy to snicker at. Set to a clockwork thump, it ordered you to boogie-oogie-oogie or to shake, shake, shake your booty. Disco stormed the charts from 1973 through 1979, but many critics see it as the soundtrack of a vapid decade — a time in which self-indulgence replaced the lofty striving of the ’60s.

headline: Paperback Row
text: HOW IT ENDED: New and Collected Stories,  by Jay McInerney (Vintage, $15.95.) The short fiction collected here spans the nearly three decades of McInerney’s career, beginning with early stories like “It’s Six A.M. Do You Know Where You Are?,” which grew into his first novel, “Bright Lights, Big City.” This book, his 10th, reminds us “how impressively broad McInerney’s scope has been,” our reviewer, Sam Tanenhaus, said, adding that McInerney’s prose seems “free of self-consciousness and of mannerism, at once postmodern and naturalistic.”

headline: Nonfiction Chronicle
text: MAKING TOAST  A Family Story.  By Roger Rosenblatt.  Ecco/HarperCollins, $21.99.

headline: Reading Tim O’Brien in Hanoi
text: Last month, on a typically dull, gray late-winter Hanoi day, I stopped in at the city’s sole respectable foreign-language bookstore, the Bookworm, for a conversation with a Vietnamese fan of Tim O’Brien. “The Things They Carried,” O’Brien’s celebrated collection of linked stories about the Vietnam War, has just been reissued in a 20th-anniversary edition, and I was interested in gathering a Vietnamese perspective on O’Brien’s work. But it took me days of calls and e-mail messages to find anyone in Hanoi who had read any of it. Finally the manager of the Bookworm suggested I speak with Tran Ngoc Hieu, a lecturer at Hanoi’s Pedagogical University. I needed a while to track him down, as he is perhaps the only person in the city who does not use a mobile phone. Hieu, 30, looks young for his age, and compensates by wearing a sport jacket and speaking a careful, deliberate English with an exceptionally rich vocabulary, interrupting himself frequently to apologize for not speaking English well.

headline: Georgia: Award in Reverse Discrimination Suit
text: A jury awarded more than $180,000 in damages Thursday in a reverse discrimination case against DeKalb County and its first black chief executive, Vernon Jones. Three white former managers in the county’s Parks and Recreation Department claimed they were victims of an attempt to replace whites with blacks. A fourth former employee, who is black, claimed he suffered retaliation when he refused to “dig up dirt” on his white colleagues. Mr. Jones, who served from 2001 to 2009, is running for Congress. He denied he had discriminated based on race and compared himself to President Obama. According to trial testimony, the county had 33 black and 61 white top managers when Mr. Jones took office and 60 blacks and 57 whites five years later.

headline: Marketing to a Problem That Needs a Polite Name
text: IN a television commercial for Poise, the bladder protection brand made by Kimberly-Clark, Whoopi Goldberg, the actress and co-host of “The View,” depicts historical figures including Helen of Troy and Joan of Arc suffering from weak bladders. “I don’t want to be painted,” says Ms. Goldberg, dressed as Mona Lisa. “I want to be dry.” As Cleopatra, she says, “I have a problem — I’ve been leaking for years.”

headline: What We’re Reading: The April Fools’ Edition
text: Thursday’s installment is a mixture of the fake and the real, but the tech editors and reporters of The New York Times sorted it out.

headline: Court Ruling on Wiretap Is a Challenge for Obama
text: WASHINGTON — As a presidential candidate, Senator Barack Obama declared that it was “unconstitutional and illegal” for the Bush administration to conduct warrantless surveillance of Americans. Many of his supporters said likewise.

headline: With Reyes Out, Mets’ Tejada Could Get a Shot
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. – With Jose Reyes starting the season on the disabled list, the Mets will need a backup for Alex Cora. Jerry Manuel said the 20-year-old Ruben Tejada and the veteran Russ Adams were the top two candidates, and that Tejada, who was hitting .344 despite never playing above Class AA, was the front runner.

headline: The Times Company Sells Part of Its Boston Red Sox Holdings
text: The New York Times Company said on Thursday that it had sold a small slice of its minority ownership of the Boston Red Sox and related properties.

headline: For the Birds
text: Video | Theatrical trailer for “Birdemic,” the cheesy cult horror flick being ranked right up there with “Plan 9 From Outer Space”:

headline: Massachusetts Insurance Regulators Reject Most Requests for Higher Rates
text: With the encouragement of Gov. Deval L. Patrick, Massachusetts insurance regulators took the extraordinary step Thursday of rejecting nearly 9 out of 10 rate increases requested by the state’s health insurers.

headline: Quake Survivors Freed From Immigration Jails
text: More than three dozen Haitian earthquake survivors were released from Florida immigration jails on Thursday after more than two months in the custody of Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

headline: Fordham Student Has His Sights Set on Nascar
text: Chase Mattioli, a 20-year-old sophomore business administration major at Fordham, reached under the bed in his dormitory room and pulled out a large blue plastic tub. He pried open the lid to reveal its contents: a steering wheel, a set of pedals and a gearshift.

headline: Discharges From Service Still Possible, Official Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Army secretary, John M. McHugh, said Thursday that he had incorrectly stated that there was a moratorium on the discharge of gay members of the military.

headline: Put This on a Billboard: Droopy Pants Can Kill
text: Hector Quinones didn’t amount to much in life, but he managed in death to make a powerful fashion statement. The statement boiled down to this: Don’t be a jerk like me.

headline: Top European Clerics Defend Benedict
text: ROME — Several prominent European churchmen on Thursday denounced suggestions that Pope Benedict XVI was anything but a vigorous defender of victims of priestly sexual abuse, arguing that the pope should not be criticized for his oversight of such cases.

headline: Clijsters Outlasts Henin to Advance to Key Biscayne Final
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Kim Clijsters’s and Justine Henin’s closely intertwined careers converged again in another captivating semifinal clash between two Belgian champions.

headline: A City Struggles to Make Room for Its Children
text: SEATTLE — Jennifer Piper was at the Olympic Sculpture Park with her family the other day and the art did what art can do: it got her thinking. With the waterfront park bustling with bicyclists and joggers, with children playing hide and seek behind Richard Serra’s abstract sculpture  “Wake,”  why did so many signs instruct people not to touch anything?

headline: Despite Few Hunters, Seal Pups Face Threats
text: OTTAWA — The annual hunt for harp seals off the coast of eastern Canada will barely take place this year. But this is not good news for the seals.

headline: Kerry Tries to Nudge Syria to Re-engage With the U.S.
text: CAIRO — Senator John Kerry met Thursday with President Bashar al-Assad of Syria in Damascus, another indication that the United States is moving to re-engage with Syria as the Obama administration works to resuscitate Middle East peace talks.

headline: Health Care for All, With Obama Down the Street
text: PORTLAND, Me.

headline: How a Molesting Case Emerged Decades Later
text: ESSEN, Germany — The case that has raised questions about the future pope’s handling of a pedophile priest in Germany came to light three decades after it occurred, and then almost by chance. It happened when Wilfried Fesselmann, an early victim, said he stumbled on Internet photographs of the priest who sexually abused him, still working with children.

headline: From Lithuania, a View of Austerity’s Costs
text: VILNIUS, Lithuania — If leaders of the world’s many indebted countries want to see what austerity looks like, they might want to visit this Baltic nation of 3.3 million.

headline: Drought Along the Mekong River
text: A severe drought has dried up farmers’ fields and left tens of millions of people short of water in southern China and Southeast Asia.

headline: For World Cup, Javier Hernández Could Be Mexico’s Next Big Thing
text: A little more than a year ago, Javier Hernández sat down to breakfast at a restaurant with his mother, his father and his agent. What was supposed to be a discussion on how best to move his soccer career along instead turned into a counseling session.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,378 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

headline: Does Wall Street Need an Estrogen Injection?
text: One of the more intriguing — yet unanswerable — questions that has arisen in the wake of the financial crisis is whether all that alpha-male testosterone at the top of Wall Street firms helped to ratchet up the excessive risk-taking, inflating the housing and securitization bubbles, the bursting of which led to a credit freeze and the worst recession in generations.

headline: J.F. terHorst, Ford Press Secretary, Dies at 87
text: J. F. terHorst, a reporter who in August 1974 was appointed White House press secretary by an old friend, President Gerald R. Ford, but who resigned less than a month later when Ford granted former President Richard M. Nixon an unconditional pardon in connection with the Watergate scandal, died Wednesday in Asheville, N.C. He was 87.

headline: A Cellphone Fine, Billed as Small, Is No Longer That
text: What started as a quest for safer driving could soon turn into a new revenue stream worth tens of millions of dollars to state and local governments. A bill working its way through Sacramento could sharply increase the penalties for driving while using a handheld cellphone, fines that some say are already deceptively higher than had been expected.

headline: Cameras for the Police
text: Some police departments in the Bay Area are expanding their use of crime-fighting technology, which can raise privacy questions. In some cases, the devices can be used to monitor the actions of police officers as well as the public. “A number of these technologies can be additional useful tools for law enforcement, but none of them is a panacea,” said David Onek, a senior fellow at the Berkeley Center for Criminal Justice and a member of the San Francisco Police Commission. “We need to look at how effective each is and balance that against legitimate civil liberties concerns.”

headline: South Africa: Union Leader’s Wife Under Scrutiny Over Financial Ties
text: Noluthando Vavi, the wife of the general secretary of the South Africa’s largest labor federation, is being paid $8,000 a month to market financial products to union members, according to an investigation by the newspaper The Mail and Guardian. Mrs. Vavi’s husband, Zwelinzima Vavi, above, has been calling for “lifestyle audits” of all senior politicians to root out the corrupt. Veon Bock, chief executive of the company involved, is said to have offered $16,000 to a reporter to withhold the story — the first payment of which was captured on a hidden video camera.

headline: Gravely Ill Butler Alumnus Joins His Team
text: INDIANAPOLIS

headline: Seeking to Help Budding Researchers With a Click of the Mouse
text: Jonas Ketterle, a top mechanical engineering student at Stanford University, and his colleague Mike Lin, a sustainable-design lecturer at Stanford and Yale, are studying how 150 million people in developing countries make do using electricity from hacked car batteries.

headline: Pay Garnishments Rise as Debtors Fall Behind
text: PHOENIX — When the bank sued Leann Weaver for not paying her credit card balance, her reaction was typical for someone in that situation. Personal and financial setbacks weighed her down, and she knew she owed the $2,470. So she never went to court to defend herself.

headline: 3 Relatives Dead, Child Feared Speaking Up, Police Say
text: CHARLOTTE — A 10-year-old girl ran out of her home with her 2-year-old brother to waiting police officers late Monday night. Leaving behind her father, who then fatally shot himself, the girl proceeded to help unravel a grisly murder-suicide, the police said. Two adults and two children were dead.

headline: Kenya: Court Is Given Names of Suspects in Election Violence
text: The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court in The Hague said Thursday that he had presented judges with a list of 20 suspects who he believed were most responsible for financing or organizing the violence after the 2007 elections in Kenya. More than 1,100 people were killed, many in ethnic violence, as the two leading parties quarreled over election results. The prosecutor, Luis Moreno-Ocampo, said at a news conference that the suspects included political and business leaders from both parties and that he would soon open criminal investigations against them. He provided no names. On Wednesday, two judges in The Hague said the international court had jurisdiction in the case after Kenya had failed to start its own prosecutions.

headline: On Bronx Stoops, a Highway’s Traffic Entertains
text: Watching traffic may not be a spectator sport, but Harriette Moore concentrates on the action before her as if she were in the front row at Wimbledon.

headline: Financial Reform 101
text: Let’s face it: Financial reform is a hard issue to follow. It’s not like health reform, which was fairly straightforward once you cut through the nonsense. Reasonable people can and do disagree about exactly what we should do to avert another banking crisis.

headline: After Traveling the World, Hunting Bugs in New York
text: He survived malaria in the Amazon, burned leeches off his body with cigarettes in Nepal, infiltrated the cricket-fighting underworld in Shanghai, and ate fried locusts in Niger.

headline: Lead Vanishes for King of the Downturn
text: JPMorgan’s share of the market for underwriting and mergers, which moved up in the financial crisis, is starting to slip.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 1, 2010

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of Good Friday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations

headline: Girls! Girls! Girls!
text: "Christopher Owens's longing for simple pleasures belies his tumultuous adolescence (his mother belonged to the Children of God sect): "I wish I had a suntan, I wish I had a pizza and a bottle of wine," he opines, his voice androgynous and warped," writes Amanda Petrusich. "Girls's songs are sad, but also buoyant and shimmery in the spirit of the Beach Boys or Elvis Costello; they promise redemption and renewal, something we can all stand to be reminded of." The band will be at Webster Hall on Saturday with Dum Dum Girls.

headline: Pillow Fight
text: It may not warrant a special designation from the United Nations, but Saturday is International Pillow Fight Day. Leave your jammies on, grab a soft, non-feather pillow, and head to Union Square for the fifth annual event. The fight, which is timed to coincide with other fights around the world, is hosted by Newmindspace, which produces "interactive public art, creative cultural interventions and urban bliss dissemination." Participants must swing lightly and clean up their mess. All leftover pillows will be donated to two Manhattan no-kill animal shelters to make bedding for puppies and kittens. The fight kicks off at 3 p.m.

headline: Seeing ‘Red’
text: "Even before you see his eyes, you're aware of the force of his gaze. Portraying the artist Mark Rothko, Alfred Molina sits with his back to the audience at the beginning of 'Red,' John Logan's intense and exciting two-character bio-drama, which opened on Thursday night at the Golden Theater," writes Ben Brantley. "Yet the set of his neck and shoulders makes it clear that he is staring hard and hungrily, locked in visual communion with the object before him. That's an abstract painting, copied from Rothko, and it is indeed very red and very dramatic. But it is Mr. Molina's stare that invests it with real drama." The show, set in a New York studio on the Bowery in the late 1950s, follows a new assistant as he is initiated into the aesthetic of the artist. " 'Red,' which arrives as fresh, yes, as paint from its recent premiere at the Donmar Warehouse in London, initially registers as a visceral exercise in art appreciation. Fortunately though, it turns out to be more a study in artist appreciation, a portrait of an angry and brilliant mind that asks you to feel the shape and texture of thoughts."

headline: Hayward Grows Into Star’s Role for Butler
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Butler Coach Brad Stevens still gets giddy recalling the day Gordon Hayward committed to playing for him nearly three years ago.

headline: Build America Bonds Will Save $12.3 Billion, Analysis Says
text: WASHINGTON — State and local governments will eventually save $12.3 billion from bonds issued in the first year of the Build America Bonds program, a Treasury Department analysis has found, compared with what they would have spent by issuing traditional tax-exempt bonds to finance projects.

headline: Questions for School on Bullying and a Suicide
text: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass. — On one point, everyone here agrees: the high school students who taunted and threatened Phoebe Prince for three months, until she hanged herself, deserve to be punished.

headline: Manhattan Surrogate’s Court Judge Is Acquitted
text: A jury decided on Thursday that a judge in Surrogate’s Court in Manhattan, along with her mentor and former boss, did not break the law by making transactions that ended with a $250,000 contribution to the judge’s campaign.

headline: State Court Limits Scope of Warrants for Searches
text: New York’s highest court ruled on Thursday that police departments cannot use general warrants that apply to a specific location to search every person they find there unless there is probable cause to believe that a particular person is involved in criminal activity.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Perfect Night for Rangers, Who Weren’t Even Playing
text: Seven games on Thursday night, including three with a direct impact on the race for the last Eastern Conference playoff spot. The 10th-place Rangers were idle but watching, you bet, and to their delight, every single result turned out their way. They go into Friday’s game at Tampa Bay 4 points out of the playoffs with at least a game in hand on everyone. Home teams listed first:

headline: Knicks’ McGrady, His Knee Healing, Says Wait Till Next Year
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — With a pristine Yankees cap pulled tight on his head and his athletic frame draped in matching navy sweats, Tracy McGrady looks as if he could have just stepped off the field at spring training.

headline: Police Kill Man Wielding a Gun
text: The police, searching for a serial-robbery suspect in Brooklyn, fatally shot a man on Thursday after he walked up to a car with three plainclothes officers inside and waved a gun, the authorities said.

headline: Man Arrested in Sunday Killings in Subway
text: The police arrested a suspect on Thursday in the subway stabbing deaths of two men, saying he had implicated himself in the Sunday killings on the No. 2 train.

headline: Mt. Sinai Vetoes Partnership With Struggling St. Vincent’s
text: Another potential savior has decided to pass on St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan, leaving the struggling Greenwich Village institution without a feasible rescue plan as it tries to stave off closing.

headline: Certain Fricassee
text: I’m kind of pretty, and pretty damn smart,I like romantic things like music and art,And as you know I have a gigantic heart!So why don’t I have a boyfriend?It sucks to be me!— Kate Monster

headline: In Pinched Times, a Frugal Winery Builds
text: As guests of last month’s World of Pinot Noir  California’s premier pinot noir conference  filed off the bus at Foxen Vineyards, the site of afternoon tastings and panel discussions, they were greeted with a surprising sight: a brand new winery complex, almost sparkling in the sun.

headline: Doing the iPad Math: Utility + Price + Desire
text: If the much-promoted iPad is going to be a mainstream consumer hit, Apple is going to have to change the minds of people like Jon Byron.

headline: To iPad, or Not to iPad
text: In the days leading up to the arrival of Apple's iPad, New York Times reporter Claire Cain Miller hit the streets of New York City to find out if consumers are willing to carry yet another gadget.

headline: Keeping the Family Plot
text: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.

headline: If All Sports Are Local, So Is ESPN
text: A year ago, ESPN started going local. For an empire devoted to conquering the United States and the world on its multitude of media platforms, Web sites focused on major cities offered a way to fulfill its manifest destiny.

headline: Apps for iPad From Some TV Networks, Not All
text: Television networks are taking sharply different approaches to the iPad.

headline: For Minaya, Mets’ Glass Is Always Half Full
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — On the first day that pitchers and catchers reported to spring training, closer Francisco Rodriguez arrived with pinkeye, the result of an eye infection. Six weeks later, as the Mets broke camp, General Manager Omar Minaya tried to look ahead through rose-colored lenses. What other choice did he have?

headline: Sharp Increase in March in Personal Bankruptcies
text: More Americans filed for bankruptcy protection in March than during any month since the federal personal bankruptcy law was tightened in October 2005, a new report says, a result of high unemployment and the housing crash.

headline: Without Rancor, Palin Show Has Debut on Fox
text: Sarah Palin’s new television special debuted on Fox News on Thursday evening and, despite the early controversy that preceded it, appeared relatively tame.

headline: Girardi Makes It Official: Granderson in Center and Gardner in Left
text: DUNEDIN, Fla. — In the Yankees’ first post-World Series championship spring training in nine years, Manager Joe Girardi had two major decisions to make. The first was tough. The second appeared obvious, especially to Brett Gardner.

headline: In Europe, a Call for Tighter Caps on Greenhouse Gas Emissions
text: BRUSSELS — Climate advocates called for tighter caps on greenhouse gas emissions in the European Union after figures released on Thursday showed that some of the dirtiest industries benefited from a surplus of permits.

headline: Corrections
text: The State of the Art column on Thursday, about the Apple iPad, misstated the top-level domain name of Slashdot, a technology news site, in some copies. It is Slashdot.org, not Slashdot.com.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Sunday about the Passover Seder at the White House misspelled, in some editions, the surname of one attendee at the dinner. He is Herbie Ziskend, not Ziskind.

headline: Basketball 101, Through Jaded-Colored Glasses
text: Dan McGrath is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: The Pulse: Charity Is Fined Over Fencing Rule
Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about a detailed defense of Pope Benedict XVI’s handling of sexual abuse cases given by a Vatican official, Cardinal William J. Levada, in which he criticized The Times’s coverage as unfair, misstated the cardinal’s former role with the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops. He was a member and served on panels, but never served as the head of the group or in another leadership post. The article also misstated the top position in the organization. It is president; there is no chairman.

headline: The Church Abuse Scandal
text: To the Editor:

headline: This Time, Listen
text: The New York State Legislature made a much-needed change when it reauthorized the law that gave Mayor Michael Bloomberg direct control of New York City schools. It required him to confer more closely with parents, community groups and other stakeholders before closing schools. We have long been concerned about Mr. Bloomberg’s commitment to that process  and a recent ruling by the State Supreme Court made us worry more.

headline: Everybody Wins
text: The new automobile fuel economy standards formally adopted by the Obama administration on Thursday will yield a trifecta of benefits: reduced dependence on foreign oil, fewer greenhouse gas emissions, and consumer savings at the pump.

headline: Serbia’s Honest Apology
text: London

headline: Someone New Is Watching
text: Ever since the semi-independent Office of Congressional Ethics was created two years ago to vet allegations against lawmakers, cynics wondered how soon it would fall into the find-no-evil track record of the House ethics committee it serves. The new office showed encouraging initiative this week when it released a report that would have been buried from public notice under the old way of doing business.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday that detailed the chronology of the case of the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphy, who was accused of molesting as many as 200 deaf boys at a school in Wisconsin over many years, misstated the date of his death in 1998. It was Aug. 21, not. Sept. 2.

headline: Who Froze the Mideast Peace Process?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Ecstasy of Fiscal Policy
text: Let’s say you’re a political consultant. You’re sitting there in your West Hollywood bondage-themed strip club with party donors picking up the tab, and, of course, you’re thinking about what a great country this is. Swept up in the spirit of gratitude, you decide you’d like to give back. You’d like to solve the country’s looming fiscal catastrophe.

headline: The Myth of Mean Girls
text: IF nine South Hadley, Mass., high school students  seven of them girls  are proved to have criminally bullied another girl who then committed suicide, as prosecutors have charged, they deserve serious legal and community condemnation.

headline: On the Front Line
text: Passing health care reform was only half of the job. It is just as important  likely just as politically difficult  to quickly and smoothly carry out the reforms. Republican critics have made clear that they are not going to stop fighting just because comprehensive reform has become the law of the land.

headline: Cash Incentives for the Poor
text: To the Editor:

headline: Helping Boys Who Are Lagging in School
text: To the Editor:

headline: Video Gambling in Bars Holds Promise of Handsome Revenues
text: On Chicago’s gritty far southeast corner, which in the past few decades has seen factories rust and grandiose plans for a Lake Calumet airport fizzle, a couple of dozen neighborhood bar and restaurant owners gathered at the Knights of Columbus hall on a late winter evening to learn about the latest big-ticket plan: video gambling.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Thursday with an article about record rains causing flooding in Rhode Island misspelled the name of a dam along the Pawtuxet River in West Warwick. It is the Artic Dam, not Arctic.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Sunday about reports by the Internal Affairs Bureau of the New York Police Department that detail crimes by police officers over the years misstated the year that the Lexow Commission investigated payoffs to officers by operators of brothels and gambling dens. It was 1894, not 1884.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about the continuing debate over menthol flavorings in cigarettes misstated the position of Dr. Mark S. Clanton, who was appointed by the Food and Drug Administration to a new scientific committee that will examine the issue. He is the chief medical officer of a division of the American Cancer Society, representing six states, not of the entire society.

headline: Dayton Wins N.I.T. and May Become Trivia Answer

headline: Amid Signs of Spring, Hints of Green
text: FOR decades, the crowds expected flashy supercars and futuristic design studies from any self-respecting auto show. But between the still-shabby economy and the specter of new fuel economy and carbon-dioxide regulations, the 2010 New York International Auto Show is the biggest eat-your-peas auto affair of recent memory, offering next to nothing in high-zoot style, speed or concept cars that hadn’t already been seen elsewhere.

headline: Shooting the Show’s Stars
text: A LUSCIOUS yellow Ferrari sits front and center in the company’s display at the auto show, a blond draped over the front fender. It’s a natural snapshot for anyone who loves cars, or blonds, or both.

headline: Monthly Film Festival Designed to Be Bad
text: Like many excellent ideas, “Bad Meaning Good” was born over a late-night round of beers. Unlike so many others, BMG, a monthly film series celebrating the worst in movie making, survived to see the light of day.

headline: Aldermen Come Close to Blow at Mayor
text: Chicago aldermen have to take their victories where they can. A special session of the City Council on Wednesday called by Aldermen Joe Moore (49th Ward), Ricardo Munoz (22nd) and Willie Cochran (20th ) to override Mayor Richard M. Daley’s proposal to centralize control over city street sweepers attracted just 25 aldermen, one shy of a quorum.

text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Corrections
text: A music review on March 1 about the American Symphony Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall, where it played Alexander Lokshin’s Symphony No. 4 among other works, referred incompletely to program information about Lokshin, a Russian composer who ran afoul of the Stalin regime. In addition to noting that former gulag prisoners had accused Lokshin of being an informer, the program said that it was unclear if the accusations were true, and that Lokshin had denied them. (Lokshin’s son raised the issue on Saturday, in an e-mail message.)

headline: Absences Worsen L.P.G.A.’s Headache
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — The 10th group off the first tee Thursday at the Kraft Nabisco Championship was technically a single.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about research into the way the brain processes literature misstated the name of the university where Lisa Zunshine, who is investigating the subject, is a professor of English. It is the University of Kentucky, not Kentucky University. The article also misidentified the school where Ms. Zunshine was a graduate student. It is the University of California, Santa Barbara  not Stanford.

headline: Corrections
text: A music column on Thursday about William Schuman, the composer who also served as president of the Juilliard School and Lincoln Center, misidentified the borough of New York City in which he was born. It was Manhattan, not the Bronx.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Janet Cardiff & George Bures Miller
text: Few artists work with sound more inventively and with a cannier sense of theater than Janet Cardiff and George Bures Miller. The main attraction here is “The Carnie,” a carousel in a dark room that looks and sounds like something you’d encounter in a “Twilight Zone” episode. In addition to Disney-esque plastic riding figures  including a giraffe, a deer, a cow and a frighteningly animated crescent moon  it has an arched, vertical framework dotted by blinking lights from which effigies of children dangle like angels. It is also outfitted with a drum kit that plays itself. As the whole merry-go-round revolves, speakers broadcast ominous, cacophonous modern music by the electronic composer Freida Abtan.

headline: John Bock
text: John Bock’s “Maltreated Frigate,” a video and sculptural documentation of an ambitious performance work involving himself and two actors, is one of the standouts in “Skin Fruit” at the New Museum. In his fifth solo show in New York (and at Kern), he demonstrates his ability to pare down, lighten up and also diversify.

headline: Lyle Ashton Harris
text: The New York artist Lyle Ashton Harris has spent a fair amount of time in Africa. For two years in the 1970s he lived in Tanzania. He later made extended trips to South Africa. Since 2005 he has spent part of every year teaching at the New York University extension in Accra, Ghana. His solo show at CRG is inspired by contemporary Ghana, and like much of his art, it’s a knotty fusion of seductive beauty and sharp sociopolitical observation.

headline: Amar Kanwar
text: Although the filmmaker Amar Kanwar is highly regarded internationally, he’s not much seen on the biennial glamour circuit. He continues to live in New Delhi, where he was born in 1964. And his documentary-based art is unswervingly grounded in what he once called “issues of justice,” meaning social justice. At the same time, however dark the content of his work, he is a vivid shaper of narratives, as two ambitious pieces at Marian Goodman attest.

headline: Nari Ward
text: Is the art world having its own referendum on health care? There’s an ambulance at the Whitney Biennial, by the Bruce High Quality Foundation, and another in Nari Ward’s first solo exhibition at Lehmann Maupin.

headline: Security Checks on Flights to U.S. to Be Revamped
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has signed off on new security protocols for people flying to the United States, establishing a system that uses intelligence information and assessment of threats to identify passengers who could have links to terrorism, a senior administration official said Thursday.

headline: Slight Rise in Manhattan Apartment Prices in First Quarter, Data Show
text: Apartment prices in Manhattan rose modestly in the first three months of this year compared with the previous quarter, but they were well below the peak of 2008, according to sales reports to be released on Friday by four major brokerage firms.

headline: Letter: A Trek in Nepal
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Last Footfall in Nepal” (March 21): I trekked in Nepal last October, and I enjoyed the article about the Annapurna Circuit. Trekking in the Himalayas is wonderful, but you need to be prepared. Anyone planning such a trek should consider the problem of contaminated water (use filters or purification tablets or boil drinking and cooking water), the possibility of unsanitary food preparation practices and the lack of easily available medical help.

headline: Letter: Preserving Macao
text: To the Editor: I enjoyed Julie Makinen’s article “Fresh Look for a Landmark” (March 21), about the restoration of the Mandarin’s House in Macao. This looks like a triumph of renovation, and Macao needs publicity on its historical and cultural attractions.

headline: The TV Watch: Palin’s Canned ‘American Stories’
text: Sarah Palin didn’t reload, she retreated into canned television formula. Fans who thought that having her own Fox News program would allow the former Alaska governor to be her true spontaneous and unfettered self had to feel let down by the debut of “Real American Stories” on Thursday night.

headline: M.L.S. Expands Designated Player Rule
text: Major League Soccer said Thursday that it was expanding the designated player rule — the so-called Beckham rule — to give clubs the chance to sign two players above the M.L.S. salary cap. The league also said it would give teams the option of buying a third slot for $250,000.

headline: Warming Trend
text: There is perhaps no better symbol of the Southern California lifestyle than the heat lamp, that industrial, propane-fueled pillar that magically appears on every restaurant terrace the moment the mercury dips below 70. As ubiquitous as cellphone towers — and as grimly utilitarian — the lamps are a not so subtle reminder that even L.A. is prone to the change of seasons. Sort of, anyway. Kindle Living aims to give the heat lamp an image makeover by reimagining it as an actual lamp. The three models currently in production come complete with pleated shades, curvaceous bases (to hide unsightly propane tanks) and an array of colors, like black — perfect for that post-Oscar bash — or pale pink for a poolside sweet 16. And true to form, the Kindle Glow, with its translucent shell, offers not just warmth but mood lighting. Now if only it provided cellphone reception.

headline: Russia Says Suicide Bomber Was Militant’s Widow

headline: A Gathering of Caravaggios in Rome
text: Caravaggio’s time to shinehas arrived in Rome, where his paintings have been collected from around the globe to mark the 400th anniversary of his death. And fittingly perhaps for a man often painted as a villain — while the work of his rivals have long adorned the papal apartments and the Sistine Chapel — his images of often shocking brutality and portraits of lascivious young men now fill the old papal stables at the Scuderie del Quirinale.

The data showed that while the Taliban can be canny and brave in combat their rifle fire is often remarkably ineffective.

text: A Survivor’s Tough Choices at Elevation | Worried that he would not survive, Mark Thomas, 26, of Berkeley, built a snow cave for Tom Bennett, also 26, who was unconscious, and left him food before making his way down Mount Shasta. The two had climbed the 14,050-foot summit, but bad weather moved in and Mr. Bennett started experiencing the effects of altitude. On Thursday, five days after Mr. Thomas left, rescuers found his friend’s body. “If I’d stayed with him any longer, I would likely be up there with him,” he said. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

headline: Houses of Their Dreams
text: Even in 3-D, Alice in Wonderland has nothing on the Surrealists, who imagined spaces far trippier than any rabbit hole. Max Ernst drew a maiden trapped inside a giant zoetrope; Alberto Giacometti created rooms strung with a spinal column and other oddities; and Salvador Dalí’s famous ‘‘Dream of Venus’’ installation, at the 1939 World’s Fair, was an aquatic funhouse filled with topless women and a rubber cow udder. For the exhibition ‘‘The Surreal House,’’ which opens June 10 at London’s Barbican gallery, the curators have worked with the architects Carmody Groarke to bring these dreamscapes to life, constructing a labyrinth of rooms and corridors that immerse visitors in the art, films and furnishings of the movement’s original and contemporary practitioners. ‘‘The idea is to radically alter the space so that you’re not sure what’s up, what’s down or where it finishes,’’ says Alona Pardo, an assistant curator at the Barbican. Rather than imagining surreal interiors, the sculptors Claude and François-Xavier Lalanne furnished them. Their zoologically inspired pieces are now on view at the Les Arts Décoratifs in Paris, including hippo-shaped bathtubs and a bed that resembles a can of sardines. The retrospective also includes pieces designed for Yves Saint Laurent’s apartment, exhibited here for the first time.

headline: Best-Selling Graphic Books: Even the Losers Get Lucky Sometimes
text: Say hello to “The Losers,” at No. 10 on our paperback list. That series, written by Andy Diggle and illustrated by Jock (no last name — think Madonna), is about members of a  special forces group who are betrayed by their handler and find themselves hunted by the C.I.A. The series ran 32 issues, from 2003 to 2006, but the run was long enough to garner interest from Hollywood. A film version of the comic is to open on April 23. Jeffrey Dean Morgan, Zoë Saldana and Chris Evans are part of the elite team, while Jason Patric plays their renegade handler, Max. “The Losers” are a reinvention of a group of DC Comics characters from the 1960s who had many adventures in World War II.

headline: Master Glass
text: A few years ago, Ted Muehling journeyed to Vienna’s venerable glassworks J. & L. Lobmeyr to research the butterfly-etched drinking set he was in the midst of designing for them. There he found an archive of flat files, filled with the stuff of a designer’s dreams: pencil sketches on graph paper by Josef Hoffmann, graceful charcoal drawings of glassware by Oswald Haerdtl and renderings of complicated patterns and engraved borders by Adolf Loos. These rich supporting materials by Vienna’s early-20th-century masters will be on view at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, alongside their delicate three-dimensional counterparts, beginning April 23 as part of ‘‘Ted Muehling Selects: Lobmeyr Glass From the Permanent Collection.’’ From a baroque, leaf-cut decanter by Ludwig Lobmeyr to the thin, attenuated muslin glass forms that have dominated the past half century, Muehling primarily chose pieces meant for celebration and ritual; the great thing about Lobmeyr, he says, is ‘‘they may be opulent and insanely expensive, but for the most part the pieces are useful and functional drinking glasses.’’

headline: He’s Not That Into You
text: In August 1852, Theresa Longworth, not yet out of her teens, met and fell in love with a 28-year-old Irish aristocrat and soldier named William Charles Yelverton on a steamer crossing from France to England. Theresa, the daughter of a Manchester silk manufacturer, and William, the son of the Viscount of Avonmore, talked through the night. Nothing clandestine happened, but seven months later Theresa picked up her pen and wrote to this attractive stranger. From the beginning, her exchange with William followed a troublesome pattern: Theresa passionately throwing herself at a man who remained reluctant and evasive. Although he often failed to write, Theresa somehow managed, as Chloë Schama writes in “Wild Romance,” her portrait of this willful woman, to turn “his apathy into a sign of his commitment.”

headline: London Dance Journal: MacMillan’s ‘Judas Tree’
text: Plenty of artists are controversial in their lifetimes, but in most cases the dust settles. The choreographer Kenneth MacMillan died in 1992. Some of his ballets remain controversial for their subject matter: abusive sexuality, abnormal psychology and social dissidence were regular themes of his. Some of his ballets remain controversial for their style, which could include aspects of exaggerated and repetitious expressionism, sexual imagery in nonsexual contexts, acrobatic hyperextension, over-manipulative partnering and jerkily mechanical pure-dance routines. And almost every ballet he ever made remains controversial for its deficiencies of construction: individual dances are too long or too irrelevant, certain scenes are expressively unclear, overall organization has too many loose ends.

headline: Stores Continue ‘Dropping Like Flies’
text: When James and Karla Murray started photographing storefronts in 2001 for their book “Storefront: The Disappearing Face of New York” (Ginkgo Press) they noticed that some shops were closing as quickly as they could gather their shots.

headline: This Was Her Story: S. Epatha Merkerson Leaves ‘Law & Order’
text: Is there a way to make the “Law & Order” donk-donk sound in a sad way, to indicate a bittersweet transition? S. Epatha Merkerson, who for nearly two decades has played that crime drama’s hard-charging police lieutenant, Anita Van Buren, will leave the show at the end of its current season, The Hollywood Reporter said. Ms. Merkerson, an Emmy Award-winner for the HBO adaptation of “Lackawanna Blues” (not to mention the performer who played Reba the mail lady on “Pee-wee’s Playhouse”), appeared in an episode of “Law & Order” in its first season, back when George Dzundza and Chris Noth were still the lead cops. She then joined the show as Lt. Van Buren in its fourth season in 1993. Since then Ms. Merkerson has appeared in more than 375 episodes of “Law & Order,” and been on the show longer than any other cast member. The Hollywood Reporter said a deal to return “Law & Order” to NBC for its 21st season was not yet in place.

headline: New Jersey Schools Brace for Cuts

headline: Married? A Bit Bored? See a Shootout
text: TWO evenings or so every month, the director Shawn Levy and his wife arrange a sitter for their three daughters and drive to Giorgio Baldi, an Italian restaurant in Santa Monica, Calif. “It’s our date night,” Mr. Levy, whose films include “Cheaper by the Dozen” and the “Night at the Museum” series, said by phone recently. The couple, who have been married for 14 years, always order the same thing: ravioli, sole, langoustines. Out at dinner a few years ago, Mr. Levy recalled, “it occurred to us as we were talking that we were just checking off boxes  which gift we had to buy for some kid’s birthday, what plans we had to get done, what happened with our daughter at school that day.”

headline: The Bun Report | Hot, Cross and Sticky
text: Lately, buns — sometimes holy — have been on everyone’s minds, bodies and menus. As a nod to Good Friday, with apologies to anyone who’s off leavened items this week, here’s a guide to the Big Apple’s best buns: sticky, cinnamon, hot cross and otherwise:STICKY BUNSLet’s start at the very beginning with a small bakery on Madison Avenue at 83rd Street, William Greenberg Jr. Desserts. When I was a child, my father went here for schnecken. The German word for snail, its reference is the spiral shape of the thing. In fact, while I identify schnecken with this particular rich-doughed, cinnamon-filled, raisin-laden, pecan-topped, caramelized breakfast staple, the label is as generic as “danish,” and can be used to describe any flattened, coiled, cinnamon-raisin pastry. Sadly, William Jr. sold his bakery a number of years ago and the goods don’t taste the same. If you want to experience a sticky bun as I knew it, you can go two blocks down to E.A.T., where Eli Zabar has created something that rivals the Greenberg classic. Or else call Scarsdale, where William’s son Seth continues to bake (and sell) his father’s schnecken. Seth uses the same ingredients as his dad and has the original 1930s recipe cards to prove it. You can taste the sour cream and butter in the dough; the perfectly burnt brown sugar in the thick glaze.

headline: Mets Correct a Chunk of World Series History
text: Last week bloggers found a statistical error in one of the commemorative bricks along the Fan Walk in front of Citi Field. On the granite stone celebrating Game 7 of the 1986 World Series, Sid Fernandez was incorrectly credited with the victory.

headline: Sebelius Begins Push for High-Risk Pools
text: In one of the first steps toward implementing the recently adopted health care legislation, the secretary of health and human services, Kathleen Sebelius, on Friday sent a letter to governors and state insurance commissioners asking whether they were interested in creating high-risk insurance pools.

headline: Great Expectations
text: When I first told my son, Charlie, about the Easter Bunny and described his duties — distributing and hiding colored eggs — my logical 3-year-old would have none of it. “But rabbits don’t have any hands,” he said. Since I never believed in the Easter Bunny, either, I didn’t apply further pressure on the issue. Next to the Crucifixion itself (whose violent details I spared my son and daughter until age 7 or so), the image of a man-size rodent that lurches around people’s houses late at night, clutching fragile treats in its curled paws, strikes me as one of the most appalling nightmare visions that adults can inflict on tender minds.

headline: High-School Redux
text: Paul was one of my best friends in high school, but we drifted apart after graduation. We weren’t good about staying in touch, and it had been years since we’d seen each other. I blew off my 20th reunion two years ago. Don’t get me wrong: I love witnessing the ravishing effects of time on bodies that aren’t mine; it’s just that you have to go through so much lame small talk to see the train wrecks. But I really wanted to know how Paul was doing. We were close once. It felt wrong that we’d gone through 22 years of life experiences without talking. If we reconnected, I wondered, could we still be friends? Does the raw material for friendship remain intact despite decades of separation?

headline: Vatican Priest Likens Criticism Over Abuse to Anti-Semitism
text: ROME — A senior Vatican priest, speaking before Pope Benedict XVI at a Good Friday service, compared the world’s outrage at sexual abuse scandals in the Catholic Church to the persecution of the Jews, prompting angry responses from victims’ advocates and consternation from Jewish groups.

headline: Setting a Curfew — or Not — for Your Child

But many of the country’s best players began their European careers in France, and it is in Ligue 1 where Eriksson might find the next name for his World Cup roster this summer: Gervais Yao Kouassi, known as Gervinho.

Mr. Dolan spoke about casting himself in his first feature (an excellent way to land a role) and the spontaneous nature by which the scenes in the film were developed:

headline: E-Book Dodge
text: I bought an e-reader for travel and was eager to begin “Under the Dome,” the new Stephen King novel. Unfortunately, the electronic version was not yet available. The publisher apparently withheld it to encourage people to buy the more expensive hardcover. So I did, all 1,074 pages, more than three and a half pounds. Then I found a pirated version online, downloaded it to my e-reader and took it on my trip. I generally disapprove of illegal downloads, but wasn’t this O.K.? C.D., BRIGHTWATERS, N.Y.

headline: Construction Damages Day Care Center Next Door
text: A day care center on the Lower East Side was displaced Thursday evening when excavation work on the building site next door caused the day care center’s building to crack, the Department of Buildings said. No one was evacuated – the day care center, Action for Progress at 255 East Houston Street near Suffolk Street, was not in session when the order was issued.

headline: A Cheese Factory to Open in Manhattan
text: Beecher’s Handmade Cheese, which has been in Seattle’s Pike Place Market since 2003, will open a cheese factory in the Flatiron district in February. The factory will be similar to the one they have in Seattle, where the entire operation can be viewed through a plate-glass partition. They also make and sell excellent mac-and-cheese and other products. They’ll add a wine bar and cheese “cave” on the lower level of the space at 900 Broadway (20th Street), in the same Stanford White building where Craftbar is located.

Feel free to taunt all you want about picks that go horribly wrong, like last year’s prediction that the Royals would win the A.L. Central. As the season begins, this is my best guess for what will happen – understanding that much of it could look foolish in six months.
