headline: Governors Receive Threats From Extremist Group
text: WASHINGTON — Governors around the country said Friday that they had received letters from an extremist group warning that they might be forcibly removed from office if they did not step down within three days.

headline: The Charms of the Loser Lettuces
text: FOR many people, the world of lettuce has changed enormously in the last decade. The standard is no longer head lettuce, but mesclun, or “baby lettuce mix,” or whatever you choose to call the omnipresent pile of variably colored leaves, tissue-thin and textureless. (I’m aware there’s sometimes a bit of radicchio thrown in there for color and flavor, but the amount is insignificant.)

headline: Bank of America Grants New Credit Card Protections to Small Businesses
text: From John Tozzi at BusinessWeek we learn that Bank of America will extend to small-business accounts the protections recently granted to individual consumers by the Credit Card Accountability Responsibility and Disclosure Act of 2009. Between May and July, Bank of America will implement new policies for its two million small-business account holders that will end rate increases on existing balances, provide at least 45 days advance notice on rate changes for future balances, eliminate the over-limit fee, and set a grace period of at least 25 days between the statement closing date and the payment due date.

headline: Keeping Score: Which Team Is Built to Win?
text: After analyzing the championship games or series of the N.F.L., N.B.A., Major League Baseball and N.H.L., and the major finals in golf and tennis, we identified 50 championships characteristics in our book, “Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological and Mathematical Method.” Based on similar research, we focused on several championship characteristics that might help predict the winner of this year’s N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.

headline: Lupone Names Winner of Book Title Contest
text: In February, when Patti LuPone announced on her Web site (pattilupone.net) that she was asking her fans to suggest potential titles for her coming memoir, readers of The New York Times’s ArtsBeat blog (nytimes.com/artsbeat) were invited to join in the competition, too. And frankly, our commenters came up with some pretty good ones, including “A Little Touch of Star Quality,” “I, Eva” and “Being LuPone.” On Friday, Ms. LuPone announced that she had chosen a title. The winner? It’s “Patti LuPone: A Memoir,” submitted by Precilla Ng of Toronto. Runners-up included “An 11 O’Clock Life”; “Entrances, Exits and Everything in Between: A Life, by Patti LuPone”; and “Eight Times a Week.” Among the submissions that Ms. LuPone said made her laugh was “Mein Kampf,” suggested by Ginny Brazier of Chicago. So apparently things could have been worse. Harmony Books will release “Patti LuPone: A Memoir” on Sept. 14.

headline: TV Dramas Yield Plenty of Ratings Agita
text: April Fools’ Day did not give the networks much to smile about as many dramas saw ratings decline on Thursday night, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Among those taking the hardest hits were the Fox series “Bones” (8.4 million) and “Fringe” (6 million viewers), which ran their first new episodes since February, and ABC’s struggling science-fiction series, “FlashForward” (5.1 million), which had some of its worst ratings to date. CBS won the night, but its hit investigation show “The Mentalist” drew an unusually low 13.9 million viewers after switching time slots for the evening with “CSI” (13.2 million). At 8 p.m., “Survivor: Heroes vs. Villains” attracted 11.1 million viewers. ABC was in second place with “Grey’s Anatomy” (9.8 million) and “Private Practice” (7.8 million), which also experienced declines. Fox ranked third, and NBC was fourth with repeats of “The Office,” followed by “The Marriage Ref” (5.3 million).

headline: Debut Is Announced for ‘Tales of the City’
text: The musical “Tales of the City,” adapted from two books by Armistead Maupin, will have its world premiere next spring at the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco, the theater has announced. Drawing on the exploits of the characters Mary Ann, Mouse, Anna Madrigal and others from “Tales of the City” and “More Tales of the City,” set in 1970s San Francisco, the musical has a score and lyrics by Jake Shears and John Garden of the rock band Scissor Sisters and a book by Jeff Whitty (a Tony Award winner for “Avenue Q”). It will be directed by Jason Moore (“Shrek the Musical,” “Avenue Q”). The production is scheduled to run May 17 to July 10, 2011. According to a statement from the theater, the creative team has been working on the musical for more than two years, with Mr. Maupin’s blessing. “I’ve always believed that a theatrical version of ‘Tales’ should be homegrown in San Francisco, just the way the story itself was back in 1976,” Mr. Maupin said in the statement. “I trust this company to be faithful to the spirit of the material and to transfer it to another medium with charm and inventiveness.”

headline: Can the Ipad Do What a Comics Store Can?
text: Sure, the Apple iPad has the power to run all kinds of applications and make you the envy of your friends. But can it help you to imagine that you’re Captain America, brandishing your shield and fists against the ruthless Red Skull? Yes, it can do that, too. On Friday, Marvel Comics, the publishing home of heroes like Spider-Man and the X-Men, said it was introducing a free application for the iPad that will give readers access to a digital library of more than 500 comics from its 70-year history. The software program, Marvel Comics App, developed by the digital comics distributor comiXology, offers free access to the first issues of titles like New Avengers and The Invincible Iron Man. Other recent and vintage issues can be downloaded for $1.99 each. Marvel says it sees the app as being complementary to the experience of buying and reading physical comics, not supplanting it. “That Wednesday, when people go to the stores, I call it a mini Comic-Con,” Ira Rubenstein, the executive vice president of Marvel’s global digital media group, said in a telephone interview. “It’s where fans gather and talk about the books and they argue about the books and speculate about the books. That experience isn’t going to change.”

headline: Jones Cancels Shows, Citing Vocal Problems
text: For Tom Jones, below, this is unusual: the singer has canceled several concerts in Asia in recent days on the advice of his doctors, who say he could risk injuring his vocal cords, Reuters reported. Last Friday, Mr. Jones, the 69-year-old Welsh crooner of “What’s New Pussycat?” and “It’s Not Unusual,” began a concert at a casino in Sentosa, the Singapore island resort, but stopped the show after two songs. He rescheduled the performance for Thursday, citing laryngitis, but canceled that show as well as a subsequent concert scheduled for Saturday in Seoul, South Korea. A statement on his Web site, tomjones.com, said the cancellations were “due to doctor’s orders.” It added that though Mr. Jones “has been resting his voice all week,” his doctors warned him that he “could risk serious permanent damage to his vocals” if he performed. The singer has additional concerts scheduled l this month in Cape Town and Johannesburg, as well as in Oman and the United Arab Emirates.

headline: S. Epatha Merkerson to Leave ‘Law & Order’
text: Is there a way to make the “Law & Order” donk-donk sound in a sad way, to indicate a bittersweet transition? S. Epatha Merkerson, right, who for more than 15 years has played that crime drama’s straightforward police lieutenant, Anita Van Buren, will leave the show at the end of its current season, The Hollywood Reporter said. Ms. Merkerson, an Emmy Award winner for the HBO adaptation of “Lackawanna Blues,” appeared in an episode of “Law & Order” in its first season, back when George Dzundza and Chris Noth were still the lead cops. She joined the show as Lt. Van Buren in its fourth season in 1993. Since then Ms. Merkerson has appeared in more than 375 episodes of “Law & Order,” and been on the show longer than any other cast member. The Hollywood Reporter said a deal to return “Law & Order” to NBC for its 21st season was not yet in place.

headline: Resounding Schuman, Rebounding Slatkin
text: From its inception, the concert that the Juilliard Orchestra presented at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night was meant to celebrate the centenary of William Schuman, the former president of the Juilliard School and of Lincoln Center who died in 1992, an American composer of originality and lasting significance. The event was a late complement to Juilliard’s 2010 Focus! festival in January, devoted to so-called mainstream American composers.

headline: Powerful Top Notes Paired With Theatrical Conviction
text: The best came last during a concert by the American soprano Sondra Radvanovsky and the Siberian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening.

headline: Larger Than Life
text: The Colombian artist Fernando Botero is back at the Nassau County Museum of Art, where more than 70 of his sketches, drawings and paintings were exhibited five years ago. The museum is now showing a small but significant collection of figure paintings, drawings and monumental sculptures; one of the sculptures, a plump female nude, enlivens the plaza fronting the museum.

headline: Growing Conversion of Movies to 3-D Draws Mixed Reactions
text: LOS ANGELES  For weeks, Hollywood has sat in judgment of a last-second decision by Warner Brothers to convert its two-dimensional “Clash of the Titans” into 3-D after filming was finished. James Cameron cried sacrilege, Michael Bay said such quickie conversions resulted in “fake 3-D” and fanboy bloggers lambasted Warner and urged people to skip it.

headline: Chic in Review | Move Over, Imelda
text: Aniston, JenniferBusts out in a hot pink Lacroix haute couture dress.  Demonstrates why she tends to only wear simple black and nude dresses.

headline: Book Review Podcast: New Vietnam War Novels
text: This week: A look at two new novels about the Vietnam War, with Tatjana Soli, the author of “The Lotus Eaters,” and Sebastian Junger, who reviews Karl Marlantes’s “Matterhorn”; the Book Review’s children’s books editor Julie Just discusses bad parents in young adult fiction; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Asked to Declare His Race, Obama Checks ‘Black’
text: It is official: Barack Obama is the nation’s first black president.

headline: In Pursuit of Sounds Delicate and Eerie
text: The Miller Theater at Columbia University was packed on Thursday night for the concert celebrating the 75th birthday of the visionary, idiosyncratic German composer Helmut Lachenmann, the last of this season’s popular Composer Portraits programs. As always with this series, the audience was mostly young. For 10 years now, the Composer Portraits have enticed young people who are curious about all kinds of extreme contemporary music to take chances on living classical composers.

headline: Rock Band and Traditional Brass, Marching From Brazil to Broadway
text: It’s been a while since a band from Pernambuco, the state in the northeastern promontory of Brazil, made a deep impression in the United States. People will tell you about the singer Chico Science, who died in 1997, and his fantastic band, Nação Zumbi. They’re still missed. Their aggressive, guitar-and-drum-centric Brazilian rock burst with sound and imagery about the complexity of Brazilian cultural identity, about limited resources and technological curiosity. It also sounded good on a beach.

headline: Need a Cab? New Analysis Shows Where to Find One
text: It is a question that taxi-seekers in New York often ponder: Is there some kind of secret formula for where to find a cab in this town?

headline: Will the iPad Cause the End of Innovation?
text: On a day in which the majority of tech news consists of breathless examination of the first round of iPad Apps, Cory Doctorow writes on the blog Boing Boing that the iPad will discourage innovation.

headline: At Couples’ Reunion, Laughs, Then Grief
text: Tyler Perry likes to give full value for the entertainment dollar, and “Tyler Perry’s Why Did I Get Married Too?” is two movies for the price of one.

headline: Inventing Tahini Soup
text: IT all started when I began obsessing over how to turn hummus, my toddler’s favorite snack, into more of a complete and vegetable-rich meal. Dipping carrot sticks into hummus doesn’t work, as she simply licks it right off.

headline: Book Review Podcast: New Vietnam War Novels
text: This week: A look at two new novels about the Vietnam War, with Tatjana Soli, the author of “The Lotus Eaters,” and Sebastian Junger, who reviews Karl Marlantes’s “Matterhorn”; the Book Review’s children’s books editor Julie Just discusses bad parents in young adult fiction; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Rebuilding in Haiti
text: The federal government recently agreed to sell most of the 120,000 formaldehyde-tainted trailers it bought nearly five years ago for Hurricane Katrina victims for pennies on the dollar. How could it not have anticipated that the sale of those units — perhaps the most visible symbol of the government’s bungled response to the hurricane — would result in outrage? And how can they sell them cheaply to middlemen who will then turn a profit selling them back to those who still remain without housing, post-Katrina?

headline: Trustees Find Board Seats Are Still Luxury Items
text: Like Prada handbags and Hermès scarves, a spot on one of New York City’s most prestigious cultural boards never goes on sale, even in a recession.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 2
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Reading Up on Gutenberg as the iPad Drops
text: With the iPad, which arrives in stores on Saturday, Apple is joining Amazon and other makers of e-readers in an effort to overturn the 500-year-old model of book publishing.

headline: Financial Tuneup: Remember to Rebalance
text: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, we’ve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

headline: Letters on a Modern Love Essay About a Woman in Prison
text: Prison’s Untold Tales

headline: At Prospect Park Lake, Graceful Swans and Chicken Feet
text: By the banks of Prospect Park Lake in Brooklyn, a handful of young children stood watching the geese and swans in the warm sunshine on Friday. A few feet away, Anne-Katrin Titze knelt over the bank’s edge and poked at the murky water with a stick until two dismembered chicken feet and some small pieces of loose, rotten flesh floated to the surface.

headline: Honoring Dizzy Gillespie With a Mix of Many Styles
text: Twenty years ago the pianist Danilo Perez was a precocious member of Dizzy Gillespie’s United Nation Orchestra, a clutch of musicians from the Americas and the Caribbean. That appointment, which ended with Gillespie’s death in 1993, was formative: Mr. Perez has said it gave him the conviction to seek out his own personal amalgam of jazz and Latin music, and in particular the folk music of his native Panama. From Gillespie, bebop’s peerless trumpet ambassador, he also learned a few things about the art of engaging an audience, even (or especially) when presenting them with a challenge.

headline: What It Takes to Fight Obesity
text: A Room for Debate forum last week discussed the effectiveness of public campaigns to promote healthy eating and reduce obesity. Many readers wrote in about their own struggles with weight, what worked for them and how public policy might be changed to help Americans keep the pounds off. Here are excerpts from their comments.

headline: What Did You Think of the New York Auto Show?
text: Yes, after tramping the New York auto show floor for two long days and posting our opinions, we want to hear your thoughts. Did you enjoy the show? What was your favorite car at the show? Which companies are building the cars that matter? Which companies are not?

headline: The Week in Pictures for April 2
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York region. Subjects include mountain climbers, the last homeless person in Times Square, and a bug safari in Central Park.

headline: Confronting a Stranger, for Art
text: At 20 minutes to closing time, Matthew Koopersmith was next in line. There was no telling if the clock would run out.

headline: Cars Starved (or Stuffed) for Attention
text: THE Tango electric commuter car is a conversation piece wherever it appears, including the Detroit auto show in January, and last fall Jay Leno took one for a highly publicized test drive.

headline: A Cure for Cabin Fever
text: TESTED 2010 Nissan 370Z Roadster

headline: Cures for Balky Gearshifts
text: TROUBLE with Acura timepieces and Jaguar gearshifts are among the problems cited in the latest technical service bulletins.

headline: Shedding Light on Safety
text: MONTVALE, N.J.

headline: An 82-Year-Old Star of the New York Auto Show
text: Again this year at the New York auto show, the LeMay Museum of Tacoma, Wash., has brought together an impressive group of classic cars that will be on display through this weekend on the lower level of the Javits Center. None has a stronger New York connection than a vintage black-and-green Packard roadster.

headline: Drill, Obama, Drill
text: We all know that people running for office make promises that they either cannot or will not fulfill when in office, and it’s hard to accuse them of hypocrisy when they yield to political realities. Thus candidate Barack Obama promised to quickly close the interrogation centers at Guanatánamo Bay, but President Obama, facing an attack of

headline: In Call, Karzai Tries to Clarify a Diatribe
text: WASHINGTON — A day after he delivered a scorching attack on the West for its conduct in Afghanistan, President Hamid Karzai telephoned Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday to express surprise that his comments had caused such a stir, administration officials said.

headline: On the iPad, Gilt Is for All Kinds of Shoppers
text: Shopping on Gilt, the site with private, limited-time sales, can be a blood sport, with shoppers competing against others for a pair of gold Calvin Klein heels in a size 8.

headline: 2010 National League Predictions
text: We’ve brought you the American League picks. Here’s the fearless forecast for the National League.

headline: A Tour of the Census Form
text: A guide to the 2010 census form, which the Census Bureau claims you can fill out in less time than it takes to cook a hard-boiled egg.

headline: Mom and Pop, Scraping By
text: JOHN Scanlon pushed up the grate on his store, Pelham Bay Home Center, one recent frosty morning and hauled onto the sidewalk a pageant of products — bathroom sinks, cabinets, countertops and a refrigerator — in the unlikely hope of catching a passer-by in need of a large appliance.

headline: Details Help Michigan State’s Izzo Channel Inner Football Coach
text: INDIANAPOLIS — The day before Tom Izzo’s first game as Michigan State coach, he had his assistant Tom Crean go to an office supplies store to purchase small plastic sheets on which he could draw the first six plays of the game.

headline: No Need for Hunting
text: DRIVE down almost any of Connecticut’s back roads and you are likely to see nearly as many “Fresh Eggs” placards as those advertising homes for sale. Seemingly overnight, the availability of farm-fresh eggs has become a sign of the times, an indication that more and more people, having taken the locavore notion to heart, are raising their own eggs — and raising money by selling off the extras.

headline: A Rematch Worth Slapping the Floor About
text: INDIANAPOLIS — West Virginia guard Joe Mazzulla made his name in the Mountaineers’ 73-67 victory over Duke in the N.C.A.A. tournament two years ago.

headline: The Unpaid Intern, Legal or Not
text: With job openings scarce for young people, the number of unpaid internships has climbed in recent years, leading federal and state regulators to worry that more employers are illegally using such internships for free labor.

headline: Healthy in a Hurry
text: It’s not unusual for food and drink establishments to use a symbol to highlight low-fat or vegetarian choices on the menu. At Mango Mix, a juice bar that also serves salads, sandwiches and omelets, the concept is taken to a new level.

headline: A Touch of Tex-Mex, and a Whole Lot More
text: THE photographs of chili peppers that adorn the walls of Roasted Peppers, Mamaroneck’s charming new restaurant, suggest a Mexican theme, but in practice, the kitchen adheres more to its claim to offer “casual American dining.” Mole and chilies occasionally appear on the menu, but there is no one-note garnish here, like overcooked rice and refried beans, the mainstay of many Tex-Mex spots.

headline: Lawyer Sues Ex-Wife of Steven Cohen Over Fees
text: Patricia Cohen, who sued her ex-husband, Steven A. Cohen, the founder of SAC Capital Advisors, over money involved in their divorce, has in turn been sued by a lawyer in the case for unpaid fees.

headline: $14 Million for Stanford Victims Fund
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission obtained more than $14.2 million for Stanford Financial Group investors in a Panamanian asset sale, the agency said Friday.

headline: Atheists’ Collection Plate, With Religious Inspiration
text: ALPHARETTA, Ga.

headline: Apollo Made Him Do It
text: Cute, young, tousle-haired Orestes has good reason to curl up in a ball on a stone bench and sleep as much as he can. He has murdered his mother and her lover, and now he’s just waiting to find out what horrible way he is going to be executed. Probably along with his sister, Electra, who aided and abetted.

headline: School Where Acting Is a Hard Sell
text: When I first saw Nilaja Sun perform “No Child ... ” four years ago in a small theater in New York City, the audience included a large number of teachers. Ms. Sun was obviously multitalented, and her story was both inspiring and deeply sad, but this was a classic case of preaching to the choir. That segment of the audience was presold on any work of art that showed just how tough and unappreciated a job teaching was.

headline: John Malkovich Seeks Bigger Madoff Return
text: John Malkovich, the actor, is seeking to recover $2.3 million from an account he had with the securities firm of Bernard L. Madoff. Irving H. Picard, the trustee liquidating Mr. Madoff’s firm, approved a claim in August for $670,000 for the actor’s pension plan and trust, more than $1.5 million short of the value of the securities listed on the November 2008 final statement of Mr. Malkovich’s account, lawyers for the actor said in a filing Thursday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. Mr. Picard told Mr. Malkovich he was not entitled to the full amount because no securities were purchased for his account and the approved claim reflects what he deposited with Mr. Madoff’s firm, according to the filing. The actor’s lawyers said Mr. Malkovich was owed the full amount on his final statement.

headline: As Expected, Bryant Signs Extension With Lakers
text: Scratch one big name from the star-studded 2010 free-agent class. It is not as if many expected Kobe Bryant to lend an ear to potential recruiters, but Bryant made official what had been expected, signing a three-year contract extension with the Lakers on Friday.

headline: Renewing Memories of a Big Hit
text: PEEKSKILL

headline: Tracking Taxi Flow Across the City
text: Information from millions of taxi trips provides a telling record of the city's vital signs.

headline: From California to Cambodia, Fighting for Women
text: MAK PRAING, Cambodia

headline: Airline Screening Plan Wins Tentative Praise
text: WASHINGTON — Aviation security experts and industry officials said Friday that new screening protocols for air passengers coming to the United States were a marked improvement over an emergency plan that has required extra screening of every passenger from 14 countries since the attempted bombing of an airliner on Christmas Day.

headline: Bagels, With a Southern Twist
text: After more than two decades in the bagel business, Dennis Pariti, 53, of Levittown, decided to add barbecue to the menu. So last May he put a hickory-burning smoker in the kitchen of the Garden City Park deli he has owned for six years and rechristened it Bagels and BBQ.

headline: From Italian Roots, a New American Palate
text: SUGO sounds like an Italian restaurant, and indeed that’s what it was when it opened in Long Beach in May 2007. Though its Web site calls its fare “Italian food with an urban edge,” the owner, Alan Adams, told me on the phone after my visits: “We’re not that anymore,” adding, “We’re now New American with world influences.”

headline: Readers’ Questions Answered
text: Church Holdings

headline: Urge to Help That Became a Life’s Work
text: TO answer a question about its complex homeless services system, Bloomberg administration officials can ask their experienced bureaucrats, call a high-priced consultant or tap into their sophisticated computerized data programs.

headline: Acorn Says It Continues Its Work
text: After months of budget problems and criticism from the right, the community organizing group Acorn plans to release a letter next week clarifying its path forward and stating that its local chapters may be closed, but the national organization is alive and well.

headline: Harlem Arts School Shuts Over Financial Problems
text: For nearly 50 years, the Harlem School of the Arts has given generations of mostly black and Latino children entree into worlds often otherwise out of their reach. It put violins and other orchestral instruments in their hands, ballet slippers on their feet and Shakespeare on their tongues.

headline: Food From the Farm, and Far Beyond
text: WHATEVER advantage a bucolic setting bestows on the appreciation of food, the restaurant Ninety Acres at Natirar uses it well.

headline: A Race to Reap Energy From the Ocean Breezes
text: As New Englanders await a decision in Massachusetts on a bitterly contested proposal to build the nation’s first offshore wind farm, the State of Rhode Island is forging ahead with its own project in the hope of outpacing — and upstaging — its neighbor.

headline: Plans for a Synagogue Upset a Town
text: Millburn, N.J.

headline: When a Papered Wall Acts Like a Web Site
text: MANY people hustle right past the wall pasted with paper fliers on Forsyth Street, in the shadow of the Manhattan Bridge. But others make pilgrimages to this easternmost reach of Chinatown, where scores of advertisements, most handwritten in Chinese, are posted, their phone-number strips curling like beckoning fingers.

headline: Paterson Deputy Is Questioned in Case Involving Another Aide
text: ALBANY — Clemmie L. Harris Jr., a top aide to Gov. David A. Paterson, appeared in Manhattan on Friday before investigators for Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo’s office in their inquiry into the Paterson administration’s handling of a domestic violence matter, people with knowledge of the case said.

headline: Tales of Obsessions and Battles That Shaped the City
text: Ready to be beguiled? Two new collections of nonfiction detective stories will help.

headline: Before the Rush, a Bite for the Staff
text: This muscular grand cafe in Greenwich Village may be famous for its towering architectural dishes, but you — the paying customer — will never get to taste what may be a more indicative meal: the free dinner that is fed each night to the staff. Just as a nation can be judged by how it cares for its least fortunate citizens, a restaurant can be judged by what it feeds its servers, barkeeps, busboys, line cooks and dishwashers before their shifts. The verdict? Pretty good — at least according to the half-dozen workers who gathered for the meal at 4 p.m. one day last week at their typical spot, in the back at Table 35.

headline: 3 Germans Die in Afghan Clash
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three German soldiers were killed on Friday during a firefight with insurgents while on patrol near the city of Kunduz in northern Afghanistan, a spokesman for the German military said.

headline: For Pro Athletes, Practice That’s All in the Thumbs
text: Video games like Nintendo’s Wii Fit or Electronics Arts’ Madden N.F.L. series aren’t just for armchair athletes.

headline: She Makes the Best Waf-Cakes
text: Sisterhood has made for a prolific collaboration between the writer Delia Ephron and her writer/director sister, Nora. Their play “Love, Loss, and What I Wore” is running Off Broadway with a fresh cast each month, and their screenwriting credits include the comedy “You’ve Got Mail.” Delia Ephron’s latest novel for young adults is “The Girl With the Mermaid Hair,” which explores a dysfunctional family and its dysfunctional relationship with cosmetic surgery. She lives in Greenwich Village with her husband, Jerome Kass, also a writer, and their multinamed Havanese, Honey Pansy Cornflower Bernice Mambo Kass. ROBIN FINN

headline: Urologist Posts His Politics on His Florida Office Door
text: MIAMI — Doctors take the Hippocratic oath promising to do no harm, but once that requirement is fulfilled, do they have a right to choose patients based on politics?

headline: Insurance Pool to Offer Reduced-Rate Coverage
text: WASHINGTON — In one of its first steps to carry out the new health care law, the Obama administration announced Friday that it was establishing a temporary insurance pool where uninsured people with medical problems could buy coverage at reduced rates.

headline: Thrilling Reminder of Old Coney Island
text: From 85 feet up, the view of Coney Island is so good you can almost see the future. You can get the Boardwalk, but also a sense of the crowds that will soon fill it. The sun peeking through the clouds, but also an image of the beachgoers who will soak it in. The familiar attractions like the Parachute Jump, and the new development that after years of controversy will make its debut in May.

headline: Pakistan: A Raft of Amendments
text: The Pakistani government on Friday introduced a package of constitutional changes in Parliament that would shift the balance of power from the president to the prime minister. Under the proposed changes, the president would no longer have the powers to dismiss the prime minister, dissolve Parliament or appoint the powerful military chiefs. The package also includes the lifting of a ban on two-time prime ministers running for a third term, essentially paving the way for a campaign by the opposition leader Nawaz Sharif. Another measure would change the name of the North-West Frontier Province to Khyber-Pakhtoonkhwa.

headline: New Health Care Law Does Not Help Democrats in Poll
text: The legislative wrangling over the health care reform bill that became law last week has not translated into improved poll ratings for any of the principal participants.

headline: A Long Chat for Obama and Hu
text: President Obama spoke by phone on Thursday night with President Hu Jintao of China for about an hour — so long that Air Force One had to be held for 10 minutes on the tarmac at Andrews Air Force Base after landing. Chinese television reported that Mr. Hu expressed a desire for healthier ties while emphasizing Beijing’s positions on Taiwan and Tibet, and the White House said Mr. Obama stressed for China to press Iran on its nuclear ambitions. Their conversation, which reportedly also touched on trade, did not appear to address the issue of China’s currency, the renminbi, and whether China would loosen the tight link between it and the dollar — a policy that keeps the renminbi’s value depressed and makes Chinese exports more competitive in global markets.

headline: Pension Funds Still Waiting for Big Payoff From Private Equity
text: Private equity deal-makers, those kings of corporate buyouts, made billions for themselves when times were good. But some of their biggest investors, public pension funds, are still waiting for the hefty rewards they were promised.

headline: Judge Dismisses Suit Seeking to Keep A.I.G. Assets in Place
text: A judge in California dismissed a lawsuit on Thursday that would have barred the American International Group from moving any assets out of that state until an independent audit could verify the company’s financial condition.

headline: Battle of $50 Bill Splitting Republican Ranks
text: CINCINNATI — It is a battle that is pitting Republican against Republican.

headline: A Cancer Survivor and His Kodachrome
text: Jeff Jacobson’s new book project, “The Last Roll,” emerged from a low point in his life. Recovering from lymphoma and the chemotherapy used to treat it, he faced his own mortality in 2005. Then he faced the end of Kodachrome 200, a medium he’d used for more than 20 years.

headline: Report Faults Training of Local Officers in Immigration Enforcement Program
text: State and local police officers who enforce federal immigration laws are not adequately screened, trained or supervised, and the civil rights of the immigrants they deal with are not consistently protected, according to a report released Friday by the Department of Homeland Security inspector general.

headline: A Pfizer Whistle-Blower Is Awarded $1.4 Million
text: A federal jury has awarded $1.37 million in damages to a former Pfizer scientist who claimed she was sickened by a genetically engineered virus at a company laboratory and then fired for raising safety concerns.

headline: Exiled Pedophile Priest May Have Continued Abuse
text: BOULDER JUNCTION, Wis. — The modest clapboard cottage projects a sense of simple rural peace, nestled amid tall pines on quiet Trout Lake. The house, in the Northwoods of Wisconsin, had been in the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphy’s family for years, his getaway in the summer months and his sanctuary where he was sent to retire in 1974, at age 48, after victims of sexual abuse demanded he be removed from work at a school for the deaf near Milwaukee.

headline: On the Street | Spring Shift
text: The heavy rains end, and New Yorkers show their colors.

headline: In SoHo Burglaries, a Case of a Taste for the Luxurious Things in Life
text: He has a taste for luxury — Michael Kors gold leather satchel bags, hand-constructed Japanese denim jeans that start at $260 and about $23,000 worth of designer sunglasses.

headline: H. Edward Roberts, PC Pioneer, Dies at 68
text: Not many people in the computer world remembered H. Edward Roberts, not after he walked away from the industry more than three decades ago to become a country doctor in Georgia. Bill Gates remembered him, though.

headline: After a 20-Year Mapping Effort, Hoping to Save Dozens of Native Plants
text: American colonists once watched for the spring bloom of the Nantucket shadbush, a sign that it was warm enough to bury the winter’s dead.

headline: In Baseball, Power Matters, but Not Absolutely
text: Among baseball people it is a reflex to praise the little things. The game’s greatest virtues are said to be situational hitting, taking the extra base and, most of all, pitching and defense. To suggest that games are won with power is like saying pizza tastes good. Everybody knows it, but most people would rather say they eat health food.

headline: New Vessels for New Perils
text: THE New York Police and Fire Departments often boast about their cutting-edge capabilities on the streets of the city. Rarely, though, do they discuss their capabilities on the water.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Thursday about Albany’s failure to complete a budget on time, using information from the state comptroller’s office, referred incorrectly to a law enacted in 1998 to help spur lawmakers toward agreement. It prohibits only legislators from being paid until a budget is approved  not the governor or other statewide elected officials.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 2, 2010

headline: IPad Apps Have Ignition
text: The rush is on to dissect and analyze the multitude of iPad-aimed applications that have emerged on the day before the tablet’s release. In the Technology section of The New York Times online, you’ll find articles about apps from National Public Radio, Netflix, ABC, the Walt Disney Company and many others.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Saturday about millions of heart patients’ receiving nitroglycerin tablets never approved by the Food and Drug Administration misstated the year the F.D.A. was established. It was in 1927, when it was spun off from the Bureau of Chemistry, not in 1938. (Its powers to require new drugs to demonstrate safety before being marketed came in 1938 with passage of the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act.)

headline: Health System Bears Cost of Implants With No Warranties
text: In January, William R. Morris’s artificial hip, just three years old, was failing so badly that it had to be replaced during an extensive procedure that cost about $50,000.

headline: Japanese Food Companies Seek Growth Abroad
text: TOKYO — Until he moved to Japan three years ago, Arturo Vega, a Spanish-language teacher, had no idea that the Sofyl brand of yogurt that he had bought in his native Mexico was made by Japanese company named Yakult Honsha.

headline: What We’re Reading: Sorry, a Little More iPad
text: Just a few more thoughts on the iPad. Forgive us.

headline: Once Uniforms, They Are Now Works of Art
text: THE traditional place for a retired soldier’s uniform is, perhaps, in a trunk in the attic. But a more creative option begins in a portable pulping machine belonging to Drew Matott, an artist who makes paper.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about the impact of a court decision that invalidated patents on two genes misstated the role of the American Civil Liberties Union in the case. It acted as a lawyer for the plaintiffs; it was not a plaintiff itself.

headline: Breaking Down the NYTimes.com Bracket Pool
text: About 40,000 brackets were submitted to the nytimes.com men’s bracket tournament, and users’ selections reveal the contrast between heavy favorites and underdogs. About 70 percent of brackets had Kansas in the Final Four, for example, while just over one percent put Butler there.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about a charity game between alumni of teams that were supposed to meet in the 1989 New Jersey high school hockey championship game but did not because of a measles outbreak misidentified the channel that will show it. The game, scheduled for today in Morristown, N.J., will be taped and shown on Cablevision’s MSG Varsity, not on the MSG Network.

headline: Apparently Floored
text: “In German, a young lady has no sex, while a turnip has.”“The Awful German Language” by Mark Twain

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Friday about General Manager Omar Minaya’s optimism for the Mets’ chances this season misstated the day that shortstop Jose Reyes, who has been told he will begin the season on the disabled list, would be eligible to play again. It is next Saturday, not Thursday.

headline: Corrections
text: Schedule information on Thursday with a theater review of “August Wilson’s Women,” at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe in the East Village, misstated the cafe’s phone number. It is (212) 780-9386.

headline: Brothers From Duke Arrive After a Detour
text: WARSAW, Ind. — When Duke forwards Mason and Miles Plumlee transferred from the public high school in this town of hay bales and basketball hoops, their father, Perky, was treated like a pariah. When he went to grab a cup of coffee after church, he said, “people would disperse as if I had poured scalding hot water on a dog.”

headline: Corrections
text: A music review on Friday about the bands xx and jj, at Webster Hall, misidentified the hit by Lil Wayne that jj reimagines in its song “Ecstasy.” It is “Lollipop,” not “A Milli.”

headline: Bloggingheads: Expand the Bracket?
text: Will Leitch, left, of Deadspin and Hampton Stevens of The Atlantic debate expanding the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about mental health coverage under the new federal health care law, using information from the American Psychological Association, overstated one provision’s requirements for covering Medicaid recipients. Only those in Medicaid managed-care plans must be offered the same mental-health and substance-abuse benefits as medical and surgical benefits; the new law does not require all Medicaid coverage to include equal benefits.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Thursday about David Mills, a television writer who explored racial issues in scripts for “NYPD Blue,” “Homicide” and other dramas, referred incorrectly to the HBO series “The Wire,” for which he also wrote. It was an urban drama that explored various aspects of Baltimore and its institutions; it was not a “taut prison series.”

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: For Butler’s Stevens, Run Began in the Driveway
text: INDIANAPOLIS — When Brad Stevens was 5 years old, he spent each morning watching videotapes of basketball games before attending afternoon kindergarten. For his eighth birthday, his mother bought him a basketball hoop and hurried home from work early to see the look of excitement on his face.

headline: How to Stop Bullying in the Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: The End of History (Books)
text: TODAY, Apple’s iPad goes on sale, and many see this as a Gutenberg moment, with digital multimedia moving one step closer toward replacing old-fashioned books.

headline: Of Jets, Voyeurs and Back Wax
text: Our challenge today is to discuss politicians who get in trouble for extravagant spending, and to do it without mentioning the Republican National Committee’s expense-account party at the bondage club.

headline: President Karzai Lashes Out
text: The rambling speech of President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Thursday was alarming. His delusional criticism of the United Nations and governments whose troops are risking their lives by fighting the Taliban complicates the difficult effort to stabilize Afghanistan.

headline: About That Webcam
text: A Pennsylvania town has been roiled by a local high school using cameras in school-issued laptops to spy on students. Almost as shocking is the fact that the federal wiretap law that should prohibit this kind of surveillance does not cover spying done through photography and video in private settings.

headline: An Alternative to Statins
text: To the Editor:

headline: Promises for and From Haiti
text: This week’s donors conference for Haiti at the United Nations was strikingly hopeful, in good part because of what participants pledged not to do.

headline: We Still Don’t Hear Him
text: The great man was moving with what seemed like great reluctance. He knew as he climbed from the car in Upper Manhattan that he was stepping into the maelstrom, that there were powerful people who would not react kindly to what he had to say.

headline: An Article of Faith
text: Since signing the health care reform bill, President Obama has been traipsing about the country trying to sell it. It’s not really working for him.

headline: A Diagnosis of Anger
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Deal at Ground Zero?
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg and other politicians are celebrating a deal to finally finish the major buildings at the World Trade Center site. Let’s hope they are right to break out the confetti. Larry Silverstein, who is developing office towers on the site, and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the 16 acres, need to make sure that the agreement does not fall apart yet again, as they fill in the remaining details.

headline: After-School Programs
text: To The Editor:

headline: Huggins Focused on a Title, Not Redemption
text: INDIANAPOLIS — West Virginia Coach Bob Huggins has carried a mottled reputation for having players with off-the-court problems, having had zero percent graduation rates and using profane language.

headline: Mountaineers and Bulldogs Play to Their Strengths
text: Zach Hillesland, a contributor to The Quad, is a former Notre Dame forward who is now an academic adviser in the university’s athletic department.

headline: Previewing Williams-Clijsters Final
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — It has been nine years since Venus Williams reached the final of the Sony Ericsson Open, but for the first time since 2001 she will be there Saturday at 12:30 p.m. to play an old rival.

headline: Loyalty Is Paramount in Woods’s Inner Circle
text: Tiger Woods, a self-acknowledged control freak, insists on loyalty as a fundamental quality in employees, associates and friends. Just how much Woods values allegiance was summed up by his father, Earl, in an interview shortly before he died.

headline: Mets Cut Six, Including Four Pitchers
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The Mets intended to wait until Saturday’s exhibition final against Baltimore in Sarasota to make their final cuts. Instead, they let six players go after Friday’s 4-2 loss to Tampa Bay, cutting pitchers Nelson Figueroa, Bobby Parnell, Kiko Calero and Elmer Dessens; infielder Russ Adams; and outfielder Chris Carter.

headline: Ochoa Has Hard Day on the Course, but a Good One
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — Life is like a long par-3 to Lorena Ochoa, the top-ranked women’s golfer. There are hazards galore, but all too soon the adventure will be over.

headline: Roddick Overcomes Nadal as Risk Is Rewarded
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Even though he knew he would be facing one of tennis’s top defensive players in Rafael Nadal, Andy Roddick felt comfortable enough in the way he had been playing to continue with what had been working.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Rangers Just 2 Points From Playoff Spot
text: Seven games on Friday, including two huge ones in the East and one in the West. Home teams listed first:

headline: Seth Curry Turns Heads Since Transferring to Duke
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Stephen and Seth Curry played seven grueling games of one-on-one last summer at the Jewish Community Center in Charlotte, N.C.

headline: Stephen Curry Brings Hope to Beleaguered Warriors
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — In the semi-charmed life of Golden State’s golden rookie, the television serves as both ego amplifier and modesty meter.

headline: Alexander McQueen’s Final Bow
text: AT approximately 10:20 a.m. on Feb. 11, a London taxi stopped at the entrance to Green Street, a normally quiet block of drab red brick houses in Mayfair — drabber on this bone-chilling Thursday — and the passengers, a man and two women, hastily got out.

headline: Yankees and Mets Get Together, Almost, in a Split Spring Doubleheader
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — After the Yankees moved their spring training base from Fort Lauderdale to Tampa in 1996, and Major League Baseball instituted interleague play in 1997, exhibition games in Florida between the Yankees and the Mets lost their attraction. The Yankees have no interest in busing two and a half hours to Port St. Lucie, and the Mets show little inclination to come over to Tampa.

headline: Rangers Roll Over the Lightning, Inching Closer to a Playoff Position
text: TAMPA, Fla.— The Rangers took a big step closer to the playoffs Friday, crushing a Tampa Bay team in disarray and gaining ground on postseason contenders.

headline: Kit Horn, Pioneer Surfer, Dies at 80
text: Kit Horn, a skilled surfer whose exploration of new surf spots along the California coast in the 1940s and 1950s — and later Oahu’s famed North Shore — helped the sport grow from a small subculture to an international pastime, died March 25 at his home in Encinitas, Calif. He was 80.

headline: Friends Reflect on Alexander McQueen’s Death
text: In this weekend’s cover story in Sunday Styles, Cathy Horyn reports on the events leading up to the suicide, at age 40, of the designer Alexander McQueen on Feb. 11. She writes movingly on his life and death, based on interviews with his closest friends, most of whom have not spoken publicly before. Among them are the fashion muse Daphne Guinness, who recalls being in a Paris hotel room with Mr. McQueen a few months earlier, celebrating a triumphant runway show earlier that day: “I had never seen him happier or so full of ideas.”

headline: Alexander McQueen: A Designer's Story
text: The designer was known for some of the most controversial collections and fashion shows of the last two decades. Here is a timeline of his life and career.

headline: Looking Ahead: The Men’s Final Four
text: Michigan St. vs. ButlerSaturday, 6:07 p.m.TV: CBS

headline: Man, 18, Is Fatally Stabbed Near Prospect Park
text: An 18-year-old man was chased and stabbed to death near Prospect Park early Friday evening after a confrontation with a group of men over a girl, the police said.

headline: 6 Afghans Die as Their Unit Is Hit in Error by Germans
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A contingent of Afghan reinforcements delivering supplies to a German military base was mistakenly fired on by German troops, and six Afghan soldiers were killed, officials said Saturday.

headline: Classic Ad: Datsun 240Z
text: In this Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the Nissan 370Z Roadster, the latest incarnation of the first Japanese sports car to win a widespread following in the United States. The original Z-car, the 1970 Datsun 240Z, was an instant sensation when it arrived in North America in October 1969, winning fans for its combination of strong performance, responsive handling, reasonable price and intelligent packaging.

headline: Best Right Tackles in the N.F.L.: The Top 10 List
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely – but not strictly – by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, though the future isn’t utterly ignored. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding ways to disagree about what you’re about to read.

headline: American Stars May Sit Out World Championships
text: As Team USA dropped from its basketball perch, many pointed to a lack of desire in representing the country from the N.B.A.’s star players as a prime component. The losses and prodding from USA Basketball managing director Jerry Colangelo helped firm up flimsy commitments, a reason the United States won the gold medal at the Beijing Games.

headline: An ‘Agonizing Wait’ Yields Tough, but Enviable, Choices
text: And so it has finally come, nearly bringing with it the crashing musical accompaniment and jarring mental edits of a scene straight from the Transformers movies — April 1 has arrived, and now passed.

headline: A Wild, Rainy Qualifier in Malaysia
text: Malaysia delivered a flood of rain again as a qualifying session turned into a massive free-for-all at the Malaysian Grand Prix. And it was Mark Webber in a Red Bull who came out on top with the third pole position of his career after he was the only driver in the top 10 to finish out the session on intermediate wet tires, instead of full-wet tires.

headline: The Final Four and Baseball’s Champions
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: 25 Members of Sunni Family Killed Near Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — The killers came at night, speaking passable English and wearing uniforms and carrying weapons that resembled those of the American military.

headline: Urban Forager | A Bitter Green Bouquet
text: In the spirit of Passover (still not too late to sneak in that Third Seder), here’s a list of wild edibles fit for a free-range Seder plate, including dandelion, garlic mustard, and common mugwort. This forager’s fantasy of bitter herbs grows freely throughout the city, and, who knows, may even be flourishing in front of your stoop or in thy neighbor’s yard.

headline: The iPad’s Big Day
text: Since the word “iPad” entered the collective consciousness back in January, there has been plenty of punditry about what Apple‘s new device means for the future of technology, media and life as we know it. On Saturday, people will finally be able to start making up their own minds about it. The iPad went on sale this morning at Apple and Best Buy stores around the country. Check back here for updates from Times reporters and from the Web at large. Please share your thoughts and experiences in the comments, especially if you are diving into the frenzy yourself.

headline: Saturday Word: Easter Address
text: As the country continues to split over the administration’s health care bill, President Obama tried to build unity among “Jews and Christians, Muslims and Hindus, believers and nonbelievers alike” in his national address the day before Easter.

headline: Sarah Weeks, Edward Daniels
text: Sarah Elizabeth Weeks and Edward Frost Daniels were married Saturday evening in Brooklyn. The Rev. Lynell H. Carter, a Lutheran minister, officiated at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios, in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

headline: Marian Westley, David Pinkus
text: Marian Bohanna Westley, an oceanographer, and David Steven Pinkus, a high school physics teacher, were married Saturday at a fusion energy research laboratory, where the couple met, at Princeton University in Plainsboro, N.J. Mayor H. Frances Enright of Spring Lake Heights, N.J., officiated.

headline: Christopher Heywood, Nicholas Tomasetti
text: Christopher Charles Heywood and Nicholas Roy Tomasetti were married Saturday evening at the Wequassett Resort and Golf Club in Chatham, Mass. The Rev. Jim F. David, a priest of the Ecumenical Catholic Church of Christ, officiated.

headline: ‘A Popcorn Law’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Under President Obama’s new airport security plan, anyone traveling to the U.S. will be stopped if they match the description of a potential terrorist. Wait, we weren’t doing this already?

headline: ‘New Tiny Cars’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Oh, you know what they do every Monday after Easter at the White House? They have the hunt, on the White House lawn. And they canceled it this year. You know why? I was stunned. I didn’t know about this. Last year a couple of kids accidentally stumbled into Dick Cheney’s underground torture chamber.

headline: Elizabeth Schwartz, Matthew Coleman
text: Elizabeth A. Schwartz, the daughter of Jeanne E. Mixon and John Schwartz of Millburn, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Matthew M. Coleman, a son of Carol A. Coleman and William H. Coleman of Dexter, Mich. Rabbi Alan Freedman officiated at an outdoor ceremony at the Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center at the University of Texas at Austin.

headline: Criticism of Chávez Stifled by Arrests
text: LOS TEQUES, Venezuela — When Judge María Lourdes Afiuni issued a ruling in December that irked President Hugo Chávez, he did little to contain his outrage. The president, contending on national television that she would have been put before a firing squad in earlier times, sent his secret intelligence police to arrest her.

headline: Mark Cuban’s Grudge Match With the S.E.C.
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to securities law and white-collar crime for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: Rejoice, Muffy and Biff: A Preppy Primer Revisited
text: Just when you thought it was safe to get back in your khakis.

headline: Yolon Jambor, Jeremy Vellon
text: Yolon S. Jambor, a daughter of Suzanne L. Bauch of Pinckney, Mich., and the late David F. Jambor, was married Monday evening to Lt. Cmdr. Jeremy E. Vellon, a son of Maria D. Vellon and Herbert G. Vellon of Brooklyn. Renate Anne Daversa, a Universal Life minister, officiated at Cuvier Park in San Diego.

headline: Vivienne La Borde, Kaddu Luyombya
text: Vivienne Ceri La Borde and Kaddu Kibuuka Luyombya were married Saturday at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York. The Rev. Daisy M. Barnum, an African Methodist Episcopal minister, officiated.

headline: Puns and Anagrams
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Mel Taub’s PandA puzzles might seem tricky at first. You can finish them if you’re patient. Think of every clue as ending with a question mark, and then it’s just like any old Thursday puzzle, only even more fun.

headline: At 89, Stevens Contemplates Law, and How to Leave It
text: WASHINGTON — “There are still pros and cons to be considered,” Justice John Paul Stevens said in his Supreme Court chambers on Friday afternoon, reflecting on his reluctance to leave a job he loves after almost 35 years. But his calculus seemed to be weighted toward departure, and he said his decision on the matter would come very soon.

headline: Burden of Paying for Wedding Bells Shifts
text: WHEN it comes to paying for a wedding while remaining financially afloat, today’s rule is all hands on deck.

headline: Anglican Archbishop Rebukes Irish Church
text: LONDON — At a time when his relations with Pope Benedict XVI are already strained over the pope’s offer to dissatisfied Anglicans of fast-track conversion to Roman Catholicism, the archbishop of Canterbury has plunged into the crisis over cases of abuse by Catholic priests, choosing the Easter weekend to describe the Catholic Church in Ireland as “losing all credibility” because of its poor handling of the crisis.

headline: Violence Helps Taliban Undo Afghan Gains
text: MARJA, Afghanistan — Since their offensive here in February, the Marines have flooded Marja with hundreds of thousands of dollars a week. The tactic aims to win over wary residents by paying them compensation for property damage or putting to work men who would otherwise look to the Taliban for support.

headline: Hijacking Too Big To Fail
text: This AP report illustrates perfectly why I’m worried about emphasizing the too-big-to-fail problem rather than the need for tighter regulation:

headline: Changeups in the Pastime
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — In the world of sports, change is not necessarily a complicated process. Brett Favre is denied a trip to the Super Bowl, perhaps by the flip of a coin, and voilà, the owners vote to change the rules of overtime. A few months after the N.C.A.A. floats the idea of expanding its men’s basketball tournament to 96 teams, it appears to be close to a fait accompli.

headline: We Are Not Mirror Images
text: Jon Chait has a post about a conservative misinformation campaign involving a truncated quote from Barney Frank — something to which I can relate. In this case, the estimateestimable Mr. Frank was saying that we need to expand regulation of runaway financial institutions, and this was clipped to make it seem as if he was calling for bigger government across the board.

headline: Why Has Greece Dropped From The Headlines?
text: It suddenly occurred to me that I wasn’t reading much about Greece the last few days. Was the situation stabilizing?

headline: Palestinian, 14, Emerges Unharmed
text: GAZA — A 14-year-old boy thought to have been killed either by Israeli gunfire or from internal Palestinian violence last week turned up unharmed at his family’s house after trying to sneak into Egypt via smuggler tunnels and being held by Egyptian security officials, his parents said Saturday.

headline: Yankees Set 25-Man Roster
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees completed the 25-man roster Saturday morning. All the injured guys seem to be better, so there were no surprises.

headline: Rites of Spring Offer Lessons for Everyone
text: Indianapolis

headline: Ride That Pony
text: Donald Frey, the man behind the Ford Mustang, died last month at age 86.

headline: Prime Number
text: 31.2: The average length of time, in weeks, that the jobless were out of work in March, the longest span since the government began collecting that data in 1948. But the news was not all bad. Employers added 162,000 jobs last month, the biggest gain in nearly three years and the latest indication that the economy is turning around. Still, the unemployment rate remained at 9.7 percent, and the government predicts that rate will average 9.8 percent next year.

headline: Contesting Jobless Claims Becomes a Boom Industry
text: WASHINGTON — With a client list that reads like a roster of Fortune 500 firms, a little-known company with an odd name, the Talx Corporation, has come to dominate a thriving industry: helping employers process — and fight — unemployment claims.

headline: A History of Complaints
text: Wisconsin officials have long complained that the Talx Corporation causes errors and delays in processing unemployment claims. The complaints were spelled out in a 2004 letter from the unemployment insurance administrator to the president of Talx. Years of subsequent e-mail messages, from front-line staff members and their supervisors, suggest that many of the problems have persisted.

headline: Fighting Words
text: "Real American Stories," a new series hosted by Sarah Palin on Fox News, announced in an ad that LL Cool J would be a guest.

headline: Correction: When Does Political Anger Turn to Violence?
text: An article last Sunday about political anger turning to violence misstated part of the name of the college where Clark McCauley, who has studied the psychology of violence, is a professor of psychology. It is Bryn Mawr College, not University.

headline: For Mets, Gloom and Doom Instead of Sunshine and Smiles
text: “Abandon hope, all ye who enter here.”

headline: Sex Business Backs the Party Animal
text: “Bondage-gate,” as it’s been called — the unfortunate convergence of Republican Party donors and a Hollywood sex club with a lesbian theme — has led to the dismissal of a party staffer, an inquiry into the use of donor money and gleeful late-night television jokes (“Me likey,” Jon Stewart quipped), but, really, is it such a big deal?

headline: Yankees vs. Red Sox Will Be Without Its Regular Rhythm
text: The Yankees and the Red Sox will play each other 18 times this season. The rivalry will be renewed each game as they move from Fenway Park, where they start their season Sunday night, to Yankee Stadium.

headline: In Maine, Last Sardine Cannery in the U.S. Is Clattering Out
text: PROSPECT HARBOR, Me. — The women in their smudged aprons here at the sardine cannery work together in mesmerizing synchronization. Their hands flying, they fill the empty tins that clatter along the conveyer belt, packing in pieces of cut herring like, well, so many sardines.

headline: The Writers’ Room at ‘24’
text: The following takes place in real time:

headline: For Woods, Exemptions No Longer in Play
text: When Tiger Woods, the face of golf for more than a decade, returns to public life at the Masters, what face will we see?

headline: School Law Clinics Face a Backlash
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — Law school students nationwide are facing growing attacks in the courts and legislatures as legal clinics at the schools increasingly take on powerful interests that few other nonprofit groups have the resources to challenge.

headline: For the Battle-Scarred, Comfort at Leash’s End
text: WASHINGTON — Just weeks after Chris Goehner, 25, an Iraq war veteran, got a dog, he was able to cut in half the dose of anxiety and sleep medications he took for post-traumatic stress disorder. The night terrors and suicidal thoughts that kept him awake for days on end ceased.

headline: There Is More to Baylor’s Griner Than Viral Videos on the Internet
text: SAN ANTONIO

headline: Protesters Block Heart of Bangkok’s Shopping Area
text: BANGKOK — Antigovernment protesters who have camped out on the streets of Bangkok for the past three weeks raised the stakes in their mass demonstrations on Saturday, converging on the heart of Bangkok’s shopping district and vowing to remain until new elections are called.

headline: UConn Needs Game Plan for Brittney Griner
text: SAN ANTONIO — Asked if he relished facing Baylor’s 6-foot-8 Brittney Griner at the Women’s Final Four on Sunday, Connecticut Coach Geno Auriemma said sure. He would be on the bench, not on the court.

headline: Where Are You When the Going Gets Tough?
text: This interview with Andrew Cosslett, chief executive of InterContinental Hotels Group,  was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: U.S. to Delay Chinese Currency Report
text: The Obama administration said Saturday that it would delay a decision on whether to declare China a currency manipulator, but it vowed to press Chinese leaders on the politically charged issue of its currency valuation during a series of meetings through June.

headline: A Primer on the Great Proton Smashup
text: For those whose physics knowledge was a bit rusty, the news about the Large Hadron Collider, the world's biggest physics machine, might have been puzzling.

headline: Weighing Benefits of 96 Teams
text: The magical run by Butler University’s fifth-seeded basketball team this month has amplified talk of expanding the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament to as many as 96 teams, ostensibly so that more colleges can participate. N.C.A.A. officials are expected to decide whether to take that step in the coming weeks.

headline: Expansion Is Tough Call for the Interim Boss
text: INDIANAPOLIS — If a theme song were to be played in the background of this Final Four, R.E.M.’s “It’s the End of the World as We Know It” would be most appropriate.

headline: Another Cousteau Working to Save the Waters
text: I FIRST went on an expedition with my father, Philippe Cousteau, and my mother when I was 4 months old. He had outfitted an amphibious plane, named the Flying Calypso, as a base of operations, and it became our home away from home. By the time I was 4, I had traveled to over a dozen countries.

headline: In Russia, Putin Escapes Blame for Terror Attack
text: MOSCOW — The Moscow subway, which is usually so punctual and sparkling that it makes New York’s seem like a third world also-ran, was slowly getting back to normal late last week. But passengers kept looking over their shoulders, casting uneasy glances at others (Could he be one? Could she?) and silently cursing terrorism’s return to their lives.

headline: Clijsters’s Win Is Like a Day in the Park
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — In less time than it might take to accompany her 2-year-old daughter to the playground, Kim Clijsters was dominant in her other job Saturday, dismissing Venus Williams in less than an hour to win the Sony Ericsson Open.

headline: When a First Pick Isn’t the Best Pick
text: AS March Madness winds down, it’s time to turn our attention to the next major sports event on the calendar. That’s right, the National Football League draft, now a three-day extravaganza with the first round broadcast in prime time on April 22.

headline: Coming to Terms With My Sabbatical
text: “I NEED a sabbatical from my sabbatical,” I recently confided to a friend. I wasn’t joking. For some time, I had been feeling exhausted from being on work-leave. And this got me to thinking: if the word “sabbatical” derives from “Sabbath,” meaning “rest,” why was I so restless and worn out?

headline: When Stocks Stop Moving Like a Herd
text: AMID all the market uncertainty of the last two years, investors have had a hard time knowing when to jump in. But once they have, they’ve at least known that their stocks stood a good chance of moving in the same direction as the broad market — until the last few months, that is.

headline: The Iraqi Voter Rewrites the Rulebook
text: BAGHDAD — Quite a few of the candidates in Iraq’s national election did so poorly they didn’t even get the votes of their wives (assuming the sole vote these candidates got was their own).

headline: At CVB Financial, Praise and Questions
text: THE plaudits are piling up at CVB Financial, the holding company for Citizens Business Bank, a midsize institution with $6.7 billion in assets based in Ontario, Calif.

headline: Packing to Leave
text: An inside look at the Stinson Seafood Company, the last sardine cannery in the United States.

headline: For Knicks, New Season Will Start on April 16
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — When the schedule has been emptied and there are no more games to lose, or shots to clank, or defensive assignments to ignore, when the Knicks have scattered across the country, Mike D’Antoni will be left alone with his thoughts.

headline: The Last Sardine Cannery
text: The Stinson Seafood Co., the last sardine cannery in the United States, will close its doors this month. This multimedia was produced by Compass Light Productions for the Penobscot Marine Museum.

headline: Is President Obama Fulfilling Clinton’s Promise?
text: WASHINGTON — For years, Bill Clinton tried to negotiate an arms control treaty for the post-cold-war era. He and Boris Yeltsin even agreed on a framework for a new Start treaty in Helsinki. But it never came to be. So when President Obama flies to Prague this week to sign a New Start treaty with Russia, it will culminate Mr. Clinton’s unfulfilled aspiration.
