text: Quick takes on five N.F.L. news items: COWBOY RELEASES

headline: Across the Country, Fans Gather for iPad
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple’s most devoted fans congregated on Saturday morning at stores around the country to pick up their latest object of desire: the eagerly anticipated iPad.

headline: Words as Weapons: Dropping the ‘Terrorism’ Bomb
text: WASHINGTON — Words can be weapons, too. So after nearly every new report of political violence, whether merely plotted or actually carried out, there is a vocabulary debate: Should it be labeled “terrorism”?

headline: Bargain Rates for a C.E.O.?
text: LAST year may have been unnerving for chief executives accustomed to all of the familiar ornaments of corporate life: eight-figure pay packages, corporate jets, memberships in select clubs, and on and on.

headline: Another Talented Teenager Gets in the Swing
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — On her left hand, Alexis Thompson is wearing a golf glove with the word Tempo written in her girlish scrawl. It is there to remind her not to be in such a rush, to take her time with her swing.

headline: Calculating the Pay Figures
text: TO measure the amounts that executives were paid last year, Sunday Business asked Equilar, an executive compensation research firm, to compile and analyze pay data from corporate filings.

headline: ‘Green Gone Wrong’: Can Capitalism Save the Planet?
text: IT may seem quaint to recall this now, but on the eve of the financial crisis, one of the biggest business stories was how large corporations were going to save the planet and make billions of dollars for their shareholders at the same time.

headline: 16-Year-Old Italian Is Set to Make History at the Masters
text: ALPHARETTA, Ga. — Matteo Manassero found himself in a hazardous place among the pine needles behind the second green at the Golf Club of Georgia. His predicament raised a couple of questions: Are there pine trees in Italy? Could he play under pressure, as well as under pine trees?

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu: April 4
text: Sunday may be a holiday for some, but there should still be a lot of chatter about jobs on the morning talk shows.

headline: Striking Gold in Stock Options
text: WERE they smart, or just lucky?

headline: European Leisure
text: I see that Ryan Avent has been sparring with Scott Sumner over the question of whether lower European GDP per capita compared with the United States — mainly the result of lower working hours rather than lower productivity — can be attributed to higher taxes.

headline: Court Rules for Woman and Against Public Course
text: Elaine Joyce, a champion amateur golfer, made a federal case of being barred from playing in a 2007 men’s tournament at Dennis Pines Golf Course, where she is a longtime member. She sued the town of Dennis, Mass., and others in 2008. Last week, the United States District Court in Boston, in a rare federal ruling involving a town, its public golf course and an accusation centering on sex discrimination, told her she had won.

headline: More Than Enough Hours in Every Day
text: My mother-in-law, Dorothy, is showing me the red spiral notebook that’s almost as precious to her as my husband’s baby pictures. Inside, in Dorothy’s distinctive script, is a list of every book she has read since 2007. For some people waking up in the middle of the night is a terrible curse; unable to drift back to sleep, they’re confronted with a big gaping hole that represents hours of lost time. For my mother-in-law, that time is a gift. At 87, she is acquiring the education she never had by working her way through the canon of great literature. She has now read close to 100 books, including every single novel by Anthony Trollope, Charles Dickens, Jane Austen, Edith Wharton, Henry James and Thomas Mann.My mother-in-law discusses her newfound passion with the enthusiasm of a young girl, although she can also be a very tough critic, writing “VG” for “very good” in the margins next to her favorites. Thus far, only a handful of books have received the top prize. Though she “loves” Mr. Darcy, especially after seeing the Masterpiece Theater version with the dashing Colin Firth, she didn’t award Jane Austen a single “VG.” “I can’t explain it,” she says. “I like her a lot and I wish she’d written more – was she sickly? I can’t remember – but she just doesn’t hold a candle to Thomas Mann (three ‘VG’s’). Everybody should read ‘Buddenbrooks.’ Where were those books when I was growing up?”

headline: The Debut of the iPad
text: After months of anticipation, Apple’s iPad finally went on sale. Eager customers had been lining up outside Apple stores to be among the first to buy one.

headline: I Saw the Crisis Coming. Why Didn’t the Fed?
text: Cupertino, Calif.

headline: Splitting Hairs
text: There are two kinds of people in the world. You know how it goes. Northerners and Southerners. Realists and dreamers. People with curly hair and people with straight hair. “Every classification throws light on something,” said Isaiah Berlin, the political philosopher and elucidator of the distinction between fox people, who know many things, and hedgehog people, who know one big thing.

headline: Social
text: In our Web-driven era of social media and social networking, we are all learning more sophisticated ways to “socialize” that go far beyond cocktail-party chatter. But being social in the 21st century can sometimes be downright unsettling.

headline: Slightly Used
text: In each episode of the fascinating BBC Radio 4 series “A History of the World in 100 Objects,” Neil MacGregor, the director of the British Museum, uses one item from that institution’s collection as a jumping-off point to discuss humanity’s long relationship with made things. The journey starts, as you would expect, with something useful: a “stone chopping tool,” believed to be about 1.8 million years old, suggests the dawning of a “relationship between humans and the things they create, which is both a love affair and a dependency,” MacGregor says. “From this point on, we can’t survive without the things we make.”

headline: How Washington Abetted the Bank Job
text: A FEW weeks ago, two Republican House members asked Ben Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, whether the Fed knew  before Lehman’s bankruptcy examiner revealed it  about the bookkeeping scam at Lehman known as “Repo 105.” This scam allowed Lehman to disguise how much debt it was carrying, right up until it collapsed. Lehman got new loans to pay off old loans, pretended the new loans were “sales,” and through a complicated series of steps made both the old and new loans disappear just in time for its quarterly reports.

headline: Yankees Set Roster
text: The Yankees completed their 25-man roster Saturday morning. All the injured players appear to be better, so there were no surprises.

headline: New York Denies Indian Point a Water Permit
text: In a major victory for environmental advocates, New York State has ruled that outmoded cooling technology at the Indian Point nuclear power plant kills so many Hudson River fish, and consumes and contaminates so much water, that it violates the federal Clean Water Act.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Hundreds of Drug Cases Are at Risk in San Francisco
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Hundreds of drug cases have been dismissed and hundreds more are being examined here by prosecutors who are scrambling to deal with the fallout from accusations that a technician in the Police Department’s crime laboratory was stealing cocaine for personal use.

headline: Rhymes and Reasons for Father-Daughter Bonding
text: “Daddy, what rhymes with Pierzynski?”

headline: Start-Ups, Not Bailouts
text: Here’s my fun fact for the day, provided courtesy of Robert Litan, who directs research at the Kauffman Foundation, which specializes in promoting innovation in America: “Between 1980 and 2005, virtually all net new jobs created in the U.S. were created by firms that were 5 years old or less,” said Litan. “That is about 40 million jobs. That means the established firms created no new net jobs during that period.”

headline: Coach Walks the Dress Code’s Fine Line
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees require jackets, but not ties, on their charter flights. So technically, the bullpen coach Mike Harkey did not violate the dress code. But Manager Joe Girardi enjoyed ragging him for an embarrassing oversight.

headline: It’s a Bird, It’s a Plane, It’s Obama!
text: NOT since Clark Kent changed in a phone booth has there been an instant image makeover to match Barack Obama’s in the aftermath of his health care victory. “He went from Jimmy Carter to F.D.R. in just a fortnight,” said one of the “Game Change” authors, Mark Halperin, on MSNBC. “Look at the steam in the man’s stride!” exclaimed Chris Matthews. “Is it just me, or does Barack Obama seem different since health care passed?” wrote Peter Beinart in The Daily Beast, which, like The Financial Times, ran an illustration portraying the gangly president as a newly bulked-up Superman.

headline: After Word
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Bob Klahn is taking it easy on us today. He’s known for his clever cluing but even more for his tough puzzles. Even top solvers know they’re in for a challenge when Will Shortz announces his name at the A.C.P.T. as a tournament constructor. A collective gulp trickles across the room. The Wrath of Klahn.

headline: Live Updates From the Men’s Final Four: Butler Beats Michigan State
text: Live coverage and analysis from the Final Four. Kevin Armstrong and Thayer Evans will provide updates from Indianapolis, along with the the longtime Quad contributor Zach Hillesland, who played in the tournament with Notre Dame. You can also follow Pete Thamel on Twitter throughout the Final Four.

headline: Mets Make Final Moves
text: The Mets completed their 25-man roster Saturday after they lost to the Orioles, 11-0, in their final spring training game.

headline: You, Too, Can Bankroll a Rock Band
text: EVEN early in their careers, the Beatles led charmed lives. Sure, they spent hundreds of nights playing the clubs of Hamburg before their inherent talent and practiced skill were discovered. But once they were waved into the privileged sanctum of the signed recording artist, they commanded the world’s attention.

headline: Does Merck Agreement Pave a Road Toward Change?
text: SHAREHOLDERS of Merck sued in 2004, contending that current and former company officers and directors had breached their fiduciary duties in the marketing of the painkiller Vioxx, causing investors to lose billions.

headline: Suns Go Back to Doing What They Do Best
text: Last year, the Phoenix Suns fired their coach, and missed the playoffs for the first time since 2004. This year, the Suns have ridden a late-season hot streak back to their customary place near the top of the Western Conference and could make some noise come playoff time.

headline: Harriet Shetler, Who Helped to Found Mental Illness Group, Dies at 92
text: Harriet Shetler, whose experience as the mother of a son with schizophrenia led her to help start a national organization to address mental health needs, died Tuesday in Madison, Wis. She was 92.

headline: Burton Joseph, Lawyer in First Amendment Cases, Is Dead at 79
text: Burton Joseph, a civil liberties lawyer in Chicago who took on tough First Amendment causes, notably the right of Nazis to march through Skokie, a Chicago suburb with a large Jewish population, died on Wednesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 79 and maintained his primary residence in Evanston, Ill.

headline: Stamkos Up, Ovechkin Down
text: TAMPA, Fla. — There will be no playoffs for the Tampa Bay sophomore Steven Stamkos, certainly not after he and the Lightning were so emphatically beaten by the Rangers on  Friday, 5-0. But Stamkos is still a big part of the hockey conversation this spring as an unforeseen contender for the Maurice Richard Trophy, awarded to the N.H.L.’s top goal scorer.

headline: Factory Food
text: No country has embraced the movement toward commercialized, prepackaged food as much as the United States.

headline: David Slivka, a Sculptor and Painter, Dies at 95
text: On the morning of Nov. 11, 1953, David Slivka, a well-known sculptor, slipped into a Manhattan funeral parlor to pay his respects to a friend. It was no ordinary visit.

headline: A Place With Good Vibrations
text: Alonzo King is the choreographer and artistic director for Alonzo King LINES Ballet, a contemporary dance company he founded in 1982. Decades ago when Mr. King was new to San Francisco, a friend took him into Golden Gate Park, where he was captivated by a roadside stand of Australian tree ferns. (His remarks have been edited and condensed.) MALIA WOLLAN

headline: Richmond’s New Priority: Taking Health Seriously
text: Daniel Weintraub has reported on California politics and policy for more than 20 years.

headline: City Endorses New Policy for Treatment of H.I.V.
text: In a major shift of H.I.V. treatment policy, San Francisco public health doctors have begun to advise patients to start taking antiviral medicines as soon as they are found to be infected, rather than waiting — sometimes years — for signs that their immune systems have started to fail.

headline: Why Hurling Rotten Fruit Is Good for Theater
text: When audiences threw rotten vegetables at actors in the old days, it generally meant they weren’t having a good time. But the San Francisco-based theater company PianoFight has been resurrecting that Shakespearean tradition in the hopes of inducing the opposite effect.

headline: City Endorses New Policy for H.I.V. Treatment, and Highlights From Sunday’s Bay Area Report
text: A Major Shift | San Francisco public health doctors have begun to advise H.I.V. patients to start taking antiviral medicines as soon as they are found to be infected, rather than waiting — sometimes years — for signs that their immune systems have started to fail. The controversial city guidelines, to be announced next week by the Department of Public Health, may be the most forceful anywhere in their endorsement of early treatment against H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

headline: Tiny Knox College Stands Tall at Commencements
text: All things considered, the graduation speaker who drones on before the mortarboards are sent skyward typically rates low on the college senior’s list of concerns.

headline: Corrections
text: A news analysis article last Sunday about coming elections in Britain, where the opposition Conservatives hope to end the Labour Party’s 13 years in power, misstated the age of Labour’s leader, Prime Minister Gordon Brown. He is 59, not 57.

headline: For Some Aspiring Political Broadcasters, Breaking the Law Does Pay
text: When James Laski finished serving his 11-month prison stint on corruption charges in 2008, he knew his political career was over. But the former Chicago city clerk had every reason to believe his rap sheet was no barrier to another coveted, high-profile job: Chicago radio broadcaster.

text: The 2900 block of Washtenaw Avenue is a quiet street in the Avondale neighborhood, where women stroll with baby carriages and parents watch their children play on the seesaw in Algonquin Park, a small playground.

headline: Taking a Different Look at Chicago’s Cultural Assets
text: In the middle of North Lawndale, now one of America’s most shamefully impoverished neighborhoods, there’s a boarded-up apartment building where Golda Meir, the former Israeli prime minister, lived briefly when she was a young librarian.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions last Sunday about the Composers of the Future program for children, held in a school behind St. Gabriel’s Roman Catholic Church in New Rochelle, N.Y., misidentified the entity that runs the program together with the Westchester Chamber Orchestra. It is Songcatchers, an after-school music group, not the church itself.

headline: Helping Patients Face Death, She Fought to Live
text: By the time she was 38, Dr. Desiree Pardi had become a leading practitioner in palliative care, one of the fastest-growing fields in medicine, counseling terminally ill patients on their choices.

headline: We Can’t Tell You
text: For more than 20 years, it was settled law, born of bitter experience, that the government may not eavesdrop on people in the United States without a warrant.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Sunday about the Charedim Shmurah Matzah Bakery in Borough Park, Brooklyn, which makes its matzo by hand, misstated part of the Web address where a photographer, Judah S. Harris, has posted pictures of the bakery. It is judahsharris.com/matzah-bakery.

text: Private equity deal makers, those kings of corporate buyouts, made billions for themselves when times were good. But some of their biggest investors, public pension funds, are still waiting for the hefty rewards they were promised, The New York Times’s Jenny Anderson reports.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about houseplants that do well in New York City apartments misidentified the genus of one plant, known as the ZZ plant. It is Zamioculcas zamiifolia, not Zamia zamiifolia.

headline: Sweet Honey on the Roof
text: Here’s the best news we have heard in a while: keeping honeybees is now legal in New York City. The old rule was based on a misunderstanding. It lumped honeybees into a long list of wild animals that may not be kept in the city  outside a zoo  including the hippopotamus and elephant.

headline: Hedge Funds Make Hay
text: Riding high on the bank bailout, hedge fund managers posted record paydays in 2009, according to an annual survey by AR: Absolute Return +Alpha magazine.

headline: Tattered Right to Counsel
text: New York State’s dysfunctional, underfinanced public defender program is a problem of constitutional dimensions. It is the subject of a class-action lawsuit, which argues credibly that indigent criminal defendants are regularly deprived of their right to effective counsel. The suit, filed by the New York Civil Liberties Union, focuses on five counties, but the problem is far broader. A commission appointed by Judith Kaye, then the chief judge, concluded in 2006 that the state’s defender system failed to provide effective representation to “a large portion of those entitled to it,” citing bloated caseloads and inadequate training and supervision.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions last Sunday about “America’s Kitchens,” an exhibition of seven period kitchens at the Long Island Museum in Stony Brook, gave an outdated name for the organization that owns the three dozen historic homes from which the kitchens were borrowed. It is now Historic New England, no longer the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities.

headline: Queasy Before Her Round, Leader Is All Smiles After It
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — Her mouth was drier than the desert, her stomach was churning and she could not feel her legs. As nervous as Karen Stupples was Saturday, she knew she was poised for a good round on moving day at the Kraft Nabisco Championship.

headline: Nearing Record, Warriors’ Nelson Prefers Not to Talk About It
text: Don Nelson had one warning for the news media.

headline: Corrections
text: A brief article on March 14 about an automobile show at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta, which includes cars once owned by Clark Gable and Steve McQueen, referred incorrectly to the actors’ preferences in cars. They both owned Jaguars; it was not the case that they had completely different tastes in cars. (As the article noted, Mr. Gable owned a big, lavish 1935 Duesenberg and Mr. McQueen owned the sleek Jaguar XKSS  both of which are in the Atlanta show. But Mr. Gable was one of the first Americans to own a Jaguar XK120, a predecessor to Mr. McQueen’s XKSS.)

headline: White Supremacist Is Killed in South Africa
text: JOHANNESBURG — The white supremacist Eugene TerreBlanche, who sought to rally Afrikaners to resist the end of apartheid, was killed Saturday on his farm by workers there, police officials said.

headline: Correction
text: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Brian Distelberg and Ryan McAuliffe misstated the middle name of Mr. McAuliffe’s father. He is Kenneth Joseph McAuliffe, not Kenneth Jay.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Sunday about low-profile attractions in Paris referred incorrectly to Louis XV’s connection to the Louvre in describing Ô Chateau, which offers wine tastings in that monarch’s private cellar. Louis XV lived at Versailles, not at the Louvre. (He oversaw additions to the Louvre.)

headline: Lookin at Lucky Falters; Eskendereya Cruises
text: ARCADIA, Calif. — Shortly after Eskendereya pulled away from an overwhelmed Wood Memorial field in New York and established himself as the early Kentucky Derby favorite, 10 horses edged into the starting gate here for the Santa Anita Derby in a race that was supposed to sort out who was the best 3-year-old in the West.

headline: Six Arrested After Girl, 7, Is Gang-Raped in New Jersey
text: New Jersey officials announced on Saturday six arrests in connection with the gang rape of a 7-year-old girl who investigators believe was sold for sex by her 15-year-old stepsister at a party in a Trenton high-rise last weekend.

headline: Correction
text: The Evening Hours column last Sunday misidentified a guest shown at the Asia Society reception on March 22. She is Chiu-Ti Jansen, not Elizabeth Han.

headline: Correction
text: The “In the Region” article in New York and New Jersey copies last Sunday about redevelopment efforts in East Orange, N.J., misstated the street number on Evergreen Place for the sales office of a new development called Evergreen Crossings. It is at No. 33 Evergreen Place, not No. 22.

headline: Swimsuit Model and Tar Heels Fan
text: Brooklyn Decker has appeared in the Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue the past five years and graced the cover in 2010, a streak of success unequaled by her beloved North Carolina Tar Heels.

headline: Shaquille O’Neal: The N.B.A.’s Salary King
text: In his 18-year career, Shaquille O’Neal has put up plenty of big numbers. He has scored 28,255 points, grabbed 12,921 rebounds, won 4 N.B.A. championships and made 5,862 free throws (though it took him 11,121 attempts.) But the biggest number of all for O’Neal is $290,846,146, his career earnings according to Basketball-Reference.com.

headline: For a Storied Coach the Ultimate Accolade
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Tom Konchalski, the editor and publisher of High School Basketball Illustrated, called St. Anthony High Coach Bob Hurley in his apartment Thursday to wish him a Happy Easter. Before speaking with Hurley, whom he has known for more than four decades, Konchalski reached his wife, Chris, who informed him that Bob would be inducted into the Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame on Aug. 13.

headline: For Butler, No Such Thing as Irreplaceable
text: INDIANAPOLIS — He does not have the mustache of his teammate Matt Howard or the baby face of Gordon Hayward, but Butler guard Shelvin Mack managed to make himself unmistakable in Butler’s run to the national championship game Saturday night.

headline: N.C.A.A. Photo Replay: April 3
text: Butler and Duke won at the Final Fourand will play for college basketball’s national championship. Butler beat Michigan State, 52-50. Duke topped West Virginia, 78-57.

headline: Late Rally Lifts Rangers Closer to Playoff Spot
text: SUNRISE, Fla. — Less than two weeks ago, the Rangers were 7 points out of a playoff spot. Now they are a hairbreadth away.

headline: Vows: Vivienne & Kaddu
text: Vivienne La Borde and Kaddu Luyombya met at a party, at which he judged her to be too thin and she found him to be arrogant. All would change three years later.

headline: A Many-Faceted Star
text: Ellen DeGeneres has established herself as one of America’s most popular entertainers.

headline: In Chicago, a Tournament That Turns Out Grandmasters
text: In 1993, Laszlo Nagy began organizing monthly tournaments in Budapest that give players a chance to earn the norms needed to gain the grandmaster and international master titles. Called the First Saturday tournaments, the events have attracted many of the world’s best players.

headline: Duke Returns to Final, but With a Different Style
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski acknowledged that the criticism had bugged him. He resented a reporter’s question last month about his team’s melting down in recent N.C.A.A. tournaments. Duke had lost to lower seeds in six consecutive seasons.

headline: Showing Softer Side, Huggins Comforts Butler
text: INDIANAPOLIS — With West Virginia Coach Bob Huggins kneeling inches from his face to comfort him, De’Sean Butler feared that he had torn the anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 3, 2010

headline: N.B.A. Gives Fans a Voice, Albeit a Small One
text: This season the N.B.A. is giving fans a chance to actually vote for the league’s M.V.P. award. Before people bring up the fact that the fans almost voted Tracy McGrady into a starting spot on the All-Star team despite the fact that he had played a mere 45 minutes all season leading up to the game, it’s worth noting that the fan vote will not actually count for much.

headline: Paris Show Puts Spotlight on New York
text: American artists have had a long-standing attraction to Paris: John Singer Sargent, Ellsworth Kelly and Edward Hopper are among the prominent names who have turned to the city for inspiration. Now a show in the French capital is returning the favor, focusing specifically on New York.

headline: Best Right Guards in the N.F.L.: The Top 10 List
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely – but not strictly – by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, though the future isn’t ignored. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble disagreeing about what you’re about to read.

headline: David Waldstein’s 2010 Predictions
text: David Waldstein is in his first season covering the Mets for The Times. Here are his picks for the playoffs and major award winners. Tyler Kepner’s A.L. picks can be found here, his N.L. picks here.

headline: A Sheaf of Rejections, But Still ‘Fabulous’
text: I’ve been rejected and I’m still fabulous.

headline: Ben Shpigel’s 2010 Predictions
text: Ben Shpigel, who covered the Mets for the Times from 2005 to 2009, is in his first year as the Yankees beat writer. Here are his predictions for the playoffs and major award winners. Tyler Kepner’s A.L. picks can be found here, his N.L. picks here.

headline: Bombs Hit Hub of Diplomacy in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — The Iraqi capital echoed with explosions on Sunday as insurgents sought to exploit political uncertainties created by painstakingly slow talks on forming a new government, with three suicide car bombings at diplomatic targets killing dozens of people and other scattered attacks disrupting areas across Baghdad.

headline: Finally, Vettel Wins a Race
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — After scoring pole position at the first two races and dropping from the lead with a technical problem each time, Sebastian Vettel of Germany leaped from third on the grid at the Malaysian Grand Prix here on Sunday to take the lead from his Red Bull teammate by the first corner. He never dropped it.

headline: Protesters Turn Up Heat in Thailand
text: BANGKOK  —  Dancing jubilantly in the streets to the beats of blaring pop and country music, anti-government demonstrators on Sunday defied calls by the government to disperse from Bangkok’s affluent commercial hub in a major escalation of three weeks of mass demonstrations.

headline: State Media Dispute Report That Kim Went to Beijing
text: SEOUL  — The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, was the host of a weekend party in his country’s capital, Pyongyang, for the new Chinese ambassador, both countries’ state media reported Sunday, disputing a South Korean news report that Mr. Kim visited China on Saturday.

headline: The Sunday Word: Resurgent Taliban
text: A resurgent Afghan Taliban is neutering the American effort to win over militants and would-be fighters in Marja, where money meant to win over residents is ending up in the hands of anti-Western forces, The Times’s Richard Oppel reported from Baghdad.

headline: Easter Support for Pope, and Some Apologies
text: VATICAN CITY — A prominent cardinal, in a marked departure from tradition, stood near Pope Benedict XVI at Easter Mass in St. Peter’s Square on Sunday and delivered pointedly public support in the face of growing anger over the Catholic Church’s sex abuse scandal — a topic untouched by the pope in his Easter appearances.

headline: ‘La Traviata,’ Take 2: Same Cast, Different Conductor
text: The cast of Verdi’s “Traviata” at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday night looked much relieved to have the conductor Marco Armiliato in the pit instead of Leonard Slatkin, who had conducted on Monday, the opening of the run.

headline: Zuma Seeks to Calm South Africa After Killing
text: JOHANNESBURG — South Africa’s president, Jacob Zuma, called for calm on Sunday, warning that “agents provocateurs” might try to incite racial hatred after the brutal killing of the white supremacist Eugene TerreBlanche.

headline: 'Lend Me a Tenor'
text: Anthony LaPaglia and Jan Maxwell in a scene from the Broadway revival of Ken Ludwig's play. (Video courtesy of the production)

headline: Greenspan Cites Economic ‘Momentum’
text: Alan Greenspan, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve and a self-described Republican libertarian, on Sunday reinforced increasingly confident assessments by the Obama administration that the nation’s latest job numbers reveal a resurgent economy.

headline: Fuel Leak Threatening Great Barrier Reef
text: HONG KONG — Salvage experts and a tugboat crew struggled on Monday to save a large Chinese freighter that slammed into the Great Barrier Reef off Australia over the weekend, trying to prevent the vessel from breaking apart as some of the 1,075 tons of engine fuel in its tanks began oozing from the hull, threatening the world’s largest collection of coral.

headline: Does Merck Agreement Pave a Road Toward Change?
text: Shareholders of Merck sued in 2004, contending that current and former company officers and directors had breached their fiduciary duties in the marketing of the painkiller Vioxx, causing investors to lose billions.

headline: BB&T Whistle-Blower Ordered Rehired
text: The BB&T Corporation must rehire a former company investigator who said she was fired after exposing a $100 million North Carolina development scam, a federal administrative law judge said in a ruling released Friday, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Bid to Keep A.I.G. Assets in California Is Dismissed
text: A judge in California dismissed a lawsuit on Thursday that would have barred the American International Group from moving any assets out of that state until an independent audit could verify the company’s financial condition, The New York Times’s Mary Williams Walsh reported Saturday.

headline: Some Claims Dismissed for Ex-Qwest Officials
text: A federal judge has thrown out some claims in a civil lawsuit filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission against former Qwest executives, including Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive, The Associated Press reported Saturday.

headline: Stanford Victims Fund Gains $14 Million
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission obtained more than $14.2 million for Stanford Financial Group investors in a Panamanian asset sale, the agency said Friday, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Easter in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — At first, I mistakenly thought that the sound was caused by the rattle of two iron rods. This is the Stone Age method still used — ironic, in a land considered one of the wealthiest in resources — to alert residents that the gas cylinder man’s cart is in their neighborhood.

headline: Alan Greenspan: Still Not A Mensch
text: Until now I’ve managed to avoid reading Alan Greenspan’s Brookings Paper (pdf). But I finally took the plunge — and discovered that he’s still not a mensch, a person of integrity willing to take responsibility for his own actions.

headline: WWS 543, April 5
text: Readings (doc)

headline: ‘Clash of the Titans’ Rules Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES  “Clash of the Titans” sold $61.4 million in tickets in North America over the weekend, enough for first place. But that strong showing was powered less by 3-D screenings than by traditional ones.

headline: Gods Are in Their Heaven, but All’s Not Right With World
text: What does a writer do when he has already won the Man Booker Prize and can make copacetic use of words like preterite, spalpeen, goitrous and phthistic? In the case of John Banville, whose accolades also include the Guinness Peat Aviation award, the answer has been to take a pseudonymous flight of escapism into genre fiction.

headline: Karzai’s Words Leave Few Choices for the West
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — As President Hamid Karzai made more antagonistic statements over the weekend toward the NATO countries fighting on behalf of his government, the West was taking stock of just how little maneuvering room it has.

headline: Verdi Chops Are Tested by ‘Traviata’
text: It is hard not to feel sorry for Leonard Slatkin in the aftermath of his withdrawal from the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of “La Traviata.” True, he has much to answer for. He had never performed this popular Verdi opera when he accepted the engagement to conduct it at the Met. By his own admission he was insufficiently prepared.

headline: It’s Not Over Till the Zonked Guy Flings
text: One, two, three, four, five. Yes, that’s five doors on the stage of the Music Box Theater, where a revival of Ken Ludwig’s “Lend Me a Tenor” opened Sunday night. Five doors, primed for slamming, in a single hotel suite. All but incontrovertible physical evidence that farce is on the bill.

headline: Grants Nurture Arts Spaces and Housing
text: As part of an effort to increase the impact of its giving, the Ford Foundation is to announce a plan on Monday to dedicate $100 million to the development of arts spaces nationwide over the next decade. The plan is by far the largest commitment the foundation has ever made to the construction, maintenance and enhancement of arts facilities.

headline: Take It to the Limit
text: In middle school my friends and I enjoyed chewing on the classic conundrums.   What happens when an irresistible force meets an immovable object?  Easy — they both explode.  Philosophy’s trivial when you’re 13.

headline: What’s True in Art Studios and Onstage
text: Painful experience has taught me to approach movies or plays about artists and their art with low expectations. For someone like me  an art critic for longer than she cares to recall who before that held various small-time jobs around the art world  these dramatic forays into the studio tend to fall gratingly wide of the mark.

headline: Ballet Stars, Up Close and Personal
text: There is something almost overwhelming about seeing dancers like Marcelo Gomes and Ashley Bouder in a space as small as the Alvin Ailey Citigroup Theater. Artists of this caliber, so accustomed to projecting in cavernous houses, offer vertiginous, sometimes surprising thrills when seen on a human scale.

headline: More Surgery for Levine Means Met Cancellations
text: In need of surgery for a lower-back problem, the conductor James Levine, right, will not be on the podium for the Metropolitan Opera’s coming productions of “Tosca” and “Lulu,” the company announced on Sunday.

headline: Juilliard Student Group Attuned to Baroque Pitch
text: The Juilliard School  which, together with Carnegie Hall and its Weill Music Institute, concocted an inscrutable name for the performing arm of their academy, the Ensemble ACJW  has come up with another puzzler: Juilliard415. The logo highlights the A in Juilliard and the 415, slipping a hint to specialists. But is an average listener (or for that matter, a typical Juilliard student) supposed to intuit that this is a group that tunes to an A of 415 cycles per second (as opposed to the modern 440 or so), a standard now thought to have been widespread in Baroque precincts, and that it must therefore be an early-music ensemble?

headline: New CDs
text: SHARON JONES & THE DAP-KINGS

headline: What, Me Solve?
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — We have another guest solver with us today, the art director of Mad magazine, Sam Viviano. We’ll get to his report after my brief notes (in Mad terms, I’ll be the letters section, with Mr. Viviano serving as the climactic fold-in).

headline: Prelude to Championships Advances Players’ Education
text: The main events at every North American Bridge Championships start on a Friday. But on the preceding evening there is a charity duplicate for the American Contract Bridge League’s Education Foundation. This is a nonprofit organization with “the goal to make bridge a game played by people of all ages and walks of life.”

headline: Featuring Iphigenia, Videos and In-Jokes
text: The news that the Ohio Theater, the SoHo home of adventurous drama for almost three decades, is closing in August is not a good sign, but let’s not get carried away. Off Off Broadway remains dynamic, and it’s no surprise that theater makers are moving away from expensive neighborhoods of Lower Manhattan. Would it be so terrible if the occasional rumor that Performance Space 122 might move to Brooklyn became true? I don’t think so.

headline: Tea Party Groups Make Harry Reid Target No. 1
text: LAS VEGAS — The television cameras went 60 miles south, to where Sarah Palin kicked off the “Showdown in Searchlight.”

headline: Handel’s Women Mean Business
text: Female operatic characters are so often victims  of murder, consumption, suicide and their own messy emotions. But in Handel’s “Partenope” the women come out on top. Its gender-bending plot and wondrous music are vividly realized in Francisco Negrin’s production, which returned to New York City Opera on Saturday evening.

headline: Boundaries Shift in Mixing and Matching of Artists and Images
text: The program handed out to those arriving for “Body Maps” at Galapagos Art Space in Dumbo, Brooklyn, on Friday night succinctly stated the event’s premise, “an evening of music and film featuring artists who have crossed oceans.” That what transpired hardly seemed so clear cut was to be expected given the event’s architects: the composer Paola Prestini, a founder of the interdisciplinary collective VisionIntoArt, and Beth Morrison, a producer who specializes in facilitating ambitious avant-garde collaborations.

headline: Singler vs. Hayward Is the Matchup to Watch
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Monday’s championship game between Duke and Butler is full of intriguing matchups, but the most intriguing will be Kyle Singler versus Gordon Hayward.

headline: A Cuban Company Taking on Its Traditions and Ballet’s
text: LONDON  The National Ballet of Cuba came to fame as the project of the ballerina Alicia Alonso, who founded it in 1948. During her exceptionally long stage career and despite the presence of other good dancers, she often eclipsed her own company. Now that she has retired from performing, her company and school have gone on producing dancers of note, including Carlos Acosta, one of the school’s most celebrated alumni. He and other dancers have become better advertisements for their alma mater than Ms. Alonso herself.

headline: Bartering Art for Taxes
text: With tax returns due this month in the United States, Americans might be interested to learn how one unidentified citizen of Britain got out of paying up there: he contributed a bronze statue by Edgar Degas to the nation instead, BBC News reported. “Dancer Looking at the Sole of Her Right Foot” was donated in place of ponying up more than $265,000 of inheritance tax the person owes, one of many items taken as payment under the “Acceptance in Lieu” program. The program, administered by the Museums, Libraries and Archives Council on behalf of the British government, allows those who owe inheritance tax to donate items deemed to be of historical or artistic importance. The Degas statue will be added to a collection of French 19th-century paintings, sculptures and drawings at the Courtauld Gallery. The British government accepted almost $30 million in artwork through the program last year.

headline: The Tour, It Is A-Changin’
text: Bob Dylan canceled a leg of his Asian tour after the Chinese government refused him permission to play scheduled performances in Shanghai and Beijing this month, Agence France-Presse reported. Brokers Brothers Herald, Mr. Dylan’s Taiwan-based promoter, said the Chinese culture ministry gave Mr. Dylan “no alternative” but to cancel subsequent shows in Hong Kong and Taiwan. “The chance to play in China was the main attraction for him,” Jeffrey Wu, Brokers’ chief of operations, told The South China Morning Post of Hong Kong. “When that fell through, everything else was called off.” The ministry did not respond to telephone calls from Agence France-Presse on Sunday, but Mr. Wu said that the Chinese government had become more selective about performances by foreigners after Bjork’s 2008 concert in Shanghai, where she shouted “Tibet, Tibet!” while performing her song “Declare Independence.” Later that year China imposed rules on such concerts, including one that said, “Those who used to take part in activities that harm our nation’s sovereignty are firmly not allowed to perform in China.”

headline: Footnotes
text: The avant-garde director, choreographer, artist and playwright Robert Wilson, known for his epic experimental works “The Civil Wars” and “Einstein on the Beach” will receive this year’s Jerome Robbins Award, Playbill reported. Robbins befriended Mr. Wilson in the 1960s, often attending open houses at Mr. Wilson’s loft to see his early works, like “The Life and Times of Sigmund Freud,” and “A Letter for Queen Victoria.” The $100,000 prize from the Jerome Robbins Foundation, as well as a bronze statue, will be awarded at a ceremony in December. ... Stephen Daldry, who directed the musical “Billy Elliot” to acclaim on Broadway, has been hired to direct the film adaptation of Jonathan Safran Foer’s novel “Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close,” according to The Hollywood Reporter. But Mr. Daldry is no stranger to book adaptations, having directed two other popular film versions, “The Hours” and “The Reader.” Paramount and Warner Brothers will co-produce the movie. Production dates have not been announced.

headline: Two Dance Groups Negotiate Merger
text: A merger of two New York dance organizations would combine the 28-year-old Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company and the 45-year-old presenter Dance Theater Workshop, Crain’s New York Business reported. The groups are in final negotiations on the merger, which would combine the staff and boards of both groups into one with a new name and a new mission. Dance Theater Workshop’s executive director, Andrea Sholler, told Crain’s that the specifics of the agreement were still being worked out, including who would run the new group. “We’re very excited about the model we’re working on,” she said. According to Crain’s, the merger will help Dance Theater Workshop, which as of last year had accumulated $4.2 million in debt. Mr. Jones, above, plans to move his company into Dance Theater Workshop’s space at 219 West 19th Street in Chelsea.

headline: A Match for ‘Emma’
text: A rare copy of Jane Austen’s “Emma,” signed by the author, has sold for almost $500,000, according to the BBC News. This three-volume first edition, below, published in 1816, was one of 12 presentation copies that the publisher, John Murray, allotted to Austen for friends and family. Austen originally gave this copy to Anne Sharp, her friend and the inspiration for the character of Mrs. Weston in the novel. In 2008 Jonkers Rare Books in Henley-on-Thames, England, bought the book for a little more than $273,000 at the Bonhams auction house in London. Last week Jonkers announced that it had sold the book to a British collector it did not identify. “The important thing is the signature of Jane Austen to her best friend,” Christiaan Jonkers, director of the booksellers, told The Henley Standard. “That’s what moves it from being a £20,000 book to a £300,000 book.”

headline: Fine for Public Nudity at Dealey Plaza, Dallas
text: Erykah Badu will receive a citation for disorderly conduct for stripping naked while filming a video in the Dallas plaza where John F. Kennedy was assassinated, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Turning Tides in Afghanistan
text: Compensation helped turn the tide of insurgency in Iraq. But in Marja, where the Taliban seem to know everything, they have already found ways to thwart the strategy.

headline: Andy Roddick’s New Plan Results in a Title
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Now that he is 27, which is middle age in men’s tennis, and plays with increased savvy and finesse, Andy Roddick is considered more sophisticated. He grudgingly accepts the compliment.

headline: Strong Mexico Quake Shakes Buildings and Nerves in California
text: LOS ANGELES — A powerful earthquake southeast of Tijuana shook Southern California on Sunday afternoon, damaging buildings in northern Mexico and border cities in California and Arizona and rattling a seismically sophisticated population as far north as Los Angeles and Las Vegas as chandeliers swayed, homes shook and the earth seemed to slide under the feet of people emerging from Easter church services for well over a minute.

headline: Mike Cuellar, Star Pitcher for Orioles, Dies at 72
text: Mike Cuellar, a Cy Young Award-winning left-hander whose brilliant screwball helped the Baltimore Orioles win three consecutive American League pennants, died Friday at a hospital in Orlando, Fla. He was 72.

headline: Dozens Rescued From Chinese Mine
text: BEIJING — Thirty-four miners were freed early Monday from a flooded coal mine in northern China where they had been trapped for more than week, and China’s state-run media said rescuers were close to saving 61 more later Monday. There was no word on the fate of 58 others trapped in the watery pit in Shanxi Province.

headline: Can CNN Be Saved?
text: Listening to Jon Stewart helped destroy CNN. Now imitating him might be the network’s only hope of salvation.

headline: New Health Initiatives Put Spotlight on Prevention
text: WASHINGTON — Amid all the rancor leading up to passage of the new health care law, Congress with little fanfare approved a set of wide-ranging public initiatives to prevent disease and encourage healthy behavior.

headline: U.S. Admits Role in February Killing of Afghan Women
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — After initially denying involvement or any cover-up in the deaths of three Afghan women during a badly bungled American Special Operations assault in February, the American-led military command in Kabul admitted late on Sunday that its forces had, in fact, killed the women during the nighttime raid.

headline: Obama Misses the Big Oil
text: Amherst, Mass.

headline: Red Sox Beat Yankees in Season Opener
text: Nearly five months after the Yankees’ Mark Teixeira closed his glove on the 2009 World Series, the 2010 Major League Baseball season opened Sunday night with a game that always has Series-level passion: Yankees-Red Sox.

headline: Drilling Plan May Buoy Efforts on Energy Policy
text: Ever since he ran Bill Clinton’s “It’s the Economy, Stupid” presidential campaign in 1992, James Carville has held a reputation for common-sense Democratic strategy.

headline: Colonial-Era Dispute Agitates South Koreans
text: TONGYEONG, South Korea — A nondescript post office here provides an appealing footnote to the history of Korean literature. From 1945 until his death in 1967, the poet Yu Chi-hwan strolled in almost daily, mailing thousands of letters to a widowed poet, his muse in one of the country’s most celebrated literary love affairs.

headline: Throw Out Skybox Tax Subsidies
text: UNTIL the 1970s, Major League Baseball was a populist sport. Bleacher seats cost as little as a dollar, meaning middle- or even working-class fans could afford to take their families to a game a few times each season.

headline: Mentally Disturbed Man Attacks Bishop in Germany
text: BERLIN — A mentally disturbed man ran amok in the Münster Cathedral during the Easter service on Sunday, attacking the bishop with a broom handle, the police said.

headline: Officer Hurt in Traffic Stop on B.Q.E.
text: A police officer suffered two broken legs just after stopping a driver he suspected was drunk, when he was struck by a second drunken driver on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway early Sunday, the authorities said.

headline: A Store Kept Afloat by the Generosity of Customers
text: POINT LOOKOUT, N.Y.

headline: Do-It-Yourself Dining at the Grand Hyatt
text: Wedged between the bell desk and an antiques store in the lobby of the Grand Hyatt New York hotel on East 42nd Street is an elegant new market offering designer pastries, salads of baby greens and hot meals to go. With sleek, dark wood floors, white stacked-tile walls and pillars bathed in sky-blue light, the space — designed by the architectural team behind the restaurants Craft, Gramercy Tavern and the Modern — feels more like a specialty food shop than an alcove in a chain hotel.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: President’s Features Reunited After 176 Years
text: Finding a politician’s mouth has rarely been a problem — unless it has been missing since 1834.

headline: In Hate-Crime Case, a Teenager Finds Himself Caught in 2 Worlds
text: PATCHOGUE, N.Y. — Hundreds stood in the rain next to the railroad tracks, around a shrine made of flowers, balloons and a mural of the man who had been killed there. Someone arranged purple and white votive candles into the shape of a heart.

headline: Branding Comes Early in Filmmaking Process
text: LOS ANGELES — Jordan Yospe had some notes on the script for “The 28th Amendment,” a thriller about a president and a rogue Special Forces agent on the run. Some of the White House scenes were not detailed enough, Mr. Yospe thought. And, he suggested, the heroes should stop for a snack while they were on the lam.

headline: For Haitian-American Doctors, a Call to Return
text: As she struggled with junior high algebra at SS. Joachim and Anne School in Queens, Marie-Dominique Toussaint knew where it was all supposed to lead: she would be a doctor, an ambition inspired by her father, a physician she rarely saw, and fueled by her mother, a nurse who immigrated from Haiti.

headline: Drones Batter Al Qaeda and Its Allies Within Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A stepped-up campaign of American drone strikes over the past three months has battered Al Qaeda and its Pakistani and Afghan brethren in the tribal area of North Waziristan, according to a mid-ranking militant and supporters of the government there.

headline: Red Bulls: Road Warriors
text: The Red Bulls had just arrived at Newark Airport on Sunday after an early-morning flight from Seattle.

headline: Spring Harvest of Debt for Parched Farms in Southern China
text: WANGZHI, China — Odds are that the drought that is parching southwest China’s Yunnan Province and its neighbors will break sometime in the next month, as the region’s usually dry winter gives way to an abundance of summer rains.

headline: States Skeptical About ‘Race to Top’ School Aid Contest
text: A dozen governors, led by Bill Ritter Jr. of Colorado, sat with Secretary of Education Arne Duncan in a hotel ballroom in Washington a few weeks back, praising his vision and gushing with enthusiasm over a $4 billion grant competition they hoped could land their states a jackpot of hundreds of millions of dollars.

headline: Without Title in Tow, McNabb Sent to Redskins
text: From the moment fans booed when Philadelphia made him the second pick in the 1999 draft, Donovan McNabb’s time with the Eagles was marked by the undercurrent that he might never be engulfed by brotherly love unless he led the Eagles to a championship. Over and over, the Eagles came close, only to fall short, fueling one off-season pledge after another that McNabb was still Andy Reid’s man.

headline: McNabb Traded to Redskins: Was It the Right Time?
text: The Eagles must think Donovan McNabb is finished.

headline: Weighty Dramas Flourish on Cable
text: Television viewers in search of challenging, original drama are flipping past the broadcast networks and going straight to the source: cable channels.

headline: Marlins’ Johnson a Power Pitcher Who’s Always Ahead of the Curve
text: The new family in Broken Arrow, Okla., came from Minneapolis with no friends in town. As always, though, they had one another, and with five boys — each spaced two years apart — that was enough to stay busy.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 4, 2010

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of the sixth and seventh days of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Developers Scramble to Strike iPad Gold
text: After getting their hands on an Apple iPad on Saturday morning, Igor Pusenjak and his brother Marko rushed back to Igor’s apartment in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, weaving around languid dogs and seafood deliverymen.

headline: Health Official Willing to Go to the Mat Over Obesity and Sugared Sodas
text: New York State’s health commissioner would be the first to admit he has soft drinks on the brain.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on March 18 about legislation pending in Brazil that could reallocate billions of dollars’ worth of oil-production revenue away from Rio de Janeiro misidentified the jurisdiction of a government labor official who criticized the legislation. The official, Carlos Lupi, is the labor minister of Brazil, not the secretary of labor for Rio.

headline: Connecticut Women Playing for Place in History
text: SAN ANTONIO

headline: Corrections
text: The Our Towns column on Thursday, about a move by New Jersey’s governor, Christopher J. Christie, to take on the state’s police and teachers’ unions in the face of a budget crisis, misspelled the surname of the director of a poll showing that Mr. Christie’s approval rating declined after his first budget address. He is Peter J. Woolley, not Wooley.

headline: Corrections
text: A music review on March 17 about a concert celebrating the 80th birthday of Stephen Sondheim, at Avery Fisher Hall, included a quotation from Mr. Sondheim in which he misstated the name of the daughter of Teddy Roosevelt to whom he attributed the quip, “First you’re young, then you’re middle-aged, then you’re wonderful.” She was Alice Roosevelt Longworth, not Alice Longworth Roosevelt.

headline: Stevens Proves to Be a Quick Study
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Butler Coach Brad Stevens is 33, and less than 10 years ago was one day from starting training at Applebee’s when he landed a job as Butler’s director of basketball operations.

headline: Corrections
text: A biographical note accompanying an Op-Ed article on Friday, about violence by girls, misstated the roles of the authors in a forthcoming book on gender and violence. Meda-Chesney Lind is a co-editor of the book; Mike Males is a contributor to it.

headline: Corrections
text: An Op-Ed article on March 28, about legislative control of redistricting in New York, misstated the year that the author, Seymour P. Lachman, had a conversation with the State Senate majority leader about redrawing districts. It took place in 2002, not 2004.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: First Time in Months Woods Makes His Game Semipublic
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The sticky cloud of pollen that had clung to the Augusta National Golf Club like a yellow haze since midmorning Sunday began to clear by 2:15 p.m., just as Tiger Woods ambled from the practice putting green to the 10th tee to join his friend Mark O’Meara for a nine-hole practice round.

headline: Ranchers Alarmed by Killing Near Border
text: DOUGLAS, Ariz. — Sooner or later, they all feared, one of them would be killed.

headline: Foreclosure Prevention 2.0
text: If all goes according to plan, the Obama administration’s new antiforeclosure effort will prevent many more foreclosures than its current one and do more to moderate the decline in home prices. That is a big if.

headline: High-Priced Hustings
text: Recently, as Congress was being lobbied to go easy on reforms aimed at Wall Street abuses, a fund-raising letter for Senator Bob Corker, a Republican point man on the issue, was offering affluent donors the pleasure of a meal with the senator for $10,000. The senator denounced the letter as a “grotesque and inappropriate” mistake when it was reported by Politico. But the V.I.P. access tab was not that unusual a symptom of political money’s abominable grip on the Capitol.

headline: Debunkers of Fictions Sift the Net
text: It is one of the paradoxes of the Internet.

headline: How Sarah Palin Became a Brand
text: When Sarah Palin made her debut as the host of “Real American Stories” on Fox News on Thursday night, she described several triumphs of regular people over insurmountable odds, but she missed an obvious one: her own.

headline: Once the Underdog, Duke Is Now the Villain
text: INDIANAPOLIS

headline: Near Fenway, a $500 View of the Bar TV
text: BOSTON — The game, of course, was sold out. The fanatics of Red Sox Nation have filled every seat at home games at Fenway Park since May 2003. But when it is opening day (or night, as was the case on Sunday), when all teams start out equal, and the air is unseasonably warm, and the opposing team is Boston’s fiercest rival, and that rival happened to have won the World Series last year, there is barely room to stand.

headline: Making It Look Easy at The New Yorker
text: David Remnick, the editor of The New Yorker, is not one to waste an opportunity. After attending John Updike’s funeral in Massachusetts in February of last year, he stopped by Harvard Law School to interview some of President Obama’s old professors. Despite the exhaustive newspaper coverage of the 44th president, Mr. Remnick suspected he had something to add.

headline: Very Public Affair for Private Colleges in Tournament
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Butler guard Ronald Nored was his freshman class’s president last year, and one of his duties was “getting classmates excited about being on campus.” Limited by time demands as a basketball player and an elementary education major, he delegated most of his assignments but helped organize dances and service events.

headline: Stanford in Final, Hoping to Make a Game of It
text: SAN ANTONIO — And next year, it will be a sister act. Shades of Venus and Serena.

headline: Peter Gowland, a Photographer Whose Women Graced 1,000 Walls, Dies at 93
text: Peter Gowland, who used camera, sunshine and imagination to portray ravishing women at a time when the pinup girl was a nearly ubiquitous fixture of American life, died on March 17 in Los Angeles. He was 93.

headline: Evaluating Teachers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Making Financial Reform Fool-Resistant
text: The White House is confident that a financial regulatory reform bill will soon pass the Senate. I’m not so sure, given the opposition of Republican leaders to any real reform. But in any case, how good is the legislation on the table, the bill put together by Senator Chris Dodd of Connecticut?

headline: An Exception for Menthol?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A ‘Free’ School Bus Ride
text: To the Editor:

headline: Praise for Student Loan Bill
text: To the Editor:

headline: Our Unhealthy Diet
text: To the Editor:

headline: Healthy, and Safe, School Lunches
text: It is probably too much to hope that the more than 30 million school lunches served every day will taste absolutely fabulous. But Congress should at least make certain that whatever lands on those cafeteria trays is nutritious and safe to eat. Every day it delays doing so is another mealtime when millions of students are cheated of programs that could help relieve hunger and reduce obesity.

headline: Desperately Seeking Watchdog
text: Government officials talk a lot about accountability. There’s even a Government Accountability Office. The trouble is, it hasn’t had a presidentially appointed, Senate-confirmed chief for more than two years.

headline: Obama’s Plan for Offshore Drilling
text: To the Editor:

headline: Parade of the Pantless, Followed by Complaints
text: PEOPLE love to complain about what they consider to be the dearth of original ideas on Madison Avenue. One reason they still watch television commercials, it seems, is to cry “Gotcha!” whenever they see a spot that reminds them of another commercial.

headline: Santana Welcomes Back an Old Friend: His Slider
text: A smile spread across the face of Dan Warthen, the Mets’ pitching coach, as he stood in the team’s spring training clubhouse on a recent morning and contemplated the possibilities.

headline: Chiefs, Inspired by ‘Slap Shot,’ Are Leaving Johnstown
text: JOHNSTOWN, Pa. — Like the die-hard fans of the fictional Charlestown Chiefs in the movie “Slap Shot,” which was filmed here in 1976, supporters of the minor league Johnstown Chiefs have reason to be angry with the team’s owners.

headline: Filipinos Criticize Eminent Imitator
text: MANILA — As the chairman of the country’s largest phone networks and a philanthropist with a compelling rags-to-riches story, he is one of the most respected businessmen in the Philippines.

headline: Wright Takes the Long View
text: David Wright hit only five home runs at Citi Field last season.

headline: Spending a Week in Solitary to Promote a Documentary
text: On television, the National Geographic Channel is using typical commercials to promote its coming “Explorer” documentary about solitary confinement. On the Web, it’s doing something very different: locking volunteers in solitary cells and video-streaming the ordeal for a week.

headline: Tseng Wins Second Major After Jolt From a Friend
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — The Kraft Nabisco Championship trophy was slipping out of Yani Tseng’s reach on Sunday at Mission Hills Country Club. Not during the final round, but afterward, when an earthquake added to the commotion surrounding her second major victory.

headline: ‘Suicide’ Query Prompts Google to Offer Hotline
text: As with any omniscient being, you can ask Google anything. You just don’t know what the answer is going to be.

headline: ‘Freakonomics’ Documentary May Be a Rarity: Profitable
text: If Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner, the authors of  “Freakonomics,”  were to examine the movie business, they might ask: Why do documentary filmmakers keep doing it?

headline: Woods as a Favorite? He Needs to Make the Cut First
text: Despite Tiger Woods’s four months in hiding from the PGA Tour, the phrase “Masters favorite” is still attached to his name. But just because he’s about to reappear on the PGA Tour on Thursday at Augusta National, he doesn’t deserve to be the favorite.

headline: Using an Electronic Device to Break in a New Violin
text: No one knows how the violins of Antonio Stradivari sounded when they first left his workbench in Cremona, Italy, hundreds of years ago. But those fabled instruments probably did not reach their full potential until they were played. And played. And then played some more.

headline: Channel Surfing While Surfing the Net
text: Last year, people vastly increased the amount of time they spent watching television and browsing the Internet simultaneously, according to Nielsen. Looking only at people who used the technologies together at least once a month, Nielsen found that the amount of time such people spent on simultaneous use had shot up 34.5 percent from December 2008 to December 2009. Such users represent about 59 percent of the total population.

headline: Dewey, Cheatem and Howe
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared business names based on puns.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS This week, reports include the ISM service index for March and pending home sales for February (Monday); F.O.M.C. minutes for March (Tuesday); Consumer credit for February (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims (Thursday).

text: INDIANAPOLIS — Matt Howard’s arrival at Butler three years ago was as ballyhooed as any in the university’s history.

headline: Red Sox Strike First, but Stay Tuned
text: BOSTON — Just think, there are 17 more of these games. The Yankees play the Red Sox 17 more times, which means 17 more chances to witness baseball played at its most exhilarating, frustrating or downright maddening.

headline: Mars on Demand
text: The High Resolution Imaging Science Experiment aboard NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter is nicknamed "the people's camera." Here are the first eight images of areas on Mars chosen by the public.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

text: lithe •\ˈlith, ˈlith\• adjective

headline: UConn Teeters in Semifinal, but It’s Baylor That Falls
text: SAN ANTONIO — The legend of Brittney Griner is just beginning. The Connecticut winning streak just keeps growing. After defeating — but not destroying — Baylor on Sunday night in the national semifinals, it is on to another championship game for Geno Auriemma’s team.

headline: Girardi Still Setting Up Yankees’ Relief Roles
text: BOSTON — In the last game of last season, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi turned to Joba Chamberlain and Damaso Marte as his bridge to Mariano Rivera. That tandem was good enough to clinch a World Series title, and it may be good enough this season as the Yankees try to defend it.

headline: Canada  Oil Sands  Are Still a Gamble
text: The stampede to the initial public offering of Athabasca Oil Sands is a tribute to the allure of Canada’s extra-heavy oil.

headline: In Mexico, Resuming Life After Quake
text: MEXICALI, Mexico — The day after one of the strongest earthquakes to strike the region in nearly two decades, residents on both sides of the border marveled that damage was relatively light even as waves of mild aftershocks troubled nerves.

headline: For Schoeneweis, Baseball Is the Easy Part
text: BOSTON – Eleven pitchers took the mound at Fenway Park in Sunday’s season opener. Only one of them was perfect: the Red Sox left-hander Scott Schoeneweis, who struck out the Yankees’ Curtis Granderson in the fifth inning, and then retired Nick Swisher and Brett Gardner in the sixth.

headline: Hard Times for Chess
text: Early last week, Silvio Danailov, the manager of Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria, said in an interview that the M-Tel Masters would not be played this year because the main sponsor, after which the tournament is named, had pulled out. (The interview, which was with Trud, a Bulgarian newspaper, was reported by the Web site Chessdom, which has a translation.) Instead, the company decided that it would get more for its money by sponsoring Topalov in his upcoming world championship match against Viswanathan Anand of India, the titleholder.

headline: News Quiz | April 5, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: SandRidge to Buy Rival Arena Resources
text: SandRidge Energy, an oil and gas exploration company, on Sunday said it agreed to buy a rival, Arena Resources, for about $1.55 billion. The move will help SandRidge increase its investments in oil, Reuters reported.

headline: Where 'Slap Shot' Was Shot
text: The Johnstown Chiefs, one of the original five teams in the East Coast Hockey League, played their final game in Pennsylvania on Saturday night and will be moving to South Carolina next season.

headline: Fornés Fest
text: As part of the 2010 New York Fornés Festival, presenting an array of work by the playwright, director and theatrical pioneer Mariá Irene Fornés in honor of her 80th birthday, there will be a rare revival of her play "And What of the Night?" at the Cherry Lane Theater tonight. Ms. Fornés, the theater historian Marc Robinson wrote recently on the ArtsBeat blog, "is among the most important contemporary playwrights, with more than 40 plays that helped establish an American version of absurdism (in her plays of the 1960s) and that codified a spare, lyrical form of realism (in her work of the 1980s). Through her influential teaching, she has also been the godmother to an enormous number of other Hispanic playwrights."

headline: Get Romantic
text: The important American baritone Thomas Hampson, artist-in-residence with the Philharmonic this season, presents "A Guide to German Romanticism," part of the orchestra's Insights series tonight at 6:30 at the Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center. "Mr. Hampson will discuss iconography, metaphor and imagery in German lieder," writes Anthony Tommasini. "He knows what he is talking about, having sung the repertory throughout his career, lived for an extended period in Vienna and done important scholarly work on the songs of Mahler. His comments will be illustrated with music, for which he will be joined by the pianist Craig Rutenberg."

headline: Plumb Funny
text: "Shannon Plumb," Ken Johnson writes, is a "terrific comic performer. She makes mock television commercials in a flickering, silent-movie style and adds rousing soundtracks of jazz, rock, folk and country music. Portraying a student with attention deficit disorder, an absurdly bewigged model for a shampoo ad, a patient suffering side effects from a stop-smoking pill and other characters, Ms. Plumb is hilarious. Comparing her to Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton might sound like a stretch, but it's not." Tonight IFC Center is presenting "An Evening with Shannon Plumb." The artist and filmmaker will be there to present a sampling of her films and participate in a discussion.

headline: Burry: I Foresaw the Crisis. Why Didn’t the Fed?
text: Alan Greenspan, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, proclaimed last month that no one could have predicted the housing bubble. “Everybody missed it,” he said, “academia, the Federal Reserve, all regulators.”

headline: Krugman: Fool-Resistant Finance Reform
text: The White House is confident that a financial regulatory reform bill will soon pass the Senate. I’m not so sure, given the opposition of Republican leaders to any real reform, Paul Krugman writes in an Op-Ed column in The New York Times. But in any case, how good is the legislation on the table, the bill put together by Senator Chris Dodd of Connecticut?

headline: Does Wall Street Need an Estrogen Injection?
text: From William D. Cohan at Opinionator:

headline: Fischer May Still Not Be Able to Rest in Peace
text: Bobby Fischer, the former world champion, died in January 2008, but the fight over his estate is still not resolved. In the latest macabre twist, a court in Iceland will soon rule whether his body must be exhumed so that a D.N.A. test can be performed to determine if Jinky Young, an 8-year-old Filipino girl, is really his daughter.

headline: Brown Said to See Bank Levy Accord Closer
text: Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain said the world’s large economies were close to agreeing a global tax on banks to help prevent another financial crisis, The Financial Times reported on Monday.

headline: Wilbur Ross Backing Virgin Money in RBS Bid
text: Wilbur Ross, the billionaire investor, said on Sunday he is prepared to commit up to £500 million ($760 million) to support Virgin Money in its bid to buy the branch network of the Royal Bank of Scotland, Reuters reported.

text: A Goldman Sachs Group buyout firm bought a minority stake in David Ganek’s $4 billion Level Global Investors, adding a hedge fund that can bet on rising as well as falling stock prices globally, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Crowds Cited in Times Sq. Shootings
text: Four people were shot in three episodes in Midtown Manhattan, and the police said they arrested 33 people as rowdy crowds roamed the area in the waning hours of Sunday and early Monday in what has become something of a violent Easter Night ritual.

headline: Afghan Investigators Say U.S. Troops Tried to Cover Up Evidence in Botched Raid
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan officials investigating the deaths of five Afghan civilians gunned down in February during a bungled raid by American Special Operations forces believe that troops tampered with evidence at the scene, the lead investigator said Monday. NATO officials disclosed that they were looking into the allegations.

text: Kingdom Holding, Prince Alwaleed bin Talal’s investment vehicle, is selling a stake in Raffles Holdings International to a group of investors, including an affiliate of Qatar’s sovereign wealth fund, in a deal worth $847 million, according to press reports.

text: Qlik Technologies, a maker of business analytics software, is hoping investors will provide as much as $100 million when it goes public, peHUB reported.

headline: Bombers Kill Policemen in Russia
text: MOSCOW — A suicide bomber killed at least two police officers in the restive North Caucasus region of Russia on Monday, officials said, the latest in a spate of such attacks, including a double bombing on the Moscow subway, that have killed more than 50 people in the last week.

headline: With Hope Dwindling, 115 Chinese Miners Are Saved
text: BEIJING — From the start, China’s latest coal mine disaster seemed likely to end as so many others had in a country where an average of seven miners die every day: a failed rescue effort, grieving relatives, few if any survivors.

Why do you think this fashion trend — at least a decade old — has hung on so long?

headline: Jogging in Paris When Spring Has Sprung
text: As blue skies finally replace wintery gray and the first spring bloom is in the air, runners start hitting the Paris streets in numbers. Whether you’re training for the city marathon, scheduled for April 11, or are just working off those croissants, Paris’s many parks, gardens and waterways make it a great place to get your heart rate up. Here are some spots to get you started. (Share your suggestions below.)

headline: Chipotle Bites the Hand It Used to Feed

Chipotle Mexican Grill is climbing aboard the ads-about-ads band wagon, beginning on Monday, with a campaign that mocks the advice given to the restaurant chain by Madison Avenue.

headline: Crestview and MidOcean Lead Deal for Insight Stake
text: A consortium of investors led by Crestview Partners and MidOcean Partners snapped up a large stake in Insight Communications, in a deal that will give the group a 42 percent holding in the regional cable outfit when the deal closes.

text: Today’s idea: Big-media business models collapse the way highly sophisticated civilizations do — of their own irreversible complexity, a professor of new media writes.

headline: Sampler: Pacific Gas and Electric Rates Might Hurt Solar, and Cats Prowl Amid Evidence
text: New Rates Could Slow Adoption of Solar | The proposed rate structure announced last week by Pacific Gas and Electric would replace the current five tiers with three. Most customers’ bills would rise, but those using the most electricity would see significant reductions, to about 30 cents per kilowatt hour from the current level of nearly 50 cents. The existing rates have been a boon to California’s residential solar industry, but these incentives would be reduced under the new plan. P.G.&E. has asked state regulators to rule on the proposal by year’s end. If approved, the rates would go into effect in May 2011. David Hochschild, a vice president for external relations at Solaria, a solar manufacturer in Fremont, said, “You can’t have one foot on the gas and one foot on the brake at the same time.” [The San Jose Mercury News]

headline: You’re on the Waiting List. Now What?
text: When some of the nation’s most selective colleges announced their decisions last week, thousands of applicants found themselves neither accepted nor rejected. Like passengers bumped from an overbooked flight — as one commenter on The Choice put it this weekend — they were instructed to sit tight in a crowded, virtual lounge, and wait to see if an opening presented itself over the next few weeks.

headline: Wanda Sykes Nabs Erykah Badu’s ‘Window Seat’
text: Last week was not an easy one for the R&B singer Erykah Badu, as tempers flared over the video for her song “Window Seat,” in which she disrobes at Dealey Plaza, the site in Dallas where John F. Kennedy was assassinated. She was later cited for disorderly conduct after the Dallas police said a witness had complained.

headline: Save the Receipt
text: Is there anyone alive not conflicted about getting and spending? Even at the height of the bubble, when Americans wallowed in an orgy of things, there were always people like Kate Bingaman-Burt, for whom the daily acquisition of stuff resulted in a pang or two. ‘‘Obsessive Consumption’’ (Princeton Architectural Press) is her sweet act of contrition. A graphic design professor from Portland, Ore., Bingaman-Burt drew three years of everyday commerce, from pizza to toothpaste, ballet slippers, zippers, tweezers, DVDs, moving boxes, airline tickets, fly swatters, diet soda, etc. She annotates where necessary — ‘‘Serta Mattress, Queen $500 No More Futon for Us!’’ — and we’re also treated to credit card bills, recreated in her own innocent hand, which somehow (maybe not for her) takes the sting out of owing MasterCard $5,522.62. Read from beginning to end, ‘‘Obsessive Consumption’’ reveals a happy (if somewhat guilty) grasshopper who likes a good bargain as much as she likes a good burrito. Bingaman-Burt engages in the same name-brand culture as the rest of us, but in her life, at least, it’s art.

headline: Ask a Hip-Hop Veteran
text: This week, Jorge Pabon, a performer and choreographer known as Pop Master Fabel, responded to questions about the history and culture of hip-hop.

headline: Blagojevich Hears a Familiar Phrase: ‘You’re Fired’

text: RSVP Cruises, a gay-friendly cruise company, is celebrating its 25th anniversary with a new sailing expedition to Hawaii.

text: Last week I prepared pickled broccoli stems for a big party. The leftover broccoli crowns took up an entire shelf in my refrigerator — and the desire to do something with them pretty much determined this week’s subject.

headline: Some First Impressions From Fenway
text: BOSTON – The first game I covered for The Times was on Aug. 2, 2005. That night at Shea Stadium, Victor Zambrano allowed four homers to the Brewers in a five-batter span. The Mets went on to overcome a four-run deficit, give up the go-ahead run in the ninth inning, tie the score in the bottom half and then win in the 11th on Mike Piazza’s bases-loaded walk. The game lasted 4 hours 28 minutes, and it was a thrilling night.

headline: Finding a Way In to Augusta National
text: Because the Augusta National Golf Club limits media credentials for covering the Masters,  news agencies are unable to increase staffing inside the gates to report on developments related to Tiger Woods’s return.
