headline: Now and Then
text: If you could never quite picture Philippe Starck’s machine-gun lamp in your own home, try picturing it in the architect Piero Portaluppi’s 1935 rationalist masterpiece, the Villa Necchi Campiglio; it has just taken up a seven-week residence in the house’s entry, alongside Konstantin Grcic’s Kanu chair, with Portaluppi’s elaborate ceiling tableaus overhead. The villa, which reopened to the public in 2008, is one of four house museums that will host more than 200 pieces of 21st-century design for ‘‘Unexpected Guests,’’ one of the headline exhibitions of Milan’s design week. Among other interventions are a Nacho Carbonell chair and Steven Holl credenza in the Museo Bagatti Valsecchi; ceramics by the upstart Tomás Alonso in the Casa Museo Boschi Di Stefano’s Lucio Fontana gallery; and at the Museo Poldi Pezzoli, Gaetano Pesce’s La Michetta modular sofa for Meritalia (above) and Front’s horse-shaped lamp for Moooi, which displaced an armored steed. The Italians may have invented design, but they still have a sense of humor about it. Go to casemuseomilano.it.

Wittman, a retired F.B.I. special agent, in a coming book titled “Priceless: How I Went Undercover to Rescue the World’s Stolen Treasures,’’ which details his efforts in 2006 and 2007 to retrieve the heisted paintings, The Boston Globe reported.

headline: Kraft Said to Trip on Cadbury Pension Plan
text: Kraft Foods has asked about 3,600 people at Cadbury, the British confectioner it recently acquired, to choose between their present pension plan or possible pay increases, The Financial Times reports.

headline: At Peter Luger’s, Breaking Bread and Talking Money
text: In July, Richard Ravitch was working his way through a steak dinner at Peter Luger’s when an aide to Gov. David A. Paterson unexpectedly arrived to swear in Mr. Ravitch as lieutenant governor. It was not long after the governor had announced his selection of Mr. Ravitch.

headline: Marlins’ Ace Had an Early View of a Champion
text: BOSTON – The day I interviewed Josh Johnson’s brother, Ryan, for this feature article on the ace of the Florida Marlins, I also attended the news conference announcing Joe Mauer’s $184 million contract extension with the Minnesota Twins.

headline: I.B.M. Needs to Do Deals, Some Investors Say
text: With I.B.M. lagging rivals like Hewlett-Packard and Oracle in growth, some investors and analysts told Bloomberg News that Big Blue needs to start up its deal machine.

headline: London Dance Journal: Pure British Dance, From Other Countries
text: LONDON — The comedian Anna Russell used to adopt sniffily congealed tones as she said, “The British style is known for its utter purity.” Today’s Royal Ballet is led by dancers from Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Cuba, Denmark, France, Italy, Japan, Romania, Ukraine, the United States and other countries, but you can see how they have all adopted the characteristics that the British find so pure.

headline: Better Birth Weight for Babies of Exercisers
text: Regular exercise during pregnancy doesn’t change a mother’s body weight but does lead to a small reduction in the baby’s weight, a new study shows.

headline: Christina Kim’s Candid Look at Life on Tour
text: The cover of Christina Kim’s account of her 2009 season, “Swinging From My Heels: Confessions of an L.P.G.A. Star,” which comes out next week, seems all wrong. Instead of the full-length color shot of Kim reacting to a putt, it should have been a plain brown wrapper, so bawdy are some of her anecdotes about life on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

headline: Damon’s True Value: Consistency

When that player, Johnny Damon, makes his debut for the Detroit Tigers on Monday afternoon, it will be with lowered expectations from his previous contract, in which he had starred for the Yankees for four seasons, winning a World Series championship.

headline: Bloggers Discuss Race and the Census
text: Updated | 5:25 p.m. Last week, CNN hosted an interesting, if brief, discussion of race and the census with three bloggers who deal with race in their work: Raquel Cepeda, a filmmaker and native New Yorker “by way of the Dominican Republic” who blogs at djali rancher; Baratunde Thurston, a comedian who brings “a Black bourgeoisie perspective” to the discussion of American politics on the blog Jack & Jill Politics; and Christian Lander, a Canadian living in the United States who started the comic blog Stuff White People Like.

headline: How to Make Checking a Bag a Little Better
text: I rarely ever wait in line to check a bag. What’s my secret? If I have to check a bag, I always check it curbside with a skycap before entering the airport.

headline: Breaking Up After a Miscarriage
text: Loss brings some couples closer, their bonds strengthened by grief. More often, though, loss seems to act as a wedge and a divider, and a study released today by researchers at the University of Michigan and published in the journal Pediatrics finds that couples are more likely to break up after the loss of a pregnancy than couples whose pregnancies go to term.

headline: Mike Zwerin, Jazz Critic and Author, Is Dead at 79
text: Mike Zwerin, a jazz trombonist and bass trumpeter who became a prominent jazz critic and author, died on April 2 in Paris, where he lived, after a long illness. He was 79.

headline: People and Accounts of Note in Advertising

Ms. Altman had been vice president and group publisher of Reader’s Digest magazine, New York, part of the Reader’s Digest Association. Parade is part of the Parade Publications unit of Advance Publications.

headline: Clinton Family Attends ‘Next to Normal’ Matinee
text: Former President Bill Clinton and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton have attended Broadway shows from time to time during their last decade living in New York, but given Mrs. Clinton’s duties and travel schedule, they haven’t had much free time to visit the Rialto over the last year. On Saturday afternoon, however, the couple, along with their daughter, Chelsea, her fiancé, Marc Mezvinsky, and a few Secret Service agents took in the matinee of the musical “Next to Normal” at the Booth Theater, according to an attendee and confirmed by the show’s management.

headline: Couples Provides Cover for Woods
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Fred Couples was no incidental bystander to Tiger Woods’s much anticipated practice round Monday. First of all, he hit a succession of outstanding shots. Straight drives, pin-seeking approach shots and calm, steady putting — Freddie put on a clinic. It was Couples, who has won three Champions Tour events this season, who looked like the world’s top-ranked golfer, not what’s-his-name walking alongside him.

headline: New Glue for You? True.
text: The rotten economy has revived an old saying from thriftier days: “Use it up, wear it out, make it do or do without.” So this may be a good time to reintroduce a familiar product that is being reformulated to help consumers repair a wide variety of household items.

headline: Corridor Of Evil
text: So Sarah Palin is insulting my home region:

headline: David Meets Goliath, With Tiger Standing By
text: Sports fans could make a convincing argument that the first Monday in April should be a national holiday. Honestly, how can anyone be expected to work as we get our good-versus-evil vibes going for the N.C.A.A. championship tonight, while absorbing all those lovely afternoon opening day baseball games while rolling our eyes at the television while Tiger Woods performs in his first actual news conference since becoming Tabloid Tiger? Really, we should get Tuesday off, too. That’s only fair considering CBS’s insistence on starting the championship game so late it stretches almost into Tuesday.

headline: Olbermann Pays a Visit to Citi Field
text: Hard to imagine better weather for a baseball opening day in this part of the country. About an hour before first pitch at Citi Field Monday between the Mets and the Florida Marlins, the temperature was 68 with low humidity and a gentle breeze blowing out to the right-field corner. (Might it help fly balls travel farther than they did in home-run deprived 2009?) The skies were partly cloudy but milky sunshine prevailed as the fans filed in.

headline: From Taft to Obama, Ceremonial First Pitches
text: BOSTON – When President Obama throws out the ceremonial first pitch at Nationals Park on Monday, he will continue a tradition that dates to 1910, when President Taft tossed the first pitch in Washington on April 14, 1910.

headline: TimesCast | April 5, 2010
text: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and the stories being covered Monday.  Today's edition includes the attack on a U.S. Consulate in Pakistan and what factors are driving the Dow over 11,000.

headline: Repos Clarified
text: My Friday column on abuses of repo accounting sparked more mail than usual, and makes me think I should have gone into more mind-numbing detail.

headline: McQueen: The Backstory and Beyond
text: Despite the number of very thoughtful tributes to Alexander McQueen that ran after his death on Feb. 11, the reality is very few people really understood him. A private man who also had difficulty switching off the creativity and finding balance in his life, he may have preferred it that way. His friends were the same, small close-bound group that went back 20 years, and of course, as we know, two of women who were integral to his life, his mother, Joyce, and his friend and mentor, Isabella Blow, had died.

headline: Stick a Fork in the Name Game
text: Southfork. That was the first name I had in mind way back when I was searching for space. I was surprised that no restaurant had gobbled up that easy play on words since the Hamptons are located on the South Fork of Long Island and the name lends itself naturally to various logos. Southfork. Sweet and simple.

headline: Supertaskers
text: People who are able competently to perform more than one task at a time.

headline: Weekend Action, Above Ground and Under
text: Despite the holiday (and the sudden proliferation of pillows), there wasn’t a lot of resting going on over the weekend. Maybe it was all the iPad lust and backlash, or the nice weather. Or the fact that Easter reportedly — and strangely — has become a kind of gang initiation day, at least around Times Square.

headline: Me And The Bubble

headline: Finding Activities for Parents With Memory Loss
text: I’ve invited the clinical psychologist Cynthia Green, an assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York and the author of several books on memory (including “Through the Seasons: An Activities Book for Memory Challenged Adults and Caregivers“), to join the conversation today. I’ve been hearing laments about the difficulties of visiting relatives with dementia; people yearn to make that time together enjoyable and meaningful, but they can’t always figure out how to connect. Dr. Green has some thoughtful suggestions.

headline: What a World: ‘Wicked’ Producers Address Piracy

text: The first robin of spring depends on location and weather. But the first boo birds of spring could be heard at Citi Field during the introductions Monday. headline: With Draft Looming, Butler Prepares for Surgery

headline: Case Will Test N.F.L. Teams’ Liability in Dementia

But this packet was different: it will almost certainly become a test case in considering National Football League teams’ liability for the dementia experienced by retired players.

headline: Artists and Vendors Bristle at Proposed Limits in Parks

headline: Childhood: In Most Holiday Injuries, Everyday Causes
text: Children’s injuries spike on holidays like Halloween and the Fourth of July, but pumpkin carving and fireworks are among the least likely culprits, a new study finds. Most of the injuries are caused by everyday activities, like riding bikes or just playing.

headline: Conservatives, Maddow and MSNBC
text: Glenn Greenwald and others have objected to a passage in today’s column in which I suggest that conservatives only show up on Rachel Maddow’s show when they have something nasty to say about the Republican Party. Greenwald has a point: I intended a touch of hyperbole about MSNBC’s biases, but, taken literally, the line reads as an anti-Maddow exaggeration, which I did not intend. She does, in fact, have conservatives on her show as conservatives, and it’s possible (as Greenwald suggests) that any seeming imbalance in her guest list is mainly the result of Republicans turning her invitations down.

headline: Artifacts | Kruger World

She uses them to hold a mirror to our entire culture — a hotbed of passive aggression if ever one was. At least, that’s the way it looks in “The Globe Shrinks,” an immersive new multichannel video installation that is challenging the presumptions of all who dare to enter the Mary Boone Gallery in Chelsea.

headline: Seeking Identity, Shaping a Nation’s
text: “The Bridge,” the title of David Remnick’s incisive new book on Barack Obama, refers to the bridge in Selma, Ala., where civil rights demonstrators were violently attacked by state troopers on March 7, 1965, in a bloody clash that would galvanize the nation and help lead to the passage of the Voting Rights Act. It refers to the observation made by one of the leaders of that march, John Lewis, that “Barack Obama is what comes at the end of that bridge in Selma”  an observation Congressman Lewis made nearly 44 years later, on the eve of Mr. Obama’s inauguration. And it refers to the hope voiced by many of the president’s supporters that he would be a bridge between the races, between red states and blue states, between conservatives and liberals, between the generations who remember the bitter days of segregation and those who have grown up in a new, increasingly multicultural America.

headline: He Shoots! He Scores! He Sells!

headline: ‘Looped’ to Close
text: The new Broadway play “Looped,” starring Valerie Harper as Tallulah Bankhead, will close on Sunday at the Lyceum Theater, the producers announced on Monday, after failing to draw much audience interest over its six weeks of performances. For its eight performances last week, for instance, “Looped” grossed $168,351, only 26 percent of the maximum possible amount. At such a low percentage, “Looped” was probably not covering its weekly running expenses, let alone turning a profit. (The weekly expenses have not been made public.) Moreover, the show was not on an upward trajectory; last week’s gross represented a decline from the previous week’s amount, $176,622. Written by Matthew Lombardo (“Tea at Five”) and directed by Rob Ruggiero, “Looped” will have played 27 preview performances and 25 regular performances when it closes. A spokesman for the show did not immediately reply to questions about the total cost for mounting the production and whether it will close at a complete loss for investors. The play is a portrait of Ms. Bankhead at the end of her film career, as she arrives, apparently drunk, at an editing studio to rerecord a line of dialogue for a movie  setting the stage for a colorful showdown between the actress and an uptight film editor. Ms. Harper drew generally positive reviews for her bravura turn as Bankhead, though the reviews for the overall production were mixed to negative.

headline: Blagojevich Loses Another Job
text: Rod R. Blagojevich has been fired once again, but this time it was Donald Trump who terminated the former governor of Illinois. The latest dismissal for Mr. Blagojevich, who was impeached and removed from office in January 2009 and is expected to stand trial this year on corruption charges, came on Sunday’s episode of “The Celebrity Apprentice,” which drew an average of 7.1 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The NBC reality show finished second in its time period behind CBS’s combination of “Undercover Boss” (12.9 million) and “Cold Case” (10.1 million). CBS placed first on Sunday over all, with a lineup that included “60 Minutes” (8.3 million) and “The Amazing Race” (9.1 million). ABC ranked second for the night with “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” (7.7 million) and a rerun of “Brothers & Sisters” (3.7 million). NBC finished in third place with “Dateline” (4.1 million) and “Minute to Win It” (5.4 million), while Fox, in fourth place, broadcast mostly repeats of its comedy lineup.

headline: Laugh It Up, Fuzzball: A ‘Star Wars’ Comedy
text: If you know the scene in “Star Wars” in which a storm trooper accidentally bonks his head on a Death Star doorway, you have probably laughed at George Lucas’s movies for reasons he never intended. Now you have the permission of Mr. Lucas, above, to find the “Star Wars” universe funny. On Monday Lucasfilm Animation said it was preparing a new series that would offer a comedic perspective on “Star Wars,” with creative help from Seth Green and Matthew Senreich, who have often satirized that science-fiction franchise on their Adult Swim animated show “Robot Chicken.” The new series, for which a title and a broadcaster have not been announced, will be produced by Jennifer Hill (“The Backyardigans”) and directed by Todd Grimes (“Back at the Barnyard”). Brendan Hay, who has written for “The Simpsons” and produced for “The Daily Show,” will also be a writer for this series, Lucasfilm said.

headline: ‘Wicked’ Pirates
text: What would Glinda do? The executive producer for the London production of “Wicked” said that a recent warning to fans that they faced a lifelong ban from the show if they were caught recording it was prompted by a theatergoer who taped the entire musical. In a post at the official Facebook page for the West End production of “Wicked,” its producers wrote: “The posting of film and audio recordings from performances is ILLEGAL and strictly prohibited. All such posts will be removed and the FANatic banned from future performances.” Michael McCabe, the executive producer of the London production, said the message was posted at the behest of the Ambassador Theater Group, which owns the Apollo Victoria Theater where “Wicked” is presented, after an incident in which a fan recorded the entire performance and posted it on YouTube. A representative for the show’s Broadway production, which is at the Gershwin Theater, said it did not have a formal policy banning audience members who are caught recording or pirating the show. The posting of “Wicked” recordings on the Internet is usually dealt with by Universal Pictures, a producer of the show.

headline: Holiday Week Helps Boost Some Broadway Shows
text: Easter, Passover and school vacations contributed to strong tickets sales for many Broadway musicals last week, yet several plays struggled to fill seats in spite of what appeared to be a surge in theater-going on Broadway, according to box office grosses of musicals and plays published on Monday afternoon.

headline: Coordinated Bombings in Northwestern Pakistan
text: Militants mounted coordinated attacks on the United States Consulate in Peshawar, Pakistan, killing at least six Pakistanis and wounding 20.

headline: New Book Says F.B.I. Infighting Hindered Efforts to Recover Stolen Art
text: Was an effort by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to recover stolen Vermeer and Rembrandt works undone by infighting at the agency? That assertion is made by Robert K. Wittman, a retired special agent, in a coming book titled “Priceless: How I Went Undercover to Rescue the World’s Stolen Treasures,” which details his efforts in 2006 and 2007 to retrieve the paintings, The Boston Globe reported. In “Priceless” Mr. Wittman writes that French middlemen with ties to a criminal gang in Corsica offered to sell the stolen paintings to him, believing that he was a rich collector. The works were among more than $500 million in art stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston on March 18, 1990, in what is regarded as the biggest art theft in American history and which remains unsolved after two decades. The Globe reported that Mr. Wittman wrote that his efforts were sabotaged by a superior, called Fred in the book, who micromanaged his work and tried to have him thrown off the case. The F.B.I. told The Globe that it was reviewing the manuscript to see if it revealed any secrets that could damage its investigations or national security. Representatives for Crown Publishing, which is releasing “Priceless,” said Mr. Wittman would not comment until the book was published in June.

headline: Surprisingly, Family Time Has Grown
text: Working parents perpetually agonize that they don’t see enough of their children. But a surprising new study finds that mothers and fathers alike are doing a better job than they think, spending far more time with their families than did parents of earlier generations.

headline: Rams Part Ways With Bulger, Clearing Way for Bradford
text: In the strongest signal yet that they intend to make Oklahoma quarterback Sam Bradford the first overall pick in the N.F.L. draft later this month, the St. Louis Rams released quarterback Marc Bulger on Monday.

headline: Even Among Animals: Leaders, Followers and Schmoozers
text: I recently tried taking a couple of online personality tests, and I must say I was disappointed by the exercise. I was asked bland amorphisms like whether I was “someone who tends to find fault” with people (duh), is generally “friendly and agreeable” (see previous response), and always “does a thorough job” (can I just skip this question?).

headline: Is Dementia an Occupational Hazard?
text: Ralph Wenzel, a retired football player, has dementia that his wife believes was caused by hits he sustained during his N.F.L. career.

headline: BlogTalk: Of Mavericks, Justices and Counts
text: Not so long ago (in fact, less than two weeks ago), Sarah Palin was calling her former running mate — or rather, the person whose running mate she was — a “maverick.’’ “For the sake of your state, for the sake of our country, send a maverick back to the United States Senate,” Ms. Palin told a rally audience at the Pima County Fairgrounds in Arizona, according to our colleague Jeff Zeleny.

headline: Goodbye, Hello
text: After two years of Bitten-izing, I’m moving my Times blogging over to Diner’s Journal to join the rest of the section in a new, improved, all-in-one New York Times Dining blog that will be unveiled on April 7. Look for me there, along with Sam Sifton, Eric Asimov (he’s moving too), Kim Severson, Julia Moskin, Florence Fabricant, Glenn Collins, Nick Fox, Pete Wells and others.

headline: A Tax to Combat America’s Sugary Diet
text: How sweet it is! The American diet, that is.

headline: Stories From the Automat Machines, in a Harlem Basement
text: They were once gleaming, efficient dispensers of comfort food, all shiny chrome and beveled milky glass. They were the heralded automat vending machines -– drop in some coins and get a piece of pie! -– and now they lie heaped ingloriously in a dank basement at 131st Street and Broadway in Harlem.

headline: Precious Echoes
text: While visiting Long Island in 1791, Thomas Jefferson, below, collected a list of words in the Unkechaug language. His list will be a building block in an effort by scholars to revive the dead language. Following is a sampling of the vocabulary Jefferson gathered:

headline: Indian Tribes Go in Search of Their Lost Languages
text: As far as the records show, no one has spoken Shinnecock or Unkechaug, languages of Long Island’s Indian tribes, for nearly 200 years. Now Stony Brook University and two of the Indian nations are initiating a joint project to revive these extinct tongues, using old documents like a vocabulary list that Thomas Jefferson wrote during a visit in 1791.

headline: Video: Excerpts From Woods News Conference
text: Tiger Woods, looking sober but professing to be cheerful about his return to golf, broke little new ground in his first news conference since a Nov. 27 car accident that sent his image on a downward spiral and interrupted his career, but he did deny performance-enhancing drug use when asked about his treatment by Dr. Anthony Galea.

headline: Seoul Survivor | A Front-Row Report From Korean Fashion Week
text: “I think they’re confused,” says the blogger Hong Sukwoo as he slowly drinks his strawberry juice with a straw in the ornate Las Vegas-meets-grandma marble lobby of Seoul’s Imperial Palace Hotel. Sukwoo is talking about Korea’s younger generation, the K-pop kids now in their late teens and early 20s who have plenty of disposable cash and a burning desire to be unique, but who barely have a clue who they are. Sukwoo, at the ripe age of 28, already considers himself part of an earlier “not so beautiful, but perhaps more thoughtful” generation. For the past four years, he has been filling his Your Boyhood blog (yourboyhood.com) with the photos he takes of Seoul’s jeunesse dorée and essays that read like sad, disjointed poems (at least when you try to decipher them with your computer’s instant translator). For him the blog is still in the early stages of a project he imagines will take him about 10 more years: to record the passing youth of one of Asia’s — and the world’s — speediest fast-track cultures. “Young Koreans haven’t found their own style yet, so they’re copying images they find on the Internet,” he says. “It’s a form of stylish cosplay.”

headline: Trailer: Tiger Woods PGA Tour Online
text: This online version of the popular Electronic Arts golf game is the first new, post-scandal Tiger Woods product to be released.

headline: Dan Hurley to Wagner, Bob Hurley to Hall of Fame
text: INDIANAPOLIS – Bob Hurley, the boys basketball coach at St. Anthony High School, was on his way to noon mass, which he attends daily near his Jersey City condominium, with his wife and grandson when a representative from the Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame called on Wednesday. It was then that he learned he would be inducted as a member in August.

headline: Strong Ties With India Goal of Trip by Geithner
text: NEW DELHI — Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary, arrives in New Delhi on Tuesday for a two-day trip to inaugurate a new economic and financial partnership between two of the world’s largest and oldest democracies.

headline: Junkyard Poet of Whirligigs and Windmills
text: LUCAMA, N.C.  Just when you think you’ve traveled too far down Wiggins Mill Road, and you start to look for a spot to turn around, the rusting masterworks of Vollis Simpson loom into view.

headline: Searching for Sept. 11 Victims, Again
text: The search for the remains of the victims of the World Trade Center attacks has begun anew.

headline: A Rare Tasting of Conterno Barolos
text: THE Barolos of Giacomo Conterno are among the most beautiful wines in the world: gorgeously pure and packed with flavors that feel almost three-dimensional. Despite the intensity, the texture is sheer, almost delicate, like silken threads that can suspend bridges.

headline: The Return Address on the Envelope Was N.Y.U.
text: I was a bit of a nervous wreck on April 1. It seems as if I’ve been waiting for New York University’s decision forever: from the time I clicked submit on the Common Application on Dec. 27, to the time I auditioned on Feb. 10th, to last Thursday.

headline: Digg Founder Kevin Rose to Replace Jay Adelson as C.E.O.
text: Jay Adelson, chief executive of Digg, the user-driven social news Web site, announced on Monday that he would step down as head of the company. Kevin Rose, Digg’s original founder, will be taking over as the new chief executive.

headline: Choosing Gay Identity in Old Hollywood
text: In some other theater season, “Looking for Billy Haines” might have been welcome as a pleasant, lightweight entertainment. It’s about a dashing gay 1920s movie star who is run out of the business when he refuses to pose as straight by marrying some starlet and giving up the man he loves. It’s also about a young aspiring actor auditioning for a part in a movie telling Haines’s story and fretting over his closeted boyfriend.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Seventh Seal’
text: This week in Critics’ Picks, A. O. Scott looks at Ingmar Bergman‘s classic meditation on life and death, “The Seventh Seal.” The film tells the story of a knight who returns from the Crusades to find his homeland ravaged by the Bubonic Plague. “In spite of its reputation as a bit of a downer,” Mr. Scott says, “‘The Seventh Seal’ is actually kinda fun.” Some of the film’s supporting characters “embody [Bergman’s] belief in the importance of art as a response to mortality,” Mr. Scott says. Please share your thoughts on “The Seventh Seal” and what it means to you.

headline: Correction
text: An earlier version of this article misstated the name of the state where a priest abused deaf children in the 1970s. It was Wisconsin, not Minnesota.

headline: More Surgery for Levine, Leaving Met in a Bind
text: Two of the most important classical music institutions in America were scrambling again this weekend because of the fragile health of a stocky 66-year-old man with a baton.

headline: U.S. Sued Over Nuclear Waste Fees
text: WASHINGTON — Sixteen utilities and a trade association sued the Energy Department on Monday to halt the government’s collection of nuclear waste disposal fees, arguing that the country no longer had a disposal plan after ruling out Yucca Mountain, Nev., as a repository.

headline: Support for Irish Who Aren’t So Lucky
text: In real life, there’s an excellent chance that you will never encounter five men sitting in a room earnestly discussing their penises. Joking or lying about their penises, sure. Talking about other men’s penises  at a urologists’ convention, for instance  sure. But analyzing their own the way some men dissect the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament? Never. We’d sooner pluck our eyes out.

headline: Autism Is Another Thing That Families Share
text: Normally, when you reach the end of a documentary and say to yourself, “I’m not sure which character that film was about,” it’s a bad thing, a sign of unclear writing and poor execution. But in the case of “Dad’s in Heaven With Nixon,” Tuesday night on Showtime, it’s a testament to how rich this bittersweet tale is.

headline: Sun and Santana Gives Mets Fans a Warm Feeling
text: No one can know for certain what fortunes await the Mets in 2010, but for one game, one significant game, things could not have gone much better.

headline: Breeden Capital Names Research and Trading Head
text: Breeden Capital Management, the activist hedge fund, said on Monday that it had named Joshua W. Fenton, a veteran investment professional, as its director of research and trading.

headline: Tools and Trinkets of the First Cities
text: Gil Stein of the University of Chicago discusses excavations in northern Syria in search of new clues about a prehistoric culture that gave rise to the first cities and the invention of writing. (National Science Foundation)

headline: Hooters Patrons Not Focused Entirely on Woods
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — All but two television sets at the Hooters on Washington Road — the one with the putting green out front, a few blocks from the Augusta National gates — were tuned Monday afternoon to Tiger Woods’ news conference.

headline: Gossip and Golf, Pollen and Scalpers in Augusta
text: The marquee outside a musical instruments store greets motorists with “Welcome to Augusta, golf fans, pollen and TMZ.”

headline: Weekend of Triumphs on Track Offset by Turmoil Off It
text: ARCADIA, Calif. — You have to love the color and pageantry of horse racing. Here in Southern California, a horse owned by the weight-loss queen Jenny Craig and tenderly named for her late husband ran off with the Santa Anita Derby on Saturday. Heartwarming? Heck, yes.

headline: Moelis & Co. Hires a Senior Adviser
text: Moelis & Company, the boutique investment bank, said on Monday that it had hired John T. Grady, a longtime asset management executive, as a senior adviser.

headline: Zebra Finches
text: Researchers have decoded the genome of the zebra finch, whose males learn a single love song from their fathers that they repeat through life.

headline: No Access Is No Problem for Some Media
text: With interest in the Masters ratcheted up by Tiger Woods’s presence, media organizations that do not normally staff the tournament have been lured to Augusta even if they lack credentialed access to the golf course.

headline: From a Songbird, New Insights Into the Brain
text: Researchers have gained new insights into the brain by decoding the genome of the zebra finch, a songbird whose males learn a single love song from their fathers that they repeat through life.

headline: After Attacks in Russia, Fears of Xenophobia
text: MOSCOW — Lilya Paizulayeva descended into the subway anxiously, trying to keep her distance from the crowds and the newly deployed and heavily armed police officers. She cringed at the train’s loud metallic shriek, pressing herself to the wall.

headline: A New Signal of the Recession’s End
text: Many have suggested that the recession probably ended last summer. But the positive jobs report released last Friday is most likely the clincher, says the Harvard economist Jeff Frankel.

headline: More Upheaval at R.N.C.
text: 7:26 p.m. | Updated There is more upheaval at the offices of the Republican National Committee as it struggles to recover from fallout from the disclosure that it had paid a $1,946 tab for staffers and contributors to go to a West Hollywood bondage and strip club.

headline: Can ‘Neuro Lit Crit’ Save the Humanities?
text: A recent Times article described the use of neurological research  and cognitive science in the field of literary theory.

headline: What We’re Reading: Tear Down, Return or Blend the iPad
text: The mood toward the iPad, at least reflected in Monday’s reading list of the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times, is a bit less kindly. Luckily, there are smartphones and Facebook.

headline: Live Updates: Duke Wins the National Title, 61-59
text: Live coverage and analysis from the men’s championship game between Duke and Butler. Kevin Armstrong and Thayer Evans will provide updates from Indianapolis, along with the the longtime Quad contributor Zach Hillesland, who played in the tournament with Notre Dame. You can also follow Pete Thamel on Twitter throughout the Final Four.

headline: Rangers Are Playing Their Best, but Time Is Running Out
text: BUFFALO — Last year at this time, the Buffalo Sabres were in the same position the Rangers find themselves as the last week of the regular season begins, trying to claw their way up to a playoff position before time runs out.

headline: Toll Mounts in West Virginia Coal Mine Explosion
text: At least 12 miners were killed and 10 were unaccounted for after an explosion ripped through a West Virginia coal mine on Monday, mining officials said.

headline: A Town Says ‘Yes, in Our Backyard’ to Nuclear Site
text: OSTHAMMAR, Sweden — Twelve years ago, fearing for her health, Inger Nordholm quit her job as a hairdresser in this seaside Swedish community, one of several that have been competing for the right to become the country’s permanent storage site for radioactive waste. “I was sick of the chemicals” for the hair treatments, said Ms. Nordholm, 45.

headline: Financial Crisis Inquiry Wrestles With Setbacks
text: WASHINGTON — The panel established by Congress to investigate the causes of the financial crisis has been hobbled by delays and internal disagreements and a lack of focus, according to interviews with a majority of its members and government officials briefed on its work.

headline: Israeli Rights Groups View Themselves as Under Siege
text: JERUSALEM — Leaders of some of Israel’s most prominent human rights organizations say they are working in an increasingly hostile environment and coming under attack for actions that their critics say endanger the country.

headline: The Health Care Law (5 Letters)
text: The Health Care Law

headline: For Weight Watchers, Jennifer Hudson Wins a Losing Battle
text: THE previous campaign for Weight Watchers featured a furry critter that tempted dieters with high-calorie foods. Now, the company has decided to get real: its new campaign will star the actress and singer Jennifer Hudson, who will talk about what she has experienced in her quest to lose weight.

headline: On First Day, Apple Sells 300,000 iPads
text: Apple said on Monday that it had sold more than 300,000 iPads on the device’s first day on the market, a figure that included preorders. That met the expectations of financial analysts who were keeping tabs on the release of the company’s highly anticipated tablet computer.

headline: South Africa: Pay Dispute Led to Killing, Mother Says
text: The white supremacist Eugene TerreBlanche was killed by two workers in a dispute about unpaid wages, according to the mother of a 15-year-old arrested for the crime. In an interview with the mother, The Associated Press reported that her son had said that some of Mr. TerreBlanche’s final words were, “I will kill you and throw you to hell.” Some white supremacists have attributed the killing to the renewed singing of an anti-apartheid song by Julius Malema, the head of the governing party’s youth league.

headline: E-Reader vs. Printed Book: Which Is Greener?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,021 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

headline: African Fossil Changes Ideas of Ant Origins
text: The first fossil ant from Africa, found in amber dating back 95 million years, challenges a previously held theory that ants originated in North America or East Asia.

headline: For Nuclear Reactors, Metals That Heal Themselves
text: A nuclear reactor is a tough place for metals. All those neutrons bouncing around wreak havoc with the crystalline structure of steel, tungsten and other metals used in fuel rods and other parts. Over time, the metals can swell and become brittle. (They become radioactive, too, but that’s another story.)

headline: Caterpillars That Thrive in Water and on Land
text: Plenty of animals can live equally well in air or water. They don’t call frogs amphibians for nothing, after all. But insects — whoever heard of an amphibious insect?

headline: A Woman With Her Own Tools? Call Security
text: I CAN’T even begin to estimate how many times I’ve flown during the last several years. I feel like I’m always in an airport. The way I figure it is that if I’m not traveling, I’m not doing any business. And that wouldn’t be good.

headline: Fans Voice Frustration, but Mets Leave It Behind
text: Tough crowd. Before the season even began, Mets fans booed the poor trainers, who were first to be introduced in the pregame ceremony on opening day.

headline: Visual Diary: Shooting by Car in Kandahar
text: Kandahar is currently bracing itself for a major operation by Afghan and NATO forces against Taliban fighters that have been infiltrating the city.

headline: A Nudge in the Ribs for Sleepy Travelers
text: MY worst experience with travel fatigue occurred about 10 years ago, when I impulsively bought a theater ticket in London after a sleepless flight from New York that was followed by a day of meetings.

headline: Video Shows U.S. Killing of Reuters Employees
text: WASHINGTON — The Web site WikiLeaks.org released a graphic video on Monday showing an American helicopter shooting and killing a Reuters photographer and driver in a July 2007 attack in Baghdad.

headline: Obama Limits When U.S. Would Use Nuclear Arms
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Monday that he was revamping American nuclear strategy to substantially narrow the conditions under which the United States would use nuclear weapons.

headline: Group Releases Classified Video of 2007 Baghdad Attack
text: An online whistle-blowing group has circulated online classified U.S. military video showing a 2007 attack by Apache helicopters that killed a dozen people in Baghdad, including two members of Reuters’ news staff. The group, WikiLeaks.org, told a news conference at the National Press Club that it acquired encrypted video of the July 12, 2007, attack from military whistle-blowers and had been able to view and investigate it after breaking the encryption code, Reuters reported.

headline: What Are iPad Owners Downloading?
text: Although it remains to be seen whether or not mainstream consumers will latch onto the iPad with the same ferocity as they did the iPhone, it’s clear that there’s no lack of appetite for apps. On Monday, Apple revealed that iPad owners were voraciously consuming applications. More than one million were downloaded before the weekend was over.

headline: Turning Our Backs on Heroes
text: Arlington, Va.

headline: Renewal, Without Sanctuary
text: For New York sports fans, the last few months have embodied lyrics from a well-worn Beatles song: Little darling, it’s been a long cold lonely winter.

headline: Ayatollah Supports Bid to Sharply Cut Iran Subsidies
text: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, offered a crucial gesture of public support Monday for President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s effort to enact a sweeping economic reform plan that would sharply curtail the country’s long-established system of state subsidies.

headline: Side Taken by Giuliani in Florida
text: MIAMI — Rudolph W. Giuliani showed once again on Monday that for him, politics is personal. Two years after Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida passed over him to endorse Senator John McCain for president, Mr. Giuliani paid back the snub by supporting Marco Rubio for the Republican nomination in Florida’s open Senate seat.

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of the eighth day of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Why New Yorkers Don’t Donate Organs
text: When I started thinking about writing about New York State’s exceptionally low number of registered organ donors — 13 percent of people 18 and older — I remembered that I had never signed up on the official registry to designate myself a donor. So I went online, assuming I would be able to click somewhere quickly, and was delighted at the prospect. How many virtuous impulses can you act on in the amount of time it takes to order staples from Fresh Direct?

headline: Problem Child Becomes Complete Player
text: SAN ANTONIO

headline: A Haitian Family Reunites in Miami, by Video
text: MIAMI — It was a Haitian reunion unlike any other: the 9-year-old boy mostly healed after coming to Miami for surgery, talking to his relatives via video teleconference with a hip-hop band and an N.F.L. star in the background.

headline: Relax, We’ll Be Fine
text: According to recent polls, 60 percent of Americans think the country is heading in the wrong direction. The same percentage believe that the U.S. is in long-term decline. The political system is dysfunctional. A fiscal crisis looks unavoidable. There are plenty of reasons to be gloomy.

headline: In California, Louder Calls to Prepare for Quakes
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As residents on both sides of the Mexican border cleaned up after Sunday’s earthquake, the authorities warned that many Californians remained unprepared for a serious quake, and emergency officials said that budget cuts have strained their ability to handle a disaster.

headline: When a Lawyer Is Wrong
text: Immigration laws have changed over the years to make it easier to deport noncitizens convicted of crimes, even nonviolent crimes. But that does not mean they should be treated unfairly in court  a point the Supreme Court drove home last week by ruling that lawyers for noncitizens must advise their clients if a guilty plea would put them at risk of being deported.

headline: Does Money Talk in the Marketplace of Ideas?
text: Supreme Court Justice Benjamin Cardozo once said that “metaphors in law are to be narrowly watched, for starting as devices to liberate thought, they end often by enslaving it.” Cardozo’s warning would seem to have been heeded by a group of A-list first amendment scholars who met on March 27 at New York University’s Brennan Center for Justice to consider the Court’s recent campaign-funding decision, Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission.

headline: Citigroup’s Chief Shrinks Company, Eyeing Growth
text: Citigroup is getting smaller, and maybe even better.

headline: Salvagers Struggle With Shipwreck at Great Barrier Reef
text: HONG KONG — Salvage experts and a tugboat crew struggled on Tuesday to save a large Chinese freighter that slammed into the Great Barrier Reef off Australia over the weekend.

headline: Returning Prospect Park to the People
text: Drugs were sold at the carousel. Muggers used the cover provided by the park’s shrubs and foliage. One year, near the skating rink, a man was found shot to death, and another year, the acting supervisor of the zoo was arrested and charged with shooting animals.

headline: Excerpts From Obama Interview
text: Following are excerpts of a New York Times interview with President Obama conducted Monday by David E. Sanger and Peter Baker in the Oval Office, about the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty:

headline: Lollapalooza Lineup Announced
text: Last week the Lollapalooza festival teased fans by slowly revealing this summer’s lineup “Wheel of Fortune”-style, filling in the name of each band one letter at a time. First, on Wednesday, came O, followed by R, I and S. By Monday morning the festival’s Web page was filled with clues like SO_I___ _IS_OR_IO_ and S_OO_. It only took a day or two — an O here, a couple of R’s there — for the online hive to piece it all together and come up with plausible guesses for most of the names, like Social Distortion and Spoon.

headline: After a Shooting, Cooperstown Searches for Answers
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — On Main Street, the signs of police activity had all but disappeared by Monday. The State Police cars were gone, the yellow police tape removed. Order, at least outside the National Baseball Hall of Fame, had been restored.

headline: We Call That Double-Dipping
text: Republican critics are continuing to pummel health care reform. Their newest charge is that the elimination of one generous tax deduction for retiree benefits would take such a bite out of corporate profits that companies may have to cut back on hiring, drop that retiree benefit, and shift added costs onto the taxpayer.

headline: Showdown at Indian Point
text: In a very welcome decision for the health of the Hudson River, New York State’s Department of Environmental Conservation has ruled that the obsolete cooling system at the Indian Point nuclear power plant violates the federal Clean Water Act by polluting the river with heated water and needlessly killing vast numbers of fish. The agency has now left the Entergy Corporation with a choice between spending many millions of dollars to install a system that recycles cooling water or shutting down the plant.

headline: Detective Testifies Long Island Teenager Confessed to Fatal Stabbing of Latino Man in 2008
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — The Long Island teenager accused of killing a Hispanic immigrant in 2008 confessed to the police that he had stabbed the man after he and a group of friends agreed to go looking for a Mexican to beat up, the lead homicide detective in the case testified on Monday.

headline: Facing Suit, Pipe Maker Extends Guarantee
text: JM Eagle, fighting to retain sales amid allegations that it knowingly sold defective pipe to municipal water systems, said on Monday that it would guarantee its products for 50 years.

headline: Bloggingheads: Bailout Outrage
text: Glenn Loury, left, and Ross Levine, both of Brown University, discuss whether the Wall Street bailout was inevitable.

headline: An Unwelcome Easter Custom in Times Square: Violence
text: In the waning hours of Sunday, what has become something of a violent Easter night ritual began to unfold. Hundreds of people filled Times Square, some pouring out of the subway, howling and unruly. By night’s end, four people had been shot, and the police had arrested 33 people.

headline: Women’s Final Renews Stars’ Friendly Rivalry
text: SAN ANTONIO — They met as sprouting pre-adolescents already on the competitive fast track and the early college scholarship prowl. Tina Charles of Queens took on Jayne Appel of Pleasant Hill, Calif., on neutral ground, at the Amateur Athletic Union nationals in Florida.

headline: Mets Replay: April 5
text: The Mets opened the season hearing boos for its training staff, then cheers for a 7-1 victory over the Marlins.

headline: Excerpts from Obama’s New Nuclear Strategy
text: The Nuclear Posture Review to be released by the Obama administration on Tuesday will renounce the development of new nuclear warheads and the use of nuclear weapons against non-nuclear states that adhere to treaty commitments. The following are excerpts from the new strategy:

headline: For Inspection Help, Restaurateurs Turn to Consultants
text: The inspection was not going well for Doma, a cafe in the West Village. The visitor with the clipboard, Mark Nealon, noted that the front door had been left wide open — grounds for a two-point violation and a $200 fine — and that trash was bundled on the stairs leading from the street to the basement kitchen.

headline: Allergy-Free New York
text: San Luis Obispo, Calif.

headline: Performance Art That Would Make Any College Proud

headline: Researchers Trace Data Theft to Intruders in China
text: TORONTO — Turning the tables on a China-based computer espionage gang, Canadian and United States computer security researchers have monitored a spying operation for the past eight months, observing while the intruders pilfered classified and restricted documents from the highest levels of the Indian Defense Ministry.

headline: 29 Down: Icicle Feature
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Do you start by looking through the clues to see if one might reveal the theme? Or jump ahead part way through? I tend to wend my way down the grid, taking things as they come, but today, after getting SPACE BAR and TRAFFIC CONE, I got curious and scanned ahead.

headline: Meet the Mets’ Memorabilia
text: With their 7-1 victory over the Marlins on Monday, the Mets officially opened their 49th season. With just two championships to their name, the Mets are eons beyond the Yankees, the Cardinals and the Dodgers.

headline: Rancher's Death Brings Attention to Illegal Border Crossings
text: The death of Robert N. Krentz, a rancher in southeast Arizona, has led residents and politicians to call for tighter border enforcement.

headline: John G. McCoy, Innovator in Banking, Dies at 97
text: John G. McCoy, who transformed the smallest bank in Columbus, Ohio, into the national powerhouse Banc One, died Sunday at his home in New Albany, Ohio. He was 97.

headline: Now to Explain the Party Favors
text: On Thursday, two of the biggest — and among the most tarnished — names on Wall Street will testify in front of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission in Washington: Charles O. Prince III, the former chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, and Robert E. Rubin, a former top adviser and director of the bank. On the watch of these men, Citigroup lost more money than almost any company in history, requiring an extraordinary government bailout.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about potential offshore wind projects under study off the coast of Rhode Island misstated the nature of a megawatt-hour in describing one project’s potential to generate electricity. A megawatt-hour is a unit of energy, not a unit of power. And an accompanying map reversed the location of Nantucket and Martha’s Vineyard. (Nantucket is southeast of the Vineyard.)

headline: Bay’s Hit: Citi Field Triple a Fenway Single?
text: Jason Bay’s line drive to the gap in left-center field leading off the sixth inning Monday had him heading for extra bases. The only question was whether he would settle for a double or race for a triple.

headline: Working With Posada, Burnett Hopes to Tame Fenway
text: BOSTON — A. J. Burnett was just standing there, on the mound at Fenway Park last Aug. 22, with his arms spread, his back to the plate and one thought and one thought only careening through his head. The thought did not stay in there very long, though. It left his mouth, a self-indictment captured by television cameras.

headline: Conservative Developer Joins Race for Governor
text: BUFFALO — Carl P. Paladino, a blunt multimillionaire developer with Tea Party political leanings, announced his campaign for governor on Monday, becoming the third Republican to enter a race that is quickly becoming a scramble for conservative support.

headline: The Ball in Flight
text: It is practice day at the start of a junior tennis tournament in Southern California. And because it’s a warm Sunday afternoon, the ball is in play all across the region  any ball, on every patch of grass, every field and diamond and pitch. At the clink of an aluminum bat and the convergence of female softball players, two boys under a nearby hoop stop facing off to see how the play turns out. So do some casual soccer players just over the fence. I feel for a moment like an alien, entranced by our fondness for small representations of the spheroid on which we live. How we love to test gravity and admire the trajectory of a spinning orb!

headline: Silence Yields to Ovation for Woods at Practice
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — In the back corners of Augusta National Golf Club, it is possible to be so sheltered by the loblolly pines, dogwoods and azaleas that the setting seems soundless. Occasionally on Monday, Tiger Woods stood in these surroundings transfixed by the simple task of hitting a little white ball.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about the rise in pay garnishments misstated the portion of a person’s wages that is exempt from being garnished by court order to repay debts. The maximum that is exempt under federal law is 75 percent of a person’s take-home pay or 30 times the minimum wage per week, whichever is more  not whichever is less. The law thus exempts a minimum of $217.50 per week from seizure, not a maximum of that amount.

headline: Helping Others See the Real World
text: Claire Azzam, 28, became an optometrist after deciding she did not have the stomach for medical school, and despite the fact that her first visit to the optician made her cry. Born in Southern California to a Palestinian father and a Mexican mother, she earned an undergraduate degree in psychobiology from the University of California, Los Angeles. That was followed by four years at the SUNY College of Optometry, from where she graduated in 2008. She lives in Hoboken, N.J., and works at Cohen’s Fashion Optical on West 72nd Street, and at DC 37, a union for the city’s public workers.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article Saturday about the awarding of damages to a workplace safety whistle-blower at Pfizer described an initiative by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration incorrectly. OSHA is considering new requirements on employers to identify and fix potential safety problems in the workplace  not new requirements on workers.

headline: Corrections
text: The Media Equation column on Monday, about Sarah Palin’s television career, erroneously included, in some copies, one television host among several who worked in politics before working in the media. The host, Sean Hannity, did not start in politics.

headline: A Family That Reads and Reviews Together
text: Like most parents, Mara and Dave Lateiner wanted their two children to love reading. The couple, from Millburn, N.J., did the usual library outings, as well as daily read-alouds, sometimes for as long as two hours. But the usual evolved into something more when last July the family went live with its own book-review blog, the Lateiner Gang Family Book Review Spot.

headline: Corrections
text: A headline on Monday about the marketing of a forthcoming program on the National Geographic Channel’s “Explorer” series referred incorrectly to the program. While the marketing campaign borrows from reality television, the program itself is a documentary, not a reality show.

headline: New Deal for Beckett Puts Red Sox Years Ahead
text: BOSTON

headline: Corrections
text: An article on the Itineraries pages last Tuesday about business travel in the armed services misstated the name of an online service that many military travelers use to make travel arrangements. It is the Defense Travel System, not the Defense Transportation System.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about professional athletes’ use of realistic video games to sharpen their skills, misstated the device that Joey Logano, a Nascar driver, uses to prepare for his races. It is his PC, not his Xbox.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Sunday about the release of the Apple iPad misspelled, in some editions, the given name of one customer waiting in line in San Francisco to purchase the device. He is Mathieu Thouvenin, not Mathiew.

headline: Massachusetts: Insurers Sue
text: Six Massachusetts health insurers and an industry trade group filed suit Monday to challenge last week’s denial by the state of nearly nine out of 10 rate increases requested by the companies. The lawsuit, filed in state court, where a hearing is scheduled for Thursday, objects to the decision by Gov. Deval Patrick’s administration to reject 235 out of 274 proposed premium increases. The increases, some as high as 34 percent, were scheduled to take effect April 1. The complaint charges that the denials were not based on a sound actuarial review. The filing said the companies would lose more than $100 million in revenues, “losses that will deplete their individual reserves, weaken their financial stability, and in some instances threaten their near-term solvency.”

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Sunday about the Rangers’ victory over the Florida Panthers on Saturday misstated the number of points they have earned in their last six games. It is 11, not 13. And because of an editing error, it misidentified, in some copies, the franchise the Panthers tied for most seasons without a playoff appearance. It was the Colorado Rockies/New Jersey Devils franchise, not the Colorado Avalanche.

headline: A Daring Proposal to Rescue Greece
text: Forget about Greece for a moment. Just think about country X, which has lived well beyond its means for years thanks to loans from inattentive or foolishly optimistic lenders. When the financial crisis comes, the people of the country will have to cut back on spending. And the country’s lenders will generally suffer from the famous rule of banking: “Can’t pay, won’t pay.”

headline: Corrections
text: A question in the “30 Seconds With ...” column on Sunday with the model Brooklyn Decker, a fan of the University of North Carolina men’s basketball team and the wife of the tennis player Andy Roddick, misstated the last year, before this one, that the Tar Heels did not play in the N.C.A.A. tournament. It was 2003, not 2004.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about James Levine’s withdrawal from productions at the Metropolitan Opera because of back surgery referred incompletely to the conductors for the coming performances of “Tosca.” Fabio Luisi will replace Mr. Levine on April 14, 17, 20 and 24. The performances on April 29, May 5, 8 and 13 will be conducted, as originally scheduled, by Philippe Auguin.

headline: Corrections
text: The Deal Professor column in the special DealBook section on Thursday, about the initial public offerings of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and Apollo Global Management, misstated Apollo’s goals for its offering. It is planning to raise $50 million through the share sale; it is not simply listing shares without seeking to raise new capital.

headline: Yelp Makes Changes in Response to Small-Business Owners
text: Small business owners have been loud and vocal in their criticism of Yelp and its reader reviews. On Tuesday, Yelp will make two significant changes to its pages to address those  complaints.

headline: Mexicali After the Quake
text: Despite some damage to buildings and belongings, a 7.2 earthquake near Mexicali in Mexico caused only a limited number of injuries.

headline: Duke Holds Off Butler to Win 4th N.C.A.A. Title
text: INDIANAPOLIS — The dark sky, tornado warnings and pelting rain here Monday night portended something ominous. The backdrop all week at the Final Four had been one of change, a feeling that the tournament as it has existed for the past quarter-century could be forever altered.

headline: More Foreign Students Applying to Graduate Schools
text: International applications to graduate programs in the United States increased by 7 percent this year, according to a report to be released Tuesday by the Council of Graduate Schools. Applications from abroad decreased sharply in 2003, 2004 and 2005. China, India and South Korea accounted for the majority of applications, and applications from China, India, the Middle East and Turkey grew by double-digit figures over last year. Applications to private institutions were up by 12 percent and applications to public institutions rose by 5 percent.

headline: Clifford Hardin, Who Cut Subsidies at Agriculture Dept., Dies at 94
text: Clifford M. Hardin, who as the first secretary of agriculture in the Nixon administration succeeded in limiting subsidy payments to the nation’s largest farmers, died Sunday at his home in Lincoln, Neb. He was 94.

headline: Deaths at West Virginia Mine Raise Issues About Safety
text: MONTCOAL, W.Va. — Rescue workers began the precarious task Tuesday of removing explosive methane gas from the coal mine where at least 25 miners died the day before. The mine owner’s dismal safety record, along with several recent evacuations of the mine, left federal officials and miners suggesting that Monday’s explosion might have been preventable.

headline: Duke Wins N.C.A.A. Championship
text: Duke held off Butler, 61-59, to win the N.C.A.A. men's national basketball title.

text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Financial Crisis Inquiry Wrestles With Setbacks
text: The panel established by Congress to investigate the causes of the financial crisis has been hobbled by delays and internal disagreements and a lack of focus, according to interviews with a majority of its members and government officials briefed on its work, Sewell Chan and Eric Dash report for The New York Times.

headline: Looking Ahead: Women’s Final
text: Connecticut’s march toward the N.C.A.A. title has seemed inevitable for months. Maybe it is: UConn has never lost in the final (6-0), and it hasn’t lost to anyone in two years. But Coach Geno Auriemma says his undefeated 2002 team — a group that, unlike this year’s, had a win over Tennessee on its résumé — was better, and Stanford is hoping to prove him right. Stanford lost at UConn by 12 points on Dec. 23, but it led by 2 at halftime.

headline: Citigroup’s Chief Shrinks Company, Eyeing Growth
text: Citigroup is getting smaller and maybe even better.

headline: Lehman’s British Unit Objects to Post-Bankruptcy Plan

headline: S.E.C. Doubts Usefulness of Pushing Back of Traders’ Servers
text: Banning traders from placing their servers close to an exchange’s trading system would not solve anything, a top securities regulator said on Monday, Reuters reported.

headline: Brightcove Nabs $12 Million

It just raised another $12 million in fourth-round venture funding, now nearing the $100 million mark, but is still barely breaking even, with just $50 million in annual revenue.

headline: Best Centers in the N.F.L.: The Top 10 List

Paterson of New York, have proposed taxing sugared sodas and juices, to encourage people to lower their consumption of such drinks – and to generate revenue for the state. headline: Sampler: Lack of Attention for Earthquake Preparations, and More Attention for ‘Story of Stuff ‘
text: Prepared for the Big One? Not Exactly | As residents on both sides of the Mexican border cleaned up after Sunday’s earthquake, the authorities warned that many Californians remained unprepared for a serious quake, and emergency officials said that budget cuts have strained their ability to handle a disaster. The budget challenges faced by firefighters and other first responders have probably affected preparedness, fire officials say, particularly in remote or lightly populated areas that often depend on larger cities or agencies for help in emergencies. Sunday’s quake registered 7.2 and centered in a largely unpopulated area of northern Mexico. But a recent study by the California Emergency Management Agency found a majority of the state’s households failing to meet recommendations for many basic emergency needs, like stockpiling water (a minimum of three gallons per person), reinforcing their homes and making disaster plans. “We know that there’s going to be an earthquake, and we know it’s going to be a major natural disaster,” said Lou Paulson, president of the California Professional Firefighters and a captain in the Contra Costa County fire protection district. “And I don’t want to be one of the people who stands in front of the state of California and says, ‘We told you so.’ ” [The New York Times]

headline: Baghdad Bombing Streak Stokes Fear of New Round of Sectarian Violence
text: BAGHDAD — Deadly blasts shook Baghdad for the second time in three days on Tuesday, deepening fears of a new outbreak of insurgent and sectarian violence.

headline: The Resurrection and the Life
text: Newsweek has an Easter-time excerpt from Lisa Miller’s forthcoming book “Heaven,” which looks at the apparent decline of a belief in the physical resurrection of the dead among contemporary religious believers. The number of Americans who believe in the literal resurrection of Jesus Christ has dropped 10 points in the last decade; only 26 percent of Christians believe that they will have bodies in the next life; and almost a third of Americans (including one in five self-identified Christians) now believe in reincarnation. Pondering these trends, Miller argues that some kind of immortality of the soul is simply “easier to swallow” than a physical resurrection; the latter, she suggests, presents all sorts of “credibility problems” that the “more reasonable” belief in purely spiritual afterlife lacks.

text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Consider Duke’s Decision to Miss on Purpose
text: After Duke’s Brian Zoubek was fouled with 3.6 seconds left, he made the first free throw  —  giving the Blue Devils a 61-59 lead in the men’s basketball championship game —  and intentionally missed the second one, apparently to hamper Butler’s chances of tying or winning the game.

headline: Preserve, Protect and Defend? Considering Violent Protests and American Values
text: Overview | Who and what is America? What are American values and beliefs? What does it mean to “take America back”? When, if ever, should Americans use threats and violence to promote and defend their definitions of America? In this lesson, students consider the recent public displays of political anger directed at members of Congress to examine differing conceptions of America by engaging in one of several multidisciplinary activities.

headline: Fed Disclosure: A Stroll Down Maiden Lane III
text: The New York branch of the Federal Reserve served up a mass of information last week on the assets it acquired from the American International Group, pages and pages of dollar amounts and their identifiers, all begging to be made sense of.

headline: Nicollette Sheridan Sues ‘Desperate Housewives’ Producers
text: A working environment where colleagues are perpetually stabbing each other in the back and occasionally inflict bodily harm on one another would seem to be de rigeur at “Desperate Housewives,” at least when the cameras are rolling. But it is those same conditions that Nicollette Sheridan, a former star of that ABC prime-time serial, says went on behind the scenes at the show, whose producers she is suing for assault and wrongful termination, The Associated Press reported. In her lawsuit, Ms. Sheridan, who played Edie Britt on the first five seasons of “Desperate Housewives,” says that the show’s creator, Marc Cherry, hit her during an incident in September 2008. When Ms. Sheridan asked Mr. Cherry about a line in the script, he “took her aside and forcefully hit her with his hand across her face and head,” the suit said, according to The A.P. When Ms. Sheridan complained to ABC, she says she was ignored and her character was later killed off in retaliation. ABC and Cherry Alley Productions, Mr. Cherry’s company, have not yet responded to the suit, which was filed on Monday in Los Angeles County Superior Court.

headline: Timeless | Out Standing
text: For Viktor & Rolf, Meret Oppenheim’s Traccia table definitely has legs.

headline: At Least 95 Are Killed as Floods Paralyze Rio
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Heavy rains and flash floods overnight left at least 95 people dead in the Brazilian state of Rio de Janeiro early Tuesday, the authorities said, paralyzing transportation and causing the city’s mayor to cancel all classes and urge people not to leave their homes.

headline: Beware of Deceptive iPad Offers
text: Even before the Apple iPad went on sale on Saturday, there were fraudulent offers on the Web of free iPads.

headline: Audi S5 Keeps V-8, but VW Golf R Not Definite for U.S.
text: And now a little news for Volkswagen enthusiasts: The V-8 engine will live on in the Audi S5 coupe for at least one more year, but hold your applause, because the hyper-peppy Golf R performance model (already on sale in Europe) is still a question mark for the United States.

headline: Start Your Engines: Jeff Koons Design for BMW Is Introduced
text: Though his design for his BMW art car emphasizes streaks of saturated hues, the artist Jeff Koons said his multicolored effort was in part inspired by a desire for a checkered flag. “I think that would be really fantastic to work on a car that could win,” Mr. Koons said Monday evening in a telephone interview. “I do hope that in the future, we can look back and this car wins.”

headline: After Cancer, Everyday Miracles
text: It has been two years since I learned that I had prostate cancer, and a bit more than a year since I had any treatment for what I eventually learned was an aggressive Stage 3 cancer.

headline: Priest in India Says He’ll Go to U.S. to Face Sex Charges
text: NEW DELHI — A Roman Catholic priest in southern India charged with sexually assaulting a teenage girl in Minnesota in 2004 said Tuesday that he would return to face the charges, though he and his supervising bishop in India said they did not know about the criminal charges until reporters contacted them.

headline: Boston College Hires Cornell Basketball Coach
text: Boston College announced Tuesday that it had chosen Steve Donahue, who led Cornell University to the Round of 16 in the N.C.A.A. tournament, as its next men’s basketball coach.

headline: Freighter Oozing Oil Remains on Reef

headline: U.S. Court Curbs F.C.C. Authority on Web Traffic
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday that regulators had limited power over Web traffic under current law. The decision will allow Internet service companies to block or slow specific sites and charge video sites like YouTube to deliver their content faster to users.

headline: Advice From Mother and Daughter on Visiting Colleges

headline: Comparing Conterno Barolos: Cascina Francias and Monfortinos
text: If you are lucky enough to have one bottle of Giacomo Conterno Barolo on your dinner table, it’s a very special evening. Not long ago I had 16 of them, dating back to 1937, which made this particular dinner not only a great event, but a column.

headline: Time to Rattle Over Rough Roads
text: Cyclists across the globe wait for spring with anticipation and even something approaching glee. For some, it’s the thrill of riding in T-shirt weather again; for others, it’s a chance to pedal beneath the blossoms on the trees.

headline: Berlin Staatsoper Prepares for a Temporary Move
text: After more than 160 years in its Berlin home, the Staatsoper Unter den Linden will move to a smaller space for three years while its longtime theater undergoes renovations, The Associated Press reported. At a news conference on Tuesday, the opera company said it was preparing to move west to Berlin’s Schiller Theater as the Staatsoper building, which opened on the Unter den Linden boulevard in 1844, begins a $321 million restoration project. Rehearsals in the Schiller Theater, which is contending with its own renovations, are to begin Aug. 19, and the Staatsoper’s 2010-2011 season will open there on Oct. 3 with the world premiere of Jens Joneleit’s “Metanoia,” directed by Christoph Schlingensief. Other conductors who are scheduled to lead the Staatsoper during the season include James Levine and Pierre Boulez. At the news conference, Daniel Barenboim, the music director for the Staatsoper, said, “Moving for three years can be seen as a calamity or as a challenge, and we have decided to see it as the latter.” Its artistic director, Jürgen Flimm, said it would be difficult for operagoers to follow the company to its new home, adding: “I hope there will be sufficient curiosity. That’s why we are doing so much.”

headline: WikiLeaks Defends Release of Video Showing Killing of Journalists in Iraq

headline: CBS Facing Possibility of Losing a Signature Event

headline: Apollo and Cedar Fair Walk Away From L.B.O. Deal

headline: Duke Looks Armed for Future N.C.A.A. Tournament Runs
text: INDIANAPOLIS — One morning in February, Drederick Irving, a bond analyst at Thomson Reuters in New York, awoke to a news report that Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski might leave for the Nets. Irving’s son, Kyrie, widely considered the nation’s best guard prospect, had recently committed to Duke, and now the father wanted to know if Krzyzewski would be there to coach. Irving called while commuting on his train.

headline: Butler Lost the Game, but Won the Season
text: The final shot hung in the air and carried a fairy tale’s fate with it. Butler had a chance to join the pantheon of greatest sports moments, not only winning a crazy-for-even-dreaming-it N.C.A.A. title, but also doing it by crushing the ultimate blueblood team in the sport. When Gordon Hayward’s shot came so tantalizingly close and caromed off the rim, Duke celebrated and reality set in. The fairy tale died. College basketball’s version of I.B.M. won.

headline: Small Endeavors and Small-Time Crooks
text: Today, everyone is loving Assami Semde, whose tale of danger and dedication neatly pairs two things that warm the urban heart: home delivery pizza and a foiled holdup.

headline: I Want My MCM
text: As far as symbols of ’80s excess go, it’s hard to beat Cindy Crawford (she of big hair and voluptuous — by model standards, anyway — body) and MCM (Mode Creation Munich), the Euro leather goods brand, whose flashy logoed caramel-colored bags gave even Gucci and Louis Vuitton a run for their money. (Did we mention this was the ’80s?) The MCM ads were equally flashy, featuring Crawford perched on a pile of suitcases or posing wearing nothing except a giant MCM logo. (If that weren’t enough, they were signed “I want my MCM” and “The beginning of a beautiful friendship.” Awwww.) And while you might think that such naked consumption went the way of the world economy, you would think wrong. Not only has the brand been on a store opening spree with 15 new Saks Fifth Avenue boutiques and a Beverly Hills Rodeo Drive boutique scheduled for later this year, but it has signed on as a sponsor for New York fashion week. MCM is even recreating its Cindy Crawford campaign, this time around with the model Coco Rocha. Under the circumstances, the images are a bit more modest — Rocha’s mane is tamed down, and she’s wearing a bustier dress — but the message is not lost.

The Rangers play their game in hand against the Maple Leafs at the Garden tomorrow and then the Rangers and the Flyers play a season-ending home-and-home series, starting Friday in New York and ending Sunday in Philadelphia.

text: Taking the train in India is usually best left to locals or seasoned adventure travelers. It takes a certain skill, and stomach, to negotiate the hordes of bodies jampacked into every available square foot, and the overwhelming sensations of sight, sound, smell and, yes, touch that are part of a typical journey. As of last month, however, an entirely new breed of locomotive has landed on the country’s tracks.

headline: Developers See Possibility (and Value) in Old Steel
text: As commercial real estate development nearly comes to a halt in the economic downturn, some well-capitalized investors are focusing instead on sprucing up existing properties. The process has various names: retrofitting, renovating, repurposing, even repositioning. But the underlying idea is to wring out more value at a time when rents will not support new construction.

text: Scenes of war and tension dominate our show for Tuesday.

headline: Hornets’ Rookies Contribute Early and Often
text: Zach Lowe writes for CelticsHub.com. He grew up in Connecticut watching the Bird-era Celtics with his father and hating Chuck Person. He now lives in Manhattan and dreams of a day in his adult lifetime when the Celtics and Knicks are both elite teams.

headline: The Visual Thing
text: There are lots of things I miss about the late, great graphic designer Alan Fletcher, but the thing I miss the most is arguing with him about design. Some of our most enjoyable arguments involved how to explain design to the 99 percent of the population that Alan pityingly described as “civilians” — in other words, those of us who aren’t lucky enough to be designers.

headline: Drawing Crowds in the West Coast Venice
text: TRUE, Abbot Kinney Boulevard, a few blocks in from the beach in Venice, Calif., is hardly off the radar and has long drawn people from outside the neighborhood. But the street’s spark never seems to dim; instead, it jumps around, alighting on one new spot after another. And, despite some tough times, the past year or so has brought a fresh crop of worth-a-visit places.

headline: Farm Fresh Down Under
text: IT seems as if everyone is releasing an iPhone application nowadays, so why not a butcher? Vic’s Premium Quality Meats, one of the fanciest meat purveyors in Sydney, Australia, now offers “Ask the Butcher,” which enables users to request information on everything from how to cook a particular cut to diagrammed references of animal bodies.

headline: The Texas Border Draws Frequent Fliers
text: ELEVEN in the morning is not the best time of day to start birding. But when my plane landed at that hour in the Rio Grande Valley, reputedly one of the best places for bird-watching in the country, I just couldn’t wait.

headline: Floyd, a Year After His 45th Masters, Announces His Retirement
