text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Raymond Floyd played his 45th and final Masters last year but waited an entire year to announce it, telling a small gathering of reporters a 9 a.m. news conference Tuesday that he would not be competing in this year’s event and that his competitive days are over on the Champions Tour as well.

headline: Relishing the Waves, Not the Crowds, in Mexico
text: IT was a blazingly bright afternoon on Cerritos Beach just outside Todos Santos, Mexico. The air was hot and dry and smelled like frying fish. Neighborhood children jumped up and down in the shoreline ripples as their parents lingered at picnic tables with tacos and icy beer. Out in the water, a dozen surfers were lying on their boards, waiting to paddle as the next swell approached.

headline: Confusion, Chairs and Charters Helped Doom Bid for Grant
text: In the hectic rush to finish New York State’s Race to the Top grant application last January, much of the spotlight fell on the State Legislature, as lawmakers wrangled over a bill that would increase the number of charter schools permitted in the state.

headline: 36 Hours in Sydney
text: SUNNY, fashion-forward and multiethnic, Sydney is an animated city bent on making its mark. But with its skyline already crowded with skyscrapers, and its place on the world stage firmly set, the city seems to be in the midst of a historical revival. Traditional Australian cuisine like meat pies is being remade in the locavore age. Sports like surfing are being celebrated in their national birthplace. And older buildings are enjoying an architectural second act as salons for the city’s cognoscenti, who can’t seem to get enough of Sydney’s homegrown charms.

headline: Store Review: GaleriAmazônica in Manaus, Brazil
text: It’s one of those only-in-the-Amazon tourist dilemmas: you want to bring home a 12-foot blowgun, but don’t know how to tell the genuine article from tourist schlock. And how do you know if a fair share of your money will get to the indigenous group that made it? Or if the tortoise shells used for adornment were responsibly obtained?

headline: Common Ground on Autism
text: Liane Kupferberg Carter got your attention back in February with her guest post here on Motherlode comparing those who would claim a cure for autism to snake-oil salesman. What got her attention was the furor that other parents hurled her way after the piece appeared.

headline: Hotel Review: Art + Hotel in Tel Aviv
text: THE BASICS

headline: Tastes of India, by New Delhi Taxi
text: WITH its fluorescent lights and laminate tables, the little restaurant near the shuttered Chanakya Cinema looked like any no-frills canteen found throughout the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu. Diners bought copies of the Daily Thanthi newspaper, written in the curlicue script of Tamil. A small statue of Balaji, a deity worshiped in southern India, sat snugly on the counter. And the food was rich with the crepe-like dosas for which the region is known.

headline: Mangia, Mangia!
text: NICOLA DE THOMASIS, a round-bellied, bearded, bespectacled man from the rough-hewn hills of Abruzzo, stood near the head of his dinner table, holding a pair of tongs  and my fate  in his hand. He had already placed on my plate an almost lethally large portion of spaghetti alla chitarra, dressed with the region’s traditional tomato-and-lamb ragù, and his tong-bearing hand kept inching closer and closer to the communal pasta platter until, at last, he dove in with the instrument, scooped up a final, fatal tangle of noodles and added them to my dish. I was done for.

headline: Saving by Tying the Knot at Sea
text: CRUISES have long been popular with honeymooners looking for a romantic getaway after the wedding. Now, a growing number of brides and grooms are tying the knot on cruise ships and sailing off into the sunset with their entire wedding party in tow.

headline: Notes From the 2010 Campaign Trail
text: Tuesday on the trail:

headline: Now Shopping | Ralph Lauren Kids
text: It’s in my blood: all the men in my family are dressed-up rowdy Texas boys at heart — my brother, our father and his father are all just a little bit taller than shotguns, and wear suits as tight as barbed wire, sharp edged as bullet holes. The fact that I shattered the family height record doesn’t stand for much: I’m 5-foot-9-ish on a really good day. I’m not one for the Napoleon complex, and anyway, there are perks to being, let’s say, compact. But there is one big difference between my forebears and me: those bastards had crazy cash, and I’m a broke scribe struggling in this sick city. So how’s a bred-for-bespoke fella supposed to pay for fancy garb without two dimes to rub together?

headline: Old Hickory, Rock Star President
text: Ladies and gentlemen, the seventh president of the United States is here to take a firsthand look at you the people, and he thinks you’re really hot. You feel the same way about him, right? You’re going to shake, rattle and roll when he makes you the ultimate promise, the one you truly want to hear from anyone who aspires to lead your nation: He solemnly swears to give you the best sex you’ve ever had.

headline: On Trial, Ex-Oil Magnate Finally Speaks
text: MOSCOW — For a year, Russia’s most famous prisoner, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, sat in a glass cage in a dingy, third-floor courtroom and listened while prosecutors sought to prolong his time behind bars by charging that he embezzled billions of dollars worth of oil. On Tuesday, Mr. Khodorkovsky finally got a chance to speak in his own defense in the politically tinged case.

headline: Fee-Based People Search Site Takes Heat
text: Amended 4/21/2010, to clarify the amount of Intelius’ business in February

headline: Winter. Summer. Is a Season Missing?
text: “April is the cruelest month,” the noted meteorologist T. S. Eliot once wrote. But Eliot was not sitting on the sun-drenched Brooklyn waterfront taking in a hazy Manhattan skyline in 78 degree warmth on Monday afternoon. Had he been around to join New Yorkers enjoying the unseasonably good weather, he might have otherwise assessed the months and their comparative cruelty.

headline: 3 Check In at Airport; 1 Departed Beforehand
text: LONDON — Something was not right about the elderly man in the wheelchair, the check-in agents at Liverpool John Lennon Airport thought when he showed up with his wife and stepdaughter for a flight to Germany on Saturday.

headline: Mercedes Says S-Class Could Become a Hybrid Line
text: The flagship V-12-powered 2010 Mercedes-Benz S600 gets only 11 miles per gallon in the city, and the well-heeled buyers of this $149,700 car probably shrug when they pay $3,000 in gas-guzzler taxes. But fuel economy that low does little for the company’s efforts to meet the stringent fuel economy and greenhouse gas standards pending in Europe and the United States, and that’s why Mercedes is considering an out-of-left-field plan to turn its entire S-Class line into full hybrids.

headline: A Brazilian Home Out of Hardwoods
text: The home was designed by the Brazilian architect Severiano Mario Porto in the 1970s andconstructed using many types of Amazonian hardwoods.

headline: Arrest Follows Threat to Kill Senator
text: 9:39 p.m. | Updated Federal agents on Tuesday arrested and charged a man with threatening to kill Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, because he was angry about her vote in favor of the major health care legislation.

headline: What You Get for... $350,000
text: NEW ORLEANS

headline: Lots of Vocal Firepower for Mendelssohn Work Despite an Absence
text: Elijah may or may not have graced your Passover Seder last week, but he put in a vivid appearance at Carnegie Hall on Monday night. Or at least the trappings were vivid, as Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos conducted the Boston Symphony Orchestra, the Tanglewood Festival Chorus and a formidable cast of vocal soloists in Mendelssohn’s grand oratorio “Elijah.”

headline: Correction
text: An earlier version of this article misspelled the name of Bishop Arulappan Amalraj.

headline: First At-Bat Home Runs
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: Park for Special-Needs Children to Open in San Antonio
text: Morgan’s Wonderland, which bills itself as the world’s first “ultra-accessible family fun park” designed specifically for children and adults with special needs, is scheduled to open April 10, just northeast of San Antonio.

headline: In Eastern Europe, Pact With Russians Raises Old Specters
text: KARLOVY VARY, CZECH REPUBLIC — As President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia and President Barack Obama prepare to arrive in Prague on Thursday to sign a landmark arms control treaty, Marcela Balounova, like many Czechs, remains haunted by her memories of 1968, when nearly one million Warsaw Pact troops invaded Czechoslovakia, ushering in a period of political repression.

headline: Special Counsel Requested in Polanski Case
text: In a new California appeals court filing, lawyers for Roman Polanski on Tuesday asked for the appointment of a special counsel to investigate claims of official misconduct in the sex-crime case against him. “The defense respectfully suggests that it is now necessary for this court to recommend the appointment of special counsel to investigate and take appropriate action through a grand jury and referral to state agencies charged with addressing and disciplining cases of professional misconduct within the criminal justice system,” the lawyers wrote in reply to the Los Angeles County district attorney’s earlier brief opposing Mr. Polanski’s appeal.

headline: A Thinker Finds His Funk
text: Rhythm ruled the music of Atoms for Peace, the band Thom Yorke led at Roseland on Monday night. It’s a side project with unspecified goals for Mr. Yorke, who also leads Radiohead, but one effect was immediate: he danced through nearly the whole set. Twitching, strutting, pivoting, hopping, jittering and gesticulating, he let the music propel him in ways that were anything but cerebral, even in songs for which he sat at the piano. Where Radiohead’s music is the triumph of thinking much too hard, Mr. Yorke on his own got sweaty and physical.

headline: Jones’s Versatility Shown in Two Swings
text: After hitting 21 home runs in 82 games last season, many wondered if Garrett Jones, the Pirates outfielder, was a fluke. He did his best on opening day to quiet that talk with home runs in his first two at-bats. But what may be most interesting about the home runs is how different they were.

headline: New Kid at Large on Urban Chessboard
text: Adaptations are tricky monsters; where do you begin when making theater out of something like “Dhalgren,” Samuel R. Delany’s classic science-fiction novel about the ravaged, metaphoric city of Bellona? How do you please devotees and guide the uninitiated (this reviewer is 95 percent in the uninitiated category, having just begun the book) while forging a self-sufficient artistic vision?

headline: When Local Control Fails
text: Today’s priestly sex abuse story features a South Asian cleric accused of assaulting a teenage girl (and robbing his diocese into the bargain) while serving temporarily in Minnesota. He had already returned to India by the time the allegations surfaced, at which point the Minnesotan bishop wrote to the Vatican suggesting that the priest might need to be removed from ministry. The priest’s bishop in India, however, ordered him to undertake a year of prayer in a monastery, rather than seeking to have him defrocked, even as further accusations surfaced in Minnesota, and the county attorney began pursuing extradition. A Vatican spokesman says that the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith recommended laicization, but (per canon law) deferred to the Indian bishop on the matter. However, the documents suggest that at least initially, the C.D.F. only recommended that the priest be monitored and kept away from minors.

headline: BlogTalk: Dr. No, Nancy Pelosi and Fox News
text: When the health bill was being debated in Congress, there was no stronger opponent to it than Senator Tom Coburn, the physician and  Republican from Oklahoma who is known in some circles as Dr. No. In December he said that seniors would die faster because of cuts in Medicare in the version of the health care measure then being considered.

headline: In Brazil, a Jungle Home
text: MANAUS, Brazil  It wasn’t the snakes and scorpions that horrified Sandra Santos back in 1996 when her husband, Edson Costa, first showed her the potential weekend getaway, a wooden home on stilts on two acres of Amazonian rainforest. It was the dark, gloomy, off-the-grid structure itself.

headline: Inspiration From Tiger: Get Out of Jail Card, Though It’s Far From Free
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — “Pulled a Tiger lately?” begins a handmade sign crafted by Christian Seklecki on a street corner just outside Augusta National Golf Club. Of all the unusual money-making schemes that invoke Tiger Woods’s name, this one is the leader in the clubhouse.

headline: What We’re Reading …
text: Using Twitter to predict box office success, an other links from around the Web.

headline: City Fined for Ignoring Court Orders in Crane Lawsuit
text: Updated, 6:09 p.m. | A judge fined the Bloomberg administration $5,000 Tuesday for repeatedly ignoring court orders to provide the families of two construction workers who died in a fatal 2008 crane collapse with documents, e-mail messages and other information concerning equipment inspected by the city.

headline: Questions to Ask Former Citi Executives
text: As several former Citigroup executives prepare to testify on Wednesday and Thursday about their onetime employer’s near-implosion, we started thinking about what the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission should ask them.

headline: Diligence Is a Factor in Controlling Risks From Methane
text: Coal mines will always have methane, often in explosive concentrations, geologists and engineers say. The only question is how diligently miners and mining companies will work to avoid explosions.

headline: App Mashes Up Social Network Functions
text: Do we need yet another social interaction app? The developers of Friends Around Me think so.

headline: For Sale in ... Panama
text: A THREE-BEDROOM THREE-AND-A-HALF-BATH LAKEFRONT HOME NEAR PANAMA CITY

headline: Lilly Pulitzer: Fashion With a Colorful Narrative
text: WES ANDERSON movies and J. D. Salinger novels both portray hyper-colorized worlds of civilized affluence. The characters are all a little too wonderful, attractive and brilliant to be believed — and they’re all a bit unstrung by their passions for sport or religion or art or each other.

headline: AOL Plans to Sell or Close Bebo Social Network
text: From Jenna Wortham at Bits:

headline: Hedge Fun
text: Rake in the cachet with new designs for the great indoors. More…

headline: Suspect Arrested After Threats to Senator Murray
text: Federal agents on Tuesday arrested and charged a man with threatening to kill Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, because he was angry about her vote in favor of the major health care legislation.

headline: ‘Dancing’ to Feature City Ballet Principal
text: The former astronaut Buzz Aldrin is among the celebrities who have been roundly criticized for their technique on the ABC television competition “Dancing With the Stars,” but the judges will have a hard time finding fault with one dancer’s skills next week. Tiler Peck, near left (with Gonzalo Garcia), a principal with New York City Ballet, is scheduled to appear on the show on Tuesday as part of the “Macy’s Stars of Dance” performance during the live results episode. According to ABC, Ms. Peck, the first City Ballet dancer to appear on the show, will perform along with 12 other dancers in a piece choreographed by Travis Wall.

headline: Nicollette Sheridan Sues ‘Housewives’ Producers
text: A working environment where colleagues are perpetually stabbing one another in the back and occasionally inflicting bodily harm would seem to be de rigueur at “Desperate Housewives,” at least when the cameras are rolling. But Nicollette Sheridan, below, a former star of that ABC prime-time serial, says those same conditions existed behind the scenes at the show, whose producers she is suing, asserting she was assaulted and wrongfully terminated, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Sheridan, who played Edie Britt on the first five seasons of “Desperate Housewives,” said the show’s creator, Marc Cherry, hit her during an incident in September 2008. When Ms. Sheridan asked Mr. Cherry about a line in the script, he “took her aside and forcefully hit her with his hand across her face and head,” the suit said, according to The A.P. When Ms. Sheridan complained to ABC, she was ignored and her character was later killed off in retaliation, she said. ABC and Cherry Alley Productions, Mr. Cherry’s company, have not yet responded to the suit, which was filed on Monday in Los Angeles County Superior Court.

headline: Broadway Opening for ‘Love Never Dies’ Is Delayed Until 2011
text: The Broadway production of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s new musical, “Love Never Dies,” a sequel to his “Phantom of the Opera,” will be delayed several months until spring 2011 as Mr. Lloyd Webber deals with “post-operative problems” from treatment for prostate cancer, according to a statement on Tuesday from the show’s Broadway producers. While Mr. Lloyd Webber’s cancer has been “eradicated,” the statement said, his doctors have asked him to avoid long airplane flights, which apparently have aggravated his condition, according to the statement. The producers did not provide details about the health of Mr. Lloyd Webber, 62, though they said he was well enough to continue appearing on a new BBC television series about his search for an actress to play Dorothy in a new production of “The Wizard of Oz.” Asked why Mr. Lloyd Webber did not postpone the television show and instead base himself in New York to work on the musical, executives involved in the Broadway production said he had a commitment to the BBC show. Mr. Lloyd Webber was not available for a telephone interview, a spokesman for the Broadway production said, though he said in a statement that he was “extremely frustrated” by the limitations on his travel. Two Broadway theater executives who met with Mr. Lloyd Webber in London in March, when “Love Never Dies” opened there, said that he reported feeling well and did not complain of post-treatment problems. “Love Never Dies” drew mixed reviews from critics in London, including a tough critique from The New York Times’s chief theater critic, Ben Brantley, prompting speculation that the Broadway run would be delayed so Mr. Lloyd Webber could overhaul it. The musical had been scheduled to open in November at the Neil Simon Theater.

headline: More Legal Woes for Annie Leibovitz
text: The photographer Annie Leibovitz, below, whose protracted legal troubles had seemed to be behind her, is back in court. Brunswick Capital Partners has filed a suit against her in New York State Supreme Court, saying that she owes the firm several hundred thousand dollars in fees for its role in finding investors who have helped her restructure her debt, Reuters reported. Ms. Leibovitz fell into financial trouble, according to friends, after years of incautious spending and expensive home renovations. Last month she reached an agreement with Colony Capital, a Los Angeles firm: it became her only creditor and agreed to help her concentrate on her career and earnings. She averted a foreclosure last summer after she missed a deadline to repay $24 million in loans to Art Capital Group, a lender that used the rights to her photographs and her real estate as collateral. In the new lawsuit, filed on Friday, Brunswick Capital says that Ms. Leibovitz has failed to pay fees for its services and a 2 percent commission on the $40 million loan that Colony made to consolidate her debt. Representatives for Ms. Leibovitz and Colony declined to comment, saying that they had not had a chance to review the suit.

headline: ‘Dancing’ vs. Duke
text: A two-hour “Dancing With the Stars” carried ABC to the top of the ratings on Monday night as an average of 20.9 million viewers tuned in to the reality show from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The celebrity dancers earned the largest audience of the night and gave a lift to ABC’s 10 p.m. show “Castle” (12.3 million), but CBS ranked a very strong second place, broadcasting a repeat of “The Big Bang Theory” at 8 (10.8 million) and a new episode of “Rules of Engagement” at 8:30 (10.2 million), followed by live coverage of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball championship game. Preliminary estimates show that the game between Duke and Butler universities, won by Duke 61-59, garnered a larger audience than last year’s championship game, which drew 17.7 million viewers when final ratings were released. Fox finished third with a two-hour episode of “24” (7.3 million), while NBC placed fourth.

headline: Smoke at the Met but No Fire
text: Ambroise Thomas’s “Hamlet” was not the only drama at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night: partway through that 3-hour-18-minute production was the 10-minute subplot of the smelly lighting gel. Shortly after 9 p.m. patrons in the upper balconies smelled smoke, and some headed for the door. At 9:16 one called the New York City Fire Department, which soon arrived and found that the gel on a stage light had burned, sending an odor through the ventilation system. No fire was detected and “the whole incident was closed in 9 minutes and 45 seconds,” a fire department spokesman said. A Met spokesman said that the performance, conducted by Louis Langrée and starring Simon Keenlyside as Hamlet and Jane Archibald as Ophélie, was not interrupted and that ticketholders who walked out were reseated.

headline: Footnote
text: The Metropolitan Opera said that Steven White would conduct the performance of “La Traviata” on Wednesday night in his Met debut. Mr. White was already scheduled to conduct the opera on Saturday, replacing Leonard Slatkin, who withdrew.

headline: Tree-mendous
text: The garden outside my window is home to an enormous and beautiful tree. I gave it a hug the other day, but the trunk is so huge I could barely get my arms round a quarter of its girth. For now, the branches are bare of leaves, so you can see its form in all its majesty, a triumph of natural architecture. And if you half-close your eyes and dream a little, you can also see its roots, stretching deep beneath the grass, much as its branches and twigs stretch outwards towards the buildings and upwards towards the sky.

headline: How the F.B.I. Identified Murray’s Caller
text: As the F.B.I. moved in on a man who allegedly threatened Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, because of her support for health care legislation, law enforcement agents faced a challenge: they needed to confirm that Charles A. Wilson, the man whose phone number was used to leave menacing messages on her office voicemail, was in fact the man who made the threats.

headline: When Corporate America Comes Calling
text: Out of the blue a couple of weeks ago, I got a call from a headhunter on my mobile phone. I happened to be walking across a parking lot at the time. I glanced over my shoulder — like a refugee in the witness-protection program — and wondered, “How did they find me?”

headline: Funds Sought to Continue Restoration at Ellis Island
text: Save Ellis Island, a nonprofit charged with restoring that historic immigrant gateway to America, may not be able to save itself.

headline: Ticket Broker Sees Sudden Interest in Woods’s Return
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — At least one licensed ticket broker has detected a spike in demand for tickets to Thursday’s first round of the Masters. Igniting the escalation is “media frenzy” over Tiger Woods’s return, according to TicketCity’s chief operating officer, Zach Anderson.

headline: Ample Optimism, Defiant Dreams
text: The headwaters of the protean talent that is Allan Harris, a baritone crooner with a husky edge, may be Nat King Cole and his trio. But to describe this pop-jazz singer, composer and guitarist as a gifted Cole acolyte doesn’t take into account the winding tributaries that bring in the blues, folk, pop-soul, light funk, Americana and Broadway flavors. Together they flow into a fertile musical delta that reflects Mr. Harris’s unfashionably hopeful vision of multicultural America.

headline: Reed Attacks Lobbying Efforts by Ratings Agencies
text: 7:35 a.m. | Updated Senator Jack Reed, Democrat of Rhode Island, on Tuesday criticized efforts by the credit ratings agencies to ward off proposed new rules, and rejected efforts to woo Republican legislators’ support as “cynical.”

headline: Bilton on ABC: Test-Driving the iPad
text: On Monday I sat down with Dan Harris, a correspondent based in new York for ABC News, to discuss some of the features of Apple’s iPad. Mr. Harris asked about the weight of the device, which is a concern for some users, along with the typing features on the device and some of the interesting games and other applications that are available. I specifically talked about Flight Control 3-D.

headline: Music Surely Soothes; Can It Also Heal?
text: When presenting concerts devoted to contemporary music in a variety of styles, an overarching theme can provide context. You regularly encounter programs bundled according to historical period, ties to other art forms or more fanciful notions. For this year’s Cutting Edge Concerts New Music Festival, an annual series presented by the composer and conductor Victoria Bond, “Music & Health: Can Music Heal?” is the banner notion.

headline: 16 Years after the Genocide, Rwanda Continues Forward
text: Josh Ruxin is the director of Rwanda Works and a Columbia University expert on public health who has spent the last few years living in Rwanda. Here he reflects on the anniversary of the genocide in Rwanda.

headline: Illuminating Prince’s Path That Led to Enlightenment
text: David Grubin, a prolific maker of television documentaries, specializes in profiles of American presidents and other prominent Westerners: Lincoln, both Roosevelts, Truman, Napoleon, Freud. For his latest PBS project, making its debut on Wednesday night, he has headed East, offering a two-hour introduction to an Asian with a large Western fan base.

headline: Less Baggage, Big Savings to Airlines
text: Airlines in the United States started charging for luggage in 2005 by instituting a fee for passengers with more than one bag to check. Soon, even the first bag wasn’t free. Now, Spirit Airlines says it will charge as much as $30 each way for carry-on bags that are too big to fit under the seat.

headline: Contrasting Percussion, From Streets Near and Far
text: For thousands of years groups of people around the world have played music on percussion instruments  for rituals, dances, ceremonies, and just for fun. But as the percussionist Daniel Druckman wrote in a program note for a concert by the Juilliard Percussion Ensemble at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, the concept of a percussion ensemble as an “independent musical entity in Western music,” that is, as a group for giving concerts, is usually traced to 1933, when Nicolas Slonimsky conducted the premiere of Varèse’s audacious “Ionization” at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Automaker Pensions Underfunded by $17 Billion
text: DETROIT — The pension plans at General Motors and Chrysler are underfunded by a total of $17 billion and could fail if the automakers do not return to profitability, according to a government report released Tuesday.

headline: Malone Reduces Control of DirecTV
text: Updated 2:50 p.m. Tuesday: DirecTV’s single largest shareholder and the chairman of its board of directors, John C. Malone, is reducing his control of the satellite television company.

headline: Tenderness and Flair for British Composers
text: The superb British mezzo-soprano Alice Coote has been justly acclaimed for her operatic trouser roles. So it seemed fitting that for her recital at Zankel Hall on Monday evening she wore tight black trousers, a long, glittery silver top and killer heels  abandoning both sartorial and repertorial tradition in her unusual program.

headline: Novartis Bias Suit to Begin
text: A class-action lawsuit alleging that Novartis Pharmaceuticals practiced sex discrimination against female employees is set to go to trial on Wednesday in federal court in New York.

headline: Health Secretary Warns of Insurance Scams
text: The secretary of health and human services, Kathleen Sebelius, wrote to state officials on Tuesday to urge that they take action against “scam artists” reportedly marketing fake insurance policies to exploit the new law overhauling the health care system.

headline: The iPad in the Eyes of the Digerati
text: Apple said it sold more than 300,000 iPads on Saturday, the device’s first day on the market. Apple iPad users downloaded more than one million apps from the company’s App Store and more than 250,000 electronic books from the iBookstore. Some reviewers said the iPad could challenge the primacy of the laptop. But others said the device, though gorgeous, simply doesn’t fill an obvious need.

headline: Edginess Over the Yankees’ Payroll
text: The Yankees paid around $150 million last season in luxury taxes and revenue sharing, the majority of it on the latter. When other teams complain about the Yankees’ high payroll, it can strike a nerve with club officials.

headline: Web Luddite No More: O’Brien Hits Internet
text: LOS ANGELES  When Conan O’Brien wanted to start a Web site last winter, he was reminded that he did not own his dot-com name, ConanOBrien.com.

headline: From the West Coast, a Punk Bronx Tale
text: After a decade spent grinding through the Los Angeles punk scene, a handful of talented, tattooed musicians formed a new band, one that promised an end to the indignities of begging promoters for shows and paying nightclubs for gigs.

headline: Say Cheese
text: For the last few years, Nora Sherman has photographed at least half of her meals and uploaded the pictures to her blog.

headline: Mourning in the Mountains
text: Charleston, W.Va.

headline: Iris Cafe, Bakeri and Culture Espresso Bar
text: A GREAT cup of coffee is enough to make any place a neighborhood favorite. And if that place also serves good food, with a couple of standouts, it could become a local institution.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Delicious Words

headline: Is Induction Cooking Ready to Go Mainstream?
text: LISA SIMPSON had been a professional cook, so when she remodeled her kitchen she was counting on a big, powerful gas range. But that would have meant installing a huge propane tank on her rural property outside Seattle. It would have been expensive, ugly and, in an area prone to earthquakes, nerve-racking.

headline: Midtown Extension of Momofuku to Open This Week
text: IN one sense, the wait will be over soon for Má Pêche, David Chang’s Midtown extension of his Momofuku brand and one of the more anticipated recent restaurant openings. It is expected to begin serving lunch later this week in the Chambers Hotel.

headline: Faustina
text: JEAN-CLAUDE IZZO wrote a terrific series of French noir novels, a Marseille trilogy of sun-baked bad guys and beautiful women, smart cops and mean situations. Mr. Izzo was a marvelous food writer in addition to being a poet of violence and regret. His books are filled with winning descriptions of Provençal meals run through with the flavors of north Africa, Italy, Greece. Also, violence. Of life in Marseille, Mr. Izzo wrote, “Even to lose, you have to know how to fight.”

headline: Ginger Ale From Bruce Cost Is Now in Stores
text: Bruce Cost, a partner in the Big Bowl Asian restaurant chain, is having the lip-smacking fresh ginger ale he sells in the restaurants bottled in Brooklyn for retail sale.

headline: London Meat Makes Products for Its Own Label
text: London Meat, a wholesaler that produces sausages and cured meats for store brands, now has its own line, Milano Suino d’Oro, or golden pig. Hot and sweet soppressata, rosemary-scented lardo (both above) and guanciale are highlights. It’s all made in the meatpacking district, though the pork, from Duroc pigs, is from Iowa.

headline: A Toaster With Glass Sides for Viewing
text: A new stainless-steel toaster has see-through insulated glass walls and a button that allows you to stop the toasting at any time, like reality TV at breakfast. It is designed in France by Robot-Coupe, which originated the food processor and first sold the toaster in Europe. This latest appliance has one-sided toasting for bagels, a button for defrosting and toasting simultaneously and a reheat button to warm the toast without further browning. A lever makes it easy to remove small pieces of toast, the ones that often require a fishing expedition in a regular toaster, and the glass walls tip out for cleaning.

headline: Heirloom Apple Crops Increase
text: Spring does not bring to mind apples, but with the start of the growing season a nonprofit group called Renewing America’s Food Traditions (RAFT), which works with Slow Food, has declared this the year of the heirloom apple.

headline: A Week With an Induction Burner
text: I SPENT a week with an All-Clad portable induction burner, a heavy silver and black unit that takes up about as much counter space as a Costco-size box of cereal.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings

headline: The Wild, Improbable Ride of the Last Mrs. Mailer
text: When Barbara Jean Davis  the future Norris Church Mailer  met Norman Mailer at a party in Russellville, Ark., in 1975, she was a high school art teacher and divorced single mother. She’d never flown in an airplane. She had a closet full of polyester clothes. When she took Mailer back to her house that first evening, she poured him a glass of Boone’s Farm apple wine.

headline: Checking in at Faustina
text: Faustina at the Cooper Square Hotel is reviewed this week.

headline: First Camera, Then Fork
text: JAVIER GARCIA, a 28-year-old neuroscientist at the University of California, Irvine, was in the campus pub recently having a grilled cheese sandwich. But before he took a bite, he snapped a digital picture of it, cheese artistically oozing between toasted white bread, just as he has photographed everything he has eaten in the last five years.

headline: Lawsuit Filed Over Eames Archives
text: One of the largest private archives documenting the mid-20th-century furniture designers Charles and Ray Eames has been withdrawn from an auction scheduled for Thursday because of a lawsuit contesting ownership. The paperwork, which fills more than 100 binders, was to be the top lot at a sale at Wright auction house in Chicago focused on furniture by the Eameses, known for their mass-produced contoured plywood and fiberglass chairs.

headline: Visual Artists to Sue Google Over Vast Library Project
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As Google awaits approval of a controversial settlement with authors and book publishers, the company’s plan to create an immense digital library and bookstore may face yet another hurdle.

headline: ‘A Ticket to the Circus’
text: Chapter 1

headline: What Are You Eating Right Now?
text: We want to see what’s for breakfast, lunch or dinner. Send us a photo and description of what you are eating, using this form or by e-mailing pix@nyt.com. The pictures will be posted throughout the day at nytimes.com/dining.

headline: How to Take Photos of Food
text: Andrew Scrivani, a freelance photographer and food stylist for The New York Times, is taking questions on how to photograph food. Andrew writes the food and photography blog Making Sunday Sauce. Post your question in the comments below and he will respond throughout the week. In the meantime, here are five basic tips on creating a successful food portrait.

headline: What We’re Reading: Videos, Design and Health Records
text: The tech editors and reporters of the New York Times were enjoying videos of a child’s encounter with an iPad and Hewlett Packard’s encounter with its slate computer as well as articles on health information and analysts’ wild estimates.

headline: AOL Plans to Sell or Shut Bebo Social Networking Site
text: Two years after AOL acquired the social networking site Bebo for $850 million, the company plans to sell or shut it.

headline: They Can’t Imagine
text: Jonathan Chait seems puzzled by a Michael Barone column in which Barone can’t imagine that a key part of the Obama stimulus plan, aid to state governments, had any purpose other than to reward unionized government workers. Chait’s puzzlement made me think of Ezra Klein’s somewhat similar puzzlement over a column by Shelby Steele, in which Steele attributed Obama’s push for health care reform to “grandiosity” and “narcissism” — never once mentioning that Obama might have, well, wanted to cover the uninsured.

headline: Pakistan Weighs Changes to Revise Constitution
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s Parliament opened debate on Tuesday on a set of amendments intended to refurbish the Constitution after decades of distortions inflicted by a series of military autocrats.

headline: G.O.P. Squirms as Spotlight Focuses on Its Leader
text: WASHINGTON — Michael Steele was hardly the consensus choice to become chairman of the Republican National Committee, scrambling to the top early last year after surviving multiple ballots in a crowded field.

headline: A Region’s Wounds Fester on Russia’s South Border
text: VLADIKAVKAZ, Russia — If anyone is still wondering why Russia finds itself entangled deeper and deeper in its attempt to pacify the Caucasus, Aslan Aushev, for one, would be happy to explain.

headline: Winfrey to Interview Rielle Hunter
text: Oprah Winfrey has arranged for the first televised interview with Rielle Hunter, the woman with whom John Edwards admitted to having an extramarital affair.

headline: Debt Rising in Europe
text: Greece is not the only country in Europe with problems with credit and debt.

headline: Immaculate Transfer Strikes Again
text: Oh, dear. Via Mark Thoma, I see that Joe Stiglitz has fallen victim to the doctrine of immaculate transfer:

headline: For Malone, a Much Smaller Piece of DirecTV
text: From Brian Stelter at Media Decoder:

headline: In Medicine, the Power of No
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Remembering Namir Noor-Eldeen
text: Updated, Wednesday, 4 p.m. | The writer, Michael Kamber, feels that some of his meaning may have been lost in the editing process. There is an addendum by him at the end of this blog post.

headline: Analysis of California Pensions Finds Half-Trillion-Dollar Gap
text: An independent analysis of California’s three big pension funds has found a hidden shortfall of more than half a trillion dollars, several times the amount reported by the funds and more than six times the value of the state’s outstanding bonds.

headline: Safety Issues at W.Va. Mine (NBC)
text: A video report highlighting the record of safety violations at the Massey Energy mine.

headline: Stanford Pushes, but Not Far Enough
text: SAN ANTONIO

headline: On Bench, a Link to Auriemma’s Past
text: SAN ANTONIO — Bud Gardler would like to say that he always knew Geno Auriemma had what it took to be a legend in his own time, but such unmitigated praise would require suppressing his acerbic side. And as Auriemma, a chip off the old coach, said, “He’s not exactly Mr. Sentimentality.”

headline: Finding the Strength of ‘Super Wonder Woman’ in Rejection
text: In a video blog post, Anne Paik, a high school senior in Los Angeles who was rejected by 11 of the 15 colleges and universities to which she applied (and wait-listed by a 12th), reflects further on the emotional fallout from that experience. Her previous post — in which she wrote, “I’ve been rejected and I’m still fabulous” — has drawn nearly 150 reader comments. — Jacques Steinberg

headline: Matsui Keeps His Production and His Following Rolling Out West
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — It was a quarter past 11 p.m., and the home dugout at Angel Stadium resembled a Tokyo subway car. Four dozen Japanese journalists — some standing, some sitting and almost all of them dressed in suits and ties — were waiting patiently to interview the former Yankee Hideki Matsui after his triumphant regular-season home debut.

headline: Latino to Lead Los Angeles Diocese
text: The Vatican has chosen Archbishop Jose H. Gomez — who was born in Mexico and became an American citizen while serving in Texas as a priest for the conservative Catholic organization Opus Dei — to become the next leader of the Archdiocese of Los Angeles, the largest Roman Catholic archdiocese in the country.

headline: Palestinians Try a Less Violent Path to Resistance
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Senior Palestinian leaders — men who once commanded militias — are joining unarmed protest marches against Israeli policies and are being arrested. Goods produced in Israeli settlements have been burned in public demonstrations. The Palestinian prime minister has entered West Bank areas officially off limits to his authority, to plant trees and declare the land part of a future state.

headline: Paris Prosecutor Investigating French Oil Firm
text: PARIS — The Paris prosecutor’s office confirmed on Tuesday that Total, the French oil giant, was being investigated in a corruption case linked to its role in the scandal-plagued oil-for-food program in Iraq.

headline: Who’s Up for Building Bridges?
text: I’m no expert on American politics, but I do know something about holes. And watching the way the Republican Party is reacting to the passage of health care, it seems to me the G.O.P. is violating the first rule of holes: “When you’re in one, stop digging.”

headline: In Australia, Interest Rate Is Raised a Fifth Time
text: HONG KONG — The Australian central bank raised its key interest rate Tuesday by a quarter of a percentage point to 4.25 percent, in a sign that it thought that the Australian economy was on solid enough footing to be weaned off the low rates.

headline: Mines Fight Strict Laws by Filing More Appeals
text: Armed with tougher federal mining laws passed in 2006, federal investigators had new powers to crack down on mines with persistent violations.

headline: From a Seat of Power to One on Greyhound
text: ABOARD GREYHOUND BUS No. 1026 — A half-hour north of Richmond, Va., Sharpe James fell asleep. His eyes were closed, his lips puckered open. His blue-and-silver tie was undone. If this had been a portrait, it might have borne the title “Disgraced Politician at Ease.”

headline: U.S. and Brazil Reach Agreement on Cotton Dispute
text: WASHINGTON — The United States and Brazil have reached an agreement aimed at settling a long-standing trade dispute over American subsidies to cotton growers, officials in both countries said Tuesday.

headline: Tupper's Prospect Park
text: As Tupper Thomas retires, her legacy in Prospect Park continues.

headline: A Red Sox Lineup With Less Power, but More Patience
text: BOSTON

headline: Iraq Video Brings Notice to a Web Site
text: Three months ago, WikiLeaks, a whistleblower Web site that posts classified and sensitive documents, put out an urgent call for help on Twitter.

headline: No Problem, Say Golfers in the Group With Woods
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Hunter Mahan stood beneath the large oak tree adjacent to the Augusta National clubhouse Tuesday as the playing groups for the first two rounds of this week’s Masters were revealed. With a reporter holding the pairings sheet in his hand, Mahan leaned over to read from it.

headline: At the Masters, Two Favorites Confront Obstacles
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The two golfers who have won combined to win half of the Masters tournaments played since the turn of the century are — surprise! — the two top favorites entering the 74th rite of spring starting Thursday at Augusta National Golf Club. But if either Tiger Woods, who has won three Masters since 2000, or Phil Mickelson, who has won two, is to win this year’s event, they will have significant obstacles to overcome.

headline: Greek Bond Yields Soar in Sell-Off
text: Investors fled Greek bonds on Tuesday, pushing up the cost of new borrowing for the debt-stricken nation and calling into question a joint rescue plan by the European Union and the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Why Tiger Matters
text: Every week I learn something from writing this column. Last week’s column taught me that if you want to bask in the adulation of your readers, you should avoid sounding like you disapprove of Tiger Woods’s off-the-course behavior.

headline: Ensnared by Error on Growing U.S. Watch List
text: Rahinah Ibrahim, a Stanford University doctoral student, arrived at San Francisco International Airport with her 14-year-old daughter for a 9 a.m. flight home to Malaysia. She asked for a wheelchair, having recently had a hysterectomy.

headline: Now Abloom on Staten Island: Flora, Potholes and Complaints
text: One month ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg helped fill what city officials said was the two millionth pothole repaired on the mayor’s watch.

headline: Abuse Crisis Strains Vatican’s Ancient Ways of Management
text: ROME — The sexual abuse scandal engulfing the Roman Catholic Church is by far the most tenacious and complex crisis Pope Benedict XVI has faced. And it is a crucial test for a papacy that many Vatican observers say has a deep internal flaw: its management.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 6, 2010

headline: City Fined Over Documents on Fatal Crane Collapse
text: A judge fined the Bloomberg administration $5,000 on Tuesday for repeatedly ignoring court orders to provide the families of two construction workers who died in a 2008 crane collapse with documents, e-mail messages and other information concerning equipment inspected by the city.

headline: U.S. Approves Targeted Killing of American Cleric
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has taken the extraordinary step of authorizing the targeted killing of an American citizen, the radical Muslim cleric Anwar al-Awlaki, who is believed to have shifted from encouraging attacks on the United States to directly participating in them, intelligence and counterterrorism officials said Tuesday.

headline: Mets Lead Majors in Flags but Would Prefer a Pennant
text: In the Mets’ opening day victory over the Florida Marlins, the Venezuelan starting pitcher Johan Santana threw six strong innings. He was replaced by his countryman Fernando Nieve, who shut down the Marlins in the seventh and eighth, and then Nieve gave way to Francisco Rodriguez, another Venezuelan, who tossed a perfect ninth.

headline: Obama’s Nuclear Strategy Intended as a Message
text: WASHINGTON — At the heart of President Obama’s new nuclear strategy lies a central gamble: that an aging, oversize, increasingly outmoded nuclear arsenal can be turned to the new purpose of adding leverage to the faltering effort to force Iran and North Korea to rethink the value of their nuclear programs.

headline: 27 Down: Rodeo Specialist
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — When I see a Richard Silvestri byline on a puzzle, there’s a 97 percent chance laughs will follow. Not necessarily knee-slapping pig-snorters, but a dose of chuckles and grins at the very least. Today’s puzzle didn’t disappoint.

headline: Off-Menu Goods Attract the Police’s Attention
text: The sign outside Chris Restaurant in Brooklyn listed some staples of Caribbean cuisine among its offerings: homemade fried chicken, jerk chicken and stew fish. But according to the authorities, there was one item that it apparently did not advertise, at least not openly — marijuana.

headline: An ‘Idol’ Ratings Loss, but Not in Its Pocketbook
text: THE hit show “American Idol” has been the playground bully of prime time for so long that it’s not surprising that long-suffering competitors relish every opportunity to tweak its sky-high nose.

headline: Another Twist in a Connecticut Triple-Murder Case
text: NEW HAVEN — Steven J. Hayes is charged with killing a mother and her two daughters in the town of Cheshire, Conn., in 2007. He faces the death penalty. And on Tuesday, he told a courtroom here that he would fight the charges.

headline: Man Gets at Least 20 Years in Murder on Nightclub Roof
text: Ingrid Estrada has had problems sleeping at night for more than a year and a half. She is sometimes listless at work, unable to get anything done. It hurts when she hears her 9-year-old son, Joshua, who has Down syndrome, ask for his sister. She cannot look at the roof of a building without horrific images flashing through her mind.

headline: South Africa Energy Needs Collide With U.S. Policy
text: JOHANNESBURG — The Obama administration, caught in an awkward bind between its own ambitions on climate change and Africa’s pressing energy needs, is facing the first test of its new guidelines discouraging coal-fired power projects in developing nations.

headline: Fire at Shoeshine Stand Seemed Random, the First Time
text: Three weeks ago, a shoeshine stand outside Bryant Park burned down in the night. There seemed to be no motive or suspect, suggesting that the fire was a random act of violence.

headline: St. Vincent’s Votes to Shut Hospital in Manhattan
text: The board of St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers voted on Tuesday night to close its flagship hospital in Greenwich Village, ending its long struggle to stay afloat despite millions of dollars of debt.

headline: Wilma Mankiller, Cherokee Chief and First Woman to Lead Major Tribe, Is Dead at 64
text: Wilma Mankiller, who as the first woman to be elected chief of a major American Indian tribe revitalized the Cherokee Nation’s tribal government and improved its education, health and housing, died Tuesday at her home near Tahlequah, Okla. She was 64.

headline: Underground Fire Disrupts Midtown
text: A buildup of carbon monoxide under a Midtown street caused an underground fire and a manhole explosion Tuesday afternoon, prompting the evacuation of four buildings near Times Square, the authorities said.

headline: Corin Redgrave, Actor and Activist, Dies at 70
text: Corin Redgrave, a versatile actor and ardent left-wing political activist who, as the son of Michael Redgrave and the brother of Vanessa and Lynn Redgrave, was the prince of the royal family of English theater, died on Tuesday in London. He was 70.

headline: Rangers Stumble in Their Run to Playoffs
text: BUFFALO — All those victories and all those points, and now one defeat may have undone everything.

headline: Mexico: 25,000 Affected by Quake
text: The earthquake that struck Baja California on Sunday has affected an estimated 25,000 people, the state’s governor said Tuesday. The governor, José Guadalupe Osuna Millán, said that the 7.2-magnitude quake caused the worst damage in the rural area south of the city of Mexicali, and that more than 5,000 families had reported that their homes were destroyed or damaged. The earthquake killed two people and injured more than 200.

headline: Malone Trims DirecTV Stake
text: John C. Malone, DirecTV’s single largest shareholder and its board chairman, is divesting most of his voting shares in the satellite television company.

headline: Robinson Still Trying to Settle in With Celtics
text: For two seasons, the Knicks have slashed, purged and repeated in order to trim payroll in an attempt to attract star players through free agency. How does a center who can haul in 18 rebounds and score 17 points against the playoff-bound Boston Celtics resonate?

headline: Thames’s Start in Left May Be the First of Many
text: BOSTON — On Tuesday night, in their second game of the season, the Yankees started a player in left field who joined the team in February on a minor league deal.

headline: Philippe Braunschweig, Prix de Lausanne Founder, Dies at 82
text: Philippe Braunschweig, the heir to a Swiss watchmaking fortune who founded the innovative and prestigious Prix de Lausanne ballet competition for young dancers, died on April 3 in Vevey, Switzerland. He was 82 and lived in Vevey.

headline: Taxpayer Could Have Kept the $600, but He Put His Country First
text: A flaw in the most recent version of TurboTax, the nation’s most popular tax-preparation software, may have caused thousands of retired federal employees to overstate their medical deductions and unwittingly underpay the Internal Revenue Service, according to federal officials.

headline: Inside the West Virginia Mine Explosion
text: Monday’s explosion at the Upper Big Branch mine in West Virginia killed 25 miners, injured two and left four missing.

headline: What Are You Eating Right Now?
text: Readers submitted photos of whatever happened to be on their plate.

headline: Nonprofit Group Will Prod Companies to Report Their Water Use
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The Carbon Disclosure Project, an investor-backed nonprofit organization that has persuaded some of the world’s largest corporations to disclose their greenhouse gas emissions, will announce on Wednesday that it is asking 302 global companies to begin issuing detailed reports on their water use.

headline: Moore Leads Connecticut to Women’s Title
text: SAN ANTONIO — Sometimes, the best coaching tactic is a desperate plea to a team’s best player. Stand up. Do something. Show us the way.

headline: Expensive Language Lessons? Doesn’t Translate
text: At the beginning of this year, I made a resolution to learn to speak Spanish and Mandarin Chinese, two of the most commonly used languages on the planet and the keys to travel over a great swath of the world.

headline: The Church’s Judas Moment
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Wednesday about an apparently coordinated hacking assault on the Yahoo e-mail accounts of a dozen rights advocates, academics and journalists who cover China included three errors. A 2005 transaction between Yahoo and Alibaba, a Chinese e-commerce company, that gave Alibaba control of Yahoo’s China operations was a sale  not a merger. The year that Yahoo turned over data that Chinese officials used to help prosecute several dissidents was 2004, not 2006. And local Chinese service providers  not Yahoo  maintain the servers in China used to store e-mail sent through Yahoo’s Chinese domain, which are considered relatively vulnerable to intrusions and have driven privacy-conscious Chinese away.

headline: Another Mining Tragedy
text: Representative Nick Rahall II, a Democrat from the district in West Virginia where disaster struck deep in the Upper Big Branch mine, summed up the mixture of sorrow and suspicion that followed the worst American mining catastrophe in a quarter-century.

headline: Mean Girls Aren’t a Myth. They’re All Too Real.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mr. Obama’s Nuclear Policy
text: President Obama has spoken eloquently about his vision of a world without nuclear weapons. It is a lofty goal that will not be achieved during his presidency  or for years after that. But in a very dangerous time, he is taking important steps to make the world safer and bolster this country’s credibility as it tries to constrain the nuclear ambitions of Iran, North Korea and others.

headline: We Won’t Bet on OTB
text: After years of mismanagement, a work force padded with patronage employees and a dwindling public interest in wagering on the horses, the corporation that runs New York City’s off-track betting parlors filed for bankruptcy protection late last year. Unless something is done, the betting parlors could start closing next week. Some lawmakers in Albany are calling for a taxpayer bailout. That is a bad idea. The New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation must find a way to pay its operating costs or the state will have to pay to close it down.

headline: It Happened on Wall St. and Main St.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Labor Board Appointee
text: To the Editor:

headline: How to Save Afghanistan From Karzai
text: IN February, the Taliban sanctuary of Marja in southern Afghanistan was attacked in the largest operation of the war. Last week, President Obama flew to Afghanistan and declared, “Our troops have pushed the Taliban out of their stronghold in Marja .... The United States of America does not quit once it starts on something.”

headline: The Labor Department Wakes Up
text: The Department of Labor has begun a long-overdue campaign to protect workers’ rights, a core part of its job that was sorely neglected in the fiercely antiregulatory Bush era. The campaign, “We Can Help,” uses public-service announcements, a Web site and a phone hot line to encourage workers  particularly those in construction, janitorial fields, hotels, food services and home health care  to report employer abuses. It also adds 250 investigators, a one-third increase, to the department’s wage and hour division.

headline: Man Charged in Shooting of 2 in Times Sq. Melee
text: A 20-year-old man was arrested Tuesday afternoon on charges that he shot two women during the sprawling melee near Times Square on Sunday night, the police said.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about an effort to replace the likeness of President Ulysses S. Grant on the $50 bill with that of President Ronald Reagan referred incorrectly to Parker Poling, whose boss, Representative Patrick T. McHenry, Republican of North Carolina, is leading the effort. Parker Poling, Mr. McHenry’s chief of staff, is a woman.

headline: A Case for Annual Stress Tests
text: Improving bank regulation may call for a little more stress. The disclosure and discipline imposed by the Federal Reserve’s stress tests of big banks a year ago drew a line under the crisis. The tests separated sheep from goats and led to tens of billions of dollars of new capital being raised. It’s a shame that stress tests aren’t becoming an annual event.

headline: Corrections
text: The Seattle Journal article on Friday, about efforts by officials to make the city more welcoming and conducive to children, misstated part of the name of a waterfront park that posts “Please Don’t Touch” signs. It is Olympic Sculpture Park, not Seattle Sculpture Park.

headline: This Time, Bullpen Holds as Yankees Get Win No. 1
text: BOSTON — About 1,400 miles from here, Phil Hughes was sitting in his condominium in Tampa, Fla., on Sunday night watching the Red Sox throttle the Yankees’ bullpen. Hughes used to be part of that group, a big part, but he has moved on.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about information gathered by New York City showing the most popular places to find a cab at any hour during the week referred incorrectly to Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. It is the busiest train station in the United States, not the world.

headline: California: City Offices Will Go Dark
text: With Los Angeles teetering toward a major fiscal crisis, Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa on Tuesday asked the city administrative officer to shut down all city agencies — except for public safety and those that generate revenue — for two days per week beginning next week. Mr. Villaraigosa’s order comes on the heels of the city controller’s warning that the city might be unable to pay employees and vendors within four weeks. The city has been pressing the Department of Water and Power for its $73.5-million contribution to the treasury, which the agency has declined to pay after the City Council recently rejected its proposed electricity rate increase.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about the rise in drama programming on cable channels erroneously included an ABC drama on a list of shows that have failed in the 10 p.m. prime-time slot on network television. The show, “The Deep End,” was shown at 8 p.m.

headline: California: If It’s Monday, It’s Veggies
text: Tuesday was a good day for vegetables — and San Franciscans who love them — as the city’s Board of Supervisors passed a nonbinding resolution declaring every Monday as “meat-free.” The resolution, sponsored by Supervisor Sophie Maxell, a vegetarian, urges restaurants, stores and schools to offer “plant-based options” every Monday to improve the general civic health. Ms. Maxwell tied the measure to the fight against global warning and said it would “encourage citizens to choose vegetarian foods as a way to protect the planet and their health.” The board also passed a nonbinding resolution commending businesses that use only cage-free eggs. Ms. Maxwell invited the entire board to her office “for a vegetarian treat.”

headline: Illinois: The Obamas’ New Neighbors
text: The Obamas will soon have new next-door neighbors in Chicago: the 6,000-square-foot house at 5040 South Greenwood Avenue, a 17-room, century-old, fixer-upper next to the Hyde Park residence of the Obamas, sold Tuesday for $1.4 million. Matt Garrison, the listing agent, and the owners, Bill and Jacky Grimshaw, had not put an asking price on the property when it went on the market in September because they were not sure what the “Obama effect” would be. They had hoped to get a record-breaking price. But the effect proved less powerful than anticipated. “At the end of the day, the property traded to a local buyer for what we felt was a very fair price,” Mr. Garrison said. The buyers were not publicly identified. The property’s estimated value in 2009 was $1.19 million, according to the Cook County Assessor’s Office.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Tuesday about Duke’s victory on Monday in the championship game of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament erroneously included one Duke player among those on past teams who were high first-round N.B.A. draft picks. The player, Carlos Boozer, was a second-round pick, in 2002.

headline: Massachusetts: Not-Guilty Pleas in Bullying
text: Lawyers entered pleas of not guilty Tuesday for three students who face charges related to the bullying of Phoebe Prince, a 15-year-old student at South Hadley High School who committed suicide. Sean Mulveyhill, 17, and Kayla Narey, 17, are charged with violation of civil rights, criminal harassment and disruption of a school assembly, all felonies. Mr. Mulveyhill and Austin Renaud, 18, are charged with statutory rape. The students did not appear in court on Tuesday. Prosecutors said Ms. Prince was subjected to relentless taunts and physical threats before she killed herself on Jan. 14. Three other students will appear in court on Thursday to face felony charges.

headline: Those Melodic Sounds, From Mysterious Spaces
text: Walking through the streets in and around New York City, you hear all sorts of sounds: cars, footsteps, the occasional argument, and, of course, music.

headline: Corrections
text: The On Basketball column on Tuesday, about the push-pull relationship between Tara VanDerveer, the Stanford women’s coach, and one of her players, misspelled the player’s surname in some editions. She is Rosalyn Gold-Onwude, not Gold-Owunde.

headline: N. Korea Sentences American to Hard Labor
text: SEOUL, South Korea — An American man who was arrested in North Korea for illegal entry was sentenced to eight years of hard labor, the North’s state-run news agency reported on Wednesday.

headline: How to Turn Your Blog’s Readers Into Paying Customers
text: We already know that everyone from Ashton Kutcher to Don Draper, the slick ad man on “Mad Men,” could build a loyal following on Twitter, Facebook, blogs and other social sites.

headline: Upbeat Signs Revive Consumers’ Mood for Spending
text: American consumers are finally coming out of hiding.

headline: Study Finds More Woes Following Foster Care
text: Only half the youths who had turned 18 and “aged out” of foster care were employed by their mid-20s. Six in 10 men had been convicted of a crime, and three in four women, many of them with children of their own, were receiving some form of public assistance. Only six in 100 had completed even a community college degree.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the Bats roundup in some editions on Saturday about the Mets’ final cuts before the new baseball season misstated the given name of a pitcher who was let go on Friday. He is Kiko Calero, not Kiki.

headline: Deadly Blasts in Baghdad
text: Bombings shook Baghdad for the second time in three days, killing 35 people and wounding more than 140.

headline: Word of the Day | curmudgeon
text: curmudgeon •\(ˌ)kər-ˈmə-jən\• noun

headline: Two Rough Games for Ortiz
text: BOSTON – Everybody in the stands, the press box and the dugout understands that the season is two games old. It is far, far too early to make snap judgments on anybody. But this is all the baseball we’ve seen in 2010.

headline: Corrections
text: A television review on Friday about “Miami Medical,” on CBS, misspelled the surname of the actress who plays Dr. Eva Zambrano. As a listing of credits with the review noted, she is Lana Parrilla, not Parilla.

headline: Corrections
text: A headline on a capsule summary in some editions on Monday about China’s new ambassador to North Korea misidentified the location of a weekend party welcoming him to the country. It was in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang  not, of course, in the South Korean capital of Seoul. (The article, which noted the correct location, was written from Seoul.)

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: News Quiz | April 7, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Greek Bond Yields Soar in Sell-Off
text: Investors fled Greek bonds on Tuesday, pushing up the cost of new borrowing for the debt-stricken nation and calling into question a joint rescue plan by the European Union and the International Monetary Fund.

headline: See No Evil
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s elections were a photographer’s dream. Millions of people turning out to vote, long lines at the ballot boxes, and everywhere photogenically purple fingers being held aloft for camera and television lenses.

headline: S.E.C. to Push for Disclosure on Mortgage-Backed Paper
text: Remember mortgage-backed securities? They were the go-go house of cards that collapsed and nearly brought down the financial system, helping usher in the recession. In response, lawmakers and government agencies have been trying to lay down stricter rules for asset-backed securities, The Associated Press reported.

headline: High-Speed Trading May Soon Be Regulated
text: United States securities regulators may formulate a plan to improve oversight of high-frequency trading by keeping track of executed transactions, The Wall Street Journal said, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Google Deal for AdMob Under the Gun at F.T.C.
text: Lawyers at the Federal Trade Commission  plan to recommend that the government try to block Google‘s proposed acquisition of mobile advertising firm AdMob on antitrust grounds, a source familiar with the matter told Reuters.

headline: Film Department Tweaks I.P.O. Size Again
text: The Film Department cut the expected price range for its initial public offering Tuesday, as the company continued its effort to raise funds by selling stock to investors.

headline: Fact-Checking the Web
text: WHO are David and Barbara Mikkelson?

headline: Union Expresses Concern Over Salaries
text: The Major League Baseball Players Association is considering, among a number of options, filing a grievance accusing owners of conspiring to suppress player salaries this past winter.

headline: Raymond James Settles With Wells Fargo
text: Raymond James Financial said on Tuesday that it had reached a confidential settlement in a brokerage raiding case with Wells Fargo, Reuters reported.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Wednesday about tomatoes grown in giant greenhouses misidentified a variety that Backyard Farms in Maine produces. It is a cocktail tomato on the vine, not a cherry tomato on the vine.

headline: Corrections
text: A brief report last Wednesday in the Off the Menu column about the opening of the restaurant Zengo referred imprecisely to its menu. It serves a fusion of Asian and Latin American food, not Asian and Mexican food, and its tequila bar serves Mexican street food, not just tacos.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Wednesday about the Irish food writer and cooking teacher Darian Allen misspelled the surname of a chef who has studied with Ms. Allen. She is Abra Berens, not Behrens.

headline: What Are You Doing This Summer?
text: Though the economy may be improving, job prospects for young people remain dim. What do you plan to do this summer? What summer options for work, education, entertainment or other kinds of enrichment are there in your area? What would you consider a summer well spent?

headline: Cohen’s Ex-Wife Says She’s Owed a Piece of SAC
text: The ex-wife of Steven A. Cohen, already suing her former husband for millions of dollars in damages, now claims the trader cheated her out a piece of his $12 billion hedge-fund empire.

headline: Making a Case for Annual Stress Tests
text: Improving bank regulation may call for a little more stress, Breakingviews says. The disclosure and discipline imposed by the Federal Reserve’s stress tests of big banks a year ago drew a line under the crisis. The tests separated sheep from goats and led to tens of billions of dollars of new capital being raised. It’s a shame that stress tests aren’t becoming an annual event, the publication says.

headline: ‘How to Save the World’ Wins Web Video Contest
text: How to fight climate change? Well, you could start by just saving some electricity. Or saying no to plastic bags. Or turning off the tap while you brush your teeth.

headline: Wall Street Turns Mixed at the End of Day
text: Wall Street traders were cautious on Tuesday amid worries that the European Union’s plan to help Greece might unwind. But signs that the Federal Reserve would keep interest rates low helped give stocks some support, The New York Times’s Javier C. Hernandez reported.

headline: How This Half Lives
text: On a recent Monday afternoon in the East Village, the 32-year-old upstart photographer Todd Selby — more commonly known as the Selby — was entertaining a guest in his modest ground-floor studio. One of the two monitors on which he creates his teeming online gallery, The Selby Is in Your Place, was tuned to a Web site called Unhappy Hipsters. The idea behind the site — which that week was reaching something of a viral mass — is pretty straightforward: cut and paste a selection of those placid, sparsely populated house shots from magazines like Dwell and run the snarkiest captions imaginable beneath them. “He’d become a caricature of what it meant to be a young, monied follower” is a typical entry. “Oh, my God,” Selby said, scrolling through the site with what appeared to be a mixture of astonishment and appreciation, as if meeting a fellow traveler. After all, Selby’s vérité approach to photographing personal spaces is precisely in tune with the urge to skewer those magazines that celebrate sleek minimalism while scorning clutter like the long-suffering mother of a teenage son.

headline: Thai Protesters Storm Parliament
text: BANGKOK — Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva of Thailand declared a state of emergency in the Bangkok area on Wednesday after antigovernment demonstrators broke into the Parliament building, forcing government ministers to flee by helicopter.

headline: Goldman Denies Conflict of Interest on Subprime
text: Goldman Sachs, in its annual letter Wednesday, denies the charge that it “bet against” its own clients at the height of the subprime mortgage crisis.

headline: Tengion Seeks to Pocket $44.4 Million in I.P..O
text: Tengion, a regenerative medicine company, plans to raise as much as $44.4 million in an initial public offering of stock this week.

headline: Stitcher Sews Up $6 Million
text: Stitcher, a service that allows listeners to stream radio shows and podcasts on mobile devices, has received $6 million in a second round of funding, PaidContent reported.

headline: Automaker Pensions Underfunded by $17 Billion
text: The pension plans at General Motors and Chrysler are underfunded by a total of $17 billion and could fail if the automakers do not return to profitability, The New York Times’s Nick Bunkley reported, citing a government report released Tuesday.

headline: Infogroup Investor Blasts Proposed Sale Price
text: An investment firm that holds nearly 6 percent of the stock of  Infogroup, a database provider, says the proposed sale of the company to the private equity firm CCMP Capital Advisors is priced too low, The Associated Press reported, citing documents released Tuesday.

headline: Metals USA Aims for $200 Million in I.P.O.
text: Metals USA Holdings is hoping to raise as much as $200 million in an initial public offering this week, The Associated Press reported.

headline: American Idol: Growing More Like a Circus
text: Casey James > Michael Lynche > Crystal Bowersox > Tim Urban > Lee DeWyze > Katie Stevens > Siobhan Magnus > Andrew Garcia > Aaron Kelly

headline: JAL Said to Plan 16,500 Layoffs to Save $870 Million
text: Japan Airlines plans to reduce its work force by a third within the fiscal year to lower labor costs by 81.7 billion yen ($870 million) a year, The Nikkei, a business daily, said.

headline: Son of Venture Capitalist Gets Foursquare Badge for Polar Trip
text: Normally if you’re the teenage child of a multimillionaire, you might expect a nice car or designer clothing as a present, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Blockbuster Agrees to Payment Terms With Studios
text: Blockbuster, the indebted video retail chain, agreed to payment terms with two movie studios that will allow it to rent DVDs on the same day they go on sale, the company said in a statement Tuesday, Reuters reported.

headline: R.B.S. Kicks Off Bond Restructuring Scheme
text: Royal Bank of Scotland on Tuesday started its planned bond exchange and buyback to restructure up to £15.8 billion ($24 billion) of debt, hitting prices of a few lower ranked bonds, Reuters reported.

headline: Macarthur Coal Cool to Peabody Energy’s Bid
text: Macarthur Coal discouraged its shareholders on Wednesday from taking action on Peabody Energy‘s increased takeover bid, worth 3.56 billion Australian dollars, and instead to wait for a board vote on an acquisition attempt by Macarthur.

headline: Upheaval in Kyrgyzstan Could Imperil Key U.S. Base
text: MOSCOW — The president of Kyrgyzstan was forced to flee the capital, Bishkek, on Wednesday after bloody protests erupted across the country over his repressive rule, a backlash that could pose a threat to the American military supply line into nearby Afghanistan.

headline: Jets’ Executive Chef Has Personal Touch
text: Jets tight end Dustin Keller, who is a budding restaurateur, will write a food column once a month for the Fifth Down. He’ll also answer football questions from readers. Post your question in the comments section.Playing in the N.F.L. is awesome. I’m very grateful that it’s something I get to do for a living. I know a lot of people would love to have this job, and I don’t ever take it for granted. You get a lot of perks playing in the league, and one of my favorites is the food. Which is why I hired the Jets’ executive chef, John Canniezaro, to come to my house to prepare my meals during the off-season.

headline: Prado Pairs ‘Las Meninas’ With American Masterpiece
text: This spring at the Prado Museum (museodelprado.es), an exhibition pays homage to that institution’s — and perhaps Spain’s — most treasured painting, “Las Meninas” (1656) by Velázquez. In what is likely to be a true once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston has lent John Singer Sargent’s famous painting “The Daughters of Edward Darley Boit” (1882), which many art historians call the “American Meninas” to be displayed next to the Velázquez painting. The loan is part of the Prado’s series of “Invited Work” exhibitions, which bring individual works of special importance or resonance to the museum, to be seen in proximity to the Prado’s collection.

headline: Automakers Unveil Partnership
text: Renault, Nissan Motor and Daimler said on Wednesday that they would swap stakes and jointly develop cars in a tie-up to gain scale and share costs, Reuters reported.

headline: Sears and Lampert Win Dismissal of Kmart Fraud Suit
text: A federal appeals court said that Sears Holdings was not liable to former Kmart Holding shareholders who accused the retailer of trying to drive down Kmart’s stock price to let executives buy shares cheaply.

headline: The Plunge Into Poverty That Wasn’t
text: Today’s idea: The global economic downturn was supposed to throw masses of people in the developing world back into poverty. It didn’t, says a columnist.

headline: Masters Offers a Glimpse of 3-D Internet
text: In movies, 3-D has certainly come of age. There is the record-setting “Avatar,” of course, and only last week “Clash of the Titans” and “Alice in Wonderland” delivered the biggest Easter weekend box office on record.

headline: Putin Marks Soviet Massacre of Polish Officers
text: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin on Wednesday became the first Russian or Soviet leader to join Polish officials in commemorating the anniversary of the murder of thousands of Polish officers by the Soviet Union at the beginning of World War II.

headline: Ford Gets $1.75 Billion in High-Yield Bond Sale
text: Ford Motor‘s finance arm sold $1.75 billion of five-year debt, taking advantage of investor demand for high-yield bonds, on pace for the longest rally since 1996, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Barclays Seeks Lehman Assets Despite Trustee Disputes
text: Barclays has asked a court to let it keep billions of dollars in Lehman Brothers Holdings assets, even though the trustee of the bankrupt investment bank says the remaining Lehman customers should probably get them, Reuters reported.

headline: I.M.F. Meeting With Greek Officials Over Reforms
text: Inspectors from the International Monetary Fund will meet Greece’s finance minister to find ways to speed up fiscal reforms, as the debt-plagued country continues to grapple with volatile borrowing costs, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Verizon Chief Sees No Appeal in Vodafone Merger
text: The top executive of Verizon Communications‘ dismissed speculation his company would merge with wireless venture partner Vodafone Group, saying such a deal would offer little benefit, Reuters reported.

headline: Buyout Shops Said to Circle R.B.S Unit
text: While the sale of hundreds of Royal Bank of Scotland branches has gotten the most attention in recent days, a slew of bidders are also reportedly lining up for another asset the government-owned  bank has put on the block.

headline: Will Greece Reverse Course on Hedge Funds?
text: As investors fled Greek bonds on Tuesday, pushing up the cost of new borrowing for the debt-stricken nation, the country may now be forced to reverse its policy of shutting out hedge funds when it starts its upcoming bond offering, The Telegraph reported.
