headline: As Rescue Efforts Continue for Miners, Officials Press for Answers
text: MONTCOAL, W.Va. — As rescue workers waited anxiously on Wednesday to re-enter the Upper Big Branch mine where at least 25 people were killed in a deadly blast this week, federal officials said two safety citations were made against the mine’s operator on the day of the explosion.

headline: Transgender Film Draws Protests at Festival Site
text: Transgender and transsexual women and men and their supporters gathered outside Tribeca Cinemas Tuesday evening to demand the removal of what they called a transphobic film from the Tribeca Film Festival lineup.

headline: Cabrera Goes From Pauper Caddie to Prince of the Greens
text: Reluctant to embrace the spotlight, particularly if English is being spoken there, Ángel Cabrera has been well served this week as he has prepared to defend his Masters title.

headline: Comeback Déjà Vu, or One of a Kind?
text: No longer master of the universe or even of his own image, Tiger Woods has succeeded in remaining the talk of the Masters in this season and situation unlike any other.

headline: Sampler: Sex Abuse by a Swim Coach, and Engineers Create Towel-Folding Robot
text: Half-Trillion-Dollar Shortfall in State Pension Funds | An independent analysis of California’s three big pension funds has found a hidden shortfall of more than half a trillion dollars, several times the amount reported by the funds and more than six times the value of the state’s outstanding bonds. The analysis was commissioned by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, who has been pressing the State Legislature to focus on the rising cost of public pensions. Graduate students identified the shortfall in the three funds serving more than 2.6 million people — the state-run employees’ pension fund, known as Calpers; a second large fund for teachers, known as Calstrs; and the University of California Retirement System. The researchers offered recommendations for closing the gap, including revamping the benefit structure. [The New York Times]

headline: Countries Urged to Plan for End of Stimulus
text: PARIS — An international financial organization urged advanced economies on Wednesday to begin laying the groundwork now so that next year they could start removing economic stimulus measures.

text: So just how much will Jon S. Corzine, who spent more than three decades at Goldman Sachs before using his vast fortune to start a career in politics as a New Jersey senator and governor, get for his return to Wall Street?

headline: WikiLeaks Draws Attention for Iraq Video
text: WikiLeaks, a Web site with offices across the globe that specializes in uncovering information that governments and other powerful interests would rather keep hidden, has drawn sudden attention because of its release Monday of a startling and graphic video showing a United States Army assault in Baghdad in 2007 that left 12 people dead, including two employees of the Reuters news agency. Noam Cohen and Brian Stelter write in The New York Times that while the group uses digital technology to uncover its scoops, it offers a mix of fact and advocacy that some find troubling. They write:

text: I.B.M. and a Saudi Arabian research institute are collaborating to develop a desalination plant powered by a new type of solar technology.

headline: From Trains to Planes, Europe Faces Strikes
text: Work stoppages are in the news. Bloomberg News is reporting, French train drivers began their third strike this year. Network Rail signal workers considered reviving a strike plan blocked by a British court. Deutsche Lufthansa pilots may strike this month. And British Airways could face another round of stoppages by flight attendants.

headline: The Early Word: The Bandwidth Plays On
text: The chief appeals court that oversees federal regulations delivered a body blow to the Federal Communications Commission by ruling that the agency lacks the explicit statutory authority to require that Internet service providers treat all customers and Web sites equally, regardless of how much or what kind of information they download or deliver.

headline: Toyota Canada Says It Learned of Pedal Repair Procedure Later Than Europe

text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely – but not strictly – by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, although the future isn’t utterly ignored. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: A Call for the Fed to Raise Rates Unsettles Investors
text: Wall Street investors were rattled on Wednesday by the prospect of higher interest rates and new signs that consumers were reluctant to spend again.

headline: Met, Where Is Thy Sting? (He’s Coming in July.)
text: 11:20 a.m. | Updated If you thought you saw a familiar, nattily attired Englishman poking around Lincoln Center in recent days, you might well have spotted Sting inspecting the Metropolitan Opera as he prepares to perform there as part of an orchestra tour this summer.

headline: The Visual Thing
text: There are lots of things I miss about the late, great graphic designer Alan Fletcher, but the thing I miss the most is arguing with him about design. Some of our most enjoyable arguments involved how to explain design to the 99 percent of the population that Alan pityingly described as “civilians” — in other words, those of us who aren’t lucky enough to be designers.

headline: Fed Reviews Find Errors in Oversight of Citigroup
text: WASHINGTON — Citigroup ran into trouble under the noses of federal regulators. But even after taxpayers rescued the financial giant, regulators failed to monitor the company adequately, according to reviews by the Federal Reserve.

headline: One Museum Tour, With Everything!
text: Dan Rossi, the lone survivor of the notorious hot dog wars outside the Metropolitan Museum of Art, takes a break from his grill, to give his own inimitable take on the art inside.

headline: Building a Green Economy
text: If you listen to climate scientists — and despite the relentless campaign to discredit their work, you should — it is long past time to do something about emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases. If we continue with business as usual, they say, we are facing a rise in global temperatures that will be little short of apocalyptic. And to avoid that apocalypse, we have to wean our economy from the use of fossil fuels, coal above all.

headline: Kobe Bryant’s Contract Extension
text: The Lakers took Kobe Bryant off the market last week, signing their franchise player to a three-year extension on Friday. Bryant had the option to become an unrestricted free agent this summer and join players like LeBron James on the open market. Instead he chose to lock in with the Lakers through the 2013-14 season.

headline: ‘Speaking at the Alcohol Convention’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: You know what happened in Las Vegas today? Sarah Palin, former governor of Alaska, was speaking at the alcohol convention in Las Vegas, Nev. Because, I mean, let’s face it, nothing says family values like gambling and liquor.

headline: ‘162,000 Jobs’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Well, the Labor Department reported that the economy added 162,000 jobs last month, all of them bodyguards for Tiger Woods.

headline: G.M.’s $4.3 Billion Loss Masks Progress
text: DETROIT — The first detailed financial report from General Motors since its bankruptcy showed a company that has largely stanched the hemorrhaging in its day-to-day business, but is still cleaning up problems left over from its collapse last year.

headline: Decoder Online Interview: Ad Age Columnist Bob Garfield Types a Final -30-
text: For the past 25 years, Bob Garfield has written the AdReview column for Advertising Age, but on Monday he filed for the last time. AdReview was a witty and sometimes withering deconstruction of all manner of advertising campaigns that had many fans. But Mr. Garfield said he was hanging it up, in part, because, “if my grand apocalyptic theories about advertising and media are correct, that’s a lot of my eggs in a couple of quickly disintegrating baskets.”

headline: Blackstone Invests in World’s ‘Most-Read’ Paper
text: Talk all you want about the structural decline of the industry, at least somebody thinks newspapers are a good investment.

headline: How Buying a Truck Can Create Cash Flow
text: April 15 is drawing closer, and somehow it doesn’t seem as scary as usual — at least not to those of us who weren’t very profitable last year. But if you’re planning to make money this year, you might want to think ahead.

headline: Building Webs of Support for People With B.D.D. and Eating Disorders
text: Overview | What do you know about psychiatric disorders that cause people to obsess over a physical feature? How can a community of parents, peers, teachers, doctors and psychiatric professionals best help and support someone with one of these disorders? In this lesson, students reflect on stories of teenagers with body dysmorphic disorder, or B.D.D., and eating disorders. By drawing and discussing support webs around each story, groups investigate the disorders from the perspectives of the individual affected and the people in their lives.

headline: Video | The Making of ‘Hedge Fun’
text: Those beautiful photos in the cover story of the April 11th Spring issue of T Design, “Hedge Fun,” didn’t take themselves. As this exclusive video demonstrates, behind the scenes and on-set, a small army of creative people, including the photographer Ilan Rubin and the set designer Stefan Beckman, worked away to create just the right composition, backdrop and lighting, among other things. But if the photos themselves look effortless, that’s exactly the point. See our cover story here.

headline: Net Neutrality: Not Just a Nerd Issue
text: The U.S. Court of Appeals ruled that the FCC overstepped its bounds in telling Comcast it could not regulate bandwidth use. So what if your Internet provider could charge you for what you use?

headline: Wednesday Reading
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: ‘Lost’ Watch: Desmond Agonistes
text: Warning: This post contains spoilers.

headline: On Eating Sustainable Fish
text: Casson Trenor, who works with Greenpeace on seafood issues, dropped by the Times the other day, and we sat and chatted for a while. My main question for him was, “What are people supposed to do?” Servers in restaurants and clerks in supermarkets are usually ignorant of what they’re serving and selling.

headline: G.M.’s $4.3 Billion Loss Masks Progress
text: General Motors said Wednesday that it lost $4.3 billion in the six months after emerging from bankruptcy protection, but that it had positive cash flow of $1 billion in that period, The New York Times’s Nick Bunkley reported.

headline: Pressure Builds on Greece as Europe Delays Details on Crisis Aid
text: With investors becoming increasingly worried about the failure so far of European officials to agree on the terms for loans to Greece, the main banks in Athens added another concern Wednesday by turning to the Greek government for more financial support.

headline: Court to FCC: Back Off on ‘Net Neutrality’
text: As Edward Wyatt wrote on Wednesday, a federal court ruled that the F.C.C. overstepped by telling Comcast it could not limit the amount of broadband available to certain heavy users.

headline: Atlanta Symphony and Dallas Opera Appoint New Leaders
text: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra and the Dallas Opera have appointed new executive leaders, the organizations announced Wednesday.

headline: For Writers, a Less Lonely Life
text: Remember when book writing used to be a solitary experience? If you needed feedback, you’d e-mail (or fax or mail) a few pages to a trusted friend and hope that he or she wouldn’t trash your efforts.

headline: New Tools to Build Your Own Credit Card
text: In late 2007, Capital One introduced a card customization tool it called Card Lab, where customers could chose certain combinations of rates, fees and rewards and customize the look of their cards.

headline: Toyota Chief Blames Communication for Crisis
text: Toyota’s chief executive, Akio Toyoda, told investment analysts on Wednesday the company felt communication was to blame for the crisis surrounding the company, not defects on its cars.

headline: Madman, Perhaps; Survivor, Definitely
text: DENNIS HOPPER  actor, filmmaker, photographer, art collector, world-class burnout, first-rate survivor  never blew it. Unlike the villains and freaks he has played over the decades  the psycho with the mommy complex in “Blue Velvet,” the mad bomber with the grudge in “Speed”  he has made it through the good, the bad and some spectacularly terrible times. He rode out the golden age of Hollywood by roaring into a new movie era with “Easy Rider.” He hung out with James Dean, played Elizabeth Taylor’s son, acted for Quentin Tarantino. He has been rich and infamous, lost and found, the next big thing, the last man standing.

headline: Herald Square, 8:38 A.M.
text: Still life, with folding chairs and pigeon.

headline: Video of Protests in Kyrgyzstan
text: Updated | 10:30 p.m. As my colleague Clifford Levy reports, opposition protesters appear to have overthrown the government of Kyrgyzstan for the second time in five years after riot police officers fired on demonstrators on Wednesday.

headline: Elle’s Carol Smith Jumps Ship to Condé Nast
text: Carol Smith, the star senior vice president and chief brand officer at Elle who helped wedge the magazine into shows like “Project Runway” and “The City,” is jumping ship for Condé Nast. There, she will oversee Bon Appétit and what is left of the Gourmet brand as vice president and publishing director for the epicurean group, a newly created position.

headline: New Clancy Thriller Contains the Sum of All Characters
text: Super groups: They worked for Blind Faith, the Avengers, Them Crooked Vultures and the 1992 men’s United States Olympic basketball team, so why not Tom Clancy? On Wednesday, Penguin Group said it would publish a new thriller by Mr. Clancy that would bring together many of his best-known characters from his last-quarter century of literary output. The new novel, called “Dead Or Alive” and written with his frequent collaborator Grant Blackwood, will feature the characters Jack Ryan, the C.I.A. analyst-turned-American president; his son and fellow analyst, Jack Ryan Jr.; the C.I.A. operative John Clark; his apprentice, Ding Chavez; and the agency executive Mary Pat Foley. In a statement, Penguin said the novel will pit them against “The Emir, a sadistic killer who has masterminded the most vicious terrorist attacks on the West” and who “has eluded capture by the world’s armed forces and law enforcement agencies.” “Dead Or Alive” will be released by the G. P. Putnam’s Sons imprint of Penguin on Dec. 7.

Submit your question to health_feedback@nytimes.com. You may also submit videos. Please remember that we cannot respond to all questions and that we cannot offer personal advice.

text: –Olivia Palermo describes the exhilaration of purchasing her first Hermès Birkin to Vogue UK. Mean girls alert!

headline: I.M.F. Says West Bank Economic Growth Is Imperiled by Israel and Arab States
text: JERUSALEM — The International Monetary Fund is preparing a report on the Palestinian economy that praises the actions of the West Bank government and the large donations of Western countries, especially European ones, but argues that healthy recent growth rates are imperiled by the parties that claim to have the most at stake — Israel and the Arab states.

headline: The Proper Place for Fights and Song
text: It seems as though there was a time when, if someone started performing or making a scene on the subway, you could be sure that he or she wanted you either to move to another car, or to part with a few dollar bills.

headline: Not a Morsel for Vegans at Cabrera’s Masters Feast
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. – It is an annual dinner at a very long rectangular table, a custom begun in 1952, when Ben Hogan suggested it might be fun to get all the living Masters champions together for dinner before the tournament. So at a famously exclusive golf club, a more selective society, one based on golf achievement, meets on the Tuesday of the first full week of each April.

headline: The Complications of Measuring Water Use
text: In The New York Times on Wednesday, I reported about the Carbon Disclosure Project’s new campaign to get global corporations to report their water use.

headline: Greenspan Again Defends Tenure as Fed Chairman
text: Alan Greenspan on Wednesday defended his record as chairman of the Federal Reserve, testifying that any “notion of inadequacy” within the regulator’s actions in the run-up to the subprime mortgage crisis was “unverifiable.”

headline: Behind Obama’s Cool
text: In 2004, Congresswoman Jan Schakowsky of Illinois attended a White House event wearing the campaign pin of her state’s candidate for the United States Senate. When she saw President Bush do a double take at the one word on her pin, she assured him that it spelled “Obama,” not “Osama.” Bush shrugged: “I don’t know him.” She answered, “You will.” Not long after this, Barack Obama gave the keynote address at the Democratic National Convention, and many people suddenly knew him. It happened so fast that he seemed to come out of nowhere. The truth was more intriguing — he had come out of everywhere.

headline: Weighing an Obama Plan to End a Mideast Logjam
text: WASHINGTON — Two weeks ago, Gen. James L. Jones, the national security adviser, was holding a meeting at the White House with a high-powered array of his predecessors when President Obama dropped in.

headline: UConn and Messi, a Level Above
text: That the two shows of dominance came on the same day, in two vastly different sports and in two distinct parts of the world, was nothing but a coincidence, but at least we can sit back and appreciate the spectacle of the soccer phenomenon Lionel Messi and the Connecticut women’s basketball team with the same part of our brains. It’s the part that forms the word wow.

headline: Bernanke Says Nation Must Take Action Soon to Shape Fiscal Future
text: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned Wednesday that an aging American population posed fiscal challenges for the United States.

headline: Updated: Classroom Resources on Mining Disasters
text: We’ve updated yesterday’s post by adding more resources, and by quoting a teacher from North Carolina who wrote to us with a simple but powerful idea for how to help kids connect this news with their own lives.

headline: Concrete Executive Gets Jail Time; Suicide Attempt Delays Sentencing of Owner
text: Updated, 12:50 p.m. | The sentencing of two executives of Testwell Laboratories, once the leading concrete testing company in New York, was reduced to one on Wednesday, after the disclosure that one of the officials again tried to kill himself.

headline: Mad Men Say a Boozy ‘Bye Bye’
text: How badly are we jonesing for new episodes of “Mad Men”? Bad enough that we sat through almost all of this video (which we were pointed to by the good folks at Vulture) in which that show’s cast and crew — many with beer bottles in hand — say farewell to their third season by singing along to Ann-Margret’s performance of “Bye Bye Birdie,” which played a crucial role on the series last year.

headline: Back to the Future
text: The early chapters of Brian Lutz’s ‘‘Knoll: A Modernist Universe’’ (Rizzoli) read like a portrait of the Greatest Generation, only with really cool furniture. Hans Knoll, an entrepreneur from a well-known German furniture-manufacturing family, and Florence Schust, an architect whose education brought her in contact with greats like Eliel Saarinen and Mies van der Rohe, married in 1946 and quickly turned Hans’s small company into a design powerhouse. They recruited people like Harry Bertoia and Eero Saarinen to design groundbreaking furniture, reintroduced classics like Mies’s Barcelona chair and started the Knoll Planning Unit, which under Florence’s direction revolutionized office interiors. Hans died in a car accident in 1955, but Florence stayed for another 10 years. Knoll after the Knolls became a more corporate place, concentrating heavily on office systems but still caring enough about furniture to commission pieces from a who’s who of design and architecture.

headline: Pressed to Act, Karzai Fires Election Monitors
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Under enormous pressure from Western governments, President Hamid Karzai ousted Afghanistan’s top two elections officials, who were seen as sanctioning the widespread fraud that favored him during last year’s presidential race.

headline: TimesCast | April 7, 2010
text: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Wednesday.  Today a look at antigovernment protests in Kyrgyzstan and Thailand, and the strategy behind Eliot Spitzer's comeback.

headline: What We’re Reading …
text: Paul Volcker on value-added taxes, and other links from around the Web.

headline: A Man, a Guitar, a Lap in a Ferrari F10 Formula One Car
text: If you divide the time I spend on YouTube into a pie chart, the two largest slices would represent Formula One videos and videos of guitar theatrics. At long last, the twain have met. In the above video (via 0-60mag.com), a man replicates a Ferrari F10 engine with his Gibson Explorer guitar. And he doesn’t just bust out a few “revs.” He actually performs a lap — matching the gear changes with a video of Fernando Alonso doing a lap in his Ferrari. It might not be as impressive as the Renault team playing “God Save the Queen” or “We Are the Champions” on its Formula One engine, but it’s pretty close.

headline: ‘Jersey Boys’ Matinee Canceled
text: The Wednesday matinee of the Broadway musical “Jersey Boys” at the August Wilson Theater has been canceled, a spokesman for the show said, in the aftermath of an electrical fire that took place on West 52nd Street on Tuesday. A buildup of carbon monoxide caused the underground fire and a manhole explosion, prompting the evacuation of several buildings in the area and causing Tuesday night’s performance of “Jersey Boys” to be canceled. According to a statement from the spokesman, the “Jersey Boys” producers were notified by authorities that it would not be possible to have a performance on Wednesday afternoon. “The problem should be solved this afternoon to make sure there is a performance tonight,” the statement said. Exchanges for the  matinee performance can be arranged at the point of purchase.

headline: Americans Still Not Confident in Banks
text: Even as the economy, and the financial sector, have shown rapid recovery, Americans’ confidence in banks remains at a historic low, according to Gallup.

headline: When the Bully’s Victim Fights Back
text: One of the points several of you made during the Motherlode discussions about bullying is that sometimes the lines become blurred. What counts as bullying? Is the threat of physical violence required? Or are sniggering and teasing more than enough? How young is too young to be considered a bully? Is excluding a child from a social circle bullying? Do all classmates have to be friends?

headline: Squeaky (Bicycle) Wheels Heard on Proposal to Raise Cellphone Fines
text: A California State Senate committee approved a bill on Tuesday to increase the fines for driving while using a hand-held cellphone, but a provision that would have held cyclists equally accountable for following the law was scaled back in the wake of cyclist complaints. Distracted driving is already against state law; distracted bicycling is not. Yet.

headline: Wi-Fi Woes for iPad?
text: Some owners of the new Apple iPad reported problems with its Wi-Fi connection right out of the box.

headline: Soft Treatments in Tough Times
text: A SOFT WEEK  In these dial-it-back times, perhaps you’ve gone ages without a facial or a massage. Starting April 12, Spa Week, a twice-a-year nationwide event, features $50 treatments. Eight hundred spas are onboard, up from 25 a decade ago. Perhaps the recession is to thank for the addition of luxury spas like Exhale and Clarins Skin Spa. A list of participants is at spaweek.com.

headline: Tanning Bed Hygiene
text: Repeat visits to tanning beds can lead to cancer and premature aging, the same way that overexposure to ultraviolet light in the sunlit world can. But lying in a tanning bed may also lead to skin infections, according to a study published in the Journal of American Academy of Dermatology.

headline: Awake for Breast Implants? If You Wish
text: SOON after Jane Z. had her B-cup breasts augmented for the first time, she realized she hadn’t gone big enough. So the second time, Jane Z., who preferred to not have her last name mentioned, was thrilled that she could choose her implant size during surgery.

headline: Usher Knocks Justin Bieber From Top of Chart
text: The upper ranks of the Billboard chart this week belong to Usher. His new album, “Raymond vs. Raymond” (Jive) — his real name is Usher Raymond IV — is No. 1, and Justin Bieber, his 16-year-old protégé, is standing strong at No. 2. “Raymond vs. Raymond” sold 329,000 copies in its first week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Mr. Bieber’s album “My World 2.0” (Island), which was No. 1 on last week’s chart, fell one spot in its second week out, with 290,000 sales. (Mr. Bieber’s EP, “My World,” released in November, fell three spots this week to No. 8, with 63,000.)

headline: ‘It’s Always Sunny on Our Channel,’ FX Tells Advertisers
text: The FX cable channel is reaching out to advertisers ahead of the 2010-11 season with a pitch centered on ratings growth as well as changes to its program lineup intended to help ratings growth.

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: British Airways Strikes on Hold, in Latest Talks
text: The union representing British Airways’ 13,500 flight attendants said Wednesday that talks with the airline’s management this week had made “serious progress” toward resolving differences over wage cuts and changes to in-flight staffing. As a result, it is putting off plans for any further strikes following two costly walkouts last month.

headline: Now Showing | Hooray for Nollywood
text: The photographer Pieter Hugo is no stranger to shocking and peculiar sights. His horrifying, arresting 2007 portrait series “The Hyena & Other Men” showcased Nigerian street performers posing alongside their exotic prey. In “Nollywood,” his latest body of work, currently on view at the Yossi Milo Gallery, Hugo once again focuses his camera on performers, only this time his subjects are actors from Nigeria’s surprisingly robust film industry, which is apparently the third largest in the world. The photographs don’t allude to any films in particular, but rather explore some of the industry’s more popular themes, like mysticism, war and the supernatural. The results are often menacing if not grotesque, and they blur the line between documentary and fiction. In one photo, a trio of zombielike children await their next cue, and, in another a well-dressed man proudly stands, camera ready, holding the entrails of a slain ox.

headline: U.S. Soccer Puts Youth Development in Reyna’s Hands
text: Claudio Reyna is coming back, not as a player but as the youth technical director for the United States Soccer Federation. The former captain of the national team will coordinate the development of young players in the U.S., from the recreational to the promising.

headline: Now Playing: The Little Big Screen
text: The new HTC  HD2 says it has the biggest screen of any phone in the United States, 4.3 inches measured diagonally. It has given the phone cinematic aspirations.

headline: How Lenders Overlook the Warning Signs of ID Theft
text: Despite all the new fraud alert tools and increased awareness of the perils of identity theft, incidence of the crime remains at 2003 levels, with about 10 million Americans falling victim every year.

headline: Redefining What It Means to Work Hard
text: David Brooks: Gail, to wrench me out of my fiscal funk last week, you allowed me to talk about sports and sex, in the person of Tiger Woods. I want you to know how much that helped.

headline: Theater Company Gets $800,000 for Traveling Classics Project

headline: No Rubber Stamp for the Mayor

headline: 2010: Mom’s Florida Avocado and Orange Salad (Adjusted)
text: By Andrew Carmellini, the chef and an owner of Locanda Verde in Manhattan. 2 Valencia or navel oranges1 Florida avocado or 2 regular avocadosJuice of 1 lime1/2 small red onion, thinly sliced 1 scant tablespoon dried oregano, preferably Mexican1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil, plus some for sprinkling1/4 teaspoon salt1 teaspoon of your favorite hot sauceHandful cilantro leaves. 1. Segment the oranges by slicing off the ends with a sharp knife. Put the orange on one end and, with a small, sharp knife, cut off the peel and white pith. Segment the orange by slicing between the membranes. Remove the segments and drop into a bowl. Squeeze the juice out of the remaining membranes into the bowl with the segments. Reserve the juice. 2. With a dinner knife (not the sharpest knife in your kitchen), cut each halved avocado half lengthwise into segments, cutting through the meat to (not into) the skin. Then cut around the outside of the avocado meat and, using the knife, push the pieces out of the skin and into the bowl with the oranges. 3. Add the lime juice, red onion, oregano, olive oil, salt, hot sauce and the reserved orange juice. Using a large spoon, mix all the ingredients together so that everything is coated and well combined. 4. Remove to a serving bowl. Garnish with cilantro leaves and drizzle with more olive oil. Serves 4 as an appetizer or antipasto.

headline: Recipe Redux: Spicy Orange Salad, Moroccan Style, 1980
text: I have never seen an orange salad on a menu or been served one at someone’s house. And now that I have tasted one, I’m outraged. Moroccan orange salad is one of the best salads in the world — sweet citrus juices countered with pungent onion and dueling kicks of spices and acidity.

headline: Why Identity Theft Is Still a Big Problem
text: Here is one possible reason why the incidence of identity theft remains at 2003 levels: Lenders are too willing to extend credit to just about anybody, according to a new report covered by the Bits blog in this post, “How Lenders Overlook the Warning Signs of ID Theft.”

text: Gov. Joe Manchin III of West Virginia speaks with The Today Show about the families of the lost coal miners and their hope despite poor odds.

headline: Abuse Case Forced Bishop in Norway to Quit in ’09
text: ROME — In May, the leader of central Norway’s small Roman Catholic population unexpectedly resigned with little explanation. The Vatican on Wednesday said why: He sexually abused a boy in the early 1990s.

headline: Will We Get a V.A.T.?
text: Everybody on the right seems convinced that a value-added tax is on its way. Sometimes this conviction is framed in alarmist, “look what the Democrats are going to do next” terms: See, for instance, this Allahpundit post today, following up on this Charles Krauthammer column from last month. Sometimes it’s couched as advice to President Obama, delivered more in sorrow than in anger, explaining what he’ll have to do if he wants to pay for the new entitlement he’s created: See Glenn Hubbard in The Wall Street Journal, for instance, or Greg Mankiw in the Times. And sometimes it’s presented as an idea that the right-of-center should learn to live with, provided that it’s part of a grand bargain of some sort: See James Pethokoukis’s ideal scenario, or Mankiw’s thoughts on the fiscal commission, or Tyler Cowen’s provocative “case for a V.A.T.”

headline: The Concierge | The Kiddie Classics

Correction: An earlier version of this article misstated President Reagan's middle initial. It is Ronald W. Reagan, not Ronald R. Reagan.

headline: Alcott Recalls Her Augusta Moment, Kept Quiet
text: If ever the lords of Augusta National were going to add a woman to their membership ranks, this week might have been their idea of perfect timing, when they could have snuck her in under everyone’s Tiger-centric radar.

headline: China Is Eager to Bring High-Speed Rail Expertise to the U.S.
text: BEIJING — Nearly 150 years after American railroads brought in thousands of Chinese laborers to build rail lines across the West, China is poised once again to play a role in American rail construction. But this time, it would be an entirely different role: supplying the technology, equipment and engineers to build high-speed rail lines.

headline: Reaction on Military Blogs to the WikiLeaks Video
text: As much as in the general public, military blogs have reacted with passion to the released Wikileaks video of a 2007 Apache attack in Iraq. With more expertise than most viewers — as well as more empathy, even among those who felt the pilots acted improperly — they explored a range of issues: Were the people in the video carrying weapons? Is Wikileaks a security risk? Did the military fail in not explaining the video more fully to the media? Should journalists operate so closely to insurgents?

headline: Payne, Augusta’s Chairman, Chastises Woods

The principal topic of conversation is often something like turf management or the speed of the greens. But on Wednesday, Billy Payne, who has led the club since 2006, did something unprecedented. Without prodding, he singled out Tiger Woods in a harsh rebuke.

Creatures of modernity, we do occasionally hear a jet overhead or a distant car. A neighbor's children play in their backyard. This is all good.

headline: Spitzer’s Long Road to Redemption
text: HERE is Eliot Spitzer on MSNBC with the host Ed Schultz, railing against fallen Wall Street titans who regain power (“absolutely insane”). There he is on Fox’s “Good Day New York,” taking swipes at Andrew Cuomo (“he has to answer the hard questions”) and Senator Kirsten Gillibrand (“I don’t like politicians who vacillate”). He’s lunching regularly at power restaurants like Michael’s (telling the waiter, “Silda wants me to have the salad”), holding hands with his wife at charity galas, attending a private salon at Tina Brown’s. Writing his twice-monthly Slate column, “The Best Policy.” Teaching undergraduates at the City College of New York, lecturing at Harvard about ethics, parsing the meaning of love on BigThink.com.

headline: A New Twist: Hockey on an Indoor Football Field

headline: When Mom Says a Bad Word
text: Vivian Manning-Schaffel is an editor for Momlogic.com and blogs at TheMadMom.com, which means she has spent a lot of time thinking about good and responsible parenting. She also is the mother of a 1-year-old daughter and a 5-year-old son and has vowed not to make certain mistakes that her own mother made decades ago.

headline: On Dance: From Broadway to the Met
text: The final new production of the Metropolitan Opera season, Rossini’s “Armida,” opens on Monday. The sorceress of the title seduces men, including the crusader Rinaldo, but the story is essentially about a powerful woman who chooses revenge over love. There are powerful women involved in the production too. The director is the theater veteran Mary Zimmerman, Renée Fleming is the star, and, also crucial, the choreographer is Graciela Daniele.

headline: In Focus | Skye Parrott
text: The photography exhibition “Younger Than I’ll Be” opens today at BAMart in Brooklyn and runs through May 23. Curated by Skye Parrott, it includes works by Jack Pierson, David Armstrong, Larry Clark and Weegee, to name but a few. Parrott is a photographer in her own right, as well as the creative director of Dossier Magazine, Dossierjournal.com and a woman about town. I caught up with Parrott — who is as lovely as she is busy — to talk about the new show, the new iPad and New York when she was young.

headline: Turmoil in Kyrgyzstan
text: Our show opens with fierce images from the protests that appear to have overthrown the government of Kyrgyzstan, an important American ally in Central Asia (Slides 1, 2, 3 and 4). Violence between riot police officers and opposition demonstrators on Wednesday killed at least 17 people. The country’s president, Kurmanbek Bakiyev, left the capital, Bishkek, on his plane, and the opposition declared that it was forming its own government.

headline: Birds And Bees Blogging
text: There have been many stories about the decline of the birth rate in 2008, with almost all attributing it to the recession. But James Trussell raises an interesting point: doesn’t it take nine months from conception to birth? Abortion aside, to reduce births in the first three quarters of 2008 in response to a recession that started in Dec. 2007 would have taken pretty impressive rational expectations.

headline: Facade of Garage Wall Collapses on West Side
text: A facade of a parking garage wall on Freedom Place at West 68th Street, near Riverside Drive, fell onto the sidewalk Wednesday afternoon, a city official said. There were no reports of injuries.

headline: Paper Magazine Editor Is Powerful, but No Power Snob
text: DOES anyone remember that, long before Madonna was a zillionairess with a fake British accent, she used to dance at the Roxy with a posse of Latino b-boys? Kim Hastreiter does. Are there many who recall when Jean-Michel Basquiat’s paintings, created in a basement on manic cocaine binges, were being sold for $200 on the street at what his dealer termed a fire sale? Well, there is Ms. Hastreiter. Are there two people alive who celebrated the bicentennial by driving cross-country from California in a Dodge truck called the Dragon Wagon to storm New York City with Joey Arias riding shotgun? There is just one.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: iPad Apps and Casual Gaming
text: In this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein catches up with Jenna Wortham, the Times technology reporter who’s been covering app development, to discover how the people who create iPad apps reacted to finally getting their hands on the new device. Most of them had to design their apps without seeing the iPad or testing on it. While some rushed their products to Apple’s App Store before the iPad’s release, others decided to wait it out.

headline: Pause: Bristol Palin and Teen Pregnancy
text: Bristol Palin, the daughter of former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska and herself a mom, has made a public service announcement for the Candie’s Foundation that asks teens to think twice before they have sex.

headline: Looking Good in Three Figures
text: BACK in the day, there were many choice slurs to run a fellow down, but somehow nothing was more damningly dismissive than to sneer that he wore a cheap suit. Then, of course, there came a new generation for whom the very term “suit,” cheap or no, was an even worse insult: a middle-management man who couldn’t think outside the boxy garb of Big Business.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend

headline: Second School Building of Day Is Evacuated
text: On the first day back after a long spring break, school officials at Public School 115 on West 177th Street in Washington Heights found that water damage had caused part of the ceiling in a couple of classrooms to tumble down. School officials were concerned about a potential asbestos contamination, so just after noon, the school was evacuated (making it the second school evacuation on Wednesday.)

headline: Disappointment Is Rarely Kind, but It Makes for Catchy Tunes
text: Whoever the boys were, they did a number on Bethany Cosentino. Ms. Cosentino is the singer and steering force behind Best Coast, an offhandedly charming no-fi indie rock band focused almost exclusively, and talmudically, on the ones that got away.

headline: Garment District Hothouse
text: “I’M going to have fun walking down the hall yelling, ‘Bibhu! Bibhu!’ ” said Waris Ahluwalia, the designer of the jewelry collection House of Waris, on his first day in his new office at 209 West 38th Street in the heart of the garment district last Tuesday. Bibhu Mohapatra, an evening-wear designer, had moved into a space down the hall a week earlier, from where he could wave hello. “Bibhu!” This has the potential to get annoying.

headline: For Designer Bargains, Step Into Their Closet
text: ON a recent foray for new spring clothes — a sundress, slouchy pants, a nautical-inspired top or two — I was determined not to break the bank.

text: SHOULD it be interpreted as a sign of the apocalypse, or just a really big trend, that both Hillary Clinton and Snooki have been accused of wearing Bumpits of late?

headline: 19th-Century Classics, and Then a Little Samba
text: LONDON  Springtime in London has become a smorgasbord of world-class dance in recent years. This year’s range of visiting and resident companies is remarkable: Pina Bausch Tanztheater Wuppertal was at the Barbican Theater, Akram Khan will be seen at Sadler’s Wells, the Royal Ballet is in residence at Covent Garden, and at the London Coliseum the succession of troupes will include the Mark Morris Dance Group, Birmingham Royal Ballet and Ballet Nacional de España.

headline: Navratilova Says She Has Breast Cancer
text: The retired tennis champion Martina Navratilova, who remains a remarkably active 53-year-old, said Wednesday that she was found to have noninvasive breast cancer in February and had undergone a lumpectomy, with radiation treatment to come in May.

headline: Hot Spot Shortcut, in the Weeds
text: You want to hear a really scary statistic? Twenty-five percent.

headline: Why Francona Is Sticking With Ortiz
text: BOSTON –- The Red Sox have a left-handed hitter with a .212 average against left-handers since the start of the 2008 season. They also have a right-handed hitter with a .307 average against left-handers in the same time frame.

headline: Hollywood Unites to Block Trading on Movie Box-Office Performance
text: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood’s advice for financial players who expect to start speculating on movie box-office receipts: Don’t bet on it.

headline: The Art of the Straddle: A Saxophonist Ranging at Will
text: The alto saxophonist David Binney upholds an agenda of indeterminacy. He doesn’t swim in the jazz mainstream, but neither is he sworn to an established avant-garde. His music accommodates elements of funk and electronic music, but rarely accepts the known artifice of fusion. To some degree his in-betweenness is a signature, characteristic since his arrival in New York more than 20 years ago. Increasingly it’s also a common ideal among up-and-coming musicians, which attests to his stealth influence on the scene.

headline: A Digital Camera That Swaps Lenses, Priced to Please
text: Any serious photographer can quickly point out the benefit of a digital camera with a large image sensor. Simply put, bigger sensors — not more pixels — yield better photos.

headline: ‘American Idol’ Ratings Hit a Low Mark
text: The chops-licking over the declining performance of Fox’s “American Idol” may grow more intense in the wake of the Tuesday night ratings for that perennial powerhouse. Fewer people watched “Idol” on Tuesday (when the contestant Crystal Bowersox performed with the didgeridoo player Ernie Fields, both left) than watched ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” on Monday. (“Dancing” runs performance episodes on Mondays, with results on Tuesdays; “Idol” generally has performance on Tuesdays with results on Wednesdays.) And for a second consecutive week, in the category Fox cares most about  viewers between the ages of 18 and 49  “Idol,” if the Tuesday overnight ratings hold, will post its lowest number ever for a two-hour edition of the show. It will also be the lowest-rated Tuesday edition of the show since an hourlong episode on Aug. 13, 2002, in its first season, when the series played in the summer. “Idol” had a total audience of about 20.4 million on Tuesday, below the 21.2 million that “Dancing” averaged for its performance show on Monday. (The “Dancing” results on Tuesday averaged a total audience of 12.3 million.) But the “Idol” 7.1 rating among viewers 18 to 49 is what will be most noticed. That is down from a 7.7 a week ago and down from the 8.1 the show averaged for the three previous weeks. Of course, “Idol” is still the dominant show on television with those younger adults advertisers love. And the success of “Dancing” has to be tempered by its skew toward older viewers. This week’s “Dancing” results episode, when the astronaut Buzz Aldrin was blasted off the show, faced the “Idol” performance on Tuesday night and scored a modest 2.4 rating in the 18 to 49 group. More tellingly, almost 70 percent of its audience was over 50.

headline: New Clancy Thriller Has All-Star Cast
text: Super groups: They worked for Blind Faith, the Avengers, Them Crooked Vultures and the 1992 men’s United States Olympic basketball team, so why not Tom Clancy? On Wednesday Penguin Group said it would publish a new thriller by Mr. Clancy that would bring together many of his best-known characters from his last-quarter century of writing. The new novel, called “Dead or Alive” and written with his frequent collaborator Grant Blackwood, will feature Jack Ryan, the C.I.A. analyst turned American president; his son and fellow analyst, Jack Ryan Jr.; the C.I.A. operative John Clark; his apprentice, Ding Chavez; and the agency executive Mary Pat Foley. Penguin said the novel would pit them against “the Emir, a sadistic killer who has masterminded the most vicious terrorist attacks on the West.” “Dead or Alive” will be released by the G. P. Putnam’s Sons imprint of Penguin on Dec. 7.

headline: Usher Tops Pop Chart
text: The upper ranks of the Billboard chart this week belong to Usher, below. His new album, “Raymond vs. Raymond” (Jive)  his real name is Usher Raymond IV  is No. 1, and Justin Bieber, his 16-year-old protégé, is standing strong at No. 2. “Raymond vs. Raymond” sold 329,000 copies in its first week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Mr. Bieber’s album “My World 2.0” (Island), which was No. 1 on last week’s chart, fell one spot in its second week out, with 290,000 sales. (Mr. Bieber’s EP, “My World,” released in November, fell three spots this week to No. 8, with 63,000.) Also on the chart, Vol. 33 in the pop compilation series “Now That’s What I Call Music!” holds at No. 3 with 123,000, and “New Amerykah Part Two: Return of the Ankh” (Universal Motown), the latest by Erykah Badu, opens at No. 4 with 110,000. Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville) fell one spot to No. 5, with 87,000. Monica’s “Still Standing” (J) fell four spots to No. 6 in its second week out, with 81,000, and “Freight Train” (Arista Nashville), the latest album by the country star Alan Jackson, opened at No. 7 with 72,000 sales.

headline: A Police Man Is Preparing to Play at the Met
text: If you thought you saw a familiar, nattily attired Englishman poking around Lincoln Center in recent days, you might well have spotted Sting, right, inspecting the Metropolitan Opera as he prepares to perform there as part of an orchestra tour this summer. On July 13 and 14, Sting, the Police man and solo pop star, will perform at the Met with the Royal Philharmonic Concert Orchestra of London, it was announced on Wednesday. While Sting said, in a telephone interview, that he was “stoked” for the full orchestra tour, which begins June 2 in Vancouver, British Columbia, his dates at the Met have him feeling “both excited and anxious.” “I think one needs to take this seriously,” Sting said. “It’s quite something to be sitting in front of the Royal Philharmonic on the Met stage. I think I’m suitably anxious.” Sting played orchestral concerts with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in May 2009 and the Philadelphia Orchestra in January.

headline: Theater Company Gets Aid for Classics Project
text: The New York-based Aquila Theater Company has received $800,000 from the National Endowment for the Humanities to support new productions of classic Greek works that will be performed for veterans’ groups and in rural and urban areas, the theater group announced on Wednesday. The grant for Aquila’s new Ancient Greeks/Modern Lives program is the largest in the theater company’s 19-year history, an Aquila spokesman said. The performances will begin in May and run through April 2013, taking place at 100 public libraries and arts centers in communities from Harlem and Washington Heights in New York to Miami, Houston, Seattle and several other cities and small towns in at least 20 states. The productions will include scenes based on Homer’s “Odyssey” and from Sophocles’ “Ajax,” Euripides’ “Herakles” and “The Trojan Women” and Aeschylus’ “Persians,” the spokesman said. In its award, the endowment said the money was intended to begin “a national program series exploring classical literature.” Aquila regularly tours America with classics.

headline: Backwoods Design and the Art of a Doo Nanny
text: A look at Butch Anthony’s home, part of an 80-acre compound in the Alabama woods, and his “micro” folk-art festival.

headline: Design Archives Auction Is Canceled
text: One of the largest private archives documenting the mid-20th-century furniture designers Charles and Ray Eames has been withdrawn from an auction scheduled for Thursday because of a lawsuit contesting their ownership. The archives were to be the top lot at a sale at Wright auction house in Chicago focused on furniture by the Eameses, known for their mass-produced contoured plywood and fiberglass chairs. The archives were put up for sale by the design historians John and Marilyn Neuhart, who are in their 80s and had collaborated with the Eameses on exhibitions and books. But on Monday Lucia Eames, the designers’ daughter, filed suit in an Illinois state court asserting that the family owns the material. The lot was estimated to bring $150,000 to $200,000. Richard Wright, the auction house owner, said, “Trying to sell these items with a cloud over the title doesn’t make any sense.” He said he would still offer a four-foot-wide model that the Neuharts built of the Eames office in Los Angeles (estimated at $10,000 to $15,000).

headline: Exploring the Cocoon
text: The Cocoon, part of the Darwin Center at the Museum of Natural History in London, puts the focus on scientific exploration itself as well as on its results.

headline: 'Moving in Place'
text: The exhibition of work by Susan Rothenberg at the Georgia O’Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe, N.M., makes comparisons between the two artists hard to avoid.

headline: Hubris of a Man Who Thought He Was Napoleon
text: “War,” Thomas Hardy once wrote, “makes rattling good history.” If you would like an example of exactly what Hardy meant, I commend “Russia Against Napoleon” by Dominic Lieven.

headline: Enjoy the Bugs, but Don’t Feed the Scientists
text: LONDON — There is something daring, almost provocative, about the Cocoon. This eight-story-high egg-shaped structure, which contains major new exhibition space along with scientific-research facilities, is housed in an enormous glass-and-steel box. It is annexed to the Natural History Museum here as if it were a gigantic specimen brought back by 21st-century heirs to the collectors, entomologists and zoologists who created that great institution.

headline: Jane Has a Really Big Closet Now
text: JANE’S CLOSET, the Internet retailer for the woman in touch with her inner Gossip Girl, has transitioned from Web site to pop-up outlet to permanent store. In February, the bricks-and-mortar location opened in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, for what was to be three months. When traffic proved promising, Jane Rim, the owner, signed an extended lease.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS Isabel Marant’s much-anticipated SoHo boutique opens on April 9. The store features Corinthian columns, poured concrete floors and, of course, the French designer’s chic collection, including her iconic slouchy boots, which are worn both in winter and summer. The Dana, below, is $1,160. Other key items are the Hola embroidered jacket ($1,370) and Xacala fur vest ($1,490). The center of the boutique is a jewelry display constructed of timbers stretching from floor to ceiling; 469 Broome Street (Greene Street), (212) 219-2284. . . . Masgaschoni has moved its store on Main Street in East Hampton, N.Y., into a 2,000-square-foot boutique nearby, just in time to stock up for summer. The store offers the brand’s trademark vibrant kaleidoscope of colors in knits, sportswear, home designs and accessories. Simple tops start at $178, cashmere coats go to $1,000; 2 Newtown Lane, East Hampton, (631) 329-8139.

headline: Clogs Get Up on Their Toes
text: BANISH all thoughts of nurses, aging hippies and potbellied, globe-trotting chefs. The lowly clog has been updated this season by designers including Michael Kors and Karl Lagerfeld.

headline: Bags Worth Celebrating
text: HAYDEN-HARNETT, the Brooklyn fashion company best known for its stylish, functional and not insanely priced handbags, is celebrating its fifth anniversary with a sale at its stores in NoLIta and Greenpoint through April 26.

headline: Kiton, but Cheaper
text: WANT a Kiton suit but get sticker shock every time you glance at the sales tag? The Bergdorf Goodman Men’s Store is now selling a lower-priced collection from this high-end Italian designer (the term “lower-priced” being relative, of course).

headline: What We’re Reading: Murdoch and Collapsing Business Models
text: The tech editors and reporters of the New York Times were reading about business deals and business models as much as gadgets.

headline: Three Classes of Digital Cameras
text: A guide for those choosing which type of digital camera to buy.

headline: Speak Easy | Laura Marling
text: Laura Marling is the most prominent member of a loose community of young London-based performers, including Johnny Flynn and Mumford and Sons, playing acoustic music inspired by British and American folk traditions. Her debut album, “Alas I Cannot Swim,” was recorded when she was 17 and nominated for the 2008 Mercury Prize. This week her follow-up, “I Speak Because I Can” (Astralwerks), was released in the United States. The album has been greeted by a sweep of five-star reviews in British newspapers, earning comparisons to Joni Mitchell’s “Court and Spark.” In a warm, dusty voice and accompanied by her intuitive guitar playing, Marling sings of being perched between adolescence and womanhood, between the rural England where she was raised and the anxious metropolis she has made her home, between despair and freedom. Marling spoke with The Moment during her recent American tour.

headline: HCA Said to Plan I.P.O. for This Year
text: HCA, the big hospital operator whose $33 billion takeover in 2006 heralded a slew of giant leveraged buyouts, is planning an initial public offering that may raise more than $3 billion, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Russia Against Napoleon’
text: There are usually three stages in the creation of empires, though these stages often overlap. First comes the conquest of empire and the elimination of foreign threats. This is generally a question of military power, diplomatic craftiness, and geopolitical context. To survive, however, an empire needs institutions, otherwise it will disintegrate with the death of the conqueror and his charisma. Establishing these institutions is the second stage in creating an empire and is often harder than the first stage, particularly when huge conquests have occurred in a short period. The third stage requires the consolidation of imperial loyalties and identities in the subject populations, and above all, in the pre-modern world, in their elites.

headline: Another Painter in O’Keeffe Territory
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — When the painter Susan Rothenberg moved to New Mexico from New York City in 1990 at the age of 45, she didn’t give a lot of thought to the parallels between herself and Georgia O’Keeffe, another woman who gained fame in New York and began spending a lot of time here at around the same age.

headline: S.E.C. Moves to Tighten Rules on Bonds Backed by Consumer Loans
text: WASHINGTON — Credit rating agencies would lose their formal role in evaluating certain bonds backed by consumer loans, like home mortgages, under rules proposed on Wednesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Instead, the companies issuing these bonds would have to vouch for their soundness.

headline: Maestro’s Pay Hangs on Unsigned Deal
text: As the conductor James Levine prepares to undergo lower-back surgery, his employers at the Metropolitan Opera and the Boston Symphony Orchestra are nervously hoping that he will recover and resume his extremely busy schedule.

headline: Man Arrested in Threat Against Pelosi
text: Federal agents on Wednesday arrested a San Francisco man in connection with threats against the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, over her role in winning adoption of landmark health care legislation, officials said.

headline: Lyon-Bordeaux Exposes France’s East-West Divide
text: Win or lose, France knew it would qualify a team for the semifinals of the UEFA Champions League on Wednesday. Bordeaux won the game, 1-0, but Lyon got the ticket through to the next round. Lyon had an edge of course, having won 3-1 in the first leg the week before at Lyon’s Gerland Stadium. But Bordeaux was playing on home turf and worked hard to please the home crowd.

headline: Plot Twists
text: In Bruges: The influential Belgian garden designer Jacques Wirtz, now in his 80s, is best known for bold landscapes with strong perspective lines, sweeping hedges, swaths of grass and geometric topiary. (His sons Peter and Martin are now in charge of the family firm, Wirtz International.) It’s a signature that’s apparent even in projects with limited space.

headline: Jets Are Courting Jason Taylor, a Fan Nemesis
text: The Jets courted the free agent defensive end Jason Taylor on Wednesday. They showed off their new stadium. They offered a tempting role.

headline: Soul Man
text: By age 12, I had a rote reply for grown-ups’ quizzical looks when they heard I went to a Waldorf school: “It’s based on the ideas of Rudolf Steiner.” Blank stare. “He was an Austrian philosopher who believed in teaching the whole student — mind, body and soul.” Luckily no one ever asked me to elaborate, because I’d have been at a loss for words — except to say that we students got to do lots of drawing and painting, which I loved, but we couldn’t skip eurythmy class (yuck). Any serious discussions of pedagogic method and what Steiner called his “spiritual science,” anthroposophy, took place out of earshot in the teachers’ room. My only mental picture of Steiner (1861-1925) came from a dim black and white photo showing a stern mouth and X-ray eyes that made me glad this guy wasn’t our headmaster. Oh, well, I reasoned, as soon as I enter the real world after graduation, it’s Goodbye, Dr. Steiner.

headline: The Tapping Looked Good, but Happened to Backfire
text: You are on defense. Declarer ruffs your opening lead in his hand. You get back in immediately. Should you continue to tap declarer, hoping that he will lose trump control, or should you shift in order to stop him from scoring his trumps separately and aiding what might turn into a dummy reversal? (In a dummy reversal, declarer does a lot of ruffing in his hand and uses dummy’s trumps to draw those of the opponents.)

headline: Toyota E-Mail Noted Pedal Trouble
text: DETROIT — A senior official in Toyota’s American operations urged his colleagues to “come clean” and admit it had mechanical problems with sticking accelerator pedals three days before the company met with federal authorities to discuss a recall, documents showed Wednesday.

headline: With Select Apps, iPad Is More Than a Pretty Face
text: Let’s set aside the question of whether you should get an iPad and suppose you already bought one last weekend. You probably floated home and loaded it with a few whiz-bang apps and maybe even passed it around to your friends.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,023 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It has confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

headline: Cano Picks and Chooses
text: BOSTON — According to the Yankees’ charts, Robinson Cano swung at more pitches out of the strike zone last season than any of his teammates.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Wednesday about school nutrition legislation now in the Senate omitted one type of milk the bill would allow in cafeterias. Besides skim, 1 percent milk could be sold.

headline: Wisconsin: Schools Warned Against Sex Education
text: A prosecutor is urging schools not to follow a new state law that requires districts with sex education programs to tell students about the proper use of contraceptives. In a letter to school districts, Scott Harold Southworth, Juneau County’s district attorney, warned that teachers face “possible criminal liability” for teaching youths how to use contraceptives. The law allows districts to opt out. State lawmakers who wrote the bill, pushed through this year by Democrats, said the warnings were incorrect, irresponsible and political. “He’s trying to make it sound as if teaching a comprehensive sex education curriculum is somehow illegal,” said Tamara Grigsby, a Democratic state representative. Mr. Southworth was unavailable for comment.

headline: Spanish Judge Indicted for Inquiry Into Franco-Era Abuses
text: MADRID — Baltasar Garzón, the Spanish judge who attained international fame for pursuing leaders like Augusto Pinochet of Chile and Silvio Berlusconi of Italy, was himself indicted Wednesday on charges of abusing his powers to investigate Spanish Civil War atrocities.

headline: California: Man Accused of Threatening Pelosi
text: Federal agents arrested a San Francisco man on Wednesday in connection with threats against Speaker Nancy Pelosi for her role in winning adoption of health care legislation, officials said. Charges were not disclosed. The man, Gregory Guisti, 48, is scheduled to appear in court Thursday. On Tuesday, a man was charged with threatening to kill Senator Patty Murray of Washington.

headline: Arkansas: Probation for Ex-Aide to Bill Clinton
text: Betsey Wright, chief of Bill Clinton’s staff as governor and a senior member of his presidential campaign in 1992, was fined $2,000 and placed on a year’s probation after pleading no contest on Wednesday to two misdemeanor charges involving prohibited items that were taken from her at a state prison where she visited death row inmates in May. Security guards seized a box cutter, a pocket knife and needles from Ms. Wright, a vocal opponent of capital punishment.

headline: Ex-Citi Executives Take Fire at Crisis Hearing
text: A group of former high-ranking Citigroup executives defended the firm’s management of risk in its credit derivatives business on Wednesday, telling an investigative panel that the firm’s multibillion-dollar subprime mortgage losses arose from unprecedented global events beyond their control.

headline: Hollywood Tries to Block Market for Movie Bets
text: LOS ANGELES — In a show of solidarity, many of the film industry’s major players, and some sympathetic lawmakers, have aligned in an 11th-hour push to block new financial instruments that would allow traders to swap contracts tied to box-office results.

headline: Trailer: Bad Company 2
text: The Electronic Arts game is the latest in the Battlefield series.

headline: Meb Keflezighi to Defend Title
text: Meb Keflezighi will be back to defend his New York City Marathon title Nov. 7, trying to become the first American since Alberto Salazar to win back-to-back titles in New York. The American women’s record-holder in the marathon, Deena Kastor, also entered, officials with the New York Road Runners announced during a drawing for the marathon lottery.

headline: Frozen Four From a Basketball Prism
text: DETROIT — The N.C.A.A. Final Four has gone Frozen, with interesting parallels between the basketball and hockey versions of the 2010 men’s tournaments.

headline: Summer Overtakes Spring; Confusion Reigns
text: When you thought about it, while mopping the dripping sweat off your brow, it was kind of absurd. What was August doing here in April?

headline: Evercore Plans a Deal and High-Level Hires
text: April 8, 8:18 a.m. | Updated Evercore Partners, the boutique investment bank, announced Thursday morning that it has bolstered its commercial real estate and mining and metals advisory businesses with an acquisition and two high-level appointments.

headline: State Panels Prove Resilient to Budget Pruning
text: Financially ailing states seeking to cut bureaucratic sprawl have zeroed in on what might seem a vulnerable target: the countless advisory, advocacy and regulatory boards and commissions that ripple out from their capitals into infinite niches of human need and pursuit.

headline: Poet and Anti-Poet
text: At a reading I attended in the Smith College science lecture hall a few years ago, Charles Bernstein, famous as a poet and anti-poet, pointed to the giant poster on the wall behind him and said, “I want to thank the Poetry Center for putting up my poem ‘The Periodic Table of the Elements.’ ” He then proceeded to give a mock-dramatic rendition of the symbols, left to right, down the page. “H, He, Li, Be!” he panted, growled and spluttered. “Why!?” he complained when he got to yttrium (Y). “I!” he declared solemnly for iodine, as if toasting his own ego. He slowed down, sped up. “No!” he bellowed for nobelium, then finally whispered “Lr,” the last chemical symbol. He turned to face the audience. “I’ve always wondered if I should have ended with ‘No’ rather than putting that ‘Lr’ on the end. I think it was a mistake. I think it would have been more emphatic with the negation.” This was the funniest, most impromptu-­brilliant, serious moment I’ve ever witnessed at a poetry reading — and very much about sound, language, expression and communication.

headline: For an Obama Mentor, a Nebulous Legal Niche
text: WASHINGTON — On a recent Saturday morning in a hardscrabble neighborhood here, a stocky man who could not afford a lawyer attended a legal clinic to ask a question about his mother’s will.

headline: In a Tour for Visitors, Baghdad’s Past Is Present
text: BAGHDAD — A group of foreign visitors went on a tour of Baghdad recently. Such an event, almost anywhere else, would have passed unnoticed. But this is Baghdad, where the rumblings of a passing thunderstorm recently had people convinced that insurgents had unleashed a string of synchronized bombings.

headline: Up Front: Barbara Kingsolver
text: In this issue, Barbara Kingsolver reviews “Anthill,” the first novel by the distinguished biologist E. O. Wilson, who turns 81 this year.

headline: In Cuomo’s Corner, a Pugnacious Aide Emerges
text: When members of the painters’ union heckled Andrew M. Cuomo as he arrived at a debate during the race for attorney general, Joseph Percoco, a burly aide to Mr. Cuomo, walked over to the union’s political director with a warning:

headline: Free Report on Credit? No Longer
text: The credit report you get from freecreditreport.com is no longer free, no matter what that Web address promises.

headline: A Tentative Contract Deal for Washington Teachers
text: Capping two years of rancorous bargaining, the Washington schools chancellor and the city’s teachers’ union on Wednesday announced an agreement on a tentative contract that would increase teacher salaries, establish a voluntary merit pay system and give the authorities clearer powers to move teachers out of the system based on their effectiveness rather than seniority.

headline: Suspense Builds Over Census for New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS — Nobody really knows how many people live here.

headline: Stepping Gingerly Into the Heat
text: In the old economy, a furnace blast of heat would have brought out the latest spring clothes. Fueled by big spending, stores had the goods early, and one of the discombobulating aspects of spring dressing was how suddenly spiffed-up everything looked in New York, as if all the city’s doormen had hosed the sidewalks clean of winter garments.

headline: Psychologists Explain Iraq Airstrike Video
text: The sight of human beings, most of them unarmed, being gunned down from above is jarring enough.

headline: Decommissioned Boards
text: Here is a sample of boards and commissions that have been eliminated as part of state government streamlining efforts.

headline: Augusta’s Chairman Rebukes Woods
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The annual Masters address by the chairman of the Augusta National Golf Club is usually a routine, even humdrum, affair. The principal topic of conversation is often the speed of the greens, and the closest thing to controversy is the yearly refusal to discuss whether the club will some day include a woman as a member. On Wednesday, Billy Payne, who has led Augusta National since 2006, did something unprecedented.

headline: Uprising in Kyrgyzstan
text: Opposition leaders declared Thursday that they had seized power in Kyrgyzstan, a crucial ally to the U.S. and strategic staging ground for the war in Afghanistan. (Video: NBC)

headline: A Charge That When Funds Crumbled, a Firm Deceived Its Brokers and Clients
text: WHEN the subprime credit structure began to shake and then to crumble, money managers who had invested in it were faced with hard decisions.

text: This article was reported by Michael Wines, Sharon LaFraniere and Jonathan Ansfield and written by Mr. Wines.

headline: Skip the South of France. Try Zimbabwe.
text: So what are the great places to visit in Africa? It surprises people to hear it, but Zimbabwe is very high on the list – and now that I’ve just returned from a week there with my family, I feel that more strongly than ever.

headline: AT&T Image Campaign Accentuates the Positive, Not Products
text: THINGS are starting to look up on Madison Avenue, or so it seems, as more advertising takes on the type of upbeat tone that had been noticeably missing during this recession.

headline: Texas Oil Firms Oppose California Climate Law
text: WASHINGTON — Several Texas oil companies are bankrolling a petition drive to suspend California’s path-breaking climate change law in a move that may prove a bellwether for national efforts to address global warming.

headline: Cash For Carbon
text: That was my working title for my piece published in Sunday’s NYT Magazine, under the title The Green Economy.

text: Henry Farrell, left, of George Washington University and Brink Lindsey of the Cato Institute discuss the video of American soldiers killing a journalist in Iraq.

text: If Kevin Durant’s maiden playoff voyage is cut short this month, he might look back to one play and one officiating mistake as the cause.

headline: Nike Ad Features Voice From Tiger Woods’s Past
text: Nike, which stood by Tiger Woods when AT&T and Accenture dropped him, began running a new 30-second commercial on Wednesday that uses the recorded voice of his father, Earl, who died in 2006.

headline: City Orders End to Sending Homeless to Illegal Houses
text: For years, homeless people were sent by the city to illegal boarding houses, places with crowded conditions, rows of bunk beds and vermin. For many of the buildings’ landlords, it was an easy way to turn a run-down house into a fairly lucrative operation — tenants were charged hundreds of dollars each month for little more than a mattress.

headline: Third Officer Pleads Guilty in Shooting
text: NEW ORLEANS —  A third police officer pleaded guilty in federal court on Wednesday to covering up evidence in a police shooting that left two dead and four others wounded in the days after Hurricane Katrina.

text: The author of  “Room for Children: Stylish Spaces for Sleep and Play,” looked for children's bedding.

headline: Earthquake  Roulette
text: SEATTLE — The real triumph of hope over experience is not a second marriage, as the saying goes, but the fact that millions of us continue to live atop some of the most fragile ground on the planet, knowing full well it could crack, shatter, splinter and heave at any moment.

headline: Legal Threats and Bike Rides by the Hudson
