headline: Harrington’s Knicks Career Likely Ending With Shoulder Surgery
text: Al Harrington’s Knicks career probably ended Sunday night in Los Angeles, though he didn’t know it at the time.

headline: The Lenox Hill Neighborhood House Gala
text: THE taxidermied swans at P. Allen Smith’s table had come all the way from Arkansas. They had been in his freezer, explained Mr. Smith, the public television garden show star, who keeps swans of the live variety on his 600-acre organic farm there, awaiting their 15 minutes.

headline: U.S. Tries to Mend Rift With Karzai
text: WASHINGTON — Seeking to quell an increasingly vitriolic and public dispute, the Obama administration said Wednesday that President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan was “a figure that we respect,” and it sharply countered claims by a former United Nations official that the president might be a drug user.

headline: Silk Trading Company Relocates
text: Silk Trading Company has moved out of ABC Carpet & Home’s basement and has opened its own store nearby. With the new location come many changes: new fabrics, furniture and accessories, and a new name — Wolf Home by Silk Trading. “We felt it was time to come out into the light,” said Warren Kay, the owner, who made the move after splitting with his business partner, Andrea Kay (Ms. Kay retains ownership of the Silk Trading Company store in Los Angeles). The concept for the store, he said, was a place where shoppers can “have a coffee, talk to designers, look at fabrics, think about color and be in a creative environment.” Products range from sofas (starting at $3,100) and limited-edition throw pillows ($59 to $150) to Molton Brown scented candles ($74). Wolf Home by Silk Trading, 936 Broadway (22nd Street), (800) 220-1893, wolfhome-ny.com.

headline: Facing Cuts, Stony Brook Will Close Programs
text: Four years after taking over an 81-acre campus in Southampton, N.Y., from Long Island University, Stony Brook University announced on Wednesday that it would close most programs at the site and stop accepting undergraduate applications.

headline: Why Do We Still Have Mining Disasters?
text: Why, after such a long history of injury and death, does coal mining remain so dangerous?

headline: Newspaper Finds Its Way Onto the Wall
text: Newsworthy, the latest wallpaper from Lori Weitzner, a textile and product designer, is made from strips of recycled newspaper woven together to create a textural surface. “It’s similar to grass cloth, which is a very popular wallcovering where they weave grass on a loom and layer it on paper,” Ms. Weitzner said. Replacing the grass with newspaper (you can still make out some of the text) was a way to create something “beautiful and interesting,” she said. The strips are woven with nylon thread to make the paper more durable and finished with a water-based topcoat that helps protect against yellowing and staining. Newsworthy is 47 inches wide and $125 a yard (to the trade). Information: (888) 609-5551, weitznerlimited.com.

headline: Geithner to Visit China, in Sign of Warming Relations
text: MUMBAI, India — In a sign of improving economic relations between the United States and China, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner will meet the Chinese vice prime minister in Beijing on Thursday on his way back to the United States from India, a Treasury spokesman said here on Wednesday.

headline: Scrutinizing Woods’s Game, and His Sportsmanship
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Shortly after Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer reunite on Thursday morning to hit the honorary opening tee shots in the Masters, 96 golfers will begin battling their own jangling nerves and a firm and fast Augusta National golf course.

headline: Bright New Bowls From Paul Smith
text: Paul Smith Dot, a new line of stainless-steel-and-enamel bowls, was designed to complement an update of Arne Jacobsen’s 1967 Cylinda pitchers and pots — given a shot of characteristic Paul Smith color with bright new handles in pink, yellow, blue, purple and green — and Jacobsen’s Cylinda cocktail set, reinterpreted in black titanium alloy.

headline: Cano, New No. 5 Hitter, Exhibits New Approach
text: BOSTON — According to the Yankees’ charts, Robinson Cano swung at more pitches out of the strike zone last season than any of his teammates.

headline: Carolina Plantation Extends Tours
text: Richard Jenrette, a retired Wall Street financier, bought Millford Plantation in Pinewood, S.C. — an antebellum house he calls the “Taj Mahal of my dreams” — in 1992. He already owned five other grand old homes, but Millford, he said, was “the finest example of pre-Civil War Greek Revival architecture in America.”

headline: Sales at Artemide, Angela Adams and Others
text: Angela Adams’s colorful, graphic wool rugs are 30 percent off while supplies last (Pooky/Blue, above, originally $1,950 for a 9-by-12-foot rug, is $1,365); 273 Congress Street, Portland, Me., (800) 255-9454 or angelaadams.com.

headline: A Mine Boss Inspires Fear, but Pride, Too
text: MONTCOAL, W.Va. — Since Monday’s mine explosion, Don L. Blankenship, the chief executive of the Massey Energy Company, which owns the Upper Big Branch mine, has appeared several times before the cameras. But he has said very little, his face seeming almost expressionless as he quietly answers questions about his concern for miner safety.

headline: Lung Function of 9/11 Rescuers Fell, Study Finds
text: Rescue workers exposed to thick clouds of dust after the attack on the World Trade Center had large drops in lung function lasting at least seven years, a study of nearly 13,000 workers has found.

headline: Thanks for the Tasteless Sermon
text: They are worse than we knew.

headline: Investigators Want to Talk to Rodriguez Assistants
text: Federal agents have reached out to several people who have worked for Alex Rodriguez in an effort to learn more about his relationship with Anthony Galea, the Canadian-based doctor under investigation by various federal authorities.

headline: United Is in Merger Talks With US Airways
text: United Airlines and US Airways are in merger talks that, if successful, would create the nation’s second-biggest airline. It is the third time in a decade that they have tried to make a deal.

headline: Job Creation Basics
text: President Obama recently noted that, by itself, government cannot replace the 8.2 million jobs lost over the past two years. What government can do, he said, is “help to create the conditions” for renewed hiring.

headline: A Ride Home
text: Former Mayor Sharpe James of Newark was released from federal prison and boarded a Greyhound bus for home.

headline: Rwanda: 6 Drown on Their Way to Genocide Memorial
text: Six people drowned after a boat taking them to a genocide memorial service capsized Wednesday in heavy winds on Lake Kivu off the coast of Rwanda. According to the provincial governor, at least 10 were still missing, and more than 50 were rescued from the waters near the city of Kibuye where services were being held to observe the 16th anniversary of the Rwandan genocide. He said that genocide survivors were among the missing. The governor said that the boat had been overloaded and that the mourners drowned within eyesight of the memorial services on the mainland.

headline: Postcard From Zimbabwe
text: HWANGE, Zimbabwe

headline: Before It Ends, Schools ‘Race’ Is a Success
text: Critics of the Obama administration’s signature education initiative have been breathing fire since it was announced that only Delaware and Tennessee had won first-round grants under the program, known as Race to the Top. Politicians from some losing states have denounced the well-designed scoring system under which the 16 finalists were evaluated. Others have thrown up their hands, suggesting that retooling applications for the next round is more trouble than it’s worth.

headline: Bystanders and Bullying
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Work Interns Do, and the Pay They Don’t Get
text: To the Editor:

headline: Our Nuclear Policy Gets a New Look
text: To the Editor:

headline: H1N1 Vaccine, Still Available
text: Just a few months ago, nervous Americans were clamoring for access to vaccines that could protect them against the swine flu. Now there is a glut of vaccine available, and American health officials are renewing their calls for more people to get vaccinated  just in case the virus resurges in coming months.

headline: Send In the Professors
text: Harrisonburg, Va.

headline: A Confederacy of Dunces
text: April is the cruelest month. Or, if you live in Virginia, Confederate History Month.

headline: How Fast Is Your Broadband?
text: There are many ways for marketing professionals to bamboozle customers into believing they are getting a better deal than they actually are  notable among them “as low as” pricing come-ons and offers that promise to deliver “up to” some standard of service.

headline: Modern Design, in Miniature, Is Growing
text: CHRISTINE FERRARA, a 39-year-old public affairs director for the Institute for Advanced Study, a research center in Princeton, N.J., has a passion for modern architecture and design. It began in 2008, when her husband, Steven Birnbaum, a technology consultant, bought her an airy modern home with floor-to-ceiling windows.

headline: Art Shapes a Rural Alabama Compound
text: SEALE, Ala.

headline: Searching for Children’s Bedding
text: AROUND the time she began working as special projects editor for House & Garden in 2003, Susanna Salk noticed that children’s rooms were being featured in shelter magazines, something that would have been almost unthinkable a decade earlier.

headline: For Executives in Concrete Testing Case, a Sentencing and a Suicide Attempt
text: The sentencing of two executives of Testwell Laboratories, once the leading concrete testing company in New York, was reduced to the sentencing of one on Wednesday, after one of the defendants made his second attempt to kill himself.

headline: Nancy Paterson, Who Aided in Milosevic Investigation, Dies at  56
text: Nancy Paterson, an international war crimes prosecutor who played a leading role in building the case linking the former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic to massacres, mass rape and ethnic cleansing in the Balkans in the 1990s, died on March 27 at her home in Bethesda, Md. She was 56.

headline: 24 Down: Vintner’s Concern
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — ’Twas frabjous. ’Twas frumious. ’Twas uffish. The adjective you use to describe today’s solve might likely depend on how familiar you are with a 44 Across creation.

headline: Coots Matthews, Cantankerous Hellfighter, Dies at 86
text: A joke has it that St. Peter was showing a Texan around heaven, with the Texan claiming that everything he saw was better in Texas. St. Peter tired of the routine and pointed to the fire of hell. “Do you have anything like that in Texas?” he asked. The Texan said no, then added, “But there are a couple good old boys in Houston who can put it out for you.”

headline: Morris Jeppson, Airman Who Flew on the Enola Gay, Dies at 87
text: Morris R. Jeppson, an Army Air Forces electronics specialist who helped arm the atomic bomb aboard the Enola Gay as it flew to Hiroshima, died March 30 at a hospital in Las Vegas. Mr. Jeppson, who was 87 and lived in Las Vegas, was the next-to-last survivor of the 12 men who carried out history’s first atomic strike.

headline: Video Hints at Mind of Man Accused in a Killing
text: The detectives were about to leave the room after informing David Tarloff that he would be charged with murdering an Upper East Side therapist, but Mr. Tarloff would not let them go without some parting words.

headline: Before and After in Washington Heights
text: A couple reinvents their living room, adding a work space, with the help of the interior designer Kimberly Hall.

headline: A Writer Gets a Home Office of Her Own
text: AFTER spending several months looking for a three-bedroom apartment in Washington Heights, Emily Raboteau and Victor LaValle, novelists who are engaged to be married this summer, finally accepted that all they could afford was a two-bedroom — which meant that only one of them would have a home office for writing.

headline: Iona Hires Cluess From C.W. Post
text: Iona College players met with their new coach, Tim Cluess, in the team’s locker room Wednesday night. Cluess, formerly the coach at C.W. Post, accepted the job of replacing Kevin Willard, who departed recently to take the same position at Seton Hall. Iona’s sports information director, Brian Beyrer, said a news conference would be scheduled for Friday.

headline: A Ranger Rises to His Coach’s Challenge
text: Coach John Tortorella admitted Wednesday that the club’s hopes of qualifying for the playoffs were growing dim. “There’s no more time,” he said. “No more time.”

headline: On the Energy Gap and Climate Crisis
text: It’s worth beginning Dot Earth’s new iteration with a few straightforward points about humans and their planet that I feel are powerfully established. Below, I start with several thoughts on energy and climate. In coming days, along with a regular flow of news-driven posts, I’ll add similar foundation-building pieces on relations between people and Earth’s other inhabitants and on ways to mesh humanity’s infinite aspirations with life on a finite planet.

headline: Bosh to Miss at Least Rest of Regular Season
text: Chris Bosh will miss at least the rest of the regular season after sustaining a facial fracture, the Toronto Raptors announced on Wednesday. The injury will cause Bosh to miss at least the final five regular-season games and probably the playoffs if the Raptors qualify.

headline: Nearby Hospitals to Fill Gap When St. Vincent’s Closes
text: A day after St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village announced it was closing its inpatient facilities, other Manhattan hospitals said Wednesday that they were making plans to accommodate its patients, doctors and employees at their own institutions.

headline: Guilty Plea in Death of N.Y.U. Professors’ Daughter
text: A man charged with murdering the daughter of two New York University professors pleaded guilty Wednesday to manslaughter as part of an agreement under which he will be sentenced to 25 years in prison.

headline: White House Presses Japan to Reopen Market to U.S. Beef
text: TOKYO — The Obama administration is stepping up pressure on Japan to reopen its market to American beef, in hopes of helping ranchers and meatpackers gain full access to what was once their most lucrative market.

headline: After One More Minor League Game, Mets’ Reyes Is Set to Play Saturday
text: Barring unexpected complications, Jose Reyes will be in the Mets’ lineup Saturday for their home game against the Nationals. The plan is for Reyes to play one more minor league game Thursday in Port St. Lucie, Fla., then travel to New York, where he will join the team Friday.

headline: At Last Allowed, Muslim Scholar Visits
text: A federal appeals court had ruled in his favor. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton had issued an order that paved the way for a visa. And so, on Wednesday afternoon, Tariq Ramadan stepped off a plane at Newark Liberty International Airport for his first visit to the United States since 2004, when the Bush administration barred him from entering, asserting he had contributed money to terrorist enterprises.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 7, 2010

headline: Newcomers Provide Pitching and Punch
text: BOSTON — Brian Cashman had concentrated on acquiring Curtis Granderson, the first new member of the 2010 Yankees, before last year’s World Series even started. Chan Ho Park, the last player to join the retooled team, did not arrive at spring training until the final day of February, two weeks into spring training.

headline: Teenager Charged in L.I. Hate Crime to Testify
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — Jeffrey Conroy, the Long Island teenager charged with a hate crime in the  fatal stabbing of a Hispanic immigrant, will most likely testify on Thursday in his murder trial. But it remains unclear if he will be allowed to tell the jury what he has told his lawyer — that someone else stabbed the immigrant.

headline: Air Marshals Intervene in Incident on Plane
text: Federal officials were investigating an incident aboard a Washington-to-Denver flight on Wednesday involving a passenger who caused a disturbance.

headline: Corrections
text: A headline and an article on March 30 and another article on April 2 about the bullying and suicide of Phoebe Prince, a freshman at South Hadley High School in Massachusetts, reported that nine students had been charged with crimes including harassment, violating civil rights and statutory rape. The number of students was taken from a March 29 statement by Elizabeth D. Scheibel, the district attorney, in which she named six students who were charged with felonies, including an 18-year-old, two 17-year-olds and three 16-year-olds. Ms. Scheibel said that “in addition,” delinquency complaints for similar crimes had been filed in juvenile court against three unnamed females. Her office refused to comment further, citing strict rules on the confidentiality of juvenile proceedings.

headline: Nike Rolls Out Woods Ad With More Questions Than Answers
text: Nike could not wait to package the contrition of Tiger Woods in a 30-second ad.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about a meeting between President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela and visiting Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia reversed their identities in some copies. Mr. Putin was shown at the left and Mr. Chávez at the right.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a powerful earthquake that shook Southern California on Sunday afternoon misstated, in some editions, the distance between Yuma, Ariz., and the quake’s epicenter just south of Mexicali, the capital of Baja California, Mexico. It is about 60 miles, not 1,600. And an accompanying map showed an incorrect location for Mexicali. It is on the United States border directly north of the earthquake’s epicenter, not north and west of the epicenter. A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/national.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about the contributions that guard Stephen Curry, a favorite for the National Basketball Association rookie of the year award, has made to the beleaguered Golden State Warriors misstated his age and the order in which he was drafted. He is 22, not 21, and he was drafted seventh over all, not fifth.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in the N.H.L. roundup in some editions on Wednesday about Philadelphia’s victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs misstated the Flyers’ lead over the Rangers in the Eastern Conference after Tuesday’s games. It was 4 points, not 6.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption in some editions on Monday with the Sports Briefing column misidentified the soccer player shown heading the ball in an English Premier League game. He is Mido of West Ham, not Leon Osman of Everton.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Wednesday misidentified the conductor whom Steve White was scheduled to replace at the Metropolitan Opera for “La Traviata” on Wednesday night and for whom he will fill in again on Saturday night. He is Leonard Slatkin, who withdrew  not James Levine, who has been sidelined by a back problem but was not scheduled to conduct those performances.

headline: Daimler, Nissan and Renault Join in Small-Car Alliance
text: PARIS — Renault, Nissan Motor and Daimler on Wednesday unveiled a strategic partnership to share small-car technology and power trains, in a move that comes as automakers are rapidly joining forces to cut costs.

headline: A Career on the Edge
text: Manohla Dargis narrates a look at the career of Dennis Hopper.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Wednesday about the actor Corin Redgrave misstated a detail in the plot of “In the Name of the Father,” one of the movies in which he appeared. The movie was about four people falsely accused in the I.R.A. bombing of a pub in Guildford, England, near London  not a pub in London.

headline: The Mets Fight Back on a Warm Night, but the Result Is All Too Familiar
text: In years past, the second home game of the year for the Mets was something best avoided. It was often cold and windy at Shea Stadium, with a few brave souls, amazed at how quickly the excitement and buzz from opening day had dissipated, shivering under blankets scattered around the vast park.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on Wednesday, about President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, incorrectly described Gen. Stanley McChrystal’s position. He is the top American commander in Afghanistan, not the head of Central Command.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Kyrgyzstan President Says He Will Not Step Down
text: MOSCOW — A transitional government in Kyrgyzstan declared that it was in charge on Thursday, a day after deadly protests forced the president to flee the capital. But the president himself insisted that he would not step down, issuing veiled threats from an unknown location that suggested the country, the site of a vital American military base, could face renewed instability.

headline: CKE’s New Mystery Bidder: Apollo
text: When CKE Restaurants said on Wednesday that it had received a new takeover offer that was likely to trump a $928 million bid from THL Partners, many investors and analysts questioned who the mystery bidder was.

headline: 2 Are Hit, Benches Are Warned, and Players Laugh
text: BOSTON — It was only natural that at some point during the Yankees’ series with the Boston Red Sox, the umpires would warn the benches. It happens so often now that the participants laugh about it.

headline: What It’s Like to Be Yelled at by Tortorella
text: Erik Christensen scored two of the Rangers’ first three goals — including one just 21 seconds after the opening draw — in their critical 5-1 victory over the visiting Maple Leafs on Wednesday. The win kept the Rangers’ playoff hopes alive going into their season-ending home-and-away weekend series against the Flyers.

headline: Obstacles Remain for the New G.M.
Backup iPhone Power in a Slim Device
text: After my recent article about how to maximize the battery life of a smartphone, I heard from many manufacturers of backup batteries hoping that I would mention their products.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Thursday about young gossip bloggers referred incorrectly to Fred Mwangaguhunga, the founder of MediaTakeOut.com. As the article noted, he is 36, so he started blogging in his fourth decade, not his third. The article also misstated the name of a former employer of Foster Kamer, a staff writer for the Village Voice news blog Runnin’ Scared. It is Blackbookmag.com, not BlackBook.com. And because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly to two sisters-in-law who were the subject of a report in The Gloss. Minnie Mortimer, not Tinsley Mortimer, married the filmmaker Stephen Gaghan.

headline: A Food-Photographing Phenomenon
text: WHO has posted nearly nearly 9,000 photos of what he’s eaten on his Web site?

headline: Assessing Response to Illegal Smoke and Quip
text: WASHINGTON — When an illicit pipe and a foolish joke aboard an airliner touches off a national megascare, scrambling fighter jets and F.B.I. agents, alerting all 4,900 flights in progress and unleashing a media flood, does that mean the security system works?

headline: Word of the Day | chimerical
text: chimerical •\ki-ˈmer-i-kəl, kə-, -ˈmir-\• adjective

headline: News Quiz | April 8, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Another Granderson Blast a Sign of Things to Come?
text: BOSTON — Just how many home runs will Curtis Granderson hit in 2010? That seemed a popular question after Granderson was traded to the Yankees, a move that assured he would get 81 games to take aim at Yankee Stadium’s right-field porch. How about 30? Or 35? Maybe 40? More?

headline: Fed Reviews Find Errors in Oversight of Citigroup
text: Citigroup ran into trouble under the noses of federal regulators. But even after taxpayers rescued the financial giant, regulators failed to monitor the company adequately, according to reviews by the Federal Reserve, Sewell Chan and Eric Dash report for The New York Times.

headline: Hollywood Tries to Block Market for Movie Bets
text: In a show of solidarity, many of the film industry’s major players, and some sympathetic lawmakers, have aligned in an 11th-hour push to block new financial instruments that would allow traders to swap contracts tied to box-office results, Michael Cieply and Joseph Plambeck write in The New York Times.

headline: Pressure Builds on Greece as Europe Dawdles
text: With investors becoming increasingly worried about the failure so far of European officials to agree on the terms for loans to Greece, the main banks in Athens added another concern Wednesday by turning to the Greek government for more financial support, Matthew Saltmarsh and Niki Kitsantonis report in The New York Times.

headline: S.E.C. Moves On Consumer Loan-Backed Bonds
text: Credit rating agencies would lose their formal role in evaluating certain bonds backed by consumer loans, like home mortgages, under rules proposed on Wednesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Instead, the companies issuing these bonds would have to vouch for their soundness.

headline: British Airways and Iberia Seal Merger
text: British Airways and the Spanish airline Iberia have signed a merger agreement, formalizing a long-awaited deal to create one of the world’s largest airline groups to compete with rivals like Air France-KLM and Lufthansa, the companies announced Thursday, Nicola Clark reports in The New York Times.

headline: Are You Optimistic About the Future of Your Country?
text: In “Relax, We’ll Be Fine,” Op-Ed columnist David Brooks writes “the fact is, despite all the problems, America’s future is exceedingly bright.” Whether you live in the U.S. or elsewhere, how do you feel about where your country is headed? Are you generally optimistic, or pessimistic? Why?

headline: Start-Ups Fuel Growth in Super-Fast Trading
text: Tumbling technology costs have opened potentially lucrative ultra-fast trading strategies to tiny start-up players, fueling growth of the opaque and controversial business across Europe and the United States, Reuters writes.

headline: JPMorgan Said to Double Tokyo Commodities Team
text: JPMorgan Chase has almost doubled the number of its Tokyo commodity traders to meet demand from utilities seeking to use coal-derivatives to hedge against price swings, said a person with knowledge of the expansion, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Plot Twists
text: Three novel solutions to the urban garden.

headline: A Call for Fed to Raise Rates Unsettles Investors
text: Wall Street investors were rattled on Wednesday by the prospect of higher interest rates and new signs that consumers were reluctant to spend again, The New York Times’s Javier C. Hernandez reported.

headline: Geithner Warns E.U. on Hedge Fund Rules
text: Timothy Geithner, the head of the Treasury, has warned Britain, France, Germany and Spain about possible new European Union rules that he fears could prevent American hedge funds from selling to European customers, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Banks Said to Sidestep Lawsuits From Crisis
text: Lawsuits leveled at banks as a result of the financial crisis are being dismissed in large numbers based on various forms of a “global financial catastrophe defense” that shifts blame to the weakened economy and away from the banks themselves, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: U.S. Judge Seizes $105 Million in Argentine Funds
text: April 9, 6:24 p.m. | Updated Argentina quickly said it would file a court appeal after a  federal judge in the United States ruled Wednesday that bondholders can seize $105 million in Argentine central bank deposits held in the United States. A bank spokesman told The Associated Press that Argentina was optimistic because similar rulings had been overturned.

headline: A Timely Global Mosaic, Created by All of Us
text: Update, May 17 | It is now possible to search the “Moment in Time” interactive gallery by the name given in the photographer’s credit line (actual name, pseudonym or screen name, as the contributor chose). You’ll find the search box in the upper right corner of the opening page. If you believe your picture wasn’t posted, we urge you to give this a try.

headline: Countries Urged to Plan for End of Stimulus
text: An international financial organization urged advanced economies on Wednesday to begin laying the groundwork now so that next year they could start removing economic stimulus measures, The New York Times’s Matthew Saltmarsh reported.

headline: China Said to Be Close to Announcing Currency Revision
text: The Chinese government is very close to announcing a revision of its currency policy in the coming days that will allow greater variation in the value of its currency combined with a small but immediate jump in its value against the dollar, people with knowledge of the consensus emerging in Beijing said Thursday, Keith Bradsher reports in The New York Times.

headline: Russia and U.S. Sign Nuclear Arms Reduction Pact
text: PRAGUE — The United States and Russia opened what they called a new era in their tumultuous relationship on Thursday as they signed an arms control treaty and presented a largely united front against Iran’s nuclear program, marking a sharp change since they broke over the Georgia war two years ago.

headline: Aeroflex Gears Up for $500 Million in I.P.O.
text: Aeroflex Holding, a maker of electronic equipment used in wireless communications, plans to raise up to $500 million in an initial public offering.

headline: Prosecutors Seek 335 Years for Petters
text: 6:34 p.m. | Updated Tom Petters was sentenced to 50 years in prison, according to Bloomberg News.When the corporate empire of a Minnesota businessman, Tom Petters, collapsed, the losers in what prosecutors say was a $335 million Ponzi scheme included not just hedge funds, but at least 10 pastors, three missionaries, dozens of retirees and a half-dozen nursing home residents, according to federal court filings.

headline: Miller Buckfire Chairman Joins A.I.G. Board
text: American International Group named Henry Miller, chairman and co-founder of the boutique investment bank Miller Buckfire, to its board, according to a company statement Wednesday.

headline: Mumbai Gets an Organic Market
text: Organic cotton: a sensible concept. Cotton candy: frivolous, but delicious. But organic cotton candy — these three words are not natural bedfellows. Nonetheless, the adventurous spirit of the Indian sweet tooth knows no bounds. Now, thanks to a new organic farmers’ market in Mumbai (Nilgiri Garden, Bandra Hindu Association, Linking Road, Bandra West), you can get a natural sugar rush — imagine eating a nimbus cloud that passed over a molasses factory — alongside local, pesticide-free food.

headline: Cumulus Media and Crestview Form Venture
text: The radio station owner Cumulus Media and private equity firm Crestview Partners said Wednesday that they formed a strategic investment partnership that may spend over $1 billion acquiring radio broadcasting companies, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Thai Leader Cancels Trip to Summit Meeting
text: BANGKOK — Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva canceled a trip to a regional summit meeting in Vietnam on Thursday as thousands of antigovernment protesters remained in the streets of central Bangkok, defying a state of emergency the government declared a day earlier.

headline: S.E.C. Says Morgan Keegan Misled Brokers and Clients
text: When the subprime credit structure began to shake and then to crumble, money managers who had invested in it were faced with hard decisions.

headline: Chinese Bank Wooed as It Prepares Major I.P.O.
text: 9:25 a.m. | Updated Reporting from Hong Kong, Bettina Wassener has more on the offering.

headline: Why Shouldn’t Vegans Eat Oysters?
text: Today’s idea: Even the strictest food ethicist should have no qualms about sliding oysters down his gullet with abandon, a writer says. After all, oysters have no central nervous system, so pain isn’t much of an issue, and farming them makes all kinds of sense.

headline: In Praise of Ron Conway
text: For those in Silicon Valley, Ron Conway is more than just an prominent angel investor, he is “crucial to our community and ecosystem,” TechCrunch’s Michael Arrington writes.

headline: Best Left Tackles in the N.F.L: The Top 10 List
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely – but not strictly – by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, although the future isn’t ignored. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: Deutsche Hires Viking Partner for H.F. Unit
text: Deutsche Bank said Wednesday that it had hired  Doug Kline, a partner at Viking Global Investors, to lead its hedge fund consulting unit, which advises funds on infrastructure and business building, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Primus Buys Majority Stake in Chapdelaine
text: Primus Financial, an independent Hong Kong investment company founded by a former senior Citigroup banker, said Wednesday that it had inked a deal to take a 70 percent stake in Chapdelaine, a New York-based municipal bond broker, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Eating Vegetables Doesn’t Stop Cancer
text: A major study tracking the eating habits of 478,000 Europeans suggests that consuming lots of fruits and vegetables has little if any effect on preventing cancer.

headline: Wilding
text: A somewhat archaic description of recent gang violence in New York.

headline: Ending ‘Too Big to Fail’
text: Simon Johnson is a professor at M.I.T.’s Sloan School of management and the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund. He is also the co-author of “13 Bankers.”As we move closer to a Senate — and presumably national — debate on financial reform, the central technical and political question is: What would prevent any bank or similar institution from being regarded — ultimately by the government — as so big that it would not be allowed to fail?

headline: Head of European Central Bank Says Greece Will Not Be Allowed to Default
text: The European Central Bank sent a signal of support to Greece on Thursday, saying that the government in Athens would not be allowed to default and that a European commitment of support should be taken seriously by investors.

headline: Sampler: Californians May Ride Chinese Rails, and Time Limits on Wine Tasting
text: Looking to China for High-Speed Rail Technology | The Chinese government has signed preliminary cooperation agreements with California and General Electric to help build rail lines. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California has closely followed progress in the discussions with China and hopes to travel to China later this year for talks with rail ministry officials, said David Crane, the governor’s special adviser for jobs and economic growth, and a board member of the California High Speed Rail Authority. China is offering not only to build a railroad in California but also to help finance construction. Chinese officials have already been shuttling between Beijing and Sacramento to make presentations, Mr. Crane said. Meanwhile, discussions are set in San Jose on details of routes and station locations for the planned high-speed rail line connecting San Francisco and Anaheim. [The New York Times, The San Francisco Examiner]

headline: Mine Operator Escaped Extra Oversight After Warning

But the mine escaped the stepped-up enforcement even though it continued to amass violations, federal records show.

In Taiwan, television viewers and Internet users are aflutter (and a-Twitter) over the latest homegrown star of a reality singing competition who, like Susan Boyle before him, shows you can’t judge a book by its cover.

headline: Soul Man
text: By age 12, I had a rote reply for grown-ups’ quizzical looks when they heard I went to a Waldorf school: “It’s based on the ideas of Rudolf Steiner.” Blank stare. “He was an Austrian philosopher who believed in teaching the whole student — mind, body and soul.” Luckily no one ever asked me to elaborate, because I’d have been at a loss for words — except to say that we students got to do lots of drawing and painting, which I loved, but we couldn’t skip eurythmy class (yuck). any serious discussions of pedagogic method and what Steiner called his “spiritual science,” anthroposophy, took place out of earshot in the teachers’ room. My only mental picture of Steiner (1861-1925) came from a dim black and white photo showing a stern mouth and X-ray eyes that made me glad this guy wasn’t our headmaster. Oh, well, I reasoned, as soon as I enter the real world after graduation, it’s Goodbye, Dr. Steiner.

headline: U.S. Retailers Report Strong Gains for March
text: The nation’s retailers reported their strongest monthly sales growth in a decade on Thursday, with robust gains in virtually every category of merchandise and every type of store.

headline: Introducing Staying Alive: What It’s Like to Struggle
text: It’s a sweltering August morning in Midtown Manhattan, and the loading dock foreman is cursing me for my terrible truck-parking skills. Yesterday I was here meeting my client, wearing a suit and tie and looking slick. Today I got up at 4 a.m. to drive the truck and deliver the job. Yesterday I went in the front door; today I take the freight elevator. Did I get demoted overnight? No, I’m the boss. I need this delivery to go smoothly, and the recession has thinned my work force, so here I am — parking the truck.

headline: Motion Comics Series Honors Americans Who Saved Jews
text: When superheroes team up in comic books, they typically combat a great evil. A similar approach is being undertaken with “They Spoke Out: American Voices Against the Holocaust,” a 10-episode series of motion comics. The project is a collaboration between Disney Educational Productions, the David S. Wyman Institute for Holocaust Studies in Washington and the veteran comic book artist Neal Adams. Each episode will highlight a rarely told story of Americans who helped rescue Jews from the Holocaust and include a mix of animation, traditional comic book art, period photographs and film.

headline: New Hominid Species Discovered in South Africa
text: CRADLE OF HUMANKIND, South Africa — Nine-year-old Matthew Berger dashed after his dog, Tau, into the high grass here one sunny morning, tripped over a log and stumbled onto a major archaeological discovery. Scientists announced Thursday that he had found the bones of a new hominid species that lived almost two million years ago during the fateful, still mysterious period spanning the emergence of the human family.

headline: New Cable Series for William H. Macy and Laura Dern
text: Is Showtime ceding its turf as the cable-television home for imperiled female protagonists? That channel — which is already home to a widow-turned-drug lord (on “Weeds”), a housewife with multiple personalities (“The United States of Tara”), that show where Carmela Soprano works at a hospital (“Nurse Jackie”), and is adding a show about a female cancer patient (“The Big C”) — said it was adding a new series that features a male lead. The Hollywood Reporter said Showtime had given a 12-episode order to “Shameless,” which stars William H. Macy (of “Fargo” and Broadway’s “Speed-the-Plow”) as the alcoholic head of a Chicago family coping with the recession. Their mother is absent from the scene, but an 18-year-old daughter (played by Emmy Rossum) brings some gender balance to the lineup.

headline: The Pattern of Irish Sex Abuse
text: As a follow-up to last week’s posts on the historical trends in priestly sex abuse in the United States, I’ve been trying to find similar data on the Irish sex abuse scandal. As far as I can tell, none of the many reports that have been issued in the last decade (the Ferns Report, the Murphy Report, etc.) contain a chronological accounting comparable to what the John Jay Report did for the American Catholic Church. (Though if I’m missing something, please point it my way). The closest thing I’ve found is the Commission to Inquire Into Child Abuse’s report on Ireland’s religious-run reform schools, which solicited claims of abuse from Irish-born adults educated in those schools between 1914 and 1999. Here’s how Brendan O’Neill, the editor of Britain’s Spiked Online, summarizes the findings:

headline: Can You Hear Me Now?

headline: Bobby Steggert, Kate Burton and Boyd Gaines to Star in New A. R. Gurney Play
text: Bobby Steggert will play a character A. R. Gurney based on his own younger self and Kate Burton will portray the stage actress who inspired him, in a production of Mr. Gurney’s new play, “The Grand Manner,” for Lincoln Center Theater, the theater company said Thursday. The production  will also star Boyd Gaines and Brenda Wehle. Mr. Steggert, who is coming off the recent production of “Yank!” at York Theater Company and was featured in the Broadway revival of “Ragtime,” will play Pete, a boarding school student who travels to New York and meets the actress Katharine Cornell (Ms. Burton, of “The Constant Wife” and “The Elephant Man”). Mr. Gaines (“Gypsy,” “Journey’s End”) will play Cornell’s husband, the director Guthrie McClintic, and Ms. Wehle (“Pygmalion,” “Come Back, Little Sheba”) will play her manager, Gert Macy. The play, which stems from Mr. Gurney’s real-life encounter with Cornell at a 1948 production of “Antony and Cleopatra,” will be directed by Mark Lamos. Previews at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater are scheduled to begin on June 1, with an opening night of June 24.

headline: Texas Governor Sponsors Sprint Cup Driver

But Mr. Labonte won the Winston Cup championship in 2000, and he is a friendly, gregarious Texan who has just picked up a one-race sponsorship from an unusual source: Gov. headline: ‘Glee’: It’s the Attitude That’s the Showstopper
text: “GLEE” is a musical, yet music is the least catchy part of the show. Oddly, that works  paradox is the core of this Fox comedy’s off-kilter appeal. It’s maudlin and self-mocking, cheesy and mordantly modern, a shameless rip-off of almost every classic teen movie and also original, a mash-up not just of pop songs and show tunes but also of narrative styles, mixing melodrama and satire. It’s an over-the-top spoof, “Arrested Development” in a high school setting, but there are flickers of “Friday Night Lights” pathos.

headline: ‘Glee’: Attitude, Yes, but Without a Song in Its Heart
text: IN one of the later episodes of the fall run of “Glee,” Finn (Cory Monteith), the malleable, doofy, hunky quarterback cum glee-club star, chooses to pledge his undying dedication to Quinn (Dianna Agron), his conniving though angelic-seeming cheerleader girlfriend, who’s pregnant with a baby he believes to be his.

headline: Disposal of Plutonium From U.S.-Russian Disarmament Is Likely to Take Decades

They say the process for destroying plutonium has not yet started to whittle down the surplus already created by previous agreements.

headline: Umpire Criticizes Yankees and Red Sox
text: Early in Derek Jeter’s career –- he does not remember the year or the opponent –- a pitcher sneaked a pitch past him before he was ready. Jeter vowed to never let it happen again, and ever since, before almost every one of the thousands of pitches he sees, Jeter gets into the batter’s box with his right arm raised, asking the umpire for time.

headline: What’s an iPad Cost to Build?
text: What satisfies serious techies more than taking a brand-new iPad out of its box?

headline: Andrew Jackson’s Term Extended
text: The Public Theater’s production of the rock musical “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson” will run for an additional two weeks, through May 9, in response to audience demand, the theater announced on Thursday. The show, which blends emo-rock with political populism in presenting the seventh president as a sort of rock-star celebrity, opened on Tuesday to rave reviews from most theater critics. Ben Brantley, writing in The New York Times, said the show stakes a claim “as the most entertaining and most perceptive political theater of the season.”

headline: Malcolm McLaren, Impresario and Rock Music Manager, Is Dead
text: 2:45 p.m. | Updated Malcolm McLaren, the impresario, promoter and self-promoter who once claimed to have invented punk rock, and who assembled and managed the youthful, unruly members of the Sex Pistols, the breakthrough British punk band, has died. He was 64.

headline: Working a Bronx Parking Lot, at Age 100
text: Joe Binder, the mascot of Arthur Avenue, in the Bronx, turns 100 this week. And to celebrate with the neighborhood, he'll take a day off from work as a valet.

headline: Florence Welch | The ‘Lungs’ Singer Is All Legs
text: It has been a whirlwind breakout year for Florence Welch of the British group Florence & the Machine. Her debut album, “Lungs,” made a splash on both sides of the pond with songs like the euphoric “You’ve Got the Love” and the mood-enhancing “Rabbit Heart (Raise It Up)” blaring in the clubs from Chelsea to, well, Chelsea.

headline: Privacy Groups Urge F.T.C. to Examine Real-Time Ad Auctions
text: Three privacy groups filed a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission on Thursday morning, asking it to examine real-time auctions for online advertising slots.

headline: Youth Recants Confession in Hate Crime Trial
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — The Long Island teenager charged with killing a Hispanic immigrant in a racially motivated attack took the stand on Thursday, not only to proclaim his innocence, but also to accuse another teenager of the murder.

headline: Teaching About Web Includes Troublesome Parts
text: MILPITAS, Calif. — When Kevin Jenkins wanted to teach his fourth-grade students at Spangler Elementary here how to use the Internet, he created a site where they could post photographs, drawings and surveys.

headline: MGMT’s Sophomore Challenges
text: IT helps to be in the right place at the right time, certainly, but the exuberance-of-youth moment that the spacey electro-pop duo MGMT captured around the summer of 2008 was less about serendipity than about having the perfectly tuned attitude, with hooks.

headline: Doctors and Patients, Lost in Paperwork
text: In “The Hostile Hospital,” from the Lemony Snicket “Series of Unfortunate Events” books, the three young orphans at the center of the story visit the fictitious Heimlich Hospital, where Babs, the head of human resources, asks them if they know what the most important work done in a hospital is.

headline: Paperwork vs. Patients
text: In today’s Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen writes about how the administrative responsibilities of doctors can sometimes steal time away from the actual patient. She writes:

headline: Advice From a Man Who Rescued New York
text: Felix G. Rohatyn, the chief architect of the plan that saved New York City from bankruptcy in the mid-1970s, said Thursday that a similar proposal being pushed by Lt. Gov. Richard Ravitch represented the best hope for New York State.

headline: The Revolving Door and S.E.C. Enforcement
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime and securities law for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: Teachers Union President Elected in Landslide
text: Michael Mulgrew has been the leader of the city teachers’ union for months already, ever since Randi Weingarten headed to Washington to lead the American Federation of Teachers and hand-picked him as her successor.

text: CARMEL, N.Y.
