text: Is it news when somebody says something if it is unthinkable that person would say the opposite?

headline: Why So Glum? Numbers Point to a Recovery
text: The American economy appears to be in a cyclical recovery that is gaining strength. Firms have begun to hire and consumer spending seems to be accelerating.

headline: Q & A With Andrew Scrivani (Round 2)
text: Q.

headline: Transportation Department to Finance Distracted-Driving Effort
text: From our colleagues at the Bits blog:

headline: Photo of the Week
text: Passengers walk past a viewing area at the Beijing Capital International Airport in Beijing, China.

headline: The Rhythm of the City, Unmuffled
text: While many city neighborhoods have been turned into sanitized and silenced versions of themselves, East Harlem is boisterous and pulses with energy. Strains of Latin music waft from car windows, elevated trains screech from above and wind chimes clink in community gardens. Street art is everywhere: on the sides of buildings, on trash in abandoned lots, among transformed town houses and around new restaurants. Here are ways to navigate its chaos and ebullience.

headline: The Morning Skate: Rangers’ Chances, Flames Doused and an Igloo Farewell
text: The Rangers’ playoff chances remain tenuous but alive. Their win Wednesday night over the Maple Leafs (Jeff Z. Klein’s Times article here) leaves them a point behind the eighth-place Bruins, 2 behind the seventh-place Flyers and 3 behind the sixth-place Canadiens. Boston has three games to play (Buffalo on Thursday, then Carolina and Washington), the Canadiens have two (Carolina on Thursday, then the Leafs) and the Flyers and Rangers play their home-and-home series Friday and Sunday.

headline: Beyond Black
text: A look at the costumes for the Broadway musical "The Addams Family," narrated by Julian Crouch, the co-designer and co-director.

headline: Prevention: More Health Care Workers Got Flu Shots This Season
text: Flu shots are recommended for all health care providers, but fewer than half get vaccinated in a typical flu season. This season was different: by mid-January, 62 percent of health care workers had received a seasonal flu shot, though only 37 percent had been vaccinated against the H1N1 swine flu, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention are reporting.

headline: Risks: Greater Risks for Cancer Patients With Diabetes
text: People with diabetes are at increased risk for developing some cancers and are more likely than nondiabetics to die of cancer. Now a study reports that they also have a higher risk of dying in the weeks just after cancer surgery.

headline: To Get to Playoffs, Rangers Must Face an Unlikely Foe
text: Standing in the Rangers’ path to the N.H.L. playoffs is Brian Boucher, a 33-year-old goaltender whom the Philadelphia Flyers drafted in the first round in 1995 with the idea that he would become the next Bernie Parent. He is the Flyers’ goalie now, but Boucher did not take a straight line to the job.

headline: For Some Fans, One and Done With Woods Was Good Enough
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — With skies darkening and personal commitments calling, gallery members kept a steady stream at the exits about 2 p.m. Thursday — many having squeezed in Tiger Woods’s first shot as their last shot of the day.

headline: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 10:45 A.M.
text: Chaperons accompanying students from France lined up on the steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art for a group photograph.

headline: Romeo, Juliet and Jeff Buckley’s Music
text: A world-premiere musical adaptation of “Romeo and Juliet,” featuring music and lyrics by the singer-songwriter Jeff Buckley, has been added to the 2010 summer season at the Williamstown Theater Festival, executives there announced on Thursday.

headline: Saying No to Back Surgery
text: The latest Journal of the American Medical Association has another example of the downsides of too much medical care: back surgeries that bring more complications and no better results. The article, by Dr. Richard A. Deyo of Oregon Health and Science University, and others, reports:

headline: Anatoly F. Dobrynin, Longtime Soviet Ambassador to the U.S., Dies at 90
text: Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the Soviet ambassador to Washington from 1962 to 1986, whose behind-the-scenes diplomacy was credited by many historians with helping to resolve the Cuban missile crisis and ease tensions in the cold war era, has died, the Kremlin announced Thursday. He was 90.

headline: Courting the U.K. Women’s Vote, Online and Unrelenting
text: LONDON — They have submitted to sharp questioning in live Web chats on Mumsnet, the popular social networking site for mothers. They have sat for lengthy interviews with Cosmopolitan, Glamour and other female-friendly publications, and regularly deployed their wives in an effort to establish good domestic-coziness credentials.

headline: Rescuers Work to Save Scores Buried in a Brazil Landslide
text: NITERÓI, Brazil — Rescue workers worked feverishly on Thursday to clear debris and uncover the bodies of as many as 200 people buried in a neighborhood built atop an old garbage dump that collapsed in a devastating landslide on the outskirts of Rio de Janeiro.

headline: Theater Listings: April 9 — 15
text: THEATER

headline: Dear FloFab: Your Dining Dilemmas, Solved
text: Each Thursday, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Picture Your Life After Cancer
text: A collage of photos and insights submitted by readers.

headline: 3 Plead Not Guilty to Corruption in Namibia
text: WINDHOEK, Namibia — Three suspects in a $12.8 million kickback scheme involving the sale of Chinese-made X-ray scanners last year to the Namibian government pleaded not guilty on Thursday to 13 charges of corruption, money laundering and fraud.

headline: Manchester United Signs Its First Mexican Player
text: Manchester United on Thursday announced the signing of the young striker Javier Hernández from Chivas Guadalajara, the first time the English Premier League club has acquired a player from Mexico.

headline: Answers From a Hip-Hop Veteran, Part 2
text: Following is the second set of answers from Jorge Pabon, a performer and choreographer known as Pop Master Fabel, who responded to questions about the history and culture of hip-hop.

headline: How Political Numbers Add Up in the Bay Area
text: The June primary election is less than two months away, and some campaigns are in full swing. The political landscape in the Bay Area is shifting as Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger’s era comes to an end and what may be the Tea Party era begins.

headline: Who Will Win Pulitzer Prize for Drama?
text: Any informed speculation, gut calls, or plain guesses on which play or musical will win the Pulitzer Prize for drama on Monday afternoon?

headline: A One-of-a-Kind Street in Fort Greene
text: From Myrtle Avenue to the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, Vanderbilt Avenue in Brooklyn is a wide downhill boulevard flanked by Greek, Gothic and Italianate houses.

headline: Met Will Finally Show a Picasso He Disowned
text: Picasso denied having painted “Erotic Scene” (known as “La Douleur,” or “The Pain”) a sexually charged canvas of a naked woman with her head buried in a young man’s lap. “I’ve done worse,” Picasso told Pierre Daix, one of his pals and the author of several books about him. “But it was a joke by friends.”

headline: Letter: The Tiger Bubble
text: Jonathan Mahler astutely assesses Tiger Woods’s impact on the world of professional golf, but he underestimates his role in promoting and popularizing the sport in the U.S., especially among minorities. Mahler writes that “Woods didn’t democratize golf. . . . Nor did Woods increase the number of people playing golf.” But several studies by the National Golf Foundation clearly prove that during the 1990s and early 2000s, increasing numbers of Hispanic-Americans, Asian-Americans, Native Americans and African-Americans began playing the game, mostly on municipal or semiprivate, daily-fee public courses. For example, the number of active black golfers over the age of 5 grew from 360,000 in 1986 to 649,000 in 1990 and to 882,000 in 1999 and to 2,330,000 in 2003.

headline: Ambulances to Cease Service to St. Vincent’s
text: The New York Fire Department will stop ambulance runs to St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village at 10 a.m. on Friday, a department spokesman said on Thursday.

headline: Letters: Losing It
text: Dominique Browning’s chronicle of her descent into and return from despair offers a message of hope to all of us whose jobs have been wrested away. She identifies the deepest insults inflicted by involuntary unemployment — the disruption of the basic routines of eating and sleeping, the awful aloneness, the doubts, the drift. She takes us with her all the way to the bottom where, face to face with nothing, she drinks a toast to life. Her account of selling the family home is a reminder that breaking with the past is not easy, but her description of her new life in Rhode Island is a testament to the healing powers of nature, music and great books. She seems to have recovered the  “I”  on her keyboard as well as the “I” in her life. She lost her job but found herself.MICHAEL MCCLAINSt. James, N.Y.

headline: Letters: Heading Off the Next Financial Crisis
text: David Leonhardt’s suggestions for reregulating the banks and shadow banks are commendable. However, I would like to express a word of caution based on a concern that the problems that led to the economic meltdown have been only partly addressed. What about some workable suggestions for cleaning up the detritus in the form of the hundreds of billions of dollars in toxic assets that remain on the balance sheets of the 19 stress-tested bank holding companies, which could cause inestimable economic damage in the event of a double-dip recession?MORLEY GORSKYToronto

headline: North Korea’s Nuclear Path Under Kim Jong-il
text: During the 17-year rule of Kim Jong-il, North Korea became a dictatorship armed to the teeth but unable to feed its own people without foreign aid.

headline: Letter: The Ethicist
text: In Randy Cohen’s response to the university teacher who expressed misgivings about her grading policy, he suggests that a grade may be awarded to inspire a student rather than to reflect that student’s achievement. But two students who perform at the same level in all aspects of a course deserve the same grade, regardless of their personalities, attitudes or talents. Using grades for any purpose other than to reflect mastery of course material is neither useful nor fair.STEVEN M. CAHNProfessor of Philosophy, CUNY Graduate CenterOld Greenwich, Conn.

headline: ‘Anthill’
text: Two weeks before Labor Day, Raphael Semmes Cody sat with his cousin Junior in Roxie's Ice Cream Palace. Both were scooping out almond crunch ice cream covered with butterscotch syrup and sprinkled with chopped walnuts. Outside, heavy air grown humid from passage over the Gulf of Mexico and torrid from radiant heat off the Florida Panhandle had come to rest upon the little town of Clayville. The Alabama sky, mercilessly clear, offered no promise of an afternoon shower. Customers entering the Palace plucked at shirts and blouses stuck with sweat to their bodies.

headline: The Rhythm of the City, Unmuffled
text: While many city neighborhoods have been turned into sanitized and silenced versions of themselves, East Harlem is boisterous and pulses with energy. Strains of Latin music waft from car windows, elevated trains screech from above and wind chimes clink in community gardens. Street art is everywhere: on the sides of buildings, on trash in abandoned lots, among transformed town houses and around new restaurants. Here are ways to navigate its chaos and ebullience.Here is a suggested itinerary, which will be in Sunday’s Metropolitan section. Share your own suggestions for things to do in East Harlem in the comments box below.

headline: Letter: Earning Her Food
text: As an octogenarian myself, I read with great admiration Betty Fussell’s Lives column of the courage and stamina she exhibited on her deer-hunting expedition in Montana with her son, Sam. It would have given me greater satisfaction, however, if she had not had the heart to pull the trigger.GLORIA GENIN LESTERDelray Beach, Fla.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Without a Leader in Kyrgyzstan
text: The demonstrations continued in Kyrgyzstan, where the upheaval led to widespread looting and vandalism (Slide 3) in the capital, Bishkek. One striking image comes from inside the ransacked Parliament building (Slide 4) — the sight of a leaderless country. But perhaps the most startling image in today’s show (Slide 7) comes from Akobo, in southern Sudan, which has been affected by drought and tribal clashes. The United Nations mission calls it “the hungriest place on earth.”

headline: Life Lessons, Taught by Insects
text: “Anthill” is E. O. Wilson’s 25th book. It is also the slightest of them, perhaps because it’s his first novel. Mr. Wilson begins with an epigraph from Webster’s Third New International Dictionary, a definition of “anthill” that suggests a parallel between ant and human societies — a potent analogy, you’d think, for a great entomologist and the founder of sociobiology.

headline: Letter: The HBO Auteur
text: As described in Wyatt Mason’s article (March 21), trying to capture the “transcendence” of a city challenges any writer or director, and to set a television show in New Orleans after the worst man-made disaster in our history will be a tough nut to crack. I had hoped that “Treme” would be set in present-day New Orleans, because we have come a long way since Hurricane Katrina, and after reading Mason’s article it looks as if David Simon can pull it off. Thank you, Mr. Simon, for understanding how truly unique this city is and for thinking of our music not just as a theme song but also as a central character to all of our lives, in good times and, in this case, very, very bad times.MARK GARCIENew Orleans

headline: Correction: The Medium
text: The Points of Entry section of The Medium column on March 28, about the ways companies present themselves to the public on their Web sites following controversy, misspelled the surname of the author of “PR! A Social History of Spin.” He is Stuart Ewen, not Ewan.

headline: The Secret Sharer
text: Your unauthorized biography of Oprah Winfrey, who turned daytime television into a form of confession and became one of the wealthiest women in the world, comes out this week. The book presents her as a cold manipulator who requires everyone around her to sign confidentiality agreements. What do you consider the most significant disclosure in the book?  What I think is the most tantalizing part is that she’s so secretive, that there are so many secrets.

headline: Apple Edges Into Selling of App Ads
text: CUPERTINO, Calif. — Apple, the maker of popular gadgets, is getting into the business of selling advertising, ratcheting up its rivalry with Google.

headline: Nikkei Restricts Links to Its New Web Site
text: TOKYO — Japan’s largest business newspaper, the Nikkei, joined the trend of other news sites last week by requiring readers to pay to view its Web site. But, in a twist, it also imposed a policy severely restricting links to its articles — or even its home page.

headline: Continuing Days of Independence for Calle 13
text: SAN JUAN, P.R.

headline: A New Way to Avoid Misbehaving Around Enforcement Cameras
text: For motorists who believe they have a right to know when they are under electronic surveillance, or who simply don’t want to get a traffic ticket, a new device alerts drivers when they are approaching a speed or red-light camera.

headline: Show Me the Money
text: Actually, show me the numbers. I won’t pass judgment on the apparent agreement about the renminbi until I get some sense of what magnitude of adjustment we’re talking about here. I fear that it will be cosmetic — a tiny rise and bit of flexibility, just to silence the Obama administration for a while. But let’s hope I’m wrong.

headline: B. Smith Closes a Chapter
text: B. SMITH could well be in many corners of your home. Her cookbooks might be in your kitchen. Her duvets may cover your bed. Now the tables are turned, and you can decorate her apartment — if you have $6 million to spare.

headline: Three-Bedroom Skybox in the Major Leagues
text: THE Mets are now the third most valuable team in baseball, worth some $858 million, according to Forbes magazine. And on Monday, they opened their season with a sound thumping of the Florida Marlins, 7-1. (We don’t have to talk about last season.) Welcome back, fellas!

headline: Fiscal Fantasies
text: David Frum is startled by Larry Kudlow’s ignorance about the federal budget; Kudlow imagines that a pay cut for federal employees could have a huge impact on the deficit, when in fact it would be trivial.

headline: London’s East End Gets Cool New Hotel
text: The  Town Hall Hotel & Apartments, a 98-room boutique hotel set to open this month in the gritty surrounds of London’s Bethnal Green, is being hailed as further proof that the city’s east end is firmly on the road to chicness.

headline: Sculptor Deaccessions Harlem Town House
text: SANDY STARKMAN, a sculptor and designer who has a line of women’s clothing on the racks at stores like Neiman Marcus, just sold his town house in Harlem for $1.9 million. The house was first listed for $3.4 million in late October 2008, about a month after the collapse of Lehman Brothers — not the optimum time to put a home on the market.

headline: Musician Royalties Rise on Satellite and Online Radio
text: For musicians, it always pays to have songs played on satellite and online radio – but in the first quarter, it paid even more than usual.

headline: Unrest and Uncertainty Grip Kyrgyzstan
text: In the wake of bloody protests, an opposition leader on Thursday announced the formation of a transitional government, but the president announced from an undisclosed location that he would not resign.

headline: Convenient to Ketchup
text: IN today’s real estate market, it is possible to get a nice one-bedroom apartment for $400,000 in Manhattan. One with some Old World charm and a lot of light.

headline: Popcast: The Return of Erykah Badu
text: This week: a review of the new album from R&B star Erykah Badu, a live EP from singer-songwriter Bill Callahan and bassist Richard Bona performs live in the studio. Sia Michels is the host.

headline: Ristretto | Why Is Coffee in Paris So Bad?
text: In Ristretto, Oliver Strand, the curator of the Times Topics coffee page, explores the world of coffee gadgets, coffee beans and why it’s never been easier to get a perfect shot of espresso.

headline: Buh-Da-Da-Dum (Snap Snap)
text: Imagine, if you dare, the agonies of the talented people trapped inside the collapsing tomb called “The Addams Family.” Being in this genuinely ghastly musical  which opened Thursday night at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater and stars a shamefully squandered Nathan Lane and Bebe Neuwirth  must feel like going to a Halloween party in a strait-jacket or a suit of armor. Sure, you make a flashy (if obvious) first impression. But then you’re stuck in the darn thing for the rest of the night, and it’s really, really uncomfortable. Why, you can barely move, and a strangled voice inside you keeps gasping, “He-e-e-lp! Get me out of here!”

headline: Lucky Ducky Redux
text: So the right is now apparently outraged at the fact that many Americans pay no income taxes — a true observation that is elided into the utterly untrue assertion that many Americans pay no taxes. (Almost everyone pays payroll taxes, everyone pays state and local sales taxes, etc.)

headline: From Japan, Psychedelic Care and Feeding
text: Psychedelia was alive and doused in reverb when the Acid Mothers Temple performed at the Knitting Factory on Wednesday night. It’s a band that has chosen its historical era and inhabits it completely, sporting shoulder-length hair and making a mighty noise  hypnotic, cavernous, and often frenetic  the way bands like Hawkwind and Pink Floyd did four decades ago. The difference is that the Acid Mothers Temple covers a broader spectrum than any individual predecessor. They revive an entire era, not a favorite band.

headline: A Photographer Whose Beat Was the World
text: Rarely has the phrase “man of the world” been more aptly applied than to the protean photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson, the subject of a handsome and large  though surely not anywhere near large enough  retrospective opening at the Museum of Modern Art on Sunday.

headline: Causing Outrage
text: Malcolm McLaren, who died today in Switzerland, was never really into fashion, though we fashion writers loved to pick his brain. Mr. McLaren saw the big cultural picture of which fashion was a part, and he sensed the small vibrations long, long before they reached the mainstream. And he continued to be alert to all kinds of changes in music, art — any form of self-presentation.

headline: Tiger Woods Nike Ad
text: The spot uses the voice of Mr. Woods's father to comment on the controversy surrounding the golfer.

headline: Off the Menu: Annisa Reopens
text: Annisa will reopen on Friday after months of renovations, and Anita Lo, the chef and an owner, said she was “really, really nervous and certainly hopeful.”

headline: Chekhov’s Aristocrats, Ever Absorbed in Themselves
text: The fog of repression that smothers many American or British productions of Chekhov’s plays is absent from the Maly Drama Theater’s emotionally unbridled staging of “Uncle Vanya,” which can be seen at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater through Sunday. Commemorating the 150th anniversary of Chekhov’s birth with an international tour, this venerable Russian company, led by Lev Dodin, brings us a savory taste of that country’s most celebrated playwright in the stinging flavors rarely seen on our shores. There is flinty, funny life in these chronically unsatisfied aristocrats absorbed in complaints about their wasted hopes and bleak futures, if only they had the wisdom to see it.

headline: After Katrina, Staying Afloat With Music
text: David Simon’s new HBO series is called “Treme” and the title alone suggests the difficulty of the subject. Treme doesn’t rhyme with ream; it’s pronounced truh-MAY, and it’s the name of an old New Orleans neighborhood famous for music  and, in some parts, for crime. It’s the kind of area sought out by intrepid travelers eager to bypass the tourist traps on Bourbon Street, the kind of place that guidebooks label “authentic.”

headline: Bloomberg Spotted at Hippie Dance Party
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg let his inner flower child blossom during the finale at Wednesday night’s performance of the Broadway revival of “Hair.”

headline: Picture Your Life After Cancer
text: How did your life change after cancer?

headline: Optimism Is Scarce
text: My Friday column, arguing that the economy is doing much better than most of the commentators say it is, was posted this afternoon, and has generated more e-mail than I am used to getting.

headline: The Fearless Press, and Other Legends
text: The clatter of typewriters and the rattle of whiskey bottles in desk drawers; the haze of cigarette smoke in the air; the fedoras and notepads, the sleeve garters and eyeshades; the cries of “Copy!” and “Get me rewrite!”

headline: Movie Listings
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Audacious Expressions on the Walls of the Temple
text: “How to get better religious art is very simple: just commission an artist. Then ask him to act as an artist, with imagination, with freedom, with vision, with daring.” So said the painter Adolph Gottlieb, one of three Modern artists who worked on an innovative Millburn, N.J., synagogue in the early 1950s.

headline: Flocking Together
text: BIRDS far outnumber people  and almost everything else  on Cedar Key in Florida. And residents of the island’s city, who number under 1,000, prefer it that way. Sure, plenty of tourists find their way to the relatively remote locale, but their reasons for coming  bird-watching, fresh clams, seafood restaurants, sports fishing and a gentler Florida  do little to disrupt the laid-back vibe.

headline: Reinvigorating an Artist’s Fantasy
text: A Victorian minaret with a white crescent finial looms over flat-topped brick town houses on a sleepy side street in the Kensington district of London. The domed building is one of the world’s gaudiest one-bedroom homes.

headline: BlogTalk: The Chief Justice, the President and Mitt Romney
text: A Couple of Young Dads Sitting Around Talking: Chief Justice John Roberts says he bears President Obama no ill will, even though their few public encounters have been colored by some awkwardness, like the time the Chief Justice flubbed the president’s oath of office, and earlier this year when the president called out the justices from the dais when he was delivering his State of the Union message.

headline: Listening to a Library at Columbia
text: To the untrained eye, the Columbia students sitting in a library Thursday afternoon reading books and listening to iPods looked a lot like college students sitting in a library reading books and listening to iPods.

headline: Four Lovers, From Masked Decorum to Today
text: Some regional ballet companies like to show what they do well and stick with it. The Richmond Ballet, performing at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday evening, tried a little bit of everything in a repertory program that ran a thematic gamut: period drama, abstract and earthy.

headline: Corcoran Cuts Off Show
text: The Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington closed a major exhibition on Wednesday because the museum’s new climate control equipment was malfunctioning, causing the humidity in three galleries to fluctuate, The Washington Post reported. The show, “Turner to Cézanne: Masterpieces From the Davies Collection, National Museum Wales,” opened Jan. 30 and had been scheduled to run until April 25. New air handling equipment was installed as part of an $11.5 million restoration of the Corcoran’s roof and skylight system, which was completed last month. (The museum previously closed for the renovation for seven weeks in early 2009.) A spokeswoman for the museum, Kristin Guiter, said the humidity levels at no point fluctuated outside the acceptable range defined in the museum’s contract with the American Federation of Arts, which organized the show with the National Museum Wales. “The art was not actually at risk,” Ms. Guiter said, but “we proactively opted to shut the show.” The exhibition, of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings and works on paper from the collection of two sisters, Gwendoline and Margaret Davies, had been well reviewed. Most had never been shown in the United States before. Ms. Guiter said the museum expected to replace the faulty equipment before July, when a show of Chuck Close prints is scheduled to open in the galleries.

headline: Kate Gosselin Plus Others’ Families
text: Kate Gosselin’s next television show will feature her without her famous brood, spending time with other families instead. Ms. Gosselin, right, who became a tabloid fixation last year when her marriage dissolved in front of TLC’s cameras, will star in the reality show “Twist of Kate” starting this summer, TLC said Thursday. In “Twist” Ms. Gosselin will visit the homes and offices of other women. TLC also said it would schedule several special episodes of “Kate Plus 8,” a spinoff of the canceled “Jon & Kate Plus 8.” Ms. Gosselin’s ex-husband, Jon, who is suing her for custody of their eight children, was not mentioned in the announcement of either show.

headline: 9/11 Memorial to Receive $2.9. Million
text: The National September 11 Memorial & Museum is receiving $2.29 million from the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the museum and the corporation announced Thursday. The money will help support the planning, development and construction of the museum’s primary exhibition, related to the events of 9/11, as told by those who experienced and survived the attacks. The exhibition is to feature audio recordings, oral histories and firsthand accounts. The National September 11 Memorial & Museum, a nonprofit corporation, is responsible for fund-raising and overseeing the design, programming and operations of the memorial section of the World Trade Center site.

headline: Steggert and Burton in New Play by Gurney
text: Bobby Steggert, right, will play a character A. R. Gurney based on his own younger self, and Kate Burton, below right, will portray the stage actress who inspired him in a production of Mr. Gurney’s new play, “The Grand Manner,” for Lincoln Center Theater, the theater company said Thursday. The production will also star Boyd Gaines and Brenda Wehle. Mr. Steggert, who is coming off the recent production of “Yank!” at the York Theater Company and was featured in the Broadway revival of “Ragtime,” will play Pete, a boarding-school student who travels to New York and meets Katharine Cornell (Ms. Burton). Mr. Gaines will play Cornell’s husband, the director Guthrie McClintic, and Ms. Wehle will play her manager, Gert Macy. The play, stemming from Mr. Gurney’s encounter with Cornell at a 1948 production of “Antony and Cleopatra,” will be directed by Mark Lamos. Previews at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater are scheduled to begin June 1, with an opening night of June 24.

headline: Part Rockette, Zenyatta Steals the Show
text: INGLEWOOD, Calif. — Zenyatta turned 6 last week and there were plenty of reasons to celebrate at her barn beneath the palm trees of Hollywood Park. Her exercise rider, Steve Willard, bought Zenyatta a birthday cake. The big mare wiped it out in no time. Later in the afternoon, she downed a bottle of Guinness.

headline: ‘Idol’ Ascendant, Still
text: The judges of “American Idol” spared 26-year-old Michael Lynche from elimination on Wednesday night as that reality show’s 9 p.m. results episode attracted 19.7 million viewers for Fox, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although down from the 20.5 million who tuned in the previous Wednesday, the show’s audience remained the night’s largest by a considerable margin. Fox earned the top ratings over all, leading the 8 p.m. hour as well with a more modest 7.7 million viewers for “Human Target,” which edged past CBS’s sitcoms in the time slot, “The New Adventures of Old Christine” (6.1 million) and “Accidentally on Purpose” (6.2 million). CBS’s crime shows “Criminal Minds” (12.5 million) and “CSI: NY” (10.6 million) drew solid ratings at 9 and 10 while NBC ranked a distant third and ABC was fourth.

headline: Equity Files Complaint Against ‘Tony N’ Tina’
text: Actors’ Equity Association has become the latest performers’ union to call foul on the producers of “Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding,” the long-running Off Broadway show, and has filed an unfair-labor-practice charge with the National Labor Relations Board against the producers, the association said Thursday. Representatives for Actors’ Equity said that about three to four weeks ago Broadway Entertainment, which produces “Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding,” posted a closing notice for the show that would end its run at the Edison Hotel. Since then, the association said, the producers have sought a new performance space, violating an Equity rule that producers cannot close and reopen a show within eight weeks without negotiating with the union. (The producers said that on Saturday the show would move to Sweet Caroline’s on West 45th Street.) Equity said in its complaint to the labor board that Broadway Entertainment had failed to recognize the union and had offered employment to its cast members on the condition they resign from Equity or work without its representation. In November the Associated Musicians of Greater New York, Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, protested “Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding” after Broadway Entertainment replaced musicians with recorded music. In a statement Broadway Entertainment said that it was “concerned about our cast,” adding, “We did not intend to violate any rules by Equity but felt we had a responsibility as their employers to offer everyone a fair chance to continue working.”

headline: Motion Comic Recalls Rescuers In Holocaust
text: When superheroes team up in comic books, they typically combat a great evil. A similar approach is being undertaken with “They Spoke Out: American Voices of Protest Against the Holocaust,” a 10-episode series of motion comics. The project is a collaboration among Disney Educational Productions, the David S. Wyman Institute for Holocaust Studies in Washington and the veteran comic book artist Neal Adams. (Above, a drawing from the series.) Each episode will highlight a rarely told story of Americans who helped rescue Jews from the Holocaust and include a mix of animation, traditional comic book art, period photographs and film. The first two episodes, “La Guardia’s War Against Hitler” and “Voyage of the Doomed,” will be screened at an art festival held by the Museum of Comic and Cartoon Art on Sunday at the 69th Regiment Armory in Manhattan. The 10-episode series was written by Rafael Medoff, the director of the Wyman Institute. The comics will also be available at theyspokeout.com beginning Friday evening.

headline: Cash Offers Not Enough to Improve Student Test Scores
text: The results are in for controversial program that promised $50 to New York seventh graders who aced tests, and they show that money was not enough to prod students to perform significantly better.

headline: For Better or Worse, and Tonight It’s Worse
text: It must be said that “Date Night”  in which a suburban married couple out for an evening in Manhattan endure car chases and the unwanted attention of thugs with guns  is superior to most recent movies of its kind, the marital action comedy. This is not saying much: better than “The Bounty Hunter” or “Did You Hear About the Morgans?” is not quite the same as “good.”

headline: A Parking Lot Poet Turns 100, and Arthur Avenue Rejoices
text: In the tiny parking lot booth just west of Arthur Avenue in the Bronx, Joe Binder writes his poems: odes to the Rat Pack and the old days in the neighborhood.

headline: A Banner Day for Augusta Flyovers — and More to Come
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The Web site for Air America Aerial Ads promises customers to “responsibly deliver attention-getting aerial messages to your target.”

headline: Cadets Develop a Fighting Spirit
text: WEST POINT, N.Y. — For more than 100 years, the United States Military Academy has required incoming male cadets to complete an introductory boxing course. The first lesson, both basic and brutal, never changes. Fist, meet face.

headline: Conversation About Picasso Spanning 4 City Blocks
text: Picasso’s prints form a world unto themselves. You can know a lot about his paintings and sculpture without having much of an inkling of his achievement in this supposedly lesser medium.

headline: As Greek Bond Rates Soar, Bankruptcy Looms
text: LONDON — As interest rates on Greek debt spiral upward again, the question facing Europe is no longer whether Athens has the political will to cut spending and raise taxes to curb its gaping budget deficit, but whether Greece will run out of money before it gets the chance to do so.

headline: He Made Antiquity Modern
text: There are lots of gorgeous drawings in “Palladio and His Legacy: A Transatlantic Journey,” which opened last week at the Morgan Library & Museum  just enough to whet the appetites of die-hard Palladio fans.

headline: The Purist | Spring Classics
text: Justin R. Saunders is the creative force behind Jjjjound, the photo-curating Web site with so many cool products that it sometimes crashes the browser. Every once in a while, we ask Saunders to share some of his all-time classic designs for men. Again, he delivered.

headline: Amorphous Improv That Ends Screeching to a Halt
text: The keyboardist Wayne Horvitz, the alto saxophonist Briggan Krauss and the percussionist Lê Quan Ninh gave it to us straight at the Stone in the East Village on Wednesday night. It was tabula-rasa free improvisation: about an hour long, aggressive but not signifying any particular school, loud and soft but mostly loud, way more gestural than narrative, instinctive, abstract, efficacious.

headline: Love the Leap. Pls Kick More. U Tired? BFF.
text: More than ever, the theater has become something of a sanctuary, a welcome diversion from everyday noise  meaning, though not limited to, the awful vibration that a cellphone makes every time a new message comes in via e-mail, text or voice mail.

headline: Of Captains, Caulkers and Hoop Skirt Makers
text: THE little 1830s house at the foot of Vanderbilt Avenue in Brooklyn is beyond wrecked — it’s close to wreckage. It’s at the end of one of the most unusual blocks in Fort Greene, from Myrtle Avenue to the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, a wide downhill boulevard flanked by Greek, Gothic and Italianate houses, an amazing salmagundi of the constructive arts.

headline: Inside the List
text: ZOMBIES FOR PRESIDENT: First the monster mash-up fad came for Abraham Lincoln. Now it’s Barack Obama’s turn. In “Obama Zombies,” Jason Mattera advises how to fend off the legions of glassy-eyed young Obamites who have fallen prey to “the Dave Matthews Electoral Magnet,” “the Hope-a-Dope Mantra,” “Health Care Hypnosis” and other dirty tricks.

headline: Zenyatta Struts Her Stuff
text: Zenyatta is one of the most dominant race horses of a generation, and she appears to know it, strutting through the paddock and hamming it up for adoring fans.

headline: A Big Day for Lacrosse at the Meadowlands
text: BALTIMORE — The N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament was all about the underdog. Just one No. 1 seed (Duke) made the Final Four, and fifth-seeded Butler received more publicity these past two weeks than in the small university’s history thanks to its improbable run to the national championship game. Throughout March, everybody was rooting for the little guy.

headline: Speed Control a Small Factor in Car Claims
text: An analysis of consumer claims submitted to auto manufacturers in recent years shows that speed-control issues — like those that have led to the recall of millions of Toyota vehicles — account for a small percentage of the possible problems brought to the attention of carmakers.

headline: Apple’s Plans for iPhone Location Privacy
text: The boom in mobile services that use information about our physical locations is exciting but also anxiety-producing.

headline: Johnny Rotten Says Farewell to Malcolm McLaren
text: “For me Malc was always entertaining, and I hope you remember that. Above all else he was an entertainer and I will miss him, and so should you.” — John Lydon, a k a Johnny Rotten, the Sex Pistols front man, on the band’s manager Malcolm McLaren, who died on Thursday.

headline: Malcolm McLaren, Seminal Punk Figure, Dies at 64
text: Malcolm McLaren, an impresario, recording artist and fashion designer who as manager of the Sex Pistols played a decisive role in creating the British punk movement, died on Thursday in Switzerland. He was 64.

headline: Protests Planned for Banks’ Shareholder Meetings
text: A coalition of labor unions and liberal interest groups are taking to the streets in a number of demonstrations against Wall Street as the fight over financial reform heats up in Washington.

headline: The Body on the Slab May Not Be All That Dead
text: Icky, nasty, calculatingly odd and a little funny, though more often strained and inadvertently absurd, “After.Life” changes its mood and apparent intentions from scene to scene, sometimes minute to minute. The period separating the words in the title probably alludes to the liminal state in which the heroine finds herself, though it might also be a way to distinguish this movie from others with the same name. Whatever the case, the little dot underscores the rather large conceits that sabotage what might have been a promising horror flick if not for the writing, acting, editing and consistently inconsistent tone.

headline: Waves Rippling and Shimmering in a Sea of Sound
text: While composing his three-movement Chamber Symphony, Louis Karchin was preoccupied with exploring the range of sonorities possible with a small ensemble that included a piano and most orchestral instruments.

headline: An iPad App With Some Ups and Downs
text: In Thursday’s Phone Smart column, I suggested a handful of apps that will most likely prolong an iPad owner’s honeymoon period. I didn‘t include one that’s been particularly great to play with: Air Coaster XL, from the San Francisco developer Ziconic. For $2, you can quickly design a roller coaster with 3-D graphics, then put yourself in the front car for a simulated ride.

headline: Perfectly Happy, Until They Venture Into the Outside World
text: “Everyone Else,” a sun-kissed German film about a young couple in love and in doubt, might not be perfect, but so much is right and true in this lovely, delicate work that it comes breathtakingly close. Written and directed by Maren Ade, it involves Gitti (Birgit Minichmayr) and Chris (Lars Eidinger), who are vacationing at his parents’ Sardinian villa. When the film opens, his sister is whisking her family off, leaving the couple alone. It’s an ideal setup for Gitti and Chris, who can’t keep their hands off each other, and in whose half-dressed bodies you can see and feel the heat of the island, the eroticism too.

headline: Three Merchants Beat the Recession by Selling to Kids
text: MICHAEL ROSENBERG, 58; Burhan Okuyan, 52; and Yosef Shimron, 52, all veteran shopkeepers on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, don’t know one another. Mr. Rosenberg is in clothing; Mr. Okuyan, art framing; Mr. Shimron, computer services. Yet all three, on their own, figured out the same thing. And that discovery has helped them survive the Great Recession when so many shops around them have closed: adults who stop spending on themselves in bad times will still spend on children.

headline: What China’s Currency Shift Could Mean
text: Updated, April 9, 7:30 a.m. |  Michael Pettis, a professor of finance at Peking University, joins the discussion.

headline: Protest Leader Ends Silence, Defying Tehran With a Meeting
text: Iran’s opposition leader renewed his campaign for resistance on Thursday in a meeting with sympathetic politicians. It was his first public act of defiance since the Iranian New Year on March 21, when the authorities boasted that they had quelled the protest movement for good.

headline: Essentials of Noir and 'The Square'
text: Nash Edgerton, the director of "The Square," discusses the elements of film noir that he uses, and discards, in his movie.

headline: Sin and Comeuppance Down Under
text: If you’ve seen “No Country for Old Men” or “A Simple Plan” or any number of other, similar movies, you probably know that nothing good is likely to come from taking somebody else’s bag full of cash. Perhaps Ray and Carla, the adulterous couple at the center of “The Square,” haven’t seen these films, or have drawn the wrong lessons from them. After Carla comes across a satchel full of money that her loutish, vaguely criminal husband has stashed in a crawl space in the laundry room of their house, she and Ray concoct a plan to snatch it and get out of town. What else would they do? And what could possibly go wrong?

headline: ‘The Harvey Girls’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Four Music-Sharing Tricks on Windows 7
text: The other day, someone asked me, “So what’s the coolest feature in Windows 7?”

headline: Correction: American Jeremiad: A Manifesto
text: Because of an editing error, a biographical note for the author of an essay on March 28, about books describing themselves as “manifestos,” misstated the position he held at the time with NPR’s “On Point.” Wen Stephenson was the program’s senior producer, not senior executive producer.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: What We’re Reading: Regulation, Mobile Ads and Cartman
text: The announcement of a new OS for the iPhone and iPad did not suck all the air from the room. Here’s what the tech reporters and editors of the New York Times were reading Thursday:

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Paperback Row
text: BROOKLYN,  by Colm Toibin (Scribner, $15.) A docile young Irishwoman emigrates to Brooklyn in the early 1950s at her sister’s behest. Homesick at first (“Nothing here was part of her”), she eventually meets a man, but when she is called back to Ireland by a family emergency she must choose whether to stay or return. Toibin “is an expert, patient fisherman of submerged emotions,” Liesl Schillinger wrote in the Book Review.

headline: Privacy Issues Hinder Plan on Tracking Terror Assets
text: MADRID — The United States stands ready to cooperate if plans for a new European Union system for tracking terrorism financing come through, a senior Treasury Department official said here on Thursday. But he would not say whether that cooperation would go so far as to share American bank account data.

headline: Protesters From Kansas Take Aim at Miners
text: MONTCOAL W.V. — Protesters from Westboro Baptist Church in Topeka, Kan., headed to the Upper Big Branch mine Thursday morning to convey the message that the explosion there that left 25 miners dead was a result of e-mail messages allegedly sent from West Virginia threatening the Church and its publisher, according to a statement from the Church.

headline: Irish Fog
text: Nothing good can emerge from the foul Dublin fog John Banville conjures in ELEGY FOR APRIL (Holt, $25), the third in an elegantly styled series of crime novels the Booker Prize-winning novelist writes under his Benjamin Black pseudonym. As the story opens, “all day long the foghorns boomed out in the bay,” sounding a dirge for the lost and ruined lives Black attributes to corruption in high places and the repressive attitudes toward gender, race and sexuality in 1950s Ireland.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.

headline: The Godfather of the E-Reader
text: In a Norwegian comedy sketch posted on YouTube, a fur-collared tech guy from a medieval “help desk” comes to the rescue of a monk confronted with a bewildering new machine, the book. Did you try to open it? the tech guy asks. Yes, says the monk, but I was afraid the words would disappear if I turned the page. Don’t worry, the tech guy reassures him. The only way the words will disappear is if you set the whole thing on fire.

headline: That Fire, Lighted and Doused
text: “He’s Hot, He’s Sexy and He’s Dead,” blared the cover line of a 1981 Rolling Stone article about the Doors’ Jim Morrison, 10 years after he died in a bathtub in Paris at 27. There was no autopsy. The same tinge of exploitation applies to “When You’re Strange: A Film About the Doors,” Tom DiCillo’s muddled, pretentious assemblage of film clips of the band shot between 1966 and 1971, with solemn narration by Johnny Depp.

headline: Dance Listings
text: Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

headline: Rangers and Flyers at Intersection of N.H.L. Playoffs
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — With 10 games left in the N.H.L. regular season, the Rangers were seven points out of the final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference. Even the players thought they were out of the running.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: SMALL KINGDOMS  By Anastasia Hobbet.  Permanent Press, $29.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Cinema 16: Film and Music in Brooklyn
text: When Amos Vogel and his wife, Marcia, formed the avant-garde film society Cinema 16 more than 60 years ago, they created an avenue that would introduce American moviegoers to a new sensibility evident in the works of Roman Polanski, John Cassavetes, Alain Resnais and other filmmakers. When the Brooklyn photographer Molly Surno revived the society two years ago, the endeavor was no less ambitious: it reimagines the act of film viewing in contemporary life.

headline: Fictional History: What It Was Like to Start Rock ’n’ Roll, Sort Of
text: “Who Do You Love”  a heavily fictionalized screen biography of Leonard Chess, a founding father of rock ’n’ roll, who with his younger brother, Phil, started Chess Records in Chicago  has neither the star power nor the epic sense of itself that infused “Cadillac Records,” the 2008 film on the same subject.

headline: In 3rd Trial, Conviction in Murders From 1985
text: A soldier acquitted of three murders more than 20 years ago in civilian court was convicted by a military jury on Thursday because of DNA tests that were not available in the earlier trial.

headline: A Change at Apple Causes Trouble for Adobe
text: As it previewed the new version of its iPhone OS on Thursday, Apple also updated the agreement that developers must adhere to if they want to create applications for Apple devices. Amid the more than 21,000 words in the agreement, there are 83 that are sure to set off a brush fire at the headquarters of Adobe Systems.

headline: ‘Cinderella’
text: If a pumpkin can change into a coach, and mice into footmen, why can’t a hen become a housemaid?

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: ‘ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO’ (Friday through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series “Dora the Explorer” and “Go, Diego, Go!” have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Children’s Museum of Manhattan, whose exhibition has separate Dora and Diego environments, including Diego’s Animal Rescue Center and Dora’s Fiesta. Intended for ages 2 to 6, the interactive, bilingual displays are designed to teach language, science and music skills, as well as facts about Latin America. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tisch Building , (212) 721-1223, cmom.org; free with museum admission: $10; $7 for 65+; free for under 1 and members.

headline: Two Nevada Republicans Call for Ensign to Bow Out
text: WASHINGTON — Senator John Ensign’s political troubles worsened Thursday as more Republican colleagues from his home state of Nevada said that the ethics investigations surrounding him have threatened to damage the party statewide.

headline: Rule on Lead Safety Set to Take Effect
text: After almost two decades of delays, the Environmental Protection Agency said Thursday that it was on track to implement a regulation requiring the construction industry to help prevent cases of lead poisoning among children.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,379 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

headline: California: Not So Fast on the Closings
text: Los Angeles may not need the two-day-a-week shutdown of some services that Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa called for to help preserve cash. Ray Ciranna, acting city administrative officer, said revenue was coming in higher and expenses were lower than the city had projected. “Our hope is that we won’t go to two-day or even one day, but we all need to be prepared,” Mr. Villaraigosa told reporters at City Hall on Thursday. The city is proceeding with plans for the service shutdown in case Mr. Ciranna’s assumptions do not pan out, the mayor said.

headline: Massachusetts: Skater’s Brother Indicted
text: The brother of Nancy Kerrigan, the former Olympic figure skater, was indicted Thursday on manslaughter charges in an attack in January that the Middlesex District Attorney said led to their father’s death. Prosecutors said the brother, Mark D. Kerrigan, 45, of Stoneham, Mass., began a fight with his father, Daniel, 70, because the son was not allowed to use the family telephone. They said this “seemingly trivial issue” prompted Mark Kerrigan into a “drunken rage” that led to a violent altercation with his father. The Kerrigan family said in a statement that they continued to support Mark and believed he was not responsible for Daniel’s death.

headline: At 1:42, Woods (Gasp!) Tees Off
text: I started watching ESPN at 11 a.m. Eastern on Thursday, 162 minutes before Tiger Woods’s 1:42 p.m. tee time at the Masters. The 1:42 tee time was critical because it was late enough for ESPN to show most of his round after its first-round coverage began at 4 p.m., and it was the only one of his shots it could show live before then.

headline: Father-Son Conflict on Streets of San Francisco
text: “La Mission” was clearly a labor of love for the Bratt brothers: Peter wrote and directed it, Benjamin is the star, and both took a producer’s credit. They were born in San Francisco in the early 1960s, and the film conveys an intense nostalgia for the Mission District of their youth. The garage of Che Rivera (Benjamin Bratt), a bus driver, ex-con and middle-aged low rider, is a shrine to the post-hippie, pre-gentrification 1970s: César Chávez, Clint Eastwood, Vito Corleone; Alcoholics Anonymous, Chicano culture, the Stylistics. The distinguished cinematographer Hiro Narita (“Never Cry Wolf”) captures the hard San Francisco light and the burnished glow of the beautifully painted cars.

headline: NASA Announces Programs and Costs for Next 5 Years
text: The administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration fleshed out plans for the coming years on Thursday by announcing a lineup of new programs and those NASA centers that would be responsible for them.

headline: From Mortal to Messiah to a Screen Near You?
text: A San Francisco economist who was declared the messiah by followers of a U.F.O.-centric New Age group could soon enter a new realm of idolatry: Hollywood.

headline: A Look Back at Elections
text: The June primary election is less than two months away, and some campaigns are in full swing. The political landscape in the Bay Area is shifting as Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger’s era comes to an end and what may be the Tea Party era begins.

headline: Pressures of New Students and Old Weigh on Community Colleges
text: Monica McCarthy, an academic counselor at City College of San Francisco for eight years, has worked with thousands of community college students hoping to transfer to state universities.

headline: For Crisis Panel, the Creativity Is Verbal Instead of Financial
text: WASHINGTON

headline: The Smallest Tall Tale
text: Hans Christian Andersen’s 1836 “Thumbelina” is the story of a tiny, passive girl, no bigger than your thumb. She is good at cleaning and music. She has a kind heart. She is exceptionally good-looking and modest. “She had no way of knowing how lovely she was,” as Sylvia Long puts it in her retelling.

headline: Small Bay Area Coffee Roasters Spread Out
text: Coffee has been part of Bay Area culture from the start. Folgers and Hills Brothers started by providing java (a term coined on San Francisco’s piers) to thirsty 49ers. And there have long been boutique roasters like Caffe Trieste in North Beach, which has made Italian-style espresso since 1956, and Peet’s, which introduced its characteristic dark roasts in Berkeley in 1966 and led, through its descendant Starbucks, to a wholesale revision in the way America drinks coffee.

headline: Rumor of Infidelities Sets Off Modern French Farce
text: PARIS — The French, like it or not, have found themselves immersed in another presidential psychodrama, spiced with Internet rumors of infidelity, intelligence and police investigations, complaints about press manipulation and foreign plots and the removal of security protection from a former minister of justice who just happens to have been a favorite of a former wife.

headline: A Celebration at Duke, but Not Everyone Cheers
text: From the outside, Duke University’s relationship with its basketball program is Camelot — a peaceful intersection of top-flight Division I athletics, research and scholarship. And yet, tension exists.

headline: Celebrating the Energy of the Newsroom, Through the Lens of Hollywood
text: Didn’t anyone ever tell Bruce Goldstein that newspapers are dead, or on their way? Of course people did, said Mr. Goldstein, who is the director of repertory programming at the Film Forum, the theater on West Houston Street where old movies go to live.

headline: Brooklyn Towers Have Trump Name but No Limos
text: There are no doormen or concierges or gyms. Wrapped in skins of dull brown brick, the towers’ only flourishes are splashes of blue or yellow tile, or the laundry that residents sometimes hang from their terraces. The apartments, at Brooklyn’s southern tip, came with vinyl floor tiles and slots for owners to install their own air-conditioners.

headline: Deaf, and Trying to Make It in Showbiz
text: Complex, candid and all-but-essential viewing for hearing audiences, Hilari Scarl’s intrepid debut feature, “See What I’m Saying: The Deaf Entertainers Documentary,” educates without lecturing and engages without effort.

headline: Judge Won’t Let Former Senator Withdraw Plea
text: A federal judge in Manhattan ruled on Thursday that former State Senator Efrain González Jr. could not withdraw a guilty plea to fraud and conspiracy charges, saying his claim that he had been coerced or pressured into entering the plea was “preposterous.”

headline: Identity Thieves Infiltrated Tax Office in Bronx, a Suit Says
text: Last year, Kevin Johns, a construction worker in the Bronx, did his taxes at the H&R Block store on Riverdale Avenue that he had used for the past 20 years or so. The next day, though, he got a call from the tax preparer: his return was rejected because he had already filed. Or at least, someone had filed in his name. That someone helped himself or herself to a $8,499 refund.

headline: After a Slow Start, Woods Plays as if He Never Left
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods had been on the golf course Thursday for about 90 minutes. If he had experienced first-tee jitters in his comeback to competitive golf after a five-month layoff, it did not show. He had received subdued but warm applause from the Augusta National gallery. As promised, he did not fling his club after an early, poor shot, nor did he do his trademark one-fisted tango after a birdie on the third hole.

headline: Woman Assaulted by Priest Settles Suit Against Newark Archdiocese
text: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark and the Diocese of Orlando have settled a lawsuit brought by a woman assaulted in 2004 by a priest who broke into her house in Florida, the woman’s lawyer announced on Thursday.

headline: Tax Files Show Harlem Art School’s Path to Ruin
text: The Harlem School of the Arts, celebrated for equipping local children with skills in everything from dance to classical music, had for decades been a favorite of the city’s most charitable donors.

headline: Miners’ Lives: Security, but Never Peace of Mind
text: HORSE CREEK, W.Va. — As Janice Quarles waited for the phone to ring with news that her husband’s body had been pulled from the Upper Big Branch mine, she vowed — much as so many West Virginia mothers have before her — that her son, Trevor, 11, would never follow his father into the mines.

headline: Ancient Evenings
text: If, during your long life of letters, you happen to run for mayor of New York, act in a film by Milos Forman, consort with a convicted killer, insult Bella Abzug, head-butt Gore Vidal, sink your teeth into Rip Torn’s ear and stab one of your ­spouses with a penknife, odds are that there will be little left to say about you by the time your sixth wife comes along and writes her memoir. Yet Norris Church Mailer’s reminiscence, “A Ticket to the Circus,” still manages to add a fat new sheaf to the public dossier on her late husband, Norman Mailer, and tells an involving coming-of-age story to boot. It’s not so much that she gives readers unexpected insights into one of the literary giants of his day — the book does little to dispel the image of Mailer as a narcissistic hothead with redeeming streaks of cuddliness and charm — but rather that, in her own in­direct way, she shows exactly what type of woman could tolerate and at least partly subdue such a king-size corkscrew of a man. The book will be of interest to anyone who works in a university marriage lab. It also shows that Norman wasn’t the only talented raconteur in the family.

headline: Documents Detail a Girl’s Final Days of Bullying
text: Phoebe Prince, the 15-year-old who killed herself after relentless taunting, spent her final days in fear of girls who had threatened to beat her up, according to the first official accounts released in a case in Massachusetts that gained wide attention last week, when six students were charged with felonies.

headline: Netanyahu Cancels Trip to U.S. Nuclear Summit
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has canceled his plans to attend the Nuclear Security summit meeting in Washington next week and will send a minister in his place, Israeli and American government officials said Thursday.

headline: What’s the Matter With Corn Syrup?
text: In the documentary “Fresh”  the latest in what we might call the what’s-the-matter-with-corn-syrup? genre  Ana Sofia Joanes provides a brisk indictment of industrial farming and its devastating toll on our soil, health and livestock.

headline: Wisconsin Trounces R.I.T. and Advances to Title Game
text: DETROIT — Maybe Wisconsin and Boston College received a message to try for touchdowns during their Frozen Four games at Ford Field.

headline: Duet for Two Pens
text: Does translation matter? Edith Grossman’s new book argues that it does, right in the title, and she ought to know. “Why Translation Matters” (an extended essay, really) is one of the first texts in Yale’s energetic new series, Why X Matters, each volume of which is to present a “concise argument for the continuing relevance of an important person or idea.” Certainly when X equals translation, I can imagine no defender more qualified — or, as it turns out, more querulous — than Grossman, whose version of “Don Quixote” a few years back caused a sensation in the shadowy realm of newly translated classics, and whose ulterior dealings with Hispanic splendors, ancient and modern, have stirred even so mild-mannered an assessor of cultural accomplishments as Harold Bloom to proclaim her, ominously enough, the Glenn Gould of translators.

headline: Experienced in Calamity, as Governor and Mourner
text: MONTCOAL, W.Va. — Unfortunately, he has been here before.

headline: After Tirade, Rutgers Coach Finds His Job in Jeopardy
text: Fred Hill’s initial inroad to the men’s basketball head coaching position at Rutgers ran through the home dugout at the university’s baseball stadium, where his father, Fred Sr., has been the coach for the last 27 years. After the younger Hill unleashed a profanity-laced tirade at Pitt Coach Joe Jordano after a baseball game last week, though, the field may have been the site of his undoing.

headline: Lottery Numbers

headline: Three Bidders, and Three Visions, Are Said to Be Competing for Miramax
text: LOS ANGELES — As the Walt Disney Company began weighing three potentially viable bids for its inactive Miramax Films unit, a central question became not so much who will own the ministudio but what exactly will it be.

headline: Paterson Says He’ll Suspend Pay Raises for Workers
text: ALBANY — Gov. David A. Paterson said Thursday that he would unilaterally withhold scheduled pay raises for thousands of state workers because New York had too little cash to afford them.

headline: Seeking Familiar Faces to Draw Out Those Who Have Not Sent in Census Forms
text: She would be, in the ideal view of the Census Bureau, the proverbial elegant, engaging Manhattan matron who can effortlessly cajole her way past the most imperious doorman, personally confront apartment dwellers on their threshold and persuade them to complete the 2010 census form.

headline: New Stadium, a Football Palace, Opens Saturday With Lacrosse
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — If the trend in baseball stadiums is intimacy, in football, it is grandeur. And the New Meadowlands Stadium, the home of the Jets and the Giants, is certainly imposing.

headline: United Chief on 3rd Verse of Old Tune
text: When Glenn F. Tilton took the helm at United Airlines eight years ago, he inherited an airline that was fighting for its life.

headline: Crown Heights Unnerved as Police Hunt a Rooftop Gunman
text: The street was crowded with students just out of school. Younger ones carried backpacks, while teenagers from two high schools popped in and out of stores. Suddenly, shots rang out from above.

headline: District Attorney Tries His Hand at Cutting Into Case Backlog
text: It was shortly after 9:30 a.m. on Thursday, and Cyrus R. Vance Jr. was thumbing through an accordion file of manila folders with practiced deftness.

headline: Base-Running Blunders Ominously Recall Last Year
text: Mets fans fearing a repeat of last year’s record of 70-92 have tended to concentrate on several early-season injuries as an omen of a reprise of the medical problems of 2009.

headline: Hot Day in the City
text: New Yorkers enjoy the record heat for a day!

headline: Across the Border, Over the Line
text: The Supreme Court’s ruling recently that lawyers have a duty to warn their noncitizen clients about the potentially disastrous immigration consequences of pleading guilty to a criminal charge seemed so sensible that it left me wondering why a question with such an obvious answer needed to be debated by the Supreme Court in the first place. Surely if the Sixth Amendment’s guarantee of effective assistance of counsel means anything, it means that lawyers must advise their clients that admitting to even a minor offense can earn a noncitizen a quick one-way ticket into what immigration law delicately calls “removal proceedings.”

headline: South Africa: World Bank to Finance Coal-Fired Plant
text: Eskom, the government-controlled utility, got its $3.75 billion loan on Thursday from the World Bank, mostly to finance a giant coal-fired power plant. The Obama administration, despite its unhappiness with the plant’s significant carbon emissions that will contribute to global warming, abstained rather than voting no and profoundly upsetting a regional powerhouse. The United States explicitly warned the bank in a statement that it would not actively oppose the loan because of South Africa’s acute energy needs, but that the bank should not bring forward similar coal projects in the future “without a plan to ensure there is no net increase in carbon emissions.”

headline: Selling Minority Students on a Career in Marketing
text: MADISON AVENUE likes to talk about reaching consumers when they are young, the better to woo them into becoming brand-loyal buyers. An initiative in Minneapolis and St. Paul seeks to do the same in trying to interest members of minority groups in advertising or marketing as a potential career.

headline: A Math Primer on Sovereign Debt
Liz Cheney and Gingrich Rally Republicans
text: NEW ORLEANS – Liz Cheney, the daughter of former Vice President Dick Cheney, opened a three-day Republican gathering here on Thursday evening by urging party activists to rally against policies of theObama administration, particularly the new health care law.

headline: Father Charged in 2008 Case of Baby Left With Cabby
text: The father of a baby girl who made headlines in 2008 when she was found after being supposedly abandoned in the back of a livery cab in Queens was arrested Thursday, the police said. The man, Carlos Cardenas, 29, of West 146th Street in Manhattan, was charged with statutory rape of the girl’s mother, who was around 14 when she gave birth to the girl, Daniella Perez.

headline: 13 Down: Some Vintage Clubs
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — When tackling a Friday or Saturday crossword, what sort of strategies do you use? My basic approach for a themeless puzzle is to take a look around for something I know, or to scan the last few Down clues, and then build from there.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about the possibility of a merger of United Airlines and US Airways erroneously attributed a distinction to Southwest Airlines. Several airlines posted a profit for 2009; Southwest was not the only major airline to do so. The article also misstated the middle initial of an industry analyst who commented on the merger talks. She is Betsy R. Snyder, not Betsy J.

headline: Meek Loss Shows How Much the Mets Are Missing
text: If and when Jose Reyes returns this weekend, the Mets might regain the energy and extra-base potential they seemed to lack Thursday night.

headline: Corrections
text: The This Land column on March 25, about efforts by the city clerk of the small Florida community of San Antonio to make sure all of its residents are counted in the 2010 federal census  unlike 2000, when only 684 of 842 were counted  misstated the budget for this year’s census. It is approximately $15 billion, not $14 billion, following the addition of $1 billion in stimulus funds.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article and a picture caption on April 1 about the costly rescue of a historic brownstone in Stuyvesant Heights, Brooklyn, misspelled, in some editions, the name of the street on which it is located. It is MacDonough Street, not McDonough.

headline: Winfrey Unveils Interview Show in Presenting Her Channel to Advertisers
text: Oprah Winfrey pitched OWN, her forthcoming cable channel, to advertisers in New York on Thursday, and said she would host a prime-time interview show on it called “Oprah’s Next Chapter.”

headline: MasterCard Set to Open an Online Shopping Mall
text: MasterCard is getting into the predictive online marketing business.

headline: ‘Death’ Is Revived, and So Quickly
text: AMERICAN remakes of foreign films are so commonplace these days that they hardly seem worth mentioning.

headline: Learning From Greece
text: The debt crisis in Greece is approaching the point of no return. As prospects for a rescue plan seem to be fading, largely thanks to German obduracy, nervous investors have driven interest rates on Greek government bonds sky-high, sharply raising the country’s borrowing costs. This will push Greece even deeper into debt, further undermining confidence. At this point it’s hard to see how the nation can escape from this death spiral into default.

headline: At The New Yorker
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Humble Hound
text: Some leaders are boardroom lions. They are superconfident, forceful and charismatic. They call for relentless transformational change.

headline: Dial-Up Law in a Broadband World
text: The Internet has given the government powerful 21st-century tools for invading people’s privacy and monitoring their activities, but the main federal law governing online privacy is a 20th-century relic. Adopted in 1986, it has had trouble keeping up with technological advances and is now badly out of date.

headline: Telling About Gay Warriors and Asking for Votes
text: As the chief House whip fighting to repeal the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy on gays serving in the military, Representative Patrick Murphy will never be dismissed as a naïve idealist.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Too Broken to Fix
text: The Department of Homeland Security’s inspector general has affirmed what sheriffs, police chiefs, civil-rights lawyers and immigrant advocates have said for years: Outsourcing immigration enforcement to an ill-trained and poorly supervised assortment of state and local law enforcement agencies creates a lot of problems.

headline: Just Like Ike (on Deterrence)
text: Aberystwyth , Wales

headline: Bernanke, Pointing to 1930s, Credits Fed’s Actions for Avoiding a Worse Downturn
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve artfully avoided a second Depression by being open to generating and testing new ideas, the central bank’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Thursday evening.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about the response of aviation security experts and industry officials to new screening protocols for air passengers traveling to the United States referred incorrectly to the passengers shown inside the main terminal of the airport in Frankfurt, Germany. They were waiting to have their carry-on luggage screened and to pass through metal detectors. They were not waiting to check in their luggage.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about the retrofitting of office buildings referred imprecisely to a project at 545 Madison Avenue. The savings realized by retrofitting the structure rather than demolishing it and rebuilding could be $50 to $100 a square foot. That range is not the cost of new construction.

headline: Just a Sweet Young Actress? $&@%# Right!
text: CHLOË GRACE MORETZ admits she felt a twinge of envy in the summer of 2008 when the action movie “Wanted” was about to be released, and the austere visage of its gun-toting star, Angelina Jolie, seemed to be staring at her from every billboard in Los Angeles.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Friday about the Kraft Nabisco Championship, the first major tournament of the year in women’s golf, misstated the given name of one of three players who were disqualified on the eve of the tournament for not showing up on time for the pro-am rounds. The player is Shanshan Feng, not Sangsang.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about former Yankee Hideki Matsui’s debut with the Los Angeles Angels misstated the given name of a fan who organized flip cards spelling out “Matsuiland” during the Monday night game in Angel Stadium. He is Claude Bilodeau, not Juan.

headline: Corrections
text: A film review on Saturday about “Tyler Perry’s Why Did I Get Married Too?” referred imprecisely to the actor Lamman Rucker’s presence in the movie. While he joins the group of actors who play married couples, he is not joining them on screen for the first time. (He was also in the film’s predecessor, “Tyler Perry’s Why Did I Get Married?”)

headline: Twins Who Are as Eccentric as the Movies They Made
text: George and Mike Kuchar, twin brothers from the Bronx, are among the most prolific and inventive American filmmakers of the past half-century, and perhaps the most eccentric. Avid moviegoers as children, they began making 8 millimeter epics, and after graduating from the High School of Industrial Arts in New York they gravitated toward the thriving underground film scene. Shooting cheaply, devising homemade special effects and casting friends and acquaintances, the Kuchars produced  sometimes in collaboration, sometimes apart  touchstones of the 1960s cinematic avant-garde like “Corruption of the Damned,” “Sins of the Fleshapoids” and “Hold Me While I’m Naked.”

headline: A New Course in Sailing, From New York to Barcelona
text: The gentle southerly breezes that lavished the Northeast early this week were not what Pepe Ribes wanted. Ribes is trying to set an unbeatable time over a new sailing course, 3,750 nautical miles from New York to Barcelona, and only a fast-moving low pressure system would do.

headline: Construction of Contentious Nord Stream Gas Line to Begin
text: BERLIN — When the first of 100,000 steel pipes of the Nord Stream pipeline project are laid Friday in Portovaya Bay, north of St. Petersburg, Russia, it will be the culmination of a long Russian-German effort to build stronger economic ties and the beginning of a project that probably will not unfold as its promoters had hoped.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Saturday about Edmund P. Pillsbury, the director of the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, using information from his family, misstated the cause of death. The Kaufman County sheriff’s office announced on Wednesday that Mr. Pillsbury died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound; he did not die of a heart attack, the “apparent cause” cited by the family. And because of an editing error, the obituary misstated the date of Mr. Pillsbury’s death. It was Thursday, March 25; not Thursday, April 1.

headline: Schools Test a New Tool for Improving Evaluation of Teachers
text: In a Chicago Public Schools system where half the schools are on probation yet 93 percent of teachers are rated “excellent” or “superior,” administrators are testing an evaluation process to more accurately measure a teacher’s classroom performance — with an eye toward closing the huge gap.

headline: The Pulse: Prime Parking Space Is Opening Up
text: Mayor Richard M. Daley’s administration is planning to remove rush-hour parking restrictions on some of Chicago’s busiest streets.

headline: The Pulse: A Pitcher’s View, 7 Decades Later
text: To commemorate the 70th anniversary of Bob Feller's no-hitter against the White Sox on April 16, 1940 - the only one ever on Opening Day - the Chicago Baseball Museum brought Feller, above, to Chicago this week.

headline: A Family Lives to Drink, and, Yes, Drinks to Live
text: “The Misfortunates,” a Belgian coming-of-age turned coming-of-reason story about a floundering 13-year-old turned struggling man, initially comes across as aggressively unpleasant as his crude, boozing father and uncles. For the Strobbes, as they proudly call themselves, alcohol is thicker than water and almost as thick as blood: it brings them together in song, mischief and misery, uniting them in liquid brotherhood. Though some of them work, they spend most of the time guzzling. They drink at the pub, they drink at home. They drink until they pass out and then, after they have had a good vomit, they drink again.

headline: Father of a Baby Left With a Cabdriver in 2008 Is Charged
text: The father of a baby girl who was abandoned two years ago and taken to a Queens firehouse by a livery-cab driver was arrested on Thursday and charged with the statutory rape of the baby’s mother, who was 14 at the time, the police said.

headline: Merchant Ivory Returns Without Its Merchant
text: FEW hansom cabs have ever stopped at its door, or countesses swept through its lobby, but the luxury co-op on Manhattan’s East Side used to be the unofficial headquarters of Merchant Ivory Productions. “We all lived in the building on different floors,” said James Ivory. “Ruth and her husband lived on the seventh floor. I lived on the 12th, and Ismail lived on the 14th. All on the G line.”
