headline: Christopher Cazenove, Suave British Actor, Dies at 66
text: Christopher Cazenove, a debonair British actor best known to American audiences as Ben Carrington, the scheming brother of Blake Carrington on the ABC prime-time soap opera “Dynasty,” died on Wednesday in London, where he lived. He was 66.

headline: Graciela Peréz-Gutierrez, Afro-Cuban Singer, Dies at 94
text: Graciela Peréz-Gutierrez, known professionally as Graciela, one of the great voices in Afro-Cuban music, died on Wednesday in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 94.

headline: Reluctant Messiah Is Now Reluctant Quarry of the Media
text: I know Raj Patel isn’t really a god, but when we met for coffee the other day, I had the urge to make an act of contrition. I felt guilty and found myself asking, “Are you O.K.? Really?”

headline: Community College Students Tread Water, and Bay Area Coffee Considered
text: A Counselor’s-Eye View of Stranded College Students | In the continuing student counseling department at San Francisco’s City College, Monica McCarthy, 44, a guidance counselor, finds herself working with some students whose academic progress has slowed if not stalled because of widespread budget cuts. The California State University system closed the spring semester this year to students transferring from other institutions. Shut out, City College students who had been poised to transfer find themselves in educational limbo, taking classes they do not really need,while waiting to move up to a university in the fall. “They’re hanging out, taking up seat space,” Ms. McCarthy said in her office on the Ocean Campus. “I say that with love.”

headline: Geoffrion’s Decision Pays Off for Wisconsin
text: DETROIT – Blake Geoffrion, Wisconsin’s senior left wing, had a big decision to make last year.

headline: David Chaim Smith: ‘Blood of Space’
text: David Chaim Smith’s densely worked, diagrammatic drawings look as if they had been made by a Renaissance-era occultist. A student of the Jewish kabbalah, alchemy and other mystical theories and practices as well as an artist with a 1989 Master of Fine Arts degree from Columbia University, Mr. Smith began executing fascinatingly articulated, chartlike drawings in pencil and black ink in 2007 after a decade of retirement from art-making.

headline: News Quiz | April 9, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Word of the Day | fortitude

headline: Meredyth Sparks: ‘Extraction’
text: In the two years since her first solo show in New York, Meredyth Sparks has ventured forth from the sanctums of relatively austere photo-appropriation. She continues to combine collage and photomontage, to use glitter and aluminum foil. But she has bulked up her efforts in every way. She now works on good-size canvases and even a folding screen, as well as on sheets of paper, piling on images and materials that evoke textiles, knitting, handwoven fabrics and sundry domestic activities and involve woodcut printing and an occasional allusion to Russian Suprematism. In addition, Ms. Sparks commissioned the artist Corrie Hogg to make door snakes of fabric stuffed with beans. They lie in wait in the second gallery.

headline: United Chief on 3rd Verse of Old Tune
text: When Glenn F. Tilton took the helm at United Airlines eight years ago, he inherited an airline that was fighting for its life, Jad Mouawad writes in The New York Times.

text: WHO are the “devotees of miniature modern design” described in this article? WHO are some of the famous modernist furniture designers whose work is replicated?

headline: Mark Greenwold: ‘Secret Storm: Paintings 1967-1975’
text: The 1970s art world was a permissive place, but not quite loose enough for Mark Greenwold. Mr. Greenwold’s paintings of swinging threesomes in cluttered suburban bedrooms annoyed the critic Lucy Lippard, among others, and were deemed too explicit for museum catalogs. Feminism was ascendant; Jeff Koons was still working as a commodities broker.

headline: Bernanke, Pointing to 1930s, Credits Fed’s Actions
text: The Federal Reserve artfully avoided a second Depression by being open to generating and testing new ideas, the central bank’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Thursday evening.

headline: As Greek Bond Rates Soar, Bankruptcy Looms
text: As interest rates on Greek debt rise again, the question facing Europe is no longer whether Athens has the political will to cut spending and raise taxes to curb its gaping budget deficit, but whether Greece will run out of money before it gets the chance to do so.

headline: How Many People Can Sign up for the New Plan?
text: Q.

headline: The Pull of a Dangerous Job
text: Mining families reflect on the risks and rewards.

headline: Woods Addresses Nike Ad
text: After his round on Thursday, Tiger Woods was asked to address his Nike television commercial, which was first broadcast Wednesday night, and the reprimand he received Wednesday afternoon from Billy Payne, the Augusta National chairman. The Nike ad shows a silent Woods staring into the camera as narration from his father is heard.

headline: Essar Energy Seeks $2.5 Billion in London Listing
text: Essar, the Indian conglomerate, said Thursday that it would take its power arm, Essar Energy, public in London as it seeks to raise $2.5 billion to grow its oil and gas exploration, production and refining operations.

headline: Macarthur Coal Gets 2nd Bid, and Rejects It
text: 3:03 a.m. | Updated Macarthur Coal, an Australian miner that is the focus of several rival bids, on Friday rejected as inadequate a surprise offer made by a rival Australian miner, New Hope, Bettina Wassener writes in The New York Times.

headline: For Crisis Panel, Dark Humor During Questioning
text: Bill Thomas, the vice chairman of the panel investigating the causes of the financial crisis, dumbfounded the crowd that filled a House hearing room on Thursday.

headline: Crowd Mourns Victims in Kyrgyzstan
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan — Crowds gathered in the center of this traumatized capital city on Friday for a memorial to the scores of people who died this week in deadly protests that forced the president to flee the capital. In front of looted and burned government buildings, they demanded that the president formally resign, though he has insisted that he will not.

headline: No Survivors Found After West Virginia Mine Disaster
text: MONTCOAL, W.Va. — An agonizing four-day wait came to a tragic end early Saturday morning when rescue workers failed to find any survivors in an underground mine after a huge explosion earlier this week.

headline: Tribune Co. Near Deal With Creditors
text: The Tribune Company, the newspaper publisher, said Thursday that it had agreed with creditors on a plan that would help it exit bankruptcy protection later this year, Reuters reported.

headline: Major Banks Said to Cover Up Debt Levels
text: Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America and Citigroup are the big names among 18 banks revealed by data from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to be hiding their risk levels in the past five quarters by lowering the amount of leverage on the balance sheet before making it available to the public, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Petters Gets 50-Year Term for Ponzi Fraud
text: A federal judge sentenced the Minnesota businessman Tom Petters to 50 years in prison on Thursday for orchestrating a $3.7 billion Ponzi scheme that included hedge funds, pastors, missionaries and retirees among its victims, The Associated Press reported.

headline: NATO Aircraft Crashes in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A NATO Osprey aircraft crashed in southern Afghanistan on Thursday night, killing three American service members and one civilian employee, according to NATO officials.

headline: Retail Shares Distract Wall Street From Europe’s Woes
text: Signs of strength from American retailers helped send Wall Street indexes higher on Thursday, offsetting worries about Greek debt and the jobs market, The New York Times’s Javier C. Hernandez reported.

headline: A Math Primer on Sovereign Debt
text: How can a country support debt of more than 100 percent of its gross domestic product for many years and then suddenly start descending toward insolvency? That question of sovereign debt arithmetic isn’t merely academic. It’s highly relevant to the likes of Greece and Italy, Brakingviews says.

headline: Emaar Comes Back to $4 Billion I.P.O. Plan
text: Emaar MGF Land revived plans to sell shares in India for the first time, leading $4 billion of property offers at a time when rising interest rates are deterring homebuyers, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Three Bidders Said to Be Competing for Miramax
text: As the Walt Disney Company began weighing three potentially viable bids for its inactive Miramax Films unit, a central question became not so much who will own the ministudio, but what exactly will it be.

text: Microchip Technology has closed its acquisition of Silicon Storage Technology, the companies said Thursday.

headline: Norilsk Nickel May Sell Montana Mines
text: Norilsk Nickel, the Russian metals company, is exploring the sale of its Montana platinum and palladium mines after prices for the precious metals rebounded sharply in recent months, The Associated Press reported.

headline: K.K.R. and Bain Said to Plot I.P.O.’s
text: Along with a reported initial public offering planned for HCA, the big hospital operator whose $33 billion takeover in 2006 heralded many giant leveraged buyouts, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Bain Capital are also said to be preparing I.P.O.’s of two of their other large portfolio companies, Toys ‘R’ Us and NXP SemiConductors, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the deals.

headline: Panel Criticizes Oversight of Citi by Two Executives
text: The two men who steered Citigroup into the eye of the financial storm offered a striking contrast on Thursday, The New York Times’s Eric Dash and Sewell Chan reported.

headline: In Paris, Mixing Up Some Salsa
text: The dancing is Latin, the location sounds German, but it’s all very Parisian.

headline: LinkedIn Taps Former Ask.com Chief
text: LinkedIn has added the former chief executive of Ask.com to its board of directors, representing the first independent director in the fast-growing social networking company’s boardroom, Reuters reported.

headline: South Korea Gets $1 Billion on Woori Sale
text: South Korea raised 1.16 trillion won ($1 billion) selling 9 percent of Woori Finance Holdings, the nation’s third-biggest financial firm by market value, as the government reduces state assets, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Brown Said to Promise Bonus Caps if Re-elected
text: Prime Minister Gordon Brown said he’ll impose new curbs on bankers’ bonuses if he wins next month’s election, giving regulators power to override employment contracts, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Jack Benny, National Savior?
text: Today’s idea: America’s love-hate relationship with thrift is on again, after a long period in which saving was viewed as something akin to a social disorder. Can thrift and Jack Benny now set us free? A lifelong saver thinks so.

headline: Afghan Marksmanship: Pointing, Not Aiming
text: This blog has recently been examining poor Afghan marksmanship, focusing on remarkably bad Taliban performance with rifles in combat and some of the probable reasons behind it. We’ll shift now to a discussion of Afghan government units, which regularly provide an opportunity to assess outgoing fire.

headline: Airline M.&A. Is No Silver Bullet, American Chief Says
text: Consolidation is no “silver bullet” for what ails the airline industry, but mergers are inevitable and the business would benefit from a smaller number of carriers, the chief executive of American Airlines said on Thursday.

headline: Former Fannie Mae Executives to Face Special Panel
text: Two former top executives of Fannie Mae will face questions Friday about the government-created mortgage titan’s role in fomenting the housing boom and its eventual bust.

headline: Norris: Numbers Point to a Recovery
text: The United States economy appears to be in a cyclical recovery that is gaining strength. Companies have begun to hire, and consumer spending seems to be accelerating, Floyd Norris writes in his latest column in The New York Times.

headline: Stray Questions for: Edith Grossman
text: Edith Grossman is a translator and the author of “Why Translation Matters.”

headline: Your Dot: Energy Gluttony, Poverty, Irrelevance
text: Here’s a roundup of reader reactions to the idea that a sustained energy quest should be an organizing principle if humanity wants to avoid hard knocks in the next few decades. I frequently try to highlight notable contributions of non-anonymous readers as a way to keep the discourse here constructive and focused more on argument and less on contradiction (this link goes to the famous Monty Python skit delineating the difference).

headline: Few Worry About Overreaction on Jet
text: WASHINGTON — When an illicit pipe and a foolish joke aboard an airliner touches off a national megascare, scrambling fighter jets and F.B.I. agents, alerting all 4,900 flights in progress and unleashing a media flood, does that mean the security system works?

headline: In Surprise Move, Wynn Bows Out of Philadelphia Casino
text: Casino operator Wynn Resorts said Thursday it is dropping its bid to rescue a troubled waterfront casino project in Philadelphia, saying the project isn’t appropriate for the company, The Associated Press reported.

headline: BlueCrest Moves Headquarters Offshore
text: BlueCrest Capital Management, the London-based hedge fund, is moving offshore.

headline: Automakers Make Greenhouse Peace, Auto Dealers Still Fighting
text: It was unfinished business. Nearly a year after automakers and federal and state regulators signed an agreement on regulating fuel economy and greenhouse gases, the auto industry has dropped its remaining legal challenges to that approach. Automakers objected to the concept of having California (and the states following its rules) regulate tailpipe greenhouse emissions separately from the federal government and filed suit in several jurisdictions.

headline: Goldman Said to Hire Former Times Reporter
text: Goldman Sachs has hired the former New York Times reporter Stephen Labaton as a full-time consultant on regulatory and legal issues, Politico reported.

headline: Q.&A.: Checking a System Backup
text: Q.

headline: Carlyle Hires Former Wyeth Chief
text: Another private equity firm has snapped up a high-profile former chief executive. The Carlyle Group announced that it had hired Wyeth‘s former chief, Robert Essner, as a senior adviser to its Global Healthcare group, Reuters reported.

headline: Speed Read for Friday, April 9
text: Here are some highlights from Friday’s edition of The New York Times:

headline: Of Hedge Funds, Reporters, Pizzas and Priests
text: A hedge fund manager apparently caught up in one of the many insider-trading scandals plaguing the industry seems to have felt the need to confess, not to the authorities but to his priest, Reuters’s Aaron Pressman writes.

headline: Cooking With Asparagus Stems
text: In the coming weeks you’re going to see Minis about pressed tofu (probably my new favorite ingredient) and asparagus “pesto.” This dish is a result of having a lot of tofu and asparagus around.

headline: How Much Can Tomlinson Help Jets?
text: It still seems a little odd that LaDainian Tomlinson will play for the Jets next season (and that Thomas Jones won’t). Neither Tomlinson nor Antonio Cromartie was impressive against the Jets in the playoffs last season, yet both wound up being coveted by the team that beat them.

headline: Hilton Reorganizes Its Debt
text: Hilton Worldwide, the operator of the Hilton hotel chain and a portfolio company of the Blackstone Group, said late on Thursday that it has reorganized its hefty debt load, cutting $4 billion in obligations and pushing back maturities.

headline: Sampler: Hikers Called Spies, the Grateful Dead Archivist and Ronald Reagan Day
text: Iran Orchestrates New Attack on Berkeley Hikers | In a brief statement read on state television, Iran’s intelligence minister charged that three students from the University of California, Berkeley, who were arrested while hiking in the mountains near the Iran-Iraq border, had ties to American intelligence services. The intelligence minister, Heidar Moslehi, made the charges on Iran’s English-language satellite channel. Coming as international tension over Iran’s nuclear program has increased, the remarks seemed to reflect a hardening of the Iranian government’s tone in the case of the hikers — Sarah Shourd, 31, and Shane Bauer and Josh Fattal, both 27. In November, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran pointed out that the United States was holding several Iranian citizens, raising the possibility that he sought a prisoner swap. “Clearly, these unlucky hikers have been caught up in international politics,” said Mark Juergensmeyer, director of the global and international studies department at the University of California, Santa Barbara. “The message is loud and clear: It screams for a prisoners’ exchange and shows that they are being kept as hostages to be used as negotiating pawns.” [The San Francisco Chronicle, The Oakland Tribune]

headline: Are Bernanke and Volcker in Club Wagner?
text: Did Ben S. Bernanke and Paul A. Volcker just join Club Wagner — our (fictional) club of policy makers, pundits and others willing to acknowledge that taxes must rise in order to pay for Medicare, Social Security, the military and other popular government programs?

headline: The Early Word: Financial Wrap-Up
text: The presidential panel in charge of seeking out the root causes of the 2008 financial collapse and recommending ways to avert another disaster wraps up three days of hearings this afternoon.

headline: Dow Slips Above 11,000 and Then Slips Back
text: The Dow Jones industrial average briefly traded above 11,000 points on Friday, the latest mile marker in a yearlong rally that has catapulted the stock market from the depths of the financial crisis.

headline: Are You Seeing Signs of Economic Recovery?
text: According to Floyd Norris, though “the American economy appears to be in a cyclical recovery that is gaining strength,” it is also true that many, whether economists or politicians, seem to doubt that a real recovery is happening. Are you seeing signs that the recession is ending in your community? If so, what have you noticed?

headline: Atlas and Reliance Form $1.7 Billion Joint Venture
text: Atlas Energy said on Friday that it has formed a natural gas joint venture with Reliance Industries of India for its position in the Marcellus Shale, in a deal valued at $1.7 billion.

headline: Leader Is Absent as N. Korean Legislature Convenes
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s rubber-stamp legislature convened Friday in the capital, Pyongyang, offering few hints of a major policy shift despite a growing desperation for economic recovery.

headline: Will Employer Plans Have to Meet Higher Standards?
text: Q.

headline: Poets of Dementia
text: Nearly nine years ago, the poet and essayist Holly J. Hughes’s 75-year-old mother died from Alzheimer’s disease. Her mother’s decline had been “a slow process of subtraction, as we lost her one brain cell, one synapse at a time,” Ms. Hughes writes in the preface to a new collection of poetry about this rampaging disease. “As with any grief that feels unspeakable, I turned to poetry.”

headline: ‘Late Night’ Creates the ‘Finnegans Wake’ of TV Parodies
text: If you just started watching television after years of reading books and interacting with people, this clip from Thursday’s “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” may not the best one to help introduce you to the medium. This latest installment of “6-bee” is essentially a parody of “Glee,” with nods to “Parks and Recreation,” “Saturday Night Live” and “Late Night” itself — 6B being the studio at 30 Rockefeller Plaza where the show is taped. We thought we also caught shout-outs to “West Side Story,” Broadway’s “Rock of Ages” and possibly Spenser’s “Faerie Queene,” though we’re not sure about that last one. Maybe it was the old daytime show “Queen for a Day.”

headline: How to Prevent the Next Crisis? Ask the Traders
text: The invisible hand just got a bit more work to do. In an op-ed for The Washington Post, Sebastian Mallaby says the financial overhaul bill should use market activity as a way to predict, and avert, the next crisis.

headline: No Pay Raises, Paterson Says
text: What we’re reading this morning: Struggling to close New York’s budget gap, Gov. David A. Paterson said he would unilaterally withhold scheduled pay raises for thousands of state workers because New York had too little cash to afford them.

headline: Food Groups Clash Over Compost Sludge
text: Alice Waters, a pioneering chef and the matriarch of the sustainable food movement, has become an unlikely target in a battle being waged by food activists in San Francisco over a city program that converts sewage sludge into gardening compost.

headline: Stupak Expected to Retire
text: Representative Bart Stupak of Michigan, who played a central role with fellow anti-abortion Democrats in negotiating a compromise in the final hours of the health care debate, intends to announce today that he will not seek re-election, a senior party official confirmed.

headline: Demonstrators Storm TV Station in Thailand
text: BANGKOK — In the first violent clash of a nearly monthlong standoff in Bangkok, antigovernment demonstrators stormed a satellite television station on Friday, climbed over rolls of barbed wire, and beat back soldiers and riot police officers who confronted them with tear gas and water cannons.

headline: France Télécom Suicides Prompt an Investigation
text: PARIS — The Paris prosecutor’s office said on Friday that it was investigating France Télécom over accusations of psychological harassment related to a recent spate of suicides.

headline: Survey Says
text: Back in 2005, when Democrats in Congress fought to preserve their right to filibuster against George W. Bush’s judicial nominees, they spoke in unison about how Republicans were “changing the rules in the middle of the game,” a slogan they had tested with focus groups like a catchphrase for breakfast cereal. The idea was to turn an arcane question of process into a basic issue of fairness in the public mind, and it worked. Now, five years later, Republicans reeling from their health care defeat are trying the same tactic. The health care law was “rammed through Congress and rammed down the throats of the American people,” Senator Jim DeMint of South Carolina declared on “Face the Nation,” echoing a chorus of other Republicans who have used the same metaphor to cast the law’s passage — accomplished partly through the technical process known as budget reconciliation — as an act of outright treachery. Republicans seem to be hoping they can steer the debate away from the actual provisions of the bill and to focus attention, instead, on the means by which it was passed.

headline: Keeping Tabs
text: Not long ago, no fewer than seven messages from RadarOnline.com, the celebrity news service, arrived in my e-mail inbox in a single day. The first one showed up at 8:08 a.m., and the others appeared at regular intervals until 7:38 p.m. What intelligence did Radar­Online need so insistently to impart? The startling news of that gossip cycle can hardly be done justice here. It seems Xanax was taken, an ex-husband throttled, a swastika tattoo revealed and an Amish upbringing forsworn — all supposedly by one Michelle (Bombshell) McGee, the supposed mistress of Jesse James, motorcycle promoter and husband of the Oscar-winning actress Sandra Bullock.

headline: No Sweat
text: The reprinting of a century-old fitness manual — with exercises for men to do in their suits — inspires a fashion shoot inside The New York Times.

headline: iPad Envy
text: Earlier this year Apple previewed its iPad tablet computer and enjoyed a blizzard of media attention. As is often the case, the most memorable response came not from a tech blog or a mainstream media outlet but from the satirical publication The Onion. In The Onion’s telling, the iPad would include this feature: “To ensure that its users receive the constant public attention they crave, the iPad will emit the phrase, ‘Hey, does that guy have an iPad?’ every eight minutes.”

headline: Fish Tale
text: Dr. Kurtland Ma found the young man lying on the stretcher in the quiet of the predawn night. He was surprised by how healthy the patient looked: he had learned over the first year of his residency training that those who came to the Jacobi Medical Center emergency room in the Bronx at that hour were often the very sickest patients.

headline: The Fare to Yangshuo
text: The taxi driver’s face brightened up when my husband and I arrived at the dingy Guilin airport in southern China on the last flight in from Shanghai. We were exhausted from traveling by plane and train every couple of days. The drive to Yangshuo, where the mountain peaks are shaped like gumdrops, would take an hour and a half.

headline: Africa’s Drug Problem
text: On the tarmac of Osvaldo Vieira, the international airport of the West African coastal country of Guinea-Bissau, sits a once-elegant Gulfstream jet, which in the normal course of events would have no reason to land in a country with no business opportunities and virtually no economy. In recent years, however, Guinea-Bissau has emerged as a nodal point in three-way cocaine-trafficking operations linking producers in South America with users in Europe; the value of the cocaine that transits this small and heartbreakingly impoverished country dwarfs its gross national product. The Gulfstream arrived unexpectedly from Venezuela on July 12, 2008, and taxied to a hangar at the adjacent military airbase — where soldiers formed a line and unloaded its contents. The contents, reportedly more than a half-ton of cocaine, vanished. The crew was arrested and released. The army permitted the government to impound the plane only after several days. Since then, the plane has sat in the harsh sun, a reminder of Guinea-Bissau’s helplessness before forces far more powerful than itself.

headline: Asking Is All Right
text: I hired a college student to tutor my daughter, paying him less than he might earn elsewhere but well above minimum wage. After a few sessions, he said he could continue only at a higher rate. My daughter has gotten so attached to him that I feel forced to pay what I consider to be blackmail. Is the tutor ethical? L. K., RHODE ISLAND

headline: Alexander Ovechkin, the Mad Russian
text: At the Olympics in Vancouver this year, in an early-round game against Slovakia, the Russian hockey player Alexander Ovechkin toppled Zdeno Chara, the normally immovable 6-foot-9 giant

headline: Ex-Copycats Find Their Own Styles

Simultaneously, the Korean automakers have been honing their own signature styles — a point reinforced by new models introduced at the New York auto show this month — and are becoming visually desirable rivals to Japanese, American and even German brands.

text: When I wrote a post about our coming office move from Midtown to Downtown, I got a few responses asking why anyone would start a business in a place as expensive as New York City, let alone commit to bigger and more expensive space in the city. Here’s what Frank wrote:

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Vampires, New Moons and Armageddon
text: Hope you’re a fan of vampires, because this week’s lists are a bonanza for bloodsuckers: the graphic-novel adaptation of “Twilight” sits at No. 1 on the hardcover list, while the latest installment of “Buffy the Vampire Slayer” sits atop our softcover list. Over on the manga list, at No. 10 is volume 12 of “Trinity Blood.” The series, published by TokyoPop, is about a dark future that finds humans locked in a constant battle against vampires. It’s a war of biblical proportions in which Armageddon has occurred, a second moon has risen and a nun named Esther and a Vatican priest named Abel Nightroad are charged with stopping Gyula, the vampire leader. Jeepers!

headline: For Many, Health Law Offers a Chance for Preventive Care
text: A PRIMARY goal of the health care overhaul was to provide insurance for more people, namely those who could not afford coverage and those with pre-existing conditions for whom insurance was too costly.

headline: ‘Apocalypse Now’ in Brooklyn Heights?
text: It may not be in the same category as a Birdemic, but many residents of Brooklyn Heights and Dumbo are feeling besieged from above by what they say is a sharp increase in noisy helicopter traffic along the East River since last weekend. They have been voicing their frustration off and online all week, and Friday, a baseball-team’s worth of elected officials heeded the call.

headline: Executives Say Fannie Mae Is Torn by Conflicting Goals
text: WASHINGTON — Too many conflicting goals make it all but impossible for the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to return to their earlier form, according to former executives of Fannie Mae and former regulators who tried to keep a watch on the companies.

headline: Russia Calls for Halt on U.S. Adoptions
text: MOSCOW — The boy was only 7, but he walked off the plane that arrived in Moscow from Washington all alone, carrying a knapsack with magic markers and candy, along with a single typewritten note. It was from a woman in Tennessee who had adopted him in Russia last year, became overwhelmed by what she described as his emotional problems and now wanted nothing more to do with him. Take him back, the note said.

headline: Solar-Powered Products in Haiti
text: Although poverty in Haiti has been amplified by the recent earthquake, the country still has plenty of one thing, and it’s free: sunshine. In this, solar companies have seen both a chance to show goodwill and an opportunity to give their businesses a boost.

headline: Complaint Box | The Lost ‘Library Voice’
text: The library of my youth, in Ocean Township, N.J., was a tomb of peace, where the only sounds were shuffles, whispers and the occasional shush — delivered with an index finger crossing the lips of a bespectacled, cardigan-wearing librarian.

headline: New Law Will Require Free Health Screenings
text: One of the best perks in the new health care legislation is that insurance companies will no longer require co-payments for preventive care like physicals, mammograms and immunizations. The new rules are explained in Friday’s Patient Money column.

headline: Europe Said to Firm Up Terms of Greek Loans
text: European Union officials firmed up plans on Friday to keep Greece from going off a financial cliff, as deputy finance ministers outlined terms to help the country borrow at below market rates.

headline: Expect Augusta to Toughen on Day 2
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. – As at any tournament, the competition officials who choose where to align the tee markers and where to position the pin placements can do much to affect scores. In Thursday’s first round of the Masters, kindness seemed to be the overriding sentiment of the competition committee. The tees were moved up and the holes were not in the most devilish spots. Amateur players were among the 31 who broke par.

headline: Come for the Doors, Stay for the Farce
text: This is unusual, even for show business: an advertisement for the current Broadway revival of “Lend Me a Tenor,” a detail of which appears above and which will appear in full in Sunday’s Arts & Leisure section, quotes a succession of critics who gave the comedy enthusiastic reviews. (“Sublime comic heights!” wrote Robert Feldberg of The Record of Hackensack, N.J.; “Lots of laughs!” said Joe Dziemianowicz of The Daily News of New York.) The lowest quotation in the ad, obscured by the oversize cartoon heads of Justin Bartha, Anthony LaPaglia and Tony Shalhoub, is attributed to Charles Isherwood, theater critic for The New York Times. You can’t see much of it, but it appears to read: “One, two, three, four, five doors.”

headline: On Day 2, Poulter and Westwood Lead British Invasion
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The tough old golf course behind the gates at the Augusta National Golf Club awoke in a bad mood Friday. The gloves came off, the scores went up and things got serious at the Masters.

headline: Procedures: Sharp Rise in Complex Back Surgery Among Older Adults
text: The percentage of older adults undergoing a complicated fusion procedure for the painful lower-back condition called spinal stenosis has increased steeply, rising fifteenfold from 2002 to 2007, a new study reports.

text: WASHINGTON — The announcement by Justice John Paul Stevens on Friday that he would retire at the end of this term gives President Obama the rare opportunity to make back-to-back appointments to the Supreme Court during the first two years of his presidency.

headline: ‘I Was Choking Her.  But I Wasn’t Trying to Kill Her.’
text: Since 1966, police officers have been required by law to remind each person they arrest and question of the right to remain silent. The standard statement of those rights includes a warning: “Anything you say can and will be used against you in a court of law.”

headline: Correction: New Life in Old Hong Kong
text: An article on March 21 about the Wan Chai neighborhood in Hong Kong described the logo of the Pawn, a gastropub that was once a pawnshop, incorrectly. The logo, which is an image still found outside pawnshops across the city, is an image of a bat with a coin; it is not a chess piece.

headline: Letters: The Window Seat
text: To the Editor: I so thoroughly enjoyed Mark Vanhoenacker’s article “With This View, Who Needs Legroom?” (March 28), since I always book a window seat either port or starboard side depending on where we are flying and the direction of sunlight. However, what often disappoints me is that pilots seldom, if ever, announce significant ground views that I think the passengers would be interested in.

headline: U.S. Amateur Winner Just Another Face in the Crowd
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Brad Benjamin is the 23-year-old winner of the 2009 United States Amateur Public Links championship, which got him invited to play in the 2010 Masters. Paired with Bernhard Langer and Scott Verplank during Thursday’s first round, Benjamin shot a 1-over-par 73, the same score as Verplank and two shots behind Langer, the two-time Masters champion.

headline: You’ve Been Warned: ‘Jersey Shore’ Returning in July
text: Despite the hopes of paleoanthropologists that the second season of “Jersey Shore” would send that show’s cast to Cradle of Humankind, South Africa, to search for two-million-year-old hominid fossils, the dreams of the scientific community will have to wait until at least Season 3. When that hit MTV reality series returns with new episodes in the summer it will split its time between the more urban locations of Miami and the Seaside Heights, N.J., setting that gave the show its name. On its Remote Control blog, MTV said that shooting for Season 2 of “Jersey Shore” began this week in Miami, and would reunite the original cast members including Jenni (JWOWW) Farley, Nicole (Snooki)  Polizzi, Michael (The Situation) Sorrentino and Angelina Pivarnick (who bailed early on Season 1) before they return to their Jersey beach house later this year. (“I.e. when the Jersey weather gets warmer,” MTV said.) Season 2 of “Jersey Shore” will have its premiere on July 29, so expect the protest letters to start arriving at MTV on July 30.

headline: Fitch Downgrades Greece’s Credit Rating
text: Greece was hit with another financial headache Friday after Fitch Ratings slashed its credit rating on the country’s debt because of concerns about the government’s ability to get a handle on its debt mountain, Reuters reported.

headline: Auto-Tweet Your Weight to the World
text: If you’re losing weight, why keep it to yourself? Now the whole world can know, automatically.

headline: Ear to the Ground
text: Scientists hardly ever write novels. Fabricating imaginary people is not the domain of the scientific method, to put it mildly. Constructing a plot, lacing it with clues to lead the reader to a well-prepared conclusion, is heretical business for those trained to unprejudiced observation. But any who take the leap may use their worldliness to good advantage, smuggling gems of empirical knowledge across the literary border to create fiction with unusually rewarding heft. Consider the meticulous puzzle­-solving of Sir ­Arthur Conan Doyle (a trained surgeon) or the flights of physics in Alan Lightman’s “Einstein’s Dreams.”

headline: Politics and Faith
text: Reading Ian Buruma makes you feel parochial. In “Taming the Gods: Religion and Democracy on Three Continents,” he writes intimately about the relationship between politics and faith in Britain, the Netherlands, France, China, Japan and the United States. And beneath every cliché — about American religious fervor, French intolerance or Japanese godlessness — he uncovers ironies that wreak havoc with popular stereotypes. Buruma shows, for instance, that the trendy, anti-imperial multiculturalism favored in the Netherlands and the United Kingdom actually echoes those countries’ policies of colonial indirect rule, in which native cultures were segregated and preserved so they could be dominated more easily. He suggests that America’s militant Christianity and Europe’s militant secularism stem from parallel anxieties about the pace of cultural change. And he explains why the jihadist fanaticism taking root among some of Europe’s Muslim young is more European than Middle Eastern, more modern than traditional, more political than religious.

headline: Stupak to Retire

headline: Counting on Each Other
text: In 2008, Paolo Giordano, an Italian physi­cist in his mid-20s, published his first novel. Called “The Solitude of Prime Numbers,” it won Italy’s most coveted book prize, the Premio Strega. Because Italy does not have a robust reading culture, the fact that this literary debut has sold more than a million copies there hints both at the extraordinary magnetism of Giordano’s voice and at the human interest lurking behind the left-brain mathi­ness of his ­title. (His being a blue-eyed, sandy-haired bel ragazzo probably didn’t hurt, either.) Already, the book has been translated into more than 30 languages, including, now, a flawlessly smooth Ameri­can English version by Shaun Whiteside.

headline: Looking Toward Wellness Discounts
text: Although one potential improvement in preventive medicine coverage will not take effect until 2014, it could be worth a few thousand dollars to you and your family when it happens.

headline: Reversal on Fuel Cells in California
text: A month after an administrative law judge with the California Public Utilities Commission proposed denying a request from two big utilities to install fuel cells, regulators reversed course on Thursday and approved the projects.

headline: Not Your Mother’s Broccoli
text: Broccoli, snubbed by presidents and children alike, has always had a bit of a public relations problem.

headline: Now Online | T Design Spring 2010 Issue
text: It’s all about. . .tending your garden of style, starting with our cover story on the latest furniture designs, set in an imaginary garden that’s both formal and surreal. And speaking of surreal, we revisit Pee-Wee’s Playhouse aesthetic and find it very chairy. Jane Garmey strolls through three urban gardens that run the gamut from sculptural to vertical, and Pilar Viladas wanders through a 1964 house in Dallas, designed by Philip Johnson, which has been meticulously restored to its former glamorous glory, only this time with a solid collection of contemporary art and a lush landscape. Mark Rozzo peeks into the new trend in design-magazine photography — capturing the less-than-perfect reality of the way we really live — while Christopher Petkanas looks back at Ruby Ross Wood, a great decorator of the 20th century, who never had a hair out of place, design-wise. Jerusalem reveals its burgeoning design scene, and we get to know the gallerist and cultural multitasker Jeanne Greenberg Rohatyn. See all stories »

headline: Travel Deals: 50% off Swiss Rail Passes
text: Rail Europe, in partnership with Switzerland Tourism, is offering 50 percent off Swiss Passes for adults, while children 16 and younger ride for free. The Switzerland Family Rail Sale takes place April 21 to 27, and is valid for travel within six months of purchase.

headline: For Top Prosecutor, Court Appearances Are Rare
text: When Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the first-year Manhattan district attorney, made a cameo handling cases in criminal court Thursday morning, it got Courthouse Confidential to thinking: just how frequently does a sitting district attorney actually handle an individual court case?

headline: Truth, Justice and Kerry Fraser
text: On Sunday, veteran referee Kerry Fraser will officiate his last game. After a 30-year career, Fraser will work the Rangers vs. Flyers game and then hang up his skates for the final time.

headline: Drug Wars
text: By the time he was 30, the British writer Jon McGregor already had two novels under his belt, both nominated for the Man Booker Prize. Starting with “If Nobody Speaks of Remarkable Things” (2002), McGregor’s precocious, attention-­grabbing early work was characterized by structural devices meant to dislocate a reader’s expectations: varied perspectives and voices, shifting time sequences, fractured narratives, misdirection, and disrupted sentences and paragraphs. McGregor wrote about the intrusion of shock, violence and disorder in the lives of ordinary, often settled, self-absorbed people, so there was symmetry between his fragmented style and vision.

headline: Romance, Aisle Two
text: The produce man at our local grocery has always been friendly. But lately he’s started patting me on the arm and kissing my fingers as I reach past him. I’m a plain, 40-ish mom, and he’s a stocky guy in his 50s. I don’t think he’s attracted to me; it’s just his shtick. I don’t mind chatting, but the physical contact has to stop. How do I cut him off without being rude?

headline: 34 Years on the Bench
text: WHO is the man wearing a bow tie in the photograph above? WHO are in contention to replace him on the Supreme Court, according to this article?

headline: Vatican Outlines Path to Restoring Faith in Church
text: ROME — After a week of angry counterattacks by the Catholic Church against its critics over clerical sexual abuse, the Vatican struck a more conciliatory tone on Friday with a statement from its spokesman that raised the possibility that Pope Benedict XVI would again meet with victims.

headline: Replacement Named for Jon Heder in Comedy Central Series
text: 1:24 p.m. | Updated  He may not have the name recognition of, say, Napoleon Dynamite, but Chris Gethard, top left, a writer, performer and veteran of the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater, will soon be a familiar face on Comedy Central’s schedule. On Friday, the cable channel said Mr. Gethard would replace Jon Heder, the “Napoleon Dynamite” star, in a new series, confirming a report on the Web site the Comic’s Comic. The series, which is tentatively titled “Big Lake,” was announced in July and is being made by Gary Sanchez Productions, the company of Will Ferrell and Adam McKay; it was to star Mr. Heder as a former financial whiz who returns to his hometown. Last month representatives for Mr. Heder said he was leaving the show because of creative differences. In addition to Mr. Gethard, a U.C.B. instructor in New York who has also written for “Saturday Night Live” and the Onion News Network, the show’s cast includes the “S.N.L.” veterans Chris Parnell and Horatio Sanz. A premiere date has not been announced.

headline: Weekend Competition: Rich Man, Poor Man, Beggar Man, Thief
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share their childhood rhymes, riddles, ditties and jingles.

headline: ABC’s ‘This Week’ to Get Checked By PolitiFact
text: The guests on ABC’s “This Week” will be fact-checked by the editors at PolitiFact.com this weekend, in an experiment first proposed by the New York University journalism professor Jay Rosen.

headline: A Quest for Belonging
text: As “The Last Summer of the Death Warriors” opens, a chatty caseworker is driving Pancho Sanchez to an orphanage in Las Cruces, N.M. Pancho assaulted another boy at a foster home, and the caseworker tells him he is lucky he’s not headed for a juvenile detention center.

headline: Kestrin Pantera and Jonathan Grubb
text: WHEN Jonathan Grubb first spotted Kestrin Pantera, she was dressed as a light-saber-wielding Jedi knight. Powerful, wise and dedicated to the “light side of the force” is how Ms. Pantera described the character she sought to embody at the 2006 Burning Man arts festival in Nevada.

headline: Roethlisberger Announcement Expected Next Week

text: The nonprofit group Ecoartspace has posted a sampler of the more than 200 works of art generated in response to my February post asking a variety of environmental thinkers to state, “What Matters Most?”

headline: Off the Menu: Aquavit’s New Chef
text: Though Marcus Samuelsson’s name still lingers at Aquavit, the Scandinavian restaurant where he was the original chef, the reality is that others have been running the kitchen for many years. Mr. Samuelsson is still a partner in the company, but he has been pursuing other ventures and is no longer involved in the food for the Midtown Manhattan restaurant.

headline: Anticipating Monday Lunch at KFC
text: Little sleep overnight as I gear up for a weekend’s worry about what it’s going to be like to taste this KFC “Double Down” sandwich the fried chicken company is releasing on Monday.

headline: Under Fire for Abortion Deal, Stupak to Retire
text: ESCANABA, Mich. — Representative Bart Stupak, a Democrat and a leading abortion opponent in Congress who ended up infuriating anti-abortion groups with his support of a compromise in the last hours of debate over landmark health care legislation, said Friday that he would not seek a 10th term in November.

headline: Are Autism and Tourette’s Related?
text: When the Patient Voices series recently featured Tourette’s syndrome, an odd and little understood disorder that causes jerking movements and tics, dozens of readers had questions for the Consults blog. Here, one reader wonders whether Tourette’s is related to autism or attention deficit disorders.

headline: Hold On, Let Me Get Him
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Two other golf courses with Augusta in their name are often mistaken for the home of the Masters.

headline: TimesCast | April 9, 2010
text: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Friday.  Topics include the retirement of Supreme Court Justice Stevens, the hunt for a brutal African warlord, and more.

headline: Clear Channel to Add News Crawl to the Car Stereo
text: In the 1990s, PointCast was the scourge of the nascent Internet, a news ticker that spread on computer screens until it began clogging corporate networks. Well, a similar news crawl is about to appear again, but this time it will be on car dashboards.

headline: Why You Can’t Get Flood Insurance Right Now
text: Updated at 12:45 p.m. and 7:30 p.m. to add reporting on the Senate Banking Committee and the Bank of America.

headline: Does Celibacy Increase Sex Abuse?
text: As I’ve said before, I don’t like it when Catholic leaders fall back on the “child abuse happens everywhere” defense to excuse the church’s egregious failings and cover-ups. I do like it, however, when mainstream media outlets do their job and report that there’s no evidence that the rate of sex abuse is higher among the Catholic clergy than among any other group. So good for Newsweek for running this piece, even if it’s only as a “web exclusive”:

headline: Ozawa Cancels More Performances But Says He Is Getting Better
text: Seiji Ozawa, the Japanese conductor and musical director of the Vienna State Opera, said on Friday that his recovery from cancer was proceeding well, even as he announced that he was canceling more dates to focus on getting better, Agence France-Presse reported. In January, Mr. Ozawa announced that he had been given a diagnosis of esophageal cancer and was canceling his performances for at least six months while he underwent treatment. Mr. Ozawa said on Friday that he was canceling additional dates, including an opera in Matsumoto, Japan, in August and concerts with the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra in Europe and Japan, on the advice of his doctors. In a statement, the conductor said: “I’m really sorry for troubling and worrying everyone. I myself feel great regret but I want to take all possible measures” to ensure his recuperation “by listening to my chief doctor’s instructions.”

headline: Picasso Doubleheader
text: The unique world of Pablo Picasso’s prints is the subject of new exhibitions at the Marlborough Gallery and the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Bahamas Tourism Campaign Says, ‘T.G.I.F.’
text: The Bahamas Ministry of Tourism is back with Version 2.0 of a popular campaign from last year centered on getting ready on Fridays for some weekend fun.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: MATTERHORN: A Novel of the Vietnam War,  by Karl Marlantes (El León Literary Arts/Atlantic Monthly, $24.95.) In this tale, 30 years in the creation, bloody folly envelops a Marine company’s construction, abandonment and retaking of a remote hilltop outpost.

headline: Who Lost Bart Stupak?
text: When news got out this morning that Representative Bart Stupak of Michigan would announce that he is not running for re-election in November, many on the right crowed that they had taken down someone who had not adhered strictly enough to their anti-abortion principles.

headline: Number of Africans Bound for South Africa Remains to Be Seen
text: As the 32 national team managers evaluate players, consider injuries and plot strategy in preparation for the 2010 World Cup, millions of soccer fans around the world are completing their own plans for the  tournament.

headline: New Flights Between Britain and Malta
text: New flights will connect Britain with Malta, the Malta Tourism Authority said Thursday.

headline: City Proposes Water Rate Increase of Nearly 13%
text: New Yorkers will pay nearly 13 percent more for each drop of water they use starting July 1 if an increase proposed Friday by the Department of Environmental Protection is approved.

headline: Why Most Firms Won’t Drop Employee Health Insurance
text: “I’ve been ‘unofficially’ told by the H.R. manager of my employer,” wrote RG from Los Angeles, “that it will be cheaper for them to take the penalty than to continue insuring us.” RG’s question — whether it was true that “many, many companies will start dumping health insurance benefits” — was one of several we fielded last week about how the new health care reform law would affect small businesses. And though this query came from an employee, not an owner, of a large company, not a small one, clearly many entrepreneurs are also worried that they’ll have to abandon group coverage.

headline: Magazine Ad Pages Continue to Drop
text: The ad-page retreat isn’t over yet.

headline: ‘People Are Returning Them’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Here’s some tech news. Apple is admitting that its iPad sometimes has a hard time connecting to the Internet, and some people are returning them. That’s just wrong. If I returned everything that had a hard time connecting to the Internet, my grandparents would be in big trouble.

headline: Spitzer Does a Turn as News Anchor
text: Eliot Spitzer, cable news anchor?

headline: The End of an Era, for Court and Nation
text: WASHINGTON — Justice John Paul Stevens, who announced his resignation from the Supreme Court on Friday after 34 years, may be the last justice from a time when ability and independence, rather than perceived ideology, were viewed as the crucial qualifications for a seat on the court. He was nominated in 1975 by President Gerald R. Ford, who said all he wanted was “the finest legal mind I could find.”

headline: Sixth in the Class, Straight A’s, Immediate Future Unclear
text: Flashback to Friday, March 26: It was the first day of the Sweet Sixteen South Regional of the NCAA college basketball tournament. I was fortunate to attend these games in Houston, and to watch Baylor v. Saint Mary’s College of California, and Duke v. Purdue.

headline: Developing a ‘Water Battery’ for Trees
text: According to the World Health Organization, 1.2 billion people – or almost 1 out of 5 people in the world – are without access to safe drinking water.  And even in areas with access, 70 percent of water withdrawn from fresh groundwater sources is used for agriculture.

headline: ‘A Big Bully’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Iranian President Mahmoud I’m-a-nut-job has called President Obama a big bully. You know, when you’re 5 feet 2 inches, you think everybody’s a big bully.

headline: ‘Not Everyone’s Happy’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: President Obama signed a historic treaty with the Russian president today. Not everyone’s happy about it. Fox News said it was a “summit between a powerful communist leader and the president of Russia.”

headline: Kyrgyzstan President Is Offered Passage From Country
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan — A tenuous calm settled on this traumatized city on Friday, with an interim government made up of the deposed president’s staunchest opponents claiming that it was rapidly consolidating control.

headline: Diocese in Germany Files Action Against Priest
text: BERLIN — A German diocese said Friday that it had filed a criminal complaint this week against a Roman Catholic priest on charges of sexually abusing minors in the 1980s and ’90s.

headline: Possible Candidates
text: Possible candidates to fill the Supreme Court seat that will be vacated by Justice John Paul Stevens, who announced that he will retire at the end of this term.

headline: The Pros and Cons of Rest
text: The N.B.A. regular season is nearly over and games with much bigger stakes are on the horizon. The last few games for the league’s top teams have brought about an annual debate of whether elite players should be rested.

headline: Sandra’s Sources | Koi Meets Girl
text: Paris Kain doesn’t like being pigeonholed. Best known for his Abraxas Rex jewelry line, which is made from ancient fossils, crystals and meteorites, Kain also paints, writes, make films and dabbles in photography. His latest project — exquisite, hand-painted kimonos with diamond-studded labels — was sparked by a pondful of colorful koi fish outside his girlfriend’s home in Santa Barbara, Calif. “I was reminded of a family I met in Kyoto a few years ago — real artisans who have been dyeing kimono silk for many generations,” he says. Each robe ($1,850) is one of a kind and will be available later this month at Barneys New York, or go to abraxasrex.com.

headline: More Protection for Radiation Patients
text: To better protect patients from faulty machines and deadly doses of radiation, the Food and Drug Administration said it will adopt tighter rules for new radiotherapy equipment.

headline: In Order Books, Signs of Broad Growth
text: THROUGHOUT much of the world, businesses are reporting a continuing surge in new orders, providing an indication that economies are growing.

headline: The Morning Skate: Goalies May Decide Rangers-Flyers Showdown
text: The Canadiens once again could have wrapped up a playoff spot last night by defeating a team not going to the postseason and failed, losing to the Hurricanes, 5-2. They get one more chance on Saturday against yet another non-playoff team, their rivals from Toronto. If they can’t beat the Leafs, or at least get a regulation tie, even Habs fans will have to acknowledge their team doesn’t belong in the tournament.

headline: Book Review Podcast: David Remnick and Norris Church Mailer
text: This week: a conversation with David Remnick about his new biography of Barack Obama; Patricia Cohen leads us through the strange new world of “neuro lit crit”; Norris Church Mailer discusses her memoir, “A Ticket to the Circus,” and her life with the great author Norman Mailer; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Suit Takes Aim at Recording Tax
text: BORROWERS in New York may not be aware of this: They pay some of the highest closing costs in the country, because of a mortgage-recording tax that few other states levy.

headline: Excerpt: 'Glee'
text: The Fox musical comedy returns with new episodes in April.

headline: Thai Protesters Seize TV Station
text: In the first major confrontation with the police in a three-day state of emergency, red-shirted protesters seized a television station that had been shut down by the government of Thailand.

headline: U.S. Now Trying Softer Approach Toward Karzai
text: WASHINGTON — After more than a year of watching America’s ability to influence President Hamid Karzai ebb, Obama administration officials now admit privately that the tough-love approach Mr. Obama adopted when he came to power may have been a big mistake.

headline: Requiem for Malcolm | McLaren’s Last Mix
text: Malcolm McLaren, who died yesterday at 64, had a vast cultural reach. The soundtrack that he composed for Dries Van Noten’s recent fall 2010 menswear show was another example of his intellectual amalgamation, combining “Love Suite” from “Vertigo” with the Mekons, Swiss yodeling, the Raincoats, ambient sounds from the Roxy c. 1977, and Burundi beat.

headline: Police Seek Suspects in Assaults on Asian Women
text: This surveillance video, taken in the lobby of the Gompers Houses on the Lower East Side while a woman is being assaulted off-camera, shows a young man and two young women who are wanted in connection with the assault.

headline: First to Be Curtailed: Tartan Day Parade
text: The recession has forced some deeply painful cutbacks for the people of New York. Raises for some government workers have been suspended. State parks might close. The city could shed 19,000 teachers and other employees.

headline: New Rules About Breast Pumps at Work
text: Writing about the difficulty that hourly workers have finding the time and space to pump breast milk while at work, my colleague Jodi Kantor noted several years ago that while it was admirable that a former Massachusetts governor, Jane Swift, had breast-fed after returning to work, doing so was more complicated for women lower on the ladder — those who work behind fast-food counters, in catalog call centers, on factory floors or as waitresses and soldiers.

headline: The Risks and Returns of Municipal Bonds
text: Municipal bonds are among the few tax shelters left for high-net-worth investors, but many of the entities backing them — cities, states and public works projects — are in such fiscal trouble that many investors are taking a closer look at these historically secure securities.

headline: Palin Is Silent on Stevens and Stupak
text: NEW ORLEANS – Sarah Palin had the stage here on Friday afternoon at the Southern Republican Leadership Conference, where a few dozen reporters and a long line of television cameras were on hand.

headline: Future Infiniti G Could Get Mercedes-Benz 4-Cylinder
text: Nissan’s Infiniti G will someday be available with a Mercedes-Benz 4-cylinder engine, said Carlos  Ghosn, chief executive of Renault and Nissan, in a conference call with reporters this week.

headline: Living in Garrison, N.Y.
text: The hamlet of Garrison, on the Hudson River in Putnam County, is 50 miles north of Manhattan. Dirt roads and spectacular views of the river abound.

headline: Book Review Podcast: David Remnick and Norris Church Mailer
text: This week: a conversation with David Remnick about his new biography of Barack Obama; Patricia Cohen leads us through the strange new world of “neuro lit crit”; Norris Church Mailer discusses her memoir, “A Ticket to the Circus,” and her life with the great author Norman Mailer; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Sweetest at the End
text: FIVE years ago, when all was well, a Boston Globe editor asked if I’d like to be one of several regular contributors to a proposed weekly column they planned to call Coupling. I would fill, unofficially, the long-married slot, and my age would appear in the italicized ID at the end of every piece — good stuff revealed, please. Perhaps I’d like to write about my grown son bringing women home?

headline: J. Bruce Llewellyn, Who Forged a Path for Blacks in Business, Is Dead at 82
text: J. Bruce Llewellyn, whose success in fields as varied as banking, broadcasting, Coca-Cola bottling and groceries made him one of the most prominent black businessmen in America, died Wednesday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: Ontario Issues $8 Billion in Renewable Energy Contracts
text: An Ontario government agency yesterday announced $8 billion in new renewable energy deals under the province’s bulked up feed-in tariff program, with 184 wind, solar, hydro and landfill gas projects winning long-term contracts to provide a total of about 2,500 megawatts of green power.

headline: Shares in Casey’s Rise After Couche-Tard’s Bid
text: Shares in Casey’s General Stores jumped nearly 24 percent on Friday after a Canadian competitor, Alimentation Couche-Tard, offered $1.9 billion in unsolicited takeover bid.

headline: A Spicy Side of Italy
text: When I went to the Abruzzo region of Italy last month to do report on this weekend’s cover story, “Mangia! Mangia!”—in which I ate meals in private homes courtesy of an organization called, appropriately, Home Food — I expected certain things. Abruzzo is a mountainous region, so there would be meat and cheese from goats and sheep. Wild boar roam the forests, so funky prosciutto and sausage would be present. In springtime, herbs and flowers blanket the slopes, and they make for excellent infusions in after-dinner drinks.

headline: Source of Earl Woods Audio Is Revealed
text: The comments by Earl Woods used in a Nike ad and that gave the impression he was mildly lecturing his son about his scandal came from a 2004 documentary in which the elder Woods discussed his and his wife’s parenting styles, ABCNews.com reported.

headline: More Fuzzy E-Book Numbers, This Time From Apple
text: As if Amazon’s fuzzy and incomplete numbers around the Kindle and e-book sales weren’t frustrating enough, now Apple is getting into the game. At the unveiling of the new iPhone operating system on Thursday, Steven P. Jobs said that 600,000 electronic books had been downloaded from Apple’s new iBookstore on the iPad.

headline: Artifacts | Jeff Koons, Car Painter
text: Winning is not supposed to be everything but that’s just what we say to a losing team. To the victors go all the spoils. For some, they include a new BMW. For BMW, the prize is art — or rather artists. It helps if they are famous enough to be their own brands — a Warhol, Lichtenstein or Haring — and a big enough sport to paint a race car headed for Le Mans. For this June’s grand prix, the artist is Jeff Koons.

headline: Older America Made Recession Look Better
text: If you adjusted the jobless numbers for the change in  America’s demographics over the years, the recent recession would look far worse.

headline: Judy Garland and ‘The Harvey Girls’
text: Jane and Michael Stern’s recent review of “Appetite for America,” Stephen Fried’s book about Fred Harvey and his restaurant chain, mentioned the Harvey Girls, who, they explained, “staffed company restaurants at railroad depots throughout the West.” An accompanying photograph showed a group of Oklahoma Harvey Girls in their modest black-and-white uniforms.

headline: Answers From a Hip-Hop Veteran, Part 3
text: Following is the third and final set of answers from Jorge Pabon, a performer and choreographer known as Pop Master Fabel, who responded to questions about the history and culture of hip-hop.

headline: Shipping an Adopted Son Back to Russia
text: There is understandable outrage in Russia after an American woman shipped her adopted 7-year-old son back to Moscow yesterday, declaring him to be “mentally unstable.”

headline: Odd Setting, Old Hat for Boston College and Wisconsin
text: DETROIT – Wisconsin and Boston College’s hockey teams share a lot in common. They’re No. 1 seeds in the N.C.A.A. tournament, play fast, have good goalies, and love to score a lot.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Dennis Hopper, Rocco Landesman, ‘Glee’ and More
text: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

headline: One Louse, Ick. Two Lice, Call for Help!
text: IS any creature less sexy than a louse?

headline: Rego Park, Queens, 10:10 A.M.
text: Jack Lano, 88, shows the young punks how it’s done at the National Masters Weightlifting Championships at the Lost Battalion Hall, a parks department recreation center on Queens Boulevard. The competition, which drew 270 competitors ages 35 and up, started Friday and runs through Sunday.

headline: Prosecutors Dispute Juror’s Account in Astor Trial
text: Manhattan prosecutors aggressively attacked the account of a holdout juror in the trial of Brooke Astor’s son that she caved in and agreed on a guilty verdict because of a threat by another juror, arguing in a brief filed Friday that the juror’s story was an exaggeration.

headline: Stevens Leaving Court After 34 Years
text: Justice John Paul Stevens, who on April 9 announced his plans to retire at the end of the current term, has seen the Supreme Court change substantially over more than three decades on the bench.

headline: Executive Says Competition Drove Fannie to Brink
text: To hear a former senior Fannie Mae executive tell it, the mortgage finance giant’s dive into questionable mortgages during the housing boom arose because the company felt compelled to compete against Wall Street.

headline: I’m Chelsea Handler. And You’re Not.
text: CHELSEA HANDLER is not exactly a household name. In fact, tonight, backstage in her drab dressing room at the Paramount Theater in Seattle — a couple of ragged sofas, cinderblock walls, a watery veggie platter — you would hardly guess that she is a celebrity at all.

headline: Steve Jones Fondly Recalls Malcolm McLaren
text: If Johnny Rotten’s remembrance of Malcolm McLaren, the Sex Pistols manager who died on Thursday, wasn’t punk enough for you, there’s also this:

headline: Ferrari Reveals 599 GTO, Its Fastest Road Car Ever
text: The new Ferrari 599 GTO may not have the supercar looks of a McLaren MP4-12C or a Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG, but it should be right up there with those two in terms of speed and quickness.

headline: A Rooftop Perch for a Midtown Bar
text: SITTING in the rooftop bar atop the new Strand Hotel on West 37th Street, it’s not a stretch to imagine that you’re perched in a skybox, watching, up close, the gorgeous light show that is Manhattan at night.

headline: No More Missed Boats for Apartment Hunters
text: FOR 12 years, ever since Warren Clamen and Guy Saint-Arnaud moved to New York from Montreal, they suffered from real estate regret. “We should have bought the second we moved here,” Mr. Clamen said. “But we didn’t have the wherewithal. We missed the boat.”

headline: U.S. Sees Increase of International Visitors
text: The U.S. Department of Commerce said that 3.4 million international visitors traveled to the United States in January, an increase of 10 percent compared to the same month a year earlier. However, international visitors spent about 3 percent less compared to January 2009.

headline: We Made It Ourselves | Bresaola Before Swine
text: Got lemons? Make lemonade. Easy. But what do you do with the bottom round on a leg of beef?

headline: VH1: Where Love Hurts
text: Somebody could write a doctoral dissertation pegged to the morphing and remorphing of VH1 over the years as it has tried, some might say desperately, to stay relevant.

headline: An Honor Justice Stevens Might Rather Forget
text: It would take a legal scholar to fully explore the relationship between the Supreme Court Associate Justice John Paul Stevens, who announced his retirement on Friday, and New York City. But a quick review of the record shows that he had at least one extraordinary connection to one of New York’s enduring industries: the adult entertainment business.

headline: Social-Media, Not Social-ism
text: The Obama administration has released guidelines for how the government should use social-media outlets to engage the public, approving new, largely unregulated, channels like Facebook as tools to informally sample public opinion.

headline: Spacecraft Spots Active Volcanoes on Venus
text: Venus is alive.

headline: Tackling the Tenant Blacklist With New Legislation
text: IF you have ever been in housing court for an eviction proceeding — whether you withheld rent because of the hole in your ceiling or because of the ticket you bought to Maui — your name may be on a list that screening companies sell to landlords to help them spot potentially troublesome tenants.

headline: To You Auteurs Out There, Just Do It
text: It’s hard to imagine a television ad more ripe for parody than one that uses voiceover. Substitute your own audio here, it all but begs amateur auteurs. And they answered the call after the Wednesday night debut of the latest Tiger Woods spot from Nike.

headline: A Banner Year for Wind Power
text: The American housing market remained in the doldrums in 2009 and automakers sputtered along, but the wind industry continued to boom, according to a report released Thursday.

headline: A Prosperous Union for ‘Tony N’ Tina’ and Actors’ Equity
text: The nuptials of Anthony Angelo Nunzio and Valentina Lynne Vitale, more than 20 years in the making, will proceed on Saturday as planned. Actors’ Equity Association said on Friday that the producers of “Tony N’ Tina’s Wedding,” the Off-Broadway show, had agreed to recognize the contract of its actors who are represented by the association and that performances of the show would continue. On Thursday, the association said it had filed an unfair-labor-practice charge with the National Labor Relations Board against Broadway Entertainment, which produces “Tony N’ Tina’s Wedding,” saying the company had closed and re-opened the show in less than eight weeks without negotiating with the union — violating a union rule — and was offering employment to its cast on the condition they resign from Equity or work without its representation. Broadway Entertainment said on Friday afternoon that it had come to an oral agreement with Actors’ Equity and that the union had committed to talks next week to resolve other matters.

headline: Venus Volcano
text: 360-degree views of a volcano on Venus. (Created by Ryan Ollerenshaw and Eric DeJong of the Solar System Visualization Group, JPL.)

headline: Looking, or Just Looking
text: SUNDAY after Sunday, a ritual is repeated throughout Manhattan and other parts of the city: Owner of a property for sale straightens up and clears out for a couple of hours. Broker comes in, tidies up some more. At scheduled time, the door opens and an urban apartment is transformed into the residential equivalent of a suburban mall, serious shoppers mingling with those who are just looking, all of them out enjoying a great American weekend activity.

headline: Nurses and Stanford Hospitals Are at Loggerheads
text: When representatives of Stanford Hospital and Clinics and Lucile Packard Children’s Hospital submitted their “Last, Best, and Final Offer” to its nurses on March 30, their gesture seemed to be an ultimatum of sorts.

headline: With Family Built In
text: IF by magic you could slice off the facade of Jennifer Acosta’s red- and cream-colored house in Woodhaven, Queens, as if it were one of those dollhouses that open to reveal what lies within, you would find most of the people she feels closest to in the world.

headline: Seeking Moderns, to Save Them
text: WESTON

headline: Live First Shot Provides Ratings Bump to ESPN
text: ESPN’s heavily promoted live airing of Tiger Woods’s first tee shot at the Masters Thursday at 1:42 p.m. Eastern generated a substantially higher rating for “SportsCenter” than it usually gets in that part of the afternoon.

headline: On Long Island, Competing Brokers Become Comrades
text: PLANDOME MANOR

headline: For the Best of the Best, Determination Outweighs Nature and Nurture
text: I’VE always been considered a good writer and a terrible singer. I pick up sports quickly but draw like a 2-year-old. My talents, such as they are, seemed pretty set by the time I was in my late teens.

headline: Whoosh! The Trash Can as a Pneumatic Tube
text: Underneath the 40-block strip of land between Queens and Manhattan known as Roosevelt Island is a complex system of pneumatic tubes that connects the island’s 12,000 or so residents. But it’s not mail that’s hurtling through them at at 30 miles an hour. It’s garbage. Vacuum cleaners, Christmas trees and last night’s unfinished dinner have all passed through the intestines of the Automated Vacuum Assisted Collections facility, a pneumatic trash system built in 1975 that seems forever ahead of its time.

headline: ‘Deeply Offensive’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Multiple Bids, but Not Exactly a War
text: DID you hear? There were 17 bids on a $1 million house in Short Hills late last month. In a slowly recovering housing market, that kind of activity tends to cause a stir.

headline: Out in Italy With Bertolli
text: A giant marketer is again sponsoring a campaign for one of its mainstream food brands that is aimed at gay and lesbian consumers.

headline: The Country, However You Define It
text: ROBERT A. MCCAFFREY, who has lived all of his 67 years in Garrison, across the Hudson River from the United States Military Academy at West Point, can recount stories of buyers who moved in, lured by the astonishing beauty of the area, and then within a year sold their homes and left for someplace closer to supermarkets and other suburban amenities.

headline: Aspen Festival Music Director Quits
text: Early this week the Aspen Music Festival and School released its schedule of programs for the summer. It should have included a blue pencil. The festival announced on Friday that David Zinman, its music director since 1997 and the director of the American Academy of Conducting at Aspen, which he founded in 2000, had resigned effective immediately.

headline: Working Financial Literacy in With the Three R’s
text: Most Americans aren’t fluent in the language of money. Yet we’re expected to make big financial decisions as early as our teens — Should I take on thousands of dollars of student debt? Should I buy a car? — even though most of us received no formal instruction on financial matters until it was too late.

headline: How Will Microsoft Explain Its Pink Phones to Partners?
text: Come Monday, Microsoft will need to apply some of its most sophisticated public relations and marketing maneuvers.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: A culinary group in Italy called Home Food seeks out exceptional home cooks, puts them through a training course and dubs them Cesarinas — little Caesars, emperors of the kitchen.  Then a few times a month, the Cesarinas open their homes to paying guests.  Matt Gross, who writes the Frugal Traveler column, grabs a fork and dives in.

headline: It’s History: Audio, Video and Live Performance
text: In 1969 Vivian Perlis, then working as a reference librarian at the Yale School of Music, started doing tape-recorded interviews with people who had known and worked with Charles Ives, a Yale graduate. That project culminated in Ms. Perlis’s landmark 1974 book, “Charles Ives Remembered: An Oral History.”

headline: Bertolli Ad by Logo
text: Charlie David of "Bump" on Logo appears in a commercial for Bertolli created by the cable channel.

headline: Andrew C. Florance
text: Mr. Florance, 46, is a founder and the chief executive of the CoStar Group, a provider of data, marketing and analytic services to the commercial real estate industry.

headline: How Would You Teach Personal Finance in School?
text: The economic crisis has provided a reminder that many Americans lack financial savvy.  So in this week’s Your Money column, I make the case for adding a subject to America’s course load: personal finance.

headline: Dear God: A Young Boy Needs a Cure. Please Help.
text: Here’s the pitch: A child with brain cancer writes letters to God and thereby touches the heart of an embittered, hard-drinking postal carrier. Even an untrained eye can see right away that a story with that much emotion in its central plotline would require restraint and subtlety to be brought credibly to the screen.

headline: Chickpea Tagine With Chicken
text: Mark Bittman cooks a one-pot meal with Moroccan flavors.

headline: Room to Grow
text: It’s one thing to commission a sumptuous landscape design to go with your impressive house design. But you know that a homeowner is serious about greenery when there’s a greenhouse involved. That was the case when B Five Studio, the New York design firm, was asked to design a greenhouse and utility sheds to go with the comfortably elegant house that it had designed in northern Westchester County, N.Y. (The extensive landscape around the house was designed by Reed Hilderbrand, a firm based in Watertown, Mass.)

headline: A Show Born in a Garden, but Not Garden Variety
text: A disclaimer before I review Paige Martin’s “Panorama”: I left 25 minutes before the show’s conclusion.

headline: An Expedited Tagine
text: TAGINES, the slow-cooked, deeply aromatic stews of North Africa, are traditionally made and served in distinctive clay pots, often with lamb, and usually over couscous.

headline: Deadline Extended to Rule on Box-Office Futures Trading
text: The federal commission that oversees futures trading said on Friday that it had extended to April 16 the deadline for deciding whether to approve a proposal to create a market for futures contracts based on movie box-office receipts.

headline: For Couples, a Day Makes a Big Difference
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — It seemed as if things were all set up for Fred Couples on Friday. He had a nice tee time, just before 10 a.m. The weather at the start of the day even matched his age and demeanor — 50 and breezy.

headline: Doctors Remove Ammunition From Soldier’s Head
text: WASHINGTON — The patient arrived in critical condition last month at the Bagram Air Base hospital in Afghanistan, with what American military doctors at first thought was an all too typical war injury: metal shrapnel from an improvised bomb lodged in his head.

headline: Revisiting Adolescence in the Secret Annex
text: A new adaptation of Anne Frank’s diary arrives on Sunday night on PBS, and it stars the unedited Anne: harshly critical of the people sharing her cramped hiding place (including her mother), self-dramatizing, sexually curious. We see her in a bra, we see her making out in the attic, we hear her talking about her period and her urge to explore her body.
