text: A wealthy client of the Swiss bank UBS pleaded guilty on Monday to tax fraud, the ninth American caught up in an investigation of the bank’s offshore private banking services.

headline: ‘Titans’ Conquers ‘Date Night’ at the Box Office
text: It may not seem to matter much now in a post-Conan-O’Brien-goes-to-TBS world, but a winner has been declared in the box-office showdown between “Clash of the Titans” and “Date Night.” After all the drachmas or denarii or whatever currency an ancient warrior might carry were counted, “Clash of the Titans” remained No. 1 for the second weekend in a row, according to the entertainment site Hollywood.com, with a three-day gross of $26.6 million; in its opening weekend “Date Night” had to settle for second place with ticket sales of $25.2 million. “Date Night” stars Tina Fey, Steve Carell and a parade of celebrities in cameo roles. But “Clash of the Titans” has the Kraken.

headline: Failure Is A Failed Strategy
text: One thing that keeps coming up in comments, both here and on my column, is the widespread belief that all we need to do on the banking front is (a) break up the big banks, so that none of them are too big to fail (b) promise not to bail out any banks in the future. That way, the claim goes, bankers will know that they will face dire consequences if they misbehave, and market discipline will do the rest.

headline: British Prime Minister Proposes Tougher Takeover Rules
text: LONDON — Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain proposed changes to the country’s takeover rules on Monday that could make it more difficult to acquire British companies.

headline: Israeli Stores Stop Selling Book That Denounces Settlers
text: Updated | Tuesday | 8:23 a.m. An Israeli bookstore chain announced on Sunday that it would stop selling “The National Left,” a political manifesto by two Israeli authors who compare settlers living on occupied Palestinian land to “brainwashing, hypnotized zombies” transforming Israel into “an apartheid state.”

headline: Does Milk Make You Phlegmy?
text: In an article last year about health myths, I wrote about research showing that drinking milk does not increase nasal secretions, cough or congestion.

headline: Because Bread Is for Wimps
text: Quick, what kind of sandwich goes calorie-for-calorie with the Big Mac  without resorting to bread? KFC’s new chicken-bacon-cheese three-bagger, the “Double Down,” that’s what kind. Our colleague Sam Sifton, after lining his stomach with wax paper and titanium, tried one at Broadway and 33rd Street on Monday morning. All he got for his troubles (other than some  unasked-for face time online) was a “slimy and unnaturally moist thing.” Read all about it here.

headline: A Google Tablet Could Be Good News for Adobe
text: As Ashlee Vance and I report in a Monday article, Hewlett-Packard, Acer, Microsoft and a suite of other companies are hard at work on products that they hope will be iPad killers.

headline: The Moviegoer | Bette Gordon’s ‘Handsome Harry’
text: The Moviegoer is a regular column on new and noteworthy films, actors and directors by John Anderson.

headline: Washington Post Wins 4 Pulitzers, New York Times Gets 3
text: The Washington Post won four Pulitzer Prizes on Monday for its work in 2009, and The New York Times won three, while ProPublica became the first of the new breed of online, nonprofit news organizations to win the most prestigious award in print journalism.

headline: 2010 Pulitzer Prizes for Letters, Drama and Music
text: The Pulitzer Prizes were announced on Monday.

headline: Europe Finds Clean Energy in Trash, but U.S. Lags
text: HORSHOLM, Denmark — The lawyers and engineers who dwell in an elegant enclave here are at peace with the hulking neighbor just over the back fence: a vast energy plant that burns thousands of tons of household garbage and industrial waste, round the clock.

headline: Some, but Not All, Savor Silence in the Stacks
text: The library may be one of the last bastions of quiet in this pinball machine world, but some of these community institutions have broken the no-shushing laws that once ruled the land.

headline: Complicated Emotions, Spurred by a Visit to Cuba
text: It’s the spring of 2004, and Ruth is angry and tired. Ruth, a Columbia University professor teaching fiction writing to graduate students she dismisses as the cowardly “children of Republicans,” rages against them and President Bush even as she rages against herself, a onetime radical, for hiding in her job. Now in her 70s, she seethes with longing: for a student with talent; for her ex-lover; and for a late-in-life show of meaning.

headline: In India, Wal-Mart Goes to the Farm
text: HAIDER NAGAR, India — At first glance, the vegetable patches in this north Indian village look no different from the many small, spare farms that dot the country.

headline: Apps We’d Like to See: Bright Light to Night Light
text: Everybody seems to have some idea for an app, and here’s mine. I think it might be worth something; it is designed to increase domestic bliss.

headline: Where Auto Insurance Is Most Expensive
text: Louisiana has the highest average auto insurance rates in the United States, while Maine has the lowest, according to new data from Insure.com that ranks the states according to their average insurance rates (see the full ranking below).

headline: Wade Plays Down Free Agency Buzz
text: Every thing LeBron James does comes under scrutiny for clues by those trying to divine where the soon-to-be free agent could be headed.

headline: 2010 Pulitzer Prizes for Journalism
text: The Pulitzer Prizes were announced on Monday. Following are the winners in Journalism.

headline: China Pledges to Work With U.S. on Iran Sanctions
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama secured a promise from President Hu Jintao of China on Monday to join negotiations on a new package of sanctions against Iran, administration officials said, but Mr. Hu made no specific commitment to backing measures that the United States considers severe enough to force a change in direction in Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Roethlisberger Isn’t Charged, but the N.F.L. Could Act
text: Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger will not face criminal charges stemming from an incident in which he was accused of sexually assaulting a 20-year-old college student, but the N.F.L. has a broadly worded personal conduct policy that gives Commissioner Roger Goodell plenty of latitude to determine its own discipline.

headline: Data on Fees to Doctors Is Called Hard to Parse
text: Pfizer recently became the latest big drug maker to start disclosing payments to doctors who act as consultants or speakers. But many followers of the pharmaceutical industry are still finding it far too difficult to follow the money.

headline: No Makeup Required
text: Oh, the irony! Have you ever noticed how many women in fashion refuse to embellish their faces? Here are five trendsetters whose daily regimen consists mostly of soap and water.

headline: In Reporting Symptoms, Don’t Patients Know Best?
text: About six years ago, my doctor gave me some samples of a drug to treat pain from an injury. I took it for a few days and then woke up one morning with a big red blister on my tongue. I’d never had anything like it before, and I wondered if the pills might be to blame. They weren’t helping much anyway, so I quit taking them. The blister went away. I mentioned it the next time I saw the doctor, but he said it must have been a coincidence.

headline: A New Lizard? Well, New to Science
text: The number of lizard species in the world — by most counts, around 4,000 — has just increased by one, with the announcement of a new species found on Luzon island in the Philippines.

headline: A Grid of Wind Turbines to Pick Up the Slack
text: Like most other sources of alternative energy, the wind can be intermittent. It does not blow uniformly, so power output from wind turbines rises and falls. And when the wind doesn’t blow at all, output drops to zero.

headline: Rare Bird, Alive and Well and Living in Colombia
text: The mountainous area around Santa Marta, on Colombia’s Caribbean coast, is a biological hotspot of sorts, filled with bird species that are found nowhere else.

headline: Sentences Get Harsher in White-Collar Cases
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: Farming Fish
text: Q. Why do ecologists seem to give the nod to farmed catfish and tilapia but not salmon?

headline: At Target Field, Puckett’s Memory Lives On
text: MINNEAPOLIS – Downstairs in the press dining room at the new Target Field on Monday, five people sat at a table in the back. It was about as exclusive a table as you could find around here: Harmon Killebrew, Rod Carew, Tony Oliva, Kent Hrbek and Kirby Puckett Jr., who is 17. The four players, and Puckett’s father, all have their numbers retired by the Twins.

headline: Nuggets Sign Karl’s Son to Contract
text: Coby Karl wants to be seen as just another member of the Denver Nuggets.

headline: ‘Tinkers’ by Paul Harding: The One That Got Away
text: Every now and then a good book completely passes us by: we don’t get a copy, for whatever reason, and we don’t request one because the book’s not on our radar. That’s what happened with Paul Harding’s first novel, “Tinkers,” which was published at the beginning of 2009 by the Bellevue Literary Press, a small publisher that had only been in business for a couple of years. Now “Tinkers” has gone and won the Pulitzer Prize — the first novel from a small press to win that award since “A Confederacy of Dunces” did it for Louisiana State University Press in 1981.

headline: ‘Tinkers’ by Paul Harding: The One That Got Away
text: Every now and then a good book completely passes us by: we don’t get a copy, for whatever reason, and we don’t request one because the book’s not on our radar. That’s what happened with Paul Harding’s first novel, “Tinkers,” which was published at the beginning of 2009 by the Bellevue Literary Press, a small publisher that had only been in business for a couple of years. Now “Tinkers” has gone and won the Pulitzer Prize — the first novel from a small press to win that award since “A Confederacy of Dunces” did it for Louisiana State University Press in 1981.

headline: Pertussis, 1913
text: Whooping cough has been a well-known disease for hundreds of years, and the term “pertussis” has been in use since the 18th century. Its symptoms are vivid: severe coughing spells ending with a whooping gasp for breath and a face that turns red or purple, often followed by vomiting and then a return to feeling fine until the next episode. But until the early 20th century, no one knew what caused it.

headline: Cancer Survival Demands Steady Progress
text: I continue to find reasons to be hopeful that one day, though probably not within my lifetime, medical researchers will overcome the challenges that thwart efforts to cure or at least contain most cancers, especially the more common ones.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Voting in Sudan
text: Sudan’s first multiparty elections in more than 20 years began on Sunday. They have been hampered by accusations of fraud and a boycott by some opposition parties. Although the incumbent president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, has been vilified in the West and charged by the International Criminal Court with crimes against humanity, he is expected to win. Across the country, thousands of candidates are competing for state, regional and national positions (Slides 1, 2 and 3). Elsewhere, leaders converged in Washington for an international nuclear security summit meeting (Slide 4).

headline: Could Health Overhaul Incentives Hurt Some?
text: The new health care law promises to extend coverage to millions of Americans and to cut costs by cultivating healthy habits and preventive care. But could its emphasis on wellness undermine one of its central achievements: putting an end to the practice of charging sick people more for health insurance?

headline: Research Reactors a Safety Challenge
text: In Cambridge, Mass., at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a nuclear reactor emits an eerie blue glow 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Its fuel is 93 percent uranium 235 — the high-purity uranium it takes to energize an atom bomb and exactly what the West fears that Tehran wants to produce.

headline: Jack Kirby’s Heroes in Waiting
text: The characteristics of a Jack Kirby illustration are easily distinguished: extravagantly costumed heroes and nefarious villains locked in titanic struggles; foreshortened fists, feet and muscles that seem to pop off the page; intricately detailed settings meant to conjure the ancient past or suggest the distant future.

headline: Fed Picks Chief of Monetary Affairs Division
text: WASHINGTON  —  The Federal Reserve Board on Monday named William B. English director of its division of monetary affairs, one of the most powerful staff positions at the central bank.

headline: The Sandcastle Worm
text: Russel J. Stewart of the University of Utah is studying the sandcastle worm's ability to glue minerals underwater in order to create a synthetic version for use as a medical adhesive.

headline: For Pediatricians in the Military, Duty Always Calls
text: In the mid-1960s, Dr. Eve Kimball was the first female intern in the Army. She started her residency in pediatrics at Madigan Army Medical Center in Tacoma, Wash., while her husband did his residency there in internal medicine. She was honorably discharged after one year for disability — she was pregnant with their first child — and has worked as a civilian pediatrician in practices that serve military families.

headline: Technology: For Nations That Lack the Expertise, an Automated System for Detecting TB
text: One of the difficulties of diagnosing tuberculosis is that there is no simple blood or urine test. Instead, a laboratory technician must take a sample of sputum coughed up from the lungs, stain it and inspect it under a microscope for the telltale bacteria, which resemble long-grain rice. It takes expertise that is often rare in poor countries.

headline: Two Media Analysts Weigh In on Conan O’Brien Deal
text: Steve Sternberg, a longtime media analyst who now blogs on The Sternberg Report, offered this opinion on Conan O’Brien’s new show on TBS in an e-mail message:

headline: London Cab, Now Made in China
text: The black cab, as much a part of London’s cityscape as Big Ben and Harrod’s, will get an update and a new manufacturer when the Geely version makes its debut later this month at the Beijing auto show.

headline: Interview Transcript: Justice John Paul Stevens
text: The following is an edited transcript of an interview with Justice John Paul Stevens conducted by Jeffrey Rosen for The New York Times Magazine article "The Dissenter," published on Sept. 23, 2007. The interview was conducted on June 22, 2007.

headline: Morgan Stanley Chief Not Satisfied With 2009 Results
text: James P. Gorman, the new chief executive of Morgan Stanley, says he is not satisfied with the firm’s financial results for last year, which included a loss of 93 cents a share, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: 11,000, Almost 11 Years Later
text: Wall Street is excited that the Dow Jones industrials closed over 11,000 today, for the first time since just after Lehman Brothers failed.

headline: Expert Answers on Multiple Myeloma
text: In Tuesday’s Science Times, the Personal Health columnist Jane Brody explores the progress being made in the treatment of cancer patients like Janet Battaile, a former reporter for The New York Times who has multiple myeloma, the second most common blood-based malignancy:

headline: Studying Sea Life for a Glue That Mends People
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Along one wall of Russell J. Stewart’s laboratory at the University of Utah sits a saltwater tank containing a strange object: a rock-hard lump the size of a soccer ball, riddled with hundreds of small holes.

headline: The High Low | Eryn Brinié Trench, $198
text: What: Eryn Brinié Spring Trench

headline: Chicago Restaurant Opens on Four Floors
text: This  is no misnomer.  Epic, as the name of this new Chicago restaurant in River North suggests, has grand ambitions. Spread across four floors including a roof deck, it spans some 14,000 square feet and has a 190-seat dining room highlighted by 24-foot-high windows.

headline: White House Dashes Chatter of Clinton as Supreme Court Nominee
text: To the list of candidates President Obama is considering for the Supreme Court, strike this name: Hillary Rodham Clinton. But add these: Sidney Thomas, Janet Napolitano, Jennifer Granholm and Leah Ward Sears.

headline: For Sky Blue’s Dutch Defender, Pay and a Platform
text: Daphne Koster was the epitome of a free agent.

headline: A Brief Sensation on TV in Taiwan
text: So much for the next Susan Boyle. A week after his pitch-perfect rendition of “I Will Always Love You” made him an online sensation, Lin Yu-chun, above, a 24-year-old contestant on the “One Million Star” show, a Taiwanese talent competition, was voted off the program, Agence France-Presse reported. Video of Mr. Lin, a shop worker who has been nicknamed Little Fatty, singing that Whitney Houston-by-way-of-Dolly Parton love ballad, was widely circulated on the Internet and was viewed more than four million times on YouTube. But those numbers apparently meant nothing to the show’s viewers and judges, who criticized Mr. Lin’s performance of a Mandarin song on the next week’s broadcast. (“You rarely hit a wrong note,” one judge said. “But you did today. What’s wrong with you?”) Stella Teng, an agent for Mr. Lin, told Agence France-Presse: “Despite the failure he still keeps a positive attitude. He feels that success cannot possibly come without failure.” Ms. Teng said that Mr. Lin would be invited back on “One Million Star” as a guest performer next week, and may give interviews or concerts in other territories, including the United States.

headline: Gotti on ‘60 Minutes’: Who Can Refuse?
text: We’re afraid to be the ones to tell him this, but John Gotti Jr. got a boost for his first interview with “60 Minutes” from CBS’s afternoon coverage of the Masters on Sunday. After Phil Mickelson’s victory at Augusta National, CBS was No. 1 for the night, according to Nielsen’s estimates, with a lineup that included “60 Minutes” (which garnered over 15 million viewers) and the season finale of its hit reality show “Undercover Boss” (14.1 million). ABC ranked second overall, benefiting from a two-hour episode of “Brothers & Sisters” (8.8 million). NBC was third with “Dateline” (3.7 million) and a rerun of “Minute to Win It” (4.5 million), followed by “The Celebrity Apprentice” (6.6 million), while Fox placed fourth with its comedy lineup including “The Simpsons” (5.6 million) and “Family Guy” (6.9 million).

headline: ‘Such Tweet Sorrow’: Posts by Shakespeare
text: Since Sunday a new Twitter user with the screen name @julietcap16 has been excitedly firing off posts about her typical teenage life, her frustrations with school and the birthday party she hopes her family will give her. But she’s not just any social-media-savvy teenager; she’s the online avatar for Juliet Capulet in a 21st-century update of “Romeo and Juliet” that the Royal Shakespeare Company has started online. BBC News reported that during the project, which is called “Such Tweet Sorrow” and will run for five weeks, actors playing Shakespeare’s star-crossed lovers (who had their disagreements about the chirping of birds) and other characters from that tragedy will play out the story on Twitter and react to real-life events. Charlotte Wakefield, an actor in the Royal Shakespeare Company who is playing Juliet (above, with the actor James Barrett), has already tweeted about her new bed and her beloved deceased mother, as well as the Robert Pattinson cutout she keeps in her bedroom. Michael Boyd, the artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company, told the BBC that the project tries to bring performers and theatergoers closer together. “Mobile phones don’t need to be the antichrist for theater,” he said.

headline: All in All, It’s Just a Tour of ‘The Wall’
text: After more than two decades of making us eat our meat, Roger Waters is finally giving us the pudding. On Monday Mr. Waters, the onetime Pink Floyd singer, songwriter and bassist, gave in to the demands of ornery students everywhere and announced a concert-tour version of “The Wall,” his former band’s concept album about post-World War II disillusionment, rock stardom and the anguish of being pursued by groupies. Billboard reported that Mr. Waters would begin the 36-date tour on Sept. 15 in Toronto and conclude it on Dec. 13 in Anaheim, Calif. Concerts, which will, of course, feature a 35-foot-tall, 240-foot-wide wall on stage, are also scheduled for Madison Square Garden (Oct. 5) and the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J. (Nov. 3). Billboard said that “The Wall” had been performed live only 31 times by Pink Floyd or Mr. Waters, who left the group in the mid-1980s: in a series of concerts the band played in 1980 and 1981, and by Mr. Waters in 1990 to mark the fall of the Berlin Wall.

headline: The Doctor Is in (an Off Broadway Play)
text: Trading in her stethoscope and the trappings of Hollywood for an Off Broadway debut, the actress Kate Walsh (Dr. Addison Montgomery on ABC’s “Private Practice”), above, will play one of the lead roles in Stephen Belber’s new play, “Dusk Rings a Bell,” at the Atlantic Theater Company this spring. She will star as a CNN executive who unexpectedly encounters a man with whom she had an adolescent fling years earlier, and the two find that their romanticized memories of youth are complicated by adult realities. Her co-star is Paul Sparks, above, who played Ejlert Lovborg in last season’s Broadway revival of “Hedda Gabler” and has acted Off Broadway most recently in “Pumpgirl” and “Essential Self-Defense.” Ms. Walsh, who trained at the Piven Theater Workshop and Oxford School of Drama, starred in several plays in Chicago and elsewhere before taking television roles on “The Drew Carey Show,” “Karen Sisco” and “Grey’s Anatomy,” on which she created the character she now plays on “Private Practice.” The play by Mr. Belber (“Match,” “Geometry of Fire”) will be directed by Sam Gold (“Circle Mirror Transformation”) at the Atlantic’s Stage 2 at 330 West 16th Street in Chelsea. The production is to begin previews on May 19 and open on May 27, running through June 20.

headline: Vatican Gets Around to Praising the Beatles
text: At a time when the Vatican could use a little positive notice in the news media, the Holy See has momentarily turned attention away from the helter skelter it has lately faced by offering its enthusiastic praise for the Beatles. In its weekend editions, L’Osservatore Romano, the official newspaper of the Vatican, commemorated the Beatles on the 40th anniversary of that group’s breakup, and endorsed the Fab Four’s music without quite giving a thumbs-up to the band members’ lifestyles, The Associated Press reported. “It’s true, they took drugs; swept up by their success, they lived dissolute and uninhibited lives,” L’Osservatore Romano wrote. “But,” the newspaper added, “listening to their songs, all of this seems distant and meaningless. Their beautiful melodies, which changed forever pop music and still give us emotions, live on like precious jewels.” Giovanni Maria Vian, the editor in chief of L’Osservatore Romano, told The A.P. that he is a fan of the Beatles, and he minimized John Lennon’s notorious 1966 remark that the band at that time was “more popular than Jesus.” “In reality it wasn’t that scandalous,” Mr. Vian said, “because the fascination with Jesus was so great that it attracted these new heroes of the time.”

headline: Does Obama Have the Right Stuff for Space?
text: Will President Obama’s plan for space exploration bring us closer to Mars — or is it a step backward for those who favor human exploration of the solar system?

headline: From ‘Life of Pi’ Author, Stuffed-Animal Allegory About Holocaust
text: Yann Martel’s 2001 novel, “Life of Pi,” was a charming, eccentric fable — part philosophical meditation on God, part children’s adventure story about a boy’s voyage across the ocean on a lifeboat with a tiger named Richard Parker.

headline: Apache to Buy Oil and Gas Assets from Devon
text: The Apache Corporation said Monday that it would acquire Devon Energy’s oil and gas assets in the Gulf of Mexico for $1.05 billion, an amount that is about $250 million more than some analysts had expected. The deal expands Apache’s presence in the region and gives Devon the cash it needs to concentrate on its land drilling operations.

headline: Where Auto Insurance Is Most Expensive
text: From our colleagues at the Bucks blog:

headline: Like, We Are a Lost Generation, You Know
text: “I mean, wouldn’t you think, it’s a bit, you know,” begins a typical exchange of ideas in “Enjoy,” Toshiki Okada’s clever portrait of the comically desperate part-time employees of a cafe in recession-racked Japan. A co-worker (Alex Torra) responds, “What do you mean, you know?”

headline: When a Doctor Plays Down Your Symptoms
text: Do doctors have a tendency to play down the symptoms and complaints of their patients?

headline: No, Minister
text: BAGHDAD – Sometimes it’s the little things that tell you all you really need to know about the big ones.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Slip Tease
text: This is the era of exhibitionism, when everybody reveals everything to everybody, like it or not. Marilyn Monroe standing over a subway grate way back when is hardly indecent now. Her giggly joy — oooh goody, I’m aerating my nether parts — was sweet, and without air conditioning on a blistering summer night, she was just being sensible.

headline: As His Health Struggles Continue, James Levine Faces Difficult Choices
text: No one is more frustrated over the serious health problems James Levine has struggled with since 2006 than Mr. Levine himself, as he has indicated in numerous interviews and news releases. For six years he has been juggling demanding music directorships at the Metropolitan Opera and the Boston Symphony Orchestra. But because of various surgical procedures and injuries requiring long recuperative periods, he has missed months of accumulated performances at each institution, not just in Boston and New York but on American and international tours.

headline: New Force Behind Agency of Wonder
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — The Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency is different from other federal agencies. For one thing, the agency, known as Darpa, created the Internet (really). For another, it is probably the only agency ever to offer a $40,000 prize for a balloon hunt, a contest that was inspired by Regina Dugan, a 47-year-old expert in mine detection, who took over last summer as its director.

headline: Channel 13 Is Putting Lincoln Center on the Set
text: It may not be the same as Matt Lauer interviewing movie stars on “Today,” but Channel 13 is betting that some people will want to press their noses to the glass to see Paula Zahn, the former CNN anchor, or Philippe de Montebello, the former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, interview curators in its new storefront studio at Lincoln Center.

headline: Percentage of Animals Put to Death in Shelters Reaches Low
text: “There’s never been a better time to be a dog in New York City,” Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proclaimed Monday morning. As usual, he had statistical proof. The percentage of dogs and cats put to death at the city’s shelters hit an all-time low last year – 33 percent, down from 69 percent in 2003.

headline: A Bike for Abel
text: My Sunday column was about an amazing set of kids living in a Zimbabwe hut together after their four parents died of AIDS. The kid in charge, a high school student, wants a bicycle to reduce his three-hour commute to school each way — and now it looks as if he’ll get it. Several readers are trying to send him money for that bike (I didn’t want to post his contact information for fear of getting him in trouble with the Zimbabwean government, and aid organizations were wary of being intermediaries for similar reasons).

headline: Bank Woes Haunt Illinois Democrat in Senate Race
text: CHICAGO – With pressure mounting over the possible demise of his family’s bank, Alexi Giannoulias, a Democrat who hopes to fill President Obama’s former seat in the United States Senate, on Monday blamed his Republican opponent for talking too much about the whole bank situation.

headline: ‘This Week’ Is Adding Online Fact Checks
text: WASHINGTON  ABC’s Sunday morning public affairs program, “This Week,” is adding an online feature that its political guests may not appreciate: fact checking.

headline: NASA, We’ve Got a Problem. But It Can Be Fixed.
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. — During his trip to the Kennedy Space Center this week, President Obama will be confronted with an awkward political reality: when it comes to space exploration, sometimes even Republicans can be passionate advocates for the public option.

headline: Hotel Talk | The Pritzker Conundrum
text: Days after the announcement that Sanaa would receive the Pritzker Prize (considered architecture’s highest honor), the Tokyo firm —  a partnership of  Kazuyo Sejima and Ryue Nishizawa — was asked to design a hotel. As part of a larger foray into the hospitality business, the international luxury goods maker LVMH plans to turn the Samaritaine department store in Paris into chic accommodations. (The company acquired the store, in a landmark building overlooking the Seine, in 2001, and closed it four years later.)

headline: Teixeira Honors a Cancer Patient
text: During his seven-plus years in the major leagues, Yankees first baseman Mark Teixeira has visited numerous children’s cancer wards and spoken to hundreds of patients. But Teixeira said none of those experiences touched him as much as the encounter he had in February with 19-year-old Brian Ernst.

headline: Luke’s Lobster Spreads Uptown
text: Luke Holden has done so well selling lobster rolls he’s quitting his day job and heading to the Upper East Side.

headline: UBS Client Pleads Guilty to Tax Fraud
text: A wealthy client of the Swiss bank UBS pleaded guilty on Monday to tax fraud, the ninth American caught up in an investigation of the bank’s offshore private banking services, The New York Times’s Lynnley Browning reports.

headline: The Long Story of a Long Revolution
text: “Invictus” isn’t the only recent film to look at apartheid and the complicated legacy it left in South Africa. But unlike Clint Eastwood and his cast, Connie Field has taken the documentary route in “Have You Heard From Johannesburg,” a series of seven films that will have its world premiere this week at Film Forum in Manhattan.

headline: Fed Names New Chief for Monetary Affairs
text: The Federal Reserve Board on Monday named William B. English as director of its division of monetary affairs, one of the most powerful staff positions at the central bank.

headline: ‘Jersey Boys’ File Suit Against ‘The Boys’
text: Oh, what a headache: the producers of “Jersey Boys” have filed suit against the producers of a touring show called “The Boys in Concert,” saying that it is trying to confuse audiences into thinking the two musicals are related, Reuters reported. “Jersey Boys,” which tells the story of Frankie Valli and his rock group, the Four Seasons, has remained a popular and lucrative show since it opened on Broadway in 2005 (and won the Tony Award for best musical), spawning several regional productions and a national tour. “The Boys in Concert,” whose cast and creators include the “Jersey Boys” alumni Christian Hoff, Michael Longoria and Daniel Reichard, features the music of several pop acts of the 1960s and 70s, including the Four Seasons. The lawsuit, which The New York Post reported was filed by Mr. Valli, as well as his band mate Bob Gaudio and the playwrights Marshall Brickman and Rick Elice, says that “The Boys in Concert” copies many elements of “Jersey Boys” and that its promotional materials represent “a deliberate and willful attempt to create public confusion and foster the misimpression” that the shows are “associated or connected.” The “Jersey Boys” producers are seeking damages and an injunction against performances of “The Boys in Concert” that use copyrighted or similar materials. Representatives for “The Boys in Concert” did not immediately respond to Reuters or The Post.

headline: An Amen From the Press Box
text: The back end of Augusta National’s challenging Amen Corner proved to be a propitious place for the Masters champion Phil Mickelson last weekend. His eagle on No. 13 on Saturday was the first of consecutive eagles that vaulted him into contention. And on Sunday, after driving into the pine needles to the right of the fairway on the par-5 510-yard hole, he opted not to lay up, but instead gambled on threading the needle between the trees. The ball landing a few feet from the hole. Though he missed the eagle, his subsequent birdie set him firmly on the path to his third Masters title.

headline: Governors Island Vision Adds Hills and Hammocks
text: When the federal government sold Governors Island to the City and State of New York for one dollar in January 2003, it wasn’t clear who had gotten the short end of the stick.

headline: Reports That Palm Is to Be Sold Lift Its Stock
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Last year Palm, a pioneering maker of hand-held devices that was lagging far behind its competitors in the phone market, bet its future on a slick new smartphone called the Pre.

headline: ‘Versed’ by Rae Armantrout: California Poet, National Recognition
text: Rae Armantrout has won the 2010 Pulitzer Prize for poetry for “Versed,” her 10th collection.

headline: Artful Way to Expand a Museum
text: To expand downtown or not to expand downtown, this is the nagging, seemingly unanswerable question facing the Whitney Museum of American Art. The museum won’t know the right answer for sure until it tries it; if it doesn’t, it will never know. But it is right in asserting that it must do something to remain viable in what has become a cutthroat competition for museum visitors in New York.

headline: Judge Sees No Progress on Ground Zero Settlement
text: The federal judge who rejected a settlement last month of lawsuits filed by rescue and cleanup workers at ground zero said on Monday at a hearing that no progress appeared to have been made in renegotiating the accord.

headline: Prokhorov Group Denies Links to Sanctioned Firms in Zimbabwe
text: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, who is close to being approved by the N.B.A. as the majority owner of the New Jersey Nets, denied a New York Post article published Sunday that said that his company might be in violation of economic sanctions imposed on Zimbabwe.

headline: Unshaven Women: Free Spirits or Unkempt?
text: SOME grooming choices are so brazen that not even an A-lister can make them palatable.

headline: Social Skills and Animals (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Loss of a Loved One (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Navigating a Course Among 4 Composers
text: The Henschel Quartet, from Germany, made news last month when it performed for Pope Benedict XVI at his residence in Vatican City. Since then it has returned to more conventional concert spaces, though on Sunday afternoon the quartet turned up at a bona fide New York mansion, the Frick Collection, for a demanding, stylistically varied program. Its musicians performed early-20th-century scores by Erwin Schulhoff and Samuel Barber, and standard repertory works by Haydn and Schumann.

headline: Studying Expressions (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Schumann Songs, Uncut, on the Lovesick Man
text: It is unclear why four songs from Schumann’s “Dichterliebe” (“A Poet’s Love”) ended up on the cutting-room floor, but according to the baritone Thomas Hampson, Schumann was not the one wielding the knife.

headline: Quantifying Quality Time (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Gluten-Free Diet (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Philly’s Newspapers Are on a Hitting Streak
text: Last week, the current ownership of the newspapers in Philadelphia won an improbable series of legal victories at the Third Circuit in an effort to keep the properties out of the hands of the lenders, and then today, The Philadelphia Daily News, the underdog newspaper owned by an underdog owner in an underdog market, won a Pulitzer for investigative reporting. (The New York Times also won a Pulitzer for investigative reporting, in conjunction with ProPublica, for a magazine article by a freelancer, Sheri Fink, about the after-effects of Hurricane Katrina on a hospital in New Orleans.)

headline: An All-Day Concert, but Only One Piece Was Performed
text: Morton Feldman’s String Quartet No. 2 is hardly standard fare for a housewarming. Composed in 1983, the work runs more than six hours when played complete. But somehow it seemed ideally suited for the first public event mounted by Issue Project Room, a vital avant-garde performing arts presenter, in its future home at 110 Livingston Street in downtown Brooklyn on Sunday. A string quartet drawn from the fine new-music ensemble Ne(x)tworks did the honors.

headline: Philips Changes Policy on Fitness Monitor
text: In December, I reviewed the Philips DirectLife — a tiny, plastic, waterproof/crushproof motion sensor. You wear it around your neck or in your pocket, and it tracks your physical activity over the days, weeks and months. In conjunction with a human coach who studies your uploaded data, the device is supposed to encourage you to be more active and become healthier.

headline: Tribune Files Bankruptcy Plan; Lenders Protest
text: The Tribune Company filed its bankruptcy reorganization plan on Monday, setting the newspaper publisher up for a showdown with a large group of lenders that called the terms unfair and demanded the right to propose a rival plan, Reuters reports.

headline: Europe Urged to Share Power Across Continent
text: BRUSSELS — Renewable energy in Europe should be generated and distributed on a continental scale to make the greatest contribution toward reducing greenhouse gases, according to a report that raises significant challenges for a fragmented region.

headline: Why Do Educated People Use Bad Words?
text: California state legislators have long pushed self-improvement schemes on their constituents. Remember the “State Task Force to Promote Self-Esteem” (1986)? The latest such effort was a “Cuss Free Week” designated last month aimed at reducing profanity in public places.

headline: Hedge Funds Get $16.6 Billion in New Money
text: Hedge funds took in $16.6 billion in new money in February as pension funds and wealthy investors raced to capture a piece of the industry’s recent strong returns, Reuters reports, citing data released on Monday.

headline: A German Riesling That Embodies Spring
text: WITH so many grapes grown in so many places around the world, even experts may be forgiven for mistaking, say, a South African sauvignon blanc for a Chilean sauvignon blanc. But a good German riesling from the Mosel region is like no other riesling in the world. It is simply one of wine’s singular glories.

headline: Kuwait Deports Critics of Egyptian President
text: 17 Egyptian residents of Kuwait were deported last week for a meeting to discuss political change in Egypt, where Mohamed ElBaradei, the former head of the International Atomic Energy Agency, has emerged as a potential presidential candidate.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'The Breakfast Club'
text: A.O. Scott revisits John Hughes's ode to adolescence.

headline: Lions Gate Urges Shareholders to Reject Icahn’s Bid
text: Lions Gate Entertainment appealed directly to shareholders on Monday to thwart a hostile takeover attempt by the billionaire activist investor Carl C. Icahn that it calls ”inadequate, opportunistic and coercive,” The Associated Press reports.

headline: Senators End Impasse on Extending Unemployment Benefits
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Monday agreed to consider a temporary extension of unemployment benefits after four Republicans joined Democrats in voting to debate the proposal, which has become the focus of an intensifying fight over deficit spending.

headline: Kabinett Rieslings
text: I’ve always wanted to go to Michigan. Seriously. It’s one of six states I’ve never been to (since you insist, the others are South Carolina, North Dakota, Nebraska, Iowa and Hawaii). But, most important, Michigan has what I imagine to be a thriving wine country.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Breakfast Club’
text: This week in Critics’ Picks, A. O. Scott looks at the 1985 film “The Breakfast Club,” an exploration of suburban teen angst — and detention — directed by John Hughes, who died last year.

headline: ‘Beatrice and Virgil’
text: (Virgil and Beatrice are sitting at the foot of the tree. They are looking out blankly. Silence.)

headline: That Corporate Jet Sometimes Makes Sense
text: AFTER two years, “business jet” no longer sounded disreputable.

headline: Bootlegging in Tribal Pakistan
text: In Pakistan's tribal areas, alcohol bootleggers, lured by enormous profits, have created clandestine delivery services to evade recent crackdowns by the Taliban and the police.

headline: Where Professors Make the Most
text: The average salary of a full-time faculty member rose 1.2 percent over the last year. That is the smallest increase professors have received in at least 50 years, according to the latest annual study from the American Association of University Professors.

headline: Bootlegging, Pakistan-Style
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Even the threat of death cannot deter one 30-year-old entrepreneur here from his appointed rounds supplying the Pakistani elite with expensive contraband Scotch.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,381 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,026 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

headline: Italian Judge Cites Profit as Justifying a Google Conviction
text: ROME — An Italian judge convicted three Google employees in February of violating privacy laws because the Internet company had sought to profit from a video of an autistic boy being bullied by classmates, according to a judicial reasoning in the case released on Monday.

headline: Vatican Publishes Procedures for Sex Abuse Cases
text: ROME — Fending off accusations that it covered up abuse and obstructed justice, the Vatican on Monday spelled out for the first time that it now strongly urges bishops to report abuse cases to civil authorities if required by local law.

headline: Jets Say Rewards Outweigh Risks With Holmes
text: Jets General Manager Mike Tannenbaum said Monday he understood the risks of making receiver Santonio Holmes part of the off-season makeover, one that already added a player of questionable character, cornerback Antonio Cromartie. But when he discovered Holmes could be had from the Pittsburgh Steelers for a fifth-round draft pick, Tannenbaum said the upside of adding a dynamic, potentially game-changing 26-year-old receiver made those risks palatable.

headline: Baffled by Health Plan? So Are Some Lawmakers
text: WASHINGTON — It is often said that the new health care law will affect almost every American in some way. And, perhaps fittingly if unintentionally, no one may be more affected than members of Congress themselves.

headline: Naming a New Chief, MasterCard Signals It Is Open to Changes
text: MasterCard named a onetime star at Citigroup as its next chief executive on Monday, a widely expected move that could nonetheless shake up the giant payment company. The appointment of the executive, Ajay Banga, is to take effect on July 1, the company said. MasterCard hired Mr. Banga as president and chief operating officer last August and signaled early that he would succeed Robert W. Selander, who has held the top job since 1997.

headline: French and German Ties Fray Over Greek Crisis
text: PARIS — France and Germany traditionally have been the “motor” of the European Union, but relations between the two countries are badly strained over the Greek debt crisis, which is just the latest example of a new German willingness to resist the demands of Europe and assert its self-interest under Chancellor Angela Merkel.

headline: Thrilling Rounds Whet Appetites for Rematch Between Mickelson and Woods
text: AUGUSTA, Ga.

headline: Footage of Chinatown Fire
text: A resident captured the seven-alarm fire in Chinatown. (Courtesy of Adam Levy)

headline: Kazakhstan to Permit Military Overflights to Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON — Kazakhstan has agreed to let the United States fly troops and weapons over its territory, a deal that opens a direct and faster route over the North Pole for American forces and lethal equipment headed to Afghanistan.

headline: Before City’s Worst Fire in Years, History of Neglect
text: The building in Chinatown where an enormous blaze started late Sunday night had more than two dozen open violations for hazardous conditions, including missing smoke detectors, lead paint and other problems that signified a history of neglect, city records show.

headline: Gathering to Watch Their City’s Star Turn
text: NEW ORLEANS — In the family center of the Charbonnet-Labat-Glapion Funeral Home on St. Philip Street, the local historic neighborhood association came together for a meeting on Sunday night. After a few mentions of “beautification issues,” they got down to the matter at hand: in a few minutes’ time, the city’s Tremé neighborhood, unknown to most and mispronounced by many, was about to become very, very famous.

headline: 4 Pulitzers for Washington Post; 3 for The Times
text: The Washington Post won four Pulitzer Prizes on Monday for its work in 2009, and The New York Times won three, while ProPublica became the first of the new breed of online, nonprofit news organizations to win the most prestigious award in print journalism.

headline: Rangers’ Top Need? An Identity
text: On Tuesday, the Rangers will assemble at their practice rink one last time before breaking up for the summer and yet another rebuilding job. They missed the playoffs because of a single shot in the season-ending shootout Sunday in Philadelphia, but there are no illusions. If they are to be considered contenders in 2010-11, their off-season to-do list will have to be a long one.

headline: O’Brien Will Move to TBS
text: EUGENE, Ore. — In a move that has shocked much of the television world, Conan O’Brien will make his comeback on a cable — not a network — channel.

headline: Democrats Push to Require Campaign Disclosure
text: WASHINGTON — The White House and leading Democrats in Congress are close to proposing legislation that would force private companies and groups to disclose their behind-the-scenes financial involvement in political campaigns and advertising, officials involved in the discussions said Monday.

headline: What We’re Reading: Technology to Help Journalism
text: Considering how distracted the New York Times tech reporters and editors were today, they did a fair amount of Web searching for other worthwhile news. Monday’s reading list includes:

headline: Their Children’s Children, as Holocaust Witnesses
text: Toby Edelstein, 9 years old, stood Sunday evening before a synagogue audience of about 350 to talk about his grandmother. The details were few, but they were enough.

headline: Old Ads That Won’t Die or Fade Away
text: MADISON AVENUE is coming up with a digital variation on an Irving Berlin standard: The campaign has ended, but the advertising lingers on.

headline: Trump and Bondholders Gain Control of Casinos
text: Donald J. Trump is hoping the third time will be the charm.

headline: Imagine the Bailouts Are Working
text: What if, after all that panting over Washington’s bailout of the financial system, we learned that it actually worked?

headline: Does Reason Know What It Is Missing?
text: The German philosopher Jürgen Habermas has long been recognized as the most persistent and influential defender of an Enlightenment rationality that has been attacked both by postmodernism, which derides formal reason’s claims of internal coherence and neutrality, and by various fundamentalisms, which subordinate reason to religious imperatives that sweep everything before them, often not stopping at violence.

headline: In Canadian Case, Filings Say Toyota Knew of Risk
text: OTTAWA — Documents filed in a Canadian civil case against Toyota complaining of accelerator problems with a Lexus sedan show that the company viewed the problems as a serious threat to its reputation, even as officials publicly played down their importance.

headline: In a Diplomatic Limbo While Waiting to Adopt
text: Randy Wills received the long-awaited call from his adoption agency last Thursday: a 10-month-old girl from eastern Russia was available for adoption. He and his wife, Magdalena Kleczkowski Wills, who live in Southington, Conn., could plan to travel to Russia in two weeks.

headline: Behind the Curtain, Cuomo Runs His P.R. Machine
text: ALBANY — Press conferences called by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo have a “Wizard of Oz” feel: They are routinely done by conference call, with Mr. Cuomo remaining invisible, a booming authoritative voice sticking carefully to his chosen subject.

headline: Apple Places New Limits on App Developers
text: Apple is tightening its already firm grip on what software can run on the iPhone and its other mobile devices, as shown by its recent changes to the rules that outside programmers must follow.

headline: Sun Shines on Twins in Their New Ballpark
text: MINNEAPOLIS — The Minnesota Twins take pride in details. From the minor leagues on up, they implore their players to execute fundamentals. For a team that for years had one of baseball’s lowest payrolls, and was nearly contracted out of existence, the approach was a matter of survival.

headline: Bloggingheads: Christians With Guns
text: Anthea Butler, left, of the University of Pennsylvania and Michelle Goldberg of The American Prospect discuss Christian militias.

headline: Lehman Channeled Risks Through ‘Alter Ego’ Firm
text: It was like a hidden passage on Wall Street, a secret channel that enabled billions of dollars to flow through Lehman Brothers.

headline: A Sailor First Ventures to Motherhood at Age 73
text: One friend told her she was too old to raise a child. Another promised it would keep her young.

headline: Political Graffiti
text: Government-financed brigades of graffiti artists and muralists are blanketing the walls of Caracas, Venezuela, with politicized images, ranging from crude, semi-anonymous graffiti tags to bold, colorful works.

headline: Child in Adoption Case Is an American Citizen, Not Russian, Experts Say
text: Russian officials and the sheriff in Shelbyville, Tenn., have both raised questions about whether the 7-year-old boy sent back to Moscow by his adoptive mother and grandmother last week is really a United States citizen.

headline: Win a Meeting With the President
text: WASHINGTON — For President Obama, the first three days of this week are the diplomatic equivalent of speed dating. Every few minutes, it seems, another foreign leader is escorted into the room. They sit, they talk, they pledge mutual cooperation. And then it is on to the next one.

headline: A Campaign Shows Signs of Progress Against Polio
text: JOHANNESBURG — A decade after the world’s original deadline for eradicating polio, the most tenacious bastions of the crippling virus — Nigeria and India — have recently shown remarkable progress in halting its spread, giving even some of the antipolio campaign’s severest doubters hope that it may yet largely achieve its goal.

headline: On Call When the Paint Chips Are Down
text: While Paul Mutimear arrived in New York from London in 1987 with dreams of rock ’n’ roll fame, these days he makes his living helping people decide between Drop Dead Gorgeous and Bed of Roses (both shades of red). Mr. Mutimear, 59, has been a paint guru for 23 years, first as a contractor specializing in decorative finishes for clients including Bobby Flay. For the last three years, he has worked as a senior color consultant for the Janovic home-design chain, most recently at the store at 888 Lexington Avenue on the Upper East Side, offering advice to high-strung customers choosing colors for their apartments.

headline: Yankees’ Moment to Cherish
text: Before he takes the mound to pitch the Yankees’ home opener against the Los Angeles Angels on Tuesday, Andy Pettitte will be handed a World Series championship ring, his fifth. He will feel the joy of achievement that comes with ceremonial ritual. He will take a moment to admire the jewelry. Then the ring will go back in the box on its way to enshrinement at his family home in Houston.

headline: Deaths Draw Attention to Dangers of Oil Tanks
text: CARNES, Miss. — When an oil tank exploded on a neighboring property early on the morning of Halloween last year, Phillip White immediately raced through his house, checking on his family’s safety. But he could not find his 18-year-old son, Wade.

headline: SUNY to Focus on Revitalizing the State
text: The State University of New York wants to expand its online offerings and capitalize on changes in health care and education over the next five years in an effort to turn the system into an economic engine for the state, according to a strategic plan to be unveiled on Tuesday by its chancellor, Nancy L. Zimpher.

headline: Classic Miles
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Do you suppose Alex Boisvert loves music? We’ve got Jimi Hendrix, Natalie Cole, Britney Spears, Sade and, of course, Miles Davis to supply the hint that ties the theme answers together and has us singing the blues.

headline: D-League Attendance Tops 1 Million
text: Below the radar, the N.B.A.’s Development League has gone from an underdeveloped asset to a key tool for N.B.A. franchises.

headline: Somali Man Accused in ’09 Piracy May Plead Guilty
text: A Somali man who was accused of piracy last year in the hijacking of an American-flagged cargo ship off Somalia appears to be in negotiations to plead guilty, according to a government letter filed on Monday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Memos Show Risky Lending at WaMu
text: WASHINGTON — New documents released by a Senate panel show how entrenched Washington Mutual was in fraudulent and risky lending, and highlighted how its top executives received rewards as their institution was hurtling toward disaster.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 12, 2010

headline: Six Games In, and the Spotlight Is on the Mets’ Manuel
text: DENVER — It was in this city nestled, appropriately enough, in the Rocky Mountains, that Bobby Valentine, then the manager of the Mets, had an epic, emotional outburst in his office at the end of a 12-game losing streak in a deteriorating 2002 season.

headline: On a Magazine’s List of the City’s ‘Most Livable Neighborhoods,’ a Few Surprises
text: Ah, Greenpoint, Brooklyn. A neighborhood at once blessed and cursed.

headline: Appeals Court Nominee Ignites a Partisan Battle
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama nominated Goodwin Liu to be an appeals court judge earlier this year, some on the left cheered. Mr. Obama had previously picked a succession of nominees who they believed were too centrist to counter the conservatives appointed during the Bush administration, they said, but finally he had selected a liberal legal rock star.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on the Personal Tech pages on Thursday about Micro Four-Thirds cameras misstated the genesis of the name of the camera standard. Four Thirds refers to the size of the image sensor measured diagonally (4/3-inch, in a sizing system derived from video camera tubes, now obsolete). The name does not stem from the 4:3 aspect ratio of the sensor.

headline: Nets Are Looking Ahead to a Fresh Start in a New Home
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Larry Brown coached the Nets’ first N.B.A. game here, long before it was named Izod Center and long before it was named Continental Airlines Arena.

headline: Sudan: Voting Period Is Extended After Problems
text: Election authorities extended voting on Monday to five days from three after election observers complained that polling stations were unprepared for the nation’s first national multiparty vote in more than two decades. Voting started Sunday.

headline: United Arab Emirates: 2 Convicted in Chechen’s Killing
text: A Dubai court convicted two men for their roles in the assassination of a former Chechen general and sentenced both to 25 years in prison. The men were accused of aiding and abetting in the murder of Sulim B. Yamadayev, who was shot dead in the garage of an apartment complex in Dubai with a Russian-made handgun in 2009. They were identified as Mahsoudjan Asmanov of Tajikistan and Mahdi Tagi Dhurnia of Iran. Mr. Yamadayev, a former Chechen general who had fallen out of favor with Chechnya’s Kremlin-backed president, Ramzan Kadyrov, had been living in Dubai under an assumed name. The Dubai police have accused four other suspects, including Adam Delimkhanov, an adviser to Mr. Kadyrov, who they say organized the killing.

headline: Garden Says Farewell to the Knicks’ Impending Free Agents
text: All goodbyes are not created equal. Some are more meaningful than others, and for suffering Knicks fans, none was more poignant than the one they delivered Monday night.

headline: Hungary: New Leader Assails Far-Right Party’s Rise
text: The incoming prime minister, Viktor Orban, left, vowed Monday to defend Hungary from the ascent of a far-right party and its black-clad paramilitary branch, which have railed against the Roma community and called the capital “Jewdapest.” Mr. Orban, 46, the leader of Fidesz, the party that defeated the incumbent Socialists in first-round parliamentary elections on Sunday, said he was unhappy over the rise of the far-right party, Jobbik, which won 16.7 percent of the vote. “No radical party will be allowed to get rid of law and order in this country,” he said. “Democracy in this country is strong enough to defend itself.”

headline: Mayor Bloomberg’s Island
text: Unable to carry its share of the costs, the New York State government has ceded responsibility for revitalizing Governors Island to New York City  which is exactly where the responsibility belongs.

headline: ‘A Different Creature’
text: Nancy Pelosi, at lunch, was making the point that this latest recession was not a typical cyclical downturn.

headline: What We Learned From H1N1’s First Year
text: Richmond, Va.

headline: Arts School in Harlem
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Changing Face of the Court
text: To the Editor:

headline: Updating Internet Privacy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tomorrow’s Menu at School
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Wrong Way and a Right Way
text: While Congress was on spring break the past two weeks, federal unemployment benefits expired for an estimated 200,000 jobless Americans. Each day, another 30,000 join the ranks of those who are both out of work and out of benefits. It did not have to come to this.

headline: Politics 1, Rule of Law 0
text: The struggle between President Obama and Republicans on Capitol Hill has claimed a fresh victim  Dawn Johnsen. She was Mr. Obama’s choice to lead the Office of Legal Counsel at the Justice Department. Ms. Johnsen withdrew her nomination after more than a year. It was clear that the White House was not going to fight to save her from Republicans who were refusing to allow a vote on her confirmation.

headline: Palestinian Tactics, Through a Historical Lens
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gao Zhisheng, Hu Jia, Liu Xiaobo
text: Washington and Beijing are, rightly, eager to lower tensions. After President Obama met President Hu Jintao of China at the White House on Monday, officials said they had agreed to work together to come up with new sanctions on Iran. That is good news.

headline: History Is Hardly on Greece’s Side
text: The International Monetary Fund is back at the peak of its power and relevance. But with Greece it has taken on a novel challenge: helping to repair a sovereign government’s finances with neither a default nor a currency devaluation. No bailout in modern history has managed such a feat.

headline: Massachusetts: Setback for Health Insurers
text: Gov. Deval L. Patrick won the first round Monday in a legal dispute with health insurers over the state’s recent rejection of rate increases requested by the companies. Ruling in a lawsuit brought by the companies, Judge Stephen E. Neel of Suffolk Superior Court in Boston said he would not block the state from denying the increases because the insurers had not exhausted their right to appeal administratively. Mr. Patrick’s insurance commissioner announced on April 1 that the state was rejecting 235 of 274 requested increases as excessive. Some were as high as 34 percent.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about the demographics of the audience for “The Tonight Show” on NBC after Jay Leno’s return misstated the median age of Jon Stewart’s audience on the Comedy Central channel. It is 40, not 49.

headline: Leno’s Longtime Music Director Moves On
text: Kevin Eubanks, the music director for “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno,” has confirmed that he will be leaving the show after 18 years. The decision was announced during the taping of Monday night’s show.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about an increase in spending by well-off consumers misstated the surname of a pilot with XOJet, a jet-leasing company in San Francisco. He is David Kinser, not Kinsner.

headline: Corrections
text: Schedule information on Wednesday with a theater review about “Bellona, Destroyer of Cities” misidentified the Web site of the Kitchen, the Chelsea performance space where the play was staged. It is thekitchen.org  not kitchen.org, a Web site guide to kitchen and bath remodelers.

headline: Last Place? Mets Have Been There, Done That
text: It is early in the 2010 season, but for the Mets, of course, it may already be too late. To no great surprise, they have staggered through their first seven games and find themselves in last place in the National League East as they proceed through what could be a disastrous six-game trip to Colorado and St. Louis.

headline: Anna Walentynowicz, Polish Provocateur Who Spurred Communism’s Fall, Dies at 80
text: Anna Walentynowicz, a labor leader whose firing as a crane operator at the Lenin shipyard in Gdansk in 1980 touched off the strike that led to the founding of Solidarity and the unraveling of Communism in Poland, died on Saturday in the plane crash in Russia in which Poland’s president and dozens of Polish leaders were killed. She was 80.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on April 3 about the actor John Forsythe, using information provided by a family spokesman, referred incorrectly to Mr. Forsythe’s marital history. His marriage to Parker McCormick lasted from 1939 to 1943, not from 1938 to 1940, and he married Julie Warren the year they divorced, not three years later.

headline: Andrew Stern, Head of S.E.I.U., Plans to Step Down
text: Andy Stern, president of the politically potent  Service Employees International Union, has told colleagues he plans to step down, two members of his union’s board said Monday.

headline: Bill Would Allow Layoffs of Teachers With Seniority
text: When the Bloomberg administration raised the prospect of teacher layoffs this year, administration officials complained that they would be forced to get rid of the youngest newest teachers, and called on legislators to rewrite the seniority rules.

headline: Corrections
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Different Takes on Top Defenders
text: Ballots are due this week for the N.B.A.’s postseason awards. Although The New York Times does not permit its reporters to vote, the N.B.A. reporters Howard Beck and Jonathan Abrams are making their picks in Off the Dribble.

headline: Jeffrey Katzenberg Goes to NAB to Talk 3-D
text: The NAB Show — the annual National Association of Broadcasters convention — has unexpectedly become the next 3-D battleground for the movie business.

headline: Gates Foundation Stops Grant to Canadian Research Center
text: The Gates Foundation has withdrawn a $5.2 million grant to a Canadian research center for planned tobacco control work in Africa, after learning that the chairwoman of the center’s board was also a board member for a unit of one of the world’s largest tobacco companies.

headline: Leg Lost, Dancer Is Caught Between Caregivers
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Fabienne Jean, a professional dancer who lost her right leg in the earthquake, hopped on her slim left leg through the dusty General Hospital compound on her way to a very important X-ray.

headline: Son of Former Congressman Enters Race to Take Rangel’s House Seat
text: Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV announced on Monday that he would challenge Representative Charles B. Rangel in the Democratic primary in the fall, setting the stage for an intensely personal rematch between two of Harlem’s biggest political names and oldest foes.

headline: Man Is Sentenced in Sex Abuse Case
text: A Brooklyn man convicted of molesting a 16-year-old boy was sentenced on Monday to up to 32 years in prison, the maximum, for sexual abuse.

headline: 3,500 at St. Vincent’s Get Termination Notices
text: St. Vincent’s Hospital handed out termination notices on Monday to all 3,500 of its employees, further sealing the fate of New York City’s last Catholic general hospital.

headline: Defense in Hate Crime Trial Says Killing Was Unintended
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — In his closing argument, the lawyer for the Long Island teenager accused of fatally stabbing an Ecuadorean immigrant struck two themes seemingly at odds with each other — that the teenager was innocent, but that even if he were guilty, he did not intend to kill or seriously hurt anyone.

headline: Racist E-Mail Tied to Candidate for Governor
text: ALBANY — Carl P. Paladino, a Republican candidate for governor from Buffalo, drew fire on Monday for racist and sexually explicit e-mail messages that a left-leaning Web site claimed he had sent to friends and business associates in recent years.

headline: Twitter Unveils Plans to Draw Money From Ads
text: Twitter will unveil on Tuesday a much-anticipated plan for making money from advertising, finally answering the question of how the company expects to turn its exponential growth into revenue.

headline: George Nissen, Father of the Trampoline, Dies at 96
text: One by one, the trapeze artists topped off their routines by dropping from their high-swinging bars into the net stretched below, then rebounding into somersaults — to the roar of the crowd at the traveling circus in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. And one kid in the stands began to wonder: Hey, what if there was a contraption that made it possible to keep on bouncing and flipping?

headline: Wal-Mart Farms in India
text: Wal-Mart is trying to establish an agricultural beachhead in India as part of its global growth strategy.

headline: Word of the Day | austere
text: austere •\ȯ-ˈstir also -ˈster\• adjective

headline: Crunching the Numbers From the Masters
text: One of the more memorable moments from Phil Mickelson’s victorious final round in the Masters on Sunday also provided a prime example of how Mickelson and many of the other leading finishers navigated Augusta National.

headline: News Quiz | April 13, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Twitter Unveils Plans to Draw Money From Ads
text: Twitter will unveil on Tuesday a much-anticipated plan for making money from advertising, finally answering the question of how the company expects to turn its exponential growth into revenue, Claire Cain Miller reports in The New York Times.

headline: Imagine the Bailouts Are Working
text: Every couple of months the Treasury Department takes a moment to strategically leak some good news about the bailouts. It happened again on Monday, when a Treasury official told The Wall Street Journal that America’s coffers would be only $89 billion lighter after all accounts were settled from the rescues, down from an earlier estimate of $250 billion.

headline: Common Sense About the Web
text: WHAT was the “first wave of parental anxiety” about the Internet focused on? WHAT, according to this article, do parents fear now?

headline: Lehman Channeled Risks Through ‘Alter Ego’ Firm
text: It was like a hidden passage on Wall Street, a secret channel that enabled billions of dollars to flow through Lehman Brothers, Louise Story and Eric Dash write in The New York Times.

headline: Brazilian Rancher Convicted in Murder of Catholic Nun
text: A jury in the Brazilian city of Belém has sentenced a rancher to 30 years in prison in a retrial for the murder of an American-born nun, news agencies reported.

headline: Woods Raises Ratings
text: Tiger Woods’s return to competitive golf helped CBS’s fourth-round Masters rating rise substantially over last year, but it did not set a record. The 12.0 preliminary overnight rating for Phil Mickelson’s victory represented a 46 percent increase from an 8.2 last year, when Ángel Cabrera won. By comparison, the highest rating for a final round at the Masters was 15.8 in 1997, when Woods won his first green jacket.

headline: UBS’s U.S. Brokerage Unit Still Losing Assets
text: Six months after Merrill Lynch veteran Bob McCann came on board to revive the United States wealth management business of UBS, the Swiss bank’s investors were reminded that a full recovery is still a ways away, Reuters reported.

headline: Deposed Kyrgyz Leader Offers Deal to Step Down
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan — The deposed president of Kyrgyzstan said Tuesday that he would formally step down if there were guarantees of safety for him and his family, speaking after the interim government that took power after bloody riots last week stripped him of immunity and threatened to send special forces to arrest him.

headline: Sticking With UBS
text: UBS’s worst days may be behind it, Reuters Breakingviews says. The Swiss bank said on Monday that it expected to make a pretax quarterly profit of at least 2.5 billion Swiss francs ($2.3 billion). With two profitable quarters under its belt, the turnaround appears to be under way.

headline: Conan O’Brien Back On Stage, but Away From TV
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Conan O’Brien thrilled a sellout crowd of frenzied fans here Monday night, putting on a two-hour,  highly energized show that referred at several points to his widely publicized departure from NBC and reached back to many of his best-loved moments from his days with the network.

headline: Israeli Troops Kill 2 Militants in Gaza
text: GAZA — At least two Palestinian militants were killed and two others were wounded Tuesday when Israeli troops shot at them as they tried to plant explosives near the border, according to an Israeli military spokesman in Tel Aviv and Palestinians in Gaza.

headline: How Much Do You Curse? Why?
text: The Room for Debate blog asks a similar question, “Why do educated people use bad words?”, that was inspired by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s overheard use of an expletive during the signing of the health care bill. Do you think people’s attitudes have changed about what is socially acceptable language? Has the Web made it easier to curse? How much do you, personally, use “bad words”? When, where, and why do you use them? What is your reaction when others curse?

headline: The Insider | Rachel Comey
text: The Insider is a recurring profile of tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Rachel Comey is a downtown New York designer whose namesake brand includes a women’s collection of clothing, shoes and accessories as well as a men’s collection of shoes and accessories. Comey moved to New York to pursue life as an artist, and her collaboration with the band Gogol Bordello garnered her and the group a place in the 2001 Whitney Biennial. She started her clothing collection, inspired by the New York music scene, shortly thereafter and has developed a loyal following. She recently introduced an e-commerce site for her coveted men’s shoes.

headline: New Chief at MasterCard Signals It’s Open to Change
text: MasterCard named a onetime star at Citigroup as its next chief executive on Monday, a widely expected move that could nonetheless shake up the giant payment company, The New York Times’s Andrew Martin and Eric Dash reported.

headline: Tencent to Invest $300 Million in Facebook Backer
text: Tencent Holdings, China’s leading Internet provider, said Monday that it was investing about  $300 million in Digital Sky Technologies, the Russian Internet holding company that acquired a stake in Facebook last year.

headline: Greece Sells $1.6 Billion in Debt Sale
text: Greece raised 1.2 billion euros ($1.6 billion) in a heavily oversubscribed auction for 26- and 52-week government bonds Tuesday, the first debt sale since details were announced of a euro-zone and International Monetary Fund rescue package over the weekend, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Dow Finishes Above 11,000
text: A few little points was all it took.

headline: Philly’s Newspapers Are on a Hitting Streak
text: From David Carr at Media Decoder:

headline: British Prime Minister Wants Tougher Takeover Rules
text: Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain proposed changes to the country’s takeover rules on Monday that could make it more difficult to acquire British companies.

headline: Apple Places New Limits on App Developers
text: Apple is tightening its already firm grip on what software can run on the iPhone and its other mobile devices, as shown by its recent changes to the rules that outside programmers must follow, The New York Times’s Jenna Wortham reported.

headline: Red Cross Staff Kidnapped in Congo
text: PARIS — The International Committee of the Red Cross said Tuesday that an “armed group” had kidnapped eight of its staff members in the South Kivu region of the Democratic Republic of Congo.

headline: A Hedge Fund Show Tune
text: From Catherine Rampell at Economix:

headline: White House Still Fighting for Financial Overhaul
text: The Obama administration vowed Monday to push for even tougher financial regulation, as legislation heads for the Senate floor as soon as next week, Reuters reported.

headline: Trump Beats Out Icahn for Control of Casinos
text: Donald J. Trump is hoping the third time will be the charm.

headline: GMAC Sells European Mortgage Arm to Fortress
text: GMAC, the bailed-out former financial service arm of General Motors, said Monday that it had sold its residential mortgage operations in Europe to the American hedge fund and private equity group, Fortress Investment.

headline: A Bidding War for Arsenal?
text: One of Arsenal Football Club’s biggest shareholders decided to sell her stake in the English Premier League club on Monday, raising the possibility of a takeover bid for the north London team, Reuters reported.

headline: The Styles of Grace at London’s V&A
text: At a time when it can be difficult to find that rare quality known as class, it is refreshing to see Grace Kelly back in the limelight. The late actress and her inimitable fashion sense are the focus of “Grace Kelly: Style Icon,” an exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum (Cromwell Road; 44-20-7942-2000; vam.ac.uk; free admission) through Sept. 26.

headline: Creditors to Respond to Dubai World Debt Talks
text: Creditors of state-owned Dubai World will give their response to the indebted conglomerate’s debt restructuring proposal within weeks, one of its main lenders said Monday.

headline: Obama Vows Fresh Proliferation Push as Summit Ends
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama completed a first meeting of world leaders on combating nuclear terrorism with a list of specific commitments from dozens of nations to eliminate or lock down nuclear materials, in what he called a “bold and pragmatic” program to finish the task in the next four years.

headline: Iceland Investigators Issue Scathing Report on Banks
text: A former prime minister and central bank head and five other former officials acted with “gross negligence” in failing to prevent Iceland’s banking collapse in 2008, an official investigation found Monday, Reuters reported.

headline: Should the N.F.L. Suspend Roethlisberger?
text: Commissioner Roger Goodell has wide latitude in punishing players under the personal conduct policy.

headline: ‘Virus’ as the New ‘Axis of Evil’
text: Today’s idea: Venezuela, Iran and Russia together pose a serious threat to American objectives worldwide, a foreign affairs scholar writes, dubbing the combined peril the “Virus.”

headline: Pimco Shuns Greek Debt Offerings
text: The Pacific Investment Management Company will not be buying new Greek debt, as it believes a euro-zone rescue package fails to tackle the country’s longer-term solvency challenges, the chief executive of the bond fund told Reuters.

headline: Lowe’s Prices $1 Billion of Debt
text: Lowe’s Companies said Monday that it will sell $1 billion of debt in two parts and will use slightly more than half of the net proceeds to pay off notes coming due in June, Reuters reported.

headline: F.D.I.C. Chief Says Banker Pay Can Still Pose Risk
text: Sheila C. Bair defended the move by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to clamp down on excessive banker pay on Monday, saying the stability of the financial system was at stake, Reuters reported.

headline: Short Sales Fall at N.Y.S.E., but Rise at Nasdaq
text: Short sales  on the New York Stock Exchange declined at the end of March, while those same positions rose on the  Nasdaq in the same period, Reuters reported.

headline: Halliburton Strikes Deal for Boots & Coots
text: Halliburton has agreed to buy the oilfield services company Boots & Coots for $240.4 million, or $3 a share, in cash and stock, The Associated Press reported.

headline: A Twitter Guide to the N.F.L. Draft
text: Sigmund Bloom, Cecil Lammey and Matt Waldman of Draftguys.com will help preview and analyze the draft for the Fifth Down. Bloom and Lammey host the always informative podcast at FootballGuys.com, and Waldman writes the  Rookie Scouting Portfolio, weighing in at a Kris Jenkins-like heft this year, with 740 pages.

headline: New Hope Says It’s in Talks With Macarthur Shareholders
text: New Hope, the coal producer which has offered $3.45 billion for its Australian rival Macarthur Coal, has begun talks with Mccarthur shareholders, it said Tuesday.

headline: Carlyle Closes Asia Fund With $2.55 Billion
text: Carlyle Group, the American private equity firm, said Tuesday that it had raised $2.55 billion for its Asia fund, Carlyle Asia Partners III, giving it a total of $5 billion for three such funds in the region.

headline: Morningstar Buys British Fund Researcher
text: Morningstar said its British subsidiary had acquired Old Broad Street Research in Britain for about $18.3 million, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Google Plunks Down for Plink
