text: As Google continues its shopping spree, the search giant has picked up Plink, the maker of an Android application that can recognize and identify artwork, The Guardian reported.

headline: Bootlegging in Tribal Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Adam Ellick writes in The New York Times about the hazards of selling alcohol in the Pakistani frontier town of Peshawar, in defiance of both the Taliban and Pakistani police.

headline: Will Twitter Twist the Timeline?
text: Twitter has become more useful as it has ballooned to more than 50 million posts a day. But it has also become harder than ever to dig through all those posts to find the most useful ones.

headline: Ford Explorer to Get 4-Cylinder EcoBoost Engine
text: Ford Motor announced that it will expand its line of EcoBoost engines by launching three new power plants before the end of the year. EcoBoost is Ford’s brand name for an engine technology package that optimizes engine efficiency through turbocharging, direct fuel injection and variable camshaft timing.

headline: A 1917 Flying Boat Goes on the Auction Block
text: Updated, 1:43 p.m. | The Curtiss MF Flying Boat sold for $506,000 on Tuesday afternoon, a Bonhams spokesman said. The buyer bid by telephone, competing against two other phone bidders and one in the auction room.

headline: Billionaire Will Try to Buy Rest of Rams
text: Stan Kroenke has decided to exercise his matching rights and try to buy the remaining 60 percent share of the St. Louis Rams, he said late Monday, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Of Hedge Fund Managers and Campaign Contributions
text: As the spotlight on hedge funds has become increasingly hotter, industry executives have increasingly poured money into politicians’ campaign coffers.

headline: Tip of the Week: Chemistry in Word
text: Chemistry students and teachers might want to check out the new Chem4Word add-on for Microsoft Word. The free software, which was developed by Microsoft Research and the Unilever Center for Molecular Science Informatics at the University of Cambridge, allows Word users to insert chemical symbols, formulas and even 2-D models of molecules into documents. Chem4Word works with Word 2007 and the current beta version of Word 2010, and is listed as a beta version itself. More information and a demonstration video are also available for scientists, aspiring scientists and those who have chemistry papers due soon.

headline: Speed Read for Tuesday, April 13
text: Highlights from today’s New York Times:

headline: The Oy of Yiddish, Part 1
text: In March, co-vocabularists were invited to revel in the delights of Yiddish and pose questions to Michael Wex – author of the bestselling “Born to Kvetch,” and, most recently, “How to Be a Mentsh and Not a Shmuck.”

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Arroz de Verduras
text: Arroz de Verduras, or vegetable rice, is an intensely flavored dish of many colors. It is rice cooked in a sofrito, a base of garlic, onions, sweet paprika, fresh tomato and saffron, and then studded with corn, edamame, peas and olives and baked until the edges are crisp and golden. It is a dish with Portuguese roots that George Mendes, the 37- year-old chef and a co-owner of Aldea, in Manhattan, introduced at his restaurant. As a first-generation American, he grew up in Danbury, Conn., surrounded by 30 relatives, all of whom had emigrated from Portugal. “My mom, and my aunts, all cooked,” he said.

headline: Prosecutors Name Targets of More Galleon Trades
text: Goldman Sachs Group, AT&T and Cisco Systems are among stocks bought and sold illegally by the Galleon Group hedge fund founder Raj Rajaratnam and others involved in a sprawling insider trading case, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Why Humanity Loves, and Needs, Cities
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.For much of its early existence, our species spread out.

headline: Book Reveals Unheard Interviews With Jacqueline Kennedy
text: Nearly seven hours of previously unreleased interviews with Jacqueline Kennedy, recorded just months after the death of President John F. Kennedy and intended for deposit in a future presidential library, will be released as a book, the publisher Hyperion said on Tuesday. The original interviews with Mrs. Kennedy were conducted in the spring of 1964 with the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. as part of an oral history project intended to preserve memories of Kennedy and his administration. In the seven interviews, Hyperion said, Mrs. Kennedy discusses various subjects including her husband’s election campaigns, his handling of challenges like the Cuban Missile Crisis, her role as a wife, mother, and first lady; and what her husband would have done in a second term as president.

headline: Ex-Northern Rock Executives Fined and Banned
text: Britain’s financial regulator has fined and banned two former executives of the mortgage lender Northern Rock — the country’s first major casualty of the global credit crunch — for misreporting figures on loan arrears, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Trading Ends With a Modest Gain as Investors Digest Earnings Reports
text: Wall Street traders took in the first batch of quarterly earnings reports on Tuesday, but nobody seemed quite sure what to make of the numbers.

headline: The Early Word: More Nuke Talks
text: It’s time for Day Two. President Obama heads back over to the Washington Convention Center today for more action at the nuclear security summit.

headline: Imports Rose in February, Building Hope for Recovery
text: Trade data on Tuesday provided another piece of evidence that spending by consumers and businesses was picking up, bolstering hopes that the recovery was gaining momentum.

headline: Today in Business Travel
text: In-Flight Food, No Longer Free, Tries to Be TastyAirlines are abandoning free in-flight food, and looking closely at what the paid options might be.Frustrated? Try Life on the ‘No Fly’ ListHe’s not supposed to be on the list. There’s a way to get off the list, but that’s not working either.

headline: Book Reveals Interviews With Jacqueline Kennedy
text: Hyperion announced this morning that nearly seven hours of previously unreleased interviews with Jacqueline Kennedy, recorded just months after the death of President John F. Kennedy and intended for deposit in a future presidential library, will be released as a book. Caroline Kennedy is editing the book, which is planned for publication in September 2011 as part of the 50th anniversary commemoration of the Kennedy presidency.

headline: Will There Be Annual Caps in the High-Risk Pools?
How We Try to Get Buy-In, Part 1
text: On the morning of June 22, 2009, all 78 associates of SRC Power Systems, which makes custom-engineered power units and is based in Springfield, Mo., filed onto the shop floor to hear an hour-long presentation about the company’s latest sales-and-marketing plan. People grabbed folding chairs where available while others sat on wire containers or floor baskets near their tools and workstations. There was a dark mood in the air. One guy leaned up against an engine crate, his arms folded across his chest and his jaw set. It was as if he already didn’t like what he was about to hear.

headline: Consumer Reports Says Lexus GX 460 Is Unsafe
text: 7:07 p.m. | Updated

headline: Pedaling for Nepal
text: When we last wrote about Apolis Activism, the socially minded clothing company had teamed up with the American heritage brand Filson to make a messenger bag using fabric sourced from Uganda. Its latest offering — a sweater produced in collaboration with the cycling outfitters at Rapha — originates from another unlikely spot: a small wool cooperative in Nepal staffed entirely by women.

headline: Smithsonian Names Director of Education
text: The Smithsonian Institution has named Claudine Brown as its first director of education. Ms. Brown, 60, who since 1995 has been the director of the arts and culture program at the Nathan Cummings Foundation, will oversee the National Science Resources Center and the Smithsonian Center for Education and Museum Studies, and coordinate the efforts of the education offices in all of the Smithsonian’s museums and science centers.

headline: Pulitzer Juror Criticizes Choice for Drama Prize
text: How did “Next to Normal” end up winning the Pulitzer Prize for drama on Monday when the five-person drama jury — responsible for evaluating the entries of plays and musicals — did not include “Next to Normal” among its three nominees for the prize?

headline: A Spy Takes the Spotlight
text: When Michael Garin, who plays the piano at Elaine’s on Sunday nights, started “Secret Agent Man,’’ few patrons noticed as the man in the blue blazer and gray slacks at the front table pulled off his shoe and did his best Maxwell Smart.

headline: Growth and Greenhouse Gases
text: So I’ve gotten some pushback from environmentalists on the proposition in my mag piece that we can afford, at real but modest cost, to limit greenhouse gas emissions. Oddly, it comes from two directions. On one side, there are those who insist that greening the economy is win-win: more jobs, more growth, as well as less carbon. On the other, those who insist that you can only be serious about protecting the planet if you admit that we have to give up on economic growth.

headline: A Woman’s Place Is in the Home — er, House
text: The May issue of Good Housekeeping, celebrating the magazine’s 125th anniversary, salutes 125 women “who changed our lives” and “who changed the world.” At an event on Monday night to celebrate the milestone, it seemed that most of them were there — and then some.

headline: ‘A Rumor Going Around’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: There’s a rumor going around that Hillary Clinton could be Obama’s choice for the next Supreme Court justice. That’s a lifetime appointment that would take up all of her time, or as Bill Clinton calls it, “She’ll take it.”

headline: ‘Financial Ruin’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Well, according to the Pentagon, Al Qaeda is in financial ruin. You know why they’re broke? Health insurance premiums.

headline: Ring Around the Rosy
text: The artist Anish Kapoor is known for his large-scale, often highly polished and mind-bending sculptures, many of which are currently on view at the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao, where he is having a major solo exhibition. The ring he recently designed for Bulgari would make the ultimate souvenir. The concave stainless-steel band capped in pink gold is like one of the artist’s works — pocket size rather than park size — and will serve as the inspiration for a larger piece to be auctioned off later this year to benefit Save the Children’s Rewrite the Future program.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Unemployment Benefits
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Sharp Adds Yellow to 3-D TV
text: The new 3-D televisions are barely out of the box, and the one-upmanship among manufacturers has begun.

headline: Dr. Deepak Chopra on Reinventing the Body

headline: Conan O’Brien, On the Road Again
text: The last time we saw Conan O’Brien on stage, he was bidding farewell to his “Tonight Show” tenure with an all-star singalong of “Free Bird.” On Monday night, he commenced his Legally Prohibited From Being Funny on Television tour at the Hult Center for the Performing Arts in Eugene, Ore., with a set that included this appropriate Willie Nelson number. Bill Carter has a report on the night’s show on Media Decoder, and at Variety, Michael Schneider has posted more video from the show (which may be yanked from the Web faster than you can say “The Jay Leno Show”).

headline: Bank Failure: Two Brief Notes
text: 1. Some commenters on this blog have argued that lots of small banks failed in Georgia, without systemic consequences. But these banks weren’t allowed to collapse; they were seized by the FDIC — in effect, nationalized — and their depositors were protected. That is, in effect they were rescued, although the stockholders were cleaned out.

headline: Unplaced Students Go Back to Square One
text: It did not matter if the envelope was thick or thin — for thousands of eighth graders around the city, whether rejected or accepted, it ended the strange state of limbo they had been in for months. The high school admissions process, normally nerve-wracking, was even longer this year because a lawsuit over the city’s plans to shutter some high schools delayed the letters several days.

headline: With Broadway On Hold, Patton Oswalt Pivots to TV
text: However the theater world may feel about Patton Oswalt, he’s still got a home on television. Weeks after the demise of the “Lips Together, Teeth Apart” revival that would have marked his Broadway debut, Mr. Oswalt, the comedian and actor (“Big Fan,” “Ratatouille,” “The King of Queens”) has been cast in a new television pilot that puts him opposite the Broadway veteran Matthew Broderick. Publicists for Mr. Oswalt said in a statement that he would star in a comedy pilot called “Beach Lane,” created by Paul Simms (“NewsRadio”), in which he will play a well-to-do if not well-educated man who is put in charge of a local newspaper in fictional Dockhampton, N.Y. Mr. Broderick will play an established journalist whom Mr. Oswalt’s character hires to help him keep the presses rolling. The cast will also feature Kristen Johnston (“Third Rock From the Sun”) and its producers include Lorne Michaels and Marci Klein (of “Saturday Night Live” and “30 Rock”).

headline: Ringo Unmoved by Vatican Praise for Beatles
text: Updated | 12:59 p.m. While newspapers in many countries continue to report on how the Roman Catholic Church has responded to the sexual abuse of children by priests, the Vatican’s daily, L’Osservatore Romano, found space in its pages over the weekend to deal with an older controversy: John Lennon’s offhand statement in 1966 that the Beatles were “more popular than Jesus.”

headline: G.O.P. Takes Aim at Plans to Curb Finance Industry
text: WASHINGTON — Drawing the lines for a fierce election-year battle over regulating the nation’s financial system, Senate Republicans on Tuesday insisted that legislation proposed by Democrats and the White House would only encourage future taxpayer bailouts of big banks.

headline: Study Says Overuse Threatens Gains From Modified Crops
text: Genetically engineered crops have provided “substantial” environmental and economic benefits to American farmers, but overuse of the technology is threatening to erode the gains, a national science advisory organization said Tuesday in a report.

headline: Mapping World Debt
text: This map, by Benjamin Hennig of the University of Sheffield’s SASI Research Group, shows the debt load around the world. The size of each country represents the total external debt of that nation (using 2010 World Bank estimates). The color of each country, on the other hand, shows the size of national debt relative to the size of each country’s economy.

headline: The New Features in Your 401(k)
text: Employers aren’t just reinstating 401(k) matches. They are also adding investment advice and target date funds and are increasingly automatically enrolling employees, according to new data from Charles Schwab.

text: President Obama today urged Americans to honor the upcoming 40th anniversary of Earth Day by acting to improve the environment around them and launched a Web site, Whitehouse.gov/EarthDay, compiling citizens’ success stories.

headline: 36 Hours in Munich
text: MUNICH is a major destination for beer lovers, history buffs and music fans, but lately the Bavarian capital has been recognized as a great place to live. Monocle magazine ranked it the world’s most livable city in 2007, citing its high-quality housing, low crime and “general feeling of Gemütlichkeit.” Its public transportation was recently deemed Europe’s best by a leading automobile club. And its storied beer culture is so ubiquitous that Lufthansa just installed its own beer garden at Munich airport.

headline: CNN Fights Back With ‘Objectivity’ Arguments
text: In a presentation to advertisers and agencies on Tuesday morning, executives of CNN indicated how they plan to counter the growing ratings of  — and buzz about — the rival Fox News Channel: play up their channel’s identity as an objective source of news.

headline: Williamsburg Waterfront Concerts Announced
text: It’s looking to be a big summer of music at East River State Park, on the waterfront in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Modest Mouse will play on July 23, in a benefit for the Open Space Alliance of North Brooklyn, a nonprofit group that runs the concert series there. Faith No More has added a second date there for July 2, after its season-opening concert on July 5 sold out, and in February Senator Charles E. Schumer declared, enthusiastically,  that the free pool parties would return this summer, but no details about those shows have been announced. Tickets for Modest Mouse go on sale Friday, and for Faith No More’s July 2 concert on April 23, both through Ticketmaster.

headline: Barney Frank Joins Talk Schedule at ‘The Temperamentals’
text: It’s not often that a politician makes it known in advance when he’ll be attending a theater event, but in this case, Representative Barney Frank not only wants you to know he’ll be at a performance of “The Temperamentals,” he hopes you’ll stick around afterward and ask him questions. Mr. Frank, the outspoken Democrat of Massachusetts, will participate in a postperformance discussion on May 3 at New World Stages, the play’s press representatives said on Tuesday. The congressman will appear with Jon Marans, the author of “The Temperamentals,” a play about forerunners of the gay rights movement in the early 1950s. Other guests planned for the talk series in future weeks include the playwrights Charles Busch and Terrence McNally, and James E. McGreevey, the former governor of New Jersey.

headline: Robert Bohr Leaves Cru
text: Robert Bohr, who was a partner and wine director at Cru since it opened in 2004, has left the restaurant. While continuing the wine consulting company he runs with Cru’s owner, Roy Welland, he has also stared working with Tom Colicchio to oversee some of the wine programs at Mr. Colicchio’s restaurants.

headline: The Incinerator as Eye Candy
text: The waste-to-energy plants I visited in Denmark this year for an article look like, well, power plants. Each has a prosaic smokestack dating from the days when all they had were old-fashioned incinerators. Twenty years ago, an important form of “pollution control” was to build a very, very tall smokestack so that dirty emissions dispersed far and wide.

headline: Sampler: Union Leader Steps Down, and Residents Fight Over Trees
text: Labor Leader Steps Down | Andrew Stern, the leader of the Service Employees International Union, signaled Monday that he would step down at the end of this week, Politico reported. Over the past year, Mr. Stern has confronted bitter resistance as he steered the union through the fastest period of growth in its history. He has been locked in a fierce struggle with a splinter S.E.I.U. health care workers’ local in the Bay Area. He has also been fighting the hotel and restaurant workers’ union Unite Here, whose leader in San Francisco, Mike Casey, is a prominent national labor figure. [Politico, The New York Times]

headline: 92nd Street Y Announces 2010-11 Season
text: The 92nd Street Y plans to focus largely, but not exclusively, on thematic programming in its 2010-11 season. Among the highlights is a three-concert Schubert series by the Takács Quartet (Oct. 16, Feb. 26, April 9), with a new work by Daniel Kellogg, based on Schubert’s “Death and the Maiden” Quartet, on the first program. The Chamber Music at the Y series, with the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio, and guests, celebrates Schumann‘s bicentenary with three programs devoted to music of Robert and Clara Schumann, Brahms and Chopin (Oct. 27 and 28, Dec. 15 and 16, April 6 and 7).

headline: Driving While Demented
text: You might hope that when the American Academy of Neurology reviews and updates its decade-old guidelines on driving and dementia, the experts would come up with clear-cut recommendations: a specific score on a specific test means someone can head for the mall without much concern, or a  particular behavior means it’s too risky to be on the road, so hand over the keys.

headline: Anti-American Demonstration in Najaf
text: NAJAF, Iraq — Earlier this week, on the seventh anniversary of the American fall of Baghdad, Shiite demonstrators held a protest in the holy city of Najaf, burning effigies of President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., and stamping on the flags of the United States and its allies. Many were supporters of Moktada al-Sadr, and carried posters of the Shiite cleric and his father, Mohammad Sadeq al-Sadr, who was assassinated during Saddam Hussein’s regime.

headline: Milan Report | Fornasetti Remix
text: It’s the start of design week here in Milan, and our first event was an off-site exhibit at one of our favorite galleries: Nilufar. Run by Nina Yashar, the gallery-cum-high-end-design-boutique specializes in antique design masterpieces as well as newly commissioned works by young designers. The standout at this year’s exhibition, however, was a bit old and a bit new. The designer Barnaba Fornasetti, son of the legendary Piero Fornasetti, has made newly commissioned pieces out of some of his father’s classic collaborations with the famed designer Gio Ponti. Instead of making these pieces in the high-gloss lacquer that is a Fornasetti trademark, these new works are covered in the original zinc lithographic plates that papa Fornasetti used to print his famous designs. The matte gray zinc is embellished in a black etched patchwork of flowers, trompe l’oeil books, faux bois and more. The zinc plates are attached to the wooden construction of the furniture by way of utilitarian yet decorative nail heads. The collection consists of two desks, a tall secretary desk, a chair, a chandelier and a wardrobe (in which Barnaba has even placed some of his own idiosyncratic Fornasetti printed suits, vests and shirts). All of the pieces are unique and are destined to become instant, if remixed, classics.

headline: Senators Invited to White House for Supreme Court Talks
text: President Obama has invited top Democratic and Republican senators to the White House next Wednesday to consult on his next pick for the Supreme Court – a move that means, in effect, there will be no announcement of a candidate for at least the next eight days.

headline: Pimentón: It’s Spanish for ‘Better Than Paprika’
text: DON’T you hate paprika? O.K., maybe that’s too strong, but isn’t it at least puzzling?

headline: Oven-Barbecued Pimentón Brisket
text: Time: 8 to 10 hours, mostly unattended

headline: South Bronx, 10:51 A.M.
text: Fans gathering for the Yankees’ home opener pass by the old stadium.

headline: The Morning Skate: Danger Looms in the First Round
text: The first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs, which starts on Wednesday, can be a danger zone for favorites. Scotty Bowman, who coached more Stanley Cup championships than anyone, told listeners of Toronto radio FAN 590 this morning (audio) that he was very aware of the possibility of first round upsets and there are no sure things. “I look at all the different TV shows and everyone’s always picking the favorites, it’s the easy thing to do. You wonder how a team that’s 20 or 30 points behind another can even have a competition.”

headline: Talking in Depth About Adoption
text: My in-box has been filling with emotion over the past few days, as I hear from parents of adopted children, would-be parents of adopted children, parents having second thoughts and those hoping that Russian officials will reconsider. This morning I am posting a sampling of what I am hearing, as a way of continuing the conversation.

headline: The Power of Pimentón
text: Paprika a power ingredient? That tasteless powder that your great-aunt sprinkled over potato salad to give it some color? Well, no. But in a fertile valley in the Spanish equivalent of the Wild West, they make a paprika with a sneaky heat and deep smokiness that takes the spice to a whole different place. Called pimentón, it’s a nearly effortless way to add complex flavor to all kinds of dishes, like barbecued brisket, or barbecue sauce, or a Spanish lamb stew, or this quick and easy kale recipe.

headline: Red Bulls May Be Close to Signing Notts County Striker (or Not)
text: 11:25 a.m. | Updated A Red Bull official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to speak publicly about Luke Rodgers, said the reports that the player has been denied a work permit were false.

headline: Former WaMu Chief Defends Loan Practices
text: The former chief executive of Washington Mutual, the biggest American savings and loan ever to fail, defended on Tuesday the bank’s actions to reduce risks from the looming housing bust, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Flowers, Bikes and Other Signs of Spring
text: Move over, D.C. — the cherry blossoms of New York are pretty impressive as well. It could even be argued that ours are more stunning, blooming as they often do near towering buildings or alongside highways rather than in manicured parks, as Found in Brooklyn and others appreciate.

headline: Yankee Stadium’s Second Season
text: Yankee Stadium opened to much fanfare last season, with the superlatives to match the team’s record number of championships. With a $1.5 billion price tag, it is the most expensive baseball stadium. The $2,500 tickets behind home plate were also the priciest in the league. And when many of them went vacant, they became the most scrutinized as well.

headline: Q. and A. on Food Safety with Michael Moss
text: Michael Moss, who won the Pulitzer Prize on Tuesday for his reporting on contaminated hamburger and gaps in federal oversight of food safety, will be taking questions from readers on Diner’s Journal this week.

headline: Random House Merges Two of Its Imprints
text: In a move to streamline its family of imprints, Random House, the world’s largest trade publisher, consolidated two of those imprints within its Random House Publishing Group, merging Bantam Dell with Ballantine Books.

headline: High and Low Dining: Barcelona
text: A review of Dos Cielos, which floats above the city on the 24th floor of the Hotel Melia ME, and Tapaç 24, a no-fuss tapas joint.

text: The parodies of Tiger Woods’s recent ad for Nike are now more popular online than the original ad.

headline: U.S. Institutions Join International Museum Day
text: Dozens of American art museums will offer free or discounted admission, store discounts and special programming on May 18, for the first time collectively joining other institutions around the world by participating in International Museum Day.

headline: Civil Rights Groups Fight Oakland Gang Injunction
text: The proposed Oakland gang injunction — introduced in February by Oakland’s city attorney, John Russo — has garnered praise from those seeking aggressive anticrime measures and wary disapproval from others concerned about racial profiling. The issue has generated considerable back-and-forth debate about the best ways to balance public safety and civil liberties.

headline: High and Low Dining: Berlin
text: A review of Dos Palillos (Two Sticks), in the new Casa Camper hotel, and YamYam Berlin, a canteen-style spot.

headline: Berlin’s ‘Terror’ Exhibition Gets New Home
text: For years, only a simple sign indicated the location of what was once the Nazi secret police headquarters in Berlin. “You are standing on the grounds of the former torture chambers of the Gestapo,” it read. More recently, an outdoor exhibition, called “The Topography of Terror,” has marked the spot. On May 7, the exhibition is scheduled to get a new home: a glass and concrete museum and documentation center built on same site.

headline: Financial Tuneup: Automate Your Debt Payments
text: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, we’ve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

text: The Knicks do not have a superstar (yet), a winning record or even a full roster for next season, but the N.B.A. is sending them on a good-will tour of Europe in October. Call it an official leap of faith in their rebuilding plan.

text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

headline: Lane Departure Warning Systems for the Rest of Us
text: Sophisticated driver assistance safety technologies, like beeping lane departure warning systems and dashboard lights that flash when you follow another car too closely, have generally only been available as a factory-installed option on new cars. Drivers of older vehicles have had to make do without it. But now at least one company hopes to make such systems more readily available to those who aren’t in the market for a new car.

headline: N.E.A Chairman Testifies on Capitol Hill
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the  National Endowment for the Arts, Rocco Landesman, delivered his first budget testimony before a House subcommittee on Tuesday, arguing for the arts as a source of jobs and an economic stimulus.

text: An ancient diet has become one of the hottest new food trends.

headline: Man Who Spread H.I.V. May Be Held
text: ALBANY — Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo’s office is moving to block the release of Nushawn J. Williams, the Brooklyn man who was believed to have knowingly infected a number of young women and girls in upstate New York with H.I.V. in a highly publicized case more than a decade ago.

headline: High and Low Dining: Moscow
text: A review of Bolshoi, by Arkady Novikov, one of Russia’s most prolific restaurateurs, and Khachapuri, a new cafe off Pushkin Square.

headline: Now Skewering | Jean Philippe Delhomme
text: In the hands of the illustrator Jean Philippe Delhomme, the unbearable lightness of being hip, rich and polished has never seemed so disarmingly down-to-earth. For more than 25 years, the artist has chronicled the in-crowd by quizzical strokes through advertisements and editorials for the likes of Barneys, Interview and Glamour. His signature is a rainfall of lifelike impressions that glitter until they prickle. “Know thyself,” he seems to say to a beau monde unwittingly silly in its distractions. Words to heed in frugal times? Recognize yourself in his world and you may feel better about being so terribly “with it.”

headline: I.M.F. Supports Charging Banks for Risks
text: Requiring the largest banks to pay surcharges based on the risks they pose to the global financial system could help provide stability, but the fees would have to be handled very carefully, the International Monetary Fund said Tuesday.

headline: Obama to Attend Funeral for Polish President
text: President Obama will travel to Krakow, Poland, this weekend to attend the funeral of Polish President Lech Kaczynski, who was killed last weekend in a plane crash.

headline: Tower on 40th St. Is Named a Landmark
text: The Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday bestowed landmark status on the Springs Mills Building, a tower clad in green glass at 104 West 40th Street, just west of Avenue of the Americas, which was built in 1963 and named for a pillowcase maker.

text: Opening day is a day for fans to wear their team’s colors. Yankees fans are no different — home white pinstripe jerseys, navy blue fitted caps and T-shirts saying, “Got rings?”

Mr. Frank described it as an unusual transgression, one that embarrassed others working on the legislation and created at least the appearance of a conflict of interest.

headline: McDonald’s Board Opposes Cage-Free Eggs  for U.S.
text: The board of directors of McDonald’s has recommended that the company’s shareholders vote against a proposal to require that 5 percent of the eggs purchased for the chain’s restaurants in the United States be the cage-free variety.

headline: Somali Radio Stations Halt Music
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — At least 14 radio stations here in the capital stopped broadcasting music on Tuesday, heeding an ultimatum by an Islamist insurgent group to stop playing songs or face “serious consequences.”

headline: A Crusade of Seduction and Sorcery
text: Renée Fleming has always made very particular and personal choices of operatic roles. Over the years, the managers of the Metropolitan Opera, fully appreciative of Ms. Fleming’s vocal artistry and star power, have been ready to accommodate her. The company has mounted house premiere productions of three strikingly diverse operas  Carlisle Floyd’s “Susannah,” Bellini’s “Pirata” and Handel’s “Rodelinda”  specifically for Ms. Fleming.

text: Love them or love to hate them, the Yankees and their fans celebrated their 2010 home opener with a championship ring ceremony (Slides 2 and 3). And be sure to check out the images of an osprey in Scotland (Slide 11) and a seal colony in England (Slide 12).

text: We hear rather less about the looming transformation of America into an evangelical theocracy now that George W. Bush is no longer president, but anyone who remembers those wearying debates will find Mark Chaves’ analysis of political activism in American churches illuminating. It turns out that evangelical congregations, despite all the exertions of the Moral Majority and the Christian Coalition, tend be less politically engaged on many fronts than their mainline Protestant, black Protestant and Catholic counterparts:

headline: High and Low Dining: Istanbul
text: A review of Mimolett, Istanbul’s newest big-night-out restaurant, and Antiochia, a small and stylish restaurant on a quiet backstreet in Beyoglu.

headline: Hesitation Complaints on Lexus ES in U.S., Too
text: As reported earlier, internal Toyota Canada documents released as part of a Canadian lawsuit indicated that many 2004 Lexus ES 330 models experienced a problem that was the mirror image of the automaker’s current acceleration issues. Rather than accelerate out of control, these Lexus sedans hesitated or slowed.

headline: HBO Orders Second Geaux-Round for New Orleans Series ‘Treme’
text: Don’t play any blues for “Treme,” HBO’s much promoted (if not easily pronounced) series about life and music in post-Katrina New Orleans. On Tuesday, just two days after the show’s premiere, the cable channel announced that it had ordered a second season. The series mixes actors like Steve Zahn, Wendell Pierce and Clarke Peters with real-life musicians like Elvis Costello and Allen Toussaint; the pedigree of David Simon, who created “Treme” with Eric Overmyer, and who also produced “The Wire” and “The Corner” for HBO, probably didn’t hurt, either.

headline: Super Modeling | T by Greg Lynn
text: Voluptuousness may be back in fashion for the fall, but as usual, the architectural designer Greg Lynn is ahead of the curve. “With everything that I design, from a church to a plate to skyscraper to a spoon,” he says, “I am always thinking about voluptuous volumes and spaces.” Add to that list Lynn’s soft-serve riff on the T logo, which he created for the spring design issue. It’s as intriguing coming as it is going. Lynn was inspired by the T’s combination of hard lines and curvilinear flourishes and scrolls. “This is something I have a great affinity for,” he says. “The combination of the hard-edged and the curvaceous.” View interactive >>

headline: Opening Day Homecoming for Matsui
text: The old place is just a shell now, on its way down. The new place is acquiring its own character, its own history. Yankee Stadium never lacks for great moments.

headline: The Jingle of Change in Europe
text: IF you’ve searched for a flight to Europe this summer and gasped at all the four-digit fares on your screen, there is some good news to report: the favorable exchange rate should help you save money once you land.

headline: Cuomo Ally to Lead State’s Democrats
text: It is Andrew M. Cuomo’s state Democratic Party, now more than ever.

headline: Different Angles on the Portrait
text: While putting together the catalog that accompanies his current show at Team Gallery, Ryan McGinley asked another photographer, Catherine Opie, if she would interview him. In some ways it was a strange choice. Ms. Opie, 49, is best known for studio portraits that are as static and deliberate as the 32-year-old Mr. McGinley’s photographs are hyperkinetic. And while both artists explore queer identity, they’re separated by gender, geography and nearly a generation.

headline: Series Rings, and Familiar Ring, at Stadium
text: The final game at Yankee Stadium last season ended with Mariano Rivera saving a victory for Andy Pettitte. The Yankees returned on Tuesday to collect their championship rings, and three hours later Rivera secured another win for Pettitte. The Yankees are trying to move past their accomplishments from 2009, but days like this recall the glory they hope to sustain.

headline: Calling All Carnivores in Portland, Ore.
text: Olympic Provisions, a new restaurant in Portland, Ore., may occupy a restored cereal mill in and industrial  neighborhood in the city’s southeast. But its meat-heavy menu reminds you more of a slaughterhouse.

headline: The Pulitzers in Drama: Expecting the Expected
text: I’ve never put much stock in artistic prizes. I enjoy the Academy Awards for much the same reason I imagine most of you do: being able to make fun of the tedium, the clothes and the fatuity the day after the presentation. (Of course, Hollywood on Oscar night has become so circumspect and airbrushed in recent years that those pleasures ain’t what they used to be.) But it’s become a self-evident truth that the correlation between Oscars and actual merit is arbitrary at best. And don’t get me started on the Tonys.

headline: For Tech Bidders, Data Recovery Seems Alluring
text: The data recovery industry received a bit of a jolt this week when Double-Take Software disclosed that an unidentified bidder had made an unsolicited offer to buy it for a premium price. Double-Take’s stock jumped about 20 percent on Monday on anticipation that a larger company was eager to acquire Double-Take’s technology to add data recovery to its list of services.

headline: More Changes for David Bouley
text: David Bouley is shrinking his holdings. On April 14, he will close Bouley Bakery and Market on the corner of Duane Street and West Broadway and he has canceled his plans for a commissary and market in SoHo.

headline: Banks Making Big Profits From Tiny Loans
text: In recent years, the idea of giving small loans to poor people became the darling of the development world, hailed as the long elusive formula to propel even the most destitute into better lives.

headline: A Fiery Scholar on the Trail of Genocide and Its Causes
text: Daniel Jonah Goldhagen, the controversial scholar who has specialized in the study of mass murder in books like “Hitler’s Willing Executioners” and “A Moral Reckoning,” has a reputation for combativeness. “Worse Than War,” Wednesday night on PBS, won’t change that.

headline: Segal Awards Are Given
text: This year’s winners of the Martin E. Segal Award, the baritone Quinn Kelsey and the dancer Daniel Ulbricht (above, with Misa Kuranaga) received their prizes on Tuesday  $7,500 each to be used for career advancement and study. The chairman of Lincoln Center, Frank A. Bennack, and its president, Reynold Levy, presided over the event. The award’s namesake, Martin E. Segal, also participated. Nominations are submitted by two of Lincoln Center’s 12 resident arts constituents on a rotating basis. This year’s winners were chosen by New York City Opera and New York City Ballet. The awards were established by the board of Lincoln Center and by a group of Mr. Segal’s friends and colleagues when he retired as Lincoln Center chairman in 1986.

headline: 92nd Street Y Announces Season
text: The 92nd Street Y plans to focus largely, but not exclusively, on thematic programming in its 2010-11 season. Among the highlights is a Schubert series by the Takacs Quartet (Oct. 16, Feb. 26, April 9), with a new work by Daniel Kellogg, based on Schubert’s “Death and the Maiden” Quartet, on the first program. The Chamber Music at the Y series, with the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio and guests, celebrates Schumann’s bicentenary with programs devoted to music of Robert and Clara Schumann, Brahms and Chopin (Oct. 27 and 28, Dec. 15 and 16, April 6 and 7). The pianist and lecturer Charles Rosen will give a talk on Chopin’s final year (Nov. 14) and play an all-Chopin recital with the cellist Fred Sherry (Nov. 20). The pianist Leon Fleisher, above, is the focus of three evenings: a recital on Nov. 13, a chamber concert on Dec. 11 and an onstage interview with a showing of the film “Two Hands: The Leon Fleisher Story,” on Dec. 12.

headline: Smithsonian Names Director of Education
text: The Smithsonian Institution has named Claudine Brown as its first director of education. Ms. Brown, 60, who has been the director of the arts and culture program at the Nathan Cummings Foundation, will oversee the National Science Resources Center and the Smithsonian Center for Education and Museum Studies, and coordinate education offices in all Smithsonian museums and science centers. Before joining the Cummings Foundation, Ms. Brown worked for the Smithsonian to develop plans for the National Museum of African American History and Culture, which is to open in 2015. In an interview, Ms. Brown said she was interested in exploring how to use technology, including video games and hand-held devices, to engage young people. “We want to be pretty aggressive about reaching young people where they are,” she said. “In the K-through-12 audience, a lot of learning is being done online, outside of the school environment.”

headline: N.E.A. Chairman Testifies on Capitol Hill
text: Rocco Landesman, left, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, delivered his first budget testimony before a House subcommittee on Tuesday, arguing for the arts as a source of jobs and an economic stimulus. The Obama administration has requested a $161.3 million budget for the endowment for fiscal year 2011, the same as its request for 2010, but less than the $167.5 million budget that Congress ultimately passed. Mr. Landesman has put his stamp on the budget, cutting a program known as American Masterpieces (though sparing one of its most popular components, the Big Read) and devoting $5 million to a pilot program, Our Town, that will support the creation of local arts districts. When Representative Mike Simpson of Idaho, the ranking Republican on the subcommittee, asked what he would do if Congress gave him $180 million, Mr. Landesman replied that Our Town could be expanded to reach more than the 35 communities currently planned. The chairman of the subcommittee, Jim Moran, Democrat of Virginia, who was in a jocular mood, congratulated Mr. Landesman several times on having hit the trifecta at the Kentucky Derby in 2001. (“I’ve been married three times,” Mr. Moran said, “but it was hardly the trifecta.”)

headline: Interviews With Jacqueline Kennedy to Be Published
text: Nearly seven hours of unreleased interviews with Jacqueline Kennedy, recorded just months after the death of President John F. Kennedy and intended for deposit in a future presidential library, will be released as a book, the publisher Hyperion said on Tuesday. The original interviews with Mrs. Kennedy took place in the spring of 1964 with the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. as part of an oral history project intended to preserve memories of Kennedy and his administration. In the seven interviews, Hyperion said, Mrs. Kennedy discusses various subjects including her husband’s election campaigns; his handling of challenges like the Cuban missile crisis; her role as a wife, mother and first lady; and what her husband would have done in a second term as president. The book, still untitled, is planned for release in September 2011 to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Kennedy presidency, and is being edited by the Kennedys’ daughter, Caroline. In a statement, Caroline Kennedy said: “My mother’s passion for history guided and informed her work in the White House. She believed in my father, his vision for America, and in the art of politics. She felt it was important to share her knowledge and excitement with future generations.”

headline: ‘Dancing’ Soars
text: For the second consecutive week, the figure skater Evan Lysacek topped the leader board on “Dancing With the Stars,” and the reality competition won the night with 20.3 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC won the night as well, as its crime series “Castle” (13.2 million) outperformed “CSI: Miami” (10.8 million) on CBS and “Law & Order” (4.1 million) on NBC. CBS was runner-up with its comedies, including “How I Met Your Mother” (6.9 million), “Rules of Engagement” (7.4 million), “Two and a Half Men” (13.5 million) and “The Big Bang Theory” (13.1 million). Fox placed third with an episode of “House” (10.5 million), directed by that series’s star, Hugh Laurie, and the winding-down “24” (8.3 million). NBC finished a distant fourth.

headline: Museums Join Program
text: Dozens of North American art museums will offer free or discounted admission, store discounts and special programming on May 18, for the first time collectively joining other institutions around the world in International Museum Day. The annual event, which began in 1977, has been widely celebrated in Europe and elsewhere, but participation among art museums in the United States has traditionally been low. The Association of Art Museum Directors, which represents 193 museum leaders in the United States, Canada and Mexico and has organized the participation of its members this year, said that as many as 75 institutions would participate (though some, because of their schedules, will celebrate the day on alternate dates). Among the museums joining are the Art Institute of Chicago, the Cleveland Museum of Art, the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the National Gallery of Canada.

headline: From Laundry to a Home in Berlin
text: Stephan Landwehr lives in a two-story, 2,695-square-foot building that had been used as a laundry for almost 100 years.

headline: Milan Report | On the Design Trail
text: First stop this morning: B&B Italia on Via Durini, where Patricia Urquiola’s Bend sofa represented the high-end company’s first foray into more affordable furniture. Also at B&B, Naoto Fukasawa’s Grande Papilio wing chair now comes in a more human-, and more New York-apartment-scaled Piccolo version.

headline: Rebuilding a Town, One Piece at a Time
text: PERRY, Iowa — Just days after the last of the winter snow melted here last month, workers descended on the corner of Second Street and Otley Avenue. In a matter of weeks, they had finished installing water, electric and sewer lines for the Perry Career Academy, a campus of Des Moines Area Community College that will train 450 adults and high school students in the vocational arts.

headline: In Berlin, a Life Worth Framing

headline: Some Respite for Greece in Successful Debt Sale
text: Investors enthusiastically snapped up Greek short-term securities on Tuesday after European Union leaders pledged to stand behind the country’s debt.

headline: Apple Lets Opera Browser Use Own Software on iPhone
text: The Norwegian company that makes the Opera Internet browser said on Tuesday that its software had been approved for use on the iPhone, making it the first browser that competes with Apple’s own software to gain full access to the device.

headline: Pregnant and Despondent
text: We have discussed postpartum depression here often on Motherlode, but the subject of depression during pregnancy comes up less frequently. I received an e-mail from a reader who is grappling with the problem — her daughter is pregnant and despondent. They are speaking with medical experts but the grandma-to-be is hoping that readers might have some advice. Have you struggled with depression during pregnancy? Has someone you loved? What might this reader do to help her daughter?

headline: If Your Name Is Powell, Take a Number
text: Here are some things you may not know about Adam Clayton Powell IV. He has considerable expertise in metallurgy and thin films. He has written widely on polymer membranes, solder wetting and electron beam melting.
