headline: Vandals Attack West Bank Mosque
text: Palestinians in the West Bank town of Hawara awoke on Wednesday to find a blue star of David painted on the outside of their mosque, after what a local resident described as an attack by Israeli settlers who live nearby.

headline: Facebook Steps Up Safety Efforts
text: Facebook on Tuesday opened a redesigned Safety Center where its users can go for information about how to protect their personal safety on the social-networking site, including dealing with impersonators, harassment and other unwanted contact, as well as content they consider objectionable or offensive.

headline: Assessing the N.B.A.’s Most Improved Player
text: Ballots are due this week for the N.B.A.’s postseason awards. Although The New York Times does not permit its reporters to vote, the N.B.A. reporters Howard Beck and Jonathan Abrams are making their picks in Off the Dribble. Today’s debate is about the Most Improved Player Award.

headline: ‘Ultimate Mini’ Heading to U.S.
text: Mini enthusiasts in the United States will, after all, get a chance to buy the hot-looking John Cooper Works World Championship 50.

headline: Swisher Unfiltered
text: Nick Swisher was so amped up about receiving his World Series ring yesterday that, at first, he didn’t notice it wasn’t the real one. Turns out that Mariano Rivera swapped Swisher’s ring at the last minute. We’ll let Swisher explain exactly what happened:

headline: Obama Faces G.O.P. Resistance on Financial Bill
text: In the face of stiff opposition from Senate Republicans, President Obama urged leaders of both parties in Congress to spend the next few weeks coming to terms on a financial regulation bill that would head off the need for bailouts in the future and bring the trading of complex financial instruments out of the shadows, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and David M. Herszenhorn of The New York Times report from Washington.

headline: The Mayor Shows a Softer Side
text: The mayor appears to be waging a mini charm offensive.

headline: Italian Vogue’s Editor Spikes ‘Trash’ Journalism
text: There is almost always a correlation between a nation’s cultural life, its history and language, and what it considers of value as a commodity, be it beautiful fashion or good food. Yet, in recent seasons one has sensed a decline on the Milan runways. Some of the collections are very good, newsworthy as well as high quality, but the overall impression isn’t so wonderful.

headline: Financial Tuneup: Check the Rules on Your Rewards Programs
text: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, we’ve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

headline: Unemployment Aid Bill Stalls Again
text: An extension of unemployment benefits stalled again in the Senate Wednesday after Democrats failed to muster 60 votes to clear a procedural hurdle.

headline: Poll: Most Find Their Income Tax Fair
text: Just ahead of Tax Day, a new New York Times/CBS News poll finds that most Americans regard the income taxes that they will have to pay this year as fair, regardless of political partisanship, ideology or income level.

headline: Britain Prepares for Its First Campaign TV Debates
text: LONDON — When Prime Minister Gordon Brown was asked in a television interview last fall whether he would agree to televised debates in the 2010 general election — breaking a taboo that has lasted in Britain since the dawn of the television age — he vacillated.

headline: Cyberwar Nominee Sees Gaps in Law
text: WASHINGTON — The Army intelligence officer nominated to lead the Pentagon’s new command devoted to warfare in cyberspace has warned Congress that policy directives and legal controls over digital combat are outdated and have failed to keep pace with the military’s technical capabilities.

headline: Staying Alive: Meet the Partner
text: What if you were working yourself to the bone in your growing business, while coping at home with a house full of little kids, and you were offered a big pile of money and expert management help in return for a 50 percent stake? Would you do it?

headline: The N.F.L. Heads to Broadway
text: The National Football League will make its first run at producing on Broadway this fall with “Lombardi,” a new play about the legendary Green Bay Packers coach Vince Lombardi that will be mounted at the Circle in the Square Theater, the producers announced on Wednesday.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS Anthropologie at Chelsea Market, opening on April 16, will showcase selected offerings from neighborhood boutiques, like romantic dresses from Geminola in the West Village ($300 to $400) and updated vintage items from the SOR Select label, carried by the NoLIta shop Some Odd Rubies ($200 to $300). The Chelsea Market space, previously a flower shop, combines the original steel beams and columns with Moroccan tile, a reclaimed-wood floor and suspended globe lamps. This store will be the first to carry Anthropologie’s decorating wares, like the wallpaper collection previously available online only ($88 to $148 a roll). Chelsea Market, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street); (212) 620-3116 ... On April 15 Sephora will open a 5,600-square-foot store at 88 Columbus Avenue (97th Street), its second on the Upper West Side: the other is at 76th and Broadway. Now Harajuku girls can score the exclusive Tokidoki beauty line. This whimsical Japanese-inspired apparel and accessories brand transports its trademark playful colors and edgy characters to items like a heart-and-crossbones eye-shadow compact and a Kabuki brush (above, $28). ... Goth meets cute at Convent, a Lower East Side boutique. Representative designers are Plain, whose one-size T-shirts fit most ($89), and Mancandy, whose cropped vest has shoulder pads ($150). 179 Stanton Street (Clinton Street), (212) 673-0233.

headline: Correction: Where a Cellphone Is Still Cutting Edge
text: An article last Sunday about cellphone usage in the developing world characterized the International Telecommunication Union incorrectly. The union is a public-private arm of the United Nations whose members include governments and private companies. It is not a trade group.

headline: Danny Meyer Helps Ralph Lauren Make Burgers on the Left Bank
text: Ralph Lauren is getting some expert help for the American restaurant with burgers, steaks and crab cakes at his lavish new store on the Left Bank in Paris — Danny Meyer’s Union Square Hospitality Group.

headline: Bulls’ Playoff Run Complicated by Spat
text: Neither Bulls Coach Vinny Del Negro nor the team’s executive vice president John Paxson have confirmed reports that the two got into a shoving match after a game on March 30, but Del Negro’s “no comment” after Tuesday’s game did not sound like much of a denial.

headline: Fathers Accused in Deaths of 2 Babies in Queens
text: Updated, 4:29 p.m. | Two men in Queens have been arrested in recent days in connection with the deaths of their baby sons, the authorities have said.

headline: Readers Ask: Multiple Myeloma
text: Apr. 19 12:26 p.m. | Updated: Scroll down for Dr. Greipp’s latest responses to reader questions. And check back for regular updates.

headline: A Lesson Lovely as a Tree: Defining and Appreciating Trees
text: Overview | What is a tree? Why are trees an important part of the environment? How do we use and connect with trees in our daily lives? In this lesson, students take an interdisciplinary approach to define and reflect on trees, including their classification and evolution, their protection and maintenance, their symbolism and their historical significance.

headline: Feeling For… | Handkerchiefs
text: As we left winter behind and started feeling the sweaty hands of summer, I, like many others, caught the annoying head cold that often accompanies seasonal transitions. It was relatively benign, but it kept me inside while others were out enjoying the warm, sunny weather. When I ventured back into the world, a friend noticed that I was using a handkerchief rather than Kleenex, and produced a striped cotton one. We talked about how, as children, our fathers had carried them and instilled the habit in us. I’ve carried a handkerchief ever since, preferring it to the fragile Kleenex that inevitably winds up in the dryer, ground up into dust.

headline: So You Want to Be a Player?
text: If you call the Tri-City ValleyCats, a minor league team in Troy, N.Y., and get put on hold, you will be treated to a loop of Abbott and Costello’s “Who’s on First?” routine. It is a sure sign that you are about to enter baseball land, with all its history and trappings. But when Heather LaVine, the director of fan development, picks up the line, it is a sure sign of another kind: the game has changed. The question for a modern-day Abbott and Costello might be, “Who’s in the front office?”

headline: Knowing the Score
text: Students and universities alike want a piece of this glitzy industry and the big bucks that seem to go along with it. But come diploma time, fantasy meets reality. “It’s not for fans,” warns Matt Winkler, associate dean of Georgetown University’s sports management program. “It’s not a hobby.” Is it for you?

headline: Voices of the Tea Party
text: Supporters submitted videos about the movement.

headline: 'Million Dollar Quartet' on Broadway
text: Levi Kreis, Robert Britton Lyons, Eddie Clendening and Lance Guest perform "Down by the Riverside." (Video courtesy of the production)

headline: A Local Dry Cleaner Tries to Compete Against P.&G.
text: FOUNDED in 2004, Hangers Cleaners of Kansas City, Mo., was started as an environmentally safe dry cleaner. It uses colorless, odorless liquid carbon dioxide instead of the aggressive chemicals applied at traditional dry cleaners. It has 35 employees and 2009 revenue of $1.6 million.

headline: Dimon Rebuts Ex-WaMu Chief: Club? What Club?
text: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, took issue with an assertion by Washington Mutual‘s former chief executive, Kerry K. Killinger, that WaMu was allowed to fail because it was not part of a government-backed “club” of protected financial firms that included the big Wall Street banks.

headline: ‘A Minister’s Wife,’ a Musical Version of ‘Candida,’ Is Headed to Lincoln Center Theater
text: A musical based on a George Bernard Shaw play? It’s worked in the past. To a 2010-2011 schedule that already includes a musical adaptation of “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown,” the transfer of the life-size puppet play “War Horse” and John Guare’s long-awaited “Free Man of Color,” Lincoln Center Theater has added a new musical based on Shaw’s “Candida,” the theater company said on Wednesday. The musical, called “A Minister’s Wife,” tells the story of a minister and his wife, Candida, whose marriage is upended by a young poet; the adaptation is by Austin Pendelton (“Orson’s Shadow”), with music by Josh Schmidt (“Adding Machine”) and lyrics by Jan Tranen (“Night in Sarajevo”). It will be directed by Michael Halberstam, the artistic director and a co-founder of the Writers’ Theater in Glencoe, Ill., where the musical had its debut last year. The Lincoln Center Theater production will begin previews at the Mitzi E. Newhouse theater on April 7 with an opening night planned for May 5. A cast has not yet been announced.

headline: A Groundbreaking 36 Years in the Making
text: On March 17, 1974, the architect Louis I. Kahn died of a heart attack as he was walking through Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. He was 73. In his briefcase were the final drawings, which he had just completed, for the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial to be built on the southern tip of Roosevelt Island.

headline: Icelandic Actors Read Entire Bank Crisis Report Aloud
text: Fresh from presenting two plays inspired by the epic collapse of the country’s banks, actors at the Reykjavik City Theatre are in the middle of an ambitious, if not particularly dramatic, effort to read the entire text of a new 2,250-page report on the crisis by a government “truth commission” to the nation.

headline: How to Fix Your iPhone (the Unofficial Edition)
text: Brendan McElroy’s living room in an apartment on the top floor of an East Village walk-up is crowded with anxious patients, each one jiggling a knee, or gnawing on a fingernail or lip.

headline: Women, Work and a Name Change
text: Women who choose to adopt their husbands’ surnames may be penalized in the job market, a new study from the Netherlands suggests.

headline: Playoff Scenarios at a Glance
text: Two more teams secured their playoff seeding Tuesday, but the N.B.A.’s postseason brackets remain wildly in flux heading into the final night of the season.

headline: Blair White, an Overlooked Gem in the Draft
text: Cecil Lammey of Draftguys.com will help preview and analyze the draft for the Fifth Down. He and Sigmund Bloom host the podcast at FootballGuys.com.

headline: Palin Invokes Tea Party Origins
text: BOSTON — Several thousand people gathered Wednesday morning on the sun-splashed Boston Common to hear Sarah Palin pay homage to the Tea Party movement and the original revolutionary events that inspired it.

headline: Holder Won’t Rule Out N.Y. 9/11 Trial
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Wednesday that Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and his accused co-conspirators in the Sept. 11 attacks may yet face trial in a federal court in the Southern District of New York, if not in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Bieber Knocks Usher From Billboard’s Top Spot
text: Last week Usher bumped his young protégé Justin Bieber from the top spot on the Billboard album chart, and this week Mr. Bieber returns the favor. “My World 2.0” (Island) by the 16-year-old Mr. Bieber — seen on “Saturday Night Live” with Tina Fey as host last week — returned to No. 1 with 102,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Usher’s “Raymond v Raymond” (Jive) fell one spot to No. 2, with 92,000. Slash, the guitarist once of Guns N’ Roses, is at No. 3 with his new, self-titled album, released by EMI, which sold just more than 60,000 copies in its first week out. The country band Lady Antebellum rose one spot to No. 4 with its album “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville), which sold just fewer than 60,000 copies. (SoundScan’s publicly released numbers are rounded; its subscribers get exact figures.)

headline: N.E.A. Names New Director of Design
text: The National Endowment for the Arts has named Jason Schupbach as its new director of design. Mr. Schupbach will oversee the distribution of the N.E.A.’s design grants (which totaled about $1.1 million in the 2009 fiscal year), the Mayors’ Institute on City Design and a new $5 million program, Our Town, focused on creating local arts districts. “Design has an intrinsic value to community building, to economic development, and to really revitalizing communities and creating jobs,” said Mr. Schupbach, who currently holds the position of creative economy industry director for the Massachusetts Office of Business Development.

headline: Defaults Rise in Loan Modification Program
text: The number of homeowners who defaulted on their mortgages even after securing cheaper terms through the government’s modification program nearly doubled in March, continuing a trend that could undermine the entire program.

headline: A Parade of Patterns
text: Print fusion is doable, if you know what you’re doing. Here are some clues.

headline: The Fungus Among Us
text: Edible mushrooms like the shiitake, wine cap, oyster and lion’s mane have taken to home domestication.

headline: Is Hangers Cleaners Taking the Right Steps?
text: We’ve just published a case study of Hangers Cleaners’ efforts to survive the arrival of a big new competitor down the road: Procter & Gamble. In the article, written by Pamela Ryckman, the owner of Hangers, Joe Runyan, explains how he has tried to emphasize his quirky side, his community roots and his door-to-door van service. Below, you’ll find the analyses of several small-business owners who have had similar experiences. Please leave your own thoughts in the comment section.

headline: N.F.L. Moves From Gridiron to Stage
text: The National Football League will make its first run at producing on Broadway this fall with “Lombardi,” a new play about the legendary Green Bay Packers coach Vince Lombardi that will be mounted at the Circle in the Square Theater, the producers announced on Wednesday.

headline: Shopping With Cindy DiPrima
text: A professional prop stylist searched for distinctive flower vases.

headline: Target Says, ‘Shaun, Just Do It’
text: Another star of the Winter Games is demonstrating that there can be life in the marketing mainstream after Vancouver.

headline: Mia Dona Meatballs Under the Sky
text: The weatherman says it will be raining Friday, but this hasn’t deterred Donatella Arpaia from launching an al fresco meatball cart that day.

headline: The Morning Skate: How Will the Playoffs Be Officiated?
text: The Stanley Cup playoffs open tonight with two early games — the defending champion Penguins hosting Ottawa and the Devils hosting the Flyers — and two late games — the Red Wings in Phoenix and the Avalanche in San Jose.

headline: Leaving the Korangal Valley
text: By the time you read this, the soldiers who lived on the small mountain base known as the Korangal Outpost will have left, taking much of the equipment they brought with them. Generators and some fuel will remain for local elders to divvy up, the sand-filled barriers known as Hescos which insulate against bomb blasts will be there still, but not much else.

headline: Taking a Sacred Plunge, One Wave of Humanity at a Time
text: HARIDWAR, India — Over the bridge they came, Hindu holy men by the tens of thousands, the most devout naked and dusted with sacramental powder, marching toward the bathing pool in the Ganges where the water is considered holiest on this most propitious of days.

headline: Specter Releases First TV Ads
text: A little more than a month before the Democratic primary in Pennsylvania, Senator Arlen Specter has taken to the airwaves to promote his ability to bring home the bacon.

headline: French Michelin Guide Offers Discounts
text: For more than 100 years the Michelin’s famous red guide to France has helped travelers with information on hotels, restaurants and service stations. Now it is also offering discounts and perks in restaurants.

headline: More on What to Do During the Flood Insurance Suspension
text: Last week, we discussed how new flood insurance policies aren’t currently available because Congress failed to reauthorize the National Flood Insurance Program — generally the only source of the insurance for consumers — before it went on recess last month.

headline: PC Sales Are on Course for Big Increase in 2010
text: The personal computer was beginning to look like yesteryear’s gizmo, a technology relic overshadowed by smartphones, e-readers and, lately, Apple’s iPad. But the old beige box has proved remarkably resilient and relevant.

headline: Vases That Make the Room
text: CINDY DiPRIMA knows a lot about accessories — that’s part of her job. As a professional prop stylist, she makes interiors and tabletop arrangements look good for the camera.

headline: Photographs by James Welling
text: Produced and edited by Valerie Green; Music by OJO

headline: UBS Shareholders Voice Opposition to Bonuses
text: Shareholders of UBS showed their frustration over bank bonuses on Wednesday, with far fewer than usual voting at the Swiss bank’s annual meeting to support last year’s compensation decisions, The New York Times’s Julia Werdigier reports from London.

headline: Are Your Taxes Too High?
text: Are your federal income taxes too high?

headline: Songs With Short Titles Explore Depths of Emotion
text: In Maude Maggart’s mesmerizing new show, “Three Little Words,” at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, songs become cat toys delicately pawed at by a performer who exhibits a feline cunning as she shape-shifts before your eyes.

headline: Renaming a Franchise Means More Than Finding a New Mascot
text: New team owners often have their hands full hiring executives, meeting fans and sponsors, and adding or cutting players. Michael Jordan, the new majority owner of the N.B.A. Charlotte Bobcats, is no different, only he may have something else on his to-do list: a new team nickname.

headline: Iran’s Parliament Limits Its Power as a Watchdog
text: Taking the unusual step of limiting its own authority, Iran’s Parliament on Wednesday adopted a law that would curb its ability to review regulations issued by the most powerful, unelected institutions of the state.

headline: Jazz Tinged With Sorrow as Well as Somber Beauty
text: Melancholia comes naturally to the Polish trumpeter Tomasz Stanko. Over the last decade, especially, during a late-career renaissance  Mr. Stanko, a pioneering figure in European jazz, is now 67  he has distilled his art into a tersely controlled expression of sorrow. His dark-hued trumpet tone reveals itself in murmurs; he often begins a note with sibilant shooshes of air. He can make a straightforward melody feel confidential, guarded. His lyricism inhabits a haunting calm and produces a somber beauty.

headline: Vazquez Slows Yankees’ Fast Start
text: The defining moments from the Yankees’ first eight games — a successful trip against two division rivals, C. C. Sabathia’s flirting with a no-hitter, an emotional championship ring ceremony — are fit for a season-ticket brochure. Just cut and paste.

headline: Defaults Rise in U.S. Loan Modification Program
text: The number of homeowners who secured cheaper mortgages through the government’s modification program only to default again nearly doubled in March, continuing a worrisome trend that threatened to undermine the entire program, The New York Times’s David Streitfeld reports.

headline: A May-December Dalliance in Paris, Both Sweet and Tart
text: Austin Pendleton has always been a cutie. He still is, even at 70. Yet when he makes his entrance in “Limonade Tous les Jours” (“Lemonade Every Day”), the lightweight one-act now playing at the Cell, an unsettling thought leaps to mind: Oh. It’s a Woody Allen movie.

text: Well, it’s not a Volt.

headline: Smithsonian Proposes Plan for Art and Industries Building
text: Wayne Clough, the secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, detailed a plan on Monday to transform the 1881 Arts and Industries building into an education center, with programming that would emphasize the four themes outlined in the Smithsonian’s new strategic plan: biodiversity and sustainability, the American experience, exploring the universe and valuing world cultures. The Arts and Industries building, which in the past housed temporary exhibits and has been empty since 2004, needs $65 million in structural renovations, according to Linda St. Thomas, the Smithsonian’s spokeswoman. On Monday, the Smithsonian’s Board of Regents reviewed a concept design for the building by the Los Angeles-based architecture firm Morphosis; its potential cost has not been determined, Ms. St. Thomas said. The Arts and Industries building has also been discussed as a possible site for a future national Latino museum. A presidential commission is studying the potential for such a museum.

headline: ‘We Did It, Mom!’
text: ATTENTION! CAUTION! RED ALERT! To all you students out there about to sign your Statement of Intent to Register to a college that you have yet to visit, stop right there and don’t move! Do not do it! I cannot emphasize that enough.

headline: Rapper’s Multiple Personalities and Crossover Aspirations
text: In the middle of B.o.B.’s coming debut album, “B.o.B. Presents: The Adventures of Bobby Ray” (Rebel Rock/Grand Hustle/Atlantic), is a song called “The Kids,” in which the Atlanta rapper-singer bemoans the street life: “Looking back on the past that I had/All my days in the streets trying to prove that I was bad/I still elevated to the level that I’m at.” That he does it to the tune of “The Kids Don’t Stand a Chance,” by Vampire Weekend  well, that’s just adding insult to injury.

headline: Driver Charged in Cyclist’s Death in Brooklyn
text: Updated | 6:31 p.m. An 18-year-old cyclist was fatally struck by an unlicensed driver who sped through a red light in Flatbush on Wednesday morning, the police said. The driver was charged with criminally negligent homicide.

headline: Going Back to School and Finding Excitement
text: If Alan Gilbert’s concerts with the New York Philharmonic were consistently played with the sense of excitement that enlivened his performance with the Juilliard Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening, perhaps we would hear less grumbling about his supposed lack of charisma.

headline: What We’re Reading: Democratic Optimism
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Former Banker for UBS Seeks Shorter Sentence
text: The former UBS private banker in prison after helping to uncover tax evasion by wealthy Americans is asking President Obama for a shorter sentence.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Aftershocks in China
text: The earthquake in China, which left hundreds dead and devastation everywhere, leads off today’s show. The news doesn’t get any better in subsequent photographs from Haridwar, India (Slide 2), where a stampede created chaos. And more violence follows from Iraq (Slide 4), Indonesia (Slide 5) and Israel (Slide 9).

headline: Blurbing ‘Catch-22’
text: Nina Bourne, the veteran publishing executive who died last Friday at age 93, was known for the crisply stylish ad campaigns she created in her four decades at Alfred A. Knopf.

headline: Off the Menu: Otarian
text: You’ve had calorie, fat and sodium counts appended to your fast food choices. A new twist is knowing your food’s carbon footprint, that is, its environmental impact. That’s what Radhika Oswal offers Otarian, a vegetarian fast food chain with the planet on its mind. Recycling, composting, sustainable building materials and no ingredients that are shipped by air are the rules here. The carbon footprints were calculated according to standards set by the World Resources Institute, an environmental organization based in Washington.

headline: For Westwood, a Classy Finish to a Disappointing Day
text: It was undeniably poignant to watch Phil Mickelson with his arms locked around his wife, Amy, just off the 18th green on Sunday after winning his third Masters title. But if you were watching closely, there was another poignant scene playing out just a few paces behind the Mickelsons.

headline: The Men Behind the Musicians of ‘Million Dollar Quartet’
text: The names of the musicians portrayed in the new Broadway musical “Million Dollar Quartet” are so first class they can fly solo: Elvis, Johnny, Jerry Lee and Carl.

headline: Moving Taped Past to Hard-Drive Future
text: It started with a call from Steve Jobs.

headline: 'Time Capsule'
text: An excerpt from Louis Faurer's film of Times Square.

headline: Tough Times in Theater, as One Partnership Knows
text: One of New York’s most fruitful recent theatrical collaborations has been between the LAByrinth Theater Company and the Public Theater, with the Public housing and helping to produce LAByrinth shows like “Jack Goes Boating” (starring Philip Seymour Hoffman) and “The Last Days of Judas Iscariot” (with Sam Rockwell and Eric Bogosian).

headline: Unwelcome at Prom, but Leading Pride Parade
text: Constance McMillen did not get to attend her high school prom after her Mississippi high school canceled it rather than allow her to bring her girlfriend. But she will be an honored guest at an even bigger celebration: she has been named a grand marshal of the gay pride parade in New York.

headline: Israel Says Syria Gave Missiles to Hezbollah
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli officials say that Syria has delivered accurate long-distance Scud missiles to the Lebanese group Hezbollah, placing cities deep in Israel’s heartland, including Tel Aviv, within range.

headline: ‘Human Films’ Still Beckon a Master of Self-Absorbed Heroes
text: When the filmmaker Bill Forsyth won a lifetime achievement award last year from the Scottish branch of the British film academy, the idea of giving an acceptance speech worried him. The self-absorbed heroes he created in comedies like “Gregory’s Girl” and “Local Hero” may not have minded being the center of attention, but Mr. Forsyth himself is modest, if not downright shy. He felt he needed help.

headline: Vain Glorious | Marie Robinson’s New Flatiron Salon
text: Sally Hershberger is not a happy camper these days. Not only did the diva of the $800 haircut lose her star colorist Marie Robinson, who famously took Scarlett Johansson from blond to brunet for the “Nanny Diaries,” but Robinson also put a dent in the staff and hired seven of her colleagues for her eponymous new salon in the Flatiron district. Included in her sweep are Tommy Buckett, Allison Woodruff and Ryan Trygstad, all favorites of the magazine world. And the celebrity stylist Danilo will also work out of the light-filled 5,000-square-foot space when he’s in town. Master Cleanse lemonade is on tap; the paint, floor stain and cooling system are all eco-friendly, and the music runs along the lines of Hot Chip and Kylie Minogue. And so far, there aren’t any $800 services on the menu. 155 Fifth Avenue; (212) 358-7780.

headline: Tchaikovsky Uninhibited, and a Hint of Humor
text: Tchaikovsky struggled to write his Grand Sonata in G in 1878 because he felt uninspired, he wrote, and wasn’t “in the mood for work.” But the pianist Yefim Bronfman clearly had no such inhibitions when he tore through this daunting and infrequently performed piece on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall.

headline: City Contests Decision on Ground Zero
text: Lawyers defending the city and its contractors from lawsuits filed by about 10,000 people who worked on rescue and cleanup operations at ground zero went to a federal appeals court on Wednesday to challenge a judge’s authority to block a settlement.

headline: Simon Property Alters Offer for Mall Operator
text: The Simon Property Group made a new offer on Wednesday to General Growth Partners, the bankrupt mall operator, offering to invest $2.5 billion along the lines of the reorganization plan it has already announced.

headline: On Dance: Dancing With the (City Ballet) Star
text: In case you missed it, Tiler Peck, a principal dancer with New York City Ballet, appeared on “Dancing With the Stars” on Tuesday  night. In a short piece choreographed by Travis Wall, she performed along with 12 other dancers and the violin duo Nuttin’ but Stringz in a hybrid work as part of the “Macy’s Stars of Dance” segment.  Ms. Peck flew to Los Angeles for the show between rehearsals for new ballets by Christopher Wheeldon and Wayne McGregor for City Ballet’s coming season. We talked to her briefly Wednesday afternoon about dancing for cameras and which contestant has her vote. Here are excerpts.

headline: Out of the Labyrinth and Onto the Screen
text: LOS ANGELES  There’s a reason Hollywood calls it “development hell.” Even when it turns out well.

headline: A Somber Moment, in Tribute to Poland
text: Before the opening work in the Philadelphia Orchestra’s concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, the pianist Piotr Anderszewski spoke to the audience about the plane crash in Russia on Saturday that took the lives of Lech Kaczynski, the president of Poland, and dozens of the country’s military and political leaders. Born in Warsaw to Polish-Hungarian parents, Mr. Anderszewski spoke of how wrenching this tragedy has been for his home country. With Charles Dutoit, the Philadelphia Orchestra’s chief conductor, looking on, Mr. Anderszewski asked for a moment of silence and dedicated the first piece on the program to those who were lost.

headline: When a Man Is an Island
text: Seeking solitude on islands in Washington and Australia, and in Sweden’s woods.

headline: Deputy Director of C.I.A. Is Stepping Down
text: WASHINGTON — Stephen R. Kappes, the veteran clandestine officer who came out of retirement in 2006 to lift morale in the Central Intelligence Agency’s troubled ranks, is stepping down as deputy director, the agency announced on Wednesday.

headline: Palm Climbs After Harbinger Buys 9.5% Stake
text: Shares of Palm climbed as much as 10 percent on Wednesday after Harbinger Capital Partners, the hedge fund run by Philip A. Falcone, disclosed that it had acquired a 9.5 percent stake in the company, which makes smartphones and other hand-held devices. But Palm later gave up much of its earlier gains and ended the day up 3.1 percent.

headline: Dish Network Looking to the Crowd
text: An initiative by Dish Network is indicative of how marketers remain enamored of crowdsourcing as a way to generate ideas for advertising campaigns, commercials, logos, packaging and the other trappings of peddling products and services.

headline: Turf for a Different Kind of N.F.L. Play: Broadway
text: The National Football League will make its first run at producing on Broadway with “Lombardi,” a new play about the legendary Green Bay Packers coach Vince Lombardi (right, after winning Super Bowl II in 1968) to be mounted at the Circle in the Square Theater this fall. According to a statement Wednesday from the producers Tony Ponturo, a sports marketing executive, and Fran Kirmser (“Hair”), the N.F.L. has authorized the show’s use of its logos as well as footage and music from its film division. Tracy Perlman, the league’s vice president for entertainment marketing and promotions, said in the statement: “Lombardi’s charisma and coaching style were legendary  and intensely theatrical.” The play is written by Eric Simonson and based on a 1999 biography of Lombardi, “When Pride Still Mattered,” by David Maraniss. Dan Lauria will star as Lombardi; the play, to be directed by Thomas Kail (“In The Heights”), is scheduled to begin previews on Sept. 23 and open on Oct. 21.

headline: One Show in, ‘Treme’ Gets a Second Season
text: Don’t play any blues for “Treme,” HBO’s much promoted series about life and music in post-Katrina New Orleans. On Tuesday, just two days after the show’s premiere, HBO said it had ordered a second season. The series mixes actors like Steve Zahn, Wendell Pierce, above, and Clarke Peters with musicians like Elvis Costello and Allen Toussaint. The pedigree of David Simon, who created “Treme” with Eric Overmyer, and who also produced “The Wire” and “The Corner” for HBO, probably didn’t hurt either. In a statement Michael Lombardo, the president of HBO Programming, said, “I can’t think of another show that is more emblematic of what we aspire to be as a network than ‘Treme.’ ”

headline: Argentine Film: Action, History, Love ... and an Oscar
text: For “The Secret in Their Eyes” the road to this year’s Academy Award as best foreign-language film began in the courtrooms of Buenos Aires. Eduardo Sacheri, a writer of the movie’s screenplay and the author of the novel on which it is based, spent five long years in bureaucratic toil there, collecting stories of injustice and intrigue.

headline: ‘South Park’ Creators Set on Mormon Musical
text: A long-gestating musical from the “South Park” creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone, and Robert Lopez, a co-creator of “Avenue Q,” is bound for Broadway in March 2011, its producers said Wednesday. Continuing the “South Park” tradition of satirizing every organized religion from Roman Catholicism to Scientology, the musical, called “The Book of Mormon,” will juxtapose a tale of two young Mormon missionaries with the story of Joseph Smith, who founded Mormonism in the 19th century (a topic that “South Park” has covered). Mr. Stone and Mr. Parker wrote the book, music and lyrics with Mr. Lopez, a Tony Award winner for “Avenue Q.” Mr. Parker will direct with Jason Moore (“Avenue Q,” “Shrek the Musical”). Scott Rudin and Anne Garefino will produce “The Book of Mormon”; no cast or theater has been announced. In January Off Broadway’s New York Theater Workshop announced plans to produce the musical this August and September. A workshop spokesman noted that “Rent” and two Claudia Shear comedies began there, adding, “I am sorry this show isn’t following the same route.” A spokesman for the Broadway production said: “The workshop did help with a previous reading, but then a decision was made to go directly to Broadway.”

headline: Herzog in a Cave
text: Can there be a 3-D movie about a work of art that predates the discovery of perspective? If anyone can make such a film, surely Werner Herzog can. The British newspaper The Guardian reported that Mr. Herzog, the director of “Grizzly Man” and “Fitzcarraldo,” is working on a movie that will take audiences inside a French cave containing drawings that are more than 30,000 years old. In a video interview on the blog of Roger Ebert, the film critic of The Chicago Sun-Times, Mr. Herzog said that he had been given permission to film inside the Chauvet Cave in the Ardèche region of France, whose walls are decorated with more than 300 images of rhinoceroses, bison and other animals. (Due to the risk of damage to the drawings, the site is usually restricted to visitors.) “It’s still tough to bring equipment down,” Mr. Herzog said. He added: “We are doing something nobody has done with 3-D.”

headline: Museum’s Deal Raises Hope and Eyebrows in Washington
text: Selling real estate can be quite an ordeal these days, but the Corcoran Gallery of Art has found a buyer for a large piece of property in a section of southwest Washington where construction has all but stalled in the economic downturn.

headline: Print Mixology
text: TAKING in the parade of patterns at the spring fashion shows was like watching seven rival marching bands converge at a four-way intersection — talk about your clash of symbols. A gal could get carried away by the devil-take-the-hindmost attitude. Does anything and everything go? Can you really wear polka dots with paisley? Can an exotic ikat waltz with a chintzy floral? Will you look like the belle of the ball — or on your way to Bellevue?

headline: Officials Say Iran Could Make Bomb Fuel in a Year
text: WASHINGTON — Two of the nation’s top military officials said Wednesday that Iran could produce bomb-grade fuel for at least one nuclear weapon within a year, but would most likely need two to five years to manufacture a workable atomic bomb.

headline: A Paler Shade of White for Passport Photos
text: In a couple of weeks, I’m on a cruise ship to Bermuda. (I know—life’s rough.) That’s what brought me to the U.S. Passport Office near my home, to renew my children’s passports.

headline: Milan Report | Design Vertigo
text: In contrast to its live-demo, let’s-put-on-a-show “Craft Punk” exhibition last year, Design Miami and Fendi’s 2010 collaboration, “Design Vertigo,” at Spazio Fendi, is a far more cerebral affair. Four site-specific installations aim to highlight the ways in which designers are venturing outside the bounds of traditional practice and joining forces with unlikely partners.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 5 through April 12 with 1,580 adults throughout the United States, including 881 who said they were “supporters of the Tea Party movement.”

headline: ‘The Great Oom’
text: Pierre Arnold Bernard, the first American yogi and a spiritual hero to members of the Lost Generation, was conducting a tour of his property for Joseph Mitchell of the New York World-Telegram. "A place of mystery," Mitchell called it. "On summer afternoons townspeople crowd about the estate and look through the edges as the solemn students of Sanskrit go through their Oriental calisthenics. Small boys dare each other to go through the gates."

headline: Poll Finds Tea Party Backers Wealthier  and More Educated
text: Tea Party supporters are wealthier and more well-educated than the general public, and are no more or less afraid of falling into a lower socioeconomic class, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Iowa Swami Who Beguiled the Jazz Age
text: Robert Love lives in Nyack, N.Y., in a cottage built in 1927 that has an Egyptian ankh carved in granite over its front door. The house next door is adorned with an ouroboros, an image of a snake eating its tail. Mr. Love wondered what chapter in local history might have produced these leftover symbols. Answering that question led him to investigate the career of Pierre Bernard, the P. T. Barnum of Hudson Valley yoga.

headline: U.S. Tightens Requirements for Energy Star Certification
text: After critical audits, the federal government said Wednesday that it would substantially tighten the certification process for products bearing the Energy Star label, its stamp of approval for an energy-efficient product.

headline: McGrady Looks to Return or Retirement
text: TORONTO — In one breath, Tracy McGrady spoke of retirement. In another, he spoke of his confidence in returning to the N.B.A. at full strength.

headline: Another View: We Need a ‘Blankfein Amendment’
text: Lance E. Lindblom and Laura Shaffer of the Nathan Cummings Foundation argue that huge paychecks for top corporate executives are out of whack with reality — especially at Goldman Sachs.

headline: Library of Congress Will Save Tweets
text: Not everyone would think that the actor Ashton Kutcher’s Twitter musings on his daily doings constitute part of “the universal body of human knowledge.”

headline: Dream Girl
text: Much as we might rag on it, the awful truth must be looked at head-on: Reality TV, that fiction of verisimilitude, is, even for people who read W. G. Sebald and enjoy grim Scottish films with subtitles, supernally addictive. Not always and (let’s hope!) not forever, but in the right now of it. Sure, sometimes one is simply not in the mood for all that virtual id, the jawing and bitching, the glaring white teeth and the faux familiarity. And it is possible to envision a day in the not-too-far-off future when one might return to an old-fashioned pastime, like doing one’s nails, over the vicarious pleasures of comparing and contrasting the suntans and blown-out blondness that beset the Real Housewives of Orange County. Meanwhile, though, one stays tuned, fascinated by the mindless commotion, caught on the hook of the souped-up dramas that barge into every episode, unsure whether one is watching a version of oneself or a counter-version or perhaps an alternate version. Which brings me to the question: Who might one be if one were to be played by a reality-show star? Who might one want to be?

headline: Scientists Say Tests Show Dangers in So-Called Bushmeat
text: Scientists who have begun testing bushmeat — meat from African wild game that is often carried through customs in luggage, or shipped by mail — say they have discovered viruses related to H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

headline: At Coachella, Strong Start to Season of Festivals
text: This year the promoters of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Indio, Calif., gambled that even in a bruised economy fans would not be able to resist the lure of a three-day weekend of connoisseur alt-rock, hip-hop and dance music in the desert sun.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Dean Kamen
text: In this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein finds out why Twitter app developers are worried. She speaks with Claire Cain Miller, The Times technology reporter who covers Twitter, about the company’s moves toward building its own tools for the microblogging service, and the concerns among developers who fear that Twitter might turn into a competitor. Independent developers have created some 70,000 apps that let users do things like track messages on cellphones, monitor multiple Twitter accounts, shorten link addresses and post photos on the service.Dean Kamen, inventor of the Segway, is also a strong advocate of promoting science and technology education. J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Mr. Kamen about his own early inspirations and about the nonprofit group he founded to encourage interest in these fields among the young. The organization, called First  (For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology), holds its 19th annual championship, with competitions in robotics, gaming and Lego construction, April 15-17 at the Georgia Dome in Atlanta.You might expect your brand new computer to have a clean hard drive, only to find programs installed on it that you didn’t ask for, or trial versions of software that pester you to buy the full version or sign up for a service. There is a name for that, as Pedro Rafael Rosado explains in his regularly featured audio essay on tech terms.Also on the show, Ms. Biersdorfer rounds up tech news of the week, including updates for the Google Docs service, a new fleet of MacBook Pro laptops from Apple; Neflix streaming movies via Wii game consoles; and prepackaged movies on portable Seagate drives. And if you can’t wait for baseball season to start, her tech tip of the week can help you get set: MySportsCal lets you download your favorite team’s schedule right into your Outlook, iCal or Google calendar.

headline: Your Financial Situation, in the Palm of Your Hand
text: April 15 can be a good day to reflect on all the poor financial decisions you made the year before — a financial day of atonement, of sorts. And it can be a good day to resolve to do better.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Is there any richer ore for writers than the family? A number of this month’s newly published books mine that vein, whether it’s looking at the current variety (you know, a recovering alcoholic mom, her child from her first marriage, plus a stepdad) or more traditional forms from the past (a Tommy-gun toting gangster and his moll, undone by her love for grandma). Ah, the ties that bind.

headline: U.S. Leads New Bid to Phase Out Whale Hunting
text: WASHINGTON — The United States is leading an effort by a handful of antiwhaling nations to broker an agreement that would limit and ultimately end whale hunting by Japan, Norway and Iceland, according to people involved with the negotiations.

headline: Making Panoramic Photos in the Computer
text: Going Wide

headline: A Jazz Pianist Who Has Honed His Style While Hiding in Plain Sight
text: Sam Yahel played his own song “Truth and Beauty” around the middle of his early set on Tuesday night at the Village Vanguard. In the past he’s recorded it on Hammond organ, in a different group, with saxophone and drums. Here he was playing it on the piano, with the bassist Matt Penman and the drummer Jochen Rückert, and it had a different personality: first more tense, with its crowded contrapuntal opening, then more permissive and abstract. Lots of space opened up. Mr. Yahel played straight notes over swung grooves and slow phrases over cruisingly fast bass and drums. The music felt suspended and comfortable, and kept its cool.

headline: W.Va. Mine Inspections Are Ordered
text: Gov. Joe Manchin III of West Virginia on Wednesday ordered the emergency inspection of all underground coal mines in the state in response to last week’s mining explosion in Raleigh County that killed 29 miners and injured 2. Mr. Manchin also called for all coal companies in the state to stop production on Friday to use the day for a review of their safety procedures.

headline: Comments by Cardinal on Sexuality Create a Stir
text: ROME — Tensions rose on Wednesday over comments made Monday by the Vatican secretary of state, Cardinal Tarcisio Bertone, who called homosexuality “a pathology” and linked it to pedophilia. The comments came as the Vatican was trying to calm a scandal over sexual abuse by priests.

headline: The Radical Center: The History of an Idea
text: At a time when politics has become an almost ­minute-by-minute spectacle, political thinkers who try to discern a sweeping interpretive pattern in current events or to predict where those events may be heading are likely to find their work evaluated in terms dismayingly like those applied to candidates and strategists. One wrong guess, or an abrupt change in the political weather, can make even an illuminating political book seem as irrelevant as a bungled campaign.

headline: The Color Index
text: New York women are ushering in spring with color.

headline: On Location: The Muralist
text: The artist Matthew Willey has covered the walls of his East Village apartment with murals.

headline: A Lengthy Tour of Airport Hell, Then a Successful Trip to Reno
text: First look at the West hand and the auction. What would you lead against three no-trump, given that it is a match-pointed pair game?

headline: Council Passes Fare Increase and Vacation for Carriage Horses
text: Concluding, for now, a debate that brought vivid responses from both sides, the City Council passed a bill Wednesday to increase the fare for horse-drawn carriage rides while improving some conditions for the horses.

headline: Congress Asks for Sanctions Against Iran
text: A bipartisan group of 363 House lawmakers sent a letter to President Obama on Wednesday urging him to impose “crippling” sanctions on Iran with or without United Nations action.

headline: A High Note for ‘Glee’
text: The midseason return of “Glee,” which added Jonathan Groff and Idina Menzel as rivals (and love interests) for the Fox show’s lead characters, earned record ratings on Tuesday, following an Elvis Presley-theme episode of “American Idol.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, about 13.7 million viewers tuned in to “Glee,” and “Idol” dominated the ratings as usual with 20.6 million viewers. CBS and ABC finished in a virtual tie for second place. On ABC, “Lost” drew 9.5 million viewers following the results episode of “Dancing With the Stars” (13.4 million), while CBS broadcast an all-repeat line-up. NBC ranked fourth, averaging 8.3 million viewers for “The Biggest Loser.”

headline: Signs of Confidence Growing in M.&A. Market
text: Corporate executives from around the globe feel more confident about making deals, with many of them planning mergers and acquisitions in the near future, according to a new survey of business confidence by Ernst & Young and the Economist Intelligence Unit.

headline: Grow Your Own Mushrooms
text: Don’t underestimate the mushroom. Yes, it often fancies dead things and dung, but the fungus is a biological kingdom unto itself. In the riot of the woods or the harbor of the backyard, mushrooms follow their own rules in their own good time.

headline: Do-It-Yourself Mushrooms
text: HAVE you seen the Mushroom Man? No? Well, have you looked in the Secret Garden? It’s a real place, you know, a half-hidden community garden at the corner of Linden Street and Broadway, in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

headline: Embracing a Life of Solitude
text: FOR the last 16 years, Nick Fahey has been living on an island in the San Juan archipelago north of Puget Sound, in Washington state, where his only full-time companion is a 26-year-old quarter horse called Ig. Mr. Fahey, 67, lives in a cabin on 100 wooded acres that has been in his family since 1930; it has no refrigerator, but there is electricity generated by solar panels, so he has light and can charge his cellphone.

headline: In the East Village, a Muralist’s Tiny Sanctuary
text: THE very personal painting on the living room wall of the muralist Matthew Willey’s East Village apartment is hard to miss: four winged horses, at full gallop, ascending toward the ceiling, as if to burst out of the apartment. It is possible someone or something is behind them, for they are in harness, but what is driving them, other than the rays of sun, is impossible to tell.

headline: Heath Ceramics Opens a Bay Area Store
text: Heath Ceramics finally has a store in the Bay Area. Last week, the 62-year-old company based in Sausalito, Calif., opened a 500-square-foot shop in the Ferry Building Marketplace in San Francisco. The company tapped Commune Design, the same firm it used for its Los Angeles shop, to design this space. “The design is highly functional and has a great balance of color and materials, but still lets the product take center stage,” said Catherine Bailey, Heath Ceramics’ co-owner and creative director. “The wood mixed with ceramic speaks to the straightforward nature of our message, and the orange steel speaks to our love of contrast and color.” The shop will sell a mix of new and vintage Heath pieces, along with factory seconds (delivered weekly). It will also have a live-feed video of the factory floor in Sausalito, so visitors can see how the products are made. Heath Ceramics, 1 Ferry Building, Suite 12, San Francisco, (415) 399-9284 or heathceramics.com.

headline: A Kitchen Island Is Also a Bar
text: “Some people have cooking islands; some people have bars,” said Scott Hudson, the chief executive of the Henrybuilt Corporation, a manufacturer of spare, minimal custom kitchen systems of wood, steel and Corian, in Seattle. But what if people want a cooking island that doubles as a bar?

headline: A Party for Scott Sanders’s ‘Picture Perfect’
text: THURSDAY night is gallery trolling night in Chelsea, so it was not surprising last week to find a crowd upstairs at the Max Lang gallery, examining the early works of the interior designer Scott Sanders.

headline: Filmmakers Turn Old Books Into a Couch
text: Freudians would call it massive displacement: a procrastinating novelist with a book due exiles himself to a writing jail in a seaside cabin. While there, he takes a violent dislike to the sofa in the room he’s chosen to write in.

headline: Wall Decals Help to Hide Cracks
text: Instead of seeing a crack on your wall as a problem that needs to be repaired, consider it an opportunity for decoration. That’s the idea behind TakeBreak, a set of wall decals created by the Taiwanese design firm AHead Creative that can transform a crack into a flowering plant inhabited by birds, snails and butterflies.

headline: Sales of Paola Lenti and Cec LePage
text: At Cec LePage’s first sale, through April 25, samples and artist’s proofs of Ms. LePage’s hand-carved Lucite furniture, vases, candleholders and bowls are marked down 30 to 70 percent (the Pucci vase, regularly $558, is $334; the Taka table, above right, originally $1,250, is $750; and assorted candleholders, above left, regularly $198 to $300, are $60 to $180); LePage New York, 72 Thompson Street (Broome Street), (212) 966-2646 or lepageny.com.

headline: Bull Market? Try Peacock
text: FASHION, they say, is an index of change, registering shifts in confidence and mood too subtle to glean from the rise and the fall of the Dow. No need to tell Natasha Jen, who tarried on Mott Street one weekend earlier this month taking in the parade of women showing off their latest buys: effusively colorful skirts and frocks in jungly hues and covered in pansies, cheetah markings and tribal geometrics that evoked Ivory Coast.

headline: Twitter Makes Itself More Useful
text: Chirp is Twitter’s first developer conference. It is also a coming out party, as Twitter the start-up turns into Twitter the big company, with more spin, more polish and more controversy.

headline: Polling the Tea Party
text: A New York Times/CBS News poll offers a glimpse at the demographics of the emerging Tea Party movement's supporters.

headline: Jobless Aid Clears Hurdle in Senate
text: It took two attempts, but Senate Democrats on Wednesday cleared the way for final approval of additional unemployment pay for out-of-work Americans who are exhausting their standard benefits.

headline: Reaping Profits From Poland’s Tragedy
text: WARSAW — By 11:54 a.m. Saturday, less than three hours after President Lech Kaczynski’s plane had crashed in Russia, killing all 96 people on board, one opportunistic Pole had already manufactured 50 T-shirts emblazoned with the Polish flag and “RIP” and was peddling them on the Internet for $8.50 each, tax and delivery fees not included.

headline: The Cheat: Salad Day
text: “One of the saddest things is that the only thing a man can do for eight hours a day, day after day, is work.” This was William Faulkner talking, 1956, an interview with Jean Stein for The Paris Review. He was reminiscing about his early days living in New Orleans and working, he said, as little as possible. Faulkner was wistful about it. He’d have preferred to do other things than paint houses or write during his waking hours. It was unfortunate, he said, that “you can’t eat eight hours a day.”

headline: Milestones: Elena Kagan
text: An interactive timeline of Elena Kagan's life and career.

headline: Stints in Court May Yield Clues to a Style
text: WASHINGTON — Two weeks ago, Solicitor General Elena Kagan, a leading contender for appointment to the Supreme Court, presented her sixth argument there. She bantered easily with the justices, and she seemed to have a special rapport with Justice Antonin Scalia, at one point responding to a question from him with one of her own.

headline: Despite Ruling, F.C.C. Says It Will Move Forward on Expanding Broadband
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission told a Congressional panel on Wednesday that a recent court ruling that the agency lacked authority to regulate the Internet should not prevent it from carrying out its plan to broadly expand the country’s high-speed Internet service.

headline: Color and the City
text: 12:54 a.m. | Updated We asked readers to send us photos of outfits with multiple patterns.  Here is a selection of what we received.

headline: Toyota Deals Quickly With GX 460 Problem
text: DETROIT — The chief engineer in Japan for the Lexus GX 460 sport utility vehicle was roused from bed early Tuesday by a telephone call from Toyota engineers in the United States.

headline: Yankees’ Mariano Rivera Is the Last No. 42
text: She had long wanted to meet him, but when they finally shook hands this past winter it was Mariano Rivera who was captivated by the presence of Rachel Robinson. He wears the number. She lived the legacy.

headline: What We’re Reading: Twitter Developers’ Angst
text: The technology editors and reporters of The New York Times hopped from Twitter and Google to Zillow and cable TV, stopping for videos of iPad-playing cats and robot cars along the way. Our reading list:

text: WASHINGTON — Sixteen years after the Contract With America, say hello to the Contract From America.

text: 2 tablespoons lemon juice

headline: Slightly Creamier Sunday-Salad Dressing
text: 2 tablespoons red-wine vinegar

headline: Some Thoughts About E-Reading
text: As always, I am reading several books at a time  actually, several stacks. One is the stack of heirloom books by my bed, which begins with the engaging and soon-to-be-published “Camel” by Robert Irwin and works haphazardly outward to Rose Macaulay’s “The Towers of Trebizond” and Bronislaw Malinowski’s “A Diary in the Strict Sense of the Term.”

headline: Italianate Sunday-Salad Dressing
text: 1 tablespoon lemon juice

headline: Big Country Salad
text: 1/4 pound slab bacon, cut into 1-inch-long lardons

headline: Jordan Steps to the Line in Charlotte
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Whenever cigar smoke wafts through the door and floats over the cubicles where various Charlotte Bobcats employees work, it means the boss is in. Michael Jordan’s office sits close to an exit, and from there he can easily step outside to a balcony and gaze down to where the Charlotte Bobcats, the team he recently purchased for $275 million, practice on the floor of the Time Warner Cable Arena.

headline: A Fairer Way to Count
text: Maryland struck a blow for electoral fairness this week with a new law requiring that prison inmates be counted at their home addresses when legislative districts are redrawn after the 2010 census. Other states should follow.

headline: Zimbabwe’s Accidental Triumph
text: IN the midst of a wave of post-election political violence in Zimbabwe in 2008, Brian James, a white farmer who had been evicted from his property years earlier during President Robert Mugabe’s seizure of white-owned lands, found himself surrounded by a throng of black Zimbabweans in downtown Mutare, my hometown. The 50-strong crowd danced, sang and chanted political slogans for more than 20 minutes before Mr. James was finally able to raise his hand, thank them for their support and announce that he was honored to have been elected mayor of the country’s third-largest city.

headline: As Playoffs Approach, Teams Weigh Risks of Playing Their Stars
text: The N.B.A. closed its regular season Wednesday night with an abundance of drama and a shortage of superstars. There was some concern, albeit muted, about that last part.

headline: Sudan’s Growth Buoys a Leader Reviled Elsewhere
text: TABGA, Sudan — From the highway, this farming village looks like yet another poor, mud-walled settlement baking in the stupefying heat.

headline: Twitter Hints About What Developers Should Build
text: Software developers who build Twitter apps and Web sites arrived at Chirp, the developer conference in San Francisco this week, with trepidation about whether Twitter’s future plans would put them out of business.

text: When the Miami Dolphins traded for Denver receiver Brandon Marshall on Wednesday, it was the latest headline-making deal in what has been an unusually active off-season for trades.

text: To the Editor:
