text: Citing the free-agent outfielder Jermaine Dye, Minnesota Twins second baseman Orlando Hudson implied that baseball ignored older black players.

headline: Bloggingheads: Bullied to Death?
text: Emily Bazelon, left, of Slate and Ann Althouse of the University of Wisconsin Law School debate the Phoebe Prince case.

headline: The Wait List Is the Hardest Part
text: Chapel Hill, N.C.

headline: Rescue of Greece Faces Test in Germany
text: FRANKFURT — The German Parliament would probably need to approve the country’s contribution to a Greek rescue package, a spokesman for the German finance minister said Wednesday. It was another indication of the complexities that would be involved in the first bailout of a country in the euro zone.

headline: Supreme Club
text: At last count, there were about 200 law schools in the United States accredited by the American Bar Association, but apparently only two of them — Harvard and Yale — can be a path to serving on the highest court in the land.

headline: New York Archbishop Praised, Though Tests Await
text: At times during his first year as the 10th Roman Catholic archbishop of New York, Timothy M. Dolan seemed to be everywhere at once, like a presidential candidate with momentum in the early primaries.

headline: Rain Multiplies Woes of Rio de Janeiro’s Squatters
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The incessant rain that killed at least 251 people last week has raised lingering questions about this Olympic city’s emergency readiness and revived a long-dormant debate over the poor squatter communities that have sprung up in areas at risk of flooding and landslides.

headline: M.L.B. Names New Medical Director
text: About a month after Dr. Elliot Pellman stepped down from the N.F.L.’s controversial committee on concussions, Major League Baseball announced on Tuesday that Pellman had been replaced as its chief medical director.

headline: A Talent to Amuse
text: WE are in a town car heading down Park Avenue from one party to another. Leigh Lezark, the Misshapes D.J., is pulling at the top of her slinky ivory pants in the back seat. Geordon Nicol, her partner, is riding shotgun. Squished on the middle hump, typing on a BlackBerry, is Derek Blasberg, a 27-year-old writer who looks, in a white one-button suit and bucks given to him by Burberry, as if he is wearing a Tom Wolfe costume, minus the hat. Talk is about work and travel and work-related travel.

headline: Take Five: LINES Ballet, and Porchlight All Stars
text: Performance  | Alonzo King LINES Ballet and the San Francisco Opera Adler FellowsThe latest cross-disciplinary collaboration from the local dance troupe Alonzo King LINES Ballet unites 10 of the company’s dancers with six singers from the San Francisco Opera’s Adler Fellowship program. The inaugural partnership features choreography to vocal works by such composers as Handel, Schubert, Brahms, Fauré, Strauss and John Sheppard. “Rasa,” a 2007 dance work choreographed to a musical score by the Indian tabla player Zakir Hussain, rounds out the program. Through April 25. Thursday at 7 p.m., Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m., Sunday at 5 p.m., Novellus Theater, Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, 700 Howard Street, San Francisco.

headline: The Curious Case of Journalist Josh Wolf, Round Two
text: Josh Wolf, 27, an independent video journalist whose name already occupies a footnote in the annals of press freedom, has run afoul with authorities again.

headline: Rough Start for Big Name in Conn. Senate Race
text: HARTFORD — Richard Blumenthal’s campaign for the Senate was supposed to be a glide. Nothing and no one could stop him.

headline: Mets Showing Some Encouraging Signs
text: DENVER — The signs of life appeared early when the Mets somehow managed to take a lead for the first time in five days. More signs materialized later when the manager argued a call, when his team closed the gap to a run in the eighth, and when they scratched out the tying run in the ninth.

headline: With Cars as Meth Labs, Evidence Litters Roads
text: ELKHART, Ind. — The toxic garbage, often in clumps, blends in easily with the more mundane litter along rural roads and highways here: used plastic water bottles, old tubing, dirty gloves, empty packs of medicine. But it is a nuisance with truly explosive potential, and evidence of something more than simply a disregard for keeping the streets clean.

headline: Undercurrents of Violence at the World Cup
text: How easy it is to forget that athletes at their peak are, by the very nature of their tasks, young but expected to be wise in their event, world-traveled but isolated and vulnerable.

headline: Two Experts on Manhattan Primates
text: A WOMAN descended from the hero who unified Germany was chatting with a woman descended from a Puerto Rican matriarch raised in a family of 14. The setting was a cocktail party on the terrace of the Grand Suite at the Pierre and the subject was diet, always fit fuel for discussion in a town where startling numbers go hungry by choice.

headline: Drawn to a Larger Scale
text: HOW did a 32-year-old college dropout from the bayou of Louisiana, with no formal training in art — well, to be frank, no training at all — end up with a one-man show in a New York gallery and a client list that includes Robert Downey Jr. and Orlando Bloom?

headline: ‘Crocs’ and ‘Style’ in the Same Breath
text: IN a new television commercial for Crocs footwear, an actress wearing black high-heel shoes enters an apartment building and wearily climbs a flight of stairs. As she opens the door to her unit, two small red animated characters based on the Crocs original clog model, with stubby arms and legs and blinking ventilation holes representing eyes, scamper toward her like puppies.

headline: City Is Urged to Evaluate Foster Care
text: At 21, a young person in foster care in New York is officially out of the child welfare system.

headline: Don’t Get Gravy on the First Lady’s Gown
text: FIRST Lady Michelle Obama is now officially a fashion plate.

headline: Ex-Student Sues Brown Over Rape Accusation
text: A former student has sued Brown University in federal court, saying university officials interfered with his efforts to clear his name after another student, the daughter of a prominent Brown alumnus and donor, accused him of rape.

headline: Obama Speech Signals a U.S. Shift on Middle East
text: WASHINGTON — It was just a phrase at the end of President Obama’s news conference on Tuesday, but it was a stark reminder of a far-reaching shift in how the United States views the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and how aggressively it might push for a peace agreement.

headline: Every (Wild) Dog Has Its Day
text: HWANGE NATIONAL PARK, Zimbabwe

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. The Supreme Court vacancy. If Obama is really after diversity, he’ll hire a WASP.

headline: U.S. Falls Short in Measure of Future Math Teachers
text: America’s future math teachers, on average, earned a C on a new test comparing their skills with their counterparts in 15 other countries, significantly outscoring college students in the Philippines and Chile but placing far below those in educationally advanced nations like Singapore and Taiwan.

headline: Jurors Hint at Prosecutors’ Hurdle in L.I. Hate Crime Case
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — Moments after a judge excused four alternate jurors from the courtroom, one of them did something that would ease the mind of any defense lawyer whose client was on trial for murder: She mouthed the words “good luck” to the defendant.

headline: Russian Authorities Search H.P.’s Offices
text: Hewlett-Packard said on Wednesday that Russian authorities searched the company’s offices in Moscow, but it did not disclose the reason for the raid.

headline: Wheels With Women in Mind
text: THE graphic designer Julie Hirschfeld had a simple manifesto for Adeline Adeline, her bicycle boutique for women: “No spandex!” The result is a store aimed at fashionistas who wouldn’t consider Lycra bike shorts, or ditching their Louboutins just because they are on two wheels. Each bike is a work of art, from the simplistically beautiful Pashley at left ($995), to the curvaceous Abici Sveltina Donna ($1,850).

headline: Just for You, Sarah Jessica, but ...
text: THE azure front-pleated Calvin Klein Collection dress that Sarah Jessica Parker wears on the May cover of Vogue was supposed to be a one-off, a modification of a dress that Francisco Costa had created for this fall.

headline: Top Hats, Bottom Prices
text: EUGENIA KIM is selling a limited-time hat collection at Target, starting April 18, all under $20. Ms. Kim’s hats, spotted on celebrities like Cameron Diaz, usually go for up to $300. The easy, breezy toppers come in cloche, fedora, sun hat, bucket hat, newsboy and pillbox silhouettes.

headline: Old Is Good, Cheaper Is Better
text: NEW WORLD ORDER, an East Village store beloved by fashion editors, is having a sale of its lush vintage clothes from designers like Oscar de la Renta, Thierry Mugler and Balenciaga. The store owner, Renee Bejil, a fashion stylist and serious collector, said that he is clearing out the old old to bring in the new old.

headline: Immigration Officer Guilty in Sexual Coercion Case
text: A federal immigration officer who was caught on tape demanding sex in exchange for a green card pleaded guilty to all the charges against him in Supreme Court in Queens on Wednesday in expectation of a prison sentence of one and a half to four and a half years.

headline: City in Oregon Considers Beacon for ‘the Big One’
text: CANNON BEACH, Ore. — Well before recent earthquakes shook Haiti, Chile and the California border with Mexico, this corner of the West Coast was trying harder than many places to prepare for the Big One. It has upgraded its warning signs and sirens, refined evacuation routes and reassessed bridges and buildings.

headline: After the Summit
text: President Obama’s nuclear security summit meeting drew long overdue attention to the terrifying danger that terrorists could buy or steal the makings for a weapon from the world’s far-too-vulnerable nuclear stocks.

headline: Celebrating the Joys of April 15
text: The Internal Revenue Service needs to get way better at marketing.

headline: Denzel Washington and Viola Davis
text: The actors, who star in the Broadway revival of August Wilson's "Fences," talk about the playwright's legacy and their early days as theater actors.

headline: Ladies’ Man
text: “Aht Uh Mi Hed”— Shuggie Otis

headline: Wall Street Must Recover Before City Can Overcome Recession, Economists Say
text: The recession may be ending in the New York metropolitan area, but if history is any guide, no substantial recovery can begin until Wall Street stops shedding jobs and starts hiring again.

headline: Is Marriage Good for Your Health?
text: In 1858, a British epidemiologist named William Farr set out to study what he called the “conjugal condition” of the people of France. He divided the adult population into three distinct categories: the “married,” consisting of husbands and wives; the “celibate,” defined as the bachelors and spinsters who had never married; and finally the “widowed,” those who had experienced the death of a spouse. Using birth, death and marriage records, Farr analyzed the relative mortality rates of the three groups at various ages. The work, a groundbreaking study that helped establish the field of medical statistics, showed that the unmarried died from disease “in undue proportion” to their married counterparts. And the widowed, Farr found, fared worst of all.

headline: Health and the Happy Marriage
text: When people think of marriage they often think of love, companionship and family. But what many don’t realize is that the health of your marriage is inextricably linked to the health of your body.

headline: St. Vincent’s Files for Bankruptcy
text: St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan filed its long-expected petition for bankruptcy on Wednesday, indicating that its largest unsecured creditor was a federal pension insurance agency.

headline: Extension of Unemployment Benefits Advances
text: Senate Democrats on Wednesday cleared the way for final approval of additional unemployment pay for out-of-work Americans who are exhausting their standard benefits. The Senate voted 60 to 40 to exempt the legislation from budget challenges and Democrats said they hoped to finish the now $18 billion measure as early as Thursday night. Senator George Voinovich of Ohio was the sole Republican to break ranks, joining Democrats and providing the crucial 60th vote. Democrats failed in their first attempt to waive the budget rules, coming up one vote short since Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, was away at a funeral. The Senate held the vote open Wednesday night to allow Mr. Leahy time to return and cast his vote.

headline: Expiring Tax Cuts’ Fate Has Parties Strategizing
text: WASHINGTON — Democrats for years have vowed to let the Bush administration’s tax cuts for the wealthiest taxpayers expire as scheduled after this year, but election-year politics and the economy’s fragility could complicate matters in Congress.

headline: Fund Proposed to Prevent Some Teacher Firings
text: Senator Tom Harkin, an Iowa Democrat, introduced legislation on Wednesday to create a $23 billion jobs fund to prevent teachers from being fired because of budget shortfalls. Job losses at public schools and colleges may top 100,000 in the next school year, Mr. Harkin said. The legislation needs to be passed now because school districts are making budget decisions this month, he said. The fund would supplement the $100 billion for education in the $862 billion stimulus package.

headline: Groups Protest Segregation of Inmates With H.I.V.
text: In Alabama, prisoners infected with H.I.V. must wear white armbands and live in special units. In South Carolina, infected men have blue dots on their badges and are housed in a maximum-security prison; female prisoners carry the name of the H.I.V./AIDS dorm on their uniforms. The two states are the last to segregate and put blanket restrictions on H.I.V.-positive inmates and on Wednesday, rights groups called for change, saying the policies violate federal and international guidelines. Infected prisoners’ chances of early release and help in re-entering society are harmed as well, according to a report issued by the American Civil Liberties Union and Human Rights Watch. South Carolina bars them from participating in work-release, for example, and Alabama limits such opportunities. Prison officials in the two states say that segregation is necessary to prevent the spread of H.I.V. and provide specialized medical care.

headline: The K.S.M. Files
text: Watching Attorney General Eric Holder struggle on Wednesday to answer senators’ questions about the detention and trial of terrorism suspects made us nostalgic for the old days  back in 2009  when the United States was making progress toward cleaning up the mess President George W. Bush made with his detention policies.

headline: Book Details Spitzer’s Fall and His Wife’s Anguish
text: ALBANY — Last month, an insider’s account of Eliot Spitzer’s turbulent career hit bookshelves. Next week, a journalistic take on Mr. Spitzer will debut, “Rough Justice: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer,” by Peter Elkind, an editor at large at Fortune magazine.

headline: John Schoenherr, Children’s Book Illustrator, Dies at 74
text: John Schoenherr, a Caldecott Medal-winning illustrator who for a half-century produced painterly, exquisitely detailed images of creatures from this world and others, died on April 8. He was 74 and lived in Delaware Township, N.J.

headline: Army Corps of Engineers Said to Err on Flooding Risk
text: An attempt by the Army Corps of Engineers to correct old data on water flows in the Mississippi may have led to underestimates of the current risk of flooding along the river, scientists argue in a new study.

headline: Helen Ranney, Pioneer in Sickle Cell Research, Dies at 89
text: Dr. Helen M. Ranney, a hematologist whose experiments in the 1950s elucidated the genetic basis of sickle cell disease, an inherited form of anemia that affects one in 500 African-Americans, died on April 5 in San Diego. She was 89.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 14, 2010

headline: Prosecutors Offer Blagojevich Evidence
text: CHICAGO — Just as Barack Obama was elected president, Rod R. Blagojevich, whose job it was as governor of Illinois to appoint Mr. Obama’s replacement to the United States Senate, began a frenetic, dizzying campaign to get something — an administration post, more than a million dollars, a high-paying job — in exchange for the appointment, a document released Wednesday by federal prosecutors suggests.

headline: Amputee Wins Sullivan
text: The ultramarathoner and amputee Amy Palmiero-Winters has won the Sullivan Award as the United States’ top amateur athlete.

headline: Fathers Tied to Deaths of 2 Babies
text: Two men in Queens have been arrested in recent days in connection with the deaths of their baby sons.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about the Whitney Museum of American Art, using information from a publicist for the Whitney, misstated the museum’s policy on endowment spending. The museum restricts the use of its endowment fund to cover yearly operating expenses to 5 percent of the fund’s value, not 5 percent of the interest income generated by the fund.

headline: Indonesia: Protests After Rumor That Tomb Would Be Moved
text: Hundreds of protesters clashed with riot police on Wednesday in northern Jakarta after rumors spread that the city planned to remove the tomb of a Muslim cleric from the area. Two people were killed in the clashes and the death toll could increase, a deputy national police spokesman, Col. Zaenuri Lubis, said, according to the Associated Press. Dozens of others were injured, including a police officer whose hand was cut off and another whose stomach was slashed, according to local television stations. The violence erupted near the city's biggest port, away from the city center. The A.P. also reported that a city spokesman Cucu Kurnia said: "We did not intend to demolish the tomb, but we want to evict the illegal settlers. In fact, the local government wanted to preserve or restore the tomb."

headline: Tense School Meeting After Charges
text: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass. —  Three parents were removed by the police on Wednesday after speaking at a tense meeting of the South Hadley School Committee, which assembled for the first time since six students were indicted in the bullying of a 15-year-old girl, Phoebe Prince, who committed suicide Jan. 14.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a listing on Tuesday of the winners of the Pulitzer Prizes omitted, in some copies, a finalist for editorial writing. Besides Marie Dillon of The Chicago Tribune and John G. Carlton of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, John McCormick, also of The Tribune, was a finalist.

headline: Arrest but No Motive in Strangling of Queens Woman
text: The victim, who went by the name Amanda, was a 29-year-old transgender woman, born male, who had yet to undergo a sex change operation. She advertised her services as a prostitute, a law enforcement official said.

headline: Congo: Rapes by Civilians Rise Sharply, Study Says
text: Rapes by civilians sharply rose in recent years in the conflict-racked eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, where armed groups have been preying upon women for years, a new study shows. According to research commissioned by Oxfam and conducted by the Harvard Humanitarian Initiative, the total number of sexual assault cases handled by a major Congolese gynecological hospital decreased between 2004 and 2008. But the number of rapes committed by civilians increased 17-fold. "Sexual violence has become more normal in civilian life," said Susan Bartels, one of the researchers. "The scale of rape over Congo's years of war has made this crime seem more acceptable." The researchers interviewed more than 4,000 women who had been raped and sought treatment at Panzi Hospital in Bukavu. The study will be made public Thursday, and Oxfam officials said total rape cases likely were on the rise again in 2009 and 2010.

headline: Brazil: Judge Suspends Awarding of Dam Contracts
text: A federal judge on Wednesday suspended an auction scheduled for April 20 to award construction contracts for a huge hydroelectric dam in the Amazon that environmentalists say would devastate indigenous communities along the Xingu River, according to a court Web site. The judge, Antonio Carlos Almeida Campelo, agreed with a federal prosecutor in Para State, who argued that awarding the contracts would violate environmental laws. The project has attracted worldwide attention from nongovernmental organizations and celebrities, including the director James Cameron, who have tried to draw attention to the dam’s potential negative impact. Mr. Cameron said Wednesday that he remained committed to stopping the dam.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about the oral antics in a hearing by the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission misidentified the witness to whom the panel’s vice chairman, Bill Thomas, directed the question “What made you walk away?” The witness was Richard Bitner, a former subprime lender  not Richard Bowen III, a former Citigroup mortgage lending officer.

headline: Critics Turn Out at Open House on N.Y.U. Expansion
text: At an open house in Greenwich Village on Wednesday evening that at times resembled a somewhat raucous cocktail party sans alcohol, New York University formally unveiled its 25-year expansion plan, giving the public a look at how it would grow by six million square feet.

headline: The Tables Turn
text: On many weeknights last year, in the depths of the recession, Tursi’s Latin King restaurant in Des Moines closed one of its three dining rooms and pared its kitchen to a skeleton crew.

headline: Arrest in Bryant Park Shoeshine Arsons
text: A 71-year-old shoeshiner, apparently angry that he was not permitted to work at a stand outside Bryant Park, set fire to it on two separate occasions in recent weeks, fire officials said Wednesday.

headline: Withholding Water Meters, Slowing Growth
text: Bolinas, Calif., is auctioning off that rarest of commodities: a water meter.

headline: Corrections
text: A “Rebounds” note in some editions on Tuesday about Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the prospective majority owner of the Nets, quoted incorrectly from a statement by the N.B.A. In addressing a report that a company owned by Mr. Prokhorov might be in violation of economic sanctions imposed on Zimbabwe, the statement said, “U.S. companies are not prohibited from doing business in Zimbabwe; rather, they are prohibited from conducting business with specifically identified individuals or entities in that country.” The statement did not say, “U.S. companies are not prohibited from conducting business with specifically identified individuals or entities in that country.”

headline: Carriage-Horse Vote
text: The City Council passed a bill on Wednesday that increases the fare for horse-drawn carriage rides and improves some conditions for the horses.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption in some copies on April 5 with the Sports Briefing column misidentified the cyclist cheered at the Wall of Geraardsbergen in Meerbeke, Belgium, during the Tour of Flanders. The photograph showed Fabian Cancellara, who won the race, not Tom Boonen.

headline: With End of the Season, the Knicks’ Future Begins
text: TORONTO — Through no merit of their own, the Knicks played a game that had playoff intrigue in the season finale before the Summer of Their Future.

headline: Corrections
text: A chart on Saturday about the careers of the three top-class thoroughbreds who have won 16 consecutive races misstated, in some editions, the age of one horse when she won in her debut, at Hollywood Park, in 2007. Zenyatta was a 3-year-old, not a 2-year-old.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about a study on financing of research into the diabetes drug Avandia referred incorrectly to a scientist who reported findings favorable to the drug. The scientist, Dr. Mark W. Stolar, an associate professor of medicine at Northwestern, has received payments from Takeda Pharmaceuticals, which makes diabetes drugs, but not from GlaxoSmithKline, which makes Avandia. (A co-author with Dr. Stolar did receive financing from Glaxo.)

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about preventive-care provisions in the new federal health law misstated the surname of the president of the American Heart Association, an advocate of comprehensive wellness programs for employees. He is Dr. Clyde W. Yancy, not Hancy.

headline: Word of the Day | canter
text: canter •\ˈkan-tər\• noun and verb

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about Fred Ascani, an Air Force test pilot and the overseer of a supersonic aircraft project, referred incorrectly to the fatalities aboard the XB-70A supersonic plane involved in a midair collision in 1966. One of the two pilots aboard that plane was killed, not “two of the XB-70A pilots.”

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: With Oil Deals, Merger Advisers Rejoice
text: Wall Street has always loved the fees generated by deal-crazy oil companies. But the recent flurry of activity in the energy industry — $130 billion so far this year and counting — is once again making them the most valuable clients for the world’s merger advisers.

headline: A Program to Certify Electronic Waste Recycling Rivals an Industry-U.S. Plan
text: The Basel Action Network, an American watchdog group that has sought to curb the export of toxic electronic waste from the United States, plans to begin a new certification and auditing program on Thursday for both recyclers and companies that generate electronic refuse.

headline: Unleash Your Inner Gleek on the iPad
text: Fans of Glee, Fox’s campy comedy about the misadventures of a high school show choir, now have one more way to “gleek” out: Using their iPhones and iPads.

headline: New Bandleader For ‘Tonight Show’
text: After years of practice NBC is finally addressing the abrupt departure of one of its signature late-night personalities with a plan for a smooth transition. (It may be only the bandleader for “The Tonight Show,” but hey, it’s a start.) On Tuesday the network said that Rickey Minor, the music director of “American Idol,” would succeed Kevin Eubanks , who announced on Monday’s broadcast that he was stepping down after 18 years of chuckling amiably at Jay Leno’s gags, 15 as the show’s musical director. Mr. Minor, who was nominated for an Emmy as the music director of the 2008 Grammy Awards, will make his “Tonight Show” debut on June 7 and continue to work with the “American Idol” creator Simon Fuller on other projects, NBC said.

headline: Bieber Knocks Usher From Top Billboard Spot
text: Last week Usher bumped his young protégé Justin Bieber from the top spot on the Billboard album chart, and this week Mr. Bieber returns the favor. “My World 2.0” (Island) by the 16-year-old Mr. Bieber  seen on “Saturday Night Live” last week  returned to No. 1 with 102,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Usher’s “Raymond vs. Raymond” (Jive) fell to No. 2, with 92,000. Slash, once the guitarist of Guns N’ Roses, is at No. 3 with his new, self-titled album, released by EMI, which sold slightly more than 60,000 in its first week out. Down the chart Madonna opened at No. 10 with her live album “Sticky & Sweet Tour” (Warner Brothers), which sold 28,000; it is her 19th album to reach the Top 10. Sharon Jones & the Dap-Kings have officially become Brooklyn’s biggest retro-soul band: their latest, “I Learned the Hard Way” (Daptone), sold 23,000 copies in its first week out to land at No. 15.

headline: News Quiz | April 15, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: My Life in Food
text: Sam Sifton shares his food diary — with calorie counts.

headline: A Set-Up Man Emerges for the Mets
text: DENVER — Jerry Manuel saw a few positive things come out of Wednesday’s 6-5 loss to the Rockies in 10 innings, not the least of which was the performance of reliever Ryota Igarashi.

headline: Former Banker for UBS Seeks Shorter Sentence
text: The former UBS private banker in prison after helping to uncover tax evasion by wealthy Americans is asking President Obama for a shorter sentence, Lynnley Browning reports in The New York Times.

headline: Rescue of Greece Faces Test in Germany
text: The German Parliament would probably need to approve the country’s contribution to a Greek rescue package, a spokesman for the German finance minister said Wednesday. It was another indication of the complexities that would be involved in the first bailout of a country in the euro zone, Jack Ewing reports in The New York Times.

headline: The Waiting Game
text: WHAT college currently has a waiting list of 3,383 students? WHAT other colleges are “hedging their bets this spring”?

headline: Euro Zone Needs Tougher Rules, Official Says
text: The European Commission said Wednesday that the euro zone needed tougher rules to require national governments to stick to economic pledges in the aftermath of the Greek debt crisis, Stephen Castle reported in The New York Times.

headline: The Day Lehman Got a Love Note From a Hedgie
text: In spring 2008, Lehman Brothers didn’t have too many friends on Wall Street, Reuters says.

headline: FLO TV Isn’t Giving Up
text: How do you keep them paying, now that they’ve seen free TV?

headline: Volcanic Ash to Curtail Air Traffic Into  Midday Friday
text: PARIS — A dark and spectacular volcanic cloud shrouded much of northern Europe on Thursday, forcing airlines to cancel thousands of flights as it drifted at high altitude south and east from an erupting volcano in Iceland. The shutdown of airspace was one of the most sweeping ever ordered in peacetime, amid fears that travel could continue to be delayed days after the cloud dissipates.

headline: S.E.C. Looks for Hedge Funders to Track Their Peers
text: Hedge fund managers may soon face a new regulatory nemesis: Their peers.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption last Thursday with an article about Eliot Spitzer’s re-emergence as a public figure misstated the year that Newsweek published a cover article about him. It was April 27, 2009  not 2008.

headline: Corrections
text: The Skin Deep column last Thursday, about breast-enhancement operations performed without general anesthesia, referred imprecisely to the ability of the anesthetic lidocaine to ward off infection. While it has antibacterial properties, they are present only in high concentrations.

headline: Corrections
text: The Seen column last Thursday, about the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House spring gala, misidentified the distributor of the television show “P. Allen Smith’s Garden Home.” It is American Public Television, not the Public Broadcasting Service.

headline: Corrections
text: The Seen column on April 1, about a fragrance symposium, misspelled the name of a participant. She is Yuka Hiyoshi, not Yoko Hiroshi.

headline: Peabody Lifts Macarthur Bid to $3.8 Billion
text: Peabody Energy raised its bid for Macarthur Coal of Australia to $3.8 billion in cash Thursday, calling it a definitive offer, a day after Macarthur rebuffed an improved bid from Peabody’s rival in the takeover effort, New Hope.

headline: Magnetar’s Big Subprime Trade
text: We can add another culprit in the bursting of the subprime mortgage lending bubble — the Illinois-based hedge fund Magnetar — The Financial Times’s John Gapper writes in a lengthy profile.

headline: VIP Passenger Syndrome
text: The theory that certain high-profile passengers may have a deleterious effect on airline pilot safety – controversially associated with the crash that killed Polish president Lech Kaczynski and 95 others.

headline: Images of Iceland’s Vast Landscapes, in Iceland’s Vast Landscape
text: Updated, Thursday, 10:30 a.m. | When Iceland’s Eyjafjalla volcano exploded on March 21, the photographer Ragnar Th. Sigurdsson boarded a Cessna and flew to the scene — one he said was “so beautiful you can’t imagine.”

headline: Democrats Press on Finance Controls
text: The White House and Democratic Congressional leaders said Wednesday that they would press forward with legislation to tighten regulation of the nation’s financial system. Rebuffing Republican criticism, the Democrats effectively dared the minority party to side with Wall Street by opposing the measure, The New York Times’s David M. Herszenhorn and Sheryl Gay Stolberg reported.

headline: Wall St. Must Recover Before N.Y.C. Can, Economists Say
text: The recession may be ending in the New York metropolitan area, but if history is any guide, no substantial recovery can begin until Wall Street stops shedding jobs and starts hiring again.

headline: Local TV Stations in Venture for Mobile Programs
text: Determined not to get left behind as television migrates to mobile devices, a formidable group of local television stations is forming a joint venture for what it calls a “national mobile content service.”

headline: Denny’s Slams Investors Leading Proxy Fight
text: Denny’s hit back at a group of investors waging a proxy battle against the company, telling shareholders that the hedge funds are doing so for their own personal gain and don’t have the company’s interest in mind, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Dollar General Prices Shareholder Offering
text: Dollar General on Wednesday priced 26 million shares at $27 each in a secondary public offering that allowed certain shareholders to sell their stock, the company said in a statement.

headline: Kyrgyz President Leaves Country
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan — The deposed president of Kyrgyzstan resigned and left the country for neighboring Kazakhstan on Thursday under an agreement brokered by Russia, regional leaders and the Obama administration. Within hours, security forces swooped in to arrest one of his brothers and a political ally.

headline: Is Prom Just an Excuse to Drink?
text: To try to curb post-prom partying, an upstate New York school is holding its junior and senior proms on school nights and requiring next-day attendance. What do you think about this plan as a way to reduce prom-night drinking?

headline: Lehman Sets Payouts to Exit Bankruptcy
text: Lehman Brothers Holdings laid out a plan Wednesday to repay creditors a portion of some $1 trillion in expected claims, under a proposal that could resolve the largest United States bankruptcy in history.

headline: Twitter Talks Money
text: Twitter, the microblogging sensation that has now signed up more than 100 million users, outlined on Wednesday several revenue-generating initiatives, declaring that making money was now a primary goal, Reuters reported.

headline: For Name Players in the N.F.L., Try the Bob Smith Test
text: Next time you’re evaluating an N.F.L. player, be sure to run a Bob Smith Test. To do this, simply ask, If this player’s name were Bob Smith, would I still notice him? How would my opinion of him differ? The answer could surprise you.

headline: Best Baguette Prize Awarded in Paris
text: The baguette, the French cultural symbol par excellence, has been part of French life for more than a hundred years. It is also, of course, part of day-to-day life in Paris. Last month, the mayor of Paris organized the Grand Prix de la Baguette, an annual contest in which more than 160 baguettes and their crispy crusts were tested by a jury. Judged on their taste, texture, look, smell, size and weight, the best baguette prize was awarded to Djibril Bodian, the Senegal-born baker at Le Grenier à Pain Abbesses in the picturesque district of Montmartre.

headline: Obama to Order Review of Troubled Mines
text: President Obama on Thursday will order federal mine safety regulators to review mines with checkered safety records, after a preliminary federal review found a “deeply troubling” safety record at a coal mine where 29 miners were killed in an explosion last week, a senior White House official said.

headline: Lehman Examiner Sees Possible Grounds for Suit
text: In a portion of the Lehman examiner’s report unsealed Wednesday, Anton Valukas, appointed to investigate the circumstances surrounding Lehman Brother’s collapse and liquidation, says that the failed investment bank might have cause to sue Goldman Sachs and Barclays for what might be a “fraudulent transaction.”

headline: Twitter Hints About What Developers Should Build
text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: With Oil Deals, Merger Advisers Rejoice
text: Wall Street has always loved the fees generated by deal-crazy oil companies, Breakingviews says. But the recent flurry of activity in the energy industry — $130 billion so far this year and counting — is once again making them the most valuable clients for the world’s merger advisers, the publication says.

headline: The Next Global Problem: Portugal
text: Like Greece, Portugal has spent far beyond its means, lacks exchange-rate flexibility as a remedy, and seems likely to be a new burden on Europe, two economists write.

headline: Standard & Poor at Highest Level Since 2008
text: Strong earnings reports excited Wall Street on Wednesday, pushing the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index above the 1,200-point threshold for the first time since the beginning of the financial crisis, The New York Times’s Javier C. Hernandez reported.

headline: Financial News Site Says It Is Imperiled by Judge’s Ban
text: Theflyonthewall.com, a financial news service, has urged a Manhattan federal judge to lift a ban barring it from quickly reporting “hot news” about analyst research from three Wall Street banks, saying the ban has cost it subscribers and could threaten its survival, Reuters reported.

headline: Racism and Obama’s Census Form
text: Today’s idea: In checking off “black” on his census form, Barack Obama “confirmed an enduring legacy of American racism,” a commentator says — that “the peculiar logic of blackness” still matters.

headline: Zell Sees ‘Political Risk’ to Investing in U.S.
text: The policies of the current U.S. administration have created “political risk” to investing in the United States, Sam Zell, who took over Tribune Company and then rode it into bankruptcy, said Wednesday.

headline: 2 Philippine Candidates Killed in Election Violence
text: MANILA — Election violence erupted again in the Philippines on Thursday as a grenade attack killed two people and injured a dozen during a meeting of local candidates.

headline: TD Ameritrade Said to Consider Acquisitions
text: TD Ameritrade Holding‘s chief executive said it had lots of cash to make a possible acquisition and, eventually, it would “absolutely make sense” for the big online brokerage to offer a dividend.

headline: John Malone Back in Europe and Looking to Buy
text: Two decades ago, the 69-year-old billionaire John Malone tried and failed to replicate his U.S. cable TV success in Europe by buying up and consolidating local carriers. Now, undeterred by losses in his international operations in 14 of the past 16 years, including in 2009, he’s ready to try again, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Soros: Germany Needs to Pay Up if E.U. Is to Survive
text: George Soros, the billionaire financier, says he thinks the euro and the European Union itself are at risk of breaking up if Germany refuses to play its traditional role and make concessions, Reuters reported, citing an interview conducted with Italian newspaper.

headline: Goldman Director Examined in Galleon Case, Report Says
text: Add another name to the long list of companies reportedly tied to the federal prosecutors’ continuing investigation into the Galleon Group: Goldman Sachs.

headline: P.I.C.C.’s Chief Says A.I.G. Is Committed to Its Stake
text: The American International Group remains a long-term investor in the People’s Insurance Company of China, China’s top non-life insurer said Thursday, even as the embattled American firm unwinds its holdings in other assets to repay the United States government, Reuters reported.

headline: Lagardère to Sell Stake in Vivendi’s Canal+
text: Lagardère, the French media company, is selling its 20 percent stake in pay-TV group Canal+ France in a move to streamline the group, which has come under fire from activist shareholder Guy Wyser-Pratte, Reuters reported.

headline: Agricultural Bank of China Announces Underwriters
text: Agricultural Bank of China announced the roster of 10 banks it has picked to handle its initial public offering, which is expected to raise as much as $20 billion, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Carlyle Said to Shop United Components
text: The Carlyle Group is shopping United Components and has tapped Goldman Sachs to help it find a buyer for the auto-parts maker, Bloomberg News reported, citing three people familiar with the plans.

headline: ‘Surprise Visit’
text: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: Russia Seeks Ways to Keep Its Children
text: MOSCOW — Russia would like to stop giving away its babies.

headline: Q.&A.: Increasing Bit Rates in Windows Audio
text: Q.

headline: Apache Buying Mariner Energy for $2.7 Billion
text: The Apache Corporation said Thursday it would buy Mariner Energy for $2.7 billion, just days after Apache said it would acquire Devon Energy‘s Gulf of Mexico oil and gas assets for more than $1 billion.

headline: Betty White and a Cadillac Named ‘Parakeet’
text: Betty White is known for her timeless charm and quick wit, but when the 88-year-old comedian and veteran of television series like “The Mary Tyler Moore Show” and “The Golden Girls” mentioned her “beloved parakeet,” I thought the joke was on me.

headline: Deadly Storm Strikes Eastern India
text: NEW DELHI — Rescuers spread across eastern India on Thursday, searching for survivors of a deadly storm that killed at least 122 people and left an estimated 100,000 homeless.

headline: Apache Makes Second Energy Deal
text: The independent energy company Apache announced Thursday that it would buy rival Mariner Energy for $2.7 billion, its second acquisition this week.

headline: Speed Read for Thursday, April 15
text: Highlights from today’s New York Times:

headline: The Early Word: Tax and Tea
text: It’s Tax Day, perfect timing for those who plan a protest.

headline: Cold, and Contrast, in Shanghai
text: If Day One in Shanghai is an indication of what is to come, then Formula One can add to its list of firsts: We’ve had the first night race in Singapore; we’ve had the first evening races in Australia and Malaysia. Now we have the winter race in Shanghai.

headline: U.S. Industrial Production Rose in March
text: An energetic rebound for manufacturers continued in March, a report showed on Thursday, bolstering hopes that the nation’s factories could help lead the American economy out of its deep downturn.

headline: Film Fest Is on Police Radar, Anarchists Say
text: Update, 11:13 a.m. Friday | An earlier version of this post mistakenly listed one of the venues for the Anarchist Film Festival as St. Mark’s Church-in-the-Bowery. The festival is not playing there. It is playing at Theater 80 St Marks and at Judson Memorial Church.

headline: Views of Volcanic Ash Plume Over Europe
text: Updated | 6:23 p.m. As my colleagues Nicola Clark and Liz Robbins report, a high-altitude cloud of ash drifting south and east from an erupting volcano in Iceland has closed airports in northern Europe. Flights have been canceled because volcanic ash contains silicates, or glass fibers, which can melt inside jet engines, causing them to flame out and stall.

headline: Is Health Coverage for Domestic Partners Still Taxed?
text: Q.

headline: Can You Write a Business Plan With Fewer Than 140 Characters?
text: The Twitter business idea pitch, also known as a “biztweet,” “twitpitch” or “twitch,” has arrived. Yes, that means entrepreneurs have 140 characters, tops, to explain their start-up ideas — making the classic elevator pitch, which can take a couple of minutes (sometimes in an actual elevator, as with Wake Forest University’s annual event), feel downright dilatory.

headline: ‘Hair’ Over There: The Broadway Revival Unfurls in London
text: Five months after the surprising announcement that the cast of the Broadway revival of “Hair” would pack up their bell-bottoms and patchouli and head to London, the transplanted American production had its official opening at the Gielgud Theater on Wednesday night. Though the Broadway production, directed by Diane Paulus, won the Tony Award for best musical revival, success in the West End wasn’t guaranteed for Will Swenson, Gavin Creel and company; a previous “Hair” revival was not well-received went it played there 15 years ago.

headline: After Quake in China, Cold and Altitude Hinder Relief
text: JIEGU, China — Rescue teams joined shovel-wielding monks in this devastated county seat on Thursday, a day after an earthquake that killed more than 700 people, as frigid temperatures threatened to claim hundreds more who remained missing, trapped beneath debris for more than a day.

headline: Charges in Bryant Park Shoeshine Arsons
text: Here’s what we’re reading this morning:

headline: Dream Girl
text: Much as we might rag on it, the awful truth must be looked at head-on: Reality TV, that fiction of verisimilitude, is, even for people who read W. G. Sebald and enjoy grim Scottish films with subtitles, supernally addictive. Not always and (let’s hope!) not forever, but in the right now of it. Sure, sometimes one is simply not in the mood for all that virtual id, the jawing and bitching, the glaring white teeth and the faux familiarity. And it is possible to envision a day in the not-too-far-off future when one might return to an old-fashioned pastime, like doing one’s nails, over the vicarious pleasures of comparing and contrasting the suntans and blown-out blondness that beset the Real Housewives of Orange County. Meanwhile, though, one stays tuned, fascinated by the mindless commotion, caught on the hook of the souped-up dramas that barge into every episode, unsure whether one is watching a version of oneself or a counter-version or perhaps an alternate version. Which brings me to the question: Who might one be if one were to be played by a reality-show star? Who might one want to be?

headline: Sit-In Grows in Central Bangkok
text: BANGKOK — Thai commandos staged a raid on Friday to capture some leaders of the anti-government protests that have gridlocked parts of Bangkok for more than a month, a senior government official said.

headline: Cannes Festival Will Show Film About Plame Affair
text: A film by Doug Liman (“The Bourne Identity,” “Mr. & Mrs. Smith”) adapted from the memoir of Valerie Plame Wilson, a formerly covert C.I.A. employee, whose identity was unmasked amid the dispute over the Iraq war, will be among the 16 movies shown in competition at the Cannes Film Festival in May, and among the 46 features chosen for the festival, The Hollywood Reporter said. Mr. Liman’s film, called “Fair Game,” stars Naomi Watts as Ms. Plame and Sean Penn as her husband, Joseph C. Wilson IV, the former ambassador. Other directors with films showing in competition include Mike Leigh (“Another Year”) and Alejandro González Iñárritu (“Biutiful”). The features making their Cannes debut out of competition include Ridley Scott‘s “Robin Hood,” starring Russell Crowe and Cate Blanchett; Oliver Stone‘s “Wall Street 2: Money Never Sleeps”; Woody Allen‘s “You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger”; and Stephen Frears‘s “Tamara Drewe.” The festival, whose jury will be led this year by Tim Burton, runs from May 12 through 23.

headline: Who Should Have Custody of Baby Emma?
text: John Wyatt says he tried to see his newborn daughter the moment he realized that his 20-year-old girlfriend gave birth, but the Virginia hospital lied to him and told him that neither the mother nor the baby was there. By the time he located them, the newborn had been given up for adoption, and while Virginia courts have recognized his right to custody, the state of Utah, where she has been living for more than a year now with her adoptive parents, say he has no claim on the girl.

headline: Best Cornerbacks in the N.F.L.: The Top 10 List
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely – but not strictly – by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, although the future isn’t ignored. Statistics weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t sneak onto Top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: With Greece Calmer, Eyes Turn to Portugal
text: From Peter Boone and Simon Johnson at Economix:

headline: Live from Tulane: Deal-Making Returns
text: NEW ORLEANS — What a difference a year makes.

headline: Nelson Gets by With Fewer and Fewer Warriors
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — The regular season came to a bizarre end here Wednesday night, in a game between the league’s two most injury-depleted teams. As the playoff-bound Trail Blazers mostly rested their key players in a game that had no consequence for their postseason positioning, the low-run Golden State Warriors brought just eight players. Two of them (Ronny Turiaf and Anthony Morrow) were declared unfit to play by the team’s trainer during warmups. Midway through the first quarter, center Chris Hunter aggravated his knee. So Coach Don Nelson, who recently became the career victories leader, used five players for the rest of the game.

headline: Shanghai Exchange Sets Plans for Foreign Listings
text: The Shanghai Stock Exchange is finishing up plans to create an international board this year, which would allow foreign companies to sell shares to Chinese investors on the mainland for the first time, David Barboza reports in The New York Times.

headline: From the Sea to a Sushi Plate, a Trail of DNA
text: One element of negotiations now under way to try to reduce the number of whales killed is the proposed creation of a central registry of whale DNA to improve efforts to track whale populations and monitor the international trade in whale meat.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live': The Will Ferrell/George W. Bush/Tina Fey/Sarah Palin Decade
text: If you watched the more than 200 episodes of “Saturday Night Live” that have been shown over the past decade, and could still see straight afterward, what story would you tell? Would it be about how NBC’s 35-year-old late-night comedy institution dealt with the departure of homegrown stars like Will Ferrell while generating new talents like Tina Fey and Jimmy Fallon? Would it be about how the show dealt with news events like the 9/11 attacks, and helped reflect opinions on political figures like George W. Bush, Al Gore, John Kerry and Sarah Palin? Or, like Shimmer, the floor polish that’s also a dessert topping, would it be both?

headline: Benjamin L. Hooks, Civil Rights Leader, Dies at 85
text: Benjamin L. Hooks, who for 15 years led the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People as it struggled to remain an effective champion of minorities in an era of rising political conservatism, died Thursday at his home in Memphis. He was 85.

headline: The Dumbest Tax Mistakes Ever
text: As I was sealing the envelopes last night, I had an unpleasant flashback.

headline: Head Man
text: Guido Palau performs hair-raising feats for the fashion elite. Sandra Ballentine gets the back (combed) story. More…

headline: Tulane: JPMorgan’s Braunstein Sees Good Signs Ahead
text: NEW ORLEANS — The recovery in deal-making may appear slow, but in the view of Douglas L. Braunstein, JPMorgan Chase‘s head of investment banking, it is real.

headline: Thursday Reading: The Extension of Jobless Benefits
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: A Killing in Zambia
text: I’m late turning to Jeffrey Goldberg’s mammoth New Yorker story on Mark and Delia Owens, a pair of celebrated conservationists who apparently went vigilante in their struggle against poachers in Zambia’s North Luangwa National Park, but I wanted both to recommend the piece (it’s the fastest-moving 17,000 words you’ll read this month), and to remark on how surprised I was, all things considered, to find myself feeling sympathetic toward its off-the-reservation subjects. The tenor is appropriately prosecutorial: Goldberg builds an extensive, persuasive case that the Owenses’ much-lauded environmental activism in the Zambian hinterland led to at least one murder, and maybe more. The victim was a poacher; the killers were probably game scouts who were trained by the Owenses as a kind of private army (and encouraged to take the fight to hunters) — and the fatal gunshots, Goldberg plausibly contends, may have been fired by Mark Owens’ own son, Christopher. (Remarkably, the murder was captured on camera by an ABC documentary crew sometime in 1995; even more remarkably, it was then broadcast, on an episode of the newsmagazine show “Turning Point” in 1996.)

headline: Off the Menu: BLT Food Truck
text: The BLT Restaurant Group will inaugurate a restaurant on wheels the weekend of April 17 and 18 when its new Go Burger truck heads out to street fairs around the city. It will have a menu of burgers, hot dogs, a breakfast frittata, a salad, sweets and milk shakes, $3 to $9.

headline: Brutal Truths About Violence
text: EVEN before it opened in theaters on Friday, “Kick-Ass” had achieved a degree of notoriety thanks to a scene in which Hit-Girl, a pint-size masked vigilante played by Chloë Grace Moretz, unleashes a barrage of obscenities against a room full of foes. Both the provocation and the published responses to it  more or less evenly split between shock and exhilaration  had a somewhat ritualized quality. We’ve been here before: A movie pointedly tests what seems to be an established boundary of propriety, and rhetorical battle lines are drawn. “How dare they!” faces off against “Oh, lighten up.”

headline: What Tea Party Backers Want
text: The latest  New York Times/CBS News poll focusing on Tea Party supporters found most of them very angry, generally well-educated, financially secure and deeply pessimistic about the direction of the country. We asked political analysts and historians what they found most illuminating about the poll’s findings, and whether the views of the Tea Party backers have commonly run through American politics.

headline: On the Blank Slate Of Governors Island, Imaginations Run Wild
text: First things first: The name. No one suggested Gilligan's, Fantasy or Treasure. Of the 147 readers who answered City Room's call on Monday for ideas about Governors Island, the 172-acre former military outpost that New York City is taking over, one suggested Trump Island.

headline: Imaginations Run Rampant on Governors I.
text: First things first: The name. No one suggested Gilligan’s, Fantasy or Treasure. Of the 147 readers who answered City Room’s call on Monday for ideas about Governors Island, the 172-acre former military outpost that New York City is taking over, one suggested Trump Island.

headline: Iceland’s Volcanic Ash Halts Flights Across Europe
text: The plume of ash from a volcano in Iceland forced aviation authorities to order the restrictions, affecting thousands of flights in a wide arc from Ireland to Scandinavia. Read more.

headline: Quadrangle Settles Pension Fund Case
text: 3:23 p.m. | Updated The Quadrangle Group, the private equity firm, has agreed to settle a corruption investigation with the New York attorney general and the Securities and Exchange Commission, Louise Story of The New York Times reports.

headline: Investment Firm Agrees to Settle Kickback Inquiry
text: The investment firm founded by Steven L. Rattner, the politically connected financier who went on to lead President Obama’s auto task force, has agreed to pay $12 million to settle allegations that it paid kickbacks to win lucrative business from the New York State pension fund.

headline: Auditing the I.R.S.
text: If you struggled with some of the complicated new changes in your tax return this year, you’re not alone. The Internal Revenue Service also had problems.

headline: Final Sales Phase for World Cup Tickets Begins With a Frenzy
text: The fifth and final phase of World Cup ticket sales began Thursday with a little more than the requisite enthusiasm. Thousands of fans lined up at retail locations in South Africa overnight to buy some of the 500,000 remaining match tickets. Some 300 tickets to the final, which was reportedly sold out, were to be made available on a first-come, first-served basis, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Eminem Album Isn’t Canceled, Just Renamed and Reinvented
text: Every so often, it pays not to jump all over a potentially contentious celebrity tweet immediately after it appears. Eminem briefly sent his followers into a tizzy when he posted a message on Twitter Wednesday morning on his Twitter feed that read: “There is no Relapse 2.” Most readers took this to mean that the rapper would not release a follow-up to his 2009 album “Relapse,” the first he had put out since “Encore” in 2004. But a few hours later, Eminem set his loyal fans straight, posting a second message that said only “RECOVERY,” and directed followers to his Web site, eminem.com. There, the rapper said that his new album, “Recovery,” will be released on June 22 by Aftermath/Interscope Records, and will feature contributions from producers including DJ Khalil, Just Blaze, Jim Jonsin and Boi-1da.

headline: Pope Urges Repentance in Homily
text: ROME — In his most direct reference to the sexual abuse crisis that has reached the Vatican, Pope Benedict XVI said Thursday that it was necessary for Christians to “repent” in light of “the attacks of the world, which speaks to us of our sins.”

headline: Solar Growth Slows, With Homes a Glaring Exception
text: A new report from a solar industry group found that the pace of solar installations slowed last year amid the economic downturn.

headline: A Song About Forgetting
text: Cynthia Scott’s voice came wafting out of my car radio on a Sunday morning. She’s a lovely singer, a veteran of jazz clubs and international festivals and, back when, one of Ray Charles’s Raelettes.

headline: ‘They Had Some Controversy’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Here in California, our attorney general said he’s going to investigate whether a university foundation that hired Sarah Palin to give a speech violated public disclosure laws. They had some controversy. Some students found her contract rider in a dumpster. That is a list of demands a performer has when they appear somewhere. Usually you see them for, like, rock stars, but Sarah Palin has one, I guess. Among other things, Palin’s rider requires two first-class tickets from Alaska or a private jet from Alaska, nothing smaller than a Lear 60, and it has to have a window she can shoot out of.

headline: ‘Deeper Space Exploration’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: President Obama is launching a new $6 billion space policy that will ultimately take astronauts to Mars. Of course, it’s $6 billion and $45 if the astronauts have a carry-on.

headline: ‘No. 1 in Science’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: The Obama administration’s top science and technology official has warned the United States cannot expect to be No. 1 in science and technology forever. Did you know we were No. 1 now? If we’re No. 1 in technology, why do I have to call India for tech support, O.K.?

headline: 42 Just One of Robinson’s Numbers
text: When future generations go to ballparks, they will see the number 42 written on outfield walls or on a team’s list of retired numbers and will be told that the number was retired by all teams to honor Jackie Robinson, the man who broke baseball’s color barrier. They may even see the number worn by all major leaguers on Jackie Robinson day, like they will in today’s games. What they won’t see is that there are plenty of other numbers that could represent Robinson’s time as an athlete, and 42 represents just his time with the Brooklyn Dodgers.

headline: In the Future, Everyone Will Be a Piñata for 15 Minutes
text: 1:13 p.m. | Updated  This 20-foot-tall piñata representation of the head of Andy Warhol, designed by the food artist Jennifer Rubell, will make its debut at a gala for the Brooklyn Museum on April 22. In answer to your next questions: Yes, you will be allowed to hit it with bats, and yes, it is filled with desserts. (In a telephone interview, Ms. Rubell said it will contain “the vernacular of American treats, which will remain nameless for the moment.”) If you have complicated feelings about Warhol, his impact on the art world or his pairing of the Velvet Underground with Nico, this could be your opportunity to release them in an appropriate forum.

headline: University of California System Assembles First Waiting Lists
text: The University of California system, which said in the midst of fiscal belt-tightening in January that it planned to compile its first waiting lists, announced on Wednesday that it had placed more than 10,000 applicants on at least one such list. The lists, long used at selective private colleges, are being employed by several U.C. campuses to insure that enrollment targets are not exceeded.

headline: Sampler: Warding Off Disaster, and Out-of-State Admissions
text: Oregon Town Considers Beacon for Big One | Cannon Beach, Ore., a seaside town of 1,500 tucked in the northern corner of Oregon, has tried harder than most places to prepare for a devastating earthquake and subsequent tsunami. It has upgraded warning signs, sirens, evacuation routes, and seismically reappraised bridges and buildings. Now, the community is trying to become the first to build a $4 million seismically sound evacuation tower that could rise over the crest of even 18-foot tsunami waves. While California is often seen as the epicenter of earthquakes in the country, new studies show that parts of the Pacific Northwest, stretching from Northern California to British Columbia, are at even greater risk of a catastrophic earthquake lasting as long as five minutes. [The New York Times]

It looks like he’s on track to make snails with pork sausage and frisée with tripe and jowl croutons the dishes of summer. Here, he shares a few of his favorite things.

headline: Teachers Set Deal With City on Discipline Process

Bloomberg and the city’s teachers’ union have agreed to do away with “rubber rooms” full of teachers accused of wrongdoing or incompetence and speed up hearings for them, reforming a disciplinary system that has made both City Hall and the teachers’ union subjects of ridicule.

headline: MySpace to Offer New Service for Concertgoers
text: MySpace is getting into the calendar business. The social networking company introduced a new service on Thursday that would allow individuals to manage their upcoming events within the site and to buy concert tickets through links on artist pages and elsewhere on the site.

headline: Fifteen Nights of Midsummer Swing
text: True to its name, there will be plenty of swing music this summer at Midsummer Night Swing, Lincoln Center‘s annual series of al fresco dancing. Its 22nd season opens on June 28 with a battle of the big bands between the George Gee Orchestra and the Bill Elliott Swing Orchestra, and the 15 nights in Damrosch Park also include various species of jazzy swing by the Time Jumpers (Western swing, July 1), the New Orleans Moonshiners (New Orleans jazz, July 6), the Wycliffe Gordon Sextet (straight-up jazz, July 10) and the Harlem Renaissance Orchestra on closing night (yet more big-band swing, July 17).

headline: 15 Minutes of Piñata Fame, 20 Feet Tall
text: That expressively expressionless visage gazing down from the exterior of the Brooklyn Museum, in case you were wondering, is Andy Warhol, reincarnated this time in 20-foot-tall piñata form. In a few days, gala attendees suffering from anxiety of influence will have the opportunity to hit it with bats. Read all about it on ArtsBeat.

headline: Some at MoMA Show Forget ‘Look but Don’t Touch’
text: A few Fridays ago, a young contemporary dancer named Will Rawls was working at his current production, the Marina Abramovic performance art retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. Specifically, he was standing naked in a gallery entrance, facing a naked woman, as museumgoers passed through the narrow space between them. It was a re-enactment of “Imponderabilia,” a well-known piece originally performed by Ms. Abramovic and a partner in the 1970s.

headline: At Internet Conference, Signs of Agreement Appear Between U.S. and Russia
text: GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany — For the 140 computer network specialists, law enforcement agents and diplomats from eight countries who met in this German ski resort this week for a Russian-sponsored conference on Internet security, the biggest challenge was finding a common ground to discuss their differences.

headline: Milan Report | Paola Navone for Barovier & Toso
text: Last year, the designer Paola Navone created a striking installation for Richard Ginori, turning an old warehouse into a fantasy china factory with palettes of stacked white ware surrounding an island of lounge seating where visitors could relax and sip an espresso while they admired a 40-foot-high wall of china plates, all hand-painted in different bright patterns. It was a coup de theatre.

headline: Tips on Shooting Video With a D.S.L.R.
text: A few weeks ago, I attended a hands-on class on shooting pro-level footage with a video-capable D.S.L.R. camera. The all-day session was led by Bruce Dorn, a professional photographer and videographer who champions the use of D.S.L.R.’s for creating sophisticated video. It was sponsored by Canon to showcase the 1080p video capabilities of its new EOS Rebel T2i.

headline: Of Meter and Money
text: Who says poetry doesn’t pay? On April 26 and 27, there will be 53 high school students from around the country reciting verse from memory before a panel of judges, vying for the title of Poetry Out Loud Champion and a total of $50,000 in prize money. The competition, a partnership between the Poetry Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts, began last month with contests in all the states (and the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands). The winners of those competitions will go to Washington for the semifinals on April 26; nine students will advance to the finals on April 27. The national champion will get $20,000, the second- and third-place finalists $10,000 and $5,000. Other finalists and semifinalists will also win cash prizes, and the finalists’ schools will each receive $500 to buy poetry books. The judges include Garrison Keillor, the poet and critic Adam Kirsch, and last year’s national champion. Both the semifinals and the finals will take place at the Lisner Auditorium at George Washington University and are free and open to the public.

headline: Black Boxes Yield Data on Crash of Polish Jet
text: MOSCOW — For a few terrifying seconds before a Polish jet crashed in western Russia on Saturday, its crew members knew they were about to die, Poland’s chief prosecutor said on Thursday, as investigators in both countries analyzed the contents of the plane’s black boxes.

headline: Hyatt to Open New Hotels in India

The company said it would open Hyatt Regency Pune, Hyatt Regency Chennai and Grand Hyatt Goa this year.

headline: Eleventh Time’s the Charm: Meet Your New ‘Doctor Who’
text: It was just three months ago that science fiction fans everywhere held their breath as “Doctor Who” said goodbye to its star David Tennant, the actor who portrayed the energetic, enigmatic adventurer known only as the Doctor. Not only did Mr. Tennant depart the BBC series in January — so, too, did Russell T Davies, the writer and producer who revived the dormant “Doctor Who” franchise in 2005, and helped restore an aura of wonder to the Doctor, his time-traveling phone booth-slash-spacecraft, the TARDIS, and his mechanical alien foes, the Daleks.

headline: Eruption Wasn’t That Powerful, but Effects May Linger
text: The volcanic eruption in Iceland that disrupted air travel in Europe on Thursday was not a particularly powerful one, experts said, but they cautioned that its effects — both on travel and on the regional climate — might linger.

headline: Former N.S.A. Official Is Charged in Leaks Case
text: WASHINGTON — In a rare legal action against a government employee accused of leaking secrets, a grand jury has indicted a former senior National Security Agency official on charges of providing classified information to a newspaper reporter in hundreds of e-mail messages in 2006 and 2007.

headline: Compartmentalizing Life and Work
text: As the word “flexibility” returns to the national work/life conversation, USA Today reporter Sharon Jayson asks whether working from home really means spending more time with your kids. That is the theory, of course, and the reason that telecommuting and flexible hours that allow employees to do some of their tasks at home have become the holy grail, for some, of a balanced life.

headline: The Power of Place: Doing Ethnographic Studies of Local Sites

In this lesson, students consider the power of place in their own lives, and then execute an ethnographic research project that dispels clichéd notions about where they live.

headline: Courtney Love’s Music Therapy
text: COURTNEY LOVE’S room at the Mercer Hotel in SoHo was a study in chaos. Racks of clothing, from 1920s vintage to this season’s Miu Miu, lined two walls. The floor was littered with boxes of photos. Empty coffee cups, half-finished bottles of juice, opened bags of candy, overflowing ashtrays and stacks of books on Buddhism and psychology were seemingly everywhere. And at the center of it all, at once manic and serene, brash and vulnerable, sat Ms. Love, watching on a battered laptop YouTube videos of her duet with the Irish singer Gavin Friday at a benefit for Red, an African AIDS charity, at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Hamas Executes Two Accused of Aiding Israel

The executions, carried out by a firing squad at dawn, were the first since the Islamic group Hamas seized control of Gaza after routing forces loyal to the president of the authority, Mahmoud Abbas, in 2007.

headline: Clog Posting
text: Among the clognoscenti, a visit with the Portland, Ore.-based Clogmaster, a k a Cecilia Tidlund, is the stuff of legend. Not only can you custom-design clogs from candy-colored, patent and metallic leathers, you’ll also receive a custom fitting — maybe even a customized dressing-down about your appalling footwear habits. (Silly me, I wore flip-flops.) Tidlund, a native of Sweden and the founder, in 1976, of one of America’s first bespoke clog companies, is an orthopedic-wellness militant à la the Soup Nazi. Which is why, when I phoned Tidlund to solicit her (withering, I was certain) take on one of spring’s big trends — the befeathered, begrommeted, open-toed, high-heeled clog (see Miu Miu, above left; Louis Vuitton, above right; and Chanel) — I was surprised that she wasn’t entirely negative. First she reminded me that ‘‘we’ve seen them before.’’ Then she added, ‘‘I’d rather people get into a bad fashion clog than a ballet flat or flip-flop. Flimsy shoes are ruining people’s feet. I’ve seen 12-year-olds with bunions.’’

headline: Jobless Rate Continues to Fall

headline: Q. & A. With Sam Sifton (Round One)
