headline: Outside of the Blue and Yellow Box
text: The Brooklyn neighborhood of Red Hook may be most famous these days for affordable Swedish design, but a group of artists is giving the once rough-and-tumble peninsula a softer, more creative edge. Their fondness for turning salvaged objects into objets d’art makes the area feel like “a small town of misfit toys,” in one resident’s words, which might also serve to describe much of the creative class that now lives there. To reach these somewhat inaccessible streets, take the B61 bus to the Red Hook Ikea; the bus runs between Queens Plaza and Red Hook, stopping in Downtown Brooklyn near the Jay Street-Borough Hall subway stop (A, C, F lines) and near the Borough Hall stop (2, 3, 4, 5, M, R). Or take the water taxi to Ikea from Pier 11 near Wall Street.

headline: Earth Day Events
text: In a city where green space has grown by 570 acres in the past eight years, every day could be considered earth day. This is especially true in April, when the events leading up to the formal Earth Day, April 25, could fill every page of your calendar (no doubt made from recycled materials).

headline: Immigration Raids Focus on Shuttle Vans
text: PHOENIX — With sweeps on both sides of the border Thursday, American and Mexican authorities delivered what they called their most serious blow toward dismantling human smuggling organizations that have brought thousands of illegal immigrants to the United States.

headline: Anchor Casts Off Home
text: IT’S been an eventful two years on Wall Street. Perhaps you’d heard? And as CNN’s chief business correspondent, Ali Velshi has been busy.

headline: The Pepsi Will Flow at the Move-In Party
text: ROGELIO M. REBOLLEDO, a man who made his fortune in snacks and sodas, and now sits on the board of the Kellogg Company and Best Buy, has bought a three-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side for $3.1 million. Now, one wonders: what will go in the pantry? Rice Krispies, for sure.

headline: Workaday Buildings That Aren’t
text: THE Historic Districts Council, a preservation advocacy group, has surveyed the blocks from Madison Square to 34th Street for potential landmark designations.

headline: Next Stop for Woods Is Quail Hollow
text: Tiger Woods will be back among golf fans in two weeks, according to his Web site, choosing to make the regular PGA Tour stop at the Quail Hollow Championship in Charlotte, N.C., his second appearance of 2010.

headline: ‘Aerialists, Athletes And Arpeggios’
text: When the Little Orchestra Society performs on Saturday, some of the most carefully planned moments will go right over the young audience members’ heads  and that’s exactly what Dino Anagnost wants.

headline: A Beer Marketer Is Painting the Town, Literally
text: One of the hottest trends in marketing is for brands to commission the creation of content — sometimes chock full of product placement, sometimes low-key in trying to peddle their wares.

headline: Credit Suisse Hires Proxy-Fight Expert
text: Credit Suisse has hired Chris Young, the director of mergers and acquisitions and proxy-fight research at Institutional Shareholder Services, to head the investment bank’s takeover defense practice. Mr. Young, who is considered a leading authority in contested M.&A. transactions and shareholder activism issues, was with I.S.S. for six years where he advised large shareholders on how to vote.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: ‘ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO’  (Friday through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series “Dora the Explorer” and “Go, Diego, Go!” have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Children’s Museum of Manhattan, whose exhibition has separate Dora and Diego environments, including Diego’s Animal Rescue Center and Dora’s Fiesta. Intended for ages 2 to 6, the interactive, bilingual displays are designed to teach language, science and music skills, as well as facts about Latin America. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street , (212) 721-1223, cmom.org; free with museum admission: $10; $7 for 65+; free for under 1 and members.20100415

headline: Google’s Profit and Revenue Rise, but Analysts Wanted More
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google may be fighting a multifront war against Apple, Microsoft, federal antitrust regulators and the government of China, but its online advertising business continues to hum along nicely.

headline: Dueling Columnists
text: A surprising disagreement has broken out between two Times columnists, with Paul Krugman demanding an apology from Andrew Ross Sorkin and Sorkin so far refusing to back down.

headline: Senegal Urged to Rein in Religious Schools
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Thousands of children in Senegal are forced to beg on the streets under the pretext that they are receiving religious instruction, Human Rights Watch said in a report Thursday that urged the government to crack down on the long-established phenomenon.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Devastation in China and Volcanic Ash in Europe
text: Rescue efforts continued in western China a day after the 7.1-magnitude quake that devastated a county seat on the Tibetan plateau (Slides 1, 2, and 3). Government teams joined shovel-wielding monks as frigid weather threatened to claim hundreds more who remained missing. In Europe, a drifting cloud of smoke and ash from a volcano in Iceland (Slide 4) grounded air traffic. The situation left passengers stranded and mostly resigned (Slides 6 and 7) at some of the world’s busiest airports.

headline: Chinese Premier Offers a Tribute to a Reformer
text: BEIJING — He was the reformist party leader whose death 21 years ago helped inspire the pro-democracy protests in Tiananmen Square. To a large extent, both the protests and the leader — the former Communist Party general secretary Hu Yaobang — have been missing from China’s official political lexicon ever since.

headline: Anger and Frustration in Tea Party Voices
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll offers an in-depth look at the 18 percent of Americans who consider themselves supporters of the Tea Party movement.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: As Church’s Windows Come Down, So Do Hopes for Restoration
text: Workers for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn have removed the dozen towering stained-glass windows from a beloved church built a century ago by Italian immigrants, prompting protests from preservationists who consider the building an important artifact – and who consider demolition imminent.

headline: Milan Report | Shopping With Stella
text: Stella McCartney just opened her first store in Milan, on via Santo Spirito in the heart of the city’s fashionable shopping district. Housed in an 18th-century building, the store — which was designed by the architects APA in London and J&R Studio in Milan — has a sustainable oak parquet floor, in McCartney’s signature color palette, that was designed by Yael Mer and Shay Alkalay of Raw Edges for Established & Sons (www.establishedandsons.com), the furniture company headed by Alasdhair Willis, McCartney’s husband. While the store’s ground floor is full of decorative touches, the second floor is a study in white on white with accents of bright color like the organic felt cubes that display shoes, and a painted ceiling that is original to the building. Moreover, the design doesn’t just look good; it does good, too — McCartney is aiming for LEED certification.

headline: Low Rates Good for Banks, but Pity the Saver
text: Aren’t low short-term interest rates wonderful?

headline: The Exotic in the Eyes of African Beholders
text: DETROIT  For centuries Euro-American eyes have been trained on Africa. We’ve scanned it from afar, surveyed it up close, put it behind glass; looked and looked, wonderingly, acquisitively, disdainfully, fearfully. But we rarely seem to be aware that during all that time Africans have been looking back at us  wonderingly, acquisitively, disdainfully, fearfully. A remarkable exhibition called “Through African Eyes: The European in African Art, 1500 to Present,” which opens Sunday at the Detroit Institute of Arts, gives a vivid hint of what they’ve seen.

headline: Cold War Nuclear Fears Now Apply to Terrorists
text: WASHINGTON — The top secret National Intelligence Estimate did not mince words. The United States faced an enemy with “no scruples about employing any weapon or tactic,” it said, and nuclear weapons smuggled across porous borders threatened to devastate American cities. Sleeper cells, the document warned, might already be inside the country.

headline: All About the Obamas’ Charitable Giving
text: Even the president has to file taxes. And so he did today, as noted by our colleagues over at the Caucus blog. In addition to paying $1.8 million in federal taxes, the Obamas donated $329,100 to charity plus the full amount of the $1.4 million he won for receiving the Nobel Peace Prize in 2009.

headline: Practice Swing Should Imitate Your Shot
text: Maybe you’re heading out to play for the first time this season. Now is a great time to break old habits that aren’t helping you. Case in point: the common, often useless practice swing.

headline: Rangers Manager Has a Season of Work After a ‘Moment of Weakness’
text: CLEVELAND — Ron Washington’s home in New Orleans is made of brick. Hurricane Katrina gutted its insides in 2005. Some of his relatives moved away, their homes totaled. Washington stayed. He has steadily restored almost everything, with only the living room and a bedroom to finish.

headline: New York City Pays Teachers Not to Teach
text: Carolyn Ryan, the Deputy Metro Editor of The Times, speaks to the reporter Jennifer Medina about the ridiculed "rubber rooms," where teachers receive pay for doing nothing.

headline: The Resurrection of a Gothic Mansion
text: The Resurrection of a Gothic Mansion

headline: From ‘Mr. Clean’ to ‘Luv Gov’
text: The Eliot Spitzer story plays like a novel that might have been plotted by Theodore Dreiser and peopled with characters by Tom Wolfe. The governor of New York, a k a “Mr. Clean,” a k a “the Sheriff of Wall Street,” is transformed by a prostitution scandal into “the Luv Gov” and “Client 9.” The tireless reformer compared to Batman’s alter ego, Bruce Wayne; the moralistic square, who carried a briefcase in junior high, finds his much ballyhooed future as a possible presidential contender smashed to pieces, and the word “disgraced” seemingly permanently stapled to his name like a Homeric epithet.

headline: Fox News Cancels Hannity’s Tea Party Broadcast
text: Update, 11:19 P.M.: Sean Hannity’s plan to broadcast from a Cincinnati Tea Party rally were canceled late Thursday.

headline: Epics and Erotica From a Grandfather of Anime
text: Today’s comic book artists and graphic novelists owe a huge debt of gratitude to Hokusai, Hiroshige and other Japanese artists who, with wonderful formal and technical ingenuity, illustrated tales of martial conflict, high seas adventure, travel and erotica, and sold them cheap in vast quantities to the pre-20th-century equivalents of manga and anime fans.

headline: President Obama’s Remarks on the Space Program
text: Following is the text of President Obama's speech on Thursday outlining his plans for space exploration at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida:

headline: Tracking Airport Status
text: A list and map of airports that have been affected by the ash cloud.

headline: Appetite for New and Next New
text: Maybe we don’t need to be reminded that the American art of the late 1950s and ’60s moved with ferocious speed. Those were the glory days, we’ve been taught, repeatedly and indelibly.

headline: A Turn in the Sun for the Cello, Equal Orchestral Partner
text: The cello is now so firmly established as a solo instrument that it’s easy to forget that it was mostly a bit player until the 19th century.

headline: Happily Settling for a More Modest Country Getaway
text: BUYERS looking for a country house in the Hudson Valley or the Catskills in New York State have settled on a more modest ideal: between $200,000 and $250,000 for a home on a few acres, with a picturesque town not too far away.

headline: Daniel Radcliffe to Star in ‘How to Succeed’ Revival on Broadway
text: How do you succeed on Broadway without really trying? It doesn’t hurt when you have a star from one of the most successful film franchises in history in a leading role. Daniel Radcliffe, the “Harry Potter” star — who, in fairness, works hard in all his endeavors, we’re sure — will play the ambitious window washer J. Pierrepont Finch in a revival of “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying” that is planned for Broadway in the spring of 2011, its producers announced on Thursday. The musical revival, with music and lyrics by Frank Loesser and book by Abe Burrows, Jack Weinstock and Willie Gilbert, will be Mr. Radcliffe’s first Broadway role since the revival of “Equus” that ran at the Broadhurst Theater in 2008 and 2009. Rob Ashford, (“Promises, Promises”; “Curtains”) will direct “How to Succced,” and it will be produced by Broadway Across America (John Gore, Thomas B. McGrath, Beth Williams), Craig Zadan and Neil Meron. The original production (with a cast that included Robert Morse and Charles Nelson Reilly) opened in 1961 and ran for more than 1,400 performances; a film version was released in 1967, and a previous Broadway revival, starring Matthew Broderick and Megan Mullally, was mounted in 1995.

headline: Visiting Audubon’s Still-Fine Feathered Friends
text: ST. FRANCISVILLE, La.

headline: Whitney Heads for the High Line
text: Even before a final decision on whether the Whitney Museum of American Art will build a $680 million downtown museum in the meatpacking district, the institution is planting its flag on the site  a parcel of land at Gansevoort and Washington Streets  in a series of outdoor exhibitions.

headline: Familiar Names Return to Madison Avenue Under New Moniker
text: Two well-known agency executives, Bill Berenter and Marty Greenhouse, are returning to advertising with a new agency.

headline: The Palm Orchard
text: WHAT Oceanfront residential resort.

headline: Icahn Raises His Bid for Lions Gate to $7 a Share
text: 5:59 p.m. | Updated The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn is not ready to be thwarted in his hostile bid for Lions Gate Entertainment.

headline: Film About Plame Affair to Be Shown at Cannes
text: A film by Doug Liman (“The Bourne Identity,” “Mr. and Mrs. Smith”) adapted from the memoir of Valerie Plame Wilson, the covert C.I.A. employee who was unmasked in a dispute over the Iraq war, will be among the 16 movies shown in competition at the Cannes Film Festival in May, and among the 46 features chosen for the festival, The Hollywood Reporter said. Mr. Liman’s film, “Fair Game,” stars Naomi Watts and Sean Penn, above, as Ms. Plame and her husband, Joseph C. Wilson IV, a former ambassador. Other directors with films showing in competition include Mike Leigh (“Another Year”) and Alejandro González Iñárritu (“Biutiful”). The features making their Cannes debut out of competition include Ridley Scott’s “Robin Hood,” starring Russell Crowe and Cate Blanchett; Oliver Stone’s “Wall Street 2: Money Never Sleeps”; Woody Allen’s “You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger”; and Stephen Frears’s “Tamara Drewe.” The festival, whose jury will be led this year by Tim Burton, runs from May 12 through 23.

headline: Theater Prizes Awarded
text: The playwright Dan LeFranc and the musical theater songwriters Peter Mills and Barry Wyner have won major awards recognizing promising new talent in American theater, the sponsors of the prizes announced. Mr. LeFranc has won the 2010 New York Times Outstanding Playwright Award for his play “Sixty Miles to Silver Lake,” about a divorced father and his teenage son on an emotionally exacting car ride together. The prize comes with $5,000 award. The downtown theater Soho Rep produced “Sixty Miles to Silver Lake” last year. The prize will be presented on May 13 at a ceremony held at TheTimesCenter in Manhattan. Mr. Mills, meanwhile, is the winner of the 2010 Kleban Prize for most promising musical theater lyricist, and Mr. Wyner is the Kleban recipient for most promising musical theater librettist. Those awards each come with a cash prize of $100,000 from the Kleban Foundation, established in 1988 under the will of Edward L. Kleban, the Tony Award and Pulitzer Prize-winning lyricist of “A Chorus Line.” The Kleban prizes will be presented June 21 at a ceremony hosted by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers.

headline: Night of Goodbyes
text: It was a night of farewells as Andrew Garcia and Katie Stevens failed to make the cut on a double-elimination episode of “American Idol,” and “Ugly Betty” showed its final original episode. “American Idol” was the night’s big winner, drawing 20.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates and leading Fox to a first-place finish. On third-place ABC the finale of “Ugly Betty” (5.4 million) was up slightly over recent episodes of the series. CBS was the night’s runner-up as its “Criminal Minds” (12.2 million) had no problem holding off Fox’s “Human Target” (7.2 million). NBC ranked fourth for the night with a line-up of repeats.

headline: Lincoln Center Plans a Musical ‘Candida’
text: A musical based on a George Bernard Shaw play? It’s worked in the past. To a 2010-11 schedule that already includes a musical adaptation of “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown,” the transfer of the life-size-puppet play “War Horse” and John Guare’s long-awaited “Free Man of Color,” Lincoln Center Theater has added a new musical based on Shaw’s “Candida,” the theater company said. The musical, called “A Minister’s Wife,” tells the story of a minister and his wife, Candida, whose marriage is upended by a young poet; the adaptation is by Austin Pendelton (“Orson’s Shadow”), with music by Josh Schmidt (“Adding Machine”) and lyrics by Jan Tranen (“Night in Sarajevo”). It will be directed by Michael Halberstam, the artistic director and a co-founder of the Writers’ Theater in Glencoe, Ill., where the musical had its debut last year. The Lincoln Center Theater production will begin previews at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater next April 7. A cast has not yet been announced.

headline: Midsummer Swing Adds New Sounds
text: True to its name, there will be plenty of swing music this summer at Midsummer Night Swing, Lincoln Center’s annual series of al fresco dancing. Its 22nd season opens on June 29 with a battle of the big bands between the George Gee Orchestra and the Bill Elliott Swing Orchestra, and the 15 nights in Damrosch Park also include various species of jazzy swing by the Time Jumpers (Western swing, July 1), the New Orleans Moonshiners (New Orleans jazz, July 6), the Wycliffe Gordon Sextet (straight-up jazz, July 10) and the Harlem Renaissance Orchestra on closing night (yet more big-band swing, July 17). But continuing the ever-more multicultural evolution of Lincoln Center’s summer series, this year’s lineup also includes some notable new sounds, like the electronic tango of the Argentinean band narcotango (June 30), the Orchestre Septentrional d’Haiti (July 2), a bhangra night with D.J. Rekha (July 8) and Afrobeat with Femi Kuti and Positive Force (July 12); the J C Hopkins Biggish Band will be joined by the drag virtuosos Justin Bond and Joey Arias as well as the comedian Lea DeLaria (July 7). Each show is preceded by a dance lesson.

headline: Eminem Album Isn’t Canceled, Just Renamed
text: When Eminem posted a message on Twitter Wednesday morning that read, “There is no Relapse 2,” most readers took it to mean that he would not release a follow-up to his 2009 album “Relapse,” the first he had put out since “Encore” in 2004. But a few hours later Eminem, right, set his loyal fans straight, posting a second message that said only “RECOVERY,” and directed followers to his Web site, eminem.com. There he said that his new album, “Recovery,” will be released on June 22 by Aftermath/Interscope Records and will feature contributions from producers like DJ Khalil, Just Blaze, Jim Jonsin and Boi-1da. In a statement Eminem said: “I had originally planned for ‘Relapse 2’ to come out last year. But as I kept recording and working with new producers, the idea of a sequel to ‘Relapse’ started to make less and less sense to me, and I wanted to make a completely new album. The music on ‘Recovery’ came out very different from ‘Relapse,’ and I think it deserves its own title.”

headline: S.B.A. Faces Potential Discrimination Trial
text: The Small Business Administration could be headed to court to defend itself against accusations of discrimination in its investment financing programs. On March 29, a federal judge in Washington ruled against the S.B.A.’s motion for summary judgment in a lawsuit filed by a would-be venture capital fund. The fund, Diamond Ventures, which is based in Atlanta and run by two African-American men, planned to invest in poor, largely black communities in the Southeast.

headline: Seeing Things | An Absolute Stitch
text: Seeing Things is a biweekly design column by Brooke Hodge, a design writer and curator based in Los Angeles.Over the years I have amassed a small collection of vintage crewel kits designed by Erica Wilson, and have long wanted to meet the needlework legend. Last weekend, on a visit to Miami, I invited myself over to the 1960s apartment complex in Palm Beach, Fla., where Wilson spends the winters with her husband, the renowned — and charming — furniture designer Vladimir Kagan.

headline: Outside of the Blue and Yellow Box
text: The Brooklyn neighborhood of Red Hook may be most famous these days for affordable Swedish design, but a group of artists is giving the once rough-and-tumble peninsula a softer, more creative edge. Their fondness for turning salvaged objects into objets d’art makes the area feel like “a small town of misfit toys,” in one resident’s words, which might also serve to describe much of the creative class that now lives there. To reach these somewhat inaccessible streets, take the B61 bus to the Red Hook Ikea; the bus runs between Queens Plaza and Red Hook, stopping in Downtown Brooklyn near the Jay Street-Borough Hall subway stop (A, C, F lines) and near the Borough Hall stop (2, 3, 4, 5, M, R). Or take the water taxi to Ikea from Pier 11 near Wall Street.

headline: Genzyme Drug Shortage Leaves Users Feeling Betrayed
text: Because of a drug factory shutdown, Jeannine Lipez of Lock Haven, Pa., says she can no longer even walk across the street without getting spasms in her left leg and will probably need an operation to replace an artery.

headline: Raising the Bar
text: Anyone out there remember soap? The Samurai Shopper does, and admits a sentimental affection for soap’s plain-Jane properties. Soap may not be the most voluptuous product you’ve ever used, but it is efficient, disposable, a marvel of minimalism. I, like many others, traded up to fancy-pants facial gels, foams and creams that smell expensive — and are. But washing with emulsions of Meyer lemon or fig makes me think: what do figs smell like anyway, and should I smell like one?

headline: Decorative and Functional, Artistry From a Female Viewpoint
text: The American Folk Art Museum has an edge over other museums when it comes to collecting art made by women. Because many of its holdings fall outside the narrow scope of “professional” creativity, the usual biases of art history don’t always apply.

headline: ‘Journal of the Plague Year’
text: Prologue

headline: Precious Drugs That Come at a Cost Few Can Afford to Meet
text: Genzyme’s close relationships with its patients has helped the company during the current product shortage, as many have considered switching to alternate drugs from Shire and Protalix Biotherapeutics that were made available even before they had regulatory approval.

headline: How to Draw Time
text: It’s only April, and my vote for the most beautiful book of the year may be all sewn up.

headline: Tour-Worthy Milestone for Brazil’s Pop King
text: ROBERTO CARLOS has been so large a pop music presence for so long that when he first emerged he was nicknamed “the Elvis Presley of Brazil” and once opened a show there for Bill Haley and His Comets. But 50 years, 120 million records and various stylistic shifts later, he is more often described as “the Frank Sinatra of Latin America.”

headline: Reach for the Song, You No-Good Lousy Varmint!
text: A little more garlic in the Bolognese would be a definite boon to “Bloodsong of Love,” a new musical subtitled “The Rock ’n’ Roll Spaghetti Western.” This small-scaled show at Ars Nova, with book, music and lyrics by Joe Iconis, isn’t as pungent as its ripe title would suggest, and can’t seem to decide whether to favor sincere homage or flippant parody.

headline: Once Told He Would Never Play Again, Young Violinist Is Now a Star
text: Even under the best circumstances, it can be difficult for a prodigy to become a successful adult musician. When the violinist Augustin Hadelich, who had given his first concert at 7, was 15, he also had to contend with a terrible accident: he was badly burned when tractor fuel caught fire on his family’s vineyard. Some doctors told him he would never play again, but he surmounted the odds to win the International Violin Competition of Indianapolis in 2006 and has become one of the most distinctive violinists of his generation.

headline: Name of Driver in Pedestrian Death Matches That of Furniture Executive
text: As we reported earlier, a 65-year-old motorist named Harley Greenfield, of York Avenue on the Upper East Side, was charged with driving while impaired by alcohol after he struck and killed a man who was crossing the Whitestone Expressway in Queens on Wednesday night.

headline: 12 Days, 132 Films, 38 Countries
text: Don’t imagine that because its subject is 9/11, Alex Gibney’s documentary “My Trip to Al-Qaeda,” is merely the latest in a long list of depressing films about the aftermath of that catastrophe. “My Trip to Al-Qaeda,” which exemplifies the loftiest ambitions of the Tribeca Film Festival, beginning its ninth year on Wednesday, is an utterly compelling (dare I say entertaining?) personal history lesson, filled with insights that come as little jolts.

headline: Theater Listings: April 16 — 22
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: Scenes From the Night Shift
text: As a photographer, I work the night shift — when daylight gives way to moonlight, neon, and street light. In cities, especially New York, the darkness awakens me in a way the light of day never can. Gradually, my insomniac wanderings have taken me to the more ambiguous, transitional zones of the city. And I am seeing these not in black and white, as I used to, but in color — as if the visual noise of daytime were transforming itself into haunting nocturnal tonalities.

headline: New Taxes for Peggy Noonan
text: PEGGY NOONAN, a columnist at The Wall Street Journal, just bought an apartment on the Upper East Side for $1.72 million.

headline: Taliban Seen Behind 2 Car Bomb Attacks in Downtown Kandahar
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Militants exploded two car bombs in downtown Kandahar on Thursday evening, killing at least 2 people and wounding 23, local officials said.

headline: Strong Outing by Pelfrey Ends the Mets’ Losing Streak
text: DENVER — In the somber moments after another depressing defeat Wednesday night, David Wright stood at his locker and declared that the Mets had better start winning games soon, and it didn’t matter how it happened. The Mets had just lost their fourth consecutive game and the fifth in their last six, and a hint of early desperation was noted.

headline: A Historic Remodel
text: Nancy Smith and John Casey live in a red brick town house on 12th Street in the West Village with their daughters.

headline: On Jackie Robinson Day, a Met Reflects
text: DENVER — When Gary Matthews Jr. was growing up at his father’s side in ballparks around the National League, he saw role models everywhere. There was his father, of course, and teammates and opponents such as Bobby Bonds, Joe Morgan, Dusty Baker and Willie McCovey.

headline: Charter Extension Denied to Low-Scoring Stanford School
text: A charter school created and overseen by Stanford University’s School of Education was denied an extension of its charter on Wednesday night after several members of the school board labeled it a failure.

headline: Say Cheese to the Droid Incredible
text: HTC has designed a phone for people who like to take pictures with a phone. It has just announced the modestly named Droid Incredible, which pairs an 8 megapixel camera with a bright 3.7-inch AMOLED screen.

headline: Trio Arrested in H.P. Case on Kickbacks
text: FRANKFURT — Authorities in Germany have arrested three people who worked for the Hewlett-Packard Company as part of an investigation into accusations that kickbacks were paid in connection with a contract to supply equipment to Russian law enforcement agencies, a prosecutor’s office said Thursday.

headline: Cold Case, Warm Hearts: Death Leads to Romance
text: The past continually forces its way into the present in “The Secret in Their Eyes,” an attractive, messy drama riddled with violence and edged with comedy that comes with a hint of Grand Guignol, a suggestion of politics and three resonant, deeply appealing performances. Set primarily in contemporary Argentina with intermittent flashbacks to the 1970s when the country was descending into a military dictatorship, the film is by turns a whodunit (and why), a romance and something of a ghost story. A young dead woman lies at the center of the mystery, but she’s scarcely the only thing here haunting the living.

headline: Tulane: In M.&A. Talk, Strine Steals the Spotlight
text: 11:02 a.m. | CorrectedNEW ORLEANS — At Tulane University’s Corporate Law Institute, it’s a fair bet that if Leo E. Strine Jr. is on your panel, he will inevitably make a few memorable remarks.

headline: Former Clinton Counsel Forms Own Law Firm
text: Lanny J. Davis, a high-profile Washington lawyer who was the special counsel to President Bill Clinton in the 1990s, is leaving McDermott Will & Emery to form his own law firm. The new firm, Lanny J. Davis & Associates, will specialize in general litigation issues, media crisis and public policy issues.

headline: Before the Doors Close, Delivering One Last Baby
text: It appears that little Abigail Yael Jancu will be able to claim her place in history from birth: the last baby born to the last Catholic hospital in New York City.

headline: Geographical Me
text: My talk for the Association of American Geographers. (pdf)

headline: ‘Smurf House’? ‘Chinese Hat’? Museum Intrigues
text: METZ, France — From afar, the new Pompidou museum in this postindustrial landscape resembles an enormous snow-white toadstool rising out of a wasteland.

headline: River Surfing, Rugby Bonding and Bicycle Soaring
text: The connection between the Tribeca Film Festival and the sports cable network ESPN, now four years old, has brought the premieres of movies like David Mamet’s “Redbelt” and Spike Lee’s “Kobe Doin’ Work” to New York. This year the partnership is more noticeable than ever, as ESPN’s “30 for 30” series of original documentaries has raised sports films to a new prominence.

headline: Inside the List
text: YES HE CAN: “The Bridge,” David Remnick’s biography of Barack Obama, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 3. It’s Remnick’s first appearance on the hardcover list, though he did notch one week on the paperback list in 1994 with “Lenin’s Tomb,” his Pulitzer Prize-winning account of the fall of the Soviet Union.

headline: Weaknesses in the Strongest Teams
text: Zach Lowe writes for CelticsHub.com. He grew up in Connecticut watching the Bird-era Celtics with his father and hating Chuck Person. He now lives in Manhattan and dreams of a day in his adult lifetime when the Celtics and Knicks are both elite teams.

headline: How to Prevent Adoption Disasters
text: Updated, April 16, 1:30 p.m. | Cynthia R. Mabry, a professor at Howard University School of Law, joins the discussion.

headline: Details on the Tribeca Film Festival
text: The 2010 Tribeca Film Festival will begin on Wednesday and run through May 2, with screenings of 85 features and 47 short films at locations in Lower Manhattan. The festival will also include postscreening panel discussions and conversations with directors and actors, as well as free events like the Tribeca Drive-In, with outdoor screenings at the World Financial Center Plaza, North Cove, at 200 Vesey Street (Thursday to April 24, beginning at sundown with activities beginning earlier, at 6 p.m.). On May 1 there are several special events from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.: the Family Festival Street Fair, on Greenwich Street, between Chambers and Harrison Streets, and at the Tribeca Performing Arts Center, Borough of Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street; and the Tribeca/ESPN Sports Day, on Duane Street, between Greenwich and Hudson Streets; and a display of contemporary artwork, at the Chanel Boutique, 134 Spring Street, SoHo.

headline: Keep Your Team Out of My Book
text: Not long ago I began reading David Benioff’s “City of Thieves.” The novel had come highly recommended to me by several friends, and as I had already seen Spike Lee’s excellent film “25th Hour,” which is based on Benioff’s first novel, I was really looking forward to reading the book.

headline: It’s a Bird, It’s a Plane, It’s a Blood Bath
text: A story about a teenager who yearns to be a superhero, and a little girl who’s the star of her own splatter-happy head trip, the big-screen comic “Kick-Ass” could not be more calculating, or cynical. Fast, periodically spit-funny and often grotesquely violent, the film at once embraces and satirizes contemporary action-film clichés with Tarantino-esque self-regard  it’s the latest in giggles-and-guts entertainment.

headline: Egypt: Mubarak Back at Work After Surgery
text: egyptbrf President Hosni Mubarak resumed his duties on Thursday, almost six weeks after undergoing an operation in Germany to remove his gallbladder and a benign growth. He led a meeting with several government ministers in Sharm El Sheikh, where he has been recuperating since his return to Egypt about three weeks ago. Mr. Mubarak, who turns 82 next month and has ruled Egypt for almost three decades, did not announce whether he planned to run for another term in the presidential election next year.

headline: Up Front: Virginia Postrel
text: In this issue, the journalist Virginia Postrel reviews Sheena Iyengar’s book “The Art of Choosing.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE BRIDGE: The Life and Rise of Barack Obama,  by David Remnick (Knopf, $29.95.) This study of Obama before he became president, by the editor of The New Yorker, has many important additions and corrections to make to our reading of “Dreams From My Father.”

headline: France: Bin Laden Son Is Denied Visa
text: Omar bin Laden, the fourth son of Osama bin Laden, has been denied a visa to promote his new book in France and elsewhere in the European Union, his French publisher told Agence France-Presse on Thursday. The book, “Osama bin Laden: A Family Portrait,” denounces his father. The book was written with his mother, Najwa, 51, the first of Osama bin Laden’s five wives, and the American journalist Jean Sasson, said a spokesman for the publisher, Denoël.

headline: Israel: Former Premier Is Suspect in New Inquiry
text: Former Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, who resigned after being accused in several corruption cases, is now a chief suspect in a major bribery investigation involving a West Jerusalem building project when he was mayor of the city, Israeli news media reported Thursday. Mr. Olmert denied any wrongdoing. “I was never offered a bribe and have never received a bribe from anybody for anything in any way, either directly or indirectly,” he said in a televised statement.

headline: Obamas Report Earnings of $5.5 Million in 2009
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and his wife, Michelle, reported earnings of $5,505,509 in 2009, more than double their 2008 income of roughly $2.6 million, according to tax returns made public on Thursday by the White House.

headline: Cuomo’s State Pension Inquiry Extends to the Current Comptroller’s Office
text: The sprawling investigation into the state pension fund has reached the office of the current state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, the attorney general’s office acknowledged on Thursday.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,029 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Truth, Fiction and Tribeca
text: Stephen Holden narrates a look at some of the films appearing in the 2010 Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Tax Day Outside New York’s Main Post Office: Now, That’s Entertainment
text: In “The Hunchback of Notre Dame,” Victor Hugo had his cour des miracles, the courtyard of miracles. It was a gathering place for all sorts: musicians, mendicants, hucksters and peddlers, including some whose stock in trade was salvation.

headline: Lawyer to Put $2 Million Into Attorney General’s Race
text: Sean Coffey, a prominent trial lawyer who is one of the many Democratic candidates for state attorney general, will invest $2 million of his own money in his campaign, he said in an interview on Thursday.

headline: More Households Getting Federal Help
text: One in four households received government benefits in the third-quarter of 2008 because their income and assets fell below the federal threshold during the economic downturn, the Census Bureau said Thursday. Between May and November 2008, the percentage receiving any so-called means-tested benefit rose to 24.7 percent from 23.2 percent. The share collecting food stamps climbed to 8.8 percent from 7.6 percent and the proportion receiving Medicaid increased to 18.5 percent from 17.5 percent.

headline: Graying in a Home, Not an Institution
text: BALDWIN, N.Y.

headline: Paperback Row
text: COLUMBINE,  by Dave Cullen (Twelve, $15.99.) Everything you think you know about the Columbine High School massacre of April 20, 1999, is wrong. The shooters, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, were not victims of bullying. They did not belong to a goth “Trench Coat Mafia.” They did not single out blacks or Christians or athletes. “Eric Harris was a psychopath, simple as that,” our reviewer, Jennifer Senior, reported. “Dylan Klebold was a suicidally depressed kid who yoked his fate to a sadist.” This book by Cullen, who as a reporter in Denver covered the story for Salon and Slate, is a “fine example of old-fashioned journalism,” Senior said.

headline: Truths and Parables
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Normal as Woods Sends Early R.S.V.P.
text: By announcing his return to a PGA Tour event two weeks beforehand, Tiger Woods appears to be sending a message that he is serious about sorting out the problems in his game — and is ready to face golf fans at an event that is open to the ticket-buying public — well before the United States Open in June at Pebble Beach.

headline: Massachusetts: Expansion of Gambling Advances
text: In an about-face from two years ago, the Massachusetts House voted Wednesday to expand gambling, arguing that building two casinos and adding slot machines at four racetracks could create jobs. It is not clear whether the Senate and Gov. Deval Patrick, a Democrat, will go along with what would be the biggest expansion of gambling since the state introduced the lottery in 1971; Senate leaders and the governor oppose slot machines. The House vote is a sharp reversal from its vote in 2008 under a different House speaker. Wednesday’s vote was the result of a tour-de-force by Speaker Robert A. DeLeo, who has two racetracks in his district.

headline: Vietnam Novels
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wyoming: Ex-Radical Sues Over College Speech
text: William Ayers, the 1960s radical and current professor of education at the University of Illinois at Chicago, filed a federal lawsuit on Thursday against the University of Wyoming over its decision to bar him from speaking there. Mr. Ayers, a founder of the Weather Underground, was invited by the university’s Social Justice Research Center, which canceled his appearance last month. Tom Buchanan, university president, cited controversy over Mr. Ayer’s planned appearance and also safety concerns. A student tried to reserve a campus site for Mr. Ayers, but the university rejected that idea as well.

headline: Wisconsin: Ex-Governor Won’t Face Feingold
text: Former Gov. Tommy G. Thompson said Thursday that he would not run against Senator Russ Feingold this year. “My family didn’t want me to run,” Mr. Thompson, a Republican, told The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel just before he gave a speech to Tea Party supporters gathered at the State Capitol in Madison. Mr. Thompson, who served from 1987 to 2001, had been a popular governor, and talk of his potential candidacy had bolstered Republicans’ hopes of taking the seat from Mr. Feingold, a Democrat seeking his fourth term.

headline: Perception and Distortion
text: To the Editor:

headline: Subpoenas Sought for Information on Shootings
text: Top-ranking senators on the Homeland Security panel said Thursday that they would subpoena the Pentagon and the Justice Department if they did not provide more information by Monday on the shootings that left 13 people dead last year at Fort Hood in Texas. A Pentagon spokesman said the department recognized the committee’s interests, but had a responsibility to investigate and prosecute the shooting suspect, Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, in a way that preserves the judicial process.

headline: Twitter Loses Its Scrappy Start-Up Status
text: Twitter’s first developer conference, held this week in San Francisco, served as a coming-out party for the four-year-old service. Twitter the start-up is becoming Twitter the big company, with more polish, controversy, competition and revenue.

headline: Indecision-Making
text: Sheena Iyengar is the psychologist responsible for the famous jam experiment. You may have heard about it: At a luxury food store in Menlo Park, researchers set up a table offering samples of jam. Sometimes, there were six different flavors to choose from. At other times, there were 24. (In both cases, popular flavors like strawberry were left out.) Shoppers were more likely to stop by the table with more flavors. But after the taste test, those who chose from the smaller number were 10 times more likely to actually buy jam: 30 percent versus 3 percent. Having too many options, it seems, made it harder to settle on a single selection.

headline: A Portrait of the Tea Party Supporters
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Endless Prom, and an Attempt to Curb It
text: To the Editor:

headline: Financial Crisis Panel
text: To the Editor:

headline: Waiving Oil Royalties
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bank Troubles in Georgia
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reviewing Mine Safety, Obama Faults Company and the Government
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Thursday ordered a fresh round of coal mine inspections and a far-reaching review of mine safety, and said the federal government was partly to blame for the explosion that claimed 29 lives at the Upper Big Branch mine in West Virginia this month.

headline: A Baseball Story
text: “The Perfect Game,” about a ragtag Mexican team that improbably wins the Little League World Series, is so overwhelmed by its own based-on-actual-events tale that it can’t find the tone to tell it effectively. From start to finish you can almost hear William Dear, the director, and W. William Winokur, the first-time screenwriter, screaming: “Wow! Isn’t this a dandy story? So let’s throw in every gimmick we can think of  coldhearted father, tentative romance, tidy lessons in racism and sexism, cruel authority figures, labored catchphrases  to make sure everyone realizes what a dandy story it is.” Just let the kids play, for cryin’ out loud.

headline: And Now, a State Microbe
text: There it was, amid the long list of crucial bills that state legislators in Wisconsin were racing to vote on before their session ends next week: A bill to select the state’s official microbe. Yes, microbe.

headline: Imam and Informant Tells Why He Lied
text: He had built a life in this country. He grew up in Queens, attended high school there, and became a religious leader in his community. He would marry and marry again, have children, and buy a plot nearby where he planned to be buried.

headline: Interview: Bahman Ghobadi
text: Bahman Ghobadi discusses the legal perils of shooting a party scene in his film about rock musicians in Iran.

headline: Ohio Lawmakers Have Tax Day Tussle
text: Tax Day has been known to make people cranky. And relations between members of the two parties in Washington can get a bit tense.

headline: Arrested in Shoeshine Arsons, and Back Out Shining Shoes
text: The gentlest-looking person on an otherwise sharp-elbowed stretch of 42nd Street on Thursday seemed to be a short, sweet-faced man of 71 years, hunched over a little wooden shoeshine box.

headline: Obama Vows Renewed Space Program
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — Pointing to Mars and asteroids as destinations, President Obama on Thursday forcefully countered criticisms that he was trying to end the nation’s human spaceflight program.

headline: Where History’s March Is a Funeral Procession
text: Wroclaw, Poland

headline: Attacks on Military Computers Cited
text: WASHINGTON — Computer networks essential to the Pentagon and military are attacked by individual hackers, criminal groups and nations hundreds of thousands of times every day, according to the officer nominated to lead a cyberwarfare command.

headline: Polish Heroes, Polish Victims
text: Warsaw

headline: Walsh and Knicks Cannot Wait for Summer Sales Pitch
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The payroll is clear, the roster is nearly empty and the pain is subsiding. All the Knicks need now is a clever sales pitch and a willing savior.

headline: The Devastating Legacy of Thalidomide
text: How rare is it to discover a documentary about disability that scorns “differently abled” euphemisms and rhapsodies of inner beauty? Rare enough to make “NoBody’s Perfect” an exemplar of fresh-air filmmaking that addresses the devastating legacy of the drug thalidomide with acidic wit and grumpy honesty.

headline: With Tax Day as Theme, Tea Party Groups Demonstrate
text: WASHINGTON — Tea Party groups used Tax Day Thursday to stage rallies around the country where they pledged to turn their nascent movement into a powerful force to root out politicians they do not consider fiscally responsible.

headline: A Reprieve for Some Who Receive Housing Aid
text: Some of the 10,000 low-income families in danger of losing the rental assistance they get through a voucher program will probably keep receiving it, thanks to $23.5 million that the New York City Housing Authority is to receive from the federal government, officials said Thursday.

headline: School’s Out! (Temporarily); The Auditorium Collapsed
text: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y. — Students were expecting a tough week here at Mount Vernon High School, trying not to fall apart as they slogged through third-quarter exams and prepared for Advanced Placement exams and Regents tests.

headline: A Tale of Two Volcanoes
text: Sandisfield, Mass.

headline: 3 Tales on Disappearance of Gay Porn Star
text: The title alone should guarantee an audience of the curious, but despite marvelously moody visuals and a tantalizing setup, “Pornography: A Thriller” finally puzzles more than it pleases.

headline: Continental and United Resume Talks to Merge
text: When the music stopped on Thursday in the airline industry’s game of musical chairs, Continental Airlines and United Airlines were back in talks again, and US Airways was still trying to grab a seat.

headline: Obama Widens Medical Rights for Gay Partners
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Thursday ordered his health secretary to issue new rules aimed at granting hospital visiting rights to same-sex partners.

headline: U.N. Report Finds Faults in Pakistani Bhutto Inquiry
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A United Nations investigation into the assassination of the former opposition leader Benazir Bhutto has concluded that the failure of Pakistani authorities to effectively investigate the killing was “deliberate” and had been “severely hampered” by the country’s powerful intelligence agencies.

headline: The Fire Next Time
text: On Tuesday, Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader, called for the abolition of municipal fire departments.

headline: Blackhawks Enter N.H.L. Playoffs With Many Stars, Just Not in Goal
text: The Chicago Blackhawks have spent a great deal of money locking in some of the league’s best young talent, but they enter the playoffs having to rely on an untested goalie they acquired on the cheap.

headline: In a First, 2 British Leaders Vying to Be the Premier Debate, but a Third Face Shines
text: LONDON — The Times of London described it as the moment when “presidential politics arrive in Britain,” and ran a grainy front-page photograph of John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon in Chicago in 1960 in the first televised American presidential election debate.

headline: Children Left Behind
text: A mind-numbing barrage of random television clips and trash-talking heads, “The Cartel” purports to be a documentary about the American public school system. In reality, however, it’s a bludgeoning rant against a single state  New Jersey  which it presents as a closed loop of Mercedes-owning administrators, obstructive teachers’ unions and corrupt school boards.

headline: Recalling ’95 Bombing, Clinton Sees Parallels
text: WASHINGTON — With the 15th anniversary of the Oklahoma City bombing approaching, former President Bill Clinton on Thursday drew parallels between the antigovernment tone that preceded that devastating attack and the political tumult of today, saying government critics must be mindful that angry words can stir violent actions.

headline: C.I.A. Document Details Destruction of Tapes
text: WASHINGTON — Porter J. Goss, the former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, in 2005 approved of the decision by one of his top aides to destroy dozens of videotapes documenting the brutal interrogation of two detainees, according to an internal C.I.A. document released Thursday.

headline: Fighting Foreclosures
text: From the start, the central concern about President Obama’s antiforeclosure effort has been that it would postpone foreclosures but ultimately not prevent enough to ease the economic strain from mass defaults. That concern seems increasingly justified.

headline: Fifth Avenue and the Pent-up Urge
text: Wall Street analysts, commenting on positive retail sales numbers, have lately used the term that they’ve “beat expectations.” This is a little like a mother saying of her new son-in-law, “He’s not the handsomest, but he’s nice.” Yes, most department stores and specialty retailers like H & M saw decent sales gains for March. In Paris, LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton reported an 11 percent quarterly increase. But this was after a not-so-pretty 2009. And several luxury companies, including LVMH, continue to express caution about the rest of the year. Many people are still out of work, or finding work that pays less.

headline: Florida Governor Splits With G.O.P. on Teacher Pay
text: MIAMI — Gov. Charlie Crist has been jawboned and buttonholed as he has traveled around the state in recent days, and his office was deluged with 120,000 messages. Passions have not run so high in Florida, the governor said, since the controversy over ending the life of Terri Schiavo in 2005.

headline: Spying, Civil Liberties and the Courts
text: Succumbing to the politics of fear during the 2008 campaign, Congress seriously diluted the First and Fourth Amendment rights of Americans by changing the 1978 law that governs electronic surveillance.

headline: City Unemployment Rate Dropped to 10% in March
text: New York City’s unemployment rate declined again in March, falling to 10 percent and lending support to the view that the recession caused by the financial crisis is winding down.

headline: Housing Plan Survives For St. Vincent’s Site
text: As officials and physicians plod through the logistics and heartache of closing one of the city’s major hospitals, preservationists and developers are preoccupied with another issue: Will the St. Vincent’s Hospital campus be turned into luxury apartment buildings?

headline: After Their Arrival
text: More than half of the working immigrants in the St. Louis area hold higher-paying white collar jobs  Here, four men and women from across the world and the economic spectrum tell their stories coming to this metropolitan area.

headline: The Gun Lobby’s Colony
text: Cravenness and horse trading are too often the political reality in Washington, but a deal now in the works is particularly cruel.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 15, 2010

headline: Work Force Fueled by Highly Skilled Immigrants
text: ST. LOUIS — After a career as a corporate executive with her name in brass on the office door, Amparo Kollman-Moore, an immigrant from Colombia, likes to drive a Jaguar and shop at Saks. “It was a good life,” she said, “a really good ride.”

headline: Another Trump Hopes What Glitters Will Be Gold
text: OF all the shiny things in Donald and Melania Trump’s dining room on the 66th floor of Trump Tower — the gold panes on the floor-to-ceiling windows, the gold candelabra, the gold-toned mirrors etched with gold — the most distracting may be Mrs. Trump herself. Wearing black J Brand skinny jeans, a white Dolce & Gabbana blouse and select items from her soon-to-be-introduced jewelry line, Mrs. Trump is every bit the lithe, shimmering beauty that her modeling photos suggest.

headline: Band on the Run, Filmed on the Fly
text: Negar and Ashkan are two young people  it’s possible that they’re a couple, but you can’t quite be sure  who want to start a band. The style they favor is what they call indie rock, an apt enough designation for the sweet, moody songs they perform together, which would not sound out of place on the soundtrack of a movie at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: A Newspaper Leaves Behind Its City Roots
text: ATLANTA — When The Atlanta Journal-Constitution moves into its new home next week, its employees will have access to free parking, more natural light and a wide variety of “retail, service and dining options” at Perimeter Mall, according to a memorandum from the newspaper’s publisher, Michael Joseph.

headline: In Playoffs, Even the Best Have Room to Improve
text: No N.B.A. team is perfect. Even the best struggle with elements of the game, either because they de-emphasize them or because they’re just not very good at them. This can be magnified if it costs a team a victory during the playoffs. So here are elements the top four teams may want to work on now that the postseason has arrived.

headline: Women Who May Make People Break Up
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I love clues like “Company with the stock symbol DPZ.” I’m sure there are a few day traders out there who knew that answer immediately but for most of us, it’s the kind of clue that seems impossible at first. Hmmm. It probably starts with D. But what is that PZ all about? I bet it only took you a few seconds. Same with the 2006 Rihanna song “___ Been the One.” I don’t know who Rihanna is but by applying a little standard crossword logic, I was able to fill the blank from just the first letter. How about that novel with the chapter “Farming in Polynesia?” You’ve never read that book but if you’ve been doing crosswords for a while, you filled in that four-letter answer immediately. Does this mean crosswords are making us smarter? Or just filling our heads with useless trivia? Either way, it’s fun.

headline: Now It’s the President’s Plan
text: When it was unveiled  in budget documents  in February, we thought President Obama’s new approach to human space flight made good sense. But it drew immediate, fierce opposition from states that feared they would lose jobs and from Congressional boosters of the traditional space program.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Thursday with the continuation of a news analysis article about a shift in the Obama administration’s Middle East policy referred incorrectly to Ramat Shlomo, the name of a Jewish housing development that Israel says it is expanding despite objections by the United States and the Palestinian Authority. It is a neighborhood in East Jerusalem, not a settlement in the West Bank.

headline: President Signs Bill to Extend Jobless Aid
text: WASHINGTON — Congress on Thursday approved legislation that would keep unemployment checks flowing to jobless Americans, and President Obama immediately signed it.

headline: B.Y.U. Women’s Rugby Team Will Forfeit if It Reaches Sunday Game
text: The women on Brigham Young University’s club rugby team had every reason to expect that they would make it to the quarterfinals of the national college playoffs this weekend in Florida and California.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about high interest rates and fees on small loans to poor people misstated the annualized interest rate paid by Rosa Gonzalez Abad, a borrower in Mexico City shown in the photograph. While analysts have calculated that Compartamos, Ms. Abad’s lender, charged an average of nearly 82 percent in interest and fees in 2008, the most recent year available, Ms. Abad said she was not sure that was her own annualized rate.

headline: China’s Recovery Keeps Focus on Interest Rates and Currency
text: BEIJING — China’s accelerating economic recovery without signs yet of a surge in inflation may give the government some leeway in making two crucial decisions: raising interest rates and revaluing the Chinese currency.

headline: Debt Worries Shift to Portugal, Spurred by Rising Bond Rates
text: LONDON — Next target: Portugal.

headline: Genteel Lives Unsettled in Uruguay
text: “The City of Your Final Destination” is as pure an example of the Merchant Ivory brand of upscale literary cinema as devotees of “Howards End,” “A Room With a View” and “The Remains of the Day” could ask for. But times have changed. Partly because the rarefied aesthetic climes conjured by the film barely exist anymore, its story feels as quaint as the once-vital Merchant Ivory ethos of hothouse nostalgia  with its antique-shop sensibility and Anglo-European snob appeal  does.

headline: Back (Way Back) to Drinking’s Basics
text: There’s no greater confirmation that the age of the byzantine cocktail and its apron-clad ministers has mellowed than the fact that the long-awaited bar from the mix maestros Jeff Hollinger and Jonny (Flash) Raglin will de-emphasize cocktails.

headline: Despite Budget Woes, University Still Has Money for Bottled Water
text: Times are tough at the University of California. The state’s budget crisis has led to cuts, layoffs and higher student fees.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on April 2 about Iran’s influence on the political groupings in Iraq that emerged after the March 7 elections misidentified the holiday celebration in Tehran attended by top officials of three major Iraqi political alliances on March 27. As noted elsewhere in the article, it was for the Persian new year, which always begins on the first day of spring  not the Islamic new year, which follows a lunar calendar and shifts each year. (The most recent Islamic new year holiday was on Dec. 18, 2009.)

headline: Rooney Says Steelers Are Prepared to Issue Roethlisberger’s Discipline
text: As more troubling details about Ben Roethlisberger’s encounter with a 20-year-old college student in a Georgia bar emerged Thursday, the Pittsburgh Steelers’ president, Art Rooney II, said the Steelers would move forward with Roethlisberger at quarterback and would prefer to discipline him themselves.

headline: Being Forced to Make Do
text: Most of the Bay Area’s nine counties and their major cities are wrestling with multimillion-dollar deficits and draconian cuts. The required reductions come at a time when they have been hit by revenue losses and the state has contributed many millions less.

headline: Remaking an Ancient Farce From 2007
text: An effective farce is a comic contraption that largely runs on its own crude mechanics. The surprises and sight gags, however they are discharged, are more important than the actors and the direction.

headline: Washington, With Few Options, Signs New Jets Deal
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Leon Washington, the electrifying back who looked as if he might make an off-season getaway from the Jets, let everyone know on Thursday that he wore Jets gear as he worked out in Florida while he recovered from a leg injury that ended his 2009 season.

headline: Postscript
text: NATIONAL

headline: Air Travel Chaos Deepens Into Weekend
text: This article is by Alan Cowell, Liz Robbins and Nicola Clark.

headline: F.D.A. Again Warns a Generic Maker About Conditions at Its Plants
text: Federal regulators have raised another red flag about the quality of generic drugs, sending a warning letter to a leading maker about manufacturing violations.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Days Of Tea And Wine
text: I just had dinner in DC with a bunch of geographers, at a cute French bistro near Dupont Circle. And who should walk in but about eight tea partiers, still carrying their protest signs. They marched in, then upstairs, and sat down for dinner.

headline: On the Street, at the Corner of Art and Trash
text: There is something indescribably odd about Thierry Guetta, the antic Frenchman and Ron Jeremy lookalike who guides our experience  and would like to guide our perceptions  of “Exit Through the Gift Shop.”

headline: On Robinson Day, a Namesake Is the Star
text: Like every player in the major leagues on Thursday, Robinson Cano wore on his back the number 42 to honor Jackie Robinson, who broke baseball’s color barrier in 1947.

headline: For Bulls, the Playoffs Are Just a Band-Aid
text: A general manager’s going for his coach’s throat is pretty radical behavior, even by the laissez-faire standards of a league that includes gun-carrying Gilbert Arenas and the unfailingly bizarre Ron Artest, among others.

headline: Agencies Are Stretched in Efforts to Aid Refugees
text: The hum of sewing machines echoed through the basement of the United Church of Rogers Park on a recent Friday morning. Refugee women from Bhutan, Iraq, Myanmar, Somalia, Eritrea and Ethiopia sat at the machines, exchanging smiles and nods, but few words.

headline: City Treasurer Threatens Defamation Suit Over Policeman’s Articles
text: Mayor Richard M. Daley grudgingly bears the news media’s tendency to “scrooten” him constantly. Stephanie D. Neely, the first-term city treasurer, is taking a different approach to dealing with scrutiny from at least one pen-wielding critic. She retained a lawyer and is threatening a defamation suit against a Chicago police officer who repeatedly criticized her in the F.O.P. News, a union newsletter published by the local Fraternal Order of Police.

headline: A Lawmaker’s Vacation, Learning by Doing
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: A Sexual Advance, a Savage Beating, Years of Guilt
text: The protagonist of “Handsome Harry,” Bette Gordon’s pungently didactic critique of the masculine mystique among American men of a certain age and generation, is an electrician in his early 50s who still has a roguish glint in his eye. The divorced father of a grown son with whom he has a distant relationship, Harry Sweeney (Jamey Sheridan) still walks with the swagger of an aging roué who knows he is catnip to women over 40 and has no need for Viagra. But in a confessional moment, he candidly admits he has been “very busy being a failure.”

headline: Big Leveraged Buyouts May Soon Make a Comeback
Now G.I. Jane Is Somebody’s Mom
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, CALIF.

headline: Buy, Buy, Buy, to Keep Up With the You-Know-Whos
text: As glossy and golden-tinged as a magazine advertisement spread, “The Joneses” proposes itself, at least at first, as a satire of modern consumerism. Members of the titular family, a foursome with perfect teeth, lithe bodies and limitless sex appeal, don’t just embody a sleek and seamless ideal of material comfort and aesthetic perfection. They also sell that ideal, with an aggression that is no less ruthless for being invisible.

headline: A.M.D. Posts Profit as Sales Rise by 34%
text: Advanced Micro Devices, the microprocessor maker, reported first-quarter sales on Thursday that beat analysts’ predictions, adding to evidence that personal computer demand was increasing.

headline: Reyes’s Moving Problem
text: DENVER — Jerry Manuel said on Thursday that he basically can’t wait to put Jose Reyes in the third spot in the batting order, but at least one player is skeptical about the Mets plan, and it’s not even Jose Reyes.

headline: Central Bank in Europe Sees a Crisis Returning
text: The European Central Bank warned Thursday that a resurgence of enormous trade imbalances and growing government debt were creating a volatile mix that could ignite new economic turmoil.

headline: Veteran Experiences His First Yankees Roll Call
text: Randy Winn played as a substitute in seven of the Yankees’ first eight games but made his first start Thursday night in the third game of a three-game series against the Los Angeles Angels at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Paroled Murderer Shoots His Parole Officer at His Desk in Brooklyn
text: A paroled murderer walked up to his parole officer in a state office in Downtown Brooklyn on Thursday evening and shot him in the shoulder, the authorities said.

headline: U.S. Clears Boston Scientific to Resume Defibrillator Sales
text: The Boston Scientific Corporation said Thursday that the Food and Drug Administration was allowing it to resume defibrillator sales after a one-month halt caused by the company’s failure to notify regulators about manufacturing changes to the devices.

headline: What We’re Reading: Opera on the iPhone
text: The tech reporters and editors of The New York Times watched the sales of a rival to Apple’s Safari and saw a backlash against Apple’s ad strategy begin to brew. Then there was that warning about a solar flare and electronic equipment. Our reading list:

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Brazil'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Terry Gilliam's sprawling dystopian science fiction film about repression.

headline: Venture Capitalists Continue to Take It Slow
text: The venture capital industry seems to need a bit longer to recover after last year, when Silicon Valley froze in response to the economic uncertainty.

text: mote •\ˈmot\• noun

headline: Senate G.O.P. Leader Calls on Party to Stop Fiscal Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, labored on Thursday to unite his caucus in opposition to legislation to tighten regulation of the nation’s financial system, as Democrats expressed dismay that Republicans were threatening not only to vote against the bill but to block the start of floor debate.

headline: Viewing Baseball Through a Prism of the Numbers
text: Sean Forman is the creator of Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores in the major and minor leagues.

headline: U.S. Nuclear Threat
text: Conventional wisdom is that the Cold War danger nuclear missile strikes has given way to a new threat: nuclear devices in the hands of terrorists.

headline: Finance Bill Consensus on a Point: No Bailouts
text: WASHINGTON — As the Obama administration and Senate Republicans clash over the future of the nation’s financial regulatory system, there is one principle on which they agree: Taxpayers should never again have to bail out giant financial institutions.

headline: Eve of Destruction
text: Eighteen months after the failure of Lehman Brothers, writers seeking to make sense of the debacle have had their say: the first responders and ­e-booksters, the polemicists and shoe-leather reporters, the boardroom whisperers and I-told-you-so scolds, the would-be screenwriters and former policy makers. For those fortunate enough to be on the receiving end of publishers’ entreaties, a certain amount of Panic of 2008 fatigue has set in. I’ve read at least five times that the ­JPMorgan Chase chief executive Jamie Dimon’s 52nd-birthday dinner at the midtown Greek restaurant Avra was interrupted by a call about Bear Stearns’s travails.

headline: Charter Extension for Stanford’s School Denied and Highlights from Friday’s Bay Area Pages
text: Stanford Charter School Faces Closure | A charter school created and overseen by Stanford University’s School of Education was denied an extension of its charter on Wednesday night after several members of the school board labeled it a failure. Last month, the state had placed the charter school, Stanford New School, on its list of persistently lowest-achieving schools.

headline: Human Orbits
text: According to the perverse aesthetics of artistic guilty pleasure, certain books and movies are so bad — so crudely conceived, despicably motivated and atrociously executed — that they’re actually rather good. “Solar,” the new novel by Ian McEwan, is just the opposite: a book so good — so ingeniously designed, irreproachably high-minded and skillfully brought off — that it’s actually quite bad. Instead of being awful yet absorbing, it’s impeccable yet numbing, achieving the sort of superbly wrought inertia of a Romanesque cathedral. There’s so little wrong with it that there’s nothing particularly right about it, either. It’s impressive to behold but something of a virtuous pain to read.

headline: Oscar Tuazon: ‘My Flesh to Your Bare Bones’
text: Oscar Tuazon’s latest solo is really a duet, in the key of postminimalism. Mr. Tuazon, a sculptor who tends to evoke collapsed or ruined architecture, has come up with a fine-tuned and personal response to a piece by Vito Acconci. It combines sound with fragmentary sculpture, both haunting.

headline: ‘Self-Fulfilling Prophecies’
text: “Self-Fulfilling Prophecies,” a group show of 18 artists ranging in age from the high 20s to the low 60s, broadcasts an undeniable cheer about art’s current condition. An in-house job organized by Leo Koenig along with Elizabeth Balogh and Nicole Russo, the gallery’s directors, it is selective without being narrow, inclusive without being lax. It doesn’t attempt to account for everything, but it also doesn’t make what’s missing feel left out. Irony abounds, and language is often a primary weapon, but strong emotions surge beneath. Parodies are parried; homage is paid, differences illuminated.

headline: Eva Hesse
text: Eva Hesse’s name still has magic, because of her radical and influential art and because of the short time she was given to make it, about a decade before her death in 1970 at the age of 34.

headline: Shirley Jaffe: ‘Selected Paintings 1969-2009’
text: Freud contended that everything means something or nothing does, and Shirley Jaffe, an American painter in her 80s who has lived in Paris since 1949, would seem to agree.

headline: Freddie Brice
text: Using wide brushes and mostly black and white house paint on thin pieces of plywood, Freddie Brice made paintings notable for their spontaneity, economy of means and comical, enigmatic imagery. Born in South Carolina in 1920, he moved to Harlem at 9, and he began painting in his early 60s at an art workshop after years of incarceration and psychiatric institutionalization. There is a childlike immediacy and simplicity about his self-taught style, a directness that appeals to eyes trained by Modernist painting. One magical picture is nothing but a white-spotted black snake about to bite its own tail. It seems unlikely that Mr. Brice would have known that this image  the uroboros  is frequently encountered in antique, mystical tomes.

headline: News Quiz | April 16, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Navigating the U.C. Budget, Without Maps
text: For this week’s column, I ventured into the labyrinth of the University of California’s budget. Or, to be more accurate, I tried to do so. I couldn’t get very far on my own, which raises questions about the transparency of the university’s finances.

headline: Macarthur to Hold Talks With Peabody
text: The Australian mining company Macarthur Coal, which for weeks has been the object of an intensifying takeover battle, on Friday said it would enter discussions with one the bidders, Peabody Energy, a United States company that earlier this week sweetened its offer to $3.8 billion, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

headline: Rare Finance Bill Consensus: No Bailouts
text: As the Obama administration and Senate Republicans clash over the future of the financial regulatory system, there is one principle on which they agree: Taxpayers should never again have to bail out giant financial institutions, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: Protest Leaders Elude Capture by Thai Commandos
text: BANGKOK — In a new humiliation for the Thai government, several leaders of the red-shirt protest movement escaped from a hotel on Friday after it had been surrounded by security forces — even as a deputy prime minister was announcing the raid live on television.

headline: Senate G.O.P. Leader Calls on Party to Stop Fiscal Bill
text: The Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, labored on Thursday to unite his caucus in opposition to legislation to tighten regulation of the nation’s financial system, as Democrats expressed dismay that Republicans were threatening not only to vote against the bill, but to block the start of floor debate, David M. Herszenhorn reports in The New York Times.

text: WHO bathed in the Ganges river in India this week?

headline: Twitter Loses Its Scrappy Start-Up Status
text: Twitter‘s first developer conference, held this week in San Francisco, served as a coming-out party for the four-year-old service. Twitter the start-up is becoming Twitter the big company, with more polish, controversy, competition and revenue.

headline: Towns in Europe Learn About Swaps the Hard Way
text: The worst global financial crisis in 70 years arrived in Saint-Étienne, France, this month, as embedded financial obligations began to blow up, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Norris: Low Rates Good for Banks, but Pity the Saver
text: Aren’t low short-term interest rates wonderful? If you are a bank, the answer is yes, particularly because the low rates are accompanied by somewhat higher longer-term rates. If you are a saver, however, your view might be very different, Floyd Norris writes in his latest column in The New York Times.

headline: Polish Insurer May Set Price Near $3.5 Billion
text: PZU Group, Poland’s largest insurer, will set on Monday the maximum price for individual investors in what is expected to be Europe’s largest initial public offering worth up to $3.5 billion, Reuters reported.

headline: The Ermintrude Effect
text: The fear of looking like a ruminant when eating watercress.(Ermintrude is a cow in the psychedelic children’s television animation, “The Magic Roundabout.”)

headline: U.S. Team Is Named
text: Two Rangers and two Islanders were among 12 players named to the United States team for the I.I.H.F. world championships in Germany next month. Forwards Brandon Dubinsky of the Rangers and Kyle Okposo of the Islanders and defensemen Matt Gilroy of the Rangers and Jack Hillen of the Islanders were among the selections.

headline: N.F.L. Wins Ruling Over Revenue Sharing
text: The N.F.L. won a labor skirmish when the special master Stephen Burbank upheld the implementation of the supplemental revenue-sharing program adopted with the 2006 collective bargaining agreement.

headline: What is Your Reaction to the News About International Adoption?
text: Russia has suspended international adoptions by Americans in response to the case of a 7-year-old boy who was sent back to Moscow alone last week by his adoptive mother in Tennessee. Have you been following this news? What is your reaction?

headline: At Coachella, California and Veteran Musicans Provide Roots
text: INDIO, Calif. — Even in the age of YouTube and Webcasts, a rock festival is the essence of a site-specific event, a convergence of geography, demographics, weather, booking and people bumping into you. The 11th Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, here at the Empire Polo Field this weekend, flaunts its location in the California desert — its small stages are named Gobi, Mojave and Sahara — and usually has a well-styled Hollywood contingent in the V.I.P. zone.

headline: Idex Nabs Seals Ltd. for $54 Million
text: Idex, a maker of pumps and metering products, said Thursday it bought Seals Ltd., a provider of seals for a broad range of industries like semiconductor and solar technologies, for about £35 million ($54 million), The Associated Press reported.

text: Authorities in Germany have arrested three people who worked for the Hewlett-Packard Company as part of an investigation into accusations that kickbacks were paid in connection with a contract to supply equipment to Russian law enforcement agencies, The New York Times’s Jack Ewing reported.

headline: Pension Corp., a British Insurer, Is Said to Diversify
text: Pension Corporation, the specialist insurer, is making a first foray into real estate and has raised its exposure to hedge funds as part of a broad effort to diversify a largely fixed-income and cash-oriented strategy, Reuters reported.

headline: In Tajikistan, Women Fill a Void
text: Mashid Mohadjerin was 8 years old when she and her family left their home in Iran after the revolution. She still remembers the sadness of leaving and the awkwardness of learning life in a new country. First, it was adjusting to Pakistan. Then, a year later, it was acclimating to Belgium. Now, at 33, Ms. Mohadjerin says she feels as if she has found her place as a resident New Yorker.

headline: Goldman-Backed Whitehall Said to Lose 98 Percent

headline: O’Neal Foiled Twice in 2007 Effort to Sell Merrill
text: Stan O’Neal, former chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch, saw his firm’s liability to $45 billion worth of collateralized debt obligations (C.D.O.’s) a year before the crisis hit, but was blocked twice in 2007 when he tried to negotiate to sell the bank, Fortune reported.

headline: In Sickness and in Wealth, Sweethearts in Crime
