text: I caught up with Thomas Jones, the former Jets running back who signed this off-season with Kansas City, in Manhattan recently. He was there to talk to a literary agent about a book, and also pursuing other entertainment-related projects. More details will be available in coming months.

headline: Street Art Goes Mainstream in Rome
text: For years, the Roman street artist was written off as a vandal who worked under the cover of night to prevent being apprehended by police. Slowly, this reputation has evolved and now many artists are featured in private galleries, awarded corporate sponsorships, and even granted public spaces by city authorities. This spring, three Roman neighborhoods will host street art exhibitions in which once anonymous artists will produce their work in public view for the first time.

headline: Will Write-Offs for Retiree Health Care Kill Jobs?
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton and a trustee or director of various health care companies and funds.

headline: Cuomo’s Pension Inquiry Extends to DiNapoli

text: Around 60 percent of the $24.8 trillion credit derivatives market can rapidly move to central clearing and reduce systemic risk, but moving much beyond that could be counterproductive, Reuters said, citing market experts.

Gupta’s decision, announced last month, not to seek re-election to Goldman Sachs‘s board came after he received notice from prosecutors that they were looking into recorded conversations Mr. Gupta held with the Galleon Group founder Raj Rajaratnam, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people close to the matter.

headline: A Private Plan for a Hydrogen Highway
text: Many alternative-fuel companies are cash-poor, which means they spend a lot of their time chasing government loans and private capital. SunHydro, a start-up founded by Tom Sullivan to establish a solar-powered fuel-cell car refueling network on the East Coast, doesn’t have that immediate challenge. In 1993, Mr. Sullivan founded Lumber Liquidators, a hardwood flooring retailer that now boasts more than 200 stores and, according to Reuters, had $544 million in net sales last year.

text: PARIS — Businesses around Europe were scrambling to make contingency plans Friday as a cloud of volcanic ash from Iceland kept airports closed, while insurance companies were hoping to avoid having to cover any losses.

headline: Sampler: Lawsuit Seeks Suede Nightclub Closure, and Palm Fronds For Oakland Elephants
text: 10,000 Turn Out for Pleasanton Tea Party Rally | Political candidates like Carly Fiorina, the Republican who is trying to unseat Senator Barbara Boxer, went to the Alameda County Fair Grounds to rally Tea Party followers to their campaigns. But most of the talk during the five-hour rally focused on general discontent with the Obama administration’s economic policies and the recently passed health care legislation. “This is great timing for us,” said Bridget Melson, the president of the Pleasanton T.E.A. (Taxed Enough Already) Party and the event’s organizer. “The passing of the health care bill has incensed and fired people up.” Among the slogans visible at the event was: “Vote the traitors out in November.” A New York Times poll shows that Tea Party supporters are wealthier than the general public, tend to be Republican and classify themselves as “angry.” [The Contra Costa Times, The New York Times]

headline: Chinese Premier Visits Tibetan Quake Survivors
text: JIEGU, China — Prime Minister Wen Jiabao spent Friday in the Tibetan high country, comforting survivors of this week’s devastating earthquake in a prominent display of concern by the country’s Han leadership for one of China’s most troubled ethnic minorities.

headline: Miss Liberty From Every Angle
text: Late Thursday morning, Katherine Dolgy Ludwig parked herself on a sun-drenched wooden bench on the High Line, took her red, yellow and blue watercolors from a canvas lunch bag and began to paint.

headline: After the Housing Bust, Construction Shows Life
text: In a modest sign that the housing market is moving toward more normal conditions, the pace of home building is finally picking up from its near-death levels.

headline: The Early Word: Visitation Rights
text: President Obama has ordered new rules that give visitation rights to same-sex partners of patients at any hospital that participates in Medicare or Medicaid.

text: ON the same day that Consumer Reports tested the 2010 Lexus GX 460 sport utility vehicle and found what it considered a dangerous handling problem, it also tested a related vehicle, the 2010 Toyota 4Runner. The Toyota did just fine.

headline: Return of a Rock Star That Didn’t Cross Over
text: A PLUME of pale-beige dust half a mile long trailed behind a vehicle racing across El Diablo Dry Lake. Ivan Stewart, a legendary off-road racer known as the Ironman, was driving flat-out at triple-digit speeds. He was at the wheel of a new Toyota 4Runner and, man, I wanted one.

headline: Shoe Shiner Arrested for Arson Keeps Shining
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Reading, Riding, Wristmanship
text: FOR enthusiasts who believe that motoring fun rides on two wheels, not four, here is a handful of short reviews, all related to motorcycles. The four books range from a history of the late and lamented English motorcycle industry to road tests of both classic and new bike designs. And there's even a DVD on precision cornering. CHARLES McEWEN

headline: Samurai Shopper | Raising the Bar
text: Anyone out there remember soap? The Samurai Shopper does, and admits a sentimental affection for soap’s plain-Jane properties. Soap may not be the most voluptuous product you’ve ever used, but it is efficient, disposable, a marvel of minimalism. I, like many others, traded up to fancy-pants facial gels, foams and creams that smell expensive — and are. But washing with emulsions of Meyer lemon or fig makes me think: what do figs smell like anyway, and should I smell like one?

headline: Should You Tell the Employees?
text: The issue of what you tell your employees when you’re trying to sell your business is a tricky one that requires careful thought. Maintaining confidentiality surrounding the sale typically takes precedence over other concerns, yet it may be impractical — or even impossible — to keep employees in the dark.

headline: Wall Street’s Win Streak Ends at 6
text: Wall Street seemed headed for another strong weekly finish on Friday — and then the news hit.

headline: Updates on the Volcanic Ash Cloud

The Lede will provide updates on the movement of the ash cloud throughout the day.

headline: Graphic Book Best-Sellers: A Big Piece of the Pie for ‘One Piece’
text: Of the eight new books on the manga list on Friday, five are volumes of “One Piece.” The series follows the adventures of Monkey D. Luffy, a 17-year-old adventurer and his ragtag crew on the search for One Piece, a pirate treasure. “One Piece” is incredibly popular in Japan: The Anime News Network reported that Volume 56 had a print run of 2.85 million copies. The publication schedule put forth by VIZ Media in the United States is an aggressive one. From January through June, the company plans to publish five installments a month, taking the series from volume 24 to 53. This week, Volumes 39-43 sit on the manga list. Previews of the first eight chapters are available here. The site also includes character bios and motion comics.

headline: Theater Prizes Are Awarded
text: The playwright Dan LeFranc and the musical theater songwriters Peter Mills and Barry Wyner have won awards recognizing promising new talent in American theater, the sponsors of the prizes announced.

headline: ‘Rough Justice’ for Eliot Spitzer, in Book and Movie Form
text: If any publicity is good publicity, then this has been an excellent week for Eliot Spitzer, the former governor of New York. In Friday’s New York Times, Michiko Kakutani reviews Peter Elkind’s “Rough Justice: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer,” which chronicles the disgraced politician’s trajectory from Sheriff of Wall Street to Client 9. For several days, the Internet has been aflame with chatter generated by a Playboy interview and photo shoot with Ashley Dupré, the woman whose 2008 encounter with Mr. Spitzer led to his downfall (don’t look for any links here). Now, via the good folks at Flavorwire, we’re led to the above clip for the documentary film version of “Rough Justice,” directed by Alex Gibney (“Taxi to the Dark Side”), a version of which will be shown at the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: U.A.W. President Says ‘Things Are Turning Around’
text: Ron Gettelfinger has had a rather bumpy ride as president of the United Auto Workers union, but he brought a message of hope with him to a meeting of the International Motor Press Association on Thursday in New York.

headline: Truth and Consequences
text: If it’s true that traits like novelty-­seeking and risk-aversion are genetic in origin, then Mary Beth Latham’s biological makeup appears to be tilted toward safety and security. Mary Beth, the narrator of Anna Quindlen’s engrossing new novel, “Every Last One,” values stability and sameness, finding quiet contentment in her long, amiable marriage to an ophthalmologist and in her flourishing career as a landscaper. But her most intense feelings and greatest concerns are centered on her three teenage children: lovely Ruby, nearing her last year of high school, and the twins, Max and Alex, who will be freshmen next year.

headline: Oracle to Buy Phase Forward for $685 Million
text: Oracle said Friday that it had agreed to buy the drug data management software company Phase Forward for about $685 million in a deal aimed at bolstering its health sciences business, Reuters reports.

headline: Upstart With the Marks of Experience
text: THERE is something ridiculous about asking Stephen Petronio how he wants his dances to live on when he’s no longer around to look after them. This svelte, handsome choreographer is only 54. Vibrant tattoos snake along his arms, an enduring stamp of his rebellious punk roots.

headline: Mayor John Lindsay
text: A selection of images from "America’s Mayor: John V. Lindsay  and the Reinvention of New York," an exhibit at the Museum of the City of New York.

headline: ‘I’ Exam
text: Over the last 25 years, the memoir — or The Story of My Life, as Vivian Gornick calls it — has become one of the major gestures of American writing. In direct opposition to the literal-­minded, linear and epistemologically naïve nature of many such works, there has emerged in the last dozen years a vital countertradition, what John D’Agata labels the “lyric essay.” It’s a form with ancient roots. Hera­clitus, anyone?

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Goldman of Fraud in Housing Deal
text: Goldman Sachs, the Wall Street powerhouse, was accused of securities fraud in a civil lawsuit filed Friday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which claims the bank created and sold a mortgage investment that was secretly intended to fail.

headline: Those Who Wait
text: In Olga Grushin’s second novel, “The Line,” hundreds of citizens spend several hours a day, every day for a year, waiting to buy tickets to a concert that may or may not take place. The premise is loosely based on Stravinsky’s 1962 concert in Leningrad, which was likewise preceded by a yearlong ticket line.

headline: Flexible Spending, a Little Less So
text: THANKS to the sweeping new health law, your flexible spending plan is about to become a bit less flexible.

headline: New Law Lowers Flex-Spending Benefit
text: In Friday’s Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad writes about one of the casualties of health reform: flexible spending benefits for health care costs are being cut.

headline: Newspaper Advertising Decline is Slowing Markedly at Gannett
text: 1:05 p.m. | Updated Looks like Moody’s Investors Service was paying attention to that Gannett quarterly report, too. Moody’s on Friday changed its outlook on the newspaper industry from “negative” to “stable.” Which could be like a hospital patient being “critical but stable.”

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Goldman of Fraud in Mortgage Deal
text: 1:56 p.m. | Updated Goldman Sachs, which emerged relatively unscathed from the financial crisis, was accused of securities fraud in a civil suit filed Friday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which claims the bank created and sold a mortgage investment that was secretly devised to fail, The New York Times’s Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson report. (Read the S.E.C.’s lawsuit after the jump.)

headline: Friday Reading: Getting More for Your Money in Europe
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Overextended Family
text: Ostensibly, the central characters in “The Bradshaw Variations,” Rachel Cusk’s seventh novel, are a husband and wife named Thomas Bradshaw and Tonie Swann. Also ostensibly, the novel’s plot follows the year Thomas leaves the work force to take care of their daughter and his wife returns to a full-time job. But it soon becomes apparent that the novel is not exactly about these two individuals, nor is it overly concerned with the “Mr. Mom” circumstances newly introduced into their lives. What “The Bradshaw Variations” is about, however, is hard to say.

headline: And Now for Something Completely Different: Terry Gilliam’s First Opera
text: As long as his production doesn’t go exorbitantly over budget, abruptly run out of funds, get ruined in a flash flood or drowned out by NATO aircraft drills — all calamities that have befallen him in the past — the director Terry Gilliam is scheduled to make his operatic debut with the English National Opera next year, The Guardian reported. Mr. Gilliam, the Monty Python alumnus whose films include “Brazil” and “The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus,” and whose disaster-plagued shoot for an aborted film, “The Man Who Killed Don Quixote,” was the subject of the documentary “Lost in La Mancha,” will direct a production of Berlioz‘s “Damnation of Faust” that is planned for May 2011.

headline: We Three Things | Lip Reading
text: If the eyes are window to the soul, then the mouth is window to the gut, revealing anxieties, turmoil and hidden appetites. My partially deaf step-aunt lip-reads, and she understands me better than any other member of my family. The way a person smiles clues us into their disposition and emotional state, and whether painted, bitten or sealed, lips are constantly speaking volumes.

headline: Fashion Hotel Opens in New York City
text: New hotels continue to pop up in New York City.  Fashion 26-A Wyndham Hotel, opened this week in the city’s garment district, a block away from the Fashion Institute of Technology on West 26th Street.

headline: The Making of the iPad Town Hall Video
text: Every week, I write and star in a goofy 3-minute video about whatever I reviewed in The Times that week. It airs on CNBC at around 1:40 p.m. Thursday, and then it goes online—to nytimes.com, YouTube, iTunes, TiVo, JetBlue and so on.

headline: Weighing the Evidence on Exercise
text: How exercise affects body weight is one of the more intriguing and vexing issues in physiology. Exercise burns calories, no one doubts that, and so it should, in theory, produce weight loss, a fact that has prompted countless people to undertake exercise programs to shed pounds. Without significantly changing their diets, few succeed. “Anecdotally, all of us have been cornered by people claiming to have spent hours each week walking, running, stair-stepping, etc., and are displeased with the results on the scale or in the mirror,” wrote Barry Braun, an associate professor of kinesiology at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, in the American College of Sports Medicine’s February newsletter.

headline: An Unnecessary Law
text: To the Editor:

headline: My Daughter, the User
text: To crudely paraphrase Tolstoy, all addicts’ families are alike, and when it comes to teenage drug abusers they’re unnervingly alike, right down to the last battering detail. So I was fewer than 30 pages into Anne Lamott’s powerful and painfully honest novel when a chill of recognition shot through me. Rosie — 17, bright and sweet and anticipating the summer before her final year of high school — has come to realize how maddeningly easy it is to deceive her mother and stepfather, Elizabeth and James. So preoccupied are they with her alcoholic mother’s faltering recovery that they forget to notice whether Rosie herself is drinking (she is). In fact, they’re so clueless about her real life that when James picks a moment for an honest chat he has no idea Rosie is coming down off Ecstasy, so “tweaked” she has to struggle not to “grind her teeth into paste” as she listens.

headline: Loyal Alumni
text: To the Editor:

headline: View From the Corner
text: Over the years, various gyms have emerged as the Sorbonne of the sweet science. In the 1930s and ’40s, there were Stillman’s and Gleason’s in New York, and much later the Kronk in Detroit. But during the late ’50s and early ’60s, the Fifth Street Gym in Miami Beach became one of the grand hubs of pugilism. It was out of that cocoon of combat that the young Cassius Clay was transmogrified into Muhammad Ali.

headline: London Dance Journal: Mark Morris Makes a Visit
text: LONDON — Pastoral is a rare genre anywhere these days. Artists still celebrate nature but seldom the tranquil harmony between nature and civilized man. In dance, the two greatest extant pastoral masterpieces are Frederick Ashton’s “La Fille mal gardée” and Mark Morris‘s “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato.” When Mr. Morris first made “L’Allegro” in Brussels in November 1988, it was just three months after Ashton had died. To some of us, connections between the two were immediately powerfully apparent: most obviously in the imagery in each work of horses, carriages and riders, of landscapes and people gazing into them, and of workers in the fields. In both, the world is young, its population innocent.

headline: What Happens to All Those No. 42 Jerseys?
text: Now that the calendar has turned past April 15, the question arises: What happens to all those No. 42 jerseys worn this week in honor of Jackie Robinson Day?

headline: Daryl F. Gates, L.A.P.D. Chief in Rodney King Era, Dies at 83
text: Daryl F. Gates, whose aggressive approach to law enforcement as chief of the Los Angeles Police Department was both admired for its innovation and criticized for the racial unrest it provoked, died Friday at his home in Dana Point, Calif. He was 83.

headline: Syllabus Sampler
text: Courses by some of the world’s foremost scholars are online, free for the viewing. Browse a selection of lecture videos.

headline: The Paper Debate
text: Before each tournament, Sam Crichton, a senior on the Wake Forest debate team, meticulously stocks a half-dozen Rubbermaid tubs with computer printouts. Each sheet of paper — perhaps 5,000 total — summarizes the argument in, say, a presidential speech or op-ed piece. These “cards” have been sorted into manila files, grouped into brown accordion folders, stacked into the tubs and labeled by argument type: affirmatives, disadvantages, counterplans, critiques, case arguments/negatives, backfiles.

headline: Postmodernspeak
text: “Stupidity is neither ignorance nor organicity, but rather, a corollary of knowing and an element of normalcy, the double of intelligence rather than its opposite. … Stupidity is always the name of the Other, and it is the sign of the feminine.”

headline: Elementary: Quiz Answers
text: 1. 30 years old

headline: Training Teacher’s Pe(s)ts
text: Back in the Paleolithic period, when men and women wore their Sunday best, classroom decorum was unquestioned; the relationship between professor and student was based on a set of unspoken rules. One wonders what their reaction would be to an e-mail message I received from a student: hey prof, owt late last nite .... am sic today. pls emal cls notes. yah thatd b great. thx see u.  I teach a course in public speaking at Borough of Manhattan Community College, part of the City University of New York, in which students give speeches ranging from how to clean a trumpet to solar energy. My job is to show them how to arrange their thoughts, use language to its best advantage and, most important, perform in front of an audience without fear.

headline: Finding a Gay-Friendly Campus
text: The scene was similar to one that plays out thousands of times a year in gyms and auditoriums around the country: a college fair. The folding tables, the school banners, the admissions officers with a student representative or two, and the brochures and tchotchkes laid out. The only thing that might have made this one appear out of the ordinary was the preponderance of handouts with rainbow designs, and the fact that the fair was being held at the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Community Center in Greenwich Village. This college fair, and several like it around the country, was devoted to recruiting gay students.

headline: The Long-Haul Degree
text: Law students get a diploma in three years. Medical students receive an M.D. in four. But for graduate students in the humanities, it takes, on average, more than nine years to complete a degree. What some of those Ph.D. recipients may not realize is that they could spend another nine years, or more, looking for a tenure-track teaching job at a college or university — without ever finding one.

headline: Exactly How Personal Is That Personal Statement?
text: Talk about chutzpah. The admissions director for Penn State’s M.B.A. program, Carrie Marcinkevage, recalls that the school once received a student essay with three of four paragraphs taken directly from an article online. “It was, ironically, in our ‘Principled Leadership’ admissions essay,” she says.

headline: Audit This
text: WHY homeschool? Maybe to brush up for an exam, get a sense of what a college is like, or just to learn. Diana E. E. Kleiner, who runs Open Yale Courses, knows of users who take open classes with friends, or who want to bone up on, say, art history before a trip to Italy. Yale’s open courses are probably the most accessible for the general consumer. Fewer casual students might be hankering to dip into the junior year of aeronautics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Still, technical courses like classical mechanics and linear algebra are consistently among the top viewed among M.I.T.’s extensive list of offerings. On the following pages, writers who know the fields weigh in on some of the highlights of free education. Fittingly, open classes have many homes on the Internet, including university Web sites and professors’ personal home pages. Access seems to be easier through big sites like YouTube and iTunes, which work in conjunction with the institutions.

headline: Are Business Schools Failing?
text: The aftermath of a historic financial crisis seems an appropriate time to take stock of graduate business education. What are we teaching these people before they head off to the executive suite?

headline: How to Learn Something for Nothing
text: Thousands of pieces of free educational material — videos and podcasts of lectures, syllabuses, entire textbooks — have been posted in the name of the open courseware movement. But how to make sense of it all? Businesses, social entrepreneurs and "edupunks," envisioning a tuition-free world untethered by classrooms, have created Web sites to help navigate the mind-boggling volume of content. Some sites tweak traditional pedagogy; others aggregate, Hulu-style.

headline: Elementary
text: George Freeman, a vice president and assistant general counsel of The New York Times, is an avid Pop Quiz taker. But, he admonished us the other day, "Make it easier!" And so we turned to the syndicated game show "Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader?," which challenges adults with questions from textbooks and curriculums from first grade through fifth. The producers agreed to share some of the toughies. Only two contestants have made it through the low grades and correctly answered fifth-grade-level and bonus questions like the ones below to win $1 million. One winner was a Nobel-laureate physics professor from the University of California, Berkeley (by answering No. 32); the other was schools superintendent of Georgia (with No. 33). And how did Mr. Freeman fare? Without any test prep, he got 21 right, including a million-dollar question.

headline: The Examined Life, Age 8
text: A few times each month, second graders at a charter school in Springfield, Mass., take time from math and reading to engage in philosophical debate. There is no mention of Hegel or Descartes, no study of syllogism or solipsism. Instead, Prof. Thomas E. Wartenberg and his undergraduate students from nearby Mount Holyoke College use classic children’s books to raise philosophical questions, which the young students then dissect with the vigor of the ancient Greeks.

headline: Living With the Boss
text: If you want to find out what it’s like to be Gail Hochman, a New York literary agent, it wouldn’t be enough to merely follow her around during the workday. You’d have to follow her home for the night and back to the office the next morning — because it is during her daily commute that Ms. Hochman, 56, goes about the business of poring over unpublished manuscript after unpublished manuscript.

headline: What They’re Watching
text: YouTube, with its view-count ticker, has become a useful tool for determining the popularity of an online video — whether it has gone “viral,” as the kids say. Atop YouTube’s list of most-popular course lectures (as of April 1) is  “Justice,”  Michael J. Sandel’s legendary philosophy class. The course’s videos also happen to be the only ones produced for public television. The Top 10 videos are the first lecture in a series, except No. 6, which is smack in the middle of a course on search engines. That lecture may have been boosted by a guest — Sergey Brin, the co-founder of Google.

text: With the Manhattan district attorney’s office facing a 25 percent budget cut from the city this year, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the office’s newly elected chief, is cutting a handful of staff members.

headline: Tocqueville: The Novel
text: Peter Carey’s 11th novel is announced by its publisher as “an improvisation on the life of Alexis de Tocqueville,” a figure perhaps a bit cerebral for one of this author’s brass-band burlesques of literature and history. But “Parrot and Olivier in America” grabs its subject and marches down Main Street playing full out, provoking a reader’s delighted applause and — as is often the case with this exuberant novelist — a small measure of exasperation.

headline: Living in a Commercial Space
text: New Yorkers sometimes wind up living in places that never before saw bed, sofa or stove.

headline: Born a Store
text: IN a city where the hot hangout changes by the minute, and people move to neighborhoods that are just starting to shed a commercial or industrial past, it is little surprise that New Yorkers sometimes wind up living in places that never before saw bed, sofa or stove.

headline: Youth, ‘Fossils’ and Planetary Progress
text: I’m on the road to a big conclave of college students, professors and administrators trying to build a better planet and society — organized by former President Bill Clinton through his Clinton Global Initiative. I’ve moved to a university. My third book on the environment, a project of The New York Times, was for middle school kids. There’s a pattern here. Youth matters.

headline: McCann Erickson Sues Kirshenbaum Bond Senecal Over Senecal
text: The hiring by one agency of a top executive from another agency is often fraught with potential pitfalls, particularly when it comes to the delicate subject of whether the executive is wooing clients and co-workers to join him or her at the new agency.

headline: Tocqueville: The Life
text: Glimpsing the human side of major historical figures is endlessly fascinating. As Melville noted, Shakespeare in his own day wasn’t Shakespeare. He was Master William Shakespeare, the harried writer — mocked as an “upstart crow” by a critic — who churned out plays for the proprietors of the Globe Theater.

headline: Josh Hamilton’s Perspective on Ron Washington
text: Josh Hamilton will always have a connection with the original Yankee Stadium, where his flurry of majestic home runs was the highlight of the All-Star Game home run derby in 2008, the final year of the ballpark. Speaking in Cleveland on Wednesday, Hamilton said he was curious to see what was left of the old Yankee Stadium –- and the answer is: not much.

headline: Halfway Between New York and Philadelphia
text: DONNA NEJAD began thinking of Branchburg Township as a “hidden gem” 12 years ago, when she and her husband, Peter, chose it from the numerous central New Jersey towns they explored after deciding to leave Staten Island.

headline: Dr. Does-It-All
text: As one of the most accomplished cardiothoracic surgeons of his generation, Mehmet Oz has transplanted lungs and repurposed hearts; implanted mechanical devices to provide the pump and pulse for patients that cannot manage that on their own; and otherwise pressed, pulled, cut and stitched inside bodies where a second’s lapse of attention or a millimeter of miscalculation could kill.

headline: The Step-by-Step Four-Story Renovation in the West Village
text: BACK in the mid-1990s, when John Casey and his wife-to-be, Nancy Smith, were looking for an affordable place to live in Manhattan, Mr. Casey chose an unusual approach to house hunting. Day after day, he prowled the city’s streets in search of rundown properties. Then he pored over records at the offices of various city agencies, hoping to come across an owner who was on the ropes financially and desperate to sell.

headline: Playing the Ball Correctly From Damaged Ground

At their home course, officials have marked a large area damaged by heavy snows as ground under repair (G.U.R.) in the fairway and rough. All four players play their tee shots and all four balls come to rest in the G.U.R.

headline: Contractors on Call to Prepare Houses for Sale
text: NERVOUS about the economy last fall, Victor Mora of Roslyn Harbor contacted a real estate broker. “If I lost my job,” he remembers thinking at the time, “I would have to sell my house.”

headline: Google Battles Bad Spellers
text: Finishing your sentences, correcting misspellings — Google is either coming to resemble a spookily sentient computer intelligence, or an annoying spouse.

headline: Middle East Boyhood
text: When playing the “conquer the world” board game Risk as an adolescent growing up in a well-to-do Cairo suburb, Kai Bird avoided occupying the Middle East. So did his American friends. Their very surroundings schooled them in the difficulty of holding the crossroads of three continents.

headline: Weekend Competition: Whelmed by Outunendo
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to create necessary neologisms by monkeying with prefixes and suffixes.

text: Each Thursday, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: A Ripe Old Age
text: Here’s how precocious Adam Thirlwell is: In 2003, when he was 24 years old, Granta named him one of Britain’s best young novelists — before his first novel had even been published. (He made the cut on the strength of the manuscript.) Once the book, “Politics,” did appear, discussions about it had one common denominator: sex. Readers and reviewers, pro and con, sought the precise location of the line demarcating smut from smart. Translated into 30 languages, “Politics” told the story of three young Londoners involved in a ménage à trois. Though few explicit descriptions were spared, the novel was ultimately less concerned with the foibles and fumblings of sexual misadventure than with what they could reveal about human nature that more conventional narratives could not.

headline: Magic Monsters
text: Images from an exhibit of Japanese prints by Utagawa Kuniyoshi.

headline: Don’t Have a Nice Day
text: Anyone who loves the short story, that perennially marginalized and disrespected form, should rejoice in the appearance of a writer’s collected stories. It’s simply good for the team. (Recent proclamations that the novel is over and done with take aim at the bigger target for a change. Welcome, novels, to the realm of the unquiet dead.) When the short-story writer in question is as innovative and idiosyncratic as Deborah Eisenberg, it’s an opportunity for both celebration and appraisal, a chance to explore our expectations of narrative in contentious times. As if there were any other times worth writing about.

headline: Obama Pushes for D.C. Voting Rights
text: President Obama called Friday for Congress to pass legislation giving voting representation to residents of the nation’s capital.

headline: Collateral Damage
text: On the opening page of “The Sandbox,” David Zimmerman’s gripping first novel about the Iraq war, Pvt. Toby Durrant’s convoy comes across a dead girl in the road, her body “a small white mound, like a fallen bird.” Toby’s response is to “put this child in the small cigar box I keep hidden in the back of my head, close its cardboard lid and snap a couple of rubber bands around it to keep it tightly shut. Just like I’ve done with the rest.”

headline: Milan Report | Saved By Droog
text: It’s impossible not to be charmed by the exhibition “Saved By Droog,” for which the Dutch design brand scoured online liquidation auctions for caches of unwanted objects — like 720 soda glasses and 50 neon-orange safety vests — and then invited 14 designers to use them as raw materials. Nearly everyone here at the furniture fair did more with less this year, but few so overtly made an asset of the crisis, the business-killing tendencies of which inspired Droog to come to the aid of all those orphaned goods. Reclamation can also apparently benefit the bottom line, considering that 125 euros ($170) will net you one of 448 wallets stamped “Money does not make me happy” by the graphic designer Stefan Sagmeister. And silicone-coated wooden spoons by the Dutch food designer Marije Vogelzang are only 29.50 euros ($40). Everything is for sale on-site, and the designers get half the profits.

headline: She’s Come Undone
text: The latest incarnation of the Patti Smith, straggly-hair, no-makeup makeup look. (See: Bettina Rheims.)

headline: Spitzer Antagonist Advises Ex-Madam’s Campaign
text: Roger J. Stone Jr. has more than a bit of a thing for Eliot Spitzer.

headline: An Unexpected Death
text: Early on in Sue Miller’s new novel, “The Lake Shore Limited,” a ­middle-aged woman loiters in a dark street, peeping into the window of a bar. Inside, a much younger woman — vivid in a crimson suit, flanked by men, “her long legs on display” — throws her head back to laugh, “either in pure pleasure or in the wish to convey pure pleasure.” The moment is quintessential Miller, touching on the themes that have animated her fiction for the past quarter-century: the potency of sex; the failure of men and women to understand each other; the hunger for a different life. Here too is the hyper-self-consciousness that afflicts her characters, who are forever questioning the authenticity of their feelings.

headline: Experts Seek Clues to How Long Eruption Will Go On
text: The volcanic eruption that has disrupted air travel in Europe for two days shows no signs of abating, an Icelandic geophysicist said Friday.

headline: Pride and Popularity
text: Jane Austen’s best-known phrase describing her own writing appears in a letter to her nephew, James Edward Austen-Leigh, an aspiring novelist and student at Winchester College. When she heard he’d lost some draft chapters, she jokingly announced that she couldn’t be accused of purloining his pages: “What should I do with your strong, manly, spirited Sketches, full of Variety & Glow? — How could I possibly join them on to the little bit (two Inches wide) of Ivory on which I work with so fine a Brush, as produces little effect after much labour?” The “little bit of Ivory,” frequently quoted to describe Austen’s virtuosic miniaturism, started out as a self-deprecating remark to a much younger, less talented relative who would later become her biographer.

headline: Is YouTube’s Safety Mode Safe? Not Very.

headline: Travel Deals: European Flight and Hotel Sale
text: Airfares are expected to jump this summer, but for now, Lufthansa and Air France are having spring flight sales to Europe, good for departures through mid-May. And for lodging once you get there, Hotels.com is offering 30 percent off hundreds of European hotels.

headline: Let the Playoffs, and the Hand-Wringing, Begin
text: It is tempting to wonder what on earth is going on in the first round of the N.H.L. playoffs. Two No. 1 seeds, Washington and San Jose, lost the openers and Capitals superstar Alex Ovechkin was held without a shot on goal for the first time since before birth. The defending champion, Pittsburgh, lost at home to — gasp — Ottawa and the Red Wings fell to Phoenix, which wasn’t even sure it still had a team. This is crazy stuff, hockey’s equivalent of a solar eclipse.

headline: Gomez Finds Scoring Touch With Puebla
text: In the annals of Major League Soccer, the 2005 season seems like ages ago.

headline: For Oil Sands Project,  a Step Forward
text: A pipeline that would carry crude oil extracted from Canadian tar sand fields to refineries in Texas has edged a bit closer to approval with the State Department’s release of a draft environmental impact statement this month. It concluded that the project’s construction and operation would have “limited adverse environmental impacts.”

headline: The Fat Trap
text: Food is never just food. Food is love. Food is solace. It is politics. It is religion. And if that’s not enough to heap on your dinner plate each night, food is also, especially for mothers, the instant-read measure of our parenting. We are not only what we eat, we are what we feed our children. So here in Berkeley — where a preoccupation with locally grown, organic, sustainable agriculture is presumed — the mom who strolls the farmers’ markets can feel superior to the one who buys pesticide-free produce trucked in from Mexico, who can, in turn, lord it over the one who stoops to conventionally grown carrots (though the folks who grow their own trump us all). Let it slip that you took the kids to McDonald’s, and watch how fast those play dates dry up.

headline: Taxes on the Rich vs. the Merely Affluent
text: A few readers wondered whether I was referring to only a very small slice of the highest-income households when I said tax rates on the wealthy had fallen more than on any other group over the last three decades. The short answer is no.

headline: Everybody’s Doing the Co-opting a Name Thing
text: What’s in a name?

headline: Body Talk
text: As the founder of the first World Fitness Day, which will be held in Atlanta on May 1, you will be leading what might be called the biggest gym class ever.  We’re taking over the Georgia Dome, which is home of the Atlanta Falcons. It can hold 3,000 people on the floor and other people in the stands. A friend of mine e-mailed and said that with all that music and fun it sounds like Woodstock without the drugs and the rain.

headline: Wellness

headline: Weinsteins Get Exclusive Window to Close a Deal to Reclaim Miramax

headline: Charles Schwab Stops Offering 2 Percent Credit Cards
text: Back in December, I warned that Charles Schwab’s generous 2 percent cash rebate credit card was in jeopardy. And sure enough, the company pulled the plug two weeks ago. It’s not accepting new applications for the card, though the company isn’t currently making any changes to the rewards structure for existing cardholders.

headline: The Anatomy of Desire
text: The two mannequins stood side by side in the back of the white van. Johan Karremans, a psychologist at Radboud University in the Netherlands, along with his student and collaborator, Sander Arons, clothed the plastic women identically in tight black tops and dark skirts. Arons then drove the van around the country to the homes of blind men.

headline: Unhappy With Your Looks? Or Is It a Disorder?
text: When is it ordinary unhappiness about the way you look, and when is it a psychological disorder? That’s the question explored by Dr. Katharine A. Phillips in this week’s Consults blog. Dr. Phillips, a professor of psychiatry at Brown Medical School, recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers’ questions about body dysmorphic disorder, or B.D.D., an unusual condition in which people become obsessed about perceived body flaws. To learn more about B.D.D., see Personal Health columnist Jane Brody’s story “When Your Looks Take Over Your Life.” Dr. Phillips writes:

headline: Naked Ambition
text: "Look for the woman in the dress,” Coco Chanel once decreed, meaning that her customer, not her clothes, should draw the eye first. With the current vogue for blush- and “flesh”-colored fashion, following this directive is at once easy and difficult. Easy when the palette is deployed in transparent fabrics (like the Rochas nude lace top that made it impossible not to look at the model . . . or at least at her instantly discernible nipples). Difficult when the individual and the outfit share the exact same coloring — a problem exemplified at this year’s Oscars by actresses from Demi Moore (whose apricot Versace gown blended seamlessly with her spray-on tan) to Anna Kendrick (all but invisible in pasty pink Elie Saab). Just last week, I myself decided not to buy a peach suede jacket by the Row because the saleswoman told me, “It looks like you’re wearing your own skin.” She seemed not to find this notion creepy.

headline: Naked Ambition

Was it so our names could ring out on some ghetto street corner? Naw, man. There’s games beyond the game.”

The banking sector declined as much as 2.6 percent on the news.

Lawrence in “Lawrence of Arabia,” embarking on a small project yet ending up on an epic quest; perhaps he’d be Jake Gittes in “Chinatown,” relentlessly digging, following what he finds even if it takes him someplace disagreeable; or maybe Jefferson Smith in “Mr. Smith Goes to Washington,” an outsider and novice who shows the establishment a thing or two.

headline: Bringing Up Baby, Dirt and All
text: My husband and I have a crawling baby who puts everything he finds into his mouth. So we don’t allow shoes in our home. A friend came over to watch a movie with me and began picking dead skin from her lip and scratching her scalp, flicking what she collected under her nails onto the floor. I didn’t want my son ingesting this! I asked if she needed a tissue, but she missed my point. Should I just keep her out of our house?

headline: Treating a Son’s O.C.D.
text: Our 12-year-old son has obsessive-compulsive disorder. His psychiatrist recommended a medication, but our son fears its potential side effects and refuses to take it. We could sneak a liquid version into his meals, but his physician said this could be considered child abuse. Yet under the circumstances, not doing so seems worse, considering that our son’s condition prevents him from making a self-healing decision. What to do? NAME WITHHELD, PENNSYLVANIA

headline: ‘The Lake Shore Limited’
text: Because it was still afternoon, because she was in a strange room, because she was napping rather than sleeping ("I'll just lie down for a bit and see what happens," she'd told Pierce) — because of all this, she was aware of herself as she dreamed, at some level conscious of working to subvert the dream she was having, to make it come out another way, different from the way it seemed to be headed.

Trump.

headline: Face Booking | Benetton Casts a Wide Net
text: Diversity is a catchword that’s often used in fashion but pretty rarely employed. Since 1982, United Colors of Benetton has been putting its money where its mouth is through its award-winning if controversial ad campaigns. Now the Italian brand has taken the message a step further with a democratic online casting, “It’s My Time.” Candidates uploaded a profile with photos of themselves, and the community — yes, that’s regular folks like you and me — voted on its favorites. The top 20, which included men and women from Iran, Belgium, Kazakhstan and India, were flown to New York City for a campaign shoot by the photographer Josh Olins. “It’s the first time I’ve been here. I want to stay!” one winner, Lorenzo, a k a “Plastic is Fantastic,” gushed last night at the a party in their honor at the Standard Hotel. (Plastic, he explained, “is the name of my favorite disco in Milano.”)

headline: Exploiting Kids on YouTube?
text: Remember “David After Dentist”? The video, recorded by his father, showed 7-year-old David DeVore in his car seat after minor oral surgery when he was still a bit loopy. The dad’s original goal was just to forward the few minutes of footage to his wife, who was at work, to show her that their son was O.K. But then he posted it on YouTube because, well, it was just so darn adorable, launching a debate over whether it is exploitation to forever immortalize online your child  making a fool of himself.

text: The S.E.C. civil suit against Goldman Sachs essentially accuses the bank of putting together a really bad investment so a hedge fund client could short it, and then selling that investment to clients without disclosing why the investment was created.  Goldman says it did nothing wrong.

headline: There’s a Theorbo in the Rock Bin
text: SHOPPING for recordings was so much easier back when genre distinctions seemed more concrete. When you hit the record store in search of Ravel or Radiohead, you had a good idea where to look. But when classically trained artists make music suited for both concert hall and nightclub (and play it in both), conventional categories become useless. Whither Clogs? Slow Six? Where does Redhooker reside?

headline: Q. & A. With Sam Sifton (Round Three)
text: Got a lot of questions just now from a guy who calls himself NYTourist, from New York. I’m going to break them apart because they’re good questions, and answer his queries as best I can. If the answers aren’t very good, and they very well might not be, it might be partly because I had lunch today — a dozen clams on the half shell followed by a salad and half a turkey club sandwich, followed by a coffee — and I’m feeling a little dazed. I went to the gym in the morning and just hammered the weights and the stair-climbing machine, and by the time I got to lunch I was ravenous. Ruh-oh. Should have gone to the gym after lunch and written in the morning instead. Either way, I would have liked to have walked about 10 more blocks than I did in advance of returning to this hot seat to write. Also because: I have a dinner reservation in a couple of hours. Welcome to my life!

headline: Pictures of the Day: Rescue Efforts in China and Frustration in Europe
text: It happened in Concepción, Chile, and in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, before that: dust-covered earthquake victims rescued against all odds from graves of rubble and twisted metal. We see it now in China’s Qinghai Province (Slide 1), where a girl was rescued 50 hours after being buried by a 7.1-magnitude quake. The chances of survival are dimming, but rescuers keep clambering over the remnants of schools, hotels and mud-brick homes looking for signs that a few of the hundreds of people still missing might be alive (Slide 3).

headline: Chatting Up the Trophy Girl, Toddler Style
text: THE future of love revealed itself to me one morning two autumns ago as I zipped up my toddler’s sweater outside a popular cafe in Boerum Hill in Brooklyn, one that played a role in my amorous past.

headline: Letters: The Love That Dare Not Squawk Its Name
text: Jon Mooallem nicely encapsulates for the general reader a broad panorama of observation, research and interpretation concerning a relatively little-known and probably somewhat hidden aspect of biology. Absent from the discourse, however, is any mention of the simple notion of pleasure or of the more complicated emotions. The animal kingdom at its higher levels is suffused with not only reproductive survival drives but also with pleasure-seeking drives, an area covered by the science of hedonics, a discipline with a name itself suffering the moralistic denunciations engaged to suppress much about sexual behavior. It is interesting to note that there seems little of what we would call prejudice among animal societies toward nonstandard behavior, and yet there was no discussion of this judgmental and too-often-punitive activity that emerges in nominally more advanced human animals. There is much more to this subject; the author barely mentioned things likethe cavorting of dolphins, the pansexuality of bonobos and the same-sex mating behavior seen in deep-sea octopuses.THOMAS W. FILARDOEvendale, Ohio

headline: Airline Merger Talks Renew Skepticism of Tie-Ups
text: Ever since the airline industry was deregulated more than three decades ago, the nation’s top carriers have operated under a basic premise: bigger is better.

headline: Letters: A Closer Reading of Roman Vishniac
text: The problems of veracity in what is termed “documentary photography” go well beyond the work of Roman Vishniac. Persuasive voices have cast doubt on the authenticity of other famous images of the Leica era: “The Falling Soldier [in the Spanish Civil War],” by Vishniac’s friend Robert Capa “Raising the Flag on Iwo Jima,” by Joe Rosenthal; and many others.

headline: Letter: Questions for Rand Paul
text: Dismissive statements by the Kentucky Senate candidate Rand Paul to Deborah Solomon on federal regulations concerning seat-belt use and public smoking are vacuous. It is simply irresponsible for anyone, least of all a physician like Paul, to tout personal freedoms at any cost. It is deplorable that anyone would openly advocate that the only thing that really matters is the personal choices of the indulgers of unsafe behavior. I’m shocked, really, that Paul would choose to make such ill-informed statements. If he can’t look at the human cost of rolling back seat-belt or antismoking legislation, perhaps he can take a look at the cold bottom line. It costs every citizen-taxpayer a fortune to support emergency assistance for traffic fatalities, and we all pay in increased health-insurance costs when smokers are ill.GEORGE C. VILLARREALLexington, Ky.

headline: Behavior: Few Young Men Counseled on Sexual Health, Study Finds
text: Despite repeated recommendations to provide reproductive health services to teenage boys and girls, few adolescent males are getting the information they need to protect themselves from H.I.V. and other sexually transmitted diseases, a new study reports.

headline: Letter: Cooking With Dexter
text: Thanks to Pete Wells for his homage to Laura Ingalls Wilder’s wonderful food scenes throughout her books (“Little House in the Hood”). When my children were young, I read “Farmer Boy” aloud to them — it was to become our favorite of the Little House series. When the book’s characters started to prepare their meals, the kids would say, “Oh no, they’re going to eat again!” and we would all laugh while enjoying the detail of hearty meals described so vividly that we could almost taste every bite.DEBORAH KNOXPittsburgh

headline: Aging: Diet May Be Linked to Lower Alzheimer’s Risk in Older People
text: Older adults appear to be at lower risk for Alzheimer’s disease if they eat a diet rich in fish, poultry, fruit, nuts, dark leafy greens, vegetables like broccoli and cauliflower, and oil-and-vinegar dressing, a new study has found.

headline: The Man in the Grey Flannel Dishdasha?
text: Edicoo, the name of a new member of Icom, a worldwide network of independent advertising agencies, is odd, but certainly not unusual in an industry whose players bear names like Anomaly and StrawberryFrog. But where Edicoo is located may seem unusual: in Erbil, in the autonomous Kurdistan region of Iraq.

headline: Formerly Unsober
text: The very first time I got drunk, I was 10. I’d gone to some event with my father, who was in A.A. Some bigger kids thought it would be funny to get me tipsy. I don’t remember how it felt. I just remember my dad, more scared than angry, yelling as the Volvo lumbered along and my head lolled against the seat: “You can’t drink! I’m an alcoholic. My father was an alcoholic!”

headline: In Some Adoptions, Love Doesn’t Conquer All
text: At times, Kelly Lytle Baehr wondered how they would all get through it.  Two years ago, she and her husband adopted three boys from Ukraine — two of them 8, the other 16 — and brought them back to their home in Omaha. She knew assimilation into a family life would not be easy; all had come from troubled backgrounds, including one who had spent the first five years of his life in a prison orphanage back in Ukraine, and had a mother who drank while she was pregnant.

headline: Now Booking | Boca Chica in Acapulco
text: Old Acapulco is finding inspiration these days in its glittery past. The latest retro revival is the Hotel Boca Chica, a ’50s era hideaway that gave birth to the margarita and sheltered John Wayne and his Hollywood cronies. Reopened a few weeks ago by Grupo Habita — the ultrahip owners of the Condesa DF in Mexico City, among other culty hotels — the Antonio Peláez-designed property has 36 minimalist rooms tucked away in a quiet cove beneath pink and white modernist bungalows that spill down the seaside cliffs where Rita Hayworth shot scenes for “The Lady From Shanghai” (1947) and Elvis filmed “Fun in Acapulco” (1963).
