headline: Footnote
text: The choreographer Bill T. Jones is this year’s recipient of the annual Jacob’s Pillow Dance Award. Mr. Jones will accept the award, which carries a $25,000 cash prize, in person at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival opening gala on June 19.

headline: Daniel Radcliffe to Star in ‘How to Succeed’
text: How do you succeed on Broadway without really trying? It doesn’t hurt when you have a star from one of the most successful film franchises in history in a leading role. Daniel Radcliffe, right, the “Harry Potter” star  who, in fairness, works hard in all his endeavors, we’re sure  will play the ambitious window washer J. Pierrepont Finch in a revival of “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying” that is planned for Broadway in the spring of 2011, its producers announced on Thursday. The musical revival, with music and lyrics by Frank Loesser and book by Abe Burrows, Jack Weinstock and Willie Gilbert, will be Mr. Radcliffe’s first Broadway role since the revival of “Equus” that ran at the Broadhurst Theater in 2008 and 2009. Rob Ashford (“Promises, Promises”; “Curtains”) will direct “How to Succeed,” and it will be produced by Broadway Across America (John Gore, Thomas B. McGrath and Beth Williams), Craig Zadan and Neil Meron. The original production (with a cast that included Robert Morse and Charles Nelson Reilly) opened in 1961 and ran for more than 1,400 performances; a film version was released in 1967, and a previous Broadway revival, starring Matthew Broderick and Megan Mullally, was mounted in 1995.

headline: Terry Gilliam Takes on His First Opera
text: As long as his production doesn’t go far over budget, abruptly run out of funds, get ruined in a flash flood or be drowned out by NATO aircraft drills  all calamities that have befallen him in the past  the director Terry Gilliam, right, is scheduled to make his operatic debut with the English National Opera next year, The Guardian reported. Mr. Gilliam, the Monty Python alumnus whose films include “Brazil,” and whose disaster-plagued shoot for an aborted film, “The Man Who Killed Don Quixote,” was the subject of the documentary “Lost in La Mancha,” will direct a production of Berlioz’s “Damnation of Faust” planned for May 2011. The English National Opera, which previously recruited the director Anthony Minghella to stage a successful production of “Madame Butterfly,” acknowledged that there were risks when anyone directs opera for the first time. (“It can be like a car crash coming at you from every angle,” John Berry, the opera company’s artistic director, told The Guardian.) But Edward Gardner, the company’s music director, said Mr. Gilliam has “a real grip on what needs to be done,” adding, “I can’t wait to tap into his crazy world and artistry.” Other works on the 2010-2011 calendar of the English National Opera include a production of Donizetti’s “Lucrezia Borgia” directed by Mike Figgis, who is also making his opera debut, and a new opera by Nico Muhly.

headline: Of Meter and Money
text: Who says poetry doesn’t pay? On April 26 and 27, there will be 53 high school students from around the country reciting verse from memory before a panel of judges, vying for the title of Poetry Out Loud Champion and a total of $50,000 in prize money. The competition, a partnership between the Poetry Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts, began last month with contests in all the states (and the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands). The winners of those competitions will go to Washington for the semifinals on April 26; nine students will advance to the finals on April 27. The national champion will receive $20,000; the second-place finalists $10,000; and the third-place, $5,000. Other finalists and semifinalists will also win cash prizes, and the finalists’ schools will each receive $500 to buy poetry books. The judges include Garrison Keillor, the poet and critic Adam Kirsch and last year’s national champion. Both the semifinals and the finals will take place at the Lisner Auditorium at George Washington University and are free to the public.

headline: Couple Honored for Years of Loyalty to Theater
text: Ever since they helped found Primary Stages in 1985 and took seats on its board of directors, Marvin and Anne Einhorn have also volunteered five days a week as receptionists manning the phones at the Off Broadway theater’s offices. On Friday, Mr. Einhorn, 89, and Mrs. Einhorn, 86, received an honor that usually goes to a millionaire donor: Primary Stages named its theater school on their behalf in recognition of their longtime commitment. The Einhorns, who have been married for 67 years, did not make a financial gift to the theater in return for naming rights, as is often the case with such tributes; rather, a Primary Stages spokesman said, they have given their time freely to handle phone calls  though they leave a bit early, at 2 p.m., on Fridays  and work on the board. The couple has long been retired; Mr. Einhorn worked for years in television, including as a director of NBC’s “Today” show.

headline: A Brand-New Time Lord, but He Sounds Familiar
text: They got rid of the high-tops, and for that alone we should be grateful. There was something profoundly irritating about watching David Tennant, the 10th Doctor Who, run around last season saving the world in a suit and sneakers.

headline: MySpace Offers Service for Concertgoers
text: MySpace introduced a new service on Thursday that would allow individuals to manage their coming events within the social networking site and to buy concert tickets through links on artist pages and elsewhere on the site. Events chosen by a user will appear on the person’s profile page and will be shared with their friends. The company hopes to expand the service beyond music and concerts, to movie and video game releases and other events, and onto mobile apps. Advertisers will be able to sponsor events, and if a ticket is sold through MySpace, the company could get a fee from the ticketing provider if there is a formal arrangement, as it has with LiveNation Entertainment. MySpace has struggled to maintain and add users in recent years, while Facebook’s popularity has continued to rise. In March 2010, the site had a little over 70 million unique users, 6 million fewer than in October 2008, according to comScore, which measures Web traffic.

headline: ‘SNL’ Shines Brightly as ‘FlashForward’ Dims
text: A special about the most recent decade of “Saturday Night Live” was a successful substitute for NBC’s Thursday night comedies, but it was a Debbie Downer kind of night on ABC as its science-fiction series “FlashForward” continued to erode. The NBC documentary, “Saturday Night Live in the 2000s: Time and Again,” drew 6.7 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates, following reruns of “The Office.” On ABC, “FlashForward” dwindled to 5 million viewers. CBS was the No. 1 network for the night with “Survivor” (12.1 million) and “CSI” (13 million), while Fox placed second with “Bones” (9.7 million) and “Fringe” (6.7 million).

headline: Pad Thai
text: Mark Bittman makes the noodle dish Pad Thai with shrimp.

headline: Pad Thai, an Easy Stir-Fry
text: IN the last 20 years or so, pad Thai has gone from being virtually unknown in this country to being a restaurant and takeout staple. It’s easy to see why: the tangy, crunchy, slightly sweet noodles are irresistible. But it’s difficult to understand why more people don’t make it at home, since pad Thai is essentially a stir-fry (in Thailand they refer to it as a Chinese noodle dish). It requires little more than chopping and stirring, and comes together in less than a half-hour.

headline: A Pulitzer Winner Gets Apple’s Reconsideration
text: Here’s a digital-age perk of winning a Pulitzer Prize: Apple might be a whole lot nicer to you and your work.

headline: Dante’s Unearthly Story Updated for the Stage
text: “La Commedia,” Louis Andriessen’s operatic dissection and reconstruction of Dante’s “Divine Comedy,” is the centerpiece of a series of concerts devoted to the composer at Carnegie Hall this month and next. The opera, heard in a concert version at Carnegie on Thursday evening, was created as an elaborate production in which important musical and dramatic elements take place on film, projected on multiple screens. It occupied Mr. Andriessen from 2004 to 2008, and when Carnegie offered him its Richard and Barbara Debs Composer’s Chair this season, “La Commedia” was the first work he said he wanted to present.

headline: Lawsuit Describes Art ‘Blacklist’ to Keep Some Collectors Away
text: Imagine a market for highly sought-after items in which the makers and sellers work hard to ensure that the items go only to certain buyers, even if other buyers might be willing to pay more. The favored buyers are then expected not to resell the items for many years, even if the values skyrocket. Ideally, in fact, the buyers are expected to give these items away eventually, for the public good. And if the buyers don’t abide by these expectations, they risk being cut off, cast out with the other unwashed wealthy who can afford to buy but have no access.

headline: A Lively Celebration of the Power of No! No!
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  “O.K., I’m just going to say it,” Patrycja Kujawska announces at the start of Charlotte Vincent’s “If We Go On.”

headline: A Magazine, Long Gone, Is Given Digital CPR
text: A few months ago Robert Whiteman dashed off an e-mail message to Warren Buffett reminding that investor that he reportedly earned his first nickel selling Liberty Magazine in the 1930s. He told Mr. Buffett that he planned to resurrect the old publication for the digital age.

headline: Pad Thai Doesn’t Have to Be Takeout
text: Pad Thai has become a takeout staple in the United States, but there is no reason to fear making it at home. This recipe is fast enough, and easy enough, that it should become a from-scratch favorite.

headline: Slow-Cooking Asparagus in Paper Packets
text: THE last thing I needed was another way to cook asparagus. What with steaming, grilling, braising, roasting, broiling and the various subgenres of frying  pan-fried, stir-fried and deep-fried  I practically had more cooking methods than weeks in the brief asparagus season. Why add another technique to the list?

headline: Next Up, Abso and Smirnie?
text: Brands have long encouraged consumers to refer to them by nicknames or diminutives. Coca-Cola is Coke. Chevrolet is Chevy. Stolichnaya is Stoli. Now, in that same vein, Belvedere vodka is introducing a campaign that suggests calling the brand as “Belve,” pronounced Bell-vee.

headline: What We’re Reading: More Cellphones Than Toilets
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Reviving Liberty
text: Robert Whiteman hopes to rekindle interest in the once-popular magazine, which stopped publishing in 1950.

headline: Demi Moore, Then and Now
text: Clips and trailers from a selection of Demi Moore's films.

headline: Detroit Seeks Exit From Doom Highway
text: There’s a war going on in Detroit, but not the one that immediately comes to mind, between drug dealers and the police, or corrupt politicians and prosecutors. This war is more abstract than those very real battles and more David-and-Goliath. At issue is whether seemingly overwhelming sociological and economic forces of decay can be reversed by a few individuals determined to fight the good fight, no matter how quixotic their efforts seem.

headline: Park Guide Is Equally Bright Eyed and Bushy Tailed
text: Ladies, gentlemen and park users of all ages, meet Pearl. She’ll be your cartoon squirrel.

headline: Europe’s Cloud of Ash Casts Pall Over World of Music
text: Ticket holders worldwide, beware. That violinist onstage this weekend may be addled by a 14-hour drive. That pianist may not be the one you expected to see. The concert hall doors may even be locked because of a cancellation.

headline: Goldman Fraud Case Weighs on Financial Bill
text: The securities fraud case against Goldman Sachs found its way into the Senate’s debate over the financial regulatory bill on Friday as senators from both parties tried to use it to their advantage, although the Democrats seemed more vocal.

headline: A $30 Cable and an iPad on a Television
text: Last year in an effort to cancel my Time Warner cable, I bought an Apple TV. I came home with my new fancy sleek white packaging, tore open the box and plugged the Apple TV into my television. It took about 15 minutes before I went from excited to utterly frustrated.

headline: No American Left Inside
text: President Obama — about the most urban president I can recall — today urged Americans to reconnect with “the great outdoors.”

headline: Iceland Volcano Disrupts Air Travel
text: Clouds of volcanic ash blanketed parts of rural Iceland as a vast, invisible plume of grit drifted over Europe, emptying the skies of planes.

headline: The Conservative Mind, Circa 2010
text: Here are a few thoughts on the conversation that Julian Sanchez started with a post on the American right’s “epistemic closure” problem (i.e. the closing of the conservative mind), and which has subsequently been taken in all sorts of interesting directions by Matt Yglesias, Noah Millman, Megan McArdle, Sanchez again, Jonah Goldberg, and Conor Friedersdorf, among others.

headline: Great Tax Expectations
text: More than 6 in 10 Americans expect their taxes to go up in the next year, according to Gallup. Even a majority of low-income taxpayers foresee an increase in their taxes:

headline: Zimbabwe: Activists Honored by Obama are Jailed Again
text: Two activists honored by President Obama for leading a movement against President Robert Mugabe were jailed again after a march, according to their organization, Women of Zimbabwe Arise.

headline: On Being an Island in a Sea of Laughs
text: “Am I missing something?”

headline: Senate Republicans Band Together in Opposing Financial Bill
text: Updated:  All 41 Senate Republicans have signed a letter urging the majority leader, Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, to adopt a more bipartisan approach in developing legislation to tighten regulation of the nation’s financial system.

headline: Sunday in the Park, Feeling Nature’s Call
text: The birds and the bees are in full view across New York’s parks these days, but when it comes to another fact of life, the signs can be a little less obvious. In Central Park, where a generous conservancy has attended to every landscaped inch, many maps posted along the way say nothing about any of the 19 free restrooms scattered across its 843 acres.

headline: Good News from the Childbirth Front
text: One of the great tragedies of the developing world is the number of women who die in pregnancy and childbirth. But what is that number? Several studies had put it at somewhat more than 500,000 a year, while a new and apparently more rigorous study suggests that it has dropped to less than 350,000 a year.

headline: No Ordinary Teachers in These Schoolrooms
text: No matter how much you enjoyed or are enjoying high school, your experiences are no match for the ones being savored by the students in “Masterclass,” a nine-part documentary series that starts Sunday on HBO.

headline: Call and Response on the State of the Black Church
text: In the first decade of the American nation, a former slave turned itinerant minister by the name of Richard Allen found himself preaching to a growing number of blacks in Philadelphia. He came to both a religious and organizational revelation. “I saw the necessity,” he later wrote, “of erecting a place of worship for the colored people.”

headline: Bove: Time to Clean House at Goldman
text: Leave it to Richard X. Bove, the outspoken banking analyst at Rochdale Securities, to call for the leaders of Goldman Sachs to “fall on their swords.”

headline: Other Lonely Shores
text: A version of this column originally ran online. More than 130 readers shared their tales of being in the minority opinion on a show or movie. Here is a sampling. More comments are at nytimes.com/artsbeat.

headline: Is the W.P.S. the iLeague?
text: Women’s Professional Soccer, now in its second season, will not only Webcast a live game this Sunday, it will also provide a stream to users of Apple’s iPhone.

headline: The Last of the Asian Godfathers
text: IT was 1994 — the Year of the Dog — and Frank Ma was in a quandary.

headline: In Narrow Win, Perfect Timing
text: The Vanderbilt and Spingold knockout team events feature 64-board matches. But even then a result can hang on a thin thread.

headline: Watching the News, Not Reporting It
text: Gabe Pressman, 86, began working in 1954 for WNBC’s radio station and then its television news. He has numerous Emmy Awards and is currently the senior correspondent for WNBC-TV, mostly as a blog writer on New York City news. He keeps working, he said, because the news is his lifeblood and because hanging around the apartment (at Central Park West and 92nd Street) would drive his wife, Vera, crazy.

headline: Super-Powered Pride
text: Photos from a recent superhero costume party and leading gay and lesbian comic characters.

headline: Weinstein Brothers Said to Be Near Deal to Buy Miramax From Disney
text: LOS ANGELES — Harvey and Bob Weinstein are on the brink of regaining control of Miramax Films, a move that would mark a triumphant and unexpected return by the pair to the independent film spotlight.

headline: Meat, and the Men Who Deal in It
text: Meat — locally grown, wickedly smoked and unapologetically fatty — is the point of this Asian-flavored, neo-Confederate barbecue joint that sits at 91 South Sixth Street in Brooklyn, literally in the shadow of the Williamsburg Bridge. Out back in the yard are two Ole Hickory smokers, imported directly from Cape Girardeau, Mo. (“It don’t get more South than that,” said the owner, Zak Pelaccio, not referring specifically to geography.) Inside are hipsters, chopstick wielders, wandering uptowners and, on a recent night, a table of dudes in the business.

headline: Google Takes Printing to the Cloud
text: When Google began discussing Chrome OS, its new approach to an operating system that places all applications in the cloud, one question that wasn’t answered was how the new OS would handle printing.

headline: Revisiting ‘Carnage’ and ‘39 Steps’ in New Incarnations
text: As that great cultural arbiter “American Idol” likes to remind us, there’s more than one way to sing a song. Two charming new quartets of performers have joined shows that might be regarded as Broadway equivalents of pop-chart toppers: “God of Carnage” and “Alfred Hitchcock’s The 39 Steps,” accessible comedies with nigh-irresistible hooks. And with these latest casts, interpretations that might have been merely dutiful or imitative have instead a sprightly freshness that makes you smile both at what’s familiar and what’s new.

headline: Sale of Texas Rangers Is Delayed by Owner’s Dispute With Banks
text: The pending sale of the Texas Rangers has become a deepening standoff between the owner of the team, who says he has lost enough money on the franchise and will keep a portion of the proceeds from its sale, and creditors, who say they stand to lose many millions even if his full amount is turned over to them.

headline: Adopting With Care, and for Good
text: A decade ago, the doctor peered at grainy videos, trying to glean a sense of the future from an out-of-focus present. Now, she’s more likely to sit at her computer, click on an e-mail message, and view crisper footage taken on a Flip camera: a toddler waving a stuffed animal, a baby lying passively in a crib.

headline: The Week in Pictures for April 16
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include a sinkhole in the Bronx, plans for New York University expansion, and a shoeshine man.

headline: Nights at the Museum, When Fun Trumps Art
text: It’s hard to talk about museums’ after-hours programs without getting confused. Differentiating among Nightlife (at the California Academy of Sciences), After Dark (the Exploratorium) and L@TE (Berkeley Art Museum)  in name, and in concept  is not easy.

headline: As Cellular Service Expands in Subways, Thefts Rise
text: BOSTON — Nashira Muniz was sending a text message on her cellphone the other day when the phone rang. “I just texted you!” she said to the caller. Nothing unusual about that, except Ms. Muniz, 25, was deep underground, riding the subway.

headline: What We’re Reading: Improving Twitter
text: The tech reporters and editors of The New York Times were provoked by these thoughts:

headline: Let’s Just Indict the Deficit
text: I don’t know how you’re spending your spring, but here in New York we are all busy waiting for Andrew Cuomo.

headline: Tough Times for Givers and Receivers
text: Grant making by foundations plunged last year, dropping an estimated 8.4 percent to $42.9 billion as the economic downturn hit even those wealthy institutions. The decline was the largest since the Foundation Center, a research group, began collecting such data in 1975. Still, it was not as severe as the center predicted last year, based on the sharp loss in the value of foundation assets. Some foundations pared expenses and reduced staffs. The Ford Foundation, for example, found $40 million in cost savings that it used for grants. Ford and other foundations also increased the portion of assets they gave away in hopes of ameliorating problems caused by the poor economy. While assets at the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation declined about 20 percent, the foundation increased the amount it paid out to 7 percent of the lower value of its assets, around $3.8 billion. Without the Gates spending, the decline in spending by foundations would have been 9.4 percent.

headline: A 30-Pack of Charmin, but Where to Store It?
text: WHEN Costco opened its first Manhattan outpost last November, in a soaring East 116th Street shopping complex with river views, management did not know precisely who or what to expect: Would customers stream in from East Harlem and Washington Heights? Or would the aisles be flooded with Upper West Siders stocking up on San Pellegrino? How much demand would there be for kosher meat? Costcos nationwide sell some 57 million rolls of Charmin per month: would people living in cramped apartments go for those 30-roll packages?

headline: Rookie From New Jersey Is Skating for the Enemy
text: NEWARK — Frans van Riemsdyk did not see his son, James, score his first N.H.L. goal live, so there was no way he was going to miss James’s first Stanley Cup playoff game Wednesday. He bumped up a few appointments and caught an earlier flight.

headline: Man Is Arrested in Shootings From a Crown Heights Rooftop
text: The police said Friday that they had arrested a man they accused of firing on a busy street in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, last week, wounding four teenage boys and sending crowds fleeing for cover. The authorities said the shooting was gang related.

headline: Silly Bandz, the Bracelets That Spring Off Shelves
text: At Michael Casaren’s toy store in South Orange, N.J., children from elementary to high school are coming in every day with their wrists and forearms wrapped in a jumble of silicone bracelets, desperate to buy more.

headline: Girls in Private Schools Ask, Thin Mints or Samoas?
text: Two dozen fourth graders from the Chapin School, all in regulation green vests that were dotted with badges, popped up from their chairs to recite the Pledge of Allegiance and the Girl Scout promise: “On my honor. ...”

headline: Iraqi Sunnis Expect Allegiance Shift to Bear Fruit
text: TIKRIT, Iraq — As he sits in his palatial home’s reception hall, Sheik Munaf Ali al-Nidah denounces the governments of both Iraq and the United States and shakes his head over the vilification of the Baath Party. Above his mantel is a photograph of a smiling Saddam Hussein. A Saddam Hussein watch is wrapped around his wrist.

headline: 10 Years After a Mea Culpa, No Hint of a ‘Me, Too’
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon

headline: When Pizza Becomes Predatory
text: By 9 o’clock each morning, the arithmetic of debt jams the courthouses of New York City, the far end of a trail that begins on Wall Street and is paved with securitized bonds and chits for appliances bought on credit.

headline: Excerpt: 'America: The Story of Us'
text: This sweeping history of America includes celebrity commentators and lots of CGI.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: In Hospital Decision, Obama Finds Safe Ground on Gay Rights
text: ATLANTA — President Obama has found a way to support gay rights that least offends those who oppose them.

headline: New York Seeks Limits on Art Vendors in Parks
text: Street vendors who have become fixtures at some of Manhattan’s busiest parks — hawking paintings, kitschy souvenirs and all sorts of ephemera — may find themselves a lonelier crowd, as the Bloomberg administration proposes to cut their numbers by 75 percent.

headline: Veto Threat Raised Over Derivatives
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama threatened on Friday to veto the financial overhaul bill making its way through Congress if it failed to include strong restrictions on derivatives, which were at the heart of the financial crisis two years ago.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: Comedy

headline: On the Street | Eggwear
text: The Fifth Avenue Easter Parade attracts visitors from around the world, eager to see the still-stylish stroll.

headline: Volcanic Eruptions Affect Hundreds of Runners’ Travel to Boston
text: The Boston Marathon is one of the most famous tests of endurance. For runners coming from Europe this year, getting to the event may be even more difficult than running the 26.2 miles.

headline: Voters’ Concerns on Immigration Spin British Campaign
text: LONDON — Few people in the working-class neighborhood of Barking seem willing to proclaim unalloyed enthusiasm for the ultra-right-wing, anti-immigration British Nationalist Party. But get past “hello” in any conversation and their feelings come spilling out.

headline: Amazon Dam Project Pits Economic Benefit Against Protection of Indigenous Lands
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The indigenous leaders had a plan. They would unite for a last, desperate stand against the mammoth dam threatening their lands in the Amazon, vowing to give their lives, if necessary, to prevent it from being built.

headline: New Look and Flavors at an Old Standby
text: FOR almost 30 years, Crabtree’s Kittle House has been a destination for all occasions, from friends meeting for a drink or casual supper to large formal groups celebrating one of life’s milestones.

headline: China Starts New Bureau to Curb Web
text: BEIJING — China has quietly formed a new bureau expected to help to police social networking sites and other user-driven forums on the Internet, which are proving harder for the government to monitor and control than ordinary news portals.

headline: Fox Canceled Hannity’s Attendance at Tea Party’s Tax Day Rally in Cincinnati
text: For more than a week on his Fox News show, Sean Hannity promoted his planned Tax Day attendance at a Tea Party rally in Cincinnati. But as hundreds of Mr. Hannity’s fans lined up for a pre-rally book signing there on Thursday, he was whisked back to New York, his plans scrapped by his bosses at the last minute.

headline: Goldman’s Stacked Bet
text: From Government Sachs to guest of the government? “Goldman Sachs, which emerged relatively unscathed from the financial crisis, was accused of securities fraud in a civil suit filed Friday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which claims the bank created and sold a mortgage investment that was secretly devised to fail,” report The Times’s Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson. Release the schadenfreude!

headline: For Burgers, Try Ostrich
text: Ramzey Rizk, 31, of Westbury said he opened the Fuel Your Body Cafe last May because “it was cheaper to open my own place than to keep driving into the city for this kind of food.”

headline: A Taste of the South (Many, Many Tastes)
text: THE restaurant LL Dent calls its food “American cuisine with a Southern flair.” The Southerner at our table, digging into collard greens and grits, called it a taste of home.

headline: Web Coupons Know Lots About You, and They Tell
text: For decades, shoppers have taken advantage of coupons. Now, the coupons are taking advantage of the shoppers.

headline: Cafeteria Fare, Korean-Style
text: School Zone in Fort Lee is a playful restaurant that takes its inspiration from school cafeterias in Korea. “This kind of food is memory food for Korean students,” said the owner, Dong Kang, 51.

headline: The Soul of a Bistro in the Form of a Diner
text: THE Skylark Diner is one strange bird. Perched on the traffic-choked flyway that is U.S. 1, its multicolored neon plumage poised for liftoff, it looks garish, flamboyant, possibly radioactive.

headline: Faces of Health Debate Point to Law’s Complexity
text: WASHINGTON — They were the human faces of the nation’s wrenching, yearlong health care debate.

headline: Congo: Red Cross Aides Are Freed
text: Eight Red Cross staff members kidnapped in the Democratic Republic of Congo last week were released unharmed on Friday, the International Committee of the Red Cross said. The staff members, seven Congolese and one Swiss citizen, had just completed an assessment mission in a war-racked pocket of eastern Congo when they were abducted by a local militia.

headline: Record Audience Tuned In for British Debate
text: LONDON — An independent audience survey conducted for Britain’s main television networks said about 9.4 million people watched the first-ever televised election debate on Thursday night among the three candidates bidding to become prime minister after the May 6 election.

headline: In the N.F.L., an Amorphous Standard for Character
text: The Jets are excited about their prospects for the new campaign. They reached the A.F.C. championship game last season and have been reloading for a Super Bowl run. They made two bold moves in the off-season — bringing in Santonio Holmes, the troubled but talented wide receiver, and Antonio Cromartie, a great cornerback talent whose work ethic was questioned last season.

headline: The Morning Glory of Lobster
text: With dinner hours limited to two nights a week, the Village Cafe and Bistro would seem to be more cafe than bistro. Yet the knotty pine floor, varnished wood counter, expressionist oils on the walls, and ample number of tables inside and out endow the place with a handsome feel that goes well beyond your basic diner.

headline: Infusing Indian Recipes With Western Touches
text: RESTAURANT row in downtown Stamford — Summer Street between Broad Street and West Park Place — is home to about 10 restaurants, most of them relatively upscale. But the Indian restaurant Tawa, the newest arrival on the block, offers several satisfying dishes at more moderate prices.

headline: A Mighty Pale Tea
text: GRAND PRAIRIE, Tex.

headline: Paltry Tribute to a Yankee Lost Too Soon
text: ON a lonely block in the South Bronx, beyond the reach of Yankee Stadium’s shadow and the championship trophies’ shine, a forgotten memorial to a fallen baseball demigod sits hidden in plain sight.

headline: What Haiti Needs Right Now
text: Haiti has an ocean’s worth of problems, but money shouldn’t be one of them. The world’s response to the Jan. 12 earthquake was swift, with more than 150 countries and organizations promising to send hundreds of millions of dollars for emergency relief and billions more for long-term rebuilding.

headline: A Hit Parade for a Pop-Hungry Set
text: When the curtain goes up on “Smokey Joe’s Café” at the Paper Mill Playhouse, four guys are standing casually around a jukebox. They begin singing “Neighborhood” (“Faded pictures in my scrapbook/Just thought I’d take one more look”) as the other five cast members stroll onstage and join in. If that setup is a playful reference to the term “jukebox musical,” no show has a greater right to use it.

headline: Watch This Case
text: Months ago, Gretchen Morgenson and Louise Story of The Times exposed Goldman Sachs’s practice of creating and selling mortgage-backed investments and then placing financial bets that those investments would fail. While appalling, it wasn’t clear whether the practice was also fraud. The Securities and Exchange Commission has now decided that it was, charging Goldman on Friday.

headline: U.S. Indicts 5 Blackwater Ex-Officials
text: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors charged the former president of Blackwater Worldwide and four other former senior company officials on Friday with weapons violations and making false statements in the first criminal inquiry to reach into the top management ranks of the private security company.

headline: Justice and Comfort
text: The cause of equal rights for gays and lesbians, which is advancing in hard-won increments, moved forward on two important fronts this week.

headline: In ‘Tom Sawyer,’ Homage to Childhood
text: There is a dead cat in Hartford Stage’s “Tom Sawyer.” Huckleberry Finn carries it around for a while for no good reason. But the animal (fake, of course) is strangely cute, like one of those puppets Craig Ferguson plays with on “The Late, Late Show.”

headline: The Whole Ravitch Rescue
text: New York State’s lawmakers remain deeply divided over how to balance a $135 billion budget with a $9.2 billion hole in it  before the state runs out of cash in June.

headline: Trooper’s Role in Helping Roethlisberger Is Investigated
text: The Pennsylvania state police are investigating whether one of their officers violated regulations on off-duty work last month when  Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger was accused of sexually assaulting a 20-year-old woman at a rural Georgia nightspot.

headline: Outpost of Economic Cheer in a Borough Weary of Recession
text: Worlie Steven Moore spent much of his working life selling stylish men’s suits in luxury stores like Saks Fifth Avenue. But in February 2009 he was laid off and spent nearly a year out of work, mostly catching up on reading because looking for employment in his field during a recession seemed futile.

headline: Filling in the Blanks
text: When is a painting finished?

headline: Reverse Mortgages Still Costly, but Less So
text: The adage that you can’t take out a loan to pay for retirement is not entirely true.

headline: Do Price Cuts Make Reverse Mortgages More Attractive?
text: This week’s Your Money column looks at the recent price cuts in reverse mortgages, which allow older homeowners to essentially take a cash advance against their home equity — without having to make any payments.

headline: Pushing the Boundaries of Dance
text: PURCHASE

headline: 104 Are Arrested in Connection With Crips-Bloods Alliance
text: The Flocc street gang had an unusual mix of members. It formed out of an alliance, law enforcement officials said, between two groups that have traditionally been rivals: the Crips and the Bloods.

headline: Frustration May Have Led Parolee to Shoot Officer
text: He had fired a bullet into his parole officer’s upper chest on Thursday evening, the police said, and now Robert Morales was aiming at the officer’s face and trying to pull the trigger again to kill the officer, which would probably send him back to prison for good.

headline: Oom the Omnipotent Was Here
text: Yoga enthusiasts in Nyack can shop for classes in styles like anusara, vinyasa, iyengar and bikram. But the scene seems almost quaint compared with 90 years ago, when Dr. Pierre Bernard (right) introduced the rich and eccentric to the joys of the tantric tradition. The media called him Oom the Omnipotent; his devotees said he was a pioneer. To others, he was trouble.

headline: John Jay College Accused of Bias Against Noncitizens
text: The Justice Department filed a lawsuit on Friday against John Jay College of Criminal Justice, alleging that the school engaged in a pattern of job discrimination against noncitizens who were authorized to work.

headline: Obama Weighs Supreme Court Nominees, and Each Potential Battle
text: WASHINGTON — As President Obama’s advisers consider Supreme Court nominees, White House officials and political activists are focusing on the vulnerabilities that conservatives could exploit to portray them as so-called liberal judicial activists, according to interviews and a review of documents.

headline: At Upstate Campus, Saving Energy Is Part of Dorm Life
text: ITHACA, N.Y. — The Energy Star label, the federal government’s nod of approval for energy-efficient products, usually calls to mind household appliances like refrigerators and air-conditioners. But at Ithaca College, a campus known for its embrace of all things sustainable, two dormitories proudly wear the Energy Star label, too.

headline: Watercolors From the Kenyan Wild
text: Shelly Malkin is no stranger to the extremes of the natural world. Ms. Malkin, an artist who lives in Greenwich, is an avid rock climber, which comes with a pretty much endless supply of breathtaking vistas.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 16, 2010

headline: Dispute Revives Battle Between Rafters and Property Owners
text: GUNNISON, Colo. — For years, Mark Schumacher has guided white-water rafts up and down the Taylor, a swift moving river that cuts through the canyons and cliffs outside Gunnison.

headline: Meteorites in Them Thar Fields
text: CHICAGO — On the first day, there was light. On the third day, land — strewn with meteorites.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about state-of-the-art incinerators in Europe that cleanly convert waste to energy referred incorrectly to the ownership status of Covanta, a New Jersey company that processes some trash from New York City at older incinerators in Newark and Hempstead, N.Y. It is a publicly traded company, not a private one.

headline: Put Vendors in Their Place
text: JUST in time for summer, proposed Department of Parks and Recreation regulations would designate  and limit  where artists may sell their works in and around New York City’s major parks. Art vendors would be able to set up shop, with table or easel, in city parks, but in certain heavily congested areas under the Parks Department’s jurisdiction their numbers would be limited. No doubt some champions of individual expression will cry censorship. Indeed, the leader of the largest art vendor group is already preparing a legal attack on the new regulations.

headline: Bloggingheads: Tea Party Anger
text: James Poulos, left, of Postmodern Conservative and James Pinkerton of Fox News discuss Tea Partiers’ politics.

headline: Toyota Agrees Lexus S.U.V. Has Problem With Handling
text: Toyota said Friday that its engineers had duplicated the errant slide that prompted Consumer Reports to issue a “don’t buy” warning on the 2010 Lexus GX 460 and acknowledged that the vehicle had a safety problem.

headline: 1 in 3 Americans Failed to Return Census Forms
text: Nearly one in three Americans failed to return their census questionnaires by Friday’s official deadline, the Census Bureau said.

headline: Strip in a Bar
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — You’re right, that’s a purposely salacious blog post title. Let me atone by tackling the bible clues first because they’re both terrific. “Biblical spot” ought to be EDEN but that’s not enough letters. There’s a lot of complex geography in those testaments but fortunately we don’t need to know any of it here as long as we’re reading the right translation. Spot is a verb. Thou SEEST? What about “Fall cuisine?” Yes, that’s biblical too but APPLE is wrong. I laughed when the answer finally came to me like MANNA from heaven.

headline: Out of the Closet and Up, Up and Away
text: DIM lighting. Rendezvous-friendly nooks. Muscled bartenders. Pulsating dance music. At first glance, it could be any Saturday night in any gay bar in New York.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about the scheduled expiration of tax cuts for wealthier taxpayers included several imprecise or incorrect references. If Congress does not change current law, the following tax rates will be in effect after this year:

headline: Sale of Texas Rangers Is Delayed by Dispute With Banks
text: The pending sale of the Texas Rangers has become a deepening standoff between the owner of the team, who says he has lost enough money on the franchise and insists on keeping some of the proceeds from its sale, and creditors, who say they stand to lose many millions even if his full amount is turned over to them.

headline: In a Rush to Judge Goldman?
text: The market wasted little time in rushing to a particularly harsh judgment against Goldman Sachs on Friday, slicing some $12.4 billion off the company’s market value after the Securities and Exchange Commission filed a blockbuster civil suit against the firm and a vice president who works there. The commission says Goldman failed to disclose to investors how a complicated mortgage-backed security was made and the conflicts that resulted from it.

headline: Yankees’ Granderson Honored for His Off-Field Work
text: After less than two weeks as a Yankee, Curtis Granderson will get his first award Saturday before a game against Texas at Yankee Stadium.

headline: ‘The Past Is Never Dead. It’s Not Even Past.’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Investor Who Made Billions Is Not Target of Suit
text: Three and half years ago, a New York hedge fund manager with a bearish view on the housing market was pounding the pavement on Wall Street.

headline: Antony Flew, Philosopher and Ex-Atheist, Dies at 87
text: Antony Flew, an English philosopher and outspoken atheist who stunned and dismayed the unbelieving faithful when he announced in 2004 that God probably did exist, died April 8 in Reading, England. He was 87 and lived in Reading.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about Timothy M. Dolan’s first year as archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York misstated part of the Latin terms for two types of Catholic bishops, the outward-looking and the inward-focused. The terms are “ad extra” and “ad intra”  not “ad estera” and “ad intera.” (A reporter writing a book about Archbishop Dolan describes him as “ad extra.”)

headline: Rain Shortens Game but Does Little to Slow Sabathia or the Yanks
text: C. C. Sabathia, the ace of the Yankees’ pitching staff, is a large man who wears a big, baggy uniform that fits him like comfortable old pajamas.

headline: Colleges Wait to Hear Their Name Called by Elite Recruit
text: BALTIMORE — Last Friday evening, Josh Selby, the nation’s most explosive high school guard yet to commit to a college, walked out the back door of Lake Clifton High School here with the Tennessee assistant Steve Forbes. The two kept chatting as they approached a light-blue Mercedes-Benz with tinted windows. Selby, keys in hand, popped the trunk, threw sneakers in it and joked with Forbes. Selby said goodbye, and drove away. It was Selby’s last visit from a coach before making his college decision.

headline: A Wall Street Invention Let the Crisis Mutate
text: Can it get any worse?

headline: At Coachella, Rap-Rock Returns
text: INDIO, Calif. — The afternoon theme du jour is that rap goes with everything — no surprise, perhaps, when the night’s headliner is Jay-Z, who has become the man for all festivals. But the more improbable corollary is that rap-rock, the widely derided late-1990s fusion that dominated FM rock radio for a few tedious years, is recovering some of its early promise. The day’s first blast of it was by P.O.S., a Minnesota rapper who details setbacks, struggles, contradictions and small, hard-won successes: “I can never be what I want to be/Nothing but a man,” he rapped. His rhymes are fast, with jagged rhythms; his band pounds without steamrollering him, and he keeps his shoutalongs simple enough to keep the crowd with him: “Yeah right!” went one, “Yeah,” went another.

headline: Best Advice for Travelers: Rebook Your Flight
text: Still trying to figure out whether you can get to Europe this weekend in spite of all the chaos caused by the cloud of volcanic ash that has virtually shut down air traffic there? You’re out of luck but not out of options.

headline: Europe Plan Would Put Tighter Rein on Banking
text: MADRID — Banks operating in the European Union will have to accept stricter external supervision and be required to set aside more money to prevent another crisis under a regulatory proposal to be presented by the European Commission in June.

headline: Movie Futures Exchange Can Open, but It Can’t Trade Yet
text: The commission that oversees futures markets approved on Friday a proposal by Veriana Networks to open a futures exchange, but expressed concerns about the company’s plans to trade contracts on that market tied to the box-office receipts of forthcoming films.

headline: Andrew Cuomo’s Message, Delivered Offstage
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama’s Failure to Fight for a Nominee
text: To the Editor:
