text: To the Editor:

headline: Igarashi Bolsters His Bid for Setup Job With Mets
text: ST. LOUIS — On a slow day toward the end of spring training, Ryota Igarashi finished a bullpen session and was approached by the Mets’ pitching coach, Dan Warthen, who was looking for something.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the Reuters Breakingviews column on Friday about America’s lack of appetite for Greek bonds misstated the size of an aid package for Greece being assembled by European countries and the International Monetary Fund. The package is valued at 45 billion euros, not $45 billion.

headline: The Cap Room Just Got a Little Bigger
text: With one unexpected and seemingly benign statement on Friday, Commissioner David Stern may have altered this summer’s free-agent landscape.

headline: Corrections
text: The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about new treatments for multiple myeloma, included an outdated reference to the insurance coverage of a patient, Janet Battaile. After she was interviewed for the column, but before the section went to press, Ms. Battaile learned that her insurer, United Healthcare, would cover her participation in a trial of the experimental drug pomalidomide; she is no longer “battling her insurance company.”

headline: Two Men Found Shot, One Fatally, in the Bronx
text: One man was killed and another critically injured Friday evening when they were shot on a dead-end street in an industrial neighborhood in the Bronx, the police said.

headline: L.I. Victim’s Family Criticizes Judge for Keeping Jury Late
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — On their third day of deliberations, the jurors determining the fate of a Long Island man accused of fatally stabbing a Hispanic immigrant in 2008 began deliberating at 9:45 a.m. Friday. By 9:30 p.m., nearly 12 hours later, they were still at the courthouse here, sitting in the courtroom listening to a court reporter read, line by line, the transcript of a lawyer’s detailed cross-examination of a witness.

headline: Leading Gay and Lesbian Comic Heroes
text: A look at the most prominent gay and lesbian comic-book superheroes.

headline: For Free Agents, Playoffs Could Be a Tipping Point
text: Dwyane Wade wants a parade in June, but he will probably be home by May Day. Chris Bosh wants a simple playoff victory, but he is firmly planted on his couch. Joe Johnson wants validation, Amar’e Stoudemire wants recognition and LeBron James wants something resembling world domination.

headline: Perez Delivers, but One Pitch Is Enough to Upend Mets
text: ST. LOUIS — All Manager Jerry Manuel wanted from Oliver Perez was for him to pitch better than he did against the Cardinals in spring training, and to last six or seven innings with the Mets in a close game. It was not an extravagant request, even for Perez, a mercurial left-hander, and he did everything Manuel asked.

headline: A Sorority of Three, and Counting
text: TWO weeks ago in Minneapolis, when Sarah Palin (the half-term Alaska governor) and Michele Bachmann (the Minnesota Republican congresswoman) took the stage to rally support for Ms. Bachmann for the midterm elections, they seemed to draw power from their proximity, like the Wonder Twins in the 1970s cartoons. But with their coordinating outfits — Ms. Palin in a shiny black jacket, glittery cross pendant and Madonna-in-the-’80s pearl strands; Ms. Bachmann in a  “Dynasty”  -bright yellow jacket — they strongly evoked another retro duo, the stars of the 1997 film  “Romy and Michele’s High School Reunion.”

headline: Chipmaker in the Netherlands Plans to Sell Shares
text: NXP Semiconductors, the Dutch chipmaker owned by KKR & Company and Bain Capital, filed to raise $1.15 billion in what would be the biggest initial public offering in the United States this year. NXP did not disclose the number of shares it intends to sell or at what price range in its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday. The chipmaker, which is based in Eindhoven, The Netherlands, and has reported losses for three straight years, plans to use the proceeds to repay debt. NXP, with 27,000 employees, makes computer chips for a broad range of electronic device makers such as Nokia Oyj and Apple, according to the filing.

headline: That’s How He Rolls
text: WILL FORTE walked into a Santa Monica, Calif., bowling alley on a recent evening carrying bowling shoes and flashing the boyish grin that makes him arguably the most crushable bachelor on “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: Internal Report Faults S.E.C. In Stanford Case
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission did not conduct a meaningful investigation of the indicted money manager R. Allen Stanford until 2005 even though examiners suspected him of operating a Ponzi scheme eight years earlier, a report by the S.E.C.’s inspector general, H. David Kotz, disclosed Friday. The S.E.C. sued Mr. Stanford in February 2009, claiming his Antigua-based firm, the Stanford International Bank, defrauded investors by selling billions of dollars in bogus certificates of deposit. He is jailed awaiting a January trial on related criminal charges that he oversaw a $7 billion Ponzi scheme.

headline: Philosophical Waxing Eases the Ouch
text: A CLIENT’S giggles bubbled up from a treatment room at the J. Sisters Salon in Midtown, which would be nothing remarkable were the client undergoing a regular salon treatment. But the laughter came over the rip-rip-rip of muslin strips covered in hot wax that were pulling hairs from her bikini area: the woman was in the midst of a Brazilian wax.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Two Marathoners Head to Boston, Each With an Eye on His Neighbor
text: A week ago, while Ryan Hall was running around sunny Walden Pond, Meb Keflezighi was back home in Mammoth Lakes, Calif., navigating through a foot of snow.

headline: Message From Union Says Upper Deck Owes Players
text: Major League Baseball’s players union told agents in an e-mail message on Friday that the trading card company Upper Deck was experiencing financial difficulty and had not paid a large number of players money it owed them.

headline: U.N.’s Bhutto Report Says What Pakistanis Already Know About Spy Agency and Army
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The long-awaited United Nations report on the assassination of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto did not answer the central question of who killed her, but did put its finger directly on what remains the most troubling part of Pakistan’s reality, the dominance of its military and intelligence services over civilian leaders.

headline: Air Travel Crisis Deepens as Europe Fears Wider Impact
text: PARIS — As an increasingly large part of European airspace was shut down for the third day on Saturday and the towering fountain of ash from an Icelandic volcano showed no signs of letting up, questions about the long-term impact of the eruption were being raised in a continent trying to recover from recession.

headline: North Korea Denies Sinking Navy Ship
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea on Saturday denied involvement in the mysterious sinking of a South Korean warship in waters disputed between the two Koreas.

headline: Photographs From Coachella, Day 1
text: Photographs from the first day of the Coachella Music and Arts Festival in Indio, California.

headline: Submit Your Questions for Clarence Seedorf
text: With five games remaining in the Italian Serie A season, A.C. Milan is in third place behind Inter Milan and Roma. Its final matches will test players’ will to challenge city rival Inter through the end of the season.

headline: ‘Biden Gave Only 1.44 Percent’
text: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: Obama Vows to Move on Regulation
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Saturday accused Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, of waging a “cynical and deceptive” attack against a measure to tighten regulation of the nation’s financial system, and vowed to move ahead on the bill with or without the minority party’s support.

headline: N.F.L. Draft: The Road Back for Ryan  Perrilloux
text: Cecil Lammey of Draftguys.com will help preview and analyze the draft for the Fifth Down. He and Sigmund Bloom host the podcast at FootballGuys.com. You can follow him on Twitter here.

headline: Urban Forager | Dandelion Wine? No, Jelly
text: Last week’s sudden 90-degree spell spurred a pageant of early flowering across the five boroughs that went far beyond the usual spring bulbs — see the magnolias, cherry blossoms and dogwoods in fervent bloom — but perhaps none more prominent than the ubiquitous yellow blossom that gardeners love to hate: the common dandelion.

headline: The New Yorker Explains Resolution Authority
text: Funny how this never happens.

headline: Every Mode but Silly Walks to Get Around
text: LONDON — For the man who worked at the Ministry of Silly Walks, travel chaos across the Continent was only a modest hurdle.

headline: Time to Reread Akerlof and Romer
text: Looting: The Economic Underworld of Bankruptcy for Profit.

headline: The Schumacher Question
text: The tension was palpable at the Mercedes team this afternoon after qualifying. Nico Rosberg had set the fourth fastest time and will therefore start fourth on the grid. His illustrious teammate, Michael Schumacher, could manage only ninth fastest — at .7 seconds slower than Rosberg.

headline: The Saturday Word: Regulate
text: President Obama used his weekly national address to rally support for his plan to regulate Wall Street, saying that tighter restrictions on the financial industry would have prevented the economic meltdown. He also chastised the Senate’s top Republican for criticizing the Democrats’ efforts.“When he returned to Washington, the Senate Republican Leader came out against the common-sense reforms we’ve proposed,” Mr. Obama said, referring to Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the minority leader. “In doing so, he made the cynical and deceptive assertion that reform would somehow enable future bailouts – when he knows that it would do just the opposite.”

headline: April’s Poli-Book Best Seller List
text: “The Big Short” by Michael Lewis debuts at No. 1, providing further evidence of sustained reader interest in the failings of Wall Street. In fact, several books on this month’s Caucus list of political best sellers continue to mine the reasons for the nation’s financial downturn and collapse of big Wall Street institutions.

headline: Fallon: ‘New Comic Book’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Jimmy Fallon: In an interview with GQ magazine, Lou Dobbs said he’s considering running for president. Hey, stranger things have happened. Lou Dobbs in GQ magazine being one of them, I think.

headline: The Shaky Planet
text: With news last week of yet another devastating earthquake, a 6.9-magnitude jolt in western China that killed at least 700, many wondered if the earth was in an especially volatile phase.

headline: Prime Number
text: 125: The approximate number of former Congressional aides and lawmakers who are lobbying for Wall Street and the financial services sector as part of a multibillion dollar effort to shape, and often scale back, federal regulatory power over the industry, according to analyses by Public Citizen and the Center for Responsive Politics, two nonpartisan watchdog groups.

headline: When an Invention Reached New Heights
text: George Nissen, inventor of the trampoline, died on April 7 at 96, but not before the acrobatics he first tried on the “bouncing rig” he built as a 16-year-old in 1930 (a canvas sheet stretched across a steel frame) became an Olympic event. Nissen was 86 and still capable of executing somersaults on his invention when he traveled to Sydney to watch the newly recognized sport. The Times was with him.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Senate Republicans took a hard line against a Democratic proposal to regulate the financial system.

headline: Correction: Stevens, the Only Protestant on the Supreme Court
text: A picture last Sunday with an article about Justice John Paul Stevens’s being the only Protestant on the Supreme Court was printed in mirror image. While Justice Stevens was correctly identified in the photograph, of the justices on the Court in 1976, he should have been shown on the far right of the second row.

headline: Video of Volcano Spewing More Ash
text: As my colleagues Julia Werdigier, Alan Cowell and Nicola Clark report, an Icelandic geologist, Magnus Tumi Gudmundsson of the University of Iceland, told The Associated Press on Saturday that activity was increasing at the Eyjafjallajokull volcano that has grounded flights across Europe.

headline: At G.W.U., Commencement Competition
text: Call it the jitter room.

headline: Copenhagen to Paris? Join the Crowd, Drink a Beer
text: The Times correspondent John Tagliabue recounts his three-day journey from Copenhagen to his home in Paris. Use the comments below to tell us how you or someone who know, besides John Cleese,  who improvised travel because of the volcanic plume over Europe.

headline: Spiral
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Wait a sec, did I read that right? Did Will Shortz just announce his retirement? The third clue today reads “Former New York Times crossword editor Will.” Former?

headline: Marine Stayed Faithful to Dream of Playing Football
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Even when the days were longest at his North Carolina Marine base, when he went to the weight room three times a day to fill the hours between the 4 a.m. physical fitness test and when he went to bed, Brandon Crawford would not join the unit football teams.

headline: The Shy Life, Sniffing Bears, Oysters Away
text: Living Quietly

headline: Fleeing Drug Violence, Mexicans Pour Into U.S.
text: FORT HANCOCK, Tex. — The giant rusty fence of metal bars along the border here, built in recent years to keep illegal immigrants from crossing into the United States, has a new nickname among local residents: Jurassic Park Gate, a nod to the barrier in a 1993 movie that kept dangerous dinosaurs at bay in a theme park.

headline: N.F.L. Draft Travels Far for a Two-Night Stay
text: No longer pro football’s off-season daytime soap opera, the N.F.L. draft will have its premiere as a two-night prime-time special this year. Under the elegant gold stage curtain of Radio City Music Hall, the 32 franchises will select more than 200 rookies over three days. Few will be instant starters, some will make the team. Many will disappear during training camp.

headline: Ferguson: ‘Send Someone to Mars’
text: Monologue |  Aired Friday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: President Obama went to NASA headquarters, where he said he wants to send someone to Mars. They’re still deciding who to send. It was an awkward moment when Bill Clinton went, “We could send Hillary.”

headline: For Goldman, a Bet’s Stakes Keep Growing
text: For Goldman Sachs, it was a relatively small transaction. But for the bank — and the rest of Wall Street — the stakes couldn’t be higher.

headline: Ski Team Pinched Everywhere but Top
text: The United States Ski and Snowboard Association continues to revel in its record-breaking success at the Vancouver Olympics, where 17 Americans took home 21 medals, the biggest haul in the organization’s 100-year history.

headline: Monica Youn and Whitney Armstrong
text: Monica Youngna Youn and Whitney Brewster Armstrong were married Saturday evening at St. Thomas Church in New York. The Rev. Jonathan M. Erdman, an Episcopal priest and the church’s curate and youth minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Where’s Bob Barker When You Need Him?
text: Ever been out playing with your buddies and thought it would be fun to try a Happy Gilmore swing on the tee? Come on, be honest.

headline: Inquiry Faults S.E.C.’s Handling of Stanford Case
text: Securities regulators suspected as early as 1997 that the Texas financier R. Allen Stanford was running a Ponzi scheme, a government investigation found, but they did nothing to stop it until late 2005.

headline: Jennifer Ku and Peter Rubin
text: Jennifer Eunmi Ku and Justice Peter Jason Rubin were married Saturday evening at the Charles Hotel in Cambridge, Mass. Rabbi Jonah D. Pesner officiated.

headline: Russia and Poland: A Blood Feud Rooted Deep in the Past
text: MOSCOW — Until very recently, President Lech Kaczynski of Poland was seen here as an especially disagreeable strain of Eastern European leader, one of those Slavic turncoats who demonized Russia and toadied up to its rivals. Then Mr. Kaczynski was killed in a plane crash on Russian soil this month, and Russia choked up.

headline: Julie Horowitz, Ian Wallace
text: Julie Heather Horowitz and Peter Ian Wallace were married Saturday in New York. Michael S. Davidson, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated at the home of the bride’s parents, Barbara and Lawrence Horowitz.

headline: Anne Leader, Richard Guether Jr.
text: Anne Conyers Leader and Richard Charles Guether Jr. were married Saturday by the Rev. William R. Heston at the First Presbyterian Church in Houston.

headline: Why Newer Appointees Offer Fewer Surprises
text: WASHINGTON — The last two justices to leave the Supreme Court, David H. Souter and Sandra Day O’Connor, were nominated by Republican presidents and then drifted left. So did Justice John Paul Stevens, who announced his retirement last week.

headline: The Benefits of a Sabathia-Cervelli Partnership
text: On the morning of an A.J. Burnett start, the concept of a personal catcher was a topic in Joe Girardi’s pregame interview session. For a change, it had nothing to do with Burnett, who is making his third straight start Saturday with Jorge Posada behind the plate. C.C. Sabathia pitched brilliantly Friday night for the second consecutive outing, and both have come with the backup, Francisco Cervelli, catching him.

headline: Jessica Shapiro, Gregory Cavic
text: Jessica Frances Shapiro and Gregory George Cavic were married Saturday at St. Steven’s Serbian Orthodox Cathedral in Alhambra, Calif. The Very Rev. Radomir Chkautovich performed the ceremony with the assistance of the Rev. Serge Veselinovich. Both are Serbian Orthodox priests.

headline: After Quake, Tibetans Distrust China’s Help
text: JIEGU, China — The Buddhist monks stood atop the jagged remains of a vocational school, struggling to move concrete slabs with pickax shovels and bare hands. Suddenly a cry went out: An arm, clearly lifeless, was poking through the debris.

headline: For Cash-Strapped  States, Sin Is Sure Lucrative
text: In tough fiscal times, everything needs to be monetized. Including morality.

headline: New York Offers Costly Lessons on Insurance
text: When her small executive search firm in New York City canceled its health insurance policy last year because of the recession and rising premiums, April Welles was able to buy her own plan and still be covered for her cancer and multiple sclerosis.

headline: Ann MacRae, Winthrop Ruml
text: Ann Cameron MacRae, a daughter of Ann Bedell MacRae and Cameron F. MacRae III of New York, was married Saturday to Winthrop Jordan Ruml, a son of Doriane Carter Ruml of Lexington, Mass. The Rev. Jonathan C. Page, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the Jupiter Island Beach Club in Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. David C. L. Prior, an Episcopal priest, assisted.

headline: Usha Pinninti and Geoffrey Kaung
text: Dr. Usha Rani Pinninti and Dr. Geoffrey Kaung were married Saturday at the Meridian House in Washington. Pandit Narayanachar Digalakote, a Hindu priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Katherine Susman, Zachary Baylin
text: Katherine Temma Susman and Zachary Jones Baylin were married Saturday evening on Pier 46 at Hudson River Park in New York. Jonathan F. Baylin, the bridegroom’s father, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: No Planes, Waiting for Trains
text: For a third day, travelers in Europe scrambled to get around as the volcanic ash plume grounded flights over much of the Continent.

headline: Hard-Luck Trail Blazers Trying to See the Basket as Half Full
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Nate McMillan could win the N.B.A.’s coach of the year award because he not only Lewis-and-Clarked the Portland Trail Blazers through the league’s strangest season to reach the playoffs, but ruptured his Achilles’ tendon in the process.

headline: For Giddyup, Give a Horse a Holiday
text: Mister Ed knew what he wanted out of a vacation. He once stowed away on a cruise ship bound for Honolulu, took up surfing and announced that he liked the Hawaiian life so much he wouldn’t be returning home.

headline: After Team’s Collapse, Fans Enjoy Final Surprise
text: PORTSMOUTH, England — Through the dourest of winters, some of England’s most ardent soccer fans winced and vented, for their cherished Portsmouth team not only dwelled in the Premier League dungeon but also moved closer to relegation for next season. The club also typified the global recession when its debts threatened the whole enterprise with extinction.

headline: A Fight to Save the House That Built Ruth
text: BALTIMORE — The hardscrabble field where George Herman Ruth Jr. learned baseball from a Xaverian brother is now a lovingly landscaped diamond. The little trees that he saw when he looked uphill from the field have grown into tall, graceful oaks.

headline: Measuring Wall Street Apologetics
text: The parade of bankers called to account for the financial crisis continued last week when Kerry K. Killinger, head of Washington Mutual, the largest bank ever to fail, apologized, sort of, as have many before him. But he also said that his firm “should have been given a chance.” Here are some of those mea culpa moments.

headline: Tea Party Supporters Doing Fine, but Angry Nonetheless
text: It makes sense that people would take to the streets to protest government spending and enormous deficits during the Great Recession, when they are feeling economic pain most acutely.

headline: After Strong Year for Hedge Funds, Investors Return
text: While the stock market was surging back last year, so, too, were hedge funds, Paul Sullivan reports in his Wealth Matters column in The New York Times. This recovery may anger the average investor who equates hedge funds with the bad deeds of Wall Street. And the funds’ quick return may surprise sophisticated investors who are still smarting from the money they lost in their rush to move their portfolios to cash.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 18
text: President Barack Obama‘s financial regulatory overhaul and the approaching midterm November elections are the talk of the town — Washington, that is — this Sunday.

headline: Uniform Number Is Just a Bit Low
text: Ever since he was 8 years old, Clay Buchholz said, he wore No. 11 on his jersey. But when Buchholz joined the Boston Red Sox in 2007, at age 23, he was given No. 61, typical for a rookie.

headline: Best Safeties in the N.F.L.: The Top 10 List
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely – but not strictly – by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, although the future isn’t ignored. Statistics weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t sneak on to Top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding something to disagree with:

headline: Castroneves Leaves Worries Behind and Finds He Is Smiling Again
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. (AP) — Hélio Castroneves is chatting with crew members outside his race hauler when fans call out his name.

headline: Confident Burton Is Gaining Speed but Not Victories
text: FORT WORTH (AP) — Jeff Burton had been running some of the fastest laps at Phoenix before he was penalized for an improper pit stop.

headline: Out of the Loop in Silicon Valley
text: San Francisco

headline: Stalking a Saltwater Trophy in Belize
text: TURNEFFE ATOLL, Belize — Less than 20 minutes from the dock at Turneffe Flats Lodge, my angling buddy Geoff Roach and I beheld a sight that would set any saltwater fly angler’s heart aflutter: the thin dorsal fins of a school of permit, slicing like a scythe through the clear Caribbean. Our guide, Michael Anderson, killed the motor, climbed onto his poling platform and began pushing us slowly toward the fish. Moving onto the skiff’s casting deck, I nervously peeled line off my reel and tried to steady my nerves.

headline: Drug War Refugees Seek Asylum at the Texas Border
text: Fort Hancock, a small Texas town on the border with Mexico, is struggling to take in an influx of people seeking asylum from drug violence.

headline: In Caucasus, Two Leaders Vie for Loyalty
text: MAGAS, Russia — Yunus-Bek Yevkurov, the president of the Russian republic of Ingushetia, was sitting in his gold-domed palace, a warren of cool, empty marble halls surrounded by rings of gunmen.

headline: John A. Paulson Is Not Target of S.E.C. Inquiry
text: Three and half years ago, a New York hedge fund manager with a bearish view on the housing market was pounding the pavement on Wall Street, The New York Times’s Gretchen Morgenson and Louise Story report. Eager to increase his bets against subprime mortgages, the investor, John A. Paulson, canvassed firm after firm, looking for new ways to profit from home loans that he was sure would go sour.

headline: In Los Angeles, the Saucer Is Ready to Land Again
text: LOS ANGELES — Before they face traffic on the 405 freeway, grab an In-N-Out burger or zip off to Rodeo Drive to see whatever they think is there, visitors who arrive here through LAX first stare up at the futuristic spider-shaped building at the center of the airport, welcoming them to the edge of America.

headline: N.H.L. Teams Fight to Keep Gloves On in Playoffs
text: No one complains when the fighting stops.

headline: Coachella’s Capitalist and Its Naysayer
text: INDIO, Calif. — Coachella’s two head-to-head headliners on Friday night, blasting away simultaneously on adjacent stages, were opposites in some ways. Jay-Z was the triumphal capitalist, touting his business savvy and long-term success with a big band, a full stage production — complete with a video backdrop and an entrance via lift — and a glamorous cameo from Beyonce, his wife, that was topped with fireworks. Public Image Ltd. (PiL on its logo), playing John Lydon’s pioneering post-punk songs for its first tour in 18 years, was the unglamorous naysayer, sneering at capitalism (in its opening tune, “This Is Not a Love Song”) and singing about death, antisocial thoughts and lifelong trauma.

headline: Carolyn Montrose, Adam Dub
text: Carolyn Heather Montrose and Adam Craig Dub were married Saturday evening at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Cantor Henry Weintraub officiated.

headline: Vikeena Bonett, Matthew Wolfe
text: Vikeena Kimberly Bonett, a daughter of Edna M. Bonett and Victor L. Bonett of Elmont, N.Y., was married in Manhattan on Saturday morning to Matthew Alan Wolfe, the son of Judy A. Wolfe of Avon, Ohio, and Robert A. Wolfe of Amherst, Ohio. The Rev. Randolph Weber performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, where he is associate minister.

headline: Graft Probe Heats Up Bingo Issue in Alabama
text: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — On the first day of April, Zeb Little was sitting down to a barbecue luncheon when he was summoned to a meeting at the State Department of Public Safety. For around 10 minutes, Mr. Little, the majority leader in the Democratic-controlled State Senate, waited at the office with several other senior Republican and Democratic lawmakers.

headline: Jen Rogers, Alex Taylor
text: Jen Lacey Rogers and Alex Bernick Taylor were married Saturday evening at the Galapagos Art Space, a performing arts and event site in Brooklyn. Brian J. Hashimoto, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated.

headline: Songs to Accompany an Air Horn
text: The time had finally come for the Washington Capitals to take a bold step. Fueled by their captain, Alex Ovechkin, the Capitals assembled a fast, young, aggressive team that scored often this season.

headline: Virginia Iglesia, Steven Weber
text: Virginia Iglesia and Steven D. Weber, lawyers, were married Saturday evening at the Westin Colonnade Hotel in Coral Gables, Fla. Judge Alan S. Gold of the United States District Court in Miami officiated.

headline: Allison Bailey, Douglas Blais
text: Allison Elizabeth Bailey and Douglas Wheeler Blais were married Saturday by the Rev. Michael L. Lindvall at Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

headline: Rebecca Sawyer, Kenneth Lin
text: Rebecca Ruth Sawyer and Kenneth Lin are to be married Sunday at Atlantis Marine World, an aquarium in Riverhead, N.Y. Jackson Gay, a Universal Life minister and a theater director, is to officiate.

headline: Other Thoughts From Coachella on Friday
text: INDIO, Calif. — Kate Miller-Heidke, an Australian songwriter who can be tenderly folky or sly and wry, has a warm voice with a secret extension: a high, operatic flutter, that had the crowd whooping every time she unleashed it. She used it sparingly, and every time was a zinger.

headline: Jessica Keefe, Brian Ryckman
text: Jessica Leanne Keefe and Brian Charles Ryckman were married Saturday evening in Savannah, Ga. The Rev. Stephen Williams, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Harper Fowlkes House, a 19th-century home and event space.

headline: Lessons From the Gridiron
text: I GREW up in Toledo, in the Old West End neighborhood near the Toledo Museum of Art. It was a predominantly African-American neighborhood. My mother worked for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, finding temporary housing for residents whose apartments were being torn down. My father was a skycap for United Airlines and worked nights as a janitor at the local library.

headline: Women’s Rugby Surges, Especially on Campus
text: WAYNE, Neb. (AP) — Long denied the chance to compete in contact sports, women are now joining rugby clubs in record numbers and relishing the hard-nosed nature of what has been called a gentleman’s game for ruffians.

headline: Darria Long and Bryce Gillespie
text: Dr. Darria Elizabeth Long and Dr. Bryce Tinker Gillespie were married Saturday evening at First Presbyterian Church in Chattanooga, Tenn. The Rev. Ben Haden, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony with the assistance of the Rev. Mike Preg, also a Presbyterian minister.

headline: Official Contends Greece Won’t Face Further Restrictions
text: MADRID — Greece’s finance minister dismissed on Saturday speculation that his government would be forced to introduce tougher austerity measures in return for securing a 45 billion euro loan package — even as he indicated that the country’s deficit had climbed higher than initially estimated.

headline: Samantha Hill, Benjamin Brutlag
text: Samantha Ariel Hill, a daughter of Frances I. Hill and Philip S. Hill III of New York, is to be married Sunday to Benjamin Daniel Brutlag, the son of Simone Claude Brutlag and Douglas Lee Brutlag of Menlo Park, Calif. Joseph N. Gruber, a Universal Life minister, will officiate at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J.

headline: Can’t Cut Spending? Look Around the Globe
text: AMERICA’S long-run fiscal outlook is bleak, mostly because of an aging population and rising health care costs. To close the gap between expenditures and revenue, we’ll likely see a combination of revenue increases and spending cuts. And we’ll need to focus especially on reducing spending, largely because that taxes on the wealthy can be raised only so high.

headline: Natalie Guthrie, Alex Taylor
text: Natalie Fostel Guthrie and Alex Gregory Taylor were married Saturday evening in Charleston, S.C. Douglas L. Farmer, a minister of the International Fellowship of Chaplains, officiated at the Wickliffe House, an event space.

headline: Letters to the Editor: A Pair of No. 42s for the Ages
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Alison Plenge, Colin Aitken
text: Alison Jo Plenge, a daughter of Jo Ann R. Plenge and Charles F. Plenge of Dallas, was married there Saturday to Colin Echeverria Aitken, the son of Lina M. Echeverria-Aitken and Bruce G. Aitken of Corning, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Fran T. Shelton, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Rosewood Crescent Hotel.

headline: Kristen Scipione, Vincent Scorza III
text: Kristen Jennifer Scipione, the daughter of John A. Scipione of Fairfax, Va., and the late Karen G. Scipione, was married Saturday evening to Vincent Francis Scorza III, the son of Christine Scorza and Mr. Scorza Jr. of Patchogue, N.Y. The Rev. Elizabeth A. Bansavage, an interfaith minister, officiated at Le Parker Meridien Hotel in New York.

headline: Every Million Counts for the Knicks
text: As reported in Off the Dribble, the Knicks got some good news on Friday when N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern provided an updated projection for the league’s salary cap. Revealing that the 2009-10 season is going better than originally thought, Stern indicated that the league was now projecting a 2010-11 salary cap of $56.1 million — although he acknowledged that “maybe we’ll have to hustle and get it.”

headline: Trench Warfare: Send In the Deputies
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Obama v. Roberts: The Struggle to Come
text: WASHINGTON — They are two of the smartest men of their generation, both magna cum laude products of Harvard Law School, both cerebral and charming and ambitious. They vaulted to the highest offices in the land after just short stints at the next level down, and each was seen initially as a conciliator only to lead on the strength of his own majority.

headline: This Bailout Is a Bargain? Think Again
text: IT’S way too early to tally the costs of the government’s various efforts to help our nation’s financial institutions survive the credit debacle. But that hasn’t stopped anonymous Treasury officials from claiming in recent days that their Armageddon-avoidance will wind up costing far less than many feared.

headline: Another Gerhart Stands Out at Stanford
text: STANFORD, Calif. (AP) — Teagan Gerhart is still regularly referred to as the younger sister of Toby Gerhart, a Heisman Trophy runner-up and former Stanford star.

headline: Police Officer Arrested in Assault on Cabby
text: An off-duty city police officer was arrested after being accused of punching a  cabdriver in the face on the East Side, the police said.

headline: Obama Cancels Trip to Poland
text: The White House announced just a short while ago that President Obama has canceled his overnight trip to Krakow, Poland, for that country’s presidential funeral on Sunday, citing the ash spewing from the Icelandic volcano.Mr. Obama released this statement:

headline: In North Korea, Juche Iron vs. American Crows
text: NEVER mind the chronic food shortage: North Korea’s propaganda apparatus is partying like it’s 99  and over there, it is. Year 1 of the Juche Calendar (named after “Juche Thought,” the regime’s official pseudo-ideology) was 1912, the birth year of the state’s founder, Kim Il-sung, whose birthday was celebrated last week. The new century will therefore be celebrated next year with all the requisite hoopla, which must then be outdone in 2012 for the 100th anniversary of Kim’s birth. The approach of back-to-back centennials, each symbolic of a national coming-of-age, puts great pressure on Kim’s successor and son, Kim Jong-il, to improve living conditions for the masses.

headline: Painful Memory Returns to Mound Against Mets
text: ST. LOUIS — Perhaps the last thing Mets fans need is a reminder of one of their most painful memories in recent years, but they will get it if they watch the St. Louis Cardinals’ Adam Wainwright take the mound against their team on Sunday night.

headline: Two Billion Laptops? It May Not Be Enough
text: ONE LAPTOP PER CHILD is a nonprofit group that thinks big. Since 2007, it has sold inexpensive but rugged laptop computers to the governments of less-developed countries. The goal is to equip each of the two billion children in the developing world with his or her own computer.

headline: Church’s Woes Follow Pope on Trip to Malta
text: VALLETTA, Malta — In spite of the cloud of volcanic ash drifting south from Iceland, Pope Benedict XVI arrived in this Catholic nation on Saturday evening in his first foreign trip since a sexual abuse crisis began engulfing the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Rodriguez Hits First Homer of Year as Yankees Mix Power and Speed
text: To begin the 1995 season, Alex Rodriguez went 48 at-bats before hitting his first home run. He was 19 then, playing his home games at the gloomy Kingdome in faraway Seattle and backing up Felix Fermin at shortstop. Now that he is a prodigious slugger whose workplace is a $1.5 billion palace, Rodriguez is no less immune to a home run drought. It is just that, as a Yankee, he snaps it in style.

headline: ‘The System Is Broken’: More From a Poll of Tea Party Backers
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll looks at the 18 percent of Americans who consider themselves supporters of the Tea Party movement.

headline: Keep the Fed on Main Street
text: Kansas City, Mo.

headline: Suicide Bombers Strike Refugees in Pakistan
text: KACHA PAKHA, Pakistan (Reuters) — Two suicide bombings at a center for people displaced by a Pakistani military offensive against militants killed at least 38 people and wounded 65 on Saturday, an official said.

headline: Troubles Turn to Olympic Gold
text: At the Beijing Olympics in 2008, Henry Cejudo, then 21, became the youngest gold medalist in United States wrestling history. This completed a most improbable journey, one captured by Cejudo and Bill Plaschke, a columnist for The Los Angeles Times, in a book titled “American Victory.” In 223 entertaining pages, Plaschke told Cejudo’s story: life on the street and in a junkyard, in fear of immigration officials and his father, a career criminal, fighting for ice cream and survival. Cejudo took a break from his book tour to talk. GREG BISHOP

headline: Cows on Drugs
text: Stanford, Calif.

headline: Africa Reboots
text: I SPENT March with a delegation of activists, entrepreneurs and policy wonks roaming western, southern and eastern Africa trying very hard to listen — always hard for a big-mouthed Irishman. With duct tape over my gob, I was able to pick up some interesting melody lines everywhere from palace to pavement ...

headline: Europe-Bound Travelers in U.S. Struggle to Cope
text: Thousands of travelers bound for Europe remained in limbo in the United States on Saturday, waiting for a volcanic ash cloud an ocean away to clear.

headline: A Thanksgiving Meal, Then Charges of Jihad: A Mother’s Tale
text: WASHINGTON — In the photograph from last November, Ramy Zamzam, 22, is a proud first-year dental student in his new white jacket, framed by his beaming parents.

headline: The Scoreboard Can’t Tell You Everything
text: This interview with Bill Carter, partner in and founder of Fuse, a youth marketing agency, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Blasts Rattle Cricket Fans in South India
text: NEW DELHI — At least 15 people were injured Saturday by two explosions near a crowded cricket stadium in Bangalore as thousands of spectators were arriving for a match in India’s popular professional league.

headline: United Nations Endorses Afghan President’s Choice to Lead Election Commission
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — After months of pressure from Western leaders seeking to avoid another fraud-ridden election, President Hamid Karzai on Saturday chose a new head of Afghanistan’s election commission, who received the immediate endorsement of the United Nations.

headline: From Dung to Coffee Brew With No Aftertaste
text: SAGADA, the Philippines — Goad Sibayan went prospecting recently in the remote Philippine highlands here known as the Cordillera. He clambered up and then down a narrow, rocky footpath that snaked around some hills, paying no heed to coffins that, in keeping with a local funeral tradition, hung very conspicuously from the surrounding sheer cliffs.

headline: After Health Care Passage, Obama Pushes to Get It Rolling
text: WASHINGTON — Mindful that the new health care law’s ability to slow rising medical costs will depend to a great extent on how it is put in effect, President Obama is assembling a high-level team to carry out key elements of the overhaul and is considering moving faster than the law requires to put them into action.

headline: Philippines Drops Charges Against Two Brothers in Mass Killings
text: MANILA — The Philippine government on Saturday dropped charges against two prominent members of a powerful political family accused of the mass killing of 57 people in November, the single worst incident of political violence on record here.

headline: This Rally Must Clear Some Tall Hurdles
text: WITH a profit recovery in full swing — and the first-quarter earnings reporting season under way — the bar on Wall Street is set high. Analysts forecast that profits for companies in the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index soared by an average of 39 percent in the first quarter, versus the period a year earlier.

headline: Whose Side Are They On?
text: Last month Democrats on the Senate banking committee passed a reasonably tough financial regulatory reform bill. Now Republican leaders have suddenly begun lashing out against it.

headline: Whats-Its
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — When I first caught on to today’s theme, I admit it seemed strange. Why is adding IT to the end of answers fun? I quickly warmed up to it, though, and I ended up loving the oddball humor of IT.

headline: A Safe, Loving Home
text: The story of Artyom Savelyev, the boy who was sent back to Russia by his American adoptive mother, is heart-wrenching. It is also threatening the dreams of thousands of other children and prospective families.

headline: When Marketing Becomes Almighty
text: SUPPOSE aliens landed on Earth today. What would be their main impression of our culture? Terry O’Reilly and Mike Tennant argue that they’d be struck by the omnipresent influence of advertising and marketing.

headline: Arizona Goes Over the Edge
text: The Arizona Legislature has just stepped off the deep end of the immigration debate, passing a harsh and mean-spirited bill that would do little to stop illegal immigration. What it would do is lead to more racial profiling, hobble local law enforcement, and open government agencies to frivolous, politically driven lawsuits.

headline: Debunking the Myths of the Telecommute
text: I’M executive director of community operations at Edmunds.com, which provides information to car buyers, sellers and drivers. I lead the team that develops systems and policies for anyone submitting comments, reviews and questions to the site. My team also works with engineering to decide how parts of the site should appear to users — the forums, the car and dealership reviews, blogs and the question-and-answer area.

headline: Columbine, 11 Years Later
text: Two rallies by gun rights celebrants and anti- government polemicists are planned Monday on both sides of Washington’s Potomac River. They will invoke the Second Amendment and the Battles of Lexington and Concord. A more apt, and tragic, anniversary to keep in mind is the Columbine school massacre of 1999. Eleven years later, and Congress has failed to close the gun show loophole that made the carnage possible.

headline: Crème de la Cell: Six-Figure Phones
text: IN 2006, Frank Nuovo was 45 — “boom!” he says, “five more years to 50!” — and at the top of his game. Except for one thing: “I’d kind of lost my soul.”

headline: Letters
text: The Trade Seesaw

headline: Library Buys 14th-Century Book by Catholic Rebels
text: Denounced by the Vatican as heretical some seven centuries ago, the writings of an influential Franciscan dissident have found their way to the fourth floor of the Newberry Library.

headline: Despite Progress, Police Chief Still Struggles
text: The next few months of warmer weather will be crucial for Jody Weis, whose job running the police department is as close as it gets to “Mission Impossible” in Chicago.

headline: Using an Islamic View to Forge Connections
text: When Rami Nashashibi and a top aide ambled toward the entrance of Taft High School in a bright morning sun last week, I assumed the outside loudspeakers would break into the theme from “Ghostbusters.”

headline: Welcome to Confederate History Month
text: It's kind of like that legendary stunt on the prime-time soap "Dallas," where we learned that nothing bad had really happened because the previous season's episodes were all a dream. We now know that the wave of anger that crashed on the Capitol as the health care bill passed last month  the death threats and epithets hurled at members of Congress  was also a mirage.

headline: The Pulse: A Post With Little to Do, but Plenty of Money to Do It
text: The vice mayor of Chicago has few responsibilities, but a budget exceeding $100,000 a year.

headline: The Pulse: Celtics Coach Sends His Regards to DePaul
text: Doc Rivers, the Boston Celtics coach, is still a Chicagoan at heart. Though he broke DePaul fans' hearts when he chose Marquette over the Blue Demons after graduating from Proviso East High School in 1980, he still follows all the Chicago-area teams, including DePaul, and applauds the hiring of Oliver Purnell as its basketball coach.

headline: A Church Mary Can Love
text: I heard a joke the other day about a pious soul who dies, goes to heaven, and gains an audience with the Virgin Mary. The visitor asks Mary why, for all her blessings, she always appears in paintings as a bit sad, a bit wistful: Is everything O.K.?

headline: Valentine at the Bat
text: With Jerry Manuel feeling the heat, Bobby Valentine has been mentioned as a possible successor. But some people remember that his first tenure with the Mets did not always go smoothly. Apologies to Ernest Thayer.

headline: Carmel Lawmaker in Front Line on Health
text: It is difficult to say which life experience will come in handier for Assemblyman Bill Monning, the new chairman of the State Assembly’s Health Committee.

headline: Sweat | ‘We Actually Get to Hit the Teacher’
text: Monday’s lesson for sixth graders at Archimedes Academy, a public school in the Southeast Bronx, was how to throw a left hook.

headline: When Foreclosure Threatens Elder-Care Homes
text: In September 2009, Sgt. Rick Turini of the Santa Clara County Sheriff’s Office drove to a house in San Jose to carry out a court-ordered eviction.

headline: Outer Beauty and Inner Peace
text: Clifford Saron is a research neuroscientist at the Center for Mind and Brain at the University of California, Davis, and director of the Shamatha Project, a study on the impact of sustained meditation on behavior and brain function. Mr. Saron, 56, has spent time at the Spirit Rock Meditation Center in West Marin as a retreat participant, a researcher and a speaker. Hundreds of people attend classes and retreats there each week, with teachers that have included the Dalai Lama. Mr. Saron lives in Marin County with his family. (His words have been edited and condensed.)  KATHERINE ELLISON

headline: Rasim Delic, Bosnian Army Commander, Dies at 61
text: Gen. Rasim Delic, who commanded Bosnia’s Army during much of the catastrophic ethnic war in the former Yugoslavia in the 1990s, died on Friday at his home in Sarajevo. He was 61.

headline: Elder-Care Home Foreclosures, Without Warning
text: Headlines everywhere have described the foreclosure tsunami that continues to overwhelm the housing market. Less noticed has been the impact on single-family homes that are used as lucrative care facilities for the elderly.

headline: Just Doing It
text: St. Louis

headline: Unemployment Is Tied to Big Drop in Demand
text: The nation’s high unemployment rate is a result of a severe drop in demand for goods and services and is not a reflection of longer-term structural changes in the economy, a top adviser to President Obama said Saturday.

headline: Gates Says U.S. Lacks a Policy to Thwart Iran
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has warned in a secret three-page memorandum to top White House officials that the United States does not have an effective long-range policy for dealing with Iran’s steady progress toward nuclear capability, according to government officials familiar with the document.

headline: Unease at Wrigley While Soriano Struggles
text: CHICAGO — The whereabouts of Alfonso Soriano had been the most perplexing mystery confronting the Chicago Cubs two weeks into the season.

headline: Capitals and Bruins Fall Behind, Then Win
text: WASHINGTON — Alex Ovechkin awoke from his one-game slumber ornery and powerful, and another Washington star, Nicklas Backstrom, completed a hat trick just 31 seconds into overtime, giving the Capitals a 6-5 victory over the Montreal Canadiens on Saturday and squaring their first-round Eastern Conference series at one game each.

headline: David Simons, Who Flew High on Eve of Space Age, Dies at 87
text: David G. Simons, whose ascent more than 19 miles above the Earth in an aluminum capsule suspended from a helium balloon set an altitude record in 1957 and helped put the United States on the road to manned space flight, died April 5 at his home in Covington, Ga. He was 87.

headline: Anonymous Sources Postscript
text: Unfortunately, there were more examples of anonymous sources that drew reader complaints than I could include in this week’s public editor column.

headline: James Aubrey, Who Portrayed the Hero in ‘Lord of the Flies’, Is Dead at 62
text: James Aubrey, a British actor who had his first role when he was an untrained schoolboy, portraying Ralph, the right-minded boy who strove to ward off the savagery of his fellow castaways in the 1963 film “Lord of the Flies,” died on April 6 at his home in Cranwell, Lincolnshire, in central England. He was 62.

headline: With O’Neal Back, Cavaliers Strike First
text: CLEVELAND — There were many witnesses here. But Joakim Noah was the one who had the most interesting experience at Quicken Loans Arena on Saturday.

headline: Squandered Trust
text: THE Times continues to hurt itself with readers by misusing anonymous sources.

text: To the Editor:
