headline: Corrections
text: An article last Sunday about Mary Kay Gallagher, 90, a real estate broker who specializes in the Victorian Flatbush section of Brooklyn, misidentified the formerly WASP-only club that she joined half a century ago. It is the Knickerbocker Field Club, a tennis club in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn  not the Knickerbocker Club, an all-male social club in Manhattan.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary in some editions last Sunday about Robert D. Franks, a former Republican congressman from New Jersey, misstated the length of his tenure in the House of Representatives. He was elected four times, but did not serve four terms. (He left the House before the end of his fourth term to run for the United States Senate in 2000.) The obituary also misstated the amount Jon S. Corzine, Mr. Franks’s Democratic opponent in the Senate election, spent on his campaign. It was $63 million, not $62 million. (A corrected version of the obituary appeared in some editions on Monday.)

headline: Michel Chartrand, Fiery Labor Union Leader in Quebec, Is Dead at 93
text: Michel Chartrand, a firebrand Canadian labor leader whose support of leftist politics and Quebec nationalism, including its most violent permutations, provoked the Trudeau government to summarily jail him in October 1970, died on April 12 in Montreal. He was 93.

headline: Private Schools Welcome the Girl Scouts
text: Girl Scouts membership has risen sharply, and unexpectedly, in private schools in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

headline: Fast Pace of Playoffs Is a Test for Kidd
text: After an 82-game season of teams grinding it out for position, the N.B.A. playoffs can seem like an entirely different game. A team can get away with an undersize player in the middle during the regular season, the way the 2006-7 Warriors did with Al Harrington, but that weakness is often highlighted in the playoffs, as when Harrington had to face the much larger Carlos Boozer in the second round.

headline: The Other Catholic Church
text: My Sunday column is about the other Catholic Church, the one I have learned to admire for its work among the poorest people around the globe. It has tended to be the bishops and cardinals who have gotten the church in trouble, while it’s the amazing priests, nuns and lay-workers who do extraordinary work at home and around the world. And as I note in the column, I’ve learned from meeting nuns in Africa, Asia and Latin America that the coolest and toughest people in the world are nuns. Their orphanages, hospitals and schools keep the world going.

headline: Corrections
text: The 36 Hours column on April 4, about San Antonio, misstated the number, and status, of golf facilities at the new JW Marriott San Antonio Hill Country Resort & Spa. There are two courses at the resort, not one, and they have been open since January; they are not opening soon.

headline: Mets Re-Fight Hundred Years’ War
text: As the Mets and the Cardinals head to the 20th inning, what is your favorite stat so far?

headline: Ubaldo Jimenez’s Moment
text: The fastest average fastball in the majors last season (minimum 162 innings) belonged to Ubaldo Jimenez of the Colorado Rockies. According to Bill James, it was 96.1 miles per hour. Jimenez also led the National League in pitches per start, with 108.2 (minimum 30 starts).

headline: A Showdown in Bulgaria for the World Championship
text: A World Chess Championship match that begins on Friday in Sofia, Bulgaria, between Viswanathan Anand of India, the titleholder, and Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria, a former champion, should be a treat for fans.

headline: Long Story Short: Mets Beat Cardinals in 20th
text: ST. LOUIS — In search of a solitary run, the Mets and the Cardinals played nearly seven hours of baseball Saturday, beginning on a warm, sunny afternoon and continuing into a chilly evening until finally the matter was resolved.

headline: Cavaliers’ Depth Costs Hickson Minutes
text: CLEVELAND — Throughout the regular season, Cavaliers Coach Mike Brown considered J.J. Hickson one of the team’s more pleasant surprises.

headline: Correction
text: An article on April 4 about same-sex pairings in animals misspelled the surname of a director at the American Civil Liberties Union who works on gay issues and who commented about animal behavior as it appliesto the rights of humans. He is James Esseks, not Essex. The article also referred imprecisely to the referencing of a book about the subject in a 2003 Supreme Court case that overturned a Texas sodomy law. While the book, “Biological Exuberance,” by Bruce Bagemihl, was cited in a brief filed for the case, it was not cited in the decision itself. Also, the educational affiliation of a biologist mentioned in the article, David Featherstone, who discovered a protein mutation in the brain of male fruit flies that made them try to have sex with other males, was incomplete. It is the University of Illinois at Chicago, not simply the University of Illinois.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 17, 2010

headline: Elite Recruit Picks Kansas, Then First Half Resumes
text: Kansas Coach Bill Self walked into the gym at Lake Clifton High in Baltimore last Friday and introduced himself to a man standing underneath one basket. Self joked that if the man’s name were Josh Selby, he could probably score 40 points at any time.

headline: Was Marathon Win a Highlight or a Lowlight for the Mets?
text: So here is the question that Mets fans can debate among themselves as their team proceeds through the final 151 games of the 2010 season: Was Saturday’s 20-inning victory over the Cardinals exhilarating or a little bit embarrassing? Yes, the Mets won the game, but they scored all of two runs — two runs! — in the final three innings with first an infielder and then an outfielder pitching for St. Louis.

headline: For Goldman, a Bet’s Stakes Keep Growing
text: For Goldman Sachs, it was a relatively small transaction. But for the bank, and the rest of Wall Street, the stakes couldn’t be higher. Accusations that Goldman defrauded customers who bought investments tied to risky subprime mortgages have only begun to reverberate through the financial world, The New York Times’s Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson report.

headline: Feeling Cradled by Nature, and Other Highlights From Sunday’s Bay Area Report
text: A Neuroscientist Studies Meditation and Finds a Place to Meditate | Clifford Saron, 56, who does research at the Center for Mind and Brain at the University of California, Davis, directs a study on the impact of sustained meditation on behavior and brain function. In a valley in West Marin, he puts his theories into practice. Katherine Ellison reports.

headline: Photographs From Coachella, Day 2
text: Photographs from the second day of the Coachella Music and Arts Festival in Indio, Calif.

headline: Deal for Coyotes Raises Eyebrows
text: Even as the Phoenix Coyotes’ amazing season continues before sellout crowds dressed in playoff white, the intrigue surrounding the N.H.L.-owned club persists.

headline: Top Recruit Picks Kansas
text: Josh Selby, the highly recruited 6-foot-3 scorer from Lake Clifton High in Baltimore, announced at Madison Square Garden that he would attend Kansas. “I think that’s the best place for me to mature and get to the next level,” said Selby, who also considered Tennessee, Connecticut, Kentucky and Arizona.

headline: Airlines Press Europe to Ease Ban on Flights
text: As Europe grounded most airline flights for a fourth day on Sunday because of a volcanic ash cloud spreading from Iceland, increasingly desperate airlines ran test flights to show that flying was safe and pressed aviation authorities to loosen the flight ban.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on April 4 with the cover article about Mauritius, an island in the Indian Ocean, misstated the location of a small island off Mauritius. As the article and an accompanying map correctly noted, the island, Île aux Cerfs, is off the east coast of Mauritius  not off Grand Baie, which is on the northwest tip of the island.

headline: What to Pair With Monet? Try Classical Music.
text: How do you enhance the splendid Impressionist collection at the quaint and elegant Musée Marmottan Monet in Paris? How about adding the strains of equally classy tunes? On certain Tuesday nights during special exhibitions, the museum hosts classical music concerts; the next events are scheduled for April 20 and 27.

headline: N.F.L. Draft: A Closer Look at Georgia Tech’s Jonathan Dwyer
text: Matt Waldman is a staff writer at Footballguys.com, where he writes The Weekly Gut Check and authors The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a 740-page film evaluation of 170-plus rookie prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

headline: Button Beats the Elements and Takes Victory in Chinese Grand Prix
text: SHANGHAI — As the world faced chaos in the skies due to a geological phenomenon, Grand Prix racing took a brief break from its own travel concerns to run a wild and challenging race, the results of which were also altered by the natural elements.

headline: Poland Mourns, but Some Look Ahead to Elections
text: KRAKOW, Poland — About 150,000 mourners bade farewell to President Lech Kaczynski and his wife, Maria, on Sunday in an emotional funeral service here marked by solemnity and a determination never to forget.

headline: The Sunday Word: Nuclear Warnings
text: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has warned that the United States does not have an effective long-range policy for dealing with Iran’s steady progress toward nuclear capability, The Times’s David Sanger and Thom Shanker reported.

headline: Pope Meets Victims Abused by Priests in Malta
text: VALLETTA, Malta — In his first such encounter since a sexual abuse scandal began to envelop the Catholic Church in recent months, Pope Benedict XVI met privately on Sunday with a small group of victims of sexual abuse by priests, expressing his “shame and sorrow” at their plight, the Vatican said.

headline: The Mystery of the Missing Man of Steel
text: Look! Up on the wall! It’s a painting! Of that strange visitor from another planet who came to Earth — well, you know how that goes.

headline: The Ears Have It
text: With the playoffs underway, few N.B.A. players would dream of covering their eyes. Their ears? That’s another story — especially where music is concerned. Most players usually augment the thump-thump-thump of the basketball on the court’s hardwood floor with the banging, reverberating bass from headphones tethered to their iPods. But flash headphones are an absolute must.

headline: Vows: Jen & Alex
text: Jen Rogers and Alex Taylor met when they were working together at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Connecticut in summer 2007. Alex won her over at the end of the summer.

headline: Flyers’ Boucher Ends Dry Spell
text: When Philadelphia Flyers goaltender Brian Boucher beat the Devils in Game 1 of their first-round series Wednesday, it was his first playoff victory since May 20, 2000. His gap between postseason victories of 9 years 329 days is the third longest in N.H.L. history.

headline: Trendspotting | Fresh Paint
text: Student photographers rove their campuses for The Times. This issue: graffiti traditions. Text by Amanda M. Fairbanks

headline: Government of Thailand Is Promised Support
text: BANGKOK — The pro-government “yellow shirt” movement added to Thailand’s tensions on Sunday with a threat to challenge the red-shirt protesters with a counterdemonstration if the government did not move quickly to crush them.

headline: Q. & A. With Sam Sifton (Round Four)
text: Shawn in Los Angeles wrote in on Saturday to make a parliamentary point about this exercise, in which I’ve been answering readers’ questions about the health and nutrition issues raised by my job as the restaurant critic for The Times.

headline: City Critic: Park Bathrooms
text: Warm weather puts more strain on a park's facilities - including its bathroom facilities. The City Critic set out to investigate.

headline: Tinkerman Takes Roma Back to the Top in Italy
text: A goal down and his team showing little signs of a pulse, Roma Coach Claudio Ranieri, derided in some circles as the Tinkerman, did what he appears to do best — he tinkered with his lineup.

headline: Progressive Rock Day
text: INDIO, Calif. — Saturday was progressive-rock day at Coachella, headlined by Muse, the three-man English band with flying fingers and sci-fi fantasies, and by the reunited Faith No More, the San Francisco band that jump-cuts from screaming hardcore to arena pomp. Leading up to them were other bands that can count well above 4/4: the early Genesis-loving Porcupine Tree, the Rush-meets-emo band Coheed and Cambria and, best of all by far, Dirty Projectors.

headline: New Video From Under the Volcano
text: Video shot on Sunday in Iceland for Britain’s Channel 4 News showed close views of the Eyjafjallajokull volcano, which continued to spew ash into the atmosphere, as my colleague Nicola Clark reports.

headline: Matthews Arena Turns 100
text: Last Friday was the 100th birthday of Matthews Arena, the world’s oldest indoor hockey rink. The marvelous old building, home of Northeastern University hockey, is the cradle of the game in Boston.

headline: Discussing Dating Woes Over Coffee
text: Little girls sketch their wedding dresses in crayon, and couples in their 90s still tell the story of how they met, which suggests that there is an appetite for romance even among those most removed from its sway.

headline: Squint, and the World Is Beautiful
text: Their plumage is wilting, their wigs are askew, and their bustiers keep slipping south to reveal unmistakably masculine chests. Yet the ladies of the chorus from “La Cage aux Folles” have never looked more appealing than they do in the warm, winning production that opened Sunday night at the Longacre Theater.

headline: Yankees Complete a Series Sweep
text: In the vast home clubhouse at Yankee Stadium, Derek Jeter commands a locker in the back next to the doorway that leads to an inner sanctum that is off limits to most visitors.

headline: Poland Bids Farewell to President
text: Some 150,000 Poles bade farewell to their president and first lady in an emotional funeral service that capped more than a week of public mourning, with the shadow of a special presidential election looming in the background.

headline: Battle Between the Decades
text: INDIO, Calif. — There was a secondary theme for Saturday: a scuffle between the 1970’s and the 1960’s, between the precise, impressive strategies of the 1970’s and the looser, shaggier methods of the 1960’s.Mid-afternoon there was a 1960’s idyll, with the slowly swaying songs of Beach House and the wistful, guitar-strumming pop of Girls — who even reached back further, to 1958, for the Everly Brothers‘ “All I Have To Do Is Dream.”

headline: Rap-Rave From South Africa
text: INDIO, Calif. — There’s a nonstop dance beat at Coachella — on the four stages with live bands, and in the Sahara tent at the festival’s far end, where D.J.’s spin discs and poke laptops, day and night.

headline: It Slices, It Dices
text: Mathematical signs and symbols are often cryptic, but the best of them offer visual clues to their own meaning. The symbols for zero, one and infinity aptly resemble an empty hole, a single mark and an endless loop: 0, 1, ∞.  And the equals sign, =, is formed by two parallel lines because, in the words of its originator, Welsh mathematician Robert Recorde in 1557, “no two things can be more equal.”

headline: Drug Violence Along Mexican Border
text: Mexicans are coming to United States border towns as they flee gang violence in Mexico and their presence has changed the small towns along the border.

headline: Junior Teams, High-Stepping Into the Big Leagues
text: For young dancers, a junior troupe is many things: a place to be noticed and to hone stagecraft and, barring irritating complications  like other, even better dancers  a steppingstone to a company contract. The 1.2.3. Festival at the Joyce Theater features three such groups in alternating performances: Ailey II, ABT II and Taylor 2.

headline: 60 Across: Indy 500, e.g.
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — We have two distinguished guest solvers with us today, the husband and wife team of Stefan and May Kanfer. He’s the author of the recent Marlon Brando biography Somebody and was a writer and editor at Time magazine for 20 years, including five as its first bylined film critic. She’s a consultant at the Early Childhood Center of Sarah Lawrence College, where she taught for some 20 years.

headline: What We Learned in Oklahoma City
text: FIFTEEN years ago today, the bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Building in Oklahoma City claimed the lives of 168 men, women and children. It was, until 9/11, the worst terrorist attack in United States history. But what emerged in its aftermath  the compassion, caring and love that countless Americans from all walks of life extended to the victims and their families  was a powerful testament to the best of America. And its lessons are as important now as they were then.

headline: Monks Assist in Rescue Effort
text: Monks set ablaze piles of the blanket-wrapped bodies of China’s earthquake victims on a mountaintop.

headline: A Broadway Baritone Unplugged, Up, Down and Piano-Ready
text: Brian Stokes Mitchell was merrier than Santa Claus on Saturday evening at Town Hall, where he performed a program, mostly of theater songs, accompanied by a pop-jazz quartet. The joie de vivre that is a trademark of Mr. Mitchell’s stage demeanor can be a powerful mood elevator for an audience. But when his cheerleading enthusiasm is pushed too far it can start to cloy, as it did on Saturday, and you wish he would lean more to the dark side.

headline: A Look at the Barely Victorious, and at Defensive Falsecarding
text: The column on April 10, about the 86.25 percent game at the Regency Whist Club, generated some correspondence.

headline: Chávez Says China to Lend Venezuela $20 Billion
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Hugo Chávez said over the weekend that China had agreed to extend $20 billion in loans to Venezuela, pointing to deepening ties between the two countries as China seeks to secure oil supplies here.

headline: Minsky Conference
text: I’ve been meaning to write up what I said at the Hyman Minsky conference on regulatory reformat the Ford Foundation, but have had too many balls in the air. I’ll try to get to it soon; meanwhile, Ryan Avent has a few notes from the meeting.

headline: Ex-Pat Paris as It Sizzled for One Literary Lioness
text: If the world’s dwindling independent bookstores have a patron saint, an exemplar to cling to in moments of duress, she is Sylvia Beach (1887-1962), the soulful and fearless owner of Shakespeare & Company, the English-language bookstore she founded in Paris in 1919 and operated on the Left Bank until the German occupation during World War II.

headline: Mr. Cinderella: From Rejection Notes to the Pulitzer
text: IOWA CITY  Six years ago Paul Harding was just another graduate of the Iowa Writers’ Workshop with a quiet little novel he hoped to publish. He sent copies of the manuscript, in which he had intertwined the deathbed memories of a New England clock repairer with episodes about the dying man’s father, to a handful of agents and editors in New York. Soon after, the rejection letters started to roll in.

headline: Art Made at the Speed of the Internet: Don’t Say ‘Geek’; Say ‘Collaborator’
text: When Robert Rauschenberg and a buttoned-down Bell Labs engineer named Billy Kluver began thinking, in the mid-1960s, about ways that people from the world of technology could help artists make art, Mr. Kluver surveyed the mighty gulf between the two groups and almost thought better of the idea. “I was scared,” he said once in an interview. “The amazing thing was that it’s possible for artists and scientists to talk together at all.”

headline: A Terrorist, Plain-Spoken and Cold
text: It’s hard to read faces, but voices are even harder to gauge. Timothy J. McVeigh, the anti-government extremist who killed 168 people in the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing, had a calm, almost reassuringly matter-of-fact way of speaking. He could have been a building inspector, a driving instructor or a Persian Gulf war veteran, which, of course, he was, having earned a Bronze Star before he went completely off his head.

headline: Hoofers Pay Tribute to the Tapper Jimmy Slyde
text: “To the man who gave me a name with wings,” reads a line on a screen at the start of Roxane Butterfly’s film “Hoofalogies,” a homage to the great tap dancer Jimmy Slyde, who died in 2008 at the age of 80. Slyde was one of the most renowned tappers of his era, and Ms. Butterfly paid tribute to his heritage in a low-key show at Symphony Space on Friday night that included her fellow hoofers Rocky Mendes and Tamango.

headline: A Cellist and Her Friends Explore Multicultural Harmonies
text: Spain’s Golden Age, an era of peaceable coexistence and cooperation among Jews, Muslims and Christians during the 9th through 15th centuries, has inspired projects by numerous prominent artists. Some, like the great Catalan viol player Jordi Savall (who will perform at Lincoln Center in May), have tried to recreate sounds of the period. “Provenance,” a program the cellist Maya Beiser presented at Le Poisson Rouge on Wednesday night, proposes a modern-day analogue with evocative modern works inspired by historical sources.

headline: 3 Premieres Highlight New-Music Concert
text: The New York Philharmonic’s sold-out concert in its new-music series “Contact!” at Symphony Space on Friday evening had an air of excitement and a refreshing informality.

headline: Yanks Head West, and So Do Rings
text: Since last Tuesday’s championship ring ceremony at Yankee Stadium, the Yankees have started dispersing rings to the rest of the 2009 team. Everyone who appeared on the active roster during the season will get one — even those who barely played, like Anthony Claggett, or never got into a game, like Steven Jackson.

headline: New CDs
text: MERLE HAGGARD

headline: ‘Dragon’ Edges Out Fake Superheroes
text: The much-hyped fake-superhero movie “Kick-Ass” brought in about $19.8 million at North American theaters over the weekend, a so-so performance that, by early estimates, was good enough only for second place. The film was probably hurt by its R rating and controversy about a violent and profane performance from its 13-year-old star. The No. 1 movie at the weekend box-office derby appeared to be the DreamWorks Animation holdover “How to Train Your Dragon,” above, which brought in about $20 million for a new total of $158.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles sales statistics. The comedy “Date Night” (20th Century Fox) was third with about $17.3 million ($49.2 million total). “Death at a Funeral,” a new comedy from Sony’s Screen Gems unit, was fourth with about $17 million. And “Clash of the Titans” (Warner Brothers) chugged away in fifth place with about $15.8 million ($133 million total).

headline: Coachella Festival, Under the Volcano
text: Entertainers, like thousands of other travelers, have been stranded since the cloud of ash from the Icelandic volcano prevented flights from taking off across much of Europe. Organizers of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Indio, Calif., tweeted that some acts were forced to pull out of the festival, held over the weekend, The Associated Press reported. British acts including the Cribs, Bad Lieutenant, Delphi, Talvin Singh, Gary Numan and Frightened Rabbit and the Chicago brass group Hypnotic Brass Ensemble, which was on tour in Europe, were unable to appear. Bad Lieutenant announced this weekend that it was also canceling concert dates through Wednesday in San Francisco, Chicago and New York because of flight disruptions. Whitney Houston, in the middle of her Nothing but Love world tour, had to take a boat across the Irish Sea to perform in Dublin because of airport closings.

headline: Domingo Returns to Ovation at La Scala
text: In his first performance since surgery for cancer more than a month ago, Plácido Domingo, above, earned a 14-minute ovation and cheers on Friday at La Scala in Milan, singing the title role in Verdi’s “Simon Boccanegra.” Mr. Domingo, 69, blew a kiss to the crowd during the performance and called his return to the stage “a great evening,” The Associated Press reported. “It was very emotional,” he said during a backstage interview. “I was happy to be in front an audience.” The applause for Mr. Domingo, who was treated for colon cancer, was mixed with boos for the conductor, Daniel Barenboim, according to The A.P. But Mr. Domingo warmly embraced Mr. Barenboim as the curtain call continued even after most of the audience had departed. Mr. Domingo said in an earlier interview that his “biggest triumph ever is the one over illness.” He also said that despite singing the baritone role of Simon Boccanegra, which he performed at the Met this year, he remains a tenor. He is scheduled for six performances at La Scala before taking the role to the Royal Opera in London in June and the Teatro Real in Madrid in July.

headline: A GLAAD Award for Fox’s ‘Glee’
text: The Fox TV musical-comedy “Glee,” the actress Drew Barrymore, above left, and the comedian Wanda Sykes, above right, were among the winners at the 21st annual Media Awards ceremony of the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, held Saturday in Los Angeles. Ryan Murphy, the creator of “Glee,” said, “We have a great responsibility with the show,” adding that the character played by Chris Colfer, top, a gay glee-club member, would have a boyfriend next season. Ms. Barrymore received the Vanguard Award, which honors efforts to increase gay visibility and understanding. In a video shown before Ms. Barrymore accepted her trophy, she listed her dog, her stylist and her agent as among her inspirational gay colleagues. Ms. Sykes received the Stephen F. Kolzak Award, which goes to an openly gay entertainer who works to eliminate homophobia. Tom Ford, the director of the film “A Single Man,” was stuck in London and unable to accept a trophy for outstanding film.

headline: Ontological Departs St. Mark’s Church
text: The Ontological-Hysteric Theater is leaving its performance space at St. Mark’s Church in the Bowery in June, the playwright and director Richard Foreman said in a news release. The Ontological, which has had a permanent home at St. Mark’s, in the East Village, since 1992, will wrap up operations there on June 30, the end of its 2009-10 season, according to the release. “My aesthetic remains the same,” Mr. Foreman said in the statement, “but after many years of making theater there’s been a thematic deepening of everything I’ve been working towards that can now only be made possible through film.” The Ontological-Hysteric Theater will continue to function, with the possibility of an occasional theatrical production, but will focus on film and video work.

headline: Rolling Stones Song Gets a Hearing
text: An unheard Rolling Stones song, “Plundered My Soul,” recorded for a 1972 album but never released, was issued as a limited-edition single in honor of Record Store Day in Britain on Saturday, an annual event celebrating independent record stores. The song, recorded during sessions for the band’s “Exile on Main Street,” was “left to languish in the vaults,” BBC News reported, but was rediscovered when the group was preparing for a May 18 reissue of the album. “Plundered My Soul” will be one of 10 bonus tracks on the deluxe edition of the reissue, Reuters reported, which will include the never-before-heard songs “Dancing in the Light,” “Following the River” and “Pass the Wine.”

headline: Scandal Forces India Politician to Step Down
text: NEW DELHI — A former high-level United Nations diplomat who had become a prominent and flamboyant figure in the Indian government resigned Sunday amid accusations that he had wrongly used his official influence to help a female friend get an ownership stake in a new franchise in India’s lucrative professional cricket league.

headline: ‘Little Ships’ Rerun Finds Its Own Dunkirk
text: DOVER, England — Few moments in modern British history are more iconic than the evacuation of the British expeditionary force of nearly 340,000 troops in the spring of 1940 from the beaches of Dunkirk, 22 miles across the Channel from the white chalk cliffs that overlook this ancient port town. At the time, Winston Churchill called it “a miracle of deliverance.”

headline: Radio Stations With No Music May Be Shut in Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Radio stations in the capital of this near-anarchical country, still scrambling to comply with an Islamist ultimatum to stop playing music, were jerked in the other direction on Sunday when the government said that all broadcasters who had heeded that ultimatum faced closing.

headline: Monks Bolster China’s Quake Relief Effort
text: JIEGU, China — Long after the bulldozers have gone silent and the rescue workers have retired to their tents, the only sound in this earthquake-battered city is the plaintive barking of dogs that have lost their homes, and in many cases, their owners.

headline: A Welcome Fall in Maternal Deaths
text: To the Editor:

headline: Companies Slowly Join Cloud-Computing
text: SAN FRANCISCO — This year, Netflix made what looked like a peculiar choice: the DVD-by-mail company decided that over the next two years, it would move most of its Web technology — customer movie queues, search tools and the like — over to the computer servers of one of its chief rivals, Amazon.com.

headline: Facebook Seeps Onto Other Web Sites
text: SAN FRANCISCO — With about half of Facebook’s 400 million users checking in daily, the social networking company has established itself as one of the Web’s most popular destinations.

headline: The Speed of Broadband
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ike Davis Era Is Approaching
text: ST. LOUIS — The Ike Davis era is approaching, and it could begin as soon as Monday, or at least in the next few days.

headline: It’s Not All About Us
text: To the Editor:

headline: Indian Who Built Yoga Empire Works on Politics
text: HARIDWAR, India — The sun slumbered well beneath the horizon, but Swami Ramdev had been up for hours. Swathed in a saffron loincloth, he led his charges, a few hundred devotees in this holy city on the Ganges River and tens of millions more watching on television, through a rapid-fire series of yoga poses.

headline: Law School Clinics vs. Corporate Interests
text: To the Editor:

headline: MTV Not Involved With ‘Jersey Shore’ Imitations
text: Success always breeds imitation. On television, there are three varieties of “CSI,” three of “Law & Order,” and at least four of “Real Housewives.” But in the case of MTV’s “Jersey Shore,” the original network is not the one doing the imitating.

headline: Modern-Day Apprentices
text: A day in the life: two externs in New York.

headline: Microcredit Loans and Responsible Lending
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fact-Checking the News
text: To the Editor:

headline: For TBS and O’Brien, a Match Made in Heaven
text: How did a channel like TBS — a cable channel without the prestige or marketing power of a broadcast outlet — manage to land Conan O’Brien’s show?

headline: James Masterson,  Narcissism Expert, Dies at 84
text: Dr. James F. Masterson, an internationally recognized psychiatrist who helped inaugurate a new approach to the study and treatment of personality disorders including narcissism, died April 12. He was 84 and lived in Rye, N.Y.

headline: Sky Above, Disaster Below
text: Oklahoma City

headline: The Fluorescent Fairway
text: Annika Sorenstam shows Bill Pennington how to train for the golf season without leaving the office.

headline: The Extremists Next Door
text: Ann Arbor, Mich.

headline: How We Picked Ourselves Up
text: Tulsa, Okla.

headline: When a Bag Speaks in Spring
text: It was a long winter. So on the first warm day this month, I charged into the garage and headed for my golf bag.

headline: For Chinese, Web Is the Way to Entertainment
text: SHANGHAI — The daily Web habits of a typical 18-year-old college student named Li Yufei show why American Internet companies, one after another, have had trouble penetrating what is now the world’s most wired nation.

headline: Six Doctrines in Search of a Policy Regime
text: Last week I gave a talk at the Levy Institute’s 19th annual Hyman P. Minsky Conference, held at the Ford Foundation. The occasion forced me to clarify my thoughts about financial reform; so here’s a version of what I said.

headline: Before Kyrgyz Uprising, Dose of Russian Soft Power
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan — Shortly before the uprising in Kyrgyzstan two weeks ago, online news sites posted a series of hard-hitting exposés accusing the family of President Kurmanbek Bakiyev of skimming money from the public coffers, an allegation that touched a nerve in this poor country and galvanized opposition to his government.

headline: For Eddie Feibusch, a Life in Zippers
text: What, you need a zipper? O.K., Eddie Feibusch is going to sell you a zipper. Brass? Nylon? Swarovski rhinestone crystals? What color? Mystery orchid? Big or little zipper? For a purse? Or a hot-air balloon cover? How many? One? A thousand?

headline: Saving the Neglected History of FM Radio’s Unsung Pioneer
text: The questions seemed simple enough: When and how did Edwin H. Armstrong, the father of FM radio, make the discovery that led to that invention?

headline: Two Stabbed in Long Island University Campus Fight
text: Two people were stabbed and four others also injured in a fight early Sunday morning at a party on the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University, the police said.

headline: Reporter and Players Wearing Same Colors
text: Sharp-eyed readers might have noticed something truly unusual in Gannett’s New Jersey newspapers. A new byline started appearing this month on articles about the New Jersey Devils hockey team, with a note under each piece stating that the author, Eric Marin, is employed by the Devils, not Gannett.

headline: Gates Pushes Back on Report of Memo About Iran Policy
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates acknowledged Sunday that he had written a classified memorandum to the White House in January raising significant questions about long-term Iran policy, but said his goal had been only “to contribute to an orderly and timely decision-making process.”

headline: New Yorkers Brace for Doorman Strike
text: It has been nearly two decades since New Yorkers faced their last doorman strike, but as the deadline for a new contract for building workers approached, the questions being posed throughout the city remained largely unchanged on Sunday.

headline: A First-Class Cabin’s Debut Diverted by Ash
text: Updated | 3:37 p.m. Until this morning, British Airways officials insisted that, ash or shine, the company would press on with its artsy debut of a new first-class cabin on Monday evening in London, even if volcanic dust prevents most of the guests from attending. It was too late, they said, to postpone.

headline: Garnett Suspended, Richardson Fined for Game 1 Altercation
text: The N.B.A. suspended Kevin Garnett for Game 2 of the Boston Celtics’ first-round playoff series against the Miami Heat and fined Miami guard Quentin Richardson $25,000 for their altercation on Saturday.

headline: Looters in Loafers
text: Last October, I saw a cartoon by Mike Peters in which a teacher asks a student to create a sentence that uses the verb “sacks,” as in looting and pillaging. The student replies, “Goldman Sachs.”

headline: Alternate Path for Teachers Gains Ground
text: Not long ago education schools had a virtual monopoly on the teaching profession. They dictated how and when people became teachers by offering coursework, arranging apprenticeships and granting master’s degrees.

headline: The F.C.C. and the Internet
text: With the Internet fast becoming the most important communications channel, it is untenable for the United States not to have a regulator to ensure nondiscriminatory access, guarantee interconnectivity among rival networks and protect consumers from potential abuse.

headline: A Case of Discrimination
text: Hastings College of the Law, part of the University of California, rightly prohibits student organizations from discriminating. A Christian group that bars non-Christian and gay students sued the school for denying it funding and access to its facilities. The Supreme Court hears arguments Monday in the case. It should rule in favor of Hastings.

headline: The Icelandic Plume

Even with all of the sophisticated monitoring technology and expertise, no one knows when the eruptions at Eyjafjallajokull  the Icelandic volcano now venting ash into the atmosphere  will subside.

headline: Scrawled in the Margins, Signs of Twain as a Critic

headline: Cassandra, the Ignored Prophet of Doom, Is a Woman for Our Times
text: In “Treme,” HBO’s new series about New Orleans, a college professor played by John Goodman railed against the needless tragedy of Hurricane Katrina. The storm was a natural disaster, he says, but the flooding that followed was a man-made catastrophe, decades in the making. Many people knew about the threat, but no one did anything about it.

headline: Doctors Hear Many Questions About Health Law

headline: Corrections
text: The Atlanta Journal article on Friday, about The Atlanta Journal-Constitution’s relocating outside the city, misstated the newspaper’s decline in weekday circulation during a six-month period in 2009 and overstated the significance of that drop. Circulation was down 20 percent  not 13.6 percent, which was the decline during a similar period in 2007-2008. And the six-month decline in 2009 was the largest circulation drop among major newspapers, not all newspapers. (The Journal-Constitution’s weekday circulation is about 211,000.)

headline: Baffled by the New Law, Patients Turn to Their Doctors

The politicians and pundits may have spoken, but the dialogue is just beginning in examination rooms around the country.

headline: Capitals’ Ovechkin Snaps Out of Late-Season Funk

headline: New Razors Place Focus on Comfort, Not Blade Count

But blade escalation continued: Rival Schick introduced the four-bladed Quattro in 2003, and Gillette struck back with the five-bladed Fusion in 2005.

headline: Dede Allen, Pioneering Film Editor, Dies at 86

headline: Sampler: Silicon Valley’s Gender Trouble, and Nursing Home Neglect

But that’s not what all of them did, an investigation found. Some 232 homes took the money while cutting staff or wages. Cloverdale Healthcare Center in Sonoma County received a $1 million increase in state money, but staffing dropped 8 percent in 2008 compared with 2004. Regulators uncovered problems at the center, including a patient who had been left in a soiled diaper for five hours. [California Watch]

headline: The Eastern Stars: Q.& A. With Mark Kurlansky
text: By 2008, 79 men and boys from San Pedro de Macorís, a small sugar mill town in the Dominican Republic, had gone on to play major league baseball. Of the 471 Dominicans who had played in at least one major league game, 1 in 6 came from San Pedro: Ozzie Virgil, Joaquin Andujar, Alfredo Griffin, George Bell, Sammy Sosa, Robinson Cano. Mark Kurlansky, who has written histories revolving around cod and salt, puts San Pedro under the microscope in his new book, “The Eastern Stars: How Baseball Changed the Dominican Town of San Pedro de Macorís” (Riverhead).

text: This week Dr. Laura Erickson-Schroth, who is working on “Trans Bodies, Trans Selves,” a resource guide for transgender and other gender-variant people, covering health, legal issues, cultural and social questions, history and theory, responded to readers’ questions about transgender life.

headline: The Last ‘Lost’ Roundup (Until the Next One)
text: With just over a month to go until the May 23 finale of “Lost,” TV Guide has published what are being called the last cast photos for the show (until its producers rewrite history, or the inevitable 10th anniversary reunion at Lost-Con 2020), and The Hollywood Reporter offers a look at the pictures.

headline: Commissioner for Homeless Resigns
text: Robert V. Hess, the city’s commissioner of homeless services, said on Monday that he will leave his post after four years of overseeing one of the Bloomberg administration’s most demanding agencies.

headline: Toward a Hung Parliament
text: Today’s column on David Cameron’s Tories has been half-overtaken by events: I was writing as if the Tories were still clinging to a slight edge in the polls, but as of this morning that may no longer be the case. The Liberal Democrats have been surging since their leader’s strong performance in last week’s debate; now they’ve surged into a narrow lead. Thanks to the way the U.K.’s Parliament apportions seats, a Lib Dem victory in the popular vote would leave either Labour or the Tories with a slight plurality in the House of Commons (not coincidentally, electoral reform is a major Lib Dem issue), but well short of the majority required to govern. For political observers, this would be a fascinating outcome: Think Florida in 2000 crossed with a brokered convention. For Britain, misgoverned and indebted and desperate for strong leadership, it would probably be a disaster.

headline: The British Election and the Wars
text: If the voters of any country know that wars fought in foreign fields rarely win or lose elections, the British do; the most stunning election upset in modern British history came in 1945, when soldiers returning from World War II, or awaiting transportation from distant battlefields, combined with restive families at home to boot Winston Churchill and his Conservatives out of office less than three months after he led the country to victory over Nazi Germany. Then, as now, voters made their choices primarily on domestic issues, and they judged Labour’s Clement Attlee better equipped for the social and economic renewal the country needed than the man widely regarded, even then, as one of the greatest Englishmen who ever lived.

headline: Jenson Button Calls Chinese Grand Prix “My Best Victory”
text: Jenson Button, the 2009 Formula One champion, may not have been on many pundits’ shortlist to repeat the title — especially after switching teams — but after four races, he is the lone driver with multiple wins. Sunday’s victory at the Chinese Grand Prix in Shanghai amid a light rain might have been one of his most impressive.

headline: The Inches That Matter
text: C. J. Chivers reports from Marja, Afghanistan, where Marines face stiff resistance from Taliban fighters, including a rarity, a trained marksman.

headline: Carrie Underwood and Michael Bublé Score at Music Awards Shows
text: Musicians from down South, up North and all points in between had reasons to celebrate as both the Academy of Country Music Awards and the Juno Awards, the Canadian equivalent of the Grammys, were handed out this weekend.

headline: Android Tries Harder
text: Remember the old Avis car-rental slogan? “We’re Number 2. We try harder.”

headline: Cutting Back the Rain Forest in New York
text: Like many other municipalities, New York City has used durable rain forest woods to build pieces of public infrastructure like benches and boardwalks. And although Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has publicly promised to limit the use of such materials, some organizations have decided that the city is not moving quickly enough.

headline: Monday Reading: Five Airlines Promise No Carry-On Bag Fees
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Obama to Confront Wall St. on Its Turf
text: President Obama will take his case for tougher financial regulation to Wall Street’s backyard this week, the White House announced Monday.

headline: Tacos: Health Food With a Kick
text: In the years before I began look closely at Mexican food, my concept of the taco was shaped by Tex-Mex restaurants and fast food chains. It was a deep-fried tortilla filled with ground beef and grated yellow cheese. Then I began to travel in Mexico, where tacos are only sometimes made with crisp-fried tortillas and rarely have greasy fillings. Wrap a warm tortilla around anything, it turned out, and it’s a taco. Taco fillings consisted of everything from fish and shellfish, to in-season vegetables and potatoes, to the fungus called huitlacoche that grows inside of cornhusks.

headline: The Dangers of Buying Medicines Overseas
text: Millions will travel overseas this coming holiday season. But whether it’s at the Great Wall of China or the Taj Mahal, Victoria Falls or Iguazu Falls, there always exists the risk that one may become ill or hospitalized while abroad and require medicine from a local pharmacy or clinic. And as a tourist pops that pill into the mouth, he or she should be concerned about the safety and efficacy of those drugs.

headline: Soft Tacos With Fish and Spinach
text: Friends who sampled all of this week’s tacos liked these the best. They’re easy to make: I used frozen Alaskan cod fillets from Trader Joe’s, approved as sustainable by the Blue Ocean Institute. I liked them very much, especially since I found no bones when I flaked the fish.

headline: Want a Higher G.P.A.? Go to a Private College
text: Update: Stuart Rojstaczer, the co-author of the grade inflation study summarized below, is taking reader questions. Submit them here.

headline: Soft Tacos With Sautéed Winter Squash and Chipotles
text: Pan-cooked, slightly caramelized winter squash contrasts beautifully with the spicy, rich-tasting chipotles that are canned in a sort of Mexican-style barbecue sauce and stocked by most supermarkets along with other Mexican ingredients. These tacos bring you lots of vitamin A, as well as vitamin C, potassium, manganese and folate.

headline: Quote Unquote | Your Grandmother’s Rodarte
text: – Kate Mulleavy of Rodarte explains her current inspiration to the Wall Street Journal. Tavi is going to love this.

headline: Soft Tacos With Potatoes and Greens
text: These tacos are comforting and filling, a great destination for greens. If you want to save time, use washed, stemmed greens that come packaged by the pound. You’ll need a little less than half of a one-pound bag. This filling isn’t spicy, so if you want spice serve it with salsa (my preference would be a green salsa).

headline: Update on European Airports
text: As Europe grounded most flights for a fourth day on Sunday because of a volcanic ash cloud spreading from Iceland, increasingly desperate airlines ran test flights to show that flying was safe and pressed aviation authorities to loosen the flight ban.

headline: How to Make Your Opera Mini Browser Sing
text: The Opera Mini Web browser for the iPhone was downloaded 1 million times on its first day in the iTunes store. So now that you have it, there are some tips and tricks to make it more useful. Some are pretty obvious, some are not.

headline: No More Mystery Behind Savage History Reviews: The Author’s Wife Did It
text: For weeks, the pseudonymous reviewer known only as Historian had been using the British book site amazon.co.uk as his or her personal shooting gallery, taking aim at the authors of works on Russian culture and history: Rachel Polonsky’s book “Molotov’s Magic Lantern” was dismissed as “dense,” “pretentious” and “the sort of book that makes you wonder why it was ever published”; and Robert Service’s work was skewered as a “dull read” (for a book about Trotsky) and “rubbish” and “an awful book” (for a history of communism). Perhaps the only author to be spared the point pen of Historian was Orlando Figes, whose book “The Whisperers” was described as a “beautiful and necessary” account of Soviet history, written by someone with “superb storytelling skills” and of whom Historian said, “I hope he writes forever.”

headline: Roundup: I.R.A.’s and Financial Aid … New Avenues for Teacher Training … L.I. Quadruplets Decide
text: As the April 1 admission-decision deadline fades and the May 1 deadline for deposits looms at many colleges, The Choice has been taking a breather to catch up on other reading.

headline: Top Qaeda Leaders in Iraq Reported Killed in Raid
text: BAGHDAD — Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki announced Monday that two top insurgent leaders had been killed, including a somewhat mythic figure who has operated under the name Abu Omar al-Baghdadi. Mr. Baghdadi has been reported dead or detained several times previously, and his very existence had been called into question a few years ago by American military leaders.

headline: Groups Urge Tax on Wall St. Bonuses
text: ALBANY — Gov. David A. Paterson and the Legislature have spent weeks arguing over how to cut enough spending to close the state’s $9 billion budget gap, with little progress.

headline: Mushroom and Poblano Tacos
text: This is inspired by a dish that Mexican chef Rick Bayless makes with huitlacoche, a black fungus that grows in lobes on ears of corn. It’s a great delicacy in Mexico but not easy to get in the United States (though you can find mail order sources on the Internet). Mushrooms are a lot easier to find, and they make a delicious taco filling. Epazote is an earthy Mexican herb that you might be able to find in a Mexican market or a farmers’ market. If you can’t find it, use cilantro.

headline: Bomber Strikes Near Pakistan Rally; Police Officer Seen as Target
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A teenage suicide bomber struck near a protest rally in the northwestern frontier city of Peshawar on Monday, killing a prominent police officer and as many as two dozen protesters, the police said.

headline: Twain's Bookshelf
text: List of 230 books from Mark Twain's personal collection.

headline: Guilty Verdict in Killing of Long Island Man
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — The white teenager accused of killing an Ecuadorean immigrant in a racially motivated attack was convicted on Monday of manslaughter as a hate crime, in a case that put a spotlight on anti-Hispanic violence on Long Island.

headline: Biden Books ‘The View’
text: What do you get when you put Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Elisabeth Hasselbeck at the same coffee table?

headline: Schott Op-Chart: British General Election Briefing
text: Last Thursday’s televised party leaders’ debate – the first in British history – injected new energy into a lackluster election campaign. The incumbent prime minister, Gordon Brown of the Labour Party, still faces a tough fight from his Conservative opponent, David Cameron – though with the polls swinging toward the third-party Liberal Democrats there is the real possibility of a “hung Parliament.”

headline: Aziz Ansari to Host MTV Movie Awards
text: MTV has named the host of its annual movie awards, and it’s a sort of surprise if you don’t keep up with industry chatter or were expecting the gig to go to Snooki. Aziz Ansari, a comedian and a co-star of the NBC comedy “Parks and Recreation,” will be the M.C. of the 2010 Movie Awards, the cable channel said on Monday, confirming longstanding reports (like this one from The Los Angeles Times in March) that he was in negotiations for the job. Mr. Ansari, who was a cast member of the MTV sketch series “Human Giant” and will appear this summer in the comedy “Get Him to the Greek,” seemed just as astounded as anyone that he was chosen over the stars of the channel’s best-known reality series. In a statement, he said, “I’m so happy Ronnie from ‘Jersey Shore’ was unavailable and this exciting opportunity was able to come my way.”

headline: Obama Opens Deficit Panel Meetings Next Week
text: Next Tuesday, President Obama will open the first meeting of the bipartisan debt reduction commission he established in February, followed by what are certain to be dire fiscal warnings from economic authorities including Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke.

headline: What We’re Reading: Wall Street Doesn’t Understand Wall Street
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Revisiting the Lindsay Era

headline: Clinton Cancels Finland Trip

headline: Staying Alive: The Wipe Out
text: Two disadvantages of selling residential furniture are that the average sale is small and you have to work really, really hard to get it. The Partner and I both realized that it would be hard to build the business (you can see my previous posts here) selling only dining furniture. Residential clients want to sit in the chair, to feel the finish and to thump the table top before they buy. Which means we could only sell to clients who came to the shop, and that’s a relatively small group.

text: Both questions this week concern the campaign to encourage Americans to take part in the 2010 Census.

headline: People and Accounts of Note in Advertising
text: AMJ Campbell Van Lines, Toronto, Canada’s largest moving company, named Ariad Custom Communications, Toronto, as its agency of record. The company had previously handled advertising internally. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Comcast Denies Connection to RightNetwork
text: Comcast denied reports Monday that it is a partner in the RightNetwork, a red state start-up that promises “content that reflects and reinforces their perspective and worldview.”

headline: Armani Hotel Delays Dubai Debut
text: The opening of the Armani Hotel Dubai, in the Burj Khalifa, the world’s tallest building, has been delayed to April 27, as ash from volcanic eruptions in Iceland forced extensive flight cancellations from Europe

headline: South Korea Vows to Find Culprit in Sinking of Warship
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Pausing to wipe away tears with a handkerchief, South Korea’s president, Lee Myung-bak, vowed Monday to respond “resolutely and unwaveringly” to last month’s deadly sinking of a South Korean warship in disputed waters near North Korea.

headline: What Changes Are Really Afoot at CNBC?
text: In a Page Six item in The New York Post on Sunday about changes coming to the business news network CNBC, a network representative said the information was “40 percent accurate.”

headline: A Final ‘Minute of Mayhem’ for Malcolm McLaren
text: It wouldn’t be a funeral for Malcolm McLaren if it didn’t feature one last stunt. On Monday relatives of Mr. McLaren, the pop provocateur, sloganeer and former manager of the British punk band the Sex Pistols, asked that his mourners observe a “minute of mayhem” when he is buried on Thursday, Reuters reported. Mr. McLaren, a former proprietor of a clothing boutique (that went by the names Let It Rock and Sex) and a former partner of the fashion designer Vivienne Westwood, died of mesothelioma on April 8. He was 64.

headline: According to D’Ag, Low Prices Are in the Bag
text: A supermarket chain once known for its quirky, light-hearted advertising is promoting itself again, this time with a humorous, make-believe “battle” between the boss and his senior management.

headline: Treasury to End Paper Checks
text: The Obama administration is phasing out paper checks to people receiving federal benefits.

headline: Photographs From Coachella, Day 3

headline: Another Cheruiyot Wins the Boston Marathon
text: BOSTON — Robert Kiprono Cheruiyot arrived at the Boston Marathon with name recognition — just not his own. He then shook up the venerable race on Monday with a memorable performance that came so fast and so soon, leaving the familiar American favorites in his dust.

headline: When It Pays to Plan Ahead
text: Looking for a new place to rent can be a stressful ordeal, a kind of ticking time bomb formulation with many moving parts — price, location, view, time frame, pets, etc. — that never seem to line up exactly right. It’s a feeling approximated — metaphorically, of course — in this frustrating Tetris-like Web game inspired by a cartoon on XKCD, titled “Hell.”

headline: Hello, Brooklyn
text: There was a dispatch from Kings County in The Financial Times over the weekend, a woman named Emily Stokes banging around Brooklyn on the F train and looking into the borough’s dining scene: the “laid-back” and hipstery crowds at Vinegar Hill House, Saraghina, Frankies Sputino, Prime Meats, the Vanderbilt.

headline: The Goldman Defense: Caveat Emptor
text: 5:43 p.m. | Updated with both Goldman response documents Months before the Securities and Exchange Commission sued Goldman Sachs for securities fraud, the investment bank outlined its defense to potential charges related to its construction of a mortgage investment.

headline: Davis’s Honesty Was Refreshing, but Not Unexpected
text: Something seemed very wrong when Brian Davis of England summoned a rules official immediately after hitting his pitch from the hazard near Calibogue Sound in Sunday’s playoff with Jim Furyk for the Verizon Heritage title. Actually, something was very right.

headline: With Flights Grounded, Kenya’s Produce Wilts
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — When Kenneth Maundu, general manager for Sunripe produce exporters, first heard about a volcano erupting in Iceland, he was excited. “I thought, ‘Oh, wow, a volcano,’ ” he said.

headline: Going Mobile: Debating and Using Cellphones in School
text: Overview | Can cellphones serve as effective instructional tools in the classroom? In what ways can the use of mobile technology support and strengthen curriculum? What are the drawbacks? In this lesson, students learn about innovative uses of cellphone technology and applications in the developing world, then explore how their phones can be used as learning tools.

headline: Monday Puzzle: Thank You, John
text: The Monday Puzzle is on the move. TierneyLab is about to shut down (John explains here why he’s closing the blog to concentrate on longer articles and his science column), but the math puzzles will continue at a new home, The Times’ WordPlay blog. The math puzzles by me with illustrations by Justin Thyme will appear there under the title “Numberplay” starting next Monday. This is the last puzzle here at the Lab, so it is time to take a stroll down memory lane . . .

headline: Volcano Set to Cost Airlines Millions
text: As volcanic ash keeps European flights grounded, air carriers claim they are losing $200 million per day. NBC's Dawna Friesen reports from London.

headline: Value-Added Taxes: A Primer
text: In recent weeks there has been lots of buzz — much of it preemptively negative — about value-added taxes. This post presents a short primer to help you get up to speed if you’re unfamiliar with this policy tool.

headline: Fabrice Tourre: Fabulous or Fatally Flawed?
text: Fabrice Tourre, the 31-year-old Goldman Sachs vice president cited by the Securities and Exchange Commission in its accusation of securities fraud against the firm, is a graduate of one of France’s oldest and best known engineering schools, the École Centrale Paris, where he studied from 1998 through 2000.

headline: A Barista’s One Shining Moment, Again
text: On Sunday, Mike Phillips of Intelligentsia Coffee and Tea won at the United States Barista Championship, for the second consecutive year. He will represent the United States at the World Barista Championship, to be held in London in June.

headline: Layoffs Announced at St. Vincent’s
text: Updated, 3:52 p.m. | More than 1,000 staff members were laid off on Monday at the bankrupt St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan, the hospital said in a statement.

headline: Vain Glorious | Kiehl’s Earth Day Initiative
text: Who: Jeff Koons, Julianne Moore, Pharrell Williams and Malia Jones.

headline: Greece’s Uncertain Future Weighs on Bond Market
text: Yields on Greek bonds pushed to fresh highs on Monday and shares in Athens sank as investors continued to worry about the country’s near-term ability to finance its debt. Some raised the specter of default even if international aid arrived soon.

headline: A Firsthand Look at Firefights in Marja
text: During the initial American-led assault earlier this year into Marja, the last large Taliban-dominated population center in Helmand Province, Marines in several companies encountered something unusual in the American experience of the Afghan war – insurgent snipers.

headline: Paedophile Pound
text: The market for mainstream products that sexualize young children.

headline: Wild Sharks-Avalanche Series Gets Even Wilder
text: The Sharks and Avalanche have only played three games in their first-round N.H.L. playoff series, but the amazing drama makes it feel like they’ve played many more.

headline: The Squeeze on the Middle Class
text: A combination of rising health insurance premiums and falling wages has hit middle-income people especially hard, causing them to lose health insurance coverage faster than workers both poorer and richer than they are, according to a recent report from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation.

headline: Travel Deals: Free Lonely Planet iPhone Guides
text: Thousands of travelers have been stranded by the eruption of Iceland’s Eyjafjallajokull volcano, which disrupted air traffic worldwide. But as Elisabeth Rosenthal reports, some stranded passengers are enjoying the forced leisure time.

headline: Florida Voters: It’s a ‘Bad Idea’ to Sue Over Health Care Law
text: Bill McCollum, Florida’s attorney general, has been crowing for months about the lawsuit he filed challenging the federal health care overhaul. His calculus, as the Republican candidate for governor, has been broadcast at every turn: Voters will love it!

headline: Iron Man and Miley Cyrus vs. the Volcano
text: A cloud of volcanic ash has done what foes like the Mandarin, Modok and the Crimson Dynamo could not — it has forced Iron Man to yield. Paramount said on Monday that it was moving the world premiere of “Iron Man 2,” its much anticipated comic-book adventure movie, to Los Angeles from London as Europe contends with travel woes caused by the eruption of an Icelandic volcano, The Hollywood Reporter said.

headline: Citi Distances Itself From Goldman’s Troubles
text: Citigroup said Monday that it was “not involved” in the government’s fraud investigation into Goldman Sachs’s subprime mortgage dealings, but the bank once again acknowledged that regulators were looking at its subprime business.

headline: Iran Mutes a Chorus of Voices for Reform
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Iranian authorities on Monday suspended two prominent opposition political parties, banned a newspaper and handed down prison sentences to three reformist political figures, in the latest sign that the country’s hard-line rulers aim to crush any official political representation by the reformist movement.

headline: Eyjafjallajokull’s Scream Could Wake a Neighbor
text: As my colleagues Alan Cowell, Nicola Clark and Mark McDonald report, the disruption to air travel in Europe is easing as the eruption of the Eyjafjallajokull volcano in Iceland has weakened, spewing less ash into the skies.

headline: Flood Insurance Program Is Back — for Now
text: The National Flood Insurance Program is back in business, at least until May 31.

headline: Man Convicted for Driving Drunk in Barbie Car
text: A few months ago I wrote about a man in Minnesota who was charged with drunken driving after he crashed his homemade motorized recliner into a parked car, and I didn’t think it got any weirder than that.

headline: Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 12:55 P.M.
text: Construction workers need lunch, too.

headline: The Insider | Gordon Harrison Hull
text: The Insider is a recurring profile of tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts.

headline: Orchestra and Lincoln Center in Deal
text: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and the New York Philharmonic have decided to extend their operating agreement to give both parties more time to resolve questions about a renovation of the orchestra’s home, Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: (Company Name Here) Presents: Martinez Schools
text: Just how much is the right to name a building at your child’s school worth to a corporate sponsor? Parents of the 4,000 students in the Martinez Unified School District could soon find out.

headline: Los Angeles Museum Board Members Ordered to Undergo Financial Training
text: The California Attorney General’s office has ordered the board members of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, which came close to a financial collapse in 2008, to undergo special fiduciary training after the office determined that the museum flouted state law in the way it managed its budget, The Los Angeles Times reported.

headline: A Mischievous Convergence of Past and Present Jazz
text: Erimaj, a band led by Jamire Williams, the young jazz drummer from Houston, features a lot of information being knocked around. There are rising and falling vamps and solos; a bit of rock and pastoral-sounding, post-Pat Metheny guitar harmony; some careful falsetto R&B; and, from Mr. Williams, fluid narrative improvising, as well as beats like fragmented hip-hop.

headline: Previous Airline Brushes with Ash Disaster
text: Here is a partial list of commercial airline flights that faced potentially disastrous problems when they flew into volcanic ash clouds. All were Boeing 747s.

headline: In Event of a Strike, How to Open the Doors
text: Here at City Room we do our best to help New Yorkers in need. Lately we’ve been reading that more than 30,000 workers in the city’s residential buildings — many of them doormen — are threatening to strike at 12:01 a.m. Wednesday.

headline: The Morning Skate: An Entertaining Start to Stanley Cup Play
text: Poor Dan Boyle. Trying to clear the puck behind his own net to teammate Douglas Murray, the Sharks defenseman’s attempt deflected off the stick of Colorado’s Ryan O’Reilly and past Evgeni Nabokov for the only goal of the game in the first minute of overtime.

headline: Auchincloss Co-op Is for Sale
text: A three-bedroom apartment on Park Avenue that was home to the author Louis Auchincloss has been put on the market for $3.9 million. Mr. Auchincloss wrote more than 60 books, most memorably about the upper echelons of society He also practiced law until 1987. He died in January at age 92. The co-op, at 1111 Park Avenue, is listed with Mary Rutherfurd and Leslie Coleman of Brown Harris Stevens.

headline: Ash Clouds and Adoption Bans
text: Among the many disruptions caused by the volcanic eruptions in Iceland was a flight to Moscow by a U.S. delegation hoping to restart adoptions with Russia. While the details of the freeze are murky, what is clear is that nothing will be clarified until negotiations start. That was supposed to happen today, but was postponed until at least next week, according to a statement from the U.S. Embassy.

headline: Good Brief | Underwear for Earth Day
text: Maybe your mother told you that you should always put clean underwear on in the morning in case you were ever to get hit by a bus. But what if every time you changed your skivvies, 20 trees would be planted in Africa? It could happen. PACT underwear [www.wearPACT.com], the pet project from the design celeb Yves Behar, donates 10 percent of its sales to an ever- increasing roster of nonprofits like Dave Eggers’s writing program, 826 Valencia, and Oceana. Each organization gets its own print so you can wear your cause on your, er, oh never mind. The newest collaboration is with the architect David Adjaye and Wangari Maathai, whose Green Belt Movement works to empower women and fight deforestation, soil erosion and water scarcity in Kenya. For Earth Week only, 100 percent of the proceeds of Adjaye’s specially designed Green Belt print underwear will contribute to the planting of 10,000 trees. (After April 25, it reverts to 10 percent.) See? Change is good!

headline: King Sunny Adé Cancels Tour After Two Deaths
text: Lots of musicians have been canceling international tour dates lately, mostly because of the hazards posed by the volcano eruption in Iceland. But concerns at once more tragic and more ordinary have forced King Sunny Adé, the legendary Nigerian bandleader, to call off his North American tour, which was scheduled to start in Canada last week and come to the Highline Ballroom in Manhattan on May 20.

headline: Davis to Play, Reyes to Sit
text: 6:18 p.m. | Updated The Mets, off to a 4-8 start and slumping at the plate, promoted first baseman Ike Davis, their top prospect, from Class AAA Buffalo on Monday.

headline: Columbine and Va. Tech Families Take On Gun Show ‘Loophole’
text: Updated: Family members of those killed or wounded in the shootings at Virginia Tech and Columbine High School signed advertisements running today that called on lawmakers to support closing the “gun show loophole.”

headline: Acrobatic Ants
text: Q. Can the tiny ants that visit me every spring hop like a flea? Sometimes I look down and suddenly there one is, working its way across my anatomy.

headline: Crist Faces New Pressure in Senate Race
text: Updated: Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida faced new pressure today to abandon his campaign to win the state’s Republican nomination for the United States Senate, with the head of the party’s senatorial re-election committee declaring that Mr. Crist has “zero chance” to win.

headline: Appliance Discounts, for the Swift
text: Whether it is newfound green consciousness ahead of Earth Day — or just the allure of a big discount on a new washing machine or air-conditioner — consumers across the country are snapping up government rebates for energy-efficient appliances.

headline: Toyota to Recall 2010 Lexus Gx 460
text: Toyota said it will recall about 9,400 of its 2010 Lexus GX 460s to re-program the electronic stability control system, which it calls Vehicle Stability Control, to correct a handling problem that caused Consumer Reports magazine to issue a don’t-buy warning.

headline: Five Trades That Need to Happen During the Draft
text: Sigmund Bloom of Draftguys.com will help preview and analyze the draft for the Fifth Down. He and Cecil Lammey host a podcast at FootballGuys.com,  and you can follow him on Twitter here.

headline: A Strange Set From the Reclusive Sly Stone
text: INDIO, Calif. — On Sunday night Sly Stone’s band was set up in one tent at 7 o’clock, the show then postponed to 9:30 and the equipment dismantled and moved to a bigger tent, where a very small crowd that had gotten word finally saw him.

headline: Fuld: I Had Never Heard of Repo 105 as C.E.O.
text: One of the biggest surprises to arise out of the court-appointed examiner’s report on Lehman Brothers was the emergence of “Repo 105,” an aggressive accounting trick that helped the investment bank look healthier than it really was.

headline: Can You Have a Happy Birthday on April 19?
text: On the little block in Providence, R.I., where I grew up, three of us kids celebrated our birthdays on April 19. I thought that was pretty remarkable; April 19 must be pretty special, I concluded. Many years later I feel the same way, but for different reasons.

headline: Luge Federation Says Olympic Track Not to Blame for Death
text: Two months after a Georgian luge athlete died in a crash on the Olympic track before the Vancouver Games, the sport’s international governing body has upheld its assertion that track design was not at fault in the racer’s death.

headline: ‘Kick-Ass’ Sneaks Ahead of ‘Dragon’ in Box-Office Race
text: “Kick-Ass” slew the dragon after all. Lionsgate executives are doing cartwheels over final box office figures that show their R-rated superhero comedy was the No. 1 movie over the weekend after all, beating DreamWorks Animation’s “How to Train Your Dragon” by a whisker. “Kick-Ass” ended up selling $19.83 million in tickets; “Dragon” moved into second place, with $19.63 million. What does it mean? For “Dragon,” not much. The animated movie, propped up by sky-high 3-D ticket prices, continues to do solid business in its fourth week in theaters. So it fell to second place – it already got a boatload of free press out of appearing to take the top slot. As for “Kick-Ass,” the No. 1 crown is psychologically important to embattled Lionsgate, which promoted the movie heavily with hopes of discovering a franchise. Joe Drake, Lionsgate’s co-chief operating officer, appears to still have hope. “Our marketing and distribution teams have brilliantly positioned it for a long and successful run,” he said in a news release on Monday.

headline: Sean Carroll Talks School Science and Time Travel
text: Q. When you go to a cocktail party, do you tell people that you are a physicist? Some physicists won’t.

headline: Brown Accuses Moody’s of ‘Blowing Off’ Inquiry
text: Attorney General Jerry Brown of California is taking Moody’s Investors Service to court. Mr. Brown contends that the credit rating agency is “blowing off the state of California” in its seven-month investigation into whether Moody’s and the two other leading credit-rating agencies, Standard & Poor’s and Fitch Ratings, acted improperly during the credit boom by assigning super-safe, triple-A ratings to mortgage-backed securities that later turned out to be extremely risky and in some cases worthless.

headline: Bring Back My Cable
text: I’ve had cable TV, but I went without without it for several months. I got all my shows online. I’m currently back to a cable setup (FiOS, if you are keeping score at home). I think cable is better for one important reason.

headline: Saturn Up Close
text: Images captured by cameras aboard the Cassini spacecraft on its mission to explore Saturn and its moons.

headline: On Ash and the Global Aviation Boom
text: A geoscientist weighs the odds of ash disruption in North America as an artist charts the aviation explosion.

headline: Chopin in All His Variety, Imaginatively Served
text: The Chopin bicentennial has brought an expected rush of celebrations, but for some performers this music is seldom out of mind. The brilliant Italian pianist Maurizio Pollini has a repertory that extends from Bach to Stockhausen, but Chopin’s music has always been a special cause, certainly since Mr. Pollini won the Chopin International Piano Competition in Warsaw in 1960.

headline: Goldman Suit Affects Reform Prospects
text: Jeff Zeleny of The Times discusses how the Goldman scandal affects the administration's attempt to pass financial regulatory reform.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Brazil’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Terry Gilliam‘s dystopian science fiction film, “Brazil.” Mr. Scott calls the film, which pits imagination against reality, “extravagant, visionary and maybe just a little bit crazy.” Please share your thoughts on “Brazil” and the career of Terry Gilliam.

headline: Blockbuster First Week for ‘Fences’
text: The Broadway revival of “Fences” had a blockbuster first week of preview performances at the box office last week, grossing $703,724 for a six-show week — technically 105 percent of the potential maximum gross, a sign that some theatergoers are paying the $325 premium ticket price for the August Wilson play starring Denzel Washington and Viola Davis.

headline: Suit Accuses USA Swimming of Negligence
text: A 21-year-old former competitive swimmer filed a civil suit Monday in Independence, Mo., against USA Swimming and her swim club, claiming they were negligent in protecting her and others from sexual abuse by a coach. Despite her complaints about his conduct, the suit said, the coach was able to move to a club in a different state.

headline: A Saturn Spectacular, With Gravity’s Help
text: When it comes to voyages of discovery, NASA’s venerable Cassini mission is about as good as it gets.

headline: Kyle MacLachlan Selling Chelsea Apartment
text: The actor Kyle MacLachlan and his wife, Desiree Gruber, an executive producer of “Project Runway,” have put their apartment up for sale. They are asking $2.875 million for a three-bedroom condo at the Chelsea Mercantile, located at 252 Seventh Avenue at 24th Street.

headline: Apple Store Says 3G iPads to Ship ‘by May 7th’
text: Apple’s formal release date for the 3G version of the iPad is still up in the air, but information posted on the Apple Online Store site says the three 3G models will ship to purchasers “by May 7th.”

headline: An Alcoholic’s Savior: God, Belladonna or Both?
text: In October 1909, Dr. Alexander Lambert boldly announced to a New York Times reporter that he had found a surefire cure for alcoholism and drug addiction. Even more astounding, he stated that the treatment required “less than five days.” The therapy consisted of an odd mixture of belladonna (deadly nightshade), along with the fluid extracts of xanthoxylum (prickly ash) and hyoscyamus (henbane). “The result is often so dramatic,” Lambert said, “that one hesitates to believe it possible.”

headline: Australia Blocks a Deal for Unit of AXA
text: National Australia Bank’s ambitions to substantially increase its position in Australia’s wealth management and life insurance market were dealt a major setback on Monday, when the country’s competition authority blocked its $12.2 billion bid for the Asia Pacific operations of the French insurance giant AXA.

headline: M2 Club Closed by the Police
text: An earlier version of this post said that M2 itself was accused of selling drugs. It should have said that M2 was accused of allowing the sale of drugs, and has been updated to reflect that correction.

headline: Artifacts | Jeff Burton’s Fantasy Life Beyond Porn
text: Jeff Burton was smitten with Stella Stevens the instant he saw “The Poseidon Adventure.” That was in 1972. He was 9. In the movie, Stevens played an ultrachic former call girl who had married a burly cop, Ernest Borgnine, and fell to her death shod in silver platform shoes. The young Burton developed a raging obsession with both Stevens and the film. Thirty-five years later, after working as a still photographer on porn movie shoots in Los Angeles, where he lives, Burton got to direct her himself — for a portrait now hanging in his seventh solo show at the Casey Kaplan Gallery.

headline: Kenya: Pig Farmers Are Focus of Effort to Stop Spread of Parasite That Causes Epilepsy
text: Researchers in Kenya have been trying a seemingly unlikely tactic to prevent epilepsy: teaching farmers to tether their pigs.

headline: Risks for Youths Who Eat What They Watch
text: Many factors influence children’s food choices: where they eat; what their friends and siblings eat; what parents eat and drink and bring into the house; what is served at school; and, of course, what they like.

headline: MLB 10: The Show
text: A trailer for the video game.

headline: Benefit for Uninsured May Still Pose Hurdle
text: William Mann of Pittsburgh earns just enough to get by. He is 46, doesn’t own a car, hasn’t taken a vacation in three years and hasn’t had health insurance for most of his adult life.

headline: With AIDS, Time to Get Beyond Blame
text: You don’t hear much about AIDS in America anymore. The few new headlines are reserved for dispatches from the developing world, where the dying young still make good old-fashioned heart-wrenching copy.

headline: Baseball Real Enough to Stink At
text: When it comes to sports video games, is there such a thing as too much realism?

headline: For Same-Sex Couples, Equality in the Hospital
text: For people in same-sex relationships, aging carries an added burden of anxiety: the fear that in a health crisis their partner might be excluded from making medical decisions, even visiting their bedside.
