headline: BlogTalk: Birthers, Doctors and the Women’s Vote
text: Tom Tancredo promotes the idea that President Obama was not born in this country and the White House reacts (sort of); more doctors are running for Congress; and a Las Vegas newspaper editorial calls for repealing the 19th Amendment, which gave women the right to vote. These are a few of the the political tidbits churning around the blogs today.

headline: The Cassini-Huygens Mission to Saturn
text: A look back at four years of the Cassini mission to explore Saturn, its rings and moons.

headline: Bracing for the End, Maybe, of Gino’s
text: Every zebra has its day. The 314 zebras on the wallpaper in Gino’s of Capri, an Upper East Side restaurant that was once a haunt for Ed Sullivan and Frank Sinatra, are not getting any younger. Their last day is May 15. Maybe.

headline: Despite Advice, Many Fail to Breast-Feed
text: The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends breast-feeding exclusively for the first six months of life, and continued nursing for a year, but a national survey has found that less than 75 percent of women breast-feed at all, and by one year only about a fifth are still nursing their babies.

headline: Global Strategy Stabilized I.B.M. During Downturn
text: I.B.M. wanted to sell its wares around the world since its early days, adopting the aspirational name International Business Machines Corporation, in 1924. And for decades, I.B.M. was the emblematic multinational with deep roots in foreign markets, mainly in the developed nations of Europe and Japan.

headline: Aleppo, Syria, to Undergo Historical Restoration
text: In this ancient fortress city in northern Syria, one of the world’s oldest continuously inhabited settlements, an ambitious restoration project is near completion in the Old City. Bloomberg is reporting that a master plan for development has been laid out for the next 15 years.

headline: A Magazine Master Builder
text: When Henry Luce graduated from the Hotchkiss School in Connecticut in 1916, he received not a single vote in the “most likely to succeed” category. That oversight remains amazing, not only because he would attain such eminence as Time Inc.’s founder and long-reigning autocrat but also because of what Luce, at 18, had already accomplished.

headline: Compulsory Education for a Museum Board
text: The California Attorney General’s office ordered the board members of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, which came close to a financial collapse in 2008, to undergo special fiduciary training last year after determining that the museum flouted state law in the way it managed its budget, The Los Angeles Times reported. The museum lost more than $30 million from its investment portfolio over several years, ending up with only $5 million on hand in 2008; it also broke state law when it paid general expenses from restricted endowment funds, according to the newspaper, which obtained a two-page letter sent to the museum by the attorney general’s office in November. In December 2008 the museum negotiated a $30 million bailout from Eli Broad, Los Angeles’s leading cultural patron, which allowed it to maintain its facilities and avoid selling off artwork. As a result of that agreement and new giving by other donors, the museum’s investments have improved, with the value rising to more than $14 million. A museum spokeswoman said the museum and the board had complied with all the requirements for training and financial reform in the attorney general’s letter.

headline: Pacino and McEntire Deliver for CBS
text: The unlikely double act of Al Pacino and Reba McEntire led CBS to a ratings victory on Sunday night. A new installment of “60 Minutes,” featuring a profile of Mr. Pacino, left, drew 10.7 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates, and the Academy of Country Music Awards show, hosted by Ms. McEntire, roped in an average of 13.1 million viewers. ABC was runner-up on the night with its more traditional pairing of “Desperate Housewives” (10.4 million) and “Brothers & Sisters” (7.9 million), while NBC was third as Donald Trump fired the wrestler Bill Goldberg from his “Celebrity Apprentice” team (6.9 million). Fox was fourth with a lineup that included new episodes of “The Simpsons” (5.9 million) and “American Dad” (5.2 million).

headline: A New Weekend Champ
text: Lionsgate executives are doing cartwheels over final box office figures that show that “Kick-Ass,” their R-rated superhero comedy that features Chloe Grace Moretz, above, was the No. 1 movie over the weekend, beating DreamWorks Animation’s “How to Train Your Dragon” by a whisker. “Kick-Ass” ended up selling $19.8 million in tickets; “Dragon” slipped to second place with $19.6 million. What does it mean? For “Dragon,” not much. Propped up by ticket prices at 3-D screenings, the film continues to do solid business in its fourth week in theaters. As for “Kick-Ass,” the No. 1 crown is important to the embattled Lionsgate, which promoted the movie heavily, hoping to build a franchise. Joe Drake, Lionsgate’s co-chief operating officer, apparently still has such hopes. “Our marketing and distribution teams have brilliantly positioned it for a long and successful run,” he said in a news release on Monday.

headline: Underwood and Bublé Score Music Awards
text: Musicians from down South, up North and all points in between had reasons to celebrate as both the Academy of Country Music Awards and the Juno Awards, the Canadian equivalent of the Grammys, were handed out this weekend. Lady Antebellum was the biggest winner on Sunday at the Academy of Country Music Awards show in Las Vegas, The Associated Press reported. The trio, based in Nashville, picked up five trophies, including one for best vocal group as well as for song and single record of the year for “Need You Now.” But the spotlight shined brightest on Carrie Underwood, above, who became the first woman to win the academy’s entertainer of the year award twice, and was given a special trophy for her previous “triple crown” victories as entertainer of the year, top female vocalist and top newcomer categories. In St. John’s, Newfoundland, the pop singer Michael Bublé won four prizes at the Juno Awards, The Hollywood Reporter said. Mr. Bublé’s “Crazy Love” won in the pop album and overall album categories, and his song “Haven’t Met You Yet” was named single of the year.

headline: Readers Reduce, Reuse and Recycle
text: Across Berlin, color-coded domes and cans stand at at the ready to take in Berliner’s recyclables, one material at a time: glass, plastic, paper. But on New York’s street corners, there is only one wide-lipped metal trash can that takes it all in, recyclable or not.

headline: ‘Minute of Mayhem’ for Malcolm McLaren
text: It wouldn’t be a funeral for Malcolm McLaren if it didn’t feature one last stunt. On Monday relatives of Mr. McLaren, the pop provocateur, sloganeer and former manager of the British punk band the Sex Pistols, asked that his mourners observe a “minute of mayhem” when he is buried on Thursday, Reuters reported. Mr. McLaren died of mesothelioma on April 8. He was 64. On the Web site of the charity Humanade, humanade.org.uk, Mr. McLaren’s son, Joseph Corré, wrote that he would be buried at Highgate Cemetery in London after a funeral procession through the city. In a statement Mr. Corré wrote: “In celebration of Malcolm’s life we are asking people to observe a MINUTE OF MAYHEM at midday on 22nd April. Put on your favorite records and let it RIP!”

headline: King Sunny Adé Cancels North American Tour
text: King Sunny Adé, the legendary Nigerian bandleader, has called off his North American tour, which was to have begun in Canada last week and come to the Highline Ballroom in Manhattan on May 20. In late March, two percussionists in Mr. Adé’s 17-piece touring band, Gabriel Ayanniyi and Omo Olope, died in a car accident in Nigeria on the way to a music video shoot. With just a few weeks before the tour was scheduled to start, efforts to get American visas for replacement members of the band proved unsuccessful. Finding replacement players in the United States was next to impossible, said Andy Frankel, the band’s manager, who is based in Philadelphia, for financial, logistical and, especially, musical reasons, given Mr. Ayanniyi’s key role as the lead talking-drum player. In Mr. Adé’s juju music  a Nigerian pop style rooted in Yoruba traditions  the talking drum is, Mr. Frankel said, “equivalent to the lead guitar in a rock band.” He added, “After King Sunny, it does everything.”

headline: Iron Man and Miley Cyrus Wait for Dust to Settle
text: A cloud of volcanic ash has done what foes like the Mandarin, Modok and the Crimson Dynamo could not  it has forced Iron Man to yield. Paramount said on Monday that it was moving the world premiere of “Iron Man 2,” the much-anticipated sequel to its comic-book adventure movie, to Los Angeles from London as Europe contends with travel woes caused by the eruption of an Icelandic volcano, The Hollywood Reporter said. The high-wattage premiere, scheduled for next Monday at the Vue Westfield theater in London, was to have included the film’s stars Robert Downey Jr., above, Scarlett Johansson and Mickey Rourke. The Hollywood Reporter said that travel uncertainties had also caused Miley Cyrus and Liam Hemsworth to cancel planned appearances at a charity screening of their movie, “The Last Song,” in London. A-listers were no match for the relatively unknown Eyjafjallajokull volcano (whose name, we’re fairly certain, was not taken from an old Stan Lee-Jack Kirby issue of Tales of Suspense).

headline: Corker Slams Both Sides in Financial Feud
text: Senator Bob Corker, the Republican of Tennessee who helped draft legislation to tighten regulation of the financial industry, criticized both Republicans and Democrats on Monday for politicizing the debate.

headline: Newbies and the Reunited Gather in the Desert
text: INDIO, Calif.  “We’re Pavement, back from the dead,” Scott Kannberg, Pavement’s rhythm guitarist, told thousands of people gathered on Sunday night at the main stage of the 11th Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival. A reunited Pavement, the epitome of disheveled 1990s indie-rock until it dissolved in 2000, wasn’t the only re-emergent act at Coachella. The three-day rock festival, in the California desert, with more than 100 bands and D.J.’s, also featured Faith No More, Public Image Ltd., the Specials and Sly Stone, whose set started four hours after it was scheduled and closed out the weekend as a funky mess.

headline: The Few Who Founded Fantasy Baseball
text: A movie about the genesis of rotisserie baseball has a built-in audience. It also has a built-in, and almost equally passionate, nonaudience. Those of us who play roto know better than to bring it up at a party, let alone beat people over the head with it for an hour.

headline: Ahead of Goldman Suit, a Tight-Lipped S.E.C.
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: Love Your Dress. Really.
text: At the Matrix Awards luncheon at the Waldorf Astoria on Monday, Tina Fey and Sheryl Crow beamed for the cameras, their composure commendable — considering that each had committed the kind of fashion faux pas that often rates more attention than the event itself. Ms. Fey and Ms. Crow, both honorees at the event, which honors New York Women in communications, wore subtle variations of a nearly identical Dolce & Gabbana dress, a sleeveless jacquard embellished with overblown roses and vines.

headline: Seeing Ourselves Through Our Children’s Eyes
text: A friend of mine famously decided to go back to work when her young daughter announced one morning: “I go to school, Daddy goes to work. And Mommy goes to … gym.”

headline: Earth Week | The Moment Picks
text: Rough and Ready by Jill Singer

headline: Voters Like Cuomo’s Aggressiveness, Poll Finds
text: Within the New York political circles that he has traveled since his 20s, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has a well-earned reputation as a hard-driving and occasionally bare-knuckled political operator.

headline: A Return to the Scene of a Tragedy of Drama
text: A wispy breath of hope, an aftershock of anger, a lingering chill of regret. That’s about all of the ghosts of Tennessee Williams and Elia Kazan that materializes in “The Really Big Once,” an exploration of a failed collaboration between two one-time kings of American drama. But any lack of more full-bodied manifestations is not for want of wishing or willing by the spirit seekers who have gathered in the close quarters of the Ontological-Hysteric Theater.

headline: Bloomberg for Prime Minister!
text: Andrew Stuttaford on the unexpected rise of Nick Clegg, leader of Britain’s Liberal Democrats:

headline: In Deep Sea, Waves With a Familiar Curl
text: Scientists exploring the deep sea have discovered a distinctive kind of breaking wave. The finding reveals the presence of a subtle new force that can stir the dark seabed, and it helps to explain some of the nuances of planetary recycling and the provision of food to abyssal life.

headline: He Gazed, She Gazed, and They Danced
text: The idea of the male gaze has played a prominent role in much of Maria Hassabi’s recent work, which deals with sculptural, often extreme poses. In “Robert and Maria,” that gaze is finally embodied, courtesy of her collaborator Robert Steijn. And Ms. Hassabi is looking right back.

headline: Yes, This Manicure Is 12 Days Old
text: MANICURES aren’t known for being everlasting. They chip. They smudge. Sometimes a nail is ruined even before you get home from the salon.

headline: For Some Birds, It’s Not Always the Same Old Song
text: Songbirds are not born with songs in their heads, but learn them from others. And as in a game of telephone, it would seem natural that, over generations, the songs might change.

headline: Overview of an Artist’s Work Helps to Explore His Sounds
text: Sometimes cooperation between arts organizations pays off in unexpected ways. When Carnegie Hall announced its current Louis Andriessen series, Ronen Givony, one of the music directors at Le Poisson Rouge, decided to present an all-Andriessen concert at that Greenwich Village club around the same time. Mr. Givony mentioned the idea to Carnegie’s director of artistic planning, Jeremy Geffen, who encouraged him and listed Le Poisson Rouge’s all-Andriessen concert on the hall’s Web site, carnegiehall.org, as a ninth event in what was originally an eight-concert series.

headline: Sigh of Relief?
text: Inglot Cosmetics, a company from Poland, has a nail polish called O2M that it calls “breathable,” meaning that it allows oxygen and moisture to penetrate to the nail. This makes the polish something of an anomaly, since most brands don’t make this claim.

headline: Calculating Water Use, Direct and Indirect
text: How much water do you use every day?

headline: Celebrating 45 Years of Preserving New York
text: One question that came to mind on Monday was: Where were you on April 19, 1965?

headline: Composing Under the Radar for Orchestra and Imagination
text: Absolute declarations are a dangerous business, but it seems safe to say that Louis Andriessen is the world’s best-known living Dutch composer, maybe even the best-known Dutch composer, period. Mr. Andriessen, who now occupies the Richard and Barbara Debs Composer’s Chair at Carnegie Hall, has been one of the most influential figures in contemporary classical music since the mid-1970s, a point made by the American Composers Orchestra in a concert just over a week ago, kicking off a Carnegie Hall series in Mr. Andriessen’s honor.

headline: Cheek to Cheek (and Tongue-in-Cheek)
text: In the realm of popular culture, there are few more terrifying circumstances than dancing on live television. On an episode of “Dancing With the Stars” this season, Aiden Turner, a chiseled soap-opera actor who was recently voted off the competition, threw up backstage.

headline: Finding a Way to Stop Ricin in Its Deadly Path
text: Humanity has produced some lethal chemical weapons over the years, but nature is no slouch in that department, either. Among naturally occurring toxins, some of the most deadly are ricin, which is found in the beans of the castor oil plant, and Shiga-like toxins, which are produced from pathogenic E. coli bacteria. (With ricin the deaths have occasionally been intentional, which is why it is classified as a bioterror agent).

headline: 'American Idiot'
text: An excerpt from the title number of the new Broadway musical based on the music of Green Day. (Video courtesy of the production)

headline: Milan’s No. 10 on the Champions League Semis, Messi and Kaka
text: In his regular discussion with New York Times readers, Clarence Seedorf discusses the UEFA Champions League semifinals, some of the brightest stars of the international game, and whether or not he thinks doping is a major problem in international soccer. Read the AC Milan midfielder’s responses post your comments below.

headline: Democrats’ Banking Bill Struggles to Get G.O.P. Support
text: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner appealed on Monday to the centrist Republican senators from Maine for their support of legislation to tighten regulation of the nation’s financial system but came up empty-handed, leaving Democrats and Republicans on an apparent collision course.

headline: G.M. Is Said to Be Ready to Pay Off Its Government Loans
text: DETROIT — General Motors, hoping to build confidence in its turnaround and move toward becoming an independent public company again, plans to repay the balance of its government loans this week, a person with direct knowledge of the plans said Monday.

headline: Obama, Biden Will Attend Miners’ Memorial
text: President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will travel to West Virginia this weekend to mourn the 29 miners killed in an explosion earlier this month in the worst mining accident in the United States in four decades, the White House announced Monday.

headline: Apollo Agrees to Cut Some Fees for Calpers
text: Apollo Management agreed on Monday to concessions for its oldest and largest investor, Calpers, cutting its fees for certain funds and dropping the use of placement agents to gain business from the California pension fund.

headline: Doubts Grow About the Sale of Palm
text: Shares of Palm dropped 12 percent on Monday after analysts voiced doubts about the chances that the maker of smartphones and other hand-held devices would be able to sell itself its current market price. Palm’s stock price jumped last week after reports emerged that the company was seeking a buyer.

headline: Recession Adds to Appeal of Short-Term Jobs
text: NORCROSS, Ga. — Michael Sinclair knows that in a few months, his stint in the marketing department of a health care manufacturing company here north of Atlanta is set to end.

headline: Making It Easier to Eat Local Food
text: A recent Times article highlighted a growing problem for small farmers across the nation: too few slaughterhouses. Many farmers who have answered the demand for locally raised meat have been forced to scale back expansion plans because local processors can’t handle any more animals and the cost of driving their livestock hundreds of miles for slaughter is too expensive.

headline: A Candidate Makes an Asset of His Wall Street Past
text: ALBANY — Harry Wilson, a former hedge fund manager, has a novel idea for New Yorkers. Why not put a Wall Street veteran in the state comptroller’s office to oversee the $129.4 billion pension fund?

headline: Cleggmania Shakes Up British Election
text: Having stolen the show from the leaders of Britain’s two largest parties during a televised debate last Thursday, Nick Clegg, the leader of the Liberal Democrats, has seen his party surge in the polls to such an extent that he is suddenly at the center of what one British reporter is calling “the hysterical condition known as Cleggmania.”

headline: For Earth Day, 7 New Rules to Live By
text: On the 40th anniversary of Earth Day, is the middle-aged green movement ready to be revived by some iconoclastic young Turqs?

headline: ‘Berkus’ Lines Up Across the Country
text: “The Nate Berkus Show,” hosted by an Oprah Winfrey protégé, is cleared for a fall premiere.

headline: Obama Raises Funds for Boxer, D.N.C.
text: 10:18 p.m. | Updated President Obama flew to Los Angeles on Monday for a political cash run to help out one of his most embattled Democratic allies, Senator Barbara Boxer of California, and warned that she was in danger of losing her seat after 18 years.

headline: New Turkish Cypriot Leader Says Talks to Resume
text: ISTANBUL — The newly elected Turkish Cypriot leader, Dervis Eroglu, sought to quell fears on Monday that he would block United Nations negotiations to resolve the island’s status, saying that talks could resume as early as mid-May.

headline: What We’re Reading: Zooey, Geeks and Hipster Nerds
text: What the tech editors and reporters of The New York Times wanted others to be certain to read:

headline: 'Sondheim on Sondheim'
text: Vanessa Williams sings "Ah, but Underneath," a number written for the 1987 London production of "Follies," in an excerpt from the new Broadway musical about the work of Stephen Sondheim. (Video: Roundabout Theater)

headline: Embracing Silence in a Noisy World
text: What is silence? I am profoundly deaf in my left ear (I have a cochlear implant). The ear is useless for hearing, though it makes a pleasant decorative ornament and serves as a place to display earrings and anchor glasses; no sound can penetrate it. You would think that profound deafness is as silent as it gets. And yet it is not quiet in there. I hear deep space sounds, a hollow hum that washes in and fades away, changes in pitch and volume.

headline: New Ash Cloud Appears Headed Toward Britain
text: A new ash clouded appeared headed toward the United Kingdom, increasing the uncertainty about the return of air traffic to certain parts of the British Isles on Tuesday, the organization that controls air traffic in the area said.

headline: A Similar Terrain for Ants and Men
text: As a former jockey, Dick Francis set all his novels at the racetrack, so it may not be surprising that the biologist Edward O. Wilson has made his newly published first novel revolve around an arena he is familiar with, that of ants. The novel is even called “Anthill,” though the title also refers to busy milling about of the human kind.

headline: Pope Says He Faces Crisis With Cardinals’ Support
text: VATICAN CITY — Buffeted by a sexual abuse scandal that is quickly defining his papacy, Pope Benedict XVI marked the fifth anniversary of his election on Monday by telling a group of cardinals that he did not feel alone at the head of what he called a “wounded and sinner” church.

headline: Never Too Late to Get Started on Reading
text: Jahara Drammeh first thought about coming to America while watching the 1988 Eddie Murphy film “Coming to America.” He liked what he saw.

headline: Vaccines and Caregivers (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mood Is Dark as Israel Marks 62nd Year as a Nation
text: JERUSALEM — Every year, Israelis approach the joy of their Independence Day right after immersing themselves in a 24-hour period of grief for fallen soldiers. Before the fireworks burst across the skies Monday night to celebrate the country’s 62nd birthday, the airwaves filled with anguished stories of servicemen and -women killed, the Kaddish prayer of mourning and speeches placing the deeply personal losses of a small country into the sweep of Jewish history.

headline: The Patient’s Perspective (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The High Cost of Medicine (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Motivating Scientists (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Turning a Corner at Citigroup
text: How did Citigroup trounce JPMorgan and Bank of America? On Monday, Citi revealed that it earned $4.4 billion last quarter, its best showing in almost three years. The megabank headed by Vikram S. Pandit not only raked in more profit than its two closest competitors, it also generated a higher return on equity.

headline: Cyberattack on Google Said to Hit Password System
text: Ever since Google disclosed in January that Internet intruders had stolen information from its computers, the exact nature and extent of the theft has been a closely guarded company secret. But a person with direct knowledge of the investigation now says that the losses included one of Google’s crown jewels, a password system that controls access by millions of users worldwide to almost all of the company’s Web services, including e-mail and business applications.

headline: In the Mood to Clean? They Know
text: THE Madison Avenue marketing calendar is chockablock with holidays both official (Presidents’ Day, the Fourth of July, Christmas) and less so (St. Patrick’s Day, Cinco de Mayo, Halloween). Then there are commercialized occasions like back to school, during which consumers are encouraged to shop for more than a day’s worth of merchandise.

headline: Lawmakers Subpoena Administration Over Fort Hood
text: Top senators on the Homeland Security panel subpoenaed the Obama administration for information they said they need for their investigation into last year’s Fort Hood shooting.

headline: Turning to Teleconferencing as Air Travel Stalls
text: WITH air service still hobbled in Europe, government transport officials scrambled on Monday to hold an emergency meeting. But as anyone stranded in this mess knows well, it’s difficult to travel to, from or very far within Europe.

headline: Albany Candidates Back Nonpartisan Redistricting
text: The four major-party candidates running or expected to run for governor of New York have pledged to support nonpartisan, independent redistricting of legislative and Congressional seats next year — a change that state lawmakers have resisted for decades.

headline: Escape From the Jet Age
text: Chicago

headline: Goldman Employees Rally Around Blankfein
text: The message went out from Lloyd C. Blankfein: circle the wagons.

headline: President Nominates Professor to Health Job
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday nominated Dr. Donald M. Berwick, a health policy expert, to be administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, which runs health programs insuring nearly one-third of all Americans.

headline:
A Finance Overhaul Fight
Draws a Swarm of Lobbyists
text: WASHINGTON — Assessing the battle to overhaul the nation’s financial regulations recently, Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, left no doubt about the consequences if Congress cracked down on his bank’s immense business in derivatives.

headline: Green Ready for His Return, Whether His Game Is or Not
text: Ken Green will take a swing at getting back to a normal life on Friday in Savannah, Ga. Slightly more than 10 months after the traffic accident that killed his brother and his girlfriend and led to the amputation of his right leg below the knee, Green will try out his newly reconstructed golf game on the Champions Tour.

headline: Gambling With the Economy
text: WHILE the Securities and Exchange Commission’s allegations that Goldman Sachs defrauded clients is certainly big news, the case also raises a far broader issue that goes to the heart of how Wall Street has strayed from its intended mission.

headline: Riders on the Storm
text: In 2001, Cass R. Sunstein wrote an essay in The Boston Review called “The Daily We: Is the Internet really a blessing for democracy?” Sunstein, a professor at the University of Chicago who now serves in the Obama administration, raised the possibility that the Internet may be harming the public square.

headline: The Court, Money and Politics
text: Advocates for unlimited campaign contributions  especially corporate contributions  are hoping the Supreme Court will blow another huge hole in the campaign finance law.

headline: Before Gay Marriage Fight, Clashes on Free Speech
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Airline Shuttles Smaller but Still Flying Hourly
text: The airline shuttles that operate between New York, Boston and Washington have been downsized, as fewer executives traveled those routes in the recession.

headline: Verdict on Long Island
text: A jury in Suffolk County, N.Y., has found Jeffrey Conroy guilty of manslaughter as a hate crime, after he fatally stabbed an Ecuadorean immigrant, Marcelo Lucero. Whatever solace the conviction brings to Mr. Lucero’s family, the shame for Suffolk County’s law enforcement and political leadership remains.

headline: Bloggingheads: How Risky Is Nuclear?
text: John Horgan, left, of the Stevens Center for Science Writings and George Johnson, author of “The Ten Most Beautiful Experiments,” debate the dangers of nuclear power.

headline: If Doormen Strike, Residents Must Pick Up the Slack
text: A possible strike this week by the doormen’s union could impose — by necessity — a spirit of cooperation in New York City’s co-ops and other apartment buildings.

headline: Final Report from the Lab
text: There’s time for one more debate here, about my Earth Day column, but first an announcement: After three years of experiments, TierneyLab is shutting down. I’ll still be testing ideas in my Findings columns and in other articles for The Times, and you can keep up with them by following me on Twitter. You can also keep trying the weekly math puzzle at its new home starting next Monday at The Times Wordplay blog.

headline: A Receiving Prospect Has His Mother in His Corner
text: AVENTURA, Fla. — One day during his sophomore season at the University of South Florida, Carlton Mitchell pulled on a pair of sweat pants that had once belonged to the boxer Antonio Tarver, a family friend.

headline: Debate on Internet’s Limits Grows in Indonesia
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Displeased that a statue of a 10-year-old Barack Obama was installed in a park here, Indonesians took their protest not to this capital’s most famous traffic circle but to Facebook. More than 56,000 online protesters later, city officials gave in to arguments that the park should be reserved to honor an Indonesian.

headline: Justices Get Personal Over Privacy of Messages
text: WASHINGTON — The question in a case argued Monday in the Supreme Court sounded both irresistible and important: Did a California police department violate the Constitution by reading sexually explicit text messages sent by an officer on a department-issued pager?

headline: Optimism, Then a Victory, After Arrival of Davis
text: If it had been a normal night, the highlight of the Mets’ game Monday would have been the two-run home run by Angel Pagan that broke a seventh-inning tie and sparked a 6-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

headline: When Wall Street Deals Resemble Casino Wagers
text: The government’s civil fraud case against Goldman Sachs raises so many provocative questions.

headline: N.J. Voters Asked to Pay More for Less at Schools
text: EDISON, N.J. — School budget talks have become so contentious in this township that 700 people recently packed a school board meeting — and 100 of them stayed more than nine hours, until 4 a.m.

headline: For Apple, Lost iPhone Is a Big Deal
text: For anyone who has ever lost a cellphone, remember this: it could be worse. You could be the person who left his phone in a bar in California. And it wasn’t just any phone; it was a supersecret version of the next iPhone. That model is not expected to be formally unveiled for a couple of months.

headline: You’re Welcome, Wall Street
text: In a 1964 concurring opinion deciding Jacobellis v. Ohio, Associate Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart wrote about “hard-core pornography” and his struggle to define it: “Perhaps I could never succeed in intelligibly doing so. But I know it when I see it.”

headline: Europe to Ease Aviation Ban, Amid Criticism
text: PARIS — European transport ministers announced a plan to begin easing the ban on aviation traffic around the Continent by Tuesday, but only after a barrage of criticism that the European Union had failed a fresh test of leadership.

headline: Two Dead in Tennessee Hospital Shooting
text: A gunman fatally shot a woman and injured two others before killing himself outside a hospital in Knoxville, Tenn., the police said.

headline: Trial Opens for Ex-Officer Accused of Shoving Bicyclist
text: It was a clear evening two summers ago when two young men crossed paths in Times Square.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 19, 2010

headline: Sleeping (or Not) by the Wrong Clock
text: Fine tuning the body’s internal clock through chronotherapy can bring relief to those with sleep disorders.

headline:
Lehman Examiner to Testify That S.E.C.
Sat on Its Hands
text: WASHINGTON — The court-appointed examiner who dissected the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy is expected to criticize the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday for its decision to “stand by idly” as the investment bank veered toward collapse.

headline: With Plenty of Problems, Mets Check One Off Their List
text: Jerry Manuel spoke Monday about the perils of promoting an acclaimed prospect after the season had begun. The more he talked, the more you wondered why the Mets ever held back Ike Davis.

headline: A Difficult Path in Goldman Case
text: WASHINGTON — In accusing Goldman Sachs of defrauding investors, regulators are not only taking aim at a company with deep pockets and a will to fight — they are also pursuing an unusual claim that could be difficult to prove in court, legal experts said.

headline: Do the Math
text: Last fall, Michelle Rhee, the tough-minded and creative schools chancellor in Washington, laid off 266 teachers, citing a budget crunch. She has since reported finding a budget surplus. The city’s teachers’ union, which challenged the layoffs unsuccessfully last fall, has now asked a judge to review them again. The atmosphere has grown increasingly toxic.

headline: Mexico’s First Lady Quietly Takes Strong Stance
text: MEXICO CITY — When Margarita Zavala, the wife of Mexico’s president, is reminded that newspapers here all ran front-page photographs of her attending a recent memorial service for two university students killed in drug violence, she frowns just slightly.

headline: Cancer Fight: Unclear Tests for New Drug
text: Dr. Linda Griffith was at a conference in Singapore in early January when she felt a lump in her breast. She assumed it was nothing — a cyst. And anyway, she had no time for it. She was returning on a Sunday night and the next Tuesday morning was leaving for a conference in Florida.

headline: Iran, Sanctions and the Memo
text: Sometime this spring, but still months later than President Obama predicted, Iran may finally face new United Nations sanctions for its illicit nuclear program.

headline: Reyna Has Lesson Plan for U.S.
text: Let’s clear up a couple of urban legends at once.

headline: Small Child, but a Big Passport Headache
text: ON one of my very first business trips, I was fortunate enough to have my wife accompany me to Paris. We were young and didn’t have a lot of money. So this was an incredible treat. My son was only 3 months old, and since he was nursing, he came along, too.

headline: Insurers See Millions in Claims by Travelers
text: The travel insurance industry is generally paying claims to travelers stranded in Europe and elsewhere by the drifting Icelandic volcanic ash, treating it mostly as a weather-related event in their policies, industry officials said. Some said the claims were expected to total millions of dollars.

headline: Two Stars to Stay on Comedy Central Through 2012
text: With Conan O’Brien about to change the calculus of late-night cable programming, the Comedy Central channel has made a move to lock up its two dominant stars, Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert.

headline: Obama Raises Money in California for Barbara Boxer
text: President Obama flew to Los Angeles on Monday for a political cash run to help out one of his most embattled Democratic allies, Senator Barbara Boxer of California, and warned that she was in danger of losing her seat after 18 years.

headline: First Top Scorer Leaves Rutgers, Then the Coach
text: When Mike Rosario won a New Jersey state title with his St. Anthony High School teammates in March 2008, he ran off the court at the Louis Brown Athletic Center at Rutgers and past Scarlet Knights Coach Fred Hill.

headline: Scary, Baby, Ginger, Posh and Sporty
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — The old joke at 1 Across put me in a good mood from the get-go, a feeling that lasted through the rest of the puzzle. It’s a nice Tuesday theme and a good solve from a name we’ve been seeing a lot of recently, Paula Gamache.

headline: College Conferences Ponder Expansion, and Their Extinction
text: With the 11 Football Bowl Subdivision conference commissioners gathering in Scottsdale, Ariz., on Tuesday for the annual Bowl Championship Series meetings, the prospect of significant change in the collegiate conference landscape is becoming increasingly likely.

headline: When It Comes to Volcanic Ash, Airline Procedure Is Clear: Avoid
text: Last year, when the Mount Redoubt volcano blew up southwest of Anchorage, Alaska Airlines’s response was to ground its fleet, divert flights and wrap the engines in the parked planes in plastic.

headline: Where a Greedy Wall Street Villain Would Feel Right at Home
text: Bankers who have spent two decades quoting Gordon Gekko’s sayings — or what they remember Gekko saying — like “Greed is good” and “Lunch is for wimps” hope to lap up more of his insights when the sequel, “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps,” comes out this fall.

headline: Maternal Deaths
text: To the Editor:

headline: Beyond the Mining Tragedy: Safety for All Workers
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Uproar Over Goldman Sachs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nude Art at MoMA
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Effort to Limit C-Sections, Two Methods Yield Different Results on Staten Island
text: This is a tale of two hospitals.

headline: Police Close Sister Clubs, M2 and Pink, in Chelsea
text: The thousands of party people who every night pack the M2 UltraLounge in Chelsea, one of the largest and busiest clubs in the city, will have to go somewhere else for a while: the Police Department shut it down on Friday.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Friday with a Washington Memo article, comparing the concerns over nuclear attacks during the cold war with the fear of terrorist attacks today, reversed the identities of two of the three senators shown observing a Geiger counter demonstration in Washington in 1950. The senators, from left, were: John W. Bricker, William F. Knowland and Brien McMahon  not Brien McMahon and William F. Knowland. Numerous readers alerted The Times to the error, which was traced to the original picture in the newspaper’s archives. The incorrect identities also appeared in some copies on March 18, 1950.

headline: Jefferson Has Yet to Pay Off for Spurs
text: DALLAS — Shortly before his playoff debut with the San Antonio Spurs, Richard Jefferson discussed his newfound serenity after a bumpy introduction to Spurs basketball. A critical factor, he said, was Coach Gregg Popovich’s recent decision to allow him to play the entire first quarter.

headline: Law Banning Blasphemy Is Upheld in Indonesia
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia’s Constitutional Court ruled 8 to 1 Monday that a controversial 45-year-old law banning religious blasphemy was constitutional.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about ideas for travelers trying to cope with disruptions caused by a volcanic ash cloud from Iceland misstated the number of flights that pass over the North Atlantic in a 12-hour period. It is 900 to 1,200 flights  not 9,000 to 12,000.

headline: Alan Cumming Drops Out of ‘Spider-Man’ Musical
text: The actor Alan Cumming has withdrawn from the long-delayed Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” because of a scheduling conflict, a spokesman for the show confirmed on Monday night.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about the rate of mail responses to the 2010 census referred incorrectly to a decades-long decline in participation by mail. It was reversed by the 2000 census, so this year’s could not do so.

headline: Immigration Bill Reflects a Firebrand’s Impact
text: PHOENIX — The Arizona Senate passed one of the most stringent immigration laws in the country on Monday, marking a new level of influence for a Republican state senator who not long ago was seen by many as an eccentric firebrand.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about efforts to save Edwin H. Armstrong, the father of FM radio, from undeserved obscurity misspelled the surname of an emeritus professor at Columbia University who raised funds to get Armstrong’s archives organized. He is Mischa Schwartz, not Schwarz.

headline: Pressured in Senate Race, Crist May Leave G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida, facing pressure from fellow Republicans to abandon his Senate campaign, said Monday that he would not allow party leaders in Washington to push him from the race and declared that he was considering running for the seat as an independent.

headline: U.S. Speaks to Syrian Envoy of Arms Worries
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Monday summoned the ranking Syrian diplomat in Washington to register concern about accusations that Syria transferred arms to the radical Islamic group Hezbollah. The Israeli government accused Syria last week of funneling long-range Scud missiles to Hezbollah militants in Lebanon, a charge the Syrian government has denied.

headline: Corrections
text: The Critics’ Choice column on April 12, about new CDs, including “Shame, Shame” by Dr. Dog, misidentified the band member who sings, “I do believe that there’s no more tricks up my sleeve/The good old days are past,” on the album’s first song, “Stranger.” He is Toby Leaman, not Scott McMicken.

headline: Corrections
text: A music review last Tuesday about a concert presented by Issue Project Room at the Old American Can Factory in Brooklyn misidentified the neighborhood in which the Factory is located. It is Gowanus, not Carroll Gardens.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture credit on Thursday with the Books of The Times review, about “The Great Oom: The Improbable Birth of Yoga in America” by Robert Love, using information from the publisher, misspelled the given name of the photographer who took the picture of Mr. Love. She is Nichol Hlinka, not Nicole.

headline: Corrections
text: A jazz entry in the Listings pages on Friday about Apex, featuring Rudresh Mahanthappa and Bunky Green, at the Jazz Standard in Manhattan, misidentified Mr. Green’s home base. While he lived in Chicago for nearly 30 years, he has been director of jazz studies at the University of North Florida in Jacksonville for the last two decades. Chicago is no longer his home base.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Corrections
text: A caption on March 16 for a grouping of four photographs with an article about new research on thalidomide described the bottom two photographs incorrectly. These pictures of a zebrafish and chick embryo showed the result of exposing the embryos to both thalidomide and a protein that blocked the creation of deformities. They did not show deformities induced by thalidomide and the protein. The error was pointed out by e-mail the day the article ran; this correction was delayed for research.

headline: Pakistan: President Gives Up Expanded Powers
text: President Asif Ali Zardari signed into law legislation that would strip the president of expanded powers acquired under previous military governments, such as the authority to dissolve the Parliament and to appoint the head of the military. The legislation, known as the 18th amendment, gives many of the powers to the prime minister and restores Pakistan to a parliamentary democracy. Mr. Zardari retains extraordinary influence as the leader of the governing political party.

headline: Wrongful-Death Lawsuit Over Rapper Is Dismissed
text: Adding perhaps a final twist to one of the longest-running and most contentious cases of celebrity justice, a federal judge in Los Angeles has dismissed an eight-year-old wrongful-death suit filed against the city by the family of the rapper Notorious B.I.G.

headline: A State Holiday Tailored for Sports Fans
text: BOSTON — While most of the country went about business as usual on Monday, the third Monday in April here is an official state holiday, one that brings together a cacophonous mix of distance running, baseball and Revolutionary War role playing.

headline: Alejandro Robaina, Grower for Top Cuban Cigars, Dies at 91
text: Alejandro Robaina, Cuba’s most revered tobacco grower, whose leaves wrap the country’s finest Habano cigars, died Saturday at his home near San Luis. He was 91.

headline: Robert Pound, Physicist Whose Work Advanced Medicine, Is Dead at 90
text: Robert Pound, a Harvard physicist whose experiments provided the first laboratory confirmation of Einstein’s general theory of relativity and helped pave the way for the age of magnetic resonance imaging, died on April 12 in Belmont, Mass. He was 90.

headline: Mapping Out a Route to the Final in Europe
text: Iceland has no teams in the semifinals of the UEFA Champions League, the Europa League or the Women’s Champions League, but all three competitions have been or will be affected by the torrent of ash and particles from the country’s Eyjafjallajokull volcano, which has disrupted travel and commerce in Europe for nearly a week. (Travel problems could also have an effect on a European futsal tournament and Thursday’s scheduled Women’s World Cup qualifier between the Netherlands and host Macedonia.)

headline: Encouraging Start for the Ike Davis Era
text: After the first game of Ike Davis’s career, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel said his new first baseman seemed unfazed, without the anxiety you sometimes see in first-time major leaguers.

headline: Photographers Prepare for a Moment in May
text: Update, May 17 | It is now possible to search the “Moment in Time” interactive gallery by the name given in the photographer’s credit line (actual name, pseudonym or screen name, as the contributor chose). You’ll find the search box in the upper right corner of the opening page. If you believe your picture wasn’t posted, we urge you to give this a try.

headline: Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert to Stay on Comedy Central Through 2012 Election
text: With Conan O’Brien about to change the calculus of late-night cable programming, the Comedy Central channel has made a move to lock up its two dominant stars, Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert.

headline: Rule Change Takes Aim at Loophole in Title IX
text: The Department of Education will no longer allow universities to rely solely on student surveys to prove they are meeting the requirements of the gender-equity law known as Title IX, a reversal of a Bush administration policy that had been opposed by the N.C.A.A. and women’s sports advocates.

headline: In M.V.P. Race, There’s No Debate
text: Voting concluded last week for the N.B.A.’s postseason awards. Although The New York Times does not permit its reporters to vote, the N.B.A. reporters Howard Beck and Jonathan Abrams are making their picks in Off the Dribble. This is the most valuable player discussion.

headline: Word of the Day | scaffold
text: scaffold •\ˈska-fəld also -ˌfold\• noun and verb

headline: Hoover Commercial
text: A commercial from a new campaign for Hoover aimed at consumers doing spring cleaning.

headline: Fantasy Island
text: WHERE is Governors Island?

headline: News Quiz | April 20, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Suit Charges Elderly Gay Partners Were Forced Apart
text: Clay M. Greene’s story, as recounted in his recent lawsuit against Sonoma County, is a tale of loss, doubled and redoubled. For gay men and lesbians, the series of events outlined in the complaint hits very close to home.

headline: When Wall Street Deals Resemble Casino Wagers
text: Why was Goldman Sachs, or any regulated bank, allowed to create and sell a product like the synthetic C.D.O. at the center of the government’s case? What purpose does a synthetic C.D.O. — which is a bet on the value of a bundle of mortgages that the investors didn’t even own — serve for the capital markets, and for society?

headline: Britain Opens Its Airspace as Travel Crisis Begins to Ebb
text: LONDON — After six days of mostly closed skies, Britain abruptly lifted a ban on flights late on Tuesday as thousands of passengers stranded by a plume of volcanic ash began to make their way home after Europe’s worst peacetime aviation crisis.

headline: Goldman Employees Rally Around Blankfein
text: The message went out from Lloyd C. Blankfein: circle the wagons.

headline: For Former Thai Premier, Exile but Not Irrelevance
text: BANGKOK — Thaksin Shinawatra is angry. “This is the worst political accusation I ever had,” Mr. Thaksin, a former prime minister, said Tuesday in a message delivered by a spokesman — sent, as always, from an undisclosed location abroad.

headline: A Finance Overhaul Fight Draws a Swarm of Lobbyists
text: Assessing the battle to overhaul the nation’s financial regulations recently, Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, left no doubt about the consequences if Congress cracked down on his bank’s immense business in derivatives, Edward Wyatt and Eric Lichtblau report in The New York Times.

headline: In Harry Wilson’s War, Wall St. Could Be an Asset
text: Harry Wilson, a former hedge fund manager, has a novel idea for New Yorkers. Why not put a Wall Street veteran in the state comptroller’s office to oversee the $129.4 billion pension fund?

headline: Generation R
text: British workers who kept their jobs during the recession but took on more responsibility for the same pay.

headline: Lowenstein: Gambling With the Economy
text: From Roger Lowenstein at The New York Times’s Opinion Pages:

headline: Banking Bill Struggles to Get G.O.P. Support
text: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner appealed on Monday to the centrist Republican senators from Maine for their support of legislation to tighten regulation of the nation’s financial system but came up empty-handed, leaving Democrats and Republicans on an apparent collision course.

headline: Here Come the L.B.O.’s
text: Public companies have quickly become leveraged-buyout targets again. The five “take private” deals of at least $500 million announced since February outnumber the four completed in all of 2009. The surprise return of such acquisitions signifies a marked change from the acrimony that surrounded the last round of private equity deals, Reuters Breakingviews says.

headline: SPS Commerce Eyes $26 Million I.P.O.
text: SPS Commerce is planning to raise $26 million in an initial public offering this week, The Associated Press reported.

headline: A Difficult Path in Goldman Case
text: In accusing Goldman Sachs of defrauding investors, regulators are not only taking aim at a company with deep pockets and a will to fight — they are also pursuing an unusual claim that could be difficult to prove in court, legal experts said, Binyamin Appelbaum reports in The New York Times.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Store? Why?
text: “For Eddie Feibusch, a Life in Zippers” tells the story of 86-year-old man who has owned a New York City store called ZipperStop since 1941. (“Nobody makes them better,” he says.) What’s your favorite store? Is it small and quirky and unique, like this one, or is it a store that’s in every mall? Tell us what you like about it with as much colorful detail as you can.

headline: Platinum Taps ING Portfolio Manager as President
text: A top portfolio manager at ING will be is set to become the new president of Platinum Partners, a $500 million boutique hedge fund, InvestmentNews reported.

headline: Griffin to Quit Tisbury for GLG
text: GLG Partners, the London-based hedge fund, will soon be joined by Gerard Griffin, founder and manager of the former $2.75 billion fund, Tisbury Capital Management, which he is shutting down, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: DynaVox Aims to Raise $150 Million in I.P.O.
text: DynaVox, which makes special-education software and devices for people who are unable to speak, is looking to raise about $150 million in an initial public offering this week, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Another $20 Million for BlackArrow
text: BlackArrow, a maker of advertising technology designed to target on-demand audiences, has landed $20 million in a third round of financing, led by NDS Group, Paid Content reported.

headline: Big Brokerages Lost Market Share, Study Finds
text: The four biggest brokerage companies dominate the American wealth management space, but independent and regional firms have been catching up since they gained clients and assets after the 2008 downturn, Reuters reported.

headline: Drop in Commodity Prices Pushes Indexes Down
text: Worries about the effect of government efforts to strengthen oversight of banks faded somewhat on Monday, helping Wall Street indexes to end the day mostly higher.

headline: Groupon Gets $135 Million From D.S.T.
text: Groupon, the social commerce site, has landed a hefty $135 million round from Facebook backer Digital Sky Technologies.

headline: Greek Bailout Unconstitutional, Report Says
text: The Greek bailout as currently proposed may run afoul of European Union rules, the Center for European Policy, a policy research organization, said Monday, as Greece struggles to refinance its mountain of debt despite European Union assurances of support.

headline: Scientific Games Scores Sceptre Leisure Solutions
text: Scientific Games, the gaming equipment maker, said Monday that it had bought Sceptre Leisure Solutions‘ assets, which include 751 server-based gaming terminals and related contracts for £3.8 million ($5.8 million), The Associated Press reported.

headline: Calpers to Examine Goldman Practices
text: The chief investment officer of California’s giant pension fund said Monday he was disturbed by the allegations of wrongdoing against the investment firm Goldman Sachs, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Paulson Said to Buy 13% of American Capital
text: 10:47 a.m. | Updated The billionaire investor John A. Paulson is buying about a 13 percent stake in American Capital, the business development company, as it gets a much-needed capital infusion to restructure debt, sending its shares up 14 percent, Reuters reported.

headline: Turning a Corner at Citigroup?
text: How did Citigroup trounce JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America?

headline: Terra Firma Said to Plan Asking More of Investors
text: Guy Hands, head of Terra Firma, has his feet on the ground — whether he wants them there or not — but he’s got highflying plans.

headline: Kirk Returns Goldman Cash in ‘Example on Ethics’
text: Goldman Sachs‘s problems with the Securities and Exchange Commission are spilling over into the United States midterm elections.

headline: The Real Problem? Wall Street Doesn’t Get Wall Street
text: That most investors couldn’t fully comprehend the the complex and exotic financial instruments Wall Street created and sold during the boom years is now considered a given.

headline: F.S.A. Investigating Goldman Sachs
text: 6:03 a.m. | Updated The Financial Services Authority, Britain’s financial regulator, said Tuesday it had opened a formal investigation into Goldman Sachs in relation to recent accusations that the firm had defrauded investors, Julia Werdigier reports in The New York Times.

headline: ABN Amro’s Path to Credit Derivatives, and Disaster
text: ABN Amro, one of two banks cited by the Securities and Exchange Commission in the Goldman Sachs case as buying credit derivatives that soon went sour, came to those bets late in the game, according to an in-depth article in Het Financieele Dagblad, the Dutch financial daily.

headline: A Few Draft Sleepers Who Could Jolt the N.F.L.
text: Matt Waldman is a staff writer at Footballguys.com, where he writes The Weekly Gut Check and authors The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a 740-page film evaluation of 170-plus rookie prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

headline: Hong Kong Rappers to Reunite in Macao
text: Lilting Mandarin Chinese, the mainland’s official language, is an ideal tongue for love songs. But the stop-start Cantonese dialect spoken in Hong Kong and neighboring Guangdong is perfect for another lyrical style — rap. One celebrated group that specializes in the latter is LMF.

headline: Netflix Founder Acquires Online Education Start-Up
text: Reed Hastings, the founder and chief executive of Netflix, used the Web to make it easier for us to rent movies. Now Mr. Hastings, who is also a former high school math teacher, is using the Web for a less entertaining, more educational cause — teaching math to children.

headline: A Home Library’s Educational Edge
text: Today’s idea: Home libraries, and the fostering of learning they represent, correlate with extra years of educational attainment and better odds of finishing college, a study says.

headline: British Regulator Opens Goldman Inquiry
text: LONDON — The Financial Services Authority, Britain’s financial regulator, said Tuesday that it had opened an investigation into Goldman Sachs in relation to recent accusations in the United States that the firm defrauded investors.

headline: Goldman Posts $3.46 Billion 1st-Quarter Profit
text: 8:01 a.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Nelson D. Schwartz provides more details about the financial results at Goldman Sachs.

headline: A Tale of Many Cities
text: An economist looks at why an unlikely mathematical formula seems to predict population patterns — and affirms the value of proximity.

headline: Goldman’s Earnings Fail to Shift Focus From Case
text: On Wall Street, the numbers usually speak for themselves.

headline: Nissan to Begin Firming Up Leaf Reservation List
text: More than 115,000 Americans have gone on the Internet and registered their interest in the 2011 Nissan Leaf battery electric car, and beginning Tuesday the company will begin trying to move those electronic tire-kickers onto the more select reservation list. The price to get on the waiting list for the first round of cars is $99, which is refundable if you buy a Leaf or opt out of the program.

headline: Sampler: Breach of Google Passwords, and Cash for Old Appliances
text: Hackers Breached Google’s Password System | Google disclosed in January that Internet intruders had stolen information from its computers. Now, a person with direct knowledge of the investigation has told John Markoff of The New York Times that the company’s password system was breached. The program, known as Gaia for the Greek goddess of the earth, allows users to sign in once to operate a range of services. It was attacked last December. The hackers do not appear to have stolen Gmail users’ passwords, and the company quickly beefed up security. But the theft leaves open the possibility that hackers can find other weaknesses, according to independent computer experts. [The New York Times]

headline: Happy Christmas in July: ‘Mad Men’ Returning This Summer
text: When we last saw the scheming, self-loathing advertising executives of “Mad Men” they had just orchestrated a Christmas coup, as Don Draper, Bertram Cooper, Roger Sterling and their newfound frenemy, Lane Pryce, bailed on their former agency to start their own shop. So what’s in store for Season 4? Did Don and Betty pull the plug on their marriage? Have we seen the last of Sal Romano, and has little Sally Draper conquered her lisp? Will Pete and Trudy Campbell dance again?

headline: With Chorus Stuck in Russia, Philharmonic Amends Stravinsky Programs
text: 12:40 p.m. | Updated The rumblings of an Icelandic volcano continue to be felt as far away as New York, as the travel restrictions in Europe forced by volcanic ash have required the New York Philharmonic to make changes to its Stravinsky-themed programming that starts this week. The Philharmonic said on Tuesday that the Mariinsky Theater Chorus of St. Petersburg would be unable to perform in the “Russian Stravinsky” festival concerts planned for Wednesday and Thursday. As a result, the Philharmonic will offer all-orchestral programs on those nights, which will still be conducted by Valery Gergiev; “Jeu de Cartes” will be performed in place of “Les Noces.” The rest of the programs on those nights, including Symphonies of Wind Instruments and “The Firebird,” are not affected. The “Russian Stravinsky” festival runs through May 8.

headline: N.F.L. Donates $1 Million for Brain Studies

headline: After Repairs, a Picasso Returns
text: To the untutored eye little is different about “The Actor,” the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s rare Rose Period Picasso, other than that it is now safely behind plexiglass. It’s virtually impossible to tell that on a January afternoon a woman taking an adult education class accidentally fell into the canvas, causing a six-inch vertical tear along the lower right-hand corner.

headline: Are You the Favored Parent?
text: One of the books on my bedside table is “The Favorite Child” by the psychologist Ellen Weber Libby; an examination of the taboo subject. Parents are not supposed to “love” one child more, though every so often a survey comes along hinting that many do. Libby goes so far as to say that “there are favorite children in every family” with lifelong consequences for every family member.

headline: Green Thinking | A Loomstate State of Mind
text: “A Barneys girl likes a sexy tee, so we wanted to give her an organic option,” says the store’s fashion director and eco-crusader, Julie Gilhart, of Barneys’ Earth Day collaboration with Loomstate. “We wanted to do a blank T-shirt with a sexy fit like Alexander Wang or the Row, and we wanted to make it all organic but affordable, too.” The deep-V design, which sells for $40 (for the 40th Anniversary of Earth Day), comes in your usual New Yorker hues — namely, black, white and gray — but also in the colors of the NBC peacock. Gilhart, it turns out, is also one of the headliners for Christie’s’ first ever “green” auction, A Bid to Save the Earth, and NBC has signed on as a media sponsor. The live auction on April 22, which benefits the N.R.D.C., the Central Park Conservancy, Oceana and Conservation International, includes such fashionable prizes as lunch with Vera Wang — plus a $10,000 shopping spree at her flagship store — and a fitting with Stella McCartney for bespoke his and hers suits. For Gilhart, creating such fashion synergy is all in a day’s work: “We just thought, Hey we’re all on the same page, so let’s get together.”

headline: The Canadian Example
text: If you want to feel dispirited about America’s fiscal situation, read Tyler Cowen’s weekend column, which argues persuasively that the American public’s mistrust of government and our cynicism about political elites will actually make spending cuts harder to achieve. If you want to feel really depressed, though, first ponder his example of how a more statist, socially cohesive country cut spending successfully, and then try to imagine the same scenario playing out in America:

headline: Putting Taliban Sniper Fire in Context
text: A video and a blog post here on Monday presented a closer look at Taliban snipers, who were an unusual factor in the fighting in Marja this year. To understand the role that Taliban snipers have — or have not — played in the larger Afghan war, a look with more sweep is necessary. Afghanistan is a sprawling place, and the insurgency operates in some ways like a complicated syndicate, with varied groups and leaders in different parts of the country loosely collaborating with one another on some matters but not at all on others. So how significant have Taliban snipers been over all in the larger war? How much of a threat have they posed?

headline: Media Cycle | Bikes We Like
text: Mayor Bloomberg has been so kind as to install 200 bike-lane miles in the five boroughs. Why not explore them on a snazzy new bike? headline: A Location App That Cures Oversharing
text: The problem with popular apps that tell your friends where you are, like Foursquare, Brightkite and Latitude, is they also inform people who are not your friends where you are — or aren’t. A  Web site called “Please Rob Me” republished such alerts to point out that telling a network of people where you are, tells burglars where you are not – protecting your home.

headline: Ashes to Airlines: Examining the Effects of a Volcanic Eruption on Our Global Community
text: Overview | How can some local events have global consequences? What lessons can we learn from the eruption of the Eyjafjallajokull volcano in Iceland about the fragility of our interconnected world? In this lesson, students examine how the eruption has illuminated how connected we are and how fragile our global web may be. By collating stories of people, businesses and organizations affected by the eruption on a world map, students create a visual representation of the wide-reaching effects of the eruption.

headline: Hungry Goats on Council Agenda in Oakland
text: The Oakland City Council will probably approve on Tuesday night a $250,000 payment to some goats and their human and canine herders. The financing, which is on the Council’s consent calendar, is for fire-prevention services in 2008 and 2009 from a company based in Dixon called Ecosystem Concepts. The goats hope to be back chewing up the vegetation on the Oakland hills again this spring.

headline: Larry David Searches Soul, Finds Nothing and Plans Return to ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’

Recreate Andy Kaufman’s notorious appearances on his short-lived 1980s comedy “Fridays”? We’ll find out in due time: on Tuesday, HBO announced that it was ordering another season of “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” on which Mr. David plays a dyspeptic fictionalized version of himself.
