text: Red Hook Lobster Pound, which has been bringing fresh lobsters south from Maine, will soon exhaust its drivers even more, offering lobster rolls in Washington, D.C., and its suburbs.

headline: Clip: 'Food Jammers'
text: In "Food Jammers," one of shows on the upcoming Cooking Channel, Micah Donovan, Christopher Martin and Nobu Adilman build unusual cooking contraptions.

headline: Local Food for Local Diners in Durham
text: In a part of North Carolina where tobacco was once king, the new focus is on area producers and restaurants.

headline: Samurai Shopper | The Impossible Cream
text: In a perfect world, everything we eat would be clean, fresh, healthy and delicious. Every beauty product available would use extracts from the finest sources, formulated by artisans with profound botanical and pharmacological knowledge. We would never suffer the heartbreak of psoriasis, acne, or any dermatological catastrophe brought on by something ingested or applied.

headline: Transit Cuts Are Protested in Atlanta
text: ATLANTA — When Danielle White boarded her bus to go to work on Tuesday morning, it was emblazoned from top to bottom with a giant, painted red X. Ms. White knew what that meant.

headline: Shoved Cyclist Admits He Was Poor Driver
text: The man who was pushed from his bicycle by a police officer two years ago admitted in court on Tuesday that he had struck and killed a pedestrian with his car nearly a decade ago when he lived in North Carolina.

headline: The Obamas Didn’t Snub the Boy Scouts
text: Last week, we published a list of nonprofit groups that received donations from the Obama family in 2009. They gave to the Girl Scouts but not to the Boy Scouts.

headline: Financial Tuneup: Walk Someone Through Your Files
text: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, we’ve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

headline: McCain’s Tough Stance on Arizona Immigration Bill
text: Updated: PHOENIX — When Senator John McCain broke his silence Monday on his home state’s tough, new immigration enforcement bill, some immigrant advocates wished he had kept quiet and worried that he was backpedaling on what had been one of his signature bipartisan issues.

headline: Travel Insurance and the Volcano
text: Some guidance on what volcano-related costs travel insurance will and won’t cover from the president of the US Travel Insurance Association. Read more.

headline: Making Noise
text: A London friend, his travels delayed by “the cloud,” noted this morning the remarkable blueness of the sky minus jet trails, and he wondered, too, if the city was less noisy. That may change on Thursday, when the funeral procession for Malcolm McLaren is expected to travel from Camden Town to Highgate Cemetery. Mr. McLaren’s son, Joe Corre, has asked that people create some “mayhem for Malcolm” at midday by playing something loud for one minute. The funeral should be a spectacle to observe. Among those planning to attend are Vivienne Westwood, who was Mr. McLaren’s partner during the 1970s, and her husband, Andreas Kronthaler.

headline: Food Network Spinoff Announces Its Lineup
text: Allen Salkin has the details, and some background on the rationale for the new Cooking Channel. Although the Food Network has been a ratings powerhouse, even some insiders apparently feel it has become a little bland. One internal study from 2007 concluded that Food Network executives “tend to see the current FN brand as friendly, approachable and middle of the road — though sometimes to a fault. Most would like to see the brand infused with more passion, excitement, drama and entertainment.”

headline: A Novel Argument for Girls’ Education
text: Greetings from South Sudan, where at the moment I’m in Marial Bai, visiting the school started by a “lost boy” named Valentino Deng. Over the course of talking to local people about customs, I learned that people typically pay a huge “bride price” here to the parents of a girl whom their son marries. This is often 100 head of cattle — a huge sum in a poor area.

headline: What Next, the Official Salad Dressing of ‘Sex and the City 2’?
text: It seems that not a day goes by without news of another marketing partnership for “Sex and the City 2,” due from the New Line Cinema unit of Warner Brothers on May 27. First, there was Skyy vodka. Last week, there was Moët & Chandon Champagne, followed by Lipton Sparkling Surprise tea.

headline: Parenting an Autistic Adult
text: When we talk about autism (which we are doing often during Autism Awareness Month), we tend to talk about children and ways that their parents can help. But children grow, and the parents of autistic children become parents of autistic adults, a role that is less defined and less discussed. In a guest blog today, Laura Shumaker,  author of “A Regular Guy:Growing Up With Autism,” describes one weekend with her grown son Matthew, navigating the changing rules one interaction at a time.

headline: Bush War Crimes Play Coming to Off Broadway
text: A new play that imagines President George W. Bush on trial for war crimes has been added to the lineup of the “Americas Off Broadway” festival at 59E59 Theaters in Manhattan, theater executives said on Tuesday. The festival runs from April 28 through July 3.

headline: IPhonegate: Lost, Stolen or a Conspiracy?
text: 10:30 a.m. | Update Fixed a link to the Guardian Technology blog and corrected Charles Arthur’s title.

headline: What You Get for ... $975,000
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Did U.S. Miss an Early Warning on Toyota Acceleration?
text: Late in 2003, an investigator for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration concluded that the newly adopted drive-by-wire gas pedals of Toyota Camrys might be a cause of unintended acceleration.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iceland and Elsewhere
text: While the rest of the world concerns itself with the airborne residue of Iceland’s volcano, farmers there are trying to cope with the ground-level aftermath. As The Associated Press reported on Sunday, in “Iceland’s Farmers Try to Save Herds From Toxic Ash,” they are “scrambling to protect their herds from inhaling or ingesting the ash, which can cause internal bleeding, long-term bone damage and teeth loss.” On Monday, The Boston Globe’s Big Picture blog prepared a striking album, “More From Eyjafjallajokull.”

headline: Goldman Fails to Shift Focus From Fraud Case
text: On Wall Street, the numbers usually speak for themselves. But for Goldman Sachs, even a blockbuster earnings report on Tuesday failed to shift attention away from the fraud accusations leveled last week by the Securities and Exchange Commission, Nelson D. Schwartz of The New York Times reports.

headline: Your Jokes: ‘Don’t Trust Washington’
text: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: Goldman Inquiry Comes at Key Time for British Regulator
text: LONDON — Hector Sants, the chief of Britain’s financial regulator, pledged last year to reverse his agency’s reputation as a toothless tiger. He wanted to spread fear across the financial services industry by stepping up the aggressiveness of its inquiries and by pursuing more prominent fraud cases.

headline: Eco Chic | Wasara Paper Bowls
text: Believe it or not, there’s a line of disposable tableware that you won’t want to throw away, let alone get wet. The Japanese company Wasara has a line of sculptural plates, bowls and cups made from a thin composite of bamboo, reed and sugarcane waste that looks and feels like something you’d find at Ted Muehling.

headline: Somali Pirates Hijack Vessels 1,200 Miles Offshore
text: A band of Somali pirates hijacked three Thai fishing boats and captured 77 sailors in an attack more than 1,200 miles offshore in the Indian Ocean, the European Union naval force said on Tuesday. The attack on Sunday was closer to India than Somalia, said John Harbour, a European Union spokesman, and was “the furthest east we are aware of since we started operations” in December 2008. The three fishing boats are now heading toward a notorious pirate den on the Somali shore. Somali pirates have made millions of dollars in recent years hijacking vessels and holding them ransom despite increased naval patrols. JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

headline: Jets Sign Jason Taylor to Improve Pass Rush
text: Nearly three weeks after April Fool’s Day, Jason Taylor decided Tuesday to accept a two-year contract with the Jets. In related news, the Hatfields dealt for a McCoy.

headline: War of Words Regarding the Financial Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — Hoping to seize on populist fury on a day when Goldman Sachs reported blockbuster earnings, Senate Democrats on Tuesday sought to portray Republicans as siding with wealthy Wall Street interests in opposing tougher financial regulations.

headline: Testing the iPad’s Trip-Worthiness
text: IF you plan on vacationing in the near future, you should be ready to share an airplane ride with at least a few preening iPad owners. Whether you should succumb to gadget envy or not depends on just what type of traveler you are.

headline: Son of Michael Douglas Is Sentenced
text: Cameron Douglas, the 31-year-old son of the actor Michael Douglas, was sentenced to five years in prison on drug-related charges in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Tuesday.

headline: Carbonated Comedy
text: Video | Way back when, Phil Hartman had a Billy Mays-like soda pitch:

headline: An Interview With Dorothy Height
text: In a January interview with The Times's Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Dorothy Height discussed race, her own life and President Obama.

headline: A 19th-Century Landmark in Newfoundland
text: The building, near the harbor, is a Registered Heritage Structure in Newfoundland and Labrador.

headline: Corrections
text: The DealBook column on Tuesday, about the possibility of the government’s making a profit on its bailout of banks, overstated the position of the economists Paul Krugman and Nouriel Roubini, at the height of the financial crisis, on nationalizing banks. While both supported guaranteeing the liabilities of the banking industry and a temporary government takeover of certain failing institutions, they did not recommend nationalization of the entire banking system.

headline: House Hunting in ... Newfoundland, Canada
text: A 19TH-CENTURY THREE-BEDROOM THREE-AND-A-HALF-BATH HISTORIC HOME WITH WATER VIEWS IN ST. JOHN’S

headline: Update: ‘Ferris Bueller’ Ferrari Sold
text: A replica 1961 Ferrari 250GT California Spyder used in the film “Ferris Bueller’s Day Off” fetched $122,000 at Bonhams in London on Monday, far exceeding the auction house’s pre-sale estimate of $45,000 to $60,000.

headline: Which Grease for a Squeaky Wheel?
text: WD-40, the 52-year-old brand of household lubricant, emphasizes versatility to consumers, with its Web site listing more than 2,000 ways that customers say they have used the product, like “cleans magazine for an AK-47” and “cleans peanut butter from shoestrings.” One recent print ad proclaimed it “The jack-of-all-trades’ trade secret” while another, for a new nonaerosol pump spray, promised, “More versatility, more control, same WD-40.”

headline: New Victory Theater’s ‘Elephant’ Canceled This Weekend
text: The New Victory Theater on Tuesday canceled the start of performances this weekend for “Elephant,” a work that blends African song, tribal dance and puppets — including life-size elephant puppets — because the show’s 12-member cast and crew have been unable to fly from Britain because of the volcanic ash cloud.

headline: Best Nonholiday Quarter for Apple
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The mobile computing revolution unleashed by Apple three years ago with the release of the iPhone is picking up speed, and Apple is reaping the rewards.

headline: Vintage Acapulco Revival
text: Despite recent violence, Acapulco continues to reclaim its retro-glamour – this time at a midcentury modern hotel that appeared in the 1963 film with Elvis Presley, “Fun in Acapulco.”

headline: Anatomy of a Number: 'American Idiot'
text: The director Michael Mayer narrates a look at the title number from the new musical "American Idiot," based on the music of Green Day.

headline: Fla. Senator Named by Crist Is in a Bind
text: The increasing flirtation by Florida Gov. Charlie Crist with running for the Senate as an independent rather than a Republican, is creating an awkward situation for Senator George S. LeMieux, the governor’s former chief of staff, top political adviser and handpicked Senate placeholder.

headline: MCC Theater Delays ‘Family Week’
text: MCC Theater’s production of “Family Week,” which marks the Off Broadway directing debut of the filmmaker Jonathan Demme, will delay its opening night by one week, the theater announced on Tuesday, as Mr. Demme and the playwright Beth Henley continue working on the show.

headline: Little Green Men and Flying Saucers Are So Passé: New Ideas About Aliens
text: The scientific project known as SETI  the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence  began in earnest 50 years ago, when an astronomer named Frank Drake pointed a radio telescope toward a few nearby stars and began to sift through the aural static. A half-century later SETI has matured and remains a bustling enterprise, even though it no longer receives government financing and even though E. T., if he’s out there, does not appear to have Earth on his speed dial.

headline: Cooper Union President to Retire Next Year
text: George Campbell Jr., the president of Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, announced on Tuesday that he would retire next year, capping a decade in which he raised the profile of the college and stabilized its finances.

headline: 'Someday Melissa' Trailer
text: Judy Avrin chose an unusual way to deal with her daughter’s death from bulimia. She made a documentary about it.

headline: Lehman Examiner: Fuld Probably Knew of Repo 105
text: The examiner in the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy, Anton R. Valukas, told Congress on Tuesday afternoon that his investigation had found evidence that Richard S. Fuld Jr., the firm’s former chief executive, was aware of an accounting technique that helped Lehman mask billions of dollars worth of troubled assets on its books.

headline: How a Man of Words Heard Music
text: A musical about Langston Hughes? Why not? He, too, sang America, making his poems, like the songs he heard on the street, “gay songs, because you had to be gay or die; sad songs, because you couldn’t help being sad sometimes,” as he wrote in his memoir “The Big Sea.”

headline: A Market for Red Hook
text: A seasonal outdoor weekend market will open on Van Brunt Street, the main drag of Brooklyn’s once-barren Red Hook neighborhood. Called Red Hook Mercado, for the Spanish word for market, it will include the open-air cooking of some of the vendors who cater to the weekend crowds at the Red Hook ball fields, as well as other well-known food vendors.

headline: Surrendering to the Role, Not to Illness
text: After wrapping her last full season on the NBC series “ER” in May 2008, the actress Maura Tierney placed a phone call that would prove prophetic.

headline: ‘The Eerie Silence’
text: Chapter 1: Is Anybody Out There?

headline: Take Me – and My Tires and Lawn and Cellphone – Out to the Ball Game
text: When it comes to the 2010 All-Star Game and advertisers, Major League Baseball is not content with a single or a double. It’s going for a triple. (Or perhaps, in variance with the rules of the game, a triple-header.)

headline: White House Responds to Ex-Counsel’s Aid to Goldman Sachs
text: The White House offered a tepid response Tuesday to word that President Obama’s former White House counsel is now representing Goldman Sachs as the giant financial firm responds to allegations that it defrauded investors.

headline: Fabulous Dead People | Rudi Gernreich
text: Rudi Gernreich (1922-1985) is a great example of how far we haven’t come. Forty-six years after he introduced the monokini, public beaches in America are still scrubbed clean of naked breasts. Women who want to seem enlightened and “European” but are no more likely to air their chests than install a dance pole in their basements are lucky. The law gives them cover. Impress your friends! Keep your clothes on! It’s never been easier.

headline: Is Apple’s Spell Wearing Off?
text: Gizmodo’s unmasking of the fourth-generation iPhone has set off a maelstrom of activity around the Web: conspiracy theories are running rampant and scores of sideline observers, like myself, are riveted by the events unfolding on their screens.

headline: A Concrete-and-Glass Town House in Barcelona
text: Luis Alonso, an architect, tore down an "architecturally uninteresting" 100-year-old building to build his narrow six-story home.

headline: The Model Whisperer
text: The Sports Illustrated model is bent in downward-dog position, feet planted in a wide V. Each Asics resting on a gliding disc, she slides first her right foot across and beneath her torso, then repeats the motion with her left foot. Someone who did not know better might imagine Irina Shayk was playing Twister, that goofy ’60s game involving a spinner and a vinyl polka-dot floor mat. But working out is no more a game for someone in Shayk’s line of work than it would be for a professional athlete. In a business where a pert behind and firm inner thighs are career requisites, more models are moving away from body-shaping routines built on a diet of Moët & Chandon and Marlboro Reds and doing something their predecessors assiduously avoided: hitting the gym.

headline: In Miami, Condo Sales Rise as Prices Bottom Out
text: MIAMI — Though it overlooks the Atlantic Ocean and offers high-end amenities like a wine vault and a cigar humidor, the Caribbean condominium complex in Miami Beach seemed by last summer to be just another casualty of the glutted South Florida housing market.

headline: A Hunt for the Perfect Bathroom, in the Name of Film
text: Brooks Branch urgently needed to find a toilet. Not for himself, for Timothy Hutton.

headline: A Switch for the Google Age
text: 4:19 p.m. | Updated  One of Arista’s competitors offered a comment on Arista’s  plans.

headline: War of Words Flares Up in Senate Over Financial Bill
text: Seizing on the populist fury over the government bailouts of big banks, Senate Democrats stepped up their efforts to portray Republicans as siding with wealthy Wall Street interests in opposing legislation to tighten regulation of the nation’s financial system, The New York Times’s David M. Herszenhorn and Edward Wyatt report from Washington.

headline: Campaign Against British ‘Fascists’ Heats Up
text: In the wake of a scandal over some outlandish expenses claimed by members of the British Parliament, which soured many voters on politicians from the country’s two largest parties, several smaller parties are hoping to pick up seats in the new Parliament that will be elected on May 6.

headline: Brookfield Won’t Change Its General Growth Offer
text: Brookfield Asset Management of Canada told General Growth Properties on Monday that it won’t change its investment offer for the bankrupt mall operator, potentially setting up a battle with the Simon Property Group at federal court hearing next week.

headline: Sisters Open a Pie Shop in Brooklyn
text: Pie-making is in the DNA of Melissa (at center in photo) and Emily Elsen (at left). Their grandmother baked pies for their mother’s restaurant in Hecla, S.D., and it was from her that they learned their craft. And now, after a year of baking pies for a growing list of clients, they have opened a bakery and cafe in Gowanus, Brooklyn. There’s an open kitchen in the rear of the whitewashed store, rustic tables and chairs in front of the counter, and restored decorative touches, like patterned pressed tin.

headline: Now Online | Patrik Ervell
text: “The predominant aesthetic in American men’s wear right now is old-timey,” Patrik Ervell says. “And that irritates me. Actually, the whole industry is anachronistic.” Not one to sit around and grouse, Ervell, who has stuck to a modernist aesthetic since starting his line two years ago, has put his money where his ideals are by opening his first store — online. “I thought, What’s the most modern way of presenting your brand to your customer? The traditional idea is to have a beautiful shop on a street in Paris. That may work for Chanel, but it doesn’t make any sense for a young brand.”

headline: Britain Opens Airspace
text: Britain reopened its airspace Tuesday evening as British Airways said a flight had arrived at London’s Heathrow Airport, an indication that the worst of the air traffic crisis plaguing Europe may be coming to an end.

headline: How to Rack Up $20,000 Worth of Sushi (Tip Not Included)
text: The $20,000 worth of sushi that State Senate Majority Leader Pedro Espada Jr. is accused of having bought with money siphoned from a nonprofit he founded is probably a blur to him now.

headline: Celebrating a World of Happy Endings
text: A gilded fantasy of an American Camelot flickered over Carnegie Hall on Friday evening as the New York Pops presented “The Best of Lerner and Loewe,” a greatest-hits anthology of beloved show tunes. Frederick Loewe’s sweeping Old World melodies, sung by Kelli O’Hara and Paulo Szot, the lovebirds of the “South Pacific” revival, joined by the tenor Michael Slattery, conjured a bygone era of romantic nobility.

headline: Democrats Outpace G.O.P. in Recent Fund-Raising, but Republicans Claim Momentum
text: Congressional Republicans are enthusiastic about their performance in the all-important midterm money chase. But the Democratic House and Senate campaign committees still managed to out-raise the Republican organizations last month and have more cash in the bank even though Republicans claim the momentum.

headline: White House Tepid as Ex-Aide Joins Goldman Defense
text: From Peter Baker at The Caucus:

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Dinner Theater

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings

headline: Rustic Polenta From a New York Farm
text: Rustic, coarse-grained polenta from upstate New York is giving Anson Mills in South Carolina some competition for the favor of chefs. The variegated mixture from Wild Hive Farm has real character.

headline: Korean Beef Jerky From a Family Recipe
text: Preparing beef jerky is not what most Koreans consider home cooking. But Robert Kim was lucky to have had a grandmother who made her own and passed along her recipe. He started making it with a dehydrator in his kitchen in Armonk, N.Y., instead of sun-drying eye round of beef the old-fashioned way.

headline: No. 7 Sub
text: TYLER KORD may be the Willy Wonka of submarine sandwiches.

headline: Durham, a Tobacco Town, Turns to Local Food
text: Durham, N.C.

headline: In Los Angeles, Jidori Chicken Is the New Kid in the Coop
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Roast Chicken With Root Vegetables and Verjus Beurre Blanc
text: Adapted from Josiah Citrin, Mélisse, Santa Monica, Calif.

headline: Has Trust Leaked Away With the Tritium?
text: 12:11 p.m. | Updated  Fixed broken link to Beyond Nuclear report.

headline: Music in Review
text: ORION STRING QUARTET

headline: Clip: 'Food Jammers'
text: In "Food Jammers," one of shows on the upcoming Cooking Channel, Micah Donovan, Christopher Martin and Nobu Adilman build unusual cooking contraptions.

headline: Volcano Causes Changes in Classical Concerts
text: The rumblings of an Icelandic volcano continue to be felt far away, as travel restrictions in Europe forced changes to classical music programs in Manhattan. The New York Philharmonic said on Tuesday that the Mariinsky Theater Chorus of St. Petersburg would be unable to perform in the “Russian Stravinsky” festival concerts planned for Wednesday and Thursday. The Philharmonic will now offer all-orchestral programs on those nights, which will still be conducted by Valery Gergiev; “Jeu de Cartes” will be performed in place of “Les Noces.” The rest of the programs, including Symphonies of Wind Instruments and “The Firebird,” are not affected. The “Russian Stravinsky” festival runs through May 8. Lincoln Center said on Tuesday that its “Great Performers” recital featuring the Armenian brother and sister musicians Sergey (violin) and Lusine Khachatryan (piano) scheduled for Wednesday had been canceled because of the flight restrictions. Lincoln Center said the concert would not be rescheduled, and that refunds or exchanges were available through its customer service department.

headline: Brooklyn Festival Grows
text: The real estate firm Two Trees Management is expanding the Dumbo Arts Festival in Brooklyn, adding a greater diversity of programming to a mix that already includes visual art and performances. The festival will now be organized by a variety of arts professionals, rather than solely by the Dumbo Arts Center, which founded it. The festival, entering its 14th year, will run Sept. 24-26 and will take over that waterfront neighborhood’s galleries, stores, performance spaces and studios. Two Trees  led by David C. Walentas and his son Jed  owns most of Dumbo along with properties in Downtown Brooklyn, Brooklyn Heights, Cobble Hill and Boerum Hill.

headline: Bravo Developing ‘Approval Matrix’ Show
text: Aiming for the highbrow brilliant quadrant, the Bravo cable channel is developing a show based on New York magazine’s “Approval Matrix,” a grid that charts cultural moments based on the admittedly subjective tastes of its editors. If it goes forward, “The Approval Matrix” would be a weekly series with four guests debating where on the matrix to place newsmakers and events. (Presumably they would include some of Bravo’s housewives and designers.) The matrix  with highbrow, lowbrow, brilliant and despicable quadrants  is well known to magazine readers. The show is “meant to be a dissection of the week in culture,” said Michael Hirschorn, one of the show’s executive producers. “It’s a way to gather some smart people in a room and have a fun cocktail-party-type conversation about the week.”

headline: Susan Boyle’s Story in Her Own Words
text: Her exterior masked a singing voice that took the Internet and the music industry by storm, so could Susan Boyle, below, also be concealing a prose style to rival Jane Austen’s or Virginia Woolf’s? The British publisher Transworld is willing to make that bet and has signed up Ms. Boyle, the reality television-turned-recording star, to write her autobiography, BBC News reported. Transworld said the book, which will be called “The Woman I Was Born to Be,” will document Ms. Boyle’s sudden rise after her 2009 appearance on “Britain’s Got Talent,” which led to her best-selling debut album, “I Dreamed a Dream.” A British release is planned for the fall; no American publication date has been announced. In a statement reported by the BBC, Ms. Boyle said she was “writing this book to try to show that you shouldn’t judge a book by its cover.” She added: “When I strutted on to the stage for that audition, I was a scared wee lassie, still grieving for my mother, not caring how I looked. I think I’ve grown up a lot in the last year, become more of a lady, and I’m not so frightened anymore.”

headline: Production Suspended on Next Bond Film
text: You can call him Bond  James Bond  but don’t bother calling him at the office, because Agent 007 is being suspended from duty. The producers of the James Bond film franchise, which since 1962 has yielded 22 movies adapted from or inspired by Ian Fleming’s stories, said they were halting work on a 23rd Bond film while they awaited the possible auction of MGM, the studio that releases the movies. In a statement reported by Reuters, the producers Michael Wilson and Barbara Broccoli said, “Due to the continuing uncertainty surrounding the future of MGM and the failure to close a sale of the studio, we have suspended development on Bond 23 indefinitely.” The last two movies in the franchise, “Casino Royale” (2006) and “Quantum of Solace” (2008), which starred Daniel Craig, right, as Bond, sold a total of nearly $1.2 billion in tickets worldwide.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Sets Summer Return Date
text: When we last saw the scheming self-loathing advertising executives of the hit drama “Mad Men” they had just orchestrated a Christmas coup as Don Draper, Bertram Cooper, Roger Sterling and their newfound frenemy, Lane Pryce, bailed on their former agency to start their own shop. So what’s in store for Season 4? Did Don and Betty pull the plug on their marriage? Have we seen the last of Sal Romano, and has little Sally Draper conquered her lisp? Will Pete and Trudy Campbell dance again? AMC isn’t saying much about the new season of “Mad Men,” but on Tuesday that cable channel announced that new episodes would start on July 25.

headline: Another Deal on Jackson, With Cirque
text: Michael Jackson is getting the Cirque du Soleil treatment.

headline: What’s in a Label? Say It in French
text: ALL the hot girls are going berserk for Isabel Marant, the young Frenchwoman whose label has mastered the jet-set bohemian look associated with carefree Parisian chicks: that thrown-together, cigarette-hanging-from-pouty-mouth style that pretends to shrug off effort. “Quoi, this? Pfff. I slept in this shirt, you silly child, and these pants were on the floor.”

headline: Ensemble Examines Runaways and Poetry
text: Trendy ensembles that play accessible, eclectic new music get most of the attention (and listeners) these days, but you have to admire groups like the New York New Music Ensemble for continuing to champion the more rigorous end of the contemporary repertory. These are musicians for whom sharp-edged themes, complex rhythms and dense harmonies hold no terrors, and they usually make the works they play, however thorny, sound fresh and vital.

headline: Stomping Onto Broadway With a Punk Temper Tantrum
text: Rage and love, those consuming emotions felt with a particularly acute pang in youth, all but burn up the stage in “American Idiot,” the thrillingly raucous and gorgeously wrought Broadway musical adapted from the blockbuster pop-punk album by Green Day.

headline: A Fairy Tale Stripped to the Bones of Beastliness
text: “It’s like the Oscars of the burlesque and performance art world!” burbled a woman in the audience at “Beauty and the Beast” at the Abrons Arts Center on Monday night. “Like, everyone is here!”

headline: Properties for $975,000
text: A former firehouse in San Francisco, a three-bedroom in Austin, Tex., and a carriage house in Charleston, S.C.

headline: Interpublic and MDC Settle Lawsuit
text: Five days after word began circulating about a lawsuit pitting advertising agencies against each other, the lawsuit has been settled.

headline: An App That Pays
text: Most smartphone apps come in two varieties: those you pay for and those that are free. Now here’s one that pays you to use it.

headline: Paris Sweets | Ceci N’est Pas un Macaron
text: As macarons make their way across the pond from France to New York, there has been a twee treats exchange: in various branché districts of Paris, le cupcake est arrivé. It’s not unlike New York City’s cakelet rush of the early aughts, though here, “Sex and the City” is only partly to blame. (Since the show came to French TV in 1999 and has run almost ever since, les filles have loved their Carrie, but many of the new bakers have come through the United Kingdom.) Last year, Synie’s Cupcakes opened in tony Saint-Germain, and in Abbesses, the Paris neighborhood that most resembles Magnolia Bakery’s West Village, there are not one but two new spots peddling the goods: Miss Cupcake, run by the 30-something ex-London-dweller Laurence Kreitmann, situated in the crook of the tiny rue Vieuville; and on the rue Lepic, the second outpost of Berko, a bakery destined to miff any New Yorker for its epitaph (“Original Cupcake”) and its prices — two euros for a cake about one-fourth the size of your average Buttercup Bakery wares.

headline: SHO Shaun Hergatt
text: SOME restaurants are time machines. SHO Shaun Hergatt, the strange and occasionally terrific restaurant on the second floor of a condominium building in the financial district, even looks like one, down to the elevator that whisks you up from the lobby.

headline: Cuomo Accuses Espada of Diverting Millions From Clinics
text: ALBANY — Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo filed a civil lawsuit against the Senate majority leader, Pedro Espada Jr., on Tuesday, accusing Mr. Espada, his family and his political aides of siphoning more than $14 million from a network of nonprofit health care clinics he founded — money used for meals, vacations and campaign expenses.

headline: All He Had Was a Slingshot and Itchy Feet
text: Mehreen Jabbar’s lyrical film “Ramchand Pakistani” tells the story of an 8-year-old Pakistani Hindu boy who accidentally strays across the border with India and is immediately seized by Indian soldiers. Based on a true story, it begins in 2002 during a period of extreme tension between Pakistan and India and explores what can happen to innocents caught up in geopolitical crossfire.

headline: It’s SHO Time
text: Sam Sifton reviews SHO Shaun Hergatt.

headline: Lorena Ochoa to Retire at 28
text: Lorena Ochoa, the top-ranked player in women’s golf and one of the L.P.G.A.’s biggest stars, announced Tuesday that she was retiring from professional golf. She said she would discuss her decision and her plans at a news conference Friday.

headline: Portraying the Man Known as Dr. Death
text: In the HBO film “You Don’t Know Jack,” there is something both familiar and unsettling in the man’s visage when it first comes into view. It’s hard to place precisely, but after taking in the obstinate rhetoric, the throwback glasses and the wan smile, we think we know this guy. Oh yeah, Dr. Death, the man with the mortally friendly bedside manner.

headline: What’s Missing in the Financial Rules Bill?
text: President Obama will be in New York on Thursday to lobby for the Democrats’ effort to overhaul financial regulations, as Senator Christopher Dodd, the chairman of the banking committee and sponsor of the legislation, and Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner try to gain the support of centrist Congressional Republicans for the measure.

headline: In Barcelona, Six Stories of Glass
text: BARCELONA  Luis Alonso wanted to build a town house inspired by glass, air and concrete. But when he explained the idea to his New York-born wife Denise Mermelstein, she couldn’t picture his vision, even when he brought home a model. With the amount of transparency and empty space the structure promised to encompass, the plans were nearly impossible to read. But she gave the nod anyway, taking a giant leap of faith.

headline: Nomura’s Meissner to Join BofA Merrill
text: Christian Meissner, a high-ranking investment banker at Nomura, has left the Japanese firm to join Bank of America Merrill Lynch as its head of investment banking for Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

headline: Regents Plan New Route to Master’s in Teaching
text: The New York State Board of Regents voted unanimously on Tuesday to approve a pilot program that would allow educational groups like Teach for America to create their own master’s degree programs, a role long reserved for education schools.

headline: Former Mayor of Hoboken Pleads Guilty to Corruption
text: He was not the one accused of human organ trafficking, nor the money-laundering rabbi. No, in the sprawling corruption sting that shook New Jersey last year, what marked Peter J. Cammarano III, then the mayor of Hoboken, was the spectacle of a promising career blown apart almost before it started.

headline: Broadway, Now Firmly in Her Grasp
text: THE last few days of March were the most nerve-racking of Sherie Rene Scott’s acting career. After trying unsuccessfully through the fall and winter to move her critically acclaimed Off Broadway musical, “Everyday Rapture,” to Broadway, she was emotionally raw and awash in self-doubt when, out of the blue, she learned that Roundabout Theater Company was considering her show as a last-minute replacement for its scuttled Broadway production of “Lips Together, Teeth Apart.”

headline: Lawyer Says Concerns About Domestic Violence Prompted Separation of Gay Partners
text: 1:39 p.m. Pacific Time | Updated

headline: Country in Another Dimension
text: The country singer Kenny Chesney has worked awfully hard to earn the title his press kit confers: “the most popular live music act of the 21st century.” Mr. Chesney’s tours sold more than a million tickets in each of the last eight summers, and now he’s tired. Taking this year off, at least from the biggest stages, he offers in his stead “Kenny Chesney: Summer in 3D,” culled from six 2009 stadium shows.

headline: 25 Years for Leader of Argentine Dictatorship
text: BUENOS AIRES — A special tribunal on Tuesday sentenced Argentina’s last military president to 25 years in prison and handed down stiff sentences to six other former military and police officials for their part in running a concentration camp during this country’s bloody dictatorship.

headline: Texas Town Adjusts to Life Without Bush
text: CRAWFORD, Tex. — The first thing you see when you arrive in this minuscule town is a defunct curio store where people once bought souvenirs of their visit to President George W. Bush’s adopted hometown.

headline: Democrats Top G.O.P. in Fund-Raising for Midterms
text: Congressional Republicans are enthusiastic about their performance in the all-important midterm money chase. But the Democratic House and Senate campaign committees still managed to out-raise the Republican organizations last month and have more cash in the bank even though Republicans claim the momentum.

headline: Friends in Avian Form
text: In the novel documentary “The Red Birds,” the director Brigitte Cornand imagines 14 of her female artist friends in avian form. Matching voices to species  like the whiskey tones of Louise Bourgeois to the distinctive cardinal  she layers interview fragments over rustic images of flocking and flying.

headline: Keeping His Spies Close, and Maybe a Cartel Closer
text: SAN PEDRO GARZA GARCÍA, Mexico — Perhaps only in Mexico could the mayor of a wealthy suburb run his own intelligence operation, complete with confidential informants inside organized crime and a network so formidable that he can announce the murder of a major mobster before law enforcement officials have even found the body.

headline: What We’re Reading: Apple Leaks
text: What the tech editors and reporters of The New York Times were reading Tuesday:

headline: A Look at Woods’s TV Presence
text: Tiger Woods’s presence during the first round of the Masters on ESPN was dominant — from his live tee shot on “SportsCenter” to his starring role when continuous coverage of the round began that day at 4 p.m. Eastern.

headline: How to Regulate the Internet Tap
text: “TRANSPARENCY is non-negotiable,” declared Europe’s new commissioner for digital issues, Neelie Kroes, in a speech last week laying out her thoughts on net neutrality. “In a complex system like the Internet, it must be crystal-clear what the practices of operators controlling the network mean for all users.”

headline: N.F.L. Gives $1 Million to Brain Researchers
text: Researchers at the Boston University School of Medicine’s Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy have decided that the N.F.L.’s offer of support is what they had hoped: $1 million, and zero strings.

headline: Farewell to Korengal
text: LAST week the United States military pulled out of the Korengal Valley in eastern Afghanistan. Six miles long, sparsely populated and of dubious strategic value, the Korengal was the scene of some of the most relentless fighting of the Afghan war. American forces have been there in one form or another since the summer of 2005, when Taliban fighters cornered a four-man Navy Seal team on a nearby mountain and killed three of them. They then shot down a Chinook helicopter with 16 commandos on board. All of them died.

headline: Bloomberg Said to Rely on Financier Under Fire
text: Steven L. Rattner, the financier under increasing scrutiny in a state and federal kickbacks investigation, is playing a key role in creating a new investment firm that will manage Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s fortune and finance his philanthropic foundation, according to three people told of the arrangement.

headline: Rookie Sparks the Mets. Not Him, the Other One.
text: All the hubbub over the successful major league debut of Mets first baseman Ike Davis on Monday night obscured another positive development: a good outing by another rookie, starter Jon Niese, in a 6-1 victory over the Cubs.

headline: Our $48 Billion Credit Card Bill
text: Washington

headline: Ex-Adviser to Obama Now Lawyer for Goldman
text: WASHINGTON — Word that President Obama’s former White House counsel, Gregory Craig, is now representing Goldman Sachs led the administration on Tuesday to say that it had no advance knowledge of the move and to distance itself from any suggestion that Mr. Craig might try to lobby the government on behalf of the investment firm.

headline: Dispute Flares After NATO Convoy Kills 4 in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A NATO military convoy in eastern Afghanistan shot to death four unarmed civilians in a vehicle early Monday evening, including a police officer and a 12-year-old student, Afghan officials said Tuesday.

headline: China: Street Crime Sweep in Shanghai
text: As part of a crackdown ahead of the coming World Expo in Shanghai, police officers have detained about 6,000 people in the city suspected of street crimes like theft and prostitution, China Daily, an official English-language newspaper, reported on Tuesday. The crackdown, involving 30,000 officers, lasted from April 3 to 14 and was the fourth of its kind in less than two months. The sweep took place around the park where the World Expo is scheduled to be held in May. Dozens of foreigners were also detained, some on charges of being in China illegally or using drugs.

headline: F.D.A. Is Urged to Set Limits for Levels of Salt in Food
text: High levels of salt in supermarket and restaurant foods should be declared unsafe by the federal government, according to a new report that called on the Food and Drug Administration to mandate maximum levels of sodium in food.

headline: Somalia: Off Again, on Again Radio
text: Two radio stations in Somalia were shut down by the transitional government on Tuesday because they had stopped broadcasting music after threats from Islamist insurgents, but the stations were allowed back on the air hours later. The quick turnaround appeared to expose a difference of opinion in the government, which had earlier warned of shutdowns. Security agents had ordered the stations closed Tuesday, but the Information Ministry, citing the freedom of the press, countermanded the orders. Islamic insurgents had demanded the stations stop playing music because they deemed it un-Islamic. The warning about music is part of a broader assault on the influence of Western culture and ideology that the Islamists fighting the government hope to purge from the country.

headline: Bill to Give Washington a Vote Stalls
text: WASHINGTON —  The House will not vote this week — or probably even this year — on legislation that would grant the District of Columbia a voting representative in Congress, Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, the House majority leader, said Tuesday.

headline: USA Swimming Outlines Plan to Stop Misconduct
text: USA Swimming’s beleaguered board of directors, contending with the fallout from two high-profile cases that sent veteran coaches to prison for sexual misconduct, convened an emergency teleconference Sunday night. They devised a seven-point plan to address the issue of coaches’ taking advantage of their young athletes.

headline: Ralph Snodsmith, 70, Gardening Expert, Is Dead
text: Ralph Snodsmith, who as the longtime host of the Sunday morning radio show “The Garden Hotline” offered homey, often chuckle-inducing advice to callers nationwide wondering when to plant a particular biennial or how to properly prune, died on Saturday in Fredericksburg, Va. He was 70 and lived in Stafford, Va.

headline: Fiat’s Changes to Include Installing 34-Year-Old Scion at the Helm
text: The Fiat Group on Tuesday announced a shake-up of its board that would elevate the young scion of the founding Agnelli dynasty to the head of the Italian automotive giant.

headline: Senate Bill Sets a Plan to Regulate Premiums
text: WASHINGTON — Fearing that health insurance premiums may shoot up in the next few years, Senate Democrats laid a foundation on Tuesday for federal regulation of rates, four weeks after President Obama signed a law intended to rein in soaring health costs.

headline: The Dandelion King
text: As I’ve told my neighbors, I feel bad about lowering the value of their property. I mean, it isn’t my goal to have a front yard that, by standard reckoning, is unattractive. The unkept look of my lawn is just a byproduct of a conclusion I reached a few years ago: the war on weeds, though not unwinnable, isn’t winnable at a morally acceptable cost.

headline: Reform and Massachusetts
text: Four years after Massachusetts enacted its ambitious health care reform, the state has achieved its goal: covering most of the uninsured without seriously straining its budget. Most citizens seem to like it.

headline: New Hate-Crime Murder Trial, This Time in Brooklyn
text: A taxi driver testified on Tuesday that he had a clear view when an Ecuadorean immigrant was fatally beaten in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn — a killing that prosecutors said was motivated by hate.

headline: Title IX, Back on Track
text: For those of us old enough to remember, school sports used to be all about the boys. In 1972, Congress passed Title IX, which outlawed gender discrimination in educational programs and activities receiving federal financing, including school sports, at all levels.

headline: In Ex-Officer’s Trial, Defense Took a Big Detour, but the Video Didn’t
text: No matter how many times they played the videos in court on Tuesday, from whatever angle, the story remained the same: A young police officer named Patrick Pogan deliberately shoved a man off his bicycle as he rode through Times Square one night in July 2008. And contrary to the police charges, the videos show that the rider did not ram the officer, nor did he knock him down.

headline: Crawford, Tex., After the Bush Years
text: As former President George W. Bush has settled quietly into retirement in Dallas, so has his adopted hometown.

headline: In Pakistan, Violence on Campus
text: At Pakistan's largest public university, the beating of a professor by members of an Islamic student group highlights a power struggle over the future of the country.

headline: Top Obama Aide Utters Words All but Unthinkable in Chicago
text: CHICAGO — Few politicians around here will admit — much less announce — that they have designs on becoming mayor of Chicago. Not with The Mayor, Richard M. Daley, also known as Mayor for Life, assumed to be headed for yet another re-election bid next year and for as many times after that as he might please. As one political analyst here delicately put it: Most people might think such a declaration unwise.

headline: Charges Called ‘New Low’ for Gambinos
text: When members of the Gambino crime family correctly suspected in the late 1990s that a nephew of one of their most powerful captains was cooperating with the government, they plotted to kill him, the authorities say.

headline: Brain Damage
text: Being fat is bad for your brain.

headline: Cool Debater Helps Britain’s Also-Ran Party
text: CHIPPENHAM, England — As Nick Clegg sped across the lush green landscape west of London by train on Tuesday, he spent much of his time disputing suggestions that with the May 6 election just two weeks away, he is well on his way to causing the biggest upset in Britain’s recent history.

headline: Everybody Loves a Winner
text: I’ve been thinking about President Obama’s foreign policy lately, but first, a golf tip: I went to Dave Pelz’s famous short-game school this winter to improve my putting and chipping, and a funny thing happened  my long game got better. It brings to mind something that happened to Obama. The president got health care reform passed, and it may turn out to be his single most important foreign policy achievement.

headline: At Top University, a Fight for Pakistan’s Future
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — The professor was working in his office here on the campus of Pakistan’s largest university this month when members of an Islamic student group battered open the door, beat him with metal rods and bashed him over the head with a giant flower pot.

headline: Exchanging Problems, Cubs Find a Solution
text: The tricky part of free agency for teams is to know what they are paying for. The worst free-agent contracts are rewards for past work. The best are deals that predict future performance and value it properly.

headline: We Can’t Tell You Why
text: The Census Bureau is hiring a million or more people to assist with the 2010 count. It is temporary work, but it pays well. With national unemployment at nearly 10 percent, it looks like an excellent opportunity. That is unless you are one of the nearly 50 million Americans with any arrest or conviction on record.

headline: Questions for Banks That Put Together Deals
text: They were the black boxes of the subprime era, byzantine creations of the brightest minds on Wall Street that made — and then lost — vast fortunes.

headline: Werner Schroeter, German Film and Stage Director, Dies at 65
text: Werner Schroeter, a German film and stage director whose flair for lush visuals and heightened emotions introduced an operatic sensibility to the New German Cinema movement of the 1970s, died on April 12 in Kassel, Germany. He was 65.

headline: You Call That Charity?
text: There had been a lull in sleazy Albany headlines. Have no fear, nothing has changed. Attorney General Andrew Cuomo provided a reminder of that on Tuesday, filing a civil lawsuit against Pedro Espada Jr., the Senate majority leader, claiming that Mr. Espada, his family and aides took at least $14 million from a family-run charity.

headline: Bloomberg Said to Need Rattner to Manage Fortune
text: Steven L. Rattner, the financier under increasing scrutiny in a state and federal kickbacks investigation, is playing a key role in creating a new investment firm that will manage Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s fortune and finance his philanthropic foundation, The New York Times’s Michael Barbaro reported Tuesday, citing three people told of the arrangement.

headline: April Anxiety: On the Waiting List for College
text: To the Editor:

headline: Yankees’ Jewelry Store Is Still Open
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The exiled Yankees are slowly receiving their championship rings.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 20, 2010

headline: Ochoa, Top Player, Is Retiring at Age 28
text: Lorena Ochoa, whose role as the No. 1 player and top draw in women’s golf lasted three years, announced Tuesday that she would step away from the game at age 28. Ochoa will discuss the details of the early retirement at a news conference on Friday in Mexico City.

headline: A State With Plenty of Jobs but Few Places to Live
text: WILLISTON, N.D. — When Joey Scott arrived here recently from Montana, he had no trouble finding work — he signed almost immediately with a company working to drill in the oil fields. But finding housing was another matter.

headline: Guru, Rapper Known for Social Themes, Dies at 48
text: Guru, the gravel-voiced rapper who as a member of the duo Gang Starr was one of the most expressive rappers of the 1990s and a major figure in bridging hip-hop and jazz, died Monday in New York. He was 48.

headline: Gordon Gekko’s Protégé Slept Here
text: A Chelsea apartment that will be seen in the “Wall Street” sequel that comes out this fall is for sale in real life.

headline: Mumbai Hotel, a Killing Zone, Is Grand Again
text: MUMBAI, India — On Wednesday, the Oberoi Hotel, one of two five-star hotel complexes attacked by 10 Pakistan-based gunmen in November 2008, will welcome its first guests after a comprehensive $45 million reconstruction.

headline: Homeless in a Boom State
text: Thousands of job seekers from around the country are moving to North Dakota to work in the booming oil fields.  But many soon discover there's nowhere to live.

headline: As Some Flights Resume, New Confusion Emerges
text: What a jigsaw puzzle it was, with Paris open, but Frankfurt still mostly closed. Barcelona and Rome were definitely open, as was London by the end of Tuesday night.

headline: Arnold Spohr, Former Artistic Director of Winnipeg Ballet, Dies at 86
text: Arnold Spohr, who, as artistic director of the Royal Winnipeg Ballet for 30 years brought a small regional company on the prairie to international prominence, died April 12 in Winnipeg, where he lived. He was 86.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on April 13 with an article about progress in the effort to halt the spread of polio in Nigeria and India misstated the location of Bhubaneswar, India, home to a health center where slum children were shown receiving polio vaccine drops. It is in the state of Orissa, not Bihar.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about travel disruptions in New York City caused by a plume of ash from an erupting volcano in Iceland misstated the name of the airline on which one traveler at Kennedy International Airport, Emilie Rigaud, was booked for a return flight to France. It is Swiss International Air Lines, known as Swiss  not Swissair. (Swissair, the former national airline of Switzerland, went bankrupt in 2001.)

headline: Toga Go-Withs
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — A collection of circles are parked in today’s grid — two minivans and four sedans’ worth — with the four circles in the lower left being the most appropriate, given the company’s logo.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about a former student at Brown who has sued the university over a rape accusation paraphrased incorrectly from a comment by David Josephson, an associate professor who acted as a student advocate in a 1996 sexual misconduct case. Professor Josephson said he sat in on a meeting about the student’s case with Brown officials; he did not say he sat in on a meeting between the student, William McCormick III, and Brown officials. (Mr. McCormick did not attend the meeting.)

text: To the Editor:

headline: The Benefits of Union Mines
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Few Wishes on Israel’s Birthday
text: To the Editor:

headline: Indian Point and Hudson River Aquatic Life
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bid to Make Banks Fix Crumbling Bronx Properties
text: The hot water was out again on Tuesday, so Maria Paulino, a woman of 103 years, had to bathe with a pan of water heated on the stove.

headline: When Heart Devices Fail, Who Should Be Blamed?
text: It was a landmark episode brought to light by two Minneapolis cardiologists that changed the way the medical device industry deals with the safety of heart implants.

headline: Senate Takes Steps on Backlog of Nominations
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate showed signs on Tuesday of breaking a logjam of nominations being blocked by Republicans over growing objections from the White House and Democrats in Congress.

headline: California: 2 Archdioceses Sued
text: Lawyers for a Mexican man who says he was abused as a boy by his priest in Mexico filed a civil complaint Tuesday against archdioceses here and in Mexico. The complaint was filed under the Alien Tort Claims Act, meant to prosecute human rights abuses committed outside the United States. The complaint accuses Cardinals Roger Mahony of Los Angeles and Norberto Rivera of Tehuacan, Mexico, of transferring the priest, the Rev. Nicolás Aguilar-Rivera, a Mexican citizen, between dioceses despite his history of sexual abuse. Tod Tamberg, a spokesman for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles, said Cardinal Mahony was not warned of the priest’s history before the transfer. A 20-year-old warrant for the arrest of the priest on 19 counts of child rape is pending in Los Angeles. He was defrocked in 2009.

headline: More Immigrants Have Doctorates
text: Immigrants, who account for a disproportionate share of Americans without a high school diploma, also made up nearly one-third of Americans with doctoral degrees in 2009 — a sharp increase compared with five years earlier, the Census Bureau reported Tuesday. For the first time, fully 1 in 10 adults had an education beyond a bachelor’s degree. Among adults in their late 20s, 35 percent of women and 27 percent of men had a bachelor’s degree, an eight percentage point gender gap, compared with three percentage points in 1999.

headline: Rematch of Vikings and Saints Opens 2010
text: Wondering if Brett Favre is going to play next season?

headline: Reyes Stretches His Legs as Pelfrey Sits Down Cubs
text: The image was familiar for the Mets, but it was one that had not been seen this season: Jose Reyes, the front of his uniform caked in dirt, smiling and clapping while springing to his feet at third base after a triple.

headline: N.C.A.A. Praises Change of Rule for Title IX Compliance
text: The N.C.A.A. praised a decision by the Department of Education on Tuesday to rescind a controversial rule allowing universities to use student surveys to comply with the federal gender-equity law known as Title IX.

headline: The Sedins Encounter a Question of Grit
text: LOS ANGELES — “Don’t Fear the Gingers” read the sign, held aloft Monday night by a Los Angeles Kings fan and serving as a welcome mat for the Sedin twins, Henrik and Daniel, whose skills are admired as much as their toughness is questioned.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Thursday about an open house on New York University’s 25-year expansion plan gave an outdated name for a Brooklyn engineering school with which N.Y.U. is affiliated. It is Polytechnic Institute of New York University, no longer Polytechnic University.

headline: Corrections
text: Schedule information on Saturday with a television review of “Masterclass,” a nine-part documentary series on HBO, referred incompletely to the broadcast times and days. While the first episode was shown at 5:30 p.m. Eastern and Pacific times on Sunday, and the third is scheduled for Sunday, May 2, at that time, the times for the others vary, and one will be shown on a Wednesday, and one on a Friday. Complete schedule information is available at hbo.com.

headline: A Lot to Like in Ike
text: Ike Davis’s major league career has only just begun, but already his name is resonating, in part because it evokes one of the great artifacts of American political history — the “I Like Ike” campaign slogan used on behalf of Dwight D. Eisenhower in the 1950s, when he was twice elected president.

headline: By Signing Anderson, Oakland Serves Notice It’s Prepared to Contend
text: Signing a top young pitcher to a contract extension is not headline news for a lot of teams, but it tends to draw attention when you are the budget-conscious Athletics. Oakland did it with Tim Hudson, Barry Zito, Mark Mulder and Rich Harden, all of them standouts.

headline: Corrections
text: An entry in the “What’s On Today” television highlights on Saturday about “Richard Heffner’s Open Mind,” on Channel 13, misspelled the surname of a staff writer for The New Yorker who was on the program discussing his latest book, “Denialism: How Irrational Thinking Hinders Scientific Progress, Harms the Planet, and Threatens Our Lives.” He is Michael Specter, not Spector.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the Antiques column on April 2 about remnants of a ferry that were raised from water near the Ellis Island dock erroneously included a branch of the military as a participant with the National Park Service in the dredging and salvage process. While the Navy has been involved in previous efforts, it did not take part in this one.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Gates Calls for Easing Limits on Exports
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates called on Tuesday for an overhaul of the nation’s export control system that he said would loosen sales of sensitive technology to American allies without letting up on restrictions over nations like Iran.

headline: Lack of Offense Is Dooming the Cubs
text: The amazing thing about the Chicago Cubs is that their starters are pitching quite well. Taking out opening day, when Carlos Zambrano was roughed up in Atlanta, they have a 2.63 earned run average in 13 starts. Yet the team is 5-9, and looks listless.

headline: Financial Debate Renews Scrutiny on Banks’ Size
text: WASHINGTON — One question has vexed the Obama administration and Congress since the start of the financial crisis: how to prevent big bank bailouts.

headline: How to Decide
text: Figure out whether to buy or rent by looking at rent ratios across the nation.

headline: Pushing Pedals, Not Budgets
text: It was a busy day. In the morning, I’d followed a creek as far upstream as I could, until it disappeared underground. At midday, I’d stopped in town for a slice of pepperoni pizza. And in the afternoon, I’d explored a chain-link-fence maze at the edge of a university. Now, with dinnertime approaching, I was pedaling home on the trusty bicycle that had taken me to the far corners of my world. I was 10 years old.

headline: Bank Says Losses Prove No Ill Intent
text: Fabrice P. Tourre was in a bind: his seemingly lucrative deal for Goldman Sachs was going horribly wrong.

headline: Last Mile May Be Hardest in Former A.I.G. Chief’s Legal Journey
text: The final stop in Maurice R. Greenberg’s long legal odyssey is shaping up to be the toughest.

headline: Lights, Camera, Pierogi: Movies in Greenpoint
text: The Greenpoint neighborhood in Brooklyn, long a haven for Polish immigrants and more recently for artists and craftsmen, is fast becoming a local center of the film and television industry.

headline: Happy Birthday, Mr. Mayor
text: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner would have been 100 on Tuesday, and a dozen of his former colleagues and friends celebrated and reminisced over a birthday lunch in Manhattan. Mr. Wagner, who died in 1991, was one of only four three-term mayors (he served from 1954 to 1965).

headline: Deutsche Trader Steps Down
text: Greg Lippmann, a mortgage trader who made his name with big bets on a housing bust, formally stepped down as Deutsche Bank’s global head of asset-backed securities trading on Tuesday, the company said.

headline: Citigroup’s Annual Meeting Is More Relaxed After Big Quarterly Profit
text: With Citigroup under siege last year, Richard D. Parsons, its chairman, told shareholders at the annual meeting that the bank skipped the coffee and doughnuts to save cash after three bailouts.

headline: McCartney Moves His Music Catalog
text: Three years ago, Paul McCartney was one of the most outspoken of the disgruntled acts at EMI, the record label that had been his home since the earliest days of the Beatles.

headline: Greece Sells Bills, but Prospects Are Dim
text: Greece easily sold a block of three-month securities on Tuesday, and at a lower interest rate than many had forecast. But its long-term prospects worsened amid skepticism that the country could pull itself out of a financial hole without drawing on aid from the European Union and the International Monetary Fund.

headline: In a Hookah Cafe in the East Village
text: Micah Gaugh, a 38-year-old alto saxophonist from Dallas, introduces himself in the third installment of Ozier Muhammad’s series, “Sounds From Uncommon Spaces.”

headline: Deal Is Reached, Averting Doormen’s Strike
text: Updated, 12:47 a.m. | The owners of more than 3,200 apartment buildings in New York City reached an agreement on a new labor contract with the union that represents about 30,000 doormen, porters, janitors and building superintendents, averting a strike that was to begin at 7 a.m. Wednesday.

headline: No Garnett No Problem as Celtics Rout Heat
text: BOSTON — With a few select words and a bodily taunt, Quentin Richardson managed to crack the Boston Celtics’ steely veneer and remove a critical piece of their championship foundation.

headline: What Investors in Goldman Fear
text: Goldman Sachs could be fined by the S.E.C., but its shareholders dread tighter reins on the use of derivatives.

headline: Word of the Day | palatial
text: palatial •\pə-ˈla-shəl\• adjective

headline: Deal Reached That Averts a Walkout by Doormen
text: The owners of more than 3,200 apartment buildings in New York City reached an agreement on a new labor contract with the union that represents about 30,000 doormen, porters, janitors and building superintendents, averting a strike that was due to begin at 7 a.m. Wednesday.

headline: In Sour Home Market, Buying Often Beats Renting
text: In much of the country, for much of the last decade, renting a home has usually been a better financial move than buying one. It’s been true in Southern California, San Francisco, Phoenix, Las Vegas and large parts of Florida, the Pacific Northwest and the Northeast.

headline: Greece Sells Bills, but Prospects Are Dim
text: Greece easily sold a block of three-month securities on Tuesday, and at a lower interest rate than many had forecast. But its long-term prospects worsened amid skepticism that the country could pull itself out of a financial hole without drawing on aid from the European Union and the International Monetary Fund, The New York Times’s David Jolly reported.

headline: Is US Airways Just a ‘Stalking Horse’ for United?
text: United Airlines and Continental Airlines are in the early stages of exchanging financial information that could lead to a deal to combine and create the world’s biggest airline, The Associated Press reported, citing people briefed on the talks.

headline: Music in the Desert
text: WHAT is the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival?

headline: I.M.F. Lends Its Support to Charging Bank Fees
text: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund has endorsed proposals to charge a levy on the largest banks for the cost of any future government-led rescues as well as a tax based on bank profits and compensation.

headline: In Ash’s Wake, E.U. to Hasten Plan to Merge Airspace
text: PARIS — As airlines around the world finally began moving to overcome a huge backlog of passengers left stranded by Iceland’s volcanic ash cloud, the European Commission on Wednesday set the stage for a potentially acrimonious debate over plans to create a single authority with the power to override member states’ control over their skies.

headline: Goldman Inquiry Comes at Key Time in Britain
text: Hector Sants, the chief of Britain’s financial regulator, pledged last year to reverse his agency’s reputation as a toothless tiger. He wanted to spread fear across the financial services industry by stepping up the aggressiveness of its inquiries and by pursuing more prominent fraud cases.

headline: Financial Debate Renews Scrutiny on Banks’ Size
text: One question has vexed the Obama administration and Congress since the start of the financial crisis: how to prevent big bank bailouts, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: I.M.F. Lends Its Support to Charging Bank Fees
text: The International Monetary Fund has endorsed proposals to charge a levy on the largest banks for the cost of any future government-led rescues as well as a tax based on bank profits and compensation, Sewell Chan writes in The New York Times.

headline: Vancouver Estimates Cost
text: A report presented to the Vancouver City Council estimated that it cost the city $554 million to host the Winter Olympics. The amount did not include nearly $1 billion the city borrowed to ensure completion of the athletes’ village or spending by other levels of government. It is also separate from the budget of the Games’ organizing committee, which has yet to issue its final financial report.

headline: Lippmann, Deutsche Trader, Steps Down
text: Greg Lippmann, a mortgage trader who made his name with big bets on a housing bust, formally stepped down as Deutsche Bank‘s global head of asset-backed securities trading on Tuesday, the company said.

headline: Citi’s Yearly Meeting More Relaxed After Profit
text: With Citigroup under siege last year, Richard D. Parsons, its chairman, told shareholders at the annual meeting that the bank skipped the coffee and doughnuts to save cash after three bailouts, Eric Dash reports in The New York Times.

headline: Snoo-Bo
text: Portmanteau term for a threatened duet between Susan Boyle (SuBo) and Snoop Dogg.

headline: S.E.C. Said to Consider Risk Masking Clampdown
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking to take action against the widespread practice of masking risk levels by big-name banks, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Being and Frumpiness
text: Last week, Knopf published a new translation of “The Second Sex,” Simone de Beauvoir’s feminist masterpiece. The original English translation, in print for over 60 years, was widely considered to be a botched job, done by a zoology professor with imperfect French and significantly abridged by the publisher. This latest translation got us thinking about de Beauvoir’s accidental style statements — about her whole amazing, intellectual frump thing. Digging into the New York Times photo morgue, we’ve come up with what must be the world’s first “Simone de Beauvoir Look-Book.” Which is nothing if not reductionist and superficial. But hey, we’ve graded dictators and literary lions before, so why should existentialists be exempt?

headline: The Deregistration of M. Tourre
text: How do you say fall guy in French? “Bouc emissaire” is the closest.

headline: South Korea Arrests 2 From North in Alleged Assassination Plot
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korean security officials said Wednesday that they had arrested two North Korean agents who had posed as defectors in a plot to assassinate the highest-ranking North Korean defector by slitting his throat.

headline: Justice and F.T.C. Propose New Merger Guidelines
text: American antitrust enforcers have released proposed new guidelines describing how they approach mergers between rivals, with a range of experts describing the revisions as providing greater clarity and giving officials more discretion, Reuters reported.

headline: McCartney Says Goodbye to E.M.I., Hello to Concord

headline: Banks Counter TheFlyOnTheWall in Court
text: Three Wall Street banks urged a Manhattan federal judge not to lift an injunction on TheFlyOnTheWall.com‘s quick publication of analyst rating changes, saying the financial news service failed to show the ban threatens its ability to stay in business, Reuters reported.

headline: Lone Star Funds Said to Step Up KEB Move
text: The United States private equity firm Lone Star Funds is once again shopping around the acquisition that may have given its head, John Grayken, his biggest case of buyer’s regret. For sale is Korea Exchange Bank, one of South Korea’s largest lenders, according to The Financial Times.

headline: A Loss, a Journal Entry and Some Random Thoughts
text: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Women’s Professional Soccer in the league’s first season. Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, will be filing to the Goal blog during the defending champions’ 2010 season.

headline: Don’t Fear the Invisible Tax
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: London Documentary Festival Expands
text: After just three years in the game, the London International Documentary Film Festival, which runs from April 23 to May 8, is changing its scope. In addition to screening roughly 90 films from around the world and hosting panel discussions, screen talks, and live events — as it has in the past — this year the festival will also include photography and radio documentaries. “We think the dialogue between these different disciplines — but all story-tellers — will be beneficial and refreshing,” said Patrick Hazard, festival director.

headline: Salesforce Buys Jigsaw for $142 Million
text: The computing company Salesforce.com has said it agreed to a deal of about $142 million to acquire Jigsaw, a Web site that offers that offers a Wikipedia-style sourced business directory, TechCrunch reported.

text: Wall Street is unforgiving to the weak, and although Goldman Sachs is unfamiliar with the role of prey instead of predator, its rivals are trying to punish it while the bank is under scrutiny from the S.E.C.

headline: CKE Restaurants Says New Takeover Bid Is Better
text: CKE Restaurants, the operator of Carl’s Jr. and Hardee’s restaurants said Tuesday that a rival buyout offer from an unnamed bidder was better than the one it had from a private equity firm, The Associated Press reported.

text: Innkeepers USA Trust, an American real estate investment trust with interests in about 73 hotels, is getting ready for a possible bankruptcy filing after missing debt payments this month, Reuters reported, citing four people familiar with the matter.

headline: Sampler: Muni Service Cuts, and Aggressive Bats in American Canyon
text: 10 Percent Cut in Muni Service Proposed | You can expect your ride on Muni over the next year to get more uncomfortable and your wait for buses and trolleys longer, if  San Francisco’s Board of Supervisors approves the lean budget adopted Tuesday by the Municipal Transportation Authority. A 10 percent service cut would take effect on May 8, according to the new $750 million budget. Transit officials had hoped an infusion of cash from the state would prevent service reductions, but now say that won’t be possible until July 2011. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

headline: A Pasta Carbonara Too Good to Share
text: The last time my wife, Jackie, and I ate in a restaurant operated by the French chef-restaurateur Joël Robuchon was at his place on rue de Longchamp, in Paris, which closed in 1993. We were probably there in 1980s. What I remember best about that dinner, apart from an overall impression of excellence and a stunning tomato tart, was a snatch of overheard conversation: Older man leans across the table and purrrrrrs to (much) younger woman, “Un dîner digne de madame” – “A dinner worthy of the lady.” You can’t say these things in English, and probably not even in French nowadays, but it has become one of our catchphrases, often applied to meals like the leftover pizza we had the other night.

headline: As Some Flights Resume, New Confusion Emerges
text: Six days after volcanic ash virtually shut down European airspace, the airlines slowly resumed flights there on Tuesday. But airlines are still uncertain about when they can return to a regular schedule. And thousands of stranded travelers and would-be vacationers now face a logistical nightmare as they try to figure out when their flights are going to take off — and from where. Read more.

headline: Eyjafjallajokull, the Musical
text: Updated | 4:20 p.m. As my colleagues Nicola Clark, Alan Cowell and Mark McDonald report, air travel in Europe is ramping up as the volcanic ash over the continent dissipates. But, given that the last eruption of the same volcano in Iceland continued on-and-off from 1821 to 1823, this might not be the last we hear of Eyjafjallajokull.

headline: Morgan Stanley Posts $1.8 Billion Profit
text: 11:05 a.m. | Updated Morgan Stanley reported a $1.8 billion profit on Wednesday, bolstered by trading gains as the firm continues to rebuild itself from its near-death experience during the financial crisis.

headline: The Man the White House Wakes Up To
text: Before he goes to sleep, between 11 and midnight, Dan Pfeiffer, the White House communications director, typically checks in by e-mail with the same reporter: Mike Allen of Politico, who is also the first reporter Pfeiffer corresponds with after he wakes up at 4:20. A hyperactive former Eagle Scout, Allen will have been up for hours, if he ever went to bed. Whether or not he did is one of the many little mysteries that surround him. The abiding certainty about Allen is that sometime between 5:30 and 8:30 a.m., seven days a week, he hits “send” on a mass e-mail newsletter that some of America’s most influential people will read before they say a word to their spouses.

headline: A Big Bet on Solar Technology
text: In one of the biggest green technology deals of the year, a prominent Silicon Valley venture capital firm is leading a $129.4 million investment in a long-promising solar technology that is starting to gain traction in the United States.

headline: Cooking Tools: iPad’s Epicurious vs. BigOven

As long as you can avoid slathering it with grease and dusting it (lightly or otherwise) with flour, it beats phones and laptops for overall kitchen-counter friendliness, and is poised to be an indispensable tool, once enough of the cookbooks we all love go digital.

headline: ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Minus Kate
text: Pour out an ounce of your favorite Capri Sun fruit drink in honor of the reality-television mom Kate Gosselin, whose mannequin-like mien gave way to honest-to-goodness tears when she was voted off “Dancing With the Stars” on Tuesday night. We could use this space to look back on some of Ms. Gosselin’s more questionable routines, but given the gravity of the moment, we’ll just say thanks: Thank you, Ms. Gosselin, for bringing some unpredictability to prime-time television; thank you for making Pamela Anderson look like a worthy competitor; and thank you for providing endless fodder for blogs and daytime television talk shows. And thank you, ABC “World News Now,” for allowing us zero seconds to mourn Ms. Gosselin’s loss before reminding us that she’s about to go to court against her ex-husband, Jon.

headline: Juan Antonio Samaranch, Who Transformed the Olympics, Dies at 89
text: Juan Antonio Samaranch, a dominant figure in the modern Olympic movement who over 21 years guided the Games from a period of boycotts and near bankruptcy to an era of unprecedented success and damaging scandal, died on Wednesday in his home city, Barcelona, Spain. He was 89.

Cuomo, in cooperation with federal agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Internal Revenue Service, raided the Bronx offices of the Soundview HealthCare Network early Wednesday, seeking records as part of an investigation into the business and political activities of Senator Pedro Espada Jr., a Bronx Democrat who is the State Senate majority leader.
