headline: Magna Carta Enjoys an Extended Visit to New York
text: 11:25 a.m. | Updated The Magna Carta may have helped establish our right to protection against unlawful legal detention, but that doesn’t mean the venerated document can’t be held in New York a little longer than expected while Europe resolves its travel woes. The Morgan Library & Museum in Manhattan said a rare manuscript of the Magna Carta that it started showing Wednesday would remain on display through May 30 while arrangements were made to transport it home to Britain.

headline: 3 Emotional Questions Every Home Buyer Should Ask
text: I’ve been a big fan of Seth Godin ever since the olden days in the 1990s when we both wrote for Fast Company magazine. This week, he poses questions on his blog that will change the way you think about shopping for a home.

headline: Donors Save Harlem School of Arts
text: The sudden closing of the Harlem School of the Arts this month is proving to be temporary: The mayor and other city officials and a host of donors have stepped in to resuscitate the storied and fiscally troubled Harlem institution, and it is to reopen on Saturday.

headline: Paulson Said to Have Told ACA of Short Plans
text: CNBC has reported that the Securities and Exchange Commission received testimony, as yet unreleased, from an employee at the hedge fund Paulson & Company, that he informed ACA Management of the firm’s intention to short the credit derivative it was structuring at the behest of Goldman Sachs.

headline: The Calculations for Renting or Buying
text: Is it better to rent or buy? In his column today David Leonhardt takes a fresh look at the issue. According to Mr. Leonhardt, the decision depends on where you live. In some areas, like South Florida, Phoenix and Las Vegas, buying has become more attractive since home prices have declined so much relative to rents. In others, like Manhattan or San Francisco, it still may make financial sense to rent.

headline: The Model Whisperer
text: The Sports Illustrated model is bent in downward-dog position, feet planted in a wide V. Each Asics resting on a gliding disc, she slides first her right foot across and beneath her torso, then repeats the motion with her left foot. Someone who did not know better might imagine Irina Shayk was playing Twister, that goofy ’60s game involving a spinner and a vinyl polka-dot floor mat. But working out is no more a game for someone in Shayk’s line of work than it would be for a professional athlete. In a business where a pert behind and firm inner thighs are career requisites, more models are moving away from body-shaping routines built on a diet of Moët & Chandon and Marlboro Reds and doing something their predecessors assiduously avoided: hitting the gym.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Renting a Bike on a Budget

headline: Obama and the ‘Birthers’ in the Latest Poll
text: President Obama was born in Hawaii on Aug. 4, 1961. A scanned image of his birth certificate released during the 2008 presidential campaign says he was, and Hawaii’s health director and its registrar of vital statistics have confirmed it.

headline: Change Is in the Air at B.C.S. Meetings
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — The fountains at the Royal Palms Resort trickled softly under the desert sun on Tuesday, providing a peaceful backdrop for what could be one of college sports’ most chaotic periods.

headline: G.M. Repays U.S. Loan, While Chrysler Posts Improved Quarterly Results
text: DETROIT — General Motors repaid a government loan and Chrysler posted improved quarterly results on Wednesday — proof, the companies said, that they were turning their operations around.

headline: Panasonic Cameras Most Reliable, Survey Finds
text: If you’re looking for the most reliable point-and-shoot digital camera, you might do well to focus on a Panasonic. That’s the conclusion from a study of 60,000 warranties on cameras conducted by SquareTrade, a warranty provider for tech products.

headline: EMC’s Profit Rises as Executive Sees Rosy Outlook for Corporate Spending
text: An executive at EMC, the data storage giant, has offered some of the most positive language to date about the state of corporate spending on technology, saying customers were at last planning for the future rather than just battening down the hatches. And he uttered one of the most beloved phrases in the technology industry vocabulary – “new innovative projects.”

headline: Once More, With Conviction: ‘Oz’ Stars Are Coming to Primary Stages
text: It’s not an official “Oz” reunion, but short of the cast members of that HBO prison drama getting thrown into a maximum-security penitentiary together, it’s as close as we’re likely to get. Primary Stages said that it would end its season with two stage readings of “Godfather IV,” an original work by Tom Fontana, the “Oz” creator, and starring Christopher Meloni, Lee Tergesen and Dean Winters, who all appeared on that eye-gougingly violent series. “Godfather IV” is not a sequel to Francis Ford Coppola‘s mafia movies, but a piece in which the “Oz” actors discuss the plausibility of a key scene in “The Godfather,” and Mr. Tergesen and Mr. Winters resolve to put a horse’s head in Mr. Meloni’s bed.

headline: Is 15 a Better Rent-Ratio Cutoff?
text: Dean Baker, one of those economists who saw the housing bubble for what it was in real time, argues that I’m wrong to use 20 as a rule of thumb for the rent ratio. He writes:

headline: NATO Apologizes for Killing Unarmed Afghans in Car
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — NATO apologized Wednesday for shooting to death four unarmed Afghan civilians this week in Khost Province and acknowledged that it had wrongly described two of the victims as “known insurgents.”

headline: No Nail Clipping on the Platform, Please
text: First the Working Families Party riffed on them in a campaign against transit service cuts and fare increases last month. Now it’s an artist, frustrated with the behavior of some riders, who has taken the subway’s service change posters as inspiration, creating a series of 10 versions of his own that urge riders to — please! — show some proper etiquette on the trains.

The full bill could be brought to the Senate floor by the end of the week or by Monday.

headline: Residents Grapple With Oakland’s Violent Reputation
text: I walked south on Telegraph Avenue in Oakland at 4 p.m. on Tuesday. It was in the same place at about the same time on Friday — maybe an hour earlier — that a father and son had gotten out of their car nearby.

headline: 2 Chinese Lawyers Are Facing Disbarment for Defending Falun Gong
text: BEIJING — Two Chinese lawyers who represented a follower of the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement could have their licenses permanently revoked in an administrative hearing on Thursday. The action against the lawyers is the latest move in an increasingly harsh government crackdown on lawyers who take on human rights cases.

headline: Should You Join a Business Group?
text: Running a small business requires some level of expertise in many areas. There are management issues, marketing questions and financial realities. Trying to master all areas, or at least sort them all out, can be frustrating, exhausting and scary. Entrepreneurship differs from many other “professions” in that by definition you are on your own: no colleagues back at the office, no mentor or boss to show you the way. In addition, it is not just your paycheck that is at risk; it can be everything you have, not to mention money put up by friends and family.

headline: University of California Trying Again on Museum Project
text: The University of California, Berkeley, decided last fall to scrap its ambitious designs for a new Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive, saying that it had been unable to raise enough money. Now it is considering proposals from 10 architectural firms for the conversion of an old printing plant in downtown Berkeley to become the museum’s new home, The San Francisco Chronicle reported. The university declined to identify the competitors for the job but the newspaper reported that three firms had confirmed that they were invited to take part: Bernard Tschumi Architects of New York, Tod Williams Billie Tsien Architects of New York and Will Bruder + Partners of Phoenix.

headline: An Official Mourning in China for Quake Victims
text: BEIJING — In an elaborately orchestrated outpouring of grief, China on Wednesday mourned the victims of the earthquake in western Qinghai Province by printing monochromatic newspapers, shutting karaoke parlors and canceling sporting events across the country.

headline: Japan Stops Beef Exports in Possible Foot-and-Mouth Outbreak
text: The Associated Press reports that Japan suspended beef exports on Tuesday after three of 16 beef cattle at a farm in Miyazaki prefecture were found to have symptoms of foot-and-mouth disease earlier this month. headline: Income Falls, but Wells Fargo Sees Improvement
text: Wells Fargo said Wednesday that its first-quarter net income declined 16 percent, to $2.54 billion, as the bank dealt with continuing losses on consumer loans. However, the bank said it had “turned the corner” with its credit problems, The Associated Press reports. Income in the quarter a year earlier was $3.04 billion.

headline: Mourning the Death of a Pet
text: Years ago, I had an orange tabby cat named Dave who was more person than pet. Sometimes when my husband and I were visiting our neighbors in Houston, we would hear a knock at the door. “It’s probably Dave,” our friends would say, and sure enough, there he was on the step, waiting to be invited in with the rest of us.

headline: Theodore Roosevelt, Empire Builder
text: These are books about men who wanted a war. Or at least the next best thing: a state of intimidation, fear, anxiety and excitement, which would produce the fruits of war, foremost among them order and peace. But what these men got was not always what they yearned for. And the price was not what they were ready — or even able — to pay.

headline: Bieber Still on Top
text: Justin Bieber’s “My World 2.0” (Island) is the top album in the United States for the second week in a row, with 92,000 sales, Nielsen SoundScan reported, and the Brooklyn band MGMT enters the chart this week in second place, with 66,000 sales of its second album, “Congratulations” (Columbia). Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville) is No. 3 with 65,000, Usher’s “Raymond v Raymond” (LaFace) is in fourth place, with 64,000 sales, and the New York hard-rock band Coheed and Cambria opened at No. 5 with “Year of the Black Rainbow” (Columbia), which sold 51,000.

text: If you watched “Silly Little Game,” a documentary about the origins of rotisserie baseball, on ESPN on Tuesday night after reading The New York Times review, you may have noticed that one scene did not play out the way it was described. Discussing an imagined scene in which an actor portraying Neil Allen, a significant figure in the history of the original rotisserie baseball league, was shown downing a tall glass of beer, I wrote, “Presumably everyone involved knew that Mr. Allen’s baseball career was ruined by alcoholism, but thought that the joke was worth it anyway.”

headline: U.S. Volcano Monitors Laugh Last
text: Last year, before everyone struggled to learn how to pronounce Eyjafjallajokull, Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana told the nation that President Obama’s economic stimulus package was “larded with wasteful spending.” He chuckled at the absurdity of it all as he listed his examples. Finally the governor arrived at this punch line: “… and $140 million for something called ‘volcano monitoring.’ Instead of monitoring volcanoes, what Congress should be monitoring is the eruption of spending in Washington, D.C.”

headline: Now Booking | Boutique Hotels in Joshua Tree
text: U2 and Lady Gaga videos notwithstanding, the lure of lonesome Joshua Tree has always been the desolation. There’s nothing like 25,000 square miles of Mojave wasteland to put things in perspective. But in those arid badlands of Southern California, accommodations — when you can find them — tend to be either motel-dismal or perfunctorily kitschy. Except for these two recent discoveries. Sacred Sands is a wisp of high-desert chic just one mile from the west entrance to Joshua Tree National Park. Here, at the base of a rocky ridge, Steve Pratt and Scott Cutler have fashioned a luxe eco-friendly retreat that’s unapologetically open to the barrens. It has just two suites ($269 and $299 a night) — though two more are in the works — both with wraparound terraces. Each has an outdoor hot tub spiked with Dead Sea salts and tea tree oil along with a meditation platform, essentially a full-size bed where guests can sleep al fresco. And many do: “For city dwellers, it might be a little frightening at first,” Cutler says, “but most people who doze off under the stars say it’s the best sleep they’ve ever had.” In the morning, fresh chilaquiles with homemade mole sauce, oven-baked pancakes and yam hash give incentive to rise.

headline: Beverly Sills Award Winner Is Named
text: Susanna Phillips, a 28-year-old soprano from Huntsville, Ala., was named the winner of the Beverly Sills Artist Award, the Metropolitan Opera said on Wednesday. The award, for singers age 25 to  40 who have appeared in featured solo roles at the Met, has been given annually since 2006 and comes with a prize of $50,000. Its previous winners include the baritone Nathan Gunn, the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato, the tenor Matthew Polenzani and the bass John Relyea. Ms. Phillips made her Met debut last season in the role of Musetta in “La Bohème”; she has also sung Pamina in “Die Zauberflöte” and will reprise the role in the Met’s 2010-2011 season. The award was to be officially presented to Ms. Phillips at the Met by Dr. Agnes Varis, a managing director on the Met board who with her husband, Karl Leichtman, endowed the award, and Muffy Greenough, Ms. Sills’s daughter.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Distracted Driving and Green Gadgets

headline: When to Tell the Boss You’re Pregnant
text: When I was pregnant with my first child, I kept it a secret from everyone at work for the first three months. That was logistically simple — I was working in the Houston bureau of The Times at the time, and my editors and colleagues were almost all in New York. But it was physically and emotionally exhausting. I was spending as much energy pretending I wasn’t pregnant as I was actually being pregnant, which adds up to an awful lot of energy.

text: Gay kids emerging from their cocoons these days can tune into any Bravo reality show to find an assortment of potential role models. But a few decades back, kinship ran thinner in popular culture.

headline: Obama Denies Link to Timing of S.E.C. Case
text: President Obama denied “categorically” on Wednesday any political involvement or advance knowledge of the federal case against Goldman Sachs, saying he learned about the civil fraud suit from television.

headline: Ever Active, Tannenbaum Reshapes Jets’ Roster
text: General Manager Mike Tannenbaum conducted this Jets off-season in typical fashion under atypical circumstances.

headline: But Aren’t Home Prices Still Falling?
text: Ryan Avent, Ezra Klein and Annie Lowrey all question the idea that now may be a good time to buy a home in Phoenix, Las Vegas or some other place where prices have plummeted. They point out that these areas tend to have weak economies right now. “As of February, Las Vegas’s unemployment rate was 13.9%,” Mr. Avent writes on The Economist’s Web site. “Should we be encouraging people to chain themselves to labor markets like this for at least five to seven years?” Brett Barry, a real estate agent in Phoenix, makes a similar point here.

headline: Taylor Ready to Let Bygones Be Bygones With Jets Fans
text: Jason Taylor is excited about the opportunity to play for Jets Coach Rex Ryan, but Taylor said in a conference call Wednesday that his original goal this off-season was to return to the Miami Dolphins, the team he played for during 12 of his 13 seasons in the N.F.L.

headline: A Taste of Europe at Red Bull Arena
text: That gaping hole in the July schedule of the New York Red Bulls will be filled with the first New York Football Challenge, a tournament that will include Manchester City and Tottenham Hotspur of the English Premier League; and (tentatively, the Red Bulls said) Sporting Clube de Portugal, known widely as Sporting Lisbon. The tournament will be played from July 22 to July 25.

headline: Case Study | Cocchi Americano: Waking the Dead
text: It is a universal truism, not to mention a bedrock commercial ploy, that when you tell someone they can’t have something, they’ll likely become obsessed with obtaining it. This is readily demonstrated by liquor fanatics, who will cross the globe for a bottle of the most obscure and often pointless spirits, just to say they’ve tasted them. I am as guilty of this as anyone, and need only point to my several-year hunt for the elusive Cocchi Aperitivo Americano (pronounced co-key), for which I’ve buttonholed friends heading to Italy and Oakland, Calif., where it was once rumored to have an importer, all in vain.

headline: The Smart Way to Increase Your Exports
text: A lot of business owners stumble into exporting through serendipity. They happen to meet a distributor or they happen to get a a call from an intrigued customer in an overseas market. In a small-business guide to exporting we’ve just published, Ian Mount suggests that more small businesses should be going after foreign markets, that the Obama administration has taken some recent steps to make this easier, and that it helps to take a proactive approach.

headline: How to Help the Young Superheroes
text: In response to Nick’s April 10 column featuring a family of orphans in Zimbabwe, over 100 readers wrote in asking what they could do to make a difference. Many readers, for example, wanted to send a bicycle to the oldest brother to expedite his nine-mile trek to school.

headline: Style Icon | Grace Kelly
text: For anyone raised on Madonna or Rihanna, it’s hard to fathom how a rich girl with a wardrobe full of shirtdresses, twin sets and pearls  and a firm disbeliever in women wearing trousers  could become the fashion idol of her generation. But Grace Kelly epitomized a time before rebellion was a virtue, and the forthcoming “Grace Kelly: Style Icon” exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London pays homage to the actress-turned-princess’s sartorial legacy, from her rise to stardom in the ’50s to her untimely death in 1982. “She certainly didn’t see herself as a style leader, liking such conservative clothes,” says the show¹s curator, Jenny Lister. “But audiences loved her kind of uncontrived, natural beauty.” Highlights of the show include Kelly’s namesake Hermès bag, dresses from her films “High Society” and “Rear Window,” and items from among the 80 pieces of luggage she carried to Monaco for her wedding to Prince Rainier in 1956. But perhaps more intriguing is what happened in the decades that followed, when Kelly found herself outside her comfort zone  amid all the tiaras and Dior ballgowns are the odd nods to rising hemlines and changing times, like her YSL Mondrian dress. In the end though, says Lister, “she was always happier in a Chanel suit.”

headline: The Seas, and the Humans Who Could Drown Them
text: After wowing us in the skies with “Winged Migration,” the two Jacques (Perrin and Cluzaud) are back to entice us to gaze in the opposite direction. In “Oceans,” Disneynature’s reconstitution of the 2009 French release “Océans,” the filmmakers venture in, on and around our seas to discover photogenic oddities and endangered wonders.

headline: A Sly Suggestion Is All It May Take to Kill a Marriage
text: In the world of August Strindberg, where everyone is always armed and dangerous, it takes only 90 minutes to destroy a marriage. That’s the time required to perform the thrilling new interpretation of “Creditors,” which opened Tuesday night at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. When this impeccably acted three-character drama has put the last of those minutes to cruel and careful use, you’re likely to feel you’ve had the breath knocked out of you. Despite yourself, you’ll probably be smiling too.

headline: Facebook Spreads Itself Across the Web
text: Call it Facebook to go.

headline: All Creatures Great and Repulsive
text: Nature has taken up residence in your television set, and it wants to kill you. Happy Earth Day.

headline: Pardon My French
text: Paris

headline: Same Game, Other Side of Tracks
text: AUSTIN, Tex.

headline: Despite Anxiety and Naysayers, Composer Wins Her Pulitzer
text: PHILADELPHIA  Jennifer Higdon wishes there were a 12-step program on how to deal with all the various stages of composing anxiety, she said, laughing, on Sunday in the spacious apartment here that she shares with her partner, Cheryl Lawson.

headline: Ready, Shreddy, Go!
text: This past Saturday at Webster Hall’s grand ballroom, it all came down to two very different but equally impressive New York City “shredders”: Dylan Brenner, a 15-year old Les Paul-wielding prodigy from Long Island, and Lily Maase, a 27-year old guitarist who splits her time between Bushwick, Brooklyn, and Spanish Harlem. Both had out-rocked opponents in three previous rounds and were now facing off in the finals. Following two blistering 90-second solos, the judges were at an impasse and the audience was in an uproar.

headline: 'The Sorter'
text: A video from the New York Public Library about the book sorting machine.

headline: All Hail the Mighty ‘Regis and Kelly’ Rolodex
text: David Letterman, near right, is rarely on television outside his own bailiwick, but when he does make a guest appearance, it is pretty much out of loyalty and friendship. Those are surely factors behind his decision to appear as a guest on “Live With Regis and Kelly” on the morning of April 30. Regis Philbin, above center, is a frequent guest on Mr. Letterman’s “Late Show” on CBS, and Mr. Letterman has often expressed affection and admiration for him. (Mr. Letterman was last a guest on “Live” in April 2007, when Mr. Philbin returned to the show after heart surgery.) This visit helps kick off a big effort by “Live” during the next ratings sweeps period, which begins next Thursday. Besides Mr. Letterman, the show has booked stars including Robert Downey Jr., Gwyneth Paltrow (above right), Russell Crowe, Denzel Washington, Jimmy Kimmel and the Jonas Brothers.

headline: Alabama Soprano Wins Sills Award
text: Susanna Phillips, below, a 28-year-old soprano from Huntsville, Ala., was named the winner of the Beverly Sills Artist Award, the Metropolitan Opera said on Wednesday. The award, for singers between the ages of 25 and 40 who have appeared in featured solo roles at the Met, has been given annually since 2006, and comes with a prize of $50,000. Ms. Phillips made her Met debut last season in the role of Musetta in “La Bohème”; she has also sung Pamina in “Die Zauberflöte” and will reprise that role in the Met’s 2010-11 season.

headline: ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’ Gets Another Season
text: For his most recent run of “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” Larry David, below, performed the seemingly impossible and reunited the cast of “Seinfeld.” So what will he do for an encore? We’ll find out in due time: on Tuesday, HBO said it was ordering another season of “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” on which Mr. David plays a dyspeptic fictionalized version of himself. Mr. David said in a statement: “After much soul searching  and by the way, it was nowhere to be found  I have decided to do another season of ‘Curb.’ I look forward to the end of shooting, when I can once again resume the hunt for my elusive soul. I know it’s here somewhere, or perhaps in the rugged mountainous regions of Pakistan.” Wherever Mr. David may find his vital force, HBO said that production of new episodes would begin this summer in New York and Los Angeles and would be shown next year.

headline: Bieber Continues to Sell
text: Justin Bieber’s “My World 2.0” (Island) is the top-selling album in the United States for the second week in a row, with sales of 92,000, Nielsen SoundScan reported, and the Brooklyn band MGMT enters the chart this week in second place, with 66,000 in sales of its second album, “Congratulations” (Columbia). Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville) is No. 3, with 65,000; Usher’s “Raymond v. Raymond” (LaFace) is in fourth place with 64,000 sales; and the New York hard-rock band Coheed and Cambria opened at No. 5 with “Year of the Black Rainbow” (Columbia), which sold 51,000. For most music retailers it was a slow week; the sales for “My World 2.0” are the fewest for a No. 1 album since last May, when Chrisette Michele’s “Epiphany” sold 83,000.

headline: Muslim Group Warns ‘South Park’
text: An Islamic group based in New York said that a recent episode of “South Park,” the satirical animated series, insulted the Prophet Muhammad, and compared the show’s creators, Trey Parker and Matt Stone, to Theo van Gogh, the Dutch filmmaker who was killed in 2004 by an Islamic militant, CNN reported. The group, Revolution Muslim, published its post after a “South Park” episode last week that depicted the founders of various religions, including Moses, Jesus and Buddha, but declined to show the Prophet Muhammad, instead representing him as wearing a bear costume. The post, written by Abu Talhah Al-Amrikee, said that the episode had “outright insulted” Muhammad, adding: “We have to warn Matt and Trey that what they are doing is stupid, and they will probably wind up like Theo van Gogh for airing this show. This is not a threat, but a warning of the reality of what will likely happen to them.” Mr. van Gogh was killed in Amsterdam after making a film that discussed the abuse of Muslim women in some Islamic societies. A telephone message left at a number listed on the group’s Web site, revolutionmuslim.com, was not immediately returned; on Wednesday the Web site was largely inaccessible. Comedy Central declined to comment on the group’s remarks or say if it was taking any precautions because of them.

headline: Fox Takes Tuesday
text: Fox’s “Glee” continued to hit ratings high notes as its Madonna-theme episode finished second only to “American Idol” on Tuesday night. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 13.5 million viewers tuned in to “Glee” at 9 p.m., nearly matching the series’s record set last week (13.6 million). Although the audience for “Idol” was down somewhat at 8 (19.1 million), that show still dominated the night, surpassing ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” results episode in the hour (13.4 million), in which Kate Gosselin reached the end of her run. CBS placed third for the night with all reruns, while NBC finished fourth.

headline: For the Magna Carta, an Extended Layover
text: The Magna Carta may have helped establish the right to protection against unlawful legal detention, but that doesn’t mean it can’t be held in New York a little longer than expected while Europe resolves its travel woes. The Morgan Library & Museum in Manhattan said a rare manuscript of the Magna Carta that it started showing on Wednesday would remain on display through May 30 while arrangements were made to transport it home to Britain. The original Magna Carta was sealed by King John of England in 1215 at Runnymede, putting limits on the king’s power and laying the groundwork for legal principles like the writ of habeas corpus. The version at the Morgan, which comes from the Bodleian Library at Oxford University, dates to 1217 and is one of 17 surviving originals produced in the 13th century that bear the royal seal. Richard Ovenden, the Bodleian’s associate director and keeper of special collections, said this Magna Carta made its first visit to New York for a special event for Oxford alumni in the United States held on Saturday at the Waldorf-Astoria. As the ash from the eruption of an Icelandic volcano disrupted air travel, Mr. Ovenden said, transportation for the document became more perilous, and airlines, concerned with getting people home, were reluctant to carry it.

headline: Cops Who Deliver a Bang for the Buck
text: DALLAS

headline: Schapiro Hits Back at G.O.P. Critics of Goldman Case
text: Mary L. Schapiro, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, defended her agency on Wednesday against Republican critics who had accused the S.E.C. of playing politics by filing securities fraud charges against Goldman Sachs while the Senate was debating a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s financial regulations.

headline: Oxygen Channel Founder Selling Co-op
text: Geraldine Laybourne, who had a long career in television and was founder of the Oxygen channel, has just put her Manhattan co-op on the market for $14.5 million.

headline: 400-Year-Old Work Gets a Fresh Look
text: Many a conductor has muttered it at the start of an under-rehearsed performance: “God help me.” But Steven Fox sang it resoundingly at Park Avenue Christian Church on Monday evening  “Deus in adjutorium meum intende,” more formally translated as, “O God, make haste to save me”  and there was nothing undercooked about the performance to follow.

headline: City Saves $50 Million in New Deal With Unions
text: Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco has struck a two-year deal with major unions representing city employees, staving off more than 1,000 planned layoffs, city officials said.

headline: Music With and Without Musicians
text: The primary focus of the MATA Festival, a vital annual new-music series, is on fresh sounds fashioned by young creators. But not every piece requires live performers: sound installations and electronic music also factor into the mix. The first formal concert of MATA’s 12th season was held on Tuesday night at Le Poisson Rouge, the Greenwich Village nightclub. But the festivities had actually started the night before, when Matt Wright, an English composer and improviser, activated his “Totem for Gobi  New York” in the club’s Gallery Bar.

headline: Tracing King’s Killer in a World of Shadow
text: In writing “Hellhound on His Trail,” the hands-on historian Hampton Sides (“Ghost Soldiers,” “Blood and Thunder”) has undertaken a hugely risky proposition. He has pieced together a viscerally dramatic account of the last days of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and intercut Dr. King’s story with the maneuverings of James Earl Ray, the man tried and convicted as his assassin. The potential for exploitation is immense, especially in light of Mr. Sides’s most visible literary influence. Here is the King assassination as imagined not only in the black and white of the civil rights movement’s era but in James Ellroy’s noir.

headline: Robust Collection of Singing Visitors
text: In the great Anglican tradition, St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue has a superb men and boys choir, as well as a school for the training of its young singers. The choristers sing the church services and have an estimable concert series: their annual “Messiah” performances have long been the best in town.

headline: Can’t Stand to Sit Too Long? There’s a Desk for That
text: It takes courage to stand up at work. I’m not talking about sticking your neck out, speaking truth to power or anything else so dramatic. I mean it literally; it is hard to find a way to work standing up at your desk instead of sitting down.

headline: One Deceived by Experience, the Other by the Heart Queen
text: In the April 10 column I claimed  on the basis of personal experience  that it is easier to get a huge match-point score in a pair event that has many tables. But Richard Zeckhauser, the Frank P. Ramsey professor of political economy at the Kennedy School at Harvard University and twice a national bridge champion, points out that the fewer tables, the more likely you are to have a big score.

headline: Nike’s Women Problem
text: Is there anything creepier than a big, beer-breathed celebrity athlete exposing himself in a night club and hitting on underage girls, all the while protected by an entourage of off-duty cops? Well, yes. It’s the big, corporate sponsor — Nike, in this case — that continues trying to sell product with the creep as their role model.

headline: From Different Generations but on the Same Page
text: Rudresh Mahanthappa and Bunky Green are alto saxophonists born 36 years apart. The younger, Mr. Mahanthappa, matured in the 1990s in New York after studying at Berklee College of Music. Mr. Green played in clubs as a teenager in Milwaukee in the early 1950s, when jazz was still a vernacular language, then went on to New York and Chicago, working with Charles Mingus and Sonny Stitt.

headline: That Mighty Sorting Machine Is Certainly One for the Books
text: A couple of years ago Salvatore Magaddino, who oversees the distribution of materials for the New York Public Library, complained at a meeting that he was having trouble recruiting book sorters, the people responsible for sorting the millions of books sent each year from one branch library to another.

headline: Priestess of the Night
text: THERE are two Shien Lees: the schoolgirl, demure in a checkered frock and cardigan; and the siren, faintly dissolute in a lace-edged scarlet frock. Ms. Lee, a recent graduate of Columbia University, is fresh-scrubbed by day, pursuing a range of cultural interests that include the study of 1920s German art and 18th-century opera. By night, she is an events planner and the entrepreneurial force behind a series of monthly costume parties that are at the center of a thriving New York vintage scene.

headline: Havasupai Case Highlights Risks in DNA Research
text: A settlement between 41 members of the Havasupai Indian tribe and Arizona State University highlights the risk researchers take when they fail to secure what is known as “informed consent,” fully informing research participants how their DNA may be used, legal experts and civil rights advocates said.

headline: Timing the Delivery of Your E-Mail Messages
text: Timed Delivery

headline: Goldman Executives Are Expected to Testify Before Senate Panel
text: The government’s case against Goldman Sachs is about to get its first public airing, in what could be a gripping preview of the legal battle to come.

headline: Q.&A.: Timed Delivery for E-Mail
text: Q.

headline: Microcredit Is Still a Good Tool to Reduce Poverty
text: To the Editor:

headline: C. K. Prahalad, Proponent of Poor as Consumers, Dies at 68
text: C. K. Prahalad, a management professor and author who popularized the idea that companies could make money while helping to alleviate poverty, died Friday in the La Jolla neighborhood of San Diego. He was 68 and lived in San Diego.

headline: Cuban May Try to Block Weinsteins on Miramax
text: Mark Cuban, the billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks basketball team, told Bloomberg News that he might try to stop Harvey and Bob Weinstein from joining a buyout of Miramax films in a dispute over the performance of the “The Road,” a Weinstein movie.

headline: Tough Cameras Make Underwater Photography Easier
text: When normal people hear that they’re going to the Bahamas, they think: “Bathing suit!” “Sunscreen!” “Flip-flops!”

headline: Simon Lines Up More Investors for General Growth Plan
text: 10:03 p.m. | Updated The Simon Property Group said on Wednesday that it had lined up an additional $1.1 billion in new capital for its proposed investment in General Growth Properties, the bankrupt mall operator.

headline: ‘Hellhound on His Trail’
text: Chapter 1: City of White Gold

headline: What We’re Reading: iPad Jokes
text: The tech editors and reporters of the New York Times had a varied reading list Wednesday:

headline: Standouts at the Milan Furniture Fair
text: Fluid, lithe and angular pieces helped define this year’s Salone del Mobile in Milan.

headline: LED Lamps With Porcelain Flowers
text: Frederick P. Victoria, who founded the Manhattan furniture shop that bears his name in 1933, was “a huge pack rat,” said Freddy Victoria, his grandson and the vice president for new development at the company, which is now in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: The Conran Shop at ABC Carpet & Home
text: Fans of the Conran Shop, which for more than a decade resided in the distinctive — but painfully inconvenient — space underneath the Queensboro Bridge on East 59th Street, have every reason to be excited about the store’s relocation to the lower level of ABC Carpet & Home.

headline: A Collection of Felt Shades and Stools
text: Lily Latifi, an Iranian textile designer living in Paris, created her new collection of room dividers, shades and stools out of wool felt because “it’s like sculpture,” she said. “It’s very simple and minimalistic.” And in Iran, Ms. Latifi added, people who cannot afford a Persian carpet often have a rug of felt instead.

headline: Converting a Garage Outside Seattle Into a Tiny Home
text: SEATTLE

headline: Slobproof Sofas and Chairs
text: Debbie Wiener once cared about keeping her home pristine. Then she got married.

headline: Sales at John Robshaw and Others
text: At Armand Diradourian’s spring sale, which continues through May 1, cashmere throws and decorative pillows are 40 to 60 percent off (hand-knit pillows, originally $440, are $175; striped throws, originally $950, are $500); Armand Diradourian, 19 West 21st Street, (212) 924-5787.

headline: At the Kitchen and Bath Industry Show, Bathrooms That Beckon
text: YOU need a little razzle-dazzle to pull in the crowd at a trade show, and from a showbiz point of view — lights! music! dance! — it was hard to beat Kohler’s DTV II shower, set up prominently near the entrance to the Kitchen & Bath Industry Show at the McCormick Place Convention Center in Chicago last weekend.

headline: How the Other Half Lives
text: DUANE HAMPTON is a clipper and a stacker, of New Yorker cartoons, theater reviews, newspaper and magazine articles, hardcover books from the best-seller lists. They stand in neat bundles — napoleons of inspiration, exhortation and whimsy — competing for space with the many side chairs, end tables and foot stools that patrol her Park Avenue apartment.

headline: At the Milan Furniture Fair, a Fluid Design Emerges
text: MILAN

headline: Brides Magazine Hosts a Newlywed Nest
text: ELIZABETH CROWLEY, 27, leaned deep into the mouth of a calla lily and took its photo. “Purple is my color,” explained Ms. Crowley, who is marrying soon and whose three bridesmaids, she said, will be wearing purple dresses.

headline: California’s Solar Scorecard
text: California set an ambitious energy goal at the start of 2007: to have one million of the state’s households outfitted with solar roofs by 2018. Out of 7.7 million single family homes in the state, only about 50,000 homeowners (or 60,000, according to industry numbers) currently use solar panels, but advocates of the initiative in California say that the numbers have increased rapidly in the last year.

headline: $3 Million Deal Ends a Holdout in Brooklyn
text: For the past six years, Daniel Goldstein has been at the center of just about every rally, house party, concert and lawsuit opposed to the $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn.

headline: A Family Gathering, but Not for Long
text: “IT was never about the money,” Joshua White said. “It was about ‘Can we make a happening? Can we make a scene?’ ”

headline: Secret Baghdad Jail Held Sunnis From the North
text: BAGHDAD — An Iraqi security force under Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s direct command held hundreds of detainees from northern Iraq in an undisclosed prison in Baghdad, torturing dozens of them, until the country’s human rights minister and the United States intervened late last month, Iraqi and American officials said.

headline: Further Inquiries Into Former Rep. Massa
text: The House ethics committee announced Wednesday that it would open an inquiry into whether lawmakers or staff failed to pursue reports of misconduct by former Representative Eric Massa, a New York Democrat who resigned his seat last month after complaints of sexual harassment of male staffers.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,032 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: You Don’t Hide Behind These
text: SELIMA OPTIQUE’S Bond Street boutique is host to a small pop-up for Cutler & Gross, the London eyewear line, which includes vintage specs. The most requested is the Cat Eye sunglasses that Kate Hudson wore with a swinging ’60s fringed silver minidress in the movie “Nine.” The glasses, known by their style number, 866, come in turtle brown or black (below right, $425). The store is scheduled to be open until May, but since “pop-up” seems to be retail code for “test run,” the end date may be extended. Cutler & Gross Pop-up at Bond 07 by Selima Optique, 7 Bond Street, (212) 677-8487.

headline: Just Call Them Edwardian
text: YES, the co-owner (along with Paul Birardi) of Odin New York is named Eddy, and the in-house collection by the design team Duckie Brown, which was started last fall, is named Edward. But the two have no connection, said Eddy Chai. “I begged them not to do it,” he insisted, saying that he was outvoted by the designers. “We all have an Edward in our lives, so it seemed a good fit,” he said, resignedly. No matter. The bottom line is that the store’s recently arrived collection of short-sleeve plaid and checked shirts is a great way to embrace spring. Pictured above: Edward Blue Check, left, and Edward Blue Plaid, right, $185 each. The store also has plaid shirts from Eddy Chai’s brother, the designer Richard Chai (center, $169). Odin New York is at 328 East 11th Street, (212) 475-0666; 199 Lafayette Street, (212) 966-0026; and 750 Greenwich Street, (212) 420-8446; odinnewyork.com.

headline: Many Feet Shall Be Shod
text: SHOE worshipers will be making a pilgrimage to the Sigerson Morrison Warehouse Sale next week. On sale will be shoes from many past seasons — flats, heels, boots and sandals. Among the offerings is the pointy black flat with gold-sequined toe (above), which retailed at $495 and will be $150. Boots that were $995 are now $295; booties, reduced from $695 to $225. The sister line, Belle by Sigerson Morrison, offers edgier shoes at lower prices.

headline: Senate Hot Seat Awaits Goldman Officers and Trader
text: Fabrice P. Tourre, the Goldman Sachs trader accused of fraud by federal regulators, and at least three Goldman officers have agreed to testify before a Senate panel next week in an attempt to defend the firm’s dealings and reputation, Eric Dash of The New York Times reports, citing people briefed on the proceedings.

headline: G.O.P. and Finance Bill
text: To the Editor:

headline: Who Needs a $100 Bill?
text: When was the last time you used a $100 bill?

headline: At 40, Earth Day Is Now Big Business
text: So strong was the antibusiness sentiment for the first Earth Day in 1970 that organizers took no money from corporations and held teach-ins “to challenge corporate and government leaders.”

headline: Animal Cruelty Videos: A Ruling on Free Speech
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spoil Your Wrist
text: THE centerpiece of the first American retail store for Girard-Perregaux, the Swiss watchmaking firm that dates back to 1791, is a workshop used by a skilled watchmaker, Yuriy Vasekevich, who sits in a slightly elevated enclosed glass space. But Mr. Vaskevich isn’t a performance artist; he’s actually there to answer customers’ questions about the watches on sale. His artistlike presence does feel appropriate, however: the store (above) is practically a museum, hushed and reverential, displaying the wares of the luxury brand with prices from $10,000 to $500,000. The boutique is a compact 900 square feet with 16-foot ceilings, and a combination of surfaces including wood, metal, glass, leather and stone. There are two limited-edition timepieces that are exclusive to the New York boutique. The woman’s watch — named Shopping Madison — is bejeweled and white, and it sells for $20,600; 701 Madison Avenue (at 63rd Street), (646) 495-9915; girard-perregaux.com.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: E-Playgrounds Can Get Vicious
text: LAST February, I wrote a piece for Salon about the Postpartum Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder I experienced after the traumatic delivery of my son. I was able to, unfortunately, write it from the first person: In the article, I discussed statistics, research and my initial ambivalence over a diagnosis that seemed reserved for war veterans and rape victims. My piece was not meant to evoke sympathy; it was meant to be informative. Besides, with the amount of antidepressants ultimately prescribed for my condition, I was far too numb to feel sorry for myself.

headline: Trying to Save Wild Tigers by Rehabilitating Them
text: BALIMBING, Indonesia — The two wild Sumatran tigers, held in large, adjoining cages here, had killed at least eight people between them.

headline: Settlement for a Grand Canyon Tribe
text: The Havasupai Indians received a settlement from Arizona State University's Board of Regents for wrongful use of DNA samples given to university researchers in 1990.

headline: Leaders Start to Formulate Details of Greek Aid Program
text: PARIS — Talks over details of an international aid package for Greece began Wednesday as European leaders worked to reach a framework to help the troubled country.

headline: Fashion Goes Farm to Table
text: WHAT do daughters of Russian billionaires and Williamsburg scenesters have in sartorial common? Curiously, a penchant for overalls. On the February cover of Russian Vogue, a tousled blonde wears Ralph Lauren’s bibbed denim version, neo-hippie accessorized with a gold woven bustier, a low-slung fringed belt and skin-baring provocative side curve.

headline: How Judges See the Constitution
text: To the Editor:

headline: Dalai Lama Mourns on Facebook for Earthquake Victims
text: As my colleague Andrew Jacbos reports from Beijing, China mourned the victims of last week’s earthquake in western Qinghai Province on Wednesday. Most of the more than 2,000 victims who were killed were ethnic Tibetans and the disaster devastated Jiegu, a high-altitude Tibetan city.

headline: MSNBC Cancels Guest Anchor’s Show After a Controversial Segment
text: A television segment about angry media commentators created a furor inside MSNBC this week, one that extended outside the cable news channel after the segment’s host, Donny Deutsch, found himself dismissed as a guest anchor Wednesday.

headline: Mets and Marines Share a Day
text: Bill Welyczko earned himself the nickname the Human Magnet over in Vietnam, for the way flying objects found their way to him, twice when his vehicles hit land mines, once from direct rifle fire.

headline: Woods Commits to More Tournaments
text: Tiger Woods has again given tournament officials early notification of his commitment to play — this time naming two additional events for 2010. Just as he did before the Masters and next week’s PGA Tour event, the Quail Hollow Championship, Woods on Wednesday committed early to the Players Championship, set to begin May 6 at T.P.C. Sawgrass, and to the AT&T National, which will start July 1 at the Aronimink Golf Club outside Philadelphia.

headline: Are You Ready for Some Picks at Night?
text: The popularity of the N.F.L. draft on television is proof that millions of people can be riveted by the sight of Commissioner Roger Goodell reading index cards and posing beside the men whose names he has announced.

headline: Fouling to Protect a Lead: Debated but Rarely Done
text: The first-round playoff series last year between the Boston Celtics and the Chicago Bulls was a memorable montage of overtimes and clutch shots. Celtics Coach Doc Rivers remembers it for another reason.

headline: Japan Tries to Face Up to Growing Poverty Problem
text: MEMURO, Japan — Satomi Sato, a 51-year-old widow, knew she had it tough, raising a teenage daughter on the less than $17,000 a year she earned from two jobs. Still, she was surprised last autumn when the government announced for the first time an official poverty line — and she was below it.

headline: EBay Remakes an iPhone App Specifically for the iPad
text: The best eBay shopping experience — and one of the best shopping experiences on the Web — might just be on the iPad.

headline: Gasping Devils May Be Finished Before Getting Started
text: NEWARK — The Devils gathered Wednesday afternoon for what might have been the last practice of an inconsistent season, and the chatter among the players barely drifted over the glass at Prudential Center. They seem to have a lot of things to fix, and they do not have much time.

headline: U.S.O.C. Ends Plans for Its Own Olympic Channel
text: The United States Olympic Committee and Comcast have ended their plans to create an Olympic channel.

headline: Mets’ Setup Man Sidelined by Hamstring Tear
text: After just seven games in the United States, the right-handed reliever Ryota Igarashi joined the fraternity of injured Mets when the team placed him on the 15-day disabled list Wednesday with a minor tear in his left hamstring.

headline: Visa Buys CyberSource for $2 Billion
text: Betting that electronic payments will increasingly replace cash, Visa announced on Wednesday that it would pay $2 billion to buy CyberSource, which facilitates payments for big online merchants.

headline: The World of Doormen Is Obvious, Yet Mysterious
text: The thing about doormen is, often they were doing completely unrelated work, like selling survival gear or bagging pork chops, when something random happened and suddenly they were doormen, tipping their caps and announcing that the in-laws were on the way up with a fruitcake.

headline: At Least 6 People Abducted in Mexican Hotel Raids
text: MEXICO CITY — Armed men raided two hotels in the center of Monterrey, Mexico’s industrial capital, early Wednesday morning, hauling away four guests and as many as three staff members and sending a wave of panic across a city that has experienced a spate of violent episodes in recent weeks, the authorities said.

headline: Ruling for Plaintiff in Tobacco Case
text: R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, one of the country’s biggest cigarette makers, must pay $46.3 million to the widow of a Florida man who died from lung cancer in 1995, a jury in Gainesville, Fla., decided Wednesday.

headline: Earth Day, the Sequel
text: The genesis of the modern environmental movement was the subject of “Earth Days,” the most recent film by Robert Stone, an Oscar-nominated documentarian who has explored subjects ranging from the space race to the legacy of Lee Harvey Oswald’s life and death. So I thought it worth having a Skype chat with Stone about the meaning of that era, and the crossroads confronting the environmental community now — which relates to the subject of his next film.

headline: Using Cash as an Enticement in Tough Economic Times
text: THURSDAY is Earth Day, but for consumers, it does not have to be April 22 to be a green day.

headline: Admiration and Pluck Pave the Way to ‘Idiot’
text: Austin Regan, 24, above left, landed a job as an assistant director two years ago by knocking on the right door: in his case, the stage door where the celebrated director Michael Mayer, right, had a show. Mr. Regan studied theater at the Boston Conservatory, where he realized he loved directing more than acting. He has been busy with Mr. Mayer’s current musical, “American Idiot,” based on Green Day’s album of the same name, which opened Tuesday on Broadway.

headline: Invaders, Yes. But Perhaps Quite Tasty.

headline: What Is Sleep?
text: I am convinced that during bouts of insomnia I have sometimes slept without knowing it. The thoughts of waking seem to mingle with thoughts that may be part of sleep. Has the clock moved too quickly? Did I doze off? Some years ago in a rented house in Vermont, I couldn’t sleep and lay awake listening to the sounds of mice in the walls, bears that sounded like owls calling to each other in the woods and the wind in the trees. I then dreamed I was lying awake on the very bed where in fact I was sleeping, but someone had broken into the house. Because the room where I actually was and the room I dreamed were identical, the threshold between waking and sleeping had blurred and, when I woke up, I thought I heard the burglar moving around downstairs. It was a frightening experience, a temporary loss of the boundaries between waking experience and the illusions of dreams.

headline: How to Green Your Parents
text: Thursday is the 40th anniversary of the original Earth Day. Over the years, the impact of this once seminal day has lessened. Earth Day brings people together for nice gatherings and noble efforts but has, for the most part, made sustainable action more of an annual event than a daily habit. We’ve got to change that.

headline: Samaranch Pushed for Inclusion of Women
text: Juan Antonio Samaranch’s reign over the Olympic movement was tarnished by doping and bribery scandals. But to some, his successes as president of the International Olympic Committee far outweighed his failures, especially regarding one issue that remained dear to him: promoting women in sports.

headline: A Child’s Best Interest
text: Children need loving homes. Prejudice shouldn’t stand in the way of that. So it is welcome news that a state judge in Arkansas has struck down a pernicious 2008 state law that barred even qualified same-sex couples and other unmarried couples living together from serving as adoptive or foster parents.

headline: What Would You Do?
text: Many American workers know how a bad economy can chain them to a bad job or a bad boss. But what if you’re an immigrant guest worker and that boss holds your visa and can get rid of you with one phone call to the feds? What if he just threatened to call? Which would you choose  to be exploited or deported? To suffer silently here or in destitution back home?

What he got, courtesy of an erupting volcano in Iceland, was more like a presidential road trip — nine countries in four days — evoking the sedate diplomacy of a bygone era.

headline: Facing Political Challenges Along With the Legal Ones
text: Pedro Espada Jr., the outspoken State Senate majority leader, likes to point out that he is the state’s highest ranking Latino elected official. The network of nonprofit health care clinics he founded in the Bronx has cemented that status and won him the loyalty of voters who believe he has brought much-needed care to a neglected part of the city.

headline: Japan Bans Beef Exports
text: Japanese authorities imposed a temporary ban on beef exports on Tuesday after finding suspected cases of foot-and-mouth disease in cows on a single farm in southern Japan. The agriculture minister, Hirotaka Akamatsu, told reporters that mouth ulcers, a symptom of the disease, were detected in three cows from the farm in southern Miyazaki prefecture, an area known for its prized beef. The ban affects Japan’s relatively tiny exports — worth about $40 million last year — of mainly gourmet beef to countries like China and the United States. The agriculture ministry said it would also kill all 16 cows on the farm. The disease, which is not fatal to humans, was last detected in Japan 10 years ago. MARTIN FACKLER

In an important committee vote on Wednesday, 13 senators  including one Republican for a refreshing change  approved a measure that would go a long way toward regulating derivatives, the complex instruments at the heart of the bubble, the bust, the bailouts and the Goldman case.

headline: Afghanistan: Talks on Taliban Postponed
text: Afghan officials said they would delay by several weeks a “peace jirga” intended to establish the framework for how to negotiate with members of the Taliban who want to reconcile with the government. The jirga, a gathering that is expected to bring together more than 1,000 government officials, tribal elders and other Afghan leaders, was originally planned to start on May 2. But Afghan officials said in Kabul on Wednesday that they had decided to delay the gathering two to three weeks until after President Hamid Karzai’s trip to Washington in May.

headline: Kyrgyzstan: Ousted Leader Is Defiant
text: The deposed president of Kyrgyzstan, Kurmanbek Bakiyev, insisted on Wednesday that he was still his country’s legitimate leader, even though he resigned in a handwritten note before going into exile. Mr. Bakiyev, left, was driven from office this month after major demonstrations turned violent. “I, as president of Kyrgyzstan, as guarantor of the Constitution, have not given up my responsibility for the catastrophe which my people are enduring,” he said. Leaders of the interim government scoffed at his remarks, saying that his resignation had been recognized internationally. The interim authorities had signed off on a deal to allow him to leave the country, but the chief of staff for the government appeared to backtrack on Tuesday, saying the government would eventually seek his extradition.

In the wake of reports that his chief of staff received a $40,000 raise just before the resignation, the panel said it would also look into whether “monies or other payments may have been misappropriated, or otherwise fraudulently or improperly distributed.” Mr. Massa has denied approving the increase.

headline: Miracle Worker
text: The fountain of youth is legendary in myth and history; some scientists and skin-care experts think it still exists, thanks to an enzyme called telomerase. Dr. Gregory Bays Brown of RéVive has created a $1,500 skin cream, Peau Magnifique, containing telomerase. In fact, the 2009 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine went to three scientists who discovered how chromosomes are protected by the enzyme, and further research could prove telomerase to be a key factor in infinite cell proliferation. No one’s promising the death of funerals yet, but hope springs eternal. Here’s the CliffsNote: As cells divide, they send copies of themselves to new cells. But that copying process chops off bits of the originals’ protective tips. As we age, the tips, known as telomeres, get shorter and shorter till the original cells die, and we do too. Cancer cells, stem cells and some rogue cells produce a substance that blocks the snipping process — telomerase. How it can be deconstructed, harnessed and activated remains to be seen: lab-made telomerase would have to penetrate skin, pass through tissue and cell walls, and hook into chromosomal activity in order to be effective. But RéVive’s Brown claims that telomerase can recruit the skin’s resting stem cells — which exist in case of injury — to manufacture new skin. So far, there are no major peer-review studies or clinical trials. And animal testing isn’t possible since only humans produce it. Nevertheless, the party has definitely begun; in addition to RéVive, Jan Marini’s Age Intervention Regeneration Booster and Goldfaden’s DNA Telomere Cream boast telomere science. Other beauty products are sure to follow.

headline: Moore Vents About Greek Bailout, Report Says
text: Louis Moore Bacon’s feeling about the European Union‘s plans to bail out Greece? He hated it.

headline: By Fits and Starts, an Arduous Clean-Up
text: Judging from this 70-year timeline, the history of environmental awareness and action in the United States is one of lonely voices and local crises growing into potent national concerns.

headline: Your Jokes: ‘All the Wrong Notes’
text: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: Was Goldman Deal Fraud, or Just Flawed?
text: As a report surfaced Wednesday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had received testimony, as yet unreleased, from an employee at the hedge fund Paulson & Company that may undermine its fraud case against Goldman Sachs, industry observers wondered if the regulator’s suit against the investment bank might be more than a little shaky.

headline: In the Wild, With Tent and Tablecloth
text: LAST year, Janelle Criscione celebrated her 66th birthday on a white-water rafting trip along the Snake River in Idaho and Oregon. Along the way, she camped and hiked in rugged Hells Canyon, North America’s deepest river gorge. She also chopped vegetables and sampled wine. Ms. Criscione, a retired nurse who lives in St. Louis, is a big outdoor enthusiast; for her birthday the year before, she’d gone climbing in the Teton Mountains in Wyoming.

headline: G.M. Looks for Design Edge With New Studio in Seoul
text: For the past several years, General Motors has relied on its partnership with the South Korean automaker Daewoo for the design of many of its small cars, like the Chevrolet Cruze. With South Korea — behind the recent rise of Hyundai — becoming a stronger force in the auto industry, G.M. is now giving its Advanced Design Studio in Seoul star treatment with a move to one of the city’s most trendy districts.

headline: Obama Issues Sharp Call for Wall St. Reforms
text: President Obama is traveling to the shadow of Wall Street on Thursday to counter what he calls “the furious efforts of industry lobbyists” trying to weaken or kill new financial regulations that he says are needed to stave off a second Great Depression, Peter Baker reports in The New York Times.

headline: Ash Turns Routine Flights Into Overland Odysseys
text: Airports rumbled back to life across Europe, but travelers who opted for land or sea journeys told of epic adventures. Read more.Related

headline: BofA Sells $1.9 Billion in Assets to Axa P.E.
text: Bank of America has sold a $1.9 billion portfolio of private equity investments to Axa Private Equity, Flore Larger, a spokeswoman for the unit of the French insurance giant, confirmed to DealBook on Thursday.

headline: Carlyle and RPK Capital Plan Aviation Venture
text: U.S. private equity firm Carlyle Group intends to invest $600 million in a joint venture with RPK Capital Management that will buy commercial aviation assets around the world, the Financial Times said.

headline: Sampler: Cash to Avoid Eviction, and Looted Appliances
text: Handing Out Cash to Stave Off Homelessness | In the past two years, Antonio Moore, 30, has gone from a $75,000-a-year job as a mortgage consultant to working part-time for $10-an-hour as a line cook at a fast-food restaurant. He lost his three-bedroom house and his Lexus. Mr. Moore, who lives in San Mateo, is now in danger of becoming homeless because he cannot pay the rent on his studio apartment. He’s been able to avoid eviction through a $1.5 billion federal program, financed with stimulus money, that quickly sent a $775 check to his landlord.  [The New York Times]

headline: TPG Pays $1.3 Billion for American Tire
text: TPG Capital is shelling out $1.43 billion to drive off with American Tire Distributors, Reuters reported.

headline: The President and Club Wagner
text: Our colleague John Harwood did a good interview with President Obama on Wednesday. A full transcript is available here. I wanted to highlight one section on the deficit.

headline: The Lipstick Foreclosure: Madoff Site in Trouble
text: It’s not often that a criminal mastermind’s former lair goes up for sale.

headline: Viewer’s Guide to First Round of the 2010 N.F.L. Draft
text: Sigmund Bloom of Draftguys.com will help preview and analyze the draft for the Fifth Down. He and Cecil Lammey host an information-packed podcast at FootballGuys.com,  and you can follow him on Twitter here.

headline: Bangkok Explosions Stoke Fears of Wider Violence
text: BANGKOK — Five grenades exploded in the heart of Bangkok’s business district on Thursday evening, killing at least one person and wounding 75 as rival groups of protesters demonstrated and shouted insults at one another across a makeshift barricade.

headline: Times Company Reports Profit
text: The New York Times Company reported results on Thursday that reflected a turnaround driven by cost-cutting and an improved advertising market.

headline: The Early Word: The Closer
text: With senators advancing a proposal to rewrite the laws governing Wall Street, President Obama travels to New York City today to make the argument for the overhaul, confronting industry leaders on their home turf.

headline: ‘South Park’ Episode Is Altered After Muslim Group’s Warning
text: 3:36 p.m. | Updated An episode of “South Park” that continued a story line involving the Prophet Muhammad was shown Wednesday night on Comedy Central with audio bleeps and image blocks reading “CENSORED” after a Muslim group warned the show’s creators that they could face violence for depicting that holy Islamic prophet. Revolution Muslim, a group based in New York, wrote on its Web site that the “South Park” creators Matt Stone and Trey Parker “will probably wind up like Theo Van Gogh” for an episode shown last week in which a character said to be the Prophet Muhammad was seen wearing a bear costume. Mr. Van Gogh was slain in Amsterdam in 2004 after making a film that discussed the abuse of Muslim women in some Islamic societies.

headline: Sales of Existing Homes Are Aided by Tax Credit
text: Sales of existing homes rose sharply in March, an indication that a government tax credit was luring buyers to the market.

headline: U.S. Resists Push by Allies for Tactical Nuclear Cuts
text: TALLINN, Estonia — Fresh from signing a strategic nuclear arms agreement with Russia, the United States is parrying a push by several NATO allies to withdraw its aging stockpile of tactical nuclear weapons from Europe.

headline: Many Alzheimer’s Patients Find Comfort in Books
text: Familiar music can engage those with Alzheimer’s when almost nothing else can, researchers have shown. Now it appears that books written for these patients may have a similar effect.

headline: Can Cobra Be Extended for a Disability?
text: Q.

headline: Lead Poisoning Hazards Persist
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Blackstone Posts $360 Million 1st-Quarter Profit
text: The Blackstone Group reported a $360 million profit for its first quarter, swinging from a loss at the same time last year as the private equity industry continues to rebound from the depths of the credit crisis.

headline: For United, a Merger Still Looms
text: The announcement by US Airways on Thursday that it was ending merger discussions with United Airlines clears the path for rival talks between Continental Airlines and United.

headline: Mumbai Oberoi Hotel Reopens Grander Than Before
text: On Wednesday, the Oberoi Hotel, one of two five-star hotel complexes attacked by 10 Pakistan-based gunmen in November 2008, will welcome its first guests after a comprehensive $45 million reconstruction.

headline: Killings Rattle Pakistan’s Swat Valley
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least five anti-Taliban political leaders have been killed in the Swat Valley in northern Pakistan over the past two weeks, residents there said, raising fears that the Taliban forces that once ruled the area could be regrouping.

headline: Sustainable Art | The Starns’s Big Bambu
text: Big Bambu, the massive installation by the artists Mike and Doug Starn, is green is every sense of the word. It’s green, literally. It’s made from one of the most sustainable materials around. And it’s even recyclable. The original 50 foot tall sculpture, which was assembled from a network of 2000 bamboo poles at the former Talix Foundry in Beacon, New York, was reconfigured into a T for the cover of our 5th anniversary issue. And it recently moved to the roof of the Metropolitan Museum where it will be on view from April 27 through October 31.

headline: Search Ends for Missing Oil Workers
text: NEW ORLEANS — The Coast Guard called off its search Friday for 11 oil rig workers who had been missing since an explosion on the rig Tuesday night in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: That’s Entertainment!
text: Jim Manzi has written a characteristically searching critique of Mark Levin’s “Liberty and Tyranny.” Kathryn Jean Lopez responds:

headline: Q. and A.: From the Streets to a Powerful State Perch
text: On the eve of the 40th anniversary of Earth Day, we had a few questions for Pete Grannis, the commissioner of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, a longtime environmental campaigner and one of the 20 original signers of the Earth Day proclamation in 1970. Here are his answers, which he provided by e-mail.

headline: Greece and Talk of Regulation Hamper Trading
text: Wall Street overcame concerns about Greece’s financial troubles on Thursday and rebounded from early losses, helped by enthusiasm for shares of consumer-oriented companies.

headline: Staying Alive: Crawling From the Wreckage
text: The day after laying off half of my workers, I sat with the others in my office. They knew we were in trouble, but The Partner’s policy of silence had kept me from revealing just how bad it was. They were angry about being kept in the dark, and many were ready to quit. So I made a promise that from that day forward I would answer any question, any time, as completely and honestly as possible. I laid out for them what the near-term future would look like: we had work, but not much. More might be coming, but maybe not.

headline: Blood Test May Reduce Biopsies  After Transplants
text: A blood test that analyzes genetic activity could let heart transplant patients avoid many of the invasive and uncomfortable biopsies now used to monitor whether their immune systems are rejecting their new organs, doctors said in a study published Thursday.

headline: Can Botox Stop the Hands From Shaking?
text: Millions of people suffer from the common but mysterious ailment known as “essential tremor” — the uncontrollable shaking of the hands, head or other body parts that occurs during voluntary movement. Here, one reader asks whether Botox is a good option for somebody with shaking in the hand.

headline: Popcast: Merle Haggard, Willie Nelson, The Morning Benders and More
text: This week: Jon Caramanica compares the latest albums from the country legends Merle Haggard and Willie Nelson, “I Am What I Am” and “Country Music”; Ben Ratliff on the Houston rapper Devin the Dude’s latest release, “Suite #420″; and the Morning Benders perform live and discuss their new album, “Big Echo,” with Ben Sisario. Sia Michel is the host.

headline: Leave Your Kids at the Playground
text: In honor of “Take Our Sons and Daughters to Work Day,” Lenore Skenazy, who inspired the “free range” parenting movement when she allowed her 9-year-old son to take the subway home by himself and then wrote about it, has suggested a riff on this day. She has proposed that May 22 be declared “Take Our Children to the Park … and Leave Them There Day.”Her vision, as described on her blog:

headline: Straighten Out Your Game With an Alignment Aid
text: There is something very elementary that recreational players can do to improve their games in a highly sophisticated way. First, when you get to the range, pick a target in the distance to aim at — a specific flag or a cluster of small trees. Then, lay a club on the ground parallel with your shoulders so that it is pointing in the direction of the target. Before you hit your first ball, it is essential that you use an alignment aid to train your eyes to aim properly.

headline: A Pastor’s Job Offers Become a Curse
text: Luis Malagon felt blessed when he, his wife and their daughter were offered $11,000 a month to work at a new religious social service agency being planned in Brooklyn. He quit his job as a building inspector in South Carolina in February, put his house up for sale and borrowed money to move to Sunset Park.

headline: Dear FloFab: Open My Wine, Now!
text: Each Thursday, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Now Custom Ordering | Volkcraft’s Craft
text: “We make clothes because it makes us happy,” says David Gensler, the designer, branding guru, business innovator and main brain behind the KDU, a Brooklyn-based consultancy and design collective. The multifaceted branding department (with clients like LVMH and Diesel) is the collective’s breadwinner, but Volkcraft, its meticulous men’s clothing line, is the love child. The jacket-focused collection, designed by Gensler, the creative director Aerosyn-Lex Mestrovic and the senior designer Portia Wells, consists of made-to-measure garments that combine Savile Row luxury, avant-garde fashion and high-tech sportswear; it is meant to evoke a jet-setting, high-performing lifestyle similar to their own. “One week we’ll be standing by an erupting volcano in Iceland and the next we’ll be walking the Great Wall of China,” Gensler says.

headline: After ‘Office’ Hours, Mindy Kaling Writes a Book
text: On “The Office,” the bubbly Kelly Kapoor does not seem capable of writing much more than her name (with smiley faces in the o’s). In real life, Mindy Kaling, the actress and writer who portrays her on that NBC comedy, is much more prolific: her work as an author includes the play “Matt & Ben” (written with Brenda Withers), numerous episodes of “The Office” and a prodigious amount of blog posts and tweets. And soon, a book.

headline: Thursday Reading: How to Earn Additional JetBlue Points
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: German Bishop Resigns His Position in Latest Jolt to Church
text: BERLIN — A German bishop accused of beating children decades ago when he was a priest has tendered his resignation to Pope Benedict XVI, the diocese in Augsburg said Thursday, the latest jolt to the Roman Catholic Church in Germany as it grapples with a swirling sexual abuse scandal.

headline: Big Picture Examined at B.C.S. Meetings
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — The Bowl Championship Series meetings usually revolve around minutiae, like who will be voting in the Harris college football poll and how the standings formula will be tweaked. But when the 11 Football Bowl Subdivision conference commissioners gathered here this week, those issues rested on the back burner.

headline: A Last Laugh From Malcolm McLaren
text: Malcolm McLaren, the punk provocateur and former manager of the Sex Pistols, was buried on Thursday in a coffin befitting the sloganeering style he favored in life, BBC News reported. Mr. McLaren died of mesothelioma  this month at the age of 64. Among those attending his funeral were the musicians Adam Ant, whom Mr. McLaren managed, and Bob Geldof, as well as the fashion designer Vivienne Westwood, Mr. McLaren’s former partner, who wore a headband reading “Chaos.”

headline: Kimmel: ‘Freedom Fighters Like This Guy’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Yesterday was 4/20, known to stoners around the country as National Weed Day. There were pro-marijuana legalization rallies all around the country, especially here in California, where freedom fighters like this guy exercised their right to free speech vigorously. “Here in the meadow, people were chilling out. Some, maybe too much. We’re here just to have a bunch of fun in a field.” That’s a good way to spend a Tuesday, while your parents are paying tuition.

headline: Letterman: ‘Talking About Air Travel’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Talking about air travel and the volcano. The good news, ladies and gentlemen, regular airline service is resuming. The bad news — regular airline service is resuming.

headline: Leno: ‘School Lunches Are a Threat’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Well, the government said today Somali pirates being held in U.S. custody will be brought to the United States for prosecution, and they will be tried by a jury of their peers. So I’m guessing that’s what, Goldman Sachs?

headline: South Korean Navy Was Warned of ‘Human Torpedo’
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea’s military intelligence warned the country’s navy of a possible human torpedo attack from North Korea months before a South Korean warship sank in a mysterious explosion in late March, a newspaper report said Thursday.

headline: CUNY TV Programs Awarded Four Emmys
text: City University of New York has had more and more to boast about lately, and now it’s collected four local Emmys for its programming.

text: In a new video, reporters Sewell Chan and Jackie Calmes discuss the latest developments in the Congressional debate to overhaul financial regulation.

text: I lost it to Stephen Sondheim, and I still marvel at how lucky I was to have had such an initiator.

headline: On Our Radar
text: A European Union report concludes that biofuels produce up to four times the carbon dioxide emissions that regular gasoline and diesel do.

headline: Tube Tops and Teddy Bears
text: LOTS of young women today show their bedrooms, clothes and character in the thousands of “haul” videos made for YouTube. These are short videos that feature a woman’s recent shopping haul, hence the name.

headline: Volcano Crisis Could Delay Emissions Regulation, Airline Chief Says
text: The top representative for the airline industry asserted Thursday that the disruption caused by the eruption of an Icelandic volcano had undermined efforts to include aviation in the European Union’s Emissions Trading System.

headline: Investigation of Jail Death Is Criticized in Russia
text: MOSCOW — Two human rights campaigners said Thursday that despite personal intervention by President Dmitri A. Medvedev, officials responsible for the death of a lawyer last year in pretrial detention were facing no substantial punishment.

headline: More Hybrids to Hit the Streets
text: Thursday, as we know, is Earth Day, and while no one is suggesting that N.Y.P.D. Blue morph into the N.Y.P.D. Green, the Police Department is nonetheless taking steps to reduce its carbon footprint.

headline: Video of Oil Rig Fire and Rescue Efforts
text: As my colleague Campbell Robertson reports, after an explosion on oil rig off the southeast coast of Louisiana on Tuesday night, rescue workers are still searching in the Gulf of Mexico for 11 missing members of the crew.

headline: Who’s Who of Wall St. at Obama’s Speech
text: We’ve already reported that Goldman Sachs‘s top executives, Lloyd C. Blankfein and Gary D. Cohn, will be on hand for President Obama‘s speech on overhauling financial regulation.

headline: Obama to Wall St.: ‘Join Us, Instead of Fighting Us’
text: President Obama took his rhetoric of reform on Thursday to the nation’s financial capital in a high-profile foray to chide Wall Street bankers for their “reckless practices” and to press for tighter regulations meant to avert another financial crisis.

headline: Obama to Wall St.: ‘Join Us, Instead of Fighting Us’
text: 12:57 p.m. | Updated President Obama ventured into the backyard of Wall Street on Thursday to directly challenge some of the nation’s most influential bankers to call off their “battalions of financial industry lobbyists” and embrace a new regulatory structure to avert another economic crisis, The New York Times’s Peter Baker reports.

headline: Interview: Bryan Goluboff
