text: Bryan Goluboff, the writer and director of "Beware the Gonzo," discusses his comedy about a rebel high school journalist who starts an underground newspaper.

headline: D’Arcy James Returning to ‘Next to Normal’
text: When “Next to Normal” had its premiere Off Broadway at Second Stage Theater in 2008, Brian d’Arcy James starred as Dan Goodman, a man trying to keep his family together in the face of his wife’s crippling depression. When the decision was made to move the musical, which later won the Tony and a Pulitzer Prize, to Broadway’s Booth Theater, Mr. d’Arcy James had already committed to starring as a big green ogre in the musical “Shrek.”  Starting May 17, Mr. d’Arcy  James will be returning to the role he originated, replacing J. Robert Spencer. He’ll rejoin Alice Ripley, who won a Tony for her performance as the wife, and Jennifer Damiano and Adam Chanler-Berat, who play the Goodmans’ daughter and her boyfriend, who were all in the original production with Mr. d’Arcy James.

headline: Tracking a Pastor and His Promise of Jobs
text: Our colleague David Gonzalez just posted his latest installment in the increasingly tangled saga of the Rev. Isidro Bolaños, the Brooklyn pastor who promised jobs at a new social service agency to hundreds of his congregants, got them to give him copies of their identity documents and disappeared. The story behind the story has its share of twists and turns, too. We asked David to share them with us.

headline: No More Bailouts?
text: President Obama, in his New York speech, accepted the argument that the most important goal for financial reform is to prevent future bailouts. He claims the bill would allow the closure of companies without threatening the rest of the system.

headline: All Rise for the Draft
text: It is mostly a testament to the wearying nature of recent news — the waves of Tiger Woods to Ben Roethlisberger revelations that have millions of parents considering grounding their daughters until they turn 35 — but the pure silliness that is N.F.L. draft mania actually feels a little liberating this year. It’s comforting to know Mel Kiper Jr. can be counted on to bring his hair and erupt in a volcano of statistics and analysis after every pick. There are the fans in their jerseys screaming wildly for players who they have never seen play. There is N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell trading his sheriff’s hat for the role of game show host.

headline: Q&A: A First-Time Trip to Brazil
text: Q.

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: 3 American Writers in Running for Orange Prize
text: Three American authors have been named to the shortlist for the  Orange Prize for fiction, the British honor awarded annually for a novel written by a woman in English.  The finalists this year include Barbara Kingsolver for “The Lacuna,” Attica Locke for “Black Water Rising” and Lorrie Moore for “A Gate at the Stairs.” Ms. Locke is a first-time novelist. The list also includes the much-garlanded Hilary Mantel, for “Wolf Hall,” which has already won the Man Booker Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction. Rounding out the list of finalists are the British writer Rosie Alison for “The Very Thought of You,” and Monique Roffey, who was born in Trinidad, for “The White Woman on the Green Bicycle.”  The winner will be announced on June 9 in London. The prize comes with a check for about $46,000 and a bronze statue called a Bessie.

headline: A Passion for the Cinematic Avant-Garde
text: Even if you don’t immediately recognize Chuck Workman’s name, you almost surely know his cinematic output: for two decades he has made film montages for the Academy Awards ceremony, including its annual “In Memoriam” tribute sequence. He is also an Oscar winner for best short film and the director of features like “Superstar,” a documentary about Andy Warhol, and “The Source,” a film about the Beat poets.

headline: Earth Day Protest at an Oakland Gas Station
text: At 8 a.m. Thursday, 50 people gathered at the Valero gas station at the corner of Telegraph and Grand Avenues near downtown Oakland. Their issue was the role of the oil company Valero in the campaign for a ballot measure to derail, at least temporarily, the 2006 California law designed to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions to 1990 levels by 2020.

headline: At Coachella | Poppy De Villeneuve
text: What is it about music festival photography that is so transfixing? Iconic crowd shots from Newport, Woodstock, Live Aid or Glastonbury can do more to explain an era’s zeitgeist than shelves of sociological studies. Music’s liberating power combined with the absence of authority can make for mesmerizing glimpses of youth culture — its tribes, rituals, uniforms, couplings, body adornment, accouterments — in all its uninhibited glory.

headline: Cheney Endorses Rubio in Florida
text: Former Vice President Dick Cheney is the latest high-profile Republican to endorse Marco Rubio in Florida’s Senate primary.

headline: A Convenient, Mysterious Service From Cable Companies
text: A year ago, I wrote about how Cablevision, my cable company, had quietly begun installing Wi-Fi hot spots all over its market area: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. These hot spots began popping up in all the public areas: shopping centers, main streets, train stations, parks, marinas and sports complexes. The best part: these hot spots are free to anyone who subscribes to Internet service from Cablevision at home.

headline: TV Deal Pushes N.C.A.A. Closer to 68-Team Tournament
text: CBS and Turner Broadcasting said Thursday that they would pay $10.8 billion from 2011 to 2024 to carry the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament. The broadcasting partners will show the next 14 versions of the tournament on four networks and carry each game nationally, ending CBS’s regional coverage of early-round games.

headline: TimesCast | April 22, 2010
text: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Thursday.  Topics include efforts to prevent the next financial crisis, politicians on a diet and new conventional weapons.

headline: What We’re Reading: Selling Earth Day
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: U.S. Attorney Sues Superintendent for Sexual Harassment
text: A superintendent and convicted child sex offender who worked for eight years at three buildings on Manhattan’s Upper West Side has been sued by the United States attorney’s office, which accused him of sexually harassing female tenants and demanding sexual favors in exchange for reductions in rent.

headline: F.D.R.’s Brief Dip Into Tidal Energy
text: Eastport, a city of about 1,600 people that is about as down east in Maine as you can get, has seen better days. At one point in its history it was the sardine capital of the East, but overfishing and resulting catch restrictions led to that industry’s long slow death. The old canneries along the shore are shuttered and decaying, and the last one in the region — indeed, in the country — about 50 miles to the southeast in Prospect Harbor, closed just last week.

headline: An Unforeseen Complication of Electronic Medical Records
text: One afternoon several years ago, I found myself faced with an unexpected challenge while seeing patients in clinic. The hospital had just put in effect an electronic medical records system, or EMR, and along with the dozens of shiny new computer terminals installed in nursing stations on every ward came the promise of fewer missing charts, streamlined information and efficient work-flow patterns for all. By the time the first computers were finally installed in exam rooms, my colleagues and I were already fluent enough in the system’s software that we were creating and trading order sets, progress note templates and clinical checklists like kids exchanging baseball cards and CDs.

headline: Start-Up Goes After Big Data With Hadoop Helper
text: Over the past couple of years, Hadoop has turned into the Justin Bieber of megascale data center software, with just about every Web company of consequence — Yahoo, Amazon.com, Facebook and Twitter, for example — fawning over its mystical powers. Now a start-up, Datameer, has appeared on the scene as the latest Hadoop groupie, but with a tweak on the Hadoop approach.

headline: Reid Calls for Debate on Financial Bill
text: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said today that he would ask Republicans to begin debating a bill to tighten regulation of Wall Street — but he and other Democratic leaders said they suspected the Republicans of stalling and would try to push ahead one way or another.

headline: Juggling Patients and Computers in the Exam Room
text: Can physicians type and doctor at the same time?

headline: Saab Keeps North American Headquarters in Michigan
text: ROYAL OAK, Mich. — On Tuesday evening, Saab North America welcomed the media here to its new corporate headquarters for a grand-opening celebration, where the company also announced an almost $50,000 price for the new 2010 Saab 9-5.

headline: Study Finds Increasing Willingness to Switch Banks
text: Customers’ satisfaction with their banks continues to drop and they appear more willing to switch banks than in the past, according to a study released Thursday by J.D. Power and Associates.

headline: Earth Day: The Simple, Local Stuff
text: A quick photographic Earth Day note: Even as societies ponder how to smooth the human journey on a finite planet at the global scale, it doesn’t hurt to try to get things reasonably right in our own neighborhoods.

headline: Cleaning Smudges From the iPad
text: Children love your shiny new iPad, and it has the fingerprints to prove it. What’s the best way to keep it looking new?

headline: Close Encounters of the Annual Kind
text: It’s almost summer, when legions of interns, do-gooders and intern do-gooders arrive in the city to make life easier (by fetching coffee, indoors) and a bit more unpleasant (by waving and trying to get at your wallet and/or your soul, outdoors.)

headline: CenturyTel to Acquire Qwest in $10.6 Billion Deal
text: In one of the largest telecommunications deals in years, CenturyTel, a provider of local phone and Internet services, said Thursday that it would acquire Qwest Communications in a $10.6 billion stock swap.

headline: Learning While You Dream
text: Why do we dream? It’s a question dream analysts and sleep researchers have been studying for years. Now new research suggests that some dreams may actually result from the brain’s effort to keep learning, even as we sleep.

headline: Country Inns, a World Apart
text: FIVE years ago Richard Gere was riding past an abandoned restaurant in Bedford, N.Y. The building, formerly an Italian joint called Nino’s, was “on the verge of falling down,” he said. So Mr. Gere, who lives nearby, had an idea: Why not buy the property and turn it into an inn?

headline: Reid Calls for Debate on Financial Bill
text: From David M. Herszenhorn at The Caucus:

headline: Trying to Corner the Market on Charity
text: WATER MILL, N.Y.

headline: Costume Drama | Under the Big Top With Kym Barrett
text: The Australian costume designer Kym Barrett kitted up Val Kilmer for a trip to the “Red Planet,” camouflaged George Clooney and the other “Three Kings” for a tour of duty in Iraq, put Speed Racer in a sleek onesie and Keanu Reeves in a black leather trench. This Christmas her sleek, now trademark styling returns with “The Green Hornet,” Michel Gondry’s take on the classic ’60s TV serial. With such a list of film credits to her name, it was only a matter of time until Barrett was tapped to do the costumes for another high-flying visual extravaganza: Robert Lepage’s 2010 production of Cirque de Soleil, which opens in Montreal on April 22.

headline: Two Arrested in Killing of Livery-Cab Driver
text: 7:11 p.m., April 23 |

headline: White House Chooses Cutter to Pitch Health Care
text: Stephanie Cutter, the Democratic communications strategist who spearheaded the White House effort last year to win Senate confirmation of Justice Sonia Sotomayor to the Supreme Court, is returning to the Obama administration to help sell the newly passed health care bill.

headline: TimesCast: Obama’s Speech at Cooper Union
text: President Obama traveled to New York City today to promote his plan to overhaul financial regulation, asking Wall Street to embrace a new regulatory structure meant to avert another economic crisis.

headline: Gallery Owner Says Artist Has ‘Blacklist’
text: Naming names is a rare thing in the highly private business of selling art, but a Manhattan gallery owner testified in federal court this week that a prominent contemporary painter maintains an extensive blacklist of art collectors and dealers whom she punishes for reselling her works, Art & Auction magazine reported Wednesday on its Web site.

headline: Good Company: The Musicals of Stephen Sondheim
text: A look at the New York stage productions of the composer's shows through reviews, photos and videos.

headline: ‘Divine Right’s Trip': A Forgotten Hippie Novel
text: Today is Earth Day. Which has me thinking, via a little free association, about Gurney Norman’s “Divine Right’s Trip” — a hippie, druggie road-trip-novel-cum-lifestyle-manifesto that first appeared “episodically” as a series of sidebars on right-hand pages of Stewart Brand’s 1971 “Last Whole Earth Catalog.”

headline: Portraits: Alice Neel’s Legacy of Realism
text: ALICE NEEL’S art is unmistakable, from her startling images of 20th-century art-world figures to her signature pregnant nudes. One of the first artists in the Works Progress Administration program of the Great Depression, Neel started out as a Social Realist and then defiantly painted figurative work during the height of Abstract Expressionism. She focused on the least fashionable of realist genres, portraiture, which had long since been declared dead, bringing to it an electrifying verve.

headline: Suspension Gets Goodell’s Point Across to Rookies
text: Commissioner Roger Goodell met with a group of incoming rookies this week in New York for the annual N.F.L. draft. His message, not surprisingly, was about conduct, comportment, behavior. He told the young men that the N.F.L. wanted players to understand the importance of responsibility and good judgment.

headline: A Movie Goes to Press
text: Good old-fashioned print media are the focus of Bryan Goluboff’s teen comedy “Beware the Gonzo.” The film’s lead character, Eddie “Gonzo” Gillman (Ezra Miller), is a rebel with a reverence for the printed word and publishes an underground newspaper at his school.

headline: Reflections on Our Found Poem Challenge
text: Volcanic ash, the Tea Party, spaghetti, mean girls, punk rock, Timothy McVeigh, Timothy Leary, Spanish spices, Chicano art, Haiti, Lily Pulitzer, coal mining, the Beatles, lettuce, gray hair, Alexander McQueen, a Brooklyn grocer, marijuana, Afghanistan, drought in southern China, Duke basketball and lice.

headline: Where Was Facebook’s Location?
text: 3:02 p.m. | Updated: Added a link to the Inside Facebook blog about location references in the developer tools.

headline: The Morning Skate: Errors Doom Sabres, Canadiens and the Jelly Hits the Wall
text: During our usual Tuesday night skate, Augie Cardinale, who was playing on the other team, shot the puck innocently from the corner toward our net and our defenseman, Mike Williams, attempted steer the puck out of danger. But he accidentally directed it past our goalie Matty DeNicola and into the net. “Dan Boyle!” some of us shouted at Mike, although it wasn’t exactly the same situation that gained the Sharks defenseman some measure of infamy a few nights earlier in San Jose’s Game 3 loss to Colorado.

headline: Take Five: Jewish Ritual and Vietnamese Poetry
text: Wondering what to do this weekend? We have you covered.

headline: To See the Art, Just Stroll the Streets
text: Long Island City is dotted with former industrial buildings, but it is also rich in artistic endeavors, like the transformation of a warehouse and a landfill into public art spaces. Socrates Sculpture Park, the former landfill, is a huge green canvas for large artworks; recent displays include a bright yellow walkway made of inner tubes, and a concrete rat and pigeon on a podium. And some of the local art is accidental. At 49th Avenue and Vernon Boulevard, a passer-by will see at dusk the nearby Gothic spires of St. Mary’s Roman Catholic Church and, above the rooftops and across the river, the twinkling lights of the Empire State and Chrysler Buildings.

headline: Answers About Transgender Issues, Part 2
text: Following is the second set of responses from Dr. Laura Erickson-Schroth, who is working on “Trans Bodies, Trans Selves,” a resource guide for transgender and other gender-variant people, covering health, legal issues, cultural and social questions, history and theory.

headline: Pelosi Says She’ll Talk to Ethics Panel About Massa
text: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Thursday that she was willing to meet with House ethics investigators looking into the conduct of former Representative Eric Massa.

headline: Shouldering Waste on the Trek Down Mount Everest
text: In 1963 — just 10 years after the first ascent of Mount Everest by Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay, a Sherpa guide -– a fellow climber, Dr. Barry Bishop, wrote in National Geographic that parts of the mountain had become “the highest junkyard on the face of the Earth.” Expedition teams were trashing Everest by wantonly disposing of empty oxygen canisters, torn tents and other rubbish at base camp and just a few thousand feet below the summit, Dr. Bishop reported.

headline: Cuomo Seeks Records for Espada Aides
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo issued a subpoena to the New York State Senate on Thursday seeking the employment records of 10 Senate aides in the office of Pedro Espada Jr., the Senate majority leader, whose business and political activities are under scrutiny by Mr. Cuomo’s office and federal prosecutors.

headline: Politicians Are Watching Waste and Waistlines
text: ALBANY — Assemblyman Joseph S. Saladino is off the manicotti. His colleague Michelle Schimel has a new rule: “No white food” like rice or white bread. State Senator Craig M. Johnson has turned to Weight Watchers.

headline: Notes on the New Atheists
text: Given the durability and predictability of the arguments involved, and the amount of ink spilled on them over the years (and centuries, and millennia), it’s hard to come up with something interesting to say on the question of Christianity versus the “new” atheists. But the Orthodox theologian David Bentley Hart has now managed the trick twice: Once in his slim book “Atheist Delusions: The Christian Revolution and Its Fashionable Enemies,” which came out last year, and now in a fine essay for the latest First Things. Here’s his concluding reflection — but do read the whole thing:

headline: Lehman Bankruptcy Bill Approaches $750 Million
text: Lehman Brothers has paid all its lawyers and advisers a total of $731.6 million in the 18 months since its collapse, including more than $250 million paid to its bankruptcy liquidator, Alvarez & Marsal, Bloomberg News reports, citing a regulatory filing by the onetime Wall Street firm.

headline: East Village, 12:20 P.M.
text: Police on patrol while the president speaks at Cooper Union.

headline: Bo Barks: Take Your Pet to Work Day
text: WASHINGTON – Bo stole the show.

headline: Obama's Speech on Financial Regulation
text: Pushing an overhaul plan for financial regulation on Thursday, the president said, "Unless your business model depends on bilking people, there is little to fear from these new rules."  (Video: NBC)

headline: Spectacular Images of the Sun From NASA
text: NASA has released spectacular, new images of the sun, taken from a spacecraft called the Solar Dynamics Observatory, which was launched into space in February. The video clips, embedded above and below, were made from images shot by the craft’s Atmospheric Imaging Assembly, which is a series of four telescopes that look at the sun in different wavelengths, producing images of different colors. More images of the sun, and video reports explaining the project, can be found on the mission’s YouTube channel. Readers can also follow the mission on Twitter.

headline: Republicans Block Start of Debate on Financial Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Thursday blocked an effort by Democrats to start debate on legislation to tighten regulation of the nation’s financial system, and the two sides traded bitter accusations about who was standing in the way of a bipartisan agreement.

headline: The War on Cliché. (That’s Such a Cliché.)
text: Here at the Book Review, we argue about words. A lot. We argue with the stylebook. We argue with one another. We’ve had intense discussion about the worth of words like “famously” and “focus” and “saga” and “reveal” — and that’s just in the past couple of weeks. (Seriously: I can show you the scars.)

headline: Updates on Second British Leaders’ Debate
text: A week after the first televised debate in British history among candidates for the office of prime minister shook up the election campaign — jolting Nick Clegg, the leader of the Liberal Democrats, to sudden prominence — the leaders are meeting again on Thursday night in a debate focused on foreign policy in the city of Bristol.

headline: All Eyes on Jordan the Owner
text: It’s one thing to be one of the greatest players in the history of the N.B.A., blessed with talent, drive and experience.

headline: Transformation in Long Island City
text: Long Island City is checkered with former industrial buildings, but it is also rich in artistic endeavors.

headline: The Clock Ticks Toward May 1: Chapel Hill, or Washington Square?
text: “Be careful what you wish for.”

headline: Underwater Cameras 2010
text: David Pogue takes two underwater cameras to a local pool.

headline: Obama’s First Year
text: To the Editor:

headline: Letters: Green Economics
text: Paul Krugman surveys admirably the climate-change debate. Favoring cap and trade over direct carbon taxes, however, he ignores a critical variable. Once the caps have been disseminated by auction or (politically corruptible) direct allocation to the millions of emitters, how do we ensure that the emitters stay within their caps? Monitoring a cap system would be an administrative nightmare, evoking even more anger over big-government intervention in our lives. Despite the political antipathy, carbon taxes levied at the primary energy-source level make more operational sense. Aetna Professor Emeritus, John F. Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University, Cambridge, Mass.F. M. SCHERERAetna Professor Emeritus, John F. Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University,Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Financial Tuneup: Why and How to Read Your Tax Return
text: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, we’ve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

headline: ‘Hot Stuff’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Writerly Recognition
text: To the Editor:

headline: Letter: Africa’s Drug Problem
text: James Traub’s poignant article shows how highly organized and parasitic drug trafficking has become. The problem was serious enough 19 years ago, when I worked with Nigerian journalists in Lagos on a project sponsored by the U.S. Information Agency to write about Nigerians who had become dangerously addicted to the drugs they were transporting. We had access to a dozen of them who were in the final stagesof basic drug treatment and housed in the psychiatric wing of a Lagos hospital.

headline: A Doctor With a Prescription for Headlines
text: When it comes to assisted suicide, it is possible to love the sin and hate the sinner. That’s how many feel about Jack Kevorkian  plenty of those who favor mercy killing draw the line at Dr. Death.

headline: Ronaldo on Track to Eclipse Beckham’s Riches
text: Cristiano Ronaldo continues to follow David Beckham. Both players wore No. 7 at Manchester United, where they had tremendously successful and lucrative spells for a club that is itself the epitome of soccer success. Ronaldo, like Beckham before him, moved from England to Spain, to play for Real Madrid. And now, the Portuguese wing appears poised to follow the former England captain to the top of the soccer economy.

headline: Photo of the Week
text: A crowd watches a four-month old hawksbill turtle swimming into deep water off Pramuka Island, north of Jakarta.

headline: Gear Factor | Let It Rain
text: April showers are year-round in Portland, Ore. So last year, the innovative store Stand Up Comedy asked Mary Ping of Slow and Steady Wins the Race to design No. 20 Rainwear, a line of wearable weatherproof items that would look great in crummy weather in any city.

headline: Paperback Row
text: FLANNERY: A Life of Flannery O’Connor,  by Brad Gooch (Back Bay/­Little, Brown, $16.99.) This “big, calm, gentlemanly biography,” as Joy Williams described it in the Book Review, is the first major life of O’Connor, who died in 1964 at age 39. Relying on letters and interviews, Gooch meticulously reconstructs the sedate life of a writer whose novels and stories were anything but.

headline: Signs of Life for Mideast Peace Talks
text: JERUSALEM — The American envoy to the Middle East, George J. Mitchell, flew here on Thursday to meet with Israeli and Palestinian leaders, a sign that indirect Israeli-Palestinian peace talks may be getting back on track, officials from all three parties said.

headline: To See the Art, Just Stroll the Streets
text: Long Island City, Queens, is dotted with former industrial buildings, but it is also rich in artistic endeavors, like the transformation of a warehouse and a landfill into public art spaces. Socrates Sculpture Park, the former landfill, is a huge green canvas for large artworks; recent displays include a bright yellow walkway made of inner tubes, and a concrete rat and pigeon on a podium. And some of the local art is accidental. At 49th Avenue and Vernon Boulevard, a passer-by will see at dusk the nearby Gothic spires of St. Mary’s Roman Catholic Church and, above the rooftops and across the river, the twinkling lights of the Empire State and Chrysler Buildings.

headline: Prepaid Is the New Wireless Battleground
text: From new restaurant openings to an improving job market, there are signs everywhere that the economy is flickering back to life.

headline: Big Coal Booming on Earth Day
text: Just a quick note to those seeking a rapid decline in emissions of greenhouse gases (and other pollution) from coal combustion: The challenge, in a world with rising populations and energy appetites, is getting harder by the day.

headline: Millions Sought for Global Fund to Aid Farms
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is proposing to add $408 million to a global fund to boost food production and encourage good farming practices in the developing world, the Treasury Department announced on Thursday.

headline: The Strategy Behind the CenturyTel-Qwest Deal
text: CenturyTel’s $10.6 billion acquisition of Qwest Communications will bring together two second-tier telecommunications companies that will control a larger percentage of a declining phone market — landlines. The defensive acquisition is expected to cut costs and buy time as the landline market fades.

headline: Bruins Beat Sabres by a Little, Lead Series by a Lot
text: Oh, Buffalo. Whoa, Boston.

headline: Blagojevich Wants to Subpoena Obama
text: 7:21 p.m. | Updated  CHICAGO – Here is an invitation the White House would surely rather never arrive: Lawyers for Rod R. Blagojevich, the indicted former governor of Illinois, want to subpoena President Obama to testify at Mr. Blagojevich’s corruption trial, set to start in June.

headline: Parents With Disabilities
text: Sarah Kovac is a 26-year-old young mother of an infant son. In a video on the CNN Web site she is seen feeding the baby and changing a diaper — using only her feet.

headline: Mind Over Murder
text: There are eerie echoes of Barbara Vine in THE EXECUTOR (Putnam, $25.95), Jesse Kellerman’s stunning novel of psychological suspense: the clinical dissection of a mind that refuses to examine itself; the disintegration of moral boundaries when such a mind develops a fixation; the macabre humor of people who think too much; and, most unnerving, a certain playful cruelty about matters of life and death.

headline: Suit Filed to Allow Photography Near U.S. Buildings
text: Citizens should be allowed to take photos while standing in public spaces near federal buildings, according to a lawsuit filed on Thursday by the New York Civil Liberties Union. The lawsuit challenges regulations that prohibit photography on federal property.

headline: U.S. Lists Companies Aiding Iran’s Energy Projects
text: WASHINGTON — Over the past five years, 41 foreign companies have helped Iran develop its oil and gas sector, which accounts for more than half of the Iranian government’s revenues, Congressional investigators reported Thursday.

headline: Hymn to Himself: Something Hummable
text: God has spoken on the subject of His existence. And you will be pleased to know that He seems resigned to and amused by the obeisance and sacrifices that are made in His name. Listen, O children of Broadway, to His own words, chanted by a chosen tribe of His disciples at the theater at Studio 54 (once a pagan temple to the gods of disco) as His sardonic image smiles down upon them.

headline: So Much Muss and Fuss
text: Video | Set to Beatles music, a montage of the many ways your life is messed up, according to infomercials that claim to make it better:

headline: Poetry Chronicle
text: LIGHTHEAD  By Terrance Hayes.  Penguin Poets. Paper, $18.

headline: Fiat Plots New Directions for Ferrari and Maserati
text: An “affordable” Maserati? A new Enzo supercar? Those were just two surprises that emerged Wednesday from a daylong conference call in which Fiat laid out its five-year plan.

headline: Republicans Block Start of Debate on Financial Bill
text: Senate Republicans on Thursday blocked an effort by Democrats to start debate on legislation to tighten regulation of the nation’s financial system, and the two sides traded bitter accusations about who was standing in the way of a bipartisan agreement, The New York Times’s David M. Herszenhorn reports.

headline: Off to the Races With OTB
text: This week the City Critic heads to the races – or at least, to Off-Track Betting. Having lost money for years, the state-run OTB parlors, which are supposed to help the state, the city and the horse racing industry, were expected to close for good this past week. At the last minute, however, the board of directors came up with a plan to keep the operation alive for another year.

headline: Movie Listings
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Hotel Review: Andaz Wall Street in New York City
text: THE BASICS

headline: A Minneapolis Stretch Reborn
text: POLES used to rule 13th Avenue in northeast Minneapolis. A Polish deli and a Polish clothing store marked one end of this commercial stretch along the old Broadway streetcar line, five minutes north of downtown. The Polish White Eagle Association, a fraternal organization, anchored the other. Empty storefronts dotted the brick buildings in between like missing teeth in an uneasy smile.

headline: Restaurant Review: Tegui in Buenos Aires
text: Usually, restaurants vie for attention in Buenos Aires’s Palermo Viejo neighborhood. Tegui, which the star chef Germán Martitegui opened in January 2009, tries a different approach. With its graffiti-covered facade and tiny lettering on an ugly security door, it’s easy to miss. But that would be a shame, given what awaits inside.

headline: Off the Menu: The Lion
text: In the 1960s, the Lion was a popular hangout in Greenwich Village where Bette Midler and Barbra Streisand performed. Eventually the town house space, with its soaring ceiling and domed skylight, became Village, a local bistro. Now, John DeLucie, who has taken a leave of absence from the kitchen at the Waverly Inn, is turning it into a tavern and restaurant with the original name, to open on May 10.

headline: Lost at Upper Big Branch
text: Glimpses at the lives outside the mountain of the victims of the explosion at the Upper Big Branch mine.

headline: Puppets Aplenty, Improv Abounds
text: Attention people with boring jobs or lives: Please do not sit on the aisle if attending “Stuffed and Unstrung” at the Union Square Theater. A show like this one, which depends heavily on folks who are pulled out of the audience for improvised bits, cannot afford to have the bland and the uninteresting clogging up the prime plucking seats.

headline: Microsoft’s Income Rises 35%, Driven by Sales of Windows 7
text: Sometimes breaking a sales record isn’t good enough. Just ask Microsoft.

headline: 36 Hours in Kyoto, Japan
text: KYOTO, the former imperial capital of Japan, is a vibrant mash-up, an ancient city electrified by the breathtakingly new. Cruise the futuristic food halls of a department store, gaping at the perfect fruit and glistening sea creatures, before zipping up to the traditional floor, with its kimonos and tea ceremony implements. See 2,000 ancient temples and shrines, then dine at a sleekly modern restaurant. Glimpse a geisha gliding down a cobblestone lane, bracketed by wooden machiya houses, and feel yourself catapulted to the 18th century  until you see her duck into a very 21st-century taxi, with a passenger door that opens and shuts automatically.

headline: Top Baristas on Display in New York
text: So far, baristas haven’t found their place in the pecking order of culinary personalities.Chefs are stars, waiters aren’t. Pastry chefs blog, bakers get book deals and bartenders (excuse me, mixologists) go on TV.

headline: Pitfalls of a Blue-Skies Perspective
text: Living under a cloud of volcanic ash in Europe has driven home for me the disconnect between the chemical reactions that take place high in the atmosphere – the ones that create “climate” – and the immediate weather conditions that we experience on the ground.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangkok and Elsewhere
text: The first photograph in Thursday’s slide show, by Vincent Yu of The Associated Press, brings to mind another picture — taken almost exactly 40 years ago by John Filo — of the bloody end to an antiwar demonstration at Kent State University. The genders are reversed, and the victim in Thailand was not killed. But a bystander’s desperate cry is no less painful.

headline: Short and Sweet
text: My darling granddaughter will soon read from the Torah at her brother’s bar mitzvah. She modeled the dress that she intends to wear to the synagogue for me. It is so short that you could describe it, not in inches above her knees, but in millimeters beneath her hips. I’m afraid that she will be the subject of much conversation — none of it having to do with her reading. The dress is completely inappropriate. Her parents think this is funny; I do not. What’s a grandmother to do?

headline: Even Lobbyists Feel the Economic Pinch
text: Lobbyists sometime seem immune to the business cycle, with their numbers — and fees — growing year after year no matter how low the Dow Jones dips.

headline: Goodbye to the Field of 96?
text: A deal that would give CBS and Turner Broadcasting the rights to carry the men’s N.C.A.A. tournament from 2011 to 2024 also means that the field will increase to 68 teams, not the 96 that was considered.

headline: A Convenient, Mysterious Service From Cable Companies
text: A year ago, I wrote about how Cablevision, my cable company, had quietly begun installing Wi-Fi hot spots all over its market area: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. These hot spots began popping up in all the public areas: shopping centers, main streets, train stations, parks, marinas and sports complexes. The best part: these hot spots are free to anyone who subscribes to Internet service from Cablevision at home.

headline: ‘Sex and the City’ Actor Selling Condo
text: A Pad Without Plaid

headline: Yet Another Term for Andrew Jackson
text: “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson,” the rock musical at the Public Theater, is being extended once again, for three weeks through May 30. Blending emo-rock with populism, the widely praised show presents Jackson as a rock star. The Public is turning three Saturday nights into beer night — or wine, soda or liquor night — with audience members receiving a free drink coupon with a ticket for the 9:30 p.m. shows on May 15, 22 and 29 for $49. Benjamin Walker stars as Jackson. The musical is written and directed by Alex Timbers, with music and lyrics by Michael Friedman.

headline: Oxygen Founder Selling Her Co-op
text: Co-op for Sale;

headline: Restaurant 3 Years in the Making Opens in London
text: A restaurant three years in the making, Viajante opened on April 18 in the Town Hall Hotel in east London’s Bethnal Green neighborhood. The Portuguese chef Nuno Mendes, who once worked under Ferran Adrià at El Bulli, signed on back in 2007. In the years since, he has developed menus and recipes at the Loft, the supper club and test kitchen he ran out of his own home, serving multi-course tasting menus to those lucky enough to get a reservation.

headline: Cartoon Network Gets ‘Looney’
text: Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck are making a comeback in “The Looney Tunes Show,” a new series that situates the characters in the suburbs with wacky neighbors like Yosemite Sam, Tweety and Sylvester. The series was announced by the Cartoon Network during a presentation to advertisers of its coming season. Other series include “Mad Magazine,” an animated sketch-comedy series based on the long-running print publication that will include the Spy vs. Spy characters, and “Young Justice,” about a group of teenage super heroes who must deal with teachers, parents, crime-fighting mentors and power-crazed super villains. The team will consist of Robin, Kid Flash, Superboy, Miss Martian, Artemis and Aqualad, who is white (and from Atlantis) in the comic books, but who is black in the cartoon.

headline: Senate Confirms Federal District Judge for Appeals Court
text: Denny Chin, a federal district judge in Manhattan, was confirmed by the Senate 98-0 on Thursday for elevation to the prestigious United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

headline: Thinking of Summer
text: WITH spring having settled in and summer not far behind, it is tempting to let your mind wander to the Hamptons, where the lucky few will cool off when temperatures rise while the rest of us wade along steamy city sidewalks.

headline: ‘Fabulous Fab’ Unlikely to Cross Blankfein’s Path
text: Now it’s official: Lloyd C. Blankfein, chief executive of Goldman Sachs, and Fabrice P. Tourre, a/k/a the “Fabulous Fab,” will both appear at a Senate hearing next week after federal regulators accused the firm and Mr. Tourre of securities fraud. But don’t expect Mr. Blankfein and Mr. Tourre to be in the hearing room at the same time.

headline: Post-Shanghai Flight Notes
text: The Chinese Grand Prix was a challenge for the teams, drivers, media and fans, but returning home was, of course, even more so since most of the people involved live in Europe and the airports were all closed thanks to that friendly volcano. Now that most of the team people have made it back to Europe, some of them are sending out the stories of how they won the race back home.

headline: Amazon Now a Larger Seller of Stuff Other Than Media
text: Amazon.com is still known by many consumers primarily for selling books, music and DVDs, even though it also offers a ridiculous variation of other products, like HDTVs, patio furniture and replicas of human fat.

headline: Trooping to the Guillotine, in Martyrdom
text: For the students in the Juilliard School’s vocal arts program, works like Poulenc’s wrenching “Dialogues des Carmélites,” which the Juilliard Opera is now presenting at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, are a crucial counterweight to centerpieces of the operatic canon. The enduring 19th-century bread-and-butter works teach young singers that melodic beauty and vocal virtuosity are paramount values, and that in tragic repertory, oceans of larger-than-life emotion can be wrung from stories of star-crossed love and family politics. But “Dialogues” is a reminder that opera can deal with deeper conflicts too.

headline: An R&B Chameleon Turns Into Dance Club Diva
text: What kind of weird is Kelis? Over the last 10 years or so there have been several versions. She’s been a thrashing soul screamer, a coquettish teaser, a brassy seductress, a shiny pop cyborg. Her only constant has been change.

headline: On Piano and Violin, Partnership of Equals
text: On the eve of its 50th anniversary, Young Concert Artists remains a perceptive talent scout. Many of its former protégés, like Emanuel Ax and Murray Perahia, have enjoyed prestigious careers.

headline: Budget Impasse in Vegas Imperils Jobs
text: LAS VEGAS – A standoff between the mayor and the municipal labor unions here spells more bad news for this embattled city, with scores of city workers, including police officers and firefighters set to lose their jobs.

headline: D’arcy James Returning to ‘Next to Normal’
text: When “Next to Normal” had its premiere Off Broadway at Second Stage Theater in 2008, Brian d’Arcy James starred as Dan Goodman, a man trying to keep his family together in the face of his wife’s crippling depression. When the decision was made to move the musical, which later won three Tony Awards and last week a Pulitzer Prize, to Broadway, at the Booth Theater, Mr. d’Arcy James had already committed to starring as a big green ogre in the musical “Shrek.” But starting May 17 he will be returning to the role he originated, replacing J. Robert Spencer. He’ll rejoin Alice Ripley, who won a Tony for her performance as the wife, and Jennifer Damiano and Adam Chanler-Berat, who play the Goodmans’ daughter and her boyfriend, who were all in the original production.

headline: ‘Idol Gives Back’ Gives Fox a Victory
text: “Idol Gives Back,” the annual “American Idol” charity special, delivered the top ratings in prime time on Wednesday, lifting Fox to No. 1 on the night by a wide margin. The special, which included cameos from President Barack Obama and Michelle Obama and saw the contestant Tim Urban eliminated from the show, drew an average of 18.3 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS was runner-up, earning 5.3 million viewers for its sitcoms “The New Adventures of Old Christine” and “Accidentally on Purpose.” NBC broadcast “Mercy” (5 million) at 8 and “Law & Order: SVU” (8.7 million) at 10 with a rerun of “SVU” (5.3 million) at 9. ABC placed fourth over all with a lineup of repeats.

headline: 3 American Writers on Orange Prize List
text: Three American authors have been named to the shortlist for the Orange Prize for Fiction, the British honor awarded annually to a novel written by a woman in English. The finalists this year include Barbara Kingsolver, for “The Lacuna,” Attica Locke (left) for “Black Water Rising” and Lorrie Moore (below left) for “A Gate at the Stairs.” Ms. Locke is a first-time novelist. The list also includes the much-garlanded Hilary Mantel, for “Wolf Hall,” which has already won the Man Booker Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction. Rounding out the list of finalists are the British writer Rosie Alison, for “The Very Thought of You,” and Monique Roffey, who was born in Trinidad, for “The White Woman on the Green Bicycle.” The winner will be announced on June 9 in London. The prize comes with a check for about $46,000 and a bronze statue called a Bessie.

headline: After ‘Office’ Hours, Mindy Kaling Writes
text: On “The Office” the bubbly Kelly Kapoor does not seem able to write much more than her name (with smiley faces in the o’s). In real life Mindy Kaling, left, the actress and writer who portrays her on that NBC comedy, is much more prolific. Her work as an author includes the play “Matt & Ben” (written with Brenda Withers), many episodes of “The Office” and a prodigious amount of blog posts and tweets. And soon a book. The Crown Publishing Group said on Thursday that it had acquired a book from Ms. Kaling called “The Contents of My Purse,” planned for a fall 2011 release. The publisher described it as a cross between “Love, Loss and What I Wore” and Ms. Kaling’s blog, “Things I’ve Bought That I Love” (mindyephron.blogspot.com). But in a telephone interview Ms. Kaling indicated that she might have other plans. “What they bought was a funny book of comedy essays,” she said, “but maybe I’ll just turn it into a Jon Krakauer piece about murder in Siberia and perilous adventure to find details about that. I don’t want to be boxed in.” Assuming she sticks to the original plan, Ms. Kaling said the book would probably be “stories about my life and my opinions.”

headline: Gallery Owner Says Artist Has a Blacklist
text: Naming names is a rare thing in the highly private business of selling art, but a Manhattan gallery owner did so in federal court in Manhattan this week, testifying that a prominent contemporary painter maintains a blacklist of art collectors and dealers whom she punishes for reselling her works, the Web site artinfo.com reported Wednesday. The gallery owner, Jack Tilton, testified that Marlene Dumas, a South African-born artist whose work is sought by important collectors and whom he represented for many years, has long kept a list that prevents those she views as turning over her works too quickly from buying more by her. Mr. Tilton  who testified as the result of a subpoena by a Miami collector, Craig Robins, the plaintiff in a lawsuit related to the list  said that besides Mr. Robins, other well-known collectors and dealers like Richard Cooper and Daniel Holtz were on the list. In his suit Mr. Robins says that he sold a painting by Ms. Dumas through the David Zwirner Gallery in Chelsea in 2004 with an agreement that the sale remain confidential. But the Zwirner gallery, which took over representation of Ms. Dumas in 2008, told her about it, Mr. Robins asserts, causing her to add his name to the blacklist, according to his suit. The suit says that Mr. Zwirner promised to help get Mr. Robins off the blacklist and sell him choice paintings from “Against the Wall,” the current show of Ms. Dumas’s work at Zwirner, but that this did not happen. Mr. Zwirner  who was also on Ms. Dumas’s blacklist at one point, Mr. Tilton said  denies both assertions. Ms. Dumas has declined to comment on the suit.

headline: Ayckbourn and Seldes Are Early Tony Winners
text: The Tony Awards Administration Committee announced on Thursday that the playwright and director Alan Ayckbourn and the Tony Award-winning actress Marian Seldes had been chosen to receive Lifetime Achievement Awards. Mr. Ayckbourn, who has written more than 70 plays, is probably best known for the “The Norman Conquests,” which won the Tony Award for best revival of a play in 2009. Ms. Seldes, who made her Broadway debut in “Medea” in 1947, won as featured actress for “A Delicate Balance” in 1967. Another familiar face on Broadway, David Hyde Pierce, above, is being given the Isabelle Stevenson Award, which recognizes charitable and humanitarian work. He is being honored for his contributions toward finding a cure for Alzheimer’s disease.

headline: Henry Luce, the Editor in Chief
text: Of all the arguments under way these days at the noisy crossroads of the news business, none is quite so basic as the debate over journalistic authority — who has it, and what it is worth.

headline: Arrest Led to Strike on Two Top Iraq Militant Leaders
text: BAGHDAD — The previously undisclosed arrest of a senior leader of Al Qaeda in Iraq in Baghdad last month provided Iraqi and American security forces with a trove of intelligence that led to the killing of the group’s two top leaders in an early morning raid this week, senior Iraqi officials said Thursday.

headline: A Yurt With a View
text: WHO Michelle Menter, 33, and her daughter, Elsa, 3

headline: For Developers’ Foe, Suggestions for the Next Battleground
text: Now Daniel Goldstein needs to move. But where?

headline: World Cup Survey … and the Winner Is …
text: What sacrifices would fans make to see their native country win the World Cup?

headline: New York Birders Get Their Own App
text: Thursday’s PhoneSmart column, on mobile apps for birdwatchers, featured wide-ranging apps for birders in all regions of the United States. But for New York City birders, a new alternative appeared this week: Audubon Birds of Central Park ($7 for iPhones).

headline: Parents, Meet My Job
text: As the annual day to bring your children to work winds down, a public relations agency in New York is getting ready for an alternative event on Friday during which the visitors to the office will definitely be older.

headline: A Taste of the Heartland, Bleak and Somber
text: For most rockers, going country means a chance to try some good-time music. Not Jakob Dylan, who brought his new roots-rock band, Three Legs, to Town Hall on Wednesday night. The stage backdrop was a flat, empty prairie, and the songs were just as desolate: mostly slow, mostly in minor keys and almost entirely bleak.

headline: BlogTalk: Bankers and Chickens
text: President Obama got something of a laugh during his address today on Wall Street when he read a passage from Time magazine about the “wild-eyed alarm’’ running through “the great banking houses of Manhattan’’ over a Congressional measure designed to protect consumers.

headline: ‘South Park’ Episode Altered After Muslim Group’s Warning
text: “South Park,” the Comedy Central series, is an animated show that tries its best to push buttons and the boundaries of free speech by mocking every high-profile target in sight, from Hollywood celebrities to religious figures. But its creators may have gotten more than they bargained for with two recent episodes that satirized the Prophet Muhammad  one that elicited an ominous message from an Islamic group based in New York, and one that was censored by the cable network that shows it.

headline: The Fountain of Reinvention
text: CLEARWATER, Fla.

headline: Soccer and Cocaine: A Nation’s Twin Obsessions
text: When ESPN contracted Jeff and Michael Zimbalist about making a documentary about the infiltration of drug money into professional soccer in Colombia during the 1980s and ’90s, the brothers’ original plan was to make a 50-minute film. The finished product, called “The Two Escobars,” came in at twice that length, and in addition to its showing on ESPN in June,  made the line-up at the Tribeca Film Festival. Its world premiere on Thursday night is to be followed by three other showings.

headline: The United Nations: The Evolution of an Idea
text: The United Nations was not the first idea for the land  between First Avenue and the East River.

headline: One Among Many Ideas for the U.N. Site
text: THE United Nations is starting the long-awaited restoration of its 1951 headquarters building to the way it was when it was fresh and new. The project, costing almost $2 billion, will empty the main building and take until 2013.

headline: Suicide Support Group as a Scene for Singles
text: It gives a whole new meaning to meeting cute: at a support group for people who have survived suicide attempts, Lily (Krysten Ritter) and Robert (Ivan Sergei) are paired up, fight, yell about his dead wife and her (imaginary) dead lover and then have sex on the sidewalk.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music.

headline: Love Means Having to Say, ‘I Feel ...’
text: It’s hard to pinpoint when the American romantic comedy went into therapy, though you have to assume it was not long after filmmakers started hitting the couch, or at least cruising the self-help bookshelves. Once upon a studio time, romantic comedies involved a man and a woman engaged in delicate (or crude) power negotiations. The shrew had to be tamed and the boy had to grow up so he could handle her, or some variation on that idea. That template is still in use, though the banter that accompanied those negotiations has given way to speeches about feelings. Freud might have hit Hollywood decades earlier, but Woody Allen and the generations of funnymen and women he inspired, have a lot to answer for.

headline: Documents Show Internal Qualms at Rating Agencies
text: WASHINGTON — In 2004, well before the risks embedded in Wall Street’s bets on subprime mortgages became widely known, employees at Standard & Poor’s, the credit rating agency, were feeling pressure to expand the business.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.

headline: Ristretto | Chemex
text: The Chemex coffee maker has hardly changed since first introduced by Peter Schlumbohm in 1941. It still has that familiar hourglass figure, that bentwood collar tied in place with a rawhide strap threaded through a wood bead. The Chemex you can buy today is essentially the same object that was added to the collection of the Museum of Modern Art almost 70 years ago.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.

headline: The Underside of a Film Festival, Where Some Dark Treasures Dwell
text: For several weeks now friends have been asking for Tribeca Film Festival advice: What about “My Trip to Al-Qaeda”? Is “Micmacs” any good? How did they make a movie out of “Freakonomics”?

headline: You Are Not Hallucinating: Ronald Reagan and James Dean, Together
text: Ronald Reagan and James Dean together? Cast as adversaries in a television drama no less? That notion definitely falls into the category of hard to believe. But it happens to be true, and the proof is a rare kinescope of their performance, out of circulation for more than 55 years, that has surfaced and can be viewed on the Web site of the monthly magazine The Atlantic.

headline: Volcanic Energy Shakes Up a Festival
text: “So how has your week been?,” an exhausted-looking Zarin Mehta, president of the New York Philharmonic, asked the audience at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night before the opening concert of The Russian Stravinsky: A Philharmonic Festival.

headline: Up Front: Bill Keller
text: Bill Keller, the executive editor of The New York Times since 2003, reviews Alan Brinkley’s new biography, “The Publisher: Henry Luce and His American Century,” on the cover this week.

headline: Dance Listings
text: Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

headline: Mystique of Tut, Increasing With Age
text: There has always been something a little disorienting, almost out of proportion, about King Tut. Is there any Egyptian pharaoh now more widely known, any more celebrated? The extraordinary objects found in his tomb have been viewed by millions, and the more objects from that horde are seen, the larger Tut looms. Yet the more we know, the less imposing he becomes, and the more puzzling the contrast seems.

headline: Hollywood Hair Club for (Wo)Men
text: On a recent Monday morning, a number of Hollywood executives were rolling calls outside the offices of Dr. Peter Goldman. One talent agent, dressed in a black Prada suit, was in the middle of negotiating a deal when the doctor’s assistant came to take him back to an examination room. As she motioned for him to follow her, the agent sputtered into his BlackBerry, “I gotta go.” This did not put an end to the conversation until he finally gritted his teeth and snarled, “I’m at Dr. Goldman’s.”

headline: Yanks Turn Triple Play; A-Rod Kicks Dirt on Unwritten Rule
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Alex Rodriguez had a busy sixth inning Thursday. Before initiating the Yankees’ first triple play in 42 years, Rodriguez may or may not have violated a code in the unwritten rules of baseball. Either way, when he wandered across the pitching mound on his way back to first base, Rodriguez infuriated Oakland starter Dallas Braden and ignited a storm of verbal jousting after the Yankees’ 4-2 loss to the Athletics at Oakland Coliseum.

headline: Krawcheck’s Global Ambitions for Merrill Lynch
text: Bank of America really wants to go global. Sallie Krawcheck, the president of the bank’s global wealth and investment management division, said Thursday that it would expand its Merrill Lynch operations outside the United States, as many more of the world’s newly super-rich come from emerging markets, Reuters reports.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Divinamente New York
text: It may not seem obvious while you’re munching popcorn and watching “Kick-Ass” at the multiplex, but time was when artistic expression was inextricably linked to spirituality. The Dionysian festivals of ancient Greece spring to mind. Divinamente New York, a short festival that began on Thursday and runs through Monday, celebrates that connection.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Time Capsule'
text: Lisa Hostetler, curator of photography at the Milwaukee Art Museum, narrates a look at a rediscovered short film by the photographer Louis Faurer.

headline: The Streets, Frozen in Neon
text: ON a recent Sunday afternoon, Mark Faurer, a New York City cab driver, led a museum curator and a reporter on a tour of historic Times Square. Strolling down Broadway, Mr. Faurer pointed out the sites of onetime attractions like the Planters store near 47th Street, which sold fresh-roasted peanuts; the Camel billboard at 44th Street that used to puff steam “smoke rings” over passers-by; Hubert’s Dime Museum, home of a freak show and flea circus on 42nd Street, west of Seventh Avenue; and the strip of movie theaters that lined and lighted up that same block, where you could see B movies and first-run films at cut-rate prices.

headline: Astronomy Weekend
text: The Hudson River Museum is inviting young visitors to have a blast. Literally.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: ‘ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO’  (Friday through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series “Dora the Explorer” and “Go, Diego, Go!” have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Children’s Museum of Manhattan, whose exhibition has separate Dora and Diego environments, including Diego’s Animal Rescue Center and Dora’s Fiesta. Intended for ages 2 to 6, the interactive, bilingual displays are designed to teach language, science and music skills, as well as facts about Latin America. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street , Manhattan, (212) 721-1223, cmom.org; free with museum admission: $10; $7 for 65+; free for under 1 and members.20100422

headline: Lots of Happy Tunes (Yes, They’re Related)
text: Perky identical twins, identically dressed, chirping Broadway show tunes in bright, almost identical chorus-boy voices: no, they’re not 8-year-old stage moppets trying out for a talent show but rather Will and Anthony Nunziata, the proudly Italian-American 20-something duo that opened a five-night engagement at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency on Tuesday evening.

headline: Giant Insects Invade the City, Infesting Their Show With Lots of Buzz
text: We’re entering the time of year when insects, especially the ones that suck your blood or ruin your garden, need to be murdered, but you may not want to take on the ones performing under the big top on Randalls Island. Most of them could probably squash you like, well, a bug.

headline: Ripples in Memories After a Death
text: In the past Sue Miller has demonstrated a taste for decidedly melodramatic plots: a woman’s boyfriend is accused of molesting her daughter (“The Good Mother”) or mows down her children’s baby sitter with his car (“For Love”). A brutal murder (“While I Was Gone”) or blackmail for sex (“Lost in the Forest”) shreds the delicate fabric of daily life.

headline: A London Apartment Done Up in French
text: Jayne Wrightsman, the famously private philanthropist, is allowing a glimpse of her home life. Ms. Wrightsman, the 90-year-old oil heiress, is emptying out her London duplex apartment, the contents of which have been shipped to Sotheby’s in New York for an auction on Wednesday. A preview revealed how her staff pampered guests with fine linens and china, and what lighthearted motifs course through her rarified French antiques.

headline: A Late Picasso Goes to Auction
text: As pleasurable as it may be to live with a Monet, a Picasso or a Warhol, there are also downsides: expensive insurance and constant concerns about security.

headline: Artistic Matchmaking in Met Galleries
text: Navigating the Metropolitan Museum of Art can be bewildering  there is so much great stuff to see in every direction that you can feel rudderless. So it helps to have a plan. Here is a good one: Oberlin College’s Allen Memorial Art Museum in Ohio, under renovation, has sent 19 of its best paintings and one sculpture to New York, where they are in permanent collection galleries along with the works they relate to at the Met. This may not sound like much on paper, but it makes for a rewarding scavenger hunt.

headline: Genre Kicks
text: Images from the films in the Cinemania series at the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: A Jungle of Bamboo Is Growing Atop the Met
text: ON a recent summerlike morning, men in T-shirts and women in bikini tops were busily working to the loud strains of Michael Jackson, Led Zeppelin and Jimi Hendrix. Some looked like tightrope walkers, delicately balancing on horizontal poles in bare feet; others could be seen shinnying up vertical poles like monkeys, securing intersections with colored nylon ropes; and still others were building teepeelike configurations on the ground.

headline: Live Updates: First Round of the N.F.L. Draft
text: New York Times reporters will be providing updates and analysis of tonight’s N.F.L. draft festivities. Judy Battista is at Radio City Music Hall, Greg Bishop is with the Jets and Dave Caldwell with the Giants, while Fifth Down contributor Mike Tanier will be providing analysis of each pick. Paul Myerberg of The Times will be hosting the live updates. The Rams open the night on the clock. Barring any trades, the Giants will pick No. 15 and the Jets No. 29. You can also follow Judy on Twitter.

headline: Muriel Spark: Playing God
text: Muriel Spark used to be lumped all the time with Evelyn Waugh and Graham Greene. They were the three greatest British writers of their era, it was said, and as it happened, all three were converts to Roman Catholicism. Spark died in 2006, at 88, outliving both Waugh and Greene, but by then her reputation had already begun to sink faster than theirs. So even if it isn’t the last word, as its subtitle seems to boast, Martin Stannard’s new biography may just restore Spark in her singularity. As a writer, she more nearly resembled Waugh than Greene, but she wasn’t really much like either, or like anyone else, for that matter.

headline: Rove and Romney on the Republican Party After Bush
text: Karl Rove, George W. Bush’s longtime chief adviser, was one of the most important players in American politics during the last decade. Mitt Romney, former governor of Massachusetts and current presidential prospect, aspires to be the most important figure in American politics during the next decade. Over the years, I have covered and interviewed both men and admittedly have found them rather difficult to decode, personally and sometimes professionally. Now, both have written best-selling books presenting their inspirations and influ­ences — books that, while not fully revelatory, offer far deeper insights than have ever been available ­before.

headline: Your Money, Their Pockets
text: Seldom in our 230-odd years as a country have Congress and the White House had the fortitude to impose on American bankers and financiers a set of regulations sufficiently stringent to prevent them from pushing us into destructive panics and recessions. And once again Washington may be demonstrating its lack of backbone.

headline: Dream Catcher
text: “Tell a dream, lose a reader,” the saying goes, but Brad Watson ignored that advice in his splendidly dream-laden novel, “The Heaven of Mercury,” and watched it become a finalist for the National Book Award in 2002. Watson’s dreams work because they avoid twee mysticism or kitsch — they’re made of reality with a slight shift, as if his characters phase just out of the earthly plane, then return with visions that seem logical, essential to our understanding of the story. In that book, dreams took us deep into the main character’s past, and they offered sweeping descriptions of the Gulf Coast, a region that Watson, a Mississippi native, describes with the combined powers of a botanist and a draftsman.

headline: The Deep End
text: Holly LeCraw’s first novel, “The Swimming Pool,” is about the most miserable group of people to summer in New England since all those nice folks had their vacations ruined in “Jaws.” LeCraw’s characters have baggage. Steamer trunks of it.

headline: Derek Walcott, Man of Many Voices
text: More than almost any other contemporary poet, Derek Walcott might seem to be fulfilling T. S. Eliot’s program for poetry. He has distinguished himself in all of what Eliot described as the “three voices of poetry”: the lyric, the narrative or epic, and the dramatic. Since at least his 1984 book “Midsummer,” Walcott has been publishing what might be described as concatenated lyrics, individual poems numbered consecutively and intended to form a conceptual whole. His long 1990 poem “Omeros” would be called canonical were that word not so problematic these days. And, like Eliot, Walcott is also a playwright. Through his long connection with the Trinidad Theater Workshop, he has amassed an impressive body of dramatic works, both in prose and in that tricky form called verse drama.

headline: These Awards Need Warning Labels
text: It’s been a good week for Brookses in the NBA. Scott Brooks, who guided the Oklahoma City Thunder to its first playoff berth, won Coach of the Year on Wednesday. Aaron Brooks, the Houston Rockets’ young point guard, was named Most Improved Player on Thursday. Their celebrations might not last long, if history is any guide.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,383 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: E-Mails Offer Look at Rating Firms During Crisis
text: As the housing market began to falter 2006 and the risks embedded in Wall Street’s giant collective bet on subprime mortgages became apparent, a sense of omen filled the corridors of Standard & Poor’s and Moody’s Investors Service, the two big credit rating agencies. The New York Times’s Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

headline: Humor Needs No Words in a Demented World
text: Somebody is missing out on a heckuva marketing gimmick by not pairing “The Irish Curse,” a play about the trials and tribulations of men with small penises, with “666,” the appallingly entertaining production now at the Minetta Lane Theater.

headline: Oh, Those Bawdy, Gaudy Ladies
text: The indiscreet ladies who would meet the elite on bawdy, gaudy 42nd Street, as the old song had it, were probably more than just careless. You wouldn’t know it from the musical “42nd Street,” certainly, but those ladies were probably bumping and grinding amid feathery fans and gurgling soap bubbles. In the 1930s, Times Square was where professional straight men like Robert Alda (father of Alan) warmed up audiences that strippers put on boil. A popular entertainment, stripping was  or so the theater owner Herbert Minsky insisted  an American art. But in New York and elsewhere, burlesque came with a price: a milieu of vice that alarmed religious leaders and business owners and the politicians who catered to them.

headline: Compose Your Own
text: My nine-month old son engages with music in a variety of ways as he moves through his daily life. He listens to music in the background while he focuses on other activities. He moves to music as my wife or I clap his hands and bounce him up and down in time to a song. And he creates music, banging his fists on a piano keyboard to play clusters of high and low notes. As judged by laughs and smiles, he likes all of these activities, but he enjoys creating music the most.

headline: U.S. Faces Choice on New Weapons for Fast Strikes
text: WASHINGTON — In coming years, President Obama will decide whether to deploy a new class of weapons capable of reaching any corner of the earth from the United States in under an hour and with such accuracy and force that they would greatly diminish America’s reliance on its nuclear arsenal.

headline: Their Real Art Form Is Backstabbing
text: Only one of the dozen or so characters in “Boogie Woogie,” Duncan Ward’s beyond-nasty art-world satire, has the semblance of a soul. He is Dewey (Alan Cumming), a gay London gadabout and the best friend and promoter of Elaine (Jaime Winstone), an artistic exhibitionist whose would-be chef-d’oeuvre is a video diary of her ravenous sex life. That diary focuses on her lesbian encounters with women she stalks and surreptitiously records during their steamy couplings. Some might call it pornography.

headline: Explosions in Bangkok Wound Dozens
text: At least five grenades exploded in the heart of Bangkok’s business district, killing three people and wounding at least 75 as rival groups of protesters demonstrated.

headline: Outsiders, Tender and Troubled
text: Watching “The Aliens,” a gentle and extraordinarily beautiful new play by Annie Baker that opened Thursday night at the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, is a bit like standing in front of an unshowy work by a less-heralded old master. You wouldn’t absorb much from a Chardin painting, say, if you sped past it during an hourlong drive-by of art’s greatest hits at the Louvre or the Met. Its magic is too subtle for that. But the longer you look, the more you see and the more you feel.

headline: House Republicans Call For Earmark Action
text: A group of top House Republicans on Thursday called on their Democratic counterparts to team up for a one-year moratorium on all earmarks, with the savings shifted to pay down part of the deficit.

headline: Pelosi Faces New Set of Interrogators
text: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, as usual, took a fairly broad range of questions from reporters at her news conference today, on topics ranging from immigration reform to the ethics investigation into the conduct of former Representative Eric Massa.

headline: The Impact: Quarterback Sam Bradford
text: While much of the focus during the N.F.L. draft will be on, well, the N.F.L., Nick Corasaniti is keeping his eyes on college football. He is breaking down how the first-round picks will be replaced, or not, by their former college teams.

headline: Theater Listings: April 23 — 29
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: Triangle: Man, Wife and Friend (Imaginary)
text: “Paper Man” is an intelligent, meticulously constructed, well-acted movie that has been written to death. As it inches toward a moony catharsis, this whimsical/melancholy exploration of writer’s block and middle-aged angst builds an elaborate, symbolic framework to justify the attention it lavishes on its hapless protagonist, Richard Dunne (Jeff Daniels), a novelist.

headline: Fortunate Timing Seals a Deal
text: Sometimes there really are coincidences. Those who campaign for greater financial regulation have benefited from two of them over the last decade. In each case, the coincidence offset a lot of expensive lobbying.

headline: The Impact: Defensive Tackle Ndamukong Suh
text: While much of the focus during the N.F.L. draft will be on, well, the N.F.L., Nick Corasaniti is keeping his eyes on college football. He is breaking down how the first-round picks will be replaced, or not, by their former college teams.

headline: Florida: Health Overhaul on November Ballot
text: Voters will decide this fall whether to ban health insurance mandates, including those required by the federal health care overhaul. The Republican-controlled Florida Legislature voted on Thursday to place a constitutional amendment on the ballot that would ban any laws that compel someone to “participate in any health care system.” Republican legislators said the amendment was needed to block an attack on freedom and individual rights by Congress. Democrats said the debate echoed the battle over states’ rights when the federal government ordered school integration and said the amendment could not trump federal law. Sixty percent of voters must approve the amendment in order for it take effect.

headline: The New Age of Travel: Blimps and Beyond
text: The Icelandic volcano that disrupted global air travel last week raised a concern: should we be thinking of alternative ways to move masses of people and goods? Scientists warn that more eruptions may cause new turmoil in the months ahead, a prospect that has generated discussion of future — even futuristic — modes of transportation.

headline: The Impact: Defensive Tackle Gerald McCoy
text: While much of the focus during the N.F.L. draft will be on, well, the N.F.L., Nick Corasaniti is keeping his eyes on college football. He is breaking down how the first-round picks will be replaced, or not, by their former college teams.

headline: A Band of Brothers, Seriously Ticked Off
text: Remember “The Dirty Dozen”? Well, apparently Hollywood does. “The Losers,” yet another movie about a team (more B than A) of grunting smart alecks with big guns and cool toys, isn’t the kind of flick you can call exactly new. The manufacturer’s date might be relatively recent, but almost all the ideas and moves are definitely older than the likable cast members. About the only thing that distinguishes this iteration from those of yore is that the violence is more explicit, the edits are faster, and no one has a stogie stuck in his kisser, or, from the looks of the swishing, herky-jerky cinematography, a tripod attached to a camera.

headline: Tagliabue Has Stern Words for Big Ten
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. – The former N.F.L. commissioner Paul Tagliabue will be working with the Big East as an unpaid consultant to help the league maximize its value when it renegotiates its next television contracts.

headline: In Venezuela’s Savanna, Clash of Science and Fire
text: YUNÉK, Venezuela — The mist-shrouded mountains rising out of the forest here form one of the world’s most beguiling frontiers of exploration and research, inspiring Arthur Conan Doyle’s 1912 fantasy novel “The Lost World” and teams of biologists who still mount expeditions to remote escarpments in hopes of finding species new to science.

headline: The Impact: Offensive Tackle Trent Williams
text: While much of the focus during the N.F.L. draft will be on, well, the N.F.L., Nick Corasaniti is keeping his eyes on college football. He is breaking down how the first-round picks will be replaced, or not, by their former college teams.

headline: A Brisk First Round on Supreme Court Search
text: President Obama, moving quickly to select a new Supreme Court nominee, on Thursday wrapped up his consultations with members of the Senate Judiciary Committee, the White House said.

headline: For Web’s New Wave, Sharing Details Is the Point
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Brooks wants the whole Web to know that he spent $41 on an iPad case at an Apple store, $24 eating at an Applebee’s, and $6,450 at a Florida plastic surgery clinic for nose work.

headline: Stirring Up 1930s Train-Robbing Action
text: One way to look at the career of the South Korean director Kim Jee-woon would be to praise him for refusing to repeat himself; another would be to write him off as a dilettante who dabbles in one film genre after another without putting down any roots. His trajectory has not been promising: a charming knockabout comedy (“The Foul King”) was followed by a creepy but unsurprising horror movie (“A Tale of Two Sisters”) and then a slick, soulless film noir (“A Bittersweet Life”). He hits a new low with “The Good, the Bad, the Weird,” a hyper-violent action movie that takes the form of an Asian western.

headline: The Impact: Safety Eric Berry
text: While much of the focus during the N.F.L. draft will be on, well, the N.F.L., Nick Corasaniti is keeping his eyes on college football. He is breaking down how the first-round picks will be replaced, or not, by their former college teams.

headline: What We’re Reading: iPhone Loser
text: Here’s what the tech editors and reporters of the New York Times were reading Thursday:

headline: What Danger Do Blippy and Swipely Pose to Amazon?
text: The social buying site Blippy is part of what one might call the Internet’s “Too Much Information Movement,” which I write about in Friday’s paper.

headline: Hurt by Rivals, Nokia Misses Profit Forecast
text: Nokia, the world’s biggest maker of mobile phones, posted a lower-than-expected increase in first-quarter profit on Thursday, hurt by competition from iPhone and BlackBerry smartphones and a loss at its network unit.

headline: To See the Boy King
