headline: Can Debt Collectors Overuse the Courts, and More in Friday’s Bay Area Report
text: The Wages of Debt | About $100 billion in credit card debt is sold annually in the United States, and debt collectors are increasingly turning to the courts to enforce payment of uncollected debts, which are sold and resold among debt collectors. Critics say the practice clogs the courts and turns corporate lists of debtors into free-fire zones that sometimes target the innocent. In the Bay Area, a loose-knit group of public-interest lawyers pools resources to fight what they see as a misuse of the court system. “We found that these law firms count on a huge percentage of the people that they sue defaulting,” or not responding to the legal actions, said Osha Neumann, a lawyer with the East Bay Community Law Center. “That’s how the debt buyers make their money.”

headline: Rainer Ganahl: ‘Language of Emigration & Pictures of Emigration’
text: The latest exhibition from the veteran Conceptual artist Rainer Ganahl is a resonant feat of site-specificity, a fit of art and space so unforced yet so affecting as to be breathtaking. Basically Mr. Ganahl has used nearly every square foot of the fledgling Alex Zachary gallery, an empty brownstone garden duplex of 1980s rehab. (It is located on without being quite of the Upper East Side. It keeps Thursday-to-Sunday Lower East Side hours, and Mr. Zachary still has his day job at Gavin Brown’s gallery in the West Village.)

headline: William Scott
text: There are obvious criticisms to be made of the canvases of the British painter William Scott (1913-1989), which are having their first solo in New York since 1992. His art can be seen as sentimental and timid, as abstract paintings for people who don’t like abstraction. But what remains is some wonderfully solid, serenely formal images that refuse to banish reality. Their fusion of the mundane and exalted remains vibrant and may be especially useful at the moment, with so many painters exploring new ways of balancing meaning and form.

headline: Dahesh Museum of Art: ‘Becoming an Artist: The Academy in 19th-Century France’
text: Unlike today’s aspring artists, for those in pre-20th-century France the path to success was pretty clear. “Becoming an Artist: The Academy in 19th-Century France” explains the rigid system by which careers were made. (The show was organized by the peripatetic Dahesh Museum of Art, which is still seeking a home of its own.) The academy required three years of drawing, followed by painting under a recognized master’s tutelage and, finally, winning the Prix de Rome. There is more to learn about the process from this compact show, but the main attraction is in the surprising number of mostly small, beautifully made paintings and drawings on display.

headline: Corrections
text: An art entry in the Listings pages last Friday about “Rome After Raphael,” at the Morgan Library & Museum, misspelled the given name of an artist whose work appears in the exhibition. He was Annibale Carracci, not Anibale. (The error has appeared in the Listings pages each Friday since Feb. 12 and was pointed out in an e-mail message from a reader on Wednesday.)

headline: Friend to Wall Street, Schumer Falls Quiet

headline: The National Agenda
text: IN THE DEAD of late January, the five members of the band the National were sprawled around a music studio in the attic of a weathered, gray Bridgeport, Conn., mansion. The studio belongs to the National’s producer, Peter Katis, and after many long months of recording and rerecording their fifth album in Brooklyn, where the band members all now live, they had come to Connecticut for an efficient few weeks of mixing. Things were not turning out that way. The National is composed of the identical-twin guitar-playing brothers Bryce and Aaron Dessner; a second pair of brothers, Bryan Devendorf, the drummer, and Scott Devendorf, who usually plays bass; and Matt Berninger, the band’s vocalist. Matt also writes the lyrics. He is tall, with a sturdy jib, cool blue eyes, a three-day reddish blond beard and enough lead-singer swagger to hold his own among all those siblings.

headline: In the Health Bill, a New Focus on Elder Abuse

headline: Surreal Reveal
text: Most beauty stories are about the latest makeup trends. For “Surreal Reveal,” the makeup artist Peter Philips and the photographer Richard Burbridge took a decidedly reductive, and ultimately seductive, route. Using photographs by Man Ray as a springboard, Philips, who is Chanel’s global creative director of makeup, stripped down the idea of a beauty image to its naked core. He didn’t even use foundation on the model’s skin. “After all, great skin is the ultimate luxury,” he says. But bare doesn’t mean you don’t use any makeup at all, he stresses. “When you pare it down to such an extent, every element you do wear has to be perfect — the perfect lipstick, the perfect eyeliner, the perfect nail polish.” For Philips, the new bare lies somewhere between the overdone maquillage of the late ’80s and the raw, unkempt look of the early ’90s. “I don’t think women today feel the need to be so extreme,” he says. Working on the shoot, Philips found the contradictions inherent in creating deconstructed beauty images to be both intriguing and modern. “The iconic, formal poses in the photos are a reference to old fashion photography, and are completely at odds with how we played with the pristine, expensive objects in the shots,” he says. (It’s true that a lot of women might shudder at the idea of drawing on a quilted Chanel bag with eyeliner.) “I love the fact that you can never see the model’s eyes,” Philips continues. “Makeup can be a mask that a woman hides behind. I compare it to a woman who overaccessorizes or wears over-the-top fashion — the accessories and clothes almost act as armor.” Whether a woman decides to get away with a mere swipe of mascara or puts on a full face, Philips supports the idea that less can truly be more: “You can wear the most dramatic red lipstick, but if you wear it with confidence, as if you own it, it will look completely natural.”

headline: Imagining a Jet-Free Europe

Since flying is by far the most highly emitting form of transportation, the central question was “How would Europe look and function without aviation or with much less aviation than we have now?” as Peder Jensen, the agency’s transportation expert and the event’s organizer, put it.

headline: Cube Roots: Revisiting the Raiders and N.W.A. in Ice Cube’s ‘Straight Outta L.A.’
text: As befits an actor-rapper multi-hyphenate like Ice Cube, his documentary “Straight Outta L.A.” is two stories in one: it’s the tale of how the Oakland Raiders owner Al Davis moved the team to Los Angeles in the 1980s, and how it helped inspire the city and bring it together, before the Raiders returned to Oakland in 1995. It’s also the story of N.W.A., the gangsta rap group that included Ice Cube, Dr. Dre and Eazy-E, and how it made the Raiders’ clothing and sometimes ruthless spirit an essential part of its act. “Straight Outta L.A.” will have its premiere Friday at the Tribeca Film Festival, as part of the Tribeca/ESPN Sports Film Festival, and will be shown on ESPN as part of its “30 for 30″ film series next month.

headline: Complaint Box | Horns and Drivers
text: I have a burning question for those clueless, self-absorbed troglodytes who honk their horns in residential neighborhoods. Why, because the person in front of you doesn’t move within a millisecond of a green light, do you feel that slamming your jarring, piercing horn does anything other than upset everyone else in the vicinity — particularly those whose right to the quiet enjoyment of their residential premises is being violated?

headline: Absent Grandparents
text: One of the many complicated questions raised by Abbie Dorn’s haunting story yesterday was what rights her parents have under the law. They are the grandparents in this case, asking for visitation on their daughter’s behalf. Lawyers for their former son-in-law argued that they had no legal standing, but a judge ruled otherwise.

headline: Obama Slams Arizona’s Immigration Bill
text: President Obama on Friday strongly criticized restrictive immigration legislation pending in Arizona, calling for a federal overhaul of the nation’s laws instead.

headline: One Man’s Trash . . .
text: Working with a patient he calls Debra, a compulsive hoarder, the psychologist Randy O. Frost tried a simple experiment. Frost proposed sending Debra a postcard, blank but for the name and address. Debra’s assignment was to throw it away.

headline: Parent Hood
text: The set-up of Peter Hedges’ third novel, “The Heights,” is classic and promising. An attractive young couple, married with children, are roused from their quotidian rounds of diapers-and-drop-offs when a rich, beautiful stranger comes to town — “town,” in this case, being the mediacentric, well-heeled, aesthetically unbeatable Brooklyn Heights, where the husband teaches history at an exclusive academy a lot like St. Ann’s. Private school, real estate, a marriage at risk: what more could anyone want?

headline: Tebow’s Draft Magic
text: Perhaps the best news from the first day of the N.F.L. draft Thursday was that Florida quarterback Tim Tebow was selected in the first round, sparing us from hearing about him for the next two days.

headline: Dress Like You Care
text: These style-conscious pieces will make you feel pretty on the inside.

headline: Zipcar Expands in Europe
text: Car-sharing companies, which sign up members who pay fees for access to strategically located fleets, are clearly on a roll.

headline: On Our Radar: Tracking Asian Monsoons
text: Using tree rings, scientists chart Asian monsoons back to the Middle Ages and link the collapse of the Ming dynasty to drought.

headline: Reclaiming the Blood of the Havasupai
text: “Blood Journey” (06:02)

headline: Does H. Sapiens Need a New Tune?
text: The day after the 40th Earth Day is a good moment to revisit music of this sphere and ponder whether humans should start singing a new tune about forging a more durable relationship with their home planet. I love the music of the 20th-century environmental movement. No song captures the spirit of that era better than Tom Paxton’s “Whose Garden Was this?”

headline: Fleas Hither and Thither
text: On Saturday, fleas come to Manhattan.

headline: McDaniels Has Great Faith in Tebow’s Talents
text: In 2007, Josh McDaniels was the prepubescent looking offensive coordinator who steered the New England Patriots’ offense, the most explosive the N.F.L. had ever seen. The Patriots dragged the spread into the N.F.L. spotlight, a scheme that McDaniels admitted he stole largely from the University of Florida, where his long-time friend Urban Meyer has dominated the college game.

headline: Letter: Italy’s Home Cooks
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Mangia, Mangia!” (April 11): So good to see Italy’s home cooks  mostly women behind the scenes in Italy’s homes  finally getting the recognition they deserve! In a world where five-star chefs and celebrity chefs often get most of the attention, this is a refreshing article.

headline: Letter: A Fictional Mauritius
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Mauritius Dreaming” (April 4): To transport oneself to the island of Mauritius, read “The Prospector” (“Le Chercheur d’Or”), a novel by the Nobel laureate J. M. G. Le Clézio, who has dual French and Mauritian citizenship. (His French father was born on Mauritius.) The protagonist of the story grows up on Mauritius and later travels to the nearby island of Rodrigues in a quest for treasure.

headline: A Mysterious Service From Cable, Part II
text: Yesterday, in my weekly e-mail column (sign up here: nytimes.com/email), and in this blog, I wrote about the explosion of free WiFi hot spots for home cable-Internet customers. I wrote that I love these developments, but just can’t figure out why the cable companies are going to all this expense. Surely, I wrote, this must be a big preemptive move to ward off … something.

headline: Correction: 36 Hours in Sydney
text: The 36 Hours column on April 11, about Sydney, Australia, misstated the location of a men’s clothing store. As the article noted, Halfsleeve is at 133 Goulburn Street. But the store is in the basement of the Mark Foys Warehouse, now converted to apartments known as Sydney Mansions. It is not in the Griffiths Teas Building across the street. And because of an editing error, the article also referred incorrectly to the airline service between Sydney and New York City. Some flights between the two cities require a layover, not a connecting flight.

headline: Swapping Old Duds for a Good Cause
text: For years Orli Cotel, a spokeswoman for the Sierra Club and host of the nationally syndicated show “Sierra Club Radio,”  hosted clothing swaps as a way to freshen up her wardrobe for free and recycle clothes among her friends.

headline: Beijing Auto Show: Ford Start Concept
text: Ford introduced its Start Concept urban car Friday morning at the Beijing auto show. With China emerging as the world’s hottest and most congested automotive market, Beijing seems an obvious choice for the automaker to show off a vehicle that features its lightweight materials and EcoBoost engine technology.

headline: A Euro-Style David vs. Minivan Goliaths
text: SOME cars just make sense. But that doesn’t mean Americans will like them.

headline: Smile on Your Face. Bugs in Your Teeth.
text: THE Ariel Atom 3 has the performance of a Ferrari, the style of a Formula racecar and all the luxuries of a Razor scooter.

headline: A Modest Car for a Man of Means
text: THE glossy catalogs thunking into mailboxes in the weeks before a major collector-car auction have been known to reduce sober adults to drooling daydreamers. I know this from experience.

headline: Spreading That Secure Feeling
text: FORD and General Motors aren’t the only automakers offering interactive entertainment and crash-reporting systems. In fact, G.M.’s OnStar was initially licensed to other automakers, including Acura, Audi, Isuzu, Lexus, Subaru and Volkswagen, but it is now exclusive to G.M. and its former Saab brand.

headline: Two Paths to Similar Ends for In-Car Data Systems
text: THE idea that the first call to a 911 operator after a traffic accident would be placed by one of the cars involved, rather than a witness, was once the stuff of science fiction.

headline: M.I.T. Economist Wins John Bates Clark Medal
text: Esther Duflo

headline: The First Coach
text: Your new memoir, “A Game of Character,” opens in a small apartment on Euclid Avenue on the South Side of Chicago, where you and your kid sister, Michelle, shared a bedroom until high school and indulged in a good deal of ribbing. You say she used to tease you about being a goody-two-shoes. She had some other stuff. She was always worried that I would go out and not know how to dance or talk to girls and that kind of thing, so she wanted to make sure I was schooled well from that standpoint.

headline: Two Chicks Very Ready to Make Music
text: AUSTIN, Tex.

headline: From Jameson to Fela Kuti, Preshow Rites of a Soul Band
text: SHARON JONES is, as the saying goes, the real deal. A 5-foot-1 vocal powerhouse who has been nicknamed the Queen of Funk, Ms. Jones, 53, grew up singing at home in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, in church and in local bands. But professional success in music eluded her; for a time she worked as a prison guard at Rikers Island, where the inmates would sometimes make requests. Now, as the leader of the Dap-Kings, the house band of the Brooklyn record label Daptone, Ms. Jones is the epitome of the soul revival. “I Learned the Hard Way,” the fourth album by Sharon Jones & the Dap-Kings, which entered the Billboard album chart at No. 15 this month, earned praise for staying true to the analog grit of its predecessors. Ms. Jones still lives with her mother in a public housing in Far Rockaway, Queens, a rough area she escapes by going fishing in the Delaware Water Gap. In an interview in the waiting room of her ear, nose and throat doctor  Ms. Jones needed a checkup before a European tour  she and Neal Sugarman, a Dap-King saxophonist and a founder of Daptone, talked about the musicians they draw inspiration from, like Otis Redding and Etta James, and their recently upgraded life on tour. After years of buying her own vintage dresses, Ms. Jones now has a stage wardrobe that comes courtesy of the designers Trina Turk and Minna. And the shoes she dances up a storm in? “Payless,” she stage-whispered. “Don’t tell anyone.”

headline: Ahab Sings! (The Whale Does Not)
text: SEEKING adventure may mean looking for trouble, but how much trouble did you have in mind? Five years ago, when the Dallas Opera began planning its move to the luxurious new Winspear Opera House, the company’s artistic director, Jonathan Pell, approached the composer Jake Heggie to commission an opera for the inaugural season, with all the risks such a project entailed. Not missing a beat Mr. Heggie told him, “I want to set ‘Moby-Dick.’ ”

headline: More Scrutiny of Lawyers in Deals Gone Bad
text: After the Securities and Exchange Commission accused Stephen J. Czarnik, a securities lawyer, of facilitating an illegal pump-and-dump investment scheme, Mr. Czarnik’s lawyer filed a vigorous defense brief in Manhattan federal court two weeks ago.

headline: Anchors Don’t Come in Pretty Boxes
text: DURING my wedding my best friend’s house burned down. Dylan and her boyfriend, Clay, had anticipated their home’s combustion; wildfires had been raging for days in the mountains east of Tucson where they lived. As my wedding drew near, they packed their VW bus with Dylan’s bridesmaid dress, their dog, laptops and photographs, and drove cross-country to East Hampton, N.Y., where, during the festivities, they monitored events back home by phone.

headline: Advice from ‘Yale Mom’ for an Applicant with a Choice
text: Those of you who stumbled on The Choice soon after its inception last spring may remember Nicholas Geiser. He was a high school senior from San Francisco who wrote for our blog about a perfect batting average: he was accepted to all 12 colleges to which he applied, and ultimately chose Yale over Harvard and a prestigious Morehead-Cain Scholarship at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill.

headline: TimesCast | April 23, 2010
text: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Friday.  Topics include finding the votes for financial regulation, Jon Stewart takes on Fox and Hollywood wants a natural look.

headline: Can Big Food Fight Fat?
text: Two articles in the current American Journal of Public Health (links via Marion Nestle’s piece here) discuss the potentially constructive role of Big Food in improving global diet.

headline: King Tut in New York
text: Images from two exhibitions of King Tut artifacts.

headline: You Can Judge a Book by Its Movie
text: MADISON, Wis.

headline: We Made It Ourselves | Mom-and-Pop Pop
text: There’s something comforting and delightful about a classic soda fountain. That’s what Anton Nocito thinks, and his dream is to open one in New York City. He’s starting small with homemade soda.

headline: Draft Q.& A. With Mike Tanier (Questions)
text: Mike Tanier, an analyst for footballoutsiders.com and a contributor to the Fifth Down, took readers’ questions about the N.F.L. draft and answered them here. Look for his insight and analysis on Rounds 2 and 3 of the draft, delivered with a joke or two, Friday night on the Fifth Down. He wrote about Tim Tebow after he was picked by the Denver Broncos on Thursday:

headline: Inside the List
text: POISON PEN: “Oprah,” the latest biography from the celebrity-slayer Kitty Kelley, enters the hardcover non­fiction list at No. 1. Readers scanning the lengthy index for dirt on Leo Tolstoy, William Faulkner and other authors featured in the classics phase of Oprah’s Book Club will be disappointed, though there is an entry for Alice B. Toklas. Kelley also quotes the terse note that her subject sent to the publisher Nan Talese, after Talese endured a painful televised browbeating over the fabrications in James Frey’s memoir “A Million Little Pieces.” “Dear Nan,” the note read. “Thanks for being on the show. Sincerely, Oprah.” Apparently, she was following a tip from Bill Clinton, who likes to write single-page letters suitable for framing.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: SOLAR,  by Ian McEwan (Nan A. Talese/­Doubleday, $26.95.) In McEwan’s funniest novel yet, a self-­deluding physicist cheats on his wives, sends an innocent man to jail and tries to cash in on another scientist’s plans against global warming.

headline: Levine’s Operation Deemed a Success
text: James Levine’s manager, Ronald Wilford, said his client was released from the hospital on Wednesday after lower back surgery and “never looked better.” He said the operation had been “enormously successful” and that despite a series of canceled performances recently, Mr. Levine still hoped to conduct at the Tanglewood Festival this summer. “He wants to come back to conducting as quickly as possible, but he doesn’t want to screw it up,” Mr. Wilford said in a telephone interview. “He’s really frustrated.”

headline: Letterman: ‘Kind of Perplexing’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: You know, a lot of people were flying and got delayed by the Icelandic volcano, and everybody is upset. They lost billions of dollars in revenue. And I said, “O.K., it’s kind of their fault. I mean to be flying during the volcano season, come on! Are you nuts? Really? Your own fault.”

headline: Bombings in Iraq Follow Killing of Militant Chiefs
text: Officials said 12 bombs killed dozens of people in a series of attacks in Baghdad and western Iraq that came days after two top insurgents were killed.

headline: Leno: ‘An Obama-Themed Nightclub’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Happy Earth Day. To demonstrate their commitment, environmentalists all across the country risked their lives driving Priuses.

headline: Tech Entrepreneurs Share Sentiments in Therapy That Aren’t Fit for Twitter
text: It was true confession time at Founder Therapy, a monthly support group for tech entrepreneurs in the new Silicon Alley, and a 27-year-old man in a red-striped T-shirt had a doozy.

headline: Why Women Find Their Parents Unpleasant
text: I recently received a copy of “Wellbeing: The Five Essential Elements” in the mail. The book, published by Gallup Press, is a readable digest of survey data and academic research on what makes people happy and what makes them unhappy. To the uninitiated in this subject, you may find that the things you think make people happy are, in the words of the book’s authors, “misguided or just plain wrong.”

headline: Adoption and Loss, From Three Angles
text: JUDGING from a quick spin through the adoption-related movies listed on the Internet Movie Database, where the roster includes titles like “Broken Promises: Taking Emily Back” and “Dwarf Family Adoption,” it’s easy to conclude that popular culture tends to approach the subject as either tragically sad or slightly weird.

headline: When Over-Sharing Leads to Problems
text: 2:59 p.m. | Updated  Added Blippy’s explanation on its Web site of what went wrong.

headline: Jorda Piskuloska, Christopher Eilert
text: Jorda Piskuloska and Christopher W. Eilert were married Friday evening at Most Sacred Heart of Jesus Church in Wallington, N.J. The Very Rev. Felix R. Marciniak, a Roman Catholic priest and the pastor of the church, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Steven D. D’Andrea, the church’s parochial vicar, taking part.

headline: Not Afraid to Follow the Money
text: WHAT do Eliot Spitzer, Ken Kesey, Lance Armstrong, sumo wrestling, Al Qaeda and the imprisoned lobbyist Jack Abramoff have in common? They’re all subjects of Alex Gibney films being released in 2010.

headline: In Turf Battle, City Cedes to Ball Players
text: The tennis bubble at Queensboro Ovalwill be removed in May, paving the way for a return of the softball and baseball leagues that nearly lost their summertime fields.

headline: Change in Experiment Will Delay Shuttle’s End
text: A $1.5 billion seven-ton cosmic-ray experiment scheduled to be carried aloft July 29 on the space shuttle Endeavour won’t be ready until August, according to the experiment’s leader, Samuel Ting of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, delaying the end of the 29-year-old shuttle program.

headline: ‘Race’ Pays Off for Producers
text: The Broadway production of David Mamet’s play “Race” has earned back its initial investment of about $2.5 million after five months of performances this season, the producers announced this week. It is one of a handful of commercial plays this season to have recouped the investment spent on mounting the productions on Broadway.

headline: ‘Uncollected Poems': Subtitle as Oxymoron
text: We are easily amused. Thus, titles like James Schuyler’s “Other Flowers: Uncollected Poems,” reviewed this weekend in the Book Review, elicit chuckles. (Which is not to say anything bad about the book itself; Stephen Burt, our reviewer, has only high praise.)

headline: Whaling ‘Peace Plan’ Just Less of the Same?
text: On Earth Day, the leadership of the International Whaling Commission issued a long-discussed proposal for a “peace plan” aimed at reining in expanding whale hunts by Japan, Norway and Iceland that have, in various ways, skirted the longstanding moratorium on commercial whaling.

headline: F.D.A. Steps Up Oversight of Infusion Pumps
text: Federal regulators say they are moving to tighten their oversight of medical devices, including one of the most ubiquitous and problematic pieces of medical equipment — automated pumps that intravenously deliver drugs, food and other solutions to patients.

headline: Beijing Auto Show: BMW Gran Coupé Concept
text: BMW introduced a new ‘tweener sedan concept at this week’s auto show in Beijing, a design study that hints at how far the brand thinks it can push its styling without giving up its signature elements. Called the Gran Coupé, it would slot into BMW’s lineup between the 5 Series and 7 Series.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Biographies of Henry Luce and Muriel Spark
text: This week: Alan Brinkley discusses the life of Henry Luce, creator of the Time-Life magazine empire; Charles McGrath talks about a biography of the author Muriel Spark; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: TimesCast: Financial Legislation
text: One day after President Obama addressed some of the nation’s most influential bankers on the need for a new financial regulatory structure, lawmakers in Congress are battling over the details of the overhaul bill.

headline: Top Senators on Finance Bill to Meet — on Sunday Talk Show
text: The fate of the big financial regulation legislation is largely in the hands of two chief negotiators: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, the chairman of the banking committee, and Senator Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, the panel’s senior Republican.

headline: Divac Selected to Lead Serbian Olympic Committee
text: Former N.B.A. star center Vlade Divac has had many titles in his career: All-star, two-time Olympic silver medalist, two-time world champion, savvy flopper, basketball ambassador.

headline: Milan Report | Pull Up a Chair
text: Last week, in spite of the volcanic ash cloud, Milan was abuzz with design, both at the furniture fair and at the many exhibitions outside it. There was plenty to see, and to sit on. Chairs were somewhat more restrained than in recent years, and there was a strong bent toward practicality, with a liberal sprinkling of eco-friendliness. But beauty, and even whimsy, was also on the menu. Here are a few of The Moment’s favorites.

headline: Cleveland Groups Team Up to Offer Stravinsky and Vonnegut
text: The Cleveland Play House, the Cleveland Orchestra, and GroundWorks DanceTheater have undertaken an unusual collaboration this weekend to present a new production of Stravinsky’s “Soldier’s Tale,” which includes a libretto by Kurt Vonnegut Jr. that sets the work during World War II.

headline: Just a Moment: Photographing Ordinary Life
text: Overview | What if hundreds of people around the world took pictures at the same moment and uploaded them to one digital album? The New York Times’s Lens blog has invited people to submit photos taken at the same time on Sunday, May 2, 2010. In this lesson, students look at and critique Times reader-submitted photos that capture a moment and/or express a theme. They then do a “trial run” for “A Moment in Time,” create a presentation of their images and prepare to participate in and/or view and assess the May 2 event.

headline: Chelsea, 10:49 A.M.
text: Outside a public hearing on West 25th Street, artists protest proposed rules to limit the number of vendors selling art in city parks.

headline: The Amazing Jason Pierre-Paul
text: You’ve probably read a lot about Jason Pierre-Paul and his amazing athletic ability. But if you’ve yet to witness it, here’s the YouTube video everyone has been talking about.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: ‘Friday Night Lights,’ Peter Martins, Nicole Holofcener and More
text: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

headline: Financial Tuneup: Treat Giving Like Saving
text: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, we’ve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

headline: China Asks Monks to Leave Quake Area
text: BEIJING — Chinese authorities confirmed Friday reports that they had asked Buddhist monks to end their relief work in Qinghai, the province in central China’s highlands where an earthquake last week left at least 2,187 people dead.

headline: What is the New Age of Travel?
text: The Icelandic volcano that disrupted global air travel last week raised a concern: should we be thinking of alternative ways to move masses of people and goods? Read more.

headline: Donor Takes Aim at Espada
text: As investigators continue looking into the business and political dealings of Pedro Espada Jr., the Senate majority leader, a top Democratic donor announced Friday that he planned to direct as much as $250,000 toward defeating Mr. Espada in this year’s election.

headline: For Jamie Dimon, a Sinking Feeling About Housing
text: Think the real estate bust has been tough for everyone? Just ask Jamie Dimon.

headline: Former Officer Testifies in Bicyclist-Shoving Case
text: Ever since a videotape of a police officer knocking a man off of his bicycle in Times Square surfaced on the Internet two years ago, people have asked the same question: What was the officer thinking? The cyclist did appear, after all, to be veering away from the officer, trying to avoid a collision.

headline: Forecast Says China Provides Opportunities and Competition
text: A new five-year forecast by J.D. Power and Associates anticipates a 55 percent growth for the automotive market in China by 2015, with sales of passenger vehicles — defined as cars, sport utility vehicles and minivans — expected to increase from 8.7 million in 2009 to 13.5 million in 2015.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Biographies of Henry Luce and Muriel Spark
text: This week: Alan Brinkley discusses the life of Henry Luce, creator of the Time-Life magazine empire; Charles McGrath talks about a biography of the author Muriel Spark; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Bling Around the Collar
text: Something borrowed, something old, something new — the only thing missing from this one-off necklace ($2,900) by Marsha Chun-Matsubara (her fledgling label is called Abakus) is something blue. Unicorn Disco, inspired by a client’s old necklace, is made of vintage aluminum disks from Germany, bubble pearls, antique copper mesh, fake coral, rhinestone buttons and snakeskin printed beads. “It reminds me of something by Miriam Haskell,” Chun-Matsubara says, “but turbocharged.” Go to abakuscollection.com for information.

headline: Beamalot
text: Video | Now for something completely different with Kirk and Spock:

headline: Living in Queens Plaza
text: Once known for its strip clubs, the area just over the Queensboro Bridge is slowly gaining an identity as a place to live and work.

headline: Arizona Enacts Stringent Law on Immigration
text: PHOENIX — Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona signed the nation’s toughest bill on illegal immigration into law on Friday. Its aim is to identify, prosecute and deport illegal immigrants.

headline: Lehman Moves to Disallow Nomura Claims
text: Lehman Brothers Holdings, the bankruptcy estate of the failed investment bank, moved to dismiss more than $1 billion worth of creditor claims by Nomura of Japan, arguing that they are vastly overstated.

headline: Welcome to Queens. Please Stay Awhile.
text: QUEENS PLAZA has the distinction of being the gateway to Queens, a traveler’s first sight after alighting from Manhattan via the Queensboro Bridge. But that is not to say it has always been a sparkling example of a hospitable welcome.

headline: A Popular U.S. Export: The $100 Bill
text: ONE of the most successful export businesses in the United States is run by the government, which produces a product for a small fraction of the price that people will pay for it.

headline: Profiting From Distressed Homes
text: Upper Brookville

headline: How to Opt Out of Facebook’s Instant Personalization
text: This week, Facebook introduced the “open graph,” a giant expansion of the “social graph” concept on which Facebook is built. The word “open” alone should be a tip-off that there are significant new privacy issues to weigh.

headline: Awake, Wall Street
text: Barry Ritholtz has a good post on the Goldman Sachs case. In it he describes Robert Khuzami, the former prosecutor now running the S.E.C.’s enforcement division:

headline: In Manhattan, Rents Are Creeping Back Up
text: ONE month free!

headline: Fresh Pencils, Books, and Free Computers
text: Nearly 20,000 sixth graders who attend low-income schools will receive free computers beginning in September, thanks to a $22 million federal grant meant to increase broadband access in New York City.

headline: With Impact Investing, a Focus on More Than Returns
text: The very phrase “impact investing” sounds rapacious, but it is an emerging hybrid of philanthropy and private equity that proponents say is about to become more widespread. It is also something that has some very rich people intrigued.

headline: A New Crop of Rental Units Hits the Market
text: ROUGHLY 1,500 rental units are gradually being rolled onto the northern New Jersey market starting this spring. One large new building in Hoboken will start leasing this week; several other apartment complexes in both cities and suburbs have opened or are about to, and two tall rental towers are being readied to open early in 2011.

headline: Now Online | T Women’s Fashion Summer 2010
text: It’s all about … undone beauty, starring our cover girl, the actress Rebecca Hall, who channels ‘Horses’-era Patti Smith to capture the season’s effortless style. Speaking of undone, we present a portfolio of beauties  from Karen O to Greta Gerwig  for whom messy is more, revisit Bettina Rheims’s bare beauties, explore the history of nude fashion and bring you up to date on the latest in dry shampoos and wispy fragrances. Chanel makeup artist Peter Philips performs a surreal reveal, hair star Guido Palau picks his favorite products and Anjelica Huston talks about her favorite scent (hint: it isn’t Joy). Susan Campos combs through Hollywood’s secret hair-restoration club, Daphne Merkin dreams of life as a Real Housewife  complacent husband and all, and Guy Trebay reveals the naked truth about today’s models.

headline: For the Sweet-Toothed, Cocktails and Cake
text: UPON entering the Red Velvet Lounge on the Lower East Side, one can’t help but notice a rather grave Marie Antoinette and Louis XVI watching over everyone — not exactly the usual faces seen out and about on a Saturday night. The hand-painted ceiling features the distinguished duo’s larger-than-life portraits hovering over the crowd in a let-them-eat-cake tribute to liquor-laced cupcakes.

headline: Kenneth D. Levien
text: Mr. Levien, 58, is a founder and principal of Levien & Company, a real estate project manager based in New York.

headline: Era Ends as Chevrolet Account Drives Off to Publicis
text: One of the longest relationships between an advertiser and an agency is ending after 96 years as the Chevrolet division of General Motors cuts its remaining ties with Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: N.F.L. Draft: What Were They Thinking?
text: A surprising number of teams spent their first-round pick on a position that, going into the draft, seemed already to be filled. These moves are always intriguing. Sometimes they’re a result of a team following the “best player available” drafting model. But usually, it’s a team saying, “Fans might like the players we already have at this position, but we sure don’t.”

headline: Tour of TECO
text: Coal mining carries inherent risks. But the TECO Coal Corporation, operator of the E3-1 mine in Hazard, Ky., places a high priority on mine safety.

headline: Love and Writing
text: The great Marisa Silver, guest-blogging last week at The Elegant Variation, offered a short but valuable list of “Advice for the Lovelorn … I Mean Writers,” in which she applied relationship lessons to literature. Among her tips: “Get lost. Be scared. Have no idea where you’re headed.”

headline: Bias Accord as Harbinger
text: A DECISION this month by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to drop its racial-discrimination lawsuit against Wells Fargo in exchange for a say in reviewing its lending practices could set the stage for similar agreements with other big mortgage lenders, some experts say.

headline: A Condo in the Thick of Things
text: AS soon as Joy and Brian J. Pape moved into their one-bedroom co-op in Manhattan, they wanted out.

headline: Pocket-Sized on West 47th Street
text: SOME of the multitudes who saw an early touring production of “Cats” in the mid-1980s might remember an exuberant orange tabby called Skimbleshanks. The character was played by a 20-something dancer named Jonathan Cerullo, swathed from ears to tail in yak hair.

headline: Sketching Lives Long Buried and Forgotten
text: The drawing is nearly devoid of detail. It shows a vague-faced man in a suit, ripped from context, leaning his hand up against nothing.

headline: ‘The Swimming Pool’
text: I

headline: Rural UConn Is a University in Want of a Town
text: STORRS

headline: Durbin, Too, Gets Blagojevich Subpoena
text: Senator Richard J. Durbin told reporters on Friday that he has been subpoenaed to testify in former Illinois Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich’s upcoming corruption trial, according to news media reports.

headline: A Kitchen, and Filmmaker, With Soul
text: The name Fatih Akin is not likely the first that comes to mind when thinking of jovial movie comedies. His 2004 film “Head On” dealt with two strangers with suicidal tendencies, and 2007’s “The Edge of Heaven” was a serious exploration of the generational and geographical distances between parents and children. Mr. Akin goes in a different direction with “Soul Kitchen,” a lighter look at the frenetic life of a restaurant owner in Hamburg, Germany.

headline: The Morning Skate: Sympathy for the Devils
text: There is much talk around the Devils today of how disappointed players are (Rich Chere in The Star-Ledger quotes many of them), and how equally disappointed many of the fans are (like blogger John Fischer of In Lou We Trust), how much more everyone expected from a team whose cornerstones are Hall of Famers Lou Lamoriello and Jacques Lemaire and future Hall of Fame goalie Martin Brodeur.

headline: Objects of Accumulation
text: People spend the first half of their lives accumulating stuff and the last half getting rid of it. That’s the story of eBay. And of my parents — except for the getting-rid-of-it part. If their life were a Frank Capra movie, it would be called “You Can’t Throw It Away.” Or, in the language of reality TV: “Hoarders: Rubber-Band and Rotary-Phone Edition.” Which is great if you want to put your hands on that lifelike machine gun you had when you were 9. But not so great when it comes time to sell the house.

headline: Mind Over Meds
text: One day several years ago, I was reaching the end of my first visit with a patient, J.J., who had come to see me for anxiety and insomnia. He was a salesman for a struggling telecommunications company, and he was having trouble managing the strain on his finances and his family. He was sleeping poorly, and as soon as he opened his eyes in the early morning, the worries began. “I wake up with a list of things to worry about,” he said. “I just go through the list, and it seems to get longer every day.”

headline: Hitting Rewind on the Cassette Tape
text: Over the last couple of years, sales of vinyl records increased; the numbers aren’t huge, but they sparked a lot of public musing about the format’s qualities. Cassette sales, meanwhile, steadily dwindled to a mere 34,000 last year through the retail venues tracked by SoundScan. Considering this not long ago, I concluded that the romance associated with vinyl doesn’t apply to its longtime analog rival. I was wrong about that. In looking (and asking) around online, I realize now that there is extensive evidence of ongoing appreciation for the cassette — or at least the idea of the cassette.

headline: Cracked Foundation: Reforming Housing Finance
text: Timothy Geithner, a man whose taste for Kierkegaard is usually kept under wraps, recently held forth to the House Financial Services Committee on the “central, existential question” that is facing America or, at the very least, that is facing its reform of housing finance. The Treasury secretary is bedeviled over what to do with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the bailed-out mortgage giants that have cost the taxpayers upward of $125 billion with as yet no end in sight. Shutting them down is not so easy because — get ready for this — since their bailout, in September 2008, Fannie and Freddie have become more, not less, important to the U.S. housing market. At present, 9 of every 10 new mortgages are sold to, or guaranteed by, arms of the U.S. government, the majority of them to Fannie and Freddie. Which is to say, without Uncle Sam, it is not clear that the private market for housing would even exist.

headline: ‘Lost’ in Translation
text: On a recent Tuesday, Twitter crackled with anticipation. A significant episode of “Lost,” the eerie long-running TV series about plane-crash survivors on a haunted island, was coming up. A Twitterer called dmaul53854 announced his plans to lift weights and “get ready for some #Lost awesomeness!” using the pound sign to create a tag to make his tweet easier to find. “Happy #LOST day!” wrote peterkz. Macarolribeiro tested her character allowance: “#LOSTDAY!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!!”

headline: Existential Crisis of a Plastic Bag
text: An 18-minute film chronicling the life of a plastic bag has gone viral on the Internet.

headline: Post-Debate Spin in British Newspapers
text: British newspapers are known for many things, but the impulse to hide their political views under a bushel of subtlety is not among them. For Americans taught that newspapers are supposed to be impartial in their news pages, a headline like “The Cam Back Kid,” which adorned the front page of The Sun on Friday — hailing the Conservative leader David Cameron’s “victory” in the tabloid’s own poll of viewers of Thursday’s televised debate — might seem to err on the side of editorializing. On the newspaper’s Web site, readers were shown a huge photograph of Mr. Cameron downing a celebratory pint of beer, “to celebrate bouncing back in style to win the second party leaders’ debate.”

headline: Now Screening | Take It Off!
text: The photographers Coppi Barbieri made this video, “Nude,” to coincide with the T Women’s Fashion Summer 2010 issue, the theme of which is undone beauty. As you’ll see, model Adela Capova comes undone beautifully.

headline: BlogTalk: Prayer and Immigration
text: Two topics buzzing through the blogs today concern the Army’s decision to “disinvite’’ the Rev. Franklin Graham, son of the evangelist Billy Graham, to lead the services at the National Day of Prayer event at the Pentagon next month, and President Obama criticizing Arizona’s pending immigration legislation.

headline: ‘13 Bankers’
text: Introduction

headline: Ford Joins the App Generation
text: If you can’t stop them, link to them. That is the approach Ford is taking to the use of smartphones in the car. Later this year, the automaker will introduce software that allows applications, like Pandora and Twitter, to be used with  cellphones connected to its in-car Sync systems (a topic that is covered in an article in Sunday’s Automobiles section).

headline: Cat Disposal
text: Our neighbor has 10 cats that live outdoors and make our yard a constant target for defecation (which is illegal). We often step in cat feces and fear our toddler will catch parasites. Our neighbor will not address this problem. The township will fine him but not remove the cats. We tried cat repellents, including coyote-urine powder and a motion-detecting sprinkler. None helped. We now plan to take the cats to a shelter (legally), where they will likely be euthanized eventually. This saddens us, but haven’t we done all we can? S. F., ARDMORE,PA.

headline: Comments of the Week: iPhonegate, Privacy and Facebook
text: As the week comes to a close iPhonegate continues to captivate the country; stores remain closed, truckers can’t buy gasoline, life is essentially at a standstill … O.K., it didn’t really captivate the country, but the missing iPhone did make it onto almost every major media outlet, including “Good Morning America” and “Late Show With David Letterman.” Still, in the nerdosphere, the debate continues among technologist and gadget blogs. But what did commenters on The Times Web site think? Many believed that the entire production was just another Apple publicity stunt.

headline: An Online Alias Keeps Colleges Off Their Trail
text: TO the list of the typical high school rites of passage — first crush, first kiss, first pimple — technology may be adding a ritual: changing your name.

headline: The Moviegoer | At the Tribeca Film Festival
text: The Moviegoer is a regular column on new and noteworthy films, actors and directors by John Anderson.

headline: Reyes to Bat Third in New Lineup
text: Manager Jerry Manuel unveiled his promised new lineup on Friday afternoon, and it has Jose Reyes batting third, the first time Reyes has not been in the leadoff spot since July 5, 2005.

headline: Corrections
text: The Remarkable Creatures column on March 23, about sex determination in marine reptiles, referred imprecisely to sea snakes and their behavior. While true sea snakes, or Hydrophiidae, spend their entire lives in water and all bear live young, not all sea snakes do so. A few species return to land to lay eggs.

headline: Zipcar Expands to London and Beyond
text: Zipcar members will soon be able to cross the Atlantic and unlock a fleet of cars parked throughout London and other cities in England.

headline: What We’re Reading: Recycled Toilet Paper
text: Link from around the Web.

headline: Omnivore Returns to New York
text: Last year, the French culinary organization Omnivore held its first festival in New York. On Friday, the group released details of an expanded and more ambitious event to be held June 4 and 5. This one is to be split between Manhattan and Brooklyn.

headline: Cool, Green or Both?
text: In this article, adapted from “Sexy and Good: Sustainable Product Design,” which appeared in the Fall/Winter 2009/2010 issue of the Harvard Design Magazine, the T columnist and International Herald Tribune design critic Alice Rawsthorn discusses the design and ecological pros and cons of nine products.

headline: Nice Guy Eddie: 15 Years of Film Festivals With Edward Burns
text: Is it really a film festival if Edward Burns isn’t there? Since his debut feature, “The Brothers McMullen,” broke through at the Sundance Film Festival in 1995, Mr. Burns has become a frequent presence at the Tribeca Film Festival, where his directorial efforts like “Ash Wednesday,” “Looking For Kitty” and “Purple Violets” have made their debuts. In the years between, he’s also acted in films like “Saving Private Ryan” and as a fictional version of himself on the HBO comedy “Entourage.” This year he’s back at Tribeca with “Nice Guy Johnny,” about a young man (Matt Bush) pulled between two paths in life and two women, and his miscreant uncle (Mr. Burns) trying to help his decision-making process.

headline: Answers About Transgender Issues, Part 3
text: Following is the third and final set of responses from Dr. Laura Erickson-Schroth, who is working on “Trans Bodies, Trans Selves,” a resource guide for transgender and other gender-variant people, covering health, legal issues, cultural and social questions, history and theory.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Baghdad and Elsewhere
text: Religious violence erupted in numerous places around the world on Friday, most grievously in Baghdad. Karim Kadim — a member of the Associated Press team that won the 2005 Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography — was on the scene and took the first three pictures in today’s report; an unusual presence for a single photographer on any given day.

headline: Pakistani Soldiers Killed in Ambush
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — Pakistani militants ambushed a military convoy in the North Waziristan area of northern Pakistan on Thursday, killing seven soldiers and wounding 16 others in the deadliest attack on the military in months.

headline: Halston, the Life of the Party
text: Halston was the party monster’s party monster, the “Emperor of Studio 54,” until the excesses of his life finally did him in. And now he is the subject of a new documentary, “Ultrasuede: In Search of Halston,” one of the most anticipated films at this year’s Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: A Private Spat, With a Very Public Apology
text: Updated, Saturday, 8:19 p.m. | There is considerable evidence that this is a hoax. Jeff Ragsdale has worked as a comedian and actor, and his work sometimes involves blurring lines between reality and performance.

headline: ‘The Show-Book of the World': Henry Luce’s Life Magazine Prospectus
text: Below is a rather extraordinary document: Henry Luce’s prospectus for what would become Life magazine. According to Alan Brinkley’s biography of Luce, “The Publisher,” which The Times’s executive editor, Bill Keller, reviews in this Sunday’s Book Review:

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 23
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Brief Getaway in Asheville for the Obamas
text: ASHEVILLE, N.C. – Well, President Obama can check this campaign promise off the list at least. While running for president, he camped out in this scenic small city surrounded by the Blue Ridge Mountains in October 2008 to prepare for a debate, and the candidate liked it so much he vowed to come back.

headline: ‘The Firing Squad, Please,’ Says Prisoner
text: Ronnie Lee Gardner had a quarter-century to ponder his choice, whether to die by lethal injection or take four bullets in the heart.

headline: A Yoga Manifesto
text: ZEN is expensive. The flattering Groove pants, Lululemon’s answer to Spanx, may set Luluheads, the devoted followers of the yoga-apparel brand, back $108. Manduka yoga mats, favored for their slip resistance and thickness, can reach $100 for a limited-edition version. Drop-in classes at yoga studios in New York are edging beyond $20 a session, which quickly adds up, and the high-end Pure Yoga, a chain with two outposts in Manhattan, requires a $40 initiation fee, and costs $125 to $185 a month.

headline: Bright Falls: Episode 2
text: The second episode in the live-action prequel for the video game Alan Wake.

headline: Domesticities | For a Mars Explorer, a Solar Studio
text: View Slide Show >>

headline: Stanford’s Charter Elementary School Is Suspended
text: The Ravenswood City School District board voted on Thursday night to end grades K-4 at a charter school run by Stanford University’s School of Education.

headline: Bright Falls: Episode I
text: The first episode in the live-action prequel for the video game Alan Wake.

headline: Creating a Video Game’s World With Real People
text: It has been five years since Microsoft and Remedy Entertainment of Finland announced that they were developing a mature psychological action thriller for the Xbox 360 called Alan Wake. The game isn’t scheduled to hit stores until May 18, but its milieu — the disturbing, mist-shrouded Northwestern town known as Bright Falls — is first coming to life in a live-action suspense series.

headline: Scrap Metal Radiation Raises Concerns in India
text: NEW DELHI — To walk through the squalor of Mayapuri, a grimy industrial area of hundreds of tiny scrap-metal shops, is to bear witness to the industrial detritus of the world: tons of rusted iron pipes, twisted steel poles, copper and other discarded metals from Europe, Russia, Japan and the United States, as well as from India.

headline: A Little Too Ready for Her Close-Up?
text: IT took years for Hollywood to create the perfect woman. Now it wants the old one back.

headline: Former Employees Criticize Culture of Rating Firms
text: WASHINGTON — Former executives at Moody’s and Standard & Poor’s offered damaging critiques on Friday of the practices at the two credit rating agencies during the run-up to the financial crisis.

headline: Report from a Pashtun Teen: Arranged Marriage
text: Sher Bano is a 17-year-old Pashtun girl from Pakistan who spent last year as an exchange student in Evanston, Illinois, as part of the Youth Exchange and Study (YES) Program. She is now back in the city of Peshawar in the northwest of Pakistan. As a guest blogger, she’ll be writing about life in Pakistan from the perspective of a teenage girl who has spent time in the West. This is her second post.

headline: New Vantage for a Palestinian Photographer
text: Given the commotion outside his office in the West Bank one day in 2006 — armed protesters, some of them firing into the air, were marching through the streets of Ramallah — Osama Silwadi, a well-known Palestinian photojournalist, naturally, went to the window to see what was going on.

headline: A High-Minded Look at Electric Cars
text: The setting was the sun-dappled campus of Columbia University, so perhaps it wasn’t surprising that today’s forum on “New York and the Electric Car,” sponsored by the university and General Motors, took on a somewhat elevated tone.

headline: Live Updates: Rounds Two and Three of the N.F.L. Draft
text: New York Times reporters will be providing updates and analysis of the second and third rounds of the N.F.L. draft. Paul Myerberg of The Times will be hosting the festivities, and Judy Battista is at Radio City Music Hall, Greg Bishop is with the Jets and Dave Caldwell with the Giants. You can also follow Judy on Twitter. You can catch up on last night’s coverage here.

headline: The Numbers Climb Online: A Score of 88.61
text: The record for the biggest game continues to be challenged. On Christmas Day last year, Meyer Kotkin and Marty Seligman of Philadelphia played in a 37-pair, 12-board event on Bridge Base Online (bridgebase.com).

headline: Green Piece | Eco Luxe From Imitation and Disguise
text: Ecologically correct fashion can be more than hemp totes and Veja sneakers — even more than vegan platforms from Stella McCartney. In the hands of the Franco-Brazilian designer Jean-Philippe Gawronski, it’s something you want to wear well beyond the yoga studio. The handsome 30-year-old designer, who honed his skills at Lanvin for a year, realized that there was something missing at the high end of the green market. In 2007, he launched Imitation and Disguise, a focused collection of luxurious clothing and accessories made with ecologically certified materials. “I wanted to create clothes that make a woman look elegant, sexy and of the moment,” he said from Paris.

headline: A Long Way From Brooklyn
text: BARBARA STANWYCK must be one of the best represented classical-era stars on DVD. With its new boxed set  six films on three discs  Universal all but clears the shelves of any remaining Stanwyck titles in its library (which includes pre-1948 Paramount sound features).

headline: Pesos, Ponzi, And Financial Sector Profits
text: There’s been an interesting exchange over my suggestion — which is by no means original — that the stability of banks between 1935 and 1980 or so had a lot to do with lack of competition, which gave banks a franchise value that executives didn’t want to endanger with risky strategies.

headline: Coney Island’s Revival
text: A new amusement park on Coney Island will feature 22 new rides manufactured by Italy's Zamperla Group.

headline: What You Get, Where.
text: Apartments from $1,300 to $3,000 in Manhattan.

headline: Jon Stewart’s Punching Bag, Fox News
text: George W. Bush and Dick Cheney are long gone. Fox News Channel is Jon Stewart’s new enemy No. 1.

headline: Give This Round to Icahn in Lions Gate Fight
text: Things are picking up for Carl C. Icahn in his takeover battle for Lions Gate Entertainment.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: Luxury resorts at motel prices. Sugary beaches without crowds. In the weeks between spring break and the summer crush, travelers are few and deals abound. Lionel Beehner offers eight places to enjoy the off-season.

headline: On the Street | In the Trenches
text: The pastel spring coat disappeared decades ago, replaced by variations of the between-season trench coat.

headline: Layoff Anxiety Persists
text: Even though the job market appears to be turning around, more than one in five American workers still thinks the axe may be coming for them in the next year.

headline: The Real Chicken-Checkup Fallacy
text: Everyone’s having fun with the chickens for checkups story, in which Sue Lowden, the leading Republican Senate candidate in Nevada, expressed a desire to return to the good old days in which people who wanted a checkup from their doctor would offer a chicken in exchange. And she’s not backing down!

headline: That Fine Comedic Art of Hurling Pies at Faces
text: Perhaps some old TV shows are best left in the vault.

headline: Fete Accompli | Food and Fashion at the Brooklyn Museum
text: Last night I gave some bum advice to Rachel Feinstein.

headline: Bike Stolen? Check the Police Station
text: Updated, 7:07 p.m. | The crowds that lined East Houston Street on Thursday morning to watch Barack Obama’s motorcade speed toward Cooper Union got a glimpse of the pomp and protection that accompanies the president. There were black sedans with tinted windows, S.U.V.’s full of Secret Service agents and a brigade of motorcycle officers from the New York Police Department led by a high-ranking officer wearing a white shirt.

headline: Escarole Soup With Rice
text: Mark Bittman prepares a pot of Italian spring soup.

headline: A New Times Blog on All Things Green
text: My colleagues on the news side of The Times have expanded the focus of the great Green Inc. blog, which was reborn this week simply as Green. I hope you’ll track their work on environmental commerce, science, energy policy and related issues. You can contact the Green team with tips or feedback at greenblog@nytimes.com.

headline: Birthday Party With Mexican Flair
text: For the venerable Anna Sokolow, who would have been 100 this year  she made it to 90  art wasn’t an understated or passive act, but something meant to be a reflection and a comment on contemporary life. In a program celebrating her centennial from Sokolow Theater/Dance Ensemble, which opened on Thursday night at the Joyce SoHo, that expressive nature was on display.

headline: Chinese Military Seeks to Extend Its Naval Power
text: YALONG BAY, China — The Chinese military is seeking to project naval power well beyond the Chinese coast, from the oil ports of the Middle East to the shipping lanes of the Pacific, where the United States Navy has long reigned as the dominant force, military officials and analysts say.

headline: Green Day Surprises Broadway Audience
text: The Broadway show “American Idiot” turned into a rock concert with a supercharged encore on Thursday night: a surprise appearance by Green Day, the band that wrote the music. The three-man band, and an additional guitarist, took to the stage after the show as audience members screamed. “This is my first night on Broadway,” the singer-guitarist Billie Joe Armstrong, right, declared, then blared out the opening power chords of “American Idiot,” the show’s title song. The cast was onstage, pogoing and singing along. One cast member tried crowd-surfing, traveling about three rows. Mr. Armstrong jumped around, stuck out his tongue and filled in the part of rock ’n’ roll that’s absent from the Broadway show: audience participation, with singalongs of “Heys” and “Day-Os” from “The Banana Boat Song.” The drummer, Tré Cool, flung his drum sticks into the audience, as if the set were over. But it wasn’t. Green Day went on to play an older song, “Basket Case,” which isn’t part of the show. Audience members squealed anew and shouted the lyrics when the bassist Mike Dirnt pointed a microphone their way. Cast members knew them, too, cementing some punk-rock credentials. Afterward, a few of them lifted the grinning Mr. Armstrong off his feet.

headline: Levine’s Back Surgery Is Deemed a Success
text: Ronald Wilford, the manager of James Levine, below, said his client was released from the hospital on Wednesday after lower back surgery and “never looked better.” He said the operation had been “enormously successful” and that despite a series of canceled performances recently Mr. Levine still hoped to conduct at the Tanglewood Festival this summer. “He wants to come back to conducting as quickly as possible, but he doesn’t want to screw it up,” Mr. Wilford said in a telephone interview. “He’s really frustrated.”

headline: ‘Oz’ Breakout: Escape to Theater
text: It’s not an official “Oz” reunion, but short of the cast members of that HBO prison drama getting thrown into a maximum-security penitentiary together it’s as close as we’re likely to get. Primary Stages said that it would end its season with two stage readings of “Godfather IV,” an original work by Tom Fontana, the “Oz” creator. It will star Christopher Meloni, Lee Tergesen and Dean Winters, who all appeared on that eye-gougingly violent series. “Godfather IV” is not a sequel to Francis Ford Coppola’s mafia movies, but a piece in which the “Oz” actors discuss the plausibility of a key scene in “The Godfather,” and Mr. Tergesen and Mr. Winters resolve to put a horse’s head in Mr. Meloni’s bed. The readings, scheduled for May 2 at 59E59 Theaters, are being presented as a benefit for Primary Stages and the Writers Guild of America, East Foundation. They will be directed by Linda Laundra (“Homicide: Life on the Street”) and will also feature the “Oz” alumni Mike Doyle, Zeljko Ivanek, Terry Kinney, David Laundra, Kristin Rohde, Eamonn Walker and Catherine Wolf, as well as an appearance by Mr. Fontana.

headline: ‘Mentalist’ Wins for CBS
text: CBS led the ratings race on Thursday night, earning the most viewers during every hour of prime time. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “The Mentalist” attracted the largest audience, as 14.8 million viewers tuned into the CBS crime show at 10 p.m. CBS’s “Survivor” was first in the 8 p.m. hour (11.8 million), while “CSI,” at 9, led with 13.3 million. Fox was the runner-up, drawing a modest 5.9 million viewers for “Fringe” at 9, but faring better at 8 with “Bones” (8.8 million). ABC ranked third with “FlashForward” at 8 (5.7 million), “Private Practice” at 9 (7.4 million) and a rerun of “Grey’s Anatomy” at 10 (4.4 million), while NBC placed fourth with its comedies.

headline: A New Character in Archie’s Town
text: A new man is moving into Riverdale, the home of comics’ perennial teenager Archie Andrews and his gang. His name is Kevin Keller, and he’s blond-haired, blue-eyed and gay. Kevin will be introduced in Veronica No. 202, right, in a story titled, “Isn’t it Bromantic?” The inclusion of the character meets twin goals, one real world and one in-story. “Riverdale has to reflect the diversity of the world today,” said Jon Goldwater, co-chief executive of Archie Comic Publications. “We want to be all inclusive.” Mr. Goldwater also said he’s not afraid of any repercussions. “We think everyone is going to enjoy the story,” he said. “It’s completely in the tradition of your typical Archie comic.” Dan Parent will be writing and illustrating the story of Kevin’s introduction. He said his goal was simple: “Veronica is always chasing guys and getting what she wants. Who could we introduce that she could not get?” Mr. Parent said Kevin would be more than a one-off character with future stories already mapped out. The issue will hit newsstands on Sept. 1.

headline: Polanski Fails in Bid to Block Extradition
text: The director Roman Polanski failed in his latest attempt to block his extradition to the United States from Switzerland, where he is under house arrest, and end the 33-year-old case against him for having sex with a minor. In a decision on Thursday, a California appeals court denied a request to end the proceedings by sentencing him to time already served, despite Mr. Polanski’s assertions that new evidence showed hitherto undisclosed corruption in the case. The authorities in Switzerland have said they will not act on the request for Mr. Polanski’s extradition to the United States until the courts in California clarify his status. The denial of his latest appeal makes clear that he is expected to appear in the United States to face sentencing.

headline: ‘Race’ Pays Off for Its Producers
text: The Broadway production of David Mamet’s play “Race” has earned back its initial investment of approximately $2.5 million after five months of performances, the producers announced. It is one of a handful of commercial plays this season that have recouped the investment spent on mounting the productions on Broadway. All of those plays had star performers in lead roles, a common box office strategy nowadays. “Race” stars James Spader (“Boston Legal”) as a lawyer who spars with two colleagues, played by David Alan Grier and Kerry Washington, about defending a white man facing ugly criminal accusations from a black woman. Other star-driven plays that recouped this season are “A Steady Rain” (with Hugh Jackman and Daniel Craig) and the revivals of “Hamlet” (Jude Law) and “A View From the Bridge” (Liev Schreiber and Scarlett Johansson). Directed by Mr. Mamet, “Race” opened at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Dec. 6, and is scheduled to run through June 13. Its lead producers are Jeffrey Richards and Jerry Frankel.

headline: Creating a World, if Not a Story
text: Gerald Casel must be tired of hearing that his choreography is reminiscent of the work of Stephen Petronio, whose company he danced with for seven years. But it’s true that choreographers with distinctive physical styles and dynamics tend to imprint those qualities on a younger generation. (Mr. Petronio was himself strongly influenced by Trisha Brown, with whom he too danced for seven years.)

headline: The Latest Line, on a Desolate Racetrack
text: Bettors at Aqueduct racetrack, in Queens, N.Y., are devoted to their no-frills track, which is in for another lean season.

headline: A Reason to Be Bitter in Spring
text: LIKE radicchio and other bitter, tough greens, escarole can survive the winter in many places and appear early in spring. But unlike radicchio, escarole is inexpensive. And it’s more versatile: it tastes better cooked than does its round, red cousin.

headline: Ex-Employees Criticize Culture of Rating Firms
text: Former executives at Moody’s Investors Service and Standard & Poor’s offered damaging critiques on Friday of the practices at the two credit-rating agencies during the run-up to the financial crisis, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

headline: Add Gay Spirit to Taste, Then Stir
text: How at ease is Leslie Jordan with himself these days? Comfortable enough that when he was hired to perform on a recent Alaska-bound cruise, he invited his mother to take the extra stateroom he was offered.

headline: The Week in Pictures for April 23
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York region. Subjects include showers for stranded travelers, the bar car on the Metro-North, and a party at the Hudson Hotel.

headline: Government Says Al Qaeda Ordered N.Y. Plot
text: The failed plot to bomb three New York City subway lines during the morning rush last September was hatched in 2008 by two senior Qaeda leaders in the tribal areas of Pakistan, where they met personally with three would-be suicide attackers from Queens to urge them to carry out a strike, federal authorities said Friday.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 23
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Making a Flute Do Tricks in Pieces Old and New
text: New York is full of talented musicians, as well as artistic entrepreneurs who busily create their own opportunities to flourish. The flutist Claire Chase fits into each of those categories and then some. Both as a performer and as the executive director of the International Contemporary Ensemble, which she helped found in 2001, she has had a hand in some of the most memorable musical events of the last several years.

headline: Chic in Review | Azzedine for H&M?
text: Alaïa, AzzedineClaims he would love to design for H&M. Chic!

headline: A Conductor Visits Before Moving In
text: NEWARK — The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra offered a glimpse of its future on Thursday afternoon at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here, when Jacques Lacombe, a fresh-faced conductor from the Trois-Rivières Symphony Orchestra in Quebec, led the ensemble for the first time since being chosen to be its next music director. Based on this initial encounter, a program featuring standard works by Brahms and Dvorak, the prognosis is decidedly positive.

headline: Being the Tastemakers, and the Main Course
text: Much as you shouldn’t judge a book by its cover  unless, say, it’s incredibly well designed or pockmarked with typos  it’s generally imprudent to judge a band by its opening acts. They might be friends of the promoter or the club owner, or have won a radio station contest, or be owed a favor.

headline: Gunmen Ambush Police Officers in Ciudad Juárez
text: MEXICO CITY — When a police officer is killed in Mexico, as seven of them were Friday on the streets of Ciudad Juárez, the sad question that immediately arises is, “Whose side were they on?”

headline: It’s the Military, Undergraduate
text: On Dec. 16, 2009, I boarded a plane to Kabul, where I would spend five weeks as a research assistant.

headline: Ruling Party in Nigeria Is Fractured by Infighting
text: DAKAR, Senegal — An outbreak of public infighting within Nigeria’s governing party this week has exposed how confused the country’s politics remain in the wake of the recent shaky transfer of power at the top, analysts contend.

headline: A Man of Funk’s Straight-Ahead Groove
text: The saxophonist Pee Wee Ellis played just one original in his first set at Iridium on Thursday night, and it delivered the only dose of nonswinging groove. That ratio felt emphatic, like a statement of principle.

headline: A Restorative Spring Dinner
text: This week’s Minimalist column uses escarole, one of the first spring greens and more affordable than other early offerings like radicchio. Its flavor is better cooked than raw, especially when mixed with creamy rice and the sweet mellow bite of garlic.

headline: Chords Unfold and Soar, Evoking Birds and Bells
text: Works by two Pulitzer Prize-winning composers of similar aesthetic bents were featured in the first half of the Lark Quartet’s program at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening.

headline: For the Fitzgeralds, the Ecstasy and Then the Agony
text: The beautiful and doomed Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald, those glittering emblems of the Jazz Age, are resurrected to do the Charleston once again in “This Side of Paradise,” a sadly limp new musical at the Theater at St. Clements.

headline: Registering an Atom: Location Matters
text: AN Ariel Atom may be quick, but a buyer must wait four months to take delivery of an American-spec car.

headline: Music Review: More of ‘The Russian Stravinsky’
text: 3:47 p.m. | Updated After many flights to New York were delayed because of the volcanic ash  clouds over Europe, the Chorus of the Mariinsky Theater finally arrived at Avery Fisher Hall in time for the second concert of “The Russian Stravinsky: A Philharmonic Festival” on Thursday night. The chorus was missed in Wednesday’s opening-night program, conducted (as is the entire festival) by Valery Gergiev, which was to have included “Les Noces,” not heard at the Philharmonic since 1982.

headline: Financial Advice by Women for Women
text: Several personal finance books aimed at women landed in my mailbox recently. They were hard to miss. The books had pink covers and the catchy, if cringeworthy, titles, “Shoo, Jimmy Choo!” and “Hot (Broke) Messes.” And then there was the one I found on Amazon, “A Purse of Your Own.”

headline: Penny-Pinching Is Fine, but It Won’t Save the Profligate
text: SOMETIMES I read about ways to pinch pennies and I feel good. We turn off lights, often buy in bulk, use compact fluorescent light bulbs and put tap water in our reusable bottles instead of buying disposable ones.

headline: Will Wall Street Be Saved by Porn?
text: Goldman Sachs is in the federal dock, President Obama is in New York talking tough to Wall Street, regulatory packages are flying through Congress — what could possibly get in the way of the financial reform juggernaut? “The Securities and Exchange Commission is the sheriff of the financial industry,” reports Jonathan Karl of ABC News, “but a new government report obtained by ABC News has concluded that some senior employees spent hours on the agency’s computers looking at sites such as naughty.com, skankwire and youporn as the financial crisis was unfolding.”

text: Gary Contessa knows that his starter in the Derby Trial Stakes is fast and gifted, maybe as talented as any 3-year-old in the country.

Lessing of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., was married Friday evening in Hobe Sound, Fla., to Timothy Joseph Mullen, a son of Claire Cranwell Mullen and Patrick J. Mullen of Spring Lake, N.J. The Rev. Luke L. Travers performed the ceremony at St. Christopher Catholic Church, with the Rev. Daniel K. Lahart participating. Both are Roman Catholic priests.

headline: A Cacophony of Musical Playthings in the Desert
text: PHOENIX  There are complete skins of animals, dried, tied and knotted, their orifices fitted with hollow canes and reeds. Other hides are stretched taut over enormous gourds. Strings, spun from intestines, are pulled and pegged into the ends of long necks. Antlers, bones and horns are cut, carved and drilled. Elephant, goat, antelope, lizard, gazelle  the skins of all are used.

text: Cate Doty and Michael McElroy were married Saturday evening in Charlottesville, Va. Deputy D. L. Duncan of the Charlottesville sheriff’s office officiated at Ash Lawn-Highland, the former residence of President James Monroe.

text: Twitter was born as a text messaging service; tweets are 140 characters because that is the length of a text message, minus a few characters for the author’s name.

Cary Stockett, who also is a United Methodist minister.

Cohen and David J. Cohen of Westport, Conn. Former Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York officiated at Battery Gardens, a restaurant.

text: Braves closer Billy Wagner has been around professional baseball long enough to be able to differentiate the prospects who will develop steadily, the ones who will flame out, and the few who will live up to the promise of the extreme hype that surrounds them.
