Lowman, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Columbia Country Club in Chevy Chase, Md., at a ceremony that was led by Wesley Pippert, a former lay preacher and a friend of the bride’s family.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about the work of the photographer Louis Faurer misstated the closing date of an exhibition at the Milwaukee Art Museum, “Street Seen: The Psychological Gesture in American Photography, 1940-59,” that features work by Mr. Faurer and other photographers. It is Sunday, not May 4.

headline: The Man Baseball Loves to Hate
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — According to some of his peers, Alex Rodriguez is a hypocrite and a “prima donna.” He is not the “Yankee type,” either, and he has “monopolized all the attention” since arriving in the Bronx in 2004. Others have described his on-field conduct as “bush league,” “a little cheap,” an “unsportsmanlike act of cheating” and more typical of “junior high school baseball.” Tough crowd.

headline: G-20 Split on the Need for a Global Tax on Banks
text: WASHINGTON — Proposals to establish a global tax on banks and charge them for the cost of government bailouts divided representatives of the Group of 20 countries during a summit meeting here on Friday.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in the Escapes pages on Friday about the Old North Branch Inn in North Branch, N.Y., and the Bedford Post Inn in Bedford, N.Y., misstated the schedule of meditation classes at the Bedford Post. They are offered on Wednesday nights, not every night.

headline: C.D.O. Days, S&M Nights at Derivatives Conference
text: SAN FRANCISCO — By day, they dealt with risk. At night, it got risqué.

headline: Is All That Sitting Really Killing Us?
text: Yes, we all sit too much, but will our sedentary ways reduce our lifespans? Olivia Judson, in a recent online Op-Ed column in The Times, told readers to “Stand Up While You Read This,” and an article in The Times’s business section reviewed different models of standing desks.

headline: Hearing on Limits for Vendors Gets Creative Response
text: When the city’s artists are fuming, they create. And when the focus of their rage is Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his efforts to crack down on selling art in parks, a new genre is born.

headline: As Tower Rises, So Do Efforts to Buy In
text: The planned skyscraper once known as the Freedom Tower was scorned for years by urban planners, downtown residents and real estate executives who regarded it as an oversize and unnecessary exercise in waste and hubris.

headline: Coney Island Getting a $30 Million Italian Makeover
text: ALTAVILLA VICENTINA, Italy — Alberto Zamperla sweeps through the cavernous workshop here where his amusement rides are manufactured while workers measure and bang and solder enormous platforms, oddly shaped beams and assorted fiberglass vehicles.

headline: With a Push From Kevin Durant, the Thunder Steps Forward
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — The N.B.A.’s elite can blame themselves for Kevin Durant’s evolution. He takes from here and there. He mimics and copies. At 21, Durant does not have much experience of his own to draw on. Instead, he copies Carmelo Anthony’s rip move, Dwyane Wade’s craftiness in luring fouls and Kobe Bryant’s resilience.

headline: A Top High School’s Move From a College Campus Prompts Anger
text: For over two decades, students at University Heights High School have attended classes on the leafy campus of Bronx Community College, a 50-acre haven that offers serene views of the Harlem River and a refuge from bustling Bronx streets.

headline: Plan Gives Pedestrians a Plaza at Union Square
text: First the city repurposed Times Square, converting some of its streets to a pedestrian promenade. Similar plans are in store for 34th Street by the Empire State Building.

headline: $18.5 Million in Liability for Scouts in Abuse Case
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — The Boy Scouts of America were ordered Friday to pay $18.5 million in a lawsuit that has focused new attention on the secret files the Scouts keep to document claims of sexual abuse by troop leaders and volunteers.

headline: A Tokyo Start, but Most at Home on 125th Street
text: Tommy Tomita walked past the red awning, down three concrete stairs, opened a gray door covered in duct tape and entered the jazz dive.

headline: Don’t Call It ‘Pot’ in This Circle; It’s a Profession
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Like hip-hop, health food and snowboarding, marijuana is going corporate.

headline: Explosion in the Gulf
text: Nearly a dozen people are missing and presumed dead after the huge explosion aboard a deep-water oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico. The accident provides further evidence that despite advances in technology, oil drilling poses big environmental and human risks.

headline: Against Trail Blazers, Suns Reap  Rewards of Playing Defense
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — As Amar’e Stoudemire sat at his locker stall Thursday night, he made a proclamation that drew a chuckle from several reporters — and probably outright laughter around the N.B.A.

headline: Beautiful Brutes
text: Brutalism, a severe architectural style that came out of postwar Europe, is enjoying somewhat of a Renaissance.

headline: Companies Feeling More Pressure to Cut Iran Ties
text: WASHINGTON — While President Obama struggles to negotiate United Nations sanctions with teeth against Iran, a parallel campaign to turn up the heat is gaining momentum by pressuring American and foreign corporations individually to cut their business ties there.

headline: Rebellious Mood Takes Root in Rural Thailand
text: KHON KAEN, Thailand — Six weeks of demonstrations by red-shirted protesters turned violent this week in Bangkok, but the capital is not the only place with a whiff of insurrection in the air.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 23, 2010

headline: Greece and Who’s Next?
text: As Greece careened ever close to default this week, frightened investors also rushed to dump bonds from financially troubled Portugal, Spain and Ireland. But while the markets increasingly see this as a euro zone crisis, many European leaders are in denial.

headline: Summer Crickets and College
text: Frank Calderon, an assistant district attorney in Albany, was 9 years old the first time he heard a cricket. He had left his family’s small apartment in a housing project in Brooklyn for a two-week stay with a host family upstate, thanks to the Fresh Air Fund.

headline: Running on Empty
text: The election season is starting in earnest, and already one thing is crystal clear. Both the Democrats and the Republicans are hopeless. It seems inconceivable that either party can possibly win anything. This may be the year when the Whigs finally get to make their comeback.

headline: The New World Trade Center
text: Panoramic views of 1 World Trade Center show the progress of building.

headline: For School Company, Issues of Money and Control
text: When the energy executive Dennis Bakke retired with a fortune from the AES Corporation, the company he co-founded, he and his wife, Eileen, decided to direct their attention and money to education.

headline: Kyrgyzstan: A Promise to Stay Away
text: Kyrgyzstan’s ousted president said Friday that he would not try to return to the country, but he maintained that his resignation was not valid. In Belarus, where he arrived this week, the president, Kurmanbek Bakiyev, said that he had signed a letter formally stepping down, butsaid that it was no longer valid because the interim government had not kept its promise to safeguard his family.

headline: Zimbabwe: Iranian President Opens Trade Fair
text: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran opened Zimbabwe’s international trade fair in Bulawayo on Friday. He and Zimbabwe’s president, Robert Mugabe, who both held on to power after violent, discredited elections — Mr. Mugabe in 2008 and Mr. Ahmadinejad last year — strongly criticized the West, according to The Herald, the state-owned newspaper in Harare controlled by Mr. Mugabe.

headline: American (Judicial) Idol
text: Americans are justifiably proud of having given the world a model for the architecture of democratic self-government. Democracies old and new have emulated the separation of powers and the idea of a constitutional court with the authority to review and invalidate actions of the other branches.

headline: China: Rare Public Protest Against an Official
text: Three protesters criticized a well-known propaganda official, Wu Hao, as he gave a speech at People’s University in Beijing on Thursday, a rare instance in which a prominent official was humiliated in public. The protesters, graduates of the university, tossed currency notes worth five mao, or less than ten cents, onto the stage as Mr. Wu, deputy director of the propaganda department in Yunnan Province, spoke, many Chinese Web sites reported Friday. The notes were a reference to the “five-mao party,” a derogatory term for Chinese Internet users who are supposedly paid five mao per posting by officials to spread propaganda on the Internet.

headline: Wide Receiver Welker
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s solve was a tale of two puzzles for me. The top went well. The bottom was slooow.

headline: Pakistan: Military Convoy Ambushed
text: Pakistani militants ambushed a military convoy in the North Waziristan area Thursday, killing seven soldiers and wounding 16 others in the deadliest attack on the military in months. The convoy was carrying out a “routine movement” in the village of Boya, according to a statement on the Pakistani military’s Web site. The military carried out a campaign in South Waziristan last year, taking territory that once belonged to the leadership of the Pakistani Taliban. Many believe that the leadership fled to North Waziristan, where other tribes, as well as the Qaeda operative Sirajuddin Haqqani, an Afghan, are thought to be hiding.

headline: Jets Make an Unlikely Selection
text: The Jets’ second-round pick is named Vladimir Ducasse, and if you hadn’t heard of him before Friday night, don’t worry, you’re not alone. Turns out, Ducasse is a raw offensive lineman who played tackle in college at UMass, but more likely will play guard for the Jets, if he  plays at all.

headline: The Court and Free Speech
text: When the Supreme Court ruled 8-to-1 this week that a federal law banning the sale of animal-cruelty videos violates the First Amendment, it reaffirmed the right to engage in even highly unpopular speech. And it wisely declined to create another category of expression outside of the First Amendment’s protection.

headline: Bloggingheads: Is Repeal for Real?
text: Timothy Noah, left, of Slate and Rich Lowry of National Review debate the G.O.P.’s push to repeal health care reform.

headline: Kyle Wilson’s Can’t-Miss Play for Attention
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The first time Kyle Wilson saw his family’s new recreational vehicle, he cringed. He looked at the 34-foot beast and saw the gaudy decoration, the bright mixture of blue and orange, the three pictures, including one of him without a shirt splashed across the back of the vehicle.

headline: Greece, Out of Ideas, Requests Global Aid
text: ATHENS — Describing his country’s economy as “a sinking ship,” Greece’s prime minister formally requested an international bailout on Friday, creating the biggest test so far to the European monetary union.

headline: Giants Gain More Weight in 2nd Round
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Rather than using their second-round pick in the N.F.L. draft on a middle linebacker to replace Antonio Pierce, the Giants took a 315-pound defensive tackle whom General Manager Jerry Reese unglamorously referred to as a “human post.”

headline: Rating Agency Data Aided Wall Street in Deals
text: One of the mysteries of the financial crisis is how mortgage investments that turned out to be so bad earned credit ratings that made them look so good.

headline: Search Ends for Missing Oil Rig Workers
text: NEW ORLEANS — Three days after an explosion on an oil rig off the southeast coast of Louisiana, an environmental disaster has been at least temporarily forestalled, but the search for 11 missing workers has ended, the Coast Guard said Friday evening.

headline: Vivaldi, the Way He Wanted to Be Heard
text: Early music can bring out the pedant in a player, and Vivaldi’s “The Four Seasons” is, despite its popularity, no exception. But some musicians take a more passionate approach to the piece — none, perhaps, more than the members of the Venice Baroque Orchestra, a 13-year-old ensemble from Vivaldi’s hometown.

headline: A New Bellisimo, Much Like the Old One
text: AFTER a year or more of hearing buzz on Bellisimo, an Italian restaurant in Hillsborough, I finally planned a visit last winter, only to learn that the place had closed. I had missed my opportunity by days. Instead, I later visited the new Bellisimo on the same premises, owned by Jim Nelson and his wife, Barbara, who opened it in early February.

headline: A Film Fest, and Beyond
text: There are movies about music in the Connecticut Film Festival in Danbury this year, like “The Wrecking Crew,” focusing on studio musicians who backed up famous performers including Frank Sinatra and the Beach Boys. And there are movies about illness, from the deadly serious “Still Here,” about a man living with H.I.V. for 30 years, to the quirky “Collecting Things,” the story of a woman with a borderline hoarding disorder. But as far as I can tell, only one film on the festival schedule (May 4 to May 9) deals with the biggest issue of the decade: the economy. That is Matt Judge’s “I Work in Public,” about a laid-off administrative assistant who takes an unusual approach to entrepreneurship.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: THE LUCKY SKILL GAME AND LOUNGE, on 40th Road just off Main Street, has large Chinese characters outside advertising slot machines. Inside, there are dozens of computerized terminals resembling the kind of slots you see in Atlantic City or at Yonkers Raceway. “But these are not slot machines — they’re games of skill — so they’re legal in New York State,” said Joy Shyu, 35, who with her companion opened what they call the first casino in New York City. It is a sleek lounge with throbbing music and is open until 3 a.m. Snacks and a juice bar are available, since such places cannot serve alcohol, Ms. Shyu said. She said they hoped to open more outlets with these slot machines — er, games of skill — in the city. “People come in and they say, ‘Wow, we can’t believe there’s a real casino right here,’ ” she said.

headline: Cheese and Yogurt, Fresh From the Sheep
text: Sheep’s milk cheese is less well known in the United States than cheeses made with cow’s or goat’s milk, but a handful of farms are working to change that with some wonderful products. One of the best is in Columbia County: Old Chatham Sheepherding Company.

headline: A New Theater Out of an Old One
text: For most of Bay Street Theater’s 19 years, its directors have dreamed of having a second stage, a smaller theater where they could present edgier fare from fall through spring, said Murphy Davis, co-artistic director of the nonprofit theater, in Sag Harbor. But where to locate the new house presented a problem.

headline: Where Musicians Are Seen and Heard
text: In its 21 years, the Raritan River Music Festival, which will present four intimate concerts at four different spots in western New Jersey next month, has earned its reputation as a destination series: Ticket holders have come from as far away as Chicago to places like the historic Prallsville Mills in Stockton, where the first show will take place May 1.

headline: The OTB Parlors, Limping Along
text: The Off-Track Betting Corporation has just survived the latest of its many brushes with death, but on Monday at the Yankee Clipper, its South Street Seaport outpost, rumors of the institution’s demise seemed, well, just about accurate.

headline: Contemporary Twists on Indian Food
text: JUST inside the doorway at Orissa, a Dobbs Ferry newcomer, you’ll see a small stack of books prominently displayed. “Modern Indian Cooking,” by Hari Nayak and Vikas Khanna, with a foreword by the chef Daniel Boulud, is for sale, but it’s also a notice: This isn’t your typical Indian restaurant.

headline: Holding the Strings to the Heart and Soul
text: KATONAH

headline: Getting the Royal Treatment
text: One of Prince Dimitri’s favorite family stories involves King Louis XIV of France. Louis, Dimitri’s great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-grandfather, was undergoing surgery so painful that he fell unconscious. When the Sun King finally awoke, his subjects gathered around his bed in the palace at Versailles and asked how he felt. Even as he lay in agony, by Prince Dimitri’s recounting, Louis XIV stammered: “The man is suffering. But the king is all right.”

headline: A Concert With Students and Their Virtuoso Mentors
text: Bay Shore

headline: Mysteries and Conspiracies, Over a Couple of Beers
text: The jukebox in the bar in Steven Dietz’s “Yankee Tavern” doesn’t work. It suddenly went dead on Sept. 11, 2001, at 8:46 a.m., just as the first hijacked plane rammed into the north tower of the World Trade Center. Right in the middle of the lyric “Bye, bye, Miss American Pie.”

headline: A Real Housewife of the Upper East Side Takes a Break
text: Ramona Singer is among the five original “housewives” from the 2008 debut season of the Bravo reality series “The Real Housewives of New York City.” She’s still at it; she also sells her Art Deco-inspired jewelry on HSN and a skin care line called Tru Renewal. Ms. Singer, 53, lives on the Upper East Side and spends summers in Southampton with her husband, Mario, 56, a jeweler; their teenage daughter, Avery; and a Shih Tzu named Coco.

headline: Merrily They Roll Along, Performing
text: WHEN the Arts Council of Greater New Haven began searching for a vehicle to transport arts programs around the city, it ran into a problem. “We didn’t have any money for the vehicle,” said David Brensilver, a council spokesman.

text: BY 11 a.m. most weekdays, lunchtime aromas are already wafting up Cedar Street opposite Yale New Haven Hospital.

headline: Spreading His Gospel of Warm and Fuzzy
text: It was early in the class, in a nondescript room on Union Square, where more than a dozen business managers had gathered to learn the hospitality secrets that have made Danny Meyer one of the nation’s most successful restaurateurs. The moment to share had arrived.

headline: Awash in $100 Bills That Add Up to Zero
text: For eight nights in March, the Allman Brothers played at the United Palace Theater in Washington Heights, and after the shows, their fans would come steaming along Broadway. One celebratory stop was at Coogan’son 169th Street.

headline: Learning How to Fight the Collector
text: Among debt collectors, Steven Katz is known as a “credit terrorist.” For years, he has run what he calls the Steven Katz School of Bill Collector Education, otherwise known as the “credit terrorist training camp.”

headline: Health Care Cost Increase Is Projected for New Law
text: WASHINGTON — A government analysis of the new health care law says it will not slow the overall growth of health spending because the expansion of insurance and services to 34 million people will offset cost reductions in Medicare and other programs.

headline: Lehman Asks for Dismissal of Japanese Firm’s Claims
text: Lehman Brothers Holdings, the bankruptcy estate of the collapsed investment bank, asked a judge on Friday to dismiss more than $1 billion of creditor claims by Nomura of Japan, arguing that they were vastly overstated and that the firm instead owed millions of dollars.

headline: A Tax Inquiry Jolts the World of Indian Cricket
Gorilla Coffee to Reopen Monday
text: Gorilla Coffee, the juggernaut Park Slope java-and-lifestyle dispensary that has been closed since April 9 after the entire staff quit  to protest a “perpetually malicious, hostile and demeaning work environment,” will reopen Monday. So said the smiling woman inside the half-rolled-up gate of the shop at Fifth Avenue and Park Place at 7 Friday evening.

headline: Panthers End Clausen’s Wait at No. 48
text: One by one, the picks came and went. And Jimmy Clausen went nowhere.

headline: Death by Firing Squad in Utah
text: Utah is the last state that still allows some condemned prisoners to choose to die by the bullet, as two did in 1977 and 1996, and a third chose in April.

headline: On Night of Moves, Mets Find Stability
text: By juggling his batting order Friday night, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel added energy that helped forge a 5-2 victory over the Atlanta Braves and boost his team’s momentum.

headline: Strategizing Legalization’s Pros and Cons
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As a longtime Democratic consultant, Chris Lehane has worked for presidents and managed scandals. But his current gig — as a strategist for the campaign to legalize, tax and regulate marijuana in California — is the one that has really caught the attention of his colleagues.

headline: Bay Has Overcome Worse Slumps
text: The first time Jason Bay was mired in a serious slump, it almost changed the direction of his life. But instead of switching to a career in finance, as he nearly did, he stuck with baseball and became an All-Star.

headline: Amid Cheers, Green Makes an Inspired Comeback
text: SAVANNAH, Ga. — No one would have blamed Ken Green if the thought of quitting crossed his mind Friday. Partnering with his friend Mike Reid in the Liberty Mutual Legends of Golf, he was operating on one hour’s sleep and he looked it, playing in his first official round of a Champions Tour event since the motor home accident last June that turned his world upside down.

headline: Purvis Young, Folk Artist Who Peppered Miami With Images, Dies at 67
text: Purvis Young, a self-taught painter who emerged from prison as a young man and by dint of his striking, expressionist vision of urban life and mammoth output over more than three decades transformed a forgotten Miami neighborhood into a destination for contemporary art aficionados, died on Tuesday in Miami. He was 67.

headline: Sabres Lead Early and Don’t Look Back
text: BUFFALO — For the fifth straight game, the Buffalo Sabres scored first in their opening-round series against the Boston Bruins. Only this time, on Friday night at HSBC Arena, Buffalo held on to win, 4-1.

headline: Protests Erupt Over Immigration in Arizona
text: Hundreds of demonstrators descended on the Arizona Capitol after Gov. Jan Brewer signed a bill aimed at identifying, prosecuting and deporting illegal immigrants.

headline: Nighttime Draft Is Attracting More Viewers
text: The N.F.L.’s decision to move the draft from Saturday afternoon to Thursday evening paid off with an average of 7.3 million viewers, making it the sixth-most-watched program of the night.

headline: Court Filing Sheds Light on Bin Laden Bodyguard
text: He was told that the question, posed through an intermediary, had come from Osama bin Laden: Will you be my bodyguard?

headline: Morales’s 2-Run Shot Off Chamberlain in the 8th Sinks Yankees
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Red is the dominant color at Angel Stadium. It is on the tops of the dugouts, the Angels’ uniforms, the Big A looming outside and the Not-As-Big A atop the left-field scoreboard. It is a cheery shade, but in their visits here the Yankees find little charm. Their memories, despite their success here last autumn, are overwhelmingly negative.

headline: Tensions Rise Between the Koreas as Ship Is Raised
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea on Saturday salvaged the remaining half of a warship that sank near a disputed sea border with North Korea, as suspicion of a North Korean torpedo attack deepened and two former South Korean presidents urged the country’s leaders to punish Pyongyang economically.

headline: Big Draft Day for Rutgers and Piscataway
text: Rutgers finished 3-4 in the Big East last season but sent two of its players to the first round of the draft: offensive tackle Anthony Davis to the Niners at No. 11 and cornerback Devin McCourty to the Patriots at No. 27. The only other Big East player selected in the first round was defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul of South Florida (to the Giants at No. 15).

headline: The Saturday Word: Autos and Finance
text: President Obama used his weekly national address to defend the government’s decision to bail out and restructure the American auto industry, highlighting the progress the car companies have made since the depths of the recession.

headline: Interview: Dana Adam Shapiro
text: Dana Adam Shapiro, the director and co-writer of "Monogamy," discusses the highs and lows of relationships.

headline: Soupy, Explained
text: City Room has always had a soft spot in its heart for Soupy Sales while growing up, even if we never quite got him the way we did, say, “Magic Garden.” The puppets, the pies, the Dean-Martin-esque faux(?)-drunk diction -– what was up with that? And what were we youngsters supposed to make of it? Even watching clips now, the main impression we get is that the 1960s were a very long time ago indeed. But Saturday at 6 p.m. on WLIW-TV (Channel 21 on all city cable providers), all will become clear, over the course of “Soupy Sales: The Gang’s All Here” a one-hour survey of the man’s oeuvre. It will be shown again Sunday at 4:30 p.m.

headline: Goldman Cited ‘Serious’ Profit on Mortgages
text: In late 2007, as the mortgage crisis gained momentum and many banks were suffering losses, Goldman Sachs executives traded e-mail messages saying that they would make “some serious money” betting against the housing markets.

headline: Howard Is Only Half a Force Inside
text: On Tuesday, Dwight Howard was named the defensive player of the year for the second consecutive year. Two days before, in the series opener between the Orlando Magic and the Charlotte Bobcats, he showed why with nine blocks in an Orlando victory.

headline: Republicans Look to 1994 Playbook
text: WASHINGTON — In the minds of many Republicans, Democrats never really won control of the House. Republicans gave it away.

headline: Are S.B.A. Loans in Trouble?
text: The Reuters headline on Thursday was alarming: “Weakness rife in US small business loans.” The article reported on testimony at a hearing held by the House Small Business Committee. “The U.S. Small Business Administration‘s inspector general found weakness in more than two-thirds of loans it examined in a program aimed at encouraging construction projects,” Reuters reported. “Some $255 million worth of these so-called 504 loans were made to borrowers who might not be eligible or might not be able to repay them.”

headline: Ferguson: ‘Well Known in Britain’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: That volcano in Iceland is still causing problems! Planes are flying again, but thousands of people are stranded. I didn’t think it would affect me, but now it has. Last night, I was supposed to go to a concert by my musical hero, Gary Numan, who couldn’t get a flight here because of that volcano. Numan is well known in Britain, but only has one hit here. It was “Cars.” It was a hit in America. “Here in my car, I feel safest of all.” This was before Toyotas.

headline: Letterman: ‘Don’t Worry About Him’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: John Paul Stevens, 90 years old, Supreme Court justice, is retiring. But don’t worry about him. He’s getting his own show on T.B.S. He’ll be fine.

headline: Leno: ‘Executives Were Shaking’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Well, one good thing has come out of this volcano in Iceland. Economists say consumers can now expect a huge drop in the price of lava lamps.

headline: From Twain, Turn-of-the-Century Twitter Posts
text: As they came and went — major dignitaries and minor deities, old friends and pint-size new ones, people who left too soon and people who showed up unannounced — Mark Twain recorded it all in a handsome brown guest book.

headline: Former British Home Secretary Tries to Rebound
text: REDDITCH, England — When Jacqui Smith set out to knock on doors in this recession-hit English town on a chilly, gusting evening last week, the venture had the air of an itinerant penance, among a population reluctant to forgive.

headline: From Jets Who Know, Life Lessons for Rookies
text: A year ago, Mark Sanchez was a rookie in waiting and the talk of the N.F.L. draft. Selected by the Jets fifth over all, he had an up-and-down season. There was the fast 3-0 start, then a steep descent. By the end of the season, Sanchez was a spark that carried the Jets to the A.F.C. championship game.

headline: Greek Hero Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s quote is both very funny and seemingly true. I’ve spent many a day here in the suburbs of New York discovering the very thing it mentions.

headline: Vatican Seeks ‘Transparency’ in Abuse Cases
text: ROME — As the Roman Catholic Church grapples with a widening sexual abuse scandal involving its clergy, it must show that it has “nothing to hide,” the Vatican spokesman said Saturday.

headline: Football, Not Basketball, Could Determine the Future of the Big East
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — The commissioners and athletic directors from the 11 Football Bowl Subdivision conferences departed Friday, leaving more questions than answers

headline: S. African Jews Relent on Bar Mitzvah
text: JOHANNESBURG — Richard Goldstone, the South African judge who had said threatened protests at his grandson’s bar mitzvah would keep him from attending, has reached an agreement with Jewish groups here that will allow him to go to the ceremony after all.

headline: A Graying Population, a Graying Work Force
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — One recent morning Antonia Antonaccio, a home care aide, got a call to help an elderly couple whose regular aide could not make it. The regular aide, who is 68 years old, had thrown out her back.

headline: Last Teacher In, First Out? City Has Another Idea

headline: Vegas Mob Museums, Set to Go to the Mattresses
text: LAS VEGAS — The people of Chicago debate the Cubs versus the White Sox. In Philadelphia, the cheese steak purveyors Pat’s and Geno’s have long divided the citizenry. Soon, the residents of Las Vegas — and the millions of people who visit — will be able to argue over which museum best depicts the moral turpitude of organized crime.

headline: Spitzer on Cuomo: He’s Driven, Often by Politics
text: He questions whether the candidate has the will to stand up to powerful interests. He faults him for failing to aggressively take on Wall Street. And he is not sure that he will vote for him for governor this fall, saying he wants to see “who else will be in the race.”

headline: G-20 Split on Need for Global Tax on Banks
text: Proposals to establish a global tax on banks and charge them for the cost of government bailouts divided representatives of the Group of 20 countries during a summit meeting in Washington on Friday, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan reports.

headline: Feeling Warehoused in Army Trauma Care Units
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — A year ago, Specialist Michael Crawford wanted nothing more than to get into Fort Carson’s Warrior Transition Battalion, a special unit created to provide closely managed care for soldiers with physical wounds and severe psychological trauma.

headline: At the White House, It Is Often Good Politics to Play Ball
text: When the World Series champion Yankees visit the White House on Monday to meet President Obama, they will continue a tradition, stretching back a century and a half, of baseball players mixing with commanders in chief.

headline: The Great One: ‘I’m Just Hanging Out’
text: Wayne Gretzky, the N.H.L.’s career leader in goals (894) and points (2,857), met his match in Viktor Ghamari of Sweden in a shootout on April 14. They were playing N.H.L. 10, part of the EA Sports Champions of Gaming Finals, staged by Gillette in Manhattan. (Ghamari was chosen from more than 350,000 online entrants to compete against a celebrity.)

headline: Ochoa Says Goodbye to Golf and Hello to the Rest of Her Life
text: Lorena Ochoa walked away from competitive golf with grace and humility, the same way she walked in. For sure, as she might say, there were few regrets. None were important enough to mention to reporters on Friday, when she preferred to accentuate the positive, again, one of her endearing traits.

headline: Rating Agency Data Aided Wall Street in Deals
text: One of the mysteries of the financial crisis is how mortgage investments that turned out to be so bad earned credit ratings that made them look so good, The New York Times’s Gretchen Morgenson and Louise Story report. One answer is that Wall Street was given access to the formulas behind those magic ratings — and hired away some of the very people who had devised them.

headline: Giants Focus on Defense but Grab a Spare Punter
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Compared with the team with which they will share a new stadium — that would be Rex Ryan’s noisy Jets — the Giants were downright dull during the three-day N.F.L. draft. Seven picks up, seven picks down, no trades of picks or players, not a whiff of controversy.

text: If there is one thing you can say for sure about Kendrick Perkins, the Boston Celtics’ center, it is that he knows how to do his job and then stay out of the way.

headline: Lust and Marriage
text: To cheat or not to cheat? That is one of many questions proposed in Dana Adam Shapiro‘s relationship drama/thriller “Monogamy.” The film stars Chris Messina as Theo, a photographer who shoots surveillance-style photos for his clients. One series of racy pictures sets off events that put a strain on Theo’s relationship with his fiancée (Rashida Jones).

headline: Maine Says He’s O.K., but Mets Will Wait and See
text: John Maine said his sore left (nonthrowing) elbow, which forced him from his start Friday, was feeling better Saturday morning and he was hopeful he would make his next scheduled start Wednesday against the Dodgers at Citi Field.

headline: Perils Remain Despite Recovery’s Pace, I.M.F. Head Says
text: WASHINGTON — The head of the International Monetary Fund said Saturday that the global economic recovery, while moving along faster than expected, was vulnerable to threats posed by long-term unemployment and unsustainable public debts.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Alex Rodriguez may have breached an unwritten rule of baseball etiquette last week when, after making it to third base on a foul ball hit by a teammate, he wandered across the pitcher’s mound on his way back to first. Dallas Braden, the pitcher for the Oakland Athletics, was not happy.

headline: Criminal Charges Possible in the Case of the Lost iPhone
text: 10:23 a.m. | Updated  Correcting name of the law enforcement agency involved, the Rapid Enforcement Allied Computer Team.

headline: A Dream, Just Not That Dream
text: For as long as he could remember, Sergio Santos would dream about what his first day in the big leagues would be like.

headline: Two-Wheeled Tribes
text: On New York’s hurried streets, one passing cyclist can appear no different from another. But cyclists are hardly a monolithic subculture — more like a collection of finely divided sub-subcultures, each with its own uniform, lingo and attitude toward the bicycle’s place in the urban landscape.

headline: In the Draft, Winners, Losers and the Patriots
text: If there is one thing that will resonate about the 2010 N.F.L. draft, it will not be the slides of quarterbacks Jimmy Clausen and Colt McCoy, who were this year’s reminders that serendipity plays nearly as big a role in where some players are drafted as evaluation does. It also won’t be the fact that Day 3 turned into a fire sale of unwanted veterans like Leon Washington, LenDale White and Jason Campbell.

headline: Stealth Salt in the Pantry
text: There are some foods that you expect to be generously salted.

text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets finished their latest roster remodeling with a striking flourish as the N.F.L. draft ended Saturday.

headline: Troop Therapy
text: Haleiwa, Hawaii

headline: C.D.O. Days, S&M Nights at Derivatives Conference
text: By day, they dealt with risk. At night, it got risqué. Financiers, lawyers, traders and accountants gathered this week at the annual International Swaps and Derivatives Association conference in San Francisco to discuss “Collateralization and Netting — the Impact” and “Systemic Risk: Advances and Challenges in the Wake of the Crisis.”

headline: Prime Number
text: 3.3: The average grade point average at private colleges and universities, according to a study by Stuart Rojstaczer and Christopher Healy in the journal Teachers College Record, based on data collected from more than 160 schools. At public schools, the average G.P.A. is 3.0. The authors said that private schools are “apparently conferring small but measurable advantages to their students by more generous grading.” But whether public or private, “colleges and universities are on average grading easier than ever before.”

headline: National Security and the Waistline
text: Terrorists. Nuclear weapons. Cyberattacks. Now a group of retired military leaders is warning of another risk to the nation’s security: overweight 17- to 24-year-olds. The Army estimates that 27 percent of those Americans, more than nine million in all, are too fat to enlist. The retired leaders — members of the group Mission: Readiness — urged Congress last week to remove junk food and high-calorie beverages from schools, increase financing for healthy school lunch programs and support efforts to encourage healthier life styles. “When over a quarter of young adults are too fat to fight, we need to take notice,” said James Barnett Jr., a retired Navy rear admiral.

headline: Obama Marks Genocide Without Saying the Word
text: ASHEVILLE, N.C. — President Obama, who as a candidate vowed to use the term genocide to describe the Ottoman mass slaughter of Armenians nearly a century ago, once again declined to do so on Saturday as he marked the anniversary of the start of the killings.

headline: Promises the Pill Could Never Keep
text: Minneapolis

headline: A New Book Echoes Bouton’s ‘Ball Four’
text: The best way to describe Dirk Hayhurst is that he is in baseball, but not of it. Or maybe that is not quite right; technically, Hayhurst is out of baseball for now, recovering from shoulder surgery in Hudson, Ohio. He pitched 15 games for Toronto last season and 10 for San Diego in 2008.

headline: Anatomy of a Benjamin
text: Last week, the Treasury Department introduced its new $100 bill, a redesign intended to frustrate high-tech counterfeiters when it goes into circulation Feb. 10.

headline: Faking West, Going East
text: COMING in at No. 3 is MARGARET MITCHELL. Her “Gone With the Wind” captivated a huge international audience and brought her virtually unanimous literary acclaim, topped off by the Pulitzer Prize for 1937 and the ultimate accolade: a furious argument within the serious-lit hive over whether this was or wasn’t that long-awaited elixir, the Great American Novel.

headline: Dnt Txt N Drv
text: Chicago

headline: New Orleans Tournament Has a Friend in Switzerland
text: Martin Senn, the new chief executive of the Zurich Financial Services Group, had his trip from Switzerland to New Orleans delayed a day because of ash in the atmosphere following the eruption of the volcano Eyjafjallajokull. But Senn, who took charge of the Zurich group in January, quickly made the earth move for tournament and PGA Tour officials in his first public on-site remarks as C.E.O.

headline: At Each Stop, the Thunder’s Diligent Presti Learned Well
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — As a do-everything player at Emerson College in Boston, Sam Presti once took six charges in a game against Daniel Webster College. In the moments before body met body, Presti anticipated the bruises. He also understood that collecting them would help his team.

headline: At 85, an Accomplished Marathoner Still Sees the Road Ahead
text: BEND, Ore. (AP) — Unlike age, which is measured precisely by years, vitality is not so easy to gauge.

headline: Sabres-Bruins Is Battle of the Stingiest
text: BUFFALO — Consider two goalies. One was the most valuable player of the Olympic tournament in February and is a finalist for the Vezina Trophy, for the N.H.L.’s best goaltender. When it comes to hockey in the United States, his is the closest to a household name.

headline: They’ve Got It: Fixes for the Financial System
text: WASHINGTON — Congress is consumed by the proposed legislation to overhaul the financial system, with lawmakers clashing over the best ways to regulate derivatives, protect consumers and end taxpayer-supported bailouts.

headline: Cup-Winning Goalies Are Rested Goalies
text: Can an N.H.L. goalie be overworked? Teams used to think so, but over the last decade or so, more No. 1 goaltenders are playing about 70 regular-season games each year.

headline: Mallett Is Working to Lead Arkansas to New Heights
text: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP) — Ryan Mallett stood several yards behind the line of scrimmage, safely away from the action. He clapped his hands after a nice play and raised his arms after a touchdown. At one point, he took a quick break to throw short tosses of about 15 yards to a teammate.

headline: For Now, a Refuge for the Catholic Church in Poland
text: BERLIN — When I think back on Poland’s period of mourning after the plane crash that claimed the lives of the country’s president and 95 other people, what stands out are flickering votive candles by the thousands and murmured prayers in unison from as many mouths; the priests sprinkling holy water on the president’s coffin; and the high pointed hats of bishops that seemed to tower above the crowds at every event.

headline: Plunking Parallel: Steroid Use and Hit Batsmen
text: The so-called steroids era produced plenty of pumped-up statistics. Everyone talked about the home runs, but few noticed the soaring number of batters hit by pitches.

headline: Faltering Cancer Trials
text: The nation’s most important system for judging the clinical effectiveness of cancer treatments is approaching “a state of crisis.” That is the disturbing verdict of experts assembled by the National Academy of Sciences to review the performance of clinical trials sponsored by the National Cancer Institute.

headline: North Korea Appears to Tap Leader’s Son as Enigmatic Heir
text: SUNGNAM, South Korea — The black-and-white photographs that were published last month in a North Korean newspaper appear no different from other propaganda coming from North Korea: they show the supreme leader, Kim Jong-il, touring a steel plant in a fur cap and his trademark sunglasses.

headline: Why Should They Believe Us?
text: Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada, the host of this June’s Group of 8 summit meeting, said last week that “if the G-8 is to remain credible, accountability is absolutely necessary.” He is right. Leaders of the world’s wealthiest nations can start bolstering their credibility by explaining how they plan to fill the $20 billion gap between the foreign aid they promised to send to developing countries and what they are actually giving.

headline: Afraid of the Sunshine
text: One, and only one, Congressional Republican has decided that unregulated money should not be allowed to swamp this campaign year. Representative Michael Castle of Delaware is daring to co-sponsor a bill to repair some of the damage from the Supreme Court’s decision to give corporations and unions free rein to spend unlimited amounts on campaign ads and advocacy.

headline: The Family’s Ghosts
text: The playwright Horton Foote died last year, never to see theater lovers turned away nightly from his parting masterwork, “Orphans’ Home Cycle.” Rooted in his 1920s Texas boyhood, it is a canny celebration of life, its hopes and disappointments, in scenes that resonate with ordinary characters.

headline: The Church, Seen in Another Light
text: To the Editor:

headline: China Replaces Leader of the Restive Xinjiang Region
text: BEIJING — Chinese leaders announced Saturday that they had replaced Wang Lequan, the ruling official in the vast western region of Xinjiang, whose capital was engulfed last summer by the deadliest ethnic violence in China in decades.

headline: To Mets, Reaching .500 Does Not Feel Half Bad
text: Less than two weeks ago, the Mets were among the worst teams in baseball, staggering to a 2-6 record to open the season as speculation raged over how long it would be before they might take drastic action, like firing the manager. Since then, the Mets have fought their way back to respectability with excellent pitching and fundamental play, even as many of the hitters have slumped.

headline: Writing the Book on Unwritten Rules
text: When Dallas Braden, the Oakland Athletics starting pitcher, criticized the Yankees’ Alex Rodriguez for running over the pitcher’s mound during last Thursday’s game, it put the focus on baseball’s unwritten rules, with many people unaware that Rodriguez had broken one.

headline: On the Sceptred Isle, Immigration Is an Issue Fit for Whispers

headline: Tea Party With a Difference
text: I’ve been trying to understand the Tea Party Movement. Sounds like a lot of angry people who want to get the government out of their lives and cut both taxes and the deficit. Nothing wrong with that  although one does wonder where they were in the Bush years. Never mind. I’m sure like all such protest movements the Tea Partiers will get their 10 to 20 percent of the vote. But should the Tea Partiers actually aspire to break out of that range, attract lots of young people and become something more than just entertainment for Fox News, I have a suggestion:

text: MARIAL BAI, Sudan

headline: Graham Pulls Support for Major Senate Climate Bill
text: WASHINGTON — In a move that may derail a comprehensive climate change and energy bill in the Senate, one of the measure’s central architects, Senator Lindsey Graham, has issued an angry protest over what he says are Democratic plans to give priority to a debate over immigration policy.

headline: Rebuilding a Town Hub From a Store’s Ashes
text: PUTNEY, Vt. — When residents saw flames shooting out of the Putney General Store in November, they were filled with an all-too familiar sense of dread.

headline: States Warn of ‘Obamacare’ Scams
text: In Illinois, a telemarketer recently sold an elderly woman a fraudulent health insurance plan that supposedly protected her against “death panels,” the state insurance director says.

headline: CKE Restaurants Chooses Apollo Bid Over THL’s
text: CKE Restaurants, the operator of the Hardee’s and Carl’s Jr. fast-food chains, said Saturday that it had accepted a $693.9 million takeover offer from Apollo Management, ending an earlier takeover agreement with THL Partners.

headline: F.D.I.C.’s Seizure of Senate Candidate’s Family Bank Further Complicates an Illinois Race
text: CHICAGO — Some Democrats had long worried that Alexi Giannoulias might not be their best hope of holding onto President Obama’s former seat in the United States Senate, and then came word that federal regulators on Friday night had seized Broadway Bank, an institution here owned by Mr. Giannoulias’s family.

headline: Monumental Achievement
text: Note: When this puzzle is done, the seven circled letters can be arranged to spell a common word, which is missing from seven of the clues, as indicated by [ ]. Connect the seven letters in order with a line and you will get an outline of the object that the word names.

headline: Where’d You Go With My DNA?
text: The cultural gap between the impoverished Havasupai Indians who view their blood as sacred and the Arizona State University researchers who helicoptered in to their Grand Canyon home to collect it was at the heart of a lawsuit over the scope of a genetic study that ended last week with a settlement for the tribe.

headline: Robert Hicks, Leader in Armed Rights Group, Dies at 81
text: Someone had called to say the Ku Klux Klan was coming to bomb Robert Hicks’s house. The police said there was nothing they could do. It was the night of Feb. 1, 1965, in Bogalusa, La.

headline: Europe Under the Ash
text: Eyjafjallajokull, that unpronounceable volcano, prompted inevitable chatter about nature’s awesome fury and the inadequacy of human invention to deal with it. Few Europeans had even heard of the volcano before, and they marveled at, but mostly grumbled about, how such widespread havoc could be caused by such teensy particles of ash, adrift from Iceland. On the whole, Europeans tend to forget about Iceland until some fresh calamity compels their attention. The last was the banking implosion, and a line making the rounds in Europe has it that Iceland’s final wish after its economy kicked the bucket was to spread its ashes across Europe.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 25
text: The debate over financial regulation heats up on Sunday’s talk shows as the hosts and guests discuss the merits of President Obama‘s overhaul and the federal government’s case against Goldman Sachs.

headline: Calling Almost Everyone’s Tune
text: “It’s tough to handle this fortune and fame.

headline: Dozens Ignored a Man Dying on a Sidewalk in Queens
text: Hugo Alfredo Tale-Yax’s last act may have been helping a woman who was having an argument with another man last Sunday morning in Queens. But his last hour or so was spent as a curiosity for people passing him on the street as he lay face down in blood after being stabbed several times.

headline: Democrats’ Long-Held Seats Face G.O.P. Threat
text: ASHLAND, Wis. — Representative David R. Obey has won 21 straight races, easily prevailing through wars and economic crises that have spanned presidencies from Nixon’s to Obama’s. Yet the discontent with Washington surging through politics is now threatening not only his seat but also Democratic control of Congress.

headline: Do You Have Any Reforms in Size XL?
text: EVERY once in a while, Congress awakens from its lobbyist-induced torpor, realizes that the masses are cranky and sets out to appease them. Such a moment occurred last week when lawmakers finally got the message that Main Street is disgusted with Wall Street and wants them to do something about it.

headline: Fierce Tornado Causes Deaths Across Mississippi
text: A tornado described by one Mississippi official as the worst in the area in decades swept through the state on Saturday, leaving at least 10 people dead in its path.

headline: Oil Leaking Underwater From Well in Rig Blast
text: NEW ORLEANS — Robotic devices monitoring the deepwater well where a giant oil rig exploded and sank last week have discovered oil leaking from the well, a development that a senior Coast Guard official on Saturday called a “game changer.”

headline: The Giants Critique the Giants’ Picks
text: Coach Tom Coughlin, General Manager Jerry Reese and other team officials discussed the Giants’ seven new draft picks on Saturday. (The day’s biggest news might have been the possible retirement of punter Jeff Feagles.) Here are some of their comments:

headline: Bolt Draws Crowd and Delivers a Record at Penn Relays
text: PHILADELPHIA — Green and yellow were the colors of the 116th Penn Relays at Franklin Field on Saturday.

headline: What’s Wrong With Saying ‘I Don’t Know’?
text: This interview with Rachel Ashwell, founder of the home furnishings retailer Shabby Chic, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Reviewing the Jets’ Draft Picks
text: We break down the Jets’ busy day of picking and trading in this article, but here’s a quick review of the team’s selections in the draft itself. We encourage you to add your own critiques in the comments.

headline: Yanks Provide Runs, but Pettitte Shows He Needs Little Help
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Already this month, Andy Pettitte has watched C. C. Sabathia and Phil Hughes take no-hit bids into the eighth inning. It is someone else’s turn in the Yankees’ rotation to outdo them, though Pettitte does not think it will be him. He has never thrown a no-hitter and at 37, he figures his time has passed.

headline: Last Days of the Dynamo
text: One of the greatest clubs in the history of hockey, Dynamo Moscow, announced last week that it was ceasing operations on April 30.

headline: The Tax Hiding in Your Paycheck
text: EVERY year at tax time, libertarians indignantly denounce government income transfers from rich to poor. Society’s income distribution, they argue, should reflect as closely as possible what people would earn in unregulated private markets.

headline: The Rise of the Fleet-Footed Start-Up
text: ERIC RIES and Steven Blank think they have a better way to build a start-up, one that takes less time and money to try new ideas and find paying customers. They are leading proponents of the “lean start-up” — a fresh approach to creating companies that has attracted much attention in the last year or so among Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, technologists and investors.

headline: Goldman E-Mail Cited ‘Serious’ Profit on Mortgages
text: In late 2007, as the mortgage crisis gained momentum and many banks were suffering losses, Goldman Sachs executives traded e-mail messages saying that they would make “some serious money” betting against the housing markets, The New York Times’s Louise Story and Sewell Chan report.

headline: Rachel Alexandra May Return This Week
text: The connections for the horse of the year Rachel Alexandra are eying the $400,000 La Troienne Stakes on the Kentucky Oaks undercard Friday at Churchill Downs for her next race.

headline: Correction
text: An entry on the paperback nonfiction best-seller list on Feb. 28 for “A Patriot’s History of the United States,” by Larry Schweikart and Michael Allen, misstated the book’s price. It is $25, not $21.95. (The error was repeated in successive issues through April 11; it was recently brought to editors’ attention by the publisher.)

headline: Paul Schaefer, German Guilty of Chile Child Abuse, Dies at 89
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — A former Nazi-era German soldier who founded a secretive German cult in southern Chile, where he sexually abused about 25 children, died of heart failure at a prison hospital early Saturday, Chilean officials said. He was 89.

headline: In Luxury Watches, Beauty Is More Than Skin Deep
text: ADDING a diamond-studded dial isn’t the only way to turn a wristwatch into a luxury item. Some buyers go for the clockwork inside the case — and the more intricate the mechanisms, the classier.

headline: Your Comments on Valentino’s School
text: My Sunday column is about the quite extraordinary school built by the equally extraordinary Valentino Deng. I highly recommend “What is the What,” the Dave Eggers best-selling book about Valentino — and buy it, since the royalties go to support the school!

text: In this Tea Party age, when thousands of people demonstrate nationwide against high taxes, the 15,000 people who rallied in Springfield last week tried a change-of-pace chant. “Raise My Taxes!” they shouted at the television cameras and any lawmakers who happened by.

headline: Educators and Parents Await News on Cuts
text: Principals, teachers and parents in Chicago will find out Monday what the $1.3 billion in proposed cuts to state education spending will mean to their schools.

text: In its push for more stores in Chicago, Wal-Mart recently enlisted help from the brother of Cook County Sheriff Thomas J. Dart, as well as from a former aide to Mayor Richard M. Daley.

headline: ‘Liberal’ Reputation Precedes Ninth Circuit Court
text: When President Obama earlier this year nominated Goodwin Liu, a liberal Berkeley law professor, to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, conservatives did not just criticize Mr. Liu — they also attacked the circuit court he hopes to join.

headline: A Writer With a View to Share
text: Several times a week, Daniel Handler and his 5-year-old son, Otto, walk from their home in Ashbury Heights to the Randall Museum, which sits on Corona Heights with spectacular views of San Francisco. Mr. Handler, the author of the best-selling series of children’s books, “A Series of Unfortunate Events” (under the pen name Lemony Snicket), has also written three novels. His current projects include a fourth novel, a children’s picture book titled “13 Words,” and the script for the second Lemony Snicket movie. His words have been edited and condensed. TRACEY TAYLOR

headline: Community College Tax on Ballot in San Mateo
text: San Mateo County voters could soon become the first in California to approve a special parcel tax on property to help pay for community college education in the county.

headline: Letter: Where Were the Jobs?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jocks vs. Swans, in a Win-Win for Dance
text: The worlds of contemporary dance and college athletics rarely intersect. But performers from ODC/Dance in San Francisco and student athletes from the University of California, Berkeley, have been coming together annually since 2007 to match physical wits in an attempt to settle a longstanding debate: Which group has greater physical prowess?

headline: Highlights From Sunday’s Bay Area Pages
text: Vistas: Corona Heights Park | Daniel Handler, the author of the best-selling series of children’s books, “A Series of Unfortunate Events” (under the pen name Lemony Snicket), enjoys the walk from his home in Ashbury Heights to the Randall Museum.

headline: Inside the Ninth Circuit
text: The lead article for Sunday’s Bay Area pages is about the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, an institution that knows its reputation for being out in left field. But it can laugh about it, and even about itself.

headline: Not the Retiring Type
text: I GREW up surrounded by mathematicians near the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Richland, Wash. At football games, cheerleaders carried a 4-foot-tall replica of a bomb with fins, painted in the school colors of green and gold. Our team name was the Bombers.

headline: Rays of Hope for Job Hunters
text: FOR the first time in two years, many job seekers may have reason to feel hopeful. Employers are beginning to hire again — or at least think about it.

headline: Tornado Sweeps Through Mississippi
text: A tornado described by one Mississippi official as the worst in the area in decades swept through the state, leaving at least 10 people dead in its path.

headline: Better Options in Practice Golf Balls
text: There are a lot of types of practice golf balls. They’ve been around for decades. Some are pretty useless, like the hard white plastic ones with no holes. They do not mimic a true ball’s flight in any way. Here are some better alternatives:

headline: Think Blankfein Will Resign? Want to Bet?
text: Goldman Sachs, if you listen to Congress, is little more than a casino where gamblers masquerade as traders and bet on the fortunes of the rest of us. Well, now the rest of us can bet on Goldman, Nelson D. Schwartz writes in The New York Times.

headline: Time and Alice Neel
text: A look at how the artist’s work has influenced other realist painters.

headline: Vows: Amelia & Kamil
text: Kamil Kaluza, an Australian, came to New York for graduate school, where he met and started dating Amelia Erwitt. As years went by, they became inseparable despite the greatest distance apart.

headline: Ask About New York School Data
text: The New York Times has assembled an extensive database of New York education statistics that will help readers put the vast sea of information about schools into better context. Test out the widget by entering a school’s name or your current ZIP code. The database includes all New York schools.

headline: Obama to Speak at Memorial for W.Va. Miners
text: ASHEVILLE, N.C. — President Obama plans to fly to West Virginia on Sunday to pay tribute to 29 coal miners who died in an underground explosion earlier this month and to vow to work to “save lives from being lost in another such tragedy.”

headline: Buika, Genre-Busting Artist, Plays Berlin
text: When Concha Buika’s plaintive hit “My Niña Lola” began flooding European airwaves in 2006, listeners had a difficult time categorizing her sound — but they couldn’t forget her distinctly husky voice and the tender tone of her songs. Like Billie Holiday and Nina Simone — both of whose names recur as influences — it’s not what she sings but how she sings. Audiences in Berlin will get a chance to hear those qualities for themselves on Thursday, April 29, when she performs at Passionskirche (Marheinekeplatz 1).

headline: Still Time to Vote for Collectible Car of the Year
text: Are you passionate about purple Pacers? Do vintage Checker taxis set your meter running? Would you write a check for a Czech-built Tatra?

headline: The Draft Match Game: The How and Why Behind the Picks
text: Matt Waldman is a staff writer at Footballguys.com, where he pens The Weekly Gut Check and authors The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a 740-page film evaluation of 170-plus rookie prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver, and tight end.

headline: Ship Attack Shows South Korean Quandary Over How to Respond to North
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea’s defense minister on Sunday said a torpedo attack was the most likely cause for the sinking of a South Korean warship that killed at least 40 sailors last month, a statement that inched the country closer to placing blame on North Korea and added urgency to the question of how the South might respond.

headline: A Letter to a Distant Daughter
text: Good-byes loom this time of year. High-school seniors choose where they will spend their next chapter, often far from home, and begin taking leave of family and friends. New jobs beckon new graduates (if they are lucky), often farther from home. It’s a favorite time for marriage, for moving, for change.

headline: The Sunday Word: Energy
text: Lawmakers decided to delay the unveiling of their bipartisan climate change and energy bill, while tens of thousands of environmental activists will descend upon Washington today to rally for swift action on the measure.

headline: Babson Competition Winners Sell Viral Videos, Healthful Foods
text: Babson College started the first ever business plan competition for undergraduates in 1984. That helped it achieve its status as a top United States college for aspiring entrepreneurs, especially at the undergraduate level.

headline: Thai Premier Rejects Protesters’ ‘Intimidation,’ but Seeks Peaceful End to Standoff
text: BANGKOK — Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva of Thailand said Sunday that he continued to seek a peaceful solution to the country’s tense political standoff, but that he would not give in to what he called intimidation by antigovernment demonstrators.

headline: Like Kicking Back in Istanbul
text: Before the owners of AKCafé in Clifton had a restaurant, they owned a grocery store across the street, AKMarket, stocked with Turkish staples like yogurt, spicy soujouk (dried sausage) and spices.

headline: Derby Favorite Scratched After Injury
text: Not that we needed it or wanted it, but thoroughbred enthusiasts received a heartbreaking reminder Sunday of how ephemeral Kentucky Derby dreams can be and how fragile an athlete they are built on. The 136th running of the Derby will be contested without Eskendereya, perhaps the best 3-year-old of his generation.

headline: Till Debt Do Us Part
text: Robin Wells and I review Reinhart-Rogoff and the IMF.

headline: What Start-Ups Can Teach Big Companies
text: My Sunday column, “The Rise of the Fleet-Footed Start-Up,” looks at a concept called the “lean start-up.”

headline: Allison Stacey Cowles, Educational Advocate, Dies at 75
text: Allison Stacey Cowles, a longtime trustee of Wellesley College who was the wife of a newspaper publisher in Spokane, Wash., and, after he died, of a former publisher of The New York Times, died Saturday night in Spokane. She was 75.

headline: Democrats, Pressuring G.O.P., Unite on Finance Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats said Sunday that they had bridged internal party differences and coalesced around a plan to tighten regulation of derivatives, the complex financial instruments that were a major factor in the 2008 economic crisis.

headline: Seeking Cultural Subtlety in 10 Questions
text: The Vietnamese version of the 2010 census questionnaire used the words “dieu tra” to describe the population tally — but what the words really conveyed was something like a communist government investigation. On Korean forms, “county” was translated into “nation.” And the Chinese hot line offered information only in Mandarin at first, although elderly Chinese immigrants, who are less likely to be proficient in English, speak Cantonese.

headline: Old Firm in the New World
text: The two most powerful teams (some would say the only two teams) in Scottish soccer — Glasgow Rangers and Celtic — are considering playing a preseason version of the Old Firm match at Boston’s Fenway Park on July 21.

headline: 90,000 Protest U.S. Base on Okinawa
text: TOKYO — More than 90,000 Okinawans rallied Sunday to oppose the relocation of an American air base on their island, adding to the pressure on Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama to resolve an issue that has divided Tokyo and Washington.

headline: Can’t Anybody Here Play This Game?
text: Bear with me while I vent for a moment. On financial reform, there are clear villains in the political process: Mitch McConnell, the US Chamber of Commerce, etc.. But at this point I’m accustomed to that sort of thing.

headline: Oil Leaks Could Take Months to Stop
text: NEW ORLEANS — Officials worked Sunday to try to stop oil leaks coming from the deepwater well drilled by a rig that sank last week near Louisiana, but they acknowledged that it could be months before they are able to stem the flow of what is now about 42,000 gallons of oil a day pouring into the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Obama Visits the Rev. Billy Graham
text: MONTREAT, N.C. – President Obama ventured to the mountaintop on Sunday to visit the Rev. Billy Graham, becoming the 12th commander in chief to meet the famed pastor to the presidents.

headline: Israeli Rightists Stir Tensions in East Jerusalem
text: JERUSALEM — A small group of ultra-right-wing Israelis marched through a volatile neighborhood of East Jerusalem on Sunday, arousing passions over the future of the contested city as an American envoy wrapped up an inconclusive three-day visit aimed at getting peace talks under way.

headline: Thousands Gather on the Mall for Earth Day
text: Tens of thousands of people gathered Sunday on the National Mall in Washington to observe the 40th anniversary of Earth Day and to urge Congress to pass climate and energy legislation.

headline: At the Biltmore, McKinley vs. Obama
text: ASHEVILLE, N.C. — President Obama likes to boast that he runs the most transparent White House in history. But William McKinley gives him a run for the money in at least one respect.

headline: Epistemic Closure In Macroeconomics
text: There’s been a huge outpouring of blogospheric discussion about “epistemic closure” on the right: a complete refusal to look at evidence or arguments that don’t come from the like-minded. I don’t have much to say about all that aside from the fact that it’s obvious, and has been going on for years.

headline: The New Left at Red Bull Arena
text: The final stat sheet from the Red Bulls match Saturday night against the visiting expansion Philadelphia Union showed that Brian Nielsen had played 67 minutes, had two shots and was offside once. That said, Nielsen made an instant impression in the match’s early minutes when he sped down the left flank, latched on to a lead pass and slipped a dangerous cross into the Philadelphia goal box.

headline: The Fresh Perspective of Dirk Hayhurst
text: When Dirk Hayhurst was growing up, he could never relate to friends who idolized major league baseball players.

headline: Austrian President on Way to Landslide Victory
text: BERLIN — President Heinz Fischer of Austria appeared to be heading for a landslide victory in his bid for a second term on Sunday, winning nearly 80 percent of the vote, according to preliminary results that were not expected to change.

headline: Chances Are
text: Have you ever had that anxiety dream where you suddenly realize you have to take the final exam in some course you’ve never attended?  For professors, it works the other way around — you dream you’re giving a lecture for a class you know nothing about.

text: This article is by Thom Shanker, Helene Cooper and Richard A. Oppel Jr.
