text: Mike Tanier writes for Football Outsiders and is a contributor for the Fifth Down.

headline: Reducing Pay for Cultural Executives in New York
text: For years chief executives at many major cultural organizations in New York City enjoyed salary growth that was buoyed by a booming economy and rivaled that seen in corporate America. Compensation increases of 25 percent to 50 percent over five years were not unusual, and in some cases packages nearly doubled.

headline: United-Continental Talks Said to Snag Over Price
text: 6:17 p.m. | Updated Merger talks between United Airlines and Continental Airlines reached an impasse over the weekend over a disagreement about the price of a stock-for-stock deal, people involved in the negotiations told DealBook.

headline: Anand Wins Game 2 to Square Title Match
text: After a bad error in Game 1, the world champion grinds down his opponent in the second game to pull even.

headline: A Dark Day That Still Resonates
text: The slaughter of hundreds of unarmed villagers in Quang Ngai Province, Vietnam, in March 1968  an event that came to be known as the My Lai massacre  is both an open wound in the American psyche and a cautionary tale at a time when we are once again fighting wars, and killing civilians, on foreign soil.

headline: Assessing Jewish Identity of Author Killed by Nazis
text: The first novel of Irène Némirovsky’s that most people read was the last one she wrote. Némirovsky, the Russian Jewish author, died at Auschwitz in 1942 at 39 after completing two parts of a five-part novel titled “Suite Française.” Secreted away in a trunk carried by Némirovsky’s daughters, Denise and Elizabeth, as they escaped from German-occupied France, the manuscript was not published for more than 60 years. It received stunning reviews that simultaneously announced the discovery and loss of an enormous talent.

headline: Doing Something Risky
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Are you a crossword fan or, more generally, a puzzle aficionado? The former probably knows or at least might be pleased to learn that the word “aficionado” implies not just a devotee, but an enthusiastic amateur. The latter might then view that as the start of a logic puzzle. Will Shortz can’t be an aficionado because he’s a professional, therefore the man in the blue house must smoke Lucky Strikes, or however that old syllogism goes. We’re going to do something a little risky, perhaps, by expanding the scope of Wordplay just a little. More on that further down.

headline: A Roundabout Route Ending at the Met
text: The English pianist Paul Lewis faced the same travel problems as other Europeans who were grounded because of ash from the volcano in Iceland, but he had a recital to play at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday evening, and he was determined to be here. When his flight from London to New York was canceled on Tuesday, he first considered going to Paris, but there was no guarantee that flights to New York would leave from there either. Then it turned out that he could get to New York with a connection in, of all places, Reykjavik, which was close enough to the action not to be affected.

headline: Behind Bryzgalov, Coyotes Force Game 7 Against Red Wings
text: DETROIT — The Phoenix Coyotes have already had a dream season, and they continued to follow that Cinderella script Sunday in Game 6 of their opening-round series against the Detroit Red Wings.

headline: He Just Did What Came Naturally
text: In the days before the Internet and other electronic distractions, many people of all ages played bridge. Some of the young experts went on to become well known in the bridge world, winning national and international championships. But others chose different careers.

headline: Let the Choir Sing (in Earthy, Idiomatic Voices)
text: After many flights to New York were delayed because of the volcanic ash clouds hovering over Europe, the Chorus of the Mariinsky Theater finally arrived at Avery Fisher Hall in time for the second concert of “The Russian Stravinsky: A Philharmonic Festival” on Thursday night. The chorus was missed in Wednesday’s opening-night program, conducted (as is the entire festival) by Valery Gergiev, which was to have included “Les Noces,” not heard at the Philharmonic since 1982.

headline: On the Good Ship Wagner, Some High Seas Looming
text: Wagner’s early milestone “Der Fliegende Holländer” (“The Flying Dutchman”) returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday night after a nearly 10-year absence, and the timing was right. There is a devoted audience for this opera, a mythical tale of a satanically accursed ship captain condemned to sail the seas forever, allowed one fleeting chance every seven years to dock his vessel and find redemption through the love of a woman. And August Everding’s engrossing 1989 production effectively combines realistic settings with starkly modern imagery.

headline: New CDs
text: MELISSA ETHERIDGE

headline: Obama Eulogizes Victims of Mine Accident
text: BECKLEY, W.Va. — Twenty days later and twenty miles away, they came to say farewell to the dead of Upper Big Branch on Sunday, the widows and orphans, the friends and neighbors, and a president of the United States.

headline: In One Sad Day, an Old World Artisan Confronts a New World
text: In “Market Day,” by the cartoonist James Sturm, Mendleman, a Jewish rug maker in Eastern Europe during the early 1900s, experiences a momentous 24 hours. Mendleman, who fashions his wares by hand, realizes change is in the air (cheaply made goods are beginning to rule the day), and one of the many strengths of this graphic novel is its ability to convey the rug maker’s highs and lows during this transition.

headline: New York City Subways: Mostly Fewer Riders
text: Job losses sent ridership down in 2009, especially in Manhattan, but some lines experienced growth.

headline: A Two-Fold History Lesson, Courtesy of Four Midcentury Masters
text: In reviving little-known little gems by four leading mid-20th-century choreographers, as it did in the “Signatures 10” program on Saturday at Gould Hall, New York Theater Ballet confirms its status as an invaluable company. Very few in the audience can have seen all these gems before; fewer can feel that they know even one well.

headline: Kudrow’s Web Series Going to Showtime
text: The actress Lisa Kudrow’s online series, “Web Therapy,” has found a second life on television. Showtime said it would telecast at least 10 half-hour episodes starting next year. In the largely ad-libbed Web episodes, Ms. Kudrow, right, plays Dr. Fiona Wallice, a therapist who shows more interest in herself than her patients. This well-regarded series just began its third season and can be seen at lstudio.com and elsewhere. “As the TV landscape continues to change, we really fell in love with the idea of taking something that has made so much noise on the Web and re-conceiving it with the original creators as a completely satisfying yet different experience for a half-hour audience on a television network,” Robert Greenblatt, the president for entertainment for Showtime, said in a statement Friday. The channel said the TV version of “Web Therapy” would include new scenes yet to be shot.

headline: ‘Dragon’ Back in First Place
text: It was a slow weekend at the movies as two new wide releases, “The Back-Up Plan” and “The Losers,” aptly titled, stumbled at the North American box office. “The Back-Up Plan,” a $30 million romantic comedy starring Jennifer Lopez and released by CBS Films, came in second place with an estimated $12.3 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. (CBS Films, which aggressively interpreted its film’s opening as “very solid,” hopes a shortage of female-oriented pictures will eventually turn the heavily marketed “Back-Up Plan” into a winner.) The $25 million thriller “The Losers” became the latest in a string of flops from Joel Silver’s Dark Castle Entertainment with about $9.6 million, putting it in fourth place. The No. 1 film was a holdover: DreamWorks Animation’s “How to Train Your Dragon,” with positive word of mouth and premium-priced 3-D tickets, brought in about $15 million and a new total of $178 million. The comedy “Date Night” from 20th Century Fox chugged away in third place with about $10.6 million ($63.5 million total). The violent superhero comedy “Kick-Ass,” No. 1 last weekend, sunk to fifth place with $9.5 million ($34.9 million total).

headline: Departures at ‘Carmen’
text: The production of Georges Bizet’s “Carmen” at the Vienna State Opera that Ioan Holender planned as his farewell as the company’s general manager seems to be turning into more of a farewell to the production’s stars. Representatives of the opera house announced on Friday that the mezzo soprano Elina Garanca, who was to sing the title role, has withdrawn from next month’s five-show engagement for health reasons, Agence France-Presse reported. In a letter to the opera house Ms. Garanca’s management wrote that she was feeling “exhausted and off-color” after undergoing minor surgery this month. She is the third artist to withdraw from this production for health reasons. The tenor Rolando Villazón canceled his involvement last year after undergoing surgery to remove a cyst on his vocal cords. Then, a few days ago the conductor Mariss Jansons also withdrew because of ill health. Mr. Holender, who is stepping down as general manager at the end of this season and had scheduled “Carmen” as a parting gift, has not given up. He has replaced Ms. Garanca with Nadia Krasteva, Mr. Villazón with Massimo Giordano, and Mr. Jansons with Andris Nelsons.

headline: ‘Scottsboro Boys’ Finds a New Home
text: The Vineyard Theater’s recent production of “The Scottsboro Boys,” above, the musical by John Kander and Fred Ebb, is not disappearing just yet. Producers for the show, which ended its Off Broadway run this month, announced Thursday that it would play for eight weeks at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, with previews beginning on July 31. This month producers canceled plans for a Broadway transfer, saying no available theaters were appropriate for the show. The run at the Guthrie may buy producers more time to find the right home in New York. The show, with direction and choreography by Susan Stroman and a book by David Thompson,  about a group of young black men who were falsely accused of raping two white women in the 1930s, opens on Aug. 6 and runs through Sept. 25. .... The Vineyard’s new season is beginning to take shape, opening with the world premiere of Will Eno’s “Middletown” on Oct. 6, the theater’s directors announced. Ken Rus Schmoll (“What Once We Felt”) is to direct the play, which explores the universe of a small American town through the forging of a friendship between a longtime resident and a new arrival. Casting and an official opening date have not been determined.

headline: Gervais and Merchant Plan a New Series
text: Ricky Gervais and Stephen Merchant, creators of “The Office” and “Extras,” have been commissioned to write a new series for BBC2, BBC News reported. The 30-minute comedy, called “Life’s Too Short,” will revolve around Warwick Davis, right, an actor who has dwarfism. The show will follow Mr. Davis, best known for his performances in the “Harry Potter” and “Star Wars” films, in his daily life, with occasional appearances from Mr. Gervais and Mr. Merchant. “We’re having so much fun working with Warwick,” Mr. Gervais said. “Pound for pound he is one of the funniest men I know.” The show is also being developed for HBO in the United States; broadcast dates for both networks have not been announced.

headline: The Joyce’s New Season
text: Acclaimed local troupes and international companies are expected at the Joyce Theater for the coming season, running Sept. 18 through Feb. 6. Among the headliners are the dancer Cédric Andrieux, in a “visual autobiography” conceived and directed by Jérôme Bel; the Israeli dance company Batsheva Dance, returning after a 27-year absence from the Joyce; Ballet Hispanico; and Garth Fagan Dance. The full schedule is at joyce.org.

headline: Random House Cedes Some Digital Rights to Styron Heirs
text: After publicly staking a claim to the right to publish electronic versions of books that already have a long history in print, Random House appears to be letting go of digital rights to several works by one prominent author without a fight, potentially opening the way for other authors to take their e-books away from traditional publishers.

headline: Iraqi Insurgent Group Acknowledges Killing of Two Leaders
text: BAGHDAD — The insurgent group that includes Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia acknowledged in a statement circulated Sunday that its two leaders were killed in a raid a week ago, but it vowed to continue to wage war against “the Green Zone government” of Iraq.

headline: Back in the ’60s: Let’s Tryst Again
text: For a bunch of desk jockeys, the boys from Consolidated Life are surprisingly athletic. In Rob Ashford’s revival of the 1968 musical “Promises, Promises,” which opened on Sunday night at the Broadway Theater, the male members of the chorus demonstrate that wearing skinny suits needn’t keep corporate executives from playing leap frog, turning cart wheels, bouncing off desks or frugging like, well, mad men.

headline: 'Promises, Promises'
text: Images from the new Broadway revival.

headline: Spammers Pay Others to Answer Security Tests
text: MUMBAI, India — Faced with stricter Internet security measures, some spammers have begun borrowing a page from corporate America’s playbook: they are outsourcing.

headline: To Preserve Whales
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Futile ‘War on Drugs’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hospital Visiting Rights for Same-Sex Partners
text: To the Editor:

headline: Coyote vs. Greyhound: The Battle Lines Are Drawn
text: ELGIN, Okla. — One morning in an otherwise quiet corner of the Great Plains, high-pitched yips and deep growls sprang from a cluster of trees. Two greyhounds were fighting a pack of coyotes.

headline: When Human Rights Becomes a Political Football
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Rebuilding Phase for Independent Film
text: Only five years ago, the center of the still thriving independent film universe lay behind the green doors of a converted TriBeCa warehouse from which the Weinstein brothers, Bob and Harvey, ran Miramax Films.

headline: After Girardi Is Not Decisive, Morales’s Homer Is
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — To Joe Girardi, one of the worst things anyone could say about him as a manager is that he was unprepared. He has a trusty binder that is loaded with trends, scouting reports, matchups, everything he could possibly want or need. When he makes decisions, he does so with conviction. He does not look back.

headline: Fuel Trucks Attacked in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Twelve trucks, most of them carrying fuel to a NATO base in eastern Afghanistan, were burned by an angry crowd early Sunday less than 30 miles from Kabul, according to local officials and NATO reports. The attack was thought to be in retribution for two raids by a joint Afghan-American force over the weekend, Afghan officials said.

headline: U.S. Extradition Effort Strains Relationship With Jamaica
text: MEXICO CITY — Christopher Coke’s nicknames are numerous: General, President, Shortman, Dudus. But the one that American law enforcement officials say sums up his illicit activities best of all is simply Mr. Coke.

headline: Monetizing an iPhone Spectacle
text: We all know that advertisers need to pay for clicks to keep the Web spinning. But what does it mean when publishers start paying for them as well?

headline: Pressure Is Building on Disputed Wind Farm
text: BOSTON — Political pressure continues to build on Interior Secretary Ken Salazar as he prepares to announce his decision this week on the fate of a proposed wind farm off the coast of Cape Cod, Mass., that has been stalled for nine years.

headline: Modernizing the ‘Kodak Moment’ as Social Sharing
text: DESPITE the predictions of naysayers, the concept of the “Kodak moment” has endured into the 21st century, even if Kodachrome film is going the way of the Brownie Starmite camera. Now, Eastman Kodak, eager to sustain some recent momentum, is seeking to redefine the phrase for a new generation of picture-takers.

headline: Ready for a Room Full of Fourth Graders?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Former Ball State Walk-On Gets Tryout With Giants
text: Brandon Crawford, the 33-year-old former Ball State defensive end who held on to his hopes of reaching the N.F.L. through a high school arrest and a stint in the Marines, will get a chance to prove he belongs after all. Crawford was invited to try out for the Giants at their rookie camp this weekend.

headline: Africa’s Role in the U.S. Slave Trade
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mississippi Assessing Damage by Tornado
text: YAZOO CITY, Miss. — Carolyn Veazey fought back tears on Sunday outside the remains of her home, hoping to find her missing cat and unsure of her next move, a day after a deadly tornado tore through town.

headline: South Africa Redoubles Efforts Against AIDS
text: SOVANE, South Africa — South Africa, trying to overcome years of denial and delay in confronting its monumental AIDS crisis, is now in the midst of a feverish buildup of testing, treatment and prevention that United Nations officials say is the largest and fastest expansion of AIDS services ever attempted by any nation.

headline: Socialists in Hungary Are Ousted in Elections
text: PRAGUE — Hungary’s center-right Fidesz party secured a two-thirds majority in second-round parliamentary elections on Sunday, ousting the governing Socialist Party and giving it the authority to pass legislation, including crucial economic changes, without having to form alliances with the opposition.

headline: Brooklyn School Scores High Despite Poverty
text: To ace the state standardized tests, which begin on Monday, Public School 172 in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, finds money for coaches in writing, reading and math. Teachers keep detailed notes on each child, writing down weaknesses and encouraging them to repeat tasks. There is after-school help and Saturday school.

headline: No Secrets in the Sky
text: Washington

headline: Apple Allows a Cartoon App, and a Glimpse of Free Speech
text: Mark Fiore’s cartoon application is now available through the Apple App Store. But a group that represents cartoonists like him is now lobbying for the company to change its rules for humorous, politically charged apps.

headline: Classical Music’s Comeback, on Public Radio
text: In the last decade, public radio stations could not get rid of classical music fast enough, as station after station abandoned the format for news and talk, alienating classical fans.

headline: Sex Scandal Is New Crisis for Troubled French Team
text: PARIS — Less than two months before the start of the World Cup in South Africa, the French national soccer team, its on-field reputation in decline, is dealing with a sex scandal involving several players and under-age prostitutes.

headline: A Strong Woman Behind the Men of DreamWorks
text: Hollywood’s index skimmers may want to jump past the big names — Steven Spielberg, Jeffrey Katzenberg, David Geffen — in Nicole LaPorte’s new book on DreamWorks, “The Men Who Would Be King,” in favor of Terry Press.

headline: Why Doormen?
text: JUST like everyone else, I was overjoyed that a doorman strike was averted last week in New York. But as I read the articles leading up to the resolution  an arc as dramatic as that of the Cuban missile crisis  I found myself asking a disturbing question: Are doormen necessary? Necessary? Why, the very thought could only be the product of a troubled mind. You might as well ask if the Holland Tunnel is necessary! You might as well ask if the Knicks are necessary! (Actually, never mind about that one.)

headline: ‘Foolish’ Memo on Pope’s Visit Spurs Apology by the British
text: LONDON — Britain’s Foreign Office has apologized publicly for a “foolish” internal memo circulated to government departments that suggested, with apparent sarcasm, that the “ideal” itinerary for Pope Benedict XVI’s visit to Britain in September might include the pope’s opening an abortion clinic, blessing a gay marriage and introducing a “Benedict” brand of condoms.

headline: Borrowing Our Way to Failure
text: Albany

headline: Indian Justice Inches Closer to Chapters of Violence
text: NEW DELHI — On Oct. 31, 1984, two Sikh bodyguards gunned down Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in her garden. In the three harrowing days that followed, more than 3,000 Sikhs were killed by enraged mobs seeking to avenge her death.

headline: Paying Tribute to Fallen Miners
text: Family members gathered at a memorial service for the victims of the Upper Big Branch mine disaster in West Virginia. President Obama and Gov. Joe Manchin III took part in the ceremony.

headline: Sex Ads Seen Adding Revenue to Craigslist
text: Craigslist, one of the most popular Web sites in the United States, is on track to increase its revenue 22 percent this year, largely from its controversial sex advertisements. That financial success is reviving scrutiny from law-enforcement officials who say the ads are still being used for illegal ends.

headline: W. Willard Wirtz, Labor Chief, Dies at 98
text: W. Willard Wirtz, an outspoken champion of the unemployed who was secretary of labor under Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson and was the last surviving member of the Kennedy cabinet, died on Saturday. He was 98.

headline: Not Even in South Park?
text: Two months before 9/11, Comedy Central aired an episode of “South Park” entitled “Super Best Friends,” in which the cartoon show’s foul-mouthed urchins sought assistance from an unusual team of superheroes. These particular superfriends were all religious figures: Jesus, Krishna, Buddha, Mormonism’s Joseph Smith, Taoism’s Lao-tse  and the Prophet Muhammad, depicted with a turban and a 5 o’clock shadow, and introduced as “the Muslim prophet with the powers of flame.”

headline: Investigation Links Critic’s Death to Top Chechens
text: VIENNA — Umar S. Israilov, a whistleblower living in hiding after accusing Chechnya’s president of personally participating in torture, kidnapping and murder, was gunned down here last year as he stepped from a grocery store with yogurt, eggs and bags of M&M’s and Gummi Bears for his three young children.

headline: From the Mall to the Docks, Signs of Rebound
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — The docks are humming again at this sprawling Pacific port, with clouds of golden dust billowing off the piles of grain spilling into the bellies of giant tankers.

headline: All Bets Are Off in British Campaign
text: LONDON — With 10 campaigning days left until a general election that has seen a strong and unexpected surge by the left-of-center Liberal Democrats, Britain has been thrust into a complex new political calculus about which party — or parties — will govern after May 6.

headline: United and Continental Merger Talks Said to Stall
text: Merger talks between United Airlines and Continental Airlines reached an impasse over the weekend over a disagreement about the price of a deal, people involved in the negotiations said on Sunday.

headline: Stop by Stop, Subway’s Decline and Growth in 2009
text: Every year, New York City Transit releases a station-by-station breakdown of ridership in the biggest subway system in the nation. Shake-ups are rare; the usual suspects — Times Square, Grand Central Station — routinely top the list, and last year was no exception.

headline: Corrections
text: A theater review on Friday about “Sondheim on Sondheim,” at Studio 54, referred incorrectly to a New York magazine article in 1994 that was the inspiration for “God,” a new Stephen Sondheim song that was performed. The article was featured inside the magazine; it was not the cover article.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: After the Storm
text: Hundreds of Mississippians were affected by violent weather that led to damaging winds and powerful tornadoes.

headline: The Understated Elegance of the Yankees’ Rivera
text: He entered the clubhouse with the same purposeful stride with which he exits the bullpen. Into the big room came Mariano Rivera as if protecting a one-run lead in the ninth inning, the middle of the order due up.

headline: An Uneasy Marriage of the Cultish and the Rumpled
text: When Bloomberg L.P. bought Businessweek in December, a group of the magazine’s writers, who were being transferred to the Bloomberg newswire, attended a two-week training session. They learned that the terminals, costing about $20,000 a year, drove Bloomberg’s business; they discovered that the main elevators stop only on the sixth and ninth floors, forcing a manic feeling in the building as employees dash up and down staircases.

headline: Berating the Raters
text: Let’s hear it for the Senate’s Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations. Its work on the financial crisis is increasingly looking like the 21st-century version of the Pecora hearings, which helped usher in New Deal-era financial regulation. In the past few days scandalous Wall Street e-mail messages released by the subcommittee have made headlines.

headline: Strides, Often Painful, but Always, Always Forward
text: Hicksville, N.Y.

headline: A Better Chance
text: Gov. David Paterson’s juvenile justice task force was on the mark when it advised him to stop sending low-risk young offenders to faraway lockups and place more of them in lower-cost community-based programs.

headline: Cape Wind and Mr. Salazar
text: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar is expected to announce this week whether a controversial wind farm off the coast of Massachusetts can proceed. Given the country’s need for alternative energy sources  and the administration’s commitment to promoting them  it would be dismaying if he did not give the go-ahead.

headline: Questions Surround a Delay in Help for a Dying Man
text: It will probably never be clear how many people realized that Hugo Alfredo Tale-Yax was dying.

headline: St. Vincent’s Is Putting Building on Market
text: Less than two weeks after St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan filed for bankruptcy, the hospital is officially putting on the market the first of many buildings in its valuable Greenwich Village real estate portfolio.

headline: Poorer Nations Get Larger Role in World Bank
text: WASHINGTON — Members of the World Bank agreed on Sunday to support a $5.1 billion increase in its operating capital, the largest increase in general financing since 1988, and to give developing economies a greater say in running the antipoverty institution.

headline: Growing Split in Arizona Over Immigration
text: MESA, Ariz. — They stood a few miles from each other, but as far apart as heat and cold.

headline: When the System Works
text: Education Secretary Arne Duncan has vowed to press states to remake the 5,000 or so chronically failing schools that account for about half of the nation’s dropouts and usually serve  or more to the point fail to serve  the poorest children. A $4 billion school improvement fund is intended to give states the help and the incentive to turn these schools around.

headline: Prosecutors Seek an 8-Year Term for Bruno
text: Federal prosecutors are seeking more than eight years of prison time for Joseph L. Bruno, the former Republican majority leader of the State Senate, as punishment for concealing hundreds of thousands of dollars in payments from a businessman who sought help from the Legislature.

headline: New Yorkers Earn More, Early On, a Study Shows
text: New York City may be one of the best places for men with college degrees to seek their fortunes — at least until they reach their late 30s. After that, they might be better off in Atlanta or Dallas.

headline: Praise for Reports on Hurricane Katrina
text: They are not winning trophies or plaques, but some journalists who write about New Orleans are unwittingly earning “Seals of Approval” from Levees.org, a group that educates people about why the city was so vulnerable.

headline: ‘God of Carnage’ to Close
text: After more than 400 performances and three different casts, Yasmina Reza’s “God of Carnage” will close on Broadway on June 27, the producers announced. In a statement they said they were “incredibly proud and thrilled with the success” of the show but had decided to end the run with the completion of the current cast’s contracts. “Carnage,” a comedy about two couples who fight over an altercation between their sons, opened in March 2009 at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater with Jeff Daniels, Hope Davis, James Gandolfini and Marcia Gay Harden. It went on to win the 2009 Tony award for best play, as well as a best actress award for Ms. Harden and best director for Matthew Warchus. At the time it was one of the highest-grossing plays on Broadway. In November a second cast  Christine Lahti, Annie Potts, Jimmy Smits and Ken Stott  took over; then a third cast, with Janet McTeer, Lucy Liu, Mr. Daniels in a different role, and Dylan Baker, opened in March. The show continued to gain critical acclaim with each new cast, but it failed to sustain its original commercial success. Also, recent talks of a national tour ended after producers found that not enough theaters in major cities would be available for booking.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Charles River Said Close to $1.6 Billion Deal
text: 11:44 p.m. | Updated Charles River Laboratories, a laboratory services provider, is close to acquiring WuXi AppTec, a Chinese pharmaceutical outsourcing services provider, for about $1.6 billion, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Sunday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 25, 2010

headline: New York’s Mayor, but Bermuda Shares Custody
text: HAMILTON, Bermuda — At Greg’s Steakhouse, the power lunch spot on this sun-soaked island, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is such a regular that he has his own booth, with a view of the Parliament building. The waiters have memorized his order: coffee-rubbed New York strip steak.

headline: What Are They Doing?
text: So tell us again why we are paying their salaries? New York’s Legislature was supposed to approve a state budget before April 1. Nearly a month later, the leaders still can’t come up with a plan to close a $9.2 billion deficit. Meanwhile, the other 210 senators and Assembly members are mostly sitting on their hands.

headline: Accounts, People and Miscellany
text: Accounts

headline: Governor Christie vs. the Teachers: Nastiness in New Jersey
text: Even given the current decibel level in politics, the nasty din surrounding the customarily snore-inducing rubber-stamping of local school board budgets in New Jersey last week was something to behold.

headline: In Court Nominees, Is Obama Looking for Empathy by Another Name?
text: WASHINGTON — Empathy is out. Understanding ordinary lives is in. Is there a difference? President Obama is about to find out.

headline: From New York Harbor’s Depths, Muck to Restore Islands in Jamaica Bay
text: For generations, the islands of Jamaica Bay, the 26-square-mile natural sanctuary off the Brooklyn and Queens shoreline that is home to hundreds of species of migratory birds and marine life, have been disappearing, victims of environmental neglect.

headline: For Gardener, Love of a Park Comes With the Job
text: First the man, with a ponytail and fraying green pants, started picking up the trash. Then he planted a purple plum tree and a garden with hydrangeas. By the time he put up a sign in Coffey Park requesting banana peels, the neighborhood was paying attention.

headline: Girardi Can’t Decide, but You Can
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. – Three weeks into my first season covering the Yankees, I don’t have a frame of reference to say just how indecisive Joe Girardi was during the seventh inning of Sunday’s 8-4 loss to the Angels. But I asked Tyler Kepner, who covered the Yankees for years, and he said nothing similar immediately came to mind.

headline: Urban Forager | Wilds of the Rooftop
text: “The weeds are welcome here,” said Anasa Scott as we walked across a gravel rooftop at the City College of New York on a sunny day in Harlem, making our way around a solar panel and a satellite receiver to check out a series of south-facing soil beds that comprised the green roof.

headline: Mets May Have Musical Edge on Yankees
text: Ruth Roberts and Lou Stallman own musical pieces of New York baseball history.

headline: Longtime Hollywood Hand Is Joining Boutique Bank
text: LOS ANGELES — Skip Paul, the video game pioneer, pal of Steven Spielberg and all-around Hollywood power broker, is headlining a push into the movie capital by one of New York’s fastest-rising investment banks.

headline: After 15 Months in Office, Policy vs. Politics for Obama
text: Inside Washington, President Obama is savoring a springtime resurgence: signs of economic recovery, victory on health care, the upper hand in the financial regulation debate.

headline: Best Hope for Greece: Minimize the Losses
text: Only a few weeks ago, the idea that Greece might restructure its debt seemed like the nuclear option. Now restructuring — a polite alternative to outright “default” — is not only thinkable, but even likely.

headline: Baseball Songs for New York: Write the Lyrics
text: New York’s two major league teams have their own signature songs. “Meet the Mets” was first played at the Polo Grounds in 1963 and continues to be played at Citi Field. A short, instrumental version of “Here Come the Yankees,” which was written in the late 1960s, is played before and after each game on WCBS Radio. But do either of the songs still reflect the image of the teams?

headline: Cavaliers Overwhelm the Bulls, With James Providing the Muscle
text: CHICAGO — These days, LeBron James speaks often of goals and destinations, dialing it in and turning it up, being mentally prepared and on the same page, remaining focused and taking care of business.

headline: Major Earners in the Cultural World
text: A list of the culture world's major earners.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the Standard & Poor’s Case-Shiller home price index for February and consumer confidence for April (Tuesday); and first-quarter gross domestic product and the Reuters/University of Michigan consumer confidence index for March (Friday).

headline: Charles River Said to Be Near a Deal for Drug Research Firm in China
text: Charles River Laboratories is close to acquiring WuXi AppTec, a Chinese pharmaceutical outsourcing services provider, for about $1.6 billion, people briefed on the matter said Sunday.

headline: A Milestone for Internet Ad Revenue
text: For the first time, marketers spent more in 2009 on Internet advertising than in magazines, according to a report from ZenithOptimedia, which said online ad spending would rapidly close ground on newspapers. Despite a record-setting $6.3 billion fourth quarter, online advertising revenue declined 3.4 percent for the year from 2008, the first year-over-year falloff since 2002. The loss in ad spending across all media was an even steeper 12.3 percent for the year and 2 percent for the fourth quarter.

headline: Quake Strikes Off Coast of Taiwan
text: A 6.9-magnitude earthquake struck off the southeast coast of Taiwan Monday morning, the United States Geological Survey said.

headline: Too Much Risk in Film Futures
text: Markets allowing bets on movie ticket sales have gotten a regulatory thumbs-up — most recently Cantor Fitzgerald’s proposal last week. Trading box-office futures could provide studios a new way to hedge and to raise money. But such speculation also risks encouraging all sorts of risky behavior. For Hollywood, Wall Street’s antics are better left on-screen.

headline: Alan Rich, Los Angeles Music Critic, Dies at 85
text: Alan Rich, a critic whose eloquent and passionate writing about classical music in both New York and Los Angeles made him an important voice in the American musical world over a long career, died on Friday at his home in West Los Angeles. He was 85.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: New York, New York, New York, New York
text: Hiroyuki Ito, a freelancer for The New York Times, was born in Tokyo in 1968. He moved to New York 18 years ago, studied at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University and began his freelancing career at The Village Voice. He now lives in Astoria, Queens. In “Camera Obscura,” Mr. Ito described his practice of storing exposed film rolls in the vegetable compartment of his refrigerator. “Every few months, I need to develop all these films so that the vegetables can reclaim their space.”

headline: Word of the Day | ignoble
text: ignoble •\ ig-ˈno-bəl \• adjective

headline: At the Range, Drive Less and Practice More
text: I have seen you at the driving range. Wherever you play, I have seen you.

headline: A Mets Mystery That Might Solve Itself
text: Through the first three weeks of the season, the Mets right-hander John Maine has been vexed, perplexed and maybe a little hexed. His latest problem — pain in his left elbow — caused him to leave Friday night’s game early, and left him muttering the word “frustrating” amid phrases like “it’s one thing after another.”

headline: Alan Sillitoe, ‘Angry’ British Novelist, Dies at 82
text: Alan Sillitoe, a British writer whose two early works  a novel, “Saturday Night and Sunday Morning,” and a short story, “The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner”  drew attention to the seething alienation of the postwar working class in England, died on Sunday in London. He was 82.

headline: Melvyn Zerman, Publisher of Performing Arts Books, Dies at 79
text: Melvyn Zerman, whose Limelight Editions gave a second life to neglected classics on the performing arts by bringing them back in paperback, and who published an eclectic list of hardcover titles as well, died on April 19 at his home in Manhattan. He was 79.

headline: Hertz to Buy Dollar Thrifty for $1.2 Billion
text: Hertz Global Holdings said late on Sunday that it has agreed to buy the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group for $1.2 billion in cash and stock, uniting two of the biggest names in the rental car business.

headline: Buyout Firms Said to Prepare a Nielsen I.P.O.
text: The private equity owners of Nielsen, best-known for its expansive television and Internet ratings research, are preparing to stage an initial public offering for the company, The Financial Times reported Monday, citing unnamed sources.

headline: Pelfrey, Then Cloudburst, Close Out the Braves
text: Mets starter Mike Pelfrey has four victories in four starts this season, but Sunday night’s quirky triumph — 1-0 over the Atlanta Braves — merits an asterisk for at least two reasons.

headline: Longtime Hollywood Hand Is Joining Centerview
text: Skip Paul, the video game pioneer, pal of Steven Spielberg and all-around Hollywood power broker, is headlining a push into the movie capital by one of New York’s fastest-rising investment banks, The New York Times’s Brooks Barnes reports.

headline: News Quiz | April 26, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Encountering Kyoto
text: WHERE on a world map is Kyoto?

headline: Democrats Unite on Finance Bill, Pressuring G.O.P.
text: Senate Democrats said Sunday that they had bridged internal party differences and coalesced around a plan to tighten regulation of derivatives, the complex financial instruments that were a major factor in the 2008 economic crisis.

headline: The Rise of the Fleet-Footed Start-Up
text: Eric Ries and Steven Blank think they have a better way to build a start-up, one that takes less time and money to try new ideas and find paying customers. They are leading proponents of the “lean start-up” — a fresh approach to creating companies that has attracted much attention in the last year or so among Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, technologists and investors.

headline: What Do You Think About the New Arizona Immigration Law?
text: Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona signed the nation’s toughest bill on illegal immigration into law on Friday. Aiming to identify, prosecute and deport illegal immigrants, it will make the failure to carry immigration documents a crime and give the police broad power to detain anyone suspected of being in the country illegally. What do you think of this law? Why?

headline: Pressure Is Building on Disputed Wind Farm
text: Political pressure continues to build on Interior Secretary Ken Salazar as he prepares to announce his decision this week on the fate of a proposed wind farm off the coast of Cape Cod, Mass., that has been stalled for nine years.

headline: Babson Winners Sell Viral Videos and Healthy Foods
text: From Lora Kolodny at You’re the Boss:

headline: Rich: Fight On, Goldman Sachs!
text: From Frank Rich on The New York Times’s Op-Ed Page:

text: From Paul Krugman on The New York Times’s Opinion page:

headline: Dow Ends Week Up, Extending Streak to 5 Days
text: Stocks pushed higher on Friday as the Dow Jones industrial average rose for a fifth consecutive day, and analysts saw little economic news on the horizon that would upset market sentiment next week.

headline: Twitter Snaps Up a Text-Messaging Company
text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: Suicide Attacker Misses British Ambassador’s Convoy Traveling in Yemeni Capital
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The British ambassador in Yemen survived an attack on Monday morning by a lone suicide bomber who detonated his explosive belt as the ambassador’s armored convoy was passing, witnesses said.

headline: A Marriage of the Cultish and the Rumpled
text: When Bloomberg L.P. bought BusinessWeek in December, a group of the magazine’s writers, who were being transferred to the Bloomberg newswire, attended a two-week training session. They learned that the terminals, costing about $20,000 a year, drove Bloomberg’s business; they discovered that the main elevators stop only on the sixth and ninth floors, forcing a manic feeling in the building as employees dash up and down staircases, The New York Times’s Stephanie Clifford writes.

headline: More Than 200,000 a Day Now Cycling, Data Suggests
text: Build it and they will ride. That’s the message conveyed in the latest annual estimate of the number of bicyclists in New York City by Transportation Alternatives, which found roughly 236,000 New Yorkers riding each day in 2009, up 28 percent from 185,000 daily riders the year before.

headline: Too Much Risk in Film Futures?
text: Markets allowing bets on movie ticket sales have gotten a regulatory thumbs-up — most recently, Cantor Fitzgerald’s proposal last week. Trading box-office futures could provide studios a new way to hedge and to raise money. But such speculation also risks encouraging all sorts of risky behavior. For Hollywood, Wall Street’s antics are better left on-screen, Reuters Breakingviews argues.

headline: Snipping Zithers With Scissors
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have tirelessly tied our tongues with a tonnage of tongue twisters.

headline: Review: Your Money, Their Pockets
text: Seldom in our 230-odd years as a country have Congress and the White House had the fortitude to impose on American bankers and financiers a set of regulations sufficiently stringent to prevent them from pushing us into destructive panics and recessions. And once again Washington may be demonstrating its lack of backbone, The New York Times’s Louis Uchitelle writes.

headline: Sears Buys Stake in Canadian Unit From Ackman
text: The Sears Holdings Corporation said on Friday that it was buying a stake in Sears Canada from the hedge fund manager Bill Ackman for $560 million, taking a step toward full ownership of its Canadian unit.

headline: Morgenson: Got Any Reforms in Size XL?
text: From Gretchen Morgenson’s latest Fair Game column:

headline: Bank of Ireland to Raise $4.5 Billion
text: Bank of Ireland, the country’s biggest bank by market value, plans to raise as much as 3.4 billion euros ($4.5 billion) to bolster capital as real-estate losses surge, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: With Impact Investing, Not Only Returns Matter
text: From Paul Sullivan’s latest Wealth Matters column:

headline: South Korea Mourns Victims of Warship Sinking
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Politicians, soldiers and citizens lined up in the rain on Monday to pay tribute to at least 40 sailors killed in the sinking of a warship, as the country inched closer to placing blame on North Korea and faced the urgent question of how it might respond.

headline: Former Official in Kyrgyzstan Is Extradited From Russia
text: MOSCOW — Kyrgyzstan’s provisional government said Monday that Russian special forces had seized and extradited Kyrgyzstan’s former interior minister, who had been convalescing in Moscow after being severely beaten during bloody antigovernment riots this month.

headline: In Hong Kong, One Chef’s Private Dinners
text: Many of the most interesting meals in Hong Kong are being served behind closed doors. “Private kitchens” are all the rage – and help chefs skirt the city’s strict licensing on restaurants.

headline: New Tourre E-mails Show Trader Under Duress
text: The Senate’s Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations released a number of Goldman Sachs e-mails this weekend in preparation for their hearing Tuesday on the causes of the financial crisis, and reported in detail here.

headline: Do Nice Gals Finish Last?
text: Research suggests that women are less Machiavellian, more agreeable and more altruistic than men, with negative consequences for their earnings, an economist writes.

headline: Emerson Electric Bids $1.1 Billion for Chloride
text: Emerson Electric said Monday it has made a hostile £723 million ($1.1 billion) offer to acquire Chloride Group, a British competitor in providing back-up power supply systems, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Obama Fulfills Pledge With Entrepreneur Summit
text: President Barack Obama on Monday will begin a new effort to build business and social ties to the Muslim world, Reuters reported.

headline: E.On Said to Shortlist 3 Bidders For U.S. Business
text: Germany’s E.On, the world’s largest utility by sales, has shortlisted three bidders for the multibillion-euro sale of its United States business, Reuters reported, citing three people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: UBS-U.S. Deal Tied to Bank Bonuses?
text: Switzerland’s economy minister said she hoped Parliament would not link a deal between UBS and the United States on disclosing secret bank accounts with questions such as bankers’ bonuses, the newspaper Sonntag reported on Sunday.

headline: Summers on Goldman E-Mails and Transparency
text: E-mail messages sent by Goldman Sachs executives describing the money the firm made by betting against risky mortgage securities highlight the need for transparency in financial markets, Lawrence Summers, a senior White House adviser, said on Sunday.

headline: Vue Said to Eye Possible Sale
text: Vue Entertainment, which controls more than 600 movie screens in the U.K., is planning a strategic review which might lead to a sale, The Financial Times reported. The move comes as Lloyds Banking Group is reportedly gearing up to sell a portfolio of equity stakes, which includes a 29 percent stake in Vue.

headline: BofA Said to Near Decision on Chairman
text: Bank of America has narrowed the contenders for chairman to the directors Frank Bramble and Charles Holliday, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: The Trouble With College Costs
text: Today’s idea: Because universities lock away objective information about how well they teach, consumers obsess on college reputation rather than true quality and drive up costs astronomically, a critic says.

headline: Geithner Resents ‘Wall Streeter’ Tag
text: Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner would like you to know that he’s no Wall Streeter, thank you very much.

headline: Hong Kong Landlord Plans $2.7 Billion I.P.O.
text: Swire Properties, landlord to Time Warner and Societe Generale in Hong Kong, plans to raise as much as HK$20.8 billion ($2.7 billion) in an initial public offering, said four people with knowledge of the plan, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: A New Blog on Climate and Energy Choices
text: I first got to know Michael A. Levi, a talented young analyst of the interface between science, technology, economics and policy, while reporting on the unnerving prospect of “dirty bombs” in the wake of the 2001 World Trade Center attacks. Since then, as a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, he’s dived in deep on climate and energy policy, and I’ve found him consistently able to cut through the confounding layers of the “super wicked” world of climate diplomacy (or the lack of it).

headline: Buffett Wants Grandfather Clause for Derivatives
text: As Democrats moved closer to an overhaul of financial regulations Sunday, The Wall Street Journal reported that Warren Buffett — the man who once branded derivatives as “financial weapons of mass destruction” — has been fighting against the deal.

headline: Hong Kong Regulator Seeks Trading Ban on Tiger Asia
text: Hong Kong’s securities regulator is asking a court to impose a trading ban on Tiger Asia Management, amid new allegations of insider trading at the New York-based firm seeded by hedge fund veteran Julian Robertson, according to press reports.

headline: Why Small-Business Owners Raid the College Fund
text: I have been following with great interest the trials and tribulations of Paul Downs and his woodworking business as he navigates troubled waters (I’ll get back to business groups in my next post). I’ve also been following the comments that Paul’s posts have been getting.

headline: Q. and A.: Getting Ready for a Close-Up
text: Q.

headline: Senate Braces for Financial Showdown
text: It’s a question of who will blink in the Senate this week as Democrats and Republicans head for a showdown over new rules to rein in the nation’s financial institutions.

headline: Best Hope for Greece: Minimize the Losses
text: Only a few weeks ago, the idea that Greece might restructure its debt seemed like the nuclear option. Now restructuring — a polite alternative to outright “default” — is not only thinkable, but even likely.

headline: Charles River Buys Chinese Drug Research Firm
text: Charles River Laboratories said Monday that it had agreed to acquire WuXi Pharma Tech, a Chinese pharmaceutical outsourcing services provider, in a cash and stock deal worth $1.6 billion, David Barboza and Michael J. de la Merced reported in The New York Times.

headline: Sampler: San Francisco City Salaries Soar, and Pot Goes Corporate
text: One in Three San Francisco Employees Made $100,000 | Almost one in three of 27,000 city workers in San Francisco made six-figure salaries last year, more than one in three of all city employees. It’s a pay club whose membership has grown steadily over the past decade, even without counting health insurance or pension benefits. Overtime and payouts for unused vacation days sent many of those city workers’ 2009 compensations over the $100,000 level. The retired deputy police chief, Charles Keohane, who left the force in mid-2009, led the pay pack, receiving $516,118 because of stored-up vacation, sick days and comp time. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

headline: When Good Is Better Than Best
text: Let’s say a subway station had peeling paint, decaying ceilings, cracked tiles. And let’s say you would be happy to see just one of those problems go away.

headline: Harbinger Continues to Trim Times Co. Stake
text: One of The New York Times Company’s largest shareholders, Harbinger Capital Partners, said last week that it cut its stake to 9.4 percent, as the firm continues to pare its holdings in the newspaper publisher.

headline: Faneca Is Upset With Jets’ Decision? Are You?
text: “You’re going to stay the same, get better or get worse. We’re getting better. That’s why we made the move we made.”— Coach Rex Ryan, on the decision to break up one of the best offensive lines in the league

headline: Speed Read for Monday, April 26
text: Here are some highlights from Monday’s edition of The New York Times:

headline: Hertz to Buy Dollar Thrifty for $1.2 Billion
text: From our colleagues at DealBook:

headline: Media Equation: The Case of the iPhone Prototype
text: Just how much is a scoop worth? David Carr writes in his Media Equation column about the prototype iPhone that someone found in a California bar and sold to Gawker Media, which doled out the juicy details last week on its Gizmodo Web site. Was Gawker’s chief, Nick Denton, right to pay for it? Mr. Carr writes:

headline: Your Jokes: ‘New Slogan for Tab’
text: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Healthy Eggplant Parmigiana
text: Michael Scelfo, the 36-year-old executive chef at both the Temple Bar and the Russell House Tavern in Cambridge, Mass., invented this variation on eggplant parmigiana three years ago.

headline: Off to the Races
text: Welcome back to The Rail, where for the next six weeks or so we unapologetic horseplayers and horse lovers will dissect and prognosticate, analyze and bloviate about all things thoroughbred racing. I’ve come to think of this space as one of those cozy bars off the paddock, where trainers and owners come to watch the replays of the races as soon as their horses are off the track, and where handicappers divine genius between busting each other’s chops.

headline: In Defense of Giants’ Pick of Pierre-Paul
text: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down.

headline: Treasury Prepares 1.5 Billion Citi Shares for Sale
text: The Treasury Department said on Monday that it was preparing to sell 1.5 billion Citigroup shares, the next step in its efforts to withdraw from its big ownership position in the bank.

headline: Submit Your Funny Caption
text: Big Ben? | Tell us what’s going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned images we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. The latest funniest captions are at right.

headline: Dollars and Daggers in California’s Energy Battles
text: In California, where government-by-ballot-proposition has been raised to a high art, energy companies are pouring millions of dollars into efforts to protect their interests. The one that has gotten the most attention is a push to derail the state’s landmark 2006 law to combat global warming.

headline: The Team That Built the S.E.C.’s Goldman Case
text: What kind of team do you assemble when you’re trying to catch an investment bank?

headline: New York’s Indie Film Scene Struggles Toward Resurrection
text: Hollywood correspondent Michael Cieply digs into the indie film scene in New York, and finds that a new group of moviemakers are attempting to revitalize the movement with a mix of low production costs, penny-pinching marketing and an eagerness to distribute through any platform available. For more than a decade, New York dominated the indie film scene, but the financial collapse and credit crisis has decimated it. He writes:

headline: The Early Word: Financial Forays
text: Democrats will press ahead with their plan to overhaul the nation’s financial regulatory system this week, amid mounting pressure to tackle climate and immigration legislation before the midterm elections.

headline: High Rates of Poverty, and High Test Scores
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Stifel Financial and Thomas Weisel Merge
text: Stifel Financial, the brokerage house based in St. Louis, said Monday that it had reached a merger agreement with Thomas Weisel Partners worth about $300 million.

headline: Girls Just Want the Day Off
text: If you have a case of the Mondays and would prefer to be anywhere but your place of work, why not try the 11th-hour excuse that Cyndi Lauper broke out Sunday night on “The Celebrity Apprentice”? The degree of difficulty is extremely high if you’re not a rock star, but if you have an alibi to match hers, we say you deserve the day off. (Note: We tried this on our boss. He didn’t buy it.)

headline: Must Self-Insured Companies Cover Adult Children?
text: Q.

headline: In Bermuda, Bloomberg’s Construction Woes
text: HAMILTON, Bermuda — In New York City, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has taken a harsh line against builders whose work is not up to code, beefing up inspections and levying hefty fines for violations.

headline: Ex-Leader’s Twin Declares Run in Poland
text: BERLIN — Despite facing long odds against a victory, Poland’s former prime minister on Monday declared his candidacy for president in a special election to replace his twin brother, who was killed in a plane crash earlier this month.

headline: Bush Memoir Coming in November
text: Former President George W. Bush‘s memoir, “Decision Points,” will be released by Crown Publishers, a division of Random House, on Nov. 9, the publisher said Monday. Mr. Bush will write about political and personal challenges and discuss his handling of events including the 9/11 attacks and Hurricane Katrina, as well as his embracing of his faith amid his effort to quit drinking. In a news release, Crown said that Mr. Bush would focus on 14 critical decisions in his life and share his reflections on subjects including the closely fought 2000 presidential election and the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.

headline: Q.&A.: Sanders Looks at Financial Bill From the Left
text: Senator Bernard Sanders, the Vermont independent, has won a reputation for being one of Wall Street’s toughest critics. Mr. Sanders has been pushing hard to secure a strong financial regulatory bill that would keep banks from being too big to fail in an effort to eliminate the need for future government bailouts. The Senate is expected to take a key procedural vote on the bill by Monday evening.

headline: Strong Earnings but Little Direction
text: Stocks ended mixed on Monday, wavering between optimism over strong corporate earnings and persistent concerns in the financial sector about regulation and Greece’s debt troubles.

headline: Smog in a Rural Valley? Mystery Is Solved
text: The smog in California’s San Joaquin Valley has puzzled scientists for years. Even though the region is largely rural and agricultural, its smog levels exceed those of densely populated cities like Los Angeles.

headline: Celebrated Spanish Matador Survives Goring
text: Over the weekend, doctors in Mexico struggled to save the life of Spain’s most celebrated matador, José Tomás Román Martín, after a bull tore a six-inch gash in his left thigh on Saturday in the Mexican city of Aguascalientes. The bullfighter, who is known to fans and the media simply by his double-barreled first name, José Tomás, needed 17 pints of blood and three hours of emergency surgery after being gored by an 1,100-pound bull named Navegante  on Saturday afternoon.

headline: The Morning Line: Eskendereya’s Defection
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

headline: Sauces for Grains and Vegetables
text: Lately I’ve received several requests from readers for sauces to serve with cooked grains and vegetables. One reader cited an item called simply a “bowl” at a vegan restaurant in Southern California. The “bowl,” it turns out, is only a generous serving of whole grains accompanied by vegetables and a sauce.

headline: The Novelists and the Candidates: A Campaign Finance Survey
text: Thanks to the Supreme Court and Ronald Dworkin, I’ve been thinking lately about campaign financing and free speech. So just for fun the other day, I searched an online database of contributors for the 2008 election, to see which novelists had ponied up for which candidates. (I limited my search to self-described “novelists,” because expanding it to “authors” and “writers” returned more than 2,500 pages.)

headline: Orange Aioli With Grains and Roasted Beets
text: Beets and their greens go well with a garlicky sauce. This twist on a Mediterranean classic pairs them with a garlic mayonnaise flavored with toasted orange peel. Serve the greens with cooked bulgur, wheat berries, quinoa or barley. The mayonnaise is delicious with roasted or steamed vegetables and makes a great condiment for a sandwich.

headline: More Steep Circulation Declines at Newspapers
text: The reality facing American newspaper publishers continues to look stark, as figures released Monday show deep circulation declines, with average weekday sales down almost 9 percent since last year.

headline: Beet Tzatziki
text: In the Eastern Mediterranean, the familiar tzatziki is made not just with thick yogurt and cucumbers, but also with grated cooked beets. The combination is quite wonderful, though the bright pink color may give you pause. Serve the tzatziki with rice or bulgur and steamed or blanched beet greens.

headline: Peanut and Chile Salsa
text: This Mexican sauce, traditionally made with de arbol chiles, is quite spicy. Small, narrow de arbol chiles are available from plenty of online sources. I’m offering two types of salsa here, a mild version that requires only chili powder and the authentic one. Whichever you choose to make, you’ll find it irresistible; the salsa is great with brown rice and any number of vegetables, grilled or steamed, or with a mixture of brown rice and edamame. The salsa is also wonderful with fish and shrimp.

headline: Hot and Sour Peanut Sauce
text: Buckwheat noodles are my favorite food to serve with this pungent, spicy, rich-tasting sauce. It also goes well with any number of grains and with raw and cooked vegetables.

headline: Election Ruling in Iraq Favors Prime Minister
text: BAGHDAD — Seven weeks after Iraqis went to the polls, a special elections court disqualified a winning parliamentary candidate, most likely reversing the narrow defeat of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s alliance and possibly allowing him the first chance to form a new coalition government.

headline: Brodsky Makes His Case for Attorney General
text: Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky of Westchester is one of potentially half a dozen Democrats running for attorney general this year. Mr. Brodsky, 63, has made his name in the Legislature as chairman of the Assembly Committee on Corporations, Authorities and Commissions, using his post to undertake investigations on everything from the financing of Yankee Stadium to corruption at the Canal Corporation. This is his second race for attorney general.

headline: Obama Asks Supporters to Return to the Polls
text: President Obama delivered a fresh appeal today to the millions of new voters who helped send him to the White House two years ago, saying that the Democratic majority in Congress – and his agenda – depended on their roles in this year’s midterm elections.

headline: Too Popular: Justin Bieber Concert Canceled in Australia
text: With his floppy bowl haircut and adorable lisp, the teenage pop star Justin Bieber may not seem like a dangerous figure. But make no mistake: his public appearances can be battlegrounds. On Monday the Australian police shut down a free performance that Mr. Bieber, 16, was to give in Sydney as his fans began injuring one another at the crowded concert site, Agence France-Presse reported. More than 4,000 fans, some who camped out overnight, showed up to hear Mr. Bieber sing three songs at Sydney Harbor, but the plug was pulled on the event hours before showtime when attendees started pushing and shoving. “I am so sorry that it got out of control,” Mr. Bieber said later in an Australian television appearance. “We don’t want anyone to get hurt. It gets crazy sometimes.” Last November, an appearance by Mr. Bieber at the Roosevelt Field Mall in Garden City, N.Y., resulted in a fan stampede after which the singer’s manager, Scott Braun, was arrested on charges of reckless endangerment and criminal nuisance. The Australian police said that fans at Sydney Harbor had sustained only minor injuries and were treated at the scene.

headline: Too Fancy? Too Long? How to Name a Co-op
text: The world of Manhattan co-op boards is rich with infighting over issues like cigar smoke spilling into hallways, mammoth dogs that take up the whole elevator or Verdi recordings played at Carnegie Hall volume. So it would have seemed that residents at one pet-loving high-rise on East 56th Street had been blessed with a minor task: choosing a building name.

headline: Monday Reading: Do Blondes Have More Financial Success?
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Teammates Gordon and Johnson Feuding?
text: For the second straight Sprint Cup race, Jeff Gordon and Jimmie Johnson, teammates at Hendrick Motorsports, got together as they fought for position.

headline: Does Conservatism Need Fox News?
text: Amid a long commentary on last week’s Jim Manzi-Mark Levin dust-up (and related matters), Jonah Goldberg made the following observation:

headline: Robots Work to Stop Leak of Oil in Gulf
text: NEW ORLEANS — Oil continued to pour into the Gulf of Mexico on Monday as the authorities waited to see if the quickest possible method of stopping the leaks would bring an end to what was threatening to become an environmental disaster.

headline: GTCR to Buy Protection One
text: 2:24 p.m. | Updated GTCR, a private equity firm, has struck a deal to buy Protection One, an electronic surveillance company, in a deal valued at about $828 million, including Protection One’s debt.

headline: Bush Memoir Coming in November
text: At our sib-blog ArtsBeat, colleague Dave Itzkoff offers up a few choice details on the release later this year of the memoir, “Decision Points,” by former President George W. Bush.

headline: Swiss Hold 3 in Plot Against I.B.M.
text: GENEVA — Three people suspected of planning an attack against a Swiss branch of I.B.M. were arrested this month, the Swiss authorities said Monday.

headline: Hold the Advice, However Well-Intended
text: I have never been quite sure what to make of the usual “you should go to this college” comment. Usually it comes from former classmates — those a year ahead of me, enjoying their freshman year at any one of many exciting colleges.

headline: The Artist at Work and Play
text: Bobby Sheehan, the director of the documentary "Arias With a Twist," describes what the performer Joey Arias represents in the contemporary art scene.

headline: Tweezer Food
text: High-end restaurant cuisine that is delicately prepared and presented – often literally with tweezers.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘A Ball of Yarn Saved Her Life’
text: We received nearly 200 imaginative and interesting submissions to our April Found Poem Challenge for students, and, though it was difficult to choose among them, we’ve selected 10 favorites.

headline: Fools’ Gold: An Oral History of the Insane Clown Posse Parodies
text: Even for guys who paint their faces with clown makeup and rap about brutality, thuggishness and dead bodies they took in off the streets, the past few months have been strange ones for Insane Clown Posse. Though that hip-hop act, consisting of the Detroit natives Shaggy 2 Dope and Violent J, has been a proud representative of the horrorcore rap scene for nearly two decades, the group is enjoying a resurgence in attention, if not popularity, from a wave of Internet comedy videos poking fun at their music and their legions of harlequin-faced fans, who call themselves Juggalos.

headline: Gorilla Coffee Reopens, With New Workers
text: It was not until about 9:45 the morning of its reopening that the Gorilla coffee shop in Park Slope, Brooklyn, began to look a little like its old self: a few patrons lined up at the cash register, waiting for lattes and Balthazar pastries; several others sitting at red Formica tables, drinking coffee and tapping away at their laptops.

headline: The High Low | Alice Park Wallet, $65
text: What: Alice Park kidskin wallet

headline: Rent vs. Buy in Nine More Areas
text: A few readers noticed that I said last week that The Times had analyzed house prices and rents in 54 metropolitan areas but that our chart included only 45. Space constraints were the reason.

headline: Report: 2010 College Budget Deficits = 2025 State Work Force Deficits
text: At a time when public colleges and universities in California are scaling back, a report released last week argues that state-funded higher education should expand to the tune of $1.6 billion annually to meet the needs of the state’s economy by 2025.

headline: Thai King Avoids Talk of Unrest in Address
text: BANGKOK — Thailand’s ailing king spoke on national television on Monday night, his first remarks since his nation descended into a political crisis, but he made no reference to the conflict that now threatens to spin out of control.

headline: On Our Radar: Lessons From a Deep Current
text: A huge Antarctic deep-water current has been discovered that sheds light on the workings of an “ocean conveyor belt.”

headline: Director of ‘Crude’ Will Resist Chevron’s Request for Footage
text: 4:13 p.m. | Updated A documentary filmmaker says he will fight a request by Chevron to turn over hundreds of hours of footage he shot for a documentary about pollution in the Amazon rainforests of Ecuador, film the company says may be useful in lawsuits it faces accusing it of damaging the environment there.

headline: Financial Tuneup: Reread Your Will
text: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, we’ve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

headline: Buildings Named Badly
text: It may seem like only neurotic New Yorkers would need 18 months and a team of professionals to choose a new name for an apartment building. But building naming is serious business in this city: It is perceived as helping drive up real estate values.

headline: Draft Is Over; We Now Resume Our Regularly Scheduled Programming
text: Now that the N.F.L. draft has freed us from its grasp (although is it possible we all napped through the announcement that it would be extended to 93 rounds and last until June?) all that’s left is three months of analysis, Brett Favre-watching and placing bets on when the risk-happy Jets will implode, with the over-under currently at Week 5.

headline: Seaver’s Tales of Wine and Roses
text: Tom Seaver has never lacked for words, confidence or enthusiasm. With little prompting, he can launch into stories about pitching to Henry Aaron, winning it all with the 1969 Mets or any of a thousand other moments in his Hall of Fame career.At 65, Seaver has not lost that passion, only now he has rechanneled it into wine making and his Seaver Family Vineyards. After several years of planting, pruning and planning, Seaver’s two cabernets – GTS and Nancy’s Fancy – are coming into their own.

headline: Confronting the Mire on 34th Street
text: The Bloomberg administration has announced that it will create a new Midtown pedestrian mall, this one running on 34th Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues — that is, between Macy’s and the Empire State Building.

headline: Iceland’s Main Airport Reopens
text: Keflavik International Airport, the main international airport in Iceland, reopened on Monday after a three-day shutdown because of ash from the Eyjafjallajokull volcano. The airport was closed Friday after easterly winds began blowing volcano ash toward the capital, Reykjavik.

headline: In Portugal, Train Drivers Begin Rush-Hour Strikes
text: A morning rush-hour strike by train drivers caused widespread travel disruption in Portugal on Monday as the workers protested a government pay freeze at publicly owned companies.

headline: Downtown Performance Art, Aliens Included
text: “Arias With a Twist: The Docufantasy,”  which examines the theatrical collaboration between the performance artist Joey Arias (best known for his vocal style that channels Billie Holiday) and the puppeteer Basil Twist as a way to explore the history of New York’s downtown art and club scene. Traversing the ’70s until today, the film includes interviews with several artists who were a part of the scene. But its most intriguing subject is Mr. Arias himself, who has spent more than 30 years at his craft.

headline: Which Android Platform Is Netflix Working On?
text: When Netflix opened its doors for business in 1998 it offered one product: DVDs by mail. Since then the video company has plastered itself everywhere.

headline: The Wheel Thing
text: Laugh all you want, but the name ‘‘Design Within Reach’’ was never meant to be about affordability. When Rob Forbes founded the high-end modern furniture retailer in 1999, he was throwing open the doors to a realm that was — at least in this country — maddeningly difficult for the average civilian to penetrate without the help of an interior designer. With his new company, Public, he’s taking the pain out of acquiring another elusive design object: the stylish, practical city bike, the kind that the Dutch and Danish ride. A longtime urban cyclist himself, Forbes watched as places like New York, San Francisco and even Louisville, Ky., spent the last decade opening bike lanes and encouraging alternative transportation, and yet, he argues, most American bike stores still cater primarily to athletes. ‘‘Bicycle technology here is centered on lightweight performance, so they’re not as interested in a customer that wants a kickstand, rack and fenders,’’ he says. The Public M (left) is a lightweight update on classic French models from the ’60s and ’70s, à la ‘‘Jules et Jim.’’ And at $600 to $1,200, Public’s bikes are more or less within reach. Forbes still believes in living a well-designed life, but this time around he’s taking his gospel to the streets. Go to publicbikes.com.

headline: What to Watch at Senate’s Hearing on Goldman
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: Electric Cabs Begin 90-day Trial in Tokyo
text: Three electric cabs began a 90-day trial in Tokyo on Monday that officials and the company involved said could eventually lead to the electrification of the entire taxi fleet.

headline: TimesCast | April 26, 2010
text: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Monday.  Topics include a new release of Goldman Sachs documents, a battle over a Cape Cod wind farm and saving sharks in Belize.

headline: Thumbs Up:  Ferrari Combines P.R. With Whimsy
text: A Ferrari sponsor, Banco Santander, held an event in Spain today to promote the brand, and they made Fernando Alonso available to the invited media. I was not there, but the team put up a whimsical press release on the event, talking about how Fernando Alonso has had his thumbs insured by Banco Santander.

headline: Shake-Up in Top Schools Posts
text: There’s another changing of the guard coming at the Education Department’s Tweed Courthouse. Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein is poised to announce what is, by our count, the fourth administrative overhaul in his eight-year tenure.

headline: Wall Street Journal Says It’s Up to You, New York, New York
text: The Wall Street Journal’s much-anticipated New York edition hit the doorsteps of the city and brought with it the first broadsheet newspaper competition in decades.

headline: Presidential Yankees and Mets
text: The Yankees’ visit to the White House on Monday and the flurry of “I Like Ike” signs at Citi Field welcoming Ike Davis, the Mets’ new first baseman, got us thinking about other “presidential” names from the Yankees and the Mets.

headline: 'The Actor' Returns
text: Images of paintings from “Picasso in the Metropolitan Museum of Art,” including “The Actor.”

headline: The Art Is Instrumental
text: Images from the Musical Instrument Museum.

headline: Eskendereya’s Scratching Highlights Fragile Nature of Sport
text: Steve Zorn, who writes the Business of Racing blog, is the racing manager for Castle Village Farm thoroughbred partnerships. He is also a board member of the New York Thoroughbred Horsemen’s Association and the Backstretch Employees’ Service Team, the health program for workers at NYRA tracks.

headline: Current TV Reporters to Discuss Imprisonment in N. Korea
text: Laura Ling and Euna Lee, the two journalists who were imprisoned in North Korea, have spent the better part of a year out of public view.

headline: G.O.P. Blocks Debate on Financial Oversight Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans, united in opposition to the Democrats’ legislation to tighten regulation of the financial system, voted on Monday to block the bill from reaching the floor for debate. As both sides dug in, the battle has huge ramifications for the economy and for their political prospects in this year’s midterm elections.

headline: Odette Fada Leaving SD26
text: After 14 years with the restaurateur Tony May, Odette Fada is leaving SD26 on May 3. She was executive chef of San Domenico on Central Park South, which closed in 2008, then at SD26, the relocated, updated version of the restaurant that opened last year on Madison Square Park. Her replacement, Matteo BerganiniBergamini, who is from Lake Garda in northern Italy, has been the chef de cuisine and also worked for two years with Daniel Boulud.

headline: BlackRock’s Shares Drop as Results Disappoint
text: Shares of BlackRock fell sharply on Monday after the giant money management firm reported weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings as its funds businesses saw outflows and customers shifted to passive funds over more actively managed ones.

headline: ‘Memphis’ and ‘The Royal Family’ Lead Outer Critics Circle Awards Nominations
text: The Broadway musical “Memphis” and the recent revival of “The Royal Family” were the most recognized productions at Monday’s announcement of the nominations for the Outer Critics Circle awards, edging the John Kander and Fred Ebb musical “The Scottsboro Boys” and the critically reviled “Addams Family.”

headline: Encouraging Older Volunteers
text: Evidence of the benefits that volunteering can bring older people continues to roll in. “Volunteers have improved physical and social functioning,” said Fengyan Tang, an assistant professor at the University of Pittsburgh School of Social Work, who has studied older volunteers. “They report better well-being and greater life satisfaction. There’s a reduced risk for mortality compared to non-volunteers.”

headline: Lemaire Steps Down as Devils Coach
text: The Devils announced (first on their Twitter pge) that Jacques Lemaire is stepping down as their coach and retiring.

headline: The Curious Politics of Immigration
text: Just a quick note: my take on the politics of immigration is that it divides both parties, but in different ways.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: The ‘Moore’ the Merrier, Paint Marketer Proclaims
text: Forget about painting the town red. A leading brand of paint wants you to paint the town read, as in, “I read about it on Facebook.”
