headline: Whirling Bull
text: It is an article of faith in some circles that consumer spending cannot really recover, because so many of us are over-indebted and underemployed.

headline: People and Accounts of Note in Advertising
text: Andy Bateman joined Leading Edge, Sydney, Australia, part of the Photon Group, as chief executive. He assumes those duties from Nigel Long, chairman at Leading Edge, who had been filling the post temporarily after Mark Sundquist left last year. Mr. Bateman had been chief executive of the New York office of Interbrand, part of the Omnicom Group, where a search for a successor is under way. Mr. Bateman, who will be based in Sydney, will oversee the planned opening of an office for Leading Edge in New York.

headline: Thunder, a Young Team Learning Fast, Outrunning Lakers
text: Perhaps it took two games for the young Oklahoma City Thunder to get a hang of this N.B.A. playoff thing.

headline: The Future May Not Resemble the Last 6 Months
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Clearwater Asset Management. He answered questions from Bucks readers in November.

headline: Time Is Running Out on Davies’s Comeback
text: Five months ago, Charlie Davies could not stand on his own. His once sculptured legs shook under the strain of his own weight. His girlfriend pushed him around in a wheelchair because he could not walk.

headline: Fading Ads, Pickled in Pixels
text: Today, as on many days, Ephemeral New York is taken by that charming and most visible symbol of the changing city: the fading painted advertisement.

headline: The Well-Dressed Chair
text: Artek, the Finnish company that was co-founded by the architect Alvar Aalto to produce his furniture designs, is celebrating its 75th anniversary by asking designers and artists to reinterpret its classic armchairs in a program called Dress the Chair! For the opening of Artek’s new Stockholm showroom earlier this year, the British designer Ilse Crawford covered Aalto’s chunky 1936 Armchair 400 — better known as the Tank chair — with reindeer fur, in a nod to its Finnish roots. And the Swedish textile designer Fanny Aronsen covered Aalto’s chairs in her own colorful fabrics. The second stop was Milan, where the fashion house Missoni dressed the Tank chair in its graphic textiles (above) during last month’s furniture fair. New York, Sydney, London and Tokyo come next, with more guest designers, before a final stop back home in Helsinki.

headline: Two Dance Visions in a Creative Pas de Deux
text: A theater merging with a choreographer’s company? As the New York dance world puzzled over the unusual prospect of a union between the downtown presenter Dance Theater Workshop and Bill T. Jones’s company — one surprised former staff member of the workshop likened it to a merger of a museum and an artist — new details have emerged about the proposal.

headline: Numberplay: Surreal Hat Tricks
text: Greetings folks, and welcome to the new Numberplay section of the Wordplay blog, the reincarnation of the TierneyLab Monday Puzzle. I extend a hearty welcome to both old friends and new. TierneyLab regulars, you will find the same suite of mathematical, logical and scientific puzzles that brightened up your Mondays, complete with Justin Thyme’s stunning illustrations and graphical hints. Wordplay faithfuls, it might surprise you to learn that the TierneyLab Monday puzzle suite had a word challenge of its own every week. Today, in your honor, I’ve expanded that portion to feature a mini-crossword with a twist. I hope you enjoy it.

headline: G.O.P. Readies a Rival Bill on Financial Rules
text: 3:10 p.m. | Updated Senate Republicans are working to complete their own version of legislation to tighten regulation of the nation’s financial system, and aides said their version could be put forward as a rival to the Democrats’ proposal if a bipartisan deal is not reached before an important procedural vote later on Monday, The New York Times’s David M. Herszenhorn reports from Washington.

headline: Nick Clegg Is (Not) the British Obama
text: As my colleague John Burns reports from London, “a strong and unexpected surge by the left-of-center Liberal Democrats” ahead of the general election in Britain on May 6 has thrown the spotlight on the party’s youthful leader, Nick Clegg.

headline: The Biker Who Took ‘Big Air’ to the Big Time
text: If you associate “Jackass” with outrageous, over-the-top feats, know that the guys behind that hit MTV stunt show appreciate athleticism, too. In his new documentary “The Birth of Big Air,” Jeff Tremaine, the “Jackass” co-creator and director, pays tribute to Mat Hoffman, the freestyle BMX biker who ushered the sport from backyard ramps in the 1980s to the two-story-tall half-pipes of the modern-day X Games. The eerily mature film is also a grown-up endeavor for the “Jackass” star Johnny Knoxville, who is one of its producers.

headline: Bashir Wins Election as Sudan Edges Toward Split
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Sudan’s incumbent president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, handily won the country’s first multiparty election in more than 20 years, according to results released Monday, offering a glimpse into the kind of lopsided contests that may continue if the nation splits in two next year as expected.

headline: Now Booking | English Countryside Hotels
text: If you thought Britain’s country house hotels — usually dilapidated and ennui-inducing throwbacks to Olde England — had remained comfortingly formulaic, think again. A new generation of clued-in hoteliers are sprucing up some of the once-forgotten countryside piles, turning them into stylish getaways with impeccable interiors, haute cuisine and, more often than not, spectacular spas — all amid a pastoral panorama dotted with horses, foraging sheep and darting deer.

headline: After Doubts About Pastor’s Project, Council Members Resign
text: A group of pastors and advisers have resigned as the executive council of a faith-based social service start-up in Brooklyn after saying it has been plagued by “incongruities and lies” and concluding that it could not even vouch for the project’s veracity.

headline: Sally on Her 75th Birthday
text: Facing dementia, one woman celebrates her 75th birthday.

headline: Jones Says He’s Sorry for Off-Tone Joke
text: Just when it looked like the Obama administration couldn’t get into any more trouble with the pro-Israel lobby, Gen. James L. Jones, the national security adviser, had to issue a formal apology Monday for possibly offending Jews with a joke he told to start a speech last week.

headline: Scarborough and Brzezinski to Revamp, Expand Their Radio Show
text: Citadel Media put “The Joe Scarborough Show” on an immediate hiatus on Monday and said it was developing a longer version of the radio show featuring Mr. Scarborough and Mika Brzezinski.

headline: Obama, Leno and a Low-Carbon Menu
text: The White House Correspondents’ Dinner, an annual black-tie festival of schmoozing, preening and source-greasing, is taking steps this year to reduce its carbon footprint. From decorations to menu choices to recommended modes of transport, the association is trying to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions generated by its 2,600 revelers.

headline: What’s the Difference? Writing to Compare and Contrast
text: Overview | What are the purposes of doing a written comparison? How can a writer execute a well-developed and meaningful comparison? In this lesson, students explore sound topics and strategies for a written comparison as well as its authentic purpose, and then write their own compare/contrast essays, based on and inspired by models from The Times.

headline: TimesCast: A Key Vote on Financial Regulation
text: TimesCast, a daily look inside The New York Times newsroom and articles planned for coverage, begins with a segment on the debate in Congress on the overhaul of financial regulations, and why the battle for a bipartisan bill may not be as difficult as the one surrounding health care.

headline: Homeownership Falls Further
text: The homeownership rate fell further last quarter, and is now at its lowest level in a decade, according to a Census Bureau report released today.

headline: Book Offers View of the Motoring Future
text: Last month, General Motors introduced its new Electric Networked Vehicle, or EN-V, a two person, podlike device created jointly with Segway.

headline: Special Teams Lifting Coyotes
text: It should be pretty easy for the Phoenix Coyotes to figure out what they need to do to beat the Detroit Red Wings:

headline: Travel Deals: Tuscan Castle Vacation
text: If staying in a Tuscan villa is not luxurious enough, how about sleeping in a castle?

headline: Deep in December, It’s Nice to Remember: Tom Jones Returns to ‘The Fantasticks’
text: At 82, the musical-theater lyricist and actor Tom Jones does not need to do much to make himself look like an elderly character on stage, he volunteered in a recent conversation. But on Monday night, he will use makeup to add sags to his face and bulges to his eyes and an eyebrow pencil to make his teeth look rotted as he returns to the role of Henry the old actor in the Off Broadway production of “The Fantasticks” to recognize its 50th anniversary on May 3.

headline: Hertz Aims to Push Forward With Dollar Thrifty
text: Hertz Global Holdings appears confident the that government will approve its $1.2 billion acquisition of the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, a rival rental car company, noting that it could be forced to carve out operations in some smaller markets.

headline: It’s No More Mr. Nice Guy for This Everyman
text: When Denzel Washington talks about challenging death to a wrestling match, you suddenly sense that everything’s going to be all right. Not for Troy Maxson, the character portrayed by Mr. Washington in the vibrantly acted Broadway revival of August Wilson’s “Fences,” which opened on Monday night at the Cort Theater; Troy might as well have “Warning: Explosives” tattooed across his forehead, with “Breakable” stamped on his back.

headline: Gowanus, Brooklyn, 11:13 A.M.
text: A metal gleaner named Lucky pushed his load of scrap to Benson Scrap Metal near the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn in the rain on Monday.

headline: Edward P. Jones and Nam Le Win PEN/Malamud Award
text: The short story is not so small that it can’t accommodate two winners for one of the more prestigious prizes in that genre. On Monday, the organizers of the PEN/Malamud Award for Excellence in the Short Story, which in recent years has recognized a veteran author and a writer at the start of a career, announced that Edward P. Jones and Nam Le were the winners of its 2010 prize. Mr. Jones, a Pulitzer Prize winner in 2004 for his novel “The Known World,” was cited for short story collections like “Lost in the City” (from 1992) and “All Aunt Hagar’s Children” (2007). Mr. Le, a Vietnamese-born writer who splits his time between the United States and Australia, was honored for his debut collection, “The Boat,” which was published in 2008. Mr. Jones and Mr. Le will a share a prize of $5,000 and take part in the 2010-11 PEN/Faulkner Reading Series at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington.

headline: The Claim: Lack of Sleep Increases Weight
text: THE FACTS

headline: Less Sleep Linked With More Eating
text: People who sleep less appear to eat more the next day.

headline: Identifying Students With the Most Debt
text: The College Board, in a new report, found that bachelor’s degree recipients who graduated with the most student debt tended to be those who went to for-profit institutions or were independent — meaning they generally did not get support from their parents.

headline: Cape Cod Project Is Crucial Step for U.S. Wind Industry
text: More than 800 giant wind turbines spin off the coasts of Denmark, Britain and seven other European countries, generating enough electricity from strong ocean breezes to power hundreds of thousands of homes. China’s first offshore wind farm, a 102-megawatt venture near Shanghai, goes online this month, with more in the pipeline.

headline: To Beat the Heat, Drink a Slushie First
text: It’s no surprise that it’s hard to exercise on a hot day. You go slower. An easy workout is grueling. You have no endurance.

headline: The Slushie Workout
text: Exercisers are always looking for ways to boost their energy, particularly during hot weather. Now Personal Best columnist, Gina Kolata, offers this advice for keeping your cool during a workout: drink a slushie.

headline: 'Learning How to Learn'
text: Rosie O'Donnell speaks about auditory processing disorder and the therapy that has helped her son.

headline: On Tour, Conan O’Brien Gets Some Super Assistance
text: Conan O’Brien got a little help from an old friend in a couple of boisterous stage shows on his Legally Prohibited From Being Funny on Television Tour in Los Angeles on Saturday and Sunday nights:

headline: Who Will Build the First Offshore Wind Farm in North America?
text: Back in December, I had an opportunity to take a helicopter ride low over the North Sea, about 13 miles off the western shores of Denmark, to view an offshore wind farm.

headline: Body After Baby
text: On the one hand we have all those breathless magazine covers, celebrating “Body After Baby,” and making it seem as if baby weight is something that can, nay, should, melt off in six weeks, leaving Heidi Klum’s body behind.

headline: Advice for New Head of Homeless Services
text: Monday is the first day on the job for Seth Diamond, the city’s new homeless services commissioner.

headline: The Morning Skate: A ‘Dramatical’ Turn, an Ironic Ending, a Confused Aftermath
text: When the Blackhawks take the ice in Nashville tonight for Game 6 of their opening-round series and try to close out the Predators, they will have Marian Hossa in the lineup.

headline: Thomson Reuters CEO Has a Sympathetic Ear for Goldman Sachs
text: Thomson Reuters chief executive Tom Glocer has taken an unusual step for a media executive, issuing a blog post defending Goldman Sachs.

headline: Viola Davis on 'Fences'
text: The actress talks about performing with Denzel Washington in the Broadway revival of August Wilson's play.

headline: Coyote vs. Greyhound: One Man's Sport
text: John Hardzog uses trained greyhounds to hunt coyotes, a common pest for farmers. It's a practice that goes back generations, but is also opposed by some animal rights groups.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Glengarry Glen Ross'
text: A. O. Scott takes a look back at the 1992 film adapted from David Mamet's play about the real estate world's culture of unfettered selling.

headline:
Mortgage Deals
Under Scrutiny as Goldman Faces Senators
text: WASHINGTON — The legal storm buffeting Goldman Sachs continued to rage Tuesday just ahead of what is expected to be a contentious Senate hearing at which bank executives plan to defend their actions during the housing crisis.

headline: Isn’t It Surreal? | Dorothea Tanning at the Drawing Center
text: Dorothea Tanning, the last of the Surrealists, has always been something of a fashion plate. A long-limbed beauty and a piquant dresser, Tanning scoured vintage shops and played dress-up with extravagant 19th-century pieces. Her eclectic style sense is celebrated in the 1942 self-portrait “Birthday” in which the bare-breasted artist sports an Elizabethan-style jacket, a draped skirt and what appears to the be the entire root system of a very large tree.

headline: Roethlisberger Apologizes and Accepts His Suspension
text: In his first public comments since he was suspended for up to six games by the N.F.L. last week, Pittsburgh quarterback Ben Roethlisberger emphasized Monday that he committed no crime during an incident with a 20-year-old college student in a Georgia bar, but added that he was sorry he let his teammates and Steelers fans down. Roethlisberger said he would not appeal the suspension, which could be reduced to four games — or lengthened beyond six games — depending on Roethlisberger’s compliance with a behavioral evaluation ordered by the league.

headline: Milan Report | A Forest of Coat Trees
text: Every year at the Milan furniture fair, there is a stand-out, seemingly ubiquitous object; this time around we couldn’t help but notice the abundance of cool coat trees. For those who don’t have an entry hall closet, or, for that matter, an entry hall, the coat tree stands as the perfect design solution. One of the best was the 25 Liter Coat Stand by the design darling Peter Marigold for Skitsch. The quasi-ready-made is anchored by a 25 liter plastic tank — filled with water for stability — and has a metal tube with hooks extending out of the spout. At Japanese furniture manufacturer Karimoku, the Swiss design trio Big-Game came up with the Signs coat tree. Made in natural or gray stained wood, this coat stand has movable arms which pivot out from the frame when you place your coat on it or snap back in place with hidden magnets when not in use.

headline: The Search for Genes Leads to Unexpected Places
text: Edward M. Marcotte is looking for drugs that can kill tumors by stopping blood vessel growth, and he and his colleagues at the University of Texas at Austin recently found some good targets — five human genes that are essential for that growth. Now they’re hunting for drugs that can stop those genes from working. Strangely, though, Dr. Marcotte did not discover the new genes in the human genome, nor in lab mice or even fruit flies. He and his colleagues found the genes in yeast.

headline: Caveat Emptor Is Not a Business Plan
For Kennedys Tribute, Torch Is Passed to Three A-Listers
text: With more than 240 credits among the three of them (but surprisingly only three Academy Awards), it was merely a matter of time before Robert De Niro, Morgan Freeman and Ed Harris found the right project to appear in together. In this case, it is the debut performance of the multimedia work “The Dream Lives On: A Portrait of the Kennedy Brothers,” which will take place as part of the Boston Pops’ 125th anniversary season, the orchestra said on Monday. The work, which will have its premiere on May 18 at Symphony Hall in Boston, will have the actors narrating as three of the Kennedy siblings: Mr. De Niro as John F. Kennedy, Mr. Harris as Robert F. Kennedy and Mr. Freeman as Edward M. Kennedy. Composed by Peter Boyer with lyrics by Lynn Ahrens, “The Dream Lives On” will also feature the Boston Pops Orchestra conducted by Keith Lockhart and the Tanglewood Festival Chorus, as well as original texts and videos. The work will receive additional performances May 19 through 22 and July 3 and 4. It will also be performed on July 18 at Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., with Alec Baldwin narrating, and on Aug. 1 at the Hyannis Village Green in Hyannis, Mass., where it will be narrated by Chris Cooper.

headline: Hope for Sharks and Reefs in Belize
text: Glover's Reef in Belize is a Marine Protected Area where strict limits on fishing have helped shark populations.

headline: How Do Lawyers Get Away With This Stuff?
text: At my company, we try so hard to provide great customer service that I sometimes forget that bad customer service exists. And then I hired a lawyer.

headline: Cancer Patient Dies Despite Daring Surgery
text: They seemed like a formidable team. The surgeon was skilled and daring, the patient fiercely determined to live. But talent and grit were not enough. Robert Collison, 59, died on Friday at a hospital in Milwaukee, four months after undergoing 43 hours of surgery in New York to remove a huge cancerous tumor from his abdomen.

headline: Fish Versus Flax
text: Q. How does flaxseed oil compare with fish oil in nutritional benefits?

headline: 17 Years Later, Stage 4 Survivor Is Savoring a Life Well Lived
text: Each year on a day in January — the 15th, to be precise — I go to a Web site and post a message to hundreds of women I’ve never met, saying, essentially, “I’m still here.”

headline: What We’re Reading: New York Landmarking
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Targeting a Shepard Fairey Mural
text: It’s par for the course in the world of street art: getting painted over. But by the unwritten code of the scene, most artists leave others’ work alone; business-owners and antigraffiti activists are usually the ones brandishing the whitewash.

headline: The Unspoken State of the Judiciary
text: The first State of the Judiciary message by New York’s new chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, was presented Monday. And no one came.

headline: Inquiry Says Health Care Charges Were Proper
text: WASHINGTON — When major companies declared that a provision of the new health care law would hurt earnings, Democrats were skeptical. But after investigating, House Democrats have concluded that the companies were right to tell investors and the government about the expected adverse effects of the law on their financial results.

headline: Obama Welcomes Yankees, Chides Their ‘Long Wait’
text: President Barack Obama welcomed the Yankees to the White House on Monday, lauding them for the franchise’s 27th championship, and poking a bit of fun at how long it took to win this one.

headline: Where’s My Car?
text: If there’s one thing that’s guaranteed to make me feel like a dope, it’s when I can’t remember where I parked my car. And based on the number of products that are designed to help in this situation, I’m not the only one with the problem.

headline: Save Emergency Rooms for Emergencies
text: One of President George W. Bush’s most injudicious statements was his suggestion in 2007 that anyone who could not afford private medical care could always go to the emergency room.

headline: Protected Reef Offers Model for Conservation
text: GLOVER’S REEF, Belize — As Alex Tilley powers his 15-foot skiff over the turquoise surface, a dark form slips across the white sand floor below. “Sting ray,” Mr. Tilley says.

headline: Little-Known Disorder Can Take a Toll on Learning
text: Parents and teachers often tell children to pay attention — to be a “good listener.” But what if your child’s brain doesn’t know how to listen?

headline: In Response to Car Horns, Readers Sound Off
text: It can be a satisfying experience to lay on your car’s horn. Some people do it so frequently, they may believe the sound will part the cars ahead, or maybe even get that old lady to cross the street a little faster. But the cacophony can drive pedestrians and residents to distraction.

headline: Traveling a Primeval Medical Landscape
text: The world was young, leafy green and overrun with dinosaurs so many eons ago that stories from prehistoric times are mostly fantasy and supposition. But the medical world was exactly that young, primitive and full of unusual creatures barely a century ago, giving historians ample fodder for true stories stranger than any fantasy.

headline: Putting a Compliment in Context
text: One leftover item from President Obama’s weekend break in Asheville, N.C., by way of the  Asheville Citizen-Times, which reports that Mr. Obama ran into some local residents at the 12th hole of the golf course at Grove Park Inn.

headline: A Closer Look at the Derby Crop
text: Mike Welsch of the Daily Racing Form, who watches all of the Kentucky Derby horses work out and train leading up to the big race, shared some of his thoughts on the best workouts he’s witnessed and this year’s crop of top 3-year-olds.

headline: China in the Driver’s Seat
text: “The Chinese don’t understand us,” Amedeo Felisa, Ferrari’s global chief executive, told me in a recent interview. “They don’t understand why we make only two-door cars. They don’t understand why we don’t make a limousine.”

headline: The Other Great Divide | Posterior Lifting 101
text: Products to lift your posterior. Read related article.

headline: With Expanded Coverage for the Poor, Fears of a Big Headache
text: Of all the changes wrought by the new health care law, none is more sweeping than the transformation of Medicaid — from the government’s health insurance plan for poor families into a much wider program for millions of the poorest Americans who cannot afford insurance on their own.

headline: Exploring the Complexities of Nerdiness, for Laughs
text: BURBANK, Calif. — Shudders and groans went around the blogs and coffee rooms of the physics world back in the summer of 2007, when CBS announced plans for a new comedy series about a pair of nerdy physicists and their buxom blonde waitress neighbor.

headline: Don’t Wait for an Emergency
text: Savvy health care consumers do some advance checking before selecting a personal physician or seeing a specialist. But how many check out the emergency room in advance of a medical crisis?

headline: Mixed Smoke Signals in San Francisco
text: Last weekend, San Francisco’s new antismoking ordinance—which bans smoking in public places like bus stop shelters, outdoor dining areas and A.T.M. lines — went into effect.

headline: Ambinder on the Conservative Mind
text: As a former colleague of Marc Ambinder and a longtime admirer of his work, I’m genuinely distressed to learn that he believes this:

headline: For $520 Million, AstraZeneca Will Settle Case Over Marketing of a Drug
text: AstraZeneca has completed a deal to pay $520 million to settle federal investigations into marketing practices for its blockbuster schizophrenia drug, Seroquel. The Justice Department plans a news conference on Wednesday to disclose details of the case, according to two people close to the negotiations who were not authorized to discuss it publicly.

headline: No Closure in the ‘Epistemic Closure’ Debate
text: The Great “Epistemic Closure” debate is still raging.

headline: Is the M.T.A. Down Another $72 Million?
text: For the financially troubled Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the numbers seem to keep getting worse.

headline: Obama Welcomes Yankees to the White House
text: President Obama welcomed the Yankees to the White House today, lauding them for the franchise’s 27th championship, and poking a bit of fun at how long it took to win this one.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Glengarry Glen Ross’
text: A. O. Scott learns his ABC’s (Always Be Closing) with the film adaptation of David Mamet‘s play “Glengarry Glen Ross.” The film looks at a group of aggressive salesmen who jockey for the top position in a cutthroat real estate office. Mr. Scott praises the film’s dialogue, saying that “nobody but David Mamet can write with this kind of hard-boiled, lyrical mysticism.” Mr. Scott also says the film points to the origins of the current economic crisis, looking at a culture of relentless buying and selling that muddled the true value of things. Please share your thoughts on “Glengarry Glen Ross.”

headline: Recognized for Risk, Ortmeyer Is Among Masterton Finalists
text: After the final faceoff, when most players are thinking about postgame plans, Jed Ortmeyer is giving himself a shot in the stomach — a daily reminder of the risks he takes to play the sport he loves.

headline: A Filly Is Entered in the Derby
text: Todd Pletcher may have lost three starters for the Kentucky Derby in recent days, including the favorite, Eskendereya, but he gained one starter with the entry of the filly Devil May Care.

headline: Eager to Rebuild Willets Point, City Faces Legal Fight From Property Owners
text: It is one of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s signature projects — the sweeping transformation of Willets Point, a slice of Queens that has long been among the city’s most neglected pieces of real estate. And a little over a year ago, it seemed like a done deal.

headline: Authorities Seize Gizmodo Editor’s Computers
text: 10:21 a.m. | Updated Correcting name of law enforcement agency involved, the Rapid Enforcement Allied Computer Team.

headline: Child Health Director Has Background in Genetics
text: Dr. Alan Guttmacher, a Harvard-trained geneticist and pediatrician, is the new acting director of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, the federal agency that finances research into child and maternal health. Dr. Guttmacher, 60, previously worked with Francis Collins on the Human Genome Project and then as the deputy director of the National Human Genome Research Institute of the National Institutes of Health. We spoke for three hours in his Bethesda, Md., offices and then later by telephone. An edited version of the conversations follows.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
text: Jerry Lampen of Reuters photographed an anti-government red-shirt protester being arrested by soldiers of the Thai army. With Thailand’s political crisis worsening, King Bhumibol Adulyadej spoke on national television Monday from the hospital. Though he did not explicitly address the situation, his remarks could have been construed as indirect criticism.

headline: Computers Seized at Home of Gizmodo Reporter Who Wrote About iPhone, Gawker Media Says
text: Gawker Media said on Monday that computers belonging to one of its editors, Jason Chen, were seized from his home on Friday as part of what appeared to be an investigation into the sale of a next-generation iPhone.

headline: The Bachelor Shaw Woos With His Wit
text: There’s great fun in watching witty people fall in love. While some of us sputter in shyness, the well-spoken are infinitely more appealing as they bat bons mots back and forth. “Engaging Shaw” is just such a matchup, a charming romantic comedy featuring four razor-sharp tongues. If there’s a minute of the play that’s less than clever, you’ll be hard pressed to find it.

headline: Conciliatory Tone Expected From Blankfein
text: 5:15 p.m. | Updated Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, plans to tell lawmakers on Tuesday that the day the Securities and Exchange Commission accused his firm of securities fraud was “one of the worst days” in his life, The New York Times’s Louise Story reports.

headline: Home From One War, Walking Into Another
text: Playwrights know what evil lurks in the hearts of American families: the homely, petty kind. In Frank D. Gilroy’s 1964 work “The Subject Was Roses,” the Clearys  mom, dad and Timmy, just back from the war  are the specimens under the microscope, their battles and shifting alliances the stuff of kitchen-sink (or perhaps waffle-iron) drama.

headline: The Attack Coming From Bytes, Not Bombs
text: Blackouts hit New York, Los Angeles, Washington and more than 100 other American cities. Subways crash. Trains derail. Airplanes fall from the sky.

headline: Peter Carey: At Home in Australia, New York and Writing
text: The novelist Peter Carey, whose new book, “Parrot and Olivier in America,” came out last week, likes to call himself a Marshian, which is another way of saying he’s from Australia.

headline: G.O.P. Blocks Debate on Financial Oversight Bill
text: Senate Republicans, united in opposition to the Democrats’ legislation to tighten regulation of the financial system, voted on Monday evening to block the start of floor debate, The New York Times’s David M. Herszenhorn reports from Washington.

headline: The Unfortunate Salesman
text: Just in time for wedding season comes the unfortunate tale of David Goldberg, a young salesman who, 109 years ago today, sued his fiancée, Yetta Wolman, of the Upper West Side, for certain untoward matters that occurred during what The New York Times, in an article on the case, referred to as a “courtship that was fraught with nothing but heartache and unceasing expense to him.”

headline: Three-Spined Stickleback Proves a Purposeful Cannibal
text: It’s a fact of life in the animal world that some fish (and birds, mammals, reptiles, insects, crustaceans — you name it) eat their young.

headline: Insect May Make Moves to Survive the Harvest
text: One thing about evolution — you never know what’s going to influence it. Take the European corn borer, for instance. Researchers have just made a strong case that a certain aspect of its behavior has evolved because of human harvesting of corn.

headline: Like Origami, Pollen Grains Fold Just So
text: After it is released from a flower’s anther, a pollen grain walks a humidity tightrope. It dries up a bit as it travels through the air, the cellular material inside becoming dormant so it survives until it reaches the humid environment of another flower’s stigma. But it can’t become so dry that the material dies.

headline: Vaccinations: A Hot Debate Still Burning
text: “The Vaccine War,” a look at the debate that has been raging for years over the safety of, and necessity for, childhood vaccinations, has only a few moments that might be illuminating to those who have been following this now familiar controversy.

headline: Beneath a Bower, Passions of a Lovelorn Trio
text: Lawrence Goldhuber’s choreography has tended to revolve around his onstage persona: a fat man in the skinny world of dance. Mr. Goldhuber was an actor before joining the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, and when he began to create his own work, he frequently focused on the effects of his 350-pound body in both choreographic and comedic terms.

headline: Pop Songs Exhibiting a Measure of Mortality
text: A mash-up, a conceptual exercise, an amateur talent show, a pop critique, piano-bar karaoke and a meditation on mortality: that’s “End of the Road,” the production of the Young@Heart Chorus by No Theater, at St. Ann’s Warehouse through May 1.

headline: Orchestra Celebrates 25th With Beethoven No. 9
text: For any artistic organization of independent means to survive and flourish for 25 years is a real achievement. But the feat seems even more impressive for a period-instrument ensemble based in the New York area, where several such groups have arrived with a bang and ended with the proverbial whimper. It was cause for celebration, then, that the American Classical Orchestra, founded by Thomas Crawford in Fairfield, Conn., had reached the quarter-century mark. Celebrate it did on Saturday night at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

headline: Wal-Mart Gender Case Divides Court
text: In a closely watched case, a sharply divided federal appeals court on Monday ruled 6-5 that a sex discrimination lawsuit against Wal-Mart could proceed as a class action for more than a million women. The suit is the biggest employment discrimination case in the nation’s history.

headline: Cracking Orca’s Code: It Comes in Several Types
text: Imagine you are a killer whale, or orca, as you probably prefer to be known. You are thinking about lunch, specifically a nice fat penguin, and there on that ice floe is a whole flock of flippered lunch units.

headline: A Morphing Mural
text: Shepard Fairey’s latest street-art piece, a freshly installed mural on Houston Street near the Bowery in Lower Manhattan, includes Mr. Fairey’s signature Andre the Giant, Communist propaganda-tinged images and, perhaps presciently, a target. Hours after the mural went up last week, the graffiti writer known as NAW added his tag to it; a security guard tried to apprehend NAW, but he escaped, apparently by wriggling out of his shirt, according to the blogger Bucky Turco. The tag was quickly removed. More recently, someone punctured the piece, perhaps with a rock or a brick, leaving several small holes and a gaping one through which a previous mural, by the twins known as Os Gemeos, is visible. The piece is a prelude to Mr. Fairey’s exhibition at Deitch Projects, the gallery’s final show before it closes. Andrea Cashman, a spokeswoman for Deitch, said the puncture and tagging were “a natural occurrence” for any large outdoor project. She said that members of Mr. Fairey’s team would be filling the punctures soon. Mr. Fairey said in a telephone interview that he hadn’t seen the damage, but that if critics wanted to express themselves by vandalizing the mural, “that’s fair.” He added, “I assume that they think that putting a bullet hole through it is a clever interactive addition, which I actually agree with.”

headline: While Contestant Ails, ‘Apprentice’ Thrives
text: Amid a weekend’s outpouring of support for Bret Michaels, the rock musician and “Celebrity Apprentice” contestant who was hospitalized with a brain hemorrhage on Thursday, ratings for that NBC reality show hit their highest level in six weeks on Sunday night. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “Celebrity Apprentice” earned an average of 7.9 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., its best finish since this season’s premiere and enough to beat CBS’s Hallmark movie, “When Love Is Not Enough: The Lois Wilson Story” (7.1 million). CBS still won the night, with a lineup that included “60 Minutes” (11.2 million) and “The Amazing Race” (10.6 million). ABC was runner-up with “Desperate Housewives” (11.1 million) and “Brothers & Sisters” (8.4 million), while NBC ranked third and Fox was fourth.

headline: Chevron Vs. Filmmaker
text: A documentary filmmaker says he will fight a request by Chevron to turn over hundreds of hours of footage he shot for a documentary about pollution in the Amazon rainforest in Ecuador. Chevron says the material may be useful in lawsuits accusing it of damaging the environment there. The filmmaker, Joe Berlinger, whose documentaries include “Paradise Lost” and “Metallica: Some Kind of Monster,” said he had been served with a request from Chevron for more than 600 hours of unused footage for his 2009 documentary “Crude.” The movie, seen in a scene above, chronicles Ecuadoreans who sued Texaco, which is now owned by Chevron, saying the companies’ practices at the Lago Agrio oil field resulted in the contamination of their drinking and bathing water. Mr. Berlinger, who is scheduled to appear in United States District Court in Manhattan on Friday, said Chevron’s request violated his First Amendment rights. If Chevron obtained his footage, he said, “It would have a serious chilling effect on these kinds of investigative films.” Randy M. Mastro, a lawyer representing Chevron, said the company “simply seeks here outtakes relating to the access this filmmaker was given to film the plaintiffs and their lawyers, government officials and supposedly independent experts’ meetings with the plaintiffs and their lawyers.”

headline: George W. Bush Memoir Coming In November
text: Former President George W. Bush’s memoir, “Decision Points,” will be released by Crown Publishers, a division of Random House, on Nov. 9, the publisher said on Monday. Mr. Bush will write about political and personal challenges and discuss his handling of events, including the Sept. 11 attacks and Hurricane Katrina, as well as embracing his faith amid an effort to quit drinking. In a news release, Crown said that Mr. Bush would focus on 14 critical decisions in his life and share his reflections on subjects including the closely fought 2000 presidential election and the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq. Crown said that Mr. Bush had given few speeches or interviews since leaving office. “Instead, he has spent almost every day writing ‘Decision Points,’ ” the release said, adding, “He writes honestly and directly about his flaws and mistakes, as well as his historic achievements.” The book will be released in hardcover and in audio and e-book formats. Mr. Bush will also go on a national book tour.

headline: Bieber Concert Canceled After Fans Go Wild
text: With his floppy bowl haircut and adorable lisp, the teenage pop star Justin Bieber, below, may not seem like a dangerous figure. But make no mistake: his public appearances can be battlegrounds. On Monday the Australian police shut down a free performance that Mr. Bieber, 16, was to give in Sydney as some fans were injured at the crowded concert site, Agence France-Presse reported. More than 4,000 fans, some who camped out overnight, showed up to hear Mr. Bieber sing three songs at Sydney Harbor, but the plug was pulled on the event hours before showtime when attendees started pushing and shoving. “I am so sorry that it got out of control,” Mr. Bieber said later in an Australian television appearance. In November an appearance by Mr. Bieber at the Roosevelt Field Mall in Garden City, N.Y., resulted in a fan stampede after which the singer’s manager, Scott Braun, was arrested on charges of reckless endangerment and criminal nuisance. The Australian police said that fans at Sydney Harbor had sustained only minor injuries and were treated at the scene.

headline: Privilege Pulls Qatar Toward Unhealthy Choices
text: DOHA, Qatar — For such a small country, a finger of sand poking into the Persian Gulf from the eastern side of the Arabian Peninsula, Qatar is a land of big numbers.

headline: Two Authors Win Pen/malamud Award
text: The short story is not so small that it can’t accommodate two winners for one of the more prestigious prizes in that genre. On Monday the organizers of the PEN/Malamud Award for Excellence in the Short Story, which in recent years has recognized both a veteran author and a writer at the start of a career, announced that Edward P. Jones, above left, and Nam Le, above right, won its 2010 prize. Mr. Jones, a Pulitzer Prize winner in 2004 for his novel “The Known World,” was cited for story collections like “Lost in the City” (1992) and “All Aunt Hagar’s Children” (2007). Mr. Le, a Vietnamese-born writer who splits his time between the United States and Australia, was honored for his debut collection, “The Boat,” published in 2008. Mr. Jones and Mr. Le will share a prize of $5,000 and take part in the 2010/11 PEN/Faulkner Reading Series at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington.

headline: Old-Time Jazz Swing, but Modern Metabolism
text: The New York jazz landscape has always been defined partly by its underground, with the tacit understanding that such a region is usually zoned for experimentation. That’s as true as it ever was, but it’s an incomplete truth because of all that it overlooks. One case in point would be the Ear Regulars, the traditional jazz cohort led by the trumpeter Jon-Erik Kellso and the guitarist Matt Munisteri every Sunday night at the Ear Inn, on the westernmost edge of the South Village, near the entrance to the Holland Tunnel.

headline: A Change of Topics for Pandit: World Growth
text: Vikram S. Pandit, the chief executive of Citigroup, must have welcomed the chance on Monday to talk about something other than the challenges facing his bank and the overall financial industry.

headline: A Man Who Stopped Time to Set It in Motion Again
text: WASHINGTON — Technology moves fast, art slower. You could say that art is still catching up to Eadweard Muybridge (1830-1904), a pioneer of stop-motion photography and early filmmaking.

headline: ‘Architecture of Dance’
text: Images from rehearsals of the new works in New York City Ballet’s spring season.

headline: Folding Pollen Grain
text: Researchers studied pollen from lilies and other flowers, and their work could have implications for engineers.

headline: Obama Talks to Muslim Entrepreneurs
text: President Obama vowed to continue to press for a comprehensive peace deal between Israelis and Palestinians, exhorting young entrepreneurs from Muslim majority countries on Monday to look for ways to work with their American counterparts on a wide range of issues.

headline: Will Arizona’s Immigration Law Survive?
text: Arizona’s tough new immigration enforcement law, which was signed on Friday, will face many legal challenges before it goes into effect this summer. Some opponents of the law, the toughest in the nation,  predict that it will suffer the same fate as California’s Proposition 187, which was passed in 1994 but never carried out because of legal setbacks and political opposition.

headline: Living With Tinnitus (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Couples and Caregiving (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: What We’re Reading: Android Gains
text: What’s on the reading list of The Times’s tech editors and reporters Monday:

headline: 'Enron'
text: An excerpt from the new Broadway play. (Video courtesy of the production)

headline: Making Healthy Choices (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Earth as Greenhouse (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chatter of Swindles and Scams at Auction House
text: PARIS — In a warren of side streets not far from the stately Boulevard Haussmann is a squat concrete building that contains another world.

headline: Grass-Roots Choice Leads Race for Top Union Post
text: Mary Kay Henry, a dark-horse candidate who is a leader of the health care division of the Service Employees International Union, has locked up the votes to succeed Andy Stern as the union president, several top union officials said Monday.

headline: Justices to Consider Law Limiting the Sale of Violent Video Games
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether California may forbid the sale of violent video games to children.

headline: Beacon to Hollywood Stays Alive in the Hills
text: LOS ANGELES — The landmark Hollywood sign will stand, unobscured, on scrub-covered slopes overlooking production studios and palm trees here, thanks to a $900,000 donation by Hugh Hefner in the ninth inning of a yearlong effort by conservationists to protect the hilltop around the sign from developers.

headline: Newspaper Circulation Falls Nearly 9%
text: The reality facing many American newspaper publishers continues to look stark, as figures released Monday show deep circulation declines, with average weekday sales down almost 9 percent since the same time last year.

headline: Russian Adoptees Get a Respite on the Range
text: EUREKA, Mont. — Hundreds of adopted children, most of them Russian, have come here to northwest Montana to live and perhaps find healing grace with the horses and cows and rolling fields on Joyce Sterkel’s ranch. Some want to return to the families that adopted them, despite their troubles.

headline: McDaniels and Tebow Know How to Adapt
text: Josh McDaniels and the Denver Broncos have inextricably linked their futures to Tim Tebow, which seems like a dicey decision considering how raw Tebow’s talent is. But this is not the first time there have been questions about how well Tebow can adjust to a new system.

headline: ESPN Can’t Seem to Get Enough of the Mets
text: ESPN’s early-season Sunday night schedule reveals one inescapable fact: the network loves the Mets.

headline: Russia’s Power (and Strictly Platonic) Couple
text: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia made clear on Monday that he and his protégé, President Dmitri A. Medvedev, were just friends. Really.

headline: Franklin Mieuli, Offbeat N.B.A. Owner, Dies at 89
text: Franklin Mieuli, the unconventional and popular owner of the Golden State Warriors for nearly a quarter century who in 1975 brought the franchise its only National Basketball Association championship in 48 years on the West Coast, died Sunday. He was 89.

headline: The Comfort of Having a Nurse on Board
text: I mostly fly to Seattle or Washington, D.C., for business. I’m on the board of a small pharmaceutical company working on drugs to treat late-stage cancer. It’s based in the state of Washington. I enjoy going there since it’s very interesting work and my son lives in Washington. And I always manage to squeeze in some “mom time” when I travel there.

headline: Meet the Real Villain of the Financial Crisis
text: TODAY, we will have the pleasure of watching outraged members of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations fire questions at a half-dozen executives from Goldman Sachs. The firm first attracted anger for its return to making billions, and paying its employees millions, right after the financial crisis. And since the Securities and Exchange Commission this month charged Goldman with fraud over an investment tied to subprime mortgages, politicians have turned the firm into the arch-villain of the economic collapse.

headline: Encouraging the Text Generation to Rediscover Its Voice
text: Julia Sokoloff, 14, woke up around 8 on Sunday morning and reached for her phone the way hard-core smokers reach for their cigarettes, before they’re even fully conscious. She sent a text, something about a play rehearsal, and then it hit her.

headline: A Better Chance at Justice for Abuse Victims
text: LAST week, Pope Benedict XVI told victims of sexual abuse by priests in Malta that the Catholic Church was doing all it could to investigate abuse accusations and find ways to safeguard children in the future. With the pope’s pledge, and the resignation in recent days of three European bishops involved in the sex abuse scandal, it might appear that the church is finally taking responsibility for failing to protect children against molesters for hundreds of years.

headline: Reed College’s President Is Told to Crack Down on Campus Drug Use
text: After the heroin overdose death of a Reed College student last month, law enforcement authorities in Portland, Ore., told Reed’s president, Colin Diver, to rein in drug use at his campus.

headline: Future Pope’s Role in Abuse Case Was Complex
text: VIENNA — As Pope Benedict XVI has come under scrutiny for his handling of sexual abuse cases, both his supporters and his critics have paid fresh attention to the way he responded to a sexual abuse scandal in Austria in the 1990s, one of the most damaging to confront the church in Europe.

headline: Breathing While Undocumented
text: I’m glad I’ve already seen the Grand Canyon.

headline: Army Officers Defend Units From Critics
text: WASHINGTON — Army officers on Monday defended a program intended to help service members with physical wounds and severe psychological trauma, saying recent criticism of the program by soldiers and their families was not representative.

headline: Home Tax Credit Called Successful, but Costly
text: Realtors, home buyers and sellers are rushing to complete sales agreements before the tax credit for home purchases expires this week.

headline: Instead of Falling, Sky Is Now Limit for the Mets
text: Chicken Little was taken out of context. He would have us believe that he did not say, “The sky is falling,” but rather, “The sky could still fall if certain things happen.”

headline: Noriega Extradited to France to Face Charges
text: MEXICO CITY — Two decades after United States troops invaded Panama and arrested Manuel Noriega, the country’s dictator, Mr. Noriega left federal prison in Miami on Monday and was extradited to France.

headline: A Dangerous Squabble
text: Among the Senate’s most important tasks this year are fashioning a rational, humane immigration policy and a rational, comprehensive energy policy to address climate change and oil dependency. Unless Lindsey Graham and Harry Reid can patch up a needless feud, the Senate could end up doing neither. That would be a terrible outcome, since nobody knows what the appetite for either task will be after the November elections.

headline: Is China Chortling at Senate Climate Stasis?
text: Senator John Kerry is trying to tamp down the advance obituaries on his effort, with two colleagues, to cobble a passable Senate energy and climate bill. He just listed three reasons for climate optimism on Talking Points Memo. The first was that he and Senators Joseph Lieberman and Lindsey Graham had invested enormous amounts of time and effort; the second, that a very variegated coalition (from oil companies to environmental groups) was behind the effort; and the third, that everyone recognized China would celebrate if the effort failed.

headline: Midwest Trip With Political Fortunes on the Line
text: MOUNT PLEASANT, Iowa — President Obama is making an appeal to the legions of new voters who sent him to the White House, imploring them to preserve the Democratic majority in Congress. But party leaders have an even more pressing wish: that he help himself before he helps his fellow Democrats.

headline: Listen to the Families
text: There are two tragic anniversaries this month. It is 11 years since two Colorado students gunned down 12 of their fellow classmates and one teacher at Columbine High School and three years since 32 students and faculty members were gunned down at Virginia Tech.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,384 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,036 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It has confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

headline: Tribal Genes and a Fair Settlement
text: A bitter seven-year legal struggle between an impoverished Indian tribe and scientists at Arizona State University reached a reasonable settlement when the university’s regents agreed to pay $700,000 and to collaborate on other forms of assistance dealing with health, education and economic development. Left unresolved was the underlying question of how scientists can best obtain “informed consent” from patients whose education and command of English may be limited.

headline: The First Amendment and Kittens
text: To anyone who has been following First Amendment jurisprudence in the past 40 or 50 years, the recent Supreme Court decision (United States v. Stevens, April 20) striking down a statute criminalizing the production and sale of videos depicting animal cruelty in a manner intended to satisfy a particular “sexual fetish” will come as no surprise.The proverbial ordinary citizen, however, may be surprised to learn that, according to Chief Justice John Roberts’ majority opinion, the First Amendment must be read to allow the production and dissemination of so called “crush videos,” videos (and I quote from Roberts’ opinion) that “feature the intentional torture and killing of helpless animals” often by women wearing high-heeled “spike” shoes who slowly “crush animals to death” while talking to them in “a kind of dominatrix patter” as they scream and squeal “in great pain.” How has it come to this?

headline: Pakistan's Power Crisis
text: Adam Ellick reports from Lahore, Pakistan, about the worst power shortages the country has been facing in decades.

headline: The White House’s G.O.P. Mainstay? Maybe Not
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Lindsey Graham makes no pretense about it. He wants to be where the action is.

headline: Computers Seized From Home of Blogger in iPhone Inquiry
text: Gawker Media said Monday that computers belonging to one of its editors, Jason Chen, were seized from his home on Friday in an apparent investigation into the sale of a next-generation Apple iPhone. Gawker suggested the action violated California’s shield law for journalists.

headline: View of the Sun
text: There has always been something miraculous about transmissions from space  those thin datastreams trickling toward Earth from research spacecraft. Over the years, the transmissions have grown more and more robust, richer in information, giving us dazzling and detailed panoramas of Saturn’s moons and rings and the surface of Mars. But there has never really been anything like the Solar Dynamics Observatory. Launched in mid-February, it is shipping a torrent of data our way from its orbit above the Sun.

headline: Q. & A. With United States Forward Charlie Davies
text: The American striker Charlie Davies fractured the tibia, fibula and femur in his right leg in a car accident last October. He broke his elbow, his nose and his eye socket. His bladder was lacerated and he had a serious head trauma. Doctors estimated a 6- to 12-month recovery period, which would have ruled out his participation in this summer’s World Cup. But after seven operations and more than six months of grueling physical rehabilitation, Davies is making a feverish, last-ditch effort to make the American team that will travel to South Africa. Last month, Jeffrey Marcus had several telephone conversations with Davies while he was at CERS, a sports rehabilitation center in Capbreton, France, and when he returned to Montbeliard and resumed training with his club team, Sochaux. Here are edited excerpts from those conversations.

headline: Russian Billionaire Is White Knight for the Nets
text: Mikhail D. Prokhorov has a net worth of $17.8 billion, enough to buy every team in the National Basketball Association, stock them with All-Stars and take them on a world tour aboard his 200-foot yacht.

headline: Pakistanis Living on Brink, and Often in the Dark
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — The Taliban may be plotting bombings, and the economy is on the brink. But these days, the single biggest woe tormenting Pakistanis is as basic as an electric light bulb.

headline: We Have Met the Enemy and He Is PowerPoint
text: WASHINGTON — Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the leader of American and NATO forces in Afghanistan, was shown a PowerPoint slide in Kabul last summer that was meant to portray the complexity of American military strategy, but looked more like a bowl of spaghetti.

headline: Off Wall St., Worries About Financial Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Mars, the maker of M&M’s and Snickers, wants to make sure it can continue dabbling in the derivatives market to protect the price of sugar and chocolate for its candies.

headline: Islamist Death Threats Aren’t a Cartoon Joke
text: Let’s see. A mobster warns that you will wind up like Paul Castellano, the crime boss who was gunned down outside a Midtown steakhouse in 1985. Maybe the guy is merely a blowhard. But maybe he is a sociopath. You’re not really sure. Either way, you’ve been handed a death threat. Shouldn’t you count on his being arrested?

headline: Words of Wisdom From the Mavericks’ Cuban
text: Mark Cuban, who bought the Dallas Mavericks in 2000, is one of the most passionate, outspoken and accessible owners in professional sports. He is a vivid example of how an owner’s personality can be just as important as his largesse. With the Russian billionaire Mikhail Prokhorov on the verge of taking control of the Nets, Cuban spoke about his insights on ownership.

headline: The Goldman Drama
text: Between 1997 and 2006, consumers, lenders and builders created a housing bubble, and pretty much the entire establishment missed it. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and the people who regulate them missed it. The big commercial banks and the people who regulate them missed it. The Federal Reserve missed it, as did the ratings agencies, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the political class in general.

headline: Howard Slims Down, Cashes In
text: The evolution of Ryan Howard’s game has been striking. To watch him against the Atlanta Braves last week – stretching to make a catch, diving to spear a sharp grounder, nimbly executing a flawless slide at the plate – was to see a player who has reinvented himself.

headline: Inspector Says He Faked Data in New York Building Tests
text: A safety inspector licensed to make critical assessments of asbestos and lead risks in buildings and at construction sites across the city made a stunning admission in federal court: Despite filing hundreds of reports saying his tests had found no danger, he had not performed a single one of the tests.

headline: Boozy, Bawdy Reality TV, With a Few Wrinkles
text: SURPRISE, Ariz.  “Pedal to the metal, baby!” shouted Joanne Hauncher, 63, as she swerved wildly through traffic on a busy street in this Phoenix suburb. A truck driver slammed on his brakes and stared  she was driving a golf cart, after all  as Ms. Hauncher completed an illegal U-turn.

headline: Dugout to Derby: Torre’s Interest Grows
text: Don Zimmer decided to sneak out to the racetrack one day in 1996 and asked Joe Torre if he wanted to come along. Torre could not get away, but he gave his longtime friend a few hundred dollars and asked Zimmer to invest it for him at the betting windows at Baltimore’s Pimlico Race Course. Zimmer must have had one of those days at the track where every horse he picked ran like a champion. Torre’s bankroll grew exponentially.

headline: In Wake of Immigration Law, Calls for an Economic Boycott of Arizona
text: A spreading call for an economic boycott of Arizona after its adoption of a tough immigration law that opponents consider racially discriminatory worried business leaders on Monday and angered the governor.

headline: Bloggingheads: Blame Wall Street!
text: Jesse Eisinger, left, of ProPublica and Mike Konczal of the Roosevelt Institute discuss responsibility for the housing crisis.

headline: Corrections
In Shake-Up, Principals May Get More Say Over What Is Taught
text: The schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, said Monday that he was reshuffling the top jobs at city’s Education Department headquarters and eliminating the division that oversees school curriculum and teacher training programs.

headline: Corrections
text: A listing of credits on Monday with a theater review of “Promises, Promises,” at the Broadway Theater, misstated the surname of the music coordinator. He is Howard Joines, not Jones.

headline: Brewing Coffee Again in Brooklyn After a Barista Walkout
text: Not until about 9:45 a.m. on Monday, the morning of its reopening, did Gorilla Coffee in Brooklyn begin to look a little like its old self. A few patrons lined up at the cash register, waiting for lattes and Balthazar pastries; a smattering of others sat at shiny red tables, tapping away at laptops.

headline: Street Weapon
text: “Obi-Wan Kenobi. Obi-Wan … Now, that’s a name I’ve not heard in a long time. A long time.”— 23 Across

headline: Democrats, Republicans and the Role of Government
text: To the Editor:

headline: Air Force Tanker Deal
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Storm Over Arizona and Immigrants
text: To the Editor:

headline: Preparing Our Teachers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Saving Mothers’ Lives
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections
text: THE ARTS

headline: A Crowd With Pity for Goldman
text: Beverly Hills, Calif.

headline: Belgium: King Accepts Government’s Resignation
text: The Belgian political crisis worsened on Monday when King Albert II, left, accepted the government’s resignation, tendered last Thursday, after negotiations failed to solve a dispute between Dutch- and French-speaking legislators over a bilingual voting district. The king asked Prime Minister Yves Leterme to continue in a caretaker capacity, since Belgium takes over the rotating presidency of the European Union on July 1. New elections are likely in the country, which is deeply divided between Dutch-speakers in the north and French-speakers in the south.

headline: West Bank: Israeli Forces Kill a Hamas Militant
text: A Hamas militant long wanted by Israel was killed Monday by Israeli forces in Beit Awwa, in the West Bank, according to the Israeli military and Hamas. The military said that forces surrounded a house where the militant, Ali Suweiti, was hiding, that he refused to surrender, and that he was killed in an exchange of fire. Israel said that Mr. Suweiti was responsible for several shootings, including one in which a border police officer was killed. Hamas issued a statement hailing its fighter as a martyr who had refused to surrender.

headline: G.M. Plans to Upgrade 5 Factories
text: DETROIT – General Motors plans to announce Tuesday that it will spend $890 million to retool five engine and component plants as the automaker uses its growing cash reserves to increase investment in new products.

headline: Mexico: 5 Arrested in the Killing of 7 Police Officers
text: Mexican soldiers have arrested five men who confessed to killing seven police officers last week in a brazen midday shooting in the border city of Ciudad Juárez, the authorities said Monday. The gunmen ambushed the officers on a main street, spraying a police pick-up truck with bullets. A 17-year-old civilian was also killed. The suspects, who said they were members of La Línea, the enforcement arm of the Juárez drug cartel, confessed to 36 other killings since the beginning of 2009, the Chihuahua State attorney general’s office said.

headline: Game 7 Arrives Against Red Wings, and Coyotes Hope to Stick Around
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  —  The Detroit Red Wings’ deep-seated tradition runs the gamut from Gordie Howe to Stanley Cup championships (11) to octopus-tossing to star-studded international rosters. The Phoenix Coyotes are famous mainly for going bankrupt a year ago and almost moving to Hamilton, Ontario.

headline: Bloomberg’s Bermuda
text: Neighbors and friends say Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is in Bermuda about twice a month, depending on the weather in Bermuda (no sun, no Bloomberg) and the political climate in New York.

headline: Confidence About Greek Debt Falters in Germany
text: BERLIN — Confidence in Greek assets sank to a new low on Monday, as Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany kept up the pressure on Greece, insisting on tougher austerity measures.

headline: Russia: American Seeks Denial of Visas to 60 Russian Officials
text: Senator Benjamin L. Cardin, Democrat of Maryland, asked the State Department on Monday to deny visas to 60 Russian officials who he said were involved in prosecuting and detaining Sergei L. Magnitsky, a 37-year-old lawyer who died in a Moscow jail after having requested medical care. Mr. Magnitsky was held in a tax evasion case against the Hermitage Fund, whose American-born owner had clashed bitterly with Russian officials. The sanctions would apply to senior officials in Russian law-enforcement agencies and their family members. The proposal is based on a 2004 presidential proclamation denying visas to people engaged in corruption.

headline: Somalia: Pirates Abandon Town as Insurgents Approach
text: Pirates based in the notorious pirate town of Xarardheere evacuated after Islamist insurgents took over a nearby coastal town late last week, officials and residents there said Monday. Residents said the pirates had all left and the town was now quiet. Last week, the Shabab, Somalia’s most powerful Islamist insurgent group, fought local clan militias in central Somalia, taking over several towns. At least 40 people have been reported killed, mainly from the warring groups. On Saturday, the Shabab looted a warehouse used by the United Nations World Food Program and distributed the food to the local residents, local news media reported.

headline: Italy: 31 Charged in Illegal Immigration Ring
text: Three months after violent race riots shook the Southern Italian city of Rosarno, Italian authorities on Monday broke up an illegal immigration ring in the area, arresting 31 people from Italy and North Africa and seizing 20 businesses and farmland valued at $13.3 million. Prosecutors in Calabria said that middlemen, most from North Africa, had procured immigrants for Italian landowners, who paid them wages as low as $33 a day to work in the fields. The arrests were not directly tied to the riots, in which about 50 people were wounded, but authorities said the illegal immigration ring contributed to the tensions in the area. In January, the police arrested eight people for inciting the riots, but human rights groups have criticized Italian authorities for not making more arrests.

headline: Setbacks in the Air Add to Lure of Virtual Meetings
text: TELECONFERENCING as an alternative to some business travel has gained traction as the air travel experience deteriorated in recent years. But last week, with European airspace shut down by volcanic ash, some companies that were already using teleconferencing found they could use it even more.

headline: Body of a Brooklyn Woman Who Vanished in 2008 Is Found
text: The authorities have identified skeletal remains found this month in a remote area of Pennsylvania as those of a 25-year-old Brooklyn woman who vanished in December 2008 after leaving a nightclub in Manhattan.

headline: City Is Held in Contempt on Loitering
text: In a blunt, 44-page critique, a federal judge in Manhattan held New York City in contempt of court on Monday for failing to comply with orders to stop enforcing loitering laws that were ruled unconstitutional about two decades ago.

headline: Yankees Take Celebration to Washington
text: WASHINGTON — In a room packed with politicians, baseball fans and some people who were both, President Obama welcomed the Yankees to the White House on Monday, congratulating them for being so good at making his life as a Chicago White Sox fan so miserable.

headline: City College Names a CUNY Alumna President
text: The board of trustees of the City University of New York on Monday named Lisa Staiano-Coico, the provost at Temple University, as the next president of City College, the oldest and most venerated in the CUNY system.

headline: After a Peek at the Police Dept., a Thanks With a Check
text: The chef Daniel Boulud was shown how to use a Taser gun. The television anchor Dan Rather joined in a search for a robber at a housing project. The media tycoon Barry Diller was assigned to the Police Department’s harbor unit.

headline: Railyards Deal May Still Be Weeks Away
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Related Companies, the real estate concern, appear to be weeks away from a final agreement on the long-delayed $15 billion redevelopment of the railyards on the Far West Side of Manhattan.

headline: Hospital Given Grant to Handle Some St. Vincent’s Patients
text: New York State on Monday awarded a $9.4 million grant to an Upper East Side hospital to run an urgent care center that would treat the minor emergencies of some patients displaced by the closing of St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village.

headline: Subway Worker Is Electrocuted
text: A subway maintenance supervisor was electrocuted early Monday morning while working on track repairs in the Rockaways, the first on-the-job death of a transit worker in three years.

headline: Smoothing the Way
text: People with disabilities never have an easy time traveling, but a rash of recent improvements, including more wheelchair-accessible taxis and rental vehicles — and even Web sites for people with dexterity or vision problems — have made it easier.

headline: Jury to Be Anonymous in Trial of Ex-Student Accused of Aiding Al Qaeda
text: When Syed Hashmi, a former Brooklyn College student charged with providing material support to Al Qaeda, goes on trial this week in Manhattan, the jury will be anonymous, a judge ruled on Monday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 26, 2010

headline: Alice Miller, Psychoanalyst, Dies at 87; Laid Human Problems to Parental Acts
text: Alice Miller, a psychoanalyst who repositioned the family as a locus of dysfunction with her theory that parental power and punishment lay at the root of nearly all human problems, died at her home in Provence on April 14. She was 87.

headline: Gene Lees, Jazz Critic and Historian, Dies at 82
text: Gene Lees, a prolific jazz critic and historian who approached his subject with a journalist’s rigor and an insider’s understanding, died on Thursday at his home in Ojai, Calif. He was 82.

headline: Judge Says 3 Can Bid at Newspaper Auction
text: A bankruptcy judge said on Monday that all three bids submitted for Philadelphia’s two newspapers were qualified to be included in Tuesday’s auction for the distressed company that owns them.

headline: Ernst & Young Is Added to a Lehman Lawsuit
text: Ernst & Young, the auditor for Lehman Brothers Holdings, was added as a defendant in a lawsuit seeking to recover money from former Lehman executives and underwriters for failing to disclose Repo 105 transactions.

headline: Burglary Suspect Dies, Apparently at His Own Hand
text: A burglary suspect apparently shot and killed himself on Monday night after fleeing police officers who exchanged fire with him outside a house in Brooklyn, the police said.

headline: In a World of Ads, Teaching the Young How to Read Them
text: A federal agency is undertaking an effort to school youngsters in the ways of Madison Avenue.

headline: Hertz to Acquire Dollar Thrifty
text: Hertz Global Holdings will buy the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group for $41 a share, the two rivals announced early Monday.

headline: Easing Conflicts One Episode at a Time
text: Many people subscribe to the notion that soccer can explain the world. In the view of FIFA executives, four major tournaments in 2009-10, culminating in the World Cup in South Africa beginning June 11, present the game as a unifying force.

headline: The Moment Nears
text: Update, May 17 | It is now possible to search the “Moment in Time” interactive gallery by the name given in the photographer’s credit line (actual name, pseudonym or screen name, as the contributor chose). You’ll find the search box in the upper right corner of the opening page. If you believe your picture wasn’t posted, we urge you to give this a try.

headline: Word of the Day | premonitory
text: premonitory •\pri-ˈmä-nə-ˌtȯr-e\• adjective

headline: Citi Field Is Playing to the Mets’ Strengths So Far
text: A year ago, when Mets players hit 49 home runs in the expansive dimensions of brand-new Citi Field, the possible solutions to the problem came thick and fast. Move the fences in, some said. Push home plate and the whole diamond forward 10 feet. Lower the walls, for goodness sake.

headline: Correction
text: An editorial on Sunday about faltering cancer studies incorrectly cited two figures for the number of patients participating annually in advanced clinical trials financed by the National Cancer Institute. There are more than 25,000 patients and 14,000 investigators.

text: When seven current and former employees of Goldman Sachs — Lloyd Blankfein, its chief executive, and Fabrice Tourre, a French trader at the firm, among them — appear before a Senate committee on Tuesday, there is a danger that the hearing will become consumed with grandstanding and headline-grabbing hectoring.

headline: News Quiz | April 27, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: A Crowd With Pity for Goldman
text: In Beverly Hills, at the gathering once known as the Predator’s Ball, the bankers, investors and analysts in attendance look at the Goldman Sachs scandal and feel not outrage, but sympathy, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.
