headline: We Have Met the Enemy and He Is PowerPoint
text: Elisabeth Bumiller has an amusing, yet serious, article in the NYT today about PowerPoint, the presentation tool which “has crept into the daily lives of military commanders and reached the level of near obsession.”

headline: Confidence About Greek Debt Falters in Germany
text: Confidence in Greek assets sank to a new low on Monday, as Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany kept up the pressure on Greece, insisting on tougher austerity measures, Judy Dempsey and Matthew Saltmarsh report in The New York Times.

headline: Noriega Arrives in France for Charges
text: PARIS – After a six year extradition battle, former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega arrived early Tuesday in France, where he was served with an international arrest warrant and is expected to face charges of laundering drug money.

headline: White Knight for the Nets
text: Mikhail D. Prokhorov has a net worth of $17.8 billion, enough to buy every team in the National Basketball Association, stock them with All-Stars and take them on a world tour aboard his 200-foot yacht, Howard Beck reports in The New York Times.

headline: Fakelaki, Rousfeti and the 4-4-2 System
text: Three terms associated with Greece’s culture of bribery.

headline: Goldman Faces New Mortgage Allegations
text: The legal storm buffeting Goldman Sachs intensified on Monday as Senate investigators claimed the Wall Street giant had devised not one but a series of complex deals to profit from the collapse of the home mortgage market.

headline: Pru Shareholder Might Kill AIA Takeover
text: Capital Research and Management, Prudential Plc‘s largest shareholder, could potentially scuttle the British insurer’s $35.5 billion takeover of Asian rival AIA, The Daily Telegraph reported Tuesday.

headline: Judge Says Three Can Bid at Newspaper Auction
text: A bankruptcy judge said on Monday that all three bids submitted for Philadelphia’s two newspapers were qualified to be included in Tuesday’s auction for the distressed company that owns them.

headline: Famous Faces in ‘Fences’
text: Since its Broadway debut on March 26, 1987, "Fences" has been August Wilson's most widely produced play. The roles of Troy Maxson; his friend Jim Bono; his wife, Rose; his sons Lyons and Cory; and his brother Gabriel have offered rich parts to black actors. Some have gone on to fame; others have played the same roles in various regional theaters; yet others, as they've gotten older, have moved from one role to another. "A whole army of people have cut their teeth on that work and are making a living in the business," said Lou Bellamy, artistic director and founder of the Penumbra Theater Company in St. Paul, Minn. (He has both played Troy and directed the drama.) "Where else is there a writer who allows black people to go deep," he said of Wilson, "and still stay black?" Following is a selective guide to some of the actors who've stepped into Wilson's Pittsburgh backyard.

headline: Rising Oil Price Benefits BP Earnings
text: LONDON  —  BP, the British oil company, said Tuesday that its profit more than doubled in the first quarter, helped by higher oil prices.

headline: Wind Project Is Crucial Step for U.S. Sector
text: More than 800 giant wind turbines spin off the coasts of Denmark, Britain and seven other European countries, generating enough electricity from strong ocean breezes to power hundreds of thousands of homes. But despite a decade of efforts, not a single offshore turbine has been built in the United States, The New York Times’s Tom Zeller Jr. writes.

headline: Deutsche Profit Up by a Third
text: Deutsche Bank, Germany’s largest bank, said Tuesday that its profit rose by a third in the first quarter of 2010, well above expectations, driven by a revival in investment banking, The New York Times’s Jack Ewing reported.

headline: Lehman and Barclays Start Trial Over Sale
text: Lawyers for Lehman Brothers and Barclays sparred in court on Monday as they began a trial over whether the British bank received an improper $11.2 billion windfall from its takeover of Lehman’s core United States brokerage firm in September 2008, Reuters reported.

headline: Credit Agricole Fund Eyes Japanese Properties
text: Credit Agricole‘s CLSA Capital Partners is looking to take advantage of declining prices in Tokyo by acquiring two to three properties through its $816 million Fudo Capital II real estate fund, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: C&C Planning Canadian I.P.O.
text: C&C Energy Canada is planning an initial public offering to raise about 165 million Canadian dollars, Bloomberg News reported. The group, which is exploring for oil in Colombia, is looking to hold the I.P.O. next month, the news service said, citing two people familiar with the transaction.

headline: Oracle C.E.O. Sets Up Prearranged Trading Plan
text: Oracle said Monday that Larry Ellison, its chief executive, set up a prearranged plan to sell up to 50 million shares — or about 4 percent of his stake in the company — over 10 months, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Indian Man Dies After Radiation Exposure
text: NEW DELHI — A man hospitalized for radiation exposure died Monday night from multiple organ failure, the first fatality stemming from a major case of radiation exposure earlier this month that forced authorities to temporarily cordon off an industrial area near the heart of the national capital.

headline: Calpers Looking to Win More Fee Cuts
text: Calpers, the biggest public pension fund in the United States, hopes to win fee cuts from other private equity firms following a deal it struck with Apollo to slice up to $125 million off fees, its chief investment officer said Monday, Reuters reported.

headline: SolarBridge Grabs $15 Million
text: From Camille Ricketts at VentureBeat

headline: Australia Suspends Emissions Trading Proposal
text: SYDNEY, Australia — After two years of deadlock, Prime Minister Kevin Rudd said on Tuesday that his Labor government had put its carbon emissions trading plan on hold. The proposed emissions trading system had aimed to cut Australia’s emissions by 5 percent of 2000 levels by 2020, while giving significant concessions to energy-intensive industries. The plan was twice rejected by a bloc of conservative and Green Party lawmakers in the Senate last year and faced almost certain defeat were it to go before Parliament again this year.

headline: Onward, Christian Investors: Church Index Is Born
text: The Stoxx Europe Christian Index, the first European Christian equity index, was launched on Monday, The Financial Times reported. The launch came as a response to increasing investor demand for so-called ethical stocks following the financial crisis, the newspaper said.

headline: Ousted Kyrgyz President Charged With Murder
text: MOSCOW — Kyrgyzstan’s new authorities have charged the country’s former president with mass murder in the deaths of scores of antigovernment protesters earlier this month, an official in the provisional government said Tuesday.

headline: Lloyds Swings Back to Profit, With Outlook High
text: The Lloyds Banking Group, one of several major lenders Britain was forced to rescue during the financial crisis, said Tuesday that it had swung back to profit because of improved trading and fewer provisions against bad debt.

headline: Hollywood Ending for the Hollywood Sign
text: The fate of an iconic Hollywood landmark was preserved on Monday with a $900,000 infusion from an iconic Hollywood playboy.

Torre owns a 10 percent stake in Homeboykris, who is trained by Rick Dutrow and is expected to be one of the longest shots in Saturday’s Kentucky Derby. Read the full article here.

text: Continuing bickering over how to calculate the share price in a potential stock-swap merger between United Airlines and Continental Airlines remains a sticky issue for the parties to resolve, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Bidding for Treasures in Paris
text: The auction rooms at the Hôtel Drouot in Paris date to 1852. They’ve been modernized since then, but the general atmosphere probably hasn’t changed much. On any day of the week, a throng of characters straight out of a Maupassant novel can be found bidding for dusty treasures straight out of the proverbial Old Curiosity Shop. Annually, about 800,000 lots pass through the 16 rooms, over the course of more than 3,000 auctions.

text: Emily Oster is an economics professor at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business. Rebecca Thornton is an economics professor at the University of Michigan.

headline: Jihua Boots Up I.P.O.
text: Jihua Group of China plans to raise up to 3.2 billion yuan ($469 million) from an initial public offering in Shanghai, Finance Asia reported. The Chinese regulator is set to study the application on April 28.

headline: DBS to Invest in Myo Fund
text: DBS is to invest up to $150 million in a new fund from Hong Kong-based Myo Capital. Reuters reported that the new fund would pick distressed debt in the Asia-Pacific region.

Smoke bombs were set off in the chamber. Glue was poured into voting machines. The legislative leader directed the session behind umbrellas held by his aides, to protect him from projectiles.

There are consequences when you target a whole people.” Dennis Herrera, the city attorney, also called for a boycott and pledged to have lawyers in his office work with the city to figure out how to break contracts with Arizona. [SF Weekly, The San Francisco Chronicle]

headline: Hip (Replacement) Hop: ‘Betty White Lines’
text: Apparently 80 is the new 20. It’s not only reality-television producers who are salivating over the retirement-age demographic these days: There are also some comedy nerds who are so excited about Betty White‘s coming stint as host of “Saturday Night Live,” slated for May 8, that they’ve produced their own rap video in tribute to the occasion. In the above clip, Frank DeCaro, Fredrick Ford and Jim Colucci — calling themselves the St. Olaf Glee Club — perform “Betty White Lines,” a hybrid of Grandmaster Melle Mel’s “White Lines (Don’t Do It)” and Ms. White’s work on shows like “The Golden Girls,” “The Mary Tyler Moore Show” and elsewhere.

text: Bidding on real estate assets of failed banks has become aggressive, as investors searching for distressed opportunities in the sector wait in vain for property to come to the market, Reuters reported.

headline: Russia and Norway Reach Accord on Barents Sea
text: OSLO — The leaders of Russia and Norway on Tuesday resolved a 40-year-old dispute over dividing the Barents Sea and part of the Arctic Ocean into clear economic zones extending to the edge of Europe’s northern continental shelf. The agreement could herald oil and natural gas exploration in a huge and potentially lucrative region.

headline: The Prepared Remarks of Goldman’s Tourre and Others

headline: Report Calls Zambia’s Prisons ‘Death Traps’
text: JOHANNESBURG — For punishment, inmates in Zambia’s prisons are commonly stripped naked and held in solitary confinement in small, windowless cells, sometimes for days on end, in ankle-to-calf-high water contaminated with their own excrement, according to a report released Tuesday by Human Rights Watch and two African human rights groups.

headline: House Prices, Though Higher Than Last Year, Are Weakening Again
text: Housing prices recorded their first annual increase in more than three years in February, but there was little cause for celebration as the monthly number again showed a decline.

headline: Alphabet Chic
text: In their nearly 20 years together, the graphic artists Michael Amzalag and Mathias Augustyniak — who go by the name M/M (Paris) — have designed more than 50 typefaces, from an alphabet built from the sliced-up photographs of 26 male models to the inky resin letter forms that spell out ‘‘Medulla’’ on the cover of Bjork’s 2004 album. Their latest, the Pradalphabet (above), was originally conceived as a temporary five-letter logotype for the house of Miuccia: Prada-M. (The M stands for Milano and M/M.) But the duo’s ideographic tendencies got the best of them, and in the end, M/M designed a whole alphabet of ornamented initials, each representing a hazy portrait of the Prada brand. ‘‘It’s like looking at a planet from afar,’’ says Augustyniak, who along with Amzalag spent up to six hours hand-drawing each letter. ‘‘You can see a continent, but it’s impossible to say what’s inside.’’ Examine the letters closely, however, and you’ll spot cleaning implements, Italian phrases, strange machines and a picture of two men standing on a balcony. (‘‘They’re inhabitants of the Prada world,’’ Amzalag says.) For now, they live in a collector’s edition of T-shirts, each silk-screened with a P, R, A, D or M and packaged in a cloth-bound box with a 64-page album describing the project. Other letters are available on demand at Prada stores worldwide.

headline: Militant Video Said to Show Abdulmutallab in Yemen Before Failed Jet Bombing
text: Updated | 12:16 p.m. Video obtained by a Yemeni journalist working for ABC News appears to show Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, a Nigerian who is charged with trying to bomb a jet over Detroit on Christmas Day, training in Yemen and making a martyrdom tape.

headline: Morning Line: Eyes Turn to Lookin at Lucky
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

headline: Panel’s Blunt Questions Put Goldman on Defensive
text: WASHINGTON — Even before the first question was leveled inside the Senate chamber, Tuesday was going to be uncomfortable for Goldman Sachs.

headline: M.I.A. Video for ‘Born Free’ Is Pulled From YouTube
text: 4:20 p.m. | Updated Within a day of its splashy and widely discussed debut on the Web, the video for M.I.A.‘s song “Born Free” was in some instances removed from YouTube and in some instances labeled with an age restriction. The video, made for the first single of M.I.A.’s coming album and directed by Romain Gavras, the son of Costa-Gavras, depicts an unspecified military force, with some members wearing American flags on their uniforms, rounding up red-headed men from an apartment complex and taking them to a desert to be tortured and executed.

headline: Best Inside Linebackers in N.F.L.: The Top 10 List
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -– but not strictly -– by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, though the future isn’t ignored. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: UAL Corporation Reports Smaller Quarterly Loss
text: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, on Tuesday posted a $92 million loss for the first quarter, almost a fifth of what it lost for the same quarter last year in the midst of the financial crisis, beating expectations.

headline: May the Trimmest Building Win
text: The Environmental Protection Agency has announced an energy efficiency contest to help buildings around the nation trim their consumption.

headline: Should You Pay $240 for an SD Card?
text: If you shoot a lot of video or snap huge amounts of RAW digital photos, you’ve probably heard about the SanDisk Ultra 64-gigabyte memory card. The card uses the new SDXC format, which will enable memory card makers to achieve huge capacities of up to 2 terabytes.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘Our Heroes Are Hurt’
text: Today’s poem, chosen from nearly 200 submissions to our Found Poem Student Challenge, comes from Melissa, who is 14 years old and lives in Lincoln, R.I.

headline: Fallon: ‘How Many Decision Points Do I Get?’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: George W. Bush’s memoir is coming out Nov. 9. On the cover, Bush is wearing a dark suit and holding a briefing book with his head slightly turned from the camera, or as Bush calls it, “posing all serious-like.”

headline: Tuesday Reading: More on Whether to Rent or Buy
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Cities Do It Better
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

headline: Letterman: ‘Honestly and Directly’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Former President Bush is writing his memoir. Writing his autobiography about his eight years in the White House. He’s not done with it yet, but he’s already put up the mission accomplished banner.

headline: Researchers Find Rare Giant Worm Doesn’t Live Up to Its Billing
text: HELENA, Mont.— Once feared extinct, the giant Palouse earthworm, reputed to grow up to three feet long and smell like lilies, has been found alive.

headline: Leno: ‘One Embarrassing Moment’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Last week, President Obama gave a speech in New York City about his plan to reform these rules on Wall Street, you know? And one embarrassing moment. When the head of Goldman Sachs was going through security, he was asked to empty his pockets and five Republican senators fell out.

headline: US Airways and United Post Narrower Quarterly Losses
text: The UAL Corporation, the parent company of United Airlines, and US Airways, which broke off merger talks last week, both reported narrower losses in the first quarter on Tuesday as an improving economy allowed airlines to raise fares and increase revenue.

headline: New Zealand Inoculates Itself for Bieber Fever
text: Please be advised that if you see Justin Bieber on his tour of the Southern Hemisphere, do not attempt to apprehend him yourself, as he may be adorable — and dangerous. One day after the seemingly harmless 16-year-old singer’s planned appearance at  Sydney Harbor in Australia led to pushing and shoving that forced the cancellation of the event, the authorities in New Zealand are taking no chances when Mr. Bieber brings his floppy hair and boyish pipes to their country on Wednesday.

headline: Not Pets, but Rescued and Returned
text: In a dimly lighted warehouse in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a handful of orphaned baby animals, no bigger than dormice, squinted and opened their tiny black eyes for the first time a week ago in cages the size of shoe boxes.

headline: Hikers: Can You Hear Me Now?
text: The next time you lace up your boots and head out for even an hour’s jaunt on a Bay Area trail, bring your cellphone. That’s the lesson that local park officials hope amblers will learn from the rescue of two Bay Area hikers on Friday night.

headline: Lessons in Tough Love at a Court for Truants
text: Trayvon Johnson stepped into one of New York’s newest courts the other day in East Harlem, nervously squeezing a balled-up tissue. So far, it was a familiar court scene.

headline: The Morning Skate: Habs and Halak Push Caps to Game 7
text: When a team has a chance to close out a playoff series on home ice and fails, that often signals trouble ahead. The Red Wings had a chance to dispose of the Coyotes in Game 6 at the Joe Louis Arena on Sunday, couldn’t do it, and now face a Game 7 in Phoenix. And anything can happen in a one-game series. Jeff Z. Klein has an article on that contest in Tuesday’s New York Times.

headline: When Spell-Check Can’t Help
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: When Spell-Check Can’t Help
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: In the Beginning, There Was the Word … A Word From Our Sponsor, Who Art in Heaven
text: Once, advertising by churches and religious organizations was seen only in local markets, particularly in so-called Bible Belt states. But in recent years, such marketing outreach has been increasing, as tens of millions of viewers noticed on Super Bowl Sunday in February when CBS broadcast a commercial from Focus on the Family.

headline: Graduate Students Ask N.Y.U. to Recognize Union
text: Graduate students who assist professors with teaching and research may not seem like typical workers, but more than 1,000 such assistants petitioned New York University on Monday to recognize a union that would represent their interests.

headline: Buy a House, Get a Ferrari F40
text: Three years ago, home sellers on the exclusive north side of Malibu, Calif., could incite bidding wars simply by opening their doors. In the current market, sweeping ocean vistas and the cachet of celebrity neighbors barely bring out the tire-kickers, let alone buyers with real offers. Recognizing this, one Malibu listing agent has hatched an incentive that commands considerably more curb appeal than any federal tax credit.

headline: How to Lower the Burden of Student Loans
text: President Obama recently signed legislation that changes the federal student loan program. The new law eliminates fees to private bank intermediaries, expands Pell grants and makes it easier for students who borrow money, starting in July 2014, to pay it back.

headline: Obama Tells Debt Commission ‘Everything Has to Be on the Table’
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama told his bipartisan debt commission on Tuesday that “everything has to be on the table,” while the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, suggested overhauling the nation’s tax code to raise more revenue.

headline: A Good Bad Week for Catholicism
text: Last Wednesday, the Vatican formally accepted the resignation of Bishop James Moriarty, the third Irish prelate to step down over his role in sex abuse cover-ups. The next day, a German bishop, Walter Mixa of Augsburg, offered his resignation over allegations that he’d been involved in physical abuse at an orphanage in the 1970s and ’80s. Then on Friday it was Belgium’s turn: The bishop of Brugges resigned after publicly admitting to having sexually abused a minor two decades ago. And over the weekend, Sweden’s lone Catholic bishop announced his willingness to resign over a woman’s claim that he’d failed to respond to an allegation of sex abuse against one of his diocese’s priests.

headline: Charter School Teachers Back Off From Union
text: Charter schools came under a harsh spotlight last week, with State Senator Bill Perkins holding his long-awaited hearing in an attempt to examine how the privately operated schools spend their public money. The hearings prompted several articles in the papers exploring potential conflicts of interest and other practices that have raised the ire of critics — and the issues are not limited to New York. And The New York Post took on Mr. Perkins with zeal in its editorial pages.

headline: China’s Motives on Climate and Energy
text: Mark Lynas, the author of “Six Degrees” and an adviser to the president of Maldives on climate policy, wrote in following my post yesterday touching on China’s stance in the entwined arenas of climate and energy policy:

headline: Goldman Shares Are Up as Executives Testify
text: Shares in Goldman Sachs were up slightly in morning trading on Tuesday, as current and former executives of the firm testify before a Senate panel investigating the financial crisis.

headline: Having ‘The Talk’ With Your Child
text: April is both National Child Abuse Prevention Month and Sexual Assault Awareness Month, and the twin subjects keep Sierra Black awake at night. A former journalist who now lives in the Boston area with her three children, she is also a rape survivor, and keeping her daughters safe from sexual violence is on her mind 12 months a year.

headline: Profile in Style | Kelly Wearstler
text: Kelly Wearstler’s life is as vibrant and busy as the rooms she creates. With her husband and sons Oliver, 7, and Elliott, 6; residences in Beverly Hills and Malibu, Calif.; and a business that takes her from Los Angeles to Anguilla to Paris in the space of a week, her only downtime is in the air. (Not a fan of flying, she travels with her good-luck charm, Franc, the stuffed bear that belonged to her grandmother and mother. She had him re-covered in linen since ‘‘his fur had been loved off,’’ and sewed on the buttons from her grandfather’s navy blazer to replace his eyes.) When she does escape, she says she likes places ‘‘where I can relax, but also go into a city and be inspired and shop. Otherwise I go stir crazy.’’ View interactive >>

headline: Cleaning-Products Companies’ Spat Puts Petals to the Metal
text: Remember the old song that starts, “Daisy, daisy, give me your answer do”? A couple of companies that market household cleaning products are looking for an answer as they duke it out over dueling daisies.

headline: ‘Squeakquel’ Breeds a Chipmunks Lawsuit
text: In more innocent days, when Alvin and the Chipmunks needed an authority figure to get something done they turned to a witch doctor. Now they go to their lawyers: The Hollywood Reporter said that the production company behind the Chipmunk characters and a relative of their creator are suing 20th Century Fox, saying that studio owes them half of the profits from last year’s hit film “Alvin & the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel.”

headline: Banyan Tree Opens Third Thai Hotel
text: Despite continuing political unrest in Thailand, Banyan Tree is expected to open its third resort in the country – this time on the island of Koh Samui — on July 15.

headline: Sting Sells Co-op on Central Park
text: A duplex apartment owned by Sting has just gone into contract.

headline: Living for Years With Late-Stage Cancer
text: Tuesday’s Cases column explores the world of late-stage cancer patients who don’t die. It’s written by Katherine Russell Rich, who was given two years to live after a diagnosis of stage IV breast cancer. She’s now on year 17.

headline: Standard & Poor’s Lowers Greek Debt Rating Sharply
text: Greece’s debt has been downgraded to noninvestment status by Standard & Poor’s amid mounting fear that the debt crisis in Europe is spiraling out of control, The Associated Press reported Tuesday.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Enron'
text: The director Rupert Goold narrates a look at  a scene from the new Broadway show.

headline: On Our Radar: Australia Shelves Carbon Trading Plan
text: A carbon emissions trading plan founders in the Australian Parliament.

headline: Why We Blame Our Parents
text: If you blame your parents for your problems, or even if you don’t, be sure to read this fascinating obituary of Alice Miller, a psychoanalyst whose focus on family dysfunction started it all. Her work alerted therapists to the problem of child abuse, but it also offered adults the opportunity to blame their difficulties in life on their upbringing.

headline: In Lawsuit on Adoption, Focus Is on Disclosure
text: Scores of complaints have been made in recent years against adoption agencies by people claiming they were inadequately informed or ill-prepared for problems their children turned out to have.

headline: Oh My Lady Gaga
text: A replacement for “Oh My God” (O.M.G) among China’s young Internet users.

headline: An Image in Tatters
text: Today’s Leading Off pays homage to the word-generating computer that Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger used to create his clearly from the heart apology to Steeler Nation in response to his six-game N.F.L. suspension for aggravated loutishness. If you missed his statement, so touchingly e-mailed to interested parties, the highlight quickly became a classic in robot-created poetry circles. Roethlisberger vowed he would “make the necessary improvements,” although he did not elaborate whether he could get that done at the same place he gets his oil changed.

headline: Democrats Take Aim at Romney as Wall Street Pal
text: Maybe the Democrats and their supporters have tired of painting Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican minority leader, as the villain in the financial regulatory debate. Or perhaps some of you, as readers and followers of the legislative impasse, have grown weary of the name-calling, too.

headline: China Moves to Tighten Data Controls
text: BEIJING — China is on the verge of requiring telecommunications companies and Internet service providers to halt and report leaks of what the government deems to be state secrets, the latest in a series of moves intended to strengthen the government’s control over private communications.

headline: TimesCast | April 27, 2010
text: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Tuesday.  Today's show is devoted to the battle for financial regulation in Washington.

headline: Words Worth
text: A graphic design primer.

headline: Eskendereya and the Racing Gods
text: Teresa Genaro writes regularly about New York racing at Brooklyn Backstretch.

headline: Hamas Prods Israel With Cartoon Threat
text: According to a Palestinian news agency, Mahmoud Zahar, a senior Hamas official, has criticized his party’s military wing for broadcasting an animated video on Sunday that implicitly threatens the life of Staff Sgt. Gilad Shalit, an Israeli soldier who has been held captive in Gaza since 2006, when he was seized in Israel, near its border with the Palestinian territory.

headline: Google’s Andy Rubin on Everything Android
text: Andy Rubin, a vice president for engineering at Google, leads one of the search giant’s most important efforts—the development of Android, Google’s open source platform for smartphones and other mobile devices.

headline: Citi Names Managing Director on Health Care Team
text: Citigroup has hired Jennifer Jarrett from Credit Suisse to join its global health care investment banking team as a managing director, according to an internal memo obtained by DealBook.

headline: Its Light Extinguished, a Canceled Soap Opera Sells Its Scenery
text: What happens to a long-running soap opera once it has been canceled, after all its characters have recovered from amnesia, reconciled their marriages and made amends with their evil twins who were recently revived from comas? It has to find new homes for all the props and set pieces it accumulated during its decades on the air.

headline: Full of Fight, Brown Still Lags With British Voters
text: ABOARD THE SOUTHAMPTON-LONDON TRAIN — In the newspapers, cataclysm was looming for Prime Minister Gordon Brown’s faltering Labour government. Cabinet ministers were reportedly scheming, squabbling and snapping “Shut up!” at one another in panicky strategy sessions. The question was not whether Labour would lose the election on May 6, but how thoroughly.

headline: Cosmetic Surgeries Get a Little Nip and Tuck
text: COSMETIC surgery wasn’t as popular in 2009 as it used to be, according to the American Society of Plastic Surgeons, which annually surveys its members as well as dermatologists and ear-nose-and-throat doctors.

headline: Color Fields | Beauty’s Brightest Hues
text: The photographer Eric Maillet takes a fresh look at this season’s makeup shades, turning blushes and shadows into brilliant works of art. View interactive >>

headline: Strict Abortion Measures Enacted in Oklahoma
text: HOUSTON — The Oklahoma Legislature voted Tuesday to override the governor’s vetoes of two abortion measures, one of which requires women to undergo an ultrasound and listen to a detailed description of the fetus before getting an abortion.

headline: ‘Like’ the N.H.L.? Share It With Friends
text: The N.H.L. recently announced a partnership with Facebook that would integrate various features from the popular social networking site into NHL.com. Visitors to the league site immediately noticed that they could now “like” teams and players and have that information shared with their Facebook friends.

headline: To Get the City’s Attention, Be Creative!
text: As Goldmanfreude continues in Washington, it seems a good time to highlight some ordinary, artistic, non-market-moving forms of local creativity floating around today.

headline: Senators Can’t Resist a Few Bad Words
text: Not once, not twice, but about eight times did Senator Carl Levin use a vulgar term during a Senate hearing today with Goldman Sachs executives — a term we can’t even partially spell out here, because of The Times’s  strict rules on proper language.

headline: How Close Should We Get to the Wild (and Vice Versa)?
text: Among the first items I heard after I turned on KCBS radio on Tuesday morning was one about a mountain lion. It had appeared, early Sunday morning, on the porch of a home about a half-mile from mine on the Peninsula.

headline: Learning About U.S. Immigration With The New York Times
text: Update: May 21, 2013

headline: A Genentech Eye Treatment Is Found to Help Prevent Vision Loss in Diabetics
text: The drug Lucentis can improve eyesight being lost to diabetes, researchers reported on Tuesday, a finding they hailed as a major advance in combating a common cause of blindness.

headline: Roll-Call Votes and Roulette: Times APIs
text: It’s been far too long since we last looked at some creative and instructive uses of Times APIs. Here’s a quick sampling of apps and tools that will help you explore Times APIs — and maybe even inspire you to build something of your own.

headline: After 44 Years, England Wonders if Its Time Is Now
text: LONDON — It has been reported that England’s national soccer team will sleep in special tents to prepare for the altitude in South Africa, site of the coming World Cup.

headline: Jordan to Play in Pro-Am, but Not With Woods
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – An answer arrived for at least one of the burning pre-tournament questions at the Quail Hollow Championship on Tuesday morning: yes, Michael Jordan will be playing in the Wednesday pro-am.

headline: Howard Going Hollywood?
text: Maybe there’s something about being an All-Star center for the Orlando Magic that sparks the desire to perform.

headline: On Climate Certainty and Climate Credibility
text: In 2003, Judith Curry, a climate researcher at the Georgia Institute of Technology, wrote the following passage in a submission to a federal effort aimed at charting how to reduce uncertainties in the science pointing to a growing human influence on climate:

headline: Judge Rejects Plea Deal on Guidant Heart Device
text: A federal judge in Minnesota on Tuesday rejected a plea agreement between the federal government and the Guidant Corporation, saying that the deal did not hold the company sufficiently accountable for an episode in which it sold potentially flawed heart defibrillators.

headline: In Shanghai, Hiding Bootlegs Before the World Visits
text: SHANGHAI — The latest mystery in Shanghai, complete with sliding bookshelves, secret passageways and contraband goods, is this: Why are all the popular DVDs and CDs missing from this city’s shops?

headline: College Students’ Transfer Rate Is About 1 in 3
text: Lost in the shuffle of university admission and graduation rates is a reality that those statistics often mask: about 1 in 3 students who enroll in either a four-year or two-year college will probably transfer  at some point. This, to me, is the takeaway statistic in a report issued Tuesday by the National Association for College Admission Counseling.

headline: For Summer Sentinels, a Firefly Count
text: I have fond childhood memories of counting fireflies on summer nights in Ohio.

headline: Car Sharing Expands to Nashville
text: WeCar, a car-sharing program operated by Enterprise Rent-A-Car, recently expanded into Nashville, where members can hop around town in a Nissan Cube for $8 an hour. The service, however, will have only four cars to share at first.

headline: Financial Tuneup: Consider a Flexible Spending Account
text: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, we’ve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

headline: Obsessions | Suction Without the Lipo
text: Having given birth almost a year ago, I now have modest hopes for a slim figure. Where I once aspired to look like the Olympian Dara Torres, I’m now hoping to resemble Oprah at one of her less zaftig junctures, like the pop-epic moment when she pulled the red wagon loaded with 67 pounds of fat onto the stage of her talk show while wearing those teeny-tiny jeans. To a certain weight-obsessed group of women, Oprah in her size-10 skinny jeans and black turtleneck was as important a sociocultural milestone as the landing on the moon.

headline: For $520 Million, AstraZeneca Settles Case Over Marketing of a Drug
text: AstraZeneca has completed a deal to pay $520 million to settle federal investigations into marketing practices for its blockbuster schizophrenia drug, Seroquel, the Attorney General, Eric Holder, said at a news conference Tuesday afternoon.

headline: Remembering the Last Act
text: Sally Mehl’s 75th birthday celebration was shaping up to be a major bash. All five children and six grandchildren would come to the small house in Roseland, N.J., where they’d grown up; the siblings were already parceling out responsibility for the food and the cake. Her daughter Ann would take Mrs. Mehl to the beauty shop for a wash-and-set. Even her cockapoo, Sarah, would be groomed in honor of the occasion.

headline: Federal Plaza, Manhattan, 12:25 P.M.
text: Protesters rallied at Federal Plaza near City Hall against the treatment of immigrants in Arizona.

headline: Lessons From the Icelandic Volcano Eruption
text: THE airlines use the phrase “irregular operations” to refer to travel disruptions caused by blizzards, power failures and thunderstorms. But what happened in the wake of the Icelandic volcano eruption was referred to by a different phrase: total chaos.

headline: In Monroe’s Own Handwriting, New Book Documents Search for ‘The Real Marilyn’
text: Some of the most personal correspondence that Marilyn Monroe wrote in her life, as well as the messages, both intimate and trivial, that she jotted for herself will be published for the first time in a book planned for the fall.

headline: War and Peace…In Sudan
text: We in journalism are pretty good at covering wars after they start. But we make a lousy early warning system about wars that are approaching on the horizon. That’s mostly because until people start shooting, there’s not much to write about or film; the prospect of war just isn’t very dramatic, especially in visual terms.

headline: TimesCast: Goldman Bankers Testify on Capitol Hill
text: Goldman Sachs is in the hot seat today, as former and current officials from the investment bank testified before a Senate panel that they did nothing wrong when marketing mortgage-based investments in the months before the global economic crisis.

headline: The Future — There’s an App for That
text: Lately, I’ve settled into a gloomy rut with my iPhone.

headline: Obama Makes Iowa Appeal
text: OTTUMWA, Iowa — President Obama, returning to the scene of one of his greatest political triumphs, appealed today to the Iowa voters who helped send him to the White House to keep Democrats in Congress come November.

headline: Do Gay Couples Give Up Their U.S. Citizenship?
text: American expatriates are having a more difficult time living and working abroad, a recent Times article found, causing a small but growing number of them to renounce their United States citizenship.

headline: Countdown Begins for Derby Horses
text: The majority of horses who are pointing to run in this year’s Kentucky Derby have completed their final workouts.

headline: Would You Pay $1.9 Million for This Business?
text: Some businesses have the power to capture the entire essence of a community, city or region. This working lobster wharf and restaurant, currently being offered for sale in a popular tourist destination on the coast of Maine, is a perfect example.

headline: Nelson’s Investment in Berkshire Hathaway
text: 5:50 p.m. | Updated Senator Ben Nelson, the Nebraska Democrat who switched sides this week to help block consideration of an overhaul of financial regulations, reported last year that he and his wife, Diane, owned up to $6 million in stock in the investment company run by the famed Nebraska investor Warren E. Buffett, who could be hurt by passage of the measure, records show.

headline: News Business Lags at High Schools, Too
text: This has been a bad month for statistics about newspapers. Monday brought new misery-by-the-numbers: Circulation figures showed a drop of 8.7 percent in weekday newspaper sales for the six months that ended March 31, compared with the same stretch of 2008 and 2009.

headline: Float Me Out to the Ballgame
text: In recent years, the Mets have urged fans to take the train to games to avoid the traffic jams and parking bottlenecks. Now, they can avoid both and take a boat instead.

headline: America’s Multiethnic Military
text: The French Foreign Legion is famous for taking recruits of any nationality and molding them into premier soldiers. If recruits complete the arduous training, they not only join the ranks of a prestigious military unit but also become French citizens. The United States  military has, in many ways, also adopted this method of immigration.

headline: Rolls-Royce and G.E. Cut Price to Build F-35 Engines
text: Fighting to save a significant contract, General Electric and Rolls-Royce said on Tuesday that they had once again cut their prices in an offer to build alternate engines for the Pentagon’s Joint Strike Fighter.

headline: Q&A: Miami on the Cheap
text: Q.

headline: Smith Calls Nuggets ‘Selfish’
text: So does guard J.R. Smith really think his Denver Nuggets teammates play “selfish” basketball?

headline: Tim Burton Retrospective Packed ‘Em In at MoMA
text: Evidently there are a lot of people in New York who identify with the forlorn Edward Scissorhands (and possibly with the murderous Sweeney Todd, too). The Museum of Modern Art said on Tuesday that its retrospective on Tim Burton, the filmmaker of “Edward Scissorhands,” “Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street” and “Alice in Wonderland,” drew the third-highest attendance of any exhibition in the museum’s history. During the run of the show, which opened on Nov. 22, 2009, and closed on Monday, 810,500 visitors went to see artifacts like Mr. Burton’s early illustrations and a prop of Sarah Jessica Parker‘s severed head from his movie “Mars Attacks!” (Additionally, 10,700 people attended ticketed screenings of Mr. Burton’s films as part of the exhibition.) Mr. Burton is now in the rarefied company of Picasso, whose 1980 retrospective at MoMA remains the museum’s most popular (with 976,800 visitors), and Matisse, whose 1992 retrospective is still the runner-up (with 940,000).

headline: Rubio Criticizes Arizona’s Immigration Law
text: WEST MIAMI, Fla. — While Marco Rubio said Tuesday that he sympathized with Arizona and its concern about crimes committed by illegal immigrants, he said provisions of the state’s new law that give the police more power to arrest immigrants go too far.

headline: Apple Buys Intrinsity, a Maker of Fast Chips
text: Apple wants the fastest chip for its mobile devices and has bought another chip maker to gain an edge over its competitors.

headline: Letters: Budget Bicycling
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Pushing Pedals, Not Budgets” (April 25): I spend winters on Maui, and this year we purchased bikes on Craigslist and sold them for the same price a few months later. The cost of flying my bike to the island or renting locally was prohibitive. The bikes needed a little T.L.C., and anticipating that, I brought a few tools along.

headline: LRB Panel: The Future of Reading
text: The writers on The London Review of Books’s panel “The Author in the Age of the Internet” this past Saturday might have been divided into two categories: those who know how to operate a portable electronic gadget, and those who don’t. In the “do” camp: James Wood (critic, novelist, subject of YouTube “finger drum” video) and John Lanchester (journalist, novelist, proud owner of new iPad). In the “don’t” camp: Colm Toibin (novelist, teacher, enthusiastic chronicler of gay chat-room culture), who claims such an aversion to phones, mobile or not, that he’s grateful that in the Age of the Internet, we have e-mail, which “doesn’t ring.” Also on the panel was Mary-Kay Wilmers, editor of the Review, and Nicholas Spice, publisher, who moderated. Neither was forthcoming about his or her gadget use, although there were some early, tricky moments having to do with a microphone.

headline: What Does Howard’s Deal Mean for Fielder?
text: Ryan Howard, a big and powerful National League All-Star first baseman, cashed in Monday by signing a five-year, $125 million contract extension with the Phillies. How will this affect Prince Fielder, the Brewers’ larger (270 pounds to 255 pounds) and just as powerful All-Star first baseman, who will potentially join a list of high-profile free-agent first basemen heading into the 2012 season?

headline: A Dust-Up in the Ukrainian Parliament
text: After a rowdy debate, the Ukrainian Parliament narrowly approved an agreement to allow Russia to extend a lease on a naval base in Ukrainian territory.

headline: A Divine Escape in ‘Sons of Perdition’
text: As former Mormons, Tyler Measom and Jennilyn Merten were naturally drawn to the subject of their new documentary playing at the Tribeca Film Festival, “Sons of Perdition.” The film follows three boys who escaped from a polygamist sect led by Warren S. Jeffs, the self-proclaimed prophet of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, which broke away from the mainstream Mormon church about a century ago.

headline: Facebook Stirs Privacy Concerns Again
text: Last week, Facebook’s move to provide “Instant Personalization” on partner Web sites stirred privacy concerns once again. But another related change is also being received poorly by some users.

headline: Travels With Gordon
text: It can be easy to forget, in all the excitement over the current election, that Britain is a small country that does things in a small way. Its election season is a paltry four weeks long, though it can sometimes stretch to six. The two main parties typically spend about 18 million pounds (not much more than $27 million) apiece on a national campaign (Labour, which has had trouble raising money this past year, is likely to spend considerably less this time around).

headline: The Golden Years: Feisty, Fit and Flirty
text: It’s not true that there are no old people on television, but they mostly stand out in ads that veer between extremes. The elderly are either vernally lithe, active and amorous (Cialis) or feeble home-care patients dependent on emergency alert systems and Exelon, an Alzheimer’s patch, to stave off undignified and agonizing deaths.

headline: On Patrol With the Reef Ranger
text: Gilbert Martínez has his work cut out for him. A reef ranger for the Belize Department of Fisheries, he spends his days patrolling a 87,000-acre Marine Protected Area called Glover’s Reef, an azure paradise of an atoll about 28 miles from the country’s mainland. I met him while reporting for an article in Tuesday’s Science Times about a reef-monitoring project in the atoll that is sponsored by the Bronx-based Wildlife Conservation Society.

headline: Malibu Wines
text: “If anybody said this was Malibu, you’d say they were crazy,” says Richard Hirsh, the millionaire clothier-turned-vintner standing in the vineyards of his Cielo Farms estate.

headline: Critic’s Notebook: New Orleans Dining
text: Four of the restaurants that embody the city and its post-Katrina comeback.

headline: A Familiar Voice in Unfamiliar Territory
text: The Garminfone, an Android phone with the full Garmin GPS features, will sound familiar to lots of people. Not because of Garmin’s nearly forgotten Nuviphone, but because of a new feature called Garmin Voice Studio, which allows you to replace the voice that gives you directions with that of anyone who will agree to be recorded.

headline: Met Opera Announces Principal Guest Conductor
text: The Metropolitan Opera, hobbled by the ailments to its maestro, James Levine, has moved to bolster its musical direction by appointing a principal guest conductor — only the second in its recent history.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: When we last left Sergei Supinsky of Agence France-Presse at the Ukrainian Parliament in early March, he was recording the departure of Yulia V. Tymoshenko from the chamber after a no-confidence vote removed her as prime minister. At the time, the scene seemed to reflect the best “peaceful transition” school of legislative behavior. On Tuesday, however, the scene was strikingly different. Mr. Supinsky (and Efrem Lukatsky and Genia Savilov) depicted members of parliament throwing punches, igniting smoke bombs, tossing eggs and abandoning decorum completely. Those of us who live in New York State could take momentary comfort.

headline: Want to Make an Impact? Join Jordan
text: Dear LeBron:

headline: Senators Ask Facebook for Privacy Fixes
text: 4:09 p.m. | Updated  Added a report from the senators’ meeting with Facebook executives.

headline: The Met Anoints a Guest Conductor
text: The Metropolitan Opera, hobbled by the ailments of its maestro, James Levine, has moved to bolster its musical direction by appointing a principal guest conductor, only the second in its recent history.

headline: Few, but Tanatalizing, Hints of United’s Deal Talks
text: During United Airlines‘ first-quarter earnings call on Tuesday, executives stayed tight-lipped about the company’s merger talks with Continental Airlines. (DealBook broke the news that the talks had hit a snag over the mechanics of a potential transaction.)

headline: Study Questions Number of Cyclists in New York
text: The Bloomberg administration has worked tirelessly to turn bicycling into a mainstream mode of getting around New York, creating more than 200 miles of bicycle-only lanes and placing protected bike paths on major thoroughfares like Broadway and Ninth Avenue.

headline: The Cohesion Crisis
text: Enough with the PIIGS, a totally unhelpful acronym. What we’re really seeing now is a crisis of the “cohesion countries” — the countries that entered the EU relatively poor, and for a time received substantial aid in the form of “cohesion funds”. (In Eurospeak, it’s important to know the difference between cohesion and convergence: cohesion means convergence in per capita GDP, while convergence means getting inflation rates in line so that monetary cohesion is possible. Get it?)

headline: Titans of Tangled Finances Kick Up Their Heels Again
text: In Lucy Prebble’s “Enron,” the flashy but labored economics lesson that opened on Tuesday night at the Broadhurst Theater, money doesn’t just talk. It sings. It dances. It puts on funny animal costumes. And of course it blows bubbles.

headline: Properties of $275,000
text: Properties in Pittsburgh, Cochiti Lake, N.M., and Baton Rouge, La.

headline: A Bank Tax as Insurance for Us All
text: Washington

headline: What You Get for $275,000
text: PITTSBURGH

headline: On a Hillside in Macao
text: A five-bedroom three-bath apartment in Macao is on the market for $1.42 million.

headline: Vegas for Budget Betters
text: New hotels in Las Vegas tend to target high rollers. But in these recessionary times, a string of old motels that are being rehabbed and rebranded are making a splash.

headline: A Change for American Némirovsky Translation
text: The English translation of “The Life of Irène Némirovsky,” by Olivier Philipponnat and Patrick Lienhardt, which arrives in bookstores next month is slightly different from the English translation of the biography that appeared in Britain.

headline: Waiting on a Derby Moment
text: In a “bucket list” moment, Julie June Stewart woke up at 4 a.m. and bought a ticket to the 2008 Belmont Stakes. She hasn’t stopped going to the races since — when she isn’t taking on a wildfire, hurricane or volcano as the nation’s leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

headline: In Budapest, a View of 'O Street'
text: Erik D'Amato and Janet Haven bought their 1,600-square-foot apartment in Budapest for around $100,000 in 2001.

headline: In Budapest, Uncovering Walled-Over History
text: BUDAPEST  The walled-over doorframe behind Erik D’Amato and Janet Haven’s bed  paired with another one at the other end of the apartment  hints that their home, as large as it might appear, must have originally been quite a bit bigger.

headline: House Hunting in ... China
text: A FIVE-BEDROOM THREE-BATH APARTMENT IN MACAO

headline: Conan O’Brien Will Appear on ’60 Minutes’ on Sunday
text: Conan O’Brien will break his post-NBC silence Sunday night when he gives his first interview about his departure from “The Tonight Show” to CBS’s “60 Minutes.”

headline: A Pointillist Tour, Revolution to Riots
text: If you’d like a status update on Britain’s tangled feelings about its neighbor France, you could do worse than study The Sunday Times of London’s current hardcover nonfiction best-seller list. At No. 9 is the book in front of us now: the British historian Graham Robb’s admiring “Parisians: An Adventure History of Paris.” More beloved by English readers, though, at No. 4, is a book by Stephen Clarke with this impish title: “1000 Years of Annoying the French.” Garçon, there’s some snark in my soup.

headline: Paterson Raises the Prospect of Furloughs
text: ALBANY — Gov. David A. Paterson said on Tuesday that he would seek legislative approval to begin furloughing state workers one day per week, saying that the refusal by their unions to reopen their contracts or accept other concessions on pay and benefits amid New York’s fiscal crisis left him little choice.

headline: Who’s Afraid of a Bank Tax?
text: You won’t be surprised to learn that Wall Street doesn’t like the idea of a bank tax. Wall Street lobbyists argue that a tax on banks — meant to discourage risky investments and cover the costs of financial crises — will keep banks from being able to lend to worthy borrowers. That’s not theoretically impossible, but it doesn’t seem very likely. The taxes under discussion would have a low rate. It’s also worth remembering that Wall Street’s lobbyists often claim that they are just looking out for the interests of borrowers.

headline: Summer’s Heat Breeds Love, Loathing and Darwinian Competition
text: “Man will only become better when you make him see what he is like,” Anton Chekhov wrote in one of his notebooks. Such a man emerges in “Anton Chekhov’s The Duel,” a very satisfying and tonally precise English-language adaptation of an 1891 Chekhov novella. Set in a seaside town in the Caucasus, where Europe meets Asia against stark mountain ranges and the blue of the sky as it melts into the darker sea, the story turns on a handful of Russians during a sweltering summer. Amid this small world, there are moments of comedy, dark sentiments, invocations of Tolstoy and a generous attitude toward human frailties.

headline: Henry Blanco, Cecil Fielder and Feats of Base Stealing
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.This past Saturday, Henry Blanco stole second base in the fifth inning for his first stolen base since 2001. It had been 522 games, 1,593 at-bats, 359 hits and 120 walks since he had stolen a base.

headline: This Bucolic Midwestern Town Is Friendly. Or Is It?
text: You should know where you stand on “Happy Town” just a few minutes into the pilot on Wednesday night. That’s when Tommy Conroy (Geoff Stults) gives his young daughter a speech pooh-poohing his wife’s notion of moving to California from their middle-American paradise in Minnesota.

headline: Los Angeles Times Adds Paid Links in Articles
text: The Los Angeles Times, which has pushed ad-edit boundaries with a number of print advertisements, began adding sponsored links within some online articles today.

headline: Republicans Reject Finance Bill Again, and Offer a Plan of Their Own
text: WASHINGTON — Republicans thwarted the Democrats’ efforts to overhaul financial regulation for a second day on Tuesday and floated an alternative proposal with some crucial differences in the regulation of consumer lending.

headline: Hints a Murder Suspect Had More Targets
text: On a sleepy Connecticut cul-de-sac on Monday morning, the police said a man drove up in a red minivan, armed with three handguns, 1,000 rounds of ammunition, Google maps and dossiers on three former colleagues — all of whom were involved in his dismissal from a Brooklyn hospital.

headline: A Hitchcock Dialogue, From Screen to Stage and Back
text: The first sign of changing times may have been when scenes started becoming shorter. Then projections, video and animation started flashing across stage walls, and live theater became less so. That the movies were radically altering the way plays are made was once a cause of concern. Now it’s just a fact, and in the experimental world, where the most sophisticated multimedia is done, it is fully embraced.

headline: Tim Burton a Hit at Moma
text: Evidently there are a lot of people in New York who identify with the forlorn Edward Scissorhands (and possibly with the murderous Sweeney Todd, too). The Museum of Modern Art said on Tuesday that its retrospective on Tim Burton, the filmmaker of “Alice in Wonderland” and others, drew the third-highest attendance of any exhibition in the museum’s history. During the run, which opened on Nov. 22 and closed on Monday, 810,500 visitors came to see artifacts like Mr. Burton’s early illustrations and a prop of Sarah Jessica Parker’s severed head from his movie “Mars Attacks!” Mr. Burton is now in the rarefied company of Picasso, whose 1980 retrospective at MoMA remains the museum’s all-time most popular (with 976,800 visitors), and Matisse, whose 1992 retrospective remains runner-up (with 940,000). Above, one work from the exhibition.

headline: M.I.A. Video Pulled From Youtube
text: Within a day of its widely discussed debut on the Web, the video for M.I.A.’s song “Born Free” has, in some instances, been removed from YouTube and in others labeled with an age restriction. The video, made for the first single of M.I.A.’s coming album and directed by Romain Gavras, the son of Costa-Gavras, depicts an unspecified military force, with some members wearing American flags on their uniforms, rounding up redheaded men from an apartment complex and taking them to a desert to be tortured and executed. In its community guidelines, YouTube says videos can be taken down from the site for violations like excessive violence, and can be flagged if users believe the videos violate these guidelines. YouTube declined to say if any versions of the M.I.A. video were taken down due to its violent content. The video is also posted on M.I.A.’s Web site, miauk.com.

headline: Title Match Remains Tied After Game 3 Is Drawn
text: An uneventful draw after the first two games of the match produced decisive results.

headline: A Soap Opera Sells Its Scenery
text: Soap opera fans will have a chance to own pieces of broadcasting history when the props of a long-lived and recently canceled television serial are sold at an auction on Saturday. The catch is that Procter & Gamble won’t give permission for the name of the soap opera to be used in the promotion of the auction. But here’s some guidance: the show was the longest-running scripted program in broadcasting history before CBS ran its final episode in September. Castners Auction & Appraisal Service will sell hundreds of items from  uh, that show  on Saturday at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The inventory is being sold by Props NYC, which is owned by Nicole Stiegelbauer. Her family’s scenery company, Stiegelbauer Associates, built sets for shows like “As the World Turns” and a certain other soap opera before the shows were canceled. “When you clean out a soundstage for a show that’s been in existence for 20, 30, 40 years, it’s levels upon levels of history that just all of a sudden unravel,” Ms. Stiegelbauer said. “You’re like, ‘What does one do?’ ” In this case the items will be gathered by the truckload at Building 10 at the Brooklyn Navy Yard; a preview will begin at 9 a.m. on Saturday with the sale starting at 11 a.m.

headline: ‘Squeakquel’ Breeds a Chipmunks Lawsuit
text: In more innocent days, when Alvin and the Chipmunks needed an authority figure to get something done, they turned to a witch doctor. Now they go to their lawyers. The Hollywood Reporter said that the production company behind the Chipmunk characters and a relative of their creator are suing 20th Century Fox, saying that studio owes them half of the profits from last year’s hit film “Alvin & the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel.” The lawsuit was filed in United States District Court in Los Angeles by Bagdasarian Productions and the writer Janice Karman, whose father-in-law, Ross Bagdasarian Sr., created the Chipmunks and originally provided the voice of their human caretaker, David Seville. The suit says Ms. Karman wrote a script for an “Alvin & the Chipmunks” sequel after the original 2007 film grossed more than $361 million worldwide, and though she never reached a deal with Fox on her compensation, she provided additional revisions after two other writers were hired to polish what Ms. Karman says was her draft. The plaintiffs say they are co-owners of the script to the “Squeakquel,” which grossed more than $442 million worldwide, and that Fox also breached a producers’ agreement. In a statement to The Hollywood Reporter, Fox said the claims were “completely without merit.”

headline: Art and Auction | Wines at the Whitney
text: On Wednesday, the worlds of wine collectors and art collectors will merge at the Whitney. There, they will bid on limited-edition bottles of 2007 Ornellaia with labels designed by Ghada Amer and Reza Farkhondeh to benefit the museum. The lot of 18 double-magnums with the phrase “Happily*Ever*After” spelled out among them is pretty, but the obvious keepers are the imperial (six-liter) bottles whose labels feature hand embroidery, and the salmanazar (nine-liter) bottle with its one-of-a-kind painted and embroidered canvas label signed by the artists. The question is: drink it or frame it?

headline: ‘Dancing’ Dominates
text: “Dancing With the Stars” dominated another Monday in the ratings as ABC earned its sixth consecutive victory on the night as the most-watched network. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 20.2 million viewers tuned in to a 90-minute installment of that dancing reality show. Fox ranked runner-up on the night with solid ratings for “House” at 8 (10.6 million) and “24” at 9 (9.2 million), while CBS placed third with a lineup of mostly all reruns. NBC was fourth. On Sunday night, the History Channel posted its best ratings ever as part one of its miniseries “America: The Story of Us” attracted 5.7 million viewers.

headline: Vietnamese Immigrants Carry on a Cajun Food Tradition
text: ATLANTA

headline: In Arkansas, They Brake for the Woodpeckers
text: Generally speaking, bird-watching is a pastime that is extremely interesting to a few people and not at all interesting to anyone else. But Scott Crocker has turned a bird-watching tale into a multilayered story that will fascinate practically everybody in “Ghost Bird,” a witty, wistful documentary about the supposed rediscovery in Arkansas of the ivory-billed woodpecker, a bird thought to have been extinct for decades.

headline: Kennedy Tribute Draws Star Narrators
text: With more than 240 credits among the three of them (but surprisingly only three Academy Awards), it was merely a matter of time before Robert De Niro, Morgan Freeman and Ed Harris found the right project to appear in together. In this case it is the debut performance of the multimedia work “The Dream Lives On: A Portrait of the Kennedy Brothers,” which will take place as part of the Boston Pops’ 125th anniversary season, the orchestra said. The work, which will have its premiere on May 18 at Symphony Hall in Boston, will feature the actors narrating as three of the Kennedy siblings: Mr. De Niro as John F. Kennedy, Mr. Harris as Robert F. Kennedy and Mr. Freeman as Edward M. Kennedy. The work, composed by Peter Boyer with lyrics by Lynn Ahrens, will receive additional performances May 19 through 22 and July 3 and 4. It will also be performed on July 18 at Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., with Alec Baldwin narrating, and on Aug. 1 at the Hyannis Village Green in Hyannis, Mass., where it will be narrated by Chris Cooper.

headline: Voters Spar With David Cameron
text: She may not end up becoming as famous as Joe the Plumber, but Chloe Green, a 19-year-old student who engaged in an impromptu televised debate with David Cameron, the leader of Britain’s Conservative Party, on Monday has earned herself the postmodern equivalent of 15 minutes of fame — her name is now a hash tag on Twitter.

headline: A Time to Play, in a Flashback to the ’70s Art World
text: Participatory art came to the Museum of Modern Art long before Marina Abramovic began her daylong vigils seated opposite one random museum visitor at a time. It arrived at least as early as 1970, with the interactive, sewn-canvas sculptures of a young German artist named Franz Erhard Walther. These works were included in the museum’s “Spaces” exhibition, a show of installations by five artists and one collective that was itself among the first of its kind.

headline: NBC Is Upfront About Returning to a Traditional Upfront
text: After two years of experimenting with different ways to woo advertisers and agencies ahead of the coming fall TV season, NBC is reassuring Madison Avenue that it is returning to the tried-and-true rituals of the so-called upfront week.

headline: In New Orleans, the Taste of a Comeback
text: NEW ORLEANS

headline: A Program Served With a Side of Wings
text: Dino Anagnost, the music director of the Little Orchestra Society, had some big programming ideas for his ensemble’s concert at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening. He had a theme and a title, two titles actually, yoked together: “Music Takes Flight — Airborne Symphonies.” He had plenty of music to choose from, particularly once he decided to look beyond the classical orchestral canon and include pieces like Robert Crawford’s “U.S. Air Force” — you remember it: “Off we go, into the wild blue yonder” — and Bill Conti’s theme for  “The Right Stuff.”

headline: ‘Epistemic Closure’? Those Are Fighting Words
text: It is hard to believe that a phrase as dry as “epistemic closure” could get anyone excited, but the term has sparked a heated argument among conservatives in recent weeks about their movement’s intellectual health.

headline: Sleep: Loss
text: I used to think that the only thing worse than having insomnia is having insomnia next to someone who falls fast asleep and stays soundlessly so till morning.

headline: Can Gizmodo Win the iPhone Legal Battle?
text: As we move into the second week of the iPhone-left-in-the-bar saga, the plot is moving from a technology news story to a legal one — and entering a cul-de-sac of speculation.

headline: Donatella Arpaia Is Putting Chef’s Whites Over Her Prada
text: CLICKETY-CLACK. Here was Donatella, coming through, charging into her new $2.5-million restaurant construction site. Donatella, nervelessly pushing past the yellow caution tape to traverse the splintery floor in nude-patent-leather four-inch Louboutins. Donatella, in short-short Prada silk. Donatella, pointing. Donatella, dishing. Donatella, certamente!

headline: Republicans Offer Alternative Financial Overhaul
text: Senate Republicans have put forward an alternative proposal to the Democratic bill to overhaul the nation’s financial regulations. A review of the 20-page summary of the proposal shows substantial differences from the Democratic measure, which has the support of the Obama administration.

headline: Will DreamWorks Animation Abandon Paramount?
text: Is DreamWorks Animation getting ready to drop Paramount as its distributor? Wall Street analysts have been chattering about the possibility, but Jeffrey Katzenberg, chief executive of the animation studio, poured cold water on the idea in a quarterly conference call on Tuesday.

headline: A Moment in Time: Strasburg at Class AA
text: READING, Pa. — A giant yellow duck cavorts around the field at First Energy Stadium right now, and a few hundred school children are clustered along the left-field line. Two men wearing “WaWa Fan-Cam” sweatshirts are scanning the stands behind the plate. There are picnic tables beyond the outfield wall, but no stands, just a vista of rolling green hills.

headline: Village Tart and the Spot Dessert Bar
text: GIVE Pichet Ong credit for his faith in dessert.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Rosé Roundup

headline: French-Style Fresh Cheese From Vermont
text: This French-style fresh cheese from Vermont is a little like fromage blanc, only richer. Originally from the Loire Valley, La Faisselle is made from fresh curds hand-ladled into molds that are perforated so extra whey can drain out. But it’s made from whole milk. Place it on a plate with some of the strawberries that are bound to hit the market soon and you have dessert.

headline: Striking Oil With Squash Seeds
text: Greg Woodworth and Kelly Coughlin were selling cookies in Geneva, N.Y. Peter Martin was a farmer processing butternut squash for supermarkets, with seeds to spare. Now, the three are producing Stony Brook butternut squash oil  golden and nutty, tasting slightly of sesame. They also have a delicata squash oil the color of raspberries, with a more floral flavor.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings:

headline: Argentina Opens the Tap for Malbec
text: FOR the last few years the wine business has been riddled with dire warnings and disastrous portents. In the United States and around the world, producers have struggled with the bad economy and the sluggish market. One slender segment, seemingly alone, has not only weathered the storm but also prospered: malbec from Argentina.

headline: Il Cantuccio Bakery Settles in Greenwich Village
text: Simone Bertini (above left), Lorenzo Palombo (above right) and Camilla Bottari, bakers from Prato, not far from Florence, Italy, found a space in Greenwich Village for Il Cantuccio, an American edition of their Tuscan bakery cafe. They renovated, but a fire last fall forced them to start again. They are finally open.

headline: A Fresh Batch of Spices for True Indian Flavors
text: I ENJOY cooking Indian food, though I never prepare it as often as I think I will. Not that it stops me from shopping for ingredients. When I make my annual pilgrimage to Kalustyan’s, the hub of international spices on Lexington Avenue near 28th Street, I tend to stockpile, ending up with so much Imperial Hot Curry Powder that by the time I get around to using it three years later, I could coat chicken nuggets with it and toddlers wouldn’t blink an eye.

headline: Stale-Bread Pizza
text: Adapted from Donatella Arpaia

headline: Getting the Big Picture From Phone Photos
text: The great thing about the phone camera is that it is almost always there when you need it.

headline: Republicans Block Bill Again, and Offer Their Plan
text: While most of Wall Street was focused on the Senate smackdown of Goldman Sachs on Tuesday, lawmakers in Washington continued their partisan wrangling over the financial regulatory bill.

headline: The Mark Restaurant by Jean-Georges
text: ONE of Jean-Georges Vongerichten’s newest ventures is a tangle of given names called the Mark Restaurant by Jean-Georges, in the Mark Hotel on East 77th Street. It lies behind a small bar filled with low-slung pony-skin chairs. Older men unsure of how they’re going to get out of them sit there, pondering the issue over vodka as cubs and cougars banter and text. Dinner seems unlikely.

headline: On the Mark
text: This week’s review is of Jean-Georges Vongerichten’s latest, at the Mark Hotel.

headline: Military Disputes Taliban on Korangal Valley Outpost
text: KABUL—Local people, some of them armed, have taken over the Korangal outpost, which was recently abandoned by the American military, according to residents of the area and Afghan officials. However, there is no indication that the Taliban are using the post as a fighting position despite boasts made on a satellite television channel.

headline: Do C.D.O.’s Have Social Value?
text: What do the Goldman hearings tell us about the risks of financial “innovations”?

headline: Senate Panel Will Get Some Ft. Hood Files
text: The Obama administration will allow a Senate panel to review the personnel file of the Army psychiatrist accused in the shooting that left 13 people dead at Fort Hood in Texas last November.

headline: E.P.A. Makes Its Case on Climate Change
text: Polls show that tackling climate change is a low priority for the American public. Indeed, a Yale poll found that only 12 percent of Americans were “very worried” about global warming.

headline: Top Chechen Ordered Abduction, Austria Says
text: Chechnya’s president, Ramzan A. Kadyrov, ordered the kidnapping of a Chechen whistle-blower in Vienna last year, in which the man was fatally shot, Austria’s counterterrorism department concluded after a yearlong investigation. The nation’s public prosecutor’s office released the news on Tuesday.

headline: A Little Danish Mermaid Comes Up for Air in China
text: COPENHAGEN — Some call it mermaid diplomacy; others, tongue in cheek, speak darkly of illicit trafficking in young women.

headline: Democrats Use Goldman to Push Bank Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — Politicians like nothing more than a convenient foil, and Democrats locked in a stubborn impasse with Republicans over new rules to govern Wall Street believe they have found a gold-plated one in Goldman Sachs.

headline: ‘Controlled Burn’ Considered for Gulf Oil Spill
text: With a vast oil slick now within only 20 miles of the ecologically fragile Louisiana coastline, Coast Guard officials said they were considering a “controlled burn” of the petroleum on the surface of the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Report Details Torture at Secret Baghdad Prison
text: BAGHDAD — The torture of Iraqi detainees at a secret prison in Baghdad was far more systematic and brutal than initially reported, Human Rights Watch reported on Tuesday.

headline: Russian Adoptees Get a Respite
text: Hundreds of adopted children, most of them Russian, travel to northwest Montana to find healing on Joyce Sterkel's Ranch for Kids.

headline: Sweep by Mets Puts Them in First Place
text: In the first game of a successful doubleheader Tuesday against the Los Angeles Dodgers, Johan Santana was what he usually has been: a determined, focused competitor who overcame adversity.

headline: A Frenzied Pace for Lawyer Behind Vatican Suits
text: ST. PAUL — Jeffrey R. Anderson, the lawyer whose pursuit of the Roman Catholic Church has been perhaps the loudest, is the center of his own tornado. As employees race in and out of his ornate offices, Mr. Anderson is planning a news conference in Los Angeles about an abusive priest, answering calls from the family of a victim of another from Florida, and preparing a lawsuit in Milwaukee naming the Vatican and the pope as defendants. And this is only a Monday.

headline: A Hip-Hop Contest to Promote a Brand
text: MAGNUM, the Trojan subbrand of large condoms, has climbed steadily from a 4.6 percent share of the condom market in 2001 to an 18.8 percent share today, according to the SymphonyIRI Group, a research firm whose data does not include Wal-Mart. What may strike some on Madison Avenue as more remarkable than that growth, however, is that although Trojan has been widely advertised, parent company Church & Dwight has never advertised Magnum specifically.

headline: Gamble Sours for Many Kentucky Horse Breeders
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — The for-sale signs on horse farms are as common as the bluegrass and the limestone fences here, and breeders have grown accustomed to sending horses through the auction ring and feeling fortunate when they fetch half of their asking price — or anything at all. The run-up to the Kentucky Derby is normally an exciting time for lawyers playing matchmaker between deep-pocketed clients and owners of can’t-miss stallion prospects.

headline: Live-Blogging the Senate Hearing on Goldman
text: Brendan Smialowski for The New York Times Lloyd. C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, looks through hundreds of pages of Senate exhibits.

headline: New York City’s Inspection Scandal
text: New Yorkers are rightly alarmed at the ease with which an inspector who was licensed to test buildings and construction sites for lead or asbestos risks got away with filing hundreds of false reports for at least a decade. The Bloomberg administration says reforms that were already in progress when the deception was uncovered will make it less likely to happen in the future.

headline: Europeans Fear Greek Debt Crisis Will Spread
text: As Greece inches closer to the brink of financial collapse, fear that the debt crisis will spread is engulfing Europe.

headline: Deep Thoughts Before Armageddon
text: Beginning any moment now, you’ll see a month-long trickle of news articles, op-eds and blog posts about the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty review conference, which gets underway in New York City this Monday and lasts through May 28. Since the fate of the world could hinge on stemming the spread of nuclear weapons, and this goal could in turn hinge on strengthening the treaty at these every-five-years review conferences, you may feel you should read much of this coverage. And your likely failure to do so may cause guilt feelings.

headline: What’s More Compromising Than Money?
text: The Supreme Court abdicated its responsibility to address fundamental questions of ethics and fairness when it declined to review the case of Charles Dean Hood, an inmate on death row in Texas.

headline: Wall Street Casino
text: Congressional Republicans have concluded that screaming foul about the banking bailout and blocking financial reform is a clever strategy for the fall elections.

headline: Goldman Sachs Faces Questions on Sale of Investments
text: Goldman Sachs officials met with confrontation and blunt questioning as senators from both parties challenged them over their aggressive marketing of mortgage investments at a time when the housing market was already starting to falter.

headline: For Some on Wall St., the Spectacle on TV Was Background Noise
text: Maybe it was the deepening debt crisis in Europe. Maybe it was the rare treat of a Mets-Dodgers doubleheader starting just before happy hour. Or maybe it was the lack of a “Holy cow” moment.

headline: Celebrating U.S. Future in Space, Hopefully
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — With rock music blaring, fifth graders count down from 10-9-8 to the rocket boosters’ firing up, and blasting the computer-generated astronauts toward space.

headline: Failure Is Not an Option
text: China is having a good week in America. Yes it is. I’d even suggest that there is some high-fiving going on in Beijing.
