I mean, wouldn’t you if you saw America’s Democratic and Republican leaders conspiring to ensure that America cedes the next great global industry  E.T., energy technology  to China?

headline: Getting Out
text: Nine Angus bulls are moving down the fence line in a pasture along Clear Creek, north central Wyoming. I can see only their backs, black and as powerfully angled as the mounded coal in the hopper cars running north to Montana. There is a man on horseback ahead of the bulls and another behind them. They turn the bulls, out onto the asphalt just at the highway crossroads.

headline: University of Washington President Named to Run N.C.A.A.
text: Mark A. Emmert, the president of the University of Washington, was named the president of the N.C.A.A. on Tuesday, concluding a seven-month search for the successor to Myles Brand, who died last September of pancreatic cancer.

headline: Laura Bush Opens Up About Crash
text: Laura Bush has finally opened up publicly about the mysterious car accident she had when she was 17, a crash that claimed the life of a high school friend on a dark country road in Midland, Tex.

headline: Korean Is First Woman to Scale 14 Highest Peaks
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Climbing on all fours after 13 grueling hours, a diminutive South Korean woman, Oh Eun-sun, reached the summit of one of the Himalayan giants on Tuesday to lay claim to being the first woman to scale the world’s 14 highest mountains.

headline: Power From Trash ...
text: IT’S been 25 years since the New York City Board of Estimate, under Mayor Edward Koch’s leadership, approved a plan to reduce the need for putting municipal garbage in landfills by developing facilities to burn it to create energy. At the same time, the city took the first steps toward creating a recycling program. Since then, disposal costs have risen faster than inflation, and the need to find better methods of getting rid of wastes is even greater.

headline: European Countries Are Cautioned to Be Even-Handed in Assisting Airlines
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union warned governments on Tuesday against lavishing emergency aid on airlines to make up for losses from disruptions caused by the volcano eruption in Iceland.

headline: Obama Sticks to a Deadline in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama approved a plan to withdraw combat forces from Iraq this summer, it was based on the assumption that a newly elected government would be in place by the time Americans headed home. Fourteen months later, that assumption is exploding but the plan remains the same.

headline: How Fans Can Do the Wave on the Way to the Ballgame
text: In recent years, the Mets have urged fans to take the train to games to avoid the traffic jams and parking bottlenecks. Now, fans can avoid both and take a boat instead.

headline: Immigration Issue Poses a Complex Test for 2 Parties
text: WASHINGTON — Senator John McCain of Arizona took to the Senate floor the other day to embrace a tough new Arizona law giving the police the authority to detain people they suspect are illegal immigrants. Mr. McCain, long an outspoken champion of giving illegal immigrants a path to citizenship, is facing a primary challenge this summer from a conservative who backs tough immigration measures.

headline: Olive Oil and Snake Oil
text: WASHINGTON

headline: ... And Sewage, Too
text: Leeds, England

headline: Talented Filly Had No Plans for Derby
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Much has been made about the filly Devil May Care’s running on Saturday in the 136th Kentucky Derby, but perhaps the reason she will be competing against the boys is that she would be running for second place in the Kentucky Oaks.

headline: Sharks Earn Chance to Fail Once Again
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — George Bernard Shaw never played professional hockey. But his quotation about his reputation growing with every failure could very well apply to the San Jose Sharks, a team renowned for its superb regular seasons and disastrous early playoff exits.

headline: E.U. Proposes Measures to Help Airlines After Ash
text: The European Union warned governments against lavishing aid on airlines but proposed measures to help after a week-long shutdown of travel. Read more.

headline: Lidge Says He’s Ready, and Praises Strasburg
text: READING, Pa. – Brad Lidge had been on the mound for the final out of the World Series, and Stephen Strasburg has never thrown a pitch in the major leagues. Yet when Lidge walked into a packed conference room down the right field line at FirstEnergy Stadium on Tuesday, he smiled and said, “Strasburg must’ve thrown tonight.”

headline: Citing Obesity of Children, County Bans Fast-Food Toys
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It was not a happy day for the Happy Meal.

headline: Bankers Remain Fans of E-Mail
text: Embarrassing e-mail messages aren’t new to Wall Street. After the dot-com bubble popped, star technology analysts were condemned for sending messages mocking the same stocks they had urged investors to buy.

headline: Nimbi
text: “I’m a little teapot,Short and stout …”

headline: The Spectrum Still Has a Hold
text: PHILADELPHIA — Reverently bathed in spotlights, its concrete walkways and stair steps kept tidy, its prim interior virtually untouched, the Spectrum looks as if it could reopen tomorrow, even though it played host to its last event six months ago and its future is doomed.

headline: A Surprise on Wall Street: Luxury Rentals May Benefit From Stabilization
text: Ben Rosen, a 23-year-old private equity analyst, never had second thoughts about moving into 37 Wall Street, a luxury Beaux-Arts building that houses a Tiffany store and sits among the country’s halls of financial might. It had all the amenities any titan in training might want.

headline: Despair Grows on Devastated Street in Haiti
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — More than 100 long days after the earthquake, Ginette Lemazor, her husband and their impish 5-year-old boy are still living in a filthy mechanics’ lot on Avenue Poupelard.

headline: On the Road With Gordon Brown
text: As Prime Minister Gordon Brown finished a day of campaigning on Monday, the man who might not lead Britain for much longer dismissed the alarming reports about his prospects as merely agitation by the news media.

headline: Here to Aid His Family, Left to Die on the Street
text: He persuaded his father to bless his departure from their poor village in the mountains of Guatemala by laying out a plan. He would go to New York, work hard and save enough money to buy his family a bigger piece of land.

headline: Oil Rig Blast Complicates Push for Energy and Climate Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The loss of life and the looming ecological catastrophe from the oil rig explosion in the Gulf of Mexico have piled political complications onto the push for energy and climate change legislation here, officials and interest groups say.

headline: Deutsche’s Profit Surges, but Forecasts Are Cautious
text: FRANKFURT — Deutsche Bank, the largest German bank, said on Tuesday that its profit rose by a third in the first quarter of 2010, well above expectations, driven by a revival in investment banking.

headline: Agency Owes Millions to City, an Audit Finds
text: The agency responsible for economic development under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has failed to turn over to the city more than $125 million in payments, taxes and fees, according to an audit conducted by the city comptroller to be released on Wednesday.

headline: Allen Swift, Voice Actor for Radio and TV, Dies at 86
text: Allen Swift, the voice of Mighty Mouse, Dinky Duck and, for a brief period, Howdy Doody, not to mention an Eveready battery, a toilet plunger for Drano, Vita’s Beloved Herring Maven and other characters both human and inanimate in more than 30,000 television and radio commercials, died on April 18 at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: A Law Facing a Tough Road Through the Courts
text: Can Arizona’s controversial new immigration law — allowing the police to stop people and demand proof of citizenship — pass constitutional muster?

headline: Museum Board Member Caught in Russian Intrigue
text: Since joining the board of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation three years ago, Janna Bullock, a Russian-born real estate developer, has been a frequent and glamorous presence on the circuit of art fairs, galas and biennials. She has sponsored art exhibitions in Venice and Miami, socialized with artists and collectors and even taken a motorcycle trip from St. Petersburg to Moscow with the actors Dennis Hopper and Jeremy Irons and Thomas Krens, the former Guggenheim director.

headline: Elizabeth Post of the Etiquette Family Dies at 89
text: Elizabeth L. Post, who succeeded her grandmother-in-law, Emily Post, as the doyenne of etiquette in repeated editions of Emily’s celebrated advice book, died Saturday in Naples, Fla.

headline: U.S. Begins Inquiry on Spy Network in Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has opened an inquiry into whether a top Defense Department official violated Pentagon rules by setting up a network of private contractors to gather intelligence in Pakistan and Afghanistan.

headline: Paying for the Sins of the Fathers, and of Others, Too
text: Should it be possible to sue the city of New York for sexual abuse by public school teachers that happened decades ago? How about doctors or hospital attendants? Police officers? Welfare workers? Playground attendants?

headline: Fleeting Glimpses of a Rising Star and His Fastball
text: READING, Pa.

headline: Yanks Turn the Capital a Bit More Bipartisan
text: BALTIMORE — For devoted Yankees fans like the Supreme Court Justices Sonia Sotomayor and Antonin Scalia, posing for photographs Tuesday with the World Series championship trophy must have been a thrill. For a devoted Red Sox fan like Justice Stephen Breyer, seeing the trophy might have been agonizing.

headline: Mavericks Force Game 6; Celtics and Cavaliers Clinch
text: DALLAS — The first member of the Dallas Mavericks to break a sweat Tuesday night was the owner. Mark Cuban was climbing virtual stairs and breathlessly batting away doubts about his team’s flagging playoff fortunes.

headline: Sudan’s Future Is Now, U.S. Envoy Says
text: WASHINGTON — A day after Sudan’s leader coasted to victory in a fraud-tainted election, a senior Obama administration official defended the vote, and said the United States should turn its attention to getting southern Sudan ready for its likely future as an independent state.

headline: Authorities Vow to Close Mines Found to Be Unsafe
text: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators told Congress on Tuesday that they would become more aggressive in enforcing mine safety laws, vowing to close mines with repeated safety violations and shut down sections of mines when inspectors find serious violations.

headline: Study Finds Young Hispanics Face Obstacles to Integration
text: A snapshot of Hispanic youngsters — the fastest-growing group in the United States by age and ethnicity — concludes that the obstacles and inequalities they face today “may hinder the broader integration of Latinos into U.S. society if left unattended.”

headline: Pace of Planning for East Jerusalem Projects Slows
text: JERUSALEM — After a recent spike in Israeli-American tensions over Israeli building plans for Jewish housing in contested East Jerusalem, there appears to have been a lull in the planning process.

headline: Russian Plan to Bolster Security Agency Evokes K.G.B.’s Powers
text: MOSCOW — Russian lawmakers are considering extending new powers to the F.S.B., the successor to the Soviet-era K.G.B., allowing its officers to summon citizens and issue verbal or written warnings that their activities are “unacceptable” and leading toward a crime, even if no violation has occurred.

headline: Arthur Winograd, Hartford Symphony Music Director, Dies at 90
text: Arthur Winograd, the founding cellist of the Juilliard String Quartet and later the longtime music director of the Hartford Symphony Orchestra, died in Morristown, N.J., on Thursday, his 90th birthday.

headline: In Greeting Iowa Voters, Obama Focuses on Finances
text: OTTUMWA, Iowa — President Obama strongly criticized Senate Republicans on Tuesday for blocking proposed legislation to tighten regulation of the financial system, vowing that he would “not let this effort fall victim to industry lobbyists who want to kill it.”

headline: Trailing Disasters: Savings, but at What Price?
text: In the past two months, political demonstrations have gripped the streets of Bangkok. Tens of thousands of supporters of  former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra — the so-called red shirts  —  have shut down parts of the city, forcing cancellation of an Association of Southeast Asian Nations meeting and prompting security responses that have resulted in the deaths of at least two dozen people.

headline: Devils’ Move Paying Off for Team, and Newark
text: NEWARK — An hour before a recent playoff game, Jeff Vanderbeek, chairman of the Devils, was mobbed as he gave away red towels to fans at the train station, a short walk from the team’s home, Prudential Center.

headline: Corrections
text: A television column on March 19 about “Breaking Bad,” on AMC, misstated the length of the character Jesse’s stay at a rehabilitation center. He leaves at the end of the season’s first episode; he is not there for the first few episodes. The error was pointed out in an e-mail message from a reader the day the column appeared; this correction was delayed for research.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: How Bombing Case Helped Shape Career of a Potential Justice
text: WASHINGTON — Days after a huge bomb killed 168 people in Oklahoma City in April 1995, Merrick B. Garland was on the ground even as bodies were still being recovered, examining the crime scene and preparing for an eventual prosecution.

headline: Profiting From Low Interest Rates
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Goldman Deal and the Housing Market
text: To the Editor:

headline: Dorothy Height and an Apology From Barnard
text: To the Editor:

headline: Inside the Units Treating War Trauma
text: To the Editor:

headline: Found Alive: The Loch Ness Monster of the Northwest Prairie. Alas, It Disappoints
text: HELENA, Mont.— Once feared extinct, the giant Palouse earthworm, reputed to grow up to three feet long and smell like lilies, has been found alive.

headline: Ex-Official Is Criticized for Misusing State Workers
text: ALBANY — When Lee Kyriacou left a financial-services consulting firm to become the director of a small state agency in 2007, he had certain expectations of his staff that did not go over very well.

headline: In New Jersey, a Civics Lesson in the Internet Age
text: It was a silent call to arms: an easy-to-overlook message urging New Jersey students to take a stand against the budget cuts that threaten class sizes and choices as well as after-school activities. But some 18,000 students accepted the invitation posted last month on Facebook, the social media site better known for publicizing parties and sporting events. And on Tuesday many of them — and many others — walked out of class in one of the largest grass-roots demonstrations to hit New Jersey in years.

headline: Thomas H. Connell III, Longtime Met Stage Manager, Dies at 67
text: It wasn’t so much the extraordinary that kept Thomas H. Connell III on his toes — not the singing horse or the stumbling soldier or the curious incident of the dog,  “Falstaff”  and the beckoning tree stump. It was the routine things — the fire-breathing dragons, the indoor blizzards, Valhalla collapsing in flames as the Rhine overflows — that night after night were the truest tests of his skill.

headline: Just Vazquez’s Luck
text: BALTIMORE – The way things are going for Javier Vazquez, this had to happen: A wicked liner off the bat of Nick Markakis zoomed into the Yankees’ dugout in the fifth inning Tuesday night. Vazquez was quick enough to avoid sustaining a direct hit, but the ball caromed off the back wall and struck him in the side. If it had nailed him on the fly, Vazquez said it really would have stung.

headline: Robert Natkin, Abstract Painter, Is Dead at 79
text: Robert Natkin, a painter who rose to prominence in the late 1960s and 1970s with work that blended Abstraction with Post-Impressionist colors, died on April 20 in Danbury, Conn. He was 79 and lived in Redding, Conn.

headline: Laura Bush Writes About Fatal Car Crash
text: The Times’s Anahad O’Connor reports how Laura Bush, in her new autobiography, finally opens up about the car crash she was involved in that took the life of a friend when she was a teenager. A copy of the book, Spoken From the Heart, which is to be released in early May, was obtained by The Times at a book store.

headline: Orioles’ Long Road Eases for One Night Against Yankees
text: BALTIMORE — The Orioles, like every team, were full of optimism and good cheer three weeks ago. If their rotation thrived, their bullpen performed and their lineup produced, they would have a good season. They could finish in fourth place.

headline: Two Convicted of Denying Access to Abortion Clinic
text: For the first time in New York City, federal prosecutors have used the Freedom of Access to Clinics Entrances Act to secure a conviction in a case where access was blocked to a clinic that provides abortions.

headline: Community Pacts Questioned in the Zoning Process
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg suffered an embarrassment last December when the City Council rejected a major developer’s plan to spend hundreds of millions of dollars transforming an unused armory in the Bronx, the city’s poorest borough, into a shopping mall.

headline: Laura Bush Writes About Fatal Car Crash
text: The Times’s Anahad O’Connor reports that Laura Bush, in her new autobiography, finally opens up about the car crash she was involved in that took the life of a friend when she was a teenager. A copy of the book, “Spoken From the Heart,” which is to be released in early May, was obtained by The Times at a bookstore.

headline: Connecticut Quadruplets Will Attend Yale
text: After each received an offer of early acceptance to Yale last fall, the Crouch quadruplets of Danbury, Conn., went on to collect letters of admission this spring from more than a dozen other colleges.

headline: Grand Makeover Is Set for Maryland Strip City
text: ROCKVILLE, Md. — Over the last century, Rockville Pike in Montgomery County, Md., has grown, unfettered and unplanned, into a sprawling strip city — a hodge-podge of shopping centers, parking lots and gridlocked traffic that frustrates motorists and discourages pedestrians.

headline: Kim to Have Thumb Operation
text: Anthony Kim and his management team will decide soon when to have the detached ligament in his left thumb surgically repaired. Kim, coming off a victory at the Shell Houston Open and a third-place finish at the Masters in his last two outings, said he would have the operation and was prepared to skip major championships to be ready for the Ryder Cup in September.

headline: Ex-Brooklyn College Student Admits Conspiring to Help Al Qaeda
text: In a widely watched terrorism case, a former Brooklyn College student admitted in court on Tuesday that he had conspired to provide Al Qaeda with what prosecutors described as military gear.

headline: Afghanistan: U.N. Pulls Workers
text: The United Nations withdrew most of its local staff members from Kandahar on Tuesday and instructed its local Afghan employees there to stay home in the coming days because of what it called the “deteriorating” security situation in the southern city, a spokeswoman said. The United Nations is often a bellwether of the level of insecurity, and the decision forced it to effectively suspend its operations, said Susan Manuel, the organization’s spokeswoman in Kabul. “We hope it will be temporary,” she said. There are about 200 United Nations employees in Kandahar.

headline: Margherita, Primavera, Siciliana e Viola
text: Jeannie Oliver-Cretara introduces herself in the fourth installment of Ozier Muhammad’s series, “Sounds From Uncommon Spaces.” Her remarks, to Mr. Muhammad, were condensed and edited for brevity and clarity.

headline: Egypt: New Trial in Singer’s Death
text: The retrial of a real estate mogul and former legislator, whose death sentence for the murder of a Lebanese pop diva was thrown out last month by Egypt’s highest court, opened this week under heavy security. The mogul, Hisham Talaat Moustafa, and his co-defendant, Mohsen al-Sukari, a retired police officer, pleaded not guilty on Monday, state media reported. Mr. Moustafa is accused of paying millions of dollars to Mr. Sukari to stab the 30-year-old singer, Suzanne Tamim, who was found dead in her Dubai apartment in July 2008.

headline: First Defendant’s Trial in 2007 Newark Triple Murder Begins
text: NEWARK — Nearly three years later, this city on Tuesday began to relive one of the most notorious crimes in its recent history, as the first of six defendants went on trial in the execution-style murders of three students in a schoolyard on a summer night.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 27, 2010

headline: A Bad Hughes Is Still Pretty Good
text: BALTIMORE – When Phil Hughes struggled in this very ballpark last May, he faced 16 batters and allowed eight of them to score. When Hughes struggled at Camden Yards on Tuesday night, he gave up one run and two hits in five and two-thirds innings.

headline: Iran: Opposition Calls for Protests
text: The Iranian opposition leaders Mehdi Karroubi and Mir Hussein Moussavi called Monday for protests on June 12 to observe the anniversary of last year’s presidential election, which they say was marred by widespread fraud. It was the first public call for protests by the leading opposition figures in months. The two men also deplored the government’s economic policies, imprisonment of reformists and what they said was corruption by the vice president. “These acts are anti-Islamic,” Mr. Moussavi said. He added, “I truly don’t understand how they will answer to God.”

headline: Argentina: Pardons Overturned
text: The Supreme Court overturned pardons of a dictatorship-era president and economy minister on Tuesday, paving the way for them to be tried for kidnapping and extortion. Former President Jorge Videla, left, and his economy minister, José Martínez de Hoz, are accused of detaining Federico Gutheim, a textile merchant, and his son Miguel for five months in 1976 and 1977 to force them to settle a trade dispute. The court upheld a lower-court ruling that the pardons were unconstitutional.

headline: Doctors Raise Questions About St. Vincent’s Plan
text: New York State’s decision to pick Lenox Hill Hospital to run the new urgent care center at St. Vincent’s Hospital was a curious choice, some doctors said on Tuesday, if only because Lenox Hill is on the Upper East Side, while St. Vincent’s is in Greenwich Village.

headline: China Lifts Ban on Visitors Who Are H.I.V. Positive
text: BEIJING — Days before travelers worldwide are to begin arriving for Shanghai’s world exposition, China has lifted a two-decade ban on travel to the country by people who carry the virus that causes AIDS or who have other sexually transmitted diseases.

headline: Brooks: The Goldman Drama
text: Between 1997 and 2006, consumers, lenders and builders created a housing bubble, and pretty much the entire establishment missed it. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and the people who regulate them missed it. The big commercial banks and the people who regulate them missed it. The Federal Reserve missed it, as did the ratings agencies, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the political class in general.

headline: How Much Are You Influenced by Advertising?
text: A federal agency is trying to teach young people about how advertising works “so they can make better, more informed choices when they shop,” according to an article from the Business section. Do you think you or your peers need to learn more about how advertisers persuade? How often do you buy things in response to an ad? Do you think advertising influences you in ways you aren’t aware of?

headline: News Quiz | April 28, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Europeans Fear Greek Debt Crisis Will Spread
text: As Greece inches closer to the brink of financial collapse, fear that the debt crisis will spread is engulfing Europe.

headline: Lakers Start Fast and Finish Strong
text: LOS ANGELES — When the Lakers returned home from Oklahoma City in a position they did not expect to be in, a series that was all even, it turned out they were not the only ones in for an attitude adjustment.

headline: Democrats Use Goldman to Push Bank Bill
text: Politicians like nothing more than a convenient foil, and Democrats locked in a stubborn impasse with Republicans over new rules to govern Wall Street believe they have found a gold-plated one in Goldman Sachs, Carl Hulse reports in The New York Times.

headline: Leonhardt: Bank Tax as Insurance for Us All
text: The financial regulation bill before the Senate has the potential to do a lot of good. But it also has at least one major flaw: it would not do enough to prevent taxpayers from paying the bill for a future crisis, David Leonhardt writes in his latest column for The New York Times.

headline: Panel Assails Goldman; Greek Fears Seize European Union
text: Even before the first question was leveled inside the Senate chamber, Tuesday was going to be uncomfortable for Goldman Sachs.

headline: In Rare Road Game 7, Red Wings Rout Coyotes
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — The proud legacy of the Detroit Red Wings is safe.

headline: I.M.F. Promises More Aid for Greece as European Crisis Grows
text: Hoping to quell its biggest crisis since the Asian woes of 1997, the International Monetary Fund promised on Wednesday to increase the 45 billion-euro aid package for Greece to as much as 120 billion euros over three years.

headline: Death Zone
text: The altitude at which there is insufficient oxygen to sustain normal human functions.

headline: B.C. Regulators Quash Lions Gate Poison Pill
text: Regulators in British Columbia on Tuesday voided a shareholders rights plan by Lions Gate Entertainment that would have prevented a takeover attempt by investor Carl Icahn, The Associated Press reported.

headline: China Said to Block Real Estate Fund-Raising
text: China will place a moratorium on capital-raising by real estate firms as part of a broader campaign to rein in property price rises, state media reported on Wednesday, citing unidentified sources.

headline: Bezos, Dell and Carey Invest in Qliance
text: Jeff Bezos,  Michael Dell and  Drew Carey are coming together to invest in Qliance Medical Management, a Seattle firm that intends to deliver primary care to patients by excising insurance companies from the chain.

headline: Corrections
text: A review last Wednesday about the restaurant SHO Shaun Hergatt misidentified an ingredient in the beurre blanc served with striped bass and crayfish tails. It is vin jaune, meaning “yellow wine,” from the Jura region  not “young” wine.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Wednesday about the Cooking Channel, a cable network scheduled to start on May 31, misidentified the country of origin of “Indian Food Made Easy,” one of its programs. It is England, not Canada.

headline: Corrections
text: A listing in the Dining Calendar on April 14 referred imprecisely to the group Hand in Hand, which held a benefit cooking demonstration on April 21. The group supports cooperative Arab-Jewish schools in Israel, not Arab-Israeli schools.

headline: Investor’s Lagardere Move Thwarted
text: Guy Wyser-Pratte, an activist investor and hedge fund owner, saw his effort at gaining a seat on the board of Lagardere thwarted on Tuesday, when shareholders rejected the attempt with 78 percent of votes.

headline: The Goldman E-Mails, or How to Sell Junk
text: Evidence released Tuesday by Senator Carl Levin, the Michigan Democrat in charge of the Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, includes a series of e-mail messages sent by executives at Goldman Sachs as the bank attempted to shed mortgage-related assets in the run-up to the subprime crisis of 2007.

headline: Zong Dials Up $15 Million
text: Zong, a company that allows customers to buy virtual goods using their mobile phones, has closed a $15 million funding round with backing from Matrix Partners, TechCrunch reported.

headline: Bay Area’s Anchor Brewing Is Sold
text: Anchor Brewing, the San Francisco beer company that helped spark the modern microbrewery movement, has been sold to two Bay Area entrepreneurs who are in the artisan beer and spirits business, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Apple Buys Intrinsity, a Maker of Fast Chips
text: Apple wants the fastest chip for its mobile devices and has bought another chip maker to gain an edge over its competitors. To that end, Apple has acquired a small Austin, Tex., company called Intrinsity, known for making zippy versions of a computer chip often found in mobile devices, The New York Times’s Ashlee Vance and Brad Stone reported.

headline: Icahn Plans to Fix What’s ‘Broken’ at Genzyme
text: If elected to the board of Genzyme, billionaire investor Carl Icahn will work to understand and help the company fix what is “broken,” according to proxy documents filed on Tuesday with the  Securities and Exchange Commission, Reuters reported.

headline: Pru Takeover May Be Undermined by Exodus
text: The Financial Times reports that many senior AIA executives, actuaries and agents don’t plan to stay after the British insurer Prudential Plc closes its $35.5 billion takeover.

headline: S.E.C. Said to Probe Funds’ ‘Side Pockets’
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is taking a closer look at whether hedge fund managers abused a practice known as “side pockets” to prevent clients from withdrawing billions of dollars during the 2008 financial crisis, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Sales, Not I.P.O.’s, Becomes Popular in Australia
text: Private equity firms looking to sell some of their midsize Australian businesses are finding strong enough interest from trade buyers so that they may be able to avoid I.P.O.’s, Reuters reported.

headline: Leonsis Gets Washington Wizards and Verizon Center
text: Ted Leonsis, owner of the Washington Capitals hockey team, has reached a deal with the Pollin family to acquire a majority share of the Washington Wizards basketball team and the Verizon Center where the teams play.

headline: TheWrap.com Gets $2 Million in 2nd Round
text: TheWrap.com, a Hollywood business news Web site, has received a fresh injection of $2 million in a second round of funding, PaidContent reported.

headline: Swiss Banks to Crack Down on Euro Clients
text: Swiss banks want to crack down on European clients who may be avoiding taxes in their home countries, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: How to Be a Bollywood Star (O.K., an Extra)
text: Being a star in a big Bollywood production takes lots of training. But if all you want is to be an extra, join the tourist crowds on Colaba Causeway, at popular spots like Leopold Café or Café Mondegar.

headline: Good News From the Housing Sector
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Whitman on Hot Seat Over Time at Goldman
text: Meg Whitman, the former eBay chief executive, said Tuesday she regrets taking part in a now-banned stock sale practice at Goldman Sachs and said she left the investment bank’s board in 2002 after 15 months  because she “wasn’t a good fit.”

headline: Backed by Flowers, Shinsei Plans Sell-Off
text: Shinsei Bank, the Japanese lender backed by the investor J. Christopher Flowers, plans to sell more than 100 billion yen ($1.1 billion) of overseas investments, two people with knowledge of the matter told Bloomberg News.

headline: American Idol: The Top 6 Tackle Shania Twain
text: Siobhan Magnus > Michael Lynche > Crystal Bowersox > Casey James > Aaron Kelly > Lee DeWyze

headline: Pro-Football-Reference.com Reviews Drafts of Giants and Jets
text: For those with N.F.L. draft delirium tremens (seek help if you would give anything to hear the sound of Todd McShay’s voice) …

headline: Sinopec to Sell Nearly $3 Billion in Bonds
text: Sinopec will carry out China’s biggest exchange-listed corporate debt issue when it sells up to $2.93 billion in bonds on the Shanghai Stock Exchange next month.

headline: Adam Smith, Mr. Softee
text: Today’s idea: Adam Smith wasn’t the free-market fundamentalist he’s cracked up to have been, writes a Nobel-winning economist, arguing the 18th-century philosopher had a soft spot for government welfare and the little guy.

headline: British Authority Asked to Investigate Uralchem I.P.O.
text: The U.K.’s Financial Services Authority has been asked by a former minority investor to take a closer look at the proposed $600 million London listing of Russian fertilizer firm, Uralchem. The Telegraph reported that the investor claims Uralchem has not been sufficiently forthcoming about the risks to its business in the prospectus for its I.P.O.

headline: How I Got My Company Back
text: We started 2010 with a very short list of projects on the books. I needed to close some deals or we would run out of work and cash by February.

headline: Ander Monson’s ‘Vanishing Point': The Future of the Book
text: The writers participating in The London Review of Books’s panel on Saturday speculated about the future of reading and writing, but they had a slightly harder time trying to imagine how the Book of the Future might change the reading experience. John Lanchester predicted that if a book were to interact with the Web, it would most likely resemble a video game.

headline: Word of the Day | tangential

text: Three months after delaying the listing of its United States unit, JBS is ready to raise $1.04 billion by selling new voting shares. The world’s largest beef producer, based in Brazil, will sell 230 million shares, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: For Some on Wall St., Hearings Were Background Noise

headline: Rusty Aston Could Fetch More Than $250,000 at Auction
text: No superlatives will be used to describe the condition of the 1964 Aston Martin DB5 that will be offered at Bonhams’s Monaco auction on Friday. In fact, Bonhams will dutifully point out that the automobile’s paint is chipped and faded, the metal is rusted, the leather seats are ripped and cracked, and the filthy, corroded engine hasn’t been started in two decades. Yet, this rusting hulk is expected to bring as much as $266,000.

headline: Sampler: Fast-Food Toys Tossed, and iPhone Inquiry Stalled
text: Santa Clara Tables Toys with Fast-Food Meals | Happy meals were sad in Santa Clara County on Tuesday. Supervisors voted by 3-2 to prohibit restaurants from serving toys with meals packed with fat, sugar and calories. The ordinance, the nation’s first such law, seeks to fight childhood obesity. The law’s practical impact will be extremely limited, however, because it only applies to restaurants in the unincorporated areas of the county, like San Martin, Cambrian, Burbank and Stanford University. Before the toy ban takes effect, the board will vote to reaffirm the decision on May 11. [The San Jose Mercury News]

headline: Auction Begins for Philadelphia Newspapers
text: The auction to determine the next owner of Philadelphia’s bankrupt newspapers finally got off the ground early Wednesday morning. The bidding was expected to start at 11 a.m. Tuesday, but it was delayed until almost 4 a.m. Wednesday because of wrangling over the initial offers, according to a company spokesman.

headline: The Editors: Wall Street Casino
text: Congressional Republicans have concluded that screaming foul about the banking bailout and blocking financial reform is a clever strategy for the fall elections, The New York Times editorial board writes.

headline: Gordon Brown Calls Voter ‘Bigoted’
text: Last Updated | 12:25 p.m. Apparently unaware that his microphone was still on as his motorcade sped away from a stop on the campaign trail on Wednesday, Prime Minister Gordon Brown was overheard telling an aide that a woman he had just sparred with on the campaign trail was “bigoted.” Mr. Brown’s remarks, made in Rochdale, England, about a woman named Gillian Duffy who complained to him about immigrants from Eastern Europe, can be heard near the end of video posted on the Web site of Britain’s Channel 4 News.

headline: The Data-Driven Life
text: Humans make errors. We make errors of fact and errors of judgment. We have blind spots in our field of vision and gaps in our stream of attention. Sometimes we can’t even answer the simplest questions. Where was I last week at this time? How long have I had this pain in my knee? How much money do I typically spend in a day? These weaknesses put us at a disadvantage. We make decisions with partial information. We are forced to steer by guesswork. We go with our gut.

headline: Guggenheim Board Member Caught in Russian Intrigue
text: Janna Bullock, a Russian-born real estate developer who joined the board of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation in 2007, abruptly left that position two weeks ago to deal with a business dispute in Russia — a conflict involving her husband, who was a regional finance official there, and a company connected to the former judo coach of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin. Ms. Bullock’s departure from the board, which oversees the Guggenheim Museum, is the latest twist in an operatic life of a woman who immigrated from St. Petersburg, and worked as a nanny in Brooklyn before starting a New York real estate business that grew into a $2 billion company. A report by Kate Taylor and Andrew E. Kramer of The New York Times can be found here.

headline: Let the Good Meals Roll
text: Sam Sifton had a pretty good time finding out what defines New Orleans dining these days. He sipped vodka with caviar at Stella!, tucked in to the cochon at Cochon, snacked on banh mi at Dong Phuong and finished up with a banana cream pie at Emeril’s — all places were chefs can hold their heads high.

headline: Jane Hotel Ballroom Is Allowed to Reopen
text: Updated, 10:27 a.m. | The ballroom at the Jane Hotel, which earned enmity from its West Village neighbors for the throngs of partygoers drawn to the exclusive and lushly restored space until the city shut it down in October, could be on the verge of reopening. It has been given two important stamps of approval by the city.

headline: What a Dish
text: Rudolf Stingel has a lot on his plate these days — literally. The New York-based conceptual artist collaborated with Bernardaud, the French porcelain company, and the Art Production Fund’s WOW (Works on Whatever) on a pair of luscious-looking dinner plates that are almost too beautiful to mar with a meal. The plates, which come in an edition of 2,500 in both black and white, are based on photographs of a wall relief that Stingel began in 2008. Fittingly, that project was inspired by the wallpaper in the dining room of his childhood home. Why make tableware? ‘‘I like to eat,’’ the artist says. ‘‘And I like to look at my work — two birds, one stone.’’ It’s not the artist’s first excursion into the everyday. In 2004, he famously swathed Grand Central Station’s cavernous Vanderbilt Hall in floral carpeting. Impressive, of course. But this is one project he’ll be able to dine out on for years. And at $98 each, so will you. Available at worksonwhatever.com and Bernardaud boutiques in New York and Chicago.

text: As “American Idol” enters the home stretch, Simon Cowell may not be able to put his thumb on the scale for the contestant Crystal Bowersox as blatantly as he did at the start of the season. (In fact, we’re pretty sure his dismissal of her performance of Shania Twain’s “No One Needs to Know” on Tuesday night’s show was all part of some elaborate head game.) headline: Do-Good Design
text: What’s the point of design these days, anyway? That’s the question the curators at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum wrestled with for nearly three years as they assembled ‘‘Why Design Now?,’’ the museum’s fourth National Design Triennial, which opens May 14. Their response, presented through 134 projects from around the world, might be the design equivalent of the Hippocratic oath. Many are high-minded, utilitarian responses to critical problems overseas (cleaner-burning stoves, a land-mine-removal suit) and at home (New York City’s new Hoop bike rack, M.I.T.’s prototype for a lightweight electric city car). ‘‘There’s room for high-style design, but there also needs to be room for the rest of the world,’’ says Matilda McQuaid, the museum’s deputy curatorial director. But its definition of socially responsible has room for whimsical conceptualism (Interactive Institute’s Energy Aware Clock, above), architectural grandiosity (Foster & Partners’ sustainable city of Masdar in Abu Dhabi) and simple beauty (Heath Ceramics tableware). Even Twitter made the cut. ‘‘People say the focus on socially responsible design is just because of the Wall Street crisis and isn’t going to survive once things are back to normal,’’ McQuaid says. ‘‘I think it’s here to stay.’’

I really did respect John McCain for working with Edward Kennedy to come up with a sane bill in 2007, and it did cost him politically. Although not a whole lot in the end, what with his being nominated for president and all.

headline: High Gloss
text: If you are strong enough not to be moved by dolphin console tables and rococo plasterwork, Syrie Maugham is probably nothing more to you than the wife of the sulfurous literary lion W. Somerset Maugham. For the rest of us, it’s a different story. A domestic-arts arbiter of adventurous originality, Syrie set up shop in London in 1922 and went on to forge a triumphantly theatrical look celebrating glamour and luxury. Some of her ideas were odd, some immensely profitable. She said that by stripping peonies of their leaves, party guests could be fooled into believing they were wax, a look she preferred to fresh. Indifferent antiques were ruthlessly cut down, painted, pickled or otherwise “improved” until they sang arias of sustained chic. Were dealers already referring to “amusing” pieces — furniture with little intrinsic worth but a surfeit of charm — before Syrie Maugham came on the scene? I suspect it all began with her. As it happens, we’re on the verge of a Syrie fest. Two forthcoming books, Selina Hastings’s “The Secret Lives of Somerset Maugham” (Random House) and Pauline C. Metcalf’s “Syrie Maugham: Staging the Glamorous Interior” (Acanthus Press), make the point that no pedestal was too high for the woman who popularized the “all-white room,” an icily moderne cocktail of mirrored screens and fireplaces, geometrically sculptured carpets, shagreen tables, satin slipcovers, towering plaster lamps in the form of palm trees and velvet — velvet! — lampshades. You would have thought that with two books already out there — “Syrie Maugham,” a rare 1978 monograph, and 1980’s “The Scandal of Syrie Maugham” — to say nothing of Beverley Nichols’s 1966 screed “A Case of Human Bondage,” which was dedicated entirely to her toxic marriage, there was nothing left to say or dig up. Happily, this is not the case. Too much is never enough for Syrie cultists.

headline: Copenhagen Restaurant Rated No. 1 on S. Pellegrino Best 50
text: Bloomberg is reporting, the Copenhagen restaurant Noma has been ranked No. 1 in the S. Pellegrino World’s 50 Best Restaurants list for 2010, rising from No. 3 last year. At No.2 was El Bulli, which was No. 1 last year. It is run by Ferran Adrià in Spain and has been in the top three since the awards were begun in 2002. Fat Duck, operated by Heston Blumenthal in England, was rated No. 3 after being ranked at No. 2 last year. Rounding out the top five were two other restaurants in Spain: El Celler de Can Roca and Mugaritz.

headline: Cutting No Corners on This Side of the Street
text: LET’S begin at the end, with me walking out of Epaulet in Brooklyn, bag in hand, purchases swaddled in neon-green tissue paper, content. This is how I want to feel when leaving a store having parted with cash — somehow more whole, as if I’ve snapped a puzzle piece successfully into place. In shopping, at least, tenacity rewards the shallow.

headline: A Life In and Out of Sync
text: Clio Barnard’s film “The Arbor” is hard to categorize. It’s a documentary, as it uses the interviews of real people to tell its story of the British playwright Andrea Dunbar (who died in 1990 at age 29) and the difficult relationship she had with her daughter Lorraine. But it’s also a narrative feature, because it uses actors to lip-sync the audio of those interviews in highly stylized scenes. Also mixed in is a performance of Ms. Dunbar’s play “The Arbor,” staged and filmed on the street where she lived in Bradford, England. The film screens Wednesday night at the Tribeca Film Festival and includes a post-screening panel.

headline: Oakland Teachers to Strike on Thursday
text: Public school teachers in Oakland plan to pick up picket signs for a one-day strike on Thursday. The action follows a controversial new contract imposed last week by the Oakland School Board that left teachers without pay raises for at least a year.

headline: A Good Night for the Old Guard
text: Sometimes, sports provides a moment of truth for a dynasty, a proud team facing its inevitable decline but given a chance to fight back, if only one more time. The tension becomes whether pride and experience are enough to hold off a younger, spunkier opponent giddy with its chance to play giant killer.

headline: A Thumbs Up on Cape Wind
text: The federal government has given the green light to the Cape Wind project off the Massachusetts coast. The Interior secretary, Ken Salazar, announced the decision in Boston. Read the story here.

text: Gina Rarick has been training horses since 2001, alongside a career in journalism. She left the newspaper business to train full-time last year, becoming the first American woman licensed as a professional racehorse trainer in France. You can read more on her blog, Gallop France.

headline: City of Endangered Languages
text: New York has long been a city of immigrants, but linguists now consider it a laboratory for studying and preserving languages in rapid decline elsewhere in the world.

headline: The Self-Appointed Twitter Scolds

headline: Espada Paid Workers $1.70 an Hour, Cuomo Says
text: ALBANY — The Senate majority leader, Pedro Espada Jr., paid janitors for his Soundview health clinics $1.70 an hour, according to a lawsuit filed Wednesday by the office of Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo. The federal minimum wage is $7.25.

headline: Cleanup Crew Eradicates Banksy Rat
text: Where Banksy is involved, there usually are no accidents, but in this case it truly does appear to be an accident that a street-cleaning crew in Melbourne, Australia, painted over a mural by that pseudonymous graffiti artist and provocateur. The Associated Press reported that Susan Riley, the deputy lord mayor of Melbourne, dispatched street cleaners to the city’s Hosier Lane after residents complained about squalid conditions at an alley known for its displays of public art. Among the works painted there was a stencil of a goggle-wearing rat, created by Banksy during a visit to Melbourne in 2003 – and removed by the crew, which was instructed to remove all graffiti from the area. In an interview on Australian radio, Kathy Alexander, the chief executive of the city of Melbourne, said, “Unfortunately, the contractors were not made aware by us that that was an important piece and unfortunately that means the piece is gone.”

headline: Soundtracks Top Charts
text: Billboard’s album chart this week is all about soundtracks. “The Power of Madonna” (Columbia), the seven-song companion to last week’s all-Madonna episode of the Fox show “Glee,” opened at No. 1 with 98,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and 75 percent of its sales were as digital downloads — an extraordinary number, although not quite record-breaking. (In January, Kesha’s “Animal” had 76 percent, and the “Hope for Haiti” charity album was released only online.) Not far behind “Glee,” the all-AC/DC soundtrack to “Iron Man 2” (Columbia) reached No. 4 in its first week, with 76,000 sales. Billboard reported that it is the first time in the five-decade history of its main album chart that two soundtracks have made their debuts in the Top 5.

headline: Washington Post Unveils New Political Homepage
text: Move over New York, you’re not alone with a budding local news war. A battle is also heating up in Washington.

And there was a lot worth seeing — so much, in fact, that T has put together a roundup of some (but not all) of the things we couldn’t fit into reports from the field.

headline: Ride Home With It
text: ROMPERS, jumpsuits and now ... unitards? SoulCycle, the indoor spin-class studios, has just added the one-piece made famous by Queen’s Freddie Mercury to its latest collection of workout clothes (right). And very, very confident New York women have been spotted wearing them outside the spin class, accessorized with high boots and long cardigans. “We were inspired by all the jumpsuits out now and the ’80s music we were listening to,” said Julie Rice, a SoulCycle owner, whose play list features Pat Benatar’s “Hit Me With Your Best Shot.” Seventies-era Spandex has been replaced by Vaporex, a moisture-wicking fabric ($150). Available at the SoulCycle studios in Manhattan, including 1470 Third Avenue; (212) 639-1300, and online at soul-cycle.com.

headline: Business as Usual for Woods at Quail Hollow
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – It was 45 degrees and quiet when Tiger Woods walked to the first tee Wednesday morning, threading his way from the putting green through a dewy, roped-off corridor at Quail Hollow Club. His pro-am time was 7:30 and his breath was visible in the morning chill as he told a couple of kids pleading for autographs that he would sign after the round.

headline: It Fights Aging, but It Gets Old
text: AGING ANTI-AGERS Makeup spoils. From the moment a mascara or a face cream that contains plant-derived substances is opened, it is a petri dish for bacteria. But stickers like these from Beauty Alert ($8.50 for 24) can help keep track of when it’s time to say goodbye, as can the labels in the Once Opened Beauty Expiration Kit ($9.95 for 24).

headline: Spain’s Debt Rating Cut as Finance Officials Meet
text: The ratings agency Standard & Poor’s lowered the debt rating of Spain on Wednesday, its third downgrade of a European country in two days, The New York Times’s Landon Thomas Jr. reports.

headline: Paying With Your Phone
text: A wave of new technologies are making us less and less dependent on cash.

headline: Toyota Announces Another Recall
text: Toyota announced a second recall Wednesday related to the vehicle stability control system on its sport utility vehicles, this one concerning the 2003 model year Sequoia.

headline: Quiet Progress on Senate Climate Bill
text: Although the public progress of the Senate attempt to write a comprehensive climate change energy bill has ground to a halt because of a protest by one of its chief sponsors, an outline of the bill’s major provisions is moving forward.

headline: Self Magazine Hands Out Product Awards
text: PRODUCTS PRAISED Pomegranate is in. Or so proclaimed the 1,108 testers who helped Self magazine select 88 products for its Healthy Beauty Awards, which are named in the May issue. Elaine D’Farley, Self’s beauty director, said at a breakfast for winners and members of the news media, “Eyes are the new focal point.”

headline: Plastic-Surgery Group Starts Advice Web Site
text: NEW ONLINE At a new site from the American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery — ProjectBeauty.com — there are articles about fitness and skin care, and videos from patients who underwent breast augmentation. The site is not meant to drive business to plastic surgeons, one of its creators said, but to offer unbiased information.

headline: G.O.P. Agrees to Start Debate on Financial Bill
text: Senate Republicans ended three days of resistance on Wednesday and signaled that they are ready to allow debate of legislation to overhaul regulation of the nation’s financial system, David M. Herszenhorn and Edward Wyatt of The New York Times report from Washington.

headline: Bipartisan Agreement: Raise Taxes, Cut Spending
text: To coincide with today’s big deficit gathering in Washington, the Peter G. Peterson Foundation has released the results of a new survey. Here’s how the foundation describes the people approached for the survey:

headline: TimesCast: The Political Calculus of the G.O.P.
text: Republicans in the Senate have once again prevented Democrats from bringing to the floor legislation that would overhaul financial regulations.

headline: Cellphone Payments Offer Alternative to Cash
text: You win a bet, but the loser does not have enough cash on him to settle it. If he has a credit card, and most people usually do, there is finally a solution. A number of big and small companies — including eBay’s PayPal unit, Intuit, VeriFone and Square — are creating innovative ways for individuals to avoid cash and checks and settle all debts, public and private, using their cellphones.

headline: Bigoted Woman
text: Gordon Brown’s private description of a 65-year-old Labour supporter.

headline: Smoke Alarm, but No Fire, Leads to Chilly Outdoor ‘Passion Play’
text: In its performances at the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, Epic Theater Ensemble‘s production of Sarah Ruhl‘s “Passion Play” aspires to a certain bare aesthetic, though perhaps not quite as bare as what its cast members experienced at the show’s first preview on Tuesday night.

headline: The Morning Skate: Good Vibes for Capitals or History for the Habs?
text: A hugely entertaining opening round of the Stanley Cup playoffs ends tonight in Washington when the Capitals, the N.H.L.’s best regular-season team, try to advance in Game 7 against the Canadiens, who finished 33 points behind them in the standings.

headline: Why Does This Pair of Pants Cost $550?
text: EVEN in a season when designers made no secret about reining in prices to appeal to the newly chastened luxury consumer, it is still possible to walk into a store and wonder what exactly they were thinking when a pair of khaki cotton pants — right there on the hanger, no special packaging or 3G plan or anything — can cost as much as an iPad.

headline: Feeling Free of All Ties
text: GIRLY-GIRL sneakerheads with a passion for sequins and fond memories of the playgrounds of their youth may want to check out a new line of Keds designed by Stacey Bendet, founder of Alice + Olivia. These stylish mash-ups, which Ms. Bendet sees as an alternative to the ubiquitous ballet flat worn with dresses, jeans and leggings, may have had roots in her own childhood, when she was not one to obsess about keeping her kicks clean. “My Keds were a chalkboard,” she said. “I would draw all over them — even the white leather version.” Ms. Bendet remembers that as a budding trendsetter she carried off the de rigueur look of the time: slouch socks, leggings, no laces. Drawing on those memories, she took the laces out of this collection. The shoes (left) are $88 at Neiman Marcus stores and neimanmarcus.com.

headline: Dress Like a Benefactor
text: CIVIC-MINDED shoppers (and, after all, who isn’t one?) will be able to buy a cage dress designed by Christian Cota (left, $3,950) without feeling too bad about that four-figure price tag. The dress is one of 17 created by emerging fashion designers for Saks Fifth Avenue, which says it will donate 10 percent of the proceeds to benefit the Whitney Museum of American Art. There are also several dresses by Prabal Gurung, including a one-shoulder blue crepe dress ($1,750), and a black-and-white one-shoulder cocktail dress ($2,850), as well as three playful print floral dresses by Erdem Moralioglu ($1,240 to $700), all named Frances, after a friend of the designer’s who accompanied him on an inspirational trip to Japan. Also represented are Doo.Ri, Marios Schwab and Aquilano.Rimondi. Saks Fifth Avenue, 611 Fifth Avenue, (212) 753-4000.

headline: One Team’s Dream Is Another Team’s Obsession
text: 4:41 p.m. |Inter Through to Final

headline: Land of Lonely Tongues
text: An article on the Web site of The Times this afternoon describes the efforts of the Endangered Language Alliance at the City University of New York to track down New Yorkers who speak languages that are not only rare here but may be falling extinct in their homelands, too.

headline: Goldman Wins Top Spot in Private Equity Ranking
text: Goldman Sachs may be a bank holding company, but its private equity unit is ranked first place on Private Equity International’s latest list of the largest private equity firms, supplanting pure-play firms like last year’s winner, TPG.

headline: Dust Off the Old Stock
text: THE new Gant Rugger store on Bleecker Street — the first stand-alone retail outlet for the Rugger brand — channels factory chic from the company’s manufacturing roots in New Haven, with exposed industrial piping and a sewing machine in front of the dressing rooms. Christopher Bastin (above), the head designer for Gant Rugger and a self-proclaimed “vintage nerd,” also mined the sportswear’s past by updating fabrics and silhouettes. “I basically went on eBay and started buying vintage Gant to build up the archives,” Mr. Bastin said. A Hopsack blazer ($495), available in navy and gray, includes 30-year-old buttons recently unearthed at the company’s Portugal factory. Also featured are madras shirts ($125), chinos ($125), polo shirts ($79 to $89) and a single-speed cruiser bike ($995) in a limited edition of 20. Gant Rugger, 353 Bleecker Street, (212) 620-5949.

headline: Bill Clinton, on Immigration and Wall Street
text: Former President Bill Clinton waded into two of the season’s biggest controversies on Wednesday with the bravado of someone never facing election again, calling for more immigration and expressing doubt about whether Goldman Sachs broke any laws, as the government alleges.

headline: Celtics Not a Trendy Upset Pick
text: Anyone picking the Boston Celtics to upend the high-flying Cleveland Cavaliers in their second-round N.B.A. playoff series?

headline: Too Busy for Oil Awards
text: Scratch the awards luncheon for offshore drilling safety.

headline: USC to Create an Oral Archive of Behind-the-Scenes Hollywood
text: Now it can be told! The stories behind the Hollywood stories from years past will apparently find their way into history via a new oral archive project at the University of Southern California’s School of Cinematic Arts. The now-retired Times correspondent Bernard Weinraub, who long held the Hollywood beat, is listed among the first contributors to the archive, which is being initially funded and produced by the powerhouse entertainment law firm, Hansen, Jacobson, Teller, Hoberman, Newman, Warren & Richman.

headline: Crist Drops More Hints
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Gov. Charlie Crist on Wednesday solved one part of his campaign mystery by saying there was no chance he would drop out of the race for the United States Senate.

headline: Obama to Nominate Three to the Central Bank
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will nominate Janet L. Yellen on Thursday to be vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, and fill two remaining seats on the central bank’s board of governors, officials said Wednesday evening.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. The Arizona House of Representatives passes a provision that will require President Obama to show his birth certificate to get on the state’s ballot in 2012. At which point a morose civil servant will ask, “Don’t I know you from somewhere?”

headline: How They Do Things Back in St. Olaf: Flirting Fleetingly With Betty White
text: Thank you for being a friend — but not that kind of friend.

headline: You Don’t Mess With Sassoon
text: He was Picasso, Copernicus, a Shakespeare with shears. Yes, those are grand comparisons, but they’re consistent with the gushing of hair geeks interviewed for “Vidal Sassoon The Movie,” a documentary that had its world premiere on Friday at the Tribeca Film Festival. Was Sassoon really so great? From his Bond Street salon in the 1960s, he created a geometric approach to the cut, exemplified by the “five-point,” which coiffeurs still speak of like it’s their Rosetta stone. “You cut hair like we cut clothes,” the Swinging Sixties designer Mary Quant tells Sassoon during a tender scene in which they sift through old pictures of the models Nancy Kwan and Grace Coddington. A narrative quickly emerges: Quant popularizes the mini-skirt, Sassoon tops off the King’s Road look, and the rest — the shampoo bottles, the global network of salons and styling academies — is history. Well, not quite.

headline: A Day in the Life of an Exercise Rider
text: Today I thought I would take you through my morning activity, so you can get a sense of what an exercise rider does. Exercise riders are those guys who are piloting the Kentucky Derby horses around the track for their morning training. I have never had the privilege of galloping a horse that is preparing for the Derby, but I have galloped at least one horse who ran in the Derby. Storm Treasure, trained by Steve Asmussen, ran the year Barbaro won. He came up to Woodbine in 2008 and 2009 when I was galloping for Asmussen in Canada.

headline: Warning: Measure Your Salt
text: I was a Diamond Crystal baby. Diamond Crystal kosher salt was the only salt my mother used, the only one I knew as a child. Now, half a century later (yikes!), it remains the salt I reach for first — although I now have to fish for it among half a dozen that sit on the shelf. All those fancy sea salts, however, are used to finish dishes or added at the table, where their varied textures are a source of tactile delight. For cooking, I rarely use anything but the kosher salt of my childhood; I can judge, by eye and by feel, how much I need for any task from making a well balanced vinaigrette to seasoning a steak.

headline: Travel Deals: Variety and Carnival Cruise Sales
text: Variety Cruises, a fleet of upscale large yachts with 25 to 36 cabins, is offering two-for-one fares, starting at $2,690, on cruises along the Adriatic Coast.

headline: Beyond Bouncy Castles and Pony Rides
text: Have you noticed how almost no one sells products or services anymore, but rather “experiences”? And it’s the “experience” offered by Games2U, a fleet of vans stocked with video games, that David Pikoff, a co-founder of the company, says will make the venture a success.

headline: 26 in Egypt Are Convicted in Terror Plot
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian court on Wednesday convicted 26 men of belonging to a Hezbollah cell that was charged with planning to attack Israeli tourists in the Sinai Peninsula, fire on ships passing through the Suez Canal and smuggle weapons, supplies and people through tunnels to the Gaza Strip.

headline: Bryant Redefines Role and Reinvigorates Lakers
text: LOS ANGELES — In recent weeks, Kobe Bryant had aged before the world’s eyes. The broken right index finger, which has morphed into an arthritic knuckle, had diminished his ball-handling ability and shooting touch. His twisted left ankle had compromised his leaping ability and his swollen right knee had become so troublesome that Bryant, for the second time this season, took a week off to rest it.

headline: China Lifts Ban on Visitors Who Are H.I.V. Positive
text: Days before travelers worldwide are to begin arriving for Shanghai’s world exposition, China has lifted a two-decade ban on travel to the country by people who carry the virus that causes AIDS or who have other sexually transmitted diseases. Read full story

headline: Answers About New York School Data
text: Following is the first set of responses from Robert Gebeloff, a computer-assisted journalist with an expertise in education, who has been working on an extensive database of New York education statistics for The New York Times.

headline: Lawmakers Call for Action on Immigration
text: The political challenge that Arizona’s tough immigration law poses for both parties was evident Wednesday as members called loudly for federal action.

headline: Shift of Funds at the Metropolitan Opera
text: The Metropolitan Opera last year freed up $22 million of its $242 million endowment to help cover operating expenses. With the permission of the donors, $15 million was shifted into the less restrictive endowment trust as an emergency reserve. The move, reported in the Wall Street Journal on Wednesday, was yet another effort by the Met to manage a deficit that is expected to be about $4 million for this fiscal year. With the permission of Chevron Texaco, the Met also moved $7 million in restricted funds. The Met has reduced the total budget by $18 million for the current fiscal year, resulting in an operating budget of about $300 million.

text: ON THE SHELVES

headline: In Area With Few Options, Rigs Are Mixed Blessing
text: JONESVILLE, La. — Here, people live on streets named after their grandfathers.

headline: On a Holiday for Afghans, Tight Security and Violence
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The celebration of the 18th anniversary of the victory of the mujahedeen commanders over the Communist government in 1992 put Afghanistan’s contradictory impulses toward war and peace on public display on Wednesday.

headline: Needle and Thread Still Have a Home
text: HOW is the garment district like a coral reef? A coral reef, as Animal Planet instructs us, shelters diverse species of sponges, snakes, clownfish and barracudas. So does the garment district. A coral reef is a rich universe with its own organically evolved architecture, home to its own assortment of beasts and weeds. Garment district buildings are the same. Plunge down alongside a reef and hang in the flow, currents eddying around you, and as the designer Yeohlee Teng said recently, “You never know what is going to swim by.”

headline: Science Quiz: Happy Birthday, Hubble!
text: The Hubble Telescope was launched into space 20 years ago, on April 24, 1990. To mark this anniversary, instead of a regular science lesson we present a 12-question interactive quiz about the observatory that astronomy educator and blogger Phil Plait calls “arguably the world’s most famous telescope.”

headline: Quiet Progress on Senate Climate Bill
text: Although the public progress of the Senate attempt to write a comprehensive climate change energy bill has ground to a halt because of a protest by one of its chief sponsors, an outline of the bill’s major provisions is moving forward.

headline: Day 2 of Obama’s Road Trip
text: MACON, Mo. — President Obama, continuing his tour of the Midwest, told workers at a bio-ethanol plant Wednesday that he intended to achieve his goal of tripling America’s biofuels production in the next 12 years.

headline: Everything the Traffic Will Allow
text: City Room looked into its crystal ball. This is what we saw:

headline: This Is Not a Blank Canvas
text: LAST week I gave some bum advice to Rachel Feinstein. We were both navigating the D.I.Y. cocktail bar at the Brooklyn Museum at its Thursday night gala to celebrate the exhibition “American High Style: Fashioning a National Collection,” which meant selecting a glass from hundreds carefully arranged on a vast wood box; walking past the pile of paint tubes of vegetable pastes and a cascade of potato chips the size of a sleeping linebacker (an homage to Paul McCarthy); dodging the splatter of head-shaped cheese sculptures suspended from the ceiling, melting into raclette under some ominous heat guns (an homage to Bruce Nauman); then strolling up to the Champagne fountain (Duchamp) at the other end of the gallery. Or so I thought.

headline: Clues for Personalizing Breast Cancer Treatment
text: A new study of women with the earliest form of breast cancer offers clues into which patients may need aggressive therapy and who can be spared unnecessary treatment.

headline: After Bryant’s Interview Controversy, Union Chief Urges More Respect
text: The private interviews N.F.L. teams hold with draft prospects have often been odd affairs, littered with questions of the “if you were a tree, what tree would you be?” variety. General managers and scouts have complained that players are so thoroughly prepped for interviews by their agents that it is increasingly difficult to get a accurate read on players’ personalities. This year, though, in an attempt to divine a players’ character, Miami General Manager Jeff Ireland may have finally crossed a line by asking receiver Dez Bryant if his mother was a prostitute.

headline: Justices’ Ruling Blocks Cross Removal
text: WASHINGTON — A badly fractured Supreme Court, with six justices writing opinions, reopened the possibility on Wednesday that a large cross serving as a war memorial in a remote part of the Mojave Desert may be permitted to remain there.

headline: ABC News Concludes Major Staff Cutbacks
text: ABC News has completed a wrenching series of buyouts and layoffs that have reduced its workforce by nearly 400 people, or roughly 25 percent of the network news division.

headline: What Is the Worst Toy of the Year?
text: Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood, the Boston-based organization that has become a thorn in the side of Big Media, is soliciting votes for its second-annual Toady award for the “worst toy of the year.” The Toady (which stands for Toys Oppressive and Destructive to Young Children) will go to one of five finalists selected by the group:

headline: Republicans Allow Debate on Financial Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — With political pressure mounting, Senate Republicans relented on Wednesday and agreed to let Democrats open debate on legislation that would impose the most far-reaching overhaul of the nation’s financial regulatory system since the aftermath of the Depression.

headline: Asked and Answered | Michael Bastian
text: When Michael Bastian decided to leave his job as men’s fashion director of Bergdorf Goodman to start his own line, his parents were so concerned that they told him he could move back home if it didn’t work out. “That’s exactly the push I needed,” he said. “To know that if the worst happened, I could move back into my bedroom in Rochester!” Four years later, Mr. and Mrs. Bastian still have a spare room, and their son has carved out a niche for himself as the go-to guy for better-than-the-original takes on classic American sportswear. Come fall, he’ll expand his fan base further with a lower-priced collection for Gant. Here, Bastian talks to The Moment about finding the perfect Nantucket Reds, women in ties, and the importance of cut-offs.

headline: Bringing an Innovative Razor to the Masses
text: L.P.I. Consumer Products makes and distributes patented ShaveMate all-in-one razors that feature shaving cream dispensed from the handle. The company, which has been in business since 1987, has been developing its line of razors since 1997.

headline: Man Accused of Selling Fake Vintage Horror Movie Posters
text: A Georgia man accused of selling fake vintage horror movie posters and lobby cards over the Internet was arrested on Wednesday on mail fraud charges.

headline: ‘World Class’ World Cup a Difficult Proposition for African Fans
text: All that is missing, said Danny Jordaan, is the soccer.

headline: A Mischievous Charmer, Showing Vulnerability
text: A fearless playfulness has been the show business currency of Alan Cumming since he made a splash on Broadway 12 years ago as the androgynous M.C. in the revival of “Cabaret,” toying seductively with nervous audience members of both sexes. The same devil-may-care impulse to tweak the status quo and liberate the uptight infused his performance on Tuesday, the first of a five-night engagement, at an actual cabaret, Feinstein’s at Loews Regency.

headline: Georgia Man Arrested in Sale of Fake Movie Posters
text: A counterfeiting scandal that been rocking the close-knit world of movie poster collectors grew more serious on Wednesday, as federal authorities arrested Kerry T. Haggard, a Georgia-based dealer, on mail fraud charges related to the sale of fake horror-movie posters and lobby cards.

headline: City Pushes Shift for Special Education
text: The Bloomberg administration, struggling to address the needs of a growing number of students with learning disabilities, is overhauling special education by asking every principal to take in more of the students and giving them greater flexibility in deciding how to teach them.

headline: Winning Streak at 7 as the Mets Close Out a Stirring Homestand
text: A well-equipped fan attending games at Citi Field over the last 10 days needed a scorecard to follow the significant lineup changes, an umbrella to fend off rain, a sturdy windbreaker and at least two brooms.

headline: Motorcycle Helmet Maker Forced to End Production
text: On its Web site, the motorcycle helmet manufacturer Advanced Carbon Composites warns buyers not to trust helmets made in China or India and instead to buy its American-made models. But the company’s helmets have been recalled so many times by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, that the agency has demanded that the company never make another motorcycle helmet.

headline: Ailey Company Names New Director
text: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, one of the nation’s most successful dance troupes, said Wednesday that it would entrust its future to Robert Battle, a 36-year-old outside choreographer who has had a long association with the company.

headline: Hollywood Directors Union Agrees to Early Contract Talks
text: Hollywood’s production companies and major unions took another step toward early resolution of the next round of contract talks, as the Directors Guild of America agreed to begin negotiations toward a new contract in mid-November, even though its current deal with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers does not expire until June 30, 2011.

headline: Creditors Win Philadelphia Papers
text: The lenders of Philadelphia’s bankrupt newspapers, The Inquirer and The Daily News, won an auction on Wednesday to take control of the company, outbidding a group of local investors.

headline: More Members of Congress Oppose Trading of Movie Box-Office Futures
text: Political opposition to a pair of proposed exchanges that would trade futures contracts keyed to the movie box office grew on Wednesday, as 10 members of the House of Representatives sent the Commodity Futures Trading Commission a letter voicing concerns about the plans. The letter urged the commission to move slowly in reviewing the proposals by Cantor Fitzgerald and Veriana Networks while Congress considers legislation that would ban the futures.

headline: How Can ShaveMate Compete With Gillette?
text: We’ve just published a case study of ShaveMate‘s efforts to get a toehold in the razor and blade market. In the article, written by Mickey Meece, the inventors of the company’s patented all-in-one razors — which have the shaving cream in the handle — explain the steps they’ve taken to get shelf space in a world dominated by Schick and Gillette. Below, you’ll find the analyses of several small-business owners and experts who have had similar experiences. Please leave your own thoughts in the comment section.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangkok and Elsewhere
text: David Guttenfelder, a photographer for The Associated Press who distinguished himself in Afghanistan last year, took the picture we chose to lead Wednesday’s report, of soldiers firing on antigovernment demonstrators in Bangkok. An unusually turbulent day also saw clashes in Mexico, Brazil and Gaza. The Ukrainian Parliament seems to have calmed down, however.

headline: An Indie Rocker Finds His Inner Child
text: “Willy Was a Whale” is the kind of head-bopping, silly-clever song that is a staple of the kiddie rock movement. It comes complete with a hand motion — throw arms up to form a big W with your head — for the tots in the mosh pit up front at concerts, and a little joke — Willy walks “all the way down to Weno, Nevada” — for the parents who buy the tickets. Justin Roberts and the Not Ready for Naptime Players do  “Willy”  at pretty much every show: it’s their  “Born to Run.”

headline: Your Phone Is Locked. Just Drive.

headline: Study Shows ‘Invisible’ Burden of Family Doctors
text: A new study detailing the uncompensated work burden on family doctors points to the need to change how they are paid, medical experts say — particularly as the new health care law promises to add millions more patients to the system.

headline: German Banks Have Big Investment in Greece
text: There may be a good reason why German taxpayers are so unhappy about having to lend money to Greece. In effect, they already have. Germany’s financial institutions hold some 28 billion euros, or $37 billion, in Greek bonds, Barclays Capital estimates, extrapolating from International Monetary Fund data,  Jack Ewing of The New York Times reports from Frankfurt.

headline: Greg Kinnear Will Play John F. Kennedy in History Channel Miniseries
text: “The Kennedys,” the coming History Channel miniseries, has found its lead actors to play the central members of that Democratic political clan. Greg Kinnear, an Academy Award nominee for “As Good As It Gets,” will play John F. Kennedy; Barry Pepper (“Saving Private Ryan”) will play Robert F. Kennedy; Tom Wilkinson, an Emmy Award winner for “John Adams,” will play the family patriarch, Joseph P. Kennedy; and Katie Holmes (“Batman Begins,” “Dawson’s Creek”) will play Jacqueline Kennedy.

headline: IndyCar to Crown Oval and Road Race Champions
text: Apparently, it will no longer be good enough for the Izod IndyCar Series to crown just one champion. The open-wheel series that that has lost much of its traction to Nascar announced on Tuesday that it will begin to recognize three champions: an overall champion, plus separate series champions in races on ovals and in races on road and street courses.

headline: Anand Wins Again to Lead World Championship
