headline: Nuts and Bolts in Madagascar
text: Wednesday morning in Madagascar’s capital, Antananarivo, which is known as Tana, and with all research permits now in hand, it is time to start thinking about the practical aspects of starting the fieldwork. That means trying to plan (and pack) for everything that can go wrong.  And a lot can go wrong in Madagascar.  For example, when the car breaks down and strands you in the middle of nowhere, with absolutely no roadside towing, except maybe a couple of zebu cows in the closest village, if you can find their owner.  So, a very good place to start the practical preparation is with the car — my trusty old Land Rover, “Baby.”

headline: Armani Debuts in Dubai
text: After years of hype, Giorgio Armani has opened his first hotel in Dubai, extending his already large fashion and accessories empire into the travel industry.

headline: H.P. to Pay $1.2 Billion for Palm
text: With its $1.2 billion purchase of Palm, Hewlett-Packard signaled that it would take drastic action to remain relevant to consumers whose tastes in computing devices were radically changing.

headline: In Focus | Hyères Photo Festival
text: It seems wherever you look there’s a photo festival happening somewhere in the world, but perhaps the most anticipated one is the International Festival of Fashion & Photography in Hyères, France. The festival, which takes place April 30 to May 3, is located at the Villa Noailles, a former modernist residence that has since become a venue for cultural events. Each year ten up-and-coming photographers exhibit their work to the public and an esteemed jury of media professionals. This year’s highlights include Carlo van de Roer’s ethereal Polaroid portraits, James Reeve’s nocturnal cityscapes, and Yann Gross’s Ugandan skateboarder series. Hyères 2010 will also feature a Walter Pfeiffer retrospective and a new video by Steven Klein depicting his fashion photography from the past ten years. Klein’s highly structured, subversive images are a good counterbalance to Pfeiffer’s more jocular, candid photos. In case you can’t make the festival this weekend, the exhibitions run until May 30.

headline: Scott Turow Elected President of the Authors Guild
text: The lawyer and the queen of teenage lit are in the house!

headline: A Literary Life Can Turn Lonely When the Cheering Stops
text: As good actors age  perhaps a more felicitous word would be mature  they learn how to do more with less.

headline: John Dockery, Ex-Jet, Sells Town House
text: When you think about Brooklyn Heights, you probably think brownstones, book agents, and perhaps a famous actor or two.

headline: Video: ‘Passion Play’ by Street Light
text: Earlier, ArtsBeat covered Tuesday night’s performance of Sarah Ruhl’s “Passion Play” by the Epic Theater Ensemble, a portion of which was spontaneously presented outdoors when a fire alarm went off in the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church.

headline: Chin Up
text: ARE we becoming less vain or more frugal? Plastic surgeons suspect — and hope — it’s the latter. The number of cosmetic operations in 2009 fell by nearly 9 percent, according to the American Society of Plastic Surgeons. Even so, plenty of work was done. For instance, its survey said that nearly 4.8 million doses of Botox or Dysport were injected (at about $400 each), averting countless wrinkles.

headline: BlogTalk: Race Cards and Coyotes
text: Former Gov. Tim Kaine, the head of the Democratic National Committee, today announced his party’s strategy to win elections this fall. The main plank is to sell the Democrats as the “Results Party,” he said at a luncheon, and to paint the Republicans as obstructionist.

headline: Report Details Infighting at Bronx Science
text: Update, May 4 |  We added a live link to the letter that David Brodsky, head of labor relations for the education department, wrote in which he rejected the conclusions of the fact-finding report. See last paragraph of post.

headline: Laura Bush, a Lonely Texas Girl Far From Home
text: Laura Bush’s new memoir, “Spoken From the Heart,” is really two books. The first is a deeply felt, keenly observed account of her childhood and youth in Texas — an account that captures a time and place with exacting emotional precision and that demonstrates how Mrs. Bush’s lifelong love of books has imprinted her imagination. The second book is a thoroughly conventional autobiography by a politician’s wife — a rote recitation of travel, public appearances and meetings with foreign dignitaries that sheds not the faintest new light on the presidency of the author’s husband, George W. Bush.

headline: Six Flags, Two Brand Characters
text: The concept of a venerable brand character getting a younger sidekick is a popular one in advertising. Some even say it echoes the tradition in superhero comics to give, say, Batman a Robin, or Superman a Supergirl.

headline: 5 Killed in Gaza Shooting and Fire
text: GAZA — A 20-year-old Palestinian demonstrator was shot dead in Gaza by Israeli security forces on Wednesday, and at least four other men who were smuggling fuel died in a tunnel after the Egyptian authorities blew up another tunnel nearby, officials here said.

headline: "Ultrasuede: In Search of Halston"
text: A documentary about Roy Halston Frowick's clothes and lifestyle, directed by Whitney Sudler-Smith.

headline: Table Hopping | Dill in Reykjavik
text: The word up north these days is no longer Scandinavian, please, it’s Nordic. More precisely, in food trends, it’s New Nordic — a kind of frosty Slow Food locavore movement in which chefs (with toques off to Rene Redzepi of Noma in Copenhagen) are resurrecting and refreshing old food traditions. Butter and rapeseed oil are in, and Tuscan olive oil is out.

headline: More From the Frontlines of the Epistemic Closure Debate
text: After Wednesday’s article on the Great Epistemic Closure Debate that has engaged conservatives, a number of philosophers wrote in to complain: Don’t drag philosophy into it! The obscure term “epistemic closure” is being used in a vigorous online discussion to refer to a tendency on the right to operate in a closed information bubble, where news from outside the bubble is immediately ignored or discounted. Julian Sanchez, a libertarian at the Cato Institute, was the first to use the phrase in this context, and he noted, as did The Times article, that it had an unrelated meaning in philosophy, where it refers to a problem of logical deduction. Here are two links for the ambitious from Stanford and the Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy.

headline: The Rail Bookshelf: ‘Black Diamond and Blake’
text: Deborah Blumenthal has written 12 books, 9 for children, and has been a regular contributor to The Times, covering fitness, beauty, consumer issues and travel. Her latest picture book, “The Blue House Dog,” (Peachtree Publishers) is coming out Aug. 1.

headline: Shopping With Tony Daniels
text: An architect and sustainability expert shopped for products to help improve a home's environmental performance.

headline: Asian-Inflected Program With Unexpected Accent
text: One of the endearing attributes of the International Contemporary Ensemble, or ICE, is that it appears to have avoided taking on a stylistic agenda. Its players are virtuosic and flexible, and over the last few years they have been heard in modern works with nearly every kind of accent.

headline: A Masterpiece Good Enough to Walk On
text: If you thought you didn’t see enough Picassos at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where an exhibition of 300 opened on Tuesday, there is one other place to look. Picasso’s “The Dream” is taking shape on a sidewalk a few blocks away.

headline: A Choreographer’s Stamp, Still Unmistakable
text: Although we don’t think about it much in daily life, the way someone moves is as distinctive as a voice or facial features. Of course some movements, voices or features are more striking than others. So it is, in dance terms, with Stephen Petronio, one of the few contemporary choreographers to have created an instantly recognizable style and also a substantial oeuvre, built over 25 years upon hard-driving, limb-lashing, fascinatingly dense coordinations.

headline: Dead Zone Doldrums Test Skills of iPhone Customers
text: Owners of iPhones know that their love for Steve Jobs’s touch-screen marvel comes at a price. The iPhone’s cellular coverage, provided exclusively by AT&T Wireless, is notoriously spotty. In some parts of New York and San Francisco, it’s impossible to connect.

headline: Al Fresco Dining in Times Square
text: Hector’s, Rectors and Howard Johnson: time to come back!

headline: A Banksy Rat Is Victim of a Cleanup Campaign
text: Where Banksy is involved, there usually are no accidents, but it truly does appear to have been an accident that a street-cleaning crew in Melbourne, Australia, painted over a mural by that graffiti artist and provocateur. The Associated Press reported that Susan Riley, the deputy lord mayor of Melbourne, dispatched street cleaners to Hosier Lane there after residents complained about squalid conditions in an alley known for its displays of public art. Among the works was a stencil of a goggle-wearing rat created by Banksy during a visit to Melbourne in 2003 — and removed by the crew, which was instructed to eliminate all graffiti from the area. In an interview on Australian radio Kathy Alexander, the chief executive of the city, said, “Unfortunately the contractors were not made aware by us that that was an important piece, and unfortunately that means the piece is gone.”

headline: In the ’70s, Vicariously
text: WHITNEY SUDLER-SMITH was too young to be a part of the raucous party scene that was 1970s New York. So the 41-year-old screenwriter and son of the socialite Patricia Altschul did the next best thing: he made a movie about it.

headline: Arizona Iced Tea Forced to Show Its Papers
text: Update 2 | Thursday | 9:32 a.m. Travis Nichols just got in touch with The Lede and confirmed that, yes, he was joking when he called Arizona Iced Tea “the drink of fascists” on Twitter on Tuesday. He added that he was traveling for work yesterday and had no idea, until checking his e-mail at the end of the day, that his comment — which was inspired, he said, by the Twitter-based comic musings of @conanobrien and @colsonwhitehead — was being taken seriously by critics of Arizona boycotts and the media.

headline: Soundtracks Top Charts
text: Billboard’s album chart this week is all about soundtracks. According to Nielsen SoundScan “The Power of Madonna” (Columbia), the seven-song companion to last week’s all-Madonna episode of the Fox show “Glee,” opened at No. 1 with 98,000 sales, 75 percent of which were as digital downloads, an extraordinary ratio, although not quite record breaking. (In January, Kesha’s “Animal” had 76 percent, and the “Hope for Haiti” charity album was released only online.) Not far behind “Glee,” the all-AC/DC soundtrack to “Iron Man 2” (Columbia) reached No. 4 in its first week, with 76,000 sales. Billboard reported that it was the first time in the five-decade history of its main album chart that two soundtracks made their debuts in the Top 5. Also on this week’s chart Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville), shaping up as one of the steadiest sellers of the year, jumped a spot, to No. 2, with 83,000 sales, a 27 percent gain over the previous week. “My World 2.0” (Island) by Justin Bieber, the No. 1 album for the last two weeks, fell to No. 3 with 81,000, and Usher’s “Raymond vs. Raymond” (Jive) is No. 5 with 52,000.

headline: Mosley Plans His Legacy and His Efforts to Ruin Everyone Else’s
text: BIG BEAR LAKE, Calif. — Sugar Shane Mosley sits upstairs in the man cave at his training compound, the one with a massage table in the corner and a hot tub on the deck.

headline: Esteemed Dance Troupe Says It Is Open to Change
text: To New Yorkers, to Americans and to the world, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is in most respects one of the most valued of dance companies. Its popularity speaks for itself. Just 52 years old, it has continually toured the globe since the 1960s, it has danced in 48 states of the union, and its yearly seasons at New York City Center are five-week lovefests between dancers and audience.

headline: ‘Idol’ Leads the Night, but by Smaller Margin
text: Viewers were not much impressed with a Shania Twain-themed episode of “American Idol” on Tuesday night, as Fox’s usually substantial margin of victory shrank against a lineup of new CBS shows. According to Nielsen’s estimates, Fox’s “American Idol” led the 8 p.m. time slot as usual, but with a somewhat reduced 18.8 million viewers, as it faced stiff competition from “NCIS” (15.9 million) on CBS and “Dancing With the Stars “ (12.2 million) on ABC. At 9, CBS’s “NCIS: Los Angeles” (15.5 million) won the hour, ahead of Fox’s “Glee” (12.6 million), which was down almost a half-million viewers from last week. CBS also led at 10 p.m. as its drama “The Good Wife” (12.1 million) topped NBC’s “Parenthood” (5.9 million) and ABC’s “V” (5 million). Fox still managed to place first for the night over all, with CBS second and ABC third. NBC finished fourth, with “The Biggest Loser” (7.5 million).

headline: Metropolitan Opera Dips Into Endowment
text: The Metropolitan Opera last year freed up $22 million of its $242 million endowment to help cover operating expenses. With the permission of the donors, $15 million was shifted into the less restrictive endowment trust as an emergency reserve. The move, reported in the Wall Street Journal on Wednesday, was yet another effort by the Met to manage a deficit that is expected to be about $4 million for this fiscal year. With the permission of Chevron Texaco, the Met also moved $7 million in restricted funds. The Met has reduced the total budget by $18 million for the current fiscal year, resulting in an operating budget of about $300 million.

headline: Letters
text: A Daughter’s Story

headline: The Real Marilyn, In Her Own Words
text: Some of the most personal correspondence that Marilyn Monroe wrote is scheduled to be published for the first time in a book planned for the fall. The publisher Farrar, Straus & Giroux said it would release the book, “Fragments,” in October, and that it would contain rare photographs of Monroe, right, as well as reproductions of her typewritten and handwritten letters from the late 1950s and early ’60s. Courtney Hodell, an editor at the publishing house, said Monroe’s writing covered a wide range of subjects, including notes on the roles she was working on, exhortations to herself to become a better actress and lists of resolutions on how to do so, notes from her readings about Italian Renaissance art and how to decorate her apartment, and a recipe for stuffing. There are also diary-style entries on Monroe’s relationship with Arthur Miller, as well as letters to her psychoanalysts and to Lee Strasberg, her friend and acting instructor, written when she was in the locked psychiatric ward of the Payne Whitney Clinic in New York. “She’s trying to live the life of an artist and suffering a lot,” Ms. Hodell said in a telephone interview. The letters in the book, Ms. Hodell added, were part of the estate that Strasberg inherited after Monroe’s death in August 1962. The letters were given by his widow, Anna Strasberg, to Stanley Buchthal, a family friend and adviser, and Bernard Comment, an editor at the publisher Éditions du Seuil in Paris, to be compiled and edited for “Fragments.”

headline: When You Wish Upon a Star, Now You Can Call It by Name
text: Choose a clear night and hold your phone skyward, and the heavens suddenly make sense — that is, with the help of a stargazing application.

headline: While the Artists Chatted, He Taped
text: For a couple of decades the lowly plastic cassette tape, full of good sounds, cheaply copied and passed around like samizdat, served as creative raw material mostly in the indie-music world and the college dorm room.

headline: Lo-Fi High Art
text: William Furlong's new book, “Speaking of Art,” offers a sampling of interviews from Audio Arts, a “magazine” composed solely of cassette recordings of interviews with artists.

headline: Chaos Continues To Follow Justin Bieber
text: As Bill Bixby used to warn each week at the beginning of “The Incredible Hulk,” you wouldn’t like him when he’s angry. Now it appears that fans have stirred a slumbering giant within the diminutive figure of Justin Bieber, the 16-year-old pop star. Mr. Bieber admonished his followers on Wednesday morning after Auckland Airport in New Zealand was overrun with excited young fans, above, because of his arrival, BBC News reported. On his Twitter feed Mr. Bieber wrote: “The airport was crazy. Not happy that someone stole my hat and knocked down my mama. Come on people.” He continued in a second tweet: “I want to be able to sign and take pics and meet my fans, but if you are all pushing security wont let me. let’s keep it safe and have fun.” An Auckland Airport spokesman had said it was increasing security in anticipation of Mr. Bieber’s visit and keeping his arrival time secret, though it apparently did not stay secret for long. This incident follows the cancellation of a free outdoor show that Mr. Bieber was to perform in Sydney, Australia, where more than 4,000 fans were pushing and shoving one another.

headline: Where Ballads and Screams Coalesce
text: Courtney Love showed nerve when she led her new lineup of Hole at Terminal 5 on Tuesday night. But it wasn’t the kind of nerve that has kept fans loyal through 12 years between Hole albums, 8 since the band announced its breakup, and 6 since Ms. Love’s solo album, “America’s Sweetheart.” Ms. Love has made a public spectacle of herself for two decades, from tabloids to Twitter. She has been reckless, open, outrageous, thoughtless, funny, bizarre, self-destructive and self-promoting. For her, posturing and honesty have long since fused. And she has carried that tumult into songs that can tap into a primal fury.

headline: Managing Light and Shadow for eBay Pictures
text: Photo Tips

headline: An Anguished Howl of Folky Emo-ness
text: Hair in a tattered shag, pants super tight, two streaks of eye black slashing across his cheeks, Christofer Drew Ingle cut a woolly figure Tuesday night at the Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza. The feelings were raw too.

headline: The Conservative Dilemma
text: On a day when the political gods have smiled on David Cameron, Patrick Ruffini has a thoughtfully critical post on the Tory leader, his “Big Society” concept, and how it maps (or doesn’t) onto American conservatism. Along the way, Ruffini puts his finger on the major tension between the Cameronist spirit and the current mood on the American right — which is really a tension, and a dilemma, that runs through all conservative efforts to restrain, shrink and decentralize the state. It’s suggested by this passage from one of Cameron’s “Big Society” speeches, which Ruffini quotes:

headline: In Broadway Lights: No Vacancy
text: AFTER opening in November to some of the best reviews of the theater season, the Off Broadway production of “The Orphans’ Home Cycle” seemed on a fast track for Broadway. Three of New York’s most prominent play producers began trying to raise $2.5 million to move the show, even though its length (nine hours, broken into three parts) and lack of star performers made it an iffy investment for commercial Broadway. But the producers thought the show, the final opus of the acclaimed writer Horton Foote, had a good shot at Tony Awards  which go only to Broadway productions  and they believed that a wide audience would want to see the work, given the huge demand for tickets at its 160-seat Off Broadway house.

headline: Local Heroes, Far From Home
text: Rome

headline: Lenders Win Auction for Philadelphia Newspapers
text: 1:44 a.m. | Updated The lenders of Philadelphia’s bankrupt newspapers, The Inquirer and The Daily News, won an auction on Wednesday to take control of the company, outbidding a group of local investors, Joseph Plambeck reports in The New York Times.

headline: With ‘Enron,’ Financial Misdeeds Hit Broadway
text: Even with all the financial drama going on these days, including this week’s performance of “Goldman Sachs: The Senate Hearing,” the action is not limited to Wall Street. Just look at Broadway, where “Enron,” a theatrical tale of greed and manipulation, opened on Tuesday night.

headline: In the Garden: Unusual New Plants
text: Tony Avent, the owner of Plant Delights Nursery, is considered one of the forerunners in the field of breeding new varieties of plants for the consumer market.

headline: Who Should Be the Next Justice?
text: What criteria should President Obama use to choose a replacement for Justice John Paul Stevens on the Supreme Court?

headline: How to Play a Powerhouse, From a Leading Polish Expert
text: Krzysztof Martens from Poland is a two-time world champion (1984 World Team Olympiad and 1997 Transnational Teams) and three-time European team champion. But another great achievement is his series of 12 books, originally written in Polish and translated into English by Irena Chodorowska and Maciej Potz. They are aimed at good players and those who wish to be.

headline: On Location: Childproof, in a Cool Way
text: A couple’s East Village apartment is furnished with elegant pieces that are sturdy enough for their young sons to play on.

headline: China Stripped of Gymnastics Medal
text: The International Olympic Committee on Wednesday stripped the Chinese women’s gymnastics team of a bronze medal it won at the 2000 Sydney Olympics. The move came two months after one of China’s athletes, Dong Fangxiao, was found to be under-age at those Summer Games.

headline: Bid for Right to Sign Ballot Petitions in Secret Stirs Skeptics on the Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — A request that the Supreme Court create a new First Amendment right to keep secret the names of people who sign ballot petitions met with intense skepticism at the Supreme Court on Wednesday from justices across the ideological spectrum.

headline: Yanks’ Dave Robertson Is No Stranger to Bad Luck
text: BALTIMORE — The final batter Dave Robertson faced in college hit a game-winning, two-run homer off him, knocking Alabama out of the super regional round of the N.C.A.A. tournament. The first batter he faced that summer in the Cape Cod League blasted his first pitch for a grand slam.

headline: Hand-Me-Downs, Before and After
text: Adults who take over the homes of their parents face complicated decisions of what to keep and what to change.

headline: Director Is Elected at Times Co.
text: Carolyn Greenspon, a fifth-generation member of the family that controls The New York Times Company, was elected as a director.

headline: Comcast’s Revenue Rises 3.8% as Local Ads Start to Return
text: Beating Wall Street expectations, Comcast, the nation’s largest cable company, reported strong revenue gains and a turnaround in local advertising on Wednesday.

headline: How Reversible Is The Euro?
text: For a long time my view on the euro has been that it may well have been a mistake, but that bygones were bygones — it could not be undone. I was strongly influenced by the view expressed by Barry Eichengreen in a classic 2007 article (although I had heard that argument — maybe from Barry? — long before that piece was published): as Eichengreen argued, any move to leave the euro would require time and preparation, and during the transition period there would be devastating bank runs. So the idea of a euro breakup was a non-starter.

headline: Bank of America Names a New Chairman
text: Bank of America named DuPont’s longtime chief executive, Charles O. Holliday Jr., as its chairman on Wednesday, Reuters reports. He succeeds Walter E. Massey, who retired from the board after reaching the mandatory retirement age of 72.

headline: Posada Leaves Game After Being Hit
text: 8:18 p.m. | Updated BALTIMORE — Jorge Posada left Wednesday night’s game against the Orioles in the second inning after being struck on the right kneecap by a Jeremy Guthrie pitch.

headline: A Long Walk for a Cause
text: Four immigrant students arrived at the White House on Wednesday after walking from Miami to raise support for legislation to open a path to legal status for students who are illegal immigrants.

headline: Family and Friendship in Stately Victor’s Name
text: Louisville, Ky.

headline: Book Questions World Cup Business Arrangements
text: LONDON — Essentially, two World Cups were awarded to South Africa for 2010. Most visible was the 32-team soccer tournament that is the world’s largest sporting event. Less observable — and more contentious — were business arrangements that have raised serious questions of conflict of interest between the public and private sectors.

headline: Mets Handle Dodgers in Addition to Wind and Trash
text: The wind at Citi Field was so strong during the Mets’ 7-3 victory over the Dodgers on Wednesday that several players said they had never experienced anything like it.

headline: An Android That Doesn’t Follow the Pack
text: As Android phones begin to resemble one another as closely as the Fembots of an Austin Powers movie, Motorola is making a move to set its Android apart. It may be good for Motorola,  it will probably be good for developers, and it should certainly be good for the people who use the new Motorola phones.

headline: Japan Forces Bureaucrats to Defend Spending
text: TOKYO — Seeking to bring its spiraling debt under control, Japan has undertaken an unlikely exercise: lawmakers are forcing bureaucrats to defend their budgets at public hearings and are slashing wanton spending.

headline: Un-American Activities
text: So Rep. Duncan Hunter wants to deport people born in America — if their parents were illegal immigrants.

headline: The Hand-Me-Down Home
text: IN the annals of intergenerational friction, there are some familiar sources of disagreement: sex, money, music and what on earth you’re going to do with your life. Then there are the truly contentious subjects — like the fireplace tiles that used to be in Carla Weisberg’s apartment on West 12th Street in Greenwich Village.

headline: South Plaquemines Coach, Accused of  Profanity, Is Fired
text: Cyril Crutchfield, one of the top high school football coaches in Louisiana and a key figure in the recovery of the spindly peninsula located below New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina, has been fired after being accused of using profanity in a classroom.

headline: Two Designers Without Work Stage Roving Events
text: COLE NAHAL and Garrett Bowser may not have fully thought through the implications of withholding rent on their Broome Street two-bedroom for the last few months. Or was it magical thinking that prevented these two interior designers from deducing the fallout? In any case, three days after their eviction this month, the two were putting a positive spin on matters.

headline: Green House at World Financial Center
text: The Hudson, an eco-friendly, traditional prefabricated house developed by New World Home and Country Living magazine, will be on display at 220 Vesey Street at the World Financial Center from June 4 to 17, where visitors will have the opportunity to tour it before it departs for its permanent residence in Vernon, N.J.

headline: Green Products for the Home
text: ANY renovation, from a minor change to a major overhaul, offers the opportunity to reduce energy and water use and improve the comfort of a home.

headline: An East Village Apartment, Sleek and Childproof
text: AFTER hiring and firing two architects in three years, David and Blanche Uyttendaele had a home with a split personality.

headline: A Glassblower Turns to Weightier Materials
text: John Pomp made his name as a glassblower, but he is now turning his attention elsewhere. The Philadelphia designer recently introduced his first collection of furniture, mostly made of steel. “I grew up in a steel town, and my dad was a steelworker,” said Mr. Pomp, who spent his early years in Johnstown, Pa. “This collection was inspired by the stories of my past.” In fact, Mr. Pomp has been playing with steel for years, he said, fabricating tables and benches for his glassblowing studio. His new line, with Shaker influences, includes a chair, bench, coffee table, credenza, console and mirror. But the centerpiece is the $25,000 Travertine Trestle dining table, above, which has a hefty blackened steel base topped by a nine-foot slab of rough-edged travertine. All the pieces are made to order, and custom sizes are available. Information: (718) 486-9620 or johnpomp.com.

headline: American-Made Tile From Filmore Clark
text: Some people are locavores for arugula, tomatoes or lettuce. Now you can be a locavore for tile. Filmore Clark, a studio that sells artisan tiles made only in the United States, opened Feb. 1 in West Hollywood, Calif.

headline: A German Artist’s New Vases
text: Gestaltkunstwerke, a new collection of Artware Editions vases by Markus Linnenbrink, above, a German artist known for his glossy epoxy resin paintings and sculptures, grew out of Mr. Linnenbrink’s habit of recycling resin in his Bushwick, Brooklyn, studio — and out of his admiration for used plastic bottles and takeout containers. In a phone conversation from Berlin, where an exhibition of his work opens April 30 at the Fiedler Taubert Contemporary gallery, Mr. Linnenbrink explained his process.

headline: Sales at Takashimaya and Others
text: At Takashimaya New York’s closing sale, starting May 3, all merchandise will be 40 percent off (vintage kimono pillows, originally $195 to $375, will be $117 to $195; R&Y Augousti picture frames, originally $160, will be $96; and decoupage plates by Marisa Osorio Farinha, originally $395, will be $237); 693 Fifth Avenue (54th Street), (800) 753-2038.

headline: For Migrants, New Law Is Just Another Challenge
text: NOGALES, Mexico — Despite its intent to “discourage and deter” unlawful entry to the United States, Arizona’s tough new immigration law is not what prevented Verónica from sneaking into the state without papers. After all, she had already endured a harrowing train ride, escaped dangerous drug traffickers and eluded Mexican authorities who were after the money she had stuffed in her underwear.

headline: Life Sentence Is Debated for Meat Plant Ex-Chief
text: In a final chapter to the long aftermath of a 2008 immigration raid at a kosher meatpacking plant in Iowa, a federal court in Cedar Rapids heard arguments on Wednesday over the sentencing of Sholom Rubashkin, the former chief executive.

headline: The Plant Hunter
text: RALEIGH, N.C.

headline: State Senator Is Accused of a Scheme to Underpay
text: ALBANY — Two years ago, Shahking Gomez was unemployed when his job search led him to the Soundview HealthCare Network, a group of nonprofit health clinics in the Bronx operated by the State Senate majority leader, Pedro Espada Jr.

headline: Additional Misfortune for Lookin at Lucky
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Lookin at Lucky has been anything but in 2010. In the Rebel Stakes, the colt clipped the heels of another horse, stumbled and needed a late rush to eke out a head victory. In the Santa Anita Derby, he got pinned to the rail and virtually stopped before regaining his stride to finish third.

headline: A Study Offers Clues on Therapy for Cancer
text: A new study of women with the earliest form of breast cancer offers clues as to which patients may need aggressive therapy and which ones can be spared unnecessary treatment.

headline: Linking Customer Loyalty With Social Networking
text: PEPSICO wants to sell its customers sodas whether they are near a grocery store, a restaurant or a gas station. With a new partnership that weaves its loyalty program into the location-based network Foursquare, PepsiCo gets a live notification when its customers are close to those sites, and can present offers that get them into the stores.

headline: A Course of Pain That Pays Dividends
text: Tough Mudder, a semifinalist in the Harvard Business School’s annual Business Plan Contest,  appears to have found an opening in the burgeoning action-sports realm.

headline: Gulf Spill
text: Federal and oil industry officials are using every tool they have  including underwater robots and controlled burns on the water’s surface  to stanch the flow of oil from last week’s explosion of a drilling rig 50 miles offshore in the Gulf of Mexico. Every hour that passes without success brings Louisiana’s fragile wetlands and estuaries, and the marine life that depends on them, closer to environmental disaster.

headline: For Individual Reasons, Quadruplets Pick Yale
text: After Yale, for the first time in anyone’s memory, offered quadruplets early acceptance last fall, Kenny, Martina, Ray and Carol Crouch went on to receive letters of admission from more than a dozen other colleges. Among the factors they have debated in recent weeks was whether to attend the same college or to branch out.

headline: A Klatsch of Kindie Rockers
text: Organizers expect about 300 artists and industry professionals at the second annual KindieFest this weekend in Brooklyn, and another 300 children and their grownups for a festival concert on Sunday afternoon.

headline: What We’re Reading: Feelings for Apple
text: The New York Times’s tech reporters and editors are seeing reverberations from the lost iPhone prototype story,  mostly from established journalists who are grappling with their feelings toward Apple. But there are other things worth reading too:

headline: Merkel Tested as Escalating Greek Crisis Hurts Euro
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel’s strategy for dealing with Greece’s untenable debt problem was to stall and hope the crisis did not demand action until after a critical state election in early May. On Wednesday, the clock finally ran out.

headline: PPL to Buy 2 Kentucky Utilities for $6.7 Billion
text: PPL, the big American power company, agreed Wednesday to acquire Kentucky’s two largest utility companies from E.ON of Germany for $6.7 billion in cash, Reuters reports. The companies, Louisville Gas and Electric and Kentucky Utilities, serve about 1.2 million customers and operate about 7,600 megawatts of electric generation.

headline: Playing With Fire, Barbed Wire and Beer
text: A year ago, Tough Mudder was a semifinalist in the Harvard Business School’s annual Business Plan Contest. A British student named Will Dean thought he could attract 500 people to run a grueling race through mud and man-made obstacles. Professors generally considered the plan too optimistic.

headline: Candidate Bows Out of Union Race
text: Anna Burger, the secretary-treasurer of the Service Employees International Union, said Wednesday that she was ending her candidacy for union president, ceding the position to Mary Kay Henry, who has locked up the support of many large locals. Ms. Henry, an executive vice president and a leader of the union’s health care division, has rallied support since Andy Stern, the union’s president, announced two weeks ago that he planned to resign. Ms. Burger said Ms. Henry’s victory did not did represent a “shift in the S.E.I.U.’s priorities” or a “rejection of the Stern/Burger agenda.”

headline: Census Response Matches 2000 Rate
text: The Census Bureau said Wednesday that 72 percent of American households mailed back their 2010 census forms, the same rate as in 2000. Robert M. Groves, the census director, said that with response rates to most surveys declining for decades, he had expected that the 2000 rate would be "beyond reach.” He said the rate this year was helped because everyone got a short form and because follow-up forms were mailed when prompt responses were not received. Beginning Saturday, 600,000 enumerators will go door-to-door to find the up to 48 million households that failed to respond.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: D.I.Y. Electronics Repair
text: In this week’s Tech Talk podcast, J.D. Biersdorfer explores a new global effort to share information on repairing tech gear. She speaks with Kyle Wiens, a founder of the iFixit Web site, which offers free how-to advice on fixing Apple products. The site has a collaborative repair manual known as Repair 2.0 that aims to reduce electronic waste by enabling people to fix things instead of throwing them away.

headline: Goldman and Its Lobbyists Spurned in Fight on Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Last week, White House officials quietly approached leading financial firms seeking formal letters of support for a Congressional overhaul of financial regulations. One Wall Street powerhouse was left off the list: Goldman Sachs.

headline: A Listing of Home Tours for 2010
text: TRY doing this any other time of year, and you will be arrested for trespassing. But spring means the beginning of the house-and-garden tour season, allowing the curious to go through homes and outdoor spaces that otherwise sit behind closed doors and gates (unless otherwise noted, all tours are self-guided). In the New York area and around the country, stunning examples of private property become, temporarily at least, public.

headline:
In British Race, a Stray Remark
Haunts Brown
text: LONDON — Maybe it was proof of the maxim that a gaffe is when a politician tells the truth. Or maybe it was evidence that Prime Minister Gordon Brown, for all he tries to be nice, might actually be kind of mean.

headline: Obama to Nominate Three to Fed’s Board
text: President Obama will nominate Janet L. Yellen on Thursday to be vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, and fill two remaining seats on the central bank’s board of governors, officials said Wednesday evening,  Sewell Chan of The New York Times reports from Washington.

headline: In Cornfield’s Tremble, a Warning for New York
text: BERNE, N.Y.

headline: Former Fed Chief Dampens Talk of a Tax
text: WASHINGTON — Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman who recently incited speculation that the Obama administration would propose a European-style consumption tax to reduce deficits, on Wednesday said the idea was too unpopular to be under consideration “now or for the indefinite future.”

headline: Bloggingheads: Gaza Economics
text: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Bassam Nasser of Catholic Relief Services discuss Israel’s blockade of Gaza.

headline: Dangerous Games
text: By nearly all independent accounts, Iraq’s parliamentary elections last month were reasonably free and fair. Efforts now to manipulate the process  especially but not solely by Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki  are an insult to Iraqi voters. They are also dangerous. The longer it takes to form a new government, and the more questions raised about the process, the easier it will be for extremists to exploit the uncertainty.

headline: Desert Derangement Syndrome
text: PHOENIX — Driving south from the high, age-worn plateau of northern Arizona, where the earth seems to have turned itself inside-out, I pulled over to take in the full sweep and wonder of this place during one of its better moments. The infinity of sky, the open gallery of sandstone masterpieces — it never fails to amaze.

headline: Albany’s Workweek
text: Gov. David Paterson of New York has finally gotten so fed up with the failure of legislators and the unions to deal with the state’s budget crisis that he wants to do something revolutionary  make them shoulder part of the burden of saving taxpayers’ money.

headline: Cape Cod Residents Don’t Expect One Ruling to End Long Fight
text: HYANNIS, Mass. — The federal government may have described the Cape Wind project as a fait accompli, but Ian Parent does not expect to see turbines in the water or run the panini maker at his restaurant with electricity generated in Nantucket Sound any time soon.

headline: Off Patrol and High in the Trees
text: Corey J. Link is the senior arborist responsible for the health and beauty of the 30,000 trees that shade the 250 acres of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Mr. Link, 48, began moonlighting as a commercial arborist in 1997, toward the end of his 20-year stint as an officer with the New York Police Department. He was a sergeant and supervisor of detectives in the 47th Precinct in the Bronx when he retired in 2003 to turn to pruning, climbing (his specialty) and cutting full time.

headline: U.S. Subpoenas Times Reporter Over Book on C.I.A.
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is seeking to compel a writer to testify about his confidential sources for a 2006 book about the Central Intelligence Agency, a rare step that was authorized by Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.

headline: Theft of Torah Scrolls Saddens a Synagogue
text: Five sacred Torah scrolls valued at more than $30,000 each were stolen from a Brooklyn synagogue early Wednesday morning, the police said, leaving congregants shocked and saddened.

headline: City System to Carry Missing-Person Alerts
text: In an effort to further enlist the public in finding missing persons, New York City will begin sending alerts about them through a city-run information service that reaches tens of thousands of people.

headline: Woods and Mickelson Poised to Resume Rivalry
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — One might question whether Phil Mickelson and Tiger Woods generate enough electricity on the golf course to power an enduring rivalry along the lines of Palmer-Nicklaus or Nicklaus-Watson. But there is no doubt that each time they meet, they throw off more than enough sparks to generate big buzz and put a bounce in television ratings.

headline: Why Arizona Drew a Line
text: Kansas City, Kan.

headline: Cooking With Dexter: The Nut Case
text: Visiting Houston this spring, I ate the Mexican seafood cocktail called campechana de mariscos twice at two different restaurants. Each time, it was spicy, sweet and invigorating, a sufficient reason to fly to Texas. In between the two came chaos, guilt and fear.

headline: Red, Blue and Broke
text: Good news! The giant Palouse earthworm of the American plains is not extinct.

headline: Cuomo Takes Close Look at Condo Conversion at a Landmark Building
text: The New York attorney general’s office is taking a close look at plans to convert the Apthorp apartment building, one of the city’s best known, into luxury condominiums, an assemblywoman confirmed on Wednesday.

headline: Shrimp-and-Crab Campechana
text: For the campechana de mariscos sauce:

headline: Welcome to Arizona, Outpost of Contradictions
text: PHOENIX — Arizona is well accustomed to the derision of its countrymen.

headline: Dave Barry’s Fun House
text: Age: 62Occupation: WriterNext Project: His latest book, "I'll Mature When I'm Dead: Dave Barry's Amazing Tales of Adulthood," comes out May 4.

headline: At Sentencing in Killing of Professors’ Daughter, Enough Tears to Last 25 Years
text: Everyone in the courtroom knew how the proceeding would end: Michael A. Cordero would be led away in handcuffs to begin a 25-year sentence for manslaughter. But what the sentencing on Wednesday lacked in suspense, it made up for in emotion.

headline: Train Stopped Safely by ‘Dead-Man Feature’
text: They call it the dead-man feature.

headline: Gov. Crist Appears Set to Bolt Party in Senate Bid
text: MIAMI — Gov. Charlie Crist appears all but certain to announce Thursday that he is leaving the Republican Party and running independently for the United States Senate, setting up an unprecedented three-way contest without a clear front-runner.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 28, 2010

headline: Already Holding Junk, Germany Hesitates
text: FRANKFURT — Add this to the list of reasons German taxpayers are unhappy about having to lend Greece money to ease its debt crisis: In effect, they already have.

headline: State Senator Charges Racism Among  G.O.P. Lawmakers
text: ALBANY — Since he became a state senator in 2003, Kevin S. Parker has been charged with punching a traffic enforcement agent and scuffling with a photographer for The New York Post.

headline: Tory Leader Treads Confidently on Labour’s Turf
text: WAKEFIELD, England — This old coal mining town in West Yorkshire should be enemy territory for David Cameron, the Conservative Party leader who is campaigning to supplant the Labour Party prime minister, Gordon Brown, in next week’s general election.

headline: Rattlebrains
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — I wonder if you had the same reaction I did when you first saw this grid. There’s something, I don’t know, odd about it. You have to solve the puzzle to discover how appropriately odd it is.

headline: Obama Says Passing Immigration Bill May Be Difficult
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama conceded Wednesday that Congress may not have the appetite to deal with the hot-button immigration issue this year, but he vowed to continue to press lawmakers to at least begin work soon on a comprehensive bill to overhaul the country’s immigration system.

headline: Digging Deep and Seeing Greece’s Flaws
text: ATHENS — For Paul Koptides, who works in a car rental agency here, the news that Greece’s bonds had been reduced to junk status was just the latest in a series of blows, including wage cuts, new taxes and pressure from European neighbors for ever deeper austerity measures.

headline: The Oil Spill’s Effects on Wildlife
text: Maps and diagrams showing the impact of the oil spill on wildlife in the Gulf.

headline: Up in the Air, Obama Meets the Press
text: President Obama made a rare appearance in the back of Air Force One to chat with reporters on Wednesday.

headline: F. E. Dominy, Who Harnessed Water in the American West, Is Dead at 100
text: Floyd E. Dominy, a child of the Dust Bowl who pursued his dream of improving nature and human society by building vast water projects in the West — steamrolling over pristine canyons, doubtful politicians and irate conservationists — died on April 20 in Boyce, Va. He was 100.

headline: Canadiens Complete Comeback From 3-1 Deficit and Oust the Capitals
text: WASHINGTON — When Alex Ovechkin finally found a way to shoot the puck past the steely Montreal goaltender Jaroslav Halak early in the third period, he was bathed in spotlights as he dashed across the ice and the capacity crowd roared. It soon became an empty celebration.

headline: Yankees’ Swisher Finds Himself at Home at Camden Yards
text: BALTIMORE — Expressing himself has never seemed to be a problem for Nick Swisher, who nevertheless struggles to explain why he is so comfortable hitting at Camden Yards. Is it a favorable batter’s eye? The quality of the clubhouse spread? Something else?

headline: Corrections
text: EDITORS' NOTE

headline: For India’s Ruling Party, Challenge Is Governing
text: NEW DELHI — Last May, an unexpectedly strong election victory seemed to place the Indian National Congress Party at the brink of a new, more stable political era. Having struggled to lead a fractious coalition government for five years, the Congress Party made its best showing in 25 years and appeared positioned to get things done. Its opposition was in tatters.

headline: 2 Officials and 2 Views on Discussing Mideast Peace
text: WASHINGTON — For those wondering why it has been so hard for the United States and Israel to get past their dispute over Jewish housing, consider the disconnect on display this week in Washington.

headline: Labor Protests Test Egypt’s Government
text: CAIRO — Day after day, hundreds of workers from all over Egypt have staged demonstrations and sit-ins outside Parliament, turning sidewalks in the heart of the capital into makeshift camps and confounding government efforts to bring an end to the protests.

headline: China Gains Influence in Korean Affairs as North and South Warily Seek Its Help
text: SEOUL, South Korea — On Friday, President Lee Myung-bak will travel to China under growing pressure at home to make the case for crucial Chinese support for tough international sanctions against North Korea if, as is widely expected, the North is found responsible for the sinking of a South Korean ship. But he is unlikely to win that support, experts say, a reflection of China’s growing role in the Korean Peninsula.

headline: U.N. Chief Seeks to Strengthen Nuclear Pact
text: UNITED NATIONS — With the international treaty seeking to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons already wobbly, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on Wednesday called for it to be buttressed with renewed commitments toward disarmament and for tackling the knotty issue of a Middle East free of nuclear weapons.

headline: China: Schoolchildren Attacked
text: Fifteen children and a teacher in a Guangdong Province primary school were stabbed on Wednesday by an unidentified man in his 40s, but none of the injuries appear to be life-threatening, authorities in that southern region of China said. A nurse at the People’s Hospital in Leizhou, where the attack took place, said that most of the injured children were fifth and second graders. Police officers and firefighters who arrested the man later told state news agencies that he had given no motive for the knifings, which occurred on the same day that another man was executed for an attack on a primary school in Fujian Province last month that left eight children dead. That attacker said he had been despondent after breaking up with his girlfriend.

headline: Mexico: Gun Battle Outside School
text: Three people were killed in a drive-by shooting in front of children playing outside during recess in a kindergarten and elementary school in the border city of Ciudad Juárez on Wednesday, a local newspaper reported. Gunmen in one car opened fire on another as it traveled past the school, killing two men and a woman inside, the paper, El Diario de Juárez, reported. Earlier on Wednesday, gunmen burst into a bar in the city, took eight men or boys out to the parking lot and executed them, the Chihuahua State prosecutor’s office said. Despite the presence of more than 10,000 soldiers and police officers in the city, violence continues unabated.

headline: The Vatican: A Possible Mea Culpa
text: Pope Benedict XVI might offer a mea culpa about the sexual abuse of minors by priests at the culmination of a yearlong celebration of priests at the Vatican in mid-June, a high-ranking Vatican official has said. Cardinal William J. Levada, who oversees sexual abuse cases as prefect of the Vatican’s Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, said on “PBS NewsHour” that he “wouldn’t be surprised” if Benedict were to do such a thing.

headline: China: Rebuilding After Quake
text: Reconstruction work in the remote Tibetan area of Yushu, hit by a devastating earthquake on April 14, will start next Tuesday in two villages, the official English-language newspaper China Daily reported Wednesday. Officials will look at progress in two villages before releasing a comprehensive reconstruction plan for the Yushu area. The official death toll as of Sunday evening was 2,220, the report said. Officials have set a deadline of May 14 to clear the area of the ruins of major buildings.

headline: M.T.A. Plans More Rounds of Layoffs by July 4
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to lay off hundreds of bus drivers and subway workers by July 4, as the agency prepares to carry out severe service cuts to the city’s mass transit system.

headline: Winning the Worm War
text: DOR, Sudan

headline: Settlement in Police Shooting That Killed Emotionally Disturbed Man
text: Eleven years and hundreds of billable hours after Loretta M. Cerbelli sued the city over the fatal police shooting of her son in a station house in Queens, the case was finally settled on Wednesday. No money was exchanged, but both parties agreed to a meeting to discuss changes to police policy regarding the mentally ill.

headline: Listening to (and Saving) the World’s Languages
text: The chances of overhearing a conversation in Vlashki, a variant of Istro-Romanian, are greater in Queens than in the remote mountain villages in Croatia that immigrants now living in New York left years ago.

headline: Human Scale in the Grand Central Dig
text: Forty-five feet below Midtown’s busy streets, Todd Heisler of The Times took a tour of an enormous excavation project at Grand Central Terminal.

headline: Antibiotics in Animals
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rig Explosion Shows Danger of Drilling Off Our Coast
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Breast Cancer Tests
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Candidate From Xenophobia
text: As primary elections approach across the land, the award for best bottom-feeding campaigner surely belongs to Tim James, an Alabama gubernatorial candidate who vows to put an end to that grave threat posed by driver’s license tests being conducted in any language but English. “This is Alabama. We speak English,” Mr. James warns in a make-my-day growl.

headline: Apple Buys a Start-Up for Its Voice Technology
text: Apple continued its migration into Google’s turf on Wednesday with the acquisition of Siri, a mobile application that allows users to perform Web searches by voice command on a cellphone.

headline: Whitney Harris, Nuremberg Prosecutor, Dies at 97
text: Whitney Harris, one of the last of the prosecutors who brought high-ranking Nazi war criminals to justice at the Nuremberg trials and who, a half-century later, was a significant voice in the creation of the International Criminal Court, died on April 21 at his home in St. Louis. He was 97.

headline: Irish Official Calls Markets ‘Irrational’
text: A top Irish finance official said Wednesday that the soaring borrowing costs many European governments were facing showed that markets had become “irrational,” and he played down any comparison of Ireland’s financial situation to that of Greece, David Jolly reports in The New York Times.

headline: Ratings Agencies Are Overrated
text: Why do markets still pay attention to what rating agencies have to say? After their appalling record predicting the subprime mortgage crisis, it is astonishing and sad that investors still seem to quake when Standard & Poor’s reduces Greece’s rating to junk status and downgrades Spain’s.

headline: Volunteers Report on Treatment of Immigrant Detainees
text: It is the routine violations that have been most shocking to the small bands of suburban volunteers who visit immigration detainees in New Jersey jails.

headline: Word of the Day | intelligentsia
text: intelligentsia •\in-ˌte-lə-ˈjen(t)-se-ə, -ˈgen(t)-\• noun

headline: MusikPitch to Help Songwriters Compete for Contracts
text: Having raised $100,000 from angel investors, a start-up that allows songwriters to compete for custom music licensing contracts had its debut on Wednesday, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Oil and Water
text: WHERE was the photograph above taken?

headline: News Quiz | April 29, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Radio Days
text: I had the pleasure of being the “guest of the month” for April on the Brian Lehrer Show on WNYC, visiting five Thursdays, including today, to discuss population and consumption trends, the legacy of Earth Day, the longstanding paralysis over curbing emissions of greenhouse gases and a variety of other themes.

headline: Republicans Allow Debate on Financial Overhaul
text: With political pressure mounting, Senate Republicans relented on Wednesday and agreed to let Democrats open debate on legislation that would impose the most far-reaching overhaul of the nation’s financial regulatory system since the aftermath of the Depression.

headline: What Music Are You Listening To?
text: Usher? Justin Bieber? Lady Antebellum? All three are on this week’s Billboard album chart, along with the soundtrack from the all-Madonna episode of the Fox show “Glee.” What music are you listening to currently? What songs or albums have you bought or downloaded lately?

headline: Goldman and Its Lobbyists Spurned in Finance Fight
text: Last week, White House officials quietly approached leading financial firms seeking formal letters of support for a Congressional overhaul of financial regulations, Eric Lichtblau and Eric Dash report in The New York Times. One Wall Street powerhouse was left off the list: Goldman Sachs.

headline: Where the Bonuses Are Biggest
text: From Catherine Rampell at Economix:

headline: Evelyn Cunningham, Civil Rights Reporter, Dies at 94
text: Evelyn Cunningham, a civil-rights-era journalist and later an aide to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. She was 94 and lived in Harlem most of her life.

headline: Cape Cod Wind Farm Gets Approved
text: After nine years of regulatory review, the federal government gave the green light on Wednesday to the nation’s first offshore wind farm, a fiercely contested project off the coast of Cape Cod.

headline: Semiconductor Maker Prices I.P.O. for $92 Million
text: Alpha and Omega Semiconductor said Wednesday that it priced shares in its initial public offering within the expected range, Reuters reported.

headline: Tweet Seats
text: Theater seats reserved for Twitter users.

headline: Stocks Higher as Earnings Lift Sentiment
text: Stocks pushed past concerns over a widening European debt crisis and closed higher on Wall Street on Wednesday, after the Federal Reserve reassured investors that the economy was improving and left interest rates untouched as predicted, Christine Hauser reports in The New York Times.

headline: I.M.F. Promises More Greek Aid as Crisis Grows
text: Hoping to quell its biggest crisis since the Asian woes of 1997, the International Monetary Fund promised on Wednesday to increase the 45 billion-euro aid package for Greece to as much as 120 billion euros over three years, Landon Thomas Jr. and Nicholas Kulish report in The New York Times.

headline: Germany Raids Hundreds in Carbon-Trading Inquiry
text: On Wednesday, German prosecutors raided 230 offices and homes in an investigation into $238 million worth of tax evasion linked to emissions trading, Bloomberg News reported. Although they are cooperating with the search, Deutsche Bank and utility RWE said they are not the focus of the probes.

headline: Indian University Is Deemed Source of Radiation Exposure
text: NEW DELHI — The police have traced a major case of radiation exposure that killed one person and left six others hospitalized to a piece of outdated laboratory machinery auctioned off earlier this year by the chemistry department of one of India’s most prestigious universities.

headline: First Solar Buys NextLight for $285 Million
text: First Solar, the largest solar company in the world, announced Wednesday that it will acquire its chief rival, NextLight Renewable Power, a developer of solar power projects, for about $285 million. The deal will add 1.1-gigawatts worth of solar panel arrays to the larger company’s 1.4-gigawatt pipeline, VentureBeat reported.

headline: From Fake Profits to Failed Suicide: Denver Man Arrested
text: A hedge fund manager who claimed his investments never lost money, even during the economic downturn, faces allegations that he ran a Ponzi scheme and admitted to falsifying documents in an apparent suicide note, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Lions Gate Files to Appeal Poison-Pill Ruling
text: As expected, Lions Gate Entertainment is appealing a decision by regulators in British Columbia to quash a shareholders rights plan that would have helped it fend off a takeover bid by Carl C. Icahn.

headline: Santander’s Quarterly Profits Up 5.7 Percent
text: Despite the continuing woes of the Spanish economy, including the country’s sovereign debt downgrade on Wednesday, Banco Santander says its first-quarter net profit rose 5.7 percent thanks to strong revenue growth.

headline: Switzerland Takes Step to Cap Banker Bonuses
text: The Swiss government put forward a threefold plan Wednesday to cap bonuses in the banking and insurance sectors as it sought to win support from the parliamentary opposition for an agreement with U.S. authorities about UBS client data, as well as for a broader banking overhaul in Switzerland.

headline: Ex-McDonald’s Visionary Beats His Investment Drum
text: When it comes to understanding U.S. sensibilities, European entrepreneur Mats Lederhausen has always been ahead of the curve. Now, he is strategically forging his own investment agenda, Reuters writes.

headline: Goldman Stock ‘Dead Money’ at Best, Calamos Says
text: Calamos Investments sold its Goldman Sachs holdings when the news of the civil fraud charges against the bank hit, fearing the stock was at best “dead money,” Co-Chief Investment Officer Nick Calamos told Reuters on Wednesday.

headline: Amadeus Raises $1.74 Billion in I.P.O.
text: With 1.32 billion euros ($1.74 billion) raised, Amadeus IT Holding has completed the largest initial public offering in Western Europe since 2008. Bloomberg News reported that the flight-booking outfit sold shares above the midpoint of its price range selling 119.68 million shares at a price of 11 euros a piece.

headline: BlackRock and Blackstone Create New Mutual Funds
text: BlackRock and Blackstone Group‘s GSO Capital Partners have joined Goldman Sachs in announcing the creation of mutual funds to invest in loans at a time when the London interbank offer rate increases to an 8-month high.

headline: Mexican I.P.O.s on the Rise in 2010
text: In what would be the first I.P.O. in Mexico since June 2008, supermarket operator, Grupo Comercial Chedraui could raise as much as 4.8 billion pesos ($389.1 million), Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Buffett to Face Goldman Questions at Annual Gala
text: As shareholders of Berkshire Hathaway descend on Omaha, Nebraska, this weekend for its annual meeting on Saturday, Warren E. Buffett is sure to bask in the goodwill he has engendered in 45 years at the helm of Berkshire, but the world’s third-richest person always gets questions about things he could do differently.

headline: Packing a Picnic for May Day in Rome
text: Pecorino and fava beans are to May Day in Rome as a fish meal is to Christmas Eve or a lamb feast to Easter Sunday. So inextricably linked are the salty, pungent cheese and fresh, slightly bitter beans that one would be hard-pressed to find a single restaurant, home table or picnic blanket in the region without them this week. Romans head out of town for the famous May Day pairing, celebrating this worker’s holiday with some fresh air and relaxation in the nearby countryside. Here are some suggestions on where to join them.

headline: Can Europe Save Itself?
text: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. He is also a principal in Salute Capital Management Ltd. Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Millions for Top Execs Depend on Airline Merger
text: Should a merger of UAL‘s United Airlines with Continental Airlines  go forth, the top five executives at UAL are in line for millions in cash and stock, The Financial Times reported, citing a blog entry on Footnoted.org.

headline: Sinking Euro, Racing Strategists
text: As the financial crisis worsens in Europe, investors are fleeing the euro in droves — such droves that Bloomberg News says it’s happening at “a rate not seen since the collapse of Lehman Brothers.”

headline: With Settlement, Six Flags to Wave Again
text: Six Flags, the amusement park operator, has been cleared to exit bankruptcy, The Wall Street Journal reported. The clearance is the fruit of an 11th hour deal among bondholders, including groups led by Stark Investments and Avenue Capital.

headline: Attacker Stabs 28 Chinese Children
text: BEIJING — An unemployed man entered a kindergarten in Jiangsu Province in eastern China on Thursday morning and stabbed 28 kindergarten students and three adults, critically wounding at least five children, local authorities and state news agencies reported.

headline: Britain’s Got Volatility
text: Today’s idea: Britain’s own reality talent shows, and not so much American politics, are shaping the country’s volatile new experience with televised debates, a commentator says.

headline: South Korea Vows to Avenge Sailors’ Deaths
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The South Korean military vowed revenge without identifying a target as the country gave an emotional farewell on Thursday to the sailors killed when their ship sank last month near a disputed sea border with North Korea.

headline: Will E.U. Ruling Herald Hedge Fund Exodus?
text: Christopher Fawcett, a member of the hedge fund industry’s largest trade group, told Bloomberg News that a crackdown by regulators in Europe has hedge fund managers across the zone mulling the idea of putting offices in areas like Hong Kong, Singapore and Switzerland.

headline: Prudential Said to Get Korean Nod for AIA Deal
text: Prudential Plc, the British insurer, has secured South Korean antitrust approval for its planned $35.5 billion takeover of the American International Group‘s Asian life insurance business, a Korean Fair Trade Commission official told Reuters on Thursday.

headline: Buying Serena’s Handbag
text: Television viewers who crave Serena’s handbag on “Gossip Girl” or Lo’s dress on “The Hills” have been able to log on to SeenON, a Web site that identifies and links to other sites that sell the clothes that stars wear onscreen.

headline: Why I Keep Joining Business Groups
text: My first experience with a business group came about 20 years ago, when I tried to assemble my own. In theory, it seems like this should be an easy thing to do. It’s not. It is very hard to find enough people to get a group going — even if you’re not charging anything. And even if you do get it going, it can be difficult to keep it going. It feels like a full-time job because it is a full-time job – one that I wasn’t very good at and didn’t have time to do. My do-it-yourself group lasted less than a year and did not have the benefit of the resources that professional groups have, including the ability to recruit new members.

headline: Best Defensive Tackles in N.F.L.: The Top 10 List
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -– but not strictly -– by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, though the future isn’t ignored. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: No Cash? No Problem!
text: No cash? No problem. I accept mobile phones too.

headline: Omers Said to Cut Out Middlemen in Talks for I.S.S.
text: Canadian pension fund Omers is close to edging out four private equity firms by acquiring the port and shipping group Inchcape Shipping Services, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Q.& A.: You Don’t Need a Weatherman
text: Q.

headline: E.U. Says, ‘Greece’s Needs Will Be Met on Time’
text: José Manuel Barroso, the president of the European Commission, said in a statement issued on Thursday in Brussels that European Union officials were doing all they could to ensure that loans were soon provided to Greece, James Kanter reports in The New York Times.

headline: City to Overhaul Special Education
text: Here’s what we’re reading this morning.

headline: One Firm Refused to Aid a Goldman C.D.O. Plan
text: A little-known investment firm has found itself caught up in the Securities and Exchange Commission‘s fraud case against Goldman Sachs, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Sampler: Proposition 8 Trial to Return; Antioch Cancels July 4 Celebration
text: Date Set for Proposition 8 Trial Final Arguments | Same-sex marriage supporters and opponents, mark your calendars. Closing arguments in the federal trial to determine if California’s same-sex marriage ban violates the Constitution have been scheduled for June 16. After hearing testimony in January, Chief Judge Vaughn R. Walker of United States District Court for the Northern District of California wanted a break to review evidence before hearing closing arguments. But that break stretched out as Equality California and the American Civil Liberties Union fought turning over internal documents from the 2008 campaign against Proposition 8 to the measure’s supporters. On Tuesday, the groups agreed to supply the documents. [The Associated Press]

headline: Get Your Poem On
text: It’s Poem-in-Your-Pocket Day. Send us a poem about what’s in your pocket.

headline: SeenOn’s Parent to Buy Billion Dollar Babes
text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: Speed Read for Thursday, April 29
text: Here are some highlights from Thursday’s edition of The New York Times:

headline: Putting a Value on Explosive Plays, and Why Brandon Marshall Is a Dolphin
text: The beating took place Monday, Sept. 21, 2009, in Miami. The perpetrator, the Dolphin offense, ran all over the victim, the Colt defense. Forty-nine times for 239 yards, to be exact.

headline: Mullins Receives Another Suspension

But if million-dollar sculptures are out of your league, you can still admire the stuff at one of a series of new spots around the city dedicated to the business of marrying art with, well, business.

headline: The Morning Line: Unlucky Post Positions
text: The post position draw for the Kentucky Derby definitely established a theme for the media coverage, and much of the coverage today (and there was a ton of coverage) focused on the unfavorable post position draws for the favorite Lookin at Lucky and the second choice Sidney’s Candy. Papers throughout America and the U.K. focused on the unfavorable draws including The Times, Daily News, NY Post, Boston Globe, Louisville Courier-Journal, Boston Herald, and USA Today. The Racing Post in the U.K. understatedly describes Bob Baffert as making “no attempt to disguise his disappointment after favourite Lookin At Lucky was handed the unfavorable draw right on the inside rail in gate one of 20 in Saturday’s race.”

headline: Financial Reform and the Perils of the Center
text: In the debate over financial reform, the Senate G.O.P. seems to be proceeding the way Democrats and a large swathe of the chattering class wanted them to proceed on health care reform. For most of the way, they’ve been the party of “yes, if …” rather than the party of no, using the limited powers of the minority to ease the bill in their direction, rather than trying to defeat it outright. As a result, it seems likely that “FinReg” will pass with more than a few G.O.P. votes, having been amended in ways that address at least some conservative concerns. You can chalk this compromise up to pure political self-interest — financial reform is much more popular than health care reform and everybody knows it — or to the fact that the ideological stakes are lower on these issues than they were on health care. But either way, the Republicans have behaved extremely “responsibly” on the issue, at least as the Beltway consensus defines “responsible.”

headline: Love and Cartagena
text: IN the deep recesses of the Basurto market, a man is shaving the face of a pig. A razor in his hand, he glides across its face to remove the fuzz. The pig will soon be dinner. Not far away, cow hearts are on sale, and beside them cow eyes, staring out ominously, bound for a hearty potage. A shopping cart full of limes whizzes past. Alcatraz birds loom on the corrugated-tin roofs. “My Sweet Lord” is playing in one corner; in another, Caribbean songs pour from a bar lined with drinkers. It is not yet noon.

headline: Text-Blocking Apps Only Work if You Use Them
text: In my Times column Thursday morning, I reviewed cellphone apps that prevent you from calling, texting or e-mailing when you’re driving. I noted that they’re far from perfect solutions. For one thing, they work only on BlackBerrys and Android phones at this point-a tiny percentage of all phones. And they can’t distinguish between the motion of you, the driver, and the motion of you, a passenger in someone else’s car or even on a train or a bus.

headline: A Canal Zone Comes Into Its Own
text: The Gowanus neighborhood of Brooklyn, the city’s latest industrial desert turned cultural outpost, makes for a pleasant afternoon’s wander. The namesake canal, while it holds tons of poisonous stuff, is serene and calming. Things still do get a little post-apocalyptic: the weird drone of a cement factory, wide empty streets dotted with used condoms, a lone cormorant perched on the bank of a Superfund site. But with its historic bridges, canoeing club, low-slung buildings and growing selection of restaurants (Ethiopian, anyone?), Gowanus is laid-back and friendly. And markedly accessible: Jump off the B, D, M, N, Q, R, 2, 3, 4 or 5 trains at the Atlantic/Pacific station and head down Fourth Avenue from the Williamsburgh Bank tower to start your day in big-sky country.

headline: Happily Lost in the Luberon
text: WE walked down the middle of a street in L’Isle-sur-la-Sorgue as if we’d wandered in from the set of “The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie.” My five friends and I had come to this village in the Luberon, a collection of small hilltop towns in sun-baked northern Provence, to roam through its famed antiques stores before dinner. But we soon realized  to paraphrase Peter Mayle, the author of “A Year in Provence”  that here you can find everything except a bargain. And so we were walking toward a restaurant instead. And not just any restaurant, but a place I had heard tell was the region’s up-and-coming gem. The only problem? It was proving difficult to find.

headline: Where Isolation Is a Perk, and the Point
text: LAST May, on the tiny tropical resort island of Nikoi, Peter Timmer sat at an open-air, thatched-roof bar, holding an icy cocktail glass. It was a perfect day in paradise: clear sky, turquoise water as far as the eye could see, and a warm, salty breeze. With the leathery skin of a lifelong sailor and a mellow grin, he was a Robinson Crusoe-esque character who didn’t want to be rescued.

headline: F.D.A. Approves ‘Vaccine’ to Fight Prostate Cancer
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first treatment that uses a so-called cancer vaccine, a drug that trains the body’s own immune system to fight the disease.

headline: 36 Hours in Beirut
text: WANT a Beirut investment tip? Concrete. Thanks to a couple of years of political calm, the palm-fringed Middle Eastern city is bingeing on new buildings and cultural projects. A fast-expanding night-life strip, an upstart design district, new hotels and the country’s first contemporary art museum have all sprouted in the last few years. And they’re certainly not going unnoticed. A record number of travelers showed up to discover Lebanon and its capital in 2009. If the peace holds, look for an even bigger swell this year.

headline: Book Review: ‘Grounded: A Down to Earth Journey Around the World’

To reconnect with the primal vastness of the earth, they decided to go only by pre-Wright Brothers transport, renouncing the jet’s lofty perspective for the more sluggish and archaic ship, train, bicycle, motor scooter and automobile.

headline: The Case of the Back-Seat Bag
text: My cousin and I went out for the evening. I invited a friend to join us. At the end of the night, which included one too many alcoholic beverages, my cousin’s very distinct and expensive designer handbag was missing. A month later, I noticed the same bag in the back seat of my friend’s car. She tried to tell me that a boyfriend bought it for her — in a city where the designer doesn’t even have a store. Now it’s uncomfortable, especially since she wears the bag everywhere she goes. Should I confront her, or just steal it back?

headline: Pogue’s Posts: Apps to Prevent Distracted Driving
text: In my New York Times column this morning, I reviewed cellphone apps that prevent you from calling, texting or e-mailing when you’re driving. I noted that they’re far from perfect solutions. For one thing, they work only on BlackBerrys and Android phones, which is, at this point, a tiny percentage of all phones. And they can’t distinguish between the motion of you, the driver, and the motion of you, a passenger in someone else’s car or even on a train or a bus.

headline: Street Smart
text: New York streets usually offer mere glimpses into people’s apartments and town houses, so it isn’t every day that you walk past a storefront and realize that you’re staring straight into someone’s living room — and dining room and kitchen. Which is just fine with this apartment’s owners, the fashion designer Lela Rose and her husband, Brandon Jones, a hedge fund manager. Along with their two young children, the couple lives happily on view to their downtown neighbors in an expansive ground-floor space (plus parts of two subterranean floors) that was designed by Amale Andraos and Dan Wood, the founders of the seven-year-old company Work Architecture.

headline: Oh, Boy: Lennon’s Lyrics for ‘A Day in the Life’ for Sale
text: It was 43 years ago today, give or take, that a series of real-life events and everyday occurrences, including a newspaper article about the numerous potholes in the British town of Blackburn, Lancashire, inspired John Lennon and Paul McCartney to write what would become the final song on “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band” and one of the Beatles’ best-known recordings. And for a sum that could probably pay for the restoration of more than a few bumpy British roads, Lennon’s original handwritten lyrics for his part of “A Day in the Life” could be yours: Reuters reported that at an auction on June 18 Sotheby’s would sell the single sheet of paper on which  Lennon composed his verses, starting with the famous line, “I read the news today, oh boy.”
