The namesake canal, while it holds tons of poisonous stuff, is serene and calming. Things still do get a little post-apocalyptic: the weird drone of a cement factory, wide empty streets dotted with used condoms, a lone cormorant perched on the bank of a Superfund site. But with its historic bridges, canoeing club, low-slung buildings and growing selection of restaurants (Ethiopian, anyone?), Gowanus is laid-back and friendly. And markedly accessible: Jump off the B, D, M, N, Q, R, 2, 3, 4 or 5 trains at the Atlantic/Pacific station and head down Fourth Avenue from the Williamsburgh Savings Bank tower to start your day in big-sky country.

headline: ‘Innocent’
text: Nat, September 30, 2008

headline: An Emotive ‘Oedipus’ in Stravinsky Festival
text: Stravinsky, who scorned emotions in art and said — among his many, sometimes contradictory pronouncements — that music was “powerless to express anything at all,” described his opera-oratorio  “Oedipus Rex”  as austere. The first audience certainly found it dour after the excitement and exoticism of his ballets. But while Stravinsky aimed for ironic detachment, the work can seem vividly theatrical and even emotive, as it did in the striking interpretation conducted by Valery Gergiev with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening, part of the orchestra’s festival The Russian Stravinsky.

headline: The Plaza Hotel Gets Its Own Perfume
text: With luxury hotels customizing their bath collections and creating exclusive scents for their lobbies, it was only a matter of time before one came out with a signature body perfume.

headline: Save Greece, Protect Germany
text: China is to the world as Germany is to Europe.

headline: A Man With a Dead Wife on His Hands
text: Readers of Scott Turow’s engrossing 1987 novel,  “Presumed Innocent,”  will be startled to learn that in the sequel to that thriller, his hero, Rusty Sabich, now 60, is still married to Barbara, his volatile, unhappy wife, and that he’s now the chief judge of the State Court of Appeals.

headline: Hot Off the Presses: A Jungle Gym
text: While the days of the printed newspaper may be numbered, it continues to inspire a generation of … playground equipment designers. That’s right. On Wednesday, the Parks Department unveiled a new jungle gym at Printers Park in the Bronx that is shaped like the first rotary printing press, invented in 1846 by Richard March Hoe, whose former estate the park now occupies and who lent his name to Hoe Avenue, the street that runs by the park, in the Longwood neighborhood. It is part of a $1 million overhaul of the park, made possible through City Councilwoman  Maria del Carmen Arroyo.

headline: Answers About New York School Data, Part 2
text: Following is the second set of responses from Robert Gebeloff, a computer-assisted journalist with an expertise in education who has been working on an extensive database of New York education statistics.

headline: A Studio Is Added to a ‘Cronkite Portfolio’
text: VERA GIBBONS agreed to buy her one-bedroom apartment at  860-870 United Nations Plazaon one condition: that Walter Cronkite come to her Christmas party. He did.

headline: Toy Executive’s Apartment Sells
text: LYNN PRESSMAN RAYMOND was a successful woman in a man’s world — and in a child’s world, too. For some 20 years, starting in the late 1950s, she was the chief executive of the Pressman Toy Corporation.

headline: Bringing Out the Mummies at the Bass Museum
text: To expand audiences for cultural attractions in grim economic times, why not bring out a corpse or two, preferably from ancient Egypt?

headline: Tweaking a Name in Long Island City
text: Anniversaries and expansions are often a time of reflection. In the museum world they are also an occasion for rebranding. To mark the 10th anniversary of the merger between the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens, and the Museum of Modern Art, P.S. 1 has changed its name to simply MoMA PS 1.

headline: Photo of the Week
text: A jet is silhouetted against the full moon in St. Petersburg, Russia.

headline: Medieval Remnants of the Jews in Spain
text: Trick question: What world-changing event happened in 1492 involving Queen Isabella of Spain? If you answered, “The Jews were expelled from Spain by edict of the queen and her husband, Ferdinand II,” you probably have an uncommonly high history I.Q. You probably also know that Isabella and Ferdinand had started the Spanish Inquisition 14 years earlier in an effort to ferret out Jews who had ostensibly converted to Christianity but continued to practice Judaism in secret.

headline: Works That Span a Century and a Variety of Modern Moods
text: Just before the Chiara String Quartet played Webern’s Five Movements for String Quartet on Wednesday evening at Le Poisson Rouge, the group’s first violinist, Rebecca Fischer, pointed out that the work was 101 years old. There was a sense of wonder in her tone — an unspoken subtext that seemed to ask, “Can you believe that people still hear this antique as harsh modernism?” Ms. Fischer added that for her, the movements are five “tiny landscapes.”

headline: Susan Boyle Tops Global Sales Chart
text: When American album sales for last year were tallied up, Taylor Swift edged out Susan Boyle, below, for the No. 1 spot. But Ms. Boyle has the last word when it comes to the global charts. Her debut, “I Dreamed a Dream,” was the most popular album around the world, with 8.3 million sales, according to a new report by the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry, a trade group based in London. “I Dreamed a Dream,” released in late November, beat out not only Ms. Swift’s album, “Fearless,” which placed fourth in global sales, but also “The E.N.D.” by the Black Eyed Peas (No. 2) and the soundtrack to “Michael Jackson’s This Is It” (No. 3). Jackson was the best-selling artist over all, with 22.9 million album sales around the world; five of his titles are in the Top 20. The best-selling digital single of 2009 was Lady Gaga’s “Poker Face,” with 9.8 million sales. (The Black Eyed Peas’ “Boom Boom Pow” was tops in the United States, with 4.7 million downloads, according to Nielsen SoundScan.)

headline: Warning to Parents: Don’t Try This at Home
text: A marital tiff begins “Parents’ Evening,” a two-hander by Bathsheba Doran that opened Thursday night at the Flea Theater. A full-bore argument consumes much of the second act. In between there are needling, squabbling and generalized passive aggression.

headline: Kennedy Casting Set for TV Mini-Series
text: “The Kennedys,” the coming History channel mini-series, has found its lead actors to play the central members of the family. Greg Kinnear, top left, an Academy Award nominee for “As Good as It Gets,” will play John F. Kennedy; Barry Pepper, top right, (“Saving Private Ryan”) will play Robert F. Kennedy; Tom Wilkinson, above left, an Emmy Award winner for “John Adams,” will portray the family patriarch, Joseph P. Kennedy; and Katie Holmes, right, (“Batman Begins,” “Dawson’s Creek”) will play Jacqueline Kennedy. The mini-series, produced by Joel Surnow, a creator of the Fox action series “24,” has been criticized by historians who were provided early drafts of the scripts by the filmmaker Robert Greenwald, who has made liberal-leaning documentaries. The historians said the scripts had historical inaccuracies and presented an unflattering picture of President Kennedy and his family. History plans to show the eight-hour mini-series next year.

headline: Knocked for a Loop on the Road
text: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Women’s Professional Soccer in the league’s first season. Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, will be filing to the Goal blog during the defending champions’ 2010 season.

headline: Basking in Triumph, Unfurling Parasol Pop
text: V. V. Brown spent the last few moments of her show at the Bowery Ballroom on Wednesday night in recap mode, shoring up a narrative one bullet point at a time. “I’m going to tell you a story about my life,” she said as her backing band struck up a groove, and what followed was a testimonial, or maybe the foundation of a personal mythology.

headline: Polanski Lawyers Seek Prosecutor’s Testimony
text: Lawyers for Roman Polanski filed a motion in Los Angeles County Superior Court on Thursday seeking access to the sealed transcript of testimony by a prosecutor, Roger Gunson, about a judge’s sentencing plan in the 33-year-old sex case against Mr. Polanski. The motion contends that Mr. Gunson’s testimony would prove that an extradition request filed with Switzerland last year included a false depiction of the sentencing plan by Judge Laurence J. Rittenband. The request said that Judge Rittenband sent Mr. Polanski to prison in 1977 for a psychiatric study so he would “be in a better position to reach a fair and just decision” before sentencing, while Mr. Gunson, according to Mr. Polanski’s lawyers, has testified that Mr. Polanski’s prison stay was to constitute his entire sentence. Prosecutors have argued in court that the extradition request was an accurate portrayal of events. Mr. Polanski’s lawyers said that Swiss officials needed access to the sealed transcripts to fairly determine whether Mr. Polanski should be sent back to the United States, which he fled in 1978 before sentencing for having sex with a minor. A hearing on the motion was set for May 10.

headline: Fun With Feathers and Bones
text: Combine some of the materials in “Dead or Alive” at the Museum of Arts and Design, and you’d have a potent witch’s brew. A single piece by Tessa Farmer, for instance, makes use of a ram skull, a mummified frog and bat, bladderwort, hedgehog spikes, weasel skulls, a spider web and sections of a wasp’s nest. (Another sinister-sounding substance, volcanic ash, delayed the piece’s installation; it will be up by Tuesday.)

headline: For Some, Tiger Fatigue Has Set In
The Poet as Gardener and Tiger Lily
text: Emily Dickinson once called herself a “a Lunatic on Bulbs,” referring to her passion for daffodils, hyacinth and other spring perennials, which she raised indoors in winter in her family home in Amherst, Mass. And a lunatic she probably seemed to neighbors who spied her gardening by moonlight on summer evenings in the flower beds behind the house.

headline: U.S. Seeks to Revamp NATO Treaty in Europe
text: BERLIN — Spurred by a new treaty with Russia to reduce strategic nuclear missiles, the United States and NATO are seeking to revive a major treaty on conventional weapons in Europe, according to Anders Fogh Rasmussen, NATO’s secretary general.

headline: Puerto Rican Lenders Face Their Own Crisis
text: The latest American banking crisis is taking shape far from Wall Street and the empty subdivisions that stretch across the Sun Belt.

headline: New Shades of the Blue and the Gray
text: WASHINGTON — Of the Civil War, there is no end. So exhibitions commemorating the 150th anniversary of its beginning might seem superfluous. In recent decades hasn’t the Civil War been in almost continuous commemoration? It is now considered to be as central an event in the history of the United States as the Revolutionary War. Its key documents — all of them Lincoln’s, including the Gettysburg Address, the Emancipation Proclamation and the Second Inaugural Address — have become as fundamental for understanding American ideals as anything written by the founding fathers.

headline: Of Guns and Bicycles
text: This just in: The federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives on Thursday released its annual report on guns recovered in crimes in New York.

headline: Viacom’s Profit Up 37% as Ads Return
text: An increase in advertising revenue and higher fees from cable affiliates helped Viacom report a 37 percent gain in first-quarter profit on Thursday.

headline: Publisher to Release Philip K. Dick’s Insights Into Secrets of the Universe
text: After a lifetime’s worth of literature from Philip K. Dick that explored the future, the farthest regions of space and the afterlife, a posthumous work will take readers to a different alien terrain: the inside of the author’s mind.

headline: Kidding the Clowns Online, but Who Will Laugh Last?
text: EVEN for guys who paint their faces with clown makeup and rap about brutality and dead bodies they found in the streets, the past few months have been strange for Insane Clown Posse. After proudly representing the horrorcore rap scene for nearly two decades, this hip-hop group, consisting of the Detroit natives Shaggy 2 Dope and Violent J, is enjoying a resurgence in attention — if not popularity — from Internet videos poking fun at their music and their harlequin-faced fans, who call themselves Juggalos.

text: Wondering what to do this weekend? We have you covered.

headline: Rough Morning? It Could Have Been Worse
text: So maybe you overslept, and the coffee you gulped on the way out the door did not jump-start your brain. Maybe you had to wait for what seemed like an eternity until the subway came. Maybe you accomplished very little all morning. (See caffeine, lack of, above.)

headline: Video Highlights of the Final British Debate
text: During Thursday’s final televised debate among the candidates to be Britain’s next prime minister, we had live video of the encounter here on The Lede, from The BBC, which broadcast the debate. Now that the encounter has ended, we excerpts from the debate courtesy of Britain’s Channel 4 News. To read some of the rapid reaction news analysis of the debate filed to The Lede by my colleagues John Burns, Alan Cowell and Stephen Castle, during the event click here.

headline: One Woman’s ‘Truth’: Rielle Hunter Talks to Oprah
text: Rielle Hunter, who told Oprah Winfrey in a program broadcast on Thursday that John Edwards had a secret affair with her because “he wanted to live a life of truth,” is a tough interview, tougher in some ways than President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran.

headline: Holding Up a Mirror to Women, Thorns and All
text: The last words in “Please Give,” Nicole Holofcener’s latest comic drama of spiky manners, are “you’re welcome.” They’re uttered by Kate, a New York malcontent played with complex appeal by the wonderful actress Catherine Keener. Kate’s daughter, Abby (Sarah Steele), a stridently truculent teenager, has in a rare instance of filial generosity just thanked her mother for agreeing to pay for a pricey pair of jeans. From the near-beatific look on Kate’s face, it seems that after struggling to make amends for some vague, unarticulated wrong  by doling out cash to homeless people, for instance  she has found her moment of grace.

After canceling “Foyle’s War,” one of the best mysteries on television, in 2007, they did an about-face, and a three-episode seventh season begins on Sunday night on PBS’s “Masterpiece Mystery!”

headline: Retiree With Gun Seeks Young Thugs
text: Charles Bronson, meet Michael Caine, who in “Harry Brown” matches you vigilante move for move in the annals of big, bad, bloody, disreputable entertainment. Sir Michael has prowled down other mean streets several times before in his storied career, notably as a shootin’-tootin’ gangster out to avenge his brother’s death in Mike Hodges’s hard-boiled 1971 thriller, “Get Carter.” Now 77, Mr. Caine no longer conveys the cold brutality he once did. But he brings a plausible suggestion of steeliness (and a familiar gift for waterworks) to his role in this flick as the titular former military man turned trigger-happy pensioner.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington, Elsewhere
text: Like all distinguished photojournalists, Doug Mills just seems to have a knack for breaking out of pack situations — even pack situations as highly controlled as those in Washington. Think of his picture of Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s burial ceremony last August. On Thursday, Mr. Mills showed that flair again in what seems to be a remarkably introspective moment for President Obama.

headline: Reaction to Crist’s Decision
text: The decision by Gov. Charlie Crist to run as an independent not only upended the Florida Senate race, but also raised fresh questions for the midterm election year – and beyond – about the direction of the Republican Party. But Republican leaders in Washington sought to play down any divisions in the party and cast Mr. Crist’s decision as a politically craven one.

headline: 10 of the Moment | Rufus Wainwright

headline: Conan O’Brien Opens Up About NBC Departure
text: In his first interview since walking away from NBC’s “Tonight Show," Conan O’Brien tells “60 Minutes” Sunday night that he believes he was not given a fair chance to prove he could succeed and that money may have been the reason NBC decided to bring Jay Leno back to late-night television.

headline: Europe’s Debt Woes Start to Complicate China’s Money Moves
text: HONG KONG — Spreading problems in Europe’s sovereign debt markets pose potential challenges for China, which has been stepping up its investments in European government bonds and relies on Europe as its biggest export market.

headline: Finally, DealBook Is Back in Business
text: DealBook and its sibling blogs on nytimes.com were down since midmorning because of severe technical problems with our blog publishing system. (Be glad the Nasdaq doesn’t run on our system.) Now we’re back, but the system is still a bit troubled, so posting will be light this evening.

headline: Iran Reformist Tries to Enlist Labor and Teachers
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Iranian opposition leader Mir Hussein Moussavi released a video statement on Thursday calling on workers and teachers to join the reformist cause, in a bold new attempt to broaden and energize the country’s flagging protest movement.

headline: All the Picassos in the Cupboard
text: When in doubt, haul the Picassos out. There have already been several such haulings-out this year, and now comes the biggest of all, “Picasso in the Metropolitan Museum of Art,” a display of nearly every scrap in the Met’s scrappy Picasso collection: 34 paintings, 58 drawings, a dozen sculptures and ceramics, along with 200 of the museum’s 400 prints.

headline: Goldman: Still Greedy, No Longer Patient
text: Once upon a time, Goldman Sachs’ raison d’etre was to serve the ongoing needs of its clients and be paid fees for helping them raise capital, trade blocks of stock or by providing merger and acquisition advice, a business strategy that made the firm for years the envy of Wall Street and immensely profitable. This strategy forced Goldman’s bankers to be “long-term greedy”  a shopworn phrase coined by a former senior partner, Gus Levy  and to do everything possible to stay in their clients’ good graces in order to have a legitimate shot at the next fee. While it was not exactly backbreaking  or the Lord’s  work, from one year to the next nothing was assured unless the Goldman partnership maintained that fragile bond of trust.

headline: United-Continental Deal Is Said to Be Near
text: United Airlines and Continental Airlines are in advanced discussions on a merger after making progress on how to price the transaction, people briefed on the matter said Thursday.

headline: A.P. Board Elects New Members
text: Michael Golden, the vice chairman of The New York Times Company, and Katharine Weymouth, the publisher of The Washington Post, have been elected to the board of The Associated Press, the news cooperative announced on Thursday.

headline: Popcast: Melissa Etheridge, Okkervil River and Mary Gauthier
text: This week: Jon Caramanica and Ben Sisario discuss Melissa Etheridge’s career and her 10th album, “Fearless Love”; Jon Pareles on “True Love Cast Out All Evil,” a collaboration from the psychedelic rock pioneer Roky Erickson and the alternative country band Okkervil River; and the folk singer Mary Gauthier performs live and talks to Ben Sisario about her new CD, “The Foundling.” Sia Michel is the host.

headline: For Jobless Chefs, a Helping Hand
text: ON a recent Thursday night, after most of the dinner crowd had left, Bernard Ros, the owner and chef of Meli Melo, a French bistro in Manhattan, grilled three steaks, threw together a few pasta dishes and salads and pulled out two bottles of Côtes du Rhône red. By 10 p.m., he and a half-dozen friends in the restaurant business who were done working for the night — a couple of owners, a headwaiter, a wine salesman, a chef — were seated around a table in the back, talking jobs.

headline: What the Spill Means for Offshore Drilling
text: Updated, Apr. 30, 3:15 p.m. | Coast Guard officials were investigating reports that the oil had washed ashore early Friday morning. President Obama ordered a freeze on new offshore drilling leases until an investigation was completed on the oil rig explosion and new safeguards were put into place.

headline: A Semi-Star Torn Between Two Superstars
text: Just as the Broadway theater season is drawing to its close, a smashing little show has arrived to remind us of why so many of us keep going back to Broadway, even though it’s broken our heart so many times.

headline: What Would Johnny Appleseed Say?
text: The marketer responsible for some of the wackiest new-media campaigns that ever sold bushels of men’s grooming products is at it again.

headline: Brandon Victor Dixon to Play Ray Charles on Broadway
text: The actor Brandon Victor Dixon, who received critical praise for his leading role in the Off Broadway musical “The Scottsboro Boys” this spring, will depart that production to take the lead role of Ray Charles in the forthcoming Broadway show about the singer, “Unchain My Heart: The Ray Charles Musical.”

headline: Amanda Blackwell and Maj. Andrew Gallo
text: WHEN Amanda Blackwell of Columbus, Ga., first met Maj. Andrew Gallo in 2004, he mentioned having gone to West Point. She knew so little about the Army then that she thought he meant a small Georgia town called West Point.

headline: Product Red Steps Up Its Efforts With ‘Lazarus Effect’
text: Product Red is introducing a campaign intended to increase awareness for its efforts to work with companies to develop products that help efforts to fight AIDS in Africa.

headline: Freddy Krueger Is Back, With Sharp Claws and a Long Memory
text: “Remember me?” This is one of the half-clever, trailer-ready catchphrases (“Let’s play tag: you’re it!,” “Fooled you!” and so on) uttered by Freddy Krueger in the newly rebooted “Nightmare on Elm Street.” But really who, apart from Freddy’s terrified and bewildered new victims, could have forgotten? This maniac, with his jaunty hat and striped sweater, his ravaged face and murderous bladed glove, has been a fixture of pop culture for more than a quarter century.

headline: United and Continental Reported Closer to Merger
text: United Airlines and Continental Airlines are in advanced discussions on a merger after making progress on how to price the transaction,  Michael J. de la Merced and Jad Mouawad of The New York Times report, citing people briefed on the matter.

headline: Putting a Limit on Tarmac Time
text: A new rule to protect airline passengers from being held on a plane on the tarmac for too long went into effect today. The rule, issued by the Department of Transportation, was announced in December after a series of cases on various airlines left passengers stranded on the tarmac for hours without being able to get off and, in some cases, without food, water or working toilets. In one case, 47 passengers were trapped overnight on a Continental Airlines flight in August 2009 after thunderstorms forced the plane to divert to Rochester, Minn.

headline: Walk, Run or Maybe Nap for a Cure
text: The season of expending heartbeats for good causes is upon us.

text: MIAMI —The teachers stood up front and on stage with Gov. Charlie Crist as he announced Thursday that he would run for the Senate without a party affiliation. For a campaign starting over without institutional support, they were a show of force – but will they last?

headline: Planning to Build? Not in His Backyard
text: “Furry Vengeance,” directed by Roger Kumble (“Cruel Intentions”), sets itself apart from most funny-animal movies by using live animals, albeit with a lot of computer graphics and green-screen help. An actual raccoon plots the harassment of Dan Sanders (Brendan Fraser), the construction manager for a “green” housing development that will in fact wipe out an entire forest; actual skunks climb into his S.U.V. to do what skunks do. Unlike animated animals, they don’t talk; instead, they squeak and growl in ways that approximate human speech, or at least playground exclamations. If they could talk, they’d be on the phone firing their agents.

headline: Letterman: ‘All the Bad Decisions’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: George W. Bush has his new memoir coming out in November, and it’s called “Decision Points.” It’s about big decisions in his life. And I’ve already made a decision not to buy “Decision Points.”

headline: Democrats Outline Plans for Immigration
text: WASHINGTON — A coalition of top Senate Democrats laid out the contours of a proposed overhaul of immigration laws on Thursday — and appealed to Republicans to join them in pursuing it — even as doubts mounted about the prospects of winning approval of legislation this year.

headline: High-Five Etiquette
text: Video | Slap me some skin, man — correctly:

headline: Taking Inventory as Death Approaches
text: No amount of splenetic ranting by Brian Cox, a wonderful actor, when given the right role, can salvage “The Good Heart” from terminal mawkishness. When his curmudgeonly character, Jacques, the world’s most misanthropic owner of its seediest dive, lets fly, geysers of offensive epithets erupt from his mouth like Old Faithful on double time.

headline: Joe Drape’s Kentucky Derby Picks
text: The horses in the 136th Kentucky Derby on Saturday in Louisville, Ky. The Churchill Downs oddsmaker Mike Battaglia set the morning line. The horses are listed in order of preference.

headline: A Call for Transparency in Awards Voting
text: It’s a rare moment when a player wins a coveted award and his coach complains about the outcome. But it happened last week when Dwight Howard was named the N.B.A.’s defensive player of the year.

headline: In Abuse Crisis, a Church Is Pitted Against Society and Itself
text: VATICAN CITY — As the sexual abuse crisis continues to unfold in the Roman Catholic Church, with more victims coming forward worldwide and three bishops resigning last week alone, it is clear the issue is more than a passing storm or a problem of papal communications.

headline: Novelist Loses His Heart to His Critic
text: Had John Cassavetes directed “Love Story,” it might have turned out looking and sounding something like “Mercy,” a portrait of a sub-Mailer-like literary pugilist and the woman (named Mercy) who wins his heart. Odd as that juxtaposition may seem, it’s not a bad mix. The movie, directed by Patrick Hoelck and starring Scott Caan, who wrote the screenplay and served as one of its producers, may be something of a vanity project. (It is his third produced screenplay, after “Dallas 362” and “The Dog Problem.”) But it allows Mr. Caan to deliver a complex portrait of a womanizing bully with a cream-puff heart.

headline: Diamondbacks Face Backlash Over Immigration Law
text: CHICAGO — The fight over Arizona’s illegal-immigration law came to the sidewalk outside Wrigley Field on Thursday afternoon, in the shadow of a game between the Arizona Diamondbacks and the Chicago Cubs.

headline: Keeping Score: Many Games, Few Innings
text: Sean Forman is the creator of Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores in the major and minor leagues.

headline: Going to New Jersey to Find America
text: FORGET about Billy Joel and his state of mind. Right now, the brains of New York, and Madison Avenue in particular, have come down with a case of Jersey fever.

headline: Iraq: Recount to Take Weeks
text: Iraq’s state election commission said Thursday that it could take up to three weeks to complete a partial recount of votes from last month’s parliamentary election, a time frame that extends the country’s political uncertainty and makes it very unlikely that a new government will be seated by the end of August, when the remaining American combat troops are scheduled to withdraw from the country. Iraqis voted March 7, but the post-election jockeying has continued, with parties trying to form coalitions and pursuing fraud allegations. On Thursday eight people were killed when a car bomb exploded near a liquor store in southwest Baghdad, according to police and medical officials, The Associated Press reported.

headline: All Souls Rising
text: It was an art critic who coined the term “magic realism,” to describe a new wave of painting in 1920s Ger­many. The work departed from the moody Expressionism of the day, emphasizing material reality even as it unlocked an elusive otherworldliness in the arrangement of everyday objects. Sometimes, though, the fantastic rubbed elbows with the real: in one painting, a fat general nonchalantly shares a table with headless men in tuxedos.

headline: Russia: Bombing Suspect Is Killed
text: Russian authorities announced on Thursday that they had killed a militant who they said assisted in the March 29 suicide bombings in Moscow’s metro. An official told the Interfax news service that the man, Akhmet Rabadanov, in his mid-30s, had been captured on surveillance cameras in the metro on the morning two women from Dagestan blew themselves up, killing 40 commuters and wounding dozens more. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Rabadanov had returned to Dagestan, where he was kept under surveillance. He was killed with another man on Monday when they were stopped by the traffic police and opened fire, the police told Interfax.

headline: Europe Now Moving Swiftly on Greek Rescue Plan
text: European leaders raced Thursday to complete their part of a long-delayed financial rescue package for Greece, hoping to head off a chain reaction against other heavily indebted European nations that could turn into a financial crisis across the Continent, Nichols Kulish and Dan Bilefsky of The New York Times report.

headline: Three Derby Trainers, Each One of a Kind
text: Louisville, Ky.

headline: Watching and Waiting, the U.S. Defers to Europe on a Debt Crisis
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Mets Versus Halladay Was Years in the Making
text: The Mets were in an ornery mood on July 16, 2000. A quirk in the interleague schedule had them playing the first game of a series on a Sunday afternoon, and they lost in Toronto, 7-3, falling six games back in the National League East.

headline: Stopping Arizona
text: A fight is brewing over Arizona’s new law that turns all of the state’s Latinos, even legal immigrants and citizens, into criminal suspects. And this is not a local fight. The poison is spreading; there is talk in Texas of passing a version of the Arizona statute.

headline: The Cost of Delay
text: When the European Union and the International Monetary Fund first talked about a $60 billion rescue for Greece it looked as though that might be enough to calm Europe’s panicky markets. Then Germany dragged its feet, and investors raced to dump Greek bonds and bonds from the financially troubled Portugal and Spain.

headline: Apple’s Chief Makes Case Against Flash
text: Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, posted a 1,700-word letter on Apple’s Web site on Thursday, explaining the company’s decision not to allow the multimedia software Adobe Flash on Apple’s mobile devices, including the iPhone and iPad.

headline: Touching Up Camden Yards, Not Touching Its Character
text: BALTIMORE — Hard to believe, but Oriole Park at Camden Yards is nearly two decades old. Its brick facade, its asymmetrical field and its many old-time touches were so different when they were unveiled in 1992 — and so widely imitated since then — that the ballpark still seems fresh today.

headline: Montreal Canadiens Make Progress by Blocking Shots
text: WASHINGTON — Scott Gomez was headed down a long corridor to the Montreal Canadiens’ bus Wednesday night when a man stopped him to offer congratulations for helping the Canadiens oust the Washington Capitals from the Stanley Cup playoffs.

headline: Unions Hold a Rally to Protest Wall Street
text: As the Senate began debate on a financial overhaul bill, thousands of union members pressed for higher taxes on the nation’s banks and a bigger jobs program in a rally in Lower Manhattan on Thursday.

headline: No Rest for a Busy Masseur
text: “In My Sleep” is meant to be Hitchcockian  the writer and director, Allen Wolf, more or less says so in his director’s statement  and maybe it is, if you think of it as, say, Hitchcock’s senior project for film school. Mr. Wolf, in his feature film debut, generates a few genuine scares but he doesn’t yet have the style to pull off the kind of lightly surreal comic thriller that he’s trying for.

headline: Pakistan, in Shift, Weighs Attack on Militant Lair
text: This article is by Sabrina Tavernise, Carlotta Gall and Ismail Khan.

headline: Democrats Tweak Bank Bill to Preclude Bailouts
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate opened debate on Thursday on a far-reaching financial regulation bill, and Democrats moved quickly to demonstrate that the legislation would not provide any future taxpayer bailouts of failing financial companies — answering a Republican criticism that the Democrats had dismissed as false.

headline: The Euro Trap
text: Not that long ago, European economists used to mock their American counterparts for having questioned the wisdom of Europe’s march to monetary union. “On the whole,” declared an article published just this past January, “the euro has, thus far, gone much better than many U.S. economists had predicted.”

headline: Will Other Bidders Emerge for Palm?
text: As my colleague Ashlee Vance and I reported on Wednesday, Palm may not have been able to stay afloat in the smartphone industry as a standalone company. But the company has a strong trump card to keep it from going under entirely.

headline: U.S. Report on Afghan War Finds Few Gains in 6 Months
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A Pentagon report on the last six months in Afghanistan portrays an Afghan government with limited credibility among its people, a still active if not growing insurgency and an enormous reliance on American troops to train, outfit and finance the country’s defense forces for the foreseeable future.

headline: Berkshire Hathaway’s Derivatives Exposure
text: Warren Buffett says he loves simple things like ice cream. But some 40,000 shareholders at Berkshire Hathaway’s annual meeting in Nebraska this weekend may hear a lot about complex derivatives.

headline: Stranded Tourists Fall Into a Surgical Trap
text: A must-see for coprophiliacs and spanking enthusiasts, “The Human Centipede (First Sequence)” may be the year’s first mainstream fetish movie. Whether its writer and director, Tom Six, has more on his mind than mere titillation is debatable; either way this twisted, hammy bio-horror is sufficiently original to lure even the most satiated genre fans.

headline: A New Approach to Aid
text: The basic truth of foreign aid is that helping people is far, far harder than it looks. Anybody who travels in the developing world has seen projects that have been abandoned, or encountered officials who have enriched themselves. One study in Chad found that less than 10 percent of health care aid actually found its way to the clinics it was intended to help.

headline: Australia Fights Tobacco With Taxes and Plain Packs
text: Australia could become the first nation to ban brand images and colors on cigarette packages under a wide-ranging set of antismoking measures that the government unveiled Thursday.

headline: Cross in the Desert
text: A badly divided Supreme Court has overturned a good ruling against a cross that sits on federal land. The opinions did not provide much guidance but, over all, are likely to encourage those who want to entangle government and religion.

headline: ‘Big Teddy Bear’ in Mosley’s Camp Is at Home in Gym
text: LAS VEGAS — Naazim Richardson cuts an imposing figure, his arms the size of pony kegs, his full beard long turned gray, his baritone voice dispensing wisdom culled from a lifetime spent in boxing gyms.

headline: A Filly’s Chance to Rekindle Her Magic
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — A year ago Friday, a buzz built throughout the afternoon about an extraordinary filly that was destined to do something spectacular in the Kentucky Oaks. Her name was Rachel Alexandra, and for weeks she had produced workouts that were both ethereal and supersonic and had put to shame the colts getting ready for the Kentucky Derby.

headline: As Greek Drama Plays Out, Where Is Europe?
text: WASHINGTON — With new European Union leaders practically invisible and some national leaders acting largely for domestic political reasons, the burden of shaping a rapid and credible restructuring program for Greece has fallen primarily to the International Monetary Fund — exactly where proud European Union leaders had insisted it should not be.

headline: First Legal Challenges to New Arizona Law
text: The first legal challenges to Arizona’s stringent new anti-illegal-immigration law were filed Thursday in federal court in Phoenix and Tucson, heralding a legal battle that could take months, if not years, to resolve.

headline: World Cup Gets Closer and U.S. Roster Remains Unsettled
text: Coach Bob Bradley is not ready to settle on the United States team for the World Cup. But 16 to 18 spots on the roster are pretty much locked up, “some days a little higher,” Bradley said, and he will use his own calculus — more alchemy than science — to arrive at the team he will take to South Africa this summer.

headline: Puerto Rican Lenders Face Their Own Crisis
text: The latest American banking crisis is taking shape far from Wall Street and the empty subdivisions that stretch across the Sun Belt. The trouble this time is in Puerto Rico, the Caribbean commonwealth whose banks have been laid low by economic woes that make the mainland’s recession seem mild,  Eric Dash of The New York Times reports.

headline: Eastern N.B.A. Powers Wait and Wonder About Nagging Issues
text: INDEPENDENCE, Ohio — In each playoff series, the advancing team encounters moments to put away and ponder as it gains knowledge along the way. In their first-round matchups, the Eastern Conference’s powerhouses rarely gleaned that knowledge from the games’ outcomes.

headline: A Toxic Anger
text: When he arrived in Albany almost eight years ago, State Senator Kevin Parker was known as the intelligent and charming Brooklyn Democrat with a bright future. Now he is known as the man with frightening rages that could erupt at any time and on almost any subject.

headline: U.S. Said to Open Criminal Inquiry Into Goldman
text: Federal prosecutors have opened an investigation into trading at Goldman Sachs, raising the possibility of criminal charges against the Wall Street giant, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: House Approves Puerto Rico Plebiscite
text: The House passed legislation today that would allow voters in Puerto Rico to weigh in on the territory’s relationship with the United States.

headline: Bitten
text: Hugh Raffles’s beautifully written “Insectopedia” — part reference, part narrative and wholly engrossing — begins with an evocative image. On Aug. 10, 1926, a small monoplane began flying missions from Tallulah, La., to assess the population of insects in a vertical column of air. It was the first time insects had been collected by plane, and the results were astounding. In a square mile, rising to 14,000 feet, there were as many as 36 million insects.

headline: Shanghai Expo
text: China has spent $45 billion to mount an elaborate World Expo, inviting 189 countries to showcase a polished, vibrant Shanghai that it envisions as a financial capital for the region, even the world.

headline: Guilt and Death, North and South
text: Hanoi, Vietnam

headline: American Power Act
text: In 1860, Samuel Curtis, a Republican congressman of Iowa, sponsored a bill to create a transcontinental railroad. The debate over that public-private partnership was long and messy. Democrats said the proposal was unconstitutional. Others rightly argued that it meant huge giveaways to the rich.

headline: Oil Spill’s Blow to BP’s Image May Eclipse Costs
text: HAMMOND, La. — BP says that the offshore drilling accident that is spewing thousands of barrels of oil a day into the Gulf of Mexico could cost the company several hundred million dollars.

headline: Saigon’s Fall, 35 Years Later
text: Philadelphia

headline: Turmoil Builds at Aspen Music Festival and School
text: The tensions that have simmered at the Aspen Music Festival and School in Colorado since the resignation of its music director, David Zinman, on April 8, boiled over on Thursday, when the festival corporation delivered a vote of no confidence in the festival’s president and chief executive officer, Alan Fletcher.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 29, 2010

headline: Eyes on Woods, but Everyman Takes Control
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — On a day when the No. 1-ranked golfer in the world could barely find a fairway and the No. 2-ranked player was ill and stumbled at the finish, a rank-and-file golfer played a flawless first round Thursday to grab the lead at the Quail Hollow Championship with a seven-under-par 65.

headline: Leslie Buck, Designer of Iconic Coffee Cup, Dies at 87
text: It was for decades the most enduring piece of ephemera in New York City and is still among the most recognizable. Trim, blue and white, it fits neatly in the hand, sized so its contents can be downed in a New York minute. It is as vivid an emblem of the city as the Statue of Liberty, beloved of property masters who need to evoke Gotham at a glance in films and on television.

headline: Where Washington's Younger Half Lives
text: Where Washington's Younger-Half Lives

headline: More on Craigslist and Its Adult Services Ads
text: As I wrote in The New York Times on Monday, Craigslist, the largest classified advertising Web site in the United States, is making a lot of money from its sex adverisements. What’s not exactly clear is what the company is doing with the money.

headline: All the Obama 20-Somethings
text: “This party,” Herbie Ziskend announced, “is in honor of John Quincy Adams.” The dirty-blond, blue-eyed 24-year-old, who once handled luggage for Barack Obama’s campaign and now works in the vice president’s office as a staff assistant, stood in the living room of a red-brick row house in Washington and flung his arms in the air as if to pay tribute to America’s sixth president. Then he paused, deflated: “But the police are here.”

headline: How the Destinies of Motorola and Palm Grew Apart
text: For much of this decade, the fates of Palm and Motorola were intertwined. Both were early innovators in the mobile phone industry, but neither had had a hit in years.

headline: Justice Dept. Said to Open Goldman Inquiry
text: Federal prosecutors have opened an inquiry into trading at Goldman Sachs, raising the possibility of criminal charges against the Wall Street giant,  Louise Story and Michael J. de la Merced of The New York Times reports, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: A Fairy Godmother to Help With College Aid
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — The envelope arrives with good news. The college is pleased to announce that the student has been offered acceptance and, if he or she is fortunate, some scholarship money.

headline: Manhattan Woman Guilty in Husband’s 1990 Murder
text: A Manhattan woman pleaded guilty on Thursday to arranging the killing of her husband in a murder-for-hire that occurred two decades ago on the Upper East Side.

headline: What We’re Reading: iPhone Finder
text: The tech editors and reporters of The New York Times were intrigued by these items Thursday:

headline: Posada Sits, and Yanks Hope It’s Not for Long
text: BALTIMORE — When Ramiro Pena arrived at Camden Yards on Thursday afternoon, he was given a protective sheath for his left thumb. It would come in handy, he was told, if he were pressed into emergency duty at catcher. Perhaps fortunately for Pena — and for his team — the Yankees were not expecting to need his services for their game against the Orioles.

headline: Getting a Good Look at Lookin at Lucky
text: Eric Banks has written for Slate, The Financial Times, The Washington Post, The Los Angeles Times, The Chronicle of Higher Education, The Guardian, and The Wall Street Journal. He is a former editor of Bookforum, was a senior editor of Artforum and is a board member of the National Book Critics Circle.

headline: Greenwich Village, Heal Thyself
text: Drawings and interviews with people at St. Vincent’s Hospital before it closed its doors — ending 160 years of serving New York.

headline: Crushed Corn Creation
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I’ve talked about this before, but part of the thrill of crosswords is that you know things you don’t think you know. Or at least you know enough about them to EKE out the words, even when you don’t quite understand what they mean. Your examples will be specific to you but here’s what I mean.

headline: Former Variety Critic Starts a New Web Site
text: Todd McCarthy, left, the film critic laid off in March by Variety as part of a cost-cutting campaign, has landed.

headline: Shakespeare: The Question of Authorship
text: Shakespeare is not only peculiar in himself, but the cause of peculiarity in others. The surviving traces of his life, which the Shakespearean scholar Stephen Greenblatt describes as “abundant but thin,” depict a man whose parts aren’t entirely in sync: a provincial who grew wealthy but sued for paltry sums, a literary genius who seems never to have written a letter — or owned a book. But the alternate histories offered by people who reject Shakespeare’s authorship are far stranger, abounding in secret ciphers, baroque conspiracies and readings of the plays as fantastical as what’s in them. Barring the discovery of a ­doorstop-size autobiography or the invention of a time machine, we’ll never get a really satisfying explanation of how “Hamlet” and “Henry V” and all the rest were written, only varying degrees of ­improbability.

headline: Why Some Doctors Don’t Like Their Jobs
text: Many doctors love the work they do caring for patients and their families. But increasingly, practicing physicians are becoming frustrated with the constraints of a medical system that doesn’t always let them do their jobs the way they want to, writes Dr. Pauline Chen in today’s Doctor and Patient column.

headline: Promise Seen in Drug for Retardation Syndrome
text: An experimental drug succeeded in a small clinical trial in bringing about what the researchers called substantial improvements in the behaviors associated with retardation and autism in people with fragile X syndrome, the most common inherited cause of these mental disabilities.

headline: Cano Makes Sure Yankees Go Home Happy
text: BALTIMORE — There may be no such thing as an antidote right now for Robinson Cano, but the Orioles must have figured they had one in the top of the eighth inning. As Cano warmed up by the on-deck circle, Alberto Castillo, a left-handed reliever with more arm angles than an octopus, jogged in from the bullpen. He had yet to allow a hit to a left-handed batter this season, but that changed when Cano turned on an inside fastball and slugged his second homer of the game.

headline: Housing Subsidy Has High-Profile Foe
text: The mayor’s office is urging Gov. David A. Paterson to veto a bill that would offer greater rent relief to 11,000 New York City residents with H.I.V. or AIDS, saying the measure would tax the city’s strained budget.

headline: Ask the Expert: Raynaud’s Phenomenon
text: “While it’s normal to feel cold when you step outside on a winter’s day without a jacket, the feeling of cold comes way too easily for sufferers of Raynaud’s,” writes Winnie Yu in The Times Health Guide: “When Cold Fingers Mean Raynaud’s, or Worse.” “Holding a cup of yogurt, strolling through the freezer section of the supermarket, even touching a glass of water can turn fingers a mottled mix of white and blue and create chills normally reserved for the iciest exposures.” And while Raynaud’s is just a minor nuisance for the great majority of sufferers, for a small minority, coldness in the fingers and toes is a prelude to a more serious ailment like lupus or scleroderma.

headline: Last Call Looms at Freddy’s, in the Path of Atlantic Yards
text: Sometime next week, workers will start digging under the floor of a bar where a bartender known as Johnny Seatcovers poured an ocean’s worth of whisky, where police officers and anarchists alike shouted to be heard above the music, where young bands got their start and Blue Oyster Cult played a late-career gig.

headline: Obama Says Liberal Courts May Have Overreached
text: WASHINGTON — In a seeming rejection of liberal orthodoxy, President Obama has spoken disparagingly about liberal victories before the Supreme Court in the 1960s and 1970s — suggesting that justices made the “error” of overstepping their bounds and trampling on the role of elected officials.

headline: States Decide on Running New Pools for Insurance
text: WASHINGTON — The fight over the new health care law shifted Thursday to the states, as some governors claimed federal money to run a new insurance pool for people with serious medical problems, while officials in other states said they would not operate the program.

headline: Talk of ‘Truth’ and John Edwards
text: Rielle Hunter, who told Oprah Winfrey in a program broadcast on Thursday that John Edwards had a secret affair with her because “he wanted to live a life of truth,” is a tough interview, tougher in some ways than President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran.

headline: Ministry by Priest Broke Deal, Suit Says
text: A woman from New York who says she was abused by a priest from the Jesuit order of the Roman Catholic Church has filed an unusual lawsuit accusing the Jesuits of breach of contract for allowing the priest to perform public ministry even though he was barred from doing so because of a settlement stemming from an alleged sexual assault.

headline: Victoria Manalo Draves, Olympic Champion Diver, Dies at 85
text: Victoria Manalo Draves, an Asian-American diver who overcame ethnic prejudice early in her career to become the first woman to win springboard and platform gold medals in the same Olympics, in 1948, died on April 11 in Palm Springs, Calif. She was 85.

headline: No Glimmers of Recovery Seen From Financial Aid Office
text: Earlier this week, I took the train from New York to Providence, R.I., to spend an afternoon with Sandra J. Oliveira, executive director of the office of financial aid at Providence College in Providence, R.I. I was particularly curious whether the glimmers of economic recovery evident in some car showrooms and department store checkout baskets had reached her spare, wood laminate desk.

headline: Judge Won’t Add 4th Officer as Defendant in Abuse Lawsuit
text: A federal judge on Thursday rejected a request to make a police officer who is a potential witness against three other officers accused in a sexual abuse civil case a defendant in the matter.

headline: Evelyn Cunningham, Civil Rights Reporter, Dies at 94
text: Evelyn Cunningham, a civil-rights-era journalist and later an aide to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. She was 94 and lived in Harlem most of her life.

headline: Spurs Advance, as Mavericks Fall Short Again
text: SAN ANTONIO — Dirk Nowitzki grimaced and gritted his teeth, plunged into traffic and contorted himself in the lane. He bounced off every obstacle, flung those high-arching jumpers and pushed the Dallas Mavericks within inches of a revival.

text: John McWhorter, left, of the Manhattan Institute and Glenn Loury of Brown University discuss the anti-progressive strain in American history.

headline: Vision for Transforming Hunters Point Comes Before Supervisors
text: From the barren hilltop, you can see downtown San Francisco and the Bay Bridge, across the bay to Oakland and south to the San Mateo-Hayward Bridge. It is the kind of sweeping San Francisco view that could sustain million-dollar condominiums.

headline: The Political Lives of Charlie Crist
text: Gov. Charlie Crist's pragmatic brand of politics has recently obscured the conservative positioning that had made him a darling of Republicans in the past.

headline: Free Money Left on Table
text: What if residents of California — a state reeling from unemployment, a sagging economy and a gaping budget hole — had access to more than $1 billion, but did not use it? What if Alameda County residents had access to $29 million and failed to take it out of the federal treasury?

headline: Need an Appointment at the D.M.V.? Do You Feel Lucky?
text: The toughest reservation to snag in San Francisco these days is not a table at the latest Michelin star restaurant, but instead a destination few would consider particularly appetizing: the Department of Motor Vehicles.

text: Guests who are lucky enough to claim any of the 47 seats at Frances, Melissa Perello’s hot new restaurant in the Castro, are offered not only the wine list but also the choice of house wine, red or white.

headline: The Toughest Reservation in Town: The D.M.V.
text: When I think of the Department of Motor Vehicles, I envision the characters Patty and Selma Bouvier from “The Simpsons” — Homer’s chain-smoking sisters-in-law who revel in making customers miserable with petty displays of their bureaucratic muscles.

headline: Hispanic Leadership Presses to Expand Political Influence
text: When United States Representative Luis V. Gutierrez harshly criticized Gov. Patrick J. Quinn in an off-the-cuff speech early this week that recalled his cocksure political origins, the outburst said as much about roiling disagreements in the Hispanic political community as it did any substantive appraisal of Mr. Quinn’s record in office.

headline: New Curator Is Chosen for M.C.A.
text: When Madeleine Grynsztejn became director at Chicago’s Museum of Contemporary Art in 2008, the then-40-year-old institution was in the throes of what she called “a healthy midlife crisis”: slightly adrift, re-examining its place and purpose in an art landscape dominated by the Art Institute and its coming Modern Wing.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Tuesday with a television review of “The Vaccine War,” a “Frontline” report on PBS, referred incorrectly to the rally in Washington in 2008 at which the actors Jenny McCarthy and Jim Carrey were shown. Participants were calling for the elimination of what they said were toxins in children’s vaccines and for a reassessment of mandatory vaccination schedules for children; it was not “an anti-vaccine” rally.

headline: A New Emotional Intimacy in a Class on Human Anatomy
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Dorothy Provine, Shapely Actress in ’60s, Dies at 75
text: Dorothy Provine, the leggy, blond actress perhaps best known for her quirky role in the Stanley Kramer movie “It’s a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World” and as the flouncy nightclub singer on the 1960s television series “The Roaring ’20s,” died on Sunday in Bremerton, Wash. She was 75 and lived on Bainbridge Island, Wash.

headline: Corrections
text: A film review on April 21 about “Ramchand Pakistani” referred incorrectly to the character with whom Ramchand’s mother, a Hindu, carries on a discreet flirtation. He is a Muslim, and thus is not a member of a caste. The review also referred incorrectly at one point to the place Ramchand and his father are imprisoned, and referred incorrectly to the official for whom Ramchand becomes a servant. She is a police officer, not a military official, and Ramchand and his father are in a jail, not a military encampment.

headline: Way Up High, ‘Where the Real Fans Are’
text: Describing a subset of sports enthusiasts as “300-level fans” doesn’t stir the imagination — it lacks the catchy panache of, say, “Bleacher Bums.” But the third balcony at the United Center during a Blackhawks game is filled with the same type of quirky behaviors, faith-based knowledge and deep-seated passion that was so unerringly recounted in “Bleacher Bums,” the long-running play about the eccentric, obsessed regulars who hung out in Wrigley Field’s bleachers more than 30 years ago.

text: Alexander Gorlizki’s first gallery show in this country is tantalizingly rich with charm, ideas and confusion, and even comes with built-in self-criticism.

headline: Elliott Hundley
text: Collage gone crazy is an apt description of some of Elliott Hundley’s new work. It applies at least to the three immense montages that dominate his second New York gallery show.

headline: Reinventing Hunter’s Point and Other Highlights From Friday’s Bay Area Report
text: Plans for a New Face on San Francisco’s Eastern Edge |Today, the Hunters Point Naval Shipyard, now idle for more than 35 years, looks like a ghost town. Buildings stand empty. The few people on the property are involved in the continuing cleanup or are among the sculptors, painters and photographers who created an improbable artists’ colony in some of the shipyard buildings. But a crucial decision is facing the Board of Supervisors in a few weeks. It will open — or close — the door to the Lennar Corporation’s $7 billion redevelopment plan for the 770-acre site, one that would include 10,500 homes, large amounts of retail and commercial space and even new accommodations for the artists’ colony. The development project is headed by Kofi Bonner, a vice president at Lennar who spearheaded the redevelopment of Emeryville, which, like Hunter’s Point, was plagued by toxic waste. Mr. Bonner served as San Francisco’s economic development director under Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. during the 1990s.Wine on Tap | At Frances, the restaurant in San Francisco’s Castro neighborhood getting all the buzz these days, customers pay by the ounce for the wine they drink. But that is not the only difference from the way most of the city’s other eateries handle their drinks. The beverage director, Paul Einbund, blends the house wines —creating unconventional blends from the fruits of the Sierra foothills — himself, after they are brought from the wineries in kegs.

headline: In Europe, a Delicate Decision on Rates
text: Europe’s collective anguish over Greece was interrupted by some good news on Thursday. German unemployment fell more than expected, while earnings surged for some of the country’s biggest companies, Jack Ewing reports in The New York Times.

headline: Watchful, U.S. Defers to Europe on a Debt Crisis
text: The United States is the largest shareholder in the International Monetary Fund and has played a forceful, interventionist role in financial crises since the early 1990s, in countries like Mexico, South Korea, Russia and Argentina.

headline: Ruling For Former Bengals
text: A federal judge in the Southern District of Ohio rejected an attempt by the Cincinnati Bengals to block several of their former players from filing or collecting workers’ compensation claims in California for injuries sustained while with the team. The Bengals said that the players’ contracts required them to file any claims in Ohio. California is the only state with a workers’ compensation system that lets retired professional athletes file claims for long-term injuries sustained on the field years before as long as they played at least one game in the state.

headline: Stunned China Looks Inward After School Attacks
text: BEIJING — In the wake of a fourth horrific attack on Chinese schoolchildren — this time by a crazed man who on Friday beat five toddlers with a hammer, then set himself on fire with two other children in his arms — this shocked and bruised nation was of two distinctly different minds.

headline: Hedge Funds Seek $2 Billion From Porsche
text: Six more hedge funds joined a lawsuit against Porsche over alleged securities fraud and manipulation on Thursday, with the plaintiffs doubling the damages they are seeking to $2 billion, Reuters reported.

headline: Yaka-Wow
text: A misheard portmanteau of “yuck” and “wow” that became an Internet hit.

headline: Dubai World’s New Offer May Fall Flat, Analysts Say
text: Dubai World, which is in talks to restructure $26 billion in debt, is offering lenders an additional 1 percent in interest upon maturity of new debt, but the deal is unlikely to satisfy banks, analysts told Reuters on Thursday.

headline: India Tells Mobile Firms to Delay Deals for Chinese Telecom Equipment
text: NEW DELHI — Worried about reports of Chinese hackers and spying, the Indian government has effectively barred local mobile phone operators from making deals with Chinese telecommunications manufacturers, according to the head of India’s main cellular industry trade group.

headline: Barclays Posts 29% Profit Rise, Under Expectations
text: Barclays reported Friday that profit rose 29 percent in the first quarter, helped by its investment banking business and a decline in bad loans, Julia Werdigier reports in The New York Times.

text: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission’s investigation into Moore Capital’s actions in the platinum and palladium futures market culminated in a settlement Thursday, with the hedge fund ordered to pay $25 million to the regulatory body.

headline: Arpa-E Green Tech Gets $106 Million
text: The  Department of Energy has given out $106 million more in stimulus funds to 37  green technology projects under the banner of its Advanced Research Projects Agency – Energy (know best as Arpa-E). The money will be funneled into microbe, battery and carbon capture research, VentureBeat reported.

headline: S.E.C. Sues Texas Wireless Provider
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has filed a lawsuit against Dallas-based wireless service provider TierOne Converged Networks, which is suspected of  selling unregistered and misleading securities, The Dallas Morning News reported.

text: NEW ORLEANS — Officials in the Obama administration began for the first time Friday to publicly chastise BP America for its handling of the spreading oil gusher in the Gulf of Mexico, calling the oil company’s current resources inadequate to stop what is unfolding into an environmental catastrophe.

headline: Record Profit for Chinese Banks Not Likely to Last

headline: In London, Art Out in the Open
text: For art lovers, almost nothing equals the thrill of discovering what goes on behind the scenes in the studio. With that in mind, artists who live in Havelock Walk, a mews in southeast London, began opening their studios to the public nine years ago, providing visitors an opportunity to view art –and the artist — in their natural state. This year’s Open Studio weekends are scheduled for May 8 to 9 and 15 to 16.

headline: TriBeCa Festival Announces Prizewinners
text: “When We Leave,” the German director Feo Aladag’s drama about a woman’s flight to her family in Berlin from her abusive husband in Istanbul, won the Founders Award for best narrative feature at the Tribeca Film Festival, and its star Sibel Kekilli, above, won for best actress in a narrative feature, the festival’s organizers said on Thursday. Dana Adam Shapiro’s feature “Monogamy,” about a Brooklyn couple on the verge of marriage, was named best New York narrative, and the French director Kim Chapiron was named best new narrative filmmaker for the feature “Dog Pound,” about teenagers in a youth correctional center in Montana. Other award winners included Eric Elmosnino, for his portrayal of the French singer-songwriter Serge Gainsbourg in the film “Gainsbourg, Je t’Aime ... Moi Non Plus” by Joann Sfar, and Alexandra Codina’s nonfiction film “Monica & David,” about a couple with Down syndrome, which was named best documentary feature.

headline: Variety’s Former Critic Has a New Job
text: Todd McCarthy, the film critic laid off in March by Variety in a cost-cutting campaign, has landed. Mr. McCarthy said he has agreed to start a Web site called “Todd McCarthy’s Deep Focus,” at (toddmccarthyreviews.com), in association with SnagFilms as part of its IndieWire network of blogs. Mr. McCarthy said he had considered “quite a few possibilities” before agreeing to align with Snag. “I’ll do what I’ve always done: in-depth review of major films” and other writing, Mr. McCarthy said in a telephone interview. Variety’s decision to cut Mr. McCarthy and other staff members sent a shock through Hollywood, which has long held special regard for the trade paper’s powerful staff critics, who often get the first word on a new movie. At the time, Variety executives said they hoped that Mr. McCarthy would continue writing for the paper regularly on a freelance basis. Asked whether he intended to do that Mr. McCarthy said, “No.”

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Bad Meaning Good
text: This week is all about villains. The first volume of “Gotham City Sirens” stars a cabal of Batman’s female arch-foes – Catwoman, Poison Ivy and Harley Quinn – and is at No. 9 on the hardcover list. The book, published by DC Comics, emerged after a reshuffling of the line of Batman books after the apparent death of the Caped Crusader. At No. 7 on the softcover list is “Deadpool: Suicide Kings,” the latest collection of adventures starring that mutant mercenary whose powers seem to include an infinite reserve of popularity: In June alone, he is the title character in five books published by Marvel Entertainment, and he guest-stars in a sixth.

headline: Making College Applications a Full-Time Job
text: A few years ago I interviewed a mother named Gail Wiggin for a Life’s Work column because she was an outlier — she’d just quit her job in order to focus her time and energy on getting her son into college. She might not have been the only person to ever have done that, but she was certainly the only one I’d run across, and response from readers hinted that they thought she was a bit extreme, too.

headline: Letters: The Estrogen Dilemma
text: Cynthia Gorney’s early menopause symptoms were very close to my own. The estrogen patch saved my sanity and returned my life to normal. When the Women’s Health Initiative study came out, I tried to cut back my hormones but had too much anxiety to do that. I’m now 63 and still taking hormone-replacement therapy, but I’m afraid to stop. I’m so glad to hear that there are studies going on regarding the type of estrogen and the timing of taking it. We need more articles about this subject; too many of us are “winging it” just to maintain our quality of life. NANCY LEONARDNevada City, Calif.

headline: Letter: Dr. Does-It-All
text: In the early ’80s my husband and I were reading the morning papers when a very good-looking young kid running by our house waved at us. We knew his dad, Mustafa, who was our next-door neighbor, but we had never met Mehmet, then away at school. This whirlwind climbed in through our breakfast-room window, was charmingly chatty and challenged my husband, then in his late 30s, to “a little hoops” in our driveway. While mopping up the driveway with my husband, Mehmet mentioned that he was in University of Pennsylvania medical school and getting an M.B.A. from Wharton at the same time. When my husband said that seemed pretty ambitious, Mehmet just brushed that off, saying that his dad said that to practice medicine today, you have to have an M.B.A. Sounds like he hasn’t changed much — he’s not just a world-beater, he’s becoming a world-changer.JEAN KENNEDY HUNTERHouston

headline: Letter: A Closer Reading of Roman Vishniac
text: In Thomas McGovern’s letter to the magazine in the April 18 issue, he mistakenly writes that Robert Capa stated he “discovered how undiscovered” Vishniac was. To begin with, it wasn’t Robert Capa who said this (he diedin 1954); it was Cornell Capa who championed Vishniac’s work in exhibits, books and lectures at the International Center of Photography, which he, Cornell Capa, founded. I was an assistant to Cornell Capa for 35 years, and what Cornell clearly meant in his statement was his surprise that Vishniac’s work, as important as it was, was not more widely known prior to his own efforts after 1966. For McGovern to go on to say that Capa (either Robert or Cornell, take your pick) had a “similar impulse to encourage the viewers to believe things that weren’t really there” is a gross misinterpretation of the facts, and unfair conjecture.ANNA WINANDNew York

headline: Going After a Reporter’s Sources — Change We Can Believe In?
text: Excuse an utterly self-interested comment from a scribbler about reporters protecting confidential sources. You see, this was an ongoing point of contention during the Bush administration. Prosecutors sought to subpoena reporters to find their confidential sources, and courts then threatened to throw them in prison if they refused to reveal those sources. We had thought that the Obama administration would be different, a little less likely to want to menace and jail journalists. But, alas, the Obama Justice Department has now issued a subpoena for my Times colleague James Risen (although it’s for a book he wrote, not for material that appeared in the Times). Speaking obviously just for myself, not for my institution, I find this utterly disappointing. The Washington Post article writes:

headline: Dispute in Los Angeles Over Arts Financing
text: Arts advocates in Los Angeles are pushing back against new efforts by city officials to sap the funding streams that keep their organizations alive, The Los Angeles Times reported. They have flooded city hall voice-mail and e-mail in-boxes to oppose a proposal by Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa to redirect $415,000 in arts grants from groups that qualified under a standard competitive application process to four groups of his choosing. The proposal was part of the mayor’s budget recommendations, which call for a nearly 25 percent cut in city arts spending. They were presented to the City Council on April 20 and were reviewed by the council’s budget and finance committee on Thursday.

headline: Now Screening | The Woodmans
text: The photographer Francesca Woodman had all the markings of becoming the next big art star: precocious talent, beauty, charisma and a driving ambition and a work ethic to match.
