headline: It’s Time for School
text: Now that the major training is completed and we are only a day from the big race, many of the starters will have started to focus on the finer details of race preparation, which includes schooling both in the starting gate and in the paddock. It is really important that a horse is as relaxed as possible as it prepares for its race, and schooling helps with this. When I worked for Steve Asmussen, we paddock-schooled every horse before each of its races, and we gate-schooled every horse once a week. With a race as important as the Kentucky Derby, those activities take on a greater significance.

headline: Expo Offers Shanghai a Turn in the Spotlight
text: The World’s Fair may have lost the luster it brought decades ago to world capitals like Paris. But China has dusted off the concept in an attempt to give its second city, Shanghai, the same coming-out party that the 2008 Summer Olympic Games were for Beijing.

headline: Goldman’s Shares Plunge on Inquiries and Downgrades
text: How much trouble is Goldman Sachs really in?

headline: Artie Shaw: Swing and Loathing
text: Artie Shaw, the swing era’s other great clarinetist, knew just about every romantic self-immolator in the history of jazz. He roomed with both Bix Beiderbecke and Bunny Berigan, he hired Billie Holiday to sing with his band and — at least by his own account — he turned down Charlie Parker’s bid to join his saxophone section. (“I said, ‘Bird, you couldn’t play in my band, you’re too much of an individualist!’ ”) Superficially, Shaw couldn’t have been less like these doom-bound drunks and drug addicts. In “Three Chords for Beauty’s Sake,” Tom Nolan’s absorbing if somewhat sketchy new biography, we see him drunk exactly once — when he was in his teens and a prankish band mate fed him shots of rye with beer chasers — and once, at about 20, “half-stoned” on weed with Berigan. Thanks to clean living, good luck and, surely, a measure of cussedness, Shaw lived to be 94 and died, in 2004, the way Robert Frost recommended: “Better to go down dignified / With boughten friendship at your side / Than none at all. Provide, provide!” He even kept his sense of humor, or at least his memory of an old Myron Cohen joke. His personal assistant (who stayed with him for 11 years, sometimes by dint of repeating the word “mortgage” to himself) and his home-hospice caregiver were changing the old man’s bedclothes during his last days and asked if he was comfortable. “I make a living,” he said. He did, too. Though Nolan’s book doesn’t say so, Shaw’s estate was probably worth around $3 million, and he hadn’t played on a record for half a century.

headline: Updates on the Oil Slick in the Gulf of Mexico
text: As my colleagues Campbell Robertson and Liz Robbins report, “Federal and state officials criticized BP on Friday for what they said was an inadequate response to the growing oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.” The Lede will track news of the oil slick’s spread on Friday. Video of the deadly fire on the oil rig that exploded last week is in a previous post on the disaster.

headline: Real Golfers Wear Rain Suits
text: I admit I have a thing about golf rain suits. What I find most amazing about rain suits is that so few golfers have one. And I concede, I was one of those golfers who spent years trying to make due with a heavy windbreaker and lots of towels. Then I got a rain suit made for golf and wondered why I had been torturing myself. A lot of golfers will think nothing of spending $100 to play golf for one day but won’t spend $400 on a quality rain suit that might last 10 years and allow them to enjoy 40 more golf rounds when it’s raining. So think of it as an extra $10 for every round it rains. You spend that on a hot dog and drink at the turn.

headline: Artie Shaw and the High C
text: This weekend, David Gates reviews “Three Chords for Beauty’s Sake: The Life of Artie Shaw,” by Tom Nolan. Gates quotes a scene from the book recounting an exchange between Shaw and a “well-known clarinet player” who once asked Shaw if he was ever afraid of missing the high C at the end of “Concerto for Clarinet.” As Shaw told it:

headline: What Makes Marion Jones Run?
text: The sky was still dark on the March morning in 2008 when Marion Jones, the five-time Olympic medalist, folded her long legs into the passenger seat of her Honda Pilot. She had barely eaten that morning and sat silently, staring out the window as her husband began the three-hour drive to a federal prison in Fort Worth, Tex., where Jones was to begin a six-month sentence. During the ride, her husband, Obadele Thompson, pulled off the highway twice because Jones felt sick to her stomach. In the prison parking lot, Jones and Thompson hugged and kissed a couple of times, before she asked to stop; she did not want to cry. She had with her the few things she was allowed to bring: an inexpensive watch, her wedding band, small silver stud earrings, a Bible.

headline: If Football Is Favre’s Future, Quarterback Will Need Surgery
text: It’s been at least a few weeks since there was an update in the annual Brett Favre retirement watch. On Friday, we got one.

headline: Goldman Shares Dive on Inquiries and Downgrades
text: 2:33 p.m. | Updated Already facing investigations on two fronts into its practices in the mortgage market, Goldman Sachs came under pressure from investors as well on Friday.

headline: After 26 Derbys, He Still Doesn’t Know
text: With over 26 years of wagering on the sport of kings and mild success, David “Buc” Geier has as many opinions and ideas, as he does uncashable tickets in his desk drawer. Like Sisyphus and his rock, he will someday get to the mountaintop. If not, he’ll start over once again.

headline: The Worst of the West
text: This little book is a cri de coeur — an outburst of rage and sorrow in equal parts. The language of “Ill Fares the Land” is felicitous and polished, as befits such an intelligent and erudite author. But unless the reader belongs to the choir to which Tony Judt preaches — call it the Europhile liberal left, who would rather sell their Prius than forgo their New York Review of Books — he or she may ask: Where have we heard this before? A pugnacious reader might stab a felt pen at every other paragraph and scribble: “Caricature!” or “What about . . . ?”

headline: Court Voids Injunction on Would-Be ‘Catcher in the Rye’ Sequel
text: 3:26 p.m. | Updated A United States appeals court on Friday vacated a lower court’s order to enjoin the publication of a novel described as a sequel to J. D. Salinger‘s “Catcher in the Rye.” The appeals court sided with a district court’s judgment that Salinger’s lawyers would probably prevail on the merits but sent the case back to that lower court to re-evaluate whether the injunction should be ordered.

headline: Chinese Rights Lawyer Disappears Again
text: BEIJING — Gao Zhisheng, a prominent human rights lawyer whose 13-month disappearance at the hands of Chinese security agents stirred an international outcry until he resurfaced in March, has again vanished, his friends said Friday.

headline: U.S. Chamber of Commerce Backs Democrat (at Least for Now)
text: The conventional wisdom is that Senator Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas, up for re-election this fall, is one of several Democrats in danger of losing her seat. But right now, a Republican opponent is the least of her worries. Ms. Lincoln, one of the most conservative members of her caucus, is facing a tough primary challenge from the left, in the person of Lt. Governor Bill Halter. And on Tuesday, Salon’s Mike Madden reported that she was receiving help from an unexpected quarter: the United States Chamber of Commerce, in the name of small business.

headline: Emo-Tourism
text: In Deanna Fei’s first novel, “A Thread of Sky,” three generations of a family’s women confront identity issues, both timeless and of the moment. Irene, a Chinese scientist living in Queens, has sacrificed her career to stay home, making her American-born daughters the center of her universe. This disappoints her own mother, a failed revolutionary who thinks women must “push and strain forward” or “be part of the backward pull.” In turn, Irene’s outwardly perfect children forsake much of life’s joy in the name of ambition. But with Harvard, Yale and Stanford on their résumés — and all three girls were high-school valedictorians — Irene now wonders if she shouldn’t have raised them to feel “quite so special.”

headline: Like a Pigeon on a Train
text: Why did the pigeon take the train?

headline: Corporate Etymologies
text: When Keds kicked off a retro advertising campaign in March as “the original sneaker,” the venerable brand tripped over its own laces. Claiming that “Keds are the first shoes to be called sneakers,” the company’s Web site provided a seemingly authoritative origin story: “The term, coined in 1917 by Henry Nelson McKinney, an agent for the advertising firm N. W. Ayer & Son, refers to their soft, noiseless rubber soles, which allow the wearer to ‘sneak’ up on unsuspecting friends or family.”

headline: Faux-Authentic Uniforms
text: In March, Burton  Snowboards announced that later this year it would begin selling pants similar to those worn by the U.S. Olympic snowboarding team. There is a logic to this move, because the most notable thing about the team’s uniform was how much it looked like a trendy retail product. The pants, which will cost $250 in their consumer version, had the look of baggy, prefaded “distressed” jeans; the top was a plaid hooded jacket. Pretty ho-hum stuff compared with, let’s say, the spangles and feathers worn by figure skaters or the skintight hooded unitards of lugers, attire shaped either by functionality or by a kind of amped-up aesthetic spectacle. The American snowboarders appeared to have stopped off to compete in the Olympics on the way home from the mall, without even bothering to change their clothes.

headline: Once Bitten
text: What do you make of the vogue for vampires in this country? The heroine of your Sookie Stackhouse novels, a telepathic waitress who lives in Bon Temps, La., and consorts with supernatural friends, is about to re-emerge in a new season of the HBO series “True Blood,” as well as in your 10th best seller.  Well, “Dead in the Family” won’t really be out until May 4, and I hate to count my chickens before they hatch.

headline: The Sweet Hereafter
text: About a year ago, our neighbor’s beloved mutt, Bruno, went to dog heaven, followed six months later by Bear, the sweet brown Newfoundland down the block. I am not speaking metaphorically but repeating the wisdom of my 3-year-old daughter, who learned her theology from “Dog Heaven,” a picture book by Cynthia Rylant. All dogs get biscuits in Dog Heaven, Rylant writes. Even better, “The dogs in Dog Heaven who had no real homes on Earth are given one in Heaven. . . . And each dog is petted and reminded how good he is, all day long.”

headline: The Talents of a Middle-Aged Brain
text: After we hit 40, many of us begin to worry about our aging brains. Will we spend our middle years searching for car keys and forgetting names?

headline: Beasts of Burden
text: Yann Martel’s second novel,    “Life of Pi,” won him much acclaim, many readers and the 2002 Man Booker Prize. At least one reason for the book’s appeal was a story easily reduced to a one-line pitch: An Indian boy is stranded on a lifeboat with a Bengal tiger. Martel’s latest novel demonstrates the same gift for vivid description and wholehearted feeling, but it’s a lot more resistant to summary. “Beatrice and Virgil” is allusive, teasing, fragmentary.

headline: The Spurs’ Rediscovery
text: For all but the most rabid of their fans, the San Antonio Spurs are like that plant that keeps blooming in your backyard every spring. While it’s comforting to see something so durable reappear annually, you also wouldn’t mind it not coming back so you could replace it with something with a little more pizzazz.

headline: Acura Recalling 167,000 TSX Models for Fire Hazard
text: Honda is recalling about 167,000 of its 2004–8 Acura TSX models because of a fire hazard, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. It is the third recall of an Acura model for a similar problem, now affecting almost 500,000 vehicles.

headline: Jeff Stark and ‘The Sweet Cheat’
text: A slide show of photographs from the “The Sweet Cheat.”

headline: Room for One
text: The suicide itself happens offstage at a Valentine’s Day party. “Excuse me,” says a man, stepping out onto the balcony, letting the black draperies fall behind him. While his wife helps the hostess arrange fresh berries on a platter, he jumps — but a long time passes before the police knock on the door to ask if a guest is missing. Like Breughel’s Icarus plunging into the sea, he dies unwatched.

headline: Love, Labor, Loss
text: Robert von Lucius is on his way to meet Herr S, a patient in a Kafkaesque asylum in Vienna in 1865. Delusional, paranoid men line the halls — one lives in a universe of color, another repeatedly demands “a hearing, . . . a hearing” — but Lucius idealizes the clinically insane, seeing them as privy to “ancient presences” caught between “the lunar and solar.” To him, Herr S, who blames himself for the spread of a deadly childbed fever epidemic, looks “as if his bones had been broken, and had mended strangely.” Lucius vows to prevent Herr S, a k a Dr. Ignaz Semmelweis, from descending deeper into madness.

headline: Leading Mansion
text: I first came upon Villa Necchi Campiglio, an extraordinary house discreetly tucked away in the chaotic center of Milan, when I was supposed to be looking at shoes. Tod’s, the luxury accessories label, had taken over the place to showcase its latest collection. But lovely as they were, I had a hard time concentrating on the pebble-bottomed loafers: their surroundings stole the show. So I did what anyone in my place would do: snatched a glass of Champagne from the nearest waiter, snuck away for a wander and dizzily allowed myself to be dazzled. This house, I said to myself, should be in a movie.

headline: Public Enemy No. 1
text: Tell people in Belfast or Melbourne you’re from Chicago and some of them are still apt to mimic a tommy assault, spraying you with 400 rounds of hot lead per minute. Ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah! A tommy, of course, is a Thompson submachine gun, the weapon of choice for Al Capone’s “outfit,” which deployed the guns to dominate the hooch and protection rackets in and around Chicago for most of the Roaring Twenties. Old associations die hard.

headline: The Flesh Machine
text: The Swedish writer Henning Mankell has remarked that “too often we learn everything about how an African dies, but nothing about how he lives.” Mankell, who spends half the year running Teatro Avenida in Mozambique, has a point. African lives in the Western media are skewed toward their ends in statistical catastrophe, as if a continent with more than 50 countries were reducible to one vast, tangled necropolis. Many African lives may be foreshortened, but they can also be cut short in a second, imaginative sense as our emphasis on reporting disasters ignores the twists and turns, quotidian or remarkable, that shape the experiences of individuals over the long haul.

headline: Weekend Competition: It’s a Mad Mad Mad Mad Mad Men World
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to devise slogans for things not normally advertised.

headline: Vain Glorious | Whittemore House
text: Who: Victoria Hunter and Larry Raspanti

headline: The Big Banks Consumers Recommend Most Often
text: Among the big banks that people talk most about online, PNC gets the most positive recommendations while JPMorgan Chase brings up the rear, according to new data released Thursday by marketing firm Zócalo Group and research firm M/A/R/C Research.

headline: Inside the Mind of Bob Bradley
text: How would you put together a roster, plan a strategy and prepare for the World Cup? United States soccer fans, never shy, have as many opinions on how Bob Bradley should approach his job as there are blades of grass on a soccer field.

headline: ‘I Rush Through the Japanese Night’
text: I confess, dear reader: I’ve always had a problem with William T. Vollmann. I can’t fail to admire his tender heart and wide-awake conscience, and it’s hard not to appreciate his energy, his intensity, his unstoppable curiosity about the world and everything in it — women, violence, death, war zones, the night. Who else would give us a subtitle, as in his new book, that spills over and over, and begin a work of 504 pages, complete with bibliography, glossary, chronology and five appendixes, with a modest disclaimer about his “short book”? Actually, it is short when compared with his seven-volume 2003 treatise on violence, “Rising Up and Rising Down,” and the 811-page novel, “Europe Central,” that won the National Book Award in 2005. It’s now been all of 10 months since the 1,306-page Vollmann opus “Imperial” appeared, serving up every­thing you’d thought to ask about the Mexico-California border, and much you probably hadn’t.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE PUBLISHER: Henry Luce and His American Century,  by Alan Brinkley (Knopf, $35.) The creator of Time and Life used his magazines to advance political favorites, paint an uplifting portrait of the middle class and promote American intervention in the world.

headline: Paperback Row
text: SHOP CLASS AS SOULCRAFT: An Inquiry Into the Value of Work,  by Matthew B. Crawford (Penguin, $15.) This “beautiful little book about human excellence and the way it is undervalued in contemporary America,” as our reviewer, Francis Fukuyama, described it, argues against the idea that the United States labor force needs to be retrained to face the challenges of a high-tech, global economy. On the contrary, argues Crawford — a philosopher who operates a motorcycle repair shop — blue-collar work leads to knowledge both about the world and about oneself. He illustrates by explaining in detail just what is involved in rebuilding a Volkswagen engine.

headline: The Paper
text: This first novel by Tom Rachman, a London-born journalist who has lived and worked all over the world, is so good I had to read it twice simply to figure out how he pulled it off. I still haven’t answered that question, nor do I know how someone so young — Rachman turns out to be 35, though he looks even younger in his author photo — could have acquired such a precocious grasp of human foibles. The novel is alternately hilarious and heart-wrenching, and it’s assembled like a Rubik’s Cube. I almost feel sorry for Rachman, because a debut of this order sets the bar so high.

headline: Up Front: Christopher Buckley
text: Although Christopher Buckley’s most recent book, “Losing Mum and Pup,” is a memoir of his parents, William and Pat Buckley, he’s known primarily as a political satirist and the author of darkly comic novels like “The White House Mess,” “Thank You for Smoking,” “No Way to Treat a First Lady” and “Boomsday.”

headline: Privacy Concerns Limit Online Ads, Study Says
text: Privacy advocates have had an impact on Madison Avenue after all, according to a new study.

headline: NBC Rolls Out the Red Carpet
text: When viewers tune in Saturday to watch what Bob Costas calls an “incredible piece of Americana,” something will be different.

headline: Obama Hits Pause on Offshore Drilling
text: President Obama has ordered that no new offshore drilling leases be issued until an extensive review is concluded and oil rigs have new safeguards put in place, as the White House dramatically strengthened its response to the worsening oil leak in the Gulf.

headline: Gabriel Byrne Buys in NoLIta
text: The actor Gabriel Byrne has just bought a two-bedroom condo at 211 Elizabeth Street in Manhattan for $3.36 million.

headline: Don’t Cry for Charlie Crist
text: No doubt there will be some talk, in the wake of Charlie Crist’s completely unsurprising decision to run for Florida’s Senate seat as an independent, about how this shows that the intolerant Tea Party spirit is driving moderates out of the Republican Party. As I’ve argued before, this is exactly the wrong way to look at the case of Charlie Crist. The Florida governor may be a moderate in some sense, but his real loyalties are to cynicism, self-interest (though this time, I’m pretty sure that he’s misjudged where those interests lie), and the persistent pursuit of the budgetary free lunch.  At a time when the country desperately needs politicians who are equipped to make tough choices, Crist’s record suggests that he’s the last person that anyone — conservative or liberal — should want to see in a position of responsibility in Washington D.C.

headline: Switzerland Says It Does Not Seek Sealed Testimony in Polanski Case
text: Swiss justice officials said on Friday that they did not require access to the sealed testimony of a prosecutor involved in the sex case against the director Roman Polanski, even though lawyers for the filmmaker have said the testimony was needed for the officials to rule on his possible extradition to the United States. On Thursday, Mr. Polanski’s American lawyers filed a motion in Los Angeles County Superior Court seeking the sealed testimony of Roger Gunson, a retired deputy district attorney, about a sentencing plan devised by Judge Laurence J. Rittenband. Mr. Polanski pleaded guilty to having sex with a 13-year-old girl but fled the United States in 1978 before he could be sentenced by Judge Rittenband, who died in 1993.

headline: About Face
text: In 1928 Neville Chamberlain wrote a perceptive and generous private letter about one of his cabinet colleagues. “He is a brilliant but wayward child,” Chamberlain said. “One doesn’t often come across a real man of genius. . . . Winston is such a man and he has les défauts de ses qualités.”

headline: The Lure of Carbon Capture
text: Support for carbon capture and sequestration continues to grow in Washington.

headline: Ad: 'Is She You?'
text: Thierry Mugler, the fashion designer, has a new commercial for his latest fragrance, Womanity.

headline: Final British Debate in 60 Seconds
text: Readers who want to relive Thursday’s final debate of the British election campaign, among the three men vying for the keys to Number 10 Downing Street, can watch extended video highlights on The Lede, take in a witty analysis of the tape on The Guardian’s Web site, or read what my colleagues John Burns, Alan Cowell and Stephen Castle had to say about it during the event. Readers with somewhat less time on their hands might enjoy the highly condensed version of the proceedings from the Web site of Britain’s Channel 4 News above, which sums the whole thing up in 60 seconds.

text: Q.

text: Q.

headline: When Spouses Serve on a Board
text: Q.

headline: We Love Paris
text: In 1900, Émile Zola climbed to the second platform of the Eiffel Tower, camera equipment in tow, so he could photograph Paris from every angle — because only photographs could record the panoramic city he had reconstructed in his novels. In 1940, Adolf Hitler, believing he too stood at the center of something, rose from the seat of his car as it slowly circled the Place de la Concorde before dawn; later, from the top of the Parvis du Sacré-­Coeur, he gaped at the city he had fantasized about since boyhood, when he studied street maps and dreamed of reconstructing Paris in the heart of Berlin.

headline: The Wig and Me
text: Today I am in love. With a wig.

headline: Undercover Icon
text: At 93, I’m not looking forward to fame and fortune,” said Irving Harper on a warm March day signaling the end of a very long winter. Seasonal metaphors are generally to be avoided. Yet it would not be so far-fetched to suggest that Harper is enjoying a late-life thaw.

headline: A Doctor and His Imaging
text: A specialist recommended that my wife get a CT scan and suggested that she use a lab in which, we later discovered, he has an interest. She wasn’t required to use that lab, and there was no reason to question its quality or his calling for a scan. I’m O.K. with this lab — I say you either trust the specialist or you don’t — but my wife is not so sure. What do you say? PETER THORNE, GLEN HEAD, N.Y.

headline: An Out-of-Office Message for Republican Candidates
text: Some 30 months from the next presidential election, the field of potential challengers to Barack Obama is like a solar system in its infancy — unformed, gaseous and lacking a dominant star. One characteristic, however, stands out. In a recent CNN poll that tested the strength of possible Republican hopefuls, only one of the seven most likely candidates (that would be Representative Ron Paul) will actually hold an elected office by the end of this year. The two leading candidates as of today, Mike Huckabee and Mitt Romney, haven’t held a political job in more than three years. Sarah Palin gave up her governorship when the vast Alaskan frontier became too confining for her ambition, and Newt Gingrich hasn’t run for anything since the days before Google was a verb. Tim Pawlenty, Minnesota’s governor, is leaving office at the end of the year. We’ve certainly had our share of presidents who ran as former officeholders of one kind or another: Jimmy Carter ran as an ex-governor in 1976, and Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan were out of office by the time they finally won the presidency. Still, you have to go back almost three decades — to the former vice president Walter Mondale in 1984 — to find a major-party candidate who didn’t hold an office on the day he clinched the nomination. Which makes it strange that a number of Republican aspirants seem to be hoping for their own version of a jobless recovery.

headline: TimesCast | April 30, 2010
text: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Friday.  Today's topics include political fallout from the oil spill, the Kentucky Derby and a woman's triumph over disability.

headline: New York’s Cobra Extension
text: A reader asked last week about the extension of Cobra benefits for those with disabilities. Following our reply, Steven S. Landis, a lawyer in Manhattan, suggested we take a closer look at a related state law recently passed in New York. Here’s what we found.

headline: Top Pitching Prospects Not Named Strasburg
text: I don’t know if you’ve heard of this Stephen Strasburg fellow yet, but rumor has it the kid’s got talent. But he’s not the only ace-in-waiting who’s making minor league hitters look foolish this season. Of Baseball America’s top 20 prospects heading into the season, five of them are pitchers who are still in the minors and not named Strasburg. Here’s an update on how they’ve fared so far this season.

headline: Inwood, 6 A.M.
text: Early risers light up the grid of an upper Manhattan highrise.

headline: The Vinyl Countdown: Jack White’s Concept of Streaming Music
text: If all goes as planned and you are looking at this post some time between Friday afternoon and Saturday morning, what you should see above is a live Internet stream of “Sea of Cowards,” the second album from the Dead Weather, the rock supergroup. But because the band is led by Jack White, the White Stripes and Raconteurs guitarist and preciously nostalgic Luddite, this can’t be a normal online presentation — oh no. Instead of streaming the audio in a digital format, Mr. White and his crew have pointed a camera and a microphone at a record player spinning “Sea of Cowards” on vinyl at their office in Nashville.

headline: New Jersey: What the Walls Would Say
text: With the market for large older homes still slow and frail, a number of sellers are  marketing a house’s personal history right along with its physical attributes.

headline: What the Walls Would Say
text: WITH the market for large older homes still slow and frail, a number of sellers are taking a more “personal” approach — marketing a house’s history right along with its physical attributes.

headline: Pakistani Ex-Intelligence Officer Is Killed
text: ISLAMABAD — A former Pakistani intelligence officer with deep connections to the Taliban and Al Qaeda was found dead in the western tribal area of Pakistan on Friday, after being kidnapped by militants a month ago.

headline: Family in Residence, Artist Included
text: Maria Moreno signed a waiting list for an apartment in a moderate-income co-op called Amalgamated in the North Bronx. By the time her name came up, she was married and had a baby. Perfect timing.

headline: Family in Residence, Artist Included
text: IN 1998, a newly minted Spanish teacher named Maria Moreno took a flier on her future.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Was Shakespeare Really Shakespeare?

Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Do You Speak My Language? Considering the Relationship Between Language and Culture
text: Overview | What does culture mean in an increasingly globalized, connected world? What is the relationship between language and culture? In this lesson, students consider the connection between French and other cultures and languages by discussing key quotations from relevant Times articles and sharing their insights on the questions they raise.

headline: Daniel Libeskind
text: Mr. Libeskind, 63, is a co-founder, with his wife, Nina, of Studio Daniel Libeskind, and is its principal design architect.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’
text: An article last Sunday about the television series “Friday Night Lights” misstated the production titles of Michael Waxman and Nan Bernstein. Mr. Waxman is the in-house director and producer, not the first assistant director, and Ms. Bernstein is a supervising producer and unit production manager, not the series’s production manager. Because of an editing error, the article also misidentified the position that a character plays on the football team on which the show focuses. Landry (Jesse Plemons) is a kicker, not a quarterback.

headline: Obama Interviews Potential Supreme Court Nominees
text: President Obama has started the process of interviewing potential Supreme Court nominees, and two possible candidates — Judge Sidney Thomas of the federal appeals court in Montana and Judge Merrick Garland of the federal appeals court in Washington — have already been to the White House for formal interviews, officials said.

headline: Ex-Bad Boy Eager for a (Filmed) Fight
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

headline: Our 2010 Derby Picks Are Burning
text: The Rail’s contributors and a special guest picker make their Derby selections.

headline: Pardon My French
text: The Abroad column last Sunday, about the shift in francophone culture, described incorrectly the military service of the Algerian novelist Mohammed Moulessehoul, who writes under the pen name Yasmina Khadra. He went to military school at the age of 8 and later became an Alegrian Army officer in charge of counter-guerrilla activity for part of the country during Algeria’s civil war. He did not fight against the French.

headline: A Pied-à-Terre for a Vermont Couple
text: DESPITE her husband’s reluctance to buy a Manhattan apartment, Lauren Olitski Poster insisted.

headline: Fallon: ‘Not to Be Outdone’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Rielle Hunter appeared on “Oprah” to discuss her love affair with John Edwards. Not to be outdone, next week, John Edwards is appearing to discuss his love affair with John Edwards.

headline: The Importance of Watching Home Equity
text: HOMEOWNERS with secure jobs and no immediate plans to move will often watch mortgage rates anyway, just in case they have the opportunity to refinance their loans. But few of them will regularly bother to check housing sales or foreclosures, which could also affect their ability to refinance.

headline: Letterman: ‘Heightened Powers of Observation’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: There’s a show on CBS called “The Mentalist.” It’s about a detective with heightened powers of observation. Let me give you an example of how good this guy is. This guy is so good, he can tell the difference between a Goldman Sachs executive that is a lying crook and a Goldman Sachs executive that’s a lying weasel. He’s that good.

headline: U.N. Postscript
text: To the Editor:

headline: Leno: ‘This Could Be Devastating’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: John Edwards’s mistress, Rielle Hunter, was on “Oprah” today. She told Oprah she did not believe that she played a central role in the breakup of the Edwardses’ marriage. Really? So, getting pregnant by a married guy, having his kid, that’s not what broke up the marriage? You know what broke it up? Fighting over the remote. I’m sure that’s what it was.

headline: Bangkok Hospital Is Evacuated After a Raid by Protesters
text: BANGKOK — A major hospital in Bangkok evacuated hundreds of its patients on Friday and shut down all but emergency services after scores of antigovernment protesters pushed their way inside and roamed the halls in what they said was a hunt for soldiers who might be hiding there.

headline: Two Bay Area Faults Do Not Exist
text: Like Pluto, the planet-that-wasn’t, the poor Antioch and San Bruno faults have become the latest casualties of advancing science. State geologists have determined these two faults to be the geologic equivalent of false alarms. They’ve scrubbed the faults off the official state seismic map.

headline: A Director Ever in Search of Survivors
text: West Hollywood, Calif.

headline: Falling Off the World
text: CRAIG was an unemployed architect, a cat-owning vegan and recently divorced. The man was wrong for me. And yet I couldn’t get him out of my head.

headline: Game 5 of Title Match Is Drawn; Anand Retains Lead
text: The players repeated the opening from the third game and the result was the same.

headline: Law Firms Weather the Economic Storm
text: The American Lawyer on Thursday released its annual report on the financial performance of law firms — or, for those of us not in big law, a reminder of how little we earn.

headline: Kids Behind Bars: A Look at ‘Dog Pound’
text: “Dog Pound”, which follows three teenagers serving time in a youth correctional center in Montana, depicts a cruel and brutal world little different than life in adult prisons. The director Kim Chapiron, who won the award for best new narrative filmmaker at the Tribeca Film Festival, spent a year visiting juvenile detention centers across America to get to the heart of the struggles the kids in them faced. He used a combination of professional and nonprofessional actors to tell the film’s story. Above, Mr. Chapiron discusses his approach. Here is the trailer for “Dog Pound.”

headline: Washington’s New Younger Half
text: What happens when a bunch of 20-somethings are picked to work in the Obama White House, to live together and to (more or less) have their lives taped?

headline: Posterior Modern
text: This woman is walking down the street ahead of me, ordinary looking, but as she passes, every male head swivels. I can almost see dotted lines streaming from popping eyes to bobbing cheeks. And then I think, Of course, buttocks are the new breasts. Every culture and every time has its template for the ideal female form. Here in the United States, after more than 50 years of breast fixation, the bottom has come into its own. Jennifer Lopez’s generous seat probably started the trend, but it doesn’t take a degree in anthropology to tie a bottom heavy silhouette to the ascendance of African-American and Hispanic influence in entertainment (e.g., that hip-hop classic ”Baby Got Back”).

headline: What We’re Reading: Imagining Retirement
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Smoke Gets in His Eye
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Rachel Alexandra Loses Again
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Rachel Alexandra, the reigning Horse of the Year, could not find a finishing gear or her characteristic grit and was beaten in a stirring stretch duel with a determined Unrivaled Belle in the $400,000 La Troienne Stakes on Friday at Churchill Downs.

headline: The Week Ahead: May 2 — 8
text: Dance

headline: Seeing Things | Rodarte for Knoll Luxe
text: These days, fashion-design collaborations are so common that they’re beginning to seem a little, well, old hat. But the clothing label Rodarte’s collaboration with Knoll Luxe (www.knoll-luxe.com), a luxury textile division of the furniture company Knoll Inc., is anything but.

headline: Older Condos Better Than New?
text: BUYERS who once would have headed straight for the sleek lines and polished finishes of new condominiums are discovering a different sector of the market: almost-new condos.

headline: The Upper West Side Gets New Glass Rental Towers
text: TWO glassy new rental towers have shouldered their way onto the Upper West Side, bringing bold styling, expensive finishes and prices a far cry from those typically found in the neighborhood’s walk-up buildings.

headline: Brokers Get Creative at High-End Open Houses
text: Muttontown

headline: You at Home, Put a Viral Spin on It
text: A VIDEO that involves Lady Gaga and Beyoncé is bound to draw a lot of eyeballs, and sure enough, this particular YouTube sensation has been viewed more than 800,000 times. But it’s not the clip for their recent collaboration, the single “Telephone.” No, this viral hit features a 14-year-old boy and other students at the International Dance Academy in Hollywood whipping through a fast-paced combination — with hip swivels, head snaps and shimmies — created by their teacher, Dejan Tubic, and inspired in part by Lady Gaga and Beyoncé’s music and moves.

headline: An Old-Age Home All Your Own
text: ONE evening four winters ago Robert Immerman came home to discover the steep steps leading up to his house in Larchmont glazed with ice. Unable to make the ascent to the front door because of balance problems he had suffered since undergoing brain surgery, he panicked.

headline: Greece Said to Be Close to Deal on Rescue Plan
text: The Greek government, rapidly running out of time to shore up its finances, was close to completing negotiations for assistance from the International Monetary Fund, European officials said Friday, The New York Times’s Landon Thomas Jr. and James Kantor report.

headline: A Snowball Effect Heats the Arctic
text: A feedback loop can be a nasty thing. In one, a small disturbance becomes self-reinforcing and is greatly amplified — the proverbial snowball effect. This is one way that seemingly minor contributions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases to the atmosphere — a few hundred parts per million — just might destabilize the climate.

headline: 10% More Qualify for Kindergarten Gifted Programs
text: The number of children qualifying for gifted kindergarten programs in New York City public schools rose by 10 percent this year, even as the number of students taking the test dropped by about one-sixth, according to statistics released Friday by the Department of Education (pdf).

headline: Evoking the Past by Hearing Its Sounds
text: FOR Jordi Savall — early-music pioneer and master of the viola da gamba — music is always more than fleeting sounds. It enfolds histories. It reflects worlds. To draw a distinction between musicology and the sheer joy of performance is next to impossible.

headline: Two Men Are Charged With Helping Al Qaeda
text: Two former Brooklyn residents have been charged with conspiring to provide Al Qaeda with computer advice and other assistance, according to an indictment unsealed on Friday in United States District Court in Manhattan.

headline: The Story of an Innocent, Boldly Told
text: THERE are several classic recordings of Benjamin Britten’s “Billy Budd,” including the 1967 Decca release conducted by Britten, with Peter Glossop in the title role and Peter Pears in a haunting, multilayered account of a role written for him, Captain Vere.

headline:
Michael Hersch: Sonatas Nos. 1
& 2 for Unaccompanied Cello
text: MICHAEL HERSCH: SONATAS NOS. 1 & 2 FOR UNACCOMPANIED CELLO

headline: ‘The Imperfectionists’
text: "Bush Slumps to New Low in Polls"Paris Correspondent-Lloyd Burko

headline: Advertising Is Unleashed In Another Venue
text: It sometimes seems as if advertising is everywhere. And often that is because it is finding its way into and onto just about every surface of unmarked space.

headline: The Blue-Chip Period
text: OPTIMISM has returned to the multibillion-dollar art market. Expectations are so high that many will be disappointed if Picasso’s 1932 painting “Nu au Plateau de Sculpteur (Nude, Green Leaves and Bust)” doesn’t break the record for a work of art sold at auction when it is offered at Christie’s on Tuesday.

headline: Dear FloFab: Send It Back!
text: Every week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

text: SOMEWHERE IN SOUTH FLORIDA

headline: TimesCast: The Oil Spill’s Political Fallout
text: As the Gulf of Mexico oil spill reaches the coastline, its political consequences may be rising.

headline: ‘Eddie Signwriter’
text: A group of children playing in the shade of a tree nearby heard some of their brief exchange, catching only Nana Oforiwaa's last words, "So, we go inside then."

headline: Cameras, Action and Even Lights  Before the Derby
text: Louisville, Ky.

headline: As Recession Ebbs, Many Still See Gloom
text: THROUGH recession after recession over the last four decades, Americans remained more optimistic than pessimistic about their own futures, even when they grew very worried about the overall economy.

headline: After Debates, British Candidates Race to Finish Line
text: LONDON — Six days before British voters go to the polls, Britain’s three main party leaders raced toward the finish on Friday, with Prime Minister Gordon Brown struggling to recapture the sense of momentum now buoying his Conservative and Liberal Democratic rivals.

headline: The Houses of Broadway
text: An interactive tour through the Jacobs and the Broadway theaters and an expanded interactive look at the histories of each theater on Broadway.

headline: Megan and Jeff: What We Know
text: Last week in Madison Square Park, City Room happened upon a man wearing a sandwich board that said: “I WAS VERBALLY ABUSIVE I’M SORRY, MEGAN!”

headline: Putin Calls for Merger With Ukraine on Energy
text: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Friday suggested merging Ukraine’s national energy company with the Russian gas giant Gazprom, a move that, if approved in Kiev, would put Ukraine’s strategic network of gas pipelines under Moscow’s control.

headline: Man Found With Cyanide Pills in Subway Tunnel
text: Updated, 6:26 p.m. | A college student dressed as a laborer and carrying a backpack with cyanide pellets, roadway flares and water was taken into custody early Friday as he walked along the subway tracks in the tunnel between Brooklyn and Manhattan, the police said.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Julia Roberts, a Pricey Picasso, Mark Wahlberg and More
text: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

headline: Citi Executive to Retire After Cutting Toxic Assets
text: Citigroup said Richard A. Stuckey Jr., named in January 2009 to oversee $241 billion of the bank’s most troubled mortgages and bonds, would retire later this year after cutting the toxic assets pool nearly in half, Bloomberg News reports, citing an internal memo.

headline: Living in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn
text: The ocean panoramas available to buyers in Brighton Beach constitute the single most important reason people give for never moving out.

headline: Pulse
text: The British perfume house revives its classic scents; Carlos Mota’s new book, “Flowers Cheap & Chic,” gives recipes for making bouquets from things around you; and more.

headline: Waterfront Living That Doesn’t Break the Bank
text: ALONG the East and Hudson Rivers, on stretches of Jamaica Bay, and by the banks of the Gowanus Canal, formerly neglected industrial land has recently been reborn as parkland, or will be before long.

text: Introduction

headline: Financial Tuneup: Negotiate With Your Phone Company
text: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, we’ve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

headline: iPhonegate: Q.&A. With Mark D. Rasch, Computer Security Expert
text: The iPhone-lost-in-a-bar story raises all sorts of legal questions. To explore them further, I spoke with Mark D. Rasch who is the former head of the United States Department of Justice computer crime unit, and helped develop the department’s guidelines for computer crimes related to investigations, forensics and evidence gathering. Mr. Rasch is currently a principal with Secure IT Experts, a consulting company that specializes in computer security. The Q.&A. below is an edited version of our discussion.

headline: The Making of the Distracted Driving Video
text: A couple of weeks ago, in my weekly e-mail column (sign up at nytimes.com/pogue), I shared a behind-the-scenes look at how I made my weekly video. It was about the iPad, and it featured a “video wall” of people from all over the world, on my computer screen, acting as a sort of simulated live audience.

headline: Buffy Roberson, Tom Wang
text: Barbara Drane Roberson and Myles Thomas Wang were married Saturday at Harbour Court, the clubhouse of the New York Yacht Club in Newport, R.I. Frank R. Camera, a Rhode Island justice of the peace, officiated.

headline: In San Francisco, Another Meat-Centric Restaurant
text: San Francisco has never really been known for serious meat eating. But thanks to Marlowe, a new bistro near AT&T Park in the SoMa district, carnivores can gather for some meat-centric goodness.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Was Shakespeare Really Shakespeare?
text: This week: Deanna Fei, author of the novel “A Thread of Sky,” explores the complexities of being Chinese-American; Jeremy McCarter discusses the contested identity of William Shakespeare; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Grass Fed | Old-School Italian in Queens
text: The Lefferts Avenue exit off the Belt Parkway is lined with street lamps that flicker like strobe lights, one after another, over and over, in a pattern that points a path to J.F.K.’s runways.

headline: Allison Frey, Jacob Studenroth
text: Allison Coleman Frey and Jacob Zell Studenroth were married Saturday evening at the Old State House in Hartford. Rabbi Laurence A. Alpern officiated.

headline: War Against a Wind-Rich Super Grid
text: After several years of debate, a coalition has emerged around the idea of a strong national electric grid, centrally planned and broadly financed, that would promote renewable energy. The group includes giant investor-owned utilities, public power entities, influential elected officials of both parties and state energy officials, and they speak with a single voice.

headline: An Idealist and a Dream Killed in Iraq
text: LONDON

headline: Antisocial Networking?
text: “HEY, you’re a dork,” said the girl to the boy with a smile. “Just wanted you to know.”

headline: Thierry Mugler, Still Creating a Stir
text: “THIS is what I want you to show,” Thierry Mugler said as he handed over a black folder embossed with his signature in a silver lightning-bolt script.

headline: Sony’s Dash: The Upgraded Alarm Clock
text: Sony’s Dash, designed for the bedroom or kitchen.Sony’s Dash, designed for the bedroom or kitchen.Sony’s newly released “personal Internet viewer,” the Dash, is a sort of sleek alarm clock in overdrive. Designed for use in the kitchen and bedroom, the Dash hooks into a home’s Wi-Fi network to deliver news, weather, YouTube and other content through a thousand or so free apps — from Netflix, CNBC, Weather Channel, CBS Sports — from the Dash store. The Dash itself costs $200.

headline: Gratitude Adjustment
text: I have raged on multiple occasions about the tacky ascendancy of Evites, with their unpleasant public response option, over the personalized invitation. (My mother points out that the French verb éviter aptly means “to avoid.”) But what of the invitation’s alter ego, the thank-you note?

headline: Some Plays Eligible for Best-Score Tony, but Not ‘American Idiot’ or ‘Fela!’
text: While many theatergoers associate a composer’s score with a musical, this year’s Tony Award for best score could end up going to a Broadway production of a play, with the current runs of “Enron,” “Fences,” and “The Royal Family” all eligible for nominations for that award.

headline: How, Exactly, Do You Follow Bill Moyers?
text: IT’S hard to imagine Bill Moyers bantering with a co-host. But the first thing that jumped out during a recent rehearsal of “Need to Know,” the new Friday night public affairs program on PBS replacing Mr. Moyers’s, was the repartee between its co-hosts Alison Stewart and Jon Meacham, mixed with bits of irreverence in the script. “Need to Know” is no “Daily Show With Jon Stewart” by any means, or even the 11 p.m. local news, but there’s no other PBS program likely to let its anchors riff on the name of the Icelandic volcano Eyjafjallajokull. Could PBS, home to “Frontline” and “NewsHour,” be lightening up?

headline: Coal Sans CO2: Appealing Pipe Dream
text: My friends at The Times Green blog have rounded up news pointing to the persistent political appeal of developing ways to burn coal while capturing and disposing of the flood of resulting carbon dioxide emissions.

headline: Weighing the Value of a Home Security System
text: PEOPLE may be surprised to learn that when they most need their security system to protect their house, they oftentimes cannot rely on it. Jackie Ostrander discovered that when a storm knocked out power to her home in Greenwich, Conn., for a week in March — too long for her backup battery to keep going. And it took her security company three weeks to restart her system.

headline: Mr. Smith Shows His Staying Power
text: IN the opening moments of “O.F.Y.C. Showcase,” a new song by the British band the Fall, something’s up with the singer, Mark E. Smith. He sounds like a man in a cartoon who’s been hit by an anvil, birds tweeting over his head. He’s muttering, woozy. He seems in no shape to sing a rock ’n’ roll song. Mr. Smith is 53 and doesn’t sound younger. You can hear his age not just in his voice but in his nervous system. Other rock singers try to sound louche, but this one could be under sedation.

headline: Debra Dickstein, Daniel Faizakoff
text: Debra Miriam Dickstein and Daniel Benjamin Faizakoff are to be married Sunday evening. Rabbi Shmuel Goldin is to officiate, and Rabbi Mark N. Wildes is to assist, at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y.

headline: The Mambo, the Combo, Post-Bop and a Presley
text: People, Places & Things

headline: Nebraska Agency Takes It to the ‘Max’
text: There are few who still believe that the advertising agency industry is confined to New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. For decades, those clients who want to can find agencies to work with in cities like Portland, Ore.; Minneapolis; Austin, Tex.; Miami; or San Francisco.

headline: Emily Doelger, David Rosenblatt
text: Dr. Emily Milbank Doelger and David Teman Rosenblatt were married Saturday evening in Ridgeland, S.C. The Rev. Thomas Summers, a United Methodist minister, officiated at Turkey Hill Plantation, a home owned by the bride’s family.

headline: Lindsay Senter, Aaron Stern
text: Lindsay Senter and Aaron Stern were married Saturday evening at the Down Town Association, an event space in Manhattan. Rabbi Maurice A. Salth officiated.

headline: A (Top Secret) Slice of a Derby Tradition
text: There’s chocolate and there’s walnuts, and that’s about all you’re getting out of the president of Kern’s Kitchen, the makers of Derby-Pie.

headline: Art Auctions' Blue-Chip Period
text: A look at  some of the highlights of images coming to market this spring.

headline: How Operatic | Rufus Wainwright in London
text: Seconds before his sound check in Bristol, England, Rufus Wainwright spoke to The Moment. The singer and pianist is having a whirlwind year: He composed and staged an opera (“Prima Donna”), collaborated with Robert Wilson on a theatrical version of Shakespeare’s Sonnets (“Sonettes”) and found time to channel the silent film star Louise Brooks for his sixth studio album, the intense “All Days Are Nights: Songs for Lulu.” Here, Wainwright, the 36-year-old Manhattanite, explains the origins of his 30-foot eye and his disillusionment with the city’s fancy cupcakes and reveals that his opera will play the city.

headline: Inside the Documentary ‘Feathered Cocaine’
text: “Follow the falcon, find the terrorist,” says Thorkell Hardarson, the co-director of the documentary “Feathered Cocaine.” He, along with Marino Arnarson, look at the practice of falcon smuggling around the world before surprisingly veering into a discussion of Osama bin Laden and the C.I.A.

headline: Q. & A. With Julie Sahni (Round Three)
text: Julie Sahni is the owner of Julie Sahni’s Indian Cooking School in Brooklyn Heights, N.Y., and the author of 10 cookbooks, including “Savoring Herbs and Spices” and “Classic Indian Cooking.” She is answering questions on how to prepare Indian food. Related article.

headline: Sound the Alarm About Your Home Security System
text: This week’s Wealth Matters column examines what you’re really paying for when you install a home security system.

headline: Guest Room
text: Robin Standefer and Stephen Alesch of Roman and Williams are so busy designing spaces for New Yorkers to have fun in that they rarely get to have a cocktail there once they’re finished, leaving the Ace Hotel lobby (and the Breslin) and the Boom Boom Room at the Standard Hotel to the players. But on weekends, their home in Montauk, N.Y., becomes the center of a rolling house party, where the food and friends are as exquisitely arranged — yet seemingly haphazard — as their décor. Here, the bon vivant masters of tableaux vivants are at their best.

headline: Creeping in a Castle in the Dark
text: At the start of Luciana Achugar’s newest work, “Puro Deseo,” the Kitchen is transformed into a starless, moonless sky — so pitch-black, in fact, that it’s impossible to see your fingers inches from your nose. Perhaps all dances should begin with such a forceful purification of the eyes and mind, but it isn’t soothing; in “Puro Deseo,” which began performances on Thursday evening, Ms. Achugar’s rendition of the night was hardly tender.

headline: Chopin’s Gloomy Ghosts and Haunting Winds
text: Three additional rows of stage seats were set up to accommodate the overflow audience at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night for the Chopin recital by the master pianist Maurizio Pollini. This was the second of three programs that he is presenting to celebrate the 200th anniversary of Chopin’s birth.

headline: Rules Tightened for Helicopter Tours
text: Bowing to pressure from community groups upset by the noise of whirring rotors, city officials have banned most types of helicopter sightseeing flights leaving from Manhattan.

headline: A Whiplash-Inducing Ride, but They’re Young
text: Anyone who regularly attends new-music concerts has surely marveled at the versatility required of the participants. You have to be able to negotiate treacherous metrical permutations, master unorthodox playing techniques and develop sharp improvisational reflexes. For minimalism, stamina and athleticism are mandatory. You’ve got to swing convincingly in jazz-influenced pieces, and lately you also need a better-than-passing acquaintance with rock and hip-hop.

headline: BlogTalk: Arizona and Oil
text: Less than a week after Arizona’s governor signed a strict anti-illegal immigration bill into law, setting off a national debate, the state’s Department of Education has told school districts that teachers with accents must not be allowed to teach English to students with limited English skills. Also, the legislature has passed a measure that would ban ethnic studies programs in the state.

headline: World Expo in Shanghai
text: World’s Fairs don’t get the attention they used to. With little fanfare, at least in the United States, Expo Shanghai 2010 opens on Saturday.

headline: To Avoid an Unwanted Shift, Leave Easy Outs
text: At the Long Island Spring Regional, held from April 20 through last Sunday in Smithtown, N.Y., the winners of the two-session Stratified Pairs on Saturday were Jeff Aker of Briarcliff, N.Y., and Barry Rigal of Manhattan. They finished 2 match points (out of 432) ahead of Michael Gore and Steven Zlotnick of New York. Third, less than half a match point behind, were Michael Lipkin of New York and Alex Perlin of Metuchen, N.J.

headline: Down Under Striker Is Way Up There
text: Australia striker Joshua Kennedy stands out in a crowd.

headline: On the High Line: A Garden in the Sky
text: A panoramic view of the horticulture preserve above 17th Street.

headline: A Life of Determination and Dependence
text: Dayniah Manderson, a young Jamaican immigrant, struggles to achieve her goals despite a debilitating spinal disease.

headline: Fla. Republican to Retire From House
text: Representative Ginny Brown-Waite, a Florida Republican, announced on Friday that she would not run for re-election this year, citing what she called “persistent health problems.”

headline: Jeff Feagles Retires After 1,713 Punts
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — There were times, during lulls in practice, when Giants punter Jeff Feagles would practice his precision kicks by aiming balls into garbage cans standing 40 yards away. When it came time for the special teams’ portion of practice, Coach Tom Coughlin would call for a drill that asked Feagles to pin the other team inside its 5-yard line.

headline: Meat Lover | Mark Ryden’s Cool Cuts
text: Attention amateur butchers, meat lovers and hungry aesthetes: At the Paul Kasmin Gallery, the artist Mark Ryden is doing wonders with off cuts at his new show, “The Gay ’90s: Olde Tyme Art Show.” The paintings of a Gibson girl riding a bicycle built for two with Jesus and a brooding beauty in period finery are spooky and lovely, but it’s his meatier images that steal the show — a wispy girl in a gown of hams, hindquarters and sausages, or Abraham Lincoln grinding fresh chuck for a tea-drinking demoiselle. Surreally delicious.

headline: Wines by the Glass
text: Mark Bittman and Eric Asimov, the chief wine critic for The Times, on how to order wines by the glass.

headline: Exploring the Drums’ Potential as an Orchestra in Miniature
text: The drummer Tomas Fujiwara works with rhythm as a pliable substance, solid but ever shifting. Over the last five years he has established a busy profile on the experimental end of the jazz spectrum, where such perspective is vital; before that he was a cast member of “Stomp,” the polymorphously percussive Off Broadway show. His style is forward-driving but rarely blunt or aggressive, and never random. He has a way of spreading out the center of a pulse while setting up a rigorous scaffolding of restraint.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: Truth can be stranger than fiction in Cartagena, the Colombian city whose real-life blend of seediness and charm has been an important inspiration for Gabriel García Márquez, one of the most imaginative writers of the modern era. Anand Giridharadas, a columnist for The International Herald Tribune, seeks out some of the places and people behind his works.

headline: Fishermen Sign On to Clean Up Oil
text: VENICE, La. — About 1,000 angry and frustrated fishermen packed an elementary school gymnasium here Friday afternoon. In a cruel occupational twist, they were seeking employment with the company they blame for an oil spill that may wipe out their industry this year and beyond.

headline: Interview With the Foreign Minister and Government Spokesperson for Rwanda
text: Louise Mushikiwabo speaks about politics, censorship and ethnic divisions in the country.

headline: Jesse Baker, David Folkenflik
text: Jesse Baker and David Bernard Folkenflik were married Saturday at the Onteora Mountain House, a bed-and-breakfast in Boiceville, N.Y. Saman Zarifi, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Megan Lucey, Quinn Rounsaville
text: Megan Kathleen Lucey and John Quinn Rounsaville III were married Saturday at Holy Trinity Catholic Church in Washington. The Rev. James J. Greenfield, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Heidi Notman, Jay Muccifori
text: Heidi Elizabeth Notman, a daughter of Deborah C. Notman and James F. Notman Jr. of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married Saturday to John Charles Muccifori, a son of Sarah M. Muccifori and John A. Muccifori of Metuchen, N.J. The Rev. Dorsey W. M. McConnell, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, where he is rector.

headline: How Much to Donate? God Knows
text: When the Obamas released their 2009 income tax returns a few weeks ago, we itemized their charitable contributions on our Bucks personal finance blog. Some readers praised their choices and some criticized them, which was predictable. But a few others got into a far more interesting debate.

headline: Katherine Deringer, Matthew Janson
text: Katherine Ann Deringer, a daughter of Dr. Margaret R. Young of Arlington, Mass., and Dr. Paul M. Deringer of Fly Creek, N.Y., was married Saturday to Matthew Burke Janson, a son of Maryanne B. Janson and Michael M. Janson of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Mark A. Michael, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Cooperstown, N.Y.

headline: Granny Takes Another Trip
text: “It was pre-breasts, so it must have been 2001 or 2002,” Genesis P-Orridge explained, trying to date a shiny, mirrored lump that she made for an art show called “Candy Factory.” “It’s a melted disco ball.”

headline: How Much to Give (and How to Give It)
text: In this week’s Your Money column, I return to a conversation that began a few weeks ago in the comments on a post about whether the Obamas gave a big enough percentage of their income to charity.

headline: How to Avoid, or Dispute, Surprise Medical Bills
Julie Bookbinder, Jonathan Schwartz
text: Julie Pamela Bookbinder and Jonathan Lewis Schwartz are to be married Sunday, with Rabbi Aaron Krupnick performing the ceremony at Congregation Beth El in Voorhees, N.J.

headline: Erotic Sparks Fly, and Lines Are Crossed
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.

headline: Rwanda's Island Prison
text: Hundreds of vagrants, thieves and street kids, some as young as 14, have been sent, without a trial, to the remote island of Iwawa - an extreme example of the levels of repression in Rwanda.

headline: Bono Meets Obama
text: There are a whole lot of celebrities in town this weekend for the annual razzle-dazzle that is the White House Correspondents Dinner.

headline: An Island of the Unwanted
text: A program that sends street people to an island camp symbolizes what some say Rwanda has become since the 1994 genocide: orderly but repressive.

headline: Rwanda Pursues Dissenters and the Homeless
text: IWAWA ISLAND, Rwanda — A few months ago, Gasigwa Gakunzi was hanging around a ramshackle house where poor children pay to watch television when the Rwandan police arrested him for loitering. The next thing he knew, he said, he was taken away from his family and carted off to this remote island in the middle of Lake Kivu.

headline: London Underground | Pick Me Up
text: Every so often, it is nice to see designers getting down and dirty. Pick Me Up, London’s first contemporary graphic art fair, is a celebration of screen printing, hand-drawn illustration and lo-fi design.

headline: Take a Little Metal, Add a Bit of Elegance
text: The half-gauze, half-iron French band Alcest is also about half real, more a re-enacted dream than a group. It’s primarily the work of one person, Neige, who sings and plays guitar. The drums on the two Alcest albums are played by a musician named Winterhalter, but let’s not get distracted there. They sound like drums played to a songwriter’s specifications.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Oil Spill in the Gulf, and Elsewhere
text: Images of medical personnel scrubbing oil off a young Northern Gannet found offshore in Fort Jackson, La., are circulating on the Internet, underscoring the high environmental stakes of the cleanup effort in the Gulf of Mexico. But residents and workers in towns like Venice, La., are also feeling the effects of the oil spill directly. All fishing and shrimping, the area’s economic mainstay, was halted in Venice on Friday morning as the oil drew near.

headline: Ducks Adjust to Life Without Masoli
text: EUGENE, Ore. — When Nate Costa, on his thrice surgically repaired knee, bounces a screen pass at a running back’s feet, or Darron Thomas fires a pass over the head of a receiver and into the hands of a safety, as they did at a recent scrimmage, it is easy to wonder: What would Jeremiah do?

headline: Remembering the Little Man Who Was a Big Voice for Causes
text: Being a gay, Jewish, nearly deaf and otherwise disabled dwarf from Queens has its advantages, and Harry Wieder used every one of them. Arm crutches, which he needed to walk, served double duty as clubs when he felt he wasn’t being heard. “If he wanted your attention, he would hit you in the shin with his crutch,” said Marvin Wasserman, a longtime ally and occasional victim. “Sometimes he’d aim a little higher.”

headline: F.D.I.C. Closes and Sells 3 Puerto Rican Banks
text: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on Friday said it had sold off three Puerto Rican banks to head off a potentially ruinous series of failures across the commonwealth.

text: Let The Right One In (2008)

headline: BofA’s Chief Favors Bank Rescue Fund, but…
text: Brian T. Moynihan, the chief executive of Bank of America, said Friday that he supported a $50 billion “orderly liquidation” fund for large financial firms, but that he thought it should be built up over time, Reuters reports.

headline: Holmes Chastised for iPod Incident
text: Santonio Holmes, the Jets’ recently acquired wide receiver, refused to turn off his iPod on a flight Thursday from Newark to Pittsburgh, leading an airline employee to call ahead to the Allegheny County, Pa., police, who met Holmes when he got off the Colgan Air flight at Gate B77 at Pittsburgh International Airport, an incident report said.

headline: Now Online | T Magazine Design & Living Summer 2010
text: It’s all about great rooms starting with our cover story, which takes a grand tour of some of the most famous spaces of the 20th century including Robert Mallet-Stevens’s Villa Noailles and the Condé Nast apartment designed by Elsie De Wolfe. Pilar Viladas pays a visit to the fashion designer Lela Rose’s store-front loft with its and seemingly endless dining table and specially designed dog elevator! Christopher Petkanas looks at the life of Syrie Maugham, a doyenne of decorating known for her all-white rooms, and Christine Muhlke checks in with the contemporary decorating diva Kelly Wearstler who lives and works in brilliant Technicolor. Armand Limnander reports on the Villa Necchi, a 1930s Milanese house that plays a starring role in a new film and Guy Trebay meets the design legend Irving Harper whose house is jam-packed with his paper sculptures. Pull up a chair. See more from the issue »

headline: Pocket-Day Poetry Reveals the Soul of the City
text: On Thursday, we asked you to tell us what’s in your pocket — in verse form — for Poem in Your Pocket Day. The results were a delight, to us anyway. Some of you Wordsworths were clearly using this opportunity to share lines you’ve been toiling over; others dug fast and deep to create stirring verses on the fly.

headline: A Livelihood Threatened
text: Louisiana shrimpers are worried that the oil spill will threaten or destroy their livelihood for a long time to come.

headline: On Dance: Alwin Nikolais at 100
text: Before there was Pilobolus, or Momix, or even the trompe l’oeil acts of Cirque du Soleil, there was Alwin Nikolais. The choreographer, whose centenary is being celebrated this year, created work that has influenced all of those companies. “Nikolais was sensationally popular for many years, abroad as well as here, and he was one of the best-known dance makers who led the post-World War II movement against representationalism in dance,” Alastair Macaulay wrote earlier this year.

headline: The Week in Pictures for April 30
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York region. Subjects include Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s Bermuda, a legal fight over Willets Point, and a police officer turned arborist.

headline: To Protect Consumers, Who Will Be Regulated?
text: WASHINGTON — An unlikely new tenant in the halls of the Federal Reserve would set out sweeping rules on a wide swath of consumer transactions, possibly making it one of the most powerful new federal agencies in a generation.

headline: City Ballet’s Architecture of Dance Festival
text: New ballets by Benjamin Millepied and Alexei Ratmansky were presented at Koch Theater.

headline: Mine Blast That Killed 29 Prompts F.B.I. Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. has interviewed more than 20 employees of Massey Energy in a criminal investigation of the explosion that killed 29 of the company’s miners last month in West Virginia, according to two officials from the federal mine safety agency and the Department of Justice.

headline: A Couple of Graceful Leaps Into the Past
text: Back in 1972, George Balanchine told the audience for New York City Ballet’s Stravinsky Festival, “In Russia we drink the health of the guy that died,” whereupon he and Lincoln Kirstein emptied glasses of vodka onstage. Nowadays, though, a City Ballet gala has become a good excuse to toast the health of the guys who live, too, and we’re told that this is the house tradition.

headline: When Is It Smart to Abandon Your Party?
text: Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida announced this week that he would leave the Republican Party and run as an independent for the United States Senate rather than face defeat in the conservative Republican primary. A few national politicians — like Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont — are independents, but they are considered outliers, the result of the peculiar politics of those states.

headline: For Brunch, Runny Yolks and Sorrel (Thanks, Mom)
text: ALL winter long I fantasized about the sorrel on my deck, a gift from my mother last spring. On the bleakest of afternoons, I’d dream up myriad plans for cooking with that first batch. My husband, Daniel, served as a sounding board.
